Later admits sit in folding chairs on the right angle sides (transepts?) to the aisle and only the first row or 2 there can even see the choir or the other participants; the rest have to watch the service on a tv monitor. You still get the awesome acoustical experience of the choir in that great cathedral but it's not the same.

Nostalgic History. Very famous building and if you can afford it, get there early to avoid the rush and venture inside and soak up the Royal history of this iconic landmark. Unfortunately we were too early and a busy schedule awaited so I cannot remark too much but even wandering around the outside and gaze at the amazing architecture is spellbinding. It's right near Big Ben so kill two birds.
Good. Great views. The royal family church. Good views from near the roadside, though quite a crowded street I must admit. All the tourists were hanging around this place.

Expensive but worth it. Too expensive for a church but it's one of the most impressive buildings I've ever visited so I'm not complaining too much. I'd say this is one of the (many) must see places in London.

Not to be missed. We attended Sunday services at Westminster Abbey. I'm not sure what I expected but the service itself was a pretty straightforward Rite II Eucharist. It seemed that most of those in attendance were tourists which lead us to wonder if the Abbey has typical parish community. The church is closed to tourists and they vigorously keep them out so after the device, those attending were escorted out. They also have a no photography policy that they enforce as we saw several people sneaking iPhone photos that were asked to stop. We did not return on a normal visiting day as we did not want to fifth the crowds (which were big) so can't really comment on the historical aspect other than to say that it was meaningful to be in the same place where royal weddings and coronations have occurred.

Beautiful and full of history. The entrance fee is pretty steep (20 pounds a person), but we definitely wanted to go inside. You get a 'free' tour guide headset thing, and they can put it in a bunch of different languages. It's worth it to use it, because you hear about so much interesting things you would never know just from sight alone (like that Newton is buried there!)Unfortunately, no photography is allowed, but it was still well worth the visit for us.
Worth It. I don't really know what to say about this one, beautiful architecture steeped in british history,Well worth a visit.
Very Interesting. Must do whilst in London. We paid 20.00 each which seems more or less standard charge for most attractions in London. Lots of people visiting but very well organised.

Majestic. Westminster Abbey is an incredible sight, from the high ceiling and Gothic architecture, to the exquisite small chapels and elaborate resting places of past English monarchs and other persons of interest. I got the London Pass for the day, using it here and at two other attractions, and it got me past the crowds and into the "fast pass" entry. Definitely worth it, and I easily spent two to three hours here.
Historical . The abbey has a lot of history and holds the tomb of so many famous British monarchs and so many famous literary people. Definitely worth the visit but try going early.

Absolutely beautiful. so much history and beauty in one place. My only regret, that I didn't have time to stay for a service. That would have made the trip perfect. Give yourself plenty of time to walk through and make sure you do the audio tour
Oh boy. Amazing place. Wander and soak in the history. My visit was towards the end of a busy day, but my sore feet disappeared, such a peaceful haven even amongst so many.
Felt like a Princess. If you watched Princess Diana's wedding, you can get the same feel as you walk down the isle. Beautiful interior.

Overwhelming. This site can be a bit overwhelming. There is so much history and so much to see that it is easy to spend hours here and still be a bit overwhelmed. For anybody interested in English history this is a must see.

Awe inspiring. Historians and anglophiles alike must spend some time......there is just SO much to see. The free audio guide is helpful and can be used as little or as much alike. If you attend services, make sure to select a time that includes the choir as the acoustics are incredible

Have to visit here . Spent a couple of hours here today the £10 entry is well worth it.Take the time and get the audio it's very well spoken and draws you to things you may not notice your self.It was pretty busy to get in however the line moves very quickly.

Age and Beauty. We arrived just in time for Evening Song service and it was absolutely amazing to hear the hymns resonating off the old stone walls. There are no pictures allowed inside the main chapel, definiitly a must to see in person.
Magnificent architecture. This is one of the buildings that will leave you breathless when you visit it. Truly magnificent piece of architecture with such a meaning to UK history. Must see!

Iconic Building. Incredible history & beauty. The Abbey dates mostly from the 1200's. About 3300 people are buried & memorialized here. Many coronations & weddings performed here including Prince William & Kate. We arrived about 11:30am on a Monday & fast tracked the line with our London Pass. Free Audio guide in many languages is included. There is a lot to see so give yourself plenty of time. A cafe & shop on premise.

Wow what a visit. First time to Westminster abbey and a trip to remember full of history amazing Booked tickets on line always easier On arrival at the abbey the outside was impressive on entering we were guided to the audio tour person and issued a audio tour device This was a great device having the highlights of the tour and also videos and music on the device The tour was great we spent 2.5 hours in the abbey Highly recommended visit all positives no negatives
Touristy. We went during service on Sunday at 3pm, which is free. The Abbey is beautiful. You can leave early if you like.

Amazing Place of Worship. The Abbey is so steeped in history that it's easy to get lost in everything it has to offer. As a girl from a small town in Montana, I could never quite picture exactly what Poet's Corner was supposed to look like. Now I am quite proud to say that I do. The Abbey offers a convenient self-guided audio tour included in the admission price, which I highly recommend. It is a great experience simply to enjoy the amazing sculptures of various tombs within the Abbey, and the realization of who is buried within them is almost too much to grasp. The fact that it remains a functioning place of worship is also inspiring. You can pause once an hour for a prayer which is announced over the speakers of the Abbey, and they offer daily services for those who wish to participate. It is free to attend services.

Indoor Mausoleum . Beautiful iconic abbey loaded with history and mausoleum. A must see but be prepared for the crowd, pay for the audio tour. Grandiose. Don't miss Martin Luther King Jr.'s statue at the exit.

Walking in history. I've walked around Westminster Abbey two or three times and can't get over the history and people that have walked around before me. I sit around in poets corner and look at the memorials. It blows my mind to see all the names that are interred here or close by. Christmas day, 1066; William the Conquerer crowns himself in this very room! Come outside and look at the Parliament buildings. Where else can you see such magnificent architecture?
All the old graves. I was really impressed with the all structure of the building and was really impressed with the pew who were buried there it really opened my eyes.

Iconic and Historic. Royalty choose this abbey as their wedding, coronation, and funeral venue for a reason. It is stunning! And they are in good company; you can pay homage to some of the UK's greatest thinkers, artists, and leaders at their final resting place in Westminster. Note: this church is different from Westminster Cathedral.

Beautiful and impressive!. It was my first trip to London after visiting many other places on the globe so I thought it will be hard to impress me. I was wrong! Westminster Abbey is a very beautiful and impressive place. I must recommend using the free audio guide! The structure, decorations and the history of the place are interesting ad beautiful! This place has a true important role in the history of England. It is no wonder this is the coronation location for kings and queens!It’s a must see in London!
Westminster Abbey. By far the most famous church in London besides St.Pauls. add to your agenda when visiting London, Certainly worth looking into, just to admire the enormity of the building.

A must see for any London visit. What more can be said about this magnificent church!! There are wonders around every corner. The details. Admission is 20 pounds for adults. There are tours as well as audio guides. It's big, so it will take several hours for a quick view of everything. There are gift shops and food options. Nice, clean toilets. Can be crowded, so an early or late visit make sense.

The royal family church. And absolutely gorgeous church used by the royal family. It's location is very central to various other important attractions in London. Such as the church of Saint Paul which is the People's Church

Almost too much history, but in a good way.. I felt like I needed more time not only to walk through and see all the parts of the Abbey, but to process the experience afterward. It's pretty intense if you let yourself feel the weight of all that's happened here as you walk through! The audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons is top notch. Just take your time and soak it all in, and bring a sweatshirt if it's winter (it's a big stone building, don't be shocked when it's chilly).
Beautiful Church. This church is absolutely stunning. A lot of famous people are buried here. You can't take any photographs, but you can buy them in the store.

Kids activities made the difference. When we visited, there was a kids' map with puzzles and quests, and a reward of a giant gold coin. The kids were very engaged throughout the tour. The Abbey itself is very impressive, but crowded during the busy summer months.
Stunning church. The audio guide is very helpful and the church itself is so gorgeous. A lot of history and the decoration is so beautiful!

Absolutly Fabulous. We took advantage of the London Pass and started our Tour at Westminster Abbey. After a short time of waiting we entered this amazing cathedrale. It was stunning to stand their where Lady Di and William and Kate got married. Perfect way to Start the Day

Very good. I loved to see this amazing place where so many historical events have happened! The line was fast, so i spent there about 2 hours and read about its history and listened to a guide. Nice place!
Very cool to see where William and Kate got married. Hadn't planned on taking the tour but glad I did. We still did a condensed version but it was very interesting, not to mention a beautiful church.

So much history. Wow, you know it is old, but there is no comprehending the amount of history here. It is good advice to get here early and have pre-purchased tickets. We arrived about 10 minutes after opening and got in straight away. Once inside, you can go as fast or slow as you wish, you can elect to read everything, or listen to your audio guide about select things, depending on your time constraints. Unfortunately you are not able to take any photos within the Abbey itself, and there are very serious watchers to ensure that you comply. Lens caps have to be on all cameras, and no mobile phones are allowed out. The various influences on the architecture inside and the various plaques, memorials etc, the age of some of the pieces, it is all quite extraordinary and remarkable. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit. We were there when the gardens and cloisters were opened as well, and enjoyed these as well, and you were able to take photos here. After our visit we enjoyed a snack at the Cellarium. Well worth the time.
Awesome to be in a place of history.. Attend a service if you can.Note - no pics allowed to be taken inside.Clergy geared to deal with tourists.

incredible, fascinating history .. Take a Verger tour !! So happy we did ( you tube the cartwheeling Verger) Alas no pictures . Truly exciting . Beautiful . One of the best things we did . I ran out and bought books on English Kings and Queens. The gift shop has some good ones both for adults and some for kids were worthwhile too. I believe tickets are cheaper online.Either way online tickets help you skip an enormous line .
Incredible history. Self paced- and full of history. Great for families with older kids (who have had some experience with European History), but harder for smaller kids to "get into it."

Be careful when booking, staff is not helpful online or onsite. Yes it's a beautiful church though I could only see the main chapel itself. The website allowed me to select a same day booking but when I got there I was told it was too late in the afternoon to enter (around 1pm on a Saturday). Many, many other people had this same problem that were standing around the entrance with me, and we were being rudely told basically too bad and come back Monday. Well, many of us were not in town that long so basically just made a donation to the Abbey that we do not feel good about. I highly recommend they offer a refund (I also emailed and asked for this and was told again, too bad, non refundable). I would have probably said yes if they had kindly asked to make the fee a donation. but now am just annoyed. I've recommended the website block reservations if dates are not accurate (vs just processing them with the next available date-by then it's too late). No reply.

Take the Verger Tour!. Iconic. The absolute best way to see the Abbey is by taking a "Verger Tour", conducted by people who work in the Abbey. There are no "reservations" for Verger Tours, and they are not conducted at the same time every day. Immediately upon entering the Abbey ask any employee where to sign up for the Verger Tours, Tour sizes are limited to ten to twelve people and you are allowed to visit portions of the Abbey where other visitors are not allowed to go. It takes an hour and a half. Absolutely the only way to see the Abbey!!!

great building - lots of death bodies. quite bizzare that the Royals have choosen this location for weddings - its surrounded by coffins and death bodies or memorials - nevertheless it is very impressive
So magnificent. It is such a fantastic feeling to be in a place where so much history has taken place - royal weddings, coronations, funerals.

Overcrowded . Very nice place but extremely overcrowded that we had to leave less then halfway throughout westminster abbey. So many people that we could not move around and felt very claustrophobic and had to leave after paying a very large amount to get in and then they had the nerve to ask for donations on the way out. They need crowd control, seems like they just wanted to make money-lots of money, will not go there again.
A must. this was a must and it didn't disappoint enjoyed every minute of the tour all the history was a pleasant tour

Absolutely stunning church. This was on our list of must see attractions. It did not disappoint. The history is unbelievable. Well worth the price of admission. From what we see on TV, their is a lot more history in it, that I was unaware of before taking a tour through. You must see it.

Visit to westminster abbey.. Really interesting. Had use of audio guides free of charge. Very clear detailed information by Jeremy irons on the audio guide. Really enjoyed. Bit expensive as could not use buy one get one free tickets from virgin rail due to summer holidays but we enjoyed never the less.

Amazed by all of the history. This is a beautiful, historic sight. A MUST SEE in London. The audio guide was helpful in navigating, though some sections were long winded. I particularly likes seeing the tombs of Queen Mary, Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots. So much history in one place!

So Much History.!. My partner and I both visited Westminster Abbey before our tour of the Houses of Parliament, this being our first visit to the Abbey.Really wonderful Abbey, we spent a good few hours here just to make sure that we did not miss anything. The architecture in the Abbey is truly amazing and steeped in so much history. There are kings and queens, poets and many more historical people buried here. You got ourselves a hand held audio handheld each that tells you little stories about areas within the abbey or you could go for the guided tour.Unfortunately, the Museum was closed on the day we went, so we will have to come back to visit that. Overall, a really lovely day and definitely worth a visit.

loved it!. The Abbey was absolutely lovely. It was pretty crowded but the crowd was pretty spread out. When one of the guides found out we were from the US, she made sure to point out the stain glass window that was dedicated to the states.

Impressive. The traditional coronation, wedding and burial place for English monarchs is an imposing Gothic building with two, seventy meters high, towers, wide central nave and impressive entrances. It was built in the 16th century and since then witnesses almost all of the important events in British royal history. Impressive sight, full of history, where you can spend hours...
Worth it. As always buy your tickets on line you save money and jump the queue, beautiful, so glad I went. Cafe a rather expensive for travelers, nice food though. But not everyone.

Wow factor. Bristish history at every turn. So many famous people are burried here. Too many to mention. When we went it was Vetrans Day and they had each regiment of all their wars repesented outside in the front. Awesome eperience.

A Little Girls Dream. Watching royal weddings here since I was a child and have grown up seeing Westminster on television and in print. Finally stepping inside was the fulfillment of a dream. It is every bit as impressive as I imagined. Goose bumps and cold chills for this Anglophile.
Expensive but worth every penny. What an incredible place full of history and amazing architecture, it a pity that you are nor allowed to take photos as they would be nice to look back on.

Lovely Visit!. From here, you will see the Big Ben. This church is where Prince William and Kate got married. This is just few minutes walk from St. James Park, around 20-minute walk. Do not leave London without visiting the Abbey!

Loved it.. I have visited Westminister Abbey before and I Love it, I love the building, the history ,the atmosphere I always tell people it's a place they should visit at least once. I have been 3 times and find something new each time.
Beautiful and Interesting. We spent a few hours at Westminster. It was very interesting with lots to see. It is definitely worth a visit with the audio guided tour
Stunning Church. Arrive early to take in the tour at Westminster Abbey, either with a docent or with the electronic guide.

If you are going to London, this is a must-see.. I'm a big history buff, so keep that in mind. This place is unbelievable - like the Holy Grail of British history. Not cheap - I was kind of taken aback at the entrance fee, but you can stay as long as you like - you really need at least several hours to soak it all up - there is history everywhere you look. A feast for the eyes. Negatives - LOTS of tourists, whiny kids, photo-taking Asians, etc. Can get very crowded and you may find yourself swept along with the flow, but there are places that you can stop aside and take a breath. Nice gift shop. Remember that this is a house of worship and show some respect.

Swept up in the history. We spent several days in London with our 13 year old granddaughter who previously had little experience of British history. One of our stops was Westminster Abbey and she was fascinated. We were delighted to be with her seeing this magnificent church through her eyes.

A Must See In London. Very interesting and SO historical. A must see of the many historical landmarks. Go early and if you can try and get the tour with the personal guide who gives you the total historical picture of the Abbey. Well worth the time and price.

***Stunning***. A thousand years of awe-inspiring history. This was our first visit to the Abbey and we we're totally immersed and transfixed by the whole experience. History seeps out of the walls, floors and artifacts. To gaze upon the graves and tombs of kings, queens and famous people, brings history to life. We spent the whole afternoon here and only managed to see a fraction of the abbey. We visited at 1:30pm for about 3hrs, and although it was busy, we didn't have to wait too long to see most of the artifacts and tombs. The best part for us was seeing the tombs of Edward the Confessor, Henry V, Elizabeth I, Geoffrey Chaucer, Lawrence Olivier........etc, etc, etc..... and of course the tomb of the unknown warrior. We will definitely be going back for another visit soon....
Worth the effort to visit. Again, as most of London s attractions, easily to find with mass transit. Heavy tourist traffic as expected. Long lines with several small fussy children

Slice of the past. I could not believe I was inside Westminster. I was really pinching myself as I soaked up the history surrounding me. Definitely worth visiting if you are an historian or even if you are a royalist.

Cool place to visit filled with history. I enjoyed the visit because it was so close to Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament, making this church even more historically and culturally relevant. Going with a large family, it was definitely smart to buy the tickets ahead of time because it allowed us to skip the queue for tickets and go straight to the entrance. I would say we waited for 5 minutes max before going in. We also arrived around a half hour after it opened, timing it just right to avoid the tour groups that were also organizing to go in.For kids, the audio guide is pretty boring but the staff have a treasure clue hunt with questions regarding the historical tombs and monuments, which my little cousins really enjoyed. At the end, they get a chocolate gold coin, which they all loved. I'd also recommend going on a day where the rest of the areas are also open because those extra gardens and spaces were really beautiful!Overall, good place to absorb some history but it could be boring for the little ones.

There is nowhere in London like it!. This is the most incredible place to stop. We have been traveling to London for a few years and every trip, we make time in the schedule to stop here. Every trip delivers a new surprise and the Abbey is spectacular.
So much history. This Abbey is beyond beautiful. You aren't allowed to take pictures inside which is a real shame. But it is nice to put the camera away and just soak in all the beauty and history.

You can never go to Westminster too many times!!. We downloaded the Westminster app and it worked great and was right in line with the audio tour. We really enjoyed the Abbey and it is an amazing view of history and of beauty!! I hope it is around for another 200+ years!!

Absolutely Amazing!!!!. Probably my favorite place I saw while in London. We bought our tickets online, so that helped us get in much quicker. They don't let you take pictures inside but with good reason because you would never get done taking photos. So much history in one place. We spent about 2 hours doing the audio tour. The memorials and graves are breathtaking. Pay the 20 pounds, its worth the money. I recommend going early and getting your tickets in advance so you can enjoy your time before it gets busy.

Totally Amazing!!. The beautiful structure of this building must be seen from all sides.You will need to make sure you get a ticket to enter and learn about the history.It is best to go early morning to beat the crowd and is close on Sundays.
U.K. Holiday. Wonderful experience visiting this abbey. Full of history, atmosphere and amazing architecture.If your an English history buff this is a must visit.

Interesting Historical Tour. We toured Westminster Abbey one morning, which took about an hour or so. The tour was included as part of our London Pass, however, there is normally a £20 fee. The audio tour, which was extra, gave a fair amount of information on the building itself, it's history, and the people buried in it. My favorite part was Poet's corner, toward the end of the abbey.
Fabulous architecture. There was so much to see. Absolutely no way to see it all in a day. Don't miss seeing the oldest door in Britain.

Allow lots of time!. We foolishly thought we'd need less than an hour for this. We spent closer to 2, but really cut the visit short as we had other things on our agenda. The audio tour is wonderful. It is awe-inspiring just standing in the Abbey. Take the time to talk to a vicar if you see one wandering through. We did and that was one of the highlights of our time there. See how many famous people you recognize as being buried there. We saw quite a few that I didn't expect. Again, no photography is allowed which I see as a real shame. But the souvenir book wasn't too expensive.

breath taking place and its a must visit for all - historic london - to the marriage hall of kate and william. It was a beautiful experience with magnificient designing of architecture. Too bad coudnt take pictures, never seen anything like it we will be provided with memory orbs and press different buttons when we reach a place to know about it like a tour guide the way it was built was truly amazing and wonderful to look at and you must visit this place even chen would love it lots to see and explore including inside grounds with trees etc Must visit <3 also to truly like this you should kinda like historical stuff anyway thats what london is <3

Terrific tour with verger Benjamin. No doubt Westminster Abbey is a special place. For my husband and I, our experience was enhanced by the wonderful tour we received from the verger, Benjamin. You may have seen him on You Tube or CNN doing a cartwheel after the royal wedding of William and Kate. He wasn't aware the cameras were 'still rolling' when he expressed his joy for the happy couple with a cartwheel in his black robe! I had heard through friends that he gave an amazing tour of the Abbey (tours take place regularly throughout the day and are 5£ in addition to the price of admission), and we were not disappointed! Benjamin made the Abbey come alive for us during his 90-minute tour. You can ask if he is working when you sign up for your tour (at the Abbey entrance after you have purchased your admission ticket), and request his tour time. A truly memorable experience!

Best tour. This was my first stop, as it has always been on my bucket list. Got in line without a ticket, waited no longer than 20 minutes on a Friday midday. Tour was lovely, not rushed- you go at your own pace. Tour includes private headset. So wonderful and powerful. All staff was approachable and helpful. Clean restrooms.
If you like history you will love this place.. I spent roughly 2 hours in here just looking at all the beautiful and colorful artwork. The place seems buzz with history and mystery.

My Favorite Cathedral in Europe!. This is a must do! Some of the most famous people in history share their story through the Westminster abbey. With a guided tour and exquisite architecture, this is one of the most interesting churches I have seen. Be sure to check into the two for one tickets as the entrance is a little pricey.

Wow!! . We almost decided not to visit the Abbey during our visit this past weekend. I'm so glad we changed our minds. What a lovely place and jam-packed with so much history. It was crowded when we went but it was a Saturday - the Abbey is closed on Sundays. One of the most beautiful pieces of architecture that I've ever seen!

A FANTASTIC AFTERNOON WITH MY DAD AT THE ABBEY.. Dad finally made a visit to London at the age of 88,what a pleasant visit he had to Westminster Abbey, taking in the grandeur of the architecture and taking note of all the tombs and memorials throughout.A must for all tourists visiting London.

Amazing trip back into the begining of English history. Amazing historical Abbey that dates back to the beginning of England. Great view of history because of the graves, the architecture and memorials. From Issac Newton to Chaucer, the graves of Queen Elizabeth the 1st, and her sister Mary. Really worth the entry fee. The architecture and history of its expansion are really impressive.

Not to be missed. If you like history, it doesn't get much better than this. Cost is a little expensive, but it probably cuts down on the crowds. Audio devices were extremely helpful but a little confusing. Found myself sometimes struggling to determine were I should be to match up with the recording.

Amazing history. We enjoyed Westminister Abbey - it contains so much amazing history. Many famous people are buried there and that is very interesting, but it contributes to sort of a dark feeling of death. The architecture is fabulous though and it is definitely a must see while in London.

THIRD VISIT & STILL AMAZING. This was my third visit to Westmnster Abbey. It's still amazing. The history within these walls is amazing. Its around 20 pound entrance I think. We had the London Pass so it was included in that. Well worth every cent. Queen Elizabeth 1 is buried here along with her sister Queen Mary, and Mary Queen Scots is also buried here too. If you are isiting London this is amust, also the Houses of Parliment are just across the road,so make sure you get your tickets for that as well and do them at same time.

A must see!. My favorite place that we visited! The architecture is beautiful. I didn't know anything about the place so I didn't expect to see all the tombs and resting places of all the Kings and queens. Free audio tours guide tells you all the stories of the most prominent people. If you go for Sunday services you can get in for free. Near the exit you can have lunch or tea in the cellar where the monks use to keep all their food and wine!
Beautiful Architecture. A gorgeous place to stop and just take in the wonderful and intricate decor that makes up this beautiful abbey. A definite must see for everyone visiting London.
Atmosphere truly awesome. Although there were lots of people there my wife and I found it strangely peaceful by looking around us and taking in the aura we were transported to another world

This place is amazing . It's the most beautiful building I have ever seen. You could earn several Phds in history just from studying this place. Stay for a service if you can. The Abby is still a working active church.

Historical "Awe" effect. What can you say, when such a culturally iconic property comes to life in front of you? It doesn't come out and bite you, I think you have to be invested in seeing this piece of history. Buy your tickets in advance and go first thing in the morning. Again, buy your tickets in advance; it will allow you to skip a long line. Also, download the app from iTunes before you go there as we did not have data and had to try and use the QE centre across the street's free wifi to download and it didn't work well. No photos or video is allowed inside.
Lots of history. If you know your history you will love all the folks that are buried there. Architecture is interesting....but not as beautiful as St. Paul,s Cathedral.

Awesome experience!. Had the opportunity to attend evening prayer at Westminster in July of '16. It was a very memorable experience, as you are allowed to be in the Abbey when the rest of the normal tours are over. In addition to the service, got to see the tomb of Isaac Newton. Being an engineer myself - this was a definitely a bonus.

Beautiful abbey . Awe inspiring architecture and craftsmanship. What can be said about the abbey that hasn't been said so muchbetter than we could say & said for many centuries .We attended a sung Evening Prayer & it was a memorable experience.I have been to the abbey on a number of occasions over the years & I have one complaint.The quality of the food served in the cafeteria has greatly deteriorated , the service is not A1 either.Meals were left half eaten near us. I had only coffee & ' Victorian Sponge' Just 2 hefty slabs of what is really only a 'VictorianSandwich'( a type of butter cake) & only made edible with lots of jam & cream filling. Very disappointing . Whatever happened to the old crew?
Organ Recital 4th September 2016, by Donald Cook.. Magnificent performance by Donald Cook.Well organized event.Highly recommend.30 mins of Heavenly music.

Time's Attic. There is not much one can write that has not already been written about one of London's most iconic sites. Seven hundred-year old Westminster echoes with history. Within its walls, memorials, shrines, tombs and statues of seventeen monarchs and 3,300 British notables vie with one another for space. At times, it seems a jumble that detracts from seeing the actual interior. It is not the most beautiful religious edifice, but it most certainly is a monument to the nation's rich and bloody history.My favorite area was the Lady's Chapel with its richly fan-vaulted ceiling. Magnificently carved mahogany stalls contrast with the light-colored stone walls and ceiling of this chapel. These stalls were used by the Knights of the Order of the Bath and are adorned with the crest, coat of arms and heraldic banner of each knight.Audio guides are a must during the visit as it is sometimes difficult to figure out where you are as you snake your way around the abbey. My spouse and I spent three hours since you can walk at your own pace without being hurried and shuffled from place to place. We especially enjoyed hunting down the tombs of the more famous such as Darwin and Newton, along with the notables buried in the Poet's Corner.We also enjoyed seeing the cloister and garth, so don't leave without a visit.The Chapter House was closed to the public at the time, which was a disappointment.We arrived in the morning on May 09, found a long line had already formed, and expected an excruciating wait. But the line moved at a fast pace. The senior rate was 17 pounds each, and we were able to use our credit card. It was more than we paid for any other church or cathedral during our two-week tour of Great Britain. But then, one rarely has the opportunity to walk through Time's Attic.

A MUST SEE. As everyone says this is one of the most beautiful places in London. I highly recommend you spend some time here. Please do remember to be respectful, this is a place of worship and an important space to many people.
Historic. Beauty and awe inspiring. Many famous people buried there. Each crib is historically interesting and nothing like I've ever seen before. Worth going to.

Amazing architecture. This is a beautiful Abbey, I have been to London hundreds of times and have always wanted to come here, finally. I came here with family, me, my husband, brother in law and 9 year old nephew. I would think about bringing younger children here, as my nephew got bored really quickly and it ruined it a little as my husband and I wanted to spend a few hours here making sure we didn't miss anything. The architecture is amazing and steeped in so much history. There are kings and queens, poets and many more historical people buried here. You get an hand held audio machine telling you little stories about areas within the abbey or you could have a guided tour. We choose for the audio machine. Unfortunately, the Museum was closed on the day we went, but I believe that is really good too. There is a coffee shop, toilets and a souvenir shop inside the Abbey. Not sure it is suitable for wheelchairs as there are a few tight places. Overall, a lovely, interesting abbey,
WOW...so much history here.. We enjoyed the tour and found so many interesting factoids. Knowing that Lady Diana's coffin passed down the isle of this church sent chills up my spine..
Historic.... We opted for a paid tour of Westminster and it was well worth it. We were guided by a resident verger who knew his stuff back to front. Note that you cannot take pictures inside.
Incredible!. The amount of history in this one building, especially if you love English history, is amazing. If you go the guided tour is well worth it.

Beautiful architecture and design, lots of history. Definitely recommend the audio guide. We came with London Pass so we were able to wait on a much shorter queue. Lots of British history in here, was interesting to see that there were sections dedicated to scholars and poets. I really enjoyed the beauty of the Abbey!
Don't miss this. Yes, it's expensive and crowded and utterly "tourist-y", but the Abbey is also remarkable. Be sure to visit!

Important historical building. A very important historical building containing kings, queens and other important people in British history.My mother and I were in awe of the number of notable people buried here, the grandness of the tombs and the craftsmanship of the sculptures. It is difficult to take it all in, so would recommend the audio guide. The cafe (waited service) and gift shops are also very good.

Beautiful Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster. About:Westminster Abbey is a must see living pageant of British history and magnificent architecture. It is one of the UK’s ’s most notable religious buildings.The ex-cathedral and abbey is the traditional place of coronation and burial site for British and english monarchs and royal weddings.Again a must visit for Art and History lovers.Just round the corner is Big Ben and London Eye.

A must see!!. The only reason I didn't give this 5* is that I feel it's absolutely ridiculous to ask anyone to pay into a church. It's simply wrong. It was £20 or £25 each. Shocking. I've travelled the world and visited alot of churches and I've never had to pay into one ever. But because of its significance in history (royal wedding/ Charles Dickens/ William Shakespeare), I needed to visit. It was amazing. You can't take pictures inside but it's definitely worth a visit. I did expect it to be kept better (old chewing gum embedded into the beautiful floors at the entrance for example), but that aside it's an amazing experience that I feel lucky to have had the opportunity to experience.

Extremely boring place took 15 minutes to view. Not sure what we were expecting from our trip to Westminster Abbey but it certainly was not what we got,If costs about £20 quid to get in and luckily nothing to get out. Its basically a very old large church and from the outside is quite impressive, however supplies with an audio tour doodah that was as good as it got. An awful lot of people buried/interred there are no-name non-entities from the past ,who probably were rich enough to pick a plot there, Along with a load of Royal flunkies we have never heard of, all buried under a large slab of stone in the floor - fascinating not- OK they have a couple of kings,prime ministers,explorers and err poets,Not enough information or even portraits of these so say important people. The audio guide is the most boring thing I have ever listened to. The place was full of international tourists milling about the place, But as Brits we felt totally under whelmed and could'nt wait to get out of there,would I recommend it only for a wet Sunday afternoon if you are feeling suicidal
Wow!. This is the highlight of our London trip. Rich of history and art. We liked the handheld audio recorded tour, because it's easy to follow and allows you to proceed at your own pace.

Well worth visiting. I've been meaning to visit for years and it doesn't disappoint. The audio tour by Jeremy Irons was very informative but also relaxing and you can go at your own pace. The history and architecture are stunning.

Historical Heaven. I would recommend any visitor to London to visit the cathedral. It encapsulates everything London has to offer. The historical content is quite overpowering. The architecture is stunning and foreboding. Match that with the serenity of being in a church, simply wonderful. On a practical level, I would advise trying to buy your tickets before your visit. Use the free earphones, they provide a great guide to the cathedral. There is a cafe and toilets on site. The main thing is enjoy the cathedral.
Splendid area. This place has a lot of history. The free walking tour took me around Westminster. The Big Ben is a major attraction here.

Great architecture. If you have been following any news or even had British history in school you would know how significant this place is to the royals. We went to the Abby and were awe struck, the inside is as beautiful as the outside. They have maintained it very well. As visitors you have to buy tickets to go in, If you want to pray you will have to see the timings and go accordingly, it is free to people who want to attend mass. The glass paintings inside are just stunning, especially of Queen Mary and Victoria. Must visit when you go to London
So much History . Such a beautiful church it does take quite awhile to see the Abby. Suggest to get there early. Buy your passes in advance it is the best way to do it or go with the London Pass.
Lots of people lots of walking. Amazing! And the free audio guides supplied in multiple languages is a must! The architecture is just amazing.
Lots of people lots of walking. Amazing! And the free audio guides supplied in multiple languages is a must! The architecture is just amazing.
Must do. Extremely interesting piace of history. Very beautiful interiors. Best as part of London Tour, expensive otherwise. Must do.
Just for the photo op . This cost 20£ per adult. For us that was just to expensive for a quick walk through. We stuck to the outside got our pictures and moved on

Soooo Much History. Again, I have looked forward to visiting this historic cornerstone and the actual visit left me open mouthed in awe!!! Love the guides and the audio and the hourly prayer to remind us all why this amazing structure is the center and resting place of so much history. Buy the souvenir book it's worth the $

Delightful Music. We visited the Abbey for their Evensong at 5:00 and thoroughly enjoyed the music of the Lay Vicars Singers who were scheduled for the evening we were there. The music added to the beauty of the structure and was the highlight of our visit to the Abbey. Highly recommend that you take the time to visit the Evensong!
Beautiful. Beautiful building, filled to the brim with history. The audio tour guide has loads of information. Definitely worth a visit.

Favorite part of the trip. What a wonderful place. Steeped in history. And what an experience, knowing I was walking down the isle where suche events as royal weddings and funerals had talekn place. Awe inspiring.

Great Architecture. The Abbey is a really beautiful building. It can take about 2 hours to see it all and marvel at the architecture. Well worth a visit, but the price to go in what is technically a church is very expensive.

History of Nobles comes to life. Besides the beauty of the Church itself, seeing the burials of all the famous people in English History was amazing. They also had names of famed people that are buried elsewhere, but their names are still listed like winston Churchill. But the most impressive to me was Queen Elizabeth 1st, and her sister Mary.

Extremely interesting. Quite expensive to get in but well worth the money. Architecture breath taking, tomb to the unknown soldier very moving, it is the burial place for many famous historical figures. You can do your own Acoustiguide audio tour which I defiantly recommend.The only thing I would say if you want to see ever thing it can take up to 2 hours and young children would soon become very bored

Amazing Architecture. If you are by the parliament houses you will also want to stop by Westminister Abbey, which is right across the street. The architecture is so beautiful, its amazing how things like that were built so long ago without technology..

Disappointed . Wanted to see inside and light a candle for recently bereaved. Disappointed it was £20 a head, it is a church after all which should be free. Instead went inside St Margarets church next door, which was beautiful. Said a prayer, lit a candle and left a donation. No charge for entrance at St Margarets

Amazing building. Hard to believe that this cathedral is several hundred years old and yet tourists can appreciate the tombs, sculptures and artifacts up close and personal. Photography is not allowed.
Fantastic. We did this as part of the London Pass. The audio tour let's you go through at your own pace. The abbey is so rich in history and there is lots to see.
Historic Church. This place is amazing.....steeped in history. A must see if you're into anything like that. The staff are extremely knowledgeable.

Packed with people . We did all the wrong things, Sunday on a long weekend in summer about 1100. We did take a tour with a verge and felt that was worth the money. You got to see a few places the general public did not get to. My recommendation, no surprises, go mid week, middle of winter. That said it is an amazing place and I don't regret going despite the teaming masses.
More expensive. I think the entrance is too expensive when it really is can see. that's visit once and since this. not would go honestly. to see tombs don't need to pay 20 pounds entry per person

History at large. A lovely old Abby, we paid to get in and followed the suggested route, please be aware that there is no photography allowed in the Abby due to how old everything is, although tell this to foreign tourists, I did speak to one American who was happily taking photos,that he shouldn't as it damages things, he looked disgruntled but did stop.The coronation throne was being restored in a small cubicle with a viewing window where you could watch, the gravestones of famous actors and people were a good find , tomb of the unknown warrior as well
Beautiful!!!. Amazing history, we had a personal guide that shared some quirky stories about the people from this era.
Amazing!. Such history and elaborate architecture and details! Well worth a visit here as so many prominent people are buried here.

Do not miss it!. It is magnificent. History and spirituality are palpable. Best, if you're willing, is to attend a service and really understand the Abbey as a vibrant part of London, not just a tourist attraction. If you can attend a choral service, the acoustics are amazing.
Loved ir. We loveoved it and appreciated the shear beauty and history of it . But the self guided tour can be confusing. We were in the wrong spots a few times.

Always something new. I have been to Westminster Abbey 5 times, and every time I discover something new. The architecture is incredible, and looking at all the memorial stones of people buried there is fantastic. I recommend getting the audioguide.

Nice, but not worth £20. The Abbey is beautiful. But with only a cumbersome audio guide (one you hold to your head like a telephone) that mostly focusses on those buried here, I didn't think it was worth a full £20.

Amazing. Drove up past with open top bus and also taxi.
So amazingly close to Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament and the river. Beautiful to all by, stop and stare or go in.
So much history.

worth returning in the evening. Very nicely organized audio tour. The children have their own tour which they enjoyed a lot. Lots of history in this place, not to miss. We also returned for a 30-minute organ recital on Sunday at 5pm.

Expensive, very busy, but a must.. This place is very expensive to visit, it is very busy and if you don't buy tickets online you will get in a huge line-up. Inside it is full with visitors. However, the place is so full of history that it is almost a must to visit when you are in London.

Amazing. The church is so amazing. The structure and decor is absolutely amazing to just soak in. Then the history on top of that just makes it an incredible visit. It was crazy thinking of the people who had been crowned there and mourned for there. Seeing all the graves of historic figures was hard to wrap my head around that they were actually buried there or had been there. You get a free audio guide at the beginning which I found really helpful. Since there are a lot of people in there, it was nice being able to listen to the guide when you couldn't get near enough to read the signs. The guides also come in many languages. We went for opening which I would highly recommend. It gets busy very quickly so it was nice being there early. We also had the london pass so we had a bit of a fast pass in. I would also recommend giving yourself at least 2 hours to do it if not more. There is so much to see and read.

Beautiful and filled with history!. Such an incredible place like many churches in EU no photos. The many buried there or memorialized there is incredibly fascinating--Darwin? NEwton?! Use head set tour. Amazing!
Incredibly beautiful.. centuries of worship in such a beautiful place....from stained glass to poet's corner,there is much to see and learn here.

A truly amazing place . We were fortunate to have one of the best tour guides, knowledgeable, with a sense of humour and able to sustain our attention the whole time. I would have to say this is one of the best historical places I have been to, due to the amount of history in there. Take the guided tour for an extra 5 pound it is e best investment and you get to see a few more places others don't get admission to. Well worth it

One of the Best Cathedrals in the World!. Westminster is a beautiful cathedral with so many famous people buried there. It is a cathedral and a crypt. I watched the wedding of William & Kate. How fun to see the spots where they were married & think back on those memories. Fantastic choir & pipe organ. Regular church goers in particular should attend a service, evensong, or organ recital. This was my third visit there & I always enjoy going back. It should be at the top of your list if you visit London.

Crowded - beautiful - expensive. We went on a weekday in the late morning and found a line to get in but it moved quickly enough. Once inside it took a little bit to get our bearings as far as where to go especially because it was so crowded. The admission price is a bit steep but it does include an audio guide which was definitely needed to gain insight into what we were seeing. It was interesting to see the markings for the famous people buried in the Abbey such as Charles Dickens, T. S. Eliot, Newton, and Darwin. The church is beautiful inside and out. Unfortunately the only place inside where you can take photos is in the cloisters. There are toilets in the area of the cloisters as well.
Amazing History!. I'm not a big history buff, but even I was in awe at the beauty and significance of Westminster Abbey. The place was overwhelmingly crowded at times, but well worth the visit.

Essentially a museum, not a place of worship, awful staff. It is ludicrously expensive to get into despite this it gets very crowded making it difficult to see sometimes. I know Westminster Abbey rather well, having been to a local school that was serviced by the Abbey and hence my children and I chose not to use the free audio guide. Despite this a few minutes after entering the abbey a verger comes up to us telling us to use an audio guide, despite my saying we'd prefer not to his response of "well, really!" was rude aggressive and unwarranted. Visually the place is crowded and not just with shrines, plaques and graves. The information leaflet and signage is poor and visitors seem to dump their litter is all sorts of peculiar nooks and crannies. We were herded around a set walking route, fair enough, but then we see another verger tap dancing in the nave and discussing loudly whether there was anything under the flagstones with his colleagues before dancing again. Most extra-ordinary is a doorway tucked away labelled Britain's oldest door........ no evidence, no background nothing surely Britain's oldest "known" door........... You are also not able to see Edward the Confessor's Shrine - not acceptable for such a huge entrance fee - I am hardly likely to attend a service at 8am in the morning on a Tuesday to see it - we get it's old, fragile etc but sort something - even if it's only a visual by a video link. There's also no point signing medieval floor tiles when they're covered by line.......... surely some of them could be covered with acrylic? All in all underwhelming given the extensive history of the building, the staff need a lesson in manners and the place needs to decide whether it is a church and or a museum as at the moment the balance is simply not right.

Excellent tour. The abbey is well geared for tourists. The audio unit provided as part of the entry fee is excellent and provides detailed explanations of what you are seeing.It's a fascinating view of history and wonderful being able to see the tombs and memorials to so many famous characters from the past. You need a couple hours to see the place. Recommended.Not so sure about eating at the Cellarium cafe though - the cakes and scones were pretty dry and tasteless.
Beautiful. Very Beautiful both inside and out! Fantastic opportunity to go inside the Abbey and look at all the architectureStaff are very helpful and friendly

Amazing. Went in to get out of the rain and so glad we did, what an amazing place. Full of history and we spent hours just walking around as there is so much to see. Will return again as it was so good

A trip through history. If you like British history then this is for you - not too crowded either unlike most attractions in London during August. Do use the audio units which are included in the price - they are very informative.
Very busy. The Abbey is a wonderful place to visit, it was very busy the day we were there. I would advise buying tickets online beforehand to save waiting in the queue.

So much history in one place. My wife and I went on Bank Holiday Monday. Hardly any queue to enter and seemed to be well marshalled on entry. £20 for adults and $17 for concessions (over 60's and students. I would say well worth the money. So many Kings, Queens and other persons (don't want to spoil it, but absolutely loved Poets Corner).We just missed the 11am tour (maximum of 20 people) and included in the entry price was the audio system, which we were very impressed with, not too deep with just enough information. Many parts of the abbey are tight and the audio reminds you at this stage to assist by not lingering too long. All persons did exactly as they were asked and there are several times you can just sit and look around you, its amazing how much more you can see from floor to roof. Toilets well placed towards the end (and clean) of your visit and 2 shops with the usual fare plus some extras, my wife chose Christmas Tree decorations (as you do). I never saw a single flash from a camera and people seemd to be extremely well behaved. If in London I would recommend you visit. There is a café near the exit but we did not visit

History everywhere. While it was crowded, everything was seeable and the audio guide was very helpful. I was not prepared for the impact of the Poet's Corner - tombs/memorials of so many authors I grew up reading and loving. There were chairs out in this area for people to take a bit longer, if desired. Also, practically speaking, it was very nice that they let us exit to go to the bathroom and then come back in. Gift shop was outside and there were a couple of snack places beside it, as well.

Beautiful church!. The church itself is beautiful and has the crypts of many royals and famous individuals. An audio tour is included in the entrance fee. It is hard to imagine how it was constructed before modern machinery. We had afternoon tea in the tea room and it was just lovely.

Take your time!!. Again as it's my first time here but my wife's second this was another insisted visit. I LOVED IT!!! I am by no means religious but the history inside this magical place is phenomenal! Such a treat to be able to view such things and be amazed at the age of some things. It is very regimented there and they don't miss a thing but it's the only way to keep the Abbey in A1 condition. Definitely worth the visit. Not ideal for children though in my opinion.

Make time to see this. This tour was included as part of our "London Pass". This was the first tour that we took. Make some time to see the beautiful church's architecture. We had a self guided audio tour that was very informative.

Busy and packed with lots to see if you can manage the crowds.. Buy your tickets in advance. Audio guide is well worth it. Definitely a place to see if interested in British History and "Royal Stories".

Definitely worth a visit!. I visited the Abbey on a Tuesday lunchtime in August 2016. It was a lovely day but whilst the grounds of the Abbey were busy, the queues were minimal. Perhaps potential visitors preferred to enjoy the sunshine.This was my first time inside the Abbey. It is a beautiful building and packed with history. I don't resent paying £20 to get in somewhere this good: to those who complain, I would ask how else they expect the building to be maintained. Highly recommended.
The Abbey. Definitely an architectural marvel with so many details. Wish I could have gone inside but I arrived too late.
Beautiful Architecture. The Abbey is a beautiful building and there is so much history. We found it fascinating seeing the final resting place of so many historical figures.

Go for evensong. I have done tours of the Abbey but my favorite visit was evensong service on a Sunday evening. The music was wonderful and it just felt special to be in a church that is hundreds of years old.

Awesome - Don't miss this!. You rarely see so much history packed into one location - impressive architecture accompanied by thousands of historical figures buried or commemorated inside. Make use of the audio guide that's included with admission.
If you arrive at 3:00 you'll have 90 minutes to tour and then stay for evensong which starts at 5:00. The choir was wonderful.
Just amazing . From the second Jeremy Irons started the audio tour I was hooked the history and amazing architecture was breathtaking. I would whole heartedly recommend a visit here.

Good with plenty to see - e-guides included. The family fee of about £40 seems high but this include the e-guides. Very organised and the e-guides are good. Takes a couple of hours to go round. If you want to see the gardens make sure you go in the morning and check the website for times.

A Pleasant Surprise. We were running late coming from Buckingham Palace. The Abbey on that day (a Saturday) took its last entrants a bit on the early side as they had church service. Be sure to check entry times. We are so grateful we made the time cut off. I highly recommend using the audio guide. The church areas are intricate and there is so much to learn about each room. Be sure to allow enough time. We took an hour and felt a bit rushed. The grounds are beautiful as well. Don't miss this!

Fantastic!. What a beautiful church! Takes about 2 hours to see. Well worth the time and effort. Make sure you ask for the senior discount if you are one or the student discount if you are one. I highly recommend Westminster Abbey on your trip to London!

Worth the Long Wait. Got to Westminster Abbey about 9:10 for the 9:30 opening and there still was a huge line. This is one of the few places that does not have a Fast Pass line. They opened exactly at 9:30 so we waited about 25 minutes. Once inside though you will agree that it is worth the wait. There were so many little rooms to go in and read about the person buried there, etc. I consider myself a "fast reader" but we still were there over two hours. You get a headset that is very easy to use. It will say go ahead to number one and then it will talk about it. The church was absolutely breathtaking! Wish I could have taken pictures inside but they are not allowed. This is probably why once inside the crowds move smoothly from room to room. Everyone inside is in awe and respectful of the premises.

Extraordinary Experience. This a must see and worth the price of admission. The sheer beauty and history in the Abbey can't be properly conveyed without seeing it for yourself. Be sure to a lot at least 3 hours time for a "quick" walk thru tour, if not 5-6 hours for proper exploring.

Amazing!. A London must see if you love history. Bring comfortable walking shoes and note that there are some steps and a lot of walking for people that have limited mobility. I bought tickets in advance but still waited in line for about an hour. The way to avoid this is to buy from the official Westminster Abbey site and not a 3rd party.

Must See. We visited the abbey with London Walks and really appreciated the great experience provided by our guide,in fact we can't imagine going in without him. The abbey is so rich in history and full of great stories.

An amazing part of history. We visited the Abbey last week and found it fascinating. The audio tour (included with admission) is great. There are so many interesting facts and sights, and it was neat to see something in person that we have seen on televison many times. The only thing I didn't like was that you can't take photos inside (there were so many awesome shots), but it is understandable given the high volume of people.

Est 960 - Wow!. If you are a fan of history or architecture this place is not to be missed! With more than 3000 people buried or commemorated in the abbey, amazing art, statuary, and stained glass expect to spend at least an hour inside, more if you get the audio guide. I used my London Pass to gain a quick entry – look for the London Pass sign. To be in the place where William the Conqueror was crowned in 1066 to where William and Kate were married was a remarkable feeling. This is a working Church with Holy Communion mornings at 8am. You can find all service times, lots of information on the history and a virtual tour on their website.Westminster Abbey is magnificent in so many ways! It is definitely one of my favorite historical places and is easily accessible.
Stunning. An amazing place. Even our teen was impressed by the history, beauty, and the names of the notables buried here. Poet's corner gave me goosebumps.
A very big church. Outside wounderful but inside we didn't find it so great because. You can't go your own way as in St.Pauls.
Lots of Royal Weddings, not much else.. I cannot say that this is worth passing a few tourist attractions for. Does not 'tickle my boat'. Maybe your cup of tea?

Amazing! . I've visited a few churches around Europe but this one was up there as one of, if not the best. After paying for your entry you receive a free audio guide which was very informative and made the visit a lot more interesting although just the beauty of the church itself was worth it. I would suggest visiting the tower of London first to get a bit of history behind those whose bodies lie in the tombs of Westminster Abbey. We spent about an hour and a half here. Note: No photography is allowed inside the church.

Quite lovely. I enjoyed a lovely service on Sunday. The Abbey is positively stunning and the service was wonderful. I would definitely recommend attending a service but would also recommend going back on a day that you can tour and view the Abbey as well. Sundays are reserved for worship only.

Head In For Evensong. If Anglican or a Christian denomination, iHi would recommend heading to Evensong for a moving traditional service. On the evening we visited, the Boys Choir sung superbly. By all means do the guided tour earlier in the day for a full historical understanding then look at other sites or grab afternoon tea and return late afternoon/early evening for the service.

Stunning Westminster Abbey's. Get the majestic, glory and historical feel of this wonderful building. You need to be there to understanding what I mean . So if possible, if it is your trip to london, do visit. It is worth whatever entrance and have at least a minmum of four hours to enjoy the place.

Massive cathedral and history museum. It is important to remember when entering Westminster Abbey that it an active Anglican church with members and services like any other church. As such, it is also subject to closure to tourists during those services. We ran into that, but were still able to tour the abbey quite nicely in the late afternoon (just rearranged the plans for the day). So much of England's history -- it's kings and queens, statesmen, artists, and poets -- are in that one place. It is truly awesome (in the correct sense).

A walk through British history. A wonderful building where the remains of so many famous people are buried or have memorials. The architecture is magnificent, and the huge number of people buried there over such an amazing stretch of history has to be seen to be believed. We paid extra to have a guided tour, it was well worth the money and lasted nearly two hours.
London visit of my cousin from Milan . The abbey is also in Parliament Squre so you can't miss it. It. is another British landmark that's unmissable so check it out and have a photo or two or more.

Awe-inspiring and one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. A must for any history buff... I have only good things to say about this. Very beautiful and you have an audio tour guide you keep with you that informs you what everything is along the way which you can listen to as many times as you want and you can meander throughout the place at your own leisure. The only complaint I have is that photography is not allowed.
Excellent. This is worth the money. Take your time going around the Abby and listen to the guides cand the head phone set...its history is incredible

Organ Concert - great way to see inside . We enjoyed Westminster Abbey. With a large family, we weren't eager to pay the hefty entrance fee to tour the Abbey. Instead we attended an excellent organ concert for free and were able to see the inside. We didn't walk the entire cathedral - not allowed. But our kids felt like they saw enough while sitting for the concert. I think concerts are on Sunday's, late afternoons. The cathedral is quite beautiful. But the organ concert made it come alive. If it had just been my spouse and I, we may have paid the fee to tour it.

incredible site of history and beauty. This was an amazing church. The grave of Newton and Darwin were both there! As well as many kings and other incredible people. The architecture is just amazing. The audio tour is wonderful, Jeremy Irons is the narrator. There is a tour for kids that is fun to do. And it is all just totally breath-taking. Plan for 3 hours, at least. Then try to get reservations for Cellerium, the monks used to live there, where you can have high tea!
Awesome way to spend a few hours. My teenagers were asking and asking to go inside and to my surprise they spent over two hours there. They absolutely loved it.

Westminster Abbey. You could spend an entire day here looking & reading everything. Make sure you at least go thru as fast as you need too.....because it is well worth any amount of time spent. Absolutely fascinating!

Westminster Abbey. This was the first major site we visited on our day trip to London and we could have made our entire trip about this only. So much history! The line to get in wasn't too bad and the staff inside was excellent. I still can't believe I was actually inside. This is one site that I could visit over and over again.

Stunning. The highlight of our trip to London - majestic, historical, beautiful. Felt chills as we toured the grounds with the audio-guide narrated by Jeremy Irons. No photographs allowed and take care not to jump the velvet rope lest invoking the ire of the Abbey staff (they weren't too pleased with my friend who made that mistake).

AWESOME. This has so much to see, besides the architectural beauty and the wonderful stained glass windows and altars and on and on, several ( hundreds) of very famous individuals are entombed here- with an impressive poets/artists corner. It's really lovely. There is an audio tour available.
Interesting . Very interesting place. Beautiful, long history. Nicely presented. Recommended highly. Specially with your London pass
Beautiful Architecture. Westminster Abbey is simply beautiful. This should be one of the places you must visit when you are in London.

Definite must-see. We were in London for 3 days and this was high on our list. It did not disappoint. We got tickets ahead from the concierge at our hotel so we didn't have to wait in line. We were pleased to be able to claim the concession rate "senior discount." This is basically a cemetery for the famous. The audio guide was well worth it to hear more about those that are buried there. Don't miss the Chapter House in a corridor near the end of the tour. There are wall paintings and floor mosaics from medieval times.

Impressive. Westminster is a must-see when visiting London. Filled with interesting history and stunning architecture. Audio guide tour available which takes you through the cathedral. There can be a line so best to visit early morning if possible.

AMAZING!!!. We took the tour of Westminster Abbey while in London and were not disappointed. The history of the Abbey is unbelievable. The highlight of our tour was when they performed the church service. My husband and I sat down and thoroughly enjoyed the entire service. I was able to take communion and was thrilled to be able to participate in such a memorable event. The chance to experience this will be the highlight of my visit to the Abbey.

Definitely visit!. We visited on a Friday morning in early July. We showed up about 40 minutes before opening and were fifth in line. I highly recommend arriving early in the day as the crowds do swell as the day goes on. A heads up that there are two entrance lines, the one found on the right hand side as you face the door is for those with the London Pass while the line on the left is for those buying tickets. Another visitor explained a staff person had come out shortly before we arrived and told them where to stand. I am glad they did as the London pass line up was significantly longer and we were buying our tickets (using the National Rail 2for1 vouchers). There was no signage explaining this at first so that was a little confusing. In fact, the signage did not go out until about 5 minutes before they opened. If you plan on taking the free audio guide tour, I recommend downloading the audio guide app on your phone before arriving. It is very user friendly and interesting. I actually listened to part of it while waiting in line to get in. You cannot take pictures inside which I understand, but would have still loved to do given the beauty and grandeur of it all. We did not take the paid tour, but did hear snippets from tour guides as they passed by and it sounded very good. I was the only one that really wanted to visit Westminster Abbey while in London so my family went there mainly because they knew it was important to me. In the end, my husband and three teenagers all found things they appreciated there as well. We spent just over two hours there including a short visit to the gift shop. I probably could have stayed a little longer, but I could tell my kids had their fill by then and it was also starting to get much more crowded. It was well worth the admission cost and it is one of my favorite destinations while in London.

Beautiful, but no pictures allowed. I thoroughly enjoyed the Abbey. It is a beautiful place, and very large. Give yourself at minimum an hour to explore ( preferably two or three). There are no photos allowed, which was a bit of a disappointment to me. It would have been nice to have as a memory.

By tickets online. If you buy your tickets online you will save considerable time not waiting in the long lines, especially in the summer. The included audioguide is excellent. Using the audioguide, a visit should take about one hour & a quarter.

Great for kids. I wasn't sure that my 11y/o girl and 9 y/o boy would get much out of the abby, but we did the scavenger hunt and they LOVED it. I am so glad we went and visited the historical site and the kids really got something out of the visit. When they were finished they got a free chocolate from the shop for completing the scavenger hunt -- another great motivator.
Just beautiful. Westminster Abbey is just beautiful! It is breath taking both inside and out. One may spend as much time as he or she chooses to explore the abbey.

Must visit place in London. After visiting Big Ben walk to Westminster Abbey. Take your widest lens to photograph the place. Beautiful place , you may take the guided tour if you want to know more about it.

Queue to the left for tickets, right door is London Pass people.. Worth the price of admission. Full of monuments and crypts of the famous, including Poet's Corner if you are literary. Take the free tour phone but they not foolproof and a bit long. Look for little numbers for the rooms to go by.

Full of interesting (dead) people. Westminster Abbey is definitely a historic place, and it is full of graves and memorials of famous people. Most notable (in my opinion) are Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin. I find it interesting that Darwin (famous for his theory of evolution) is buried here. No photos are allowed inside the Abbey. I recommend giving yourself 2-3 hours to explore it, especially if you are doing the audio tour.
My Absolute Favorite Place in London!. My Absolute Favorite Place in London! I could have spent hours here (but with two small kids that's rough). There is SO much to see. It's absolutely stunning!

25 GBP admission but certainly worth it. I would rate this as the number 1 place to visit on a trip to London. Granted the admission price of 25 GBP is high, especially when you see that they don't keep things maintained very well. Over 3000 famous people are buried here. The audio tour is free and I highly recommend that you take advantage of it. It can get crowded, so go as early as possible. Allow a minimum of 2 hours for your visit.

Mystified. Amazing architecture and a day well spent, though all you need is 2-3 hours. Recommend buying tickets in advance to skip the lineups during the busy tourist season. Fun activity for the kids inside. Recommend a visit.

so much to see. Not to miss is you are a person who appreciates history. It takes a while to tour and pay attention to the the burial names on the floor. Many just walk right over the graves, but one must take time to see them all.

Kings at yout feet. This place is dripping in history and, literally, kings final resting places. You won't believe who is buried there. So many different rooms with so many stories. Lot's of walking so kids younger than 15 might not appreciate.

Truly one of the icinic sites in London. We visited Westminister Abbey in August 2016 & it is truly one of the iconic sites in London. The outside is impressive but the inside is really majestic. With the recorded commentary for each object & personal headsets, the Abbey can be seen at one's own pace. The architecture & sculpture inside the church is amazing & the sevice going on gives it a calming effect. If you visit London, don't miss Westminister Abbey.
Loads of History. Plan to spend the better part of a day. There's lots to see! You can even attend Mass. This abbey (church) is still in use.

Great church. I liked the Abbey better than St Paul's Cathedral. It only lets you in until 3:30pm, so take that into account (opening hours are longer, but first time I couldn't get in). Inside, a lot of royal tombs. And of course the tomb of Isaac Newton. Very beautiful inside. It has services, during which you can't get to certain parts, so take that into account as well. In general, well worth a visit
Enjoyable Hour or So. A great historic monument that is such an interesting tour and a sick gift shop stacked full of brilliant souvenirs. Highly recommended for London trippers

Very crowdy. This is a must in London. There are very long lines and very crowdy, but worth it. As you enter you are given free audio guides. It is worth listening and following the places inside. The walk is long around the Abbey and there comes a point there is no where to rest.

Never gets old.... Had my 8th trip to the abbey recently while touring with my niece. I see and learn something new everytime I go. Such an amazing experience. One tip is to purchase your ticket online in advance to avoid long queues.
Incredible. We almost passed this up, as we've seen so many churches -- this is not a regular church! Truly amazing - the history in here is unlike anything I've seen. GO HERE.

Scandalously Priced. As a working church that has so much history, I can appreciate the need to charge for entry to certain areas, however a charge of over £20 to even get into the main church is scandalous. I wanted to go in just to soak in the atmosphere and ponder and was unceremoniously ushered to a corridor with a couple of wooden chairs! I wasn't even in a small side chapel and I was sent there so I could pray? Out of order!

Historic and beautiful . I did this on one of London Walks tours. It certainly was good to have a guide to point out the more interesting aspects of the history. The guide was entertaining too.This church is very special indeed and the last time I visited was when I was 10 years old on a school trip to London.The tomb of the unknown warrior I think was the most poignant and special part of the abbey for me. You can attend Evensong at 5.00pm for free.
Gorgeous . A beautiful and worthwhile visit. It is even more beautiful inside than outside and it full of interesting historical notes. Highly recommended.

So much history- though difficult to convey to interested kids. My son (7) had wanted to visit Westminster Abbey because he enjoys watching Horrible Histories. I had been before and had thoroughly enjoyed that visit. I took my son and daughter (5).There was an quiz sheet for the kids, though given it was aimed at kids who were too young to wear the headsets, the questions could have been considerably more straightforward. We have done similar quizzes elsewhere where the kids have been able to better engage. (Though their frustration vanished when they got their large chocolate coin at the end)I took a headset, but couldn't really listen to it as I was with my two kids who had lots of questions. Unfortunately, without the headsets there isn't a lot of signage to explain what things are and the maps are VERY basic.It was also very busy when we were there, and as the kids are small, some areas were quite claustrophobic for them.Top tips: - If taking children try and book onto a tour.If travelling by rail, take advantage of the 2for1 ticket deals.

Especially good for readers. We stop in here each time we come to London, and always seem to find a new plaque of a favorite author. I can see this being a tedious visit for and with small children. However, once kids are old enough to connect a favorite author or other notable person to their burial spot, the lightbulb goes on and that which was far away turns real.
