They should make people take a test before letting them enter.. The place is awesome. The history and the dead buried there is off the chart of who was the whose who in our modern history. What bothered me the most was the lack of respect for the history from the people who visit the place. They say to not touch anything and you can see the weathered and worn down damage from people touching and vandalizing these beautiful works of art. I saw one woman who was running her hands all over anything she could get her grubby little paws on. They say not to take pictures and to be respectful because it is a holy place. Nope, absolutely no respect from the majority of people in there. They could make a Disneyland version and the idiots who go through there would be none the wiser. People are so clueless. I did see one of the greeters giving his best accent of a redneck Texan to a family from Texas. They were none too pleased, I laughed so hard and thanked him for his rendition of people from Texas. It really is a must see if you are in London. Hopefully you and your family can appreciate it.

Wow! Superb!. We were very happy we purchased our tickets on line and did not have the London Pass! On the day of our visit, the queue was quite long for London pass holders and you skip the line if you have e-tickets. As per the Abbey itself, plan at least 90 minutes to visit. It is well worthed and it is very impressive.

A Must Tour of London. We've been to London many times, but haven't had time for this tour. Very glad we finally had time!!! It's gorgeous! A true must see to complete your knowledge of London!! Audio tour is great.

Historic site. Have to pay to go in to look round. Plenty to see. A very popular site. Can go to a service in the Abbey but can't look round. Free to go to service. Lots of little chapels and tombs. Very interesting

Imposing. A definite tour destination when visiting London, Westminster Cathedral provides yet another glimpse of the power of the church and its place in British society. It hosts the tombs of many kings, queens and noted authors, playwrights, poets and other famous British subjects. The tour audio is essential to get a full understanding of the Abbey as it can be easy to miss a tomb or two.

Family visit. Beautiful setting! Breath taking as you walk through the beautiful church and grounds. Informative tour. Shop has a wonderful range of gifts. Something for everyone! Loved the jewellery section too. Right next to Westminster and Big Ben! Worth a visit!

Classic Attraction, Bit Always Delights. Although for at least the third time, we thoroughly enjoyed returning to Westminster Abbey. The entrance fee includes audio guides (in several languages) which are truly excellent for the history-oriented. Take time to visit the graves of many famous figures of British history.Opening time is a good hour to visit, since there will likely be a wait to get in and crowds to navigate inside, especially in summer, if you go later.

£ 20 to enter a church??. Absolutely disgraceful! Although beautifula and rich in history, it is not worth the extortionate entrance fee. There are many more impressive Churches around. Also, it is not worth being treated rudely by all the security on the site, including at the entrance.It does not feel like a place o worship at all.
Must see in London. Amazing place! The audio guided tour is great, even my teenagers said this was their favorite place in London. If you get the London Pass, it is free to get in.

Could Spend Hours in the Abbey. Majestic and overwhelmed with history. It was a very memorable place. The crypts underground are mesmerizing. Visitors are no longer allowed to do chalk sketching of the various crypt plates. None the less, WOW!!! It's a magnificent edifice. You can also grab a varied desert plate in the cafe underground on the Abbey grounds. Cappuccino or Cream Tea and scones. Yum.We were actually there in May 2013, but Trip Advisor doesn't allow you to go back that far. However, we are returning to London soon.

Wonderful to see but sometimes very crowded. This is such an interesting place to visit but when it is crowded it can almost be unbearable. There is so much to see so take your time and enjoy the history that is surrounding you. And don't forget to see the coronation chair on your way out of the Abbey.

A Walk through Centuries of British History. Westminster Abbey was one of my top two favorite attractions I visited during my two-week trip to England and my favorite in London. Not only is the interior beautiful from an architectural standpoint, but the extent of British history throughout the centuries that is virtually at your fingertips is mind-boggling. The final resting places of kings, queens, famous figures (for example, Charles Darwin) are all in this location. The coffins for royalty are pieces precious metal work and decorative art; I was numbed by the sheer number. Not free nor inexpensive, nor discounted with the London Pass, but well worth the visit, and recommend a second visit to fully absorb the sheer quantity of historical items. I add that it was quite crowded during my visit, which is not surprising, so prepare to blot out some of the background pandemonium and crowd effect to fully enjoy the experience.

A must see!. I always find it strange that sometimes one has to pay to visit a church or a Cathedral. Although it may be a monument, it is also a place of prayer and worship. The 10th Century Abbey is actually worth the (very high!) price. It is more than a monument, a royal burial place, home to coronations and royal weddings. Westminster Abbey is a sanctuary of faith as much as it a sanctuary of architecture and history. I asked one of the staff how long a visit would take and they said 1.5 hours. I left 2.5 hours later and I felt I would love to have had a longer detailed guided tour. Definitely worth visit at least once!

Wonderful . It a wonderful cathedral with lots of history. One of the most beatiful cathedral we're have ever seen. Been to a lot of churches and cathedrals, and Westminster is a beauty. We will come back here.

History under one church. A must see for the first time visitor. This is where the British crown their Kings and Queens. All around are chapels of Kings and Queens, artists poets and other people that contributed to British History. I was impressed by the tomb of Elizabeth 1 daughter of Henry VIII with Anne Boleyn and Mary her half sister. Enemies in life they share one tomb for eternity as sisters. The cloisters also offer lots interesting stuff. They have a cafe that serves good tea and a good lunch as well.

Beautiful and Historical to say the least. wife loved seeing it and I was amazed by the architecture. Absolutely beautiful building and so much has happened there. Right next to the Parliament and Big Ben.
A magnificent building. It was an experience we felt we should do while in London but unfortunately, it was extremely busy and was difficult to walk around in places.

Beautiful church. We toured the Abbey on a beautiful day outside. Luckily the lines were not long especially for a weekend. We grabbed an audio guide, very useful, and toured the church in about an hour. Be aware, no pictures are allowed which honestly was disappointing. We found many places in London do not allow pictures. So be sure to take ur mental pictures. It was very impressive though and to consider the history and how many royals have been crowned there. Many tombs of royals and important people through history like Darwin and Newton. The chair where the king or queen is crowned is the last thing you will see before u exit the church and it was incredibly impressive. It is behind glass, for obvious reasons. Well worth the experience and right across is Parliament and Big Ben.

Simply History At Every Turn. One of the most impressive places in all of the free world. The number of men and woman laid to rest in the hallowed halls is amazing. Worth every pence of the 20 pounds.

A Must see!. So exciting to stand where kings and queens have been coronated and wed. Go to view the final resting places of royalty, and even take part in an Anglican service. So much to see and so little time as the hours of operation seemed rather short.

Lucky visit to Westminster Abbey. We attended the ten o'clock August 7 matins service which we were pleased to learn was in remembrance of Shakespeare. We stayed for the 11:15 main service. The sermons of both services were excellent.
Wonderful!. The architecture and history are amazing. Poet's corner was my favourite part - the stained glass windows are stunning!

More dead people then most cemetaries. Really nice church. Audio guide really helps you make sense of the thousands of dead people and tributes all over the place. We didn't get there before it opened so the queue was about 30 minutes long, saw it longer earlier in the week. You can also go in for free during service times if you don't want to pay the expensive entrance fee and you would just rather see it then experience it. Saw on London Pass so was worth it to us.

A must see in London. The history was unbelievable at Westminster. We went during a downpour and it was great to be indoors, but there is almost always a line to get in, so be prepared for that. It takes about an hour and is well worth it. Don't miss the courtyard area, it was lovely.
Fascinating and beautiful. Any lover of history should go here. After all, you get to see where Elizabeth the 1st, her sister Queen Mary and Mary Queen of Scots are buried.
A must see. This place is very different than what you see on TV during a wedding or funeral. The history of this church is amazing. It was crowded but they manage the people well.

Amazing. We went there not knowing what to expect. We were so impressed with our time there. So much history, so much beauty. We could have stayed for hours exploring all the areas of the Abbey but we had another place to be later.this was the highlight of our time in London and we saw a lot in the 5 days we were there.

Bucket List Item checked off !. The Westminster Abbey is a wonderful experience that can safely be checked off my Bucket List. A true walk through the centuries and the history and the stories are amazing. A guided tour is recommended for sure... otherwise, it is just a jumble and maze to maneuver. Please check and confirm timings before you make the trip. They are sometimes closed for private mass. The gift shop was very crowded but they do have some very unique things. The Abbey is often host to songs and dance routines and performers outside... that made our trip enjoyable.

Make sure you visit. We had a great time touring the Abbey and seeing all the burial sites. Beautiful architecture, and a nice place to stop for lunch in the lower level. Make sure to get the London Pass to skip the long lines.
Wonderful church service. Some friends and I went to church here. The service was even better than I expected. The building is so gorgeous & it was a very special experience.
Ok. Many things to see. No photography allowed inside. In my opinion it lacks the atmosphere Canterbury Cathedral has. But mayve that was due to the number of large groups with guides.

Worth a Visit if You Have the Time. Arrived around 2:30 pm. Last entrance was 3:30. We didn't have London passes - those folks waited in a different line and got in slightly sooner. Although we only ended up waiting about 20 minutes. Interesting to see where Prince William and Kate Middleton got married. Lots of crypts and monuments. Definitely get the auditory tour. Probably not that interesting for children and/ or teens.
westminster abbey. Very good, enjoyed looking around, there is a queuing system but the queue moves quite quickly, close to tube station

Don't miss this especially if you love history. I love this place although you have to fight the crowds a bit but this history is incredible. The audio tour was worthwhile but I think next time I will try the live tour.

Interesting and worth a visit. What can one say, it's so rich in history and not a bad place to be buried if given the chance.I'm not really into this type of attraction. I don't do palaces etc as a matter of principle but I thought I'd take a look as I was in the area and had some time.My one major disappointment, you can't take a picture unlike in the museums. This place was crying out 'hey you, take a picture of me, that's why I've been lying here all these years.'Actually there was one other disappointment. I'd like to know who is actually buried and who just has their name engraved..I have been there once and appreciated it and I'm very glad I looked in.

The History is amazing. From the coronation chair to the famous kings and queens interned there as well as historical people this is a must see. The only thing I had issue with is it is a Church and some people treated it like an attraction but other than that the place was truly amazing to see.
Impressive. It is an historical building and a must see, but, not really worth the price to go inside, walk around, have a look from the lawn opposite, while also looking at big ben...
Stunning . Westminster Abbey is absolutely worth a visit if in London. It's a beautiful building both inside and out.

Jaw dropping beauty. When traveling in London, Westminster Abby is a must see on the itinerary. The architecture, the statues, the history. It's really amazing. Grab an audio guide & dive right into it. You won't regret it.

Don't Miss It!. There are crowds so be prepared to wait. Lines to get in are divided into three: 1. prebooked/prepaid, 2. London Pass and 3. those who have to buy a ticket. The best and fastest way to get in is to prebook/prepay. They are let in first. We had the London Pass and there was a very long line - we were let in after the prebooked/prepaid group. Would love to go back during an off time of the year as August was extremely crowded and you had to keep moving. Poets corner is a great place to meet up if you get separated from your traveling companion.

Overpriced, unfriendly, but great history!. We visited the Westminster Abby, and found it was very nice to look at. It was overpriced at over 20 pounds per adult and no pictures were allowed. Also ask for headsets, as they do not automatically give them to you. Hold onto to your tickets as some people working were unfriendly. Would not do the tour again.

Audio Tour would have been helpful. Westminster Abbey is a glorious place to visit. Unfortunately on the day that I visited the audio tours were not available; I was told that a recent storm had damaged their equipment??? Anyway, with those not available and such huge crowds of tourists, the guided tours were not especially accessible to all. I still enjoyed touring the cathedral on my own, because there is so much to see and learn about.

Museum style experience. Before we toured the Abbey, we did not realize how many incredible sculptures we were about to see. The monuments are breathtaking in some instances, and all are incredible to look at. We liked that the tour is audio guided, so my friends and I could go at our own pace, and take a seat in the sanctuary when we were done. It's a very beautiful place with a great deal of history. We enjoyed the time we spent there very much.

Amazing place - and go for Evensong!. Despite being heavily visited by tourists, it is not a trap - it is one of the most amazing places in the world. For a better experience, go to a service - Evensong at 5 pm is wonderful. You will see many of the famous memorials as you walk in, but the best part is the service with the most amazing choir I have ever heard. This experience was amazing!

Love of history... Westminster abbey is located in the heart of London, very close to bus and tube stations.There are many other places around such as big Ben.This is an active church which does not allow you to take photos but I wouldn't want to take photos but take in the history.The detailing is very beautiful and I learnt a great lot about the history of the place.
Beautiful . A beautiful architectural marvel. Didnt go in, but it was worth to just spend 15 minutes outside, take pictures and enjoy the sight.

Verger tour of Westminster abbey.. It's well worth paying the extra £5 for the escorted tour with one of the vergers. You get too see more than if you choose the self guided tour, this includes a close up look of the coronation chair. In the summer there is normally free music in the college garden, I missed this as it clashed with my tour of the Houses of Parliament. Wonderful visit I was in there 2.5 hours

Amazing. While every tourist has heard of Westminster Abbey, we were overwhelmed by the history and beauty of this amazing cathedral. Many famous authors, artists and leaders are buried here. If you visit London, Westminster Abbey should not be missed.

Lots of History . The tour was very interesting! The first part kept us wanting to see more but it became more of the same. I would not take the tour again. Loved the park area outside. Great view of Big Ben and for taking pictures.

Wonderful. It is a wonderful architectural beauty. It is a Gothic Church. Royal weddings, coronations etc. take place here. You can see here tombs, memorials, graves, and busts of great figures. Kings, queens, and famous persons like Darwin, Dickens, Hardy, Shakespeare etc. are buried here. The Gardens are beautiful. Museum is closed for refurbishing. A cafe is there to refresh. Visiting time depends on the Service time. On Sundays there are free 30-minute organ recitals at 5.45 pm. A must visit in London.

History is here. Enjoy the cathedral.. An active church with no photos allowed. Wait out the crowds to see what lies under your feet and look carefully along the walls for names and dates to learn even more about the history of this cathedral. Poets corner is full of tourists; but, full of history.

Very Impressive Abbey. The building is stunning, and the interiors too. I remember walking around feeling overwhelmed by its beauty, and the history behind it.It was also very interesting and chilling to visit the graves of people I have long held in esteem there - including Charles Darwin! My fav section was the Poets' Corner - to see Auden, Kipling, Gray, and Tennyson all side by side.
Long live the Queen! . Full of history! You can see the last resting place of the ancient kings and queens and also other important figures of our world.

Stunning. The architecture is beautiful, the inside was extremely crowded so get there early. Even so it is sometimes difficult to move around. Take advantage of the audio tours to give you the background. So amazing to see so much history. Queen Elizabeth I was breathtaking. Amazing woman.

My favorite in London. We stayed 9 days in London and tried to see as much as we could and I must confess that the Abbey was the highlight of the trip. Try to gather some information about it before the visit as it will make it more interesting. We had no idea that Charles Darwin and Issac Newton were buried there until we were inside with our audio guides. The Abbey is beautifully sculptured and the Gothic architecture is just amazing. One of the prettiest churches inside we have ever visited.

Westminister Abbey Vespers Service-London. Go in early evening, to the Vespers Service, if you want to avoid a fee to this magnificent Abbey,where famous poets, and historical figures lie in peace---it is a haunting beautiful service,with lovely music and rituals..You will come away with serene,peaceful thoughts and memories.

So graceful. A magnificent structure, very beautiful. It is a major example of a building that is centuries and centuries old, that features in historic event, but that is still relevant today - for instance as the backdrop to royal weddings.

A must see for history buffs. Go early, and line up before they open. You can get to visit some of the smaller rooms all by yourself. For the best experience, take the audio device, but don't start with #1, go on ahead to the small rooms and start there. You can always backtrack. The ability to experience these rooms alone is priceless. Westminster Abbey is huge, so you can spend many hours here, reading all the crypts and honor plaques. You can't take pictures. There are so many great people of history buried here. The architecture is beyond words. If you love history, this is the crown jewel of British history.

Be sure to buy your tickets online. I had bought our tickets online and we were glad to be able to skip the line. The space is amazing inside, it is a shame you cannot take any photos though. It was also really crowded and for the most part the different tombs did not have signs, that we saw, to identify who was inside which would have been nice. I did not do the audio tour so I suppose that might have been on there but would have been nice to have a map that identified people.

A timeless treasure. History oozes from every inch of this grand old Church. We were able to see it as actual church service attendees...an experience neither of us will ever forget. To touch and feel the actual place where so many historical events took place is a blessing. Words fail to describe. Easy to walk from Westminster Abby to Buckingham Palace. Friendly people everywhere to assist you along your journey. We took the Tube from our Doubletree Tower of London hotel, walked from church service to the changing of the guard, then got lost for several hours thru Hyde Park, major shopping and finally found the Hard Rock. This is a must see for every first timer, or even if you've seen it before!
Absolutely stunning. It is an overdose of stunning architecture; and reflects the pompous ways of the old monarchy. Certainly a must see when in London.

Histoirial. Anyone who likes history or films must visit here.The architecture alone is worthy of motivating you to walk around inside to admire it in its glorious state.The atmosphere within the Abbey is fantastic and really brings about a peace from the noise of London outside.The stain glass windows as he light pours in are wonderful to look at.
Just beautiful. Very helpful staff and the radio commentary things worked really well. Could have easily spent more time here. Two hours wasn't enough. Perhaps next time!!

Beautiful architecture. This is one of the must visit places in London if you are History or Architecture Buff. There is something for everyone. But as usual, like any other London attraction, the wait is too long. They should do something like token system where is time slot is allocated to the visitors. Otherwise considering that most attractions open at 10 Am and close by 5pm. it is very difficult to plan your day due to the crowd.But, this place is worth it. Be early and spend time here. One thing to note is that Westminister Abbey is closed on SUNDAYs. SO NEVER PLAN YOUR TRIP to this place on sunday.

Historic. It is a great architectural place and surely sure of statues and tombs, but only if you are interested in that kind. The place is huge and awesome, but not something picturesque.Its not something people go again, unless u are a historian. Once is enough

Everyone who is any one is buried here. Just astoundingly resonant with history. You will not believe the famous figures who are buried here (nor the trials that took place in the nearby Westminster Hall). Check out the log book of civilians who died in the blitzes. Also found a great tea room in a lesser known vaulted area nearby, off an Abbey Garde.

Westminster abbey. Walking down the aisle kings and queens have been baptized, married, coronated and buried was overwhelming. The abbey is massive and elaborate burials are throughout this ancient church. Buy your tickets in advance so you don't have to line up twice- once to get tickets and then to get in. Good news is the line up to get in moves quickly and you can grab a coffee and pastry at one of the vendors while you wait.

Place of Kings and Queens of England. Westminster Abbey is astounding. When you visit, you walk among the tombs of the great scientists, composers, authors, rulers, and other greats (those I cannot recall at this moment, without my Westminster map).When you visit, realize that all these historical people walked or were carried here, in the same steps upon which you now tred.

A Must See. Whether you love art or history there is something for everyone on this tour. Our family loved Henry VII's chapel- breath taking. The audio guide is a must even though it does cause a bit of congestion at points.
History. Beautiful church. Lovely architecture especially when you consider the age of the church... The lines were super long to get inside.

Religion meets Mammon. Where to start? Well get there early the queues at 10.15am were already lengthy. To get around this buy a ticket on-line before you go. This allows you to enter without having to queue. The London Ticket thingys don’t give you this benefitThe price of an adult ticket is ludicrous at £20 even with a dull audio-guide thrown in. Once inside it is awesome, even with the long lines of people stopping at each audio-guide point. The Lady Chapel is the highlight without doubt. There are real giants of British history buried in the Abbey. Don’t you love our colonial cousins? In front of the grave of Henry III one American was marvelling at being at the grave of Henry VIII. Love it.It is worth the visit, but the abbey is just being plain greedy with the £20 entrance.

Evensong. If toy have any religious or spiritual persuasion consider a service here instead of being 'just a tourist the magic pf this is well worth the fact that you might not 'see it all' or be ables to take photos. Instead you will feel part of this incredible history. You will enjoy the wonderfulAcoustics you will sit with others who feel the same from all corners of the world. Truly one of the highlights of my visit

Really interesting. I could have spent longer in here than I did but teenager was eye rolling at me! Seemed expensive when I paid but actually decided it was well worth the money when I came out. I went one day and the queues were long so I didn't bother, next time we went to London we walked up to the door. There seems to be no rhyme or reason to when the queues for this are longer than others, pot luck I think.

Dangerously crowded.. We got here half an hour before the Abby opened and made the mistake of going to get coffee at the coffee stand next to the souvenir shop instead of lining up by the door because when we got back not 10 minutes later the line had formed on either side of the entrance and we had to wait for about 20 minutes from opening time to get in. The place was ridiculously crowded with numerous guided tour groups in attendance. If there had been an emergency most of us wouldn't have been able to make it out. The Abbey is incredible and definitely worth the time.

A stunning trip back in history. If you want to have a touch of how magnificent architectures from the medieval era looks like, this is the place to be A unique opportunity to walk into the history of England and pay tribute to iconic figures in human history like Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin The only drawback here is that you cannot take photos in the Abby Oh and stay away from the cafe, rude staff and bad coffee. Walk out and there are plenty of other places

BEAUTIFUL. The Westminster abby was absolutely beautiful. There was so much history in there and the architecture was amazing. there are no pictures allowed in a lot of it which is a shame because its impossible to remember every beautiful part of the church. they had staff everywhere to help with questions. it was very busy and cost was high but it was worth it in every way.

Don't miss this - well worth a visit. This is a must see in London. You will need more time than you think! Didn't take the tour as we wanted top browse at our own pace & take it all in. Although there are queues to get in, it moves quite quickly.

Attend a mass!. The Westminster Abbey is gorgeous and even if you are not a religious person, such as myself, is worth the visit!There are 3 ways (that I know of) you can do it! You can enter freely in the main part of the Abbey, where you can pray if you want to or just admire the architecture!You can pay a fee and visit the interior, where you'll see the tombs of great kings and knights and learn the history of the Westminster Abbey, which is worth it, I highly recommend!And you can attend a mass! Again, even if you're not a religious person, is worth it! The Abbey closes, and they only let the people that want to participate enter. In other words, you have the Abbey just for yourself and some other few people for an hour! When I went, we sat at the middle of the nave and there was a choir singing for the mass. I had one hour to sit there and enjoy every single part of the paintings and structure and ornaments as the choir sang! Now, I don't know if the choir participates on every mass, so I suggest to ask or to visit the website before you go!

The Interior is Strikingly Beautiful. Some of the best architecture I have ever seen - both inside and out. Absolutely beautiful. The audio tour that is included is extremely helpful as you wander through at your own pace. You can visit the final resting places of many important figures throughout Great Britain's mighty history.
Beautiful. Beautiful area yet again have to pay to get in i think it was 18 pounds there is a little gift shop close by lots of people around this area

A must see in London!. We have visited this Abbey on every trip to London. This time we brought our 13 and 9 year old grandsons and they were as fascinated as we have always been. For us this is the number one attraction in London.
Historical. Walked thru Westminster abbey. Take the audio tour. Very helpful Enjoyed the documentary Church service began during our tour do we heard the organ. Lovely. So impressive

Worth Visiting But.... This is definitely worth visiting. The history and the shear majesty of the place is awe inspiring. I give it three stars simply because of the low class and disrespectful way that they have visitors. This should be a place for learning, solemn reflection and tribute, instead it is set up to make the most possible money. People are given cell phone like devices and walk around like zombies listening to the box. If they really wanted to make what it should be they would have small guided tours only. As it is, it is crowded with disrespectful people and feels like another tourist attraction.

Evensong + Who's Who of British History. We spent a special hour at lovely 5:00 Evensong services, appreciating that the Abbey is a modern house of worship with historical significance. The next morning we returned to soak up the history, following the audio tour and finding our favorite authors in Poets' Corner. Amazing to see the final resting places of so many significant people.

Beautiful. We visited the Notre Dame in Paris before we came here and it is nearly as good. The architecture on the outside is beautiful and really nice inside to but just not as good as notre dame and quite expensive to get in too £25 I think!!

Beautiful... lost for words. An amazing and beautiful example of many different types of architecture. Take the guided tour through the abbey, and learn about the Kings, Queens, Noble Man, and Poets that have created such an icon. Attend a service or an recital on a Sunday if you don't want to pay to go through.

A Place of Beauty. We opted to attend a church service while in London and did so at Westminster Abbey. It was an experience I won't soon forget. Upon arrival, we were escorted to a small chapel where the service was performed. It allowed us to experience the abbey in the way it was intended and to appreciate its beauty and history. There is no cost to attend a service at Westminster, and it is otherwise closed to the public.You'll have the chance to see the inside of the church, but are not able to spend time lingering before or after the service, so if you are looking to have a guided tour, the service is not the right option for you. Instead, you can buy a ticket and do a sight seeing tour. Regardless of how you see this magnificent Abbey, you will be in awe of its breathtaking beauty.

World Class Monument. It took us a while to locate the entrance of Westminster Abbey after walking from Big Ben and the Parliament. We are happy to get London Pass in advance to allow us avoid the winding queue. The audio guide was relatively user friendly and you definitely need it to enjoy a more fruitful tour. Love the history, the architecture and splendor of this venerable institution.

One of the World's Most Impressive Cathedrals. We spent a lovely afternoon at the cathedral. Of note; it is 20 Pounds to get in so we thought we should take our time seeing it. The admission price comes with an audio guide that is quite informative. Lots to see and a nice cafe for lunch or tea at the end of the tour.
Incredible . An incredible and atmospheric place, made the hairs on my arms stand up. We were lucky enough to arrive in time for a Sunday service and we will never forget it.

Beautiful. No matter how many times I visit Westminster Abbey it doesn't lose its appeal. It's huge and stunning, the architecture is amazing.... and the history within the walls is remarkable. You can learn a great deal about the history of this country by walking through this Abbey. If you don't want to pay you can attend an evensong which is lovely in its own right.
Fantastic!. Amazing history, Verger tour was excellent and allows you some behind the scenes views. Book online to skip huge lines. Great activity book for kids with prize at the end.

Perhaps the most important church Ive ever seen. 1000 years of history.. Amazing architecture! 1000 years of history, closely tied to the British monarchy. Could spend an easy 2 hours just looking at the memorials. Some parts of the site are off limits and the staff are not amused at requests to see them! (Jerusalem chamber, where the Westminister Confession, et al were penned). My favorite part was the 13th c floor at the altar. You can't go to London and not see Q. Elizabeth I's tomb, can you?

Stunning History. Plan your visit as can be very busy with long waiting times avoid middle of the day and Mondays,booking on line gives you priority access.Be prepared to be patient as parts get very crowded,the free audio guides are excellent.

London Vacation. Absolutely beautiful. If you have the London Pass entrance is included, just make sure you show up early to avoid long lines. If this is your first stop of the day, there are other great spots to hit afterwards like the Churchill War Rooms, 10 Downing Street, the Banqueting Hall, the Jewel Tower, Parliament (purchase tickets online ahead of time) to name a few.
Spectacular Attraction. Self-guided tour. A grand place! One of the many must-sees on any trip to London. A walk through history.

Westminster Abbey: A Thousand Years of History. I bought an individual ticket this time instead of the London Pass. We had a disabled person in our party of 3 so we were able to move ahead in the line. The Abbey is glorious. If you love history, you will love it here. Give yourself a few hours to see it all. The burial inscriptions are fascinating, and Poet's Corner is a who's who of literary giants. However, some of the most touching memorials are the non-famous people who line the abbey walls and floors. Based on genealogical research, it appears that I found an ancestor, and the staff let me take a photo of his burial with SPECIAL PERMISSION. You must see Queen Elizabeth I, Queen Mary, the Coronation Chair (minus Stone of Scone now), and many other famous monarchs. Also, the 1000 year old stone sarcophagi of Abbots line some of the lesser populated areas but they really touched me. Note: It is very crowded so be aware. The gift shop was also good for a couple of purchases. No matter how many times that I come to London, I always visit Westminster Abbey.

Allow enough time to visit this landmark . We arrived in the morning and had a queue of 40 minutes in the cold wind. The audio guide was informative in giving the history of this impressive church and identifying points of interest. The tombs and memorials of these well known names from history is amazing. You can imagine the coronations, funerals and weddings that have taken place here. Tired after touring the church for 3 hours, we enjoyed a well deserved lunch at the Cellarium cafe. Afternoon tea was the winner as a menu choice.

Incredible! . I think visiting Westminster Abbey was one of most interesting and amazing places that I visited while in London. It is so rich in history and the fact that it is still a living church is even more amazing! The line was rather long when we first arrived, but it moved very quickly. The audio guides were wonderful and they really provided a lot of historical information without being overwhelming. I highly recommend visiting!
Evensong!. We attended evensong. It was very nice and a good way to experience the church. Be sure to respect the wishes of The Abbey requesting that no pictures be taken.

A must to visit!. This was the most beautiful tour we have taken on our visit to London. There are no words to describe all you can see in all the rooms of this building. The richness and details of separate chapels, tombs and crypts plus all those statues you can hardly believe your eyes. A well organize system in various language lets you follow the path design to help you see all there is to see and know about this wonderful Abbey.

Historical and sacred English place!. Impressive, historical and sacred place in London! Acceptable waiting line, perfect place to pray and have a perfect spiritual / personal time. From outside perfect spot for a memorable picture!

Powerfully moving. We were here on a very rainy day so it was very crowded. Some of the chapels are rather small so it was a bit of a squash at times. That said, there is no denying the emotional impact of being surrounded by so much history. I found myself weeping at Chaucer's grave. The audio guide is great!

Impressive Architecture to Accompany Its History. The Architectural creativity of this edifice will amaze you from a distance and once you arrive at The Abbey you are totally captivated by its magnificence inside and out. In fact, it's astounding and equally, its history is positively mind boggling. What an enjoyable and enlightening experience! The Abbey is most definitely a must do sightseeing/your activity when one visits London
Do not miss this!. Amazing structure! Audio guide was very helpful. So many royals and writers are buried there. Seeing where William and Kate were married was lovely.

Architectural Gem With Tons Of History. My review was lowered by one star simply because it was difficult to enjoy the experience due to the fact that there were so many people doing the same thing; there are many small areas within the Abbey that are difficult to see with that many people. Although the Abbey is still a place of worship, it is known much more for all of the historical figures buried there, though note that many famous people have memorials in the Abbey but they were buried elsewhere. One great timesaver: book your tickets online and bring your smartphone with the ticket email - that will let you bypass the long line of people lined up to get in each day
Nice place. Nice place as long as David Cameron is not there ha ha but is a good landmark for photos and is right in the centre of London too and has many public transport points near by as well

Very, very busy in August. I have some mixed feelings on Westminster Abbey. The Abbey is definitely a must see. It contains stunning architecture, tombs and artwork. I suggest googling the long list of people buried in Westminster Abbey but the standouts for us were Darwin, Sir Issac Newton and countless poets and writers. The downside of the visit was the mass hordes of people. We arrived 30 minutes before opening with a London Pass and the line up was already long. Once the doors opened the people are funneled through the Abbey in a slow moving horde. It was very difficult to go back if you missed something because you are trying to move against the swarm of people and many areas are very narrow. It made me think what would the Da Vinci Code be like if Robert Langdon came in with the crowds and was packed shoulder to shoulder in front of Newton's tomb. I really loved the Abbey and would like to come back in an off season time and have time to peacefully explore Abbey at our own pace. The only other negative about the Abbey is it does not allow photography although I can understand why when it is so busy.

Steve . The abbey is rich with history and architectural wonder. Take your time to listen to the guided audio tour which I found very informative. This is on the top of the list of places to see while in London. Be sure to stop in the cafe to enjoy the tea and English pastries. My wife had the best cup of tea during our entire stay in England at this cafe

Watch out for pickpockets. It was very crowded but still a wonderful experience. Lots of history, enough guilded beauty for the girls, enough gory stories for the boys and enough interesting facts and graves for the grownups. I wouldn't bring any kids under 14. It's too much walking and could be boring for the little cherubs.

Astonishing...Worth the Big Bucks to Get In!. My wife is a devout Catholic and a Queenophile (Royals for that matter). We were her 2+ hours including attending the 12:30PM mass. Kate Middleton & the Prince were married here. All of the Royal were crowned here (Yes, the Royal Throne is on display) and every famous poet, writer, political figure and Royal are buried here with plaques noted. Not letting you take pictures....whatever! Go!

Go to a service if you can, it's so peaceful. This was by far one of the favorite places I toured. You can feel the amazing history in the building as you walk through and the audio is very helpful. I went to a service in the chapel before taking the tour and it was so peaceful and peace-filled.

Very Gothic! Very OLD!. Really worth seeing this old church in Westminster! It has over a thousand years of history! The style and incredible art sculpturing around it is very beautifully Gothic! A MUST when in London!

Not to miss this place. I am glad I went to this placed with all of my family! This place is must if you are visiting London for sight seeing! This place has tombs to British royalty and other notable English personnel! Strongly recommended!

G.B's history. Great Britain's history lies there. All important British ( of all times ) are there. Well not all ( Nelson is at St. Paul ). Dickens, E. Bronte, Shakespeare, Newton, Halley etc... Too bad photos are not allowed, even though you can be a . . . paparazzi :D
Fascinating. Well worth the entry charge which does seem a little high at first though we did get a two for one deal by travelling on South Eastern trains into London.
Westminster Abbey. Must see thing in London even if you don't enter (you have to pay for the entrance). Architecture it self is stunning!

My favorite thing in London. Westminster Abbey was the best thing we did in London. We arrived at opening and immediately booked the tour for 5 extra pounds per person. The tour was outstanding!!!! Learned a lot and got to see some parts of the abbey not available to the rest of the public . Well worth the money!!

Really enjoyed it. We were in here for hours! Lovely to see all the 'famous bits' and then discover the bits you don't see on TV. The lady chapel at the east end is just beautiful. The poets corner is good to search around. The audio guide is good. Some bits are two long for the space you have to look around by generally good and Jeremy Ions does the commentary. The musical options are also nice as it adds to the atmosphere in the abbey. Let downs - no photography. This isn't the same across the country in these large churches so that was disappointing. No reason for this to be honest. It works in St Pauls Basilica so not sure why it can't work here. Also, women's toilets - there were huge queues. Needs to be many more.

Choral Evensong during the season of peripatetic choirs.. This is a review of one service, not of the Abbey as a whole. As a building it speaks of 1,000 years of English and then British history; as a place of worship it can be sublime. But when attending evensong the vergers ensure that one isn't actually viewing the building without paying by ushering one in and out along strictly designated routes.Evensong is a wonderful - and particularly Anglican - service. I have managed to attend evensong in a significant number of English cathedrals, but have to say that a winter evening in Durham, or a quiet service in Manchester or Birmingham, can be more moving than in some of the 'statement' places of worship, where it is obvious that many in the congregation aren't actually there for the service.When the regular choir is away, in the summer and after Christmas, all sorts of visiting choirs appear; on this occasion services were being sung for a week by the choir of Trinity Church, Boston, MA. (This isn't the church used for the 'one lamp or two' signal at the beginning of the Revolutionary War, it would have been a delicious irony if it had been).Some Episcopalian choirs in the US are quite excellent: St Thomas, Fifth Avenue being a good example. But if a large American choir gives it their all, as in this case, some of the subtleties of the acoustics, and the music, can be lost. Or maybe Stanford and Howells don't really suit this choir. But it was still well worth attending this service.

For the random tourist and history lovers. Another must see attraction in London, pricey but worth it, make the most of your visit by reading ahead about it so you can appreciate its architecture and know about the hidden great spots in advance.It does get really packed with random tourists with their phones shooting at will which is annoying but if you're there take the one moment and wait till its quiet.Many flock to see kings and queens some to the poets corner few to see Charles Darwin.The shop is good, they usually have stuff on sale. If you can sneak into Deans yard and take a look at Westminster school is one of the oldest schools, Adam Buxton, Shane MacGowan and Dido attended there.

Sign up for the Vergers tour!. We went on the Vergers Tour - 5 GBP per person. Only way to see St Edward the Confessor's Tomb, sit in the Choir seats. Benjamin was our guide. He was engaging and funny and filled with wonderful knowledge. The time flew by.

Incredible. We were fortunate enough to to participate in mass and (our first) Holy Communion. Incredible experience! The President randomly prays for a church area in the world and happened to pick outperform home province of ?Newfoundland. We were blown away. Amazing to be in the presence of the tombs of so many remarkable people. Stunned to see that Darwin had a prominent spot. The kids loved the children's tour version. So glad they understood the importance of catering to children to make the parent's experience pleasant. Happy kids make for a happy vacation which can be difficult on historic vacations away from amusement parks.
BEAUTIFUL. Amazing place to visit! would defiantly recommend.. when we went there was no Que which was a bonus. Not to long if your going with kids.

Incredible!. This is an awesome site in London and should not be missed. I would recommend the audio tour as there is a lot of history and famous people buried here. The architecture is spectacular.We had the London Pass which was great as there is a separate line and we got in quickly - but go early to avoid standing in long lines.

Beautiful Abbey. We came here at about 8:30 in the morning, the Abbey doesn't open till 9:00 but we wanted to get a earl start. Glad we did, it got crowded fast!! There is so much to see and learn. We got the audio guide which was a plus!!
To damn expensive . I'd have loved you enter the abbey but the prices were extortionate. It's a lovely part of the city send looks great from the outside.

A must see in London. I really enjoyed the Abbey. I would recommend the audio tour here. Lots of history and famous people buried here. Spectacular architecture. A place you should visit.We had the London Pass. There was a separate line for the London Pass. Although the line was long we got in within a reasonable amount of time. There are a couple stands nearby. Grab a beverage and re-hydrate while waiting.

Fabulous tour. We bought our tickets line which saved a ton of time I would recommend doing that since we got there right at opening and the line was huge!! It was so nice seeing the place where the totals were married it is a must see.

westminster abby. Well worth the visit. audio guide is usefull if you can figure it out, its a pretty big place, and can be a little tedious walking round the whole thing, but still worth a visit as theres lots of history and I think Every reigning monarch has been crowned here.

Loved the "talking" tour -- this place is amazing!!. The tour of the Abbey is well worth the money. Just be sure to leave yourself 1-2 hours to do everything. The talking tour is superb and gives you so much historical information. The Nave is awe-inspiring and the different chapels are amazing. You can't take photos inside the Abbey but you can outside. :)
Be prepared to spend time there. . An impressive structure that spans centuries of history, plan at least two hours if you want to appreciate the visit. There is much to look at in detail.

Enjoyable. While the audio tour is good and the walls are filled with such incredible history, it lacked the grandeur of St Pauls Cathedral. Definitely worth doing if you have the time but I'd suggest you view the Abbey before you tour the Cathedral, or if you only have time (or funds) to see one, the Cathedral is definitely more awe inspiring.

Wonderful . Was able to get into Westminster Abbey without having to wait in a long line. Staff was very helpful for me. I was looking for some old family relatives that were buried at Westminster Abbey. And one staff member knew exactly where they were buried and gave me a lot of history regarding their tombs. Really appreciate their help and how much Friday actually take you working there.

Historical must see in London. Where royals are crowned, married, and buried. Every inch of this place is stuffed with history (and tourists), so the included audio tour is helpful. Cafe is a very nice place for a restorative treat. Booking online or using London Pass is recommended to avoid the very long lines.
Westminster Abbey. The Abbey complex is quite big. Cannot take pictures inside the Abbey. I must say it's a different perspective being in the Chapel that how it looks onTV. Take the time to visit.

Stunning outside, tour not for me. Whilst I appreciated the history and architecture in the building I felt that the entrance fee was way too high (I understand conservation costs but it could be reduced to even 10 pounds maybe?), it was also very crowded inside and difficult to move in parts. We visited in the morning. Photos are not allowed inside and I was left feeling underwhelmed by it. If you are tight on time it is a beautiful building to view from the outside but if I had my time again I would skip the tour.
Amazing place. The grandness of the place is awesome. Interesting history, artifacts, and famous people entombed here. Get the audio guide (free with London Pass).
fascinating but very expensive. while there is plenty to see here, the cover charge is excessive...so would advise you attend the prayer services and then have a sneaky look around.
Westminister Abbey. By far our favorite site in London. Traveling back in time and seeing the final resting place of so many great figures in history, literature and science was incredible.

Since 966- A Must See Centerpiiece. This is a ut=must-see site. Completed in 966, it has been the location of every coronation in Britain since 1066 as well as the venue for countless weddings and funerals of British royalty and other famous Brits. Notable persons in Science, the Arts, Literature and Politics are buried or memorialized there. We attended an evening organ concert and sat where the important personages in history sat. It gave me goosebumps to listen to the great organ and think of the history that surrounded us. Plan a full day to see everything and contemplate the contributions to humanity from those memorialized there.

Britain's History. I booked online and arrived before the doors opened. I recommend this as we entered the Abbey first whilst the queues for those buying tickets were already snaking around the building.It was a dream realised to walk into one of the most beautiful buildings in London but it would take more than a day to truly appreciate all that it offers. There was a free audio tour available but the Verger-led tour is well worth the extra charge. There is so much to see it is impossible to pick out a highlight but it was hard to not be overcome whilst standing by the tomb of the Unknown Warrior. Your ticket also allows you to leave and re-enter the Abbey throughout the day but it gets extremely busy, quickly. I spent two hours here and still feel there was much more to see.

Great audio tour . We could have spent a very long time here so much to see a d explore. It is just rammed with history. Royal, religious, political, war and literature. Not to mention the architecture. The audio tour was great too we booked online worth doing as made entry very easy.

So much history..... There is so much history in Westminster Abbey. Royal weddings, the throne that has been used for every monarch's coronation since the 1300's, many famous Britons are buried here as well. The Gothic architecture is beautiful.

Historic, must see. Very beautiful, can occasionally be crowded but nothing to where you are unable to move throughout. Admission is a little on the high side (it was £25, students, seniors and children is cheaper), but well worth the visit.

20 quid to get in?? Its a church.. My main issue is paying to get into was is effectively a Church and especially paying £20. I have visited other cathedrals where they only ever ask for a donation for which I am happy to give.So on this occasion I stood outside whilst my (foreign, first time trip to London) partner went in (£40 for two is ridiculous in my opinion).She liked it very much for its history and beauty.If you want to get in for FREE check out the times of the services and you can go in for the service. (The same with St Pauls)Tip. The little church right next to Westminster is a nice place to sit and rest whilst to are waiting for your partner to finish in Westminster Abbey (I think its called St Margarets)
Amazing architecture. Huge ornate building that seems to go on forever. Most in view only a small part being reconstructed, breathtaking.

Must See. There are some places that are a must see, and this is one of them. Just unbelievable history. We got there about 30 minutes before opening and were about 20th in line. We were in and out in a little over an hour. Get there early or line will be LONG.
Stunning place to visit. We found this a lovely place to visit. It was also good value for money. If you know the day you are visiting, its definitely worth booking online as you skip the queues.

It didn't stand out. Though this place was really beautiful and had a lot to see, I left feeling quite disappointed. Maybe it was because we visited the British Museum, The Houses of Parliament and the Tower of London in the days before, but next to those places Westminster Abbey looked quite pale. In all fairness we visited Westminster on a Saturday, but it was too crowded, till the point where at one of the monuments we literally couldn't move for minutes. In my opinion it was a bit pricey, especially next too the places I named above. If you dó want to visit, buy your tickets in advance! The queue was fairly impressive.

I was blown away!. There was only a very short wait to get inside. We opted not to get audio tour guides and had a blast walking through and seeing all of the memorials! It was a really pretty building!

Impressive Grandeur. Westminister Abbey is an architectural wonder, but it is also a journey through history because it has so many memorials to Kings, statesmen, churchmen, and artists who excelled in their fields, As an English literature major, my favorite part was poet's corner. It is a marvel to see poets from Chaucer to T. S. Eliot memorialized in the same spot, and to see statues and markers bearing the names of hundreds of the greatest English writers who lived. I was moved by the honor bestowed on English writers in the Abbey, and impressed with a country who gathered them and gave them a historical place to be remember.

WOW! Beautiful and Impressive!. The history of Westminster Abbey just in my short lifetime is Spectacular and the history dates back even further. The marriage of Andrew and Fergie, the Funeral for Princess Diana, the Wedding of William and Kate. The Coronation of Queeen Elizabeth and many before her. The coronation Chair is on display but photos of it are not allowed. i say it's a MUST DO!
Evensong- Breathtaking!. Take the guided tour for an additional 5 pounds as it is worth every bit. So much history in this beautiful abbey. Evensong services are fabulous.

So much history that is magical. We spent about 3 hours here. We loved it. Made me come back home and learned more about events that have taken place here. Would return again. Crowded but worth it. I would have enjoyed attending service but our schedule did not allow. Will definitely return to attend service. Fantastic!

Spectacular. To see inside this place was an amazing experience. The inside follows an Ikea-like way of movement ( one way around the church). Famous people inside include Queen Elizabeth 1st, who is in her own room of to the left side. Right at the end is the Coronation Chair which, even if you aren't a monarchist is still pretty cool to see
Much better than expected. After waiting 30 minutes to get in, I was happy we went. Definitely get the audio guide. The history and beauty are truly wonderful.
Wonderful history and architecture. Lovely architecture. Tours include information about who was married and buried there. There is a gift shop where you can buy souvenirs and postcards.

SO AMAZING (yes the all caps was on purpose). I can't even tell you how much I loved it! It was seriously an amazing walk through history. Yes, it costs money to gain entrance but it is so worth it!! It was my favorite part of the city! Beautiful inside, beautiful outside! It is overflowing with busts and and statues of people who have made outstanding contributions to society! I loved it!

Worship . Visited twice for worship during my business trip to London. A pleasant atmosphere with helpful staff. Encountered an issue in the queue with a tourist making accusations of queue jumping (untrue) but otherwise a wonderful Expierience.

Must See but Pick Your Time. This is such an historical building, full of many gravesites of everyone from Queen Elizabeth I to all the poets you may have suffered through in high school or college. But, it is a big tourist destination and can be so crowded as to make touring difficult at times. Avoid Saturdays, and if you have to wait in a line just to buy a ticket, you may want to come another time if you can. We went when it was busy and sort of had to walk through with the herd, so to speak, rather than explore as we would have preferred.

Amazing. I've probably visited here over 50 times over the years.I learn something new each and every time, and on this visit I found the tomb of Major Andre. This was special because i'd just finished reading about his role as a "spy" during the American Revolution.It really does pay to read everything carefully! PS - the guided tour is highly recommended

History with Beauty. The Abbey has more than a thousand years of history, all the way back to Edward the confessor in the 12th century.It's a great place to visit, loads to see and lots to learn.There's more history in this building than in almost any other London landmark, you get a sense of being part of history of the abbey, and can brush shoulders with the ghosts of those who've been interned there!

Evensong. This rating is for Westminster Abbey Evensong. It was a nice experience at no cost and not much of a queue. Just line up at the end of the day. Nice to get in for an activity having toured on an earlier trip. The choir singing the evening I was there didn't wow me so I left a tad underwhelmed.
History realized. To see in person those things you've only read about or seen on television is so great if you are a history buff.
One of the top attraction in London. Very impressive! The Audio guide was also very helpful. We thing it is a must to see during your London visit.
Great History. Enjoyed this place! Amazing building with beautiful art and sculptures! Get the head set, it makes it much more interesting!

Vacasiones . this place is a show for those who like to see the whole history of the royal family of England and appreciate all this wonderful piece of engineering is a place with a lot of sightseeing but Par go there to pay for everything but say it pays to know a place of these

London Vacation. An amazing place to visit. Very historical and serene. It speaks volumes about the history of England. The audio tour was the best way to see the Abbey as you could retrace your tour at any time. It was not as expensive as I thought it would be but worth the price of admission.

Amazing Art & Architecture. If you're interested in history, art, architecture or all three then this place is a must visit. It's an absolutely stunning venue and the little tour guide device you get given on entry means you can take everything in at your own pace.I was disappointed that there's no photography allowed in the main venue although it was allowed elsewhere, which was a nice surprise as I initially thought it wasn't allowed at all. It can get crowded although considering we went during summer holidays, right before the usual "peak" time of the day, the crowd wasn't too bad. Overall definitely worth the price.
Expensive for what it is. Expensive and a long wait, all things considered. I can sympathise that this is due to a huge number of tourists though.

History Unfolding. We used our 2-4-1 vouchers for a Monday morning visit in July. It was very crowded, but the historical significance was almost palpable. While it is a busy tourist attraction, it is still a working church. It was especially moving when the rector/pastor called for a minute of silence to pray for the victims of the attack in Nice, France. To suddenly see everyone, of all nationalities, stop and be still was inspiring to say the least. There was history at every turn, though you had to jostle a bit to get close to it. I think my 9 yo would have enjoyed it more had it been less crowded. However, when he turned in the kid's tour worksheet he was given as we entered for a large chocolate coin in the gift shop, it was deemed a successful visit.

Beautiful. It is a beautiful place to visit with a lot of rich history. When you visit make sure to get a audio guide so you can get all the information it is included with admition so make sure to grab one.

Was great but 20 pund. I went to see it and really liked it. It costed me 20 pound to get in which included an audio guide. That was the price for one adult. I don't think that is particular cheap but I thought it was worth it. Sine all the attractions in London charge quite a bit I decided to go to one attraction only and decided for the abbey. It was really cool to stand where Kate Middleton was walking along and to see all the old monuments. I did. It regret the 20 pound. Please note that the abbey closes at 3:30pm. So make sure you get there at about 3pm to get in still. There are usually medium lines to get in.

Beautiful!. This one of the most beautiful and historic churches in the world. So many people are buried here and so much history. Take as much time as you need to see everything. The guides are very knowledgeable and helpful, all you need to do is ask. I loved JJ Feild in TURN as Major John Andre and knew he was buried in the Abbey but couldn't find him. I asked a guide and he found another guide to take me to the stone. They were great!!

Amazing and historic. Have been there a couple of times and will always go as a pilgrimage of life. It gives a good reflection of British history going back a thousand years ago. As such a good learning experience. Amazing paintings, stained glass and structures. It is world known for its Gothic style. A must to see by a visitor to London.

Ancient and Dazzling. William the Conqueror was crowned on these grounds. Elizabeth the First is buried here. Charles and Di, William and Kate were married here. The church is incredibly impressive. Do not miss it if you are in London. Be certain to view the Coronation Chair on the side near the nave exit; it dates back to the 1300's and was sat in by Henry VIII and both Queen Elizabeths during their coronations.
Could not see it from inside. The place is quite close to Big Ben and the palace. So, do drop by to check out this place. I could not see it from inside and had to take a few shots from outside.

don't miss it. Superb and breathtaking. The history of England in one place. It will exceed you expectations.Get the audio guide - excellent.Crowds do detract from the experience, both in the queues to get in and inside. This is the only downside.

Far too busy,. Absolute free-for-all. Far too many people given access at same time. Couldn't get near some points of interest and actual congestion at certain points on tour. On website stated earphones available for downloaded app for tour...instead it was a large mobile-phone type handset.

Lovely!. Fascinating how this is not only a church, but also a burial ground!
The church is old and parts of it is falling apart because of that, but can feel the spirits of those who have passed as being very happy to be there.

Impressive.. We spent an hour there which was about right, could have stayed a bit longer as there's a lot to take in but after a while I had seen enough Victorian generals of whom I had never heard and had no interest.However, the Abbey is remarkable and extraordinarily beautiful so I think best is to look up what you want to see beforehand.

One of the nicest walks around London. Stroll through this very old Abbey's gardens and witness its wonderful architecture and specific gothic style in all its glory. Definitely a nice spot to see when visiting London, even just to sit for some moments and relax.

A must see for any history buff!. Westminster Abbey is quite simply breathtaking. Yes, it's touristy, and yes, you can argue that one shouldn't have to pay to visit a church, but I loved every moment of it. The audio tour is voiced by Jeremy Irons and is extremely thorough. It took about an hour for us to get through.

Very impressive. The tickets for Westminster Abbey are pretty steep, but it's well worth it. Reading a bit on the history of the Abbey helps.The audio guide provided is absolutely fantastic and you most definitely must get it. The British love their history and it is very well evident the way the monument is preserved.

Surreal. A most enjoyable visit. So much history in this place, definitely not a place to rush through as there is so much to take in. I enjoyed walking around imagining the Royal Weddings that have taken place there and seeing the tomb of The Unknown Soldier .

Well worth a visit. Went for Evensong last August as some reviews have suggested. It was beautiful, you can check the times on the website: http://www.westminster-abbey.org/worship/daily-servicesWorship is free during Evensong, but you're not allowed to walk around. You'll see people line up at the side door close to the time. We did end up going back using the London Pass. It was definitely worth visiting during the day. The church was beautiful. Honestly I liked St Pauls more, Westminister Abbey is more chaotic, more tombs everywhere. Nonetheless, it's a beautiful landmark and worth the visit.

Breath-taking. This was the highlight of my trip in London. The architecture in itself is astonishing so anyone without any historical background of the place or royals buried there can spend hours marveling at it. Once you have the chance to catch up on the historical aspect through the concise,beautifully-delivered comments and movies on the audio guides included in the price of the tour, you find yourself lost in time. Make sure you go there early in the day, since you might find yourself being quite hurried on if it is close to the time that the choir starts practicing for the day's mass. And yes, the price is quite steep, but I found it worth every penny. Now going with children(8&12 in my case) is a bit tricky. For an adult this can be enjoyable and interesting for many hours on end, but the kids were fed up after one hour. A run through would've sufficed for them. They're too young to appreciate history, art or architecture, so if you're planning a long visit here, you might want to reconsider. They even got a kids' course map and pencil to count lions, find other animals and answer history questions with the promise of a big commemorative chocolate coin at the end. They only managed to fill less than a quarter of their "assignment " but we're thrilled to still get a chocolate coin at the end. Our visit left sweet impressions on them too:) The gift shop is one of the best gift shops a church would offer and the prices are not exaggerated. I personally hope I'll get another chance to visit on my own someday so that I can lose myself in all that splendor for hours and hours.

A Must in London. Don't be afraid of the long lines - Westminister Abby is a must In London. Full of history and the location of the wedding of Will and Kate. You get an entirely different perspective when you visit.

Extraordinary. The Westminster Abbey is extraordinary and a must see in London. The history dates back to 1066 where the British royalty has wedded, been crowned, and been buried (it houses over 3000 tombs...39 of those kings and queens). Too, it's magical to think that William and Kate recently wedded there. Yes, you'll have to wait in line and deal with the crowds, but it is worth it.
August 2016. Checked the times of the services and attended Sung Matins at 10am on Sunday 7 August. A wonderful experience
Beautiful Abbey used personally for the Royals.. Beautiful Abbey used personally for the Royals. If you want to go in for free then wait until 5pm and you can enter for free during mass.

Unbelievable. We really liked the Abby. We paid for a Blue Badge person to take us on this tour. I would not visit this unless you are a History Major or you have a Blue badge with you. You will miss so many interesting things if you grab a audio phone and walk through it. You can ask questions and go to the places you want. I highly recommend this to all people who are going to London.

A reminder of what made Great Britian. An amazing working church, with the ability to complete a tour with the commentary on the audio system from Jeremy Irons.It provided me with reminders of history that I am sure I learnt in school but seeing the resting places of the various kings & queens makes it more real.The chapels that are not normally seen when you see the abbey on TV, are packed with memorials and plaques that I am sure would take a week if you wanted to read all of them, but the audio tour highlights the main ones for you. The tour follows a set route, and the items are numbered as you go round, I would recommend that you use the plan with the tour to make sure that you are listening to the dialogue about the right thing, I did see some visitors listening to the tour and looking at something when you know it was not the right item, it made me laugh, but not sure it helped the visitor.Photography not allowed through most of the Abbey, and limited seating.
Peaceful, beautiful. A place of beauty and peace a rare find in London.Jeremy irons is the voice for the audio guide which reminded me of Borgias!!

Impressive from outside. Arrived here after a long trip, already tired, and having spent lots of money. But we approached the Abbey, planning to go in if it wasn't too expensive & lines not too long. But it wasn't obvious to us where to purchase tickets, so we ended up walking around the entire building & deciding that we were tired and ready to go for tea (or beer) and rest for the evening. I do love a beautiful old church building, the history & the windows; but this one will have to wait for another time.

Fascinating . We visited using a London pass (highly recommended) for entry and then paying an extra £5 for a live guided tour (also highly recommended). The tour guide was very interesting and entertaining and we got to see some sights that others at the Abbey did not. I'm not at all religious but this tour was fascinating!

Majestic place and just huge!. Like the title says, majestic place, great to look at from outside! Also great architecture inside but it is just so big it made me quite dizzy! I enjoyed the Christmas mass I attended just for civil servants. However, I did not enjoy the fact that there was a VIP section for politicians/higher grades as I believe we are all equal under God! I have also visited the Abbey previously and found the tombs and other sights in it very interesting.

Star attraction!! . This is the BEST attraction in London. There are large lines and a fee to get in but spend it. Lots of famous people buried in here, a capsule of English history. You could spend hours wandering and learning about famous kings, queens, scientists, authors and philosophers. Really the best place in London to visit!!

Largest Indoor Graveyard EVER!. If you are expecting your standard church, this isn't it. The Abbey is packed with the graves of England's historical elite. If you can put these graves in context, you may soon recognize that this is the Beverly Hills/Park Avenue graveyard of choice. See the graves of most authors you struggled through in school and those of the most famous characters that shaped modern England.
A Top 10 sight. You cannot go to London without at least one trip to Westminster Abbey. The audio tour is a great guide. There's so much history, almost worth a second visit.

Gorgeous piece of history. Westminister Abbey is an iconic British attraction, and when we visited in the fall we were not disappointed. Westminister Abbey is slightly pricey to get into, costing about 20 pounds. The line up starts outside the church, and security checks bags. The line moved fairly quickly for us as we had a London Pass. We recommend buying a London Pass if going to more of these popular attractions. When you first walk in you are in awe of the church. There are burial plots dedicated to famous Brits and British elites. There is a remarkable feeling of piece as you walk through. The entirety is a work of art with amazing sculptures, stained glass, carvings, and metal work. The church is also quite large. There is the main bit where most of the famous gravesite are, but more of the church describes its complex history and changing perception in London. Walking through it we ended up exiting at a different entrance and were able to see it from a different angle. This is one place we recommend going to if you are going to be in London for a couple of hours.

A Fascinating Place!. We thought this was just going to be a large, beautiful church. Not so! This place is full of tombs of some of England's most famous nobility. There's also many plaques and statues honoring famous poets, statesmen, and royalty. Well worth the visit.

Missed the spirituell experience.... Westminster Abbey, quite a sight, but crowded with tourists and quite expensive to visit. The church is filled with the tombs of British heroes and Royal persons, God and the religious spirit is not quite so easy to spot in among all the visitors and historic burial sites. The audio guide is quite good and I do recommend the use of one (no extra charge) if you wish to hear some of the history behind the Abbey and the people buried there. In my personal view the Westminster Abbey is mainly a history lesson (certainly a very good one!), but not much of a spiritual experience. Worthy of a visit, for sure, but not one of my favorite sites in London.
Lovely building. Though they do want £20 each to get in here, which is extortion if you ask me. Nice on the outside though!

Magnificent. What can I say? The history and beauty of this Cathedral are almost beyond words. The architecture alone is stunning but when you add the history of the Royal weddings and the Kings tombs it really is incredible. The audio tour is pretty good but no pictures allowed. Be sure to stop all conversations at the top of the hour for the short prayers. There are good restrooms and a café inside. We used the London Pass. Don't miss it.

Magical experience . What a magical place to visit, no photos are aloud inside but it's understandable and it makes you stop and take it all in and appreciate it some more as you have to always look back at it in memories and not through photos. Was a wonderful place and it's so big, that it takes a while to get around it all, I didn't do the audio guide as my friend was waiting for me but it tells you about all the different parts of the church.It's amazing to view in person and see how big it really is and be able to see all parts rather then the parts you get to see on the tv. Does cost a lot to get in but it's so beautiful that it's worth it, and something that should be seen while in London.

Full of history . We went Saturday morning at 10.30 and the queue was small. There is a quick bag search which only takes a moment. Inside was quite busy and with a useful hearing device learning about the history of the Abbey was an eye opener especially understanding all the Kings and Queens buried there as well as great leaders of the country and poets over the years.Well worth a visit certainly not to be missed

So much history!. Wow! This was just an amazing place! Purchase your tickets online before you go so you dont have to wait in line. We arrived right when it opened in the morning and were able to see the entire thing in about 90 minutes. There is a free audio guide that you can download on iTunes so you dont have to use the ones there. Take headphones. We were able to go straight from the abbey to see the changing of the guard-very do-able if you walk fast. The two are not far from each other.

Timing!. Make sure you check on the hours of the day that you're going. We went on a Friday with an experienced tour guide who had the where with all to call ahead to confirm it would be open until 5. We found out it closed at 3 so made sure we got there quickly

A History Lovers Paradise. If you are a lover of English History, this place is not to be missed. One could spend hours, if not months, reading all the plaques along the walls, falls and tombs. If you get the chance, I highly recommend attending a service, especially one with music, as the acoustics in the place are amazing.
