And attending a service is free, although you don't get to wonder around the Abbey.

Outstanding!. The building itself is a work of art. Then when you consider (and see) all of the people buried in this place, it is a bit mind-blowing. Charles Dickens, Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin...plus many more well-known people and kings and queens.FYI - photography is not allowed inside the abbey. Don't even try.

An enourmous and beautiful cemetery. It was expensive to get into the abbey. Best to buy a family ticket to save some money. We arrived just in time for a summer Wednesday evening organ concert (which is a usual scheduled event) so the ambiance was awesome. In the abbey there are monuments to those buried here but also commemorative plaques for prominent (or wealthy) citizenry. My favorite spot was poets corner. Make sure you stop here to appreciate the markers for the writers of our civilization. Oh! I don't think the audio helped too much. I listened to about 5-6 sound stops. Mostly, esp w/ the music in the background I just took it all in.
AMAZING. We decided to go to the mass, as the ticket is really overpriced (17£) and it was an amazing experience:the choir, location and atmosphere were absolutely evocative

Amazing place.. This was an eye opener. Having been in Rome for over 30 months it was an experience to see the British way of doing history.Very impressive tourist attraction and a must see. We missed the changing of the guard unfortunately.

A must do for London. I somehow did not have high expectations for the Westminster Abbey as I thought it was simply a church. Well, it is ultimately a church, but it is also one of the best places to learn about England's history through their kings. The audio guide, narrated by Jeremy Irons, is mandatory.Also, in addition to major religious figures and monarchs, the abbey also pay homage (and houses the remains) of notorious englishmen and women, like Darwin, Lord Byron, Isaac Newton, etc. I think this is a must do for London.

Favorite attraction. This is so interesting. Listening to the audio guide ( which is included w admission) gives the history of the tombs. Elizabeth I and Mary queen of scots were stepsisters w opposing views. The poets corner includes so many recognizable authors.

Regardless of your faith - this house of worship should be visited.. Magnificent! The Abbey is a beautiful house of worship. The book end tombs for Mary Queen of Scots and Queen Elizabeth I were terrific. Paying tribute to the unknown soldier cannot be missed. The Lady's Chapel is the most beautiful of places - the ceiling is breathtaking. If you get the chance you really must visit.
Organ recital & Evening vespers. Gorgeous place - lots people but queues move smoothly, the on-duty people were helpful & the programme is well displayed for visitors.

Plan You Time a Bit. On my third visit, I took my wife who had never visited. I was impressed by the diversity of tributes, architecture, history, and worship experiences that are in the Abbey. I doubt anyone has the time or legs to see and appreciate everything here. It touches all of English history back to the Normans. Make sure to visit the poet's corner. I enjoyed the moments reflecting on (literally!) the famous scientists.
Awesome just breathtaking!. Truly beautiful and breathtaking. One of the must sees when visiting London. Would recommend this to anyone.

the architecture is breathtaking.. If you like to see the tomb stones of kings, queens and British aristocrats then you would enjoy it.
I personally like the architecture and the tall ceilings. It's a lot of walking. Long lines inspite of holding a London Pass.

Historic and charming!. Its a must see historic attraction in London. The audio guides are very informational. The lines could get really long but if you get tickets online you dont need to wait in line to get in.

Awesome historical place. A place of beauty. A place of such historic importance. A must see for everyone.
A free audio guide on entry. £20 per adult, reduction for families and under 5s free.
Well worth a visit.

AMAZING. This place is amazing!
Was definitely the largest or any of the churches we visited in both Ireland and England.
If you are in London you can't NOT go here.
Photography is not allowed inside the main area, but audio guides are included and give excellent information

Absolutely brilliant. I had a wonderful visit to Westminster Abbey. The information on the audio devices was spot on and very informative especially with the lovely Jeremy Irons giving the narration. Although it was busy it was still very enjoyable.

Westminster abbey. This is an excellent place to visit in London if your into your history of kings and queens it is the place for you I don't really think its the place for children as its all about the history and architecture if you take children there is a possibility that they would become bored after a short time but I would highly recommend a visit here it is not too expensive either.

good hour. Many years of historic events and worth going to see but the entry is costly for it as other places more worth the fee but it is what it is and you have to go to.They don't allow photography which they should for what you pay but all in all this is a fabulous building

An amazing grasp of history through the visit! . Amazing visit for history of religion lovers. It is really interesting how the church is distributed and organised. I loved to see the plaques of some famous people as Isaac Newton and William Shakespeare. Also, the narrow and small halls of the kings and queens are marvelous. I love every minute of the visit. Really great audio guide!
Breathtaking !!!. A tour guide really helps. Lots of information and it helps understand the background and how things are the way they are.

I cried it was so beautiful. We sat in on a service and I teared up at the sheer magnitude of the history surrounding us. My 10-year-old was a bit freaked out by the fact that people are literally entombed several feet away from you but I found it fascinating. Walking in to the service, lighting a candle and praying, the architecture, the music....all of it took my breath away. A very memorable and enjoyable experience. (Also, it's a nice way to sit for an hour or so if you're tired of walking and sightseeing.)

Amazing, but crowded. This is an amazing place for anybody to visit, but specially for those with knowledge about English history and literature. Note, however, that it can get pretty crowded from early in the morning, so try to keep an open mind. The free audioguides are great!

worth the wait. Again, we were pleased to have London Pass since we didn't arrive early. It was worth the wait. The audio tour was well done - who wouldn't mind listening to Jeremy Irons? There was so much to see -- and I found the Poets' Corner to be especially wonderful. We spent a couple of hours there while a daily service went on as well.

Expensive and aggressive place. I booked a visit here using my phone and was shocked how aggressive the person on the ticket desk was because I had not printed out the receipt. Showing her the confirmation on the phone was not good enough. While we were walking around. I got wrongly accused by one of the security guards for climbing over a rope barrier. I asked him where I had done it and was told he had received a report. There was a warden with a red coat who was able to verify to the security guard that I had not climbed any barriers. The guard then said he would sort it out with the person who had given him the report. I asked to see who had reported me who according to the guard was a member of staff but he refused to call them.

Fascinating . I didn't expect to love Westminster Abbey as much as I did. To start with, I was a bit irked to pay £20 to enter a church, however I waited in the que and paid up and I'm SO pleased I did. That's my first tip - there are ques, so get there early. I arrived at about 9.15 and was near the front, but those who arrived closer to the opening time of 9.30 were much further back. Your entry fee gives you free use and access to the excellent audio guide. Full of useful information. The Abbey is full of the tombs and memorials of numerous Kings and Queens and Nobelmen and women together with legendary writers and poets and composers like Byron, Austen, Handel. It is overwhelming, the history. I could have spent so much longer here and I hope that one day I will return.

Stunning inside and out.. The audio tour of this facility is a must or you will miss a lot of the detail. Take your time; but you WILL get overwhelmed. I was overcome with the feeling of history here ... centuries. Be sure to be respectful ... it IS a church.

Be thankful for separation of church and state in the USA. Westminster Abbey is beautiful and historic and is a must-see when visiting London. There is so much history encompassed in this one structure. It is a crowded place, but I rarely felt claustrophobic. The free audio guide is thorough and definitely helps to understand what I was looking at. As I learned about all the kings and queens who have ties in this place--beautiful and historic as it is--I couldn't help but be thankful that my home church in the US does not have a links to the government. :)

Absolutely Gorgeous ~ A Must in London!. A beautiful abbey w/ lots to see, lots of history & very intricate architecture. Take time to soak it all in. Use the free audio guide as it helps immensely. Only disappointment was no photos, but got the souvenir book as the next best thing.
Favorite part of London. The history is amazing in this building. Get there early and pre-book your tickets. I love this place and always marvel at what the building has witnessed.

Amazing Abbey. We got there about two hours before the church closing hours. There is security check for bags and large purses which caused a little bit of a wait. Once inside it was quick with the London Pass with no wait and move to pick up the audio guide for the tour. The audio guide is great but everybody with the guide tend to cluster around each station causing traffic jam in the narrow spaces. NO PICTURES in the church. The abbey is a living cemetery with so many famous people buried in this abbey. The flow of the tour is very well laid out to keep the tourists moving through the various sites. The traffic jams are around the small chapel with narrow entrance/exit. The abbey interior is large but with the large number of visitors is a bit crowded. To appreciate this abbey allow three hours for a leisure and informative pace. Great place to visit and see famous names from the past.

Beautiful Evensong Service. Skip the charge and full tour by attending the 17:00 Evensong service sung by a gorgeous choir. The quiet prayerful contemplation and exit through the main nave is wonderful.
Fascinating place. If you love history, this is the place you wouldn't want to miss. Beautiful structure, full of history and very crowded.

Pretty Cool to See. Overall the place is pretty crowded and when you get to certain parts of the tour that is self guided it is very hard to move. Overall I'm glad I came but wish I would've picked a day that you can see the full place.

London day out . As someone with a keen interest in history , I have always wanted to visit the Westminster abbey . This a definite must see for anyone visiting London and who wants to learn more about England's history. The audio tour , narrated by Jeremy Irons , was excellent and informative and the staff were happy to answer any questions . You also get to use the Coronation chair . Put aside at least two hours for this trip, as there is a lot to see .

Impressive. Very impressive cathedral, oozing with history. Although a bit pricey and with some rather long waiting queues, it was totally worth it.A must see for all those interested in history and architecture.

Magestic. What a breathtaking building, this has got to be one of the most majestic buildings in the world. So much history. I have seen this on Tv many times but that does not do this justice. You can't miss this on your tour of London.

gorgeous building and fascinating history. The abbey is beautiful and quite stunning in architecture. It is actually more of a mausoleum. There is a taped guided tour for you as you enter which was very helpful. Each area has something to see. The gift shop has some nice pictures. The worst part was the restaurant. It had few choices, was very expensive and does not use the London Pass discount that it is supposed to take. Don't eat there.

Amazing place, but you can see more if you go on a Tuesday or Thursday . This place is a walk into a another world. The Gothic style architecture shows what it was like during the Middle Ages. However go on a Tuesday or Thursday and you can see the College Garden.
Beautiful and historic must-see. This was absolutely beautiful and love all the history that is inside. They also had beautiful gardens inside..... Would definitely recommend spring time!
Don't miss this. We've been to a lot of churches in the European area, but there is just more history here than you can believe. Don't miss it!

Beautiful church full of history.. Give me an hour in Europe, and I'll spend in an old cathedral listening to some music. Be absolutely sure to attend an evensong, by far the best way to experience the cathedral.

Wonderful all over again. Westminster Abbey is a must-see—especially if you're a lover of history and / or literature. There's so much to see at every turn: the tombs of Elizabeth I, Mary, Queen of Scots, Edward Longshanks; the tribute to Shakespeare in the Poets Corner; the artwork; the architecture—among other spectacular things. The staff are amazingly friendly and helpful—keen to offer insights and information, and the audioguide is good, too. If you come to London, make this one of your stops. LOOK EVERYWHERE. You won't be disappointed. Great gift shop and café, too!
Amazing. we toured with our grandchildren. they were amazed at the history and people who are buried in the Abby.

DO NOT MISS IT!. A fantastic place to go... but get there early as it gets really crowded. So much history and culture crammed into one place its so well preserved and so well presented. The audio tour is OK but a guided tour would be much better I think
Amazing. Lovely Abbey and grounds, very peaceful. The town around the abbey is nothing much but there are some lovely pubs near by.

buy tickets early - still a line. this is a popular attraction. but the lines move fast. great self-guided audio tour. not all attractions are accessible. photos only after you leave the chapel itself. but just beautiful.

Must See In London. Don't miss seeing this beautiful Abbey. There is a lot more to Westminster than you may initially think with many smaller Chapels within Westminster. This is a place where you can spend 30 minutes or a few hours depending on how much you want to see.

We just stopped to take pictures. We heard that ti was not worth the time or money to view inside, especially if you have seen other churchs/cathedrals in Europe. If you have not then go inside. We just got off at Westminster station stop and took pictures of Big Ben and the Abbey and then went on.
Beautiful church. The church is beautiful. There are a lot of well preserved tombs as well as some art. There is plenty of information available. Can be very crowded. Still worth checking out.

A wealth of history before your eyes.. The opportunity to take a self-guided audio tour of Westminster Abbey is an enriching experience when visiting London. The history of the building is remarkable. The architecture is superb. Wandering through the various alcoves with their distinctive themes and dedications is a treasure. And it certainly develops a sense of respect and awe in one as you contemplate the various persons buried there whose lives were instrumental in western civilization.

Historic Cathedral. Westminster Abbey is a historic cathedral. Inside, you're able to see where people were buried. There are blocks on the ground and on the walls with names. Those are dead people buried beneath the floors.

Summit of tradition. If any landmark could represent Great Britain,this is it. The tour through the Abbey is well documented and available in many languages so that all can benefit from the fascinating stories and facts. It was an eye opener to see who all is buried in its hallowed halls. 20 pounds is a steep entrance fee, but I am glad I visited

Beautiful place. A beutiful place you should not miss, especially if you are a fan of history, poets, or the DaVinci Code. Newton's resting place, which is prominent in the book and movie is here. Sadly, no photo's allowed here
Gorgeous architecture. Totally beautiful inside and out, thoroughly enjoyed it and the girls seemed taken in by it all too!

Westminster Abbey. This was awesome. We purchased a London Pass and this was one of the attractions that was included to get into. Had our own line and got straight in. Spend a couple of hours in here simply in awe of the grandeur and taking the time to look at and read the entombments.

Unbelievable!! MUST SEE!!. The history of this Abbey is incredible, and I have to go every time I visit London! There's over 1,000 years of history there, and the most prominent figures in English history are there, on the crypts and monuments. Poet's Corner never ceases to impress, and the staff there have always been knowledgeable and helpful.

Royal Watchers Must See. Watching the coverage of Prince William and Kate Middleton's wedding, I knew Westminster Abbey was on the top of my London trips. This was a spur of the moment tour as our prior tour ended in Westminster Square. The kids took off to other parts and I did a self tour alone.This was awe inspiring and words cannot describe the depth of the beauty of the architecture and craftsmanship. The moment you enter, your breath is taken away. I was given a recorded tour and it flowed smoothly. I was flabbergasted to find how many crypts and tombs are in the Abbey. You are literally walking on someone's grave at almost every step. If you time it correctly, you can attend a mass. I was able to sit in a mass as well as light a candle. As with most churches and holy places in Europe, photos of the interior are prohibited. However, there are several hallways outside that have beautiful stained glass and architecture you can capture.Photos and videos of royal weddings do not capture a fraction of the amazement and grandeur of this church. It is rich with history of England. You must see it in person. I would visit it a second time on my next visit.

History Crash Course. We visited WA with our kids, who are 10 and 8. We were a bit afraid they would not enjoy it as much, but this is an incredible place to learn about British history and the ticket price (BPS 45 for family)Not only they enjoyed it, they were absorbed by how much history is behind every one of the people buried here - Sir Isaac Newton, Elizabeth I, Darwin, etc...Fascinating.

Great stop but watch out for the lines. This is a must-see, but the best way to do it is to buy a LondonPass. We went in the afternoon on a Monday in August and waited about 45 minutes to get in; the pass line moved very quickly and the wait was probably five minutes. As other reviewers have mentioned, there are many luminaries, all the way from Edward the Confessor forward, who are buried here. The audio tour comes with the price of admission, and is very informative and of an appropriate length; plan for about 90 minutes. There are prayers every hour on the hour, and a service at 3 pm every day. This is right next to the houses of parliament and Big Ben, about a 10 minute walk from Buckingham Palace.

It feels wrong to pay to visit a church.. Everything you would expect and probably more but rather crowded and with some visitors apparently unaware of the normal behaviour standards in a place of worship.
Stunning!. Unfortunately only saw it from afar but it was so beautiful. Next time we hope to go inside. Only had 11 hours to see London and so many sites to see.

British History. Arrived in the morning to avoid crowds, used the London pass with no issues. There is an audio tour included which helped but only scratched the surface of what is there. Super busy but still manageable. A. Must do in London

Don't Miss!. Westminster Abbey is the final resting place of kings, queens, poets, authors, statesmen, scientists and more. The audio tour included with your admission (narrated by Jeremy Irons!) is first rate. We were here in high season, and the crowds were thick, but it sometimes seemed like you were all alone. The ability to drift back into the history and isolate yourself with it is quite amazing. This is a must see while you are in London.Note: Crowds are huge and thick here. Try to be there at opening to get a bit ahead. Side note: We had cream tea in the cafe. It was fantastic!

Grand. The day we went to Westminster Abbey, we were on a Big Bus Tour, and hopped off to eat lunch on the grounds of the Abbey before our audio tour. The audio tour was great- had a lot of information to take in.

Barbara vacation . This is an amazing cathedral. The size and scope are not to be believed. One can take as long a visit as one wants. The visitors can study an exhibition or move on quickly. I always am amazed by the number of luminaries buried there and find something new every time I go. Not to be missed.

Lots of History. Having visited St Paul's on my last visit to London, I decided to stop here this time around. We were here at opening, grabbed an audio guide and proceeded around the abbey. Loved seeing all the details as well as the graves of so many people in church. Very interesting and definitely worth a stop.

If you love history, cathedrals or just beautiful places this place is great. I loved this place! It was huge and it had so much historic relics and tomb stones that I was amazed. I really loved the history of many tombstones and acknowledgement of many well-known Englishmen and women. This place is also a sacred place where many important events are held which made it feel more amazing that you are in the place where kings and queens are crowned and kings and queens are buried along with many other well-known people. The cathedral itself was really nice to look and had so much to offer. I highly recommend it!

Lovely (and expensive) place!. The reason why I've rated this place 4 out of 5 is the charge you have to have access. I would say it's a bit expensive. As I would assure that it's worth a visit, in any case!

Wonderful but busy. Always wanted to go and expected it to be like any other big church. But great to see the coronation chair and wonderful aisle and colours. All the memorials and headstones very OTT. Don't think I've seen a more cluttered church. Definitely worth a visit.

Lots of famous dead people. Make no mistake, this is an absolutely gorgeous place. And it's interesting to see where the queen's coronation ceremony took place, where Prince Charles (and Prince William) were married, etc. Lots of historical bodies, even beyond the royalty.

Must see. Visited again for a second time and as before this building is exceptional and as a uk resident and churchgoer fully appreciate and happy to pay an entrance fee to a place of worship, this place is not a trivial place to go to fill an hour as it deserves not only a little reverence but time to explore the many memorials and chaples and their history, there are plenty of helpful volunteers to provide advice if needed. Overall this is a working church and their is a definate sence of the devine and Christian fellowship amongst the mele of international tourism.
A must visit!. It's as important a destination in London as Big Ben, Tower Bridge... You can't afford to miss it! It takes about an hour or hour and a half once inside!
Rude Gift Shop. The lady in the gift shop was rude. She started kicking everyone our early. In the USA we let people finish shopping but how sad this was a "church" and these people behave this way.
Beautiful, but crowded.. A fabulous graveyard and example of opulent places of worship. Reminded me of A mini Vatican. Glad I did this bucket list item. Enjoyed poets' corner.

Second visit. Loved showing my boys thé tombés offre thé greats. Isaac Newton, Lord Byron, Lewis Carroll, Sir Laurence Olivier, Mary Queen or Scotts . We asked if Sir Paul McCartney WorldTour be buried Thére. NO Was thé answer
Even song. I attend the Abbey for even song this is a free service in the afternoon at 4.30 that the Abbey choir sing just so spiritual and so moving . Would highly recommend it .
Such a great day out . Went to the Abbey and wow the tour was wonderful, it was guided by Benjamin who was comical and informative. Was such a wonderful experience and would happy to visit again.

History unfolds. As an amateur historian I found Westminster Abbey fascinating. The final resting place of many famous people plus they have memorials to others who are not buried there (e.g. Mark Twain and Martin Luther King Jr.). Do the audio tour and take your time, there are crypts and tombs everywhere. When combined with Houses of Parliament you can spend a full day just on this corner.
Will visit again . First visit to the Abbey. It's crowded, go early. Book a guided tour, cost $5 pound per person but it's worth it.

So much to see. . I found this very interesting however I preferred to eavesdrop on some of the live guides giving the tour. I found the prerecorded listening tour hard to follow in places.The architecture is magnificent as is the artwork and sculptures..fabulous to just walk and look and sit..It is a place of worship and you are also welcome to join in the afternoon prayer if you are there. Would go again alone to concentrate on everything and spend longer. Lots of queues but not if you have a London Pass. The staff were also friendly and helpful.
So much history.. We really enjoyed the audio tour of this important site. Some of the side chapels can get crowded, but the audio guide allows you to stroll around at your own pace. Don't miss it!

Awe Inspiring for All ages!. Take the audio tour. Fabulous historical tour through English history. Our 17 year old loved it... See Queen Elizabeth the firsts tomb and travel through the splendour of the monarchy. A rich historical tour. The Abbey is a wonder of the world and a place of calm and peace, even when busy. A London must-see for the whole family!

Stunning building. We paid 20 pounds to go in and it was goo value. Once in you can take the audio guide (in your own language) and this guides you around the abbey and talks you through all the history of the building.
Stunning. Stunning building, a little bit sad that you can't take pictures inside of the abbey! There was a long waiting line but we got in pretty fast.

Arrive early and take the self guided tour. The history of the Abbey is so rich. The self guided tour was a must to truly appreciate the history of the Abbey, and those that are buried or memorialized there.

Westminster Abbey. We did not go into the Abbey as the lines were too long and we didn't have enough time to do it justice. We did have a look at this majestic Abby from the outside and I feel that's it is one of the most beautiful building I saw in London and its a credit to the British Royal families and government to open it to the public for tours (even though the price is 20 pounds) though saying that it probably goes to the up keep of the building and that's well worth it. Looking around outside it wasn't as big as I thought that it would be and was really surprised - guess that the only time I have seen the exterior and grounds has been a televised royal wedding and the exterior was crowded. Its a really beautiful building/church and hope they continue to keep it in such good conditionI would suggest that if you do intend to go here try and find a tour company that has skip-the-line tickets and that will save you a great deal of time. London was always being 'locked down ' when we were there and the coach and traffic had a hard time getting us anywhere on our pre-booked tour

Amazing history and architecture. Tickets for adults are just below £20 but this was definitely worth it. It's awe inspiring to see where monarchs have been crowned for so many many years. It's a little dark in the sense that the abbey does also contain tombs but it truly gives goosebumps. The architecture and art here is just incredible.

Breathtaking abbey!. The history surrounding the abbey and the people buried in the abbey is just breathtaking. It is expensive to get in but the money paid is well worth it. The abbey is very well maintained and the staff is very helpful. Pity you can't take any photo's inside.
Always Great. I never get tired of visiting this church, such history. we were the last group in, so the crowds were not too bad.
Dirty audio guides!. Very dirty audio guides, took two wipes to clean! Can not imagine how many people used them without cleaning! Only this made my experiences terrible!

Sweet and neat. Wonderful cathedral with a fantastic history. It is very worth a visit. Make sure you visit early - when the queues are at their shortest. Remember that it is NOT allowed to take PHOTOGRAPHS in the abbey. PLEASE respect this!PS: See if you spot the abbeys walkway for the monks along the walls (high up). Try and follow it around the abbey. Make sure you ask one of the volunteers/guides to tell you the good story behind this walkway.

Impressive and worthwhile! . Such an impressive abbey - it is great to look inside. You have the option in your ticket to have the audio tour. Would highly recommend this (Jeremy Irons narrates it) as you learn so much more from about the abbey's history and all the different statues/memorials. No photography is allowed inside the abbey (obvious reasons) but once you finish the abbey you can take photos in the courtyard/cloisters and chapter house which again I would recommend to go visit. Britain's oldest door is also there! Well worth the trip and would do it again :)

Must see. Visited again for a second time and as before this building is exceptional and as a uk resident and churchgoer fully appreciate and happy to pay an entrance fee to a place of worship, this place is not a trivial place to go to fill an hour as it deserves not only a little reverence but time to explore the many memorials and chaples and their history, there are plenty of helpful volunteers to provide advice if needed. Overall this is a working church and their is a definate sence of the devine and Christian fellowship amongst the mele of international tourism.
Over 1,000 years of history. My son and I visited 10 Cathedrals and Abbeys on this vacation. This was one of the finest. Highly recommended for families with children.
A must while in London. This is something you cannot miss if you are visiting London, the history is unbelievable, and is narrated by the handheld device which is included in the admission

Work of art!. There's an audio guide provided at the start of the tour which provides quite a bit of details about the more interesting exhibits (for lack of a better word!). There's a lot of history buried in here (no pun intended!). Found the fact that they had buried queen Elizabeth and her half sister Mary, queen of Scots, together rather ironical given their turbulent relationship. The whole Abbey is breathtaking and a work of art. We went on a Tues and got to visit the college garden which was open to the public that day. Spent a good two hours walking through the Abbey. But totally worth it. Aside from the the Tower of London, this is another historical place worth visiting

What a Story!. It is not only a beautiful church. Inside is the history of the Great Britain the monarchy. Tombs of kings and queens and famous. Each grave is a true monument unique and fabulous. Each of these monuments tells its own story. Cute even the garden. Really good visit! obtain advice of audio guide.
Very interesting. I highly recommend visiting this church. Lots of history, going back so many centuries. The free audio guide does a good job. The entrance was a pretty long queue.

amazing. This is a must see in London. It so amazing. We did the audio tour. Very informative. The staff is very helpful and answered every question we had. They are closed on Sunday's, we made that mistake and had to go back. But so worth it!! Enjoy!!
Must See . Truly beautiful, the architecture alone is worth the visit. The rich historical content is an added bonus. A must see in London.

Can't miss this. How could you visit London and not go see Westminster Abbey? It's simply amazing! Two things to note - the Abbey is closed on Sunday but open for services. You will not get to see the whole Abbey if you go to a service on Sunday. However, they sometimes do organ practices that are free and really amazing. Look into it and see if there is one on a Sunday during your visit!

The English Gothic Abbey not to be missed!. The most of England's kings and queens have been crowned here and buried as well. The histories of Westminster Abbey and England are almost the same as the Abbey was built in 1065 (the remains of 29 kings and queens, hundreds of memorials to poets, politicians, scientists lie under its stones). The best way to see and understand the vast history of this place is to pay the entrance fee that includes audioguide, cloisters and Abbey Museum. To avoid the steep entrance price you can attend 5:00PM evensong, but no pictures are allowed and make sure you like the 45 minutes of singing version of the evening prayer in the Anglican Church:))

Breath taking - a must!. We loved our visit to the abbey. It was well worth the £20 entrants fee, which we were happy to pay to preserve such an amazing monument. I would advise getting here early, the queues get quiet long. I wouldn't prebook as the queue to pick up the tickets was just as big. The abbey itself is gorgeous and breath taking, but the huge amount of history you are able to witness inside is amazing. The guides/staff are fantastic, so knowledgeable, don't miss out by not asking them.

Pricey. Opulent. Busy. At $18 to enter this beautiful, but crowded site, it was a slight let down. There's no doubting the beauty and history of the Abbey. The stained glass, the coronation chair, the Abbry Choir, etc are delightful. But the complimentary Cathedrals in Salisbury, Paris, and New York are equally stunning. I'm glad I went, but it's just way over priced.Plan for 2 hours here to tour...no photography allowed inside makes this one move along a little faster. The audio guide is helpful.There's a nice people watching area across from the Abbey. You can get some great photos there...and rest for tired feet.

Not to be missed.. If you are amazed with European history, then this is the place to go. This is a beautiful church with British history from the 1200s to Winston Churchill. The stories we have all heard culminate in this one great building. Take your time and enjoy. Can be crowded, but go with the flow.

Nothing Like Westminster Abbey. I really didn't know what to expect going into Westminster Abbey. My wife is a King/Queen/Prince(s) fanatic so I followed her. It didn't take 5 minutes, and I was into the Abbey !! So much to talk about here !! You must see. However, get tickets before you go (London Pass). The lines to buy tickets and then stand in line again to wait in line with a ticket is crazy. We had the London Pass and were 30 minutes early to opening, do it that way ! We came out, and the line was stupid crazy. There are so many historical things to see, you need 2-3 hours to enjoy. Lots of assistance inside for questions, bathrooms are centrally located and what an amazing place !!!

Beautiful History. Beautiful to see but do not expect to take pictures. No pictures are allowed unfortunately. There were lots of people but the flow was steady. Device and headphones were provided to listen to the numbered narratives of each exhibit.
Historical High point. What an amazing history filled place. Plan for a few hours to really see the interior and all the famous people commemorated or buried here.

just fantastic. if you got in, you will get a free audio guide.It is so-so interesting, for those who very fond of history. make sure, you take your time and can hear properly all what is provided by audioguide.

Visit for the History. Not sure what to say. Don't go on a Saturday. Don't wait in long lines because by the time you get in, you'll be to tired to enjoy it. The Abbey is worth seeing I believe, but don't take a whole day in line to get in. Go early during the week and avoid the crowds. I rate the Abbey very highly for the history and the "Who's Who" that rest there. I downed the rating because of the small issues that come with all tourist sites. Some just handle it better the others.

Majestic place. Amazing abbey with lots of history and btilliant architecture. I visited the place three times and enjoyed it every single time. Definitely one of the most interesting icons and a must see when in London.

The number of people buried there is astounding!. The tour is really interesting and free audio guides are given out so u don't have to pay for them. The tomb of the various kings as well as Queen Elizabeth I is definitely not to be missed. To think that every royal even Napoleon and Josephine were crowned here is amazing and of course to imagine Prince William and Princess Kate walking down the aisle here in this stunning church is magical.

Breathtaking. Pros: Some people say it is overrated, but I disagree. If you are an art lover this is an absolute must see while in London. This is not just a church, it is a work of art, full of history. Wonderful architecture, wonderfully decorated, the sculptures and windows are works of art. Photography inside is unfortunately prohibited, but that will get you the chance to really enjoy everything Westminster Abbey has to offer. Do get your audio guide as you will learn a lot. Cons: Entrance fee a bit pricey for a church but you can get in for free with a London Pass.

Magnificent Monument to the English History!. If in your visit to London, you have the chance to visit only one Landmark, go to Westminster Abbey and learn about its roots and history. Built by King Edward I to honor King Edward the Confessor (Saint Edward), along all these years have received several additions and modifications to accommodate the great majority of Britain most distinguished citizens, (Monarchs, Scientists, Politicians, etc.) including the Unknown Soldier Shrine. Also is the place where Monarchs are crowned, special mention that this Abbey is a survivor of the "Dissolution of the Monasteries" by Henry VIII as well as the intense bombardments by the Nazis during WWII.
Very interesting spot. The most interested thing I found in Westminster Abbey is all the famous dead people buried under the floor.
Beautiful. You're not allowed to take photographs inside however it is still amazing to see plus there are lots of clips from old kings and queens of England

Best of all places in London. Hands down!. Beautiful on the outside and inside. You can just walk around with the free audio guides and learn by yourself on the British history. Weddings, funerals and lots have taken place there. I learnt a lot and became a fan of the British history. every single inch is covered by some historical event. Its is one of the oldest buildings to stand up as a whole in the world.

Historic, but pricey and busy. It was a great experience, at 20 pounds a ticket. No pictures inside, which wouldn't have really worked out well anyways since it's wall to wall people -- all with audio tour sets pressed against their heads. We opted out of the audio guides to marvel at the decor, tombs and artifacts. If you do this, having some insight to what you want to see up front may be good as not everything is marked to well as far as who was who. The coronation chair was neat to see (of course, the stone of destiny is now in Scotland, which we say several days later).

Seeing the burial place of Elizabeth 1st was the highlight for me. Walking round Westminster Abbey is like stepping inside a history book. So many outstanding people buried and remembered there. Amazing to see the tombs of Elizabeth 1st, Edward the Confessor and Richard II. Poets Corner is so interesting and fascinating to see the burial site of Handel. Especially poignant to see the grave of the Unknown Warrior.

My favourite place in London. Westminster Abbey never fails to take my breath away. The audio guide is great, and seeing all the details in the monuments / graves is just amazing. I have visited 5 times over the years, and this is still not enough. Just beautiful.

The best of London. Westminster Abbey is spectacular and is well worth a visit no matter what religion you are. The architecture is spectacular and the place is filled with history and famous literature persons. Suitable for all ages as they also offer a children's self-guided tour/treasure hunt to keep the little ones entertained whilst you look around.Definitely pick up an audio guide, they are free and the Abbey does not have many info signs to explain the different areas. Some areas are only able to be seen on group tours that you pay extra for, so if you really want to see it thoroughly this may be worth it for you, although there are grainy videos of the areas on the audio guides to make up for this.Do make sure to visit the gardens on a nice day, they are open on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursdays and are pretty (a nice place for a picnic).. The abbey does offer a 2For1 rail ticket deal outside of peak seasons (20th July-5th September I think) so try and visit outside of this time to save money (See national rail website for more details). Otherwise entry is £20 for an adult.The staff were really helpful and friendly, they answered my questions happily.We spent about 2 hours there, listening to the whole audio tour.If you are short for time or money, then the Abbey is a bit like a larger version of St Paul's so I recommend visiting one or the other if this is the case.From memory St Paul's seemed more wheelchair accessible than the Abbey, which contained steps into many of the chapels (however the abbey do offer a video so that you do not have to miss out on seeing parts of the abbey, though these aren't great quality).

A must see!. The Abbey seems to be more of a cemetery for notable British historical figures, esp. Queen Elizabeth the 1st. It is a moving experience walking in the steps of so many historical figures and thinking about whispers and discussions that have occurred over the centuries. No photo are allowed, so be sure to buy post cards.

Truly Stunning place with amazing history!. This is a MUST for first time visitors. Astounding building with an absolutely awe inspiring history. Make sure to take the headsets and leisurely stroll with well narrated tour, through the burial places and memorials of the Kings and Queens of England. Poets Corner left me in tears with the number of famous people who are either memorialized or are buried here.

Worth the visit...but get the audio guide. Usually we like wandering around churches and historical sites on our own, but here we made a mistake in not getting the audio guide. The abbey is fascinating with its blend of religious and historical elements (quite the collection of royal tombs), but there isn't a lot of signage so having the audio guide would have added to our experience quite a bit.

Wow~!!. This was really amazing. There are so many tombs in this abbey, it will blow you away. Queen Elizabeth I, who's tomb is right overtop of her sister Mary, was our favorite, because we love the story. Be sure to visit the poet's corner and talk to the staff. We recommend the headsets while you tour.

A visit to Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey is one of the most interesting places to visit in London. One can enter the Abbey proper for no admission but if you really want to view the crypts and Poets Corner, you need to pay the admission price. When you pay, request an audio tour which will heighten your enjoyment. Finally, check carefully for the time that the crypts ad Poets Corner is open(some days these areas close by 1:30 pm. Further, after you finish touring Westminster, walk down the street to Trafalgar Square and visit the National Gallery. There is no admission to the gallery and the collection is well worth visiting.

Stunning!. I've been to Westminster twice and was blown away both times. Make sure to take the time to walk through as many chapels as possible. And pay attention to what you are walking on - it might be the burial spot of Gallileo!

London: Another "Do Not Miss" Attraction. I have visited Westminster Abbey several times. And I hope to again! I feel the history oozing out of every stone, nook, and cranny! It helps a lot if you read up on English history and read a book about the Abbey before visiting -- know something about what you are seeing! Your visit will be greatly enhanced. If you're a Christian from a denomination that values the liturgy (Catholic, Anglican, Episcopalian, Lutheran, etc.) try to attend a church service there. Most inspiring! The only negative comment I can make about the place is that it is usually crowded, so take your time and don't let yourself get pushed along by the crowd. Also there are frequently noisy groups of schoolchildren - always French in my experience, but there are certainly others from elsewhere too -- who will run you over as they move quickly from one thing to another.

A highlight of our trip. You could spend all day here and still miss some of the famous people buried here. What an amazing place steeped in history. Loved the Mary Queen of Scots tomb. What a great thing it is that kings and politicians can be buried here but so can those who worked and served the abbey.
Wonderful Abbey. Its a great tour if you get the Audio tour. Without the tour there aren't good descriptions - its also no longer free

My favorite attraction in London!. We did the self guided audio tour so we could go at our own pace. This church is filled with so much British history it was astounding to me. The beauty is amazing too. Definitely do not miss it!

Overwhelming. There is so much here, one of those attractions where you can't possibly get everything in one trip, but truly worth every visit. I'll be honest, I didn't want to go to London that much but my husband convinced me. I wasn't sold on anything and basically took advice on what "I HAD to see". Usually I'm overly prepared for trips but not this one. Westminster was worth it, just like everyone said. I can't believe how beautiful it is and all the history there. We had the London Pass so it was free entrance and audio guide. That is what we used and my husband and I took turns taking care of the stroller and baby while the other went to see the smaller areas of the church. There is just so much! You can go back every time you visit and I swear there will be more to hear. Cons: Since we did the audio guide only that's the only thing I can really comment on. It's kind of confusing starting out, you are sure if you need to stay in the initial atrium and listen to it, or if you can walk through the first hallway to get to the first station (you do). The audio guide doesn't really talk about any specific entombments at first, so even though you'll see Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton, they aren't really discussed except in passing. But stations 1-4 are excellent, lots of information (though I think they probably glazed over a lot). Things start to get very crowded after this and it's not clearly labeled (or at least I had trouble finding the stations on my own) stations 5 & 6 are good but especially 7-9, 15 & 16 are hard to find and a pain in the butt to figure out who they talking about. It's all incredibly fascinating but you can lose your baring if you're not careful.Also, I wish they would do more in the audio guide about the beginning of the church, most of it was focused on the Monarchs who had contributed to building it up but very little is said about the time it was a monastery. I did pay for the Souvenir Guide so now that I am at home I can do some further reading, but I kept hoping there would be more about that during the audio tour. Pros: Just when you think you're getting lost, you climb the stairs to Henry VII's Lady Chapel. This is, in my opinion, the best part of the entire tour. There is so much in this section of the church and as a personal Philippa Gregory fan this is the part that probably would be most interesting to younger female history fans. Make sure to see the Cloister Garth, it reminds me of Hogwarts and there are some really beautiful memorials in there. Family Tip: If you have a child young enough, I highly recommend forgoing the stroller and wearing your baby if you can. There is surprisingly a lot of London that is accommodating to strollers and while you can bring in your stroller into Westminster, take it from me, it is much much easier to wear your baby through this particular attraction.
Beautiful architecture. Westminster Abbey is steeped in more than a thousand years of history. Amazing place. I took so many pictures of the detail, it's incredible. This is absolutely a must see.

So Good and free if you do it right.. If your tired of spending money and want to get it to the Abbey for free all you have to do is attend a church service like a regular church goer. You can't take pictures during the service so that is the take back, but if your stealthy with your phone ;)

Breath taking. Completely breath-taking. Although audio-guides are provided with your entrance fee, I cannot help but wonder how it would've like to tour the Abbey with a historian or private guide to offer more insights to the stories behind what is there. Perhaps next time. For now - the complimentary audio guide was totally sufficient. Don't miss this. And get there early enough in the day so that you are allowed in - visiting entrance seems to stop at 1430 for the 1530 visiting closing time. Still worth the visit.

InterestiHistorical recint where big events have taken place. Interesting to visit this historical recint where big events have taken place. Bigger than expected. In the center of many other places worth to visit

Fantastic history. A beautiful building steeped in history. Would reccomend a visit. Its a shame no photography was allowed. A huge place with lots to look at and read about as you walk round. Lots of areas to sit and rest for those who need to. Kids loved the fact that a certain princess was married there in 2011.

Westminster Abbey is truly magnificent!. Westminster Abbey is a must on a visit to London! We did not pre-book and happily waited in a queue to gain entry. The architecture of the Abbey stunning and there is just so much to see! The sheer magnitude of the history and burial chambers is fascinating. We recommend allowing plenty of time to absorb the ambience of the Abbey and its surroundings.
Amazing. It's one of the best destination for those of you who love history. You will be astonished with the architecture and art.

Must-see for British history buffs. I visited Westminster Abbey yesterday and enjoyed my visit greatly. For a those that have studied British history it is a must see. It is basically a warehouse of remains and memorials to the whose-who of British history...on the walls and underfoot with stone coffins packed into every corner....can be a bit overwhelming. For this reason the audio guide is a must. There is little to no signs indicating whose tomb is whose and since the majority of inscriptions are in Latin, most people will be out of luck without the guide. The building is quite crowded even early in the day so it does require a bit of patience if you are going like did in the summer months and it would not be a good visit for anyone hoping to run in and out. You definitely want to set aside at least 2 hours. Also, make sure to get your tickets on line and print them ahead of time to avoid the line!
No photos. I loved this church, it was so incredible! I am just extremely sad that I could not take any photos.
Amazing Cathedral. Great self guided audio tour available in many languages. Fantastic amount of history with great deal of preservation. Beautiful architecture inside and out.
Incredible place. Westman sterling Abbey is an amazing historical and religious site. A must see when visiting London. Unfortunately you are not allowed to take photos inside.

Powerful history. I truly enjoyed this tour. It's a walking tour guides by audio through your phone, if you download the free app, or you can borrow a speaker with your preferred language. As a lover of English history, I found Westminster Abbey very moving. The tour took about an hour.

Westminster Abbey is very informative and historic. We really enjoyed our tour of Westminster Abbey. We used the Rick Steve's audio tour and really learned a lot. The audio tour there is free, but we found the Rick Steve's tour very good and is also free. This is a must-see site, eventhough the price is high.

Beautiful, but ..... I understand that entrance fee is needed to control the visitors, however, I have always found that paying to enter a religious building is absurd. I have never entered, so I cannot comment on the interior.Westminster Abbey (which is not an abbey anymore) is famous because of its significance in coronation and burial site (for royal and other significant people, such as Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin), but the building exterior itself is typical gothic that you can find anywhere else. Beautiful, but not unique in itself.

Very interesting. I have been here before and was very happy I went here again. Westminster Abbey is a very impressive building. I have seen dozens of the greatest churches from throughout the world and while it is not number 1 number 2 or number 3 it must be in the top 10. Beyond the basic architecture what is truly impressive is the history of the building instructed over so many centuries. For the beyond that people buried in the building and the nature of their tombs. The most interesting and possibly most impressive of which being poets corner. It is definitely a must-see. I wish there have been some way to get past the long lines but it was well worth it
Very big and eerie in places. Quite expensive and more for adults than kids. So much bigger inside than it seems on tv. We really got a sense of history in various parts of it.

Hauntingly Beautiful. Even for a mildly spiritual person, just siting in this abbey, especially if you're lucky enough to hear the choir practicing, is a beautiful and moving experience. Visually and historically it's worth a visit for these reasons too. Beautiful architecture, decoration, history, purpose, etc. Worth the time.
Remarkable History. I have visited on numerous occasions, and I am still in awe of the scale in detail and its history. The Abbey is for me a place of inner peace.

Well worth a visit!. So I booked my tickets online but didn't know where to go to collect them. A lady in uniform directed me to a nearby queue and said to wait on the side. I waited and watched the queue of people stream past. The security guy asked me what I was after and I explained his colleague told me to wait there. After a quick search of my bag, he let me in and I joined the queue with the others. Not quite sure why I couldn't have just joined the main queue outside as it made little difference. Once inside, we were given our wrist bands and free audio guide (I downloaded the app beforehand but didn't want to use up my battery!) and off we went. You know, I've wanted to go inside here for years, ever since I was a little girl and it was more than I could have imagined. The place is beautiful and bursting with history. You can read what you'll see here on the official website so I'll spare you the details. You're guided around (a bit like sheep) thanks to the audio guide so you're all pretty much going in the same direction. It's a lot smaller than I imagined so plenty of, "Excuse me please" was going on - so many people just stand there having conversations without a thought for the people behind waiting for a glimpse of Elizabeth I's resting place. I was there for a couple of hours but would have happily spent another two hours going around again.
Unbelievably gorgeous!. The Abbey is steeped in history and is breathtaking to see! Many royals are buried here including Queen Elizabeth I and Mary I.

What a marvelous church!!. What a majestic and marvelous church!! A must visit because it has everything!! There are tomb of all the noble and important people of the UK. So don't miss this awesome church!!

Part of England's history. It's a beautiful church full of works of art and very famous dead people! LOL. It's expensive to get in, and photos are not allowed, but at least for me it was worth the visit, as I love the Royal history.

Awesome experience, but no pics inside . Tons of awesomeness and great history facts. We did the self guided tour with the recording device and you can select the number corresponding to the viewing item. No pictures allowed inside. Great site to experience.

Beautiful and interesting. This abbey is old but still beautiful. The abbey offers ann audioguide that is very complete and the information given is practical and interesting. This abbey is a must because there are many famous characters buried here.

Westminster Abbey - Beautiful ceiling, saw Darwin's and Newton's tombs. Good visit for a rainy day. Beautiful ceiling, we saw the 100+ years old chair which was used by kings and queens when they were crowned. Darwin's and Newton's tombs were there, which was interesting. This place is good for older folks, may be 30 years old or more :-)
Beautiful . If you are in peak tourist season, get there early before it opens. Much nicer this way and less crowded. Lots of history here. Enjoy!

Moving. We enjoyed the tour through the abbey on the listening devices - we got there after 2:30p, so we couldn't have a live tour. Poet's Corner brought me to tears and Mary Queen of Scot's tomb was amazing.

Don't miss Westminister Abbey. This might be easy to not visit as it can get crowded. But I would not miss it. If you can get a tour, even better. They do have the headphones to listen to a tour, but always nice to have a scholar take you through. So much history here. So many famous people buried here.
U shd visit this place. If u like history, this is the place to go. Use their audio guide, a nice monument place. There is a cafe too.

Beautiful yet a bit pricey. To enter you need to pay 20 pounds. A bit steep but it did include a very informative audio guide. Very historic building and great to look at the important names of people buried there such as Newton, Darwin and many, many others.

Fabulous, beautiful and so much history.. Fabulous, beautiful and so much history. Long line to get in, but it moved and we heard lots of chimes. I heard about it my whole life and it did not disappoint.

A beatiful, historical Abbey, with a true air of spirituality about it. Westminster Abbey is a magnificent and truly beatiful place. The photos shown on our nations TV truly do not do it justice. I payed for the Verger guided tour and would recommend it.

Free for Mobility impaired.. This wonderful historic church has free entry for mobility impaired. One of the reasons for this is that some places are not handicapped accessible. There is still lots to see and if (like me) you can walk a little and climb a few stairs, you can see everything.
Beautiful building. Worth the trip.

Amazing history.. This is a beautiful church. I felt totally overwhelmed and unprepared for this visit. I wish I'd brushed up more on my history before I took their audio tour.
It is awesome. Loved the grave of the unnamed soldier inside the church. The art inside is beautiful and the amount of people buried inside the church is amazing.

OVERPRICED ENTRANCE FEE. I do love Westminster Abbey, but my goodness was it way over-priced to go in there (and I am not the type to complain about prices!) It is beautiful, but very pricey, I would recommend you to admire it from afar!

History and religion. You can see from the restorations and cleanings that this building has endured a lot. You line up on the outside and pay to get in. Audio guides are included in the admission price. Jeremy Lyons accompanies you on the audio journey. The nave has a tomb of the unknown soldier which was beautifully surrounded by red poppies. Of the tombs, royalty, chapels the poets' corner was most interesting. This is an active church and retains a spiritualism that is a bit offset by the ticket desks.

Worth it!. We were in London for a week, and Westminster Abbey was among our top places we wanted to see. We all, including our two daughters, liked the included 90 minute audio tour which provided great information. We did not have advance tickets, but there is a separate line for people with those tickets (to the right when you are facing the entrance). That might have saved us a few minutes, but our line was not very long. It is a beautiful church and worth seeing. It is easy to get to by tube and the site offers a great vantage for Big Ben pics. After, we had a short walk to the Churchill War Rooms, and Buckingham Palace (and surrounding parks).

Iconic and historical; Must go!. Being a seminary student, as well as someone who studied Church Architecture in seminary, this was a real treat and something I was really looking forward to in my trip to London.It's just a place so filled with rich history, especially that of the Church. And the architecture of the entire place was absolutely stunning, even down to the details of the carvings and the designs. There's something so captivating and interesting about the architecture of old church buildings such as Westminster Abbey, that you can't find anymore in our modern day. It is truly beautiful and stunning. I find that you'd really appreciate it more if you did some research on the history of the church and of the building. But this is such an iconic attraction of London, and definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful !!. This building is just bursting with history of our heritage and it is just quite simply beautiful - we stood at the grave of the "unknown soldier" and it just moves you - we loved it here.

Pleasant visit to a beautiful setting. Expensive entry fee, but a need to see in London. Add the 5Pound fee for a guided tour from a verger. You get to see the shrine of St. Edward on that tour, you can't otherwise
Westminster Abbey . Beautiful historic building. So much history inside this is a must visit when in London. Even if churches aren't your thing it's such a beautiful building well worth a visit.
Historical . A church that was built in the 1200's was amazing to see. Rich in history. You really should know the history of the church to appreciate it's presence.

Worth the visit. We had not done the tour of the Abbey, so decided it was time for a visit. We enjoyed stepping back into English history after forty years or so. The assistants were helpful and friendly. There are handheld digital guides which bring the history alive. For those who may not be interested in the religious history, Poet's Corner is still a must. After several trips to London over the years skipping a visit, it was very worthwhile to tour the place again. Go early to avoid the crowds.

A Grand Church and More. It is always special to visit Westminster Abbey and see where the royals are married, where the Heads of State are crowned and where the Anglicans in London worship. The church is a functioning church with a Godly and Spiritual atmosphere. It is used daily for prayer and services. The tour is self-guided but an audio device is provided with the tour price, it is triggered by entering numbers you see around the various landmarks and the narration is excellent - full of historical facts, interesting tidbits of information and insight into British and UK history. This is a great tour for a person of any religious persuasion who wants to learn about British history and it is especially meaningful for Christians and Anglophiles.

So much history!!!. This church is so amazing and is truly worth a visit. Please be advised that you won't be allowed to take pictures inside. Also be advised that it gets crowded. Most of the visitors are respectful. The employees are helpful and knowledgeable. There is so much history in that place. I strongly recommend!!! Charles Darwin is buried there!!!
impressive but boring for kids. the whole place was very cool, and the audio tour was great. perfect for people who are interested in history but I wouldn't suggest for kids
Have to see this in London,. Just to see the names of the people buried there was worth it so interesting and beautiful and ancient. Enjoyed it very much. Wear comfy shoes though.

Day trip to the Abbey. Not been here for a very long time , since the days of brass rubbings ! Found it a little on the pricey side at £20 a head . It was extremely busy and that made it difficult to see a lot . Beautiful building and like the fact you can listen as you go round .
Have to see if you are in London!!!. My wife and I both loved the Abbey!!!! Simply loved it. The amount of history is incredible. So many people who's names will just jump out at you.

Westminster . If you are even a mild history fan you could spend days in here. Lines are very long. I recommend purchasing the London pass and using that as it provides entry to multiple activities and this is one of them that puts you in the "fast line" seriously, the London pass is really great. Get the audio guide to Westminster. It is well narrated by Jeremy Irons and helps guide you along the best route to see the most of the abbey. Photography didn't seem to be allowed in the main part of the church but I saw people taking pictures with their phones- however, I feel like soaking it in and just absorbing the magnitude of the entire place is a better use of time than trying to photograph something you really aren't supposed to. Outside the main cathedral, photography is allowed so go to town out there. In a nutshell, give yourself plenty of time to experience this amazing site, get the audio guide, and set down the cell phone.

One of London's greatest treasures!. I am a history fanatic, and touring Westminster Abbey in person absolutely lived up to the hype. Arrive early (or you'll be waiting in line to enter!), and take your time soaking in the rich history and cultural significance of the shrines, alters, and architecture -- the admission price (use 2-FOR-1 if you've taken the train or have a paper Travelcard!) includes an audio tour, which is fantastically comprehensive, that lets you pick and choose which exhibits/sites to learn about. I would allow at least two hours to experience the Abbey, and keep in mind that no photography is allowed inside the church, but it is permitted in the cloisters.Also, make sure you check out the downstairs room in the gift shop! I found the most beautiful earrings there that were designed after the Abbey's stained glass, and they're my absolute favorite souvenir.***The review that says the toilets have a fee is inaccurate -- the restrooms inside the Abbey are free to use.

A lot of History in one small place. Of course you could rush through in 30 minutes but it would behoove you to spend a couple of hours to listen to all information on the free device when you pay your 20 pound entrance price. Could be very crowed during the summer so you need to get there at 9AM to get tickets and doors open at 9:30.

Best. Cathedral. Ever.. This place is amazing! Definitely get a ticket in to see plaques in memory of and burial places of monarchs, politicians, poets, artists. The caveat: they have a rather vigilantly enforced no photo rule, which I personally think is a bit crap.

It was our last stop on a busy day and we arrived too late for the tour!. Parliament was having a service in the chapel next to the abbey for the member who was murdered on the day of our proposed visit. We didn't get into the Abbey until late in the day, which turned out OK as instead of paying to get in as tourists (on the Days Out, 2 for 1 scheme of National Rail), we went in for evensong, which is a choral service, taking place at the end of the day. We very much enjoyed this service which was only slightly spoiled by the tourists who came in and left after 15 minutes, interrupting the service by the noise they made in leaving. We enjoyed the music and singing so much, it contributed to us going to evensong at York Minster a couple of weeks later. The disadvantage of not paying to get in earlier was that you are very restricted in what you can see at evensong and exploration of the Abbey during tour hours is strongly recommended. It is a beautiful building.

Absolutley Beautiful. So glad we visited Westminster Abbey while in London. It's a beautiful church to see from the outside and inside. We spent about 30 mins to an hour walking through. We didn't have to pay an admission fee to enter the Westminster Abbey or the grounds.

Favorite part of my London trip. Gorgeous and filled with history. It was well worth the price of admission and I really enjoyed the audio guide. I recommend buying a ticket online and printing it out, they let those people skip the queue.
Go to Mass. So rather than go to W.A. as a tourist, you can go to mass at 5:00. The choir is so soothing and the service enchanting. And, it is all free of course. Enjoy

A great place to see. We love to visit the UK with all the history and this is one of those historical places. The self guided tour with the hand held device gives you lots of information of some of the people who are there.

Stunning . A must to do . £20 entry. . Worth every cent. Stunning. Must see to to enjoy the beauty. Cant take photos inside which is understandable and reapected... well worth going inside. Arrive early. . .make sure its open for viewing . Times displayed out side.

So this is where they are all buried!!. My good lady and I took a stroll to Westminster Abbey on a Friday afternoon. After crossing Parliament Square, weaving through hordes of tourists, we were delighted to find that there was not a long queue outside. £20 each in with a booklet and audio guide. This building has been at the centre of English history for over 1000 years and every footstep is like a time travel. So much has happened here and is here. Walk slowly otherwise you will miss something! One of the best history lessons I ever had.

Where Kings and Queens are made......... The Abbey is impressive in and of itself. Entrance is free with your LONDON PASS (recommended). This is where many ancient/important people are laid to rest. This is also where Prince William and Kate Middleton were married. It is also where all reigning monarchs are crowned in the same chair (seen at the Abbey) since 1066. Very impressive all around. Be sure to light a candle........

Appreciate Stained Glass? This is the place!. The cost was about 20pounds per person. It is an absolutely beautiful church with immaculate grounds but the highlight is without a doubt the stained glass. Take the audio tour to appreciate the history and get all the information. Numerous notable historical figures entombed throughout the church within several alcoves and even the floor. Most of which can easily be missed without the the audio guidance. We found the tour worth the price of admission. But, don't forget to look up to see the most amazing stained glasswork!!

Great history. The audio guide provided as part of the tour entry cost is great explaining many features, don't be afraid though to turn it off and explore yourself from time to time as it covers the main parts of the Abbey only.

Beautiful. You should definitely go hear the Evensong service at 5pm. The church itself is beautiful! It is right next to Big Ben, so several things close to each other. It is located right next to Westminster tube station!

Filled to capacity with historical figures who shaped the world we now live in... a history lesson in stone!. Nowhere is there a burial ground of such significance. These were the movers and shakers of their day that shaped the course of human events right up to today. We are all living the results of their actions and can learn a great deal from their triumphs and mistakes. Plan to spend some time here and coordinate your visit with Parliament (reservations needed) across the street. Try to get a guided tour of the Abbey (Check with local tour groups as this is a very crowded site) and then walk around to find significant figures from the past on your own. Handicap accessible but limited access to nooks along the walls in places. A great place for older children who have studied some of these figures but be respectful as it is an active religious facility.

Breathtaking. Worth the price of admission. Audio tour is very good. You need at least 1 1/2 hours and more would be better. you can attend services (no admission) - check the schedule. We attended evensong at 5pm on Friday. It was quite a treat to hear a choir in Westminster Abbey.

Absolutely UNBELIEVABLE!. This stunning structure is beyond belief. The chapels and burials inside, including kings, queens and even famous authors & poets, are amazing. The pipe organ is the most ornate and incredible I've ever seen. The ladies' chapel is absolutely stunning, especially the ceiling. Take your time through this; you can rush through others but do not rush through this beautiful and historic abbey. You will not believe your eyes.
Amazing the History!. We visited here prior to the year Princess Diana was memorialized here. The history with all of the royals and the previous ceremonies here was amazing

It's Westminster Abbey. You must go. . This is a mind blowing experience in architecture, culture, faith, and the greats of western civilization. In the poet's corner, it feels like all of English Literature is coming to life around you. This is a wonderful experience. If you can afford it, having a private tour guide along makes the event much more meaningful, because there is so much your eyes are absorbing and it's not the same not knowing the relevance. The audio tour sold here goes smoothly but you have to pay close attention in your ears. It's really crowded and difficult to follow along. In any case, go, because there is nothing else like this on earth.
You can not miss. Outside the abbey is a visual spectacle. Inside is a great work of art that also has a large number of tombs of well-known people in the world.

Very interesting. My family visited the Westminster Abbey in July of 2016. Did we enjoy? Yes. Would we recommend it to friends? Yes. We used our London Pass to get free entry. We found it very interesting and informative. There is lots to see and do. It was a much better attraction that I thought it was going to be.If you found my review helpful, please let me know that by clicking the Helpful Button. Thanks.

One of The Highlights of our Trip. How can you describe the feeling one get while standing among the resting places of so many greats in history. All fields are represented here from scientist, to poets to kings and queens.Most of the Abbey is wheelchair accessible with some of the rooms only visible from the main hall. We toured the Abbey and then enjoyed a delicious meal in their Cellarium Cafe, while waiting for the Evensong, an awesome musical presentation by their choir and some Scripture reading. We we near the front of the line which allowed us front row seats to not only hear the choir but to actually see them sing. Such a special treat for all of us. No photography is allowed inside but the outside of the building makes for some amazing photos. Be sure to check their hours as they are limited and can be closed some days for special occasions.We almost missed it because of a special observation.
Lots of history. Great place to visit, lots of history and easy to get around one of the iconic sights to see in London
Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit. It is very interesting inside although no photos allowed. The line to get in was so long but it actually moved quite quickly.

Bigger than life cathedral. Westminster Abbey is as grand as you have read but expensive to enter. We decided not to pay the fees but to come back and attend evensong service. It was fabulous- the procession, the singing the splendor of the Church of England

Not to be missed. We stood in line in the rain for an hour to get into Westminster Abbey and it was most worthy of the wait. It is so full of history and there is so much to hear and learn with the audio tour. It is a must. This abbey is full of character and the architecture is amazing. Do not miss seeing and visiting Westminster Abbey.

History under every footstep. What an amazing piece of living history. If you are any type of history fan you must go here. Imagine tramping all over the finale resting places of folks like Darwin, Newton and Chaucer. With every turn you see people who made incredible contributions to civilization as we know it. The audio tour is very good - follow it and you will get real sense for this place.

Careful, skip the line tickets aren't always skip the line.. We bought "skip the line" tickets but we were told it wasn't so. No worries, the wait was short. The Abby was amazing from the audio tour, the rich history, the beautiful architecture and artifacts. We had a great time and learned more than we expected. Come early to miss the crowds and don't be in a hurry while here.

Beyond amazing. The architecture is stunning both internally and externally. We caught a Friday evening service and it was a real treat to be there. We sat off to the side of the altar right in the area where royalty has gotten married through the years. The choir was in their area and I remember when Princesse Diana and Prince Charles got married and seeing it on TV and now I was there in person. The architecture internally is beyond your wildest imagination of being breathtaking. There are tombs that you walk by and beautiful ornate paintings on the walls, it is just an amazing building to be in.

Wow. If you have an interest in British history this is a must do visit. It's worth paying an extra fiver to have a verger tour as they are very informative and you will get to visit places in the Abbey that you won't have access to otherwise. Loved it .

Absolutely Amazing!!. Our tour guide let us look at the front of Westminster Abby for about 10 min. I knew I wanted to go in there, so on one of our free days, I went by myself. Well worth the 20 pounds to get in. I ate on the Abby Grass, and then took a 2 hour stroll. I couldn't believe how many royalty are buried there, along with so many important people...Charles Dickens, Sir Isaac Newton, Sir Lawrence Olivia, and ironically, Charles Darwin. Sarcophagus's are everywhere. I am amazed anyone would get married with it all around them. I found it so surprising that in the middle of the Abby, is the organ loft and choir area. I have never noticed it during Kate and Will's wedding. I asked if it moves and they said no.
