In fact, if you are in the back half of the abby, there is no way to see the wedding or coronations, so they have to have televisions up to see them. That really surprised me. It is an absolute fascinating place to see.

Definitely worth the trip!. This is a fantastic place to visit if you are in London. The history, the architecture, the classic feel - its wonderful. Walking around the Abbey with the audio tour was very informative and entertaining. Give yourself 1.5 to 2 hours to see and learn all you can. It truly is a great experience. And when you are finished, the Westminster Arms is close by and a nice place to grab a pint.

Worth the ticket price! . My family and I unanimously agreed that this was by far the best attraction we went to in London! The abbey is so unbelievably beautiful! So rich in history! FIY: there is no photography in the abbey! Make sure you do the free audio tour to learn thousands of facts about the abbey!

They have a kids trial. But it takes a lot of time to fill out and you could definitely be there for hours. If your children are super focused, make sure to stop by the help area and ask for the free kids trial guide. We used the audio guide and filled it about half of the trial before we gave up and just enjoyed the history. It was amazing to walk among Kings and Queens. The hallowed walls enclose some of the most important minds and recognize the contributions of other "great" Britains.

Love it. Always enjoy a visit. One of the must do things in London, but no longer free as it takes so much money to maintain. Besides the visit in the cathedral, we went to evensong sung service held at 5:30 weekdays and sat in the choir section. The acoustics are marvelous.
If you like history and architecture, you'll love this place!. Go during the week when the crowds aren't as big. The line can look daunting, but it moves fairly fast. Fascinating place.

This church is WEIRD and awesome. Historical and mostly beautiful, but it is also absolutely covered in tombs and memorials - one on top of the next on top of the next. You get an audio guide included in the price that gives a comprehensive tour. It's the site of the coronations and Royal weddings.

Something NOT to be missed in London!. A very educational tour, breathtaking in its beauty. Be sure to visit the Poet's Corner, where you can see the graves of Charles Dickens, Rudyard Kipling, and many more.

Humbling and awesome inspiring visit. The Abbey is a remarkable structure, tardis-like, as it seems so much larger inside than out.
Gothic, medieval, Elizabethan and Georgian all in one.
The audio tour guide is free, informative, reliable and an imperative.
What splendour, what pomp, what ceremony.
We loved it

Unbelievable History lessons here!. Our whole family really enjoyed the tour. Our kids are 11 and 15. The audio tour is very interesting and helpful in learning about the rich history. No pictures are allowed here.

If you enjoy learning a bit about Monarchy history. Absolutely perfect! I'm not a science fanatic but it was pretty awesome to see where Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton were buried. You might wanna ask where though because theres a ton of tombs. If you're a fan of the TV show Reign then this is a must see! Queen Mary of Scotts is buried here in the room directly across from her rival cousin queen Elizabeth! I won't spoil too much the audio guide will fill you in on every detail just make sure you go here! Theres a line but it won't take longer than 5 maybe 10min at the most.
Must see!. This was one of my favorite sites. It is a stunning building with so much history and so much to see. The included audio tour is excellent. The earlier you visit this site, the better.
History Abounds. Loved checking this place out, having seen it on TV many times, actually being so close provides you with a great insight into how the other half live etc.

Reserve ahead of time to skip long line. We bought our tickets online from the abbey website and walked straight to the door...instead of waiting in the super long line outside. We also attended a Sunday evening service (free) which was a memorable experience and short enough for the kids to appreciate it as well. Amazing history.

Get there early.. I was surprised at how well organized this tour is. It's designed to keep people moving and the narration by Jeremy Irons is very good. Although they left out the reason the Stone of Scone isn't under the Coronation Chair LOL!!!I still can't believe I stood on Laurence Olivier's grave. Micheal Caine should get buried beside him. Man they were great in "Sleuth"!!!
Great audio tour. My husband and I enjoyed the audio tour which is included with the ticket price. Even though it was crowded, we could navigate our way around easily.

Truly a gem and something no one should miss.. I would tour Westminster Abbey every day of our visit if the family would allow it. Such a beautiful building and so much history. Photographs are not allowed and not every area is properly described in the audio tour (and there are countless memorials in Latin or are too faded to read) so I'd suggest buying the best tour guide you can find. Photographs are not allowed - which is completely understandable in a place of worship. So just be prepared.

Take a guide!!!. We went with Timothy Martin and got so much out of it. He took us through every nook and cranny and we learned so much about the Abbey and its surroundings. I don't know about the audio guide, but do something - a walk through on your own cannot possibly cover all the history that is here. Don't forget to look up- the ceiling are magnificent especially in the main/original chamber! Must see.

Incredible experience.... This one one of the places you have to see when in London. It is impossible to describe what to expect when visiting Westminster Abbey (but a lot of people is a good guess). It is a historic and fantastic impressive experience to visit the abbey Even though there was a great que when they opened you don't have to wait too long before you enter. I can't be a bit tricky to get around and see everything when it's thick with people, but you have to expect that...and it's all worth it!

Beautiful Abbey. The Tour of the Abbey is self guided ... but well worth doing. The only complaint I would have is that during peak tourist season the Abbey is quite full and its hard to get through the people to see particular attractions or to spend time admiring or contemplating all that the Abbey offers. It was very crowded while we were there...but still well worth seeing!

Our favorite stop in London. On our very first evening in London, we attended an Even Song Eucharist. As if the cathedral itself weren't beautiful and moving enough, we were lucky enough to be seated right alongside the choir! What an experience to be so close. Later in our visit, we took the audio tour, which was very well done. The best part (for me) was Poet's Corner, where I was moved to tears standing among the graves and/or memorials of the likes of Chaucer, Browning, Tennyson, Kipling, Dickens and so many others. Very powerful.

Very informative and interesting visit. We thoroughly enjoyed our tour of Westminster Abbey. The free commentary was very informative and took you very easily through the Abbey. Nice cafe for a coffee or lunch, and helpful staff made for a very enjoyable couple of hours out of the very hot sun! Would highly recommend.
Wonderful. A great self tour is available via the audio guide. Very crowed inside, but most tourist places in London are too. Loved the history and the grandness.

INTERESTING. We were very surprised by the amount of small Chapels in the Abbey. The audio info was quite good, thought I might get a feel for the many important occasions that have taken place in the Abbey but I didn't really, although to be fair it was rather busy.

Beautiful architecture and artwork. We were using the London Pass during our vacation and Westminster Abbey was one of the attractions included in the pass. This church has beautiful architecture and it is interesting to look at the various tombs and see how long many have been there.
Don't miss this site!. This is a must-do. I do wish the audio tour or pamplets had provided us with a map of where alll the burials were, however. That would be an improvement.

Beautiful inside and out. While I thoroughly enjoyed the visit to Westminster, my 18 year old son said that he felt like it was more of a cemetery than an abbey. I guess I can understand what he is saying because a lot of the audio tour focused on the people that were entombed there. The abbey itself is very beautiful and I loved the historical aspects of it.
Holy ground. Mesmerizing… Spiritual… Awe inspiring… though the line outside was very long… They managed to get us through quickly and organized

Just amazing. As a history buff I can't say enough about this place. It's all the historical novels I've read come to life. Seeing where the great kings and Queens are buried is just amazing. Such history, highly recommend a visit.

It's Westminster Abbey!. Another of our must-see attractions that did not disappoint. The long line to enter moved quickly and gave us time to view and enjoy the stunning exterior. Great recorded self-guided tour within that provides you with a lot of history. Note that the Abbey does not allow photos of the interior (unfortunately), so you'll have to rely on your "mind's eye."
More than expected. I never knew that Westminster was such a historical time capsule for Britain. The number of famous people honored there provides one with a concentrated history lesson.

Better than expected. To be honest, I wasn't expecting to enjoy this as much as I did. There was much more history than I expected and lot's of people buried there that I was familiar with, Kings, Queens, Saints and even Darwin. I would absolutely recommend this for the old history and the new, it is where Prince William and Kate were married for those that would like to see that as well.
A must see for anyone visiting London. An amazing hodgepodge of religion, tombs of actors, writers, politicians, the place where the royalty of the UK is crowned, a beautiful, exciting place.

A must see. Amazing that so much history and tradition can fit under one roof. Breathtakingly beautiful architecture. Pure buy the ticket online and grab a free audiovisual on the way in. No pictures allowed inside.

Drenched with history . A endless parade of famous tombs, beautiful chapels, stunning architecture, and resplendent statuary. I'd been decades ago, and it was better than I remembered. If you're visiting London, this should be at the top of your list of things to see.

A good tip!. This is a tip given to us - line up at about 4.30pm in the afternoon and attend Evensong. You can see the Abbey for free! The service lasts about 30 minutes but you can hear the choir and see inside the Abbey in a quiet reflective atmosphere.

Beautiful!. This is something you have to see when you are here. Knowing this is where they become king and queens here is incredible and awesome to see the way the building is made. There is a lovely store next to it which is also great and well priced

Amazing place. This was my second visit, this time with children. The architecture is amazing, the interior is filled with monuments and tombs everywhere, almost too much. The audio guide is good, but the verger tour (which we did last time) was amazing.

London trip. Trains on time and well ventilated on a very hot day and clean no problems staff also helpful as I don't like traveling on underground very friendly made my journey good from start to finish

Impressive. This was better than I expected. The ticket was pretty pricey-20 pounds. I only went in to see Isaac Newton's tomb but in the process I saw many other tombs of scientists, artists, writers, the throne chair which was disappointingly wooden and plain , etc. But it was still an enriching experience. You could probably spend a whole day inside if you like history. I would still say that 20 pounds is a rip-off though. But the pricey museum tickets are a well known aspect of tourism in London. If you don't have 20 pounds to spare on this visit, I'd advise other activities which you could do for free ☺
Big church. Big church, dead famous people, cue for ever to get in, rip off to get in, can't talk loud when you do, can't do knee slides on the shiney bits and saw no ghosts what so ever

Beautiful and Historic . Learning more about Westminster Abbey and about the monarchy was very fulfilling. This was our second trip to London and I was glad to be able to see this attraction this time around.

An amazing church. What a grand church. If you enjoy reading/listening to history then it's a good place to go and visit. If you are a Christian/Catholic then there is an opportunity to take holy communion when you are there. Mass is at a set time so just check to see what time it starts. Mass/holy communion is open to the public.

Much more than one would think!. We engaged a private guide who started us at Westminster Abbey. I thought, "Oh well, another old church in Europe". But, I was wrong, the history in this building is deep and significant, and with a guide, we learned so much we would have missed on our own, it was more than worth the price of admission!

Historical Abbey and much more (history). A church, a burial ground of the famous, just so much history. Go with a guide! get the full story. The audio headset is just okay. They made changes since my last visit. Hiding the coronation chair but I guess it's for security.

Important tip to seeing the amazing Abbey. The Abbey is worth the visit - its atmosphere, brilliant architecture, and intricate handwork is a must see,So here's the tip...If confronted with a large line to get in try going around the back and entering through the Westminster cafe.We bypassed huge crowds and lines and got straight in - but make sure you have your ticket in advance.

Brilliant for History Buffs. I visited Westminster Abbey back in April with my Mum as part of a birthday treat. I have always wanted to go and it was well worth the wait. We arrived in time to do the 11am Verger tour and Andrew our tour guide was fantastic and it was well worth the extra money to do it as you get to go inside the shrine of St. Edward the confessor. This was a particular highlight for me as this also houses the tomb of Henry V and all you see from outside the shrine are his feet. Others highlights included the Coronation Chair, the Tomb of the Unknown warrior and the plaque marking Anne Neville (Richard III's Wife). I really wanted to see this as I had seen Richard III at Bosworth field before they took him the Leicester.We had lunch in the café, while a bit pricey and slow service it was extremely good and there were not many people.It is one thing to see the Abbey on TV, but it is a whole different experience to actually be there in person and soak up the atmosphere and the history. While on the Tour Andrew told us not to worry about walking over anyone buried in the floor as there were over 3000 people in the floor. The only one which is never walked over is the Unknown Warrior as a mark of respect.I can't wait to go back!

DIssapointing- Very Rude Staff - Not worth the time or money!!!!. We were disappointed that we wasted money and time on this. The highlight is really the exterior the interior is really a graveyard of rich people, politicians and former royalty the church or Abbey is not comparable to others in Europe or locally St. Paul's. It's divided into smaller chapels and and lacks the great expanse of churches like St.Pauls (where Charles and Diana were married). We made the mistake of trying to enter the wrong entrance (where others were being admitted) and encountered a very unpleasant female employee. For anyone who likes to actually take a picture, forget about it here, my daughter went to take one picture and had this crazed deacon screaming at her. Definitely not a good experience and certainly our experience did nothing other than reflect poorly on the Christian faith. Restrooms were disgusting.
Beautiful!. Loved it! There's always a long, long line outside; book online and skip the regular line. Download the app for a self-guided tour.

the coronation church of Britain. Westminster Abbey is the coronation church of Great Britain and also the church where all the Royal weddings are held ; it is near the Parliament and Big Ben; it was built in the year 960 ,rebuilt in the year 1517 in Gothic style and the two towers 69 meters of height were built in the 18 th century ; it can't be missed when visiting London and it leaves you the impression of a perfect,gothic architectural jewelery ;
Beautiful. Lines were not too bad, the Abby is beautiful...many amazing tombs and areas inside...so much history and sites to see...it's almost overwhelming...well worth the time spent.
Very expensive. Sadly this great attraction is very expensive to visit. Great architecture from the outside and a great landmark,

week-end wedding. what a wonderful place and so full of history. Poets Corner not to be missed, however the staff made it for me, helpful and couldn't do enough for my elderly mum as we walked around. I didn't realise how many Kings and Queens of England are buried in the Abbey so a must go for any one interested in history. ..The refectory café serves lovely scones and a great pot of tea..not cheap but well worth it..
Must See. This is a must see if visiting London. We went to the Evensong service on Sunday afternoon and it was very nice.

Beautiful -but pricey. Westminster Abbey was simply lovely. Hard to really put it into words. I would highly recommend it - such beauty and history. Great audio guides. The cost to get in is a bit steep - but worth it. The only disappointing aspect for me was I couldn't take any photos.

History. The one reason I come to London is the history and Wesminster Abbey. I can spend hours and hours marveling over the architecture and the names. The only reason I gave it a low score is the reason you can't take pictures inside. Other than than that a great place for all ages.
A lot of history. Expensive price to go into a church but it is well worth it. Audio guide is good unless you know your history. Beautiful building inside and out.

If you want to see/read all of the memorials and burials, plan to spend some time.. Burials and memorials starting in the 1000's AD. Beautiful architecture and stained glass, kings, queens and notables through history.
Awe inspiring cathedral. Went for Evensong which was very moving and a wonderful experience. Could spend hours here exploring many different areas.

Its an Icon, its West Minister Abbey. Seriously as one of my other reviews stated about the Tower of London, its an Icon, its Westminister Abbey, you have to go here. We had a private tour with our guide that we hired for the day to show us the things to see in London. walking through the niches where famous people are laid to rest in the floor and hall was pretty awesome, we were surprised on how many famous people are laid to rest here.

Awe inspiring. It looks regal from the outside, inside its even more apparent. It is huge, its soaring ceilings, naves and niches are extravagant to say the least. You can almost imagine the coronation of a monarch in there. It was fun going around looking for plaques of important people...scientists, politicians, artists. Worth visiting for sure

Must view. This iconic landmark should be on the must-see list of any London visitor. Steeped in history with remembrances of great people through the ages. If you have a London Pass look for the separate queue on the right side of the entrance to save some time.

Fabulous. Do not miss visiting the Abbey! So much history -past and present. The audio tour is very good but a tour guide is even better. The more history and stories told the better the experience. The architecture alone is amazing.

Best with a vergers tour. We have done tours of many places with just the headset, but I think Westminster Abbey is worth trying to join on a vergers tour. Great insight, with access to areas the public can't. It is a pricey day out and we queued for an hour, even though it was April and not peak tourist season. Wonderful history and worth it if you have the time and money.

The history and the majesty. Don't miss it!!. Westminster Abbey is so big and beautiful and historic and iconic that words don't describe. Yeah, it's a really old church, but it's SO much more. Thousands of years old, site of many historic royal weddings and other celebrations. This is so amazing you will not regret making the time. MUST SEE!!!

The Most Awesome Historical Abbey. I was thrilled to have the opportunity to walk through this beautiful historic abbey. It gave me goosebumps walking through the many niches where famous historical people are laid to rest in the ancient crypts. Was disapointed that photos were not allowed to be taken.

History of western civilization. Only issue was the large groups of studfents all over London whiel we were visiting. It's good that they are getting an opportunity to visit so many historic and interesting places.This was our first visit since the 1980s when there was no fee and one just walked in and around.Our grand kids thought is was very interesting - good response.
My kids were bored, I appreciate the history . My kids are 12 & 7 and within under 10 min, were really bored. The family pass was 45 gpb; wish we would have skipped with the kids.

Fantastic. My family were happy just to look from the outside, I'm so happy I insisted on going in. We spent a few hours using the guided tours, I never knew there were so many interesting things held in its walls.

Life-Changing Experience. Along with the price of admission, spend an extra 8-12 pounds on a walks.com tour guide for Westminster Abbey - if you don't, you will miss out on so many significant people memorialized in the Abbey along with the royal history of the building. Tom, our walks.com tour guide, made the tour the most meaningful experience out of my time in London. This imposing Gothic building has so much historical significance, not only to England, but to the world. Highlights: William Wilberforce and Handel statues, Poet's Corner, graves of Elizabeth I and Henry V, the many adjoining chapels of the Abbey, and the stained glass windows everywhere. Whatever your interests or profession, this place has some of the most important people in history memorialized and/or buried here. It was a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

Interesting History!. Westminster Abbey is probably one of the most visited churches (one million + visitors) in the world. It has been the coronation church since 1066 and is the final resting place of seventeen monarchs. Westminster Abbey was built by Edward the Confessor, and William the Conqueror was crowned in it on Christmas Day 1066. Thousands of people are buried or have their ashes interred here, including kings, queens, statesmen, soldiers, poets, priests, heroes and villains. Some interesting facts: the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales was held here in 1997, the wedding of Prince William and Kate took place here in 2011, Queen Elizabeth II was crowned on King Edward’s Chair, along with every monarch since 1308. The Abbey is a must-see living pageant of British history. Admission Fee - Tube Station: St James's Park

Stunning.. Entrance fee of 17 pounds. You are given a phone for your guided tour. The architecture, statues, woodwork, artwork and stained glass are absolutely beautiful. Imagine yourself walking in the same aisles as the Royal Family. See the Coronation Chair. Afterwards, we shopped at the Abbey Store where I bought a rosary, stained glass and postcards at reasonable prices.

Amazing architecture. Another on the must see list for London, you will marvel at the architecture of the abbey itself and the audio tour was very helpful in guiding us through the various monuments, tombs and memorials

All I Could Think Is Wow. Wow. Now I have 99 more characters to write. THIS PLACE is spectacular and it was super fun to just stand back and stare at. I couldn't help but remember all the previous activities that have taken place here - weddings, funerals, etc.... Amazing.
A must see for London. What an incredible Cathedral. Just exquisite. Between the architecture, the history, and the ambiance I was enthralled.

Westminster wows. Westminster Abbey - I have seen it in movies , TV, and many photos of Royal weddings. The pictures don't do it justice. There are many nooks and crannies with nearly hidden treasures. Grab a map or take a tour or you will miss it! Wren was a genius. Looking up leaves you breathless. Looking down one is in awe of all of the people who changed this world in myriad ways. The organ is a must see. Allow a minimum 2.5 hrs
Westminster Abbey should be visited weekdays. We were at Westminster Abbey on a Sunday. And being a Sunday, the Abbey was busy with services. So not a great day to visit.

A can't miss. Wonderful experience. So much to look at and the history fascinating. Explanations of each artifact obtained with hand held microphones. See what you have seen on news. Very expansive. If you like antiquity and beautiful history you will love your visit here. Incredible

Beautiful. We just attended the mass to experience that Abbey from he local's perspective. A bit disappointed because the close most of the sections of the church, and although there was a choir singing, we couldn't enjoy it to its maximum. But the place is definetly worth visiting.

Of Kings and Queens and Royal Weddings!. Imagine being a young lady about to marry a Prince and all the majesty you'd imagine and you have Westminster Abby! Just the shear immenseness of this historic and architectural wonder is enough to leave you in awe! A visit to the Abby leaves you feeling regal and royal, even without your fascinator! If you are traveling to London, no trip is complete with out saying your prayers in the Abby!

A good cultural afternoon out.. Westminster Abbey provides free maps and audio guides upon entering. This is very useful and there are some staff on hand to provide assistance. The audio guide matches with numbers around the Abbey, so you listen to the audio of the number where you are. Trouble is that the numbers aren't always visible, so I was unsure which number to listen to. The best parts are the grave of the Unknown Warrior, my main site of interest, also there are the graves of Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin, although Darwin's grave, you will walk over and barely notice!!

Marvelous architecture and history. Walk among the tombs of the greatest poets, scientists, and royals in British history. Teens and adults enjoy this more than lower elementary aged kids, but my six year old didn't complain. Budget about two hours for your visit here.
beautiful but expensive. Beautiful if you have a few hours to spend there. It is expensive to view so I wouldn't pay the price for shorter (less than 2.5 or 3 hour visit).

A truly Historic and Iconic location. I was fortunate enough to have a private tour of the Abbey with several friends and family but would recommend this superb venue to everybody. The Abbey is steeped in History and may people are buried there who you would not expect. We spent 2 hours but 2 days would not be long enough. Superb.

Beautiful . A fascinating, informative and moving site. The decor in the venue itself is incredibly beautiful and the architecture is mind blowing. The audio guides are very helpful and informative and I would advise everyone to use them, they help you guide you and you learn so much historical information about the monarchy and great figures of time. A wonderful venue to admire and learn from.
Lots of History. Great place to see and highly recommend the Audio guide. Many famous people are buried here and worth taking your time. Quite busy, but enjoy the scenery.

A fascinating historical site - must see! . It's an amazing place to visit and should be on the top of your list if you're coming to London. Even if you're not overly religious, the historical significance of Westminster Abbey is worth the trip - please make sure you're respectful of their "house rules" though (e.g. silence when the group prayer is conducted each hour, no photos inside the Abbey, not touching artifacts which are marked accordingly etc). I tried to visit the Abbey a couple of weeks ago, but it was closed to sightseers unexpectedly (it is primarily a place of worship after all), so I recommend checking their website before you go to check their opening hours. A word to the wise: skip the queue by purchasing your ticket online - you bypass all queues and go straight through the rope barrier. There are no photos allowed inside the Abbey, so make use of the exterior and the Cloisters for photo opportunities. You can also purchase guidebooks or download professional photos for free from the WA website. I highly recommend paying the extra £5 to attend one of the Verger tours - their insights on the history of the Abbey, the events which take place here, and the artifacts inside are fascinating. Well worth a visit!

A Must See in London. A tour of Westminster Abbey is certainly at the top of the list for sightseeing in London. The history contained within its walls is incredible, including the final resting places of a number of Kings and Queens of England.Entrance to the Abbey is not cheap - for the 5 of us, it came to over $100 dollars US. This did include a handheld electronic device that provided a guided tour. I had wanted to see the tomb of King (Saint) Edward the Confessor, but this was blocked off from foot traffic because of its age. You could peek in to the area and see the resting place of the king who had built the Abbey. This was one of the only sights that I did not purchase tickets for in advance and it was no problem. The line was not long and moved very quickly. If you are going to visit other churches, such as St. Paul's, you may want to consider going online and buying a pass that includes entry to all of them. But, since we were not going elsewhere this worked out just fine.It took us about an hour to go all around, including reading the markers and listening to the guided tour. I'm sure that it may take others longer, depending on how much you want to study and observe. It seemed like one hour was sufficient to see most things and still not be rushed. There is a nice garden off to the side and you can sit for a little while and enjoy the peace and tranquility. There is also a nice, albeit small, gift shop at the end of the tour where you can find books on English history and other assorted mementos. All in all, a very enjoyable stop.

Worth a picture. A beautiful building to take a picture of. The architecture is incredible. However I refuse to pay to get into a place of worship. I know that you can attend a service free of charge but we would not be in the area at those times. St. Peter's in Rome is free to enter and say a prayer. All in all, a beautiful sight to behold

Spectacular Beauty and History. We spent an entire morning viewing and learning about all that is represented in this incredible structure located across from Big Ben and the Parliament buildings. We really appreciated having an audio tour so we could walk through the Abbey at our own pace. Words can hardly describe the beauty of this place from the stained glass windows to the beautiful monuments and the huge pipe organ. We learned so much about England's history in the midst of such an incredible edifice. We would consider this a must-see place to visit for anyone who vacations in London.

Historical place . Only had 1 1/2 hours to tour and skipped the audio tour and used Rick steve's guide to see the highlights since so short of time. Although we could have stayed longer, we all were glad we did it.

Bit disappointing. The last time I visited here seemed a lot more enjoyable. Now, you're no longer allowed to take photographs; and it seems a lot of the abbey is roped off and inaccessible, and what bit you can look round is so cramped & packed with everyone else who's visiting that you don't get the opportunity to really stop & look at anything.I understand that with the amount of visitors they must get each day, they have to get people round as quickly & organised as possible, but it did take some of the enjoyment out of it. We travelled to London with National Express so were able to take advantage of their 2 for 1 offer - if we'd had to pay the full £40 for the 2 of us, I'd have been pretty miffed.That said, the staff were really nice, especially the security guards.

AMAZING!!. Wow! What an incredible piece of architecture packed full of English history and heritage. Admission was free with our London Pass. Audio guide is available for a price. Well structured route around the Abbey enabled us to see everything and largely prevented people bumping into each other as everyone was going in the same direction. Suitable for buggies but young children might get bored. Make sure to look up and down as well as around you so you don't miss anything! Amazing number of recognisable names on the many tombstones underfoot. On site guides were patient and informative. There are toilets available and a tea room. The shop sells the usual souvenirs but also has a more upmarket and tasteful section with a lovely selection of jewellery, scarves and religious ornaments. Well worth a visit as you really get a sense of connecting with history.

Great Visit. We enjoyed our visit to Westminster Abbey even though we had been there many years ago. We had the audio set which was most helpful and gave us very good information as we moved along. It was also great reading and hearing of historical people buried underfoot and in the walls of the abbey. I was pleased that we could really visit the whole part of the abbey and on departing the Abbey we could see the Coronation chair which has been used for all the Coronations. It looks a bit worn but the History of it is amazing. There is a shop onsite if you require souvenirs

Architectural Narrative of English History. Founded in the 11th century by Edward the Confessor, rebuilt under Henry III, the nave tallest Gothic Nave in England completed 1376, the Lady Chapel built by Henry VII from 1456-1509, with the twin towers completed in 1745, Westminster Abbey is the architectural narrative of the history of England.Do not miss St. Edward's Chapel, the Lady Chapel, the Poet's Corner, the Cloisters, the Chapter House, the Royal Tombs - so much more. Try to attend an evensong service to experience the the glory of music in the Abbey. There are Organ Concerts on Sunday afternoon.Many years ago when we visited with our son, he had a memorable time following the children's trail brochure.

An essential London visit . Brilliant visit. I booked my tickets in advance which is a very good idea, there was a long line for tickets on the day. Despite the fact there were hundreds and hundreds of people around me I found the Abbey to be a peaceful and spiritual place. I bought a guide and would recommend it to those interested in knowing what they're looking at. I spoke to a couple of members of staff and they were keen to answer my questions and happy to chat which made me feel very welcome. Parts of the Abbey made me emotional but I always found space to take a minute of contemplation when I needed it. As a recreational historian I enjoyed feeling the weight of history around me. It was also a nice surprise to stumble upon the oldest door in Britain, I wasn't excepting that and it was fun to know even an incredibly popular, well known and famous place like Westminster Abbey can hold unexpected surprises and secrets. Just a tiny complaint, the toilets were horrendous, dirty and no toilet paper, but the Abbey was so wonderful it didn't matter to me and I'm still giving my visit 5 stars.

Awe inspiring . Beautiful and eerie at the same time. It's hard to grasp that you are walking through so much history. I have been once when I was younger. I enjoyed explaining all the history to my children this time around.
English History at its Best. A wonderful visit although I did find the audio tour not easy to follow, a shame because much time wasted by navigating and not drinking it in
Great history . This place is very amazing and full of rich history. It is quite expensive if I remember about 35 pounds or about 50 us dollar. The only bad thing is there is no photography allowed.

A piece of history. The place is simply amazing. If you love history and legends, this is the place. A piece of England's greatest past. You find (among many others) the tumbs of Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton. Long entrance queues (at least 40 minutes), you can cut the queue if you book ticket in advance. Entrance cost 20 pounds for an adult. The visit takes at least 1 hr (2 hr is more realistic). Free audio guides available just after entering.

A cultural, religious, historical...and emotional experience. By far our favorite thing that we saw in London...indescribably breathtaking. Such reverence and awe. So much history, religion, culture packed into this beautiful structure. DEFINITELY partake of the free audio tour -- you will miss many details and facts if you don't (and listening to Jeremy Iron's voice just lends to the experience). If I am ever in London again, I will probably repeat this tour -- it is simply fantastic and a must see.

Westminster cemetery. An amazing church with a lot of history. think it's a little expensive for a family visit.If you're here for several days it might be worth seeing but it wouldn't be top of the list of things to see in London. Might be better to visit when they're having an organ concert. Audio guy mostly talks about all the people that are buried there.
Bit underwhelming but the history makes it a must see. Standing where so much history including recent events have taken place is interesting. The building itself is a bit underwhelming.

A privileged visit to the Abbey. A few years ago we visited Westminster Abbey, taking a verger led guided tour which took us to areas within the Abbey that most regular paying guests could go to. This time we were privileged guests at a commemorative and thanksgiving service to mark ANZAC Day, a very special day in Australia for us. Tickets for this event are available by written application to the Australian High Commission in London, apply online.Being present for this event on such a historical day and in a historical building was a day we will not forget, the sounds of the organ and choir singing, the military bugles resonating through the Abbey, the procession of royalty, religious clergy and other dignitaries, a time honoured tradition is etched in my mind. The ANZAC Day service was incredibly moving, Westminster Abbey was a gracious host.

Beautiful.....History of England. Westminster Abbey, formally titled the Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster, is a large, mainly Gothic abbey church in the City of Westminster, London, located just to the west of the Palace of Westminster. It is one of the most notable religious buildings in the United Kingdom and has been the traditional place of coronation and burial site for English and, later, British monarchs. Between 1540 and 1556 the abbey had the status of a cathedral. Since 1560, however, the building is no longer an abbey nor a cathedral, having instead the status of a Church of England "Royal Peculiar"—a church responsible directly to the sovereign. The building itself is the original abbey church.

Free and gorgeous for Sunday evensong.. A tour would have been great but we could only go on Sunday, so we went to evensong, an hour long service. Read your tour book ahead. We sat in Poet's Corner and saw the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Although more than 3000 people are buried there, many of the statues are tributes, kind of like a walk of fame!

Very interesting!. There is so much history within those walls. The cathedral was bigger and granderthan I ever imagined. You could be there for a week and not get to see everything. We took the self guided tour and it was a little difficult to follow because some of the rooms were not clearly marked but the info on the audio players was interesting nonetheless. It made me wish I would have learned a little more about British history.
Beautiful!. Impressive! So much history. A must see! So easy to get to from the metro! We didn't realize that so many sites were all in easy walking distance.
Beautiful!. Impressive! So much history. A must see! So easy to get to from the metro! We didn't realize that so many sites were all in easy walking distance.

Free organ recitals on Sundays. We had visited the Abbey in 2014 and did the verger tour which was excellent. I called from Ohio before we left to get our names on the verger tour list. It was an additional 5 pounds plus entrance fee. This time we returned to attend the 5:45 free organ recital on Sunday. The church was full so go early to stayed in line to get into the church. What a treat!!

Breathtaking. Once again got right in with the London Pass. The headset is very informative. Allow time for the Eucharist at 12:30 P.M. if you can. The Abbey closes by 3:30 P.M. so budget your time accordingly. You need at least 2 hours to do it all justice.
Very beautiful and amazing building. The Abbey was quite busy when we visited however, we were able to take our time to truly take in the beauty and enormity of this magnificent building.

An incredible sight to see and experience. I had pre-purchased tickets for Westminster Abbey. We visited and enjoyed the audio tour. Westminster Abbey is really something to see. Allow yourself at least 90 minutes to get the most from your visit. There are places to sit at some of the audio tour stops. Buy tickets ahead of time online to save a lot of time in a queue!
Wedding. Who would want to miss to see this place when you are in London. This is the place for the royal weddings and Westminster Abbey is fit for these kind of weddings.
Arrive early before the crowds. Amazing cathedral. Walked through out the building, stopping to see the different naves. Truly spectacular.
Very interesting history lesson. This abbey is the arguably the most historic place in London and a must see. Audio guide essential to work your way around the tombs of the Kings of England.

Dark historical landmark. The Abbey is definitely a must see for first time visit to London.It has lot of history but it feels like you are walking into a graveyard instead of a place of worship ,plus it is dark inside.There was some construction when we went ,so that also made place more dark.

Amazing place.. This place has so much history in it and it's just amazing. All I have to say is visit and enjoy, it's centuries of history inside. The cloisters are nice too but they're not open all the time.

Not my favorite but its a must do for a first time visit.. It was expensive but how can you go to London and not visit? The audio tour was Ok, a little dry. I"m glad we did it but it was not my favorite. The line looks long but moves fast. There is someone who will tell you how long it should take which was nice to know. I might have skipped it had I not asked. It looked huge but they told me 20 minutes and it was true. I think the security check on bags it what holds everything up. so go enjoy just don't expect too much. Good not great.

Beautiful church service. No photos allowed during church service but this was a very lovely experience. We listened to the choir and organ during evensong It was very, very beautiful. By chance we were there to see eight young boys who had finished the choir school receive accolades from their choir master.

Wonderful church service.. We came early for the church service and enjoyed the peaceful surroundings and people watching, everybody was so dressed up who had been invited. We just came for the service and therefore didn't pay to go in, but we were part of service and made welcome. London can be a constant drain on your money, and this was a good use of time for a lovely experience with out being charged for. We will come back.

The history in this church is amazing.. Walking into Westminster Abbey is like stepping back in time. It's as if the walls really do talk. There is so much history in the building and so much to see. But alas, no snapping pictures which is really annoying.

Very overcrowded, the worst £20 I've ever spent. On previous trips to London I'd resisted the urge to visit Westminster Abbey as the price seems extortionate (£20 each !), especially considering the museums and gallery's are free....+ after all this is a church.... the Catholic Westminster Cathedral is (as all churches should be ) free to enter. I took the plunge, parted with my £20, and spent the next half hour in a crush of tourists navigating what has become an overcrowded, overpriced mausoleum. Yes there are a lot of famous kings, queens and others buried here, but it's hard to appreciate when you're amongst a mob of fellow humans trying (and failing) to get their money's worth.The only way I'll be back is if I become so special I end up being buried there. At least then I'd get in for free.
lots of history. Make sure you visit this sight, and give yourself some time.Take the audio tour, very insightful on the history of England

Evensong. If you want to worship at Westminster Abbey, Evensong is the best way. Line up at the West door beginning at about 445 pm M-Sat. It lasts about 45 minutes. Beautiful service. But it's not a good way to tour the church, it is a worship service. I saw them turn people away who made it clear they were just hoping for a free peek inside.

Packed with history. Visited Westminster Abbey with my 18 year daughter who enjoyed it as much as me. A short time was spent waiting in the queue before we were able to enter. We chose to use the audio tour which is narrated by Jeremy Irons. Favourite area was the Lady's Chapel. Allow plenty of time to visit as you could easily take half a day to see it fully.
Very Expensive!. Terrific to view if you can go when it is crowd free before the tour groups arrive. Very expensive though.

Wonderful . What a beautiful place to be able to walk through history! The kids had a little trouble understanding what they were seeing. But, for me it was wonderful. I only wish they didn't prohibit taking pictures as Maseru of a place like that is simply insufficient.

Gorgeous! Don't miss it!. Westminster Abbey was included in our London Pass (which I highly encourage purchasing). But, I highly recommend touring the Abbey. You'll need about 1-2 hours to truly hit all the highlights. We had an amazing time.
Very historic. A very historic experience. Would highly recommend lots to see and very enjoyable. One of the best historic sites to visit.
The Abbey was Awesome. That was great! I really enjoyed the place and the audio tour was awesome. It would have been perfect if it were less expensive.

Breathtaking and historic. We took an audio tour of this beautiful abbey. It was fantastic. I especially enjoyed the history behind monarchs buried there. My favorite spot was the poet's corner. I highly recommend this.

Stunning history and visual marvels on an easy self paced tour. Three of us took a self paced tour of Westminster Abbey. The line to get in was relatively short [5 mins] and it cost around 40 pounds. Even at the check in, you get a sense of the size and majesty of the architecture. There is a really superb narrated audio guide that provides wonderful details and even small videos to enhance your visit. There's no rush on the tour although in places, such as in the side chapels, you need to keep moving as the entrances and exits are narrow and single file. There is no photography allowed until you exit and head to the cloisters. It's food for thought as you try to piece together the timeline and places in history of the people who lay at rest here. At 12.30pm each day there is a short service that everyone is welcome to attend. The cloisters and chapter house complete a superb tour. Highly recommended and in a great part of London with Big Ben and the House of Parliament so close by.

Better than excellent. Wonderful place be it crowded...no surprises there. I went here on my own and was blown away by the architecture and the culture of this wonderful place. I could come here over and over again as its so spectacular. It is not difficult to get too by public transport and a must see for everyone. There is a little cafe and it food is very nice and a bit expensive but its bustling with the atmosphere of the whole place. Very educational and a great joy to visit....what are you all waiting for....go and see it......

Just one more place for non-UK tourist. This is just one more place for a non-UK tourist - just opposite to the House of Parliaments and the Big Ben. Provided one gets to see Big Ben, London Eye and House of Parliaments, this is just another place to tick on the tourist's list.

Amazing building. The audio tour is new since my last visit to London. It is great. You can travel threw the Abbey at your own pace and still receive fantastic information on what you are seeing. Leave yourself 2 - 2 1/2 hours to see it all.
Go on Sunday during Mass. Don't do a tour just go during a mass and you can walk around and see the place brought to life. I ain't really a church person but I feel it's a beautiful place a must see.

Very educational for children. We spent at least a couple of hours at Westminster Abbey today, completing the activity trail for children. The children were very interested in finding out all the information and the staff at hand was very friendly and helpful and easily engaged with us. The only drawback was the fact that it was very busy and lots of people around visiting so it was not easy to navigate our way around, always keeping an eye out not to lose the children. The café is a great addition so that we could have lunch close by, very easy and friendly service with good options for children as well.

Classic London tour. This is another great historic tour in London. Anyone fascinated with British history must tour the Abbey. We got there at 9:30 when it opened & the line was constantly moving. They do a great job getting people inside quickly. We splurged for the guided tour instead of the audio tour & happy with that decision. He was able to get us past the crowd for upfront viewing of various highlights. You can wonder on your own after the tour. This is one of my favorite touring places when in London.

Absolutely Stunning. This was my first visit to an Abby and was blown away by its stunning architecture, size, history, the audio hand set was included which added to the experience the narrative was informative and a must to take in what this Abby has gone through over the years. Whilst visiting London this was my my #1 place to visit. We visited late in the afternoon it wasn't to busy.

For those who are Royalists. Visiting the Abbey takes about 1.5-2 hours. Best to go right at the opening before lines start to form. Again using the London Pass provides the best value. Queen Elizabeth II was coronated here and William and Kate got married here. There are many prominent figures from British History who are burred here. Its right across the street from Parliament so I would visit the two together.

just awsome. enjoyed my visit, except they wont let you take pictures of the inner part of the church. thats a letdown, because it is full of picture moments it is very expensive. best buy london pass if you plan to visit. your visit might last several hours.

Beautiful Abbey. This was amazing! The history within this Abbey is second to none. We all enjoyed the architecture, history and found the digital commentary to be very informative. This is my second visit to the Abbey and I would definitely return if I had the chance.

So Beautiful and Historic. London Pass allowed us to bypass long lines to enter this beautiful church, monastery, and resting place of many famous Brits. Everything you've heard, read and more. Use the audio guide -- it enhances the experience immensely.
Architecture and History. If you are into Architecture and/or History, this place is brilliant. Lot of tombs as well. Pick up the audio guide if you want to learn more.

Beautiful Mass . The visit to Westminster Abbey is at 20 pounds but on Sunday there is no visiting but mass. We participated at the service at 11.15 and listened to a beautiful ceremony and choires. To be recommended.

Stunning piece of Architecture. Many historic churches throughout Europe, this one ranks near the top of the list.The architecture, statues, touch of gothic, paintings and appointments in this church were awe inspiring, worth the visit!

beautiful place. It's really pretty inside, and all the walls and the rooms are very ornate and detailed.they also dont let visitors take photos inside, so people can really apprecizte the beauty of the place, instead of snapping selfies. that being said, there are still people who sneak photos.

This highlight is a must. Great historical place, resting place of many important personalities, site of British most important ceremonials. Not everybody is able to process this many historical information tho. And come on, 20 GBP for the admission to the church? 17 GBP for students is ridiculous.

Beautiful, but way too crowded. I was really excited to finally get to the inside Westminster, but I didn't get to enjoy it as much as I would have liked. The entire place was filled wall to wall with people and we had to skip parts because we physically couldn't squeeze into the area. However, the writer in me was very excited to see Poet's corner and be among some of the greats! It would just be nice, if they limited the amount of people inside the Abbey at a time so that everyone can really marvel and enjoy the beauty.

Incredible. Amazing history and architecture. We arrived early as per recommendations and lined up to get in. If we had have arrived shortly after opening there wouldn't have been any need to wait in line. Audio tour was very informative. Leave your self lots of time. It can get quite crowded and has limited hours.

tham river near BIG BELL. I like to share my great time to visit big bell and west minter .The place i has been that so nice and wonderful for travelling .West minter was so great beautiful bluiding specailly The BIG BELL HALL. YOU SHOULD GO THERE some day.
Amazing place to visit. One of the best things to see in London. The history in this place is mind boggling. I will go back again. Jeremy Irons narrates the audio guide and it's very well done.

Shocked!. I was part of a group from London Walks. Most of the visit was excellent, with information eagerly given by a competent and professional guide.Our expert was in mid flow at one particular stop, when along comes verger Brett demanding that we move along and make way for his party. When asked by our guide where we move to, he wasn't bothered!!He was arrogant, ignorant and a disgrace to the Abbey. It shocks me as an ex sidesman, that he was representing a Christian institute. What makes it worse was that our party included many foreign visitors... goodness knows what they must have thought of this representative. We had all paid our money for the visit, but perhaps some people more important than others....

So much to see all around you. I'm still trying to sort out how millions of visitors walk over gravestones and yet they have not been eroded by foot traffic.My head was constantly on a swivel looking around me at the different names of people who have been buried at Westminster Abbey. I found Poet's Corner really intriguing. Not to mention the fact that Prince William and Kate Middleton got married in essentially a mausoleum. Still, it's amazing.

Missed the tour but attended am organ recital.. They have an organ recital at 17:45 every Sunday. It is free. And you can also stay after that for the evening service. That is free also. The down side is that you are not allowed to take pictures. It's worth going for the experience.
So much history.. Westminster Abbey is steeped in history and seeing just how many famous people are buried here is amazing. It is a beautiful building and a wonderful place to visit.

Wonderful Place to Visit. I know many people have reviewed Westminster Abbey and told how beautiful it is and interesting to see the various memorials, tombs and the church itself.What I would like to add is that you can buy tickets directly from the Westminster Abbey website up to 30 days from your visit. We did this and when you have your ticket printed with you, you skip every line and go directly inside. It saved us a LOT of valuable time. The Abbey itself is extremely crowded and the audio guide really is a must if you don't take a guided tour. You can download a free Westminster Abbey app on your phone that has the guide as well as a lot of additional information. This also saves you from having to stand in line. Be sure to remember your ear buds.

How do you describe a monument to all that is good in Britain?. Probably the biggest mistake a person can make in touring Westminster is not allowing enough time. Get a guide or at least the audio tour and plan on spending a long time after the tour is over. The building itself is quite historic going back to William the Conqueror. Be sure and tour the Abbey's grounds for a change. HIstory will come alive for you. I particularly enjoyed Elizabeth I's chapel where she and her sisters are buried. Visit the area where Elizabeth II's coronation and Charles and Diana's wedding took place. Be sure and note the monuments to the various soldiers and sailors. Many many notables are buried here. I would suggest you get a listing of them from online and visit the tombs of those you are most interested in. No food, and the Abbey is only moderately handicapped accessible. Be sure and schedule a time to visit when a servie will be heard.

Amazing but very crowded. On the day we had planned to visit we arrived right after lunch only to find that the Abbey was closing early (not the time that was published in our city pass book). The line that day of people waiting to get in was around the block. We decided to go first thing in the morning and arrived 45 minutes before the opening time. There was already about 100 people in line. There is a little cafe kiosk that served coffee and snacks on the corner of the Abbey. We got coffees and a pastry to share. We left our apartment very early because of rush hour on the tube (very busy at this time and took longer than we expected). We waited a little over an hour to get in. The inside is very dark and takes a little while to get used to. We got our audio guides (recommended), and enjoyed the self guided tour. It is just amazing, all the history and beautiful artifacts. The ceilings were incredible. It got extremely crowded which made it hard to stop and take a closer look. All in all it was very beautiful and not to be missed. The bathrooms are out on the side of the back courtyard, use them if you have to because it is hard to find restrooms when you leave.
My favourite Place in London. I loved everything about Westminster Abbey. It is my favourite place in London. It was the third time I had been there and will definitely go again.

So Much To Say/See. How to describe this extraordinary place? Depending upon your religious views you could experience a host of different emotions as you walk through. But it isn't entirely about religion/ it's also reverence for the people who shaped British history, not to mention some American poets. Then talk about the architecture!! Astounding as well as the artisanship of those who created the tombs and memorials!Bottom line is a visit to London would not be complete without touring this magnificent place.About £25 each to get in but worth it.

Simply amazing!. Such a beautiful place full of amazing history. The staff was helpful and the personal recording guide was great. Be prepared to spend several hours taking in all that is here. If you have the time I recommend staying for the Evensong service, unbelievable experience.

Wow!!!. The history here is just fantastic!! We did the guided tour, and it was so well worth it! One tip is to buy tickets ahead of time, as you can go to the front of the line (it's a new policy since March). So much to see here!

Must-see!. A must-see in London! Worth a trip for architectural gurus, history fanatics, and tourists in general. It is home to not just coronations and royal weddings, but tombs of some of the most famous names such as Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, Edward the Confessor, Elizabeth I, the Unknown Warrior, and the like. It's a lot bigger than it looks, so give yourself plenty of time to explore. There is an option for a self-guided tour in multiple languages. If you want to skip the line altogether, it may be in your best interest to get a personal guide. Too bad they won't let you take pictures inside, but that's because they don't want it to become too "touristy"... Umm, too late!

Layers of histroy and Beautiful Sights. Give yourself time to enjoy this attraction with the audio guide. There were so many tombs, headstones, memorials that pretty soon they all look alike--if you can read the old English in the first place. Don't miss the Author's Corner, the tea shop or the Coronation Seat.
The Abbey. the abbey is stunning, very big, I stayed at least two hours and could have spent more time. it is a must to do for anyone visiting London

A really interesting church and indoor cemetary. This is a great historic church and the main draw is that it's basically an indoor cemetery. There are lots of famous people and kings and queens buried there. Darwin, Sir Issac Newton, and Shakespeare are all there among others.
Absolutely beautiful Abbey. A wonderful abbey with as much history and beauty as you will find in the UK. It really was remarkable.

Historically stunning!. We toured on a rainy morning and were stunned by the abbey's history. It's a crowded place, so be patient. Either enlist a tour guide or use a handheld audioguide to gain as much knowledge as possible. Don't miss the Lady Chapel.

Westminster Abbey. You could spend hours touring this beautiful structure. Even if you are not a history buff the architecture will astonish and amaze you when you think it was started so long ago. The history of the people entombed there is not to be missed!
Awe struck. I simply didn't know how awe struck this visit would make me. Walking through all the history and seeing Poet's Corner was also impactful. Nice Jeremy Irons narration.

Important historical church. Visiting this church is an essential part of a trip to London. As a Catholic, it is heartbreaking to hear how King Henry VIII killed the Benedictine monks and Catholics whose church it used to be. Catholicism was only made legal again in England in the 1850's. There is so much important British history here. If you are a Roman Catholic, there is Westminister Catholic Cathedral nearby where you can attend mass.

Stunning!. Having visited St. Paul's Cathedral a few days before, I wasn't expecting it to be outdone by Westminster, but it was. Westminster Abbey is the most stunningly beautiful church I've ever visited. It would be worth visiting for the beauty itself, but with all of the historical figures buried and/or memorialized there, it is without compare to any place else. It was my favorite place in our visit to London.
Fascinating and emotional. We rarely like top tourist destinations, but Westminster Abbey was a highlight of our trip to London--worth every dime and every minute in line.

Quintessential London. A must see! It is a living church but also a cemetery of the who's who of British history, even well known Brits of today. Be sure to get the audio guide. You may not "do" it all in one visit but a good 1-2 hours will leave a lasting impression. Included in London Pass but not fast track.

Good but pricey!. I understand that it costs a fortune to run but £20 per adult is rather steep.I also asked a question about the crib in the room for Elizabeth and Mary and was met with a blank stare from one of the employees who then told me that the above were buried in there and walked away.It's a beautiful church and I enjoyed my visit
Impressive. I was really impressed by the Westminster Abbey. All its history and facts are shown on it and a little bit of it ia in the audio guide provided.

Architecture and connect with historical figures. At first, 20 pounds to get in seemed a little steep. However, the price of admission includes the audio guide, so the value is there. No photos inside the Abbey, which is a shame. The architecture of the Abbey is amazing, dating back to William the Conqueror. The Abbey tour follows one direction, so all you do is follow the map and audio tour. You get to see the burial tombs of a number of past monarchs, scientist, poets and literary figures. You also see the coronation chair and learn more about the process.

Stunning!!!. My mom works next to the Abbey 44 years ago so this was definitely a MUST VISIT!!! The gothic architecture, the sculptures, the murals, just everything about it spoke volumes into the history of the Abbey. This will always be a stop ever time we come to London
Incredible. So beautiful and worth the visit. I recommend doing it with a tour guide. You get so much more out of it to really understand the history of this church.

Do not miss a chance to take this tour; well worth the wait.. The audio tour is excellent, but the crowds can make it a little difficult to move about. The history of this building is amazing and the statutes, stained glass, etc. is breathtaking. We were able to take communion at the daily 1230 service, which was almost mystical in such majestic surroundings.
Crazy. The biggest weirdest and craziest church you will ever see -- plan ahead and have a good guide at your disposal -- it is an amazing building
So glad we went. My wife and I visited Westminster Abbey on our trip. The building has amazing detail and we took some of best pictures there. They do not let you take pictures inside...FYI.
Lovely building!. "Hands down, best abbey I've ever seen!" (Also this is a great place for fans of Friends to visit!!)
Organ recital in beautiful surroundings . We didn't take a tour of the abbey but got in on Sunday afternoon for an organ recital at 5:45. It was stunning to hear the organ in this beautiful location.

Beautiful!. Westminster Abbey is one of the most beautiful churches I have been in, rivaling the Notre Dame Cathedral itself. The amount of information and things to see in here requires at least 2-3 hours of time to make it through all of it. Make sure you get an audio guide and spend some time in and around all of the small niches that have effigies in them. My only lament is that you are not allowed to photograph inside the abbey itself. I understand the reasoning as to why, it's just a bummer!

Old and amazing. Westminster Abbey is a 800 years old church and is amazing. So much history! This church has seen coronations, royal weddings; a lot of monarchs are buried there. A lot of ordinary people, too, went through its doors over those 800 years. To be able to visit such a place it is a privilege. It is really special!Some evenings there is a mass and evensong with the choir singing - free entrance. If you want be able to walk around to visit, get tickets online and go during the day.
Beautiful. Westminster Abbey was so beautiful to see. There are a lot of things that are just fascinating to see.

World-famous abbey. This is a must see when in London. I recommend visiting early in the morning and/or during the week to avoid queues. The audio-guide is very informative and ensures an interesting tour.
Breathtaking. It's hard to be,i.e. E you're actually standing in the Abbey, where coronations and other royal events are held. Unbelievably, there's so much to see!
Beautiful building. Visited the Abbey on a recent trip to London and a stunning place to spend time to take in the majestic building and the history surrounding it and we'll worth a visit

Wow...beautiful!. I'm not religious but I seem to like to step inside these old cathedral's to take in the History. Westminster abbey was no let down. I would definitely encourage you to take your time and read as much as you can while inside. the inscriptions will give you a history lesson better then you will find in any good book!

Majestic, holy and historic Abbey. This is an absolute must for any visitor to London. The audio tour guided us around this beautiful abbey wonderfully well. We were in awe of the immense historical and religious importance of this exquisite building. A very sacred but eminently interesting and educational and profound experience for all. Our 12 and 9yo sons got so much out of it too. I really think it "pips" St. Paul's for "wow". A must see and a 2-3 hour timeframe makes it accessible for most schedules.

Visit made excellent by Verger Sheward tour. The Abbey founded in 960, is beautiful by itself but take the guided tour. We had a great Verger Benjamin Sheward that showed us through the Abbey and he was able to take us places that the general self guided tours can't go. He had such a great wit and all the little insights that truly made this an enjoyable visit on a rainy day. The mausoleum for some of the great kings and also infamously knighted people are very interesting. To think of all this history is almost overwhelming. They only offer two private tours per day with less than 20 people, so register at the Abbey early. Within the Abbey, Kings, Queens, poets, entertainers all buried within these walls. It is considered the people's church and a big tourists attraction.

Finally got in to see everything!!. Unlike three years ago (when I visited last, and this place had the wrong closing times on their signs), I actually got in and was able to tour with my daughter, who teaches English literature at the high school level. It was worth it to me to see how much joy she derived from visiting the author/poets' area, and the folks buried there. So many small rooms, nooks, and crannies to explore and check out. Truly enjoyed our time here!

From outside beatiful but the prices!!!. We went to London for a vaccation. Westminster Abbey was something we wanted to see. But after finding out that the entrance would cost us 40 Pounds we where shocked... How can you charge 20 Pounds for an adult? Sorry but my joy of this place ended with the price....Here in Germany you can get in churches for free. If you like to support the church you can donate something. For me the nicer and better way...

Westminster Abbey. Always love visiting this beautiful Abbey -- it hasn't changed over the many times we've visited. Would love to attend a service here! Glad we had a chance to visit again. We bought a CD of hymns so we are reminded of this lovely place each time we listen to the music. There is an entrance fee, but it includes a self guided, easy-to-use headset so it was easy to browse at leisure in all the areas.

The so called poor relation . Simply just Stunning Sculpture Sculpture at its Imperial BestThe memorials crammed into every tiny nook is a stark reminder of the vast Imperial strength of the London Empire - Manchester and Liverpool have the Industrial Heritage London had the Empire Heritage and nowhere is it more obvious than in Westminster Abbey Unlike other Cathedral's which are designed to dwarf the visitor Westminster for all its size is an intimate spiritual and patriotic experience steeped in History with an underlying sense of solemnity, sorrow and remembrance.

Amazing visit. We brought our teenage children to the Abbey. It is incredible. Within its walls time almost stops. Great place to learn about history of England and the contribution this country had made to the world. The audio guides were nice. A good advice was given to is by an employee. Come around 11.30 - they have fewer visitors , because many people move towards Buckingham Palace. We followed the advice and waited only 25 min on a busy Saturday.

Very enjoyable visit with a great guide from Family Twist. The history of the Abbey is fascinating and I'd recommend reading about it and doing a bit of research in advance to enjoy it even more. So much to see, to learn and to appreciate. There is something for everyone, no matter the age. Our guide Kim was very knowledgeable and helped us identify special items for our child. She had a "scavenger hunt like" booklet for our child to fill out as we went along the visit.

Great visit. Visited on the 2nd of July. We booked our tickets online; booking online means you can fast track according to the site. Wrong! You still need to join the queue and wait with everyone else. Took 45 minutes to get in. Once in you get a free audio guide. Don't download the app as suggested online - no phones in the abbey. Although it was busy you still got to see everything including poets corner and the tombs of Mary, Queen of Scots and Elizabeth I. I really wanted to see Mary's tomb and wasn't disappointed.I only give a 3 out of 5 because you misrepresented online booking and the cost. I didn't mind paying because I wanted to visit but it sits uneasy with me paying to get into a place of worship.Will I come back? Probably not, once you've seen it why bother?

Must see for important part of our history . Altho we felt this was pricey it was well worth the cost. The ticket system was dreadfully slow. We downloaded guide tour on app on phone which was excellent.

Amazing History Here!. Really enjoyed our visit here--did the audio tour and after being greeted by a very friendly member of the clergy there on staff I have to say that it was 'more' than expected. Don't miss it and don't worry if its crowded--its a big place. We did go early to avoid the lines as much as possible.

Staff need training and development in customer service!!. Felt not at ease by discourteous staff, nasty body language!! Went in to pray and reflect , but they appeared to treat us like non wanted non paying guests.

Great but too expensive. Me and my partner went here as we had never gone before. I think it is something that everyone should do at least once. But it is way too expensive. It is our national church and should be free to everyone, given it holds national monuments such as the tomb of the unknown warrior and previous kings and queens. Will not go again unless they change the price.

Beautiful abbey full of history. I absolutely love Westminster Abbey. It is full of historical burial grounds and memorials, and you choose to use a handheld audio guide or walking tour to explain the stories behind the more significant monuments. The architecture is absolutely stunning, and it is amazing to think of all of the historical events that occurred here. Be sure to visit the cafe off of the cloisters. It was a hidden gem with wonderful meals.

Very Beautiful Gothic Church. This is a large church in the City of Westminster, London, located near the Big Ben and the House of Parliement. It is one of the most notable religious buildings in United Kingdom and has been the traditional place of coronation and burial site for English and the British monarchs. The place is very beautiful with a lot of history in it.

Overwhelming experience. Visited with 2 young kids and was absolutely overwhelmed with the history and beauty contained in the building. There is an audio tour that was quite informative and easy to follow. There are many people available to answer questions. Also there are moments of peace each hour which also help remind you of your surroundings despite the tourists.

Evensong. I attended Evensong service which is held on weekdays evenings, 5pm. It is a great experience, especially hearing the choir. You can check their website for service timings. There is no entrance fee required but also no audio guides to provide information about the place.Plan to visit the abbey if you are in London. However, personally feel some churches in France and Italy are more impressive in architecture.

Pricey, but we're glad we went.. I was shocked that the price to get in for a family of 3 was 40 GBP. Once I got over the sticker shock, I enjoyed the visit. We got the audio guides and felt that they significantly added to our enjoyment of the Abbey. Some areas can get a bit crowded, but overall the flow seemed to work well. I was disappointed that I couldn't take any pictures, but sometimes it's nice to just enjoy looking only with your eyes instead of through the lens of a camera.

Worth the £20 entry fee. I've never been inside Westminster Abbey. This trip we hesitated at the ticket price, but went in anyway. I'm glad we did, it's worth it. A must for art, history and literary buffs – it's so much more than 'just' another cathedral. Avoid the restaurant though, horribly overpriced, minuscule portions and bad service.

There is only one word - Breathtaking. This one you just have to see for yourself. It is amazing and no words can really describe the spectacle of it. One word of advice - buy the tickets online from the Westminster website before you go. We skipped a very long line-even skipped the London Pass line. It was wonderful.

Very nice. My wife insisted we visit here this trip and I'm happy she did, great place to visit. Line wasn't too long. Very spectacular views, amazing details and so much history. Nothing like this in the states,

Another Must See in London. Everyone should go to the Abbey at least once in their travels. The rich history is fantastic, but next to the Sistine Chapel, this is the most beautiful church in the world. The coronations, funerals, and weddings that have gone on in the Abbey lend themselves to a depth of history second only to Rome. The audio tour is full of all the historical significance that would keep an avid sightseer entertained and educated. There are shops, and small eateries for you along the way, and you can opt in to a guided tour for pay, the audio tour is free. Be respectful that this is a church and not a museum like the Tower of London. They do have prayer and areas that may be closed off for sacred events.Some highlights of the tour include: Queen Elizabeth 1, Mary Tudor, and Mary Queen of Scots graves. There are also the graves of Isaac Newton, and several famous historical poets, like Charles Dickens. No Photos!
Somme 100. Stopped by to pay respects. Was bit shocked at entry price & amount of waiting time but enjoyed the visit once inside.

Study your British history to get the most from your visit!. Since you can no longer do chalk, wax or crayon rubbings at this location, it is a good place to check out good subjects you'd like to make a rubbing of, and then ask locals about other less populated places (like in the country) where you might be able to create such classy artwork for yourself.I've not been here since about 2012, but this recommendation remains timely (especially for families with children in need of participatory fun, entertainment, and an enjoyable way of learning some of the local culture, history, and what the locals value.

Get tickets in advance. Pretty good abbey.
