It's the final resting place for a bunch of famous people (e.g. Darwin and Newton), and also has dedications to others (e.g. Churchill and FDR).I used the app and my wife used the supplied audio tour; I don't think there were many differences (not many people used the app).But your tickets in advance to bypass the huge line outside (go right up to the front entrance with your online ticket in hand). You can only buy online tickets for a future day (not today).

Celebration of former notable people. . Tip, visit early and first. I was in the queue for about half an hour. Inside is full of famous names and beautiful memorials. It felt a little like a treasure hunt, trying to find a name you know. Worth a trip to see either a plaque or statute of William Shakespeare, William Blake, Sir Albert Einstein, and many more. Also, don't forget this is where 39 monarchs have been crowned.

N1 historical buildings in London`. If I was to suggest a single building to be visited in London, this is Westminster Abbe. The place is just beautiful and there are buried under beautiful monumental tombs many of the people that made England's history. Unfortunately it's closed on Sunday

History, history, history!. If you could only go to one place in London to absorb the history I would suggest Westminster Abbey. Had wonderful Blue Badge guide who shared her knowledge in a very accessible way.

Breathtakingly beautiful. Went to Sun am worship here couple wks ago, beautiful architecture of course. Much lovely singing from choir, hard to see tho cuz they seat you in specific area. Sermon was nice, Catholic influence of COE. The coronations, Diana's burial, all take place much father up than we're allowed to sit. Statues of war heroes, famous Englishmen all over too.

Pricy but nice. A bit pricy and not a hit with younger kids. A lot of people and the lines were very long. They allow those who are there to worship free entry. Unless you are a big history, Architecture or art history buff this might not impress unless you take the listening tour with audio device.

Stunningly Beautiful. This Abbey has something for everyone. First and foremost, Westminster Abbey is a church (so please be respectful!), and it is quite obvious when you first walk in. The alter is simply stunning. For the history buff, this is the final resting place of many people, from Queens Elizabeth and Mary the First, to Charles Darwin and Sir Isaac Newton. There are also beautiful displays for people who are not entombed there, such as William Shakespeare and Lewis Carroll. If you are a fan of architecture, you would be hard pressed to find something as stunning as Westminster Abbey. The outside itself is breathtaking, never mind the interior. The only disappointing part about our trip here is that you can't take pictures, and I would really have liked to document our experience here.
Breathtaking. The Abbey is a living history of England. It is over 900 years old. You can't take pictures in the Abbey so leave your camera at home. It is beautiful.
Just got to see the outside. Lovely to see and take photos of but there was something going on inside and our tour was unable to go in.
Beautiful Abbey. Definitely try to get there early, as the queues can be long! Was worth the wait, and very informative using the audio guide.

Richly interesting. Time, an unhurried companion, orientation, and the excellent audio guides made this return visit a richly satisfying pleasure; I had visited 30 years ago but scarcely remember anything from that visit except a blur of plaques. Certainly it is a place of memory as much as a church for national worship and royal solemnity.

Beautiful Architecture. Just seeing outside the building is beautiful. So many people when we visiting we end up just visiting the outside area and didn't went inside which a bummer. next time I will plan early so i could able to see the inside.

Fascinating. The Abbey contains so many tombs of historical figures, monarchs and pivotal people throughout the centuries. The sanctuary and the smaller chapels are maintained much as they have been since inception. Soaring architecture, symbology, stone, paintings - spend hours there.
Surprisingly good. Not sure what I expected, but the history and dignitaries entombed here was was really something, and beautiful.

Must visit attarction in London. If you like history, this is one of the must visit places. Packed with history in every corner. Some of the greatest known scientists, politicians and royalty buried at this Abbey. Get your ticket online unless you are willing to wait forever on a long line.

Gorgeous!. Westminster Abbey was gorgeous and there were tons to see! The walking tour that you listen to takes about 2 hours but it was really neat to listen to everything & hear about all the incredible things that have taken place in Westminster Abbey & all the cool people that are buried there. Definitely leave between 2/3 hours to wander around especially if you plan to listen to the audio guide.

Kings and poets. ... And Royal weddings.You can feel the history as you walk into the abbey. So beautiful. So regal. And a great monument to the King of Kings.Here you can see where many of Royal descent are buried and so too many who are honoured by the country.Not visit to London is complete without visiting the Abbey.

Incredible depth of history. What an incredible place so steeped in famous historical figures. Quite crowded however this was managed quite well with the audio-guide system. Staff also very helpful and knowledgeable.

A "must see " to be included in your London visit. I think Westminster Abbey is one of the most incredible attractions to visit in London. The history of Kings and Queens buried there, crowned there, weddings and funerals etc is truly amazing. A great piece of English history. The architecture is truly wonderful with all the arches, spires, carvings and statues etc everywhere. As I said a MUST SEE.

Visit for Evensong. It will take your breath away. This has to be one of the most fabulous churches in the world. Steeped in history and history beckons on the floor, the walls, in every nook and cranny. I love this church and everything it stands for. Wonderful

Worth the walk through the entire building.. I loved the Westminster Abbey and since we booked our tickets in advance we were able to skip the long line and walk right in. The Abbey is extensive and I did not see everything however I did see enough to have an appreciation for the historical significance. Really some amazing architecture here. Really great gift shop too!

Absolutely incredible. We went to Westminster Abbey because it was on our list of "things-to-see" while in London. It's right across the street from the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben. I couldn't have imagined how beautiful the architecture was nor the awe-inspiring history of this beautiful building. Definitely spend the £5 for the guided tour. The verger ( he'll explain his job and title) that led us was not only intelligent, articulate and knowledgeable, his humor had us giggling throughout. There is so much history packed into one tour, it's almost overwhelming. Downside: no photography allowed inside.

Amazing Architecture and History!!. Westminster Abbey is absolutely stunning as you walk up to it! It is truly an incredible feat of engineering and architecture. Also, it was really amazing to learn of all of the historic figures buried underneath Westminster Abbey. Such as Charles Darwin, Sir Issac Newton, Charles Dickens, and many others. Definitely worth taking a tour of the inside. The only down side was no photographs were allowed inside the church.
good. This was a very interesting place to isit but it was very expensive to get in. Other than that, we enjoyed it.

A definite must see. The buildings are so impressive and having the opportunity to visit a location with so much history is worth the visit. Unfortunately, we arrive a bit late for the Choir Sing and were no seats available (we opted to not stay). However, it's worth it to visit any and as much of the Abbey as you can. The gift shop is quite lovely, some typical touristy items and quite nice religious items as well.
Stunning. Beautiful old WestministerAbbey, steeped in history. Did not go inside but happy to view this amazing building from the outside.

Must see!. I've visited Westminster Abbey during spring break. The graves of famous English kings and queens are most interesting.Plan enough time to see the church and take a step in the Abbey's garden, which is a beautiful oasis far from hectic city life.
Attended a service at Westminster Abbey. a serene atmosphere if there ever was one, we attended service at Westminster Abbey which was a very moving experience.
Beautiful church!. Westminster Abbey is a very beautiful church. I'd definitely go and check it out. It's not far from Big Ben. Maybe you'll have to wait quite some time but it's worth it.
:-). Make sure you reserve few hours for this visit. You can cover this within few minutes, but I'd prefer listening to audio guide and spend some time there.

The finest mediaeval church in Europe. The list of famous people commemorated or buried here is phenomenal, including Kings and Queens. In fact this extends to over 3000. In addition to this it is the site of coronations. It is impossible to do justice to Westminster Abbey in under several volumes, so I would merely suggest you go there!Look out for Old Parr and the oldest door in Britain!

History right under your feet. This is the place to visit if you want see the where history makers lay. A beautiful church with famous historic figures all around you. (Don't forget to look where you walk) The audio tour helped you navigate through the venue at your own pace. We arrived at 11:00 AM and waited about 45-60 minutes in line to get in. It took us about 1.5 hours to wander through the site. Make time for this visit, it is well worth it and the wait.
Steeped in history. Amazing crowded but worth the wait. Every step is full of amazing history. Friendly staff self guided audio tour excellent.(included in price)

Home of Great Individuals and National Pride. Oscar Wilde, Charles Darwin Sir Laurence Olivier. These are just a few of the National heroes buried inside of this Gothic Masterpiece. Aside from being the final resting place of so many of England's greats it has been the sight of her Majesty's Coronation, every Royal Wedding and countless tearjerking choral concerts. A landmark, a symbol, a masterpiece
Sacred Ground. Stunningly beautiful! Attended "Evensong" earlier in the week & enjoyed self guided audio tour today. Two informative & uplifting experiences. Should be high on your "must see" list!

Amazing sense of history. I'd always wanted to visit Westminster Abbey and I wasn't disappointed. It was really crowded but we got to see everything we wanted to see. We didn't realise how many different people were buried here. It's definitely worth a visit to get a great sense of history.

Book online in advance. We ordered our tickets online two days before and we were so glad we did! When we arrived at the Abbey around 10:30am on a Tuesday morning, the line was stretched down the block, but we walked right in. We bypassed the audio guide to follow a briefer written tour that still hit the highlights. There is so much history at the Abbey, including the tombs of famous kings, queens and literary giants, the coronation chair, and amazing architecture.
An excellent view into histroy. One of the things you must experience in London. Great art, interesting things to see, a beautiful church and lots of great tombstones to read.
Westminster Abbey. Definitely awe inspiring. Everyone's buried here! A can't miss attraction, it's like a maze winding in and out of the crypts.

Beautiful - go see this !. This was a highlight of our trip. The Abbey is breathtaking. It's a unbelievable how beautiful it is inside and what history it has behind it. Definitely a London must see !!
Lovely cathedral. What a breathtaking cathedral,We used two for one entry with a valid voucher with our train ticket, leaflets at all railway stations

Nice service. We went for an evening service instead of the tour. When we first approached it wasn't open and we were told there was not another visit till the next day. The guard did not understand we were there for the church service and not the tour. We came back and cued up. It was a nice service and a lovely way to see this church in its intended role.

1,000 years of history in one building.. Even though this Abbey is in my home town and have visited it many times, I never get tired of going there. If anyone ever wants to get drenched in British history, then this is the place to go! Apart from the actual age of the place, which is impressive, I think that this is almost the British equivalent to Egypt's "Valley of the Kings" due to the amount of monarchs laid to rest here, not to mention the tomb of the unknown warrior. It is a bit expensive to get into, but that's London for you.

Very informative. I really enjoyed the history of Westminster Abbey. The audio guide was great in providing details about various locations within the church. It was a bit crowded the day we were there and although pictures were not permitted, I saw several people snapping photographs anyways. We respected the rules and had a great history lesson on the church and those buried within it.
The Beatles... . Going there you can miss the "Beatles's spot!" But the Abbey is a place to visit as well to appreciate the beautiful architecture. Really peaceful desire tons of tourist.
Amazing sense of history!. Simply amazing! If you get the chance, take part in the service in the chapel of Edward the Confessor. Very moving! Excellent, but busy, gift shop.
Isaac Newton inside! :). The Abbey is like a historical cemetery with Kings, scientists and a lot of history inside. Isaac newton and Darwin included.

See the location of the Coronation of Kings and Queens, Royal Weddings, etc.. This is a must for anyone interested in British history. It has been associated with the kings and queens of England since 1065. Several are buried here. There are many chapels, the Coronation Chair, monuments to statesmen, musicians, authors and poets. You can even have an inexpensive lunch in the Abbey's crypt.

Loved to experience another bucket list item.. We used the audio and it worked great. All the great items inside are pretty well known and worth seeing. But, don't miss the small garden outside in the back ..... very serene and pretty.

Disappointed. We planned to visit the Abbey as part of our trip as it was included in the National Trains 2 for 1 offer, but after queuing for over an hour to get in we were informed the offer was not currently valid. At full price it was very expensive and very busy so we were not able to look at some of the artefacts closely due to the volume of people.
Easy to use. Lots of staff to help, clear signs. You can now use a contactless bank card, you scan to get on the train and when you get off and it works the best prices out for you! So easy.

Absolutely charming full of history . A highly recommended your ..see the cathedral where Royal wedding take place all important events .
The Cathedral it self is stunning no matter what religion you are .
You will be in awe with architecture .perfect for Business event .

Amazing experience. Not free but well worth the cost of admission. Audio guide takes you around the important parts. Proceedings halt every hour for a minute in order to say a prayer and everyone was very respectful of this as it is an active church. Don't miss the beautiful nave that Catherine walked down for her wedding and the altar. Poets corner is always popular although be aware that not every poet inscribed there is actually buried there. And on your way out don't miss the Throne. The Abbey cafe is crowded but serves good food with excellent customer service. An enjoyable experience all round.
Very beautiful but, again, the line.... It is a very beautiful Cathedral but even if we had the London Pass, we had to stay in the line to visit the attraction

exquisite works. Westminster Abbey is awesome for it's exquisite works outside. A very famous church also. We could not enetr into it due to a long queue, we were overwhelmed to look it. Very adjacent to the Parliament Square and Churchill's statue , this is traveller's paradise
June 2016. Omg, where do I begin. Dripping with history and craftsmanship. Wish that I would have gone through a second time. Tour guides were friendly and knowledgeable.

Don't go on a Sunday if you want to go inside. We didn't know that the Abbey was closed to the public on a Sunday but it makes sense as it is a day of worship. Beautiful church from the outside took some good photos.

Amazing amount of history here. A must see in London.. Okay, this place is quite busy and there is an entrance fee. When you go to London, buy the "London Pass". It gets you in to all the major sites for much less than paying by visit. The history here is amazing and you get a walking headset as you go through the Abby, Huge building and really gives you a true look at the history of the past rulers of England.

A must see. London has a lot of notable landmarks with a lot of history behind each of them and Westminster Abbey was one of my favorites. It's a massive structure with a lot of ornamental detail to be appreciated.Worth the time to take a tour of the interior and get the details on its history.

Hard to take it all in!. The place was so amazing, and there was a steady line filing thru. It got tight in places but i would suggest doing a little research before going. It was overwhelming. Like for instance, we walked right past Newtons grave and didnt even notice until we were at the end.

Simply breathtaking.... My husband and I toured Westminster Abbey while on our honeymoon in London. All I can say is that it is simply breathtaking and well worth it. All that history in one little place. Amazing.

I recommend this, especially with the downloadable App tour.. One of the most significant, storied & historic sites in Europe. Come to the place where Western Civilization in the midst of its great days buried writers, poets, playwrights, kings and luminaries from all other times and professions are interred here. This is not just an architectural & historic site, it is a sacred site for no other reason than the fact that Western Civilization is heralded here.A must see.The audio tour is an especially rich, yet easy way to run through the paces here. Download the app, whether iPhone or Android.

fabulous visit. A fabulous visit to this place as you may see well-known figures connected to this church whilst admiring its remarkable and stunning architecture. Bring home some token as a reminder of British history as a part of my wanderlust.

Amazing place with tons of historical perspective. I personally am not very religious but this is a must visit. The inside of the Abbey is massive and contains the graves or grave stones of countless famous people. The various tombs and rooms for kings and royalty are extravagant and unique in their own rights. Their was a mass at noon which my parents partook in, and the audio tour was included and extremely informative and easy to navigate.

Eye-popping number of monuments to legends of history. Breathtaking abbey with hundreds of incredible carvings, sculptures, and gardens, it's hard to believe it's still in use today for services. Literary and history nerds (proud member of that tribe here!!) will love searching for the plaques of favorite writers, composers and royals. If you have smaller children, there's also a kids scavenger hunt to keep them engaged, and turning in the clipboard in the gift shop earns them a large chocolate coin!

Absolutely gorgeous. Absolutely gorgeous. Interesting walking through seeing all the crypts- a bit morbid, but so beautiful. If you have a Harry Potter fan the courtyard looks like something from Hogwarts. Check the times before you go. We had to return because we missed it the first time by two minutes.
Amazing!!. What can one say but you just have to see it for yourself. Such a unique experience to be in a building that old and be able to wander in all it's magnificent glory. GO!

A historical landmark must-see while in London. We saw the memorials to many historical people that have changed the way we live was fascinating and very informative. However, the admission was somewhat pricey. Regardless, if you are going to visit parliament, the abbey is a must-see while you are in the area. Incredible architecture.
A walk through history. The abbey is not to be missed on a visit to London. Final Resting place of Queen Elizabeth as well as many other notable brits.

Beautiful, worth a visit. Excellent place to visit, for all ages (more adult though) Because I think adults will appreciate the Architecture & beauty more. From the windows, to the ceilings to brick work, to the history of it all. simply stunning. Before we went I downloaded the Westminster abbey app (recommended) on my phone, & we shared earphones, it explained everything when walking around.I Also recommend buying a ticket before you go, otherwise you have to cue for ages, (we bought ticket before hand)

Great for Royal Watchers, but save your money with kids. The price is quite high to get in for a church, but it's understandable given the high demand to see it. My husband stayed outside with our 2 boys, ages 9 & 7, and I went in with my mother. Audio guides are free, and give more information than you could ever want. There are plenty of friendly staff stationed throughout to guide you and answer any questions. If you are a Royal Watcher, this is the place where everyone gets married. It's super fun and cool to walk the same floors that millions of people see on TV when royals get married! No photography allowed inside.

Amazing place. So much history! From the outside i thought ok it's a pretty church. We did the audio tour, highly recommended. Buy your tickets in advance! We spent a good chunk of time here. I never realized how much history there is here and everything is so well preserved. Great place to take pictures of the grounds. Just lovely.

Spectacular. Being with a guide, we walked around and entered through a back tour entrance with no line. It was good to walk around the outside because it looks different from each side. So much fascinating history is experienced inside, but be sure to use the audio guide, a guidebook, or an actual guide so the significance of each area is explained. We were there mid-morning, just after opening, and it was quickly getting crowded.

Regal and Old World Elegance. I love going to Westminster Abbey! We were fortunate that in the chapel next door, there was a beautiful quartet of horns from Manchester giving a free concert! I loved it all!
Gorgeous . It's stunning and fun to see where Kate and William were married. It's a must see on my list. Been there before and will visit again.

Imposing Gothic Abbey. Westminster Abbey is located west of the Palace of Westminster, next to Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. It is a large mainly Gothic abbey church. It has also been described as the “parish church of the world”. The nearest underground station is St James’s Park.The Abbey is steeped in over a thousand years of history. Benedictine monks came here around the tenth century, to set up a tradition of daily prayers and worship. It is first and foremost a place of worship which unfortunately many tourists seem to forget.Seventeen monarchs are buried in The Abbey as are some of the most notable people in British history. It also has the tomb of the Unknown Warrior. There are beautiful stained glass windows around the Abbey. You are not allowed to photograph within the Abbey Church – which again many tourists seem to forget.The Queen’s coronation ceremony took place in Westminster Abbey.Last entry is at 3.30pm and the Abbey closes an hour after this time. Admission prices online are GBP20.00 per adult and GBP 9.00 per child up to 16 years of age. A family of 2 adults and 2 children costs GBP45.00.

Great Place to Learn. This was a great place to visit. It was slightly expensive, but that ends up being all right, because an audio guide is included in the fee. I really liked that because it meant that the fact that I hadn't researched the history beforehand was taken care of. If there weren't audio guides, then I wouldn't have really noticed just how much history I was walking through. This is a great place to go if you have any interest in British history. There are many influential figures of history buried there such as Mary Queen of Scots. Also, the architecture is really beautiful. It has the type of ceiling which you could just lie on your back and stare at for a while. This would also be a great trip if you follow the British royalty as this is where most of them are crowned, married, and buried. Westminster Abbey is right next to Big Ben as well, so those two kind of go hand in hand. Overall it was a great visit!

Beautiful architecture steeped in rich history. The building was beautiful and the historical significance was amazing. Taking the time to listen to the audio tour was very worthwhile. Sometimes I would pause the audio tour and just absorb the site. There were some redundancy but the overall experience was great.

A high price to pay for history. Westminster Abbey is an amazing place in terms of the history it contains and also how beautiful the abbey itself is. However, it's far too expensive for a "tourist attraction". The queues are phenomenal so you should definitely pre-book and once you're in you have to follow a prescribed path around the abbey. In itself that's not a bad thing as you see everything and it controls the crowds but it does make you feel like you're just being shepherded around and you don't have time to really see everything. Also, you can't take pictures, even non-flash pictures, which seems odd when you compare it to other European and London 'attractions' of this nature.It's a beautiful abbey and I am glad I went BUT it does feel wrong to have to pay so much for an experience which isn't what I thought it would be.

History at its Greatest!. My wife and I visited London 5 years ago and decided not to visit Westminster Abbey. Don't make that same bad decision! We just got back from a 15-day trip and our last stop was Westminster Abbey. Wow - that is the best word I can use to describe it. The abbey is so rich with history it almost drips. I could have spent several days in there. They give you an audio device that tells you a story about many of the locations within the abbey. It's a bit hard to see many of the posted numbers but the map you are given should help. Sadly, you cannot take pictures inside the abbey. I would strongly suggest going on a weekday because of the huge crowds that visit. The more people the more difficult it is to get around. But go you must!

Church of Royalty. Westminster Abbey is where Kate and Prince William were married in 2011. Lots to see here so allow at least 2 hours. There is no photography allowed, but I managed to get a few before I was stopped ( I didn't realize). Like St. Paul's there are many, many historical figures buried here. Lots of statues, paintings, tombs, stained glass windows and rooms to tour through. There is an opportunity to pay at the door, the que went fast and we were given head phones inside. Besides famous royalty buried here, there are also well known poets and authors. I would not miss going here and would go again next time in London.

Worth a visit but steep admission fee. If you have a London Pass, it is worth a visit. Otherwise, the £20 is pretty steep. Self guided audio tour is very good. Lots of volunteers who are quite knowledgeable. Very welcoming place.
Great. Did this on a Saturday afternoon - try getting there in the morning. Verger Tour is extra to entry charge but well worth it as there are area's you will gain access to that others will not.
Wow.....Just Wow. Loved the history of this beautiful Abbey. Had a local guide take us through and explained many details. The history is phenomenal!!

get there EARLY. Long queues testify to the popularity of this church, which did, in my view, still retain the atmosphere of a place of worship despite it's key place not he tourist route. My favourite part was the Chapel behind the main alter. The graves and memorials to poets and scientists as well as political and historic figures contributed to a sense of the wealth of human achievement
Full tour of the Abbey. We spent a couple of hours listening to the audio as we wandered around.Lots of history and beauty to absorb.
Was goit to go in price stopped me. was going to visit on a whim but when we saw it was £20 a person and we only wanted a quick visit as we had other places to go we changed our minds

Don't go on Saturday morning. We really wanted to visit WA but the line was around the block and did t appear to be moving. We got there about 11am. It's expensive and later we were told by some Londoners that they charge to visit each chapel. So I guess I will visit it online.

Suggest that children 6 to 12 do Children's Trail Map.... Makes the experience more enriching and most importantly more engaging for the kids! The free chocolate for finding all the clues is a good motivator too. I came with a nine year old.I think there is a different version for those four and under as well. Amazing history here...a must doAlthough if you only have time for here or St. Paul's and you are traveling with school age kids, my son would vote for St. Paul's Cathedral. Climbing the stairs to the very top and then seeing the views was a huge hit! Please be smart in this area with your bags...super touristy and super busy part of town. High target area for pick pockets. My backpack was opened between the exit of the church and the entrance of the gift shop, thankfully nothinging was taken as I had stuffed my wallet deep down in an interior pocket. Keep valuables close...
Beautiful. Wonderful architecture but disappointing to find that photos of any kind are not allowed inside considering the steep price

Try going for Evensong. We saw Westminster Abbey while we were on a guided tour, but didn't get go inside. When the tour was over we went back on our own but the Abbey was closed. Then we saw a line of people entering through the main entrance. We found out it was time for Evensong. By acknowleding that we were there for the service, we were allowed to enter, saw the interior, and heard the choir. There is no admission cost to attend this service.

A visual history lesson.. We visited the Abbey on a London Walk, which had the advantage of by-passing the queues. Although I have been here before this was the first time we had had a proper guided tour which I feel is essential in a historic venue, although it is quite expensive. Although a place of worship has existed on this site since before the Norman Conquest, the present church was begun in 1245. There is so much to look at and absorb that you need time, comfortable shoes and probably to make more than one visit. For me the most memorable part was seeing the death masks of both Elizabeth 1 and her sister Mary, Queen of Scots, and the tomb of the Unknown Soldier. The ceiling is a joy to crane your neck to see. If you can, try to attend Evensong or the daily short prayer at 11am.

Beautiful!. Beautiful and peaceful. Some of the areas are small and cramped, especially when there is a crowd. If you can, download the tour guide from iTunes and use your own headset. It is the same audio tour provided upon arrival and you can listen through headphones instead of a handheld divide that feels like a telephone. Plus you can listen to the tour again should you desire.

Full of history. Visited mid June 2016, not much line up for Wed afternoon, the ticket includes audio, however photo is not allowed inside, you can only take photos around the courtyard area. Couple of highlights：1. Isaac Newton's tomb - if you are fan of The Da Vinci code2. Elizabeth 1st and Mary's tomb - at the same spot, but no effigy for Mary.3. Mary of Scot (killed by Elizabeth) - on the other side opposite Elizabeth.

Must See attraction. Long line to get in, but you can avoid it by getting a ticket on line. There is a free audio guided tour included with admission. Once you are in we recommend you sign up for a guided tour. We had a great guide, and it was the best five pounds each that we spent our entire time in London.
Go to a service. Sunday.. we had a choice of touring or going to an Anglican service for an hour.The service was the way to see this historical strucure

Enjoyable Tour. We really enjoyed the tour of Westminster Abbey, not realizing all of the history behind it prior to our trip. Free audio tour once inside was very informative and shared many details about the history and architecture of the Abbey.
Stunning!. Amazing and incredible! From the architecture to the history. they should allow photos, get the London pass and save money on entrance fees!
Not to be missed. We really enjoyed our visit here, the audio guide is informative and fascinating. No photography allowed inside the abbey, understandable, but it would have been nice.

Must see Cathedral!. Amazing place to visit! We rented the audio guides and spent several hours walking the grounds and the cathedral itself. The sheer amount of history in that one building was almost overwhelming. Every detail had meaning and importance! The architecture was breathtaking, as was the stained glass and the magnificence of the space. Note that no pictures are allowed inside, and you can visit for free if you come to attend mass. Make sure you also walk through the other sections of the abbey, including the Cloisters and chapels. I wouldn't miss Westminster Abbey if visit London.

amazing. It was pretty amazing to be in such an historical place. It is almost a mausoleum with all the buried people there. You walk through Westminster Abbey and you walk through history. Very interesting and special place.

Lovely and Historic Site. Although the gardens were closed, we watched the ladies decorating with flowers in anticipation of the Queen's Jubilee Birthday. Beautiful historic abbey and resting site of historic figures. Afterwards we walked over to Regent Cafe for a very affordably hearty home cooked meal (I had the roasted pork special which included a lovely crispy mean crust on the meat)

A London Must See. Westminster Abbey was amazing - so much history and so beautiful. Definitely recommend getting the Westminster Abbey app on your phone and using it with your own headphones as the audio tour of the Abbey. Westminster Abbey is a cannot miss! My teenage daughters also loved this tour.
Awesome. It's just awesome!! Be warned its shut on Sunday's !!!! #liveandlearn great architecture.. It's where most royals are married and buried 😂

Magnificent and fully of history. Any lovers of architecture and history should not miss Westminster Abbey. It is truly awe inspriring, almost overwhelmingly so. Originally founded in 960 and rebuilt in the gothic style by Henry III in the thirteen century.Buy your tickets online to skip the queues (lines) and pick up an audio guide as you enter. This along with a leaflet handed to you will allow you to follow a route around the Abbey and see everything of interest. Of particular interest to me were the tombs and shrines of royals such as Edward the Confessor, Edward I, Henry III, Henry VII, Elizabeth I and Mary I. There are also memoriums to historical figures such as Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin and William Wilberforce.Allow 90 minutes to two hours for your visit (depending on if you wish to visit the cafe or shop). The Abbey can be extremely busy especially in some narrow walkways.

Extraordinary. I visited Westminster Abbey yesterday, having purchased tickets on line. I paid £20 and printed my ticket off - thus avoiding the queues. I arrived around 9.30 and glad I went early as it was getting busy when I left. The abbey is easy to find - near Westminster Tube and is fairly central. Inside the architecture and history are magnificent and there is so much to see and of historical interest that it will take your breath away. I don't want to spoil any surprises for anyone as discovery is part of the pleasure but there is something for everyone there. I used the audio tour and took my time ambling around, there are plenty of places to sit during the first half of the tour but not so many once you have gone past the coronation area. The audio tour was sufficient but if I go again I would definitely go with the tour guides ( arranged at front desk), I could hear them going into more detail for other visitors going around. The museum was shut when I went but the gardens etc were open and pleasant enough. The toilets are at the end of the tour so a comfort break might be in order before visiting. The toilets are near the cafe and are clean enough, I had tea and scones for £7 in the cafe around 11.30 and I could see it was going to get very busy at lunchtime. I bought a programme on the way out for £4 (shop is on the way out) and found that very interesting to read later. This attraction was up there with the Tower of London for me and I loved it!
a fantastic architecture full of history. This is where royal family go for prayers and special events, such as Prince William and Princess Kate's wedding.
A special site to see. If one goes tomlondon and doesn't take in this magnificent site you might as well not even come to London to visit

Magnificent . This place is absolutely mind blowing. Surrounded by history and beauty. I work nearby and know a way to avoid the touristy queues. If you are visiting London this is a must see. There is app much to do inn westminster too., you can make a weekend of this tiny part of London. Go go go

Favorite London sight. Westminster Abbey is hands down my favorite place to tour in London. Words cannot describe the feeling you get when you first step inside; it truly is magnificent and so rich with history. When I visited a few weeks ago the audio guides were free, and they definitely added to the experience. The Abbey is the resting place of numerous kings and queens and other notable figures in history and the guide gave fascinating information on their lives and deaths. Take some time to just take it all in and look at the small details found everywhere. If you are going solely to take photos, forget about it as you are not allowed to take them inside. We saw many people trying to sneak them anyway and found it incredibly disrespectful in such a place. Expect to spend a couple of hours touring the Abbey if you want to see everything. I'd recommend pairing it with the Churchill War Rooms as they are right across the street from each other. This is absolutely a London must-do and it is well worth the admission price.

Most reverend place of beauty. Westminster Abbey has served as the Coronation church for over a thousand years. Queen Elizabeth II was crowned here and one can see the original Coronation chair; not as ornate as one would expect for Royalty, but is very old, and was no doubt covered by her Royal coronation robes anyway. This abbey serves many purposes; it is the place where new knights are installed in the Order of the Bath. It houses the tombs of many famous people, including that of Royal Sovereigns as far back as Elizabeth I, Edward the Confessor King, etc., and others, eg., poets, politicians and the like. Not to mention home for the many wonderful portraits which are hung here. The workmanship is exquisite. The quire stalls are also a site to behold and one can only imagine the wonderful voices singing the hymns on royal and other Holy occasions. But the public can attend the services. Founded as a Benedictine monastry, it is a living church in that it is still used for worship as well as for royal occasions.We were only going to stay a short while, but ended up staying for a few hours it was so wonderful. It is not inexpensive but is money well spent. Tickets can be bought on line and save time but one still has to queue for the security check. It is located near the houses of Parliament and Big Ben.

The Great Abbey of Our Time. It's the place where kings and queens rest, as well as poets, astronomers, musicians and writers- as well as other English influentials. Again, what a treat to see all of this- if you like English history, you'll enjoy every minute of this.

Solemn and inspiring. The age and beauty of the building are enhanced by the special feeling you have in a house of worship. We were fortunate to have been there at the 3pm prayer time. The lace ceiling in the Lady Chapel is exquisite. The cloister are peaceful and serene.

Like most old buildings, no pictures. It is rich with history but you can't take photos. Free audio tour. Don't bother path g for this unless you have the London Pass. It saves you SO much money going to it that way. Otherwise I think it was almost £40 per person. Not exactly sure. But dang it was expensive if you didn't have the LP. Also, pickpockets work this area, so keep an eye on your stuff. We didn't loose anything, but we were cautious.

A great visit, a lot of history inside. It's the monarchs own private church, not from any organized religion. It is beautiful outside and in. Do not miss the tombs of notables such as Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin.

Absolutely beautiful church . Me and my partner both really loved this church. It's one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. The audio guide was fantastic and very informative. Although I really wanted to take pictures as everything was so beautiful I think it's better that photos are not allowed to protect the sanctity of the place. It was very peaceful walking around and taking everything in. This was part of a 3 week trip I planned for my partner who had never been to England, and he told me this was one of the highlights for him. The price to get in is a little expensive, but it's worth the cost.

2 hours of history!. If you love history or if you want to know about the history of England - you should definitely visit the Abbey! Long queue and high price for entrance tickets are worth to wait 30 minutes (if you're an early bird) and pay. Perfect free audioguide and magnificent interior decoration won't let you leave the Abbey indifferent. I bring the friends to the Abbey during my second time in London and it impressed them!Enjoy!

Beautiful! Lots of History!. Westminster Abbey should not be missed. It is a beautiful church with history of royalty and history. Many Royalty and famous people ( many authors & poets) are entombed here. Audio tour gave a lot of interesting history and information. They have a fun project for kids as they go through too.

Impressive From Start to Finish. From the moment we heard the bell ring from a distance, we were mesmerized by this amazing structure. Despite not being a religious person, my wife and I thoroughly enjoyed this visit and were both amazed at how peaceful the visit made us feel.At the time of our visit, just after midday, the entry line wasn't terribly long, though we had the London Pass, so were able to walk straight in anyways.On entrance, remember to pick up the free audio guide, which was great, as the audio guides, along with clearly marked paths and signs, guided us (and the rest of the tourists) through the Abbey quickly, while learning about the Abbey's history and its significance throughout time. It also pointed out aspects of the Abbey, which would have skipped right by us were it not for the informative audio guides.It's just a shame photos were not allowed in most areas, as there's no words that can describe this amazing structure.

Beautiful and has a nice tea room inside. We didn't do the tour of the inside of the abbey, but the outside was pleasing enough. It's like a cathedral and if you're into architecture, ever angle and corner has something beautiful to offer. It has plenty of greens around it and a nice little tea shop called the Cellarium, which you can access without needing to buy the tour pass.

1,000 years of history. If you visit London and don’t take a stroll around the Abbey, you will be doing yourself a grave disservice. There are about 3,300 of them strewn about the place… graves, that is.If you have the time, join the locals and other travelers in a free service, and share a tradition which has been going on at this very site for over 1,000 years. Listen to the voices and song as they echo through the space and look up and marvel at the grandeur; all the while thinking about all of the events that have taken place within steps of your seat.

Staff was rude; expensive; hard to get tickets. It always takes an act of parliament to get tickets to this attraction because it's often closed and the schedule changed online at least twice when I was trying to make travel plans. Then, when we arrived at the ticket window, the ticket-taker loudly complained that while I had printed off three sheets from the ticket purchase, I didn't have the one that she wanted, so she sure let me know about how much time it was going to take for her to "have" to print it and scan it in for me. Heaven forbid she have to do what she was hired to do--help tourists. The Abbey is beautiful and there is a great amount of history inside; however, I probably won't ever take the time to go again considering how much it cost and how we were treated.

Organ Recital on Sunday . Visited Westminster Abby for the Sunday evening Organ Recital. We were lucky enough to be there when the Organ Master performed. People do line up for this, so arrive early to the 5:45pm performance. The music was very beautiful.

nice. It is a large, mainly Gothic abbey church in the City of Westminster, London, located just to the west of the Palace of Westminster. It is one of the most notable religious buildings in the United Kingdom .This Church is cool & it contain many famous people tomb like Grave effigy of Queen Elizabeth I also it have buried for The Unknown Warrior, it is busy place full with tourist & worth visit,

Beautiful but.... We visited Westminster Abbey towards the end of the day and there was quite a line, but it moved pretty quickly. When we got in to purchase our tickets our cashier was especially rude. We found other staff members to be quite rude as well. It was a beautiful space and wonderfully historical. Was it worth £20? I don't know. After the way we were treated, I was not thrilled.
Very nice church. Nice church to visit if you like historical buildings. I would recommend audio guide.Lot of interesting details to notice.

Do not skip this!. This was incredible to see. I am not a religious person, but walking through Westminster Abbey had a profound affect on me. Hearing all the history through the audio guide was a great help, and I really enjoyed hearing about all the various Kings and Queens throughout the history of the Abbey.
Exquisite. This is a beautiful example of Gothic Architecture as well as the cite of many famous historical events. The place is first and foremost a church so it has a serene atmosphere.

Well worth the time to walk through history!. The audio tour of this gem is informative and keeps crowds moving. Along with its role as a church it is the burial or memorial place for kings, queens, poets, writers, actors, scientists and church leaders through the centuries. It is like all of English history in one place. Amazing. It is beautiful.

Great!. Got there early so no queues.This is a favourite attractions of mine. The history, the tombs, the building = amazing! The tour was good and infornarive. Overall amazing! Recommended to anyone.
More of a museum. This is a very interesting church, full of famous peoples tombs, and lots of very interesting objects. Give this at least 3 hours, if you expect to see it all

Great history in the center of London. Across the street from the Parliament building, Westminster Abbey is tied to the history of England. Many Monarchs were crowned here, including Queen Elizabeth II. The building is beautiful with gorgeous stained glass windows.The only downside is the price. The cost is well over £20. For some it may be worthwhile, but others may be okay with just viewing the church from outside. Either way, I highly recommend stopping by Westminster Abbey.

Impressive . Always interesting to read the reviews, but how anyone can say it's nothing to see must be blind. I agree with the comments about it being more of a commercial entity than an active church, but the sheer beauty of the place is breathtaking. It's something to see.

Beautiful and interesting but crowded, photography not allowed. I lasted visited the Abbey 30 years ago and photography was allowed inside back then. It is most unfortunate and frustrating that one can no longer take photos of the beautiful interior. Would have been less frustrated if there had been decent photographs for sale in the shop, but the guide books etc all have very mediocre quality photos. I would suggest that they sell some decent photos, this would interest a lot of visitors.The Abbey is fascinating and, unusually, the audioguide is actually quite good - to the point and interesting, unlike at so many attractions where the audioguides tend to be boring and longwinded.

Childrens Choir service at 5pm is special. during the summer months there is a daily 5pm childrens choir service. talk about a special moment in a special place. the choir and church readings are uniquely calming and set in such a historical church it becomes unforgettable...try to get to see it..and its free.

Visit for its historic importance. I’m not going to give you historic details that I’m sure are all known. Just an impression of our visit.First of all, it is much more impressive and beautiful outside than inside. It should be visited inside (with tickets) just for its historic importance. It is very close to the Parliament and as such they can be visited alongside. The entrance queue is very long.
You had me in Awww. Beautiful & rich in history, simply awwww... Must do the audio tour and the phone app helps to understand so much more.
Great historical sight. This is a must see when in London. So much history. Buy your tickets ahead of time if you can so you don't have to wait in line.

Great Tourist Attraction. This is a must see when you go visis the Big Ben. When we went, there was an official ceremony going on and as we waited outside, the Mayor of Westminster arrived with his wife.

OVER 1000 YEARS OF HISTORY...... The tombs are amazing. Walking in the presence of such greatness is awe inspiring. Seeing where all the monarchs have been crowned and royal weddings took place is a privilege.
Fantastic Place. The tour was great. However lines are long and you need to get there early. Try to do the guided tour and not self-guided.
Vastly underrated.. This was one of my top three attractions in London. I would highly recommend a visit here. The audio tour was very informative.
Historical !. Never realized the history of the Abbey. Lines can be long to arrive early. Worth the visit due to the historical nature of the architecture and graves of previous monarchs.

Long Lines, But Beautiful. Went on a Saturday afternoon, long lines even though we bought tickets ahead of time. The place is very nice and the staff is friendly. If you like to see churches this is a must see, otherwise not a top priority.

Fantastic history. I last went to Westminster Abbey more years ago than I care to remember! I had forgotten what an amazing place this is, there is so much history to it that it really is mind boggling. The audio guide which is included in the entry price is very good, giving all the necessary information without going on and on. It is difficult to take in how many famous people are interred here, there is almost a feeling of excitement when coming across the tombs. Although it does get very crowded, it is simple to get around at your own pace.

A Great Piece of Living History . If you like history or even just want to connect with part of what makes Britain what it is, buy a ticket and spend a few hours here. One tip you may want to consider - We purchased tickets via their Web site and downloaded the excellent smart phone app for the audio your. (It's the same content as the box they handout but one less thing to carry and you can use your own headset or ear buds.)A great way to spend 60-90 minutes. Be aware that photography is only permitted in limited areas if you go.

Worth your time to just walk around. Westminster Abbey is located in the same area of Big Ben and the Parliament and within 5 minutes of each other. If you have time, plan ahead to get the ticket to visit the inside the galleries and attend the sermon. If you do not have time, just walk around to see activities and the buildings is worth your time.

More to see than we thought!. Much more to see than the Middle Aisle that you see on TV. There are side parts, around the back of the altar, long cloisters, underground vault, kitchen gardens, residences, shops and a café. It is a huge place with tombs and memorials everywhere - too many to take in. You get an audio guide. No photos allowed. We were there for 2 hours. Expensive to get in and café food expensive - 8.15 for tea and scones for one person.

Wonderful, fascinating history especially poets' corner. There was a long queue on a rainy day when I visited Westminster Cathedral, but we moved along quite quickly.,the entry price includes free floor plan and audio guide, well worth taking. There is too much to take on on a first visit, and it is all beautiful to look at. I especially enjoyed Pets Corner towards the end of the audio guide.I had a bowl of delicious soup at the restaurant. There is a cafe with cheaper options but I missed the entrance. The restaurant was lovely,excellent service, in a whitewashed crypt with vaulted ceilings. Not to be missed

Don't miss this. I've had my fair share of visiting cathedrals, abbeys and churches and it's fair to say that sometimes I'm "over it"! But I'm so glad I visited here. The pre-recorded commentary was excellent and the whole abbey is amazing with lots of interesting and historic areas. I learnt a lot.

Interesting church . Was very interesting church, but if you aren't into churches/history would not recommend due to the high entrance fee (20 pounds for an adult, 17 for a concession) I don't have a problem paying for church entrance for touristic purposes but I thought that was a little steep. Great audio tour included though.
Unexpected history lesson . Was crowded yet the place intrigued even a 13yr old... Cultural eye opener as well as a fantastic tool to educate youngsters..

Absolutely amazing!. An absolutely amazing cathedral. Definitely purchase your tickets online in advance, this allows you to skip the (usually very long) line of people waiting to purchase tickets on site. When I entered, I was given a free audio guide, but you can also download the audio guide to your smartphone for free. There are no pictures allowed inside the cathedral and there are multiple moments of prayer and reflection that all visitors are asked to observe. Everywhere you turn there is something to see...some piece of history. It's overwhelming the amount of history that the cathedral has seen.

Impressive inside and out. I recently took my second visit to the Abbey. It is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever visited. The statues and stained glass are incredibly beautiful. The audio tour included with admission is excellent. It gives you a lot of information of the Abbey, and helps you pinpoint where the key areas of the Abbey are located. It is really amazing to be able to walk through a church that is so well known, and has held so many historic events. It is so also a wonderful experience to attend a service if you have a chance. You can enter part of the Abbey for free if you attend a service.

Awe Inspiring. It is hard to comprehend the centuries of history that lay buried within Westminster without giving due reverence to their lives and their achievements. Especially coming from a country whose history only spans 200 or so years. Besides the architectural magnificence of the Abbey and the unimaginable ancestral bloodlines that run throughout the Abbey, there is a peace and serenity to be found within the Abbeys walls whether you are Christian or not. If you get a chance it's worth attending Evensong just for the angelic voices of the choir. The Abbey has something to offer everyone. It's simply a magical and divine place to visit.
Better than we ever thought. A bit of an investment..the entrance fee but for history buffs amazing. This was my first visit after many many visits to London. How did I miss it?

Wonderful Westminster Abbey. We were delighted to take a semi-private Verger-led tour of the Abbey which lasted approximately 90 minutes. Our guide was delightfully entertaining, and his knowledge of the abbey was impressive. Among the interesting facts and sights, we viewed the Nave, the Royal Tombs and Poets' Corner. I would definitely recommend this wonderful tour as it gets to the heart ... and through the crowds ... with ease.

Sorry horrible staff!. I write this review following a particularly bad experience that I witnessed against an American tourist today, by Westminster Abbey staff.It was obvious that the lady concerned did not understand the difference between Westminster Cathedral and Abbey (being 2 different churches), when she spoke to one of the Abbey staff about going in to worship, he was rude and appeared aggressive in his way that he replied to the lady, he rolled his eyes at her and just waived his hand and said "the cathedrals up there", she asked "sorry where"? And again he just said "up there" pointing his finger towards Victoria and turned his back on the lady, as she was a little perplexed with his lack of assistance I decided to help her and told her how to get to the Cathedral.I would seriously urge the Westminster Abbey "Management" to undertake some training with their door staff, as I found it disgraceful that someone working in the house of god can treat someone this way.What a great advertisement for UK tourism, I think not!

Breathtaking. Amazing history, ensure you take the audio tour (like a mobile phone that tells you the history as you walk around) - blew my mind the amazing people buried there, let alone the incredible history. We waited a whole 20 minutes I think in the queue, not too painful. Plus they have a food stall outside so you can munch and chat whilst you wait. No biggie and totally worth it!
Beautiful. Well worth the time to visit. Filled with history. It was very beautiful especially considering it's age. Wish we could have taken pictures.

So historic. We were so amazed at the extensive history of this icon Cathedral. Spend a few hours here - I know some Cathedrals can be a little repetitive in style, design and historical importance, but this wonderful old London treasure will delight you.
Lovely. Went to the 5 pm service, really nice, an excellent choir, everything is very organized and it is a pleasure to enjoy

Historic, ancient and gorgeous!. Recently I visited the Westminster Abby. It was on a gray day but after entering the front doors, it was a sunny beautiful sight! Long lines to enter but my husband and I had The London Pass and were able to skip the lines. Inside was well organized with guides to help and earphones with a tape player to help you understand what you were looking at. The place is amazing and impressive as you view the main altar, choir loft, and many tombs of ancient kings and queens. Well worth seeing even of you have to wait in line.

London Landmark. First hint: buy tickets on-line in advance for the day you wish to visit. Second hint: present your e-conformation to the agent at the door and skip the long line. The Westminster Abbey website has some wonderful background for the monuments inside. We didn't purchase the audio tour, but it's probably worth it as the floor map has minimal information. Great historical significance in a small space.
Beautiful . This abbey is worth all the queues. Everyone should visit at least once during their lives. If you can see s service in it, then your double lucky.

A must. Westminster Abbey is fascinating. It encompasses so much British history from Poets corner to the brand new organ (with bird carillon) in the lady chapel. It is also so close to places such as the Houses of Parliament etc., so lots to see in the area.
Visit to Westminster Abbey. We enjoyed touring the Abbey and all the notable people memorialized there. Saw Poets corner and the scientists, and the kings and queens who are entombed there.

A Most Holy Place Not to be Missed. There is 2 ways to see the inside of Westminster Abby. You can buy the Tour for 20 pounds ($30) Monday through Saturday which gets you in to see the entire inside chapels and tombs (there are lots). Or you can go to a 5 PM church service for free (please leave a donation) called Evensong (about 45 minutes long). You get to sit in the main Chapel and hear the spectacular boys choir and experience the Abby as a church which it is. This was the most relaxing and fulfilling part of our 5 day trip in London. If you only do Evensong buy and read the Guide for the tour in gift shop before you go to the service. The line for Evensong is at entrance where gift shop and starts forming around 4 PM. Guides in robes will guide you. The earlier you get there you might get to sit in ornate pews on sides by the boys choir rather than temporary chairs in center. Either way you won't be disappointed.

A Must see. This is an amazing place to see. Be sure and order your tickets online as it makes it easier to get in. Many days are sold out so if you want to see it, just book online. Also be sure and get the audio or you will have no idea what you are looking at. This is a place you can spend about 3-4 hours. You can however do it quickly, but you will miss things, so I suggest take it slow and take it all in. You can however do both the Westminster Abbey and the House of Parliament on the same day, and when your finished walk the bridge over the river look back and take a picture of Big Ben.
Not cheap. Westminster is beautiful but very expensive. Be prepared to wait in line for a hour if not more depending on what time you arrive.
My Favorite Tour,. What a place to learn the history of England. What a special tour. I was so impressed and so full of questions. I could have spent the day there.

Impressive. We went in on the train 2 for 1 offer so was excellent value. The inside is magnificent particularly round the Quire and is steeped in so much history. Staff were very helpful.
We had two disappointments, you cannot take photographs (St Paul's also note) and you cannot get high.
An important monument. It's expensive and very crowded. However, it contains important tombs and plaques to English historical and literary notables. It depends on whom you want to revere.
Excellent tour. Piece of advice: take the private "Bercer" tour, costs just a little extra, but you go into places the public does not ordinarily see. Well worth it!
Went to service . We decided to go to service since we were there to tour. It was very informative. I believe it's much I proved from 18 years ago.

I didn't want to. I visited Westminster Abbey under protest. My wife really wanted to go inside and I really wanted to just look at it from outside. We went inside -- and I'm very glad we did. There was a bit of sticker shock at the entrance fee but once inside I was immersed in a journey through history. Some I knew well and there was much that I finally pieced together. A most enjoyable couple of hours.

I see Dead People. Worth the price of admission. History is thick with dead people buried at Westminster. Plan on spending about 2 hours walking the abbey. Well worth the ability to see where history (coronations) is made.

Everything I omagined and more!. I recommend allowing yourself 2 hours (or more) to see and really digest everything. The people buried at Westminster Abbey is a who's who of medieval through recent history. Definitely use the free audio guide and map. They do a top notch job of guiding you through the Abbey. I will go again the next time I'm in London.

Quite expensive, and not very impressive... Went with one of my client, as it was first time in London for her. Tickets were really expensive, as 20£ per adult. I was not impressed with inside decor and felt like space was clotted and really chaotic.. Which I have never seen before in any other Church. I do realise it all comes to personal tastes... but for me it was waste of money.. And would not go back.. There are many more beautiful churches where you can go for free.. So if you are not a history/ architecture fanatic.. Spend money elsewhere. I must admit though, the building looks really lovely on the outside.

Absolutely Beautiful. I have been to London several times, but had never had the chance to enter Westminster Abbey. Had I known how absolutely amazing it was inside, I would have visited a long time ago. Everywhere you look is pure beauty and so much history your head starts to spin. You cannot take photos inside, which, as a photographer, almost killed me, but if you take your time and really look around you will see sights that will stick with you forever.Enter through the north door and turn right down the north aisle. At the end, see the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, as well as the Coronation Chair. From here, turn around and head down the nave, through the choir and to the High Alter. It is stunning, and so fascinating to think of all the monarchs who have been crowned and weddings that have taken place here. Around behind the High Alter is Henry VII’s Chapel, more commonly known as the Lady’s Chapel, which is stunning in every way. Just look up and you’ll understand what I mean. On opposite sides, see Elizabeth I’s tomb and Mary Queen of Scots tomb; both very fitting memorials. On the left, see Poet’s Corner, where the greatest poets, authors, musicians and even actors are either buried or honored for their contributions, including William Shakespeare, T.S. Elliot, Charles Dickens, Jane Austen, Robert Burns, George Frederic Handel, and Lawrence Olivier. The first to be interred here was Geoffrey Chaucer. Wow!From here, be sure to visit the Chapterhouse, Norman undercroft and cloisters. The gardens are especially beautiful and well worth a look. Overall, I would not hesitate to recommend a stop at Westminster Abbey. It is one of the highlights of a trip to London.

one of the most beautiful churches I have ever been in. I've seen a lot of beautiful churches all across Europe, but Westminster Abbey absolutely floored me. I would put it on par with St. Peter's Basilica in Rome in terms of architectural beauty. Make sure you either get there first thing in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the huge crowds. You need at least a good 1.5 hrs to walk through it and explore and appreciate the beauty!

Amazing. Spent a lot of time walking around here.
On the day we visited we were lucky enough to have seen princess Anne.
It's amazing walking were royally has walked and so much to look at.

A must see!. It was very crowded when we went in the summer so it was tough to really see everything, but it's so worth going. It's so beautiful and there's so much history it's impossible to take it all in! Worth the (somewhat high) admission price.
More London culture . How can anyone miss out on this amazing building. This epitomises the fantastic architecture of our country.
Very Moving . This wonderful building is a must visit the audio description is excellent and tastefully done presentation of the history cannot be faulted
Stunning. The architecture is stunning, it really can't be described with words. The church itself is just beautiful.

Stunning. I've been wanting to visit for a while and I'm so glad I made the time. From what I've seen on TV I thought I had a good idea what it would be like, but nothing can prepare you for its splendour. It's a truly stunning building with a surprising amount of things to look at.

Make Sure to DL the App!. This is a lovely place, just a quick tip to download the audio tour app from the App Store before you go (it's over 100mb so you'll need to be connected to wireless to do it). It has videos that the audio tour clearly does not, and it'll save you the bother of holding that thing to your ear and elbowing the hundreds of other people in this beautiful but very crowded place!

Take your time and soak in all the history. I had a free day and it was a spectacular spring day in London. After walking by Buckingham Palace I headed over to Westminster. As I approached Westminster Abbey I noticed that the line was not too crowded and remembered that I never had taken the time to explore the Abbey. Do get one of the tour systems and take your time exploring the Abbey. Notice the burial place of Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Elizabeth, Mary Queen of Scots, and all the other royalty. Great visit!
Wonderfull !. A place you much visit ! Impressive Abbey ,! Very close to Big Ben and British Parliament you will always people to admire it ! Dont miss it !

Evensong. We attended Evensong, an absolutely beautiful service lasting about 50 minutes. The music was fabulous. The choir sang a hauntingly beautiful choral piece to the words of a poem by W. H. Auden. The words were printed in the program. It is wonderful to enjoy this ancient cathedral quietly, in the way it was intended when it was built. We only arrived at the line at about 10 minutes before the service began, but it appeared that everyone in line did get to enter. Unforgettable.

English history beautifully preserved. First, the church itself is beautiful, an outstanding example of gothic architecture. Add in the many tombs of English royalty and you've got a history lesson you'll remember! Then there are the composers, the scientists, the poets, etc. You can hardly take a step without encountering a tomb or memorial. The audio guide is excellent. I also appreciated the prayers given by the clergy every so often. Docents are all around to answer questions. You can stay for services as well.

Everything I expected and more. For my London trip, I was most excited about visiting Westminster Abbey. Of course, that's a recipe for a let-down, but it wasn't. The visit paid off, big time. First, seeing it from the outside, I was stunned by the size. I've seen about five other cathedrals, and Westminster could hold them all. The inside was even more awe-inspiring. The sheer number and beauty of the monuments was phenomenal. For me, the Scientist's Corner was the highlight, including Maxwell, Darwin, and of course Newton. Quite humbling and inspiring at the same time. I also really enjoyed the Poet's Corner, including Tennyson, the Bronte sisters, Jane Austen, and Dickens. For added fun, tombs and monuments for many English kings and queens, including Elizabeth I. Just a really special place to visit.

Fantastic. Any word to describe the Westminster Abbey is not enough, you just have to go and visit. If there is a very beautiful historic and art place where you can see an amazing abbey is Westminster Abbey in London.

Great educational trip of the nation's Kings and Queens and great scholars.. Awesome to step into a wonderful church and place where the royals of England congregate every now & then, past & present. Their audio guide was very helpful and well planned. Go for it, you would not regret it.

Beautiful spot - but crowded. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful cathedral with amazing history. Highlights include Poet's Corner, the Coronation Chair and Henry VII's Lady Chapel. The reason for four stars instead of five is due to a few reasons. The tours are crowded, therefore you feel rushed and it is hard to see everything up close and read the plaques. In addition, it is fairly expensive but short, we were done in under an hour. I felt like St. Paul's had more to do and see. With that said, it is still a site you should visit at least once.

The Queen's Church. One of the dozens of churches within about a mile or two of each other. But this is the church that the Queen was crowned in. Very large and open worship area. Several alcoves that hold the remains of British royalty or other important people. Several private worship areas. No pictures allowed inside the church.

Worth visiting. It's simply magnificent! With the audio guide issued to all visitors , you can admire the place at your own pace. Worth visiting! Sit down and Imagine how the royal wedding took place there. Oh yes! Do Look out for the tomb of Newton and Darwin.

Beautiful!. My husband and I recently traveled to England and while we were there we saw Westminster Abbey and we loved it! The history of the abbey is so interesting and fascinating that you will want to learn more about England's history. Although we could not take any pictures on the inside, it was absolutely beautiful. If you take a trip to London, make sure you see this! I recommend spending at least 2 hours there and look into an audio guide. We did not have an audio guide and would recommend that you get one. The history and the building alone are breathtaking! It is a must see! We were able to see this attraction for free by getting the London Pass, if you are considering buying it, I would highly recommend it. We were able to see so many attractions and we also got to skip some lines!

Amazed by all the heritage of this building. This is one place not to miss on your tour of London. I work in the construction industry and to see all the details in every single square inch of the grounds is amazing. The safety challenges in building this Abbey was beyond comprehension. Enjoyed every foot step while touring.
Very special! . A real highlight of our trip to London. It even kept our teenage daughters engaged. We had our own tour guide which he explained a lot of the not so obvious history. Must do!

A very special place. I never have enough time to take in all of the wonders of this awe-inspiring place. A must for anyone who travels to London whether one's interest is religious, architectural, historical, or political.

Overwhelming. We went on May 30th with tickets booked online ahead of time which got us in the doors immediately without having to wait in any line. Could not believe how many Kings, Queens, famous poets, dignitaries were entombed there. Magnificent piece of architecture and history - an absolute must see for any trip to London. Saw the spot where Queen Elizabeth was crowned and Charles and Diana, and William and Kate were married. Should have spent hours there, but we had just come off a red-eye flight and were exhausted.

Excellent Abbey! Go and see this place.. Very Good Abbey. Amazing to see the old Tombs of some well known Kings and Queens. The place is jammed with monuments. Audio tour was good, Jeremy Irons giving a good commentary.No photos allowed in the Abbey alas.Cloister abit quieter and the little cloister nice.. Cafe seemed expensive so went elsewhere.

Overwhelming History. Westminster Abbey is overwhelmingly spectacular. There is nowhere to look that is not important in some way. With the number of people buried there alone, you could read grave markers for hours. The individual chapels and memorials are gorgeous and from such a wide range of eras that every variation on traditional architecture and design style seems to be represented. The most special part for me was the prayer service in the oldest part of the Cathedral, it is not typically accessible and only for the sure-footed. My toddler was asleep in his carrier which was the only reason he was permitted up. When he woke up, the cloisters made for a great place to work off some extra energy. I was not expecting to come across "Britain's Oldest Door," but that was a labelled attraction while walking the Cloisters. The little gardens in the middle were a calm oasis amid the grandeur and crowds. This is definitely a popular location, so bring your rain gear because you will have to wait in line outside.

Not to be missed if you are a History buff. We visited on 30th May using the London Pass. There was a long queue for London Pass holders and we had to wait for almost 45 minutes before getting in. This was around 11 am. There are excellent audio guides available. Please use them as there is so much to be seen and so much of history lies here which these guides explain. The Abbey has tombs of numerous royals and famous people. I was really excited to see Isaac Newton's tomb and the Poet's Corner. Many of the famous British poets' grave are there in this area. But what a pity , people can freely walk over these graves. Maybe it is a poignant reminder that after death even the biggest of names are reduced to dust.History buffs can easily spend half a day or even more in the Abbey. We spent only a couple of hours here as my family including our teenager children became restless after some time. But there was a lot of stuff that we couldn't cover in this short time. I had read some reviews on photography restrictions. Please note we took snaps using our iPhone in the presence of Abbey staff who did not object. This place is within 10 minutes walking distance from Westminster underground station and Big Ben.

Amazing. The sheer history and beauty of this building is breathtaking! To see the graves of so many monarchs and icons from History was awe inspiring.If you are going in for a service then entry is free otherwise as a family of 2 adults and 3 children (under 5 free) we paid £45 but I definitely felt this was worth the money.

One of the best places I have visited.. The abbey had so much history it was overwhelming could have stayed all day if it wasn't for my aching feet.Never realised it was so big and so much to see from the coronation chair to the tombs of Kings and Queens of England.The staff were extremely helpful with whatever questions you had, the only down side was no photos allowed which was a shame as there was so much I would have liked pictures of.

Evensong at Westminster . I went to an evensong service at Westminster in early June. It is a fantastic way to see inside the abbey and also have an authentic experience, all for free! The service starts at 5 and I lined up around 430 to get in. It lasted around 50 minutes. Definitely recommend to others.
Amazing!. This was the most interesting church we visited in the U. K. Especially poets corner. Only takes about 1.5 hours and is very interesting. Make sure you take the free audio guide.

Abby amazing but expensive$$$. After touring Notre Dame and several other amazing Bacilicas in France for FREE we were shocked how expensive it was to tour the Abby! (20 pounds per person that's 120 US dollars for our family of four for a unguided 30 min walk through)

Take the Verger Tour. Go on line and book direct with the Abbey and you can get a tour with one of the Vergers! So informative and our Verger was oh so fun! He even reserved seats for us at Even Song after the tour.
The abbey is steeped in history and great for history buffs.
