Always amazing. One can not visit London for the first time or even as for us the many more than first, and not visit this magnificent place. With each step you feel the history, learn new things and are reminded of others.

A Favorite Every Time. We all know of the architecture and grand history of Westminster Abbey, and sure it's filled with the notable dead, but it's the living that make this place even more delightful. I am disabled, and they made sure my visit was on parr with everyone else's. They stored my walker and loaned me a wheelchair, and arranged paths to accommodate my needs. Every single person I encountered was welcoming and warm. I am not even a Christian, but was definitely shown the traits called for in their religion that one hardly ever sees anymore. In addition to their kindness, the Abbey is fantastically beautiful. Put it high on your "to visit" list.

No Photographs. The building is steeped in history and a resting place for the most privileged in society. However, I was surprised to be instructed that photography is not permitted in this digital are. Really???

Two much fuss . We got here 10 minutes before opening so, we didn't have to queue long. Those interested in history might find this location interesting. The free audio guides elaborate about everything, but all in all, it's an abbey, many tombs and memorials, but other than that, nothing special.

An indoor cemetery . This place is quite amazing but it's one huge cemetery. There seem to be monuments squeezed in everywhere. I guess you go for the monuments if you have no interest in history I shouldn't bother if your looking for flash churches go to a Saint Pauls

Pentecost Eucharist. We attended the Pentecost Eucharist in May 2016; the ceremony was worth the visit and the setting was equally impressive. The Dean gave an excellent and very accessible sermon; I would recommend stopping in to listen anytime.

YES!. This is the most extraordinary place in London. It is thrilling and moving to walk through and pay homage to the historical and literary figures buried here, from Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin to Mary, Queen of Scots and Chaucer.
I liked it. This was part of a tour that we booked and it was interesting to hear the history. If I were to do this again I'd skip this.But great place with history.

Awesome. Although I was very disappointed that I couldn't take any photos, I did enjoy my visit. Westminster Abbey is truly rich with history, seen the tomb of Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots was really cool! Also we stayed for the Eversong which was a really nice treat to hear the beautiful organ and the choir.

History overload . Absolutely amazing collection of graves and memorials of historical giants. The building is beautiful, the guides knowledgeable and helpful. The weight of our history took my breath away. I can't believe that I haven't been here before. Moving.
Darwin is buried here!. No joke! I thought it was but here I was standing atop of his grave... The place is chilling and wonderful.

The Abbey is amazing. Please remember and respect that no photos are allowed in the Abbey. There is so much history, I'd have to go back many times to begin to absorb it all. Truly an amazing visit!! Tour guides and audio is available for detailed walking tour. It's impossible to describe the different architecture and designs. So many famous people are buried there including famous writers. Lovely memorials to all those who fought in the great wars.

Breathtaking . There is so much for the eye to see ... we waited about 10 mins to get in ... the outside if just as beautiful as the inside .. free audio was brill and very informative.. was amazing to c all the tombs of past queen and royal ppl .. loved poets corner lots of famous people to look out for .. great attraction and a must if in london

GUIDED TOUR well worth it!. Be careful when arriving and choosing the line you stand in. We originally stood in the line for LondonPass and Internet tickets but no one was telling anyone that was the purpose of the line up.The longer line up was for visitors who needed to buy a ticket.We arrived in the abbey with just enough time to book the GUIDED TOUR for an additional 5 EU per person. The tour lasts 1.5 hours, is conducted by a VERGER, a robed employee of the Abbey who assists with royal ceremonies and church services.WORTH EVERY PENNY. A great investment. The Verger provides detailed information and leads you on a historical walk of the Abbey and adds humorous anecdotes. The guided tour gives you access to a place the audio guided tours do not permit visitors: the inner alter which is a small alter area where Will & Kate disappeared to when they signed the registry.The guided tour provides interesting info also about how the Abbey is set up for CORONATION SERVICES and the process of crowning the Queen, and the history of the Coronation Throne which is also on display there.The guide was very knowledgeable about the various tombs and details tourists would be interested to know.We thoroughly enjoyed visiting the Abbey and the guided tour by a Verger made it come alive!FYI: PHOTOS ARE NOT PERMITTED IN THE ABBEY and they strictly monitor that.Although we hoped to visit EVENSONG, we didn't have time to come back.If you have an opportunity, Evensong is daily at 5pm or Saturday at 3:00 and it's FREE.It's a music based worship service with scripture reading. If you arrive early enough you sit in the Quoir with the Choir.

Famous graveyard. This church has great history.Crownings, baptisms, marriages, funerals and burrieges of historic persons took place here.Perhaps a bit over priced. If you are on a budget choose whether you want to go here or to st. Paul's cathedral. Both have their treasures.

Beautiful experience at Evensong. We went by to do quick tour and heard about the Evensong service. We stayed and truly enjoyed the music and liturgy in this amazing sanctuary. Highly recommend to all...

Chilling and moving to see these graves.... Sir Isaac Newton? Chaucer? Kipling? Darwin? Yup...and many other incredible historical, literary, and otherwise epic characters are buried right beneath your feet here. The church is beautiful but the star is the cast of characters. Goosebumps. Go see it.
worth it. So much History here. amazing place, suggest the audio phones as easy to miss things. a bit hard to find the numbers the audio sends you to though

Beautiful and historic self guided tour. We went on a Monday afternoon and it was quite crowded. The interior of this church is breathtakingly beautiful. The remains of several kings and other royalties are housed here. No photos are allowed.

Yes, value for money!. The entry fee is more than covered by the quality of the audio recordings and the opportunity to pay homage to many of the GREATS in British history. Not being from Britain, it was quite amazing to see and hear about an amazing array of Famous people and times. It was VERY easy to get around. Well worth the visit!

amazing history experience. kings, queens,scientists,philosophers,clerics and much more.wall to wall history coming at you from all directions.a must visit london experience.2 for one deal with your train ticket.loved every minute of it.

Surreal place with deep history and beauty. We loved our visit to Westminster Abbey. Please plan 2-3 hours for a detailed visit. The only drawback is the 55-pound entry fee. It seems strange to pay to see a church, but that's the standard for old cathedrals in England.

Add this to your "must visit in London" list.. We had not been here on our previous visits to London and it was a must do for this visit. Beautiful building and the history and people buried here was fascinating. We did the audio tour and thoroughly enjoyed it. We looked for ancestors but didn't find any.

An amazing experience with history. Visited Westminster Abbey on our first trip to London, I can only say that the visit to Westminster Abbey is definitely one to put on your list if you've never been before, it is both breathtakingly beautiful inside but you are quite literally walking in the footsteps of history.
Do Not Miss!. A thousand years of history under one roof. Definitely get a private guide from British tours to take you through this church

Take the tour on Wednesday in the late afternoon when crowds are lighter!. My husband and I arrived in London on a Wednesday afternoon and did not know where to start our touring. By checking a travel book, we learned that Westminster Abbey was open until 7PM pn Wednesdays. After getting settled in our hotel and learning how to take a public bus (very easy) to Westminster, we were on our way. We were delighted to walk right in - no lines, no waiting!After paying the entrance fee, we were offered a headset for a self-guided tour. Definitely take the headset as it provided valuable information on the various parts of the cathedral and visitors are able to tour at their leisure. We were fortunate that a service was being held as we walked through and we were able to hear the wonderful organ music.Westminster Abbey is filled with so much history in the form of artifacts, memorials, and tombs. Many notables are entombed here including monarchs and poets. This is such an interesting place and should be on everyone's list of must-see places in London.Try to go on Wednesday afternoon after 4:30PM. The crowd was very light. As we passed Westminster Abbey the next day, it was mobbed with people!
Walking through History . Do take the time (at least 2 hours) to let Jeremy Irons ' audioguide take you through the history of this unique place of worship - you will be taken to a different world!

Westminster Abbey. A visit to London is incomplete without seeing Westminster Abbey - unfortunately, photography is not permitted inside.This is a functioning church with a regular routine of worship.Built several centuries back, it is Britain's coronation church with the last coronation being that of Queen Elizabeth II in 1953.All coronations since 1308 have been on the Coronation Chair.Also, this is the funeral and memorial place for famous historical figures for the last few centuries, the latest being those of Princess Diana in 1997 and the Queen Mother in 2002.Audio guides in several languages are available for ease of the tourists who come in very large numbers.Highly recommended as a "MUST" see.

Historic/Beautifull. Wonderful audioguide led tour in almost every language. They did a great job getting everyone in efficiently and movement through the area was not tight nor crowded. There is so much to see and take in, it can be overwhelming. Make sure to stop and take in some overall impressions as well. I wish I would have reviewed the English King/Queen history a bit before going to have a better sense of each persons role. The tombs are not in a chronological order and I got a bit confused as to whom was in power when.
Absolutely stunning!. The staff are great, the building is beautiful and the history is amazing. People aren't that good though as they cant take photos but are still disrespectful enough to do so.

Simply Spectacular! . Westminster Abbey is quite simply stunning. The building and the architecture is amazing. It's another big attraction with tourists but one definitely worth visiting. Of course I'd seen it on the TV but seeing it in person was amazing. The building is huge, and absolutely beautiful. Plenty of picture opportunities and the souvenir shop sells some lovely gifts to remember your visit or to take home for friends and family or add to your own collection. I had a great time viewing Westminster Abbey, I'm sure you will too.

So much history here. Having a prepaid ticket is well worth your time here. The prepaid line was not too short but the other one was massive. You learn so much from the electronic guide they give you. There are so many important people who were buried here that it is like a museum visit in some ways. The staff was happy to help us find graves of the people we could not find which was really nice.

Beautiful place to visit and so much history. We loved our visit to Westminster Abbey. We went first thing in the morning when it opened as large crowds. It took at least a couple of hours to tour around, so much history with the many tombs and monuments. The architecture is outstanding, leaves one in awe. As it is still a working church, every hour there is a pause for those in attendance to take a quiet moment in prayer. We had lunch in the Cellarium Café and enjoyed the Gardens of Westminster Abbey, said to be the oldest in England.

Fast moving line, amazed at who is buried here !. Absolutely beautiful stained glass windows. Had no idea this was a burial place for so many famous people and royalty. History and art is here. Not to be missed if you are a first time visitor to London. Well worth the time.
Is so outstanding. It really has some amazing architecture, It is worth it to go and have a peak, they only allow you at certain times so please find out before you go. It wows me.
Beautiful. We visited Westminster Abbey for worship service while in London. It is a wonderful way to not only see but also to experience this beautiful building.

Evensong. Just too touristy and busy, you are herded in and out and it is not an experience I want to repeat. On the other hand, I would go to St Paul's Evensong every night. Singing and acoustics at Abbey is not as good as expected.

This is not to be missed. The history contained in this gorgeous edifice is worth at least two hours of your time while visiting London. The included audio-guide does a great job of leading one through the myriad of memorials, providing excellent background information, while at the same time keeping the huge crowds moving along and the interior quite silent. I was only able to spend 1-1/2 hours, and needed at least another hour to see the cloisters, etc.

Beauty and history rolled into one!. Pay the extra money and invest in a live personal tour of Westminster Abbey (we added on Buckingham changing of the guard too). We used Viator (TripAdvisor). The personal guide had a synced in microphone for headsets (bring your own or use their disposable) that provided constant information and story telling for the entire 3 hours. Our guide had pictures to go along with the history lesson in the Abbey that accompanied almost every area (royalty, science, literary and knight) tombs and plaques. Elizabeth and Mary tombs were quite breathtaking. See the burial plates of CS Lewis, Kipling, Newton, amongst many MANY other famous country-man. Lots of personal info about the current royals and of course the wonder and factual explanations about the changing of the guard. So worth it!

Magnificent . The Nave, Sanctuary, choir loft and pipe organ were beautiful. There were hundred of burial crypts including kings, queens, poets, soldiers,etc. The stain glass windows were magnificent. The coronation chair has been used since 1308. Th church is still in use and the tours were interrupted hourly prayers.

Crammed full of history. Although a frequent visitor to Londan I've never had the opportunity before to visit the Abbey so this was a long overdue tour round. It didn't disappoint, there's just so much to take in here though that perhaps another visit won't be far off.

Such History. Whilst quite expensive (20 Pounds) to enter, - London card covered the entrance fee, we spent two wonderful hours here. As people are let in in small groups we did not feel pressured and were able to thoroughly explore the many burial altars. Of course my favourite is Poet's Corner - such a special atmosphere
Lovely.. Beautiful structure with plenty of history within its walls. I believe the entry fee is 20 pounds but is included in the London Pass package.

Don't miss it.. Don't be dismayed by long lines. The interior of this cathedral holds thousands of incredible, enduring wonderfully beautiful things to see and ponder. Sculpture, art, graves of legendary people, not to mention the fact that it is an exceptional house of the Lord. Take a little time. Go.
Beautiful and historic!. Beautiful and historic abbey. Try to time your visit with one of the evening organ concerts...they are amazing!

Beautiful. Every trip to London should include a visit to Westminster Abbey. We had a small wait in line, even in the pouring rain, but it was well worth it. The stained glass, vaulted ceilings, statues, intricacies of the tombs, and the history of it all is mind blowing. Absolutely magnificent! Be sure to take the free audio guide so that you won't miss anything!

Worth the wait and inspiring. Both times we went here they were closing early for a special event so be flexible as it is well worth the experience. It was crowded but the audio tour was done at your own pace. Besides the church make sure to see the courtyard and side rooms

Church galore!. If you want to see the tombs of famous English royals and important persons, look no further. This abbey is full of them. You will also see where every royal has been crowned and the chair that is used. The Abbey is beautiful from top to bottom and is worth a visit.You'll get a map, an audio, and a path. Take the time to listen and note the numbers to press. There are no placards as this is a working church that will make you pause for prayers. The store is worth a visit (remember to go downstairs, there's more!) and all the workers are helpful and will explain everything. No photography!Word to the wise, get there early with something to do. I got there forty minutes early and was still not even in the first 30 people there. Bring a coffee and your phone and you'll be fine.

A must see. A really amazing place. Westminster Abbey goes back about a thousand years. So much history packed into one place. Hard to believe that they could build a place like that without modern machinery
Beautiful church building. Most impressive. Lots of tourists with long queue to get in. Many take photos just of the exterior. Worth a visit if u have the tjne

Absolutely phenomenal! . I have always had a real passion for history and had never visited the Abbey before. As a birthday day at my mum and I decided to visit. We had our tickets pre booked and saved on my phone. We went straight in with no huge queue to have to stand in. We were given our wristbands, shown where to get our audio tour and off we went. The audio was factual and not too long to listen to. The tombs and memorials were absolutely mesmerising and the hourly prayer read out was a wonderful way to slow the day down to a peaceful calm. All the staff were happy and polite. Especially the gentleman at the end collecting our head sets who was guessing the nationalities of the guests, with a huge degree of accuracy. We met the abbey cat inside who was lapping up all the attention! Would defiantly recommend to everyone with a passion for history!!!

Birthday visit. Can't go to London and not see this amazing historical site! So much history. Self guided audio tours included and worth listening to. Would probably visit again as so much to take in with one trip
The Graveyard Cathedral. The Graveyard Cathedral is what I call it, because there are tons of people buried within it. This is also the burial place of King James.
history attraction. the Abbey is a place you have to visit full of history .If you have already bought your tickets is easier . There is also a cafe if you are tired

Best part of our London experience. This was the highlight of our London trip. We've read about the Abbey and had high expectations but seeing it in person even exceeded our expectations. We were tired of all the royalty-themed sites and the Abbey was a great change.

London, a must see!. Amazing old building, imagine if you could just wonder like a public building! I imagine the parts you don't see are as fascinating as those you can! Obviously not going here is like not seeing the Eifel tower while in Paris!

Must See attraction. So rich in history. The abbey can't is a must stop venue on a trip to London. Buy your tickets online in advance directly from the abbey website. The free audio guide is narrated in English by Jeremy Irons.The cafe in site was a pleasant surprise and had a delicious full afternoon tea for $17.95 lb.

A must see in London. Although the crowds can make it difficult, this is worth the stop. It is 20 pounds for admission, 18 for students and seniors. If you have young children, this may not be a comfortable place for you. Lots of winding places and steps, tourist guides, and crowds will make it difficult for you and them. For adults, this is a fascinating look at architecture, art, and British history.

History buff bedazzled!. I was completely overwhelmed with all of the history contained in the Abbey. My mind was exploding with awe every step of the way. I wish I could have filmed my walk through, but even that wouldn't have captured the majestic building and its superb history. I could have spent days in there.

Lots of great history. If you’re visiting London for the first time, by all means visit Westminster Abbey. But having seen it twice I doubt I’d visit again. It’s not that it’s not interesting, it’s just that the cynic in me says it’s an ornate cathedral with lots of dead people. Is that heretical? Historical, yes. Beautiful, yes. Famous, yes. Much of the history buried in the cathedral is available other places and seemed repetitive. Before you even get inside, you should admire the architecture and the beauty of this grand cathedral. Pay attention to the details, because that’s where it’s really interesting. You’ll see gargoyles, intricate carvings of faces and masterful stonework. A tour about the exterior architecture would be a wonderful complement to the inside tour. See if you can find the statues of ten 20th century Christian martyrs above the Great West Door. Once inside, get an audio tour (it’s included in the price of admission) and start your self-guided tour. There’s good commentary of the fascinating history within its walls. Pictures however are forbidden.I was disappointed to learn that some plaques are simply commemorative, historical markers for famous people that aren’t actually buried in Westminster. It’s simply a sign of honor and distinction. By all means, visit. I just didn’t find it as interesting the second time.

Informative. I've always wanted to see this so I'm glad I went. An audio guide is included with the ticket, which was very helpful. The place was packed though, so I know I missed some tombs and information. My son was bored out of his mind looking at tombs, but I think it was worth the time spent there.

Amazing history. A beautiful church and museum/history tour in one.. The amount of British history here is incredible- and in such a beautiful place. So many years of politics, deaths, weddings, etc are represented here. 3000 famous british over 1000 years buried here. An incredible experience. There is so much to appreciate by the time you have explored half of the abbey it does begin to get a little redundant. But the abbey was enjoyed by all in our family- adults and ten year olds. Evensong is quite powerful also. Definitely recommend.
Great !!. Really worth to see !!!I have been there for the first time and will recommend it to everyone !!!One of the places everyone should visit .

Great place for a short visit. Friends and I visited Westminster Abbey on a Friday. The queue to get in was long although another entrance was opened up while we were waiting. We took advantage of the 241 rail card offer, (I would say £20 per adult is a little steep). Audio phones were on offer & we took advantage; I would recommend these as it gave you some useful information at certain points along the way. Best for use in conjunction with the free maps. Staff were friendly & helpful; one advised us that the upstairs part of the Abbey would be opening in 2018 so it may be worth a re-visit at this time. There were plenty of people visiting, however, it didn't feel too packed in the Abbey itself. I believe a couple of hours maximum is all you need to see what's inside. If you like history then the Abbey is definitely worth a visit.

A walk amongst Royalty. Second time visiting the Abbey and it was just as amazing as the first time six years ago. The fact you can view the tombs of famous royals as well as other prominent people make this attraction a must do while in London. You can literally spend half a day here. Be advised though you cannot take photos once inside the Abbey.

HISTORICAL. Not to be missed...got very fortunate as we got there at mass time...got to experience a mass....must stay for the entire mass...otherwise quite expensive to view! Beautiful.....not to be missed
Gorgeous. Even if you don't go on a tour of this Abbey it is a splendiferous piece of architecture to admire. One of the best Abbey's to cast your eyes over. Must do attraction while in London.

Absolutely Amazing Abbey. For anyone with any interest or curiosity about history and English history in particular, this is a place you must visit. The architecture, the stained glass and the deceased bodies buried within will make history come alive (an oxymoron I know) for you. Just thinking about it gives one perspective on the finiteness of our individual all too brief time on the planet while at the same time provides us with the opportunity to see those who have reached an historic, immortal status.

Busy, busy, bus!. Would have liked more time inside. This was one attraction I was looking forward to because of its history and I just felt that the place was too busy for me to appreciate it. We were given a headset and keyed in the numbers on the plan as we walked round. Just as well really because a lot of the inscriptions were in Latin. One or two of the numbered areas past the nave were also a little hard to find. Nearly all of Britain's monarchs had their coronations here and there are many of them now rest here but I was just overwhelmed by the sheer number of tourists bustling through. It actually felt a little bit disrespectful for those who are buried here and I question why the church asks for charitable donations when they are surely receiving thousands of pounds worth of revenue every week... Most of the museums in London don't get this sort of wealth!!
Westminster Abbey. My wife and I attended a service while we were there. Absolutely stunning architecture and history. This is a must see while in London
Interesting Look at History. Was not as grand as I'd expected but it had even more history than I'd expect. The audio guide is very helpful and it is included in the entrance fee.

Be here before but it was AMAZING!. The Abbey was incredible. I used to be an English teacher and I knew MANY of the authors in "Poet's Corner." History in the Abbey is unbelievable. so many of the names of those commemorated are known to you.

Love it!. There are many to see within this beautiful architecture that takes you back to medieval time. Many to explore and there is also a beautiful garden on the back, which is good for a photo spot when the flowers are blooming around April.

Great Audio Tour. Awesome experience. It's a little pricey to enter (20 pounds per person, but we got in free with a friend's parishioner pass), but I think the cost is worth it. Once inside you are provided with an excellent audio tour that takes you throughout the Abbey. This was a highlight of our touring London and I would do it again, even if I have to pay.

Lovely . We decided to see this church after we completed our Houses of Parliament tour which was directly next door. It's expensive to enter but it was included on the London Pass. No fast track entry available & we queued for abt 20 mins in chilly & windy weather. It was quite beautiful inside & incredibly crowded. The free audio guide made it even more interesting because there are so many interesting facts besides it being Will & Kate's wedding venue.
The Abbey. We splurged and bought tickets to see inside the Abbey. At $40 a head, a bit high. We enjoyed toured throughout.

Seriously...go to Westminster!. Even if the line looks long - it goes quickly! Westminster was breathtaking in every way! It was a wonderful place to see and so magnificent. It doesn't take long to walk around the abbey and you get an audio guide with loads of information on it about various places in the abbey! It was wonderful!
Lots of History!. This is a great place if you're a fan of history! Make sure you pick up an audioguide and if you can come for one of the vesper services it's really lovely. We enjoyed our visit!

Loved The History. A lot of history here. Kids got a bit bored with waiting to get in. It does get very busy and had to queue for ages. Nice to see the history once you get in. Suggest getting there early, otherwise you do have long waits to get in.

History at it's best. Toured at request of wife. Boy was I surprised. The feeling that came over me upon entry was amazing. The audio tour program does a great job of providing the history of the Abbey and its' famous interments. Would HIGHLY suggest a visit to this sacred site.
Magnificent gothic architecture . There are several abbeys within the abbey. Burial places for newton, queens, and other royalty. The detail on the architecture was marvelous.

Go to a Sunday Service. Westminster Abbey is wonderful, full of history and incredible style and craftsmanship. But I found going to the Sunday service, hearing the choir in that amazing space was a wonderful experience. Amazing for all Christians, but also for any other denomination or non believers. The atmosphere is quiet unique and the knowledge of those who worships and are buried here is very special . Being part of a service seemed to make it even more special for us.

Gotta see and experience it. Must do while in town.. Beautiful and worth your time. You will spend about 2 hours there and will have seen it all. Plenty to see and plenty of places to rest along the tour.

Just stop here and then you've done it. This is an enormous chapel and it is very well known to the London city. Westminister Chapel is a place for solos, families and couples. Need to get there early as the line will be enormous. You should definitely get a London card as you get in for free! But otherwise you have to pay an expensive fee. Just stop for a 30 minute walk inside it as you are in the city and just to tick it off your list for being London. You can collect free audio guides in many different languages as you go in. Also there are bathroooms and a shop just around the back corner of the chapel. Hope you enjoy!

Well worth it. As my teenagers said, 'it's a British hall of fame'. Impressive statues that led to educational discussions regarding British history and literature. Poet's corner, Tomb of the unknown warrior were highlights. FDR plaque and Congressional Medal of Honor of special interest to Americans.
Halls of History. I love walking the halls of the abbey and stepping into history. There is a thrill in contemplating the lives of the monarchs, scientists, philosophers, and poets resting here.
Beautiful Abbey. Really enjoyed all of the history that is in this abbey. From all of the famous British buried beneath to the coronation of kings and queens!

30 minute wait to get in 1st thing on Monday morning. What an experience to see this iconic and historic building in-person! It was very busy when we arrived near opening time, but as we were leaving a few hours later there was barely a line at all to enter. We would have stayed longer, but for the crush of people making it hard to read all of the grave markers.

Worth it!!!. I've been in Westminster before (usually for Sunday morning services - not to be missed). But, this trip - we took the Verger tour. This is well worth the cost.First, you are not among hundreds of your closest friends who are listening to the headset, preguided tour. Rather, a 'verger' of the church is your tour guide. And, you can see things that the average tourist can't (like Edward The Confessor's tomb).What I learned was fascinating - and, is fodder for many of my upcoming books this year.

Slightly Mixed Feelings. I really liked the audio guide. It meant for much less crowding in some of the tight areas while people listened to a guide. Also liked being able to see the quire and high altar better than in the past.However, people are no longer allowed up to the Shrine of Edward the Confessor (which means you can't see the effigies of the kings and queens whose tombs are there). Also, there is very little of the Abbey that you can see for free and you can no longer take photos anywhere within the Abbey.

Breathtaking!. Westminster Abbey was my favorite stop in London - I would recommend to anyone! Full disclosure - I love churches. Westminster Abbey, however, is so much more.The audio guide does a great job of taking you through the church and explains so much more than I ever thought. It provides some great history but you can also just relish in the beauty of the abbey. We also had the opportunity to venture into the old monk quarters and gardens (I believe this area is not always open but can't remember the details on that). It was just gorgeous. We spent probably 1.5-2 hours here and it could easily have been 3-4. Tip: We were going to visit around lunchtime but saw a big line. We headed off somewhere else and came back in late afternoon, when the line was much shorter. Since the church is pretty central and the line is outdoors, you can easily decide when to take advantage of a shorter line.
Absolutely beautiful!!!. One of the must beautiful abbeys in the world! And a great lesson of British history for those who visit.
Spectacular. I'm a big fan of Gothic cathedrals and this is obviously an iconic one. The audio tour is excellent.

Expensive!!!. At £20 to get in this is an expensive chance to see a famously beautiful abbey. Make sure you find the correct entrance to get in or you could end up queuing for a while to get in when it's busy.Fascinating inside and very ornate but not sure I'd pay to take a while family there .

Amazing. Not just another old church. We where blown away by this mainly gothic church. There rests monarchs and other VIP's. It is the place where coronations have been held since 1066. Very ornate and full of colourful stained glass. This is not a place to miss.
Must see. Very historic and beautiful. Use London pass. Handheld audio guides are easy to use and informative at your own pace.

Beautiful tombs. The abbey is the resting place of the who's who of the UK. I felt a little awkward walking over plaques containing the names of the famous people (as if I was disrespecting them) but couldn't do anything as there's hardly any empty space to walk on.The audio guide helped in understanding many of the areas & the architecture. Innumerable coronations, marriages & funerals have taken place here, & history leaps out of every corner of the abbey. It's a pity taking photographs isn't allowed inside.The place was completely packed since it was the Easter holiday. The crowds were kept moving from room to room to ensure there was no mad rush. In a nutshell, the grandeur of the marble statues & tombs is worth seeing.
A must do! . We loved it here! There is so much to see and it is all so beautiful. There was no wait to get in and is well worth the money!
.0000001 percent's burial ground. Ceiling is fantastic. Moving to remember Diana's walk down aisle snd then casket. Overwhelming how much money in the Cathedral.

The joy of westminister Abbey. While in London recently, one of the visits that I most wanted to make was to this incredible cathedral. The public tour, including individual audio data, was fantastic. It was all I could do to keep moving throughout the magnificent facility; the stunning architecture and the history of this church were nearly overwhelming to me. Details and guidelines provided by the audio headset information were of great assistance. If you tour, please take advantage of this free service.As a Christian woman, I wanted to attend a service on the Sunday I was in London. I was so excited that I actually was prepared to go on Saturday! I was kindly prevented from catching the bus from my hotel by the wonderful concierge at the Grosvenor Victoria, who gently informed me of the correct day of the week! I did, however, attend an 8:00 service the next day (appropriately Sunday...) , and it was lovely. Visiting and photographing this incredible cathedral were a major highlight of my trip. Not only is it the site of many, many historical occasions, but it is a functioning parish for the Anglican Church of England. I am blessed for spending time there.

Westminster abbey. You could spend hours in here. Fascinating piece of history. It is beautiful, crowded, well worth it. Kings and queens that you have read about are entombed here. Many of the leading writers and poets are buried here. You can also see where Prince William and Catherine got married
Westminster Abbey. Didn't go inside so can't say. Park outside and views are also good. Very close to big Ben and house of Parliament

Just do it quickly. Really interesting but I just heard the audio guideness and the visit the place (each grave) really quickly.. Otherwise you'll stuck there for quite some time and then you'll be exhausted to continue the day.. Like my friends.. I was lucky as I got there late and had to catch up with them, but didn't miss a thing.. And I sat also 15min during the jolly mass. I liked that a lot!

Stunning . Besides the historical significance, this church is stunning. The architecture is magnificent. It is also located next to Big Ben, a beautiful park with a dozen or so monuments/ statutes. It is not available to tour on Sundays.

Starstruck(?). That's how I felt visiting this magnificent abbey. Walking through and above the tombs of these historical figures is surreal. The audio guide was really helpful. Just wish that it weren't so packed so I could have explored the place at a slower pace.

Highly recommend seeing "This Most Beautiful and Historical" Abbey!. Oh my goodness!!! My sisters and I love coming to "Westminster Abbey", been here 3 times (from the USA) and always find something more to see. There is more history here than any other Abbey we've been too. It is breathtaking beautiful and romantic!We loved seeing where "William Wilberforce" (Who led the movement to abolish slavery) is buried and near by is his friend, Prime Minister, William Pitt, who played such an important role in "Pittsburg, PA" after all its named after him. Also you'll see Isaac Newton's tomb, and so many heroic people's tombs. And oh my goodness! Queen Elizabeth I, buried in a most beautiful marble sculptured tomb of her on the top of the tomb. Also to be able to stand and see where Queen Elizabeth and Phillip, Duke of Edinburgh and also Prince William and Cate, were married. Was so exciting!!! There is so much to see and experience for history lovers! which we are. They also have a lovely gift shop with beautiful things to purchase and bring back to family and friends! We will definitely go again and again.

Colossal historical value. Coronations, weddings and funerals of English monarchs have occurred here since 1066, when William the Conqueror was crowned. Unfortunately, I could not take any photos inside thanks to THE RULES. Innumerable kings, queens, prime ministers, and nation figures including politicians, scientists, poets, writers and musicians have also also been buried here. This abbey is FASCINATING. I was gobsmacked. As a fan of history, art and architecture, it was hard leave -- but eventually they made me. The building was closing for the night - LOL! This another 5-star attraction. Just go.

review. One must visit Westminster Abbey while in London. Its beautiful and historical. Plan on spending a few hours, because there is so much to see. So many monarchs are buried there and of course they were crowned and married in Westminster. The architecture is stunning. Do not miss this.

Majestic History . Although I'm from London by birth I'd only ever been here once as a child.So I decided that the time was right to experience the Abbey as an adult. It is a wonderful building stepped in English/British history. In fact quite awe inspiring if you realise how long it has been there. Thoroughly enjoyable and the audio information is as good as I've experienced elsewhere. Enjoy and let the history soak in. Take your time to really understand all aspects of the building and its use and history. Yes it is relatively expensive but the building is in constant need of upkeep so to me it was worthwhile. Definitely recommended for all ages.

Westminster Abbey. We got there just before they open but the line already formed & your London pass don't work as express pass so you have to wait online but move quickly once it open. You can't take any photo inside so you just have to buy from them (gift shop). It's very impressive to look at with all the history.

Mustn't miss. Wonderful visit to Westminster Abbey. Wasn't clear about benefit of buying tickets in advance. The two lines moved at the same pace, the no ticket line may have been faster! The Audio Tour was helpful, not sure a private tour would have been more informative. The Poets Corner was our favorite along with the Ladies Chapel. Took us about 1.5 hours to get through at a comfortable pace.Highly recommend!

Grand!. This building, the architecture and the history that lies resting here is magnificent. I loved the guided audio tour and also that you could explore the rest of the Abbey on your won. The gardens are lovely too. A MUST SEE!
A quite walk on the graves!. The place was a marvel with lots of graves around and under your feet. One is not allowed to talk loudly or take pictures.

Don't Miss the Abbey!. We enjoyed Westminster Abbey on a rainy London day. Be sure to get tickets in advance directly through the Abbey website, as they fast track you into the Abbey, and you won't have to stand in a long line, and believe me, that line is NO fun as it's long. Get an audio guide, too. It is well worth it, and easy to use. (Do not get a ticket in advance from other travel agencies, as the Abbey staff still makes you stand in the no ticket line!!! Not good!) Go directly to the Abbey website and get your eTicket there.

Nice to view - expensive to enter. The $35 ($70/pp Aus) was the stopper for us especially given the Notre Dam in Paris is free (though you are encouraged to give a small donation there). We still enjoyed the surrounds and it's a short walk th Big Ben.

Steeped in history!. Incredible historic site in which monarchs have been crowned and buried for nearly a thousand years. Walking past the tombs of generations of royalty was a truly profound experience. While I was initially disappointed that photography is prohibited, I ended up enjoying the break from taking photos as it allowed me to truly live in the moment and take in the beauty and grandeur of the Abbey's architecture, in addition to its long history that is very well detailed in the audio guide. The entry price is high, but well worth it. An absolute must for anyone enamoured with British history, as I certainly am!

Incredible! Historic and romantic!. The Abbey is an incredible place filled with history, beauty, architecture and romance.We have been there several times. Each time we disorder something different .The Evensong is beautiful . A must see if you visit London whether you are religious or not.

One of those things that can't be skipped.... This is another one of those places that a traveler HAS to see whilst in London. The lines can get long, so it is best to arrive at opening. Even with the long lines, they are efficiently managed. In cold or rainy weather, it's best to be prepared to wait outside in line for a bit. Make sure to travel off the path into the side rooms. I was amazed to find myself alone with the resting place of Queen Elizabeth I ! People seem to follow the straight line through more often than not, but some of the most amazing dedications are to the sides.
Poet's corner is my favourite. In the whole Abbey,The Poet's corner is my favourite.All these great literature legends. They are the real souls of the great Britain!
Enjoyed Evensong. We attended an Evensong Service. It was lovely. The choir is magnificent and we got to hear the great organ. The Abbey is full of history. Admission is free when attending services.

A must see monument to British Royal history. Unlike many churches/cathedrals, this one is full of Royal and notable tombs that each add to your knowledge of British history. The abbey vergers are always available to answer your questions and add anecdotes...so interesting! I would chose to visit this cathedral vs Notre Dame any day. Make sure to buy your tickets in advance and skip the line - ask the red-coated vergers to show you where.

Don;t miss it!. Westminster Abbey for any Architecture or History buff is a can't miss" visit. It's as breathtaking and inspiring as touted.Tips:1. Buy your tickets online and avail yourself of the "Fast Track" line for entry. For me, this is basically a must.2. Download the free Westminster Abbey application to your phone and bring your earbuds which are required. It's a much better experience than the handheld devices that you rent. Jeremy Irons provides the English narration (what a voice) and you can turn up the music tracks to get the full effect.3. GET THERE EARLY!. Although a lot of what you are looking at is high up, it starts betting really crowded pretty much right after it opens.

A Pricey and Restrictive Must-See Location. If you go to London, you have to see Westminster Abbey, and take the provided audio-guide tour. It's one of those few "must-see" or "must-do" activities. That being said... be advised: it costs a whopping charge of nearly $30 USD per person to get in and take the one-hour tour. What is truly offensive however, is not the price... it is the fact that after paying that extremely steep price to view the interior of this Cathedral, you are forbidden from taking any photos at any time (yes, even without the flash, you are still forbidden from taking any photos at all). We got caught 3 times trying to discretely take photos... (I think one more time and we would have been thrown out)... the "Photo Police" are EVERYWHERE and they are stealthy, and come out of nowhere with their quick and stern admonishment of "SIR... YOU CANNOT TAKE PHOTOS IN HERE!" When we went to the even more impressive Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, admission was FREE, and photos with-or-wthout flash were encouraged!

So much history! Do not miss it!. Grandeur and history all in front of you. Amazing to think of the wonderful historic moments which have taken place in this Abbey and be there to see the tombs of Kings, Queens and others who've shaped England and consequently other countries around the world. Truly awe-inspiring place.

Historic and Inspiring. Hours can be spent here exploring the Poet's corner, the nave, and the final resting places of former queens and kings. Many events in recent history have occurred here, from Royal weddings to funerals.

Classic London, worth the investment of time. When I visit London there are so many worthwhile places to see the question is where to invest that most scarce of visitor resources--Time. Every time I visit London I visit Westminster Abbey. The last three times I've taken the "verger's tour." The smalladditional charge to have a knowledgeable guide with a small group that also givesaccess to areas not available to the general public is well worth it. The verger is able to answer questions about a wide range of subjects of interest to visitors to the Abbeywhether it's a first visit or a repeat visit. Every time I visit I appreciate the grace,beauty and power of the architecture, centuries old, the resonance of being in a placewhere so many have communed with their maker for so long. And the Abbey is a living, active church and the public is welcome to attend most services free of charge, I think. Yes, for me, Westminster Abbey is well worth the investment of time.

A historic landmark. Ordinarily the Abbey charges an entry fee for tourists, which if you enjoy history, architecture and spotting the grave markers and memorial stones of famous figures will be worth the dough. The stained glass 'rose' windows are truly spectacular. Entry for worship is free (tourists are prohibited whilst a service is celebrated); I attended an Easter Sunday evensong service which was austerely beautiful, and perhaps a more authentic way to enjoy this historic landmark.

So so beautiful. This was on our list of places we wanted to visit while in London. It's expensive to your but so worth it. It's so beautiful. Soooo much history. To walk the aisle that all of nobility walked is incredible. So much history here. Be sure to see all the tombs. Especially, King Henry the Eighth.

Must see. It was closed to the public on my first attempt, but spoke to guard and discovered it would be open a couple of days later. Really enjoyed wandering around at my own pace, and learning some more about some historic characters.

Amazing. It's all been said before. Allow plenty of time to view all of the gravestones or memorials. Buy tickets online to minimize the wait to enter. There was a huge line but a staff member saw we had printouts and directed us to another door. Not sure if we would have known which door to enter otherwise. No photography allowed inside. It was amazing.

Westminster Abbey on a Rainy Day. We took a tour of the Abbey and Changing of the guard. Even though it rained, the extra time in the Abbey was wonderful. Our tour guide was very informative. We learned so much new info.

Carolineans in Westminster. We had both been to the Abbey years ago. This additional visit was a good choice, but be prepared to pay a steep entrance fee. Around $50 for two, as I recall. Something bothers me about paying to visit a church, but this place, like many in Britain, is more monument than church. We had forgotten how much history is located in this one city block. Put this on your to-do list.

Many famous people buried here. This is a beautiful Abbey. Audio guides are provided with entrance fee. Guides provide history and point out tombs and monuments. Many royal funerals and weddings have taken place here. Abbey still has regular services you can attend at set times. An iconic Abbey worth a visit.
Spectacular Building. Opposite Parliament House you will find Westminster Abbey and this is a stately old church building that is worth looking at both externally and internally.
Not to be missed. If you came to London to avoid history then don't go. British history is embodied in this building. It is worth the price of admission and included in the London Pass.

Historic building. I attended a service here. Had visited before, many years ago. This is a large and beautiful building with a lot of history. Would have liked to spend time looking round afterwards but we were not permitted to venture into the choir/altar area, and anyway were going to another event. This visit has made me want to go back and spend more time.

Place one should visist. The magnificent abbey is a must on the list of places to be visited in London.The magnificent construction represents the culture of the place.People interested in English Literature would should visit the place where well known writers and poets have been laid to rest.The service if audio guide is available with which one can see and understand the place.
Spectacular . This was the highlight of my trip to London (this time anyway). Well worth the price - use a Rail tickets and get half price with a friend!
full of history. Takes quite a long time to see everything, theres a lot more history her than i expected, did not know about all the tombs at the front of the cathedral

Like a cemetary. It is an overwhelming historical cemetery and memorial to thousands of dead people. The wait to enter was only about 20 minutes, and the visit took us about 2 hours. It is a beautiful place, but really it is a glorified cemetery.

Magnificent in every way. I knew very little about Westminster Abbey prior to my visit. I had seen the Royal Weddings, etc on TV, but did not really understand the breadth and beauty of this amazing place. It is the most astounding place that I have ever visited. The history, the architecture and the glory that is held captive, trapped in time in this holy sanctuary is more than words can describe. The only problem is that you cannot take pictures inside the abbey. I understand why they don't allow it, but I would have spent an entire day just trying to capture the essence of it on film. A place that everyone should experience in their lifetime.

Don't be the 'ugly American'. People who give this a 1 or 2 for reasons such as: couldn't see the church because a program was going on, or not enough chairs, or couldn't go to the restroom, church should be opened all the time, simply need to stay home. This is a church and a venue for programs. Check the times and programs at any venue. Take care of yourself and your needs BEFORE you go to visit ANY place. Think ahead! Don't be so ego-centric, as the 'pastor' from Omaha. No, we couldn't visit the inside either because a church service was in progress. We returned the next day and a concert was about to start, but the staff did their best to get in as many people as possible. At another church I had to step outside and go find a restroom. I did NOT expect the staff to cater to my every need. That said, Westminster has been and remains very high on any list of things to see in London. Go when the church is open for tourists and stay several hours.

Truly amazing. This was a beautiful church. On the self-guided tour, we had access to so many areas of historical significance. We bought tickets and were told that we'd get to avoid the lines when we arrived and this was not true, though the lines moved very quickly and we did not feel rushed at all in the Abbey. Do check online for closures, as the Abbey is used for services regularly.

If you enjoy seeing lots and lots and lots of crypts where very old and very famous people are buried...... We enjoyed realizing how old some of the crypts were, but honestly, once you've seen so many crypts....The architecture is fabulous.

WOW!. I can't believe how amazing this historic abbey is. My family could have stayed there for another couple of hours. There is so much to learn and so many great historians buried there. The history alone is something to spend hours learning. Highly recommend when your in London.

A must see for history lovers. This is something you can't miss while you are visiting London, but be prepared for large crowds in close quarters. Also, DON'T take pictures inside the abbey or they will threaten to throw you out (we didn't realize this wasn't allowed until someone came over to us and spoke to us rather sternly). Burial place for many kings/queens and political figures, and of course the Poet's Corner.

More Than Any Expectations!!!. Do not miss a chance to visit the most intriguing church in the world!!! Utterly fascinating!!! It is one of those places that everyone should visit at least once in a life time!!! Look out for famous tombs like Sir Isaac Newton... priceless!!!

Stunning . I was blown away! Had low expectations and was completely pumped after the visit!This is a must see attraction!First, don't buy tickets from the London Pass company or Hop on Hop off booths. They claim to allow 'skipping' the lines and give you a quicker entrance....not the case. As I was told, by employees, you need to purchase your ticket from the Abbey website and print it. That said, the line moves rather quickly.I had no idea there were tombs inside including legendary names such as 'King Henry the VII' and Charles Darwin. The coronation chair is amazing to see...what history. The audio guide is worth the purchase, otherwise, you're just looking at things.
Abbey visit. Definitely worth a visit. The free audio guide was very interesting and informative. It takes an hour or two to see it all, so allow time to explore.

Touching beauty!. How can you not be moved in such a spiritual place? The history of this place is incredible. The narration on the tour recorders is very informative. Take your time and listen to all of it.

Westminster Abbey. Beautiful church. Easy to get around. Bought our tickets from their website ahead of time. We were given headsets upon arrival to tell the history & walk you through the Abbey. Highly recommend!

Just loved it!!!. We started our tour of Westminister Abbey in their café. We had some drinks and some people were serving high tea. It was quite interesting. There is so much to see inside the Abbey. Set aside at least two hours to see everything and more time if you want do more than just walk through. There is an area where you can sit down and light candles, listen to a choir, or just rest while you look at all the amazing things in that area. The beautiful architecture, the tombs of famous people (including the poets' section which I enjoyed) and the entire atmosphere kept us in awe. You are given audio guides which help you navigate on your own or there are tours offered. There is a lot to see. It is a "must see" when visiting London.

Amazing. Nothing prepares you for Westminster. I have been to Notre Dame, The Berliner Dome, and even St. Paul's (which I love), but nothing has the history of Westminster Abbey. Poets Corner stopped me. The same could be said of numerous other areas. We later came back for a free Organ Recital (I highly recommend) which filled the entire building with music.
Stunning. What is left to say about the abbey? Amazing history, monuments of a rare quality and an interesting museum with royal funeral effigies.

Go To The Bathroom Before Worship. I'm a pastor in the US. We thought it would be cool to worship here. It was. Beautiful and sacred. Preacher was insightful. Then my nine-year-old had to go to the bathroom. While the pastor was talking about worshipping God the staff was treating us like we were an inconvenience. Which apparently we were. I guess they didn't get the little memo about when we welcome a little child we are welcoming Jesus. Or the part where Jesus talked about showing hospitality to strangers. So we couldn't go to bathroom #1 because there was an event going on. They shipped us outside to bathroom #2. We couldn't use that bathroom because the guard said would couldn't. The grumpy bathroom bouncer was kind enough to send us across the street to a bathroom that was locked. Meanwhile...the above mentioned nine-year-old has had a bladder that is ready to burst. We try to get back in the church. I finally talked my way through the security. Then James and John cut us off because worship was going on which was the whole reason we wanted to go back in. We did get to dismiss with the masses which is a euphemism for the guards detaining us from going out the main doors because of an event. They opened God's table to all. Except a visiting pastor and his nine-year-old son.

The best place in London!. My title says it all. I LOVED this place. It had an aura about it that made you feel calm and reflective. I would have gladly have stayed there my entire time in London! Westminster was my favorite place of all the places we visited.
London Landmark. Interesting building , the entrance is quite expensive , and inside are mostly graves of celebrities and kings . Here is the throne on which crowned kings .

Pretty Good Visit but No Pictures. Walked through with wife and BFF. Had not been inside in a while and they have banned camera's. Apparently the selfie stick has ruined it for everyone. OK, that out of the way they replaced the selfie stick with a recorded our so everyone bumps in to you as they are looking around with this thing to their ear, real pain-in-the-butt. BUT still good walk through British history and if you are in London please visit but its well more of a chore than it used to be.

History Buffs!!!!!. On our last day we took the tour inside...it was later in the day so the line wasn't out of control. It is on the pricey end of attractions but you're in London so everything is expensive. No photos are allowed in the abbey but your free to take them in the courtyard. Take the audio tour so you can hear about everyone your looking at. The craftsmanship of the stone work is incredible inside and out!

History Buffs!!!!!. On our last day we took the tour inside...it was later in the day so the line wasn't out of control. It is on the pricey end of attractions but you're in London so everything is expensive. No photos are allowed in the abbey but your free to take them in the courtyard. Take the audio tour so you can hear about everyone your looking at. The craftsmanship of the stone work is incredible inside and out!

Westminister Abbey--iconic London Landmark. This iconic landmark is a must see for those who have watched various British ceremonies emanating from this place, on TV. The tour is pricey, but well worth the expense. It is, self guided, well organized and comes with an earphone/video explanation device, as well as an scavenger-type pamphlet for kids to use as they follow along with the adults on the self-guided tour. We were there in the spring and the crowds were not too bad. The Abbey is the final resting place and/or tribute to many of Britian's most famous figures, from monarchs to literary, to infamous in one way or another. It is well worth a visit. The best time to go is in the morning just after they open up--check the guide books for the correct times.

A church beyond compare.. I have a passion for pipe organs, and the Harrison instrument in the Abbey is incomparable, and aided by the splendid acoustics of this extraordinary building. We have heard a number of Evensong services, and also attended the Advent Service. All were free. If you wish to take photos inside the church, you can only do so as part of a tour, for which there is an admission fee. This is an attraction that should not be missed.

Amazing!. Each time I visit I am amazed! It is most definitely worth the entry fee. Take your time. Save at least 3 hours to take in the numerous burial plots and statues. You will not be disappointed.
The Abbey. We did not do the "skip the line ticket" and we only had a 10 minute wait. We were fortunate to hear a guest choir singing and hear the wonderful organ. It was magical.

Beautiful . It is a beautiful old church with so much history attached to it. The line up to get in today was enormous and it was only open for a very short time. I balked at the £20 entrance fee but that seems consistent with Britain's excessively high charges to visit their national icons.

More than my high expectations!. Do not miss a chance to visit the most famous church in the world! I went in expecting a lot and was blown away! It is one of those places that everyone should visit at least once.

Beautiful exteriors. I haven't been inside to this amazing church actually, but if the interiors are anything like the exterior then I have no choice but to recommend this place! Near to many other attractions as well.

probably my favourite gothic architecture. I first visited almost three years ago during summer so there were many tourists, and again this year in February when there's relatively generally less people in London. Both visits were amazing. It's so historically rich and important that it'll take you quite a few hours if you'd like to digest all the history from the audio-guide. There's Sir Isaac Newton's tomb. Memorials for many famous artists, musicians (Handel), writers....You many also learn much interesting about England's complicated history with Scotland. There's also one chapel which unfortunately I've forgot the name of it, with spectacular a ceiling, a marvellous demonstration of carving art. I've visited many churches in the UK and Westminster Abbey still holds a special place in my heart.

A touch of history. What my daughter and I loved most about Westminster Abbey was the fact that the building was 1000 years old. We were able to stroll past historic monuments that we had studied in history lessons, or witnessed in television documentaries. As history buffs, visiting this Abbey was a true highlight. I highly recommend buying a hop-on-hop-off ticket as the price of the Abbey is included.

Historic CofE church. I was surprised that the tour of the Abbey was chargeable at £20 for a standard adult ticket, however it's well worth it since there is so much history buried here! Ticket cost also includes an audio guide. The resting place of many former British Monarchs and celebrated personages it was a veritable step back in time. The architecture is magnificent and along with a trip to the National Portrait Gallery, Tudor and Stewart kings and queens almost came to life. It was an extremely enjoyable visit. Queues in April were not bothersome. The afternoons did look quieter.

Wonderful piece of history and architecture. We had 3 nights in London after a cruise and decided to visit Westminster Abbey. On the advice of the hotel staff we purchased tickets online - tickets are the same price at the venue. We also downloaded the app to our smartphone so were able to listen to the guide/commentaries with our earbuds instead of the phone-like devices they give you upon entrance. Many spots are very close and with so many people it looked difficult to have to hold the device to your ear all the time. Also with tickets purchased online, we skipped the long cue to buy tickets so saved at least 30 minutes. We did the tour on a Monday and be sure to double check online because they do not allow visitors while there is a service going on.

Expensive. £20 per person. Would recommend that you get a Two for One via the Train Line or elsewhere. Very crowded so difficult to follow the talking aid. Not suitable for pushchairs or young persons. Lots of dead people, if you know what I mean. £10 eack OK, £20 to expensive, not worth it.
Westminster Abbey. History of London is here!A nice place to see London from another POV, must visit this place if only for 1 time.

Incredible building. Simply wonderful building with fantastic hidden gems in every corner, excellent guides who where very helpful and informative, I was very fortunate to witness the RAMC turning of the pages ceremony whilst I was there, very poignant indeed. A great cafe and gift shop on site as well, a very worthwhile visit.

Beautifulél architecture. It is pretty expensiv to visit this majestic church. It is a legendary historical monument, but still in use for very special occasions. You can take your time to see the details of the architecture.

History at it's best!!. This is a "don't miss" activity.....even though we had the London Pass, we still had to wait in line for about a half hour...it was a little confusing when we first got into the church and picked up our headphones, but once we got settled, it was an amazing experience, walking up the church aisles where so many historical events had taken place. I was also surprised by how many kings and queens were actually buried in the church. FABULOUS!!

1,000's of Dead. It's one of the most impressive buildings in London. The history is quite stunning. I confess I found the idea of walking on top of the deceased a bit disrespectful but with 1,000's buried there it is nigh impossible to avoid. The guided tour was interesting but our younger children lost interest quickly. All on the main level. Don't open any wooden trap doors on the floor unless you want a stern talking to from security.
A Must Do Item. I could spend many hours in Westminster Abbey. The history of the place is amazing. Spend the extra 5 pounds and get a Verger tour...it is worth every penny.
Beautiful. A beautiful church for sure. The only detractor for us was the number of people there. It really takes away from your ability to enjoy any of these great sites.

AMAZING. Amazingly beautiful. Another London icon that is a MUST visit site for the London tourist. Be prepared....no pictures allowed in the Abbey itself but you may use your camera in the cloisters which are beautiful in their own right
Wonderful!. Ohhhhh, if you can't catch a service here, come in the evening when the Organ concerts are given. A must see experience for all!

wow - surrounded by history. One of the great walking tours of the world - so much history to soak in. extremely worthwhile. You get a glimpse of 1000 years of history and look at the Royal family involvement with the Abbey
Surprising amount of history. Its by far one of the most well organized tourist sites in London with an ear piece to take you step by step into this giant spectacular church with lots of tombs in it
A must. Lots of crowds here, but it us certainly worth a visit. A nice school and courtyard is tucked in behind it too though access is limited.
Wonderful Histroic Abbey. We were fortunate to be able to attend the 2016 Anzac Day Service and how beautiful that was. Such a sense of history and so ornate.

Spectacular, but not this visit. They changed the time of last admission by 2 1/2 hrs. to 1:00 pm. No notice outside. We missed it. Check on the website for early closures. It was posted, but we only looked at the regular hours in a guide book . Disappointed because it is magnificent.
beautiful!. We were glad we got an audio guide. There was so much too see and miss if you weren't looking in the right place. I loved the history and just standing in the glory of it all.

Iconic piece of London's history. Of all the thing my wife and I saw in London, Westminster Abbey was by far our favorite. This church is as much a cemetery as a place of worship, with many alcoves full of ornate tombs covered in amazing artwork. So full in fact that it gets a little crowded in places. The Lady Chapel is particularly gorgeous. Do Not Miss It! The only drawback is that there is no photography allowed in the abbey except for in the gardens.

Westminster Eucharist Service. Westminster Abbey is lauded for architecture, history, and burials. But it's still a place of worship, and everyone is invited to their Sunday services. The queue for entry moved quickly during my visit, and everyone was given an English version of the order of service, including music and responses.I was in awe of how the acoustics enhanced the music and singing. Eucharist was open to all who partake at their home church.A bust of William Blake stared at me throughout the service, and some of the folding chairs were on top of commemorative stones. I was seated in Poet's Corner, yet I didn't realize it until I left. I'll return another day to explore the area.Friendly yet firm guides asked visitors to return Monday through Saturday when services are not held. Yet all are invited to Evensong, held nearly every late afternoon.Not to be missed, and participating in the service lets me truthfully say, "I sang at Westminster Abbey!"
Little bit of history . As you enter tomb of the on known soldier and centuries of history old graves of famous people I attended one of the services as well was nice

Take Your Time. I'm a Humanist but also have a deep interest in art and architecture so regularly visit religious buildings. Obviously I ignore the business going on and all that but take your time to really look around, down and up. Take your time. The skeletons in the study saying 'As I am so you will be' is a message for everyone. The carving around the main door is amazing. The Devil (who doesn't exist) is in the detail.
Vacation . Beautiful Church with fabulous history . Definitely tour it while in London ! The hand held audio players where great to tour the Abby and learn about all the memorials .

Just steeped in History. We should have booked on line first - do check opening times as it was only open for 2 hrs on the day we visited which was just enough to get round. A £20 entry fee may seem steep but it was well worth it. The hand held commentary was great, just the perfect amount of detail.

History and reverence together. This was on my must see list and it was well worth the visit. So many the world's who's who have been buried or remembered here and so many important events have taken place here. the location is spectacular and the stained glass windows are truely works of art.

THIS IS A MUST!. There is no wonder why Westminster Abbey welcomes over one million visitors every year, and I'm proud to finally be one of those. I have wanted to visit since I was a kid, having been a history junkie from an early age. It is an absolute must for those who love history, architecture or all things ecclesiastical. They do not come more impressive than this, and there is little wonder why this is the coronation church of England.Audio guides are free with individual entry tickets and also available as a download from the App Store on your smartphone so take your headphones. The tour takes around one hour. The English-language tour is narrated by the delicious Jeremy Irons.Every monarch since William the Conqueror has been crowned here, with the exception of Edward V who was murdered beforehand, and Edward VIII who abdicated because of his love for Mrs. Simpson.The magnificent tiled sanctuary is the iconic centrepiece of the Abbey and is stage for coronations, royal weddings and funerals.The British monarchs that have been interred here, are as follows:-• St Edward the Confessor and his wife, Edith of Wessex (St Edward was the founder of the Abbey)• Henry III of England• Edward I of England and his wife, Eleanor of Castile• Edward III of England and his wife, Philippa of Hainault• Richard II of England and his wife, Anne of Bohemia• Henry V of England and his wife, Catherine of Valois• Edward V of England• Anne Neville, wife of Richard III• Henry VII of England and his wife, Elizabeth of York• Edward VI of England• Anne of Cleves, wife of King Henry VIII• Mary I of England• Elizabeth I of England• James VI & I of Scotland England and Ireland and his wife, Anne of Denmark• Charles II of England and Scotland• Mary II of England and Scotland• William III of England and II of Scotland• Anne, Queen of Great Britain and her husband, Prince George of Denmark• George II of Great Britain and his wife, Caroline of Ansbach• Mary, Queen of Scots, mother of James VI & IPoets' Corner is the resting place of Chaucer, Dickens, Hardy, Tennyson, Dr Johnson and Kipling, as well as Handel and Sir Isaac Newton.Interesting Fact: In the 19th century researchers were looking for the tomb of James I, because he had gone walkies and nobody knew where he was. During their search they opened the vault containing the remains of Elizabeth I and her half-sister, Mary I of England (who had the then Princess Elizabeth imprisoned in the Tower). Both lead coffins were founded stacked, with Elizabeth's resting on top of Mary's.James I was finally found... in the vault of Henry VII.
Imponent. Super interesting to admire the grandiosity of the Abbey, look for tombs of famous people, and imagine yourself getting married to a prince!
Lovely. Definitely a must see in London. Worth the admission cost. There is so much history at this place. It was crowded but the line moved at a steady pace.

Tour. This place holds a lot of history, it was absolutely beautiful inside and the guides are very helpful. It has a number of stairs and can get very busy inside. Even though the line up was to the footpath next to the road, we didn't have to wait very long to get in.You can do a self guided tour with earphones if you wish.

Awesome. The history and atmosphere are breathtaking, and whether you believe or not, there's something deeply spiritual and humbling about the place. It's hard to grasp that so many figures from British history have their last resting place in the abbey - that's actually them beneath those plinths and flagstones.The only thing I struggle with, as I do in all Cathedrals etc, is having to pay an admission fee. It brings to mind Jesus in the temple with the money lenders. I'd happily donate to the upkeep, but I do resent being forced to pay: it's taken 10 years to persuade me to go inside!

Just wonderful.. . I did not get an online ticket this time and it only took my half an hour to wait to get in, that was a pleasant surprise! And that on a busy Saturday afternoon. Inside is just amazing, all the tombs and graves and all the sculptures they made to commemorate the dead. Audiotour was free and worth trying out to get more information about all the famous people there. It was a bit crowdy though but still the number one "attraction" in London for me.Inside it was not allowed to take pictures and I have honoured that, only have a picture from the outside.

So much history!. I was not prepared for the magnitude of the experience at Westminster Abbey. The architecture is very impressive. I was overwhelmed with the name of those who were buried there. So many great people. And to walk through this building where so many christenings, coronations, funerals, and weddings have been held is a solemn experience. Amazing place!

An Iconic Piece of History in London. Westminster Abbey is one of the places you just have to visit when in London. It is a magnificent piece of architecture and rich in history. You can see the Abbey during a stroll along the Embankment and see many other iconic London landmarks while you're at it. Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, #10 Downing Street, the London Eye and others.

Take the Guided Verger Tour!. This place is FILLED with important history, and a guided tour is the best way to understand and see it all. I'm so glad we spent the extra 5 pounds and did it. With the free audio tour, I felt like it would be very overwhelming and disorganized. The tour also allows you to go into some areas that aren't usually open to the public. Overall, it was an unforgettable experience.
Beautiful and tons of history!. You can't miss a visit to Westminster Abbey if you are visiting London. So beautiful and so much history. The audio guide is quite good.

Spectacular . One of the most beautiful sights I've ever had the honor of seeing with my own eyes. This is definitely a "must see" if in London. The architecture, the history....it just doesn't get better. I could not recommend seeing this more!

Impressive . Not a fast thing to do but so glad we waited in line & went. The structure is amazing & the history & stories of some buried there were interesting. Free audio tour was nice although finding some of the numbers was difficult. Some of our best souvenirs were purchased at their tiny gift shop. Thankful for nice restrooms available at the conclusion.

True history and workmanship . Lovely church with a deep rich history. We were there at night and to see it all lit up is a real treat. As you tour the grounds you can almost feel the waves of royals and famous folks that have been here before. There was music coming from within and it made for a great experience.

We went to a service on Saturday afternoon, totally stumbled upon it!. We are Catholic and weren't sure about attending the service, but it was so nice! We were able to sit there while the music was playing and enjoy looking around at the beauty of the abbey. It was about a 1 hour service. We did not have to pay to enter.
