The whole area is so nice, a short walk to Big Ben and the London Eye. Keep in mind that the area can get very congested!

Beautiful. Really amazing to see this in person. Just gorgeous inside. Very awesome narrated self guided tour handset. Pretty neat seeing a lot of old tombs of some very famous British people. It was quite busy on a Saturday though, which is not uncommon from what we found out. Make sure you buy your tickets ahead of time and print off the tickets and bring with you, will save you so much time by not having to stand in the queue. Definitely a must visit while in London.

A great tour through British history. I was prepared for the spectacular architecture but not all of the people buried or memorialized here. Tour through the Abby you are reminded or many great figures from politics, science and the arts.
Impressive. Very impressive historical construction, we didn't enter the abbey due to lack of time, must visit place

Historical place. I would recommend this tour only of you are interested in history in general. With the help of the audio guides you will be able to learn a lot of this place. For me there were too many information at the time. However I was amazed by the architecture and all the decorations found inside.
Historical interest and so much more!. Do need a guide as there is so much to see and do. Don't be distracted by other visitors. Take your time.

Awe Inspiring. We lucked out and got into the Abbey with no time spend on lineups. We rode the Hop on Hop Off bus past the venue 3 times. The first two times we didn't bother to get off the bus as the lineups were incredibly long. The third time by the Abbey, there were no lineups at all so we jumped off the bus and walked right in. We used our London Pass so we were covered for the entrance fees. The Abbey was overwhelmingly beautiful and we could have spent far more than the precious hour we were able to spend there. My favorite stops were to see the crypts of half sisters, Queen Elizabeth I and Mary Tudor, and their cousin Mary, Queen of Scots (beheaded on the order of Elizabeth I) entombed directly across from Elizabeth I on the other side of the Abbey. Religiously and historically the Abbey is a must-see but to avoid lines plan for first visit in the morning or later in the afternoon. TIP: buy the guidebook as you won't remember a third of what you see. Also use the commentary headset to get the most of your tour.

Family vacation. If you have never been, nothing will prepare you enough for the grandeur, reverence and history captured in this magnificent structure. Return visits are highly recommended as well, since there is enough here to warrant many hours of observation and appreciation.We went late on a rainy afternoon and the lineup to get in was about 15 minutes. Interior space crowds were light except in some of the small chapels. London Pass users have to queue with everyone else until you get a ticket. Having tickets in advance (pre purchased) will scoot you to the front of the line. Audio guides (20 stations - no #13!?) are very helpful for locations of interest inside (no photos permitted).Hourly prayers (very short) help preserve the sanctity of this magnificent Abbey!

Never seen anything like it.. I truly have never seen any building, any where that is as amazing as this one. There aren't words for the beauty of the building or the incredible history in it. If you visit, don't skip the audio tour because without it, you will never have the full experience because the stories and details are so wonderful.
Be for yourself . A nice place to visit Peace and calmful Daily sermons going on Must see place in London. Shows Aldo the tombs of earlier Kings and also scientists who were buried there

Easy Way To Lose Yourself In History. I love history. My husband, not as much. That being said, we lost ourselves inside of the Abbey and were shocked, when we realized that we had been there for three solid hours. My husband thoroughly enjoyed all aspects of our self-guided tour. You can go at your own pace, and we were able to arrive in time for mass. My sister had been diagnosed with an we, the week we were departing on our London excursion, so I lit a candle for her, and filled out a prayer request card, on her behalf. There were so many small chapels, to explore and the number of people who were laid to rest there was amazing. To stand in the area where Lady Dianna had married Prince Charles & to see the very spot & chair that H M Queen Elizabeth (and countless others) had used for her coronation, left me in awe. Don't miss walking around the outside. I adore gargoyles and the number and variety was exciting!

Wonderful place to visit. Westminster Abbey is a must for people who are visiting our country or for indeed people who live here, we loved it and know it's definitely a must to put on your to do list, loved it

An amazing historical abbey. The abbey itself is grand and beautiful. It has been the site for crowning the kings and queens of Britain for most of a thousand years. But the part that is most amazing is the east end of the abbey with the tombs and memorials to about every famous British person in history. But be aware that it will cost you about $35 each for the privilege. It was worth it to us but it might not be for everyone. You can go in the Abbey free for daily services but you won't be allowed to roam through the tombs and memorials. And don't think you will just wander off on your own for free. The Abbey docents (police) are not congenial. In fact they are downright rude.
Breathtaking. Such a beautiful place, words aren´t enough.20 pounds entrance fee, includes audio guide.Beautiful graves of many poets, kings and queens and the unknown soldier.

The abbey is best with a paid tour leader. Well worth paying extra to have a paid guide. Our was funny and able to show things not on the audio guide. Very educational tour. Would also recommend attending a evening service which is free and then able to hear the choir and organ.

A must see in London. So much history in one building. Have been back several times.Go early, it gets very crowded. After, walk down to the Thames totake in the view. (one block away) then walk to Churchill War rooms museum, then relax over lunch, at one of the many restaurants in the area.
Amazing. Took the audio tour through the Abbey and it was great. The history of the building and those buried here is a "who's who list" of many important people in England's history.

Absolutely beautiful building inside and out. I was astounded by the beauty of the building. I especially liked the ceilings. I am totally amazed by the fact that such workmanship could be accomplished without modern tools!
Must see!. The self guided tour was a remarkable thing to see. You are invited to stay for services later in the day as well.

Overwhelming!. As a first time visitor to Europe, I was completely overwhelmed by Westminster Abbey. It's hard to believe that people built this so long ago. We had a London Travel Pass so we were able to get in for free. we had to stand in line outside to get in and get a ticket. Even though we had a pass we still had to show it to get a ticket. We took that ticket to get an audio guide and then we got started. Tip: restrooms are in the cloisters.

Don't be a tourist!. I have been to Westminster Abbey on previous trips. This time I attended a Sunday morning communion service. I was very surprised that there were no more then 30 persons at the service. I felt blessed to be there for this intimidate moment and I felt very humbled to receive communion in this great church.
Awesome experience. If you are in London you can't miss Westminster Abbey. There is so much history in every square inch of this place. Plan a whole afternoon to see everything.

I felt as though I was standing on sacred ground. After we left London, we asked ourselves what attractions we would advise others to see. The Abbey was Number 1 on our list. Kings are buried here, historic figures are prominently mentioned in every square foot of the building and the architecture is exquisite. You can't take pictures inside so be sure to buy the guidebook and take a tour if you can. You will spend several hours here and wonder where the time went. There are worship services here as well during the week, we wish we could have gone to them. You'll be left with the feeling that for just a moment you walked on the same stones as those people whose achievements influenced the development of world history.

Take the Verger Tour - More history per square foot than just about anywhere in the Western World. So yes it's not cheap. We paid £20 admission for two using the our National Rail TravelCard two for one coupon and we each paid £5 for the Verger Tour. £30 for two was well worth it. The Verger will take you places in the abbey that you won't be able to access yourself using the audio guide (which is also good and downloadable on your iOS or Android device in advance). Arrive as close to opening time as possible during the week, not the weekends. Sign up with the Verger to attend the Evensong Service at 5pm and use the day to deeply explore Westminster Abbey or the other sights nearby (Winston War Rooms,Parliament, Royal Horse Guards Parade, St. James Park for example)
Beautiful. This was my second time here. The first time was over 30 years ago and I was still amazed !! Got to go if you're in London.

An Incredible Place to Visit. Besides being beautiful, this is the final resting place of many. I had no idea for instance that Charles Darwin is buried here. There is also a tribute to an unknown soldier from WW1. It's a definite place to visit on a trip to London.

Beautiful Sanctuary. A beautiful cathedral. Here you are given phones for the audio and you do the tour at your own pace. There are corresponding numbers for the different points of interest which you put into the audio. Even purchasing tickets ahead of time does not get you fast tracked into the Abbey. It is a place you definitely should visit, especially the Poets' Corner.

Verger Tour highly suggested!. It had been some years since my last visit to Westminster. Two things that are important, they now charge £20 to enter and NO PICTURES can be taken inside. I suggest a minimum of three-four hours as it seemed to be an extremely popular site and was packed full of people (Saturday visit). The audio tour is nice to do on your own, but let me recommend the Verger tour (approx. 90-120 mins). A Verger is someone who works in the church and helps make the church work smoothly as such. They help with services and other responsibilities. You can tell them apart from other guides by their black long verger gown. It is an extra £5 added to the £20, but well worth it as you will learn more and get to go into areas others cannot. The tours are limited to 20 people per tour, so as soon as you get into the Abbey, check at the information desk for the next possible tour. We got there at 12:30 and still hadn't seen everything by 4:30 p.m. With the Verger Tour, you are invited to Evening Song and the Verger will get you seats in a prime area. Another must do. The music and voices is heavenly. Take your time and look at every little detail of the Abbey. Well worth the £25 for the visit.
Another Must See. Did this tour with some people that had been to London before and had not seen the Abbey; they wre all impressed and wondered why they had not seen it on earlier trips
Beautiful but crowded. Getting into the church requires around 40 minutes waiting in a line that stretches about 2 blocks. I didn't go in because of it but the architecture alone is worth a see.

Wonderfully preserved.. From the time Jeremy Irons comes through the speaker (free) the experience is unparalleled. It's quite daunting to see burial plots of people you have only read about in study. Sad to see Michael Faraday obscured by a folding chair !

Get a tour guide - there is so much to learn about. Although this is a church, there is so much history here you will enjoy so much more learning all about who and what if you have a tour guide. Plan on a minimum of two and a half to three hours here. It is well worth your time.

Quite an impressive tour. We visited late in the day, just as rain was setting in. The tour includes a self guided audio transmission. As we wandered through the church, you are reminded of the history surrounding many of its patrons. The beauty of the structure is worth your visit.
Impressed and easy. So much history and amazing amounts of historic figures buried there is impressive. Kings, Queens , Darwin, Shakespeare!

Amazing landmark!. Busy place - get there early! We had a wonderful visit/tour. As an American, watched many events on TV held at Westminster Abbey. Nothing compares to experiencing it in person. As I walked down the isle - envisioned Princess Kate walking down during her wedding ceremony. However, do some homework/research before your tour. I really had no idea as to the history/burial grounds of so many. Quite amazing!

Be sure to allow time to take it all in. This is my second trip to The Abbey. Last time I was chaperoning a group of teens and it took less than two hours. This time, my husband I went and spent 5 hours here. To be fair, part of that time was taking part in worship (a ten minute prayer service with 6 others in the Chapel of Edward the Confessor and a half hour communion service) and we are history geeks. Tips: Be sure to get the audio tour (free with admission), it is very informative, get there early, as lines can be long. It opens at 9:30.

A walk down history and absolutely peaceful. If one has studied the monarchs and Kings & Queens of England, this is the place to be, every one of them is buried at the Abbey, a place where all the Royal Weddings have taken place, its absolutely beautiful from the outside and the inside. Ensure you keep a couple of hours for this place, as the lines of visitors can be really long.

Pentecost evensong with procession. What a place to be for Pentecost service. A cathedral full of (royal) atmosphere. During an evensong you participate thru your presence and listening to the liturgy which is sung by the choire of the abbey. Enjoy the sound body and get infused by the spirit of the place.

Westminster Blues. The blues start as early as the lines, long but are efficiently guided, you pay £20 for entrance and audioguide, you move along the lines and marked interest points. You see amazing statuary marking the graves of people you know nothing about, but have shaped England. It's dirty-looking and Gothic and old and relevant only l if you wish to understand a bit more of the thoughts of kinghood and empire ie: the need to rest stately and be remembered for grand things. It's a thousand year old mausoleum that functions as a transient's church. Where the oldest graves are disintegrating lumps and can't be touched for fear of collapse and the newest ones can be gaudy and as far from a spiritual monument as a Hollywood prop. It remembers the masses and the sacrifice to a righteous cause (the Unknown Soldier) and memorializes singular genius (Newton) in and among those who may have bought themselves niches in history. I don't know for sure, but it's human nature is it not? It's interesting, when you think about it you will be hard pressed to see past the spectacle and the reminders of finite time to a place of hope....I doubt if it will lift you up at all, despite all the achievements & gravitas and pageantry mori. I'm not saying it won't but for me it made this clear : our time ends, marble & history encased or not. And then you run out of buttons to push and you shuffle out...but before you walk through the glass you see a small American eagle looking fierce in a corner, away from the ages of kings and hallowed places. He is part if FDR's commemorative plaque as a friend of Great Britain. Odd, but for me, he (the eagle, not FDR) was the only thing there untouched by age...he looked alive and new and unwilling to rest stately at all. Fierce. But maybe that's because he was near the door and in the light and my mind had had enough of my moroseness.Of course, Westminster Abbey has to be seen..the above review notwithstanding, Thank God.

Evensong. We visited evensong on Sunday at 3 pm. The service was 1 hour with beautiful singing and traditional organ music that is dark and ominous but typical for evensong. I always expect to see Dracula when I hear this demonic sound but it seems to be part of Evensong. There are tv monitors so you can catch a sideways glimpse of the all male choir as they sit facing each other in rightened and white choral robes. The Abbey is amazing in its over the top architecture.
Old Church. All the tombs of kings and queens with their stories and peculiarities. Good to see. Not very good looking.

Know Your History First. If you are going to Westminster Abbey, you should know your British/English history, especially regarding the royal families! The abbey really serves as a graveyard for the royal families. Although it was beautiful and I learned quite a bit from the audioguide, most of the significance was lost on me and I felt a little uncomfortable walking over and around the dead.

Tried to Attend Evensong Service... Tip to visitors: Check the website the day you plan to visit! When we arrived to attend Evensong service we found out it had been moved to an alternate location. Unfortunately, it was our last day in London so we were unable to attend on a different day.

Closed days, open days, closing time, opening time. We had a good packed lunch in the ground so I shall forgive the fact that due to its closing time we did not get to go inside. Otherwise am sure that would have been interesting.

We didn't go in. But..... Apart from the long que. We refused to pay the pricey admittance fee. Great architecture from the outside, & the location is in the same area as, Houses of Parliament, Whitehall, Downing Street etc.

Beautiful and so historic. We visited Westminster Abbey during a short, four-day trip to London. If we had done nothing else during our trip, visiting Westminster would have made the trip worthwhile. This is the building in which British royalty has been married for centuries. Kate and William were married here. The only royals to break tradition and get married at St. Paul's Cathedral are Charles and Diana. The audio tour is very complete and discusses so many interesting points. The docents are extremely knowledgeable and helpful. It is obvious that they all love their jobs. The interior of the building is beautiful, although the stone walls are dirtier than I expected from the touch of visitors over the centuries. One could spend a full day reading the memorials and discovering the names of people who are buried there. The graves for Darwin and Newton are quite obvious. One must pass through the archway where they are buried to go from the entrance of the abbey to the altar. One section contains the graves of famous literary figures. I would not have wanted to miss visiting Westminster Abbey.A bit of advice, the line of visitors gets very long. Order and pay for tickets online before your visit. This allows one to go to the head of the line rather than waiting for an hour or longer.

Amazing Architecture. This is a must see for all visitors to London. So much history it's almost too much to take in! We liked that we were able to do the tour in our own time. Also really enjoyed the Cloisters restaurant for lunch.
Worth the Visit. I am so glad we did this stop. The Abby is a beautiful English Gothic church. You may be surprised that it seems more like a graveyard of the rich and famous of England.
Inside or Outside. A great photo opp type of place. You can also go inside. Be aware that there is usually a queue for that, but if you are a history buff, it's worth the wait.

Wow!. We got there about 20 minutes after opening time and already the queue was out onto the pavement. However, don't be put off by this - access is very efficient and we were in within about 10 minutes. The architecture is absolutely stunning and there is so much to see you could spend many hours here. It is like walking through the last thousand years of the country's history, as you see the burial and memorial places of monarch's, nobility and many other famous historical figures. I found the tomb of the unknown soldier particularly poignant and other highlights included poets corner and the coronation chair. The free audio guides are definitely worth using, giving a wealth of information as you pass through the different areas of the abbey.Tip: as we had travelled to London by train we were able to download a voucher from GWR giving us 2 for 1 entry!

Must See!. Well worth going. No photography allowed but it's an amazing piece of living history as its still a functioning church. The names that are buried and memorialized within those walls are amazing. Kings, Queens, Dukes, Duchesses, scientists, artists, etc. I was amazed at the work, money, extravagance of the memorials built for those within the walls

History galore.. Even though they asked a hefty price for entrance you need to see this historic place. Do not forget to look down or you miss out on many pieces of history. Kings, poets, statesmen they are all here.

A Must Tour Inside. This along with St Paul's are must tours inside. It is worth the time to walk inside and really absorb the history in London.
Until this visit, I was not aware that the UK has their own religion and broke away from the Catholic Church.
Non the less, very interesting!!

Good Audio Tour with clear instructions. I am not religious but found the Abbey quite overwhelming, with the tomb of the unknown soldier, poets, politicians, and royals entombed the history was fascinating.
I also enjoyed learning about the coronation chair and all those who have sat in it. The cloisters were beautiful and I wish I could have taken photos throughout but totally understand why not.

Impressive . Yes, it is a lot of tombs and memorials, however it is the resting place of counts, barons, viscounts, Knights, Kings and Queens.
Give yourself enough time to read the scripts and memorials.
The free audio guides are very helpful and enhance your visit.

Must see. Worth queuing for and paying admission. Make sure you get audio guide (included in admission price) to enhance experience as you learn lots of interesting things that is not obvious from walking around Also stop for cake and coffee, cake in cafe was lovely.

Very majestic. Huge, incredible architecture, tombs that are works of art, and ancient articles throughout, this is an iconic building. The site of coronations (there hasn't been one in my lifetime and I'm in my 50's!), royal weddings and funerals, its one of those places we've all seen, so seeing it in person is really fascinating. We went in May and bought our tickets on the way in and the wait was minimal. Go!

Great education visit. I took my 2 school children here during the holidays as they have been getting interested in History. We were all amazed by it all. The loved seeing where kings and queens were buried and where they had been married. You can easily spend hours here. It was very busy when we went and it was on a Monday when most people were back at school, maybe a little too busy with the kids as it was hard to get close to see some bits. The staff were very friendly, approachable and helpful, especially when my son needed the toilet and we couldn't find it, it was a little hidden. The court yard area was beautiful. An all round interesting visit. The entrance fee was a little higher than anticipated.

A must for all visitors. Although we didn't go in this time in London, we've been inside before, it's just amazing, the architecture is just amazing in and out, you can just feel the history all around you, we diid!! It's also a great location to get to other famous locations by foot or the street bikes you can hire, we do ,and it's a great fun way to get around. If you found this helpful, I'd appreciate your tick, thanks and have a great trip

Catherdral Beyond Compare. We have seen many life cycle events held and broadcast on TV. This site has more people buried in it that I could have ever imagined. Dating back to the 1300's and the last human burial in 1920, there is rich history and beauty in this most famous Church.

Wonderful staff. I love a bit of history, especially London history. And Westminster Abbey doesn't disappoint. With so many graves and tombs to look at of our historical greats and then the beauty of the buiding itself - wonderful! Best of all, was the staff, so friendly and informative. One older male member took us and our children (on a home education visit) totally under his wing and told us so many interesting things and was just generally extremely pleasant, he really enhanced our visit.
A must-visit ( our 2nd).. Go early, they begin at 9:30. Take your time and don't be hurried. Always a disappointment to not be able to photograph this beautiful monument:(
Beautiful. You must visit Westminster Abbey! Should be on your Life Bucket List! Budget several hours for a comprehensive visit - and also attend a service or two. Just amazing!

Gorgeous Church. We bought our tickets online so we avoided the lines. An audio guide is included and does a good job. You cannot take pictures inside the abbey.
The church is beautiful and there is a lot of history there. There are interesting sculptures and art work. And many famous people, other than royals, are buried there.
Beautiful building. I thought "another old church" but I was wrong. Big and beautiful with so many interesting stories. Really appreciated the unknown warrior grave.

Stunning sacred space. There are more royals buried here than people that lived in my hometown growing up. The stained glass windows are remarkable. Particularly liked the Royal Air Force Chapel and cathedral close. It is significantly larger than what one sees in coverage of royal events in the cathedral. This was my number one choice to visit while in London and I was more than pleasantly surprised.

Magnificent royal place of worship. Beyond the facts that is probably the most important British cathedral and that is the place where many royal weddings, coronations and funerals took place,the abbey is impressive again by its architecture and diverse interior.Another good reason to visit is that inside are many personalities' tombs, including Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Rudyard Kipling and many others, including royalties.Unfortunately, taking photos is not allowed inside.

Heavenly. During our week-long stay in London, we were blessed with the opportunity to experience the visiting Sistine Chapel Choir sing within the hallowed walls of Westminster Abbey. It was quite an event because of the confluence of Catholic and Anglican faiths. Sunday evening services are free to the public; depending on the performance/guest(s), the line could grow long. But visiting Westminster Abbey at this time for this special event and to know the history of the building and behold the beauty of the structure and and solemnity of its permanent residents . . . simply ethereal.

Awesome Historical Church. Westminster Abbey has lots of tales to tell held inside. The audio guide is very informative and you can go as in depth as you'd like at each point. Go at your own pace and relax. No pictures makes it tough, but this is a place of worship, so respect and quiet is needed.

Find out when it isn't crowded and go then. You can't visit London and NOT got to Westminister Abbey. So we went and spent about 1 hour walking at the pace of the audio tour. It got so crowded in some locations and the signage wasn't always clear about where to walk, so there were definitely bottlenecks. It is absolutely beautiful and the history on the audio tape about the people memorialized and buried here is a necessary companion.

Most beautiful church in England. Westminster Abbey is a breathtaking structure from the outside and inside. Take a tour so you can learn about the history of the space and all the people who've been buried, married, or otherwise honored at the church. If you come in the evening, you can attend Evensong (but no cameras and you must be respectful. It is a church service, after all). Guards will ask you when you're in line if you're there for the service, and any other answer will get you kicked out of line. It's worth multiple visits to take it all in.

Worth a stop. Very beautiful architecture and the inside is stunning. Where it's across from Big Ben you have to pop over for a visit. We've seen some beautiful churches such as National Cathedral in DC, but still enjoyed this visit.

A must see for the entire family!. This was our second visit to the Westminster Abbey and our teenagers first - 12 and 14 years olds. Much to our surprise they really enjoyed the self guided tour- and they are not the kids who enjoy museums and such. It is breathtaking, interesting and audio tour is easy to follow. I highly recommend you visit !!!
If you love history this is a must. The intricacies of the carvings and the encrypted members of the monarchy make this well worth it. The audio tour provides enough info without being overbearing.
Amazing building!. Absolutely beautiful building containing so much history. Helpful staff and audio guides available. Been here several times and never get bored of it.
Very impressive. I had seen it on tv but to it's very impressive to visit, especially if you are interest in history.

1000 years of history. When I was here 40 years ago, one just walked in. Now there's a fee. But it's worth it. An audio guide is offered at no additional cost. Take one use it. It helps a lot. There's a lot to see here. Don't rush right to Poet's Corner, there's so much more. There really is 1000 years of history here.

In the footsteps of Kings, Queens and centuries of famous people.. Visit London and everywhere will be busy. However few places could offer so many threads of history woven together. From Normans, to Plantagenets, to modern scientists, poets and politicians, they are all here. The architecture spans centuries. As you tread the worn flag stones, you feel part of that continuous arc of history.There is so much to see. We have been with and without children and enjoyed it both times. Definitely get the audio guides. They are informative and our three pre-teens were glued to them absorbing every word. Desperate to identify where their famous namesakes were laid to rest or commemorated. Despite the crowds there are places where you can enjoy a bit of solitude and take in your surroundings.If you are coming here to see the latest whizz-bang audio visual 3d experience you will be disappointed. If you have any interested in history you cannot fail to be impressed by a thousand years of history packaged into a single experience. Expensive? What isn't in London. For the family it was not much different from a full day travel pass on London Transport, so good value in my view.We would go back again.

All I can say is wow. Amazingly beautiful place...a must see in the UK. Tour is kind of pricey at 20 pounds for adults..but it is really a great visit. I was in awe of the sheer size and majesty of the building. Highly recommended.
Nice place to visit. Good place to get in touch with British history and kingdom. Nice place to see, spend 1-2 hours, recommended.

Interesting history. After I got over having to pay so much to go into a church, I decided to buy my ticket online ahead of time. Good move. There was a fairly long line when I arrived at about 1 p.m on a Saturday. I showed the official my online ticket and asked where I should go. He lifted the rope and said, "Come in here." It basically allowed me to skip the line and walk right in. They give you a headset that provides a lot of information as you walk through. The place is a "Who's Who" of British history. I would have appreciated more explanation of the religious art and the religious nature of the building, but I suppose not everyone would want that. My two favorites were the Lady Chapel (beautiful!) and the Chapter House. Many people might miss the Chapter House because it's not inside the Church. Be sure to walk down the cloister when you're done and you'll see it, as well as gardens. I would have really liked some places to sit down in the Lady Chapel and Chapter House to just pray and/or reflect, but you can't do that. Nowhere to sit. I would say I found this to be a great place as an experience of history (which I love), but disappointing if wanting a religious experience.

Breathtaking . This is a must for anyone visiting London, it is full of interesting artefacts, none less than the stones that mark the graves of famous people that lie beneath them. We queued for 20 minutes on a warm sunny day but the queue went quick enough. You have to own your bags for security but this is no problem and the gentleman doing this was friendly but firm - nothing would get past him. We were struck by how immaculate all the staff were, which is not always the case. Once inside you are guided by a lady checking size of your group and directing you accordingly to the appropriate cashier. Then you pick up an audio guide (included in the entrance fee) and s map of the Abbey . As you listen to the audio guide you will see people simultaneously staring at different parts of the Abbey, it's quite amusing to watch them. The real gems are the people working in the Abbey - the people in the Green robes are volunteers, with extensive knowledge about the Abbey, they should not be missed out, they stand quite unabtrosfully and will answer any questions that you may have - the are a fountain of information. We spent a lot of time with one such lady and her information was extensive and extremely interesting.The staff in the Red robes are salaried staff. They too are equally knowledgeable and full of interesting facts and information. We spent sometime with a lady in the Lady Chapel and she was extremely interesting and informative .We throughly enjoyed our visit to the Abbey. One word of warning though, there are no seats around the Abbey, just the ones in the main body of the Abbey, so do take time to sit & view the ceiling & feel the atmosphere while you rest. No visit would be complete unless you visit this wonderful Abbey.

Grand. The Westminster Abbey Experience was excellent. The Audi guides that go with the entrance price are well done. You can revisit places and need at least 90 minutes to take it all in. To see the resting places of so many famous people from history is special. There are plenty of staff to help out with questions too. There is seating in the abbey to allow tourists to rest etc.
So much history !!!. With the London pass I went there. Really liked it !!! Full of history, you are going back for centuries !!! Tho only thing I didn't like ??? I could not take pictures...

If these hallowed halls could talk........ While on business in the UK and after 7 trips to London I finally made the time to visit Westminster Abby. To say that this church is awe inspiring is to put it mildly! Breathtaking is a more accurate description. This venue is more than 900 years old and is the resting place of notables such as King Richard, Elizabeth The Virgin Queen, her arch rival Mary Queen of Scott's entombed next to her tormenting her for all eternity, Sir Isaac Newton, and Charles Darwin author of The Evolution of Species, to name just a few. The famous and infamous are laid to rest here at this magnificent chapel and you will be fascinated for every second of your time there! I arrived early just after opening and I cannot recommend doing that enough! The price of entry and the Audio tour was 20 Pounds and worth every penny. Arriving early will help with the crowds as once the day wears on it gets packed. You will need to allow your self three to three and a half hours at this chapel and do not rush! Explore every nook and cranny and soak it up. The tombs and monuments there-in are amazing and the rich history of coronations and funerals there is enough to make your head spin. The Abby is the Spiritual Center of London and it's not to be missed. You can light candles there for loved ones for just a small donation. If you are a history buff you will be thrilled with a visit here. It is very close to the Westminster Tube Station and just adjacent to Big Ben so it's easy to find. There are NO PHOTOS allowed inside so be prepared not to be able to take them. Make the time to visit the Abby in her 900 years of glory! I'm so glad that I did.
Go to see the Abbey. Very impressive and beautiful building. Anybody who is anybody is buried here. Kings, queens, warriors and writers; all are here.

So much history in this place!. The interior of the building is amazing. Just so much history there. Book a tour with a with a verger and will will learn many many more facts than the self guided tour. If you have the opportunity try to attend an 'evensong' which started at 5pm on a Friday when we were there. It is a free evening worship service in the church. The entrance gate is near the Abbey gift shop (West side I think) and entry and seating will be monitored by a verger. Doors open about 4:30. The singing of the Abbey choir is a once on a lifetime experience.

Happy I finally saw this historic place. Finally went to Westminister Abbey and it was worth the visit. Of course, it is a church and graveyard at once. Gives you a sense of how long the English have been around, and how many famous people, Darwin, Newton, Dickens have influenced the world. Really intersting self tour. I love history so this was right up my alley.

Awe inspiring, must see!. Walking past the resting places of some of the greatest names in history is humbling. The memorial for Sir Issac Newton, James Maxwell, Micheal Faraday, Lord Kelvin, and P.A.M. Dirac was an emotional highpoint for me. Poets corner - wow! The personal audio device was very helpful, easy to follow along, highly informative, and efficient. The staff was exceptional in their professionalism and assistance. The women's restroom line seemed to be a long wait each time I passed by. The cafe was convenient and reasonably priced and the blueberry apricot tart was outstanding. Great outing for a rainy day.

Evensong...you need to go.. You have seen plenty of reviews of the interior of the Abbey. Centuries of history. Go with a verger. However, if you have the chance try to attend an 'evensong' which usually starts at 5:00 p.m. It is an evening worship service in the wonderful atmosphere of the church. Makes no difference your religious belief. It's a time to put all youra cares behind you and focus on the important things in life. The entrance gate is near the Abbey gift shop and will be monitored by a verger. Start lining-up about 4:30 so as to be able to find a seat close to the 'front ' of the proceeding. The singing of the Psalms by the Abbey your choir is something special and this all costs you nothing. AS rich and rewarding experience.

So much history!. We didn't use the audio guides. In retrospect I wish we had. The maps they handed out had numbers corresponding to items of interest, but didn't say what they were. That information was only provided in the audio guides. Still, we were able to find our way around and see many interesting things. Westminster Abby is overwhelmingly large. Plan on spending several hours there.
Not always open to the public. The day we went it was closed to the public so check ahead if you want to see the inside. Next time I will be sure to go when it is open.

A must-see attraction while visiting London. Westminster Abbey has been the Coronation Church of England since the crowning of William the Conqueror back in 1066. Queen Elizabeth II was crowned here in the famous King Edward’s Chair, along with every monarch since 1308. The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton was held here in 2011. There are nearly 500 tombs and monuments on the Abbey grounds, including the tombs of Charles Dickens, Geoffrey Chaucer, and Charles Darwin. A must-see attraction. Arrive early due to long lines, but worth it.

Westminster Abbey from Roman Catholic roots to 16th Century Protestant Europe. Founded in AD 960, Westminster Abbey is the location of coronation of kings and queens and the burial place of many famous British historical figures such as Chaucer. William the Conqueror was the first crowned in 1066. It is the place of royal marriages and funerals as well. It also is a Christian place of worship and while visiting announcements are made to take a moment to pray. The Quire, Nave and vaulted ceilings and towers and individual smaller chapels and coronation chair as well as the Poet's Corner and Henry VII'S Lady Chapel are all interesting. There is a helpful audioguide. Also, the chapel garden area is worth seeing if open.

Simply amazing. Astonishing, beautiful, and awe inspiring. Walking besides and over the graves of some of the greatest names in history is humbling. Even more special was listening to the choir during Evensong.

A must see in London. Westminster Abbey is not the world's most beautiful cathedral, but it is one of the greats - and the tombs, carvings, space is beautiful. A visit to Poets' Corner is one of my favorites there as is walking through the wonderfully carved choir stalls. I especially like the tombs of Elizabeth I and her not so loved sister, Mary, together in stone. When I was there recently the line to go in was a block long. It might be better to go later in the day. Also a priest in the church offered a prayer for peace - very beautiful - and then announced that he would be in a chapel offering prayers if anyone would like to attend. Very peaceful with hundreds of people milling around.

Westminster Abbey. After discovering that there was an entry fee of 20pounds to view the Abbey I decided to attend a service which is free. Many other tourists took this option as well however, if you are going tomworship, be prepared for the masses to leave throughout once they have had a look inside. It is very distracting for those who are truly there to worship.

History you can see, experience, and enjoy!. My daughter rolled her eyes when I said we were going here (she's 12). Now she's glad she did as she realizes how cool history can be. For a well known land mark attraction there was a line but not bad, the sites were clearly marked and the electronic guide was easy to hear and understand. I would recommend this as a definite point of interest....

What a place to visit!. Thoroughly enjoyed my visit, having the audio tour meant I could take my time and see all that was there, spend about 3 hours in there. A great place for tourists to visit to see our history and experience what's great about our country
Relive history in glory. Iconic building opposite the House of Parliament. Every corner of the Abbey bestows historical charmth on every visitor. Do not miss thinking merely of the ticket price.

Good. Not sure ever how i feel about paying to visit places of worship, and I have done it now. I can see how you can spend a good few hours looking at every nook and cranny. The staff were very helpful and informative.

Best part of the trip. This was the most interesting part of our trip to London. Its a must see for any visitor! It is incredible to see the history of one country- tombs from 1020's and more recent times of so many famous people all in a beautiful architecture that has withstood time...and still a working church.
Very beautiful . Best way to see is with a tour so you get all of the history. However, worth seeing just to see it!!! Interesting how it is decided who is buried there.

Very interesting historical tour with impressive interior/exterior. With Jeremy Irons giving you the audio tour (included in the entrance fee), this gives you a rich glimpse into the lives of various kings and queens of England. Skip the expensive cafe, though. Better to just get the hotdogs outside the Abbey if you get hungry.

A MUST see!. Full disclosure: I LOVE old churches and their history. I toured Westminster Abbey on a spring Friday late morning. The line wasn't too long, kept moving, and took about 15-20 minutes to get to the enterance. They take London Pass but you don't get to skip the queue. The audio tour was absolutely fantastic--full of interesting info and easy to use. Jeremy Irons narrates and his voice is perfect for this church tour, lol. It keeps you moving throughout the church and offeres lots of spots to just sit and take it all in. You can attend a service too. If you have kids with you be aware the church is very quiet and you'd probably want to move a bit faster through the various rooms, but I do think kids would find it interesting. There were a bunch of people with strollers taking the tour without issue. There is lots to see outside the main church as well (plus restrooms and cafe) overall I loved this tour and would recommend it to anyone.

One of the Must-see places in london. History and amazing architectureit can be very crowded most of the timeit is included in the london Passnext to BigBen no photography allowed insideI loved the garden and if you are a harry potter lover you will love the corridors leading to the garden

Quite expensive but worth the visit. the history of the British monachy is well covered by a visit to Westminster Abbey even if the religious background seems to be just that i.e. "in the background. When visiting do use the audio guide.....your tour is otherwise going to be missing a substantial element

Beautiful. I'm not much for churches but Westminster Abby is special. Seeing the names of all the famous people and the special monuments to the Royals is great. We went around 3:30 and finished our tour close to 5 so we could stay for Even Song. The boys' choir is fabulous. There were some very young boys in attendance in robes who sat apart from the choir. I am presuming they were there to practice being quiet...

Amazing!. Full of history and breathtaking architecture. This is a place you MUST visit. It is somewhere where you can spend as little or as much time as you like but the more time you have the better.

just wow, so much history, grandure and elegance. an amazg place to visit.get there as early as you can as it can get very! crowded, in fact we came just before they oppend the gate and had our morning tee at the nice stand just outside. dont miss the jeremy irons narated audio guide!

Way too crowded. While the Abbey offers a unique and marvelous review of English history in that it is a veritable time-line of the great monarchs of the centuries, it is most often so crowded that one can barely see what is there. Being English, my childhood was full of stories of our monarchy from the very establishment of an 'English' king. I feel a deep connection to the monarchs crowned and then buried in the Abbey. It is part of who I am. However, it is difficult to even walk around the Abbey because there are just so many people inside at any one time, and even more difficult to actually get close to most things. I doubt that most tourists even know what they are looking at. Obviously, more people means more money for the Abbey. Expect to wait a good while before gaining admittance and look forward to being a sardine during your visit. Photography is not allowed but it wouldn't make any difference if it were.

Must make it a point to visit whilst in London. Aside from being in such an iconic area of London with view of Big Ben and Parliament, visiting Westminster Abbey is such a calming and remarkable experience. Seeing the tombs of Kings and Queens, as well as markers for Shakespeare and Sir Isaac Newton makes one appreciate the history of not only the UK, but of the collective world.

English history through graves. Free audio guide in the ticket is included.
Magnificent place, interesting history.
The statues and the graves are amazing.
Great. I recommend taking a Fat Tire BikeTour for this one. A great experience. We had lots of fun seeing Westminister Abbey.

Visited the gift shop but not the Abby. Unfortunately we where a bit late and had a timetable of our own so couldn't wait to do the tour. But did manage to spend a bit of money in the gift shop which was or would have been a great experience but for a oversized and very aggressive security guard who shouted at my 13 year old daughter hm who was waiting to pay in the Que. As she didn't notice the a till had become available the security Guard shouted next customer and my daughter didn't even get chance to move before he very abruptly shout at the top of his voice NEXT CUSTOMER!!... I mean what the hell was all that about. Jobs obviously gone to his head. He frightened the hell out of my daughter. If I had his name I would take this further. He had no right speaking in that tone of voice to my daughter No rights what so ever Not Happy. So apart from the over priced gifts in the gift shop the stunning Abby just jumps out at you. The architecture is outstanding

Blue badge tour guide review. I went to visit Westminster abbey, Tower of London and St. Paul's cathedral with Anne-Marie my blue badge tour guide. This was the best tour I have experienced so far in London. Anne-Marie was very knowledgeable and made my experience ver interesting. I would highly recommend going on any tours of London with her. I will definitely see her again when I'm back in London.

Over 1000 years of British history. The London Pass carries no favours here, it is to the back of the long queue, having said that, it moved quite quickly. The free audio was very good and about an hour is what is required.When you are walking around Westminster, you are struck by the vast number of tombs over a long period of time. The number of famous individuals buried here - it is a record of British history. The structure is truly impressive and a must see attraction.

Church of kings and queens. Westminster Abbey is where England's kings and queens are crowned. The great and the good are interred there. Some great men, such as Winston Churchill, prefer more modest burials. Westminster Abbey is surprisingly modest in its dimensions.

Should be seen... but lengthy line-up and extremely expensive.. Must be seen for its architecture, its strong history (coronation, royal wedding, etc.), its beauty, its......We appreciate this visit. Moreover our children (under 10) enjoyed this place thanks to audioguide. Despite a very very long and agonizing line up.We use our london pass (free entry included) but the posted price is highly expensive... unjustified in our view...

Gorgeous and informative!. So rich and full of history and beauty. With the free audioguide, it made the place more informative and easy to navigate. It's a real pity photos weren't allowed inside. Remember to check the website for the opening hours as there may be events which means it won't be open to the public! Perfect for history buffs too! Also good for ladies who want to imagine having their wedding here, just like Kate!

Mesmerizing !!!!. Westminster Abbey totally lives upto the it's inclusion in the Must visit spots in London . It was a humbling experience to visit this gem rich with historical significance and which is also a functioning abbey . Felt great to walk the same steps as where Kate and William walked during their wedding ceremony .. Beautiful !!!
Amazing. Every time I visit the area I find it just amazing to look at. However once again the que was far too long for me. I am told an early morning arrival is best.... Next time.
PALM SUNDAY SERVICE. I attended the Palm Sunday Service. It was so wonderful. The Abbey was full with people from all over the world. A visit anytime is very special.

The very heart of England. Another one of the must see sights in London. Well laid out, and the complimentary audio guides helps them accommodate the very large crowds. The audio guides could be a little more comprehensive, especially if one is looking for a particular tomb, monument, etc. Admittedly, many of the more notable areas had guides posted nearby. Don't expect to take pictures though, as they are forbidden; however, I think it helps keep the crowds moving. Another London location to go early in the day to avoid the huge crowds.

Poets Corner Centerbury Tales. "Poets' Corner" is the section of the South Transept. The very first poet interred here was Geoffrey Chaucer in 1400! "Canterbury Tales" anyone? High school AP English flashback, anyone? Anyway, our professor, "Dr. D" had seen fit that all of us memorize and recite ye Olde English version of the General Prologue to the Tales. Twas a nightmarish twillig gillig! Or something. I've forgotten the Prelude but never have forgotten Chaucer. He'd written one about Armageddon but I like thinking it's how one could strive to live in the present moment. Why not work like this now?..."To splash at a ten-league canvas, with brushes of comet's hair" sounds good. And then get a load of those last three lines. That's the way to live. Why wait until you are dead?

Amazing history here.. Do not miss this tour. It takes about 2 hours. You can go at your own pace with the individual tour recorders. To realize the number of kings and queens and other famous people buried within these walls is mind blowing. Get a real sense of history with a religious experience.

Nice place. I stopped her with my daughters. I loved this church. It is very old and has very cool architecture. It is quite crowded and the line is very long. A lot of famous things happened here. It's places like this that make London so cool. We all loved it. It's really a must stop.

lots of history. another "touristy" place that should be visited. While the line was long (fyi the london pass does not get you in faster) it went relatively quick. Early morning (when they open) would probably be the best time to visit as the later in the day it gets, the more people are out to tour.

Love This Amazing Place. I'd say it took us about two and a half hours to get through everything, what with the audio tour and fighting the crowds. There were a few things closed that day - the gardens and the little cloister, to be specific - but there's still plenty to see. The Abbey does tend to get crowded, so I would recommend going early, if at all possible. We got there about half an hour after they opened their doors, and it was just starting to get stifling. By the time we left, the crowd index was insanely high. I love that you're allowed to walk at your pace, and to take your time in viewing all the history surrounding you. It's amazing to me the things they have on display - that they were recovered, that they're in such fine condition, that they leave them within touching distance of some of the more oblivious tourists.

Westminster Abbey GIFT SHOP. I am rating the gift shop only in this comment. London is unusual in that there are not a lot of trash cans around the city. I had been carrying a plastic bag around with two banana peels in it for hours and needed to make room for the gifts I was about to buy in my backpack. I asked twice could I please throw away this plastic bag in your trash. I was told no the first time and I thought well maybe they can't do that for every tourist. I'll see if they do when I get to the register. The unfriendly cashier again informed me even though I was about to spend roughly $70 American dollars there that no she did not have trash in the store at all and she could not take my small plastic bag. This was really infuriating considering I was trying to be respectful of the city & not litter and I was a good paying customer. So, I couldn't bring myself to patronage their store and when she told me after ringing me up that I couldn't use their trash, I said I'm not going to purchase these items and left. She said nothing. I know some of this is cultural but my goodness have a heart!

Beautiful, great for Brit Lit enthusiasts. Inside the abbey is beautiful (photos are not allowed). It was extremely crowded when we went, but you can still see the splendor. There are several graves and memorials to great scientists and authors, as well as the tombs of kings and the like.

Historical, huge and overwhelming. I did not expect to see such a massive and impressive abbey but Westminster Abbey requires a good 2-3 hours to see it properly. No photos are allowed inside and one has to take care about the visiting hours which are hugely inconvenient (closes at 3:30 daily, 1:30 on Saturday and closed on Sundays). However once inside, you can get a free audio tour of the grand place and practically walk through history. Impressive even to a non-Christian like me.

Absolutely beautiful.. This place is absolutely beautiful and architecturally interesting. The Abbey has amazing architecture detail from every angle. This place along with the nearby House of Parliament (across the street) are the most beautiful buildings in London. (Far more impressive than Buckingham Palace)

Must visit. This is one the top places you should visit in London, even just for a day. I appreciate the history and beautiful architecture of the abbey and no words can describe it. It was such an honour to be there, being part of British and world history, where the past kings and queens coronation took place; and to stand by the tombs of famous artists, poets, royals, writers & scientists. We travelled in December 2015. The lines were extremely long. Although we used our London Pass (which we bought online from Travelcarte), we still had to queue for about 30 mins! There was an audio guide available which was really informative. I didn't expect to be overly crowded even during winter. I can't imagine how it would be like during peak season in summer! We had to squeeze about while visiting some rooms but it was all worth it.

I really wanted to love it . Firstly, there's so much history and beauty here. If you've never visited such an old cathedral, I would recommend it. However plan to spend a long time there and do the entire audio tour, preferably doing your research beforehand. The price of entry is just too expensive. It does not reflect the experience and similar cathedrals, such as Durham Cathedral which has free entry, does not try and extort its visitors.

Fantastic mix of architecture, history as well as modern royalty. Great place to visit and well worth the entry price. This includes your electronic tour guide, Jeremy Irons (very posh). They have a great collection of dead people - lots of those old monarchs - Henry V! The oldest part of the abbey goes back to Saxon times (Aethelred the Unready) and it is hard to find Saxon architecture. If you like your monarchs to be modern, then this is where they marry and get crowned. And they do have the special 'sit on this chair while you get crowned' seat. Fabulous for history lovers and a must see.

Gotta love old English Churches. If you love your gothic churches then this is a must see. If you love the Royals then this is a must see. Heck if your in London for one day then make this your destination as it's pretty darn amazing and I'm not even going to try to describe it. All I can say is you will leave with a stiff neck and a renewed appreciation for old architecture.

Take time to visit the gardens. Very grand architecture, a lot of tombs and due to the crowds, after a while you simply just move on instead of stopping. They have a quiet beautiful garden, do try to visit. would be nice to just sit there under the sun and enjoy the tranquility away from the hustle and bustle just outside of the abbey.
Spectacular. The Westminster Abby requires multiple visits as there is so much to see. Each separate area is worth the visit - beware of long lines.

ANZAC Day Service in Westminster Abbey. Went here on 25th of April for an ANZAC Day commemoration service and it was amazing. The architecture is awesome and you can quite literally, feel the history. An amazing experience.

Wonderful experience.. Wonderful experience, long wants to visit, tiny compared to St Pauls. Great audio guide with masses of information very important you have the time to enjoy everything. Go early in the day and book online if you can. I didn't but only had to wait twenty minutes which was not too bad!

Worth queuing for. Had not visited for years. But it really is a super place to see. To see such historical memorials and graves is awesome. The staff there are very helpful and there are audio guides in almost every language. Great.
Ornate, Ornate, Ornate. Really pretty building. Inside is super ornate. Be prepared and do your research before you come. Mass are held on weekends and will be closed to the public.
Beautiful. Actually was able to receive Eucharist when we arrived. Very special. Such history here. Loved it highly recommend.

Sunday Organ Recital. We visited the abbey on a Sunday evening when we went to the free organ recital at 17:45. It lasted for half an hour and you are not permitted to wander around the abbey before, during or after the recital but for me it was enough just to take in the architecture and listen to the music. You can stay for the evening service at 18:30 if you chose too, also free. A nice way to spend some time on a Sunday evening.

Surpassed Expectations!. This is the first place we visited and it surpassed all expectations I had. The only disappointment was they don't allow photography in most parts of the Abbey, so I can't show my family how amazing it is. It is amazing, there is nothing about it that does not amaze. If you visit London and miss Westminster Abbey, you really do a disservice to yourself. A few tips. The elderly couple in line with us had the London Pass. I thought and the lady thought they were supposed to be able to skip the line. Nope, even asked an employee who said they had to stay in line. They had to stay in line the whole time, even stay behind us as we entered and bought tickets, so for some reason all the hype about the London Pass and skipping queues does not work at Westminster Abbey. We were in line for about 30 minutes at 9:45 in the morning on a cold windy week day in April, so be prepared for that, I would think weekends and summer are worse.
OVERPRICED CATHEDRAL. With the exception of its historical significance and incredible roster of people who are buried here, it is grossly overpriced. I would not pay again to see this.
Beautiful Piece of History. Great place to take a walk in and see a TON of History. Was wonderful to see where Royal weddings take place as well as Coronations.

Awesome. I can see why you would charge for entry into the building due the constant upkeep required. But I thought it overpriced and especially into a house of God.The guided tour, using a handset, was a bit hit and miss to be honest and not that easy to know when to move onto the next audio.That said, we spent a couple of hours in there and it is fascinating. Loved "poets corner" and the reverence of the place is stunning. Ask those kings and queens of the UK buried there with the opulence of their status.After all said and done it was excellent, but the price stopped me putting 5!

History Manifest. The abbey is so much more than just an architectural relic... it would be difficult to visit here and not get caught up in the historical events and memories of the past.Sadly, like so many other magnificent places of worship, the religious aspects of the building are lost among the tourist trappings. It's £20 just to enter and once in, it's far too busy to do much other than follow the herds round.There's a certain feeling of disrespect with all the chattering families and kids running about. Photography is (rightly) forbidden but it doesn't stop the selfie stick generation from trying.However, the grand history of the place is magnificent and the tales brought to mind and narrated on the audio tour are fascinating... from royalty to Poets' Corner there are memorials and burial places of familiar names throughout.From the magnificence of the main Nave to the tiny memorial chapels the architecture is awe inspiring and from the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier to the Coronation Chair (finally and happily without the Stone of Scone) the history is palpable and I deny anyone not to feel a little wonderstruck.A fantastic building in which to spend a good couple of hours and, now that I've been once, I'd love to come back on a quieter day and spend a lot more time exploring the place without the cattle market atmosphere.
Nice.. Westmister abbey is easily reachable by taking a tube. It might interest those who are interested in history.

Verger-led tour of Westminster Abbey. We elected to take the verger-led tour of the Abbey, and it was well worth the extra money. Our tour leader knew the place and its history, and had a wonderful sense of humor. One thing that struck me was that he showed us memorials for Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin, then I looked down and saw that one foot was on Michael Faraday and the other on James Clerk Maxwell. (I'm an electrical engineer, so those were big names for me.) We also got to see some places that the non-guided tours didn't, like the Chapel of Edward the Confessor.

Impressive. This is a beautiful building. We did not go in since this was at the end of our vacation and we had spent a lot of money on food and other attractions. It was enough to just walk around it and enjoy the incredible architecture.

Glorious. What an architectural masterpiece. A must see for visitors. Sets a high standard for any other attractions one visits though. Every angle offers a special treat to the eye. Food to fuel the soul!
Worth visitin. Great sight to visit and close to many other London sights. The lines can be long so leave plenty of time. No photography allowed inside is a drawback for some.

Would Recommend This Beautiful Church!. It was fascinating to see so much history layer out at this museum. Plus, look up and the ceiling are beautiful and so high. I liked the Ladies Area the best, was stunning the sculptures and carvings. Also, really fun to see the nave where the latest marriage was of Prince William and Princess Kate. Felt very intimate. Great to See

One big mausoleum and VERY crowded. The crowds were unreal. It was hard to move about to see and appreciate things. We went on a Monday morning. I viewed this as one big mausoleum. TONS of famous people are buried here. The most profound aspect was seeing the walkway that the queen took when she was coronated and when William and Kate were married. A lot of the memorials are in Latin. The ornate decor was amazing. All in all, I'm glad I did it, but I wouldn't rush back to see it again, nor would it be on the top things that I'd recommend a friend to see/do in London. My children were very bored unfortunately.
Must see. You have to pay a lot of money to get in, but it is absolutely worth it! It is great to visit for everyone.

Crowning Achievement. Westminster Abbey was very interesting. Got there a little late and which I had more time. A guided tour would have been a bit better than the audio tour, but it was steeped in history and the ceiling in The Lady Chapel was breathtaking... NO PHOTOS ALLOWED.

Crowded But So Worth It. I've been numerous times and still find the interior of the Abbey to be one of London's if not the world's special places. The final resting place of so many legendary British monarchs along with Poet's corner always leaves me in a state of awe. Yes, it's touristy, crowded and there are long lines but every once in a while when I'm visitng London I just can't resist returning.

One thousand years of England in one spot. This place is amazing story of 1000 years of British religious, political, and cultural history. It tells the story of the English monarchy, including showing the throne. Many of those interred here are of little interest to Americans (and probably most Brits), but one can find interesting stories, if you have a little knowledge of history. For instance, I saw the memorial to Major Andre, who was Benedict Arnold's British contact during the American Revolution. He was caught by the Americans and hanged as a spy, but is memorialized here as a hero. Poets' Corner is not to be missed, with memorials to English speaking writers from Shakespeare to the present.This was a highlight of my visit.to London.

Amazing history . I was completely surprised about how much history and what remains of all of England's most prominent figures that are laid to rest here. Do not miss this if you love history. The price is steep but well worth it!! Must do the audio tour!!

Great!. The history of this place is amazing. The kings and queens buried here are great. There are many other well known people here too. The abbey fails to tell you who they are tho which is quite annoying. Me and my mum think one tomb was margaret beaufort but there is no signage to tell us. Audio tour may tell you but as we had a 3 yr old its impossible to listen to tou need quick to read signs.

Worth a visit to this iconic church . We only circled/walked around the outside of this iconic church. Pros: such an iconic and beautiful structure of London and an important church of the royal family. Heaps of good photo opportunities outside of the building. Cons: Limited tour times.

Don't be put off by the queue, it moves quite quickly . You know how it is, I've been to London loads of times but have never been to the Abbey, have seen it on the TV often enough so hadn't bothered. It's so much smaller than it looks on TV but because of that it seems more intimate. (It could fit inside Canterbury Cathedral a couple of times.)You really appreciate the amount of history in the building with all the Kings and Queens buried there and the plaques commemorating all those famous people, politicians, writers, artists, etc. The people in the green robes are volunteers, they are really knowledgeable and very willing to answer your questions. My hubby asked a cheeky question of where the present Queen's 'slab' will go, she was very tactful and gave us loads more information. Don't forget to pick up the audio tour it's well worth it. Not just voices but sound and vision. No photos as they are on you like a hawk if you even get your phone out. My only complaint was sometimes people were selfish and didn't move on fast enough. Not really suitable if you have any mobility issues.

Don't miss it.. Don't be turned off by the queue or the price of admission. Westminster must be on your to-do list. The history is incredible. You will learn so many things even if you are not on a guided tour. The history of the Abbey and the history of London are so intertwined, you really can't understand one without the other. Even our 8 and 10 year old kids enjoyed it. Lot's to take in here, so make sure you have a half day or so.Tip: Make reservations at the Cellarium Cafe at the Abbey for afternoon tea after you are done touring. Prices are good and so is the food. It's a nice, quiet spot to escape to after rubbing shoulders with the crowds all morning.
Always amazing. Even though we've been there before, we loved looking at everything. There is so much to see that we find something new and interesting everytime we return

Absolutely amazing. . Worth the price and the time. Take half day to make it right. If you understand English then it's a must taking the audio tour to hear Jeremy Irons tell you all the history facts and details. Beautiful in the inside and beautiful gardens outside.

Wedding Show Magic Place. True enough, the guide went on to explain that Princess Di chose a different church for the wedding because she wanted outside steps to show off her wedding gown train! Smart girl. Unfortunately, we did not have time to stand in line to see the interior, but I still loved seeing this monstrous church! There is no way possible to could miss this church. It is absolutely gorgeous! During our Sandeman's walking tour of London, I learned that usually royalty have their weddings here. For anyone old enough to remember Princess Di's wedding shown on tv, I kept thinking "This cannot be that church."

Darwin, Newton, and a Bunch of Dead Kings. There is something about being surrounded by the graves of great minds. This is a fantastic site for all of its history. Home to the final resting places of Charles Darwin, Sir Issac Newton, Charles Dickens, and so many others. Grab the free audio guides and take your time.

The best audio-guide!. My mother tongue is not among the 5 most often used languages in Europe. Still, in this beautiful abbey, my friend (who doesn't speak any of those favoured languages, managed to enjoy the visit as much as I did, because the audio-guide organizers have thought of speakers coming from a bit more "exotic" countries. Thank you for them!The whole tour is like walking through history, meeting kings and queens buried there who you only know of from your history books, and also The Poets' Corner gives you a chance to revise all those giants' names who you don't read nowadays as bedtime reading :).A wonderful visit, no-one should miss it.

Audio tour is very good. We booked by the Visitlondon website which gave us a free audio tour included which was great. However we had to queue for 50 minutes to get in as you can only queue jump if you booked directly on the Westminster Abbey Website. Well worth booking direct on the Abbey website if you do not want a long wait.The audio tour is informative and spreads people out in the abbey and it is a pleasant experience not overcrowded and the bits of information are short and to the point.Magnificent building with friendly staff well worth the long queue.
Must visit. Abbey is a heart of London. It's quiet beautiful oasis in hustle and bustle of Westminster. Love organ music and choir in the evenings.

20GBP admission and worth every penny!. After seeing many famous churches throughout Europe with a smaller admission charge or ones that are free (e.g. Notre Dame in Paris), I was a little skeptical on why the 20GBP admission fee. Just walk inside and see centuries of history and the who's who of tombs and you will leave with a big smile on your face. The surprise during this trip was the ability to walk through Abbey gardens and they were in their full spring glory. Also provides a nice backdrop of pictures for Parliament as well from the gardens. No pictures are allowed inside the abbey which is disappointing, but understandable with the volume of people and a sacred place of worship.

Great history. We conducted this tour as it was on our London Pass. Im not a religious person but i really enjoyed the self guided audio tour of the Abby. The amount of history is dripping off the walls. I would highly recommend it.

LOVED IT!. This was my favorite place in London I think. I just couldnt believe I was seeing Charles Darwin's grave and all kings of England and Elizabeth whom I learned about in a Hollywood movie. Oh my God! Beautiful and amazing!!!

Arrive early to avoid tour groups. My friend and I arrived fairly early at the Abbey and am embarrassed to say for a bit we had difficulty finding our way here. Once within sight of the place; however, it was easy to not get lost. There is a not insignificant price for entering. I must say I was a bit surprised at how expensive was the price of admission given I was entering a church. On the plus side you can get audio guides for free and these were very helpful though for some people a guide would probably be very useful as the ones we overheard were very informative and answered questions readily. I tend to want to go on my own pace so opted for the audiotape guide.This is not the place for people who feel uncomfortable if there are a lot of tombs around, which turned out to be a problem for my friend. This is also not a place for one to step in and not spend hours going through the different chapels and corners where prominent people and royalty are housed. One quickly succumbs to information overload and has to adjust the amount of attention one gives to the different effects. We spent a good 4 hours here and barely touched the place, though we did walk through all the areas, Lord Nelson's tomb is a do not miss as is the tomb of the unknown soldier, Poet's corner and the Lady's Chapel. Some of the tombs and the search for some of the people, such as one needs to do in Poet's Corner demand a lot of time and close attention.Gorgeous building inside and out. A real must see. Luckily we are planning to return and since I have now been here once I know to spend a few hours a day soaking in information and visual delights and then heading outside to recuperate to return the next day.
Expensive and gloomy. For the price they charge to enter a 'place of worship' the place is like a foisty old museum. Overcrowded and the price of souvenirs and other chattels is a rip-off.

Looks good don't miss the magic garden . Its a nice place. Amazing tombs . Stunning inner garden. That's what I'm feeling most impressed with. Only thing i didn't really like that it's forbidden to take photos inside the church ... no idea why.

Don't miss seeing this!. Great experience. There is an audio tour included in the admission price. There is a line to get in, so depending on the time of year, you may want to research that, but we only waited about 30 minutes during the end of April. Once inside (it's very crowded) grab a headset then skip around the people where the tour starts. They seem to all bottle neck in the beginning of the tour. Plan 1-2 hours inside if you are just going for a quick peek.
A Must See. It is a close distance from Buckingham Palace, and is easily reached within 15 minute walk. Also, close to Elizabeth Tower (aka Big Ben).

Amazing!. I was speechless much of the time we we touring through. Beautiful, with many interesting people interred there (including one of my favorite authors, Charles Dickens). Make sure you have a couple of hours to really soak it in.
Not Free But ....... Daily services are free to attend so this could be one way of avoiding a further drain on your tourist budget and still enjoy this spectacular building.

Accessible at a price.. You cannot help but be overwhelmed by the majesty of this iconic building; it is an absolute must for anyone who values their heritage. The tomb of the unknown soldier and poet's corner in particular always move me. I feel especially privileged that I can afford the endearingly high admission charges. I do not accept the proffered excuses about funding. Denying access to many of our fellow citizens to their heritage confirms the increasingly widely held view that the church of England is a middle-class organization for middle class people. I was astonished and ashamed.

Very worth the visit. We waited 5 minutes in line to purchase tickets for the Abbey - 20 pounds for an adult. But it's so worth it - the Abbey is packed full of history and very ornate and beautiful inside. The price of the ticket includes a hand held electronic device to listen to Jeremy Irons guide you through the Abbey, and it is controlled by you and done at your pace. I kept wanting to take pictures since it is all so breathtaking, but you cannot take photos inside the Abbey. We spent 1 1/2 hours inside the Abbey. We loved the gift shop at the end of the tour - some great souvenirs are there.

My favorite place in London. If you can do one thing in London- and love living history- do this.
