The only other place I have been in Europe that so fascinated me (personally) is Santa Croche in Florence. The final resting place for so many famous Royals and artists- with so much to explore. The audio guide is a must and take your time walking thru the side rooms for some fascinating antic dotes. In addition, coronations and weddings that have fascinated the world. GO! And if you love architecture (as I do) this is a must see!!! So much in London- but I always go here!
Breath Taking. Its just an amazing building. It took my breath away. It is a must see if you are in London...the history, the details its just amazing

Don't believe in God, but a must to visit . As my title says I don't believe in God, but boy this is worth a visit. So much history seeing the resting place of Kings, but most of all paying my up most respect to the tomb of the unknown soldier, hope he's Light Infantry. One for the bugle.

Part of English History. Westminster Abbey is one of London's iconic buildings and a must visit whilst in the city, however although we have visited London often, the £20 entrance fee always seemed to be steep! That said we made use of South West trains 2 for 1 which makes the visit far more reasonable. On arrival there was a long queue however this was clearly well managed by staff and we were quickly in the Abbey being directed to the efficient ticket desk. The next stage is the audio guide desk which I would recommend, the guide (which is in multiple languages) was easy to use (unlike St Pauls) following a logically route around the Abbey with plenty of information helped by the map provided and signage. The guide takes everyone in a circulatory route which helps to reduce pinch points and although busy wasn't over crowded. The Abbey as expected is full of English history and was as expected, one f the most important buildings in the country. Outside the Abbey main building there are the cloisters and a garden to visit which gives a further insight. On a practical level there are new toilets and a café which we didn't use. Westminster Abbey not surprisingly doesn't disappoint and should be included on any itinerary whilst visiting London (if you can swallow paying the £20 entrance fee). Recommended.

SO interesting. This was my first time inside Westminster Abbey and I found it fascinating to see those who are buried there - Oliver Cromwell, Elizabeth I (above her sister!), Charles Dickens, Wilfred Owen, Chaucer - the list goes on. i took advantage of the audio guide offered and was very pleased i did. The misericords are amazing. The sense of history and occasion (royal weddings, funerals, coronations) was awe-inspiring. By chance I happened to visit on the Queen's 90th birthday and was able to sit in the cloisters and listen to the Abbey bells ringing for her birthday - magical. I can also recommend the tea room for lunch - it was excellent. £20 entrance fee is staggering, but it was worth it for me.

Important History and Beautiful Music. When in London you must visit Westminster Abbey. I went to an evensong service there and found it a lovely, peaceful experience with beautiful music and we all sang some wonderful, well known, Anglican (Episcopalian for Americans) hymns that we often don't sing anymore. I loved seeing the many historical details and architecture and the many well known people who are buried here. Please go.

Really great - but expensive. So brilliant - with Jeremy Irons in your ear you won't go wrong! Interesting and varied, this tour is worth taking, you'll learn a lot :)Entry prices are not for the faint hearted, however!

Go inside and do the audio tour!. Its not cheap, but I would definitely recommend to go inside. Despite the use of the Abbey, which is one reason to go inside, the history and art inside are the real eye-catchers.
The audio tour is great and is amazing if you love the true British accent.
PS. There is a hot-dog stand near the exit (AMAZING!)

Westminster Abbey Amazing and Beautiful. The banners form a virtual menagerie of animals, weaponry, peculiar symbols, colorful flags and coats of arms. .A more modern historical tidbit which kids can search for in Westminster Abbey is a tiny hole in the wall at the back of the Lady Chapel. I can't really comment too much on the Abbey because we never did make it inside. I took home pictures of the huge line that we waited in though. The exterior is very impressive and I am sure that the inside is beautiful, but I find it amazing that you have to pay to go inside The small hole was blasted out during the bombing of London in World War II.

Great Kids Trail Guide. Our 3 children were completely engaged in this visit by using the kids trail guide provided when we entered. The directions were very clear, the type of points of interest were varied, the questions were interesting, and the promise of a prize at the gift shop was a nice incentive. The adults were able to listen to the audio guides at the same time the kids did the trail guide.
Pay the extra 5 pounds. There is an optional tour - 5 pounds more - that gives you great insight and history and access not available to all - asl about it...

outstanding. probably the best christian place of worship to visit in the world, outstanding. entrance is £20 and allow a couple of hours. if you get a chance join the prayers that are said its only say 15 mins the short service

Make sure you get the kids audio tour!. Traveled here with my husband and 2 boys (11 and 14). Expensive to get in if you are paying at the gate, but not bad if you have the London Pass. Even if you have to pay - I think this is a "must do" if you are in London. Everything in there is just amazing. My 11 year old got the "kid" version of the audio tour which included an activity book. This was a must since it gave him a "mission" while we were there instead of him just whining while we were looking at "old" stuff. The adult audio tour was also very good. It was very crowded when we were there in March, so I can only imagine in the summer. It might get too crowded to see anything well. Like I said - a must do in London!

Thumbs up from us 👍👍👍👍👍👍👍. Went here with the family on a booked audio tour. We all really enjoyed the tour and the audio helps us with the different areas. All of us had different favourites.Massive building, so much to see and hear. The only problem was the long waiting in line while the security checked our bags etc. Shame. But a fact of life today.

Ancient and beautifuk. The Abbey is incredible. It is the final resting place of many famous historical figures from Isaac Newton to Queen Elizabeth the first. The Abbey has hosted coronations since the days of William the Conqueror. Free audio tour is informative and I would say 60-90 mins is sufficient for a quick tour of the Abbey but you'd probably want to stay for longer.
wow amazing. Visit the grave of the unknown soldier...well worth the visit...great history!! could of spent all day there reading...or light a candle and pray

very British, very proud. A huge building , with endless rooms , all cared for meticulously. Strict security rituals on entry causing long queues even on invites. Another very British building , with stunning architecture.

Westminster Abbey a living church from 10th Century origins. Make sure you utilise the Acoustiguide audio tour which is available from the information desk in the north transept as the numbers used correspond with the signs around the Abbey and it is a good way to see and hear about some of its most important features.It is very easy to use. You can also obtain a guided tour by one of the vergers who along with the Abbey volunteers are most helpful & knowledgeable.The Abbey itself is simply awe inspiring and a two hour visit will just scratch the surface of what it has to offer. It is places like this which helps to put the 'Great' in Great Britian. The Abbey was consecrated in 1065 and William the Conqueror was crowned King here on Christmas Day in 1066. The history just goes on as does the list of kings & queens buried here along with numerous famous people from all walks of life.Be sure not to miss the gardens of Westminster Abbey as they are quite an area of interest in their own right.
fantastic visit. this tour is really one worth doing. an audio guide is provided which helps you know what each areas of the abbey. they also have other guides in the abbey who can answer questions.

Spectacular Timeline of English Pageantry, Politics, and Poets. If you are visiting London for it’s history and pageantry, then one of the must see destinations is Westminster Abbey. A fantastic church that is steeped in English royal (and non-royal) history, this is church alone can serve as a tangible timeline of English history. The tour will take you through the years of history, from the surprisingly rustic coronation chair to the remarkably ornate Lady Chapel onto the RAF Chapel. Every nook and cranny of the place seems stuffed with a monument to great kings and noteworthy contributors to the fabric of Great Britain. Westminster Abbey is definitely worth a couple of hours to take in, and the Lady Chapel steals the show.  > Buy tickets online in advance to avoid the long lines to get in > Get the audio guide on your smartphone by downloading it ahead of time > No Photos allowed inside the Abbey > Use caution as floors are uneven and there are lots of stairsThe line to get into Westminster Abbey can be quite long, but you don’t have to stand in it with a little pre-planning. When we arrived on rainy Friday afternoon, it stretched the entire length of the Abbey and around the corner. To save time, order your tickets ahead online. We did, and when we arrived and saw the daunting line, we were disappointed. However, we went to the attendant at the front of the line and asked where to go if we already had tickets -- he looked surprised, checked our tickets, and then let us in right there, and we skipped the whole line completely. Download the audio tour to your iPhone or Android device yourself before going. It’s available via the Abbey’s website, Apple Store, and Google Play. It is the same tour you get if you wait in (another) line to pick up a headset tour in the Abbey, and quite helpful for making sense of all that is around you. They don’t allow pictures inside the Abbey, which is a shame, but pretty standard in the UK. Many of the floors are quite uneven, and there are a number of steps inside the Abbey. I wouldn’t say this was a particularly accessible attraction if that would be limiting to you. Finally, the cafe at Westminster Abbey is among the better “attractions cafes” we ate at during our trip, so don’t hesitate to give them a try.

A place of significant British history. Worth a visit. Kids loved searching for famous people epitaphs, Issac Newton, ER and her infamous sister, Mary of Scots, Chauser, Shakespeare, Literary corner.Go on Tues-Thurs, you can wander the garden courtyard. Tranquil retreat with great snaps of Parliament.

Beautiful and majestical. Westminster Abbey is simply amazing and it is an absolute must do in London. I did the tour with audio guide (included with admission) and wandered around for a good couple of hours completely awestruck. The audio guide was very good, but if you prefer, real tour guides are available at set times. The tour starts with a walk through the tombs of some of the most notable figures in history, including Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton, before bringing you to the tomb of the unknown soldier. From there you begin the walk up the aisle towards the nave and quire before coming to the high altar which has seen the Coronation of Kings and Queens, royal weddings and funerals. It is stunning and you can't help but be moved by it. Following this, the tour takes you past the tombs of Edward the Confessor, Edward Longshanks, Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots and many other Kings and Queens. Poets' Corner is the resting place for Chaucer, Tennyson and Dickens and memorialises the likes of Shakespeare and Austen. Make sure you have plenty of time available to soak it all in - this is not something to be rushed.

London 2016 trip. just another awesome place to visit.....unbelievable history buried right under your feet......stood on Issac Newton's grave......1 foot away from Queen Mary 1 and Queen Elizabeth's tomb.......and walk by several more Kings and queens.......word can not totally describe what we saw

Long overdue for a visit. I decided to visit Westminster Abbey having been to London more times than I care to share. I chose a small group tour and was really impressed with our guide, Jane, who took us through the Abbey and explained the various features, it's history and role in today's modern city.You can visit the Abbey on your own - with an audio tour - however, there is a lot to be gained with a knowledgeable guide who can point out some features that may not be on your audio guide.

The main central Church of England .. Half of the church is free, while the other half and the most interesting like the coronation chair, needs entry payment. Of course, a historical site for coronations , weddings, and other memorial services. Never leave London, without visiting this memorable church steeped in history.
Beautiful. . We visited Westminster Abbey for a service and it was simply beautiful. The church, the service, all of it. Everyone should see it, religious or not.
Stunning. Stunning architecture and a beautiful place to spend time in. Expensive but I guess they need to maintain the heritage.

Glory to?. While I have seen Westminster Abbey many times in news footage, the images were mostly the same. The main sections of the Abbey are beautiful, but what really surprised me was the amount of space give over to tombs rather than religion. I don't mean any disrespect, but in a house of God should the need to glorify mortal man be the main consideration? This is historically the "done thing" but I feel sadness this is the norm.This opinion may upset some, and I apologise for doing so. But, I do acknowledge Westminster is a beautiful building well worth visiting. I just didn't feel the same joy or warmth as I did in Salisbury Cathedral. Sorry.
Majestic. Go at your own pace with headsets. Such incredible history and majesty in this place. I could have stayed all day.

Well worth a visit . If you like history this is the place to visit. A good one for a rainy day. Well organised and laid out. Plenty staff on hand to answer questions if you have them. Good value for the money. Great experience

Very Well Organized. Try to get there early. The line moves quickly and once in you are given walking tour sets and a map to explain the numbered areas. Don't be in a hurry and watch the floor to find some names not mentioned which may be familiar to you. Amazing history there.
Make sure to visit. What more can be said about Westminster Abbey that hasan't been said before, i've missed London if you havan't been there, its remarkble, dont miss it
Tombs.. This abbey has tombs, and a lot of them!I think that there is too much emphasis on the tombs(in the audio tour), and less on coronations that take place in this abbey.

Church Central. This is the second big London church that one should visit. You can spend hours wandering about looking at the names buried there or listed in memory. Visit poets corner to see some names you will know and learn about more you should know.

Historical Site. Bought tickets beforehand. There are lots of kings and queen, great Englishmen buried in Westminster Abbey. Kids were on a scavenger hunt of symbols in Westminster Abbey. It was fun. Take advantage of the audio guide - without it, most things won't be discovered.

Ancient interest. Book on Westminster abbey website before you visit to avoid long queues Good organisation & audio information Beautiful abbey with so much history past & present Small onsite cafe okay
Stress relief. Westminster is so mind stress reliefing place so If you feel like you want to walk and chat with your loved ones it's the place
Interesting historic place. If you are interested in old architecture or history, yes...you should visit it. I am not sure that it is the most relevant place in London, but it is worth a visit.
Beautiful church. Simply breathtaking from the moment you enter. So much to see and appreciate. Plan on spending 1-2 hours.

Sunday Services. My recommendation to all is to attend an early service in a unhurried or rushed manner. Observe a spiritual and sacramental observance of prayer. The guided tour taken later in the day was worth it's weight in gold especially the Throne Chair.
Superb place. Well worth the visit.There are guides at the door to welcome you and direct you everywhere.This place is so interesting and has so much History it's unbelievable.👍👍

Fabulous - British History at it''s Best. This was thr highlight of my visit to London. Mind you, it is not cheap and at £20 ahead (we did get in with a two for one voucher - but for families it can be an expensive day out). This does show Britain's history to the best, from the rich architecture, to the grand history of famous public figures such as Sir Christopher Wren, Shakespeare (he is not buried here), Chaucer etc, to the most famous of Britich Monarchs, including Elizabeth I, various Henries, Mary I, Mary Queen of Scots, etc. Not to mention the coronation chair that has been used for about 80o years. Fabulous.

Must see at least once. Westminster Abbey is Westminster Abbey. It's a larger than life part of British history, and it bears visiting at least once. That said, it is also an overcrowded tourist attraction that can be hard to appreciate as a church full of history with so many other people. Admission is also quite expensive.This was my second time going, and I'm honestly not sure I needed to go again. There were long lines, and once inside it was hard to stand to look at anything for more than a couple of seconds because of the constant push of people. The free audio-guide is good and gives you some of the highlights, but again, it's hard to use it when you're being rushed along by a steady stream of visitors. There is no photography allowed, which makes sense as it is already so crowded with people looking at things, but sometimes you wish you had the opportunity to snap a shot as the postcard collection in the shop leaves something to be desired.If you can get here during an off-peak time I think you will have a much better experience.

British History Inside One Structure!. A must-see place when you're in London! Aside from the beautiful roman architecture inside and out, inside lies the remains of great Monarchs of the past as well as reknowned political leaders and artists who shaped history! Easily one of the best places I've been while in the city!

Absolutely Amazing!!. The history & beauty of Westminster Abbey took my break away!! So many significant events - so many influential people have stepped before me in this beautiful, sacred place!! It is definitely a "MUST SEE" when you visit Lonson!

No photography allowed inside; expensive entry fee. This is such an important part of England's history so a MUST to visit. And it's spectacular inside, BUT they do not allow photography. I find that incredibly annoying!! Otherwise I would give it a four star rating; not five stars because they charge 20 pounds to visit = $38 Canadian Dollars. I have visited similar cathedrals in Europe and have never paid more than the equivalent of $20 Canadian.

No pictures or they'll follow and harass you!. It's very cool to get to go inside of Westminster Abby but it is very expensive and they do not let you take any photos. Of course you can buy a book of photos but no go inside which I think is weird. I don't remember it being that way years ago but who knows. And you can take photos at the Vatican or st Patrick's why not here? It's all a business. It's cool to see inside for sure but get ready to spend some dough!
Very interesting!. Really cool inside and out. There is so much history here and the architecture is wonderful. No pictures though.

Incredible. Was unsure it would be worth the £20. It definitely was. The architecture, sheer size, beauty, and intricacies of the Abbey was overwhelming in a wonderful sense. I would highly recommend going to see it. You can feel the history of the place coursing through it.

Very interesting. The guy on the door was quite sarcastic but helped eventually.Inside is fabulous, why do we rave about the architecture in other countries when we have buildings like this in England.An amazing building which is also full of our history.It is difficult to describe this building you have to go yourself to experience it.Well worth a visit.
Wow!. Words can not describe how stunning the Abbey is. It is beautiful and so full of history, culture and spirituality.

My favorite attraction. I live Westminster Abbey and consider it an unmissable place to visit every time I'm in London. I've been there so many times but it's magic never wears thin. The beauty of the structure is astonishing. I feel as if I'm visiting an especially important historical treasure which is as equally important as a church, an historical cultural sight and a place that is still in use today and highly relevant.

It was fun, enligthtening but tiring. I`m likely to go again. It was a rainy day and so I got wet `cause there was a line to get into the abbey...which was breathtaking. the building, the tombs, the detail...It was truly grandiose and I`m so glad I went. I like the fact the not only people of faith were honored in the abbey. You see writers and musicians memorialized, just about any one who has had a huge impact in the English society irrespective of origin. Saw the tombs of Queen Elizabeth I and Mary I (which by the way are together), Tomb of Mary, Queen of the Scots..The Abbey is huge,with so much crammed in and really beautiful so it takes a while to go through. Saw the coronation chair too! The guys in red/green jackets are really nice. They had locked up the chapel earlier than planned and one of them, Ed opened it up for me and helped me with pictures!! How nice.Helpful tips (I hope);1. Costs 20 pounds, which I believe is excessive.2. Comfortable footwear especially if you`re the sort to take in everything, is a must.3. Audio-guides are provided and are free4. Your can get a tour guide for an extra five pounds.5. Pictures aren`t permitted except in the chapel house.6. Last entry is 16:00hrs
Surprising. I didn't know what to expect going in. I learnt so much and was really impressed with the history. One of the best things I did in London
pretty architecture. beautifully located next to parliament. not much peoples notice it but a good historic places to be.

Wow. We have wanted to visit for many years and no idea why we never did!We was not disappointed.Absolutely beautifulFull of history the staff are so friendly and really had personality when talking.All staff had time to talk and explain things when asked even tho they was very busy.The cafe was bit off track but very nice
Best church I have ever visited.. This is a MUST SEE in London. Incredible church. The history, the architecture, the design - it is just beautiful. Worth the wait to get in.

Awesome Indoor Cemetery!. I was absolutely fascinated by Westminster Abbey! I didn't read up a lot on Westminster Abbey before going, and I was expecting just another cathedral. However, it was more like an indoor cemetery than a church, with centuries of kings, queens, scientists, mathematicians, and poets entombed in the floors and walls! Seeing the stones with the engravings so old they've been worn almost completely off was humbling. Some engravings were surprisingly well-preserved; even some in Latin and Old English. The "free" (£20 entry fee) audio-guide was easy to use and did a good job of explaining key points.I'm conflicted about the "no picture" policy. On one hand, I would've loved to take some pictures, since this ended up being my favorite attraction in London! On the other hand, people actually did a good job respecting the "no picture" rule, and it was refreshing walking through without a bunch of selfie sticks shoved in my face or people stopping abruptly to take pictures.

So much history in one place!. Westminster Abbey is one of my favorite places in London. I HIGHLY recommend the guided tours that are offered by the vergers. The tour costs 5 pounds, and you need to inquire about it when you buy your tickets (or check-in with the prepaid ones). They are only offered a few times a day, and sell out fast (since they are only limited to fifteen people), but the vergers bring you to areas that are not accessible by the general public and tell you "inside" stories about the different areas within the building. This was my second time participating in this tour, and I will do it again on all subsequent visits to London!

well organised tour through an ancient church. Although not cheap (20 GBP) this visit was worth it. We took an audioguide (included in the entrance fee) and walked the tour as planned on a small map. Very nice decoration in the church a lot of ancient graves of kings and queens. Very good info given via the audioguide. It was even possible to ask more questions to the staff in the church. Really worth the visit !
passing by. just seen the abbey when passing . looked very busy but looked a very impressive place would like to return when not so busy & I have more time to explore .

Historic and religious gem. Westminster Abbey has been at the heart of religious and royal history in London for 1000 years. It is a beautiful Abbey oozing history and atmosphere. Many of the Kings and Queens of England are buried here and there are some beautiful quiet corners in side chapels and the cloisters. This is a not just a tourist site but a living place of worship. As such some feel uncomfortable paying to enter but remember that the cost of maintaining this ancient building for future generations is vast, and it is of vital historic and religious importance. Don't be put off by the entrance fee, and take the time to explore, reflect and pray.

Interesting History Site. Always a nice place to go when in London, however if you're someone like me who doesn't particularly like audio guide books, you don't get a whole lot of information about the Abbey walking around.But it is nice and it's absolutely beautiful.

Amazing Westminster Abbey. If you are into history and architecture then you will be amazed at the Abbey.The proportions are huge. As you walk through the Abbey you are absolutely amazed at the skill of the Stonemason and start to understand why it took so many years to complete their apprenticeship. You also appreciate why the stone masons became an elite society in these eras.After you get over the enormity of the building you then look at the artists of the time and their contributions. Then incredible woodwork carving and carpentry confronts you.Then there are statues, tombs of Kings, Queens and nobility and much much more. Well worth the entry fee.

Landmark. Nice place that make part of the English history. One surprise: discover that one of the martyrs located above the central door is Martin Luther King. Beside the abbey, a place dedicated to the others "peace makers": Gandhi, Mandela, etc

Absolutely Gorgeous Building in the Heart of London. Let's be honest, if you're visiting London for the first time and you DON'T go to Westminster Abbey, you are doing something wrong. From the outside it's a really pretty church, but the moment you step inside and it all hits you, be prepared to pick your jaw off the floor. I was absolutely gobsmacked when I first saw the inside of the Abbey, with the stained-glass, the statues, and the monuments. One of the most beautiful buildings I've ever had the pleasure of visiting. Westminster Abbey is floor-to-ceiling amazing and I can't recommend it enough. I didn't want to leave!The line can get a bit long, and we went with the London Walks people who provided an excellent walking tour of the Abbey, a small discount on the entrance fee, and a separate entrance to avoid the line. While your mileage may vary, it was one tour that was well worth paying for.
Excellent . Great experience so much more than seen on TV. friendly staff so much real history was expensive compared to other sites in London

Literally walking on history . You are literally walking on history here. Spend some time here to learn about all the royals and others who are buried here and about the role the Abbey has played in coronations, weddings and British history in general. My favorite place to visit in London.

Britain's "Valley of the Kings!". If you are into British history then Westminster is definitely a place you must visit. More British Monarch's are buried here than anywhere else. The architecture is stunning and of course this is still a place of worship You can take communion here . My wife and I did!  Here HM Queen Elizabeth II was crowned just like many numerous monarchs before her. A walk round Westminster Abbey really is a walk through british history! Where else can you get deadly enemies such as Mary Queen of Scots Queen Elizabeth I, buried next to each other? You will even find a stone commemorating the Tyrant, Oliver Cromwell!This is a list of the Royals to spot:St Edward the Confessor and his wife, Edith of WessexHenry III of EnglandEdward I of England and his wife, Eleanor of CastileEdward III of England and his wife, Philippa of HainaultRichard II of England and his wife, Anne of BohemiaHenry V of England and his wife, Catherine of ValoisEdward V of EnglandAnne Neville, wife of Richard IIIHenry VII of England and his wife, Elizabeth of YorkEdward VI of EnglandAnne of Cleves, wife of King Henry VIIIMary I of EnglandElizabeth I of EnglandJames VI & I of Scotland England and Ireland and his wife, Anne of DenmarkCharles II of England and ScotlandMary II of England and ScotlandWilliam III of England and II of ScotlandAnne, Queen of Great Britain and her husband, Prince George of DenmarkGeorge II of Great Britain and his wife, Caroline of AnsbachMary, Queen of Scots, mother of James VI & IElizabeth of Bohemia, daughter of James VI & INot to Mention other worthies such as Sir Issac Newton, Clement Atlee, William Wilberforce and Charles Darwin!Of course the most poignant burial is the Unknown warrior which I always take time to pay my respects to.It is pricey to get in £20 for an adult , although there is concessions for Students and Seniors.If your British you must visit, if you visiting from abroad you would be mad to miss it.

An amazing place, a must see in London!. Westminster Abby is truely and amazing please to visit and tour. This is a must see if you are in London. There is so much to see, you could spend hours here and still not see it all. Rent the radios and enjoy the tour!

Excessive opulence . Gorgeous building. Can't take pictures inside. Full of dead kings, queens and important people. For being a church they make a bigger deal to dead monarchs than to God... Just saying.Tons of history and amazing beauty though.

Spoilt by high admission charges and rip off cafe. i would have given this more stars, but I think the admission charge is very steep. The audio guide is very good and there is enough to see inside - however, at the end of our tour we decided to have a cup of tea in the cellarium cafe - £6 for a pot of tea for 2, and £4.50 for a slice of cake !!! To cap it all they added 10% service charge to the bill. Felt like we had been ripped of in a church of all places - if there is a god, it's time to get your act in order !
Georgeus. Definitely worth a visit. An amazing church with such an amazing history. It was beautiful and definitely not the last time I have visited the church
History buffs delight. Beautiful building particularly the Lady Chapel. Interesting tombs for Darwin, English poets and lots of aristocracy.

A must see, but an expensive visit. Hadn't been for years, don't remember paying last time. It is a remarkable building with an amazing number of historic figures within. It costs £20 per person to enter. We made our visit on a 2 for 1 entry with our rail ticket. Presumably the London Pass would include some kind of deal for Overseas visitors. As a general tourist without using any special deals, I think the entrance fee is exhorbitant. I realise upkeep is enormous, and I don't think the Abbey gets any kind of Govt subsidy. You can of course attend the services for free. Having said the above, it truly is worth a visit.P

Westminster Abby tout. Trip was very good. It is self guided with headphones. I liked that because you can spend as much time as you want. It was very nicely recorded by Jeremy irons who had a fantastic voice. The building is so rich in history and artrchture was phenomenal. We all really enjoyed. The cost we felt was a little high.

Beautiful!. Westminster Abbey is beautiful! My recommendation would be to attend a service because you get to take in all it's beauty without it being completely overtaken by tourists. We attended an evensong service, which is a service of which the majority is sung by the choir. It was free to attend, beautiful to hear the choir sing, and a good chance just to sit down and take in the sights. I believe the evensong services during the week are around 5pm. We went on a Saturday, and the evensong service was at 3 pm. We arrived around 2:45 pm and had no problem getting a seat. Not sure if that is the case all of the time. Check the website for times of all of the different services.

Beautiful artwork. A must see landmark ,the architecture was great I loved all the artwork especially the ceiling decorations. There is a fee to get in but well worth it , we were unable to see all of it due to a wedding taking place.
A beautiful historic buliding. My wife and I had the priviledge to attend a Memoprial Service held in the Abbey and it was the fitting venue you could ever wish for.

Westminster Abbey- must see in London. Westminster Abbey has an impressive architecture and is definitely a must see place if you are in London.
This place has so much history, it’ s a beautiful abbey church that honours some of the greatest people in British history.
If you want to visit this place you need at least 3 hours for this.

A Must See. Because I was trying to save money during my visit to London, I attended Evensong at Westminster (free) instead of paying to tour the abbey. Although I wasn't able to explore, the church service was incredible and being able to experience the choir was a must-see. I hope to be back soon and tour the abbey properly.

Very Busy but steeped in History. We spent a few hours inside the abbey. As you might expect it is packed with history with some surprising things to learn. If you plan to go I suggest that you try to find out when it is least busy which will make your visit that much more comfortable. Either way any visitor to London should not miss it.

My #1 Must See in a City Full of Must Sees. Can never go to London without going to Westminster Abbey. You just feel history and mysticism swirling all around even before you go in. Queen Elizabeth and Mary Queen of Scots, Isaac Newton and Poet's Corner. Usually there are long lines, but I have been there when there are no lines, and it's almost empty. Those were my favorite visits. Be sure to look up and check out Martin Luther King Jr. when you are exiting.

It might be closed when you visit. Giving Westminster Abbey four stars based on what we thought it would be like inside. On two days of visiting (and with a London Pass), the tours and inside of the abbey were closed to the public due to private services. Well, one day was Good Friday.

Have a student group? Email and book ahead!!. You get reduced rates for students and you get to skip the line in front. Staff was very courteous and we didn't have to wait at all. The secretary made a mistake in my credit card charges and it was fixed immediately when I emailed her. There are enough reviews about the inside--consider this one an insider tip.

An unforgettable experience!. I was able to attend the official Commonwealth Day service at Westminster Abbey. It is absolutely gorgeous. Just before the service started, I took a short tour and was captured by the intricacy of the decor and the outstanding art pieces. You aren't allowed to take pictures inside but the images will never leave your mind.

One of the world's great churches. The building is amazing ! The history here makes the United Stated look like a new comer in comparison. there are so many famous people buried here and no one can do pomp and ceremony like the British. The guide was very informative and the tour takes you to some areas not accessible to the general visiting public

Westminster Abbey shows UK Social, Cultural and Political History as you walk listening (or not) to the audio tapes.. Coronations for almost a 1000 years on the same chair, Poet's Corner, memorials for Prime Minsters, Generals and Admirals, and numerous worthy people. Queen Mary and Elizabeth I may have had a love hate relationship but they are buried to-gether and Mary Queen of Scots is not far away.Wonderful art work, windows and woodwork and the surprise is having access during the tours to lovely gardens around the Abbey just beyond the Cloisters on Tue, Wed & Thu (go on a fine day take a small picnic and eat on the benches or grass in the gardens adjacent to Westminster School). Do not take larger ruksacks, suitcases or huge bags - you will be refused entrance.

Westminster Abbey Easter Services. I'm writing this review to let people know about Easter Services in the Abbey, because prior to attending myself, I couldn't find much information. Check the Abbey's website for times; the "main" Easter service this year was at 10:30 a.m., which we attended. We got there around 10:00 a.m. and there was already a long queue, though it moved rapidly. If you want a really good seat, though, get there about 45 minutes to an hour ahead. Some folks who queued up after us weren't able to get a seat (though they did allow them to stand). The choir and Kingston Brass were amazing in that setting. It's about a 1.5 hour service. PLEASE, if your children have difficulty sitting through a church service at home, DO NOT believe for a minute that they will miraculously behave during this service! Leave them with a sitter and do not ruin the experience for others.
Specific visit to Westminster Abbey Library. Specially arranged group visit to this historic library housed within the Abbey complex. Informative introduction by the archivist/librarian.

Fantastic. Visited with our 10 year old son, we were in London to celebrate him turning 10. He wanted to visit Westminster Abbey, so we obliged.Booked tickets online. £40 for 3 of us. I'm so glad we had booked online, as when we arrived around 9.40am the queue for entry was huge. Thankfully, as we'd booked online, we skipped the queue.As a huge Princess Diana fan I was looking forward to being in the Abbey where her funeral had been, and where Prince William got married.We were given audio equipment to listen to which pointed out the chapels, where Queens & Kings crypts were etc. I found it very interesting, as did our son.Seeing the altar where Queen Elizabeth was crowned & the Coronation chair were fab. And the tomb of the unknown soldier.I lit a candle for a loved one & also added a colleagues name to the prayer list, as he's suffering from cancer, I thought it lovely that we were able to do this.The Abbey is much bigger than it looks & we spent a couple of hours touring it.Visited the shop afterwards, which wasn't overpriced. I felt initially £40 to tour a church was a bit much, but having been, felt the atmosphere & seen so much history, yes, I do think the cost was justified. All the money the take from sightseers is what maintains the Abbey & pays the guides to tell us all the interesting history of the Abbey. I felt humbled as I left the Abbey. Having been where sad, happy & world changing events have taken place.Highly recommend a visit here. The only thing I was slightly annoyed at, was the ban on photography inside the Abbey. Especially as in the Basilica we were able to take pictures.

A place to put in your tour. I went with my brother to show where so many events had being held. To many people inside, couldn´t feel the the peace that the place should give, but the architecture and the history in the place is a must see.

Breathtaking. Wow. Not a religious person but the history in Westminster is unreal. There is an air to Westminster that truly takes your breath away. We enjoyed our visit to Westminster and would advise it is not to be missed.

Impressive architecture. I was in London approximately 3 years ago and was up close and personal at the Abbey. Biggest disappointment was not knowing where to go to get tickets to go inside for a tour! If the inside is anything like the impressiveness of the outside, I'm sure it's amazing. The details I could have stared at all day and I am not a history nor architecture buff! I was surprised of its location. It was there long before the hustle and bustle of the city surrounded it so its right on the main street with cars and pedestrian traffic zooming by. Take the time to visit and GO IN FOR A TOUR, as I will likely never be back to London and wished I would have asked around more to get tickets.
Must Visit. You just have to visit this place for experiencing the wealth of British history.. we spent a good 2 hours for this! Was truly amazing!

Just okay. I actually didn't go inside, but the outside looked really nice. However, there's a huge tree blocking the view of the church. Also, after visiting Rome a few days before going to London, I felt it was insulting to have to pay 20 pounds to enter the church. In Rome, it's free of charge to enter cathedrals. So I guess I was being a rebel and refused to pay the entrance fee. Oh well, I don't feel bad about not entering. I can view other people's pictures.

Get a Tour. We took a Verger tour, and she was lovely and engaging, but I'm not sure added anything over and above the audio tour (though you do see a couple of special places not otherwise accessible with general admission). It seemed rather slow, so if you are an ants in the pants kind of person like I am, probably best to skip the Verger. But do use the audio or the Verger, I went a previous time without any tour, and although it's stunning, having the historical context makes it more interesting.
Definitely Vist More Than Once. So much history. A beautiful gothic abbey church that honours some of the greatest people in British history.

Beautiful Abbey. We choice to take our children to an Even Song service at 5pm with is free as long as there is room so get there a few minutes early. This was a good time of day for everyone to sit and reflect and just to take in the beauty.
Must visit!. This is a place that you must visit! So many famous poets, kings, queens, authors, etc. You are just overwhelmed by the beauty and of some of the tombs in here.,

History. If your a History buff you will love this place, The famous people buried here is unbelievable
Staff are helpful and informative
Worth a visit. It's well worth a visit to the Abbey. So full of history it's unbelievable. Totally different to St Pauls in every way. It's one beautiful old church
A must see!. Allow yourself 2-3 hours to wonder and take it all in. Don't forget to go into the courtyard and see the outside rooms.

Worth a visit. The famous Westminister Abbey is full of history. The audio tour is well done. There is a scavenger hunt for young kids, which kept ours engaged, and they got a big piece of chocolate as a reward.
Stunning architecture. Beautiful building, not far from the Thames and Big Ben. Stunning to look at-very ornate. We only saw this briefly-I would definitely like to return to see it better

Wonderfuk. The rain did not stop us from seeing Westminster Abbey. Although the we got there later than expected and unfortunate,y the were shutting things down was still able to walk the grounds around and see the beauty of this structure. Worth the visit.

Take a London Walks walking tour to see Westminster Abbey!. The Abbey is best seen and experienced by taking a London Walks tour in the late morning. A Blue Badge guide took our small group right around the line-up for entry. All of the important points inside the Abbey are explained as you tour each of them from the burial tombs of kings and queens to Poet's Corner and more.

Extraordinarily beautiful and full of history. I would recommend visiting Westminster Abbey to everyone. Whether architecture, royalty, history or famous people interest you it's all there. The architecture is magnificent, the historical events that have taken place there are many and people who are buried there range from Sir Issac Newton to David Livingstone to Tennyson and Dickens. It is one of my favorite places in London and worth a few hours of your time. If you have kiddos, there's an activity booklet to fill out and receive a small prize at the end of the visit.
You have to see this in person. I have seen this magnificent structure in books and on tv. It doesnt' compare with the reality. Fab!

Must see, with some considerations. Regardless of weather and crowds, you must see this when in London, but it is crowded. Despite there's being a ton to see, and it's all amazing, I was a little more satisfied with some other attractions.

A history lesson. The Abbey sits alongside the Parliament buildings and the Eye so it's very accessible. Security is very tight so entry is taking longer than usual, expect a thorough bag search. Photography is not allowed within the building so take snaps of the exterior. Booking online saves time when entry line is particularly long. There is an awful lot to see and with indepth commentary provided the crowds can move along very slowly. I'd advise going early morning but check ahead as events can lead to closures. Maybe not the ideal place for very small children but great for history buffs of all ages. Currently £20 entry for adults and £9 for children. Pricey but typical London and necessary to maintain this wonderful building. Plenty of staff on duty who are very knowledgeable and friendly. Good cafe and gift shop.
Humbling. Full of historical interest. Memorials to the rich and famous , very interesting. Close to Houses of Parliament and the river Thames.

Best Abbey I have every seen. This is a really great tour make sure you get the audio set right away will help you know what you are looking at. It is very crowded and you are not allow to take pictures. I would say this is a must see you are in Europe eat and look at Churches its what you do.

Breathtaking. I visited Westminster Abbey with my very vocal atheist friend and we both agreed that this was the highlight out of all the tourist experiences we had in London and Dublin. The self-guided audio tour is so wonderfully put together and informative that you can lose yourself for a good hour or two wandering through the amazing church. To say that the history of the building is remarkable is an understatement and coupled with the incredible architecture and furnishing this is simply a must for any visitor to London. Sadly we were not there at an appropriate time to witness the organ being played but if you get the opportunity to witness this I am sure it would be simply amazing. Well done to the curators of this beautiful establishment, you have created an incredible experience for believers and non-believers alike.

The best place in london. It should clearly be number 1 on trip advisor. The grand church which is functional and beautiful has history in each corner. The audio guide is a must with this visit. U get to see the tombs/ septa of who's who of Britain from poets to politicians to Knights to kings. The place has some beautiful carvings and glass paintings.
Interesting visit. Ideal place to visit on a rainy day. Easy to get to on the tube. Very picturesque on a sunny day with fantastic architecture inside and out. Would recommend!!
Nice historic place. It is an abbey, and quite old. Visit if you are a history buff, otherwise there is not much to see here.
Great place. This place is very good! I checked around the building but I can't go inside because it was been repaired.Next time,I will try to see inside.
Tea at the Abbey. Had a delightful afternoon tea at the restaurant at Westminster Abbey. Scones with jam and cream with a pot of tea. Highly recommended.

Great for history buffs. Westminster Abbey is a must visit when you are in London. It's a bit pricey but the church itself is impressive. Seeing the burial places of great writers, historical figures, and others is very interesting as well.
Evensong. I was wanting to get a real feel of the Abbey so we attended an Evensong meeting. The choir was beautiful and so is the abbey.
A Must Visit Place!. Words indeed fail me in expressing my true feelings of visiting this beautiful, spiritual, well kept Church!!

Beautiful, evocative, historic, amazing. What can I say about this great basilica other than ten out of ten. Every time I come to London I visit Westminster abbey and find out something I never knew. I often use the library where the staff are always so helpful this time was no different.

Mind blowing. How have I never visited the Abbey before ? it is amazing. Almost everybody who is anybody is buried or commemorated there The architecture and monuments are extraordinary. Queen Elizabeth 1 tomb is beautiful.The green coated guides are very knowledgable

Magnificent. Great history and narratives.
Magnificent old building with crypts containing hundreds of years history like Duke Wellington etc.
Headphones narrative is worthwhile.

Is it a Church or a Cemetery?. If you are into history and the final resting place of hundreds of years of notables this is the place to visit. Never have seen so many memorial burial places. An active church so being respectful is part of the tour. The audio is important and no photos in the church.

Audio-Guided Tour. Be forewarned.. you can't take any pictures. But that's not to say that it's not worth going to!
The audio-guide helps direct you along the abbey. If you want to listen to everything, you'll for sure be there for a couple of hours.
The inside is beautiful and it's hard to imagine just how old the building is.

A must see. It is astounding how much history is here. This is our heritage you cannot help but emerge feeling in awe of it all and grateful to the people who are honoured there for their endeavours and achievements.

Brilliant . This is an absolute must see! It is quite expensive but well worth it. All significant kings and queens are buried here along with significant writers have flag stones in their honour. We were lucky to visit when s service was going on, which made the visit all the more interesting.

tunisa mermorial service. We went on a sad occasion, but it is so grand, when we were waiting we looked round and there is so much to see inside, all the great people that have contributed to the history of the UK are remembered there

Lovely.. A beautiful cathedral. Don't forget to stand next to Sir Isaac Newton's memorial. It costs to go in, but not if you for evensong. Go, as it's lovely music, sung by some of the best choristers in the world. But, the best is not the cathedral, but what is next to it. Yes, go out fo the cathedral, and go into the entrance where the chapter office is, and have a brownie in the Cellarium Cafe. Oh, lovely. Here, if you are not too late in the afternoon, you can also go through the corridoors, and glimpse one of the oldest gardens in Britain. oh yes.

Westminster Abby. Westminster Abbey is a fabulous, family friendly place built in the 1800's but has a very modern vibe. There are lots of memorials for Britain's greatest i also found the online tour extremely useful to find out about their historic achievements On Friday afternoon it can be very busy as the houses of Parliament and Big Ben are right next door. But i do suggest going on Tuesday/ Thursday or Saturday to view the gardens.Westminster Abby has a service everyday where everyone is invited for a blessing. I personally loved their candle lighting as well. I would definitely go again because it made me feel loved and welcomed by everyone as soon as i walked in.

Afternoon Service at the Westminister Abbey. The service is free and takes place on Tuesdays afternoon at 17.00 hrs. One has to be there early to line up in order to get in at the front when the doors are opened. The service was good and lasted only 1 hour. At least through going to the service, one doesn't need to pay in order to get into the Westminister Abbey.
Service at Westminster Abby. Beautiful and relevant service. Recommend sitting with the choir if available. Worth the hour and a half.
Good Friday. Attended Good Friday afternoon service in this very special place in the Christian calendar. Worth the effort to arrive early.
Historic. Just knowing how much royalty is entombed there is mind boggling. Amazing artwork and stained glass, statues and woodwork was crazy. Notes of the WWII damage was interesting as well.
A piece of history. It was so neat to actually see the palace. We were able to see the changing of guards, which was really neat.
a beautiful must-see in London. Sunday Evensong is a particularly great way to experience the Abbey, but you will also want to come back to see the commemorative plaques of the great departed...

Too much money. It seems everything in London is 20 pounds, including the church. I don't remember paying this much ever to go to a church, including the Vatican, Notre Dame, or pretty much any other church in the world. As beautiful as it was, it kind of nags on you the dent in your pocket.

Great visit. It is quite expensive to get in, and it is not really different from other cathedrals, but the feeling of being there with the souls of the kings, the queens, the poets and the more worth it. Great atmosphere.

Back to See the Inside This Time!. Last time we were in London, we were not able to find time to do more than admire the abbey from the outside. This time we got London Passes (highly recommend!), so we were able to get in without having to wait in line. Of course, there wasn't a line, but had there been one, we would have just ignored it. :-)Anyway, on to the review...In a word: WOW!Wandering around and seeing all the names and statues made it feel at times like all of them were still lingering there, waiting to meet everybody who passed through the doors. It is hard to explain, but the feeling is quite powerful.Even if you have to wait to get inside, it is most certainly worth it!

Don't Miss It. If you like history and the charm of the old churches this is one of the best in the world. The history is amazing, the people buried in the church is incredible. Take in a mass no matter your religious affiliation or a concert, it's worth it.

So much history!. Popular tourist attraction, and well worth the money! If you are a history buff or architecture lover or literary fiend, this is the place for you. Allow for 2-2.5 hours so that you can see everything! I particularly enjoyed the architectural side of the abbey, as well as the Poet's Corner where a lot of famous literary figures are laid to rest. The audio guide was great and gave you a full understanding of the rich history within the abbey walls.

Narrator. Westminster is beautiful and fascinating, and having Jeremy Irons as the audio tour narrator made it all the better. There's no photography inside, though a lot of people apparently couldn't read the signs. And it was packed, so I suggest going on an off peak day.

History - political, national and spiritual. I don't know what I expected, but this was better than my expectations. We took a tour from London Walks (I will reveiw them elsewhere) and that was excellent. I don't think you can just wander around - you must be part of some tour. The Abbey is still a living, working church, so visitors should be respectful of that. But the amount of history there is just amazing: from Edward the Confessor through the recent royal wedding... there is a thousand years of kings, queens, princes, wars, poets, musicians, scientists, prime ministers... it is still all rolling around in my memory! The beauty is breathtaking. Highly recommend.
Great Visit. Be prepared to queue for at least 40mins, but the wait is worth it. Audio Guide provided lots of insight to the place. Impressed by the rich history of this place.

Expensive, but worth it.. My husband and I weren't planning on going to Westminster, but seeing the beautiful Gothic architecture in person changed our minds. As soon as we walked in, we realized the steep admission price is worth it. An audio guide is included in the ticket price and is a must in order to receive the vast history the Abbey has. The coronation chair was unique to see as well.

Attached Westminster School probably the finest academic boarding school in the World. More Oxford Cambridge entries than any other school The Financial Times ranked it the number one academic school for past five years. Then the opportunity of singing in Westminster Abbey with Latin prayers three times a week. Numerous concerts and a carol service being one of the most memorable moments of any parent furthering the education of their offspring. The Abbey is Truly breathtaking.

Make sure to check the times ahead of time. Beautiful and historical, but make sure you check the admission times before you go. The times in the London Pass were off, so we had to go back later. Great gift shop!

My favorite place in London!. We visited Westminster Abbey for the first time in the Fall of 2014, returning this Fall for another visit. The lines were long, but moved along quickly and it was a terrific day so we didn't mind! Inside, the crowds were thick and we were ushered through our tour rather quickly, which is understandable with so many visitors trying to pass through. We loved seeing sections of the original floor tiles...worn but still beautiful. Stained glass, elaborate statues, paintings adorn the walls, corridors and altars. The property oozes royal history and houses the tombs of many of GB's Kings and Queens. Also memorialized and buried with the walls are authors, poets and notable historical figures. I love the sense of humor of our British friends - burying Queen Elizabeth I alongside her cousin/half sister, Mary Queen of Scott's. This past Fall, renovations to one of the entries were underway, but visitors were still welcome.

Stunning. We have visited Westminster Abbey in the past on a guided tour. this time we decided to go solo. I found it still very beautiful but I would suggest doing one of the free guided tours as you then get to hear extra things and its not boring as the audio guide.

Unmissable. Don't be put off by the entrance fee or the queue to get in, the history here is unmissable. Get one of the free audio tour headsets so you properly understand what you're looking at. The number of historic persons buried here or commemorated here makes it an outstanding visit when you're in London.

visit to london. Formally titled the Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster, is a large, mainly Gothic abbey church in the City of Westminster, London.Last rites of princes Diana was held here & since then became more famous.
Free Audio Tour. I loved the free audio tour, it gave helpful and interesting information about the Abbey. All the workers were wonderfully helpful as well.

Great from Outside. Unfortunately, the day I was there, I could not get into the Abbey as royalty was commemorating the 200th anniversary of the Duke of Wellington's victory at Waterloo. But it still took time to see everything available outside the abbey. It's quite a place full of history of both the Anglican Church and the British, in general.

Great history . Bought tickets online so no queue. Amazing architecture, very interesting to see all the burial places and commemorations of important historical figures. Very atmospheric. We didn't use the free audio guide as we like to wander around and experience things ourselves. Took part in the prayers in the resting place of Edward the confessor which was a memorable experience.

Stunning beauty plus full of history. What a combo! Simply stunning beauty in the construction and interior. Plus jam-packed with history left, right and center. You really need to take your time and explore all the areas in depth.

Bottoms up. Unlike many notable historical figures Churchill preferred to be buried Bladon rather than in the Abbey. In contrast when Elizabeth 1 died she had arranged that she should be buried above her sister Mary whose name on the tomb was made diminutive. So no sibling rivalry there. A fascinating building holding a wealth of game changing Brits.

Historic and beautiful church. We've visited Westminster Abbey several times and always enjoy wandering through the history. The Abbey is the burial site for many famous and royal people. The audio tour helps to move the crowds along and helps to ensure you see the most important areas.We had to wait in line for an hour, so strongly suggest buying a London Pass or a ticket online.

Full of History. If you want the history of the United Kingdom and the British Empire all under one roof, then this is the place to come to. Fascinating place with someone famous listed at every step you take. The sense of tradition and symbolism of Christian Britain permeates the very air you breath in this magnificent building.

Very busy but very interesting. Expensive trip for a family of 4 but I loved that the kids get a quizz to keep them busy as you walk around. Once complete, they get a free chocolate coin. You can opt for audio tour which is very useful. I found the abbey beautiful with so much information to take on. Nice little cafe again and very clean toilets! Nice to just sit and take in all the beautiful architecture. Great for a rainy day in London however, you will que if you go in the afternoon, make sure you go AM.

Overpriced. The Abbey was over-crowded with statues and gaudy tributes to the dead. I really didn't enjoy it. Also, I felt it was very overpriced compared to other historical/religious sites in the area.

All of British history under one roof. I'd been loathe to enter Westminster Abbey since they started charging for entry, however I'd been longing to see the tombs of those great monarchs and gave in! My friend and I decided to go in with a group so chose London Walks company. Effectively for an extra £7 we got the services of the excellent and entertaining Robert for a more witty and personalized tour of the Abbey.If you want the whose who of literature, Science, politics, they are all here. Best still the tombs of my favourite monarchs such as Henry V, Edward, Elizabeth 1, etc etc etc. The coronation chair and the ceiling are worth entry alone. Yes, it gets busy but as you pass through each part, with a fantastic tour guide, you felt so engrossed in the rich history you didn't notice anyone else around. In particular Robert reduced many to tears while reciting "In Flanders Fields" in front of the tomb to the Unknown Warrior from WW1, very moving. Just looking up, to the lofty ceiling, was a joy. I know it's expensive but it's worth doing, better with a guide so if they do tours while you are there pay extra, you get so much more. The only annoying thing is after the walk you are not allowed to wander freely as you've paid "group rate" - an entire £3 discount! Stingy!!You can go to services clearly for nothing, just to wonder in the majesty. It is a wonderful place and hard to beat if you want to see all that is great about British history.

Amazing history. I don't quite know how to describe the abbey other than to say that I listened to the entire audio tour. I never listen to the audio tour all the way through. Darwin, Newton, Joule, Faraday, and more rest with Henry the VIII, Elizabeth I, her sister, and bunch of other kings and queens. They are alone. Chaucer, Olivier and others from the arts are there as well. The architecture, stone carvings, high altar, chapels and the coronation chair all add the to power and awe to the experience. This is a must see.

Amazing. . I visited here a few years ago but a return visit was definitely worth it. The architecture (especially the stunning Lady Chapel) is wonderful as is the amazing history in this place. My only negative comment would be that although the commentary on the free audio guide gave some good basic information, I have to say that I found Jeremy Irons' reading a bit dull and I gave up on it very quickly...! Otherwise, fantastic.
Attended service on several occasions. Marvellous building, full of history very interesting building. Tomb of the unknown soldier just inside the West door, it is a very moving experience.

Enormous majestic building. Large but at the same time serene to visit, steeped in history and extremely interesting. Architecturally amazing. Beautiful statues. Relive the past and walk where Royalty have walked.

Gotta go inside. It's amazing outside, but even more so inside. Check times before you go, because they close early and some days are not open at all. Fun treasure hunt paper for the kids. My 10 year old loved that. And they give them a big piece of chocolate in the gift shop when they are done. Make sure you take the headset on your way in - so helpful.

A must see when in London. Firstly I cannot thank the staff enough, extremely helpful. Having seen Westminster Abbey on the TV, I was not expecting the beauty and historic impact the abbey would have. Myself and my son really enjoyed the audio guide and learnt so much. Really enjoyed absorbing all the history around this wonderful abbey.

Cannot miss in London!. I was terribly excited to see where the monarchy had been crowned for hundreds of years, and Westminster Abbey did NOT disappoint! We visited in the mid-afternoon (2:30pm) when the crowds were less and the line not as long. It was 20 quid/person but they offer a free audio guide or you can self-guide with a guidebook and have an equally grand experience. The Abbey is set up so you walk a certain route down the aisles then down the nave and then into the cloister/abbey before exiting. In all we spent about 35-45 minutes walking through the entire abbey. Well worth the money spent!

A Palace for the Dead. The overall impression that I got whilst touring the Abbey was that it was more of a palace for the dead than a church. It was interesting walking around and seeing all of the memorials and places of burial but also a little creepy. Historically, this is a fascinating place to visit. It is home to the remains of many Kings, Queens, Poets, Writers, Nobility and many others. I appreciate being able to see the graves of say Richard II or Mary Queen of Scots but it also saddened me to see a church functioning more as a beautiful palace for the dead than a house of the Lord. Also it was a bit discouraging to see a kid sitting ON THE ALTER playing a game on her phone. It's beautiful nonetheless and the architecture (especially in Henry VII's Lady's Chapel) is stunning. Also, try to read up on the history first! Westminster is, of course, a must see!
Westminster Abbey Visit and Changing of the Guard. It is a lovely and new experience to watch the changing of the guard. It takes about like a hour to watch it and look around.

Must Must Must. After reading about English history and having a lifelong literary yen, it was wonderful to finally see Westminster Abbey. Very, very crowded during a holiday week, so early in the day was a good call. Strongly recommend the audio tour utility so you know what you're looking at and what to look for.

A Must See in London for History Buffs. If you are fond of histories, Kings and Queens and all the accompanying intrigue and story, then this is a place for you. Going around with audio guide is highly recommended to appreciate the history of UK, it's rulers, and the most important personalities that shaped and define this country as one of the most influential nation in the world. It will show you the resting places of the most influential and popular monarchs of their time, and how through the centuries, they have captured the interest and imagination of countless 'commoners' like you and me. Of course, you'll get to see the exact place where they crown the Kings and Queens up to the latest one, Queen Elizabeth. I was looking though for where they placed Princess Di's final resting place.....

Guide's lowdown on the high and mighty. In a visit filled with architectural and historical wonders what most struck me were the friendly, informal and knowledgeable guides. `Samuel Johnson really liked to party' said a guide at Poet's Corner. `He was the ultimate party animal when he wasn't compiling his dictionary'. The guide's audience, mostly young, knew exactly what he meant. They loved it.Gossip. This was bringing history alive in a way that might have been unexpected in a great cathedral. Very well done that guide.

True Icon of the Greatness of the British Empire and its Heroes. This is really not a church.This is a memorial to all the great Brits who made England the greatest country in the world for several centuries. It is one memorial and grave after another of famous britsAmazing Experience to walk thru the grandeur and all the history.

Fancy building.. This is a neat building and has some beautiful scenery. I can't speak on how it is inside, we arrived after hours and was unable to see inside, but it was awesome all the same. It's another place you should visit!

Nice, but.... The abbey is amazing, a triumph of gothic architecture fraught with tombs of great kings and queens from the past. I decided to give three to complain about the price. The access is very expensive but for once in a blue moon I wouldn't mind; what I find outrageous is that they charge you more to see newton's tomb. I'm pretty sure the already high entrance fee would cover the access to that area too.

Full of biatory. Enjoyed a couple of hours here. It's not free, which surprises me for a place of worship, but worth the entrance fee. The guides are helpful and the free audio guide is very useful. You certainly get a sense of history and it's place at the heart of national events. However didn't really get a feeling of a place of God and didn't like the way you have to follow a route round.

Beautiful, reflective experience. What a beautifully crafted cathedral, we really appreciated the architecture, the burial areas of the greats and the whole sense of reflection and spirituality being inside gave you. An icon of the London landscape, this is well worth a visit.

Average. I think It's not really interesting to go here with excursion.I advice you to visit the Abbey by yourself without your guide because this place should be admired as something mysterious.I went here with excursion and didn't enjoy it.

Amazing sight. Wow, could not stop looking at this building from all views, it is awesome. Interesting facts are written up around the building as you walk by. Opposite Houses of Parliament and Big Ben, lots to see around this area and lots of history.

History, beauty, imponent. Great place to visit. Recommend the audio guide. It's a place full of history and the guide will help you to understand and appreciate all its magnificence. It's not cheap but it is worthy.

Evensong at Westminster Abbey. Beautiful service. We did have to queue and were there fifteen minutes before but wished we had gone a little earlier to get a better seat. The service is also on screens. Well worth a visit.
Stunning. Westminster Abbey was beautiful and full of culture inside. The tour was very informative and kept you very interested. A worthwhile visit for the whole family
4 days in London. Beautiful. It actually took my breath away. I had never seen anything like this in my llife and I love all the stained glass work that was in the Abbey

Very interesting for the whole family. We spent about 3 hours inside the Abbey listening to the audio guide. Very well done and informative and worth learning about all the history. The café had great tea and scones and provided a good rest and bathroom break. The Pyx chamber and other exterior sites included in the visit allow photographs so we managed to take a fair amount of photos here.

One of my favorite churches in all of Europe. I took my family to London during spring break and despite hearing of Westminster, I knew little about it. What an amazing surprise to find out what I was missing when I walked through the front doors. WA church is amazingly beautiful. The ceiling is so intricately detailed I questioned how it was even possible so many hundreds of years ago. Be sure to use the audio guide provided with your ticket purchase as the history of this church is ridiculous. Kings and queens and authors and poets are buried within the walls of WA. Names like Churchill, Darwin, Chaucer and the like are resting at WA. The cloisters at the end of tour are also worthy of viewing. Each has its own story. All are in their own right beautiful and worthy of the price of your ticket. I've been to dozens and dozens of churches all over Europe and WA is one of my favorites.
For history buffs. The sheer volume of historical figures buried here is astonishing, and the lengthy history of the building will keep your attention

Very beautiful and interesting. My adsive, book online in advance.Print the ticket and take it with you. This way, u get inside imediately. The queu for purchasing the tickets, is huge. The building is beautiful and it's very interesting. The will give you an audio guide will give you interesting and important info about the abbey.£40 family ticket at westminster abbey website

Beautiful and Fantastic History. This is a must see while in London. We were traveling with our children, ages 4, 11, & 15, and we found it appropriate for all of us. We did the audio tour & went at our own pace. There is so much to see. It is absolutely beautiful inside and outside. There is history in every corner. We loved hearing all of the extras on the audio tour.

Worth the wait. We arrived prior to the 9.30 opening and found overselves in a decent queue but it was worth the wait of approximately 20 minutes. Very informative audio guide and a great historical experience, the only downside was the large number of people let in at any one time which made it difficult to move around freely
A Lot of Culture. This place is amazing with a lot of British culture inside. The guided tour describe everything with a lot of detail.
Stunning and educational. A must see for anyone visiting London. Try to catch a service for an even more meaningful visit. The audio guide is worth it as well.

The most beautiful place i have ever visited!. The most beautiful church i have ever visited in my life. Eventough we couldnt take single photo here but i enjoy the tour inside with automatic tour guide. The feel was just amazing i feel like God was here inside. The interior design is totally the amazing one! I will go there again in the future!
Amazing . The architecture inside is incredible. The whole building is beautiful. We got the audio guides and it was fantastic to be able to stand in one place and hear so much amazing history

Disappointed believe it or not.. Paid £18 to hear Jeremy Irons droning on about the Abbey managing to make it an incredibly boring audio tour. I love history and had been looking forward to visiting the Abbey. The tour lasted an hour and I was glad to leave

The Ultimate. This is the ultimate location for history fanatics or anyone interested in the most influential British writers, scientists or musicians. The Henry VII chapel was a major highlight for me, as well as Margaret Beaufort's tomb, and Elizabeth I's tomb.Try doing the Verger tour and you will get a nice view of Edward the Confessor's tomb. It is very inexpensive, and it is a lot nicer than the audio tour. DO NOT EVEN ATTEMPT PICTURES OR TALKING ON YOUR PHONE UNLESS YOU WANT TO BE PUBLICLY HUMILIATED. This is a place of worship and eternal rest. Photos are not allowed. You can buy a book if you want photos. You can attend services if you want to get in free, but you will not be able to walk around.

Gorgeous. I am embarrassed to say I didn't realize how many important figures were buried at the Abbey, like Sir Isaac Newton. The history in this place is amazing and the audio guide was quite good. We went on a Saturday so it was quite busy, but even then it was easy to navigate and see everything. Our three tweens enjoyed it as well. We highly recommend it!

So much of our British culture is here. I had no idea how many of our poets, Kings And Queens, musicians , and politicians are buried here. I took the audio tour, narrated by Jeremy Irons. The tour was just enough information without over load. It is definitely worth booking the tour online and printing out the entry tickets. Go to the front of the line and they will let you in. Can save you hours.

History plus a sweet treat!. We walked the grounds with a map, quickly abandoned in favor of the scavenger hunt trail that guides kids through various locations in and around the Abbey. We even got a special chocolate treat for each child completing the hunt. The gift shop has the only licensed memorabilia for purchase and many areas are open, but it is a working church, so keep in mind when you visit (we did mid afternoon), there may be events that cordon off areas closed to the public. Beautiful day out!

Charles Darwin and the Queen. Where else can you see the grave sites and memorials for monarchs and scientists? We did the audio led tour and were very satisfied with the information. The docents are also very knowledgeable and provide some amazing facts. Chat them up, they have a lot of share.

A true heritage site. Wonderful visit at this site. The staff moves the enormous traffic very well. If you are looking for a relative buried at this site research well in advance. So many interment stat individuals are sometimes hard to spot unless you do some preplanning ( unless you are looking for a king or queen, of course).

Worth a visit. We were in London for 5 nights and decided to spend a Wednesday afternoon here. The sense of history was worth the trip and the wait at the door. An audio guide may have demystified the prominent positions of obscure names, but perhaps distracts from the experience a little as well.
Guided tour. The Abbey has far more to offer than the eyes meets. Many points of interest for all ages. You may recognise some of the famous people who are buried here.

England's royal history in one place. We had been advised to get here early because of the long queues, so we were there 15 min before they opened and the line was already long. Quite smooth and quick entrance process once they opened though. We picked up an audio guide (included in the entrance fee) and started our way around the church. Very good narration! Short and concise and very informative. We learned, among other things, that most English kings and queens since the 14th century are buried here. Lots of mausoleums, stained glass windows and interesting history, particularly of the royalty. Although somewhat pricey, would recommend a visit.
