Gorgeous cathedral, nice evensong service. We went to Easter evensong and it was a very nice service and great experience. We lined up about 30 minutes early and our bags were checked on the way in. We were told not to take any pictures as this was a service and not a tourist visit. People who took their phones or cameras out to take pictures were quickly told to put them away. It was amazing to sit there and think about all the kings and queens who had been crowned there and how much history has unfolded right in that church. The singing was fantastic.
quite spectacular. No doubt there are many reasons this place is considered a must-see. Visitors should be very vigilant against pick-pocket.

Great building. This is a beautiful building. The medieval stone mosaic floor us amazing. I ended up staying for evensong and the service was beautiful. The shop has a good range of wares. Well worth a visit for religious and non-religious sightseers.

Wonderful visit!. Finally got round to visiting Westminster Abbey and had a great afternoon, which included a wonderful 90-minute tour with Benjamin, the Abbey's longest-serving verger. Well worth an extra £5 and you will get exclusive entry to the shrine of Edward the Confessor, arguably the highlight of the tour. Around Edward are the tombs of other medieval kings; it's just mind-blowing to think you're actually standing around the burial sites of these legendary figures (and countless others in the Abbey). A must-do visit!
One of my Favorite. One of my favorite things in London. The audio guide was great as it adds the history and provides details of what you are viewing. So much history.

London History. This was a London must see. This was one of them, the Abbey was interesting and thank goodness we had our guide book to explain all the history to us. The kids stayed interested in all the information,'it was a beautiful building with tons of history.
Interesting!. Interesting of you are a history and art afficionado. Audio guide is helpful and the architecture is stunning.
Can't miss. Incredible history and building. A can't be missed London item! My family had a wonderful time. Go in the morning!

Dramatic. Though pricey to enter and banned from photos, the Abbey is pretty amazing in terms of history. It's picturesque and interesting, with many fascinating stories from history. Well worth it, though, like most of London's tourist attractions, impossibly, unpleasantly crowded.

So beautiful!. I have seen many churches in Italy, Spain, France, Scotland, and England, but Westminster is one of the best. The statues and tombs are a fascinating glimpse into families of the past and have an unusual variety in presentation.

Great Historic Church. You could spend hours in Westminster Abbey and still only learn a fraction of the history inside. Monarchs have been crowned here for close to a thousand years, and there are monuments and crypts of England's most important historic figures. This is popular among tourists and locals, but the we didn't have to wait long, despite the number of people waiting. I would definitely recommend Westminster Abbey to anyone visiting London.

Very unique!. This church i found very unique with its overall architectural design. Unfortunately during my visit construction was being done on the entryway, so we were unable to go inside, but it was still worth the visit.
Nice architecture. I didn't go inside because of the price, 20£, but from outside is possible to admire the nice architecture

Favourite London experience . Westminister Abbey has been my favourite part of London. I spent hours just looking at everything! The audio guide is fantastic and really adds another element to the visit. I learnt so much. Visiting to just see the brilliant sculptures is enough though !

A Must Do in London. Westminster Abbey was extremely interesting. The history is incredible-the grounds are beautiful. We spent much time exploring the Abbey. I would highly recommend going and plan on 2-3 hours.

Book online!. We visited here on Easter Saturday and had booked online. We thought we would arrive just in time for opening, believing it would be quiet. However, when we arrived the queue was already about half a mile long, but i was so glad to see the tiny queue (with no more than 5 people) for those who had booked on-line and gained access straight away. The Abbey itself and the free audio guide were really good, shame about the crowds but that it to be expected and we managed to see everything we wanted.
Evensong . This was a special way to enjoy the architecture and acoustics of this beautiful buildingThe service was more accessible to the public than was st Pauls, the night before

Awesome. If you have any sort of interest in English history, you need to go. It's great. The audio guide is great. The lines are overwhelming, so make sure to get tickets online and print them. You can cut the line.

Choral Evensong. I attended Choral Evensong on Easter Monday (free to attend). I cycled there on my Brompton (fold-up bike) however wasn't allowed to take it inside as space is at somewhat of a premium . The police officer at the gate let me park my bike around the corner and let me in without having to queue again which was very nice. Being Easter (v busy) everyone had to queue for a while inside the Abbey whilst waiting to be seated however it wasn't a problem as there are so many interesting tombs and inscriptions to look at. At one point I found myself next to the tomb of Sir Isaac Newton - an unexpected surprise. The Gothic architecture of the building is what makes it so very special, the soaring vaulted ceiling a particular highlight for me. The choral service was beautiful, so I'm glad that I went, however the overall feeling I left with was that I had visited an 'attraction' rather than a place of worship. I would like to go again at a less busy time of the year to see if the experience is any different.
Worth the wait. Everything I expected it to be, fascinating history, so many monarchs, scientists, politicians and poets all in one place. Reminded me of Santa Croce in Florence.

Stunning Architecture. The Abbey is breathtaking and full of history. Highly recommend taking advantage of the audio tour that they offer as your only other guide is a vague brochure with a layout of the abbey. Believe all the reviews that suggest arriving early. The abbey closes early compared to other attractions and the lines are long.

Beautiful / Historical!. I really enjoyed my time here. So much history buried in the Westminster Abbey. They do have some specific times that it is only available, so make sure you plan this one out. You cannot just stop by. Totally worth it though! Expect to be there for 2-3 hours.

No show. Went there in the am and there was pomp and circumstance going on. It was commenwealth day so we could not get in. Saw a limo pull up and someone got out looking like Camilla and I went to take her picture and it was on selfie so I took my picture. Ya one of those days. We were busy for the five days inLlondon and couldn't get back to see the inside. The outside in magnificent to see. Note big ben in one block away as the London Eye, Parliament, so everything is very close together. Get your walking shoes on and go for it.PS we stayed at a Hotel close to this district just for that reason. You can knock off a lot of things in a short period of time.

Amazing History, Architecture & Art. I have been in the Abbey at least a dozen times and wish i could see it alone because even the queen who became a model for the queen in a deck of cards is in there! Poets Corner is a wonderful section featuring the greatest British authors & playwrights.
best part of tour. Wife loved this because of weddings of royalty. I thought for christian church, requested donation bit high but overall recommend.

Must see!. Westminster Abbey was not high on my list of places to visit but my husband was told an ancestor of his was buried there. I was wrong because this should have been on the top of my list of must sees! It was beautiful and interesting. There are no pictures allowed but we found someone to help us locate the ancestor's burial site. It was such an exciting experience and after we explained about how excited my father in law was for us to see where his ancestor was buried, the man told us to take a picture and even directed us to the library to have them print off more information about him! It was awesome! Go visit this historic place!
Gorgeous and Historic. My husband and I waited in line for about 30 minutes and it was well worth the wait. What a magnificent place that will leave you speechless. Highly recommended.

Perfect Abbey Experience. The line moves quickly, it is not overly expensive to get in, the audio tour was informative and professionally produced, and of course the centuries of history are overwhelming to contemplate. A must-see on your trip to London.

Didn't know significance until i saw the royal wedding. This is where Royal family have their wedding. It is THE CHURCH. Must visit when you are in London to understand the "AWE" when you set your foot in.

You don't have to be religious to enjoy this. I loved the poets corner.. Poets corner where Tennyson, Chaucer, Kipling, Dickens, etc were buried was a highlight of this tour for the kids and I. They have a free audio tour- do that! I learned so much. It was interesting that Elizabeth 1 is buried here as well as Mary Queen of Scots and her son, Elizabeth's heir James. It is a beautiful Abbey and incredibly significant. Definitely a highlight of our trip.
Beautiful!. We enjoyed our self guided tour of Westminster Abbey. The tour is about an hour and is just the right amount of time and detail. Not to be missed.
Closed again. I have been in London three times, but always closed it. Now I saw the internet when it open, but it wasn't. We were a very strict program, so we haven't seen it inside.

Easter Sung Eucharist a memorable experience. We decided to go to the Sung Eucharist on Easter Sunday to take the opportunity to see inside the abbey for free, and also to hear the music. Part of our group of 4 wasn't familiar with an Anglican service, but we all highly enjoyed the experience. We arrived 45 mins before the service, and were able to sit relatively near to the front, which was great. The service lasted an hour and a half, and was extremely well organised and put together, with plenty of information in the order of service to help anyone who wasn't familiar with the order of the ceremony. The stewards were friendly and helpful. The music was outstanding, and the visit was worth it if for nothing but that. We didn't get to take any photos or get much of a look around, but we weren't there to be tourists - to be noted by anyone that wants to do the same!

Beautiful church - great history. Really enjoyed this church. There is a free audio guide which helps bring things to life. Tons of history here as well as beautiful architecture. Make sure to get there early as there was quite a line when arriving shortly after opening.
Very Interesting. Had some time to kill whilst waiting for my wife and went around the Abby very interesting tour well organised can go at your own pace with a portable handset..

Stunning Building. We went for a walk around Westminster abbey this past weekend. Unfortunately the main building was closed on good Friday for a private event, which was a shame as I would have very much liked to have visited Isaac newtons tomb which is worth a look at. We did however manage to get a walk around the building itself and the grounds which is worthwhile of itself, there are a lot of features and carvings on the building which are nice to look at such as the interesting architraves. definatly worth visiting.

Evensong. Initially I was torn between touring Westminster Abbey or attending Evensong (having limited time in London). My husband and I ended up attending Evensong, and I'm so glad we did. No photography was aloud, (which I totally understand as it's a worship service) but the experience will stay with me forever. The music was stunningly beautiful - the choir (including choirboys with voices of silver) sang with skill and feeling - the harmonies of praise to God reaching up to the heavens...Someday I'd love to go back and take the tour, but if you have to chose, I'd recommend Evensong, as the experience was unforgettable.
a landmark... I didn;t like it much, but you can include it in your landmark to visit. maybe you will like it. .. who knows.

Lots of history. If you are a history buff there is a lot to see here, and you might want to go as part of a tour or use an audio guide. I have twice been inside as part of a tour (once with London Walks, and once as part of a private tour), and when you go as part of a tour you enter through a back door and don't have to wait.If you are just interested in the architecture and visual you might consider going to a service, which is free, though donations are appreciated I'm sure.

One of the must-visit when in London. The Abbey is as beautiful as it is rich in history. Walk through the corridors where many great men and women have been, and take time to listen to the audio commentaries to fully appreciate the its significance

More interesting than you might think. We visited on Easter Monday and arrived at 3pm to miss the crowds. We used the handset guides which were most useful both with the route and additional information. A beautiful building with magnificent architecture. Wonderful decoration in the side chapels and interesting tombs and memorials of monarchs, prime ministers, poets, composers, writers and more. As they were preparing for evensong at 5pm we felt we were a little rushed at the end and they were shutting doors on the chapels and we missed out on the tomb of Elizabeth I. It was busy as we passed it earlier and intended to return as we had to pass by it again. However, the door was slammed in front of us and we were told, by a hard faced lady in a red gown, that we were too late and we could not go in. We thought this a bit harsh since there was no one else behind us wanting to go in and 2minutes would not have made any difference to the running of the Abbey. We did not argue but as a Christian myself I did not think this reflected Christian values. Had we known that we would be so rushed we would have arrived 15 minutes earlier. One benefit of being in the Abbey at this time was being treated to the wonderful singing by the choir.Generally a very special building and well worth the cost of the entry.

Not impressive. I just can't believe that somebody would pay 20 GBP to see this church. It does not look that impressive on the outside so my guess is that it's not good on the inside. Want a real church? Spend your money in St. Paul's Cathedral though I would never pay to see a church from the inside. It's just ridiculous.
Great slice of history. Loved it, well worth the entrance fee. Magnificent cathederal and lots to look at inside and the audio tour is great.

Beautiful but be patient with the long queues. Do take the audio device they give you as you learn so much more . The London Pass does not help you jump queues but it gives you the audio guide for free

Always love the Abbey!. I've been so many times and never get tired of this site. It was one of the first Abbeys I'd seen in my travels throughout the UK in college. It's as special the 4th time as it was the 1st!
Easter service. Beautiful amazing ancient building filled with sculpture, history and friendly priests. Very grand service that I was glad to participate in.

SOAKED IN HISTOTY. No visit is complete without a visit to Westminster Abbey. Ther is just generations of History in this one place that it will take a month of Sunday's to chronicle the same. You cannot visit without a guide so do pay the fees as it makes it really worthwhile
Must see. Westminster Abbey is amazing. So much history. We utilized the audio tour devices. That helped. Overall, this is a must see during your stay.

Amazing and humbling. Get the London Pass to save yourself a few bucks. This is a must see. Walking across the tombs of Kings, Prime Ministers, and notable historical figures like Isaac Newton. No cameras inside, and despite the urge to take photos, you have to respect the sanctity of the location. It is a mausoleum, after all. Expect to spend about 2 hours looking around. Have afternoon tea at the restaurant for fun.

Well worth a visit. Although at twenty pounds each I thought the abbey was going to be a disappointment I was glad to say I was wrong. The inclusive audio guide led us around the abbey at our own pace with lots of extra information on lots ofadditional subjects if required.The abbey is stunning and well worth a visit.

Buy your tickets online from the Abbey website.. Westminster Abbey is the most important site to see in London in my opinion. We found a one city block long line the first time we went to see it, so we left and bought tickets online from the Abbey website. When we returned to see it with our online tickets,we arrived 20 minutes before opening on Holy Saturday. There was already a short line for online ticket holders, but the line for those without tickets or those with London pass was the length of two city blocks! So glad we bought the online tickets. Simply awe-inspiring inside!

Pure history..... Booked in advance and looking at the queue we were glad we were able to walk straight in with our preprinted tickets. Inside we used the downloaded tour guide app but think that was probably the same as the audio guide available inside the abbey. Entry fee a bit pricey but just about worth it given the history inside and the obvious cost of ongoing repairs needed in such an old building. Good prelude to our tour of the Houses of Parliament that followed......
understand more about UK. it is a government place with high security at entrance. a must go place for a tourist to understand more about the juristic of UK

Beautiful Church. With all the corpses of eminent personalities, it should be a spooky place but it's beautiful designed and kept and you enjoy yourself in the great company, the gardens at the back are also good for nice picnic.

British history in one visit to one place. You cannot miss the abbey. The tour is via a well organized (or organised) audio tape narrated by Jeremy Irons that comes with admission price and guides you through the amazing historical figures, the queen coronations, the prominent Britons buried here, etc.
Kingdom greatness . The jewel of our kingdom and must see living pageant of British history. Now with celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Henry VII's lady chapel. A must.

Worth every penny. Pl check the website for the abbey timings...poets corner is one of the attractions you can't resistLittle expensive tickets..but worth it...There is a small chapel were you can offer prayers as well...get down at westminister station

Inspired British History and Spiritual Commitment. This trip to London, my colleague and I took the time to tour this MASSIVE beloved history-packed landmark in London. We used the audio tour and enjoyed it very much, awe-inspired by the architecture. A GREAT way to 'study' British history by the experience of walking past so many monuments and tombs. As nursing leaders traveling from Canada and India, we were granted a private opportunity to climb a steep and winding staircase to the dedicated Nurses Chapel. This was a highlight for us to say our prayers for nurses worldwide. But, we understand we were granted special privilege and this is not always given.
So amazing!!!!. Incredible audio tour and such an amazing place, 100% worth the admission fee! a must if going to London. An immense amount of history and past in this wonderful place.

A lot more to the Abbey than I realised.. What a wonderful tour of the Abbey my wife and I had. There was certainly a lot more to it than what we had initially expected even after seeing some documentaries over the years on it. Very much well worth a visit.

Steeped with history. I had last visited the Abbey 20 years ago and despite being frequent travellers to London hadn't returned as " too full of tourists". What a pity as this is a must do. Whilst not the most useful place for a pram we did navigate our way around and spend a full 2 hours with the audio commentary looking at all the famous that are interned there. Don't expect too much from the coffee shop, choice is limited and staff under pressure

Incredible Architecture. We waited approx. 15 minutes to get in. Well worth the wait. As a bonus we were able to attend mass as they hold mass weekdays at 12:30 pm. The structure is jaw dropping. Stained glass windows, marble floors, arches, tombs, statues, organ accompaniment, history. The self guided tour allows you to stroll through at your own pace. A must see!

I thought I knew ........ I thought I knew what this "church" held as I had seen it so often on TV and at £20 entrance???. However, I used the 2 for 1 offer available to any main line train travelers for my wife and I and then once inside the amount of history lying within amazed. This is a real must see.
Visit at 5pm when open late. We came at 5pm on Wednesday, no lines, lots of room in chapels. So much to take in, well worth the money given they don't receive tax money.

You have to visit here when you visit London.. If you have only time to visit one piece of history while you are in London, it has to be Westminster Abbey! It is like a time capsule of English history. There are tombs of Kings and Queens, 17 in total, as well as poets, musicians and writers. It's over one thousand years old and is one of the most famous gothic buildings in the country.

One of my favorite memorable tours in London. We bought tickets at the gate and walked inside. Oh my heavens, I was taken back by the beautiful chapels and the history within this church. While there members of the Clergy were walking around talking to us and even invited the tourist to participate in a prayer for world peace. My only regret is that I didn't return to attend service.

At 71, this was my first visit. I thought I knew it but it was still "WOW"!. You all know what you are expecting, but I guarantee you will be surprised and over-awed. Unlike some similar type buildings, this one does not zap your energy and the superb audio guide works very well, allowing you to concentrate on the features that you wish to choose. My greatest surprise was the Henry the Seventh Lady Chapel and it's wonderful ceiling which I equated in wonder with the Taj Mahal - which I have visited.The English Breakfast is worthy of investigation.Be early, it's worth it.

British History. The multi-language audio-visual guide included in the ticket price (£20) is excellent and adds to the visitor experience. Be prepared to queue for entry; in our case about 20 minutes on a Wednesday morning - booking on-line may avoid the queue! There are several fascinating aspects of British history highlighted during the tour, but do take time to speak to the guides and volunteers, who have a wealth of knowledge. Even though this was our second visit, it still took nearly 3 hours to complete the tour! Don't run out of time, as the last part of the self-guided tour is the really interesting, "Poet's Corner", where a number of British literary folk are interred or are honoured memorial plaques.
AWESOME. i was captivated by this wonderful building, well worth the entrance fee, the history is awe inspiring and there is so much to see, the place is huge. A must visit in London.

Be sure you know the open and close hours for your visit day. In a one week visit to London ask me how many times we tried to get into Westminster Abbey? Three! and we were off the hours each time once by less than five minutes. However the outside is highly photogenic as everything else in the area and you can go around the back and visit other interesting parts of the church buildings. It's also only a block or so (crowded with tourists) from the metro stop. Great photo ops of the London Eye and Big Ben.During our visit there was a war memorial display of thousands of tiny crosses and flags all over the grounds.Even if you can't get inside it's a wonderful exerience.
A Historic Treasure. The church was beautiful. You can find Queen Elizabeth the firston display. The graves were marked with headstones that were very detailed. Not very exiting.

Must-see. -entrance for free with the London pass
-interesting Tour with an Audio guide (spend as much as you like)
- historical, amazing building

Beautiful church. Such beauty & history! Definitely recommend for travelers. Recommend the audio tour!
Take your time and really look at the church & its history. Definitely an icon of London in my opinion!
Beautiful but exy . Beautiful church but very expensive for what you get... Great for photos and to see the architecture but one visit is enough to satisfy

A real highlight! . We were so impressed with Westminster Abbey! We bought entry tickets on line prior to the day. On arrival, we walked straight in ahead of a line approximately 300 metres long! We paid £5 for the verger tour and spent almost two hours being shown around by a cheerful and incredibly informative verger, and when we later did the audio tour on our own, we realised she had shown and explained almost everything we were hearing on the audio tour! During our visit,there was a minute's silence for the people of Belgium after the bombings, and the entire Abbey was completely silent. A true sign of respect. This Church has such an intimate feel despite the numbers passing through each day. It might be physically a bit chilly, but the warmth that eminates from it is very special. I found Westminster Abbey a highlight of our trip and would recommend it to anyone as a must see!

Absolutely brilliant. There are not enough to words to describe this abbey. The audio tour greatly enhances the incredible history, vision and creativity of the abbey. The staff are very helpful and obliging. I loved seeing the burial site of Mary Queen of Scots.

Very Informative. Lots of history, particularly Royal history, and the architecture is very impressive. The windows and arches are especially impressive. Quite expensive at £20 per person which I booked online to save queuing. Lot of guided tours and bored looking parties of teenagers as might be expected. Useful to listen in to the guides alongside the handheld audio guides provided. Disappointing not to be able to enter the Edward I area but I guess understandable due to it's frail condition. Plenty to keep visitors occupied for at least two or three hours. Certainly learnt a great deal in a relatively short space of time. Restaurant and snack bar is available in the Abbey. Seemed reasonably priced for London. Would have liked to have seen more of the restoration activity being performed in the older part of the Abbey.

So glad to finally see this. We finally saw Westminster Abbey on our 3rd trip to London. We had seen the outside of course but we finally got the chance to go in. We did it as a London Walks tour which I highly recommend. There is an audio guide but I find those boring. The church is quite large and there is so much history. Neither of us are overly religious but this is more of a historical building than solely a religious center. You get to see where famous people are buried or memorialized. I went to see Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots and was not disappointed. The memorial for the unknown soldier is also very moving. It was also interesting to see the coronation chair and where coronations take place and how they add scaffolding for more seats. It was also interesting to see the progression of the church and when new areas where added on.

one of the most visited churches in all the world. is one of the most famous, historical and widely visited churches, not only in Britain, but in the whole world. It, has been the church for British Coronations for every sovereign, since Edward the Confessor before 1066, except for Edward the 8thFor many centuries, it has been the burial place of kings, queens lessor royalties, warriors and the "Celebrity du JourOn display is a chair used during the Coronation ceremony. It is curious, the chair has graffiti carved all over it. In the 1850's or so, students from the Westminster School snuck into the cathedral and, as a prank, they carved their names into the wood. Since that was 150 years ago, it was just past off as a boyish prank and nothing at all happened to the kids at all. Today, who knows The day to day business of the cathedral was conducted in the Chapter House. It contains a wealth of medieval paintings and the floor of beautiful, brilliantly colored tiles are original to the 13th century. Parliament's House for the Commons, from Edward the 1st through Henry the 8th, met here.

Abbey Lane.... I so enjoyed taking a tour of this historical building. Unbelievable what they built so long ago!!!... The best part is the location of The Abbey, and what is all around the building. There is a charming little lane close by and it is the entrance, to a private school. Knowing this I still went it anyway... and took some great pictures of the Abbey, from a view most travelers don't see. Was a great afternoon out, in the city of London.

Excellent. Now I'm not a religious person, but If your visiting London you have to visit one of it's iconic buildings Westminster Abbey, there is so much history in this building that you really need to see it for yourself. Entry price is £20 for adults, with the option of a free audio guide and map which I would recommend getting, listen to the introduction then follow the guide and map and start the tour. You could easily spend a full day in here, there's so much history to see. See where the coronation of the monarchs of England takes place, take in the splendour of the architecture of the building, and view the resting places of numerous people, including former kings and queens, poets, authors, actors and actresses. I spent a good couple of hours walking around and only left because the Abbey was closing, sadly there's no photography allowed inside but well worth a visit.
Full of History. It is rather grand, but not all that big, lots of rooms behind the alter, but it so full of history and if you are into Tudor history it is the place to go.
Awe Inspiring. Amazing how the architecture has stood the test of time. Westminster Abbey is simply amazing to see.
One of TOP10 must see in London. Great building with impressive architecture. Worth visiting inside! It'a certainly the gem of London, lots of history and culture in it. I will certainly come back!

Beautiful and Historic Westminster Abbey. Highly recommend seeing Westminster Abbey, and if the timing is right you may be able to attend a short service and take communion....a real highlight for us!
AMAZING. Even if you don't go inside this church is worth seeing! It's also super close to other attractions (Parliament, Big Ben, etc). I recommend going on Sandeman's free walking tour.

See the tombs of all the Kings & Queens you learnt about in School . Amazing history - well worth a visit.
See where all the Kings and Queens were crowned and where they are buried.
Brings to life all the history lessons you had in school.
Would highly recommend.

Evensong was magnificent!. We were so fortunate to be able to participate in the Evensong Service. We sat in the choir loft, beside the men's choir, which performed beautifully. Truly the experience of a lifetime.

Brilliant place to visit - but too pricey. Why is Westminster Abbey charging so much? When you have a family, can be so expensive to go in, and will make me think again if we did want to visit.
Maybe reduce the entrance price.

Take the tour and stay for Evensong. This is on the must-do list for London. A royal peculiar (not a church, not a cathedral, etc.) this has more history per square foot than any other place in London. The tour is a bit dear, but worth the money. Go after lunch and stay for Evensong sung by the outstanding Westminster Abbey Choir. Or just go for Evensong - just queue outside the gates at the tour one hour before (check online for times as they change with the seasons). Entrance to the service is free - lasts about one hour - and is exquisite.

Brilliant!. Cannot recommend enough. Do not let the queues put you off as yes it can be quite long but before you know it you are in and it is so worth it. We has buy one get one free tickets but even at the full cost it would have been worth it. It was just a beautiful place and steeped in history too.

Really interesting even for the non-religious. The most interesting things about the abbey are the architecture and all the people buried here. It seems to really be a phenomenal graveyard (although it is still an operating church and holds the Royal functions) with not only many Royal and aristocratic people from history buried here but many recognisable writers have memorials here too.Pre purchase tickets if possible as the line is long. Also bring a jacket as the spot is quite windy and cold while you're waiting!

Impressive. This one is an impressive building. Obviously we all saw it many times over the years on various platforms but seeing it up close is a different story. Worth the time. It is one of the musts I believe

Amazing history. Amazing place to visit , so much history, so many famous people and royalty are buried here and their stories are amazing. Managed to attend a small group service in Edward the confessors tomb , really something to remember

Amazing Place. What an amazing experience! An absolutely beautiful church, we'd love to have spent much more time there listening to the history (use the audio tour) but had a tight schedule. The staff is very knowledgeable as well, even for the most odd questions... The cafe was very good, albeit their service was a bit slow.
Beautiful. It is gorgeous and ornate. My only negatives are that it is crowded and you aren't allowed to take photos.

Extremely long wait, very expensive, fairly worth it. The history in this building is magnificent. You walk in along this audio tour that you can pick up included in entry in a variety of languages, and it's very detailed and wonderful. It follows you around the main sections of the building and keeps you at an accelerated pace not to cluster too many customers. Three some of my favorite writers buried there, scientists, and of course the royalty. It's also cool that the dutchess and the prince were married there. It was over an hour in line, and about £20 each. If you're okay spending the time and money, go for it.

Lots of history here. As advertised (by travel blogs, etc., not by the church itself), Westminster Abbey has a lot of history. We enjoyed a walk through using the audio guides. Disappointed that no photography is allowed.

Respite & Reflection. We went to Westminster Abbey to look at the architecture and Poets Corner, but were pleasantly surprised to find that the Abbey runs as a church. An ecumenical short prayer and reflection (In the Anglican/Episcopal tradition) are offered every 30 minutes -- and all are invited to take a moment to silently join. It was unexpected and made a simple tourist stop more meaningful.

regular visitor. This is one of London's many iconic landmarks; the epicentre of much of our nations history. The place oozes charm, pageantry and historic events. one tip; avoid the entry charges by indulging in choral evensong, thereby reminding yourself of the true purposes of this cathedral church and soaking up the beauty of the singing of this great choir

Evensong service was spiritually moving.. We missed the last tour but stuck around for Evensong which starts promptly at 5 PM. It was completely worth it. First, the Choir has perfected the Gregorian/a Capella style and sets the ephemeral mood with superb harmonies. The Vicar and other clergy present a crisp and theologic 40 minute service and the visitor experiences the Abby as it was intended- a house of worship. No admission fee is required but I for one made a generous donation on my way out . This was a most effective way to experience the Abby.

Fantastic experience. A must for a London visit.. This was my third time to The Abbey and I feel like I learn something new every time. The architecture is amazing, the history overwhelming. It's an amazing structure and worth the expense and time to visit. The staff were extremely helpful.
Love This Place. The history of Westminster Abbey is fantastic. If you can participate in a guided tour I recommend doing so to get a better appreciation for the history.

I think the most interesting place in London. I was fascinated doing the walking audio tour. I usually find the audio tour tools to be boring and difficult to use. The one at this place is fascinating and easy to use and stay on track with. In all if you listen to it in entirety your visit will be about 2-2.5 hours.

An unforgettable experience.. After queuing for about ten minutes, we paid the entrance fee and were handed a map and a pre-recorded audio guide and listened to Jeremy Irons as we walked round the Abbey.We had a very enjoyable time exploring this magnificent building, there is so much history. The outside of the Abbey is amazing but the inside is absolutely breath-taking and the stained glass windows are beautiful.Since 1066AD Westminster Abbey has been the site where all the coronations took place and it is awe-inspiring to stand within inches from where kings and queens have been crowned. You can also get quite close to the throne in which the monarchs were seated while being crowned. This is the final resting place of many of the kings and queens we read about in our history books. Also Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, Sir Laurence Olivier and William Shakespeare to name but a few.
Beautiful. Give yourself enough time to do the audio tours. This was fascinating to me. Loved this experience. The abbey is beautiful.

Beautiful building reminiscent of the empire days of England. This building is so grand and architecturally appealing both fro. A design as well as a location prospective. Walking around the building at sunset is just amazing. Take a glimpse of the building before sunset just across from the Thames river.

We attended the evening service. We were happy to attend the evening service. This is a memorable experience with the Abbey Choir singing. The Cathedral itself is very beautiful and well worth visiting.

Living History. The visit here was one of the highlights of our visit to London. This place tells you more about England and the monarchy than any other place we visited. Beautiful cathedral and very organised too. The Dean was very friendly and gave us much information.
Remembrance Weekend. We went to the dedication of the field of remembrance outside the abbey and then in to the church. Hugely moving experience. Highly recommended.

Attend Evensong. Most days at 5pm you can attend Evensong, an app 30 min mass that includes the boys choir from the nearby Westminster Abbey Choir School. You won't be able to "tour" the church, but you get to see plenty & we thought it was a wonderful experience.

Abbey of kings, queens, and the great dead. I always find the abbey so enigmatic. It is a massive and beautiful stricture with gothic and even Norman architecture. Places you see on TV in royal celebrations and mourning actual seem small to me while the building itself seems to occupy more land than it really does. The famous and the once famous are all memorialized here and more often than not intured here. A tour of the great, the powerful, the loyal, the literary, and the most devout of England.A place of reverence that simply must be seen to be believed.
Beautiful church. A gorgeuos church at out side, and so expensive to enter! It is not necessery know about how beatiful it is!We can spend money looking at better places
History class. the interiors of the Abbey are Stunning...with famous ppl statues on display ..A definate visit for first time London visiters
Great Minster. To the ones which loves cathedrals, minsters and gothic architecture, this place really worth the visit
Definitely worth to visit - but rip off... or?. Traveller's top tip - go during service time and you can enjoy both free entry and magnificent music all for free.

The place was amazing. You can't miss out on the Westminster Abbey it is absolutely breathtaking. Pictures don't do it justice!!! All the history that is in this place is amazing! The architecture is incredible, amazing, wonderful every word I could think of to use for this amazing place you can't miss out on it!!!!
a full day. this is a definite must for anybody visiting london - been a few time now and it takes the whole day if you take time to take it all in rather than just a snapshot visit
Expensive but worth it.. Similar to most great cathedrals. There all amazing just to see. If you consider what it took to build even more so.

Amazing and so full of history. We received free entry with our London Pass (great value and would highly recommend buying this pass. We were absolutely stunned by the beauty and history of this wonderful Abbey. To think we were walking in the same place that the kings and queens of England had walked was amazing. You get a free audio guide so that you get the full history as you go and you can take your time walking around. Would definitely not miss this on your trip. The staff are also very helpful and will give extra information if you take the time to talk to them
Amazing.. Wish we had more time to visit this site. I can't say enough about the Abbey. The King Henry VII crypt alone is worth the price of admission.
All about the royals. Interesting to a limit if you really want to learn about coronation procedures and how the royals are crowned, wed and buried.

Choral Evensong - fabulous!. Went to the Abbey for choral evensong twice during our visit, The singing is amazing from the choir. The worship is peaceful & meaningful & you get to sit & look at this wonderful building. It is free of charge but a collection is taken at the end for a very worthy cause.

A great lesson in History . I must admit I was reluctant about this visit mainly due to the long line to get inside. But the waiting in line was all worth it once inside. This place is simply fantastic and the provided audio did certainly make the self-tour very informative while doing it at my own pace. It was a very appreciated piece of history. I highly recommend it as it is worth every minute.

Stunning . Anders absolute must visit in a trip to london. The building is stunning both inside and outside with a multitude of statues of both famous and infamous people. Make sure to take the guided tour it provides alot of nice information. The supposts are friendly and willing to give extra and sometimes fun info when you ask them. Too bad you are not allowed to take pictures inside.

Always a classic - but a little overrated. Personally I'm not a huge fan of the interior of Westminster Abbey. It always feels a bit crowded (even without the crowds). If you want history though, this is the place to go.

Enchanted by history. A MUST SEE for anyone visiting London. A spectacular demonstration of human ingenuity and dedication. What a great experience walking through the halls of a 7th century building. The building itself is exquisite and very well maintained. The staff are extremely professional and helpful.Entry tickets are quite expensive, but I guess worth the money.I can definitely recommend visiting Westminster Abbey.

Really a beautiful place inside and out. This is definitely worth it for any person of any religion. Just a beautiful church and some amazing history in this building. the tours are great and very informative but the audio guide is really good too. If you can see a service inside its worth staying.

Fabulous !. You can feel the history consume you the second you walk in the door. It's stunning !! The literary graves are amazing, the cloisters. The aisle Kate misddleton walked down ! It's a stunning place. Give yourself a few hours here

See where Charles Darwin is Buried!. Westminster Abbey holds so much history your visit here will surprise you beyond its beauty. Seeing the tombs for Mary Queen of Scots and Charles Darwin were amazing and then walking the aisle that Kate walked when marrying William and seeing the place where Diana's funeral took place was sobering. Highly recommend.

An astonishing place. I was surprised at how awe-inspiring this building is. Externally, it is a striking and imposing structure. Once inside, you cannot fail to be impressed by the splendour and antiquity of its contents. The audio tour is really helpful, and guides you by some astonishing reminders of our history.It was majestic, beautiful and thought-provoking. So many sights seen so often on TV were found every few steps. Poets Corner was a particular delight. A day's visit would not be long enough to take in all the Abbey has to offer.

Its got a lot of history but lots of dead people. This is a very beautiful church. But lots of dead buried people. Yes famous. I was more then done after a short time. But I had the London Pass and it was included. Look up London Pass and it will get you almost 60 attractions for one price. Well worth it if you are a mover and shaker.

Gothic Abbey has been standing the location since the 7th century. Need to say more? The place where the Kings and Queens were coronated and burial sites for the famous and infamous. Included in London Pass, they hand out tour set with multiple languages, tour on your own pace. There are people help with info and direction inside the Abbey. I deliberately asked to see the tomb or the slab for Sir Darwin and Newton, was told the remains were actually under the slab. How surreal.
Must Visit. Grand in every aspect! Worth every penny.I strongly recommend taking the audio guide - very informative and lucid.I was lucky to hear the live organ as well.

Well done. When you're a history buff and you've visited many sites around the world, you can tell which ones are well run and which ones are not. Westminster Abby is well done. I downloaded the iPhone app before going and listened on my phone rather than using the audio devices offered on site. Jeremy Irons narrates the tour, which makes it even better!

One time is not enough. An amazing walk through history, even with two visits to this outstanding cutural site one cannot possibly take it all in, sit in a few places and just appreciate the majestity of the history that surrounds you.

Spectacular Must-Do in London!. I visited right before the Christmas holiday. From the minute that you step in, you can tell that you've just walked into something really special. I loved the time spent here. The audio guides are a must. I really wish that I could have taken pictures but respect that we cannot. It's worth the 20 pounds even on a very dreadful rainy, cold day!

My Favorite Sight in London!. Too bad photos are not allowed inside! If only they allowed it, I could take pictures of its marvel, share it with the world and promote more visitors for them and in turn, make them more profitable!You'll be amazed at its architecture! I would lay on the floor and stare up the ceiling if they allowed it. It's crazy how many kings and queens are buried here and how long they've been deceased! Issac Newton and Charles Darwin are buried here!TIP:Get there early and beat the crowd! There's a cafe connected to the Abbey right around the corner called Cellarium. Have breakfast here and head to the Great North Door of the Abbey 20 mins before they open as the line starts to form.

Must-see place on your visit to London. We had been to London on other occasions, but this was a first for us to be able to visit the abbey. We arrived late morning on a Friday. There were almost no line to get in. Price was 20 pound per person, which included an audio guide. Take your time to go to each section and listen to the audio description of the rich history here. No photo's allowed inside, but you can get lots of great pics on the exterior.
A beautiful church. This church is really worth at least one visit. Unfortunately I think it is very expensive for a church

Evensong at Westminster Abbey. At 4:00 pm we headed to Westminster Abbey for a free worship service called Evening Song. We were able to sit in the choir stand and enjoy an intimate traditional worship service. A Boys Choir sang and the Priest did readings from the Bible, recitations, and prayers. An official from Grenada read John 3 one of my favorite books of the Bible. It was a up lighting experience.

A highlight and a must see.... ...carve out some time to visit. While not cheap, this visit is informative and you get to walk through one of the key places where even today royal events take place. There are seats inside to rest, a restroom, as well as a free audio guide. They serve communion every day, feel free to stay for the service - all can partake (usually around 12:30 but check the website).

Unbelievable place to visit.. Fantastic place to visit and one of London's greatest historical attractions. Can easily take a couple of hours to stroll through. Very informative audio guides are available which provide a rich background as one tours various parts of the abbey. Incredible landmark full of history dating back to 900 AD. A must see when visiting London, you won't be disappointed.

walk among the famous. what a wonderful building with the tombs of the historical makers it is a very humbling experience , the grave of the unknown soldier makes you wonder about the futility of war , walking passed the tombs of the Kings and Queens of the lessons that we were taught at school ,

The most historically important church in England. I am lucky to have lived near Westminster Abbey for the majority of my life. I tend to visit every five years or so to see if anything has changed. The beauty of the Abbey is that in a dynamic city like London very little does change inside. The highlights for me are as follows: the tomb of Edward the Confessor, for whom the Abbey was founded. He died nearly a thousand years ago; the sword of King George VI, which is really his only memorial in the Abbey, and the beautiful sparse Chapter House. If you want to start ticking off resting places of monarchs, then this place is a good start: the remains of Elizabeth I, Mary I, Mary Queen of Scots, Henry V, Henry VII, James I, Edward III, Richard II and Edward VI are all here. Just as impressive is an understated little door near the entrance to the Chapter House, which bears a plaque stating that it is 'The Oldest Door in Britain'. It was installed in the year 1050. do not miss the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, which is quite a humbling thing, and the Coronation Chair. Chaucer is here. There is a constellation of poets. And finally, do not miss Thomas Parr - 'Old Parr'.

A must-see. Worth spending time to go round Westminster Abbey with the audio guide to get most out of the visit. Lots of volunteer staff to answer questions and opportunity to sit and take in surroundings

So rich in history. You will spend about 2-3 hours here if you really want to understand what this monument is all about. First, the exterior of the church is just breathtaking. The audioguide tour is great f you want to get some basic history of what the church is about and the many events it has been a part of over the years and the people who contributed to it. Would definitely recommend a visit earlier in the morning for better lighting throughout. Sadly, no photography allowed inside the Abbey.

Don't miss this!. I didn't take the tour here the first two times I was in London, but didn't miss it this time. The history of this beautiful place is remarkable. So many things to see and learn about it is incredible. Don't miss this!

Syria. After seing all the tumbs and statues I reached the main isle where a voice asked us to pray for Syria. I had just received some news from a friend who was working as a doctor there, and he was safe. Then I read Auden's verse in the floor: " in the prision of his days, Teach the free man how to pray. I felt so blessed!

Travel back in time. We didnt book tickets in advance and there was only a small queue when we got there at about 10.30. Audio guide gives good basic information on many of the items of interest, but we latched on to a school group being shown around for a short time and picked up all sorts of fascinating info, such as Anne of Cleaves being buried jus a few feet from where the queen was crowned. If you get the chance speak to one of the guides who will probably tell you some stuff that isnt on the audio.There is a large memorial stone to Winston Churchill who refused to be buried in the Abbey. He had said that no one walked over him when he was alive and they werent going to do it when he was dead!So many influencial people buried or remembered here, blink and you will miss something.We went on a quiet day, but stil lots of people here, but I can imagine the Abbey can get pretty congested on a busy Summers day so may be best to get here early on.There is so much to see if you are interested in British history, that you will need up to 3 hours to take it all in in.There is a very nice coffee shop/restaurant to visit after you have visited the cloisters. Not cheap but service is excellent.

Breathtaking. This beautiful structure is just breathtaking from start to finish and the only challenge here is retaining the information in the volumes that come at you ! Do take the audio guide ( narrated beautifully by Jeremy Irons ) as otherwise you will miss out on vital references . Its difficult to put into a short review the importance of this monumental building . Aside from the abundance of Monarchy and historical people resting here the architecture and artistry is wonder of the world material .

Breathtaking ceiling views. Worth every since pence to see the lady's chapel. So much amazing history and beauty here! Def do the audio tour and go into all the little chapels to see the tombs of ancient kings and queens.
Excellent place to go. Have to say I didn't know what to expect from Westminster abbey! It is always a great place to go for history! All the great British statesmen and people of note are there! 👍👍👍
Must go - pay for the self-guided tour!. You must see this historic Abbey. While St. Paul's is a wonderful experience, Westminster Abbey brims with history worth the visit.

A historic mausoleum and ancient abbey. So much history to be heard from the audio guide and from the assistants walking around, they really try to answer every question you have. Beautiful tombs and preserved history, great to see where famous people and royalty are buried.

Must-see place to "meet" Kings & Queens of England. Along with the Tower of London, this is the other must-see for any history lover or person obsessed with the British monarchy. The sense of history permeates the Abbey despite the massive crowds. Strongly suggest that in any busy season you line up at least one hour before the doors open, as this will minimize your total wait time.

Overwhelmingly Amazing.. No matter what I say, nothing will prepare you for the abundance of art, architecture, history and beauty you'll find here. So much to see, I suggest going with a guide who will help you see the details without being completely overwhelmed by the magnificent splendor of it all.

Amazing. After seeing Royal weddings and Princess Diana's funeral broadcast from inside the Abbey, it was amazing to venture inside and learn more of the wonderful and amazing history of the place. Worth the entry fee and the free audio guide.

Amazing cathedral with incredible history. I managed to get in with a friend on the last tour group of the day, so it wasn't quite so packed as I could expect it to be. I took the audio tour, and there is a huge amount to see. The audit guide is pretty good, but a few things seemed to be short on the guide, but there were several docents that would answer questions. Be prepared that the full tour is quite long (as the last group we had to deal with some level of being pushed out at the end and it still took around 2 hours).The sheer amount of historic things to see, and the highly detailed workmanship is amazing, and a definite must on anyone's list if they are interested in history.

Go to Mass!. My friends and I walked by and happened to see a sign that said "Worship: All are welcome". We decided to attend the 9am service. We waited outside the gate and a priest let us in. Now, you cannot take pictures inside on a tour anyways. So we got to have mass inside one of the chapels! The abbey was cluttered with memorials and tombs! We didn't get to see everything, but we got the general idea. It was free, no line, and I got some Jesus for the day.

I see dead people. well...I didn't actually see dead people, but I read a lot about them. There is some interesting history that you read at the museum about those who were there and that is what makes the Abbey stand out.
Westminster Abbey. Free audio guide visit in several idioms. The architecture is nice and we "walk" along the history of the British monarchy.

The History of Great Britain is Here. Absolutely stunning, and always helpful to realize that this is still a functional parish of the Church of England. The history of Great Britain permeates every place one walks. A definite return trip is needed.

Very impressive!. We booked the tickets online which is advisable (cheaper and faster entry. The audio guides are very useful and the information is well presented (in German). The walk around the Abbey was awesome. Although plenty to see it's not too much and there are chairs to sit down. We had the opportunity to participate in a lunchtime service. The cellarium is to be recommended for a snack or a meal. The only slight point of criticism is the rather bored and unfriendly attitude of one staff member at the entrance. Everybody else was very attentive and helpful, especially the gentleman handing over the audio guides.

Historical Place. House of many tombs of the past kings and queens, sometimes i feel like in the movie of drwcula :) . witness place of royal weddings and dead ceremony, Including Lady Diana , its a beautiful architecture church. Must visit if you come to London

Handicapped / Wheelchair Bound Review. My son is in a large powerchair. We were able to view this attracation by using a side door entrance. There were a few areas that he wasn't able to access but very minor. Wheelchair users and a companion are free on the tour. A nice plus that most of London's attraction offer.

Unusual church. Very different church. I visited a lot of churches in Europe and this was a nice surprise. Ticket was 20 pounds, which is a lot but you get headphones so you can listen storys about history of the abby. If you come in 12 00 you can vitness service. when we visited there was some kind of restaurations going on, so the toilets were outside

Found this facsincating!. Travelled here last summer; who wouldn't want to visit Westminster Abbey where royals have been married, baptized and buried. So interesting to view inside and out. Lots to see! Was a memory I soon won't forget!

Historic and impressive church. Nice architecture. But more important this church has seen so many historic events and is so closely connected to the royals and Britain that is a must see for your London experience
Tourist Place. This is another must when visiting London. History abound here. Everyone will have a great time and pictures galore.
Sunday Worship. WOW.. To sit one else away from the alter and then to have the view. What can one say. Historic. Just to see what you see on tv and be there makes all the difference.
Absolutely breathtaking!. Even if you don't know the history behind it, you still need to visit! They include an audio tour with your tickets. Staff was super friendly. Definitely a must see!
Expensive But Worth It. fascinating but crowded. Best to get on a small tour, such as London Walks, to get the most out of the experience.
very intresting. well worth a visit, very intresting and so much history, a great abbey. i did think £20 each was expensive but we had buy one get one free with our train tickets.

definitely worth a visit. We went to Westminster Abbey on the 4th March. Expensive - yes, but it is really well organised. You're given a map of the abbey and an audio guide when you arrive. The audio guide was really easy to use (wasn't in some other places in London). Loads to see when you're there. It was busy but not swamped (it is March though).My mum uses a walking stick and is quite slow moving. We were there for just over 2 hours, so for most people you would need 1-2 hours for your visit.
one of the best places in london. A very iconic place in London, I highly suggest doing a tour if you can! they cost around 20-25 pounds but are extremely helpful!

Great overview of various aspects of British Culture. Kings, queens, artists and statesman. It's kind of a waste of time to do a review on here, since it's so iconic. But having said that, I appreciate that they give you an audioguide and you can roam about at your own pace. Most random souvenir of the visit? Walking by England's Oldest Door. O-kay.

Wonderful tour; don't miss Choral Evensong!. The audioguide enhanced the tour of the Abbey so much; great way to learn more of the history behind the architecture and events that have happened inside the church. Beautiful inside and out, but no photography allowed inside. I highly recommend attending the Choral Evensong service in the evening for an intimate worship experience. (Queue early for this service!!)

Is this 'Essex'?. Goodness, you really must visit, but it really is a place that the Church have made money out of people looking for their stair-way to Heaven! The whole place is crammed to the gunwales with anybody who can buy their place! It is, at the same time, horrible and fascinating!

Wow. As my title suggests the outside and the inside are just jaw dropping if you love architecture and history you will love Westminster abbey the scale of the building is mind blowing considering when it was built and the tools they had staff were nice and I enjoyed my visit it's a pity photos aren't allowed although that didn't stop everyone #cough# the Asians from ignoring the many signs.

A historical goldmine. Whichever way you look within the abbey is a memorial to someone that has been part of History (or someone that paid to be among those that were part of history). I'm glad I went in January as I imagine it would be less pleasant when the abbey is busy.

Phenomenal. Can't recommend this enough, enjoyed It very much. The architecture is amazing and the audio really brings the abbey to life. Every inch is a story and so much history. We took our time and really explored everything. It is a bit expensive, but we showed our train tickets and got 2 for 1. Well worth it!

My Favorite Place in the City. There is something peaceful and grounded about Westminster Abby. After living in London for a year, and visiting numerous attractions, the one to which I want to return is this. A thousand years of history with the artifacts, architecture and abbots to show for it, you simply will not be bored.

Hesitant but so happy I did the tour . My husband and I were both kind of hesitant to do the tour of this. We thought 20 pounds was a bit much, but I'm telling you, so happy we did. We both loved it. From the gorgeous architecture to the immense history, this place had us both in awe. Seeing tombs of Queen Elizabeth and many other prominent figures in English and medieval history was just too cool!
Wonderful Christmas Service. Was lucky enough to get tickets to the Christmas service at Westminister. Was a beautiful morning in a beautiful place!

Love the Architecture! . Such a beautiful structure with fascinating history! Looks amazing in the day and is lit well at night. If you stand in front by the gift shop there is easily accessible free wifi. Fun to Skype someone with the Abbey behind you!

Must see in London . I visited on a Thursday morning and the abbey was starting to get crowded. Regardless of whether you bought your tickets online or at the counter, you would have to join in the queue right at the entrance to verify your tickets before you can get it. Nevertheless the entrance fee was definitely worth it. Westminster Abbey is so magnificent and splendid! The free audio guide gave a good introduction to the various parts of the abbey and the history behind each chamber was also provided. Luckily the college garden was open and I could take a stroll through the very nice and quaint little garden. For anyone who is visiting London for the first time, or for those who have been here a couple of times but have not entered the abbey, I would highly recommend spending a morning here to soak in the wonderful interior of the building.

Another iconic location. The day we attended it was extremely busy so we didn't actually enter the building. The £20 entry per person I thought was quite steep, but the sheer presence of the building from the outside makes it a must see visit. At least you can say you've been there!!

History comes to life where Kings and Queens are buried.. Excellent visit for those interested in history. Kings, Queens, famous literary, stage and music geniuses, and a few other rich folk are buried here. Even on guy who was supposedly 152 years old. Great way to enjoy 2-3 hours of time invested. Audio guide recommended.

A mighty building.. Situated close to Big ben. An grand and mighty building which wont dissapoint the visitor. Filled with history of important people not just for England but for common world as well. Be sure to walk the whole recommended line around. In the end you can see the old monestary. A very Nice experience.

One of the best places to visit in London. The visit to Westminster Abbey is just a unique and unforgettable experience, since most of the iconic royal ceremonies (coronations, weddings, funerals) have taken place here, and many of the most important British Kings, Queens, Scientists and Poets are buried here.Before our visit we downloaded the audioguide app to our phone, and we enjoyed the tour at our own pace.

For the History Buffs. Expect long lines - Make sure you have a pass. I have seem prettier churches but this one has thousands of memorials to all the famous people just about that have lived in the last 3-400 years. This detracts somewhat from the overall building and it's purpose. Still worth seeing. Check out Poet's Corner where some of the famous writers are memorialized.

Nice. Sadly out of 3 days we were in London, Westminster Abbey was closed all of them. We were still allows to attend the service which was wonderful. I was still bummed as a Queen Elizabeth I fan, I really wanted to visit all the museums and monuments related to her and this was at the top of my list. Glad I was still able to go inside but bummed I didn't get to visit anything in there.

Worth every pound for the family entrance.. Running a couple of hours late, we were grateful that we purchased our tickets for Westminster Abbey before the visit. The queue (in the rain) at 11 am on a Saturday was getting long. We were welcomed in immediately by a friendly security guard and promptly started our tour. My husband, the atheist, enjoyed his Westminster Abbey visit much more than I had hoped. Darwin and Newton had a lot to do with that!

very interesting. Not something I often enjoy but the two hours spent looking round were very good. So much to see and very interesting. Staff helpful but not at all patronising. I think £20 a little steep as almost deterred us but recommended.

The wonders of History. The fee was outrageous even getting a discount it was still a very hard pill to swallow,but after the shock we enterd a wonder world of history you are met by people who work in the abbey full time and given paper pamphlets end an audio version of the interesting people who are laid to rest in this wonderful place.Take a look at the fabulouse architecture the gothic style it was built in by numerouse kings and queens as they have added differet parts to the abbey. Although very costly it's still worth a visit .Asthey do not get any help from the goverment for it's up keep.
A bucket list visit. We have in the past somehow missed visiting the Abbey, we did not this time and it was a great experience

OUTRAGEOUS ENTRANCE FEE.. I cannot believe they have the nerve to charge 20 pounds to enter this church. That was $59.00 for two people. Absolutely ridiculous when you consider treasures like Notre Dame are absolutely free. It was lovely and very interesting, but that price is insane. Plus, you can't take pictures inside.
Beautiful Architecture!. This building is amazing, unfortunately we didn't go in as we were late for an appointment and the ques were large. Stunning visually and architecturally.

Does not disappoint . My daughter and I visited Westminster Abbey this past Monday morning. We toured the Abbey with the audio guide which was included in the ticket price. So beautiful inside and so full of very famous people buried in it. To think that we walked the central aisle that past and current royals have walked for their coronations - unbelievable. Towards the end of the tour is the Poet's corner where famous poets, authors and composers are buried. Not to be missed. For me the highlight was seeing yhe tomb of Queen Elizabeth I. I highly recommend going to tour the Westminster Abbey. One FYI - I bought our tickets online thinking that doing this saves me from queuing at the ticket buying line. I was mistaken - still needed to go in the ticket buying line because the online ticket needed to be scanned by the person selling the tickets. The only advantage to buying online is a slight fee savings (for an adult ticket price of €18 online instead of €20 on site).

Definitely worth a visit. After passing by on many trips to London my husband and I finally got to spend time within this amazing building. Reasonably pricey to get in at £20 each but if you travel by train I believe you can get a two-for-one offer. Included in the entrance fee is a hand held audio guide which is interesting and informative but I'm sure it can't tell you everything there is to know about the building's past and about the many historical figures and monarchs buried there. As well as the main Abbey there are other things to see such as the small gardens and cloisters. Allow up to two hours for a full visit as it's worth taking the tour slowly, perhaps even taking time to sit and just look around at the architecture.
Beautiful. A very elegant & a beautiful Church I have ever seen. Doesn't look so when you look at it from outside but the interior is stunning. Must see if you are in London.

Awesome & Full of History!. While the Abbey is pricey & often has a long queue, it is worth the wait for any history lover! Walking through the Abbey, you must do you best to look in every nook & cranny and be amazed at what you find! The building itself is beautiful & breathtaking but all the added history makes the Abbey a place you will never forget.

Go during Evensong. Too incredible to pass up. Take the guided audio tour or you'll miss most of what makes it significant. Perfect for art history and history lovers. I especially love the cloisters and Poet's Corner. The Chapter House is pretty amazing as well. I attended Evensong (you get in for free that way) and walked through afterward. Otherwise, be prepared to pay entrance fees.

Oh the history.... Coming out of the Westminster underground for the first time and having Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament fill the sky, is breathtaking. The awe continues crossing the road into Westminster Abbey. I was at the front of the queue just before 10:00am and so had no problems with crowded chapels or people blocking my way. The Abbey is steeped in history and a must for visitors to London. When I paid my 20 pounds entrance I did think it was a bit steep but as I wandered through the cathedral I was aware that this ticket was good value indeed. The Abbey can be accessed for free by attending a religious service. However there is so much to explore that I think the ticket needs to complement the religious service so that all of the Abbey can be absorbed. This is an experience I won't forget.

Superb!. If you like history you'll love WA. At almost a 1000 year old this is an amazing artefact full of the history of our marvellous nation. From monarchy to music, authors to scientists, politicians to poets this building celebrates them all. To stand next to the tombs of the great Tudor monarchs, HRH Queen Elizabeth 1 and Mary 1 of England was a deeply moving experience and one I will never forget. The tomb of the unknown warrior, the original coronation chair of almost 40 British monarchs and the altar where HRH Diana, Princess of Wales was married and where her untimely funera, l service took place as well as the phenomenal architecture are all something to behold. A fabulous, ethereal experience which I would not have wanted to miss.

Very expensive. Horrific, I lived in London for nearly 20 years, and though in my time you had to pay, you could visit the first half of the abbey for free. Now we have a ticket desk immediately after you pass through the main door staffed with with a no smiles policy team (maybe a I found them on a bad day) and the prices are extraordinary. A shame as it is great place to visit.

History and then some!. Had fifteen minute wait to get in which is not bad. Last time I was here was 5 years ago so there was some changes which were good. I like that you had an audio guide to use at your leisure. The abbey was busy but not crowded when I went. Lots of things to see but for me the highlight is seeing Queens Elizabeth I and Mary's resting place together! Amazing history and beautiful church as well.

A Memorable Experience. For me, visiting Westminster Abbey was indeed something of a religious experience, as English history is without doubt my greatest passion. I was in awe. So much to explore! I could spend a week in there, happily. The memorials were my favorite part, and if you let them know you are there to worship and not just as a tourist, you can be taken to the tomb of Edward the Confessor, and English saint and the oldest tomb in the Abbey. I was there late in the say, so we stayed for evensong. What an experience! We were toward the front of the queue so we were shown to seats right in the quire, and I was directly behind a row of Choir boys. Standing up to sing "God Save the Queen" in that space is something I will never, ever forget. Highly recommend!!

Skipped the lines. Do what I did, go to church! Decided to attend an evening mass. Great experience made greater the next morning when I noticed the lines around the block to get in to see the inside.

Amazing. The architecture and history is simply astounding. One of the must see places when touring London. So much to see in this area, don't overlook the surrounding parks. Taken together with the other attractions in this area (Big Ben, Parliament, etc), you really start to get a better sense of the history.

Once in your Lifetime. As a family - you pay £45 for entrance at the Westminster Abbey - that's $70 - ouch!But inside it's pretty interesting; see all the graves from famous British king's, queens and persons.After we left, we did not had the feeling to be cheated but the pricing does hurt; especially families with small kids. Anyway, the place is not that interesting for smaller kids as it has lots to read.We spend over 2 hours in the Abbey

A must for history lovers. After numerous visits to London finally went to see Westminster Abbey,and was truly amazed.That big church you see on telly for royal weddings and funerals holds so much history of past Monarchs of this country as well as Memorials to past great writers and notable people from History,including a man named Tom Parr who lived to be 152 years old, Fascinating .

Relish the English Spirit. I feel so ashamed now when I think of the moment that I was hesitant first if i should go and visit the Abbey or not. Thank God I did it. That is one of the most interesting and amazing places I've ever been to. When you're inside and you turn your audioguide on the first thing you hear is Jeremy Irons' voice as your guide through Westminster Abbey - oh my stars, that's a perfect start to be honest with you! Then, entering rooms one by one, you feel so overwhelmed with all this beauty and an absolutely unique atmosphere that you can't even talk ( I was with my friend and we could not share emotions for another half an hour after the visit - that 's how amazed we were!). I loved the place and I highly recommend to go. You actually see everything you have learnt at school (if you learnt English as a second language) - and that makes you feel like a part of this miracle!!!

Worth a visit. Very enjoyable tour around this beautiful abbey. The whole church is full of interesting facts and artefacts. The radio tour is also extremely interesting and very well done, making the visit much more enjoyable. My only problem is at the price which I saw to be quite steep.

Large and beautiful, a must see. There is usually a bit of a wait to get in (line). It does cost money but goes to support the church upkeep. You are provided with a pamphlet and audio guide for a self guided tour.This is a must see when you are in London.
Awesome. I visited it with London pass. It's awesome inside. It has absolutely stunning architecture. It's full of statues, oltars...
Amazing Architecture and History. I am a raving atheist...but this building was a highlight of my trip to the UK.... amazing history... amazing Architecture... must do !!!!
Beautiful!. Lovely place full of history and interesting stories, also there are times in which prayer will be said which is a beautiful experience to have in such a wonderful Abbey.

Interesting tour. Westminster Abbey is well worth a visit. We booked online which was great as we went to the front of the que and got straight in. We did not go on an escorted tour but got an ear set which you followed and it told you all about those areas. The history in their is astounding and architecturally was fabulous, the ceilings and windows were so intricate, there is so much history in that one place. It was very busy but not to crowded and we were able to view everything easily. There were plenty of staff on duty who were only to pleased to be of help. At the end of the tour there is a lovely shop where you can purchase some nice souvenirs. Well worth a visit if you are in London and we would definitely visit again. Only downside was you were not able to take photographs.

Grandest Historic Church in London. Westminister Abbey, whilst expensive (20 pounds for adults and 17 for students), still remain my favourite attraction in London city. As we arrived just after 9:30 (opening time) in February, there is absolutely no line to enter into the Abbey, and it remained quite spacious even in the smallest chapels, which is always nice. Hence, early morning (like every other top attraction) is by far the best time to visit the abbey.
