You enter through the Northern entrance (not the main entrance).Westminister Abbey has been the place for grand English ceremonies in the past, and it certainly shows in architecture. The gift shop seems to emphasise this with multiple pieces on the Queen's coronation and the royal wedding. My personal favourite part of the church is the Lady Chapel (Henry VII Chapel) with one of the best ceilings in the world, and the tomb of Elizabeth I.The Jeremy Irons audio guide (both downloadable or free with entrance) is one of the best I've used in Europe. Not too dull, so you can absorb all the information about the monarch of England (with its turbulent history), other important Englishmen buried here, and the grand architecture. The only small letdown is no photos (even without flash), but that's understandable. We spent just under 2 hours in the Abbey, and it is definitely my favourite church and attraction in London.

Beautiful church. Very nice and beautiful church in the heart of Westminster, right next to Big Ben and the Houses of the Parliament. I never entered inside so my classification is just regarding the outside view.

Simply the best. Westminster Abbey is the place to go. Full of history, very well organized with audio guide and so many opportunities to understand the history of England. I recommend to absolutely go there.

When in London you must spend time at Westminster Abby. We have visited the Abby a number of times and take our visitors here to share this amazing place with them. Waking among the resting place of Royalty and the Great and the Good is quite an experience. The Abby building is an architectural treasure. It is important to understand that this remains a place of worship and during your visit you will need to respect the worship activities that will be going on around you.
Historical sight filled with beauty and peacefulness.. This should be one of the first places yo visit while in London. This is a history lesson for young and old.

The Abbey. This was a great experience! Get the London Pass because the admission price is £20 for adults but it is worth going in just to experience the site and all that has happened there. NO PICTURES CAN BE TAKEN inside the Abbey, downer

Tourist must see. It's always great to visit Westminster Abbey. You must get there early to avoid the crowds, especially the bus tour crowds who just seem to push and push their way through in a hurry as if they have some right. We were there in January and it was packed, we arrived at 8.30 and the Tourist buses weren't far behind us.It always interesting to visit and there's always something to see which you didn't see on a previous visit. With all the crowds it's not a place to just sit and have a quite moment.
Part of our heritage. We went to the service of 9 lessons and carols. A fantastic experience to see this magnificent Abbey by candle light.
Obligatory London Sight. This is like one of those places you kinda have to go see. The architecture is beautiful, the history is interesting and its easy to find.

Awesome . Went to see this recently. The wait was about an hour. Totally worth it. It's very interesting to see such a beautiful church that is also a crypt. I highly recommend this on your trip to London.

Rivals the Best Europe Has To Offer For Architecture and History. I have had an opportunity to see a number of 'famous' house of worship from Chennai India, Istanbul Turkey, Athens Greece and Western Europe. All were different and unique in their own way. The Abbey can be added to the list of must see places. I would give it 5 stars if not that you could not take pictures inside the Cathedral which was disappointing.

Wonder History Tour of the Abbey. Really enjoyed this very interesting insight into the Abbey, the audio guide was really good. Initially thought the admission fee was quite high but taking into account the cost of the upkeep of the abbey and its history then it's well worth it. The tomb of the Unknown Soldier especially poignant also the Coronation throne amazing to think the history behind this.

Lovely place!. Really lovely inside, £20 seems a bit steep but we were in there for a good hour and a half. If you like your history you will find this very interesting, and if you're into your tourism this is a must do. Me and my girlfriend thorough,y enjoyed the experience.

Awesome, fantastic and marvellous place. It was like enter another age, you go trough the abbey travelling to the past with lots of important people in humanity history. You have to pay but if you're a student, you get a discount. Wonderful place, arquitecture and magical place

Spiritually uplifting and very enjoyable occasion in this fabulous Abbey.. The Service of Choral Evensong has taken place at Westminster Abbey, at 5.00 pm every day for the last several hundred years, and it is a very special occasion.We arrived at around 4.30 pm to ensure that we had a good seat, and we found ourselves on the edge of the Quire itself, with a wonderful view of the Altar and of the almost incredibly impressive ceiling of the Abbey.At 5.00 pm, prompt, the sound of quiet chanting, in Latin, can be heard, getting gradually louder as the Choir makes it's way up the Nave to the Quire, where the Choir take their places for the Service.It is an almost mystical experience.It is easy to follow the Service from the sheet provided to each visitor, although some of the tunes are sung in Latin.The quality of the singing is superb; the choir is VERY professional and effective, and the sound of their voices seems to lift up to the wonderful ceiling above.There is time for quiet contemplation and prayer, and we stopped to pay our respects at the tomb of the unknown soldier as we returned down the Nave at the end of the Service.Although there is an Entrance fee for visiting the Abbey during the day, Entrance, together with the programme for Evensong at 5.00 pm, is absolutely free of charge, making this about the best value of any visitor event in the whole of London! They don't even pass a plate for a collection round at Evenson, so I put some money in the box for donations near the main door.Altogether, I thought that this was a fabulously uplifting experience, and I still find it hard to understand how such a magnificent place was built, using the basic technology which architects and builders had at the time.Just go to Westminster Abbey, stand in the Nave and look up at the stained glass windows and that fabulous ceiling/roof, and MARVEL that man has made such a wonderful and fitting tribute to our Loving Lord and Father.

Wonderful tour. visited on a Monday, it wasn't too busy. Got the audio pre-recorded device, walked at leisure keying in relevant number on map. So informative and interesting. Vast, magnificent inside. Well worth spending time. For those in wheelchairs I noticed if you cannot access the side chapels there is a video on the hand held device showing into the area. Had a cake and tea in the cellarium also. Being an avid history reader especially regarding War of Roses & Elizabeth I it was of high interest. Choir stalls are beautiful.

Historical. I have been to London many times over the past 30 years, yet there is something special about the region around Westminster. Between the Houses of Parliament, Big Ben tolling, and Westminster Abbey, you are surrounded by history. Take in a service as well.
lots of dead people buried here, strong history. This church is packed with history. I never realized how huge the place was and how many historic figures are buried here.

Interesting, but no photos allowed . Fascinating and beautiful, steeped in history, but my experience was somewhat ruined by the fact photos are banned. I've been in plenty of historic churches where photography is allowed. In this day and age it is a totally unnecessary way of impacting visitor's experience.

Highlight of London. At first I was put off by the steep admission price to enter the Abbey, but after spending several minutes inside studying the art, architecture and tombs, I realized the price was money well spent. The Abbey is maintained extremely well and provides a treasure trove of history. I had no idea it also serves as a mausoleum of sorts housing the remains of some of England's most well known historical figures. The chapels are incredible, particularity the Henry VII chapel with it's beautifully intricate ceiling to colorful banners hanging down the aisles. I spent a good amount of time here and would go back in a heartbeat. The only downside is that photography is banned inside (which is bittersweet and fairly typical of other churches in London).

Amazing Building, Well organised tour. We spent two hours in the Abbey one day during January. It is an amazing building and as part of the admission fee you get a pre recorded audio tour. The audio guide is available in various languages, English being ours. The guide is very descriptive and points out all the items of interest and explains them in adequate detail without getting boring.I would recommend a visit here and consider it well worth the £20 admission fee.
So much history!. I cannot recommend Westminster Abbey enough. If your a history buff, like me, you have got to pay a visit here. One of my favourite buildings in the entire world.

So many famous graves. Pick a prominent name in English history, from poets to kings to scientists and chances are they are buried in and around the Abbey. The tour is wonderful, the architecture superb. With the location right next to New Scotland Yard, the Thames and Big Ben, it's easy to get to and a must-see for a trip to London.

Over 1,000 Years of History. Many years since I had visited this site, it is a walk through history, so many names which can be linked to events through the ages. Amazing architecture and just a awesome experience.Do visit the chapter house which is the oldest remaining area and admire the wall paintings and the area of remaining tiles, the pyx chamber, the cloisers and the gardens which even in February are attractive. A trip to the cafe is most rewarding and good way to end your visit.

Amazing!. I have been here twice and would go again! A remarkable experience - sobering and awe-inspiring. So many people of note rest within these walls and it is impossible not to catch and hold your breath when observing the monuments and reading the inscriptions. The architecture is amazing.
Magnificent Building. This was very good value to see around such an amazing building. The telephone style handsets were slightly cumbersome to hold all the time but very informative.
Historic Worth the Visit. Enjoyed the grounds and history, the architecture was spectacular and it was easy to walk through at your leisure and enjoy the place.

Guided tour of Westminster Abbey. I've been to London dozens of times, having lived in the UK until I was 27 and then been back about twice a year since. But I haven't been to that many of the famous attractions for some time, due to one factor - crowds.But in mid-2014 my wife and I decide to do a London Walk, having enjoyed many Paris Walks (while in France, obviously) and as we were staying near Trafalgar Square and we'd always wanted to see Westminster Abbey we chose a tour of the Abbey.It was fabulous. The crowds were there but being with a group we didn't have to queue and the guide was amazingly knowledgeable. If we'd gone there ourselves we'd have shuffled around and looked at this amazing building but not really known what we were seeing.As it was we heard about the unknown soldier, Edward the Confessor, seen where the queen sits, heard about the royal weddings there, seen the old throne, heard about monks being flayed alive and nailed to a door (not such a nice story but fascinating) and so on.It's an amazing building packed to the gunnels with history and still much used by the nobility and the famous today - and when you do go I strongly recommend getting a great guide like we had.

Breathtaking. We loved our time here as it was an amazing experience to visit such a historic site where so many important occasions have occured. Visiting the site of famous weddings and funerals was awe inspiring.
Beautiful!. Gorgeous place. Very long line to get in. Probably best to go as early as possible. Sometimes tough to navigate through the crowds. Historic and charming...a great stop for sightseers.
Nice. I recommend visiting the Westminster Abbey. Very beautiful interior! There is an organ concert in the afternoon (check schedule before you go there). Worth the visit!

So beautiful!. It's an amazing place, beautiful and you can feel the History everywhere. There are maps and audio tours in many language available inside, for free. Admission isn't free. But its worth the money. You can easily spend a whole morning or afternoon inside. No pictures are allowed.

Worth the Money. At 20 pounds each, we wondered if we should experience the Abbey---but it was worth every pound! This church is spectacular and the history is deep. In America we don't have anything dating to the middle ages, so it was amazing see ancient crypts of historical figures. The architecture is so impressive. It was wonderful to stand where royalty had been. It was also impressive to see the graves of important artists, writers, and musicians. Yes--you can stand on Handel's grave! We also had tea in the cafe which was the perfect ending to a long day of sightseeing.

Didn't go inside but... We were just outside of the building to get a nice view of it and the area surrounding... It truly is a beautiful Abbey! Would've loved to have gone inside and looked around, but maybe next time ;)

A sacred space that is worth your time. This was tops on our list of must-sees for our trip to London. We visited twice: once for Evensong and once for a tour. While were not there early enough to sit in the choir, by all means try to sit here if you can to just absorb the sacred space and moving sound of the choir itself, it was still a peaceful respite after a day of touring. When my 9 year old heard the choir, he assumed it was a CD – like those that his father listens to – and was blown away when he realize it was live singers filling the space. After the service, we were able to walk past the Cosmoti Pavement and through the choir and as we left, the Dean of Westminster Abbey wished us well. You cannot tour during or after service. The next morning we arrived early and queued up on the North side of the church. We were among the first 20 to enter the church and immediately asked how to get the tomb of St. Edward, the King who built this church. We were told it was an additional 5 pounds, and I was willing to pay, but when I asked a red-caped docent, he immediately brought our family there. It was especially moving as there are many Edwards in our family, and with reverence and awe of all the pilgrims before us, the docent afforded us the privilege of praying in one of the niches under St. Edward the Confessor’s tomb. For us, this church and the tomb were the highlight of our trip. My advice, go early and take it all in. The audio tour is very informative – better yet, if going with kids, view one of the BBC’s documentaries beforehand (on YouTube) and the significance of this place will resonate more with them (and you). Don’t forget to walk in the cloisters on the way out and be sure to take a peak at Kind Edward’s coronation chair, on the left, just before you exit at the front of the church.
Fascinating . Planned touristy day in London, and ended up visiting the abbey! Great to see such history, and amazing to realise what is actually in the Abby! Great cost too!

I'm an atheist and it's one of my favorite destinations!. If you love history, Kings and Queens and stunning architecture this is a must! I'm an atheist and i find this Abbey one of the most peaceful spiritual interesting locations. Historically it's epic - make sure you grab the audio tour so you don't miss all the tombs and enjoy your walk in the footsteps of Kings, Queens and legends! Pity it's not free as it really should be for ALL to enjoy.

Finally made it here. Westminster Abbey has been on my bucket list to visit for years, and I was glad to be able to tick it off.A beautiful building and a testament to fabulous engineering and stonemasonry. Full of things to see and at £20 per adult, I felt it offered great value, as I love all things historical and it helps to pay for the upkeep of this national treasure. I easily passed a couple of hours in here and found the audio commentary very interesting. The staff were also very approachable and informative about the Abbey. I sat in the garden for a while as the weather was so beautiful and it is hard to believe that it is in the centre of a capital city, right next to parliament.My only gripe is that photography is not allowed inside the building. I'd have loved to have photographed some of the wonderful tombs (especially Elizabeth 1) but that is only a minor grumble.

A wonderful place to visit. I have already been to St Paul's Cathedral and thought Westminster Abbey would be very similar but they are not. The Abbey is much smaller and much more friendlier with a real sense of community within it's walls.I was part of a tour around the Abbey and it is beneficial as the whole place comes alive. I had the privilege of meeting Jenny Petersen who originates from Melbourne and she is the real face of the Abbey. She was friendly, informative and clearly adores her calling in life. A real ambassador for the Abbey. She did the call to prayer on the hour where they ask people to stand still and pause for a quiet moment of reflection and prayer. It was pitiful how few stood still.She then held a short 5 minute service of prayer inside the Edward the Confessor chapel which was lovely.I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the Abbey and it is wonderful to walk around and see where such momentous occasions have taken place over the years.

Awe struck. The audio tour is really quite boring but being able to have a look around at all the statues and to see the long standing line of nobility that passed through the doors is pretty awesome. To go for free, have a look at the listings for a mass. Be warned that they locked the doors so don't think you are able to go have a peek then leave.

This place is very cool!. My son and I loved going here. I have always wanted to visit and this place did not disappoint. One thing we found very cool were all the royalty and famous people who are buried there. You walk around and each section there are tons of stories you learn about. Also, the architecture and design were breathtaking. I highly recommend!

silence and tearful memories. visited the building with wife , the building is quite old but strong with marvellous architecture .Lot of great peoples like sir Isaac newton were buried here .A must see place in London

Great architecture . Want their for Carol concert. Great setting great concert. Good readers. As a Carol concert however I would have preferred less choir singing and more congregation participation there are some greater rousing carols.
London Sightseeing. Amazing structure and history. Can't visit London without seeing the Abbey. Lovely souvenir shop. Enjoyed the handheld microphone tour.

A Must See!. Our favorite thing we saw in London! Stunningly beautiful. Words can't even describe! The amount of history is amazing and tour is well worth the money! Self guided audio tour available. Staff friendly and answers questions. No photos allowed to be taken inside. Gift shop and restrooms available.
Iconic place . Well work a visit for seeing English history and its such a beautiful building with such detail. I've visited many times and will visit many times more.

Breathtaking Experience. Spend the money to experience this. It was £20 per person. For what you get out of it, that is an incredible price. It is a self-guided tour, and you get a complimentary voice guided tour should you choose. (I recommend it.) The amount of history in that building is incredible. Even as a non-religious person, this place was probably my favorite stop while we were in London. The history, the architecture...simply amazing. If you have never been, do yourself a favor and check it out!

Great few hours. Took my two young kids (9&7) they did the children's trail which kept them really interested. The building is stunning and the staff were so helpful if the kids couldn't find the answers. It was £20 for 3 of us as kids went free as half term. There were audio tours for adults (which we started but too much info for the kids - bug I would have enjoyed) Would recommend.
Architectural Masterpiece . The designs were breathtaking. It's a place to be when visiting London. It's a piece of history especially when travelling with children. Great building!

Family visit. Beautiful setting! Breath taking as you walk through the beautiful church and grounds. Informative tour. Shop has a wonderful range of gifts. Something for everyone! Loved the jewellery section too. Right next to Westminster and Big Ben! Worth a visit!

Amazing!!. Seriously it is worth the money going inside. Not only is it full of history but this is another one of those places where you look and are absolutely speechless. The amount of Kings/Queens, children, scientists, military personal, writers and more that are buried inside this magnificient building can and will take your breath away. You can do the listening tour where you hold your own little radio that explains different spot in the Cathedral for free. You are not allowed to take photographs inside at all. Also and I have to say this STOP TOUCHING EVERYTHING INSIDE. It's history you can't remake these things I don't care how tempting it is there are signs everywhere to not touch and the amount of times I saw people rubbing and poking things. Don't.All proceed from your entrance fee goes towards restoring and keeping up with the Cathedral. Definitely recommend!

excellent value for money. wasnt sure aboutgoing in but there was a special half term children free offer, we ended up spending about two hours here. we took the tour ourselves using the audio guide which was very easy to follow and felt that we saw everything we should have at our own pace. would reccomend this for everyone as it is totally fascinating regardless of religion or knowledge of history

Don't Miss This. It's not the largest church I've been too but it's very beautiful and filled with great history. It took 1-2 hours to observe everything and the tour was very informative. If I could get married here I totally would because it's very enchanting.
Twenty pound entry. The outside is wonderfull but going inside means you'll have to pay 20 pounds, way to much for a church!

Mindblowing. The amount of history, detail, and important figures contained at the Abbey is almost incomprehensible. It's like a Hall of Fame for the time period it has covered. I've never seen such history, including the arts, sciences, political figures, royalty, and worship, under one roof. The tour is well laid out and you can do so at your own pace. A must see in London.

Stunning. What an amazing place. Lots of friendly staff to assist you. An interactive tool to give you knowledge of your surroundings. Such history and amazing things to see, yet the tranquillity of a church. Splendid, peaceful. Amazing.
Pristine. Its been a while since Ive been here. But its definitely worth the visit and I will go back sometime soon.
Must see. If in London you must make sure you see Westminster Abbey. It is only a really short walk from the train station and really close to many other London attractions

The Place Time Forgot. We visited Westminster Abbey as part of our Three Day London Pass Tour of London which was quite overwhelming! Wandering through the Abbey one gets overwhelmed with the realisation of the time scale involved with its existence. This place dates back so far in time and the evidence stares you right in the face. The tombs, graves, inscriptions, stained glass windows and age old flags and standards are unique and priceless (if you can use that word). The Abbey is basically an age old burial site/ gave yard. It is quite vast so you will need at least half a day to spend walking through it looking at everything on show while listening to all the audio commentaries.
Awesome and Beautiful!. I've toured it several times now. It's beautiful and a great historical experience. I highly recommend the audio tour, if not an actual tour instead. It's worth it!
Very interesting.. The audio tour can be a bit boring at times, my advice is to skip the boring parts because there are certainly some very interesting things to be said about this Abbey.

Church full of History!. I absolutely loved seeing this Church! We used our 2 for 1 admission tickets from using the Stansted Express and that saved us significantly on this high priced entrance fee. The tour included an audio guide and map, which really helped provide history and information throughout the church. We loved walking down the isle that Will and Kate walked down on their wedding day. The cloisters were fun to explore, and we learned so much about royal history while we were here. The big highlight was seeing the Coronation Chair where all the Kings and Queens of England were crowned. Definitely a must see in London.

Mind-Blowing. Can't even begin to describe this place. Pictures don't and can't do it justice. The grandeur... the immensity, complexity, and beauty is overwhelming. Today, the hubby and I walked over the grave of Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, saw the tomb of Isaac Newton and the famous composer Handel- amongts countless others. We walked amongst the kings and queens of old. For a brief moment, we felt like royalty.Note: Pictures inside the Abbey are not allowed. We paid £20 each to get inside. Pick up a free map inside to go with the audio guide. You can also buy a nice guide book for £2 to take home with you. There is also a service at 12:30pm during the week, so either go earlier or later if you want to avoid it. However, communion is open to those who wish to partake. You can also write a prayer request and light a candle once inside. (No charge.)On Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday you can also visit the gardens. Not too much to see in winter, but I imagine quite impressive in the spring and summer.
Nice to see in real life. Didnt go into the but was great to wander around the area to familiarise ourselves with the great events of history that have taken place here.

Beautiful Church. I LOVED seeing this historical gem. I took the audio tour and it was great to go at my own pace. Only complaint could potentially be that some places were a little crowded but that can only be expected at somewhere that is so popular.

An icon of English history. When you walk into the Abbey you find yourself immersed in our country's history, from king Edward's 700 year old wooden coronation chair to the latest memorials in Poets Corner. Unmissable! We have visited more than once and will again.

A compost heap of history. It's not the largest or most impressive building in the world, but it has the most concentrated 'history experience' of any. Allow time, and pay extra to see the Royal Tombs behind the apse. Elizabeth I lies on top of her 'Bloody' sister Mary, the only monuments to the poor little Princes in the tower are in the same room, and you can marvel at the standard of metalwork on the tomb of Edward the Confessor. If you don't know who all the people are, take a notebook and google them afterwards. The same applies to the monuments and memorials in Poets Corner, and the transept full of long-gone philanthropists and politicians. If you're lucky enough to be there for Matins, the choir is one of the best anywhere. And when the Choir School is on holiday (well, they're only boys) other good choirs fill in. Google beforehand to see what music you might be lucky enough to hear. Don't rush this, and don't think of yourself as box-ticking tourist. If you're fortunate enough to be in London on one of the few days when the Cosmati pavement is uncovered, Do Not Miss It. It's not big or bright; it's just extraordinary.

Amazing. The abbey is one of the most famous building in the christian history, and if you see it you will understand why.The building itself is just breathtaking and the history what represents is fill up the air.If you like the historical places and like visit old buildings this is the right place for you. You can carry translator assistant machine and it will explain what you see.Opening times are short, and calculate three hours to visit.

Take the Guided Tour!. Admittedly, we got lucky and happen to go when there was no line! However, the real prize was paying a little extra for the tour guide. It wasn't expensive and not only was he informative, but he took us into parts of Westminster you cannot enter on the self-guided tour. It was amazing! It was so good people kept trying to sneak on our tour.These tours are only at specific times, so you may want to call ahead.
Beautiful and interesting. A real microcosm of English history and culture set in a beautiful building. Just go and see it and be impressed.
Be mindful of service days. The day we went, services took precedence over tourism so make sure you check that before you go.Still pretty from the outside though :)

A must during your visit to London. One of the most iconic locations in London with an amazing architecture and historical value. Plus, it contains a large collection of sculptures. Honorable mention to the Henry VII (Lady) chapel

Beautiful building. This is a beautiful building and they charge you ~15-30 GBP to get in there if there is no mass. So we did not go inside the church after realizing that they charge you to go inside. It was a long line.

Bucket list. Westminster Abbey was a great church to see. I expected to see more for the amount that was charged for the entrance fee but it was on my bucket list. Inside the Abbey were tombs of past leaders and royalty. I was expecting to feel more of a church vive but was distracted by all the tombs. Overall a beautify church with a historical presence.
Beatiful. A great piece of art and history. Unfortunatelly, you can't take photos inside but you can enjoy your visit at your own pace.
Good. Nice to wander round and full of history, but I definitely prefer St Pauls Cathedral over Westminster Abbey.

Slightly disappointing. Slightly overpriced. Get the optional tour (£5), it lasts an hour and a half and allows you to see the tomb of Edward The Confessor.Expensive. Two people + tour + gude book = £58.A few good tombs. A wonderful ceiling and tiled floor but an incoherent mass of mediocre and unimaginative marble monuments.Better on the outside.

Distilled essence and history of England and the spritiual heart of the English speaking world. Westminster Abbey is an absolute must visit place. What can you say about a cathedral that is, for all intents and purposes, the utter heart of England, perhaps of the entire English speaking world? It is absolutely magnificent and the site of almost all English/British coronations, royal weddings, and funerals. Incorpating architectural styles from Norman through high Gothic, it includes stunning memorials to some England's most famous and interesting monarchs. Also the graves of or memorials to many famous and interesting Britons. The graves of a plethora of monarchs are here: including (but not limited to): Henry III, V and VII; Edward (besides St. Edward the Confessor), I, III, V, and VI; Richard II;Mary Queen of Scots (ok, not a monarch, but still), Mary I & II, and Elizabeth I, James I (VI of Scotland), Charles II, William III (II of Scotland), George II... The graves or memorials of poets and writers. Alphabetically: W. H. Auden, William Blake, Robert Burns, Lord Byron, Lewis Caroll, Charles Dickens, John Dryden, George Eliot, T. S. Eliot, Thomas Gray, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Samuel Johnson, John Keats, Rudyard Kipling, Jenny Lind, John Masefield, John Milton, Laurence Olivier, Alexander Pope, Nicholas Rowe, Percy Bysshe Shelley, Thomas Shadwell, William Shakespeare, Alfred Lord Tennyson and William Wordsworth. And others. Not to mention scientists: Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin., along with a memorial to Michael Faraday. Plus many other famous Britons. It contains memorials in addition to Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Martin Luther King, Jr. (interesting to us as Americans), plus a memorial paid for by the Massachusetts Bay Colony. It is also a working church and cathedral. A moment of silence is held hourly in a refreshing and humble manner. Of course, services are also held daily.Westminster Abbey is an almost ridiculously magnificent and interesting place. But it is not inexpensive to visit, with a ticket for an adult costing 20 pounds, though it comes with a free and very useful audio guide.

Beautiful and Interesting!. Westminster Abbey is a fascinating step back in time as well as beautiful architecturally. You will be amazed by who you may come across resting in one of the tombs. Seeing Elizabeth I's tomb is a must--but really, take the time to walk around among the history and to take in all of the wonderful sculptures, statues, ceilings, the altar, etc. Well worth your time.

Awe Inspiring!. Went to look up an old relative who was a church organist there in the early 1800's. I actually found his grave stone on the floor in the west cloister (with assistance from WA staff). Amazed with the whole place. Centuries of history abound (along with many beautiful sculptures and artwork). A real testament to man's ingenuity and his faith. Plan on spending at least 4 hours. It's a visual and auditory extravaganza!

get your tickets ahead of time and skip the line. I purchased tickets online and when we got to the Abbey there was a looong line waiting to get in. I went to the front, ask the lady where I went with my pre-paid tickets an she let us right in right there. She also told people using the London city pass card, which is supposed to have quick pass features, to go to the back of the line. So pre -purchase tickets if you are going .
Nice!. Nice place to walk and feel the atmosphere of London. Beautiful architecture. Definitely worth visiting.

Solemn and historic!. The Abbey has witnessed almost a thousand years' changes, ups and downs, blood and joy of the country. Steps are heavy while vaults are high, tombs and monuments are cold; eveyone flies way back to long time ago...

A whole lot of history. Visited recently (using the rail ticket 2 for 1 offer), had to queue for quite a while to get in.Very good free audio guide.But i was surprised at how small the Abbey seemed, it looks a lot bigger at some of the televised ceremonies.Unable to visit Edward the Confessors tomb- unless you book a tour. All in all quite interesting but i feel York Minster is a bigger, more impressive and historical monument.
great. We visited the church but we were only outside. The architecture is so grand and beautiful. I like the rich colors, structures, and the colorful stained glass.

Too expensive. If you want to see this, go for the mass, because then you get in for free! Otherwise it is 20pounds each, which I think due to the amount of people viewing it, is a lot of money. It is a beautiful place, and great to see architecture. it amazes me how talented crafts people were years ago!

A Historical Must See. The Abbey is a must visit while in London. It is full of so much history and is absolutely gorgeous. We ordered our tickets ahead of time online. I highly recommend doing that. It was a rainy day when we visited and we were able to bypass the lines and go right in. We got the audio tour as well and I highly recommend that. Take your time walking through and pay attention to all the details on the floors and walls. There are docents walking around to answer any questions. We spent a lot of time talking to two of them when we finished our tour. They were very knowledgeable about the Abbey. The gift shop is very nice too.

good. Collegiate Church of St. Peter at Westminster or more commonly known as the Westminster Abbey, is one of the most notable churches of United Kingdom. The place is known for the coronation of 40 monarchs and has also been the location for 16 royal weddings. The church has also served as a burial ground for the British. One can visit the tomb of the past monarchs. Also present is the Poet’s corner, where poets and authors such as Charles Dickens, Geoffrey Chaucer and Rudyard Kipling are buried. One should definitely take a guided tour to the place to enjoy all the places.
Great historical visit. It speaks for itself. Great place to visit while in London. A must see. Go early to avoid long lines; we got lucky on a Saturday AM. The staff are very friendly and helpful.
History at its finest. All I can say is a visit to the Abbey is a must when in London. William the Conqueror was coronetted here.
Very beautiful. Should see for your self, historically beautiful, gift store on the outside, entrance from the backside

Unbeatable. Visited other amazing churches including the Duomo in Florence and Notre Dame in Paris but neither hold a candle to the Abbey. It's expensive to get in £20 each (not eligible for any concessions sadly) but worth every penny. Paid £5 extra to do a tour with one of the Vergers which was a great decision.

Beautiful architecture. Despite the location is very close to Big Ben, Westminster Abbey is a must to see place when you are in London. Beautiful architecture all around the site. Fee is 20 pounds, and you will be provided by audio guide.

Wonderful and breathtaking!!!. Definitely one of the most beautiful places in London. Admission is expensive but it is totally worth. The abbey is beautiful and the audio tour , available in different languages, allows the visitor to get the most out it!! Awesome

impressive building. Living in London I have visited before, however I went for a specific reason today and was shocked to find it cost £20.00 to get in. I realize it's a big building and probably costs a lot of money to keep it running but I still feel £20.00 is a lot to pay for what you get. There is an audio guide which is included in the ticket price. The audio guide was a bit of a let down, considering all the tombs and monuments in the place and the architecture of the building there were only 15 stops on it and you didn't get much information for each one. Despite all of the above, the building is still a magnificent one and should be seen at least once. Only minutes from Westminster tube station, it's only open from 9,30 am until 3.30pm so arrive early, no photos are allowed inside the Abbey either.
'Wonderful'. the best views are obviously from a distance, its a nice place, beautiful architecture and the whole area is full of nice places.
Well worth a visit. I wasn't sure about visiting the abbey given the line outside and the £20 entry fee but I believe it is worth it.

PHENOMENAL CATHEDRAL. Incredible architecture, history, art, and atmosphere. Built in several phases over several centuries, many famous people are buried there. Be sure to use the audio tour which, as I recal, was included in the admission cost.

A brief history of Britain. A good place to start your trip if it is the first time of you visiting London. It is located in the very heart of the British empire, right next to the parliament building and Downing street. In the abbey there was a marvellous collection of great names, from Cromwell to Newton. I spent a lovely afternoon in this church.

Not to be missed!. I had the privilege of attending evensong at Westminster Abbey. I didn’t want to tour the church, seeing who was buried where (although I’ve done that before, and it was great); I wanted to participate in a worship service because that’s why this breathtaking edifice was built. The service was lovely, and the atmosphere inspiring, but some of the visitors were not.Please, don’t attend a worship service if you have no intention of worshipping – it’s disrespectful. (The teenage boys across from me who were snickering, whispering with one another, and shrugging their shoulders were obviously not told by their tour guide how to behave in this setting. My advice is to follow the service in the booklet – even if that’s not something you do at home. It is always best to err on the side of politesse.) And please, please, don’t bring toddlers to an event you wouldn’t expect them to sit quietly through at home. This is an experience not to be missed, and you can find out when it is offered by visiting the website or the church itself. If you aren’t there to worship, please just take the tour and/or maintain a sense of decorum for those who are.
Special Ash Wednesday service. How wonderful to share this day with people from all over the globe in such an historic place. The choir was beautiful and music filled the air.

A must see!!!. Westminster Abbey is truly a must see place to visit whilst in London. The architecture of the building is truly beautiful and a great deal of history to learn. While we were there, we attended the Choral Evensong service which was excellent and I highly recommend attending.

So interesting. Our visit to the Abbey didn't disappoint. The audio guide was really good as you can look at things at your own pace. There is such a lot to see, you could spend a few hours there, just so much history all under the one roof. In one word Brilliant!

Magical History Tour. It is many years since I last visited Westminster Abbey and I had forgotten what a huge part is has played in our history. Beautiful on the outside, it is breathtaking inside, steeped as it is in more than one thousand years of our history. I used the free audio guide to lead me round, past the tombs of kings and queens, the burial places, of and memorials, to poets, politicians and other notables, where every coronation since 1066 has been held, where sixteen royal weddings have taken place, as well as funerals such as that of Princess Diana. A fascinating few hours and well worth the £17.

JUST GO!!. I cannot say enough amazing things about Westminster Abbey. I was blown away on the architecture, details & just overall history of the place. It was incredibly beautiful! Definitely one of the highlights of my London visit.

Definitely do the guided tour. Over priced I can't imagine what they would need 20 pounds per person for but regardless it is a beautiful church with incredible history. I would sincerely recommend doing the guided tour - you get access to areas the general public don't which is fabulous for only 7 pounds extra not to mention extra history and information you just do not get in the audio guide. I had just missed the start of the tour by 5mins and was poorly advised that the audio guide provided the same information. WRONG. After 30mins of self touring, I was able to overhear and catch up on the English tour (which was obviously much better informed about each of the areas) and after asking the guide if I could join, I was able to run back to the start, buy a ticket and join them almost halfway through. Staff not helpful, guided tours great, audio guide very average. Watch out for big groups of tours going through at the same time it can get quite crowded.

Lovely . Well worth the price to go in we used the days out in London 241 offer. £20 to get in and u also get a free hearing guide to tell you all the main points of reference. I found the guide very informative and the building is just beautiful. I especially liked the bit where Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary are buried with a similar room adjacent with Mary Queen of Scots. You can't take pictures in here which I thought was a shame as I love to document what I've Seen like Winston Churchills grave or the beautiful nave of the abbey. Photos can be take once you reach the putter part of the abbey. You also get to see the coronation chair.
impressive. Impressive , big and should be seen during a sunny day. The architecture is unique in the heart of the city

Beautiful and Interesting.. There is a lot to see here, and while the audio tour can be a little clunky, it has a lot of information. The Lady Chapel is stunning, and the Quire and the High Altar are breathtaking. I would also recommend attending the Evensong Service at 5:00 pm. It is an experience you will never forget -- the choir is amazing, and to hear them sing the service in such an historic space is such a treat.
Great . A lovely place to go up and see, your not in London if u don't go up and see Westminster there is always loads to see and loads to do, it's great for all ages

One of the most important historic sites in the world. . A thousand years of British history, sculpture gallery and final resting place of 30 Kings and Queens along with 3500 other famous Brits buried or commemorated here. Newton, Darwin, Chaucer, Handel, Dickens are just a few of the great names. Why would you miss this? Go early to beat the lines or take an in-house tour. Or go with a Blue Badge guide to circumvent the wait.

Beautiful building. We actually went to a Sunday service in the abbey rather than just looking around. This meant we could see the building, hear the organ and choir and also meet some of the clergy and staff who were happy to tell us about the building and some of its history.

Beautiful!. Be sure to take a few hours and visit this place. Breathtakingly beautiful and the history is fascinating. Through books and history classes, one learns small bits of the whole cast of characters, but to visit this place and see the tombs and hear more of the story makes it so real. Wonderful place!

When in London, see Big Ben. What is London, if not Big Ben? Strike a pose by the red telephone box with the clock tower in the background. We all do! It is an impressive site! But Westminister is so much more, and London Eye a short walk across the bridge, if you want an even better view.
Just beautiful. Rainy day, it was the best thing to do! We enjoyed every second in there and were touched by the history.
Church. I love visiting old churches. This one did not disappoint. It was breath taking inside, with lots to see.

Great views ... of so many thing. Just get to Westminster and you'll be able to see The Thames, London Eye, Big Ben. Just a walk to the Oxford Circus for shopping. Best place to begin tourist trip of London
Wonderful Cathedral. The history amazing, unfortunately so were the crowds - fortunately we had the London Pass and didn't have a long wait. Don't miss the Coronation Chair.

Just an wonderful experience. This was one of the highlights of our trip, just absolutely wonderful, this must be one of the most beautiful buildings in the world, Just a bit too crowded for my likening.
Unbelievably Beautiful. One of my favorite stops when we visited London last November. Incredible. Amazing. Beautiful. Make sure you put this on your must-do list.

Sunday Organ Recital!. If you're in London on a weekend, reserve Westminster Abbey for Sunday afternoon -- get there for 5:30pm (and check the website), there's usually an amazing organ recital which allows you to take in the abbey in a completely different and musical context!

Not to be missed London Landmark. Be sure to take a blue badge tour of this place to get 1,000 years of English history in a two hour narrative. If you have the time, attend an Evensong here or a Sunday service.

Impressive to see! Even if you are not religious!. There is just so much history to see on such a limited amount of square meters! The architecture is very impressive and the art is beautiful. More expensive than most tourist highlights, but worth a visit!

historical cornucopia. Certainly Westminster is one of the hearts of history in London. From the burial of kings and queens to Poet's Corner, you will find history abound. The tomb of Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots are shining examples of how they care for their historical items. Definitely worth a visit, even with the small charge.

THE QUEENS CHURCH. A lovely church but not open on Sundays
It looks lovely on the outside and also on the inside
Long queues and pricey tickets and can be quite busy most of the day

Beautiful sights & surrounded by history. Beautiful Westminster abbey, considered one of the new 7 wonders of the world. There is gardens where people sit to rest and have lunch and enjoy the sight, other hear historical tours and others just love to take pictures
Evensong was the highlight of our trip. My husband and I attended the evensong service. We are not catholic but we enjoyed being able to sit and listen to the choir and the acoustics.
Expensive, but a must do.. A little expense to tour, but worth the money. Every customer gets a headset that gives a wonderful tour of the abbey.

Stunning. A beautiful cathedral with a jaw dropping history. The price of entry is high, but as the flyers say, the Abbey gets no government or church funding so charging the tourists is how they survive.

Don't miss the history of this site. Beautifully maintained, with courteous volunteers, this site was impressive. The Cathedral has a youth scavenger hunt to keep young children engaged as the parents walk through this working church. We spent 4 hours here! We were very impressed.

Beautiful Even When Crowded. We went on a Saturday, which is probably the worst day to go. Still enjoyed it. The smartest thing we did was to buy our tickets online (save 2£). You get to skip the queues. This is not clearly marked, so just go to the entrance and show them your printed ticket or your PDF on your phone and they will let you in.

An encyclopedia of British monarchy, and some.. One place I've always wanted to visit but never quite found the time, until now. I'm glad I finally made the effort. Buying tickets before your visit does not really save time because you still have to queue on entry. It is advisable to arrive early because the Abbey is a major tourist attraction. There is a set route around the Abbey and a tour will take at least two hours. Audio guides are available and are free with price of admission. Photography is not allowed in the Abbey although you can take photos in the Charter House and Cloisters. Stained glass windows, fantastic carvings, tombs and artefacts to past British monarchy, memorials to poets and plaques of remembrance are all here. There is a café in the Abbey, the menu is not extensive but decent enough for luncheon. I'm really glad I visited and would strongly recommend a tour of Westminster Abbey to anyone whilst they are in London.

Not just another 1000 year old church!. We were told that it was just another 1000-year-old church by someone. We were amazed when we entered. There are fantastic sculptures, amazing architecture, loads of history, and it was cool to see the many people's burial places--from ancient kings to modern poets, like Rudyard Kipling, Darwin and Tennyson, and many more!

Amazing piece of History . Really enjoyed our visit. Just fantastic architecture and history. We were lucky to hear the choir too. I would love a behind the scenes tour. Could be something for them to consider.

Simply overwhelming. The queue outside and the fairly pricey ticket can be a hurdle. However, avoiding peak hours and planning your visit carefully can significantly help reducing the hassle.Stepping in the Abbey is like being thrown back in time, and the amount of stories and events linked to this piece or the other can easily make you feel overwhelmed.I was amazed by almost all of the points of interests you are walked through by the free audio guide, with the Lady Chapel being simply astonishing in its beauty: the colored windows and the finely chiselled ceiling provide for a show unique in its kind.I recommend the visit to anyone but families with small kids and infants, as it can get very crowded inside the abbey and the narrow paths can make it difficult to keep an eye on them.

Historic. Founded in 960, and the present church was constructed from 1275. It has been the location of most coronations since William the Conqueror’s in 1066! It was also where the 1997 funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales was held, and the 2011 wedding of her son, Prince William to Catherine Middleton. There’s no pictures allowed in the abbey, which we thought was a bit steep considering that you’re paying £20 (AUD$40) to get in! The free audio guides were making far more noise than my shutter would have made! We saw the graves of some of the most influential Britons from history, including Geoffrey Chaucer, Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Oliver Cromwell, most Kings and Queens of England from the 1200s to the 1700s, as well as the memorials at Poet’s Corner to artists such as actors and authors. The Quire was also very pretty – this is where the choristers sit, near to the organ. There was also the coronation chair that Queen Elizabeth II sat on 54 years ago, which was first used in 1308 and every royal has been crowned on it ever since! The Afternoon Tea in the Cellarium was a highlight.

Westminster is a constant seller of the sightseeing,. The Westminster temple will be a constant seller of sightseeing in London.As it is world heritage, the admission fee is uppish. It is approximately 2,300 yen in being €18.However, the inside is worth seeing. I entered at 12:20 and was until 13:40.As it considerably lines up on the occasion of entrance, it is the best that room is taken at time.Unfortunately the internal photography is not possible.

Visit during the day. It is not very interesting and I only recomend to visit outside as it does not worth to pay to go inside- it is in a good location as you can also walk to the bucjkingam palace , big ben and london eye

A must for any history buff!. Truly amazing history! Ensure you get there for the prayer at Edward the Confessor's tomb. Over 1000 years of history as you walk through the Abbey. Tremendous experience.
The history is real. This was one of my favourite things to see in London. We waited for the guided tour and it was incredibly informative. So much history!

Magnificent!. Incredible place to visit in London! Full of history with tombs of British monarchs, famous scientists such as Darwin and Newton, writers such as Chaucer, Dickens, Keats . . . the list goes on and on! It was crowded, and felt cluttered in some places, but a must-see!!

Attend a service!. The best way to fully experience Westminster Abbey is to attend a service. You truly are surrounded by the glory of this beautiful abbey. No photos are allowed, and dress appropriately.

Rather pricey for a rush tour!. My wife and I chose not to spend the precious short time we have in London being rushed thru the Abbey for 40 pounds. Outdoor space is rather breathtaking and gives you great perspective on size and scope of this national treasure.

Wonderful!. I honestly can't find adequate words to describe our visit to Westminster Abbey...it was so much more, in every sense, than I had imagined or hoped for. If you are into history & architecture, then this place will be heaven for you! The ticket cost about £20, not cheap, but includes an audio guide, which is essential in a building like this. We took our time, as we went on a Friday, when there were few other tourists around, which made the whole experience so much more relaxed & enjoyable. It took us about 2 hours to get round. Don't miss it!
full of histore. This was my first visit to Westminster Abbey. A good place to visit and a must for who travelling to London. We spent a couple of hours and loved the audio tour of the abbey.

Stunning in every way!. We toured in March and there were no crowds. I wish they would have allowed photos inside, but I understand the reverence they want to maintain. Hearing prayers said was wonderful! I must see!

Westminster Abbey, history & royal lovers unite. Enjoyed our time walking through this beautiful and historic Abbey. Only bummer no photos but definitely worth your time. We used the London Pass, if you move quickly, it is a worthy investment. The entire neighborhood surrounding the Abbey is historic and you can easily spend the entire day in the "hood".

Finally visited this spectacular Abbey!. I was not disappointed when I finally got to visit here. Headphones are definitely recommended so you can walk along at your own pace. Restaurant was also very nice but VERY busy

kings and queens. what a great building, steeped in history and sadness, the audio unit (in with the price) is a must, Jeremy Irons dulcet tones informing you all the way, guides in attendance to further enhance the information if required. Finished off with a nice coffee in the restaurant, Great visit.

Steeped in history and great architecture. Wonderfull place to visit and a must for anyone coming to London. Can be over run by tourists much like any other attraction in London be sure to tun up early.
Very moving view of history. Loved the audio tour of the abbey and the walk down a chapter of history. The ornate ceilings were breathtaking

Too Much Stuff. This was my second visit to Westminster Abbey and my opinion has not changed. While it is fascinating, it is cluttered with too many statues and relics. But everyone should see it once.

Two for one entrance fee . If you travel by train to London and print off the relevant vouchers, take them and your return tickets to the attraction. This enables you to get a two for one admission fee, and as Westminster Abbey is £20 per adult, well worth the research.
Beautiful Abbey. A must when travelling to London. Houses the resting places of some of the most famous people in British history, beautiful abbey and incredible architecture.

History, royalty and beautiful. This is a great spot and worth the 20 pounds for a dose of royal history. Kings, queens, artists and socialites have all spent much time here...some will surprise you. Recommend seeing the coronation chair inside and walk the entire Abbey as its really pretty. Make sure to go into the gardens so you don't miss out! Go hear parliament debate next door while you are here...it's free and will get you excited to see British history live! Also recommend walking on Tower Bridge while you are herd for iconic 360 views and photo opps.

Slightly dissapointed. Don't get me wrong, its a nice place and worth a visit but i couldn't help but feel disappointed. I expected it to be bigger and grander and i found it very expensive at £18 each - also you couldn't take any photos which was a shame.What Westminster Abbey lacked i found at St Paul's Cathedral which i was in awe of. If you can only afford to enter one then i would choose St Paul's by far

Very Nice. Go for Evensong in the evening, which is a beautiful service, but be prepared to be rushed out as soon as it's over by people whose job seems to be to keep us from looking at things without paying for seeing things. So if you want to see things, go during the day, wait in line, and pay to see.
Lovely Tour. We took the audio tour at Westminster Abbey and it was quite well done. The tour was very informative and of course the Abbey is a beautiful work of art
Birthday Celebration. Wonderful architecture on this very old building. Walked around the perimeter but didn't manage to fit guided tour. Next time definitely
Worth a visit. This is a place worth a visit for first timers. Personally I wouldn't do it again, I prefer St Paul's cathedral.

Beautiful Westminster.. This historic Abbey is stunning. You can take the tours during the day. I will suggest that in the late afternoon you attend Even Song. Even Song is a choir feature every afternoon. It is free and you will enter the Abbey take a seat in the historic church and quietly listen as the Westminster choir fills the Abbey with voices raised in song. It is stunning and a great opportunity to experience the Abbey in a quiet moment. Highly recommended.

All that history it's incredible! . Well run, very informative and a lot to soak in. Give yourselves a couple of hours and use the audio guides. There is so much to see and the atmosphere is amazing. I'm
not overly churchy and I found it fascinating! Great for anyone who likes people spotting! Admittedly most are dead but a tremendous number of famous faces.

Full of history and so many things to see. My wife and I have wanted to visit here for a long time and yesterday we took the train down to London..a 2 hour journey..to do exactly that.We prebooked our tickets on line which if the Abbey is likely to be busy is probably a great idea and even though it is the off season there were still quite a few visitors around.Ours were £15 each which on booking we thought was expensive but in reality was well worth the expense.We opted for a guided tour by one of the cannon/verges..not your normal type of guide but a member of the "church community".This was a further £5 each but was more than worth the cost.They only take these tours in English but will take up to 20 people apparently but surprisingly there were just the two of us on ours which made it a very personal for us.David who took us around was a excellent, full of knowledge but also very down to earth and with a great sense of humour.This lasted around 100 minutes and whilst he can't possibly show you everything,there is so much to see, we felt we had got through a lot in the time but at a nice pace with nothing rushed.There are audio tour facilities which many obviously took up.We decided to stay for the Evensong service which took place at 3 pm and lasted around 50 minutes.The Abbey choir sang at the service and were joyous to listen to.An added bonus and totally unexpected was When David found out we were attending this we were found seats in the area where the choir sit and during important services the members of the royal family etc sit.I'm sure this isn't always available but was a major treat for us.Would we go back again...we still had a lot to see..well of course we would.The only thing I would warn people is not to leave it late to go and try to establish the service times as I believe the Abbey will close to visitors during these times but equally if you are happy to join the service then everyone can provided of course you remain for the whole of it and respect the fact it is a period of worship.

Wonderful. My friend and I visited. We spent a good few hours looking around. The queue for entrance was long and just to note that printing out your e tickets does mean a queue jump. Inside the Abbey is just beautiful and lives up to all the historical reputation it has. The staff are places around the Abbey and all were very friendly,helpful and informative. Photography is not allowed inside the actual Abbey.

Beautiful, historic, a must see. Even if you are not religious you can`t help but be spellbound by the history and beauty of the abbey. Well priced, friendly and informative staff and just a general feeling of peace inside.

You really can't opt this out.... I thought I'd just skip into Westminster Abbey and out within an hour, and honestly, you probably could if you bolted it or knew what you wanted to see and get out, but I ended up spending over 2 hours here. The queue was excessive, but it moved quite fast so don't be off-put by that. You won't be waiting long. Downers about Westminster Abbey would be that you can't take photographs/videos, that they're sticklers about following the provided routes, and half the staff looks unapproachable (and some actually ARE rude). You can read and see only too much here. Highlights for me would be the Queen Mary and Elizabeth I room (for obvious reasons) and St John the Baptist's Chapel (because the monument on the right is missing a nose, making it look like Voldemort). Overall, great experience. Don't pooh-pooh the spots at the end either because you'll get great photos there since it's not "in the church."

Avoiding the entry fee.. I wanted to see inside Westminster Abbey and had heard that there is no charge for entry if you go to a public service. It is true, but you are directed along an aisle to your seat and back to the door. You have no opportunity to stop and look around. It is expensive to go in and be a tourist in Westminster Abbey, but I will gladly pay it next time.

The best place in London. I love Westminster Abbey! My husband and I visited in May 2015. There was a 20 minute wait for tickets but the gorgeous sunshine made it a lovely part of the experience. The Abbey is stunning on the inside and outside. I highly recommend it for those who love history and/or Abbeys/Cathedrals.
Beautiful . I have been here a couple of times, it is absolutely beautiful and I would suggest to anyone that they should take a look! :) go on, you know ya wanna.

A pleasant to be with the river. All tour buses take to this spot and many boat cruises also touch the harbours of westminister abbey. You get experience the thames river and a good view of the culture of London. A wonderful fascinationg experience.

What a fascinating place to visit.. A number of years ago my son was a chorister in the Abbey. What a wonderful experience he, his brothers and us, had for those years and it became a home from home. The Abbey Family was welcoming, caring and genuinely interested in everyone and everything. To go to the services was a real treat for the heavenly, spiritual music...aghhh, the memories! Do go, if you're visiting London, and enjoy all that each service has to offer..it's an experience you will never forget!

Learning history but expencive. This massive church has graves of famous and historically key persons. The list of names on it is amazing. However, the entrance fee of 20 pounds per person is expensive.

English heritage in one building. The abbey has seen it all over nearly 1000 years! There are newer, flashier sites inn London to visit but this is our history. The audio guide is included in admission cost, I didn't take one as I like to wander but I probably missed some important sights, but I will see them next time. We got there early, when it opened. By the time we came out there were queues to get in and this is winter, summer will be a nightmare. After having seen the main building the majority of the tourists leave. Big mistake. Follow the signs to the signs to the chapter house, we were the only people in this ancient building, having just passed the oldest door in Britain, made for Edward the first. Before you go, have a sausage sandwich in the cafe, best ever.

Fascinating!. My wife was insistent on visting, and I am glad we did.The interior is spectacular. Photography is not allowed and it killed me. I could have taken 1000 pictures. I can recommend this place for that reason alone. I did not care for the price of admission, but once I entered I realized it was worth it.A free audio tour, in multiple languages is provided, which I recommend taking advantage of. Since this is a active church, there are not any placards as there would be in a museum. The only problem is that there are people buried everywhere. I was taught growing up that you avoid stepping on the graves of the dead, but in here it is nearly impossible.

Love Westminster Abbey. My 3rd visit to the Abbey but still loads to see, audio guide excellent, though did not mention where the Princes in the Tower were buried, we had to ask staff. Staff excellent, went above and beyond for us, looking up tombs in catalogues.A must when visiting London, be prepared to be in there around 3 hours, pity that the Abbey Museum was closed, but we will be back, they are building a new museum up in the rafters accessible by lift

Worth it with caveats. Last year I went into the Abbey for brief private prayer, and was made to feel uncomfortable by a suspicious verger. Today I coughed up the cash.A remarkable memorialising of the history of the country, with helpful staff to talk things over with. Kings and queens blah,blah blah. I was moved by the commemorations to politicians, scientists, artists and military men. Even old Charlie Darwin gets a mention in the nation's leading house of God. I bet that wouldn't please the Oxford professor of evolutionary biology (not Darwin himself, guess who). Joking aside, I enjoyed it very much. Recommend finishing with the Chapter House, a place of simple beauty after the overwhelming clutter.Cafe is okay, with very pleasant staff.Main criticism: despite the cost of upkeep a £20 admission fee for adults is unacceptable. Furthermore, in 2015 it was £18. My dodgy maths makes that a just over 11% increase. Let's not forget money is also being made from cafe, shop and sites around the building soliciting donations. AND I understand that the vergers doing the donkey work are volunteers. Come on guys, play the game.
Full of Beauty and History. The audio tour was a great way to soak in all the history and get a good understanding on the Abbey.

Evensong - good for the soul. I attended the 5 pm evensong service. The staff were welcoming and courteous, the queueing was fairly orderly and the seating was in the heart of Abbey very near to the choir. It was a spiritual and calming experience, very good for the soul. Well worth a visit, particularly at the end of a busy day.

The Abbey!. Of course a place to visit.One of the longer queue in town. The abbey is not big but always more than full, even if ticket is very expensive. Why? Because of the history, this is the place for the coronation ceremony and the place where lots of important people lie. Scientists, poets, writers and of course members of the royal family.If you like gothic architecture, history, literature, science this is a church you can not miss.Audio guide in your languige is included and very usefull.
Very Nice. Had a great time and took vey nice pictures. It is very rich in history and the people buried below the church are incredible. Definitely a spot to visit when in London.
A marvellous experience. We went to the Christmas Day service in Westminster Abbey and it was absolutely beautiful and of course it was packed.

Beautiful site and the most friendly and patient staff. We dropped by the Abbey on a warm summer's afternoon to discover disabled people not only have free admission (as well as their carer) but they can jump the queue too! We were pulled out the back of the queue by a large and formidable security guard who took us to the front even though there was an hour wait.Inside the huge abbey soars above you into a complex symmetry of arches and ceiling bosses. The light through the stained glass windows danced a million colours across the seats laid regimentally across the centre waiting for the next service. All around, liveried staff waited with natural smiles for questions from visitors from across the world.As one would expect, burials have been going on there for over 800 years and you will discover a wide-ranging spectrum of people. From lords, kings and queens, to poets, authors, scientists, composers, as well as previous clergy and dignitaries.The centrepiece is the tomb of the unknown soldier, carried back from Flanders Field and laid to rest beneath a black marble slab near the entrance. Permanently surrounded by poppies it is a place to stand for a moment and consider the pointlessness of war.On our visit we used the facilities which were excellent for disabled and able-bodied alike. I would recommend at least two hours to get a good look at all facets of this fantastic building as the architecture alone takes some time to realise it was put together block by block with nothing more than pure grunt without the benefit of hydraulic lifting gear, laser levels and machine tools.

Wonderful illuminations at Luminiere festival. We really enjoyed the Luminiere festival which lit up the front of the Abbey. It highlighted all the statues and showed details you would not see in the daytime.
Worth a Visit. I wasnt part of a tour but they give you a mobile phone like device and a map so you get a great commentary as you enjoy the Abbey. Awesome structure. I'd reccomend a visit.

Serene place. This is a large church in the City of Westminster, London and is located just to the west of the Palace of Westminster. One of the most notable religious buildings in the UK, this has been the traditional place of coronation and burial site for English and, later, British monarchs.

Tranquil. My daughter wanted to see this so i stumped the cash to go in. In one word, amazing. From the moment you step in the history of the place assaults the senses, the tombs of the former kings and queens is a highlight.

Amazing church, beautiful inside and out!. Loved this place! It is beautiful both inside and out. Only negative is that you can not take pictures inside the church. My camera was deprived of all the beauty within but if you enter, you will always remember it. This is a must see venue! You will not be disappointed. BEAUTIFUL!!

Loved it!. I've worshipped at Westminster Abbey but never took the "tour" because it is expensive. This time we used a Two for One train ticket deal and thoroughly enjoyed walking through the Abbey. The history lessons learned are fantastic. Make sure to get the audio guide to give you all the historical details.

Interesting history and inspiring!. I always love visiting places that I've read about, and Westminster was no exception. While the entry fee is expensive (I managed to get a discount with a student card), I do believe it is well worth seeing simply for the architecture inside and the history. This is just personal preference, but If you're trying to pick between St. Pauls and Westminster, I would actually go for St. Pauls. Westminster, while beautiful, is also very crowded.
Beautiful architecture. You should definitely see this as part of the parliament tour. A beautiful building with ornate detail in the decour
Very interesting. Very nice and interesting place. I recommend to buy u guide, otherwise, you will miss a lot of interesting information.

You need to go round twice. Westminster abbey has lots to see, including burial of Issac Newton and Charles Darwin, although the two have very different status in the Abbey Darwin is on the floor and you can walk on or past it with out knowing while Newton you can't miss it - may have something to do with Darwin theory of evolution is suggesting human where not created by god - anyway don't want to turn this in the a debate more about the visit. The audio guide is good although I was a little lost around points 9 and 15 (not sure if there was any commentary. The ticket price was bit steep and I was told it use to be free so wish I had gone earlier. The most eye catching part the lady chapel very nice. If you going to listen to the audio and wonder slowly would suggest around 2 - 3 hours. If you trying to listen to the audio guide it's easy to miss certain parts so it's good to go round once with out the audio guide and see as much as you can then go round again with the audio guide. Main negative is the price, If it was £10 that would be great but £20 it all adds up and most attractions cost £20 in UK

Lovely cathedral. Worth a visit if only to see the stones of some pretty significant and influential people, including Isaac Newton, and those in Poets Corner. Also good as an Australian to see Arthur Phillip get a gig with a plaque in the middle of the nave :-)
Try to attend a service. This is historic and nice to look around, but we attended an Anglican service here and the choir and organ were very nice.

Don't miss the gardens. No point in listing what you can see in WA in a review as you can look this up elsewhere. It is just somewhere that you have to tick off a bucket list.The audio guides give you enough info for general tour and overview unless you want to go for overload.Don't however miss outside and the different gardens.Surprising the number off residences inside the Abbey grounds

Great historical insights. If you're put out by the entrance fee, don't be. Your introduction the the Abbey is an audio guide narrated by Jeremy Irons. It is steeped in history with memorials to almost all the British greats through the centuries. The wooden coronation chair has been used for centuries by dozens of monarchs and is the location for all current ceremonies. You need at least three hours, but it's worth it.

Expensive enrty fee !. Westminster is beautiful and packed with history and if you don't mind spending a bit on the entry is great. However having been to Paris in the same week and visiting " Notre Dame" which has no entry fee and is equally as stunning Westminster is expensive !
Westminster Abbey place where the Queen take oath !. Westminster Abbey place where the Queen take oath ! Baptism of future kings and queens... and much more !
Westminster.... Lovely old abbey..worth the visit..sq outside also good with famous statues..nice to c where the royals do all the big things !! recommended
Magnificent. So much history in one place. There is almost too much to take it all in. A excellent place to visit.

So much incredible history. Such an iconic and important part of British history! We were so lucky that one of the days we were there, the Queen, Prince Phillip, Prince Charles, The Duchess of Cornwall, Princess Kate and Prince William were all attending services for Commonwealth Day. We couldn't take the tour that day because of the services, but that was fine by us! We came back another day and took the full tour. The Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, Princess Diana's funeral, The Coronation Chair, Tombs of Queen Elizabeth the 1st, Mary Queen of Scots,Chaucer, Lord Byron, Thomas, Lewis Carroll, T.S. Eliot, Lord Tennyson, Dickens and more. This is a must visit in London.

Not to Be Missed! Especially if you love cathedrals!. My friend and I toured Westminster Abbey in 2012. And if I am being honest with myself it was because she and I woke early on the morning at the end of April a few years prior to watch the soon-to-be crowned Kate walk down the aisle to Price William. Although you enter from the side, instead of the bottom of the narthex, it is still breathtaking to walk in and be where so many have. The only downside is that pictures are prohibited, but that forces you to look closely all around you to capture in your mind all the incredible things you'll see. The pews, the crypts, the floor - it was all great. Don't skimp out on getting a radio/walkie talkie-thing. Those were invaluable to our visit.

A beautiful experience for spiritual respite and a touch of pomp and pageantry. We were going to have to miss seeing the abbey as the admission price was a little beyond us on this occasion. However, walking by at 2pm my daughter noticed Evensong would take place at 3pm - no entry fee would be required. We were warmly welcomed to our seat in the front row and had the pleasure of a full view of the abbey choir. For a blissful hour we were peacefully transported by the voices of angels to a higher place. We had taken time out of our busy travel schedule to sit and reflect on our blessings, all our wonderful travel experiences, to simply sit, enjoy and be grateful. I even had the pleasure, before the ceremony, of a pleasant conversation with a delightful young local who was also there to worship. Taking in the sights and sounds around us during Evensong was a special and fitting way to experience Westminster Abbey

Lumiere London ❤ . I cam here to see the Lumiere london light festival and it was a real treat.Sights all over the town, and the show at Westminster Abby did not disappoint.
