So many beautiful colours and the atmosphere at night was great.The Abby is just as pretty in the day time. If you like old buildings and history then this is a must see.
Spiritually uplifting to walk past the Wesminster Abbey. Even if one is not able to get into the Abbey on every visit, it is really spiritually uplifting to walk past it - just to enjoy and to admire

What history and what culture. i had a visit the other day inside the abbey, the house of lords and house of commons, what beauty, i felt so small in front of such history and the people that walked on these tiles.

Amazing and Powerful. Loved Westminster Abbey. Active church, very respectful of those who are on pilgrimage there and gentle reminders of the spirit of it with a short prayer on the hour. Terrific audio guide (Jeremy Irons!) and the docents are helpful. Very moving; the history gets into you. Loved the heraldry.

Enhance your experience of the Abbey by hearing the Choir. This is an amazing place! I regularly visit here and never cease to be amazed by the Abbey, the history, the pragentry and the music. To add another dimension to your visit, time your visit so you can experience a service in the Abbey, especially one where the choir is singing. The times are on the website. It is easy to visit the Abbey and forget that it is place of worship and has been so for nearly a 1,000 years.

Ground Zero for History Buffs. Between the architecture and the history oozing from every corner of this place, I could have spent a whole day here. The audioguide app (download it on your phone!) is very good and gives great insight into all the historic crypts and monuments. I also was taken in by how peaceful it is. Take a breath and stop to say a prayer or observe a moment of silence when they ask you to do so. It does the weary tourist mind a load of good! Of course, poet's corner is incredible--to think of all the literary luminaries either buried or memorialized there. Its wonderful.

Where's the faith?. Massively disappointed with the visit today. We arrived late in the day just before last admission. What made me feel so uncomfortable was the £20 a person fee and not been able to take any photos. The thing that really narks me is that this is supposed to be a holy place of worship but it hugely misses the point of being a Church, in my opinion. Sure, there are some famous kings buried here, but it's meant to be about God, not people who were friends of the royals hundreds of years ago. Maybe I'm being overly harsh; I don't know. I just feel other cathedrals are more welcoming. There was a really short prayer for people who have passed on that we love, but I thought it could have been more substantial. I did like the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior. I would like to attend one of the services in future. Maybe that would make more sense to me. Thanks for having us, and Christ be with you always.

contact with great people of the past. good grief what a sight, and thats from the outside, the building rises majestically into the skyline, and the architecture!!!!in we went, wow what a beautiful place. a choir was practising what a sound the accoustics made their sound even more beautiful,as we walked around i was amazed at the names of famous people buried here that i had heard of in the past i didnt realize how many there were.near the alter i looked back and was again amazed at the size of the place it appeared huge.i really enjoyed the visit and would thoroughly recommend it to ike minded people,

Fantastic History!. I have been to London a few times but have never done the audio tour of Westminster Abbey. Wow I have missed some amazing history. The audio tour itself was great - I learnt so much about the royal family and London itself. My favourite part was Poet's Corner - I was quite moved to see the graves and memorials to some of the greats including Shakespeare, Lawrence, Kipling, Austen, Dickens, Keats and Lewis Carroll. You can also see the burial place for Darwin and the Unknown Soldier. The Abbey is a magnificent piece of architecture and the artistry is amazing. I would recommend this over many of the tours in London. You can do this at your own pace and get lost in a world that existed hundreds of years ago. This is also where all the coronations have taken place, where the funeral of Princess Diana occurred, and where Will & Kate got married. We spent over two hours here - and our 11 year old was never bored!

Fantastic ! . What a fantastic tour ! So interesting we spent most of the day here, with a lovely cafe at the end for a welcome cream tea ! The audio tour was great and very easy to follow. I learnt so much ! A must for all you history buffs !

Impressive does not begin to cover it. A true sense of history. Get the free audio guide - 20+ stops and listen as you walk. Wife and I enjoyed seeing the names of prominent (and some not so prominent) people who were buried there. I asked how many people were buried there and was told 3,300 buried or memorialized. Felt very spiritual as we were walking around.
Expensive but impressive. Wow... More impressive than Notre Dame and Sacre Cour in Paris.... But why is entry so expensive especially when in Paris it is free to enter all places of worship.
Go to a Service if Possible . Beautiful, historical grounds with beautiful views for pictures. Check online for opportunities to go to a church service, you won't be disappointed.

Visit Westminster before you go East. The history of the Monarchy echos like an eternal flame in the halls of Westminster the site for the Coronation of Kings & Queens. Throughout history since the 13th Century Royalty, statesmen and commoners alike worship at Westminster throughout the pilgrimage of life. Queen Elizabeth I (the Virgin Queen) is buried here among other notable royal figures.

Beautiful place to visit. Have always wanted to visit so was delighted to come on a weekday and for it to be relatively quiet. Absolutely breathtaking and very friendly staff and the audio guides were so easy to use and were great to tour the Abbey at your own pace.
Jaw dropping majesty. It's not cheap to tour, but worth it. I was dying to take pictures there, which isn't allowed, but just seeing the history with your own eyes is so neat.
A bit too busy with too many stuff to look at. It was spectacular in size and history, but it felt very cramped. It seemed as if it had far too many things to look at.

Unexpected gem. Our visit to the Abbey was an unexpected gem. It was much more interesting than I had expected! I learned many new things. A well organised tour - with a brilliant app for the iphone which provides the audio tour. On hearing our Australian accent, a staff member pointed out some Australian memorials. Very friendly.

Very kid friendly. When going to an abbey, you can never be sure how the kids are going to take it. I have three sons (3, 6, and 8 y.o.), and the abbey does an excellent job of making sure that it's entertaining for them by providing audio guides that go along with a type of a scavenger hunt map. The map asks questions that you need to find the answers for, but it takes you all around the abbey. At the end of the tour, the kids get a big chocolate coin which of course they loved. The audio guides that come free with a ticket (which is expensive) are pretty good, you can pick how much you want to listen to and when to keep going.

Amazing place. Went here thinking an hour tops would do for a look around this. So wrong we were there for nearly three. So much to see and such a beautiful building you need an hour just to take in the architecture. So much history to see and such good audio guide to explain the history. Staff though were not to helpful, poorly briefed and really need better managed. Visitors made to feel as if they were a pain, some were no doubt.
Visit with our granddaughter.. We did this trip with out granddaughter and we revisited many familiar places. She loved it and the vergers even let me take her picture in the sanctuary.

Amazing place to visit. We took advantage of the rail ticket 2 for 1 offer and visited the Abbey(another sight ticked off the list!) amazing building, very interesting the handsets are useful, We were welcomed in by a volunteer helper, she was pleasant and friendly, there were lots of people around to ask for information, they were easy to spot in red and green cloaks.

Iconic Abbey. I was privileged to see the Queen in this Abbey and since then, it has been one of my most recommended churches to see in England. The location is also great, as you can walk to a lot of iconic landmarks in London. Always worth a visit when in London. Attending a church service there provides free entry (no secret there!)

Beautiful church. We decided to go and visit during the changing of the guard (we read that it is not as busy during the changing of the guard) and it was not too busy for a Saturday. We had the London Pass and we had an audio included with our ticket. No pictures are allowed to be taken in the church. I would like to go back for Mass on another trip. I took about 100 pictures of the outside of the church. They have a cafe and a gift shop at the grounds. I would suggest this as a must see for everyone.
Great photos and bustle!. Lovely to hear from the talk about the history and eras over the centuries about this Abbey and what happened. we went early to avoid the rush.

Yet Another Landmark. A tourist cannot miss visiting the Westminster Abbey which is also a great landmark in London and dating back to about 1000 years in history. It also highlights the Gothic Architecture while one can imagine the glorious history of London. One needs to walk the streets of London and these landmarks cannot be missed.

beautiful church. we went in for the saturday evensong, which was much longer than we expected - but also a nice experience and FREE. nevertheless got a bit of time to have a look around. photos not allowed, don't know if that changes when you pay the 20pound entrance fees

Appreciated that it is, first and foremost, a church. I was able to attend a prayer service at the shrine of Edward the Confessor, in the very heart of the Abbey. It was a lovely experience, and recommended.

Expensive . 20 pounds to have a look in a church....
And did not get a audio guide when i bought the ticket. And no signs to tell what the different things are.

Full of history. The headset is really handy, so make sure you grab one before you enter (they are free) or else not much of it will mean anything to you, of course, unless you have studied it all. Personally, I wasn't that much interested in it all, so after a while began to just admire the architecture instead of follow the trail of the head phones. No cameras are allowed. I believe that there are timed when choirs sing which would be a lovely experience, If you desire, communion is available at certain times as well.

Beautiful abbey. The abbey itself is simply divine and beautiful. No doubt about that. But the entrance fee is just horrible. I do understand that churches in Britain do not have something like church tax and that they are struggeling to keep up but nearly 20 pounds per person is simply too much.

Lucky if you can go inside... terrible staff. I am very against to pay for entering religious sites. It doesn't matter which religion we are talking about. In addition, the day we went, the Abbey was not available for regular public even if you paid because a group was having a meeting inside. The staff was kind of rude and very less welcoming, they know the rules and what was going on, we do not! we are tourist, they could provide little info and help.The rating was not lower since the building is colossal. I really love Gothic structures.
Ahhhhhhh. Spent the entire day here. First with a tour guide, then with an audio tour. How could you not walk the walk of history? Great experience.
Nice. It is a very nice, luxury church...but every expensive to get in, in my opinion it does not deserve this money. Yes it have a history!
Love the Abbey. There is something about Westminster Abbey and the combination of history and architecture that is an emotional experience. Do not miss this one.
Absolutely wonderful. Wonderful and magical place. At the entrance the staff give you an audio guide that fully describes all the abbey's history.
Family trip. Absolute beautiful a must see the inside and out side breathtaking Class Windows enchanting peaceful and humbling
Favorite stop in London. I'm a bit of a history buff so getting to see the tomb of so many kings and big names was awesome. The architecture's prett awesome too.

The seat of royalty - a must visit. A must for anyone visiting London. While the admission price is quite steep, visitors receive a free audio guide that walks you through the cathedral. However, it is worth looking at items not included on the audio guide (such as Darwin’s grave) to get the full scope of the cathedral. While it’s architecture is quite different than St. Paul’s, you cannot miss this spectacular location.

Beautiful. The place is beautiful. It was interesting to see all the ancient families' shields and flags, very dramatic effect. Of course, the ceiling is breathtaking, something out of this world type of stone lace work--unbelievably intricate, delicate and gorgeous. We found this room to the side that was wide and sort of round, with old painted panels in between each wall angle. One panel showed a "dromadery" with the word written next to it--a teaching moment for medieval era big wigs (but little-travelled?) sitting in the room.

Great Part of London History. Westminister Abbey is another one of those must see sights in London. Great cathedral. Audio tour lets you go at your own pace. Order tickets online to avoid long line to purchase tickets at the Abbey. They did not check the time or date on our ticket, so you may be able to get in anytime with a preordered ticket.

Best stop on our visit to London. The age of the abbey really sinks in when you walk by the crypts of the kings of history and all the other names of ages gone by. The detail on everything is awesome. Takes at least 3 hrs or more to see everything.

Wonderful . My wife and I accidentally stumbled across a service for worship here and have to say it certainly was serendipitous!Not only is the abbey stunningly beautiful and atmospheric, the choir are a national treasure. The sound they produce leaves you speechless but also with a wonderful sense of peace.I don't think I will ever forget this experience!
Gothic Structure. We reached a little early and waited outside in the lawn. lot of artists sit and sketch the structure for hours. Month of visit
Visiting the past. A must see when visiting London. So much to visit you are spoiled for choice. I never grow tired of the plzce.

Very Interesting. It was an amazing place to go and see, now I'm not one to like cathedrals and churches and all, but just looking around it was mind blowing, there were so many crypts and tombstones everywhere, it was impossible not to walk on one.

Overpriced. Went after visiting St Paul's and climbing up the dome. For 20GBP pp you'd expect more given St Paul's costs the same and is larger, more spectacular and you can climb it. Some interesting tombs but overall would recommend spending your money elsewhere.

History At Every Turn - Wonderous. It was a place of history and wonder. Many people I have only read about are buried here. Charles Dickens, Rudyard Kipling and Chaucer lie here in silence. Sir Isaac Newton rests in peace withing the Abbey. Now when I see an event in the Abbey, such as a wedding....I feel a sense of connectedness. The architecture is unbelievably beautiful and one can sense the history of bygone years.

Venture off the beaten path!. You're going to find a lot of people in the main part of the cathedral - and for good reason! It's gorgeous, and it's very fun to pretend you're Kate Middleton, walking down the center aisle. The tombs are also a beautiful piece of fascinating history. But if you continue to the chapter house, cloisters, and collegiate garden, you'll experience less crowds and really appreciate the beauty even more!

Fabulous. Was very fortunate to visit the abbey for the Battle of Britain commemoration service. Amazing place. Just sitting there thinking of all the historical events that happened here gave me goosebumps! Will revisit as a tourist to enable us to have a good look around!

Mind Blowing Center of History. I spent my New Year's day morning here and it was mind-blowing. Everyone who is anyone from British History is buried here and the architecture is mind blowing. This is a don't miss to any visitor to London.

Goosebumps. I am a huge history buff, so this place, for me, was the ultimate stop. To walk through and see Poets Corner and the resting places of Queen Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots, as well as such renowned scientists like Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin...I had goosebumps the whole time. In addition to being able to walk-through, you get a recording device that explains all the highlights of this stop. It's also historical for the fact British royalty is crowned here and most weddings took place here. This was absolutely awe-inspiring and I could have spent all day in it.

Do the audio tour. Stunning place. Overwhelming number if famous names. Felt bad that I had to walk on tombs at times. We did this tour during winter, and I would shudder to think of the number of peak season visitors! Highly recommend this tour, especially off season.

Beatiful place. Must do in London. Be sure to get tickets in advance and check the schedule to make sure its open. You're not allowed to take pictures inside, but if your like me, you try to sneak a few! The audio tour is a bit long, but very informative if you're into that sort of stuff.
INcredible. The history, the architecture (don't forget to look up), the craftsmanship, not to mention the tombs of the royal families. Not to be missed.
Beautiful Graveyard. Very busy place, beautiful Architecture. The line is long and a bit pricey. The staff are very helpful.
Was Revived. We stayed for Worship and it was a revival within my spirit. We really enjoyed the choir. Great experience.

History just speaks to you in this gorgeous, spiritual place.. This is a place that can't be missed on a trip to London--it's really breathtaking to think of all that's happened there and all that continues to happen in modern times. Don't miss this lovely place4!

Fascinating, stunning, rich history and super interesting!. Once you are in the Abbey, there is a small information desk. There you can pick up and audio self guided option. But here's a great tip.....for a couple of pounds you can have a private tour. Do it if it's available! We were escorted into areas the general public couldn't go and got a deep rich education on the Abbey.

Amazing! Loved the poet's corner and the history. Good audio tour.. Absolutely amazing! So steeped in history that you are in awe. As you take the audio tour you feel like you are walking through history itself. We had the London Pass which queued us in a different line. Royalty, poets, composers and other famous people are buried here. It is overwhelming.

Beautiful church. Really beautiful inside. Took time to attend one service, even though I am not in the religion, but still very meaningful to see. (Esp. free to enter if you are there for the service, otherwise £20)

Great for historians. We did the self guided tour with the head phones. Great to be able to get around the Abbey and still be able to learn the history at our own pace. A bit cold inside so wrap up warm.

Beautiful and exciting. This is a beautiful abbey, where many emblematic people are burried. As a scientist I particulalry got the chills when looling at Charles Darwin's and Newton's tomb, and at the other end the Poet's corner with a beautfully decorated monument to Shakespeare.

Outside is spectacular, didn't do the tour. Outside is quite spectacular to see, and tends to dominate the skyline around this area. We went into the shop and bought some souvenirs, but there appeared to be some heavy security around the area, so we didn't go for a tour.
iconic.... was a little hesitant due to rainy day..however was only a 10 minute wait and ...was it 10 pouns ..? anyway ....well worth it for the christian history lesson..;-)
A giant graveyard. The chapel in the rear was really special The rest was just a lot of graves inside the church. It's a shame the throne chair was so far away but it is over 1000 years old.
The biggest rip-off I ever saw.. Westminster Abbey has to be the most expensive church in the world to enter & sadly not worth the entry fee. Westminster Cathedral is free!
Fab. I really love churches and cathedrals and Westminster is up there with the best. The architecture is amazing. A must see.

very fun, but pricey. I liked the abbey. so much I have seen on television or in pictures, so it was fun to see the royal chair, newtons tomb.
but it is quite expensive, so it depends on how important it is to you..
But I am happy I did it, but one time is more than enough

Another must-do, but do it the right way.... It's hard to visit London and not visit Westminster Abbey, so to say "avoid it" would be a serious mistake. It's historic and lots of notable people are buried or at least have memorials there. But at the end of the day, it's not Disneyland -- it's a functioning cathedral, just like all the other functioning cathedrals one will encounter in many parts of Europe and around the world. What that means is people seem to have a different notion of what they will see there and go at great lengths to see it, which results in lots of big tourist groups, lots and lots of kids (who have very little interest in being in a cathedral), and long lines to get in during busy times of the day. In my opinion, the best way to see this iconic site without killing too much of the day is to a) read up on the Abbey before visiting, b) go either very early in the day or at the very end of the day, and c) budget no more than about 45min-1hr there and move through it at a reasonable pace. The audio tour isn't that insightful, and the crowds are quite heavy so it's hard to really enjoy the 'serenity' which might otherwise be found in most cathedrals. About 90 minutes max (including waiting to get in, seeing everything, visiting the gift shop, etc.) is about all you need.

Worth the time and money. I went around Christmas time and the line wrapped around the fence but moved quickly. Even as crowded as it was, the atmosphere is intensely historic. Highly recommend the audio guide as well.

Abbey visit. Decided to go in and was pleased with the ability to walk around and take your time. So much history in the Abbey and easily takes 2 hours. There is something in there to capture the interest of everyone wether you're into military, scientists, writers or poets.

Lost direction ?. My first visit for many years. I am British, and Anglican. A mid-70s pensioner with gradnchildren and a lover of of my own heritage. Unfortunately, I feel that the abbey, in its quest to make as much money as possible out of its pilgrims, has lost site of its true purpose as, firstly,a place of worship, secondly, a vital part of our heritage. Apart from the extortionate cost, I was amazed at the degree of regimentation, verging on the bullying, and the lack of respect for its visitors. In this I include certain voluntary staff. I am aware that many are dedicated volunteers, without whom the establishment could not function. However, there are a small minority who seem to regard the donning of fancy dress as an opportunity to dominate others. Regrettably, I will not be returning, children do not seem to be welcome. Shame on you.

Church. It's so spiritual to visit there! I love going there when I visit London. You can also have things Blessed. Plan on spending time for awhile in there because there is a lot to see. Enjoy Patricia Ortega
Royal. This is the main church of the Royals.This is where the get married. The funerals take place.This is a very old church must see worth it.

Too expensive - audio guide worst we've heard in several countries/tourist destinations. Westminister Abbey is a wonderful Abbey with great historical significance.Since our last visit (a decade ago) is seems to have become a cash cow rather than a tourist destination and celebration of history.With a recorded 2, 202, 000 visitors annually = 44,040,000 POUNDS - yes pounds!!!! income per year the standard response of it covers running the abbey surely isn't 44 millions pounds.Pro:Amazing architecture from the Gothic periodImportant figures buried there - although they are just tombs after all.Many important occasions took place hereCons:The audio guide was the biggest let down - at some stops there were 2 sentences only. Very basic stuff - wikkipedia could tell you more.No photos allowed - change from our last visit and one of the only churches you can't take photos in in the UK. This would be fine if the price they charged wasn't so exorbitant and it wasn't advertised and priced as a tourist spot.Not enough historical informationNo mention of William Wilbourforce who was the driving force behind abolishment of the slave tradeNo mention of William Pitt the Prime Minister at the time - in fact his grave plaque is unreadable and hasn't been restored..... a disgrace really. Far too many staff standing around doing nothing (peering upon people waiting to catch them out doing something wrong - reminded me of being at a catholic primary school).We learnt nothing - many tombs with no signs/translation into English or any other language. Would we go again - NO.Would recommend trying to get a discount voucher as for 20 pounds per adult and an hour visit. If you have young children they will be bored there is nothing interactive or event at child height to read or look at. Viewing their annual report shows they are in no dire straights financially although this is the spiel is many responses to posts in trip advisor - infers that the entry is what it is to cover cost of running.To the management: If you read this it would be great if more was invested in the audi guide and history - people wouldn't mind paying as much if this was quality. For reference Churchill war rooms and Edinburgh castle audio tours are outstanding.Real consideration needs to be given to your pricing - if I was with a family it would have been simply unaffordable. Do you care - not sure, but you should.In summary if you are a visitor who cannot afford or so not see the value in paying you can go in at mass times for free, take some photos out the front and buy a historical book - you will learn more.

Extra tour worth it. Pay for the extra tour it's well worth it. The knowledge and information they have about specific things in the Abbey was very interesting and we were surprised by some of the things he shared with the group.

A fantastic attraction but not cheap. The interior of the abbey is far more impressive than the exterior. To enjoy this visit you must use the audio guide or go on an organised guided tourAnyone who was anyone seems to be buried in the abbey and if you love uk history you will love this place

Well worth the wait/queue. BEAUTIFUL! I loved this place. it was a tad over crowded for my liking (and we went off-season!) But the place is just seeping in history and artifact. We absolutely loved it. I would recommend it to anyone!
Must see!. London not complete without a visit to Westminster. Effigies and burials of past kings/queens. Love the poets corner, and also Alexander Pope, Isaac Newton, and Darwin.
history, history, history!. I go every time I am in London to pay my respects to Isaac Newton, Charles Dickens, Jane Austin, etc.
Stunning, pricey. Just cruised around the outside. 20 pounds to get in, yikes. Still worth wandering past though. Close to big Benjamin too

Very long waiting time to get in (security). We were at Westminster Abbey during December we bought the London Pass and this was one of the places we could go to, so we did it - we were supposed to have "fast track entry" with the London pass but we couldn't skip the line and had to wait at the back of the very long line, this was a security check. A very beautiful place and quite enjoyable but the amount of time waiting to get in was annoying.
Beautiful place to visit. Some say it is magic. It sure might be! Some find it surprising. It sure is! Take some time and be ready for the crowd. It is worth it.

It's a church, but you have to pay to enter.. It is a very beautiful place. I did not enter, since the entrance was 20 pounds and I do not feel okay with paying so much for visiting a church. However, it is a huge church and there are lots to see. The reason I write this review is to let you know that IF you want to PRAY, there are a couple of free masses per day. Just visit the smaller entrance and check the times (the post them every week). They have the contents of the mass and the evensongs.

Direct absorption of history, beauty, and spirituality. This is one of those places that has power in them, perhaps because of its imposing beauty, perhaps because you get to actually walk on the graves of historic giants. You cannot visit London and not go to Westminster Abbey. The line is long but it moves fast enough. The audio guide is great. I do recommend learning a bit about English kings and queens, as it makes the experience much deeper. For me, it was impressive to visit the graves of Elizabeth, Mary, Henry VIII, Elizabeth of York, and so many other historic characters. Visiting the grave of sir Isaac Newton took my breath away. And all of it in this impressively beautiful spiritual place.

beautiful building, one of the best. I went to a mass here and although this is not always an option it is perhaps the best way to experience the stunning atmosphere of this staggeringly beautiful building
Very busy place. Try buying the tickets ahead of time to avoid one of the lines. The security line is long but moves quickly.

A Monument to Commerce. Westminster is my favorite historical icon. It takes several trips to really take in all that it has to offer for the history of England.Slowly reading the inscriptions on many monuments helps you realize the impact of the East India Company on the breadth of the British Empire. It was all about the money even then. For their service the soldiers, sailors, explorers, etc got a fine monument(s).

History, history, history. How many royals have been married here?? How can one building stand the tests of time and now stand with our modern life. Amazing to think of what had happened inside this building.

Family holiday . This is so worth a visit. We just looked at outside on our last holiday but as it's included in the london pass we went inside and boy we were happy we did, the abbey is beautiful on the inside and is historical, we didn't realise how big it was tbh. Had creaks in our necks again we came out..
Don't miss. Very historic and iconic. All the surrounding area is well worth a days walk about. Make sure you read a bit about the history because there is a lot to absorb

A must see!. We had only one day in London and it was our first time. Our dilemma was what to see. It was pouring rain, as expected, but we still enjoyed a walk along the Thames. We passed by the Parliament buildings and decided to go into Westminster Abbey. Although expensive, it was worth every penny. There was so much more to see than I had expected; so much history and architecture to enjoy.

A must visit in London. Going here is through our London Big Bus tour. We try to visit every church in every place especially those hundreds of old churches because of its grandeur and beautiful architecture details. Westminster Abbey is definitely magnificent and lovely outside but lovelier inside.A must visit while in a London
Great views!. Expensive but this is London! Great 360 degree view, worth doing and sits right by the river themes.

Brilliant . I didn't know what to expect from an abbey but I must say by far my favourite attractions in london so mush history wrapped up in one building. Try and get a tour check times .London pass accepted here

If Only I Could Take Pics. It's a working church so yeah you can't really take pics. So rich in history. A must visit.I finally had the Da Vinci Code moment (hehehe) after seeing Newton's apple. Had to hunt for it though. Lots of things to explore here if you're really a history nut.I like the artist corner(?) or area wherein there are epitaphs or grave stones (sorry not teally sure) of Austen and other poets and musicians.

A spectacular church. You can tell this is a grand building from the outside, but once you are inside, it manages to be even grander. Even if you are not particularly religious, I would still recommend going here to learn about the Abbey's history (and its role in history) and to see the architecture. The Henry VII chapel is incredible. Audio guides are also available for free.

Attend Evensong Service. What a humbling, awe inspiring place to be. Do not miss Westminster Abbey on your trip to London. I am not a big spender, and wanted to see what a service in the church was like, so I attended the free Evensong service. It is a service comprised mostly of singing old hymns, with a short lesson. I absolutely treasured my time during this service. Sitting in this amazing place, listening to music, is a calming, peaceful experience. I felt great by the time the service was over. I headed into the gift store afterwards, they have beautiful cross necklaces for sale here. Everything in the store was reasonably priced, no price gouging here, beautiful merchandise to commemorate a beautiful visit.

Worth to visit. Free audio guide and the staff there are really helpful. If you are interested in English History, you couldn't miss this place. and the tombs of Newton and Darwen are on the floor at the entrance of Abbey. It's easy to miss them;)

God save the Queen! Must see if in London!. We arrived at Westminister Abbey at about 13:50 (be sure to check hours of operations for Westminister as they change on the day and season). There are two entrances for visitors into Westminster, one for those who wish to pray (free, but you don’t get to tour the full grounds) and the other for tourists to visit the whole abbey (admission 20GBP). The last admission into the abbey was at 14:00 (again, based on the day and season), however I would highly recommend coming around this time, there was almost no crowd (have I mentioned I can’t stand crowds at museums?). The Abbey was absolutely breath-taking, even though we came close to closing time, we still had plenty of time to see the entire grounds. Audio-guides are offered for free giving a brief history of the highlights through the grounds. Service and prayer may be conducted during your visit, you may be asked for a moment of silence or have to go around the service to continue your tour (conversely, you can also stay and listen to the service). Be sure to see the Coronation Throne before exiting the Abbey (its over 700-years old)!
Very nice. A beautiful building full of history. Unfortunately it is not allowed to take pictures inside.A must see in London

History Comes to Life!. On a recent visit to London, I visited the Abbey twice in four days. The first visit I concentrated on the inside tour. The self-guided audio tour was fantastic and allowed me to choose which areas to focus on. The Abbey was not very crowded so the atmosphere was quiet and somewhat dark and mysterious. On the visit four days later, I spoke to some of the guards. One guard, Alex, told me he was at the Royal Wedding in 2011 and even told me to "youtube" the video that showed him standing next to Kate! And when he discovered I was from Oklahoma, he broke into song..."Oklahoma"!!!

A really interesting place to visit whether interested in history or the church. This was a really interesting couple of hours we spent here. As well as being a magnificent place of worship and piece of architecture, it is also a history lesson because of all the great people who are buried or commemorated here. The free audio guide is very good and very informative
Take the self-guided tour!. I had visited before, but this was the first time for the tour....definitely recommended. There are a number of famous people buried on site, including Isaac Newton.

Top Ten Worldwide Site. I knelt in tears as mindless tourists walked over Charles Darwin's tomb, but how can you blame them when there is so much to see. Only steps further on the last resting place of Isaac Newton. And that's only the beginning, because all the kings and queens, and the almost kings and queens, of England are buried here along with memorials to the tyrants (Cromwell) and heroes (RAF). The abbey dates back almost a thousand years, so it predates ALL buildings in the US by - say - 700 years. Incredible.

Christmas Eve Lessons and Carols Service. This service was amazing! It was a very special Christmas Eve for my family. I highly recommend attending this service at least once. This is a ticketed event, but the tickets are free. There are a limited number and they sell out very quickly. Check the Abbey website to find out what time they go on sale. There are several dates and times for the sale, but tickets sell out within minutes.

if you like going yo the church, go at service time. Me and my husband were sighseeing the church and we realized it was service time, and that is free to enter to the service (if you go at other time, of don't want to stay for the service, they charge 25pounds). The service is very pretty and you get to know the church inside, they even play the hymns with the antique organ!!. Is very very beautiful and so interesting to know there has been standing for centuries. You need to visit it.

Stunning!. It had been over 20 years since my previous visit, so I was looking forward to reacquainting myself with this glorious building - half church, half museum. Yes this is one of those London sights (unlike so many) with a steep entry fee, but it is worth every penny. The Abbey helpers are extraordinarily friendly and knowledgeable. But the audio guide is one of the finest devised. The sublime voice of Jeremy Irons accompanies you on your tour, and the beautiful sounds of the Abbey choir are constant delights. It is a magnificent building, and surprisingly compact (unlike say, St Pauls). Architecturally stunning, the highlights include the choir, the altar, countless tombs, and the exquisite Henry VII Lady Chapel - the intricacy of the ceiling will take your breath away. As a museum it offers so much - endless graves and memorials to the famous. Your favourite English composer, writer, poet, actor etc is sure to be featured. Poet's Corner and the Shakespeare Memorial stand out. And outside the main body of the church, ensure to spend some time in the cloisters, the wonderful Chapter House, and the impressive gardens. A feast for all the senses.
Carol singing just prior to Christmas was fantastic. Joined the Christmas carol service on Dec 23rd. Wonderful event and thoroughly enjoyed our time in the abbey.

Beautiful church. Like so much in London, the architecture is wonderful. Glad we went by it. There is a fee to go in. Not sure it is worth it. But great to see from the outside. Very different perspective than what we see on TV when we watch royal events in the church.

Wonderful experience!!! A "must see" history buff or not!!!. As much as ancient architecture and history fascinates me, I was never the type who'd queue for hours just to enter such facility. But since it's my 2nd time in London and I ran out of things to do, bought tickets online and went! From the moment you start the tour of this historical building up to the very end, there will be moments of astonishment, awe & breathtaking discoveries. One of those places I am very happy were righteously preserved for generations to come. Will surely recommend to everyone!

Worth spend your money on this visit. The building is amazing, very well maintained and full of history.We loved the audio guide which can adapt to your needs and refer to more numbers if you need in depth details.
Long overdue visit. History, history and more history. This is a must see. The architecture is a standout and the audio guide provides a superb introduction.

So much to see!. There is so much to see & learn about at this landmark filled with history. Leave plenty of time to be able to enjoy & soak up the history. In retrospect, we should have done an audio tour because there is so much to see it's almost overwhelming. There were personal guides as well.

Be sure and pay extra for the guided tour!. It is a bit expensive but so much of London's history is here! Very interesting and beautiful inside. We paid the extra bit for the guided tour and so glad we did. We got to go into some areas that are closed to everyone else. Glad we went.

Beatuiful. Very beautiful getting to learn and do the tour if your into this kind of stuff, its not for everyone and got a little boring at some parts but if your into this kind of stuff it would be great

A cathedral with beautiful Architecture. One of the best Cathedral i have visited in my life, its rich in History and you can see and walk in the places where Kings and Queens get married. The painting and sculptures are amazing and beautiful.

New Year's Day.. It was very interesting. We took the audio tour and walked through at our own pace. A beautiful place that is filled with history and awe . New Years wasn't too busy on account of the parade which took away traffic. It cost about 20 pounds I think. But was worth it. The tour can be somewhat confusing though because it jumps from one side of the room to another and sometimes you can't find the corresponding room to the audio number nevertheless it was still worth the visit.

Must see attraction. Took an audio guide tour of the Abbey, so many famous people that created history are either buried there or have a memorial in their honour. King Henry VIII, Mary Queen of Scots, Charles Dickens, Sir Isac Newton, Geoffrey Chauser, Rudyard Kipling, Handel, Charles Darwin, Oliver Cromwell and Elizabeth I are among the numerous notables interred in the Abbey. The place just reeks of history and grandeur, it really is a must see. I would certainly recommend buying one of the guide books which identifies who is located in the Abbey.
Historic. Huge building and very serene. A sense of spirituality and calm. Long lines and lots of people but very quiet inside.

Interesting with a lot to see... We made a day trip from Paris to London and this was on our "must-do" list. It cost around $62USD for the two of us to get in and you can't take pictures, so that's a bit of a let-down but it was well worth the cost to get in. There is so much to see. Normally I am not a fan of audio guides but I found it helpful and it wasn't too terrible to follow, although it will be crowded in certain parts.
So historic.. Don't let the line outside intimidate you, it moves quickly. Take the audio guide. You will miss a lot of detail if you don't.

Verger Tour with David Mott best money spent in 5 week visit to UK. Visited New Years Day 2016. In queue by 9.30am and already 30 in front of us. Long queue by 10am. 17 pound each for seniors and we also booked the Verger Tour extra 5 pound each. Total 44 pound so not inexpensive. Allow at least three or more hours. The Verger Tour with David Mott was undoubtably the best money we spent in our 5 week UK visit. We were taken to otherwise roped off areas that the general public could not access. There were just 7 in the group and David spoke almost non stop for the entire 90 minutes. His recollection of facts and incredible knowledge of the Abbey were impressive. This was my 4th London visit but the first time to Westminster Abbey. The memories will remain as one of the highlights of this trip.

How can you not go here... This place is magical. From the first moment you walk in, you can feel the air around you. Maybe imagine yourself as one of the lucky few who've been married here. Wouldn't that be exciting? My girls love this place, and we try to go there every time we're in London.

Loaded with histoty. Beutifull abbey loaded with history, you can fin Sir Isaac Newton memorial, Admiral Cochranne tomb and a lot of famous people that you will only find on history books. Great place to visit if you are not in a hurry.

So much history here!. We did a London Walks tour of Westminster Abbey that was so informative and worth every pence. It to us in without standing in a really long line. Our guide was very informative. She had so many stories of the royalty that was buried there.

very nice imposant attraction with a lot of history. Nice to see but if you are not interested in historics this is not worth paying the entrance. very impressing but you need to know something about the English history of kings and crowns. Also a shame there are 10 or more languages available on the audio and no Dutch!!!
Very Interesting. Very interesting place,It's too bad you can't take pictures inside. Big Ben is across the street. Highly recommend it.

Have to see it, but St. Paul's is better... Westminster Abbey is a must see of course, but be prepared for a crush of people and a confusing layout. St. Paul's is a better experience, but the Abbey is still a piece of history so don't miss it.
A wonderful cathedral. A wonderful cathedral and study the history of the nation. So many monarchs are buried here. A fascinating place

Expensive, but worth it. Everything in London is expensive, and Westminster Abbey is no exception. But you have to go. You just have to. It's beautiful and full of history and just a stunning place to see. When we arrived, the queue to get in was insane and looped down the street, but it moved fast. We bought our tickets online and that saved us some time too, so definitely do that if you can. We paid an extra 5 pounds a piece for a guided tour, and it was totally worth it. Paying for the tour gets you access to areas of the Abbey that are off limits to everyone else. Plus, the tour guides are so informative and knowledgeable. There are no pictures or video allowed inside, and they strictly enforce this policy - so put your cameras and cell phones away. It's a church, after all, and your pictures just won't do it justice anyway. The place is spectacular and beautiful and a must-see for anyone visiting London.

So much history!. Westminster is a MUST see if you are at all interested in history. Poet's corner and so many markers and tombs of well knows historic names...all very fascinating. The Cathedral itself is gorgeous. Take the time to walk through and soak up the history...I would plan to spend at least 2 to 3 hours here. The entry fee, though pricey, is worth it...but don't rush through.
A joy to experience. Visited on a Friday morning, it was crowded but not claustriphobically so. The Abbey is beautiful, historic, and reverential. Must visit!

Viewed from the outside. We decided not to go into the abbey as the cover charge seemed exorbitant. It is a beautiful building that is magnificent in size and decoration. Very ornate and plenty to see from the outside if you decide not to go on.

The History!. First - this is an expensive attraction (20 GBP per adult) as you won't spend more than 1 hour here. The crowds are usually big, you'll snake around inside the building with this crowd. The history in these walls is incredible. Spend time with the audio guide (included in your admission) to get the most out of your visit. No photos are allowed. For free admission, come for a service.

historical graveyard and church. Wonderful history of all the kings and queens and notables buried in the church. Lots to see and get a sense of the traditions that took place here. It is a living church so attend the services to see what it is like. Musical services are beautiful.

So Much History. Having already visited numerous "famous" cathedrals in Europe that were amazing, we were ready to be disappointed. We weren't...this place is incredible! So much history here, so many past kings of England buried here. We really found Westminster Abbey lived up to the hype!

Beautiful on the outside. I didn't get a chance to go in because the crowds were just horrible but from the outside it is amazing. The rose windows were so big and I believe I saw some flying buttresses but couldn't confirm. What a beauty and got some great shots. If I go back to London, I will surely go inside.

Fantastic especially if you like history. Don't get scared away by the rather high admission of 20 pounds. It's really worth it.
Audio tour is included in the price, which i would highly recommend because it teaches some history and 'nice-to-knows' while it's very easy accesible. On a monday morning in January it wasn't too crowded at all.

One of the coolest attractions in London. Gravestone of Charles Darwin & many more iconic people in history. The entire Abbey is incredibly detailed and a marvel to navigate through. One of the oldest buildings I had ever been in and definitely a highlight of London

Try and attend a sermon. What an incredible history is presented in this church.
Visit the tombstones of king's, queens and statesman.
The sermon is beautiful, with music and a chorus beyond belief.
A must-see in London.

Worth to attend the Sunday service. We only spent a few days in London and the winter opening times for visiting the abbey didn't suit our schedule, but we really wanted to see the interior ow Westminter Abbey, so we attended the Sunday morning Sung Eucharist. The entrance is free and it was well worth the visit, since one gets to feel the real atmospere of the church. The stewards at the entrance weren't particularly polite, since they were trying to prevent the tourists from entering the church for sightseeing, so make sure to tell them that you only want to attend the service, not to visit the church, otherwise they won't let you in.
Private tour - best 5 oounds spent in Lodon. Was the most informative, engaging 90 min in London. Even my kids ages 9-14 were 100% engaged. Highly recommend.
Short break . Was amazed how big the abbey is. Seen it on TVs it doesn't do it credit but being there it's fabulous especially just before Christmas

Amazing experience. I had not been that exited about seeing Westminster Abbey, because my impression was that the main theme would be royal weddings etc., but changed my mind very quickly. Where else would you be able to stand on Isaac Newton's grave with your full gravity, or see tombs of Kings from 800 years ago?

So much to see. It was my second visit, which was just as enjoyable as the first as there is so much history to take in. I wish that the audio guide (included in the ticket price) had given more information about what I was seeing and I also got confused as to which area I was looking at and then keying in the right number. The signage is not very clear, especially when there is a crush of people. I should also have liked to have seen information on the various tombs, explaining who they were and with dates. The cloisters are lovely and well worth walking round and the throne with space for the Stone of Scone in an area near the exit is a must see.If you travel to London by train, don't forget to show your train tickets when paying as this qualifies you for 2for 1 entry.

Overzealous Red Cape Wearing pests. My experience was tarnished by the pretentiopus Red Cape wearing supermen who patrol the building to nab the offending camera weilding snapper. It is so English and so pretentious to stop the tourist who has paid serious money to enter a church and to have a few pictures as memorabilia of the visit. OH NO but surely the peasants couldn't possibly take a snap of a church where the royals visit. How ludicrous of me to expect to even snap a photo of their place of worship! Now that I have had my rant - yes it is a beautiful cathedral and yes the history of the place amazes. The ceiling is a wonder of the world in my view and well worth a visit..... but please, can you not understand that taking a few happy snaps (without flash) is more thsan reasonable and expected given the hefty sum to enter this historic building. And please remember that there isn't a great big "S" on that cape.
Overpriced. I just wanted to see the church without any guided tour. But there is no option as such. For me 20 pounds in order to enter a church is too much. The abbey itself is of course gorgeous!

1000 years of British History - much more than "just" a church. It is important to note that the opening hours are 9:30 – 3:30 which means that this attraction closes much earlier than many of the other attractions in London so plan your visit accordingly. In addition, there is a fairly steep fee to visit so it is a good idea to get a London Pass or, if you are two, the 2 for 1 passes that are available at most train and tube stations. This pass literally cuts the cost of everything in half as it is taken pretty much everywhere. And the tube pass that goes along with it is a great deal too as the tube is by far the best way to travel longer distances in London. It is a great walking city if the weather permits.Westminster Abbey is well worth a visit as it is much more than “just a church.” It provides a great look into more than a 1000 years of British history and it is not just about purely religious figures….on the contrary, information is provided about kings, queens, statesmen, military, and many famous writers/poets. The audio guide is very good although it is sometimes difficult to determine exactly where you are in reference to the dialogue on the guide.There is an option for guided tours but the day we were there, they did not seem to be available. We weren’t interested but I happened to hear an upset patron. Should you be interested, I suggest you check exactly when these occur prior to your arrival.Note that if your time is short and you can only fit in one religious attraction, we were four people and we all preferred our visit to St. Paul’s Cathedral.

Incredible. We arrived at opening time and went straight in. There were audioguides provided, included in the price, but you can also download the audioguide prior to your visit on your own device. Poet's corner was a favourite for me. Unfortunately, no photographs are allowed but this is understandable. We were there for approximately 2 hours and also saw the cloisters outside in this time. The entry fee is rather high but we used a London pass to keep costs down.
Breathtaking!. Personally this was one of the places i wanted to see the most in London and was not let down! It is absolutely Amazing!

More than just another big 11th or 12th century cathedral!. It isn't free to go into Westminster Abbey but well worth the donation to such an incredible church and incredible cause. From every English king and queens to their great scholars, scientists, politicians, mathematicians, explorers and everyone that made Great Britain "great" you can find all their memorials there. How it all fits inside that colossal Cathedral is hard to believe but it does. From the very oldest to the very newest you won't miss a single part of English history here. As a church it is gorgeous and it has been beautifully restored and is a great example of its architecture.Services are lovely.

Breathtaking abbey. Visited London on a few occasions but never visited the inside of the abbey. £20 entry fee per person or £40 for a family ticket. Was very surprised by the exhibit. Commentary in the abbey is by Jeremy Irons. Takes a few hours to get around the full exhibit, very interesting and informative.

For all you history buffs. If you're a fan of history, intrigue, and architecture then Westminster Abbey should be at the top of your list of things to do in London. Please, please, please do not book a tour. Do not simply use the audio guides they give you. Ask at the entrance about a "Verger Tour." For £5pp you can join a tour with one of the Vergers on staff with the Abbey. Our Verger was Alice, and she was incredibly nice and knowledgeable. They will take you around the Abbey to personally tell you highlights of its history and of those buried there. You even get to enter into the Shrine of St. Edward the Confessor. You don't get this experience unless escorted by a Verger. Don't pass this up, it is worth it and much, much cheaper than hiring a private tour guide!

Royal burial and coronation site. Around 1050 Edward the Confessor ordered the construction of Westminster abbey and church on an older monastic site of uncertain date.Present day Westminster abbey is largely due to a reconstruction campaign initiated by Henry III from 1245 onward.Visitors can discover the church with the help of a free audio guide following a one way circuit. Sadly no photography is allowed inside the edifice. Church and abbey have great architectural interest. Highlights in this perspective include the thirteenth century Cosmati pavement in front of the high altar, the fourteenth century murals in the chapter house and the magnificent perpendicular chapel added by Henry VII.The church is particularly a must for history buffs given its use as a royal coronation and burial site. Although it is a significant plus to have some background about the deceased particularly the fifteenth and sixteenth century tombs are very ornate.The audio commentary was very interesting but I felt a lot more stories were left untold. I would therefore encourage the management to invest in extra audio tracks.Hint 1 : Online tickets come with a discount.Hint 2 : Check the opening times of the abbey online in advance as they differ each day.Hint 3 : Be aware that the shrine of Edward the Confessor can only be visited as part of a guided tour, to be inquired about in advance.
Impressive. This is an impressive monument in terms of both the history it embodies and the architecture that it displays.

a wonderful way to explore history. If you visit the UK, be sure to allow some time to explore the history. Westminster Abbey (not to be confused with Winchester Cathedral) is one of the places you want to visit. (Of course, if you're a Beatles fan, you'll want to visit the "cathedral" also).What I find fascinating is to see all the old papers. Can you imagine having to write everything out carefully by hand if you wanted a copy? Even today, some manuscripts are still copied by hand, such as the Jewish Torah, but that's another story.

The #1 Attraction in London (Tower of London is #2)!. This is a must see! The history contained in Westminster Abbey makes it one of the top attractions in London! The tombs of Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots are amazing. Also, the coronation chair is kept here (used for the coronation all the Kings and Queens of England since 1308). The history in this one building is just incredible. Take your time as there is so much to see. Arrive early!!!!

Majestic exteriors. I didnt venture inside the Abbey so not sure what I missed but its also a must visit place to tick off from your list of places to visit in London....the experience of London for me is to walk down the streets and feel the slight drizzle and the weather and the food and the people so this was not a KEY attraction for me
a tryst with Histroy. This place has an excellent for people who would love to understand and know history. The museum will take a full day to see it.

Stunning. This was on our list of 50 things to do this year. Whilst it would have preferred a guide, it did detract too much from our overall experience. The audio guides are ok, but lack depth. Equally, the lack of information boards relative to each area also prevented us from obtaining a thorough understanding of all the main artefacts, people and areas. Still, a stunning building rich in history and architecture.

Great historical experience. So much history to be seen within Westminster Abbey. Make sure to budget at least 2 hours of time to walk through the entire area. I love that the audio guide is included with admission!

Must See: thousand years of Monarchy story in one place. We spent almost 2 hours in the Abbey and felt like staying some more. The concentration of history in this place is so high that you'd like to check the Abbey stone by stone. With the 20GBP ticket you'll get a free guide that is very well done. I have notice tough that guides tours offer much more details and interesting facts not provided with the audio guides.Photos are not allowed inside, so you can leave home your heavy equipment.Amazing place to visit.

Interesting. We were shunned for taking photos while on the inside and there is an emolument you should pay for your visit. I recommend that you see this beautiful piece of history when you visit London. The outside is breathtaking. It is in a key area near Big Ben, London Eye, Parliament, and Buckingham Palace.

Brilliant!!. While I was sceptical of if I was interested given that the outside is less extravagant than other options in the city I was so glad that I went inside! The history is amazing and fascinating and being in the place where so many historic and influential people lay was a strange but cool feeling. Definitely use the audio guides that are free on entrance and give yourself plenty of time!!

Religion, Culture and Politics Converge into one abbey. I wasn't sure I wanted to wait in line or pay the fee but now consider this one of the ttrip's highlights. The abbey itself is not a memorable gothic structure as others I have seen but nothing quite compares to the history that one can learn here.
History!. Get here early and prepare to wait in line for security. Purchasing tickets online might save you a few GPBs. Don't miss this!

It's very beautiful and interesting!. It is a beautiful museum! Be prepared to spend at the museum all day (5-7 hours). If necessary, you can relax and enjoy a coffee Cake in the museum café. The museum is very interesting and I believe that he is required to attend (with a visit to London). Be sure to take the audio guide !!!!

Westminster View!. Its really good and amazing to walk around Westminster and see lots of things all together. The architecture is really amazing and appreciable to see in London, specially in Westminster Abbey and palaces.

History galore. A beautiful building next to the Houses of Parliament and Bug Ben, thereby affording you the chance to see all three in a few consecutive hours. The architecture aside, the Abbey is ladled full of history, containing the burial sites and memorials not only of monarchs, going right back to Edward the Confessor, but many famous Britons. If history and culture is your thing, you cannot afford to miss this.
Historic!. Great place to visit, full of history. I highly recommend using the London Pass for entrance otherwise it is expensive. Audio tour was great and very informative. Highly recommended.

So much history in one place. This was our second visit to Westminster Abbey, and it continues to impress. We had hoped to take a docent led tour, but the timing didn't work so we took the audio tour. That was better than just walking around.There is a lot of English history here and it is a magnificent church. It is definitely worth the visit.

The Abbey is a must to see. I loved our visit, recommend going on the weekdays might be a little less crowed. We were here on a Saturday and so many people but it was worth it. Took me right to the old Robin Hood movies of my passed, plus I was able to see a beautiful Abbey with so much history, art work, statues and a the Abbey was built so many years ago. I highly recommend a visit.

Amazing tour guide. This is one of the places that I would advise using the tour guide provided. He was knowledgeable, funny, and made my solo trip very enjoyable. He had anecdotes of the royal wedding as well as insights into the uses of different locations throughout the abbey during different time periods. I would definitely return with friends.
Charming . The history of the abbey is fascinating. The building is beautiful but is always under renovation. Don't go on a Sunday as regular worship services are held.

GREAT PLACE TO GO FOR A EVENSONG SERVICE. We were walking past Westminster and the evensong was in progress so we decided to go inside and attend the service. It is a wonderful experience and well worth going in even if you are not a church goer. Also by attending the service you will save around 20 pounds entry cost!

This is a busy venue!. The tours are well organized and can be either with an audio tour or with a Virger (Virgers are the best!). HINT: They close the abbey for tours at 3:30, but there is a sung Evansong at 5P during the week. You cannot walk around, but you sit close to the altar or next to the choir and listen to an extraordinary men and boys Choir sing. The effect is magical. Line up at 4P on the West Gate. Free entry.

So Much to See. If England has a heart, this is it. Come early to avoid the long (but not unmanageable) lines. Best to familiarize yourself with the locations of various monuments and other key features prior to entry; otherwise the sheer volume of historic items will prove overwhelming. The Shrine of Edward the Confessor is currently not accessible to visitors, but that may change. Do not miss the Chapter House (adjacent to the Abbey proper). It is in process of being restored. Some of the medieval wall paintings have been uncovered - and photography is allowed in the Chapter House, for now at least. (Photography is not permitted in the Abbey itself). Also visit the Cloister and the Pyx Chamber.

Breathtaking. The history and beauty of this landmark is stunning and overwhelming. Be sure to pick up an audio guide and make sure to visit the shrines to Queen Elizabeth as well as Mary Queen of Scotts.
expensive by good. again a must see, but no photo's, it is a working church so you may hear singing etc, loads of tombs of ancient monarchs

Amazing history. If you are a tourist in London I would highly recommend a visit to Westminster Abbey. The tour does cost but it is worth the money once you get inside, listen to the excellent audio guide and realize the history that is contained within these walls. Royal weddings and funerals, not to mention the number of famous people buried at, or remembered at the Abbey. You should allow 2-3 hours to do justice to the visit. Highly recommended.

Amazing historical site. I love British history. The Abbey has so much history in it that I had to see it. Knowing some of what has happened there, seeing all of the tombs and grave stones of those only read about, it did not disappoint.

Worth the cost and queues. Westminster Abbey is a must-visit attraction in London and is worth the cost for entry, and the queues that there are sometimes to get in. Westminster residents get free entry with a resident card.

Just ok. I was pleased when my fiancé asked, how much is it and i replied with 9pounds. I hand over a 20 and the ticketer asks for more $. I mentioned how it says 9gbp, She mentioned how I was the 3rd person that day to have confusion and it was actually 20gbp/person! Fine, too late now. I'm not a big audio tour fan, so I asked for a regular map instead and they said they didn't have one. And i said I just wanted to know who was in each room. and they said read the graves. Well... most the graves are deteriorated or written in Latin. It is good I don't know if it's 20gbp worth it, especially with no map.

Breathtaking!. This is a very populate attraction. You may have to queue to get in and there may be a lot of people inside.The history this building has seen is incredible. Download the app or get a free audio guide to hear some of the stories behind various parts of the abbey. Don't forgot to check out the coronation chair on your way out. This really is a must do for all visitors to London. Note: This is an operating church and prayers are said on the hour (I think). You will need to stand still and silent for a few minutes of this happens whirl you are there.

If you're a history buff, you shouldn't miss this!. The Abbey is somewhat spendy but it's worth it. You can enjoy the architecture from the outside as you wait in line, then be in awe of what you see inside. Even if you don't take a guided tour (we used Rick Steve's tour from his London book), you can learn a lot of history. And we didn't know we would be so interested in seeing how many famous people we could find who are buried there. This is worth the visit!
Historic . A must see for photos. The queue to get in is very long and with constantly changing weather conditions makes it difficult to wait in these queues. So we took pics and left.

Historic visit. The abbey is well worth a visit being the resting place of kings and the home of coronations. It has a wealth of history inside within the main body of the abbey and the many chapels. It is busy most of the time therefore you are required to keep moving all the time. The hand held voice guide is good but just too much information to digest in one visit. There is also a "poets corner" where dedication plaques to various British writers are placed.

Not to be missed. Had a wonderful time here, amazing to think no technology existed to aid in the building of this cathedral. Well worth talking to the guides. When you get to lady chapel, ask about the flag with tyre tracks on it and the helmet where the cat is holding a sprig of oak.Use 2 for 1 days out vouchers to half the admission price.

Beautiful, historical, spiritual. If you attend during Evensong at 3:00 PM on weekdays, you do not have to pay the 10 pound tour fee, but you cannot wander or take pictures. It is a true church service, so you will have to be respectful.

Must See History and Culture in London. Located near Big Ben and the Westminster tube station, this is a must see in London. So much history in a living and working house of worship. Staff is very helpful and ready to pray for you if you ask. The building is majestic and then you think through how many historic moments happened here. Take your time. Get an excellent history primer. See a place that has been used for almost 1000 years.

Historical and Awe Inspiring. Visiting Westminster Abbey is a moving experience that I'd highly recommend. The guided tour was a fantastic way to view the highlights of the Abbey with a knowledgeable docent. The poets and scientist corner were moving as was the soldier's memorial. Although the website indicates 90 to 120 minutes, I would suggest at least 3 hours to fully explore all the various pieces of the Abbey. Do not recommend small children.

Another must on a London visit.. Towering Gothic abbey well connected to the British Royal. Magnificent place of worship for Anglican faith. Breathing in history. A bit pricey and might expect long ques.

Christmas Day Service Was Lovely! Highly Recommended!. What a great way to celebrate Christmas in London, by attending high church in a 1000 year old cathedral. It's free to attend services, but you need to get them in advance. They "sell out" quickly, so plan accordingly.
Must not miss this. I came here for Christmas service and was awed by the architecture. It's magnificent and beautiful from whichever angle. Amazing building, mustn't miss it!

Incredible history. The role the Abbey has played in English history is truly amazing. It's boggling how many famed people are buried or represented here. A must see, even with the £24.50 per person entrance fee.

So much history under one roof!. We have a 10 and a 12 year old, the 12 year old loved it, the 10 year old became a little bored half way through. The audio tour was wonderful. The voice of Jeremy Irons guides you step by step through the Abbey and its history. A must visit for those of any faith.

Rare sunny day illuminates abbey. What a different experience seeing the abbey washed in sunlight. Lovely walk in the two gardens and got great photos of Big Ben. Cafe served excellent cream tea after spending a few hours walking around. Get audio for dulcet tones of Jeremy Irons to guide you through - having visited several times before it does add to appreciation with info eg RAF Battle of Britain memorial

Just Outstanding Architecture. Not much needs to be said about this attraction. One can make multiple visits to the outside of the site and enjoy the architecture, parliament square, feel the environment and watch the visitors from all over the world.
Must see!. It's a great time to be there, the abbey that full of history. I can imagine the past time of London life!

The Lady's Chapel is incredible!. I have visited here twice in three months and still enjoyed it equally as well. Luckily the crowds were sparse both times so time could be spent reading the information. An audio tour is included with the price of admission and it is very good. Highly recommend.
Not to be missed. It is a wonderful place to come back to again and again. It can be crowded, but still worth a visit.
Stunning. We went for the (free) carol service which was a beautiful experience and loved the glory of the building.
AMAZING. The most beautiful building! no matter even if you don't make it into the attraction it is still breathtaking to look at.
Take you back in time. The best time to go is when they have evensong. You get to hear the choir for free and it is amazing.
Poets corner. This is a wonderful Abbey full of history. The organisation of the route and the personal audio relating all the facts you wish to know.

Try to go for Mass. We stopped by Westminster one afternoon. It was nice to walk around but a lot was closed as we went on a Sunday before mass. I would go another day besides Sunday so you could see more.

great day out. well worth the money spent very interesting place to visit, abbey staff were very helpful in all questions that we asked the information available was very good. was in a queue to enter but this was solved very quickly ( about 10 mins )

Great Architecture. This is certainly a must to see. There is so much history here. We did not take the tour but were overwhelmed by the size of the structures. It is a great walk around the building where the Thames and Big Ben are in the scene.

overpriced, no photography allowed. Beautiful building and history, but entry fee is exorbitant. They say it costs £35000 a day to run, I don't believe that, if they didn't charge they wouldn't need to pay so many staff! Everyone knows they won't allow photography because they want you to buy their postcards and souvenirs, but when asked, they said for "health and safety" reasons. I thought bearing false witness, ie lying, was a deadly sin! Religion is a man-made institution, and they are fleecing the flock.

Entrance fee??!!. Loved this famous landmark, but I'm always a little put off by admission fees to church buildings. The history and architecture meet expectations. The burial place of David Livingstone is an obvious draw. Overall, much appreciated.

Extremely intricate gothic architecture and history. This is a must-see when you're in London. Located right next to the Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey is a Catholic Church where all the royal coronation takes place - Queen Elizabeth was crowned the queen at this very place in the early 1930s or so. Prince William was married here as well. You can see their wedding ceremony held at this very church (the quire) on the front of the brochure as you walk through the audio tour. While listening to the audio tour, you will also hear the Charles Darwin and Issac Newton's tombs are located there as well. Pity I could find their tombs as there are so many around. The gothic architecture is intricate and very detailed - built from 200 years of contruction and rebuilding from the war. No interior photos to share as no photography is allowed inside. This is where you really need to enjoy with your naked eye - something your camera can't capture! Enjoy

Must do in London.. At the city center and close to a good chunk of other sightseeing opportunities in London, so it should be on your list if you're a first timer in the city and quite easy to visit.Steeped in history and amazing architecture, it's well worth the visit. Expect high entry prices, long lines and no photography allowed.
Much more than a posh church. Museum quality artifacts.Great location.Amazing historical detail throughout.A true landmark.Try the tombs and the roof.

Westminster Abbey. Wonderful visit which took hours because there was so much to see. I loved the stories of so many famous people who have used this Abbey for weddings, coronations, burials. A place for pomp and ceremony but for everyone as well.

So much history, arrive early to beat the lines. This has got to be one of the must-dos in London for a first timer (or even a long timer). Amazing history from the very first step inside. The lines, however, seem to have gotten insufferably long so arrive early!

Impressive interior. The £20 entrance fee seems a little steep but there is so much history and impressive architecture to hear and view that we believe the visit is very worthwhile. The free audio guide is a must to understand the historical significance of the chapels and tombs. The on-site café/restaurant has an attractive setting below a vaulted ceiling. Although a full cooked menu was available we chose a delightful coffee and cake.
Impressive. Very impressive building to see in the heart of London. A lot of architecture to view would recommend to anyone

Located around other attractions + check schedule beforehand.. Amazing! One of the icons of London, a must see for architectural lovers. The gothic exterior embellished with great details. Westminster abbey located around a few other point of interest. Across the street are the parliament building, the queen Victoria center. The thames river is just a step away - therefore also the London eye. The nearest tube is westminster right in front of the building. To enter the westminster abbey, be sure to check their schedule. I'm posting a photo of their open-close hours (taken on 19th dec 2015) for your reference. Check on photo post.You can also take a walk (or you can take the tube) to the trafalgar square which is probably only 10-15 minutes away by foot, so does the Buckingham palace. So plan your day beforehand for efficiency. You can cramp a lot of place in a single day with westminster abbey. Hope these tips are useful.
Great sight. Amazing cathedral. A must see in London. I highly recommend the audio guide so that you make the most out of your visit.
Beautiful!. Very nice, excellent audio guide with quite good timing, the whole family enjoyed this. Some quite moving memorials too.

Highlight of my trip!. This just might have been my favorite part of my visit to London. I absolutely did not expect to be so touched by this place. I had the privilege light a candle and give a prayer request, tour the famed place where coronations, weddings and burials took place, and meet the priest on duty! This is an active church and services are held here regularly. It costs money to tour the facility (which includes use of a self-guided audio tour guide) but if you're attending service then entry is free. The memorials are spectacular and the building is well kept. Do not miss this place!PS - No pictures allowed :(
