A must for visitors. I suggest visiting the abbey for a service particularity evensong. It can be packed at peak times so go as early as possible. It is well worth taking a verger tour because it can be overwhelming. Be sure to check out the Abbey Museum.

Glorious, wonderful place to attend Evensong - one of the very best anywhere in the world. Attending any service in this ancient holy place is a privilege; Evensong is usually 5pm every weekday and if you are in the queue early enough (no later than 4.30pm) you might just be able to sit "in" the Choir - actually behind the choristers and boy! oh boy!it's like you are within a bell of glorious music - you DON'T have to be any particular faith (obviously behave yourself!!!) but you cannot fail to be moved, awed, inspired ... make sure you check online before taking the journey because they don't always have a singing choir BUT sometimes it is a special choir ... and the service is less than an hour; you can dawdle a bit on the way out and thus get to see some of the wonderful interior without the (sorry!) horrendous fee ... I will never pay to go into a "House of God" - making a donation is perfectly acceptable - and if you are fortunate enough to be able to go more than once, you'll get to see quite a bit ... of course, if you only have one chance then take it and in that case, go early, take your time and really study everything ... not dates etc but the gorgeousness and the little quirky things you will see if you have time to linger!!!

An abundance of history. The mesmerising walk through the main door, from one hall to the next. Passing sculptures, memorials, works of art, artefacts and moments of significant history. The architecture is phenomenal and if you have the chance to listen to the choir, do not hesitate. I was fortunate enough to be seated in the lantern seats in front of the alter and beside the choir, for a christmas concert.....An amazing experience!!!
Stunning!!!. After watching the royal weddings at this abbey, seeing it in person is way more impressive. Def go see.

Trip to London. Definitely a must see while in London, but try something different. Line up outside the main entrance about 4 and go to Evensong, an event that will not be soon forgotten! This event is free, but seating is limited and there is not touring of the cathedral after the event, so if you want to tour the cathedral come during regular hours and pay the admission. The choir is magnificent and you might get to sit next to the choir members. The building is very old, but still a beauty and should not be missed if you're in London.

The audio tour is a must. No photos allowed in her, so pop your phone away & your tour to your ear and absorb. There's a lot to absorb- history, magnificence, grandeur. In a way it's overwhelming, but absolutely worth braving the queue.

Did nt get through the gates!!!. Really wanted to see this beautiful abbey but unfortunately the day we went it was shut... It was Tuesday at 2pm... No way did I think for one minute it would be shut so was really disappointed.

stunning architecture, useful audio guide. Westminster Abbey is undoubtedly beautiful. grand on the outside and even more so on the inside. Audio guide was easy to follow despite having zero knowledge of British history. We went in free because we bought the London Pass and admission was included. We had to go through this slightly faster though as we were on a one-day pass and had to rush to other attractions. A must go, at least once when you're in London!

Enjoyable visit. Great place to learn about the royal family and some English history. It took us a couple of hours to make it through with almost no crowd. I am amazed at the age if the building and all the history that happened in the Abby. Look for a two for one coupon booklet at the train station and use it with you travel card to save money.

Fantastic London history. Having taken a deep breath at the £20 admission - it was worth every penny. We used the audio guides which was beautifully narrated by Jeremy Irons. Much more than just a 'church' but more a fascinating tour through history. So many interesting people are buried here - from Charles Darwin to Mary Queen of Scots to Lord Byron in Poets Corner. The beautiful medieval Lady Chamber, the tomb of the unknown soldier and the Coronation Chair are some of the many extra treats in store. I would love to have had a private guide to learn even more, but was very happy with our 2 hour visit. Highly recommend.
Interesting place to visit. Must see again, my interests were to see the place where Kate M tied the knot with Prince.Interesting historical place.

Stunning architecture and full of British history!. Westminster Abbey is like a timeline of British history - and is bursting with royal tombs and monuments to politicians, statesmen, musicians, scientists, explorers and literary giants. Highlights include the tomb of the Abbey founder, Edward the Confessor, the Coronation Chair and the fantastically ornate Lady Chapel.

A spiritual respite. This was my second visit to Westminster Abbey but instead of playing the tourist, we decided to go to the 11 AM Sunday service, and it was a wonderful experience. While Westminster is a familiar site to anyone who watches British Royalty's events on TV, and there is certainly a wealth of history at Westminster, it is first and foremost a religious site, and it was a time of prayer and reflection for us. Then it was off to Sunday Roast!

Why you should visit the seat of the Church of England, even if you aren't Anglican.. To be quite honest, after nearly a week of paying not-so-inexpensive entrance fees to phenomenal, iconic cathedrals in the UK, I was hesitant to pay one more time for this phenomenal, iconic cathedral. I went ahead, because my family religious heritage includes the Anglican Communion. I am so glad I did. As I learned, it is no longer an abbey, nor a cathedral, but it is of enormous political and historical significance. It doesn't have the majestic reputation of St. Paul's Cathedral, which is not far away. But, British history comes alive inside the Abbey. It is the resting place of kings, queens, artists and other legendary historical figures. That alone is worth the price of admission. I knew that the Abbey is an active congregation, but I was a bit surprised when I, along with everyone else, was invited to participate in the liturgies going on while we were there. That's not for everyone, but I appreciated it. Yet, here is what clinched the whole experience for me: I spent most of my time looking up: at the architecture and epitaphs on countless burial markers. While I was looking up, I heard a woman behind me remark, "I can't believe that HE is buried here." I looked down and found that I was standing on top of Charles Darwin. I haven't stopped telling that story yet, as you now know. Perhaps there are iconic structures you want to visit first, but don't miss out on a great, historical experience. Visit Westminster Abbey.
Use the headphones . Take your time and pause between the stops to enjoy the moment. Even if it is crowded, don't be rushed. There is so much to see!

The Centre of British History. I have been to Westminster Abbey at least a dozen times during business trips or vacations. In my view, it is one of the most impressive buildings in the world. The vast amount of history that took place in this building is astounding. It is amazing how many famous people are buried here. And the architecture is beautiful. Go there, get the self guided tour, and experience a thousand years of British history.

A Really Interesting Experience. We visited as a couple on Saturday morning. Please note the Abbey closes at 1.30pm on a Saturday, and is obviously not open on a Sunday for tours but you are welcome to worship free of charge.Our visit cost £20 each, but then it costs alot of money to maintain such a magnificent self funded building.We used the audio tour, following the numbers on the sign posts to hear really interesting and informative commentary from Jeremy Irons on the history of the Abbey.We saw the Coronation Chair as Westminster Abbey has been the nations Coronation Church since William the Conqueror times 1066.Staff were pleasant and helpful.The shop was well stocked with the usual assortment of gifts (at London prices).The Cellarium Cafe looked lovely but we had planned to eat elsewhere.Afterwards we walked around the Deans Yard soaking up the atmosphere of the area.Toilet facilities were good and clean.Definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful . Just happened to pass by when there was no line, thought I'd pop in for a look. So glad I did! So much history and wonderful architecture. This is a must see when visiting London. Only downside was not being allowed to take photos.

The Church to see in London. If you have traveled around Europe and been to many churches, well then Westminster Abbey is not that different. Its beautiful, elaborate, huge and filled with tombs. I went because I had the London pass and it was included, otherwise I'm not sure its worth the time spent standing in line or the money. If you have not seem some of Europe's other churches its worth it but if you have, I wouldn't put this on the top of my list.

Fabulous place to visit. If you are at all interested in history, then this Abbey will make a fantastic visit for you. I was a little taken aback that I had to pay for my visit each time I went, but it was well worth it. St Pauls has a system where you pay once, and can opt for an annual pass, but this doesn’t seem to be available at Westminster Abbey. However, I was blown away by my visit.Every corner is crammed in with sculptures, tombs, plaques, etc., to the most famous of people and many kings and queens. I was particularly tickled given the history that we read, that Queen Elizabeth I is commemorated on top of Mary, her sister (I wonder what Elizabeth was trying to say with that act), and that just down the corridor, Mary Queen of Scots is commemorated – Mary and Elizabeth would probably be turning in their graves at that one. Also Queen Elizabeth's effigy was apparently modelled on her exact hands and face which is a bit spooky when you see her.  I took an audio tour – these are also available to download onto your phone through the Abbey website, but the free audio tour kit worked very well. I also took a guided tour. Unfortunately, our guide must have had a rather long day, as she was not very animated, and appeared to be stifling sighs of boredom all around. However, she did take us into Edward Confessors shrine which was incredible, and I felt extremely fortunate and honoured to be allowed in there, given it’s age and what it’s been through over the ages. That was very special indeed.I only managed to do half the audio tour before our main tour started, and unusually the person who guided our tour really didn’t tell us much that we couldn’t have found out on the audio tour, which from my experience is an exception to the rule.However, I wonder how many of the guided tours go into visit Edward, and also save us a seat in the quire for the evensong service – that was a major bonus.I will return in a few months’ time, to complete the audio tour at a leisurely pace, in case anything was missed out on our guided tour.Evensong was ethereal whilst sitting in the quire. The choir boys and service were magical. I don’t often go to church, but I think in future, that this will be my favourite service to attend if I feel the need. One could feel that it dated way back to around Henry VIII time and was just really, really special. Normally one has to queue outside the Abbey entrance until around 5.15pm and then be let in, once the Abbey has closed to the public. But since we were on the afternoon guided tour, we were tipped off to show our visitor wrist bands and stay in the Abbey to get to the front of the queue for the best seats for the service. If you want to sit in the quire, then you need to be at the front of the queue as it is first come first served.There was disabled access to most items, although the toilets are currently in a portacabin up some steps, so I’m not sure how that would work for the disabled. There was a nice café/restaurant. The shop was a bit lacking I felt. I enjoyed the shop at St Pauls more – can’t put a finger on why though….Can’t wait to go back and explore more than just the main building – there is plenty there probably for the whole day if you take it slowly and soak it all in.Loved it.

Thousands of years in history. A must visit. This abbey showcases many past kings and their stories. It is a pity if you missed this attraction. Beware of pickpocket and photos kings are prohibited in the abbey. Good souvenir to be purchased

Evensong & Mr Anthony Trollope. Such a spectacular building & atmosphere. It was a real privilege to be able to attend Evensong. Stunning architecture, excellent choir & lovely cantor Stephen from Montana (I asked him afterwards: "You're not from round here, ey?")Beautiful wreath laying service afterwards by HRH Duke of Kent commemorating the death of Anthony Trollope whose memorial is in poets corner.

Well worth the entry fee. Wow. Westminster Abbey was absolutely amazing. Well worth the 20 pound entry fee. Spent hours wandering around this mighty Cathedral. Fascinating. You can get in for free at about 5 oclock in the afternoon when they have their evensong. You can't look right around the abbey but it is an amazing experience to hear the organ and the choir.

Arhitecture and History Abound. Do the Verger Guided Tour, If Space Is Available.. This was by far the highlight of our trip to London and I would recommend that everyone visit here at least once in their lifetime. We bought our tickets online. They are for a specific day (of your choosing and based on availability), yet fortunately they are not time certain. This at least gave us some flexibility as to when we arrived. We walked over from the St. James' Underground Station. As we approached, we could see this magnificent building rise in front of us. It is truly magnificent and knowing some of the history and events that have taken place here over the years makes it even more incredible. They were in the middle of placing the small Poppy Crosses on the lawn for the Field of Remembrance. Over 100,000 would eventually be installed. It was a time for reflection looking at all of the names, units and countries represented. It was also very much a time to be thankful for their service and sacrifice. While photos are welcome outside, you are prohibited from taking photos inside the Abbey. While this was a disappointment, it is certainly understandable. We visited in early November on a Tuesday morning and arrived right about opening time. We had read about the 90 minute Verger Tour so we inquired and found spaces were available on an upcoming tour. We opted to wait about an hour. You can look around inside during this time or go back outside. The Verger Tour only cost an additional 5 GBP and was the best money we spent on our whole trip. There is a small food wagon set up near the entrance. Their coffee is really good (not too strong). As we entered, there was basically no wait (due to the time of year) and the security guard was inspecting bags. We showed out Verger Tour ticket and were directed to some chairs to wait in or we could look around until time for our tour. Our tour was small with about 10 people (it is limited to 20 maximum). We started at the west door and worked our way down the Abbey as you would see in a formal procession, all the while being informed of historical features and events. As an example, I did not know that the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior lies in the middle of the aisle inside the main entryway near the west door. The wooden Coronation Chair is also nearby. We were taken into the choir loft and allowed to sit while we were given more details on the construction and history of the Abbey. We proceeded down to the High Altar, up the wooden steps to the Chapel containing St Edward the Confessor's Shrine and where a total of five Kings and four Queens are buried, onto the Lady Chapel where Elizabeth 1 and Mary 1 are buried in the same tomb, nearby is the tomb of Mary, Queen of Scots among the burial places of many others, finally we ended the tour at Poet's Corner. After it was over, we were free to walk around more or simply sit and enjoy the Abbey. We opted to go to the Cellarium Café for lunch. We both ordered the 8 oz Rib Eye with Béarnaise Sauce and it was the best steak we have had in quite a while. Perfectly cooked and very tasty. The menu is varied and alcoholic beverages are available. Restrooms (toilets) are nearby, as well as a small gift shop. The only negative of our whole experience was prior to our entry when we needed restroom facilities. We were directed to a large portable "sanitation station' around back that was unisex as both men and women, including the construction workers who were using this facility. There was also what appeared to be an older male employee that appeared to be responsible for maintaining this facility, however he was more concerned about listening to the game that was being blasted on the radio than cleaning the facilities. The place was disgusting and wreaked of urine. Something desperately needs to be done about the facility conditions. So, if you can hold it and eat at the Cellarium, I recommend that you use those facilities. Otherwise, this was an amazing journey through time and I am grateful for the opportunity to check another big item off of my bucket list.
Amazing old. The entrance fee is quite expensive. The Church is naturally interesting to visit. A place of dynasties and sovereigns. Cold and chilly inside.

The site is beutiful, but not much more than that.. The abby is an amazing site and truly awe striking. With that in mind, not enough has been done to make the place interesting for a tourist. The voice guide drones on about the way every room was made and in who's memory instead of ecplaining about their lives and their reign at the throne of england. The worst part is when at the very end of the tour you arrive at the poets corner and the tour ends abruptly without really explaining about almost any of them.

So excellent, iconic indeed. A wondrous experience and a must-do even if you have to wait in line, which is probable. Also please remember that it's a real church with real church services - hopefully one will happen while you're there. Seeing the tombs and memorials for anybody who's anybody in British history is just great. The cathedral is not as gorgeous as Notre Dame or Chartres, but the history and inside is without equal.
A MUST SEE. loved the history and royal connections of this beautiful abbey,the famous events in history were endless.Pleased arrived early as the queues were long after 10am.

So much History. the history in this place is amazing. It is well worth the visit. The building is gorgeous and if you are lucky enough to hear the choir - luck you. There is a free audio tour included with your entrance fee. You cannot take photos inside.

The Unknown Soldier for free. I went to see this monument only and was taken aback by the £20 admission. The good news is that if you only want to see this WW1 monument you are allowed access via the west gate where the warders allow you in to that part of the cathedral only for free to pay your respects. If you want to see the rest it's £20.

Must see. This is a must do when in London but expect to wait in line. There are no photographs inside the abbey so prepare for outside shots only. Plan to spend a couple hours walking around the abbey and looking at all the famous graves and memorials. I suggest the audio tour as there is way too much for you to find in your own. Every room is amazing and this will be a highlight of your trip without a doubt

Must See in London. I cannot imagine why anyone visiting would not visit Westminster Abbey. What a place! The history is overwhelming, the architecture takes your breath away…truly a magnificent place. We arrived at 9:30am on a weekday and the line to get in was very long and security was very thorough - which I am grateful for and respect, but just know that the wait to get in can be blustery and a bit of a wait. Once inside you follow route with the other visitors and it's amazing all of the names that you see. The sites are so old that it seems amazing to imagine what those people's London was like. It's hard to put into words how remarkable a place Westminster Abbey is, but it's a must see place in London. Also, the gift shop is very well done.

Awe Inspiring. This is an iconic piece of history that cannot be missed. As you enter and pay your admission you are guided to a kiosk where you are given an audio guide device. The tour is narrated by the actor, Jeremy Irons. They offer them in several languages. Areas have numbered signs. You key in the number and listen to the tour. There is too much to try to explain. The burial areas of the famous monarchs such as Elizabeth I and Edward the Confessor and Queen Mary. The coronation altar and the chair that dates from the 12th century. The structure itself is spectacular. One area that moved me was Poets Corner. To stand and see the burial area of Chaucer, Dickens, Dryden, TS Elliot, D H Lawrence. The list goes on and on. This is a place you can't miss.

"An absolute must see". Beautiful. Built on an island surrounded by marshland during the 7th century. Even though its real importance dates from 1066 with Edward the Confessor establishing today's Crowning of English and later, British monarchs. In 1255 Henry the second rebuilt on top of the previous Abbey.More recently, Prince William was married here. The late Diana, Princess of Wales funeral held, and seventeen Monarchs are buried within the Abbey. Very long Queues on visiting days, best to arrive early. Open 0930 to 1700 hrs weekdays. Saturday 0930 to1300 hrs. Sunday closed. Getting there. District, Circle and Jubilee lines all call at Westminster station. Short walk to the Abbey.Peter M.
Such a beautiful church. The self guided tour was fantastic and well worth the money. So much beautiful detail and so many resting places and so many historical people.

Beautiful architecture with lots of history.. The abbey is near the Big Ben and underground. You will see a long queue outside the abbey. I got a lot of information about the abbey from the audio guide,its very informative! Interesting but a bit expensive(£20). There is a college garden within the abbey area,you can go and see it.

A must see. This is a fascinating place rich with history. Much more than I expected. A bit expensive, but the fee goes to maintenance. Some very ancient history going way way back. The coronation chair was a highlight for me. I'd love to attend Mass there.

A Remembrance Day must!. If you haven't visited the Abbey and the courtyards surrounding it on remembrance day I recommend it - such a breath taking experience; a time to reflect on all those lives lost and actually visualise it with the sea of Poppy's covering most of the courtyard. The abbey itself is beautiful of course, and there's plenty of reviews about it - but not enough recommending you visit here in November.

Rule Britania. Even the most casual awareness of the progress of history will whet the appetite for exploration of this monument. Saints, scientists, kings, queens, poets, actors are commemorated and even buried here. Coronations, weddings, funerals have filled the pews. Imagine the Kings Speech, Queen Elizabeth's coronation, Princess Di's funeral. Is it worth £30? Sure. Please plan for a wait in Line because the security is tight. Also, at the expense of being preachy, bear in mind this is first a church, second a national treasure, and only lastly a tourist attraction. Let's give the respect this hallowed hall has earned
Coronation place. BeautifulAnd very close to BigBen, this is the place of queen coronation and Prince William & Kate got married. Don't miss it.
Good historical place to visit. Enjoyed this but due to cost decided not to pay for the guide. This meant it was easy to miss some of the highlights as not well marked understandably.

Lots of history - very crowded. A must when visiting London. Probably more historical interest than any other site in the country. The audio guide is very informative and keeps you moving, which is just as well as even in December it was very crowded. Do not expect a religious experience however, unless you choose to go to one of the services of course.
London core. The visit is very well organized: an audio guide explains all the details allowing historical deep dive. If visited in a sunny day, the artistic windows are really impressive.

An architectural and historical gem. Having not been to the abbey since a child I was taken by a visiting friend. There are invariably long queues and it's not cheap - but it's worth the wait and the money. Advance booking online allows you to skip the queues and download the audio tour which is free for all visitors.The architectural splendour of the exterior continues inside and you get to put into perspective what many hundreds of millions have seen on TV watching high profile state and royal occasions.What those TV pictures don't show are the wall to wall graves and memorials to the great and the good down through British history. From Elizabeth I to Rudyard Kipling to William Wilberforce and Laurence Olivier there are magnificent tombs and simple memorial plaques. Each invariably merits a few moments/minutes of your time so be prepared for a good couple of hours in the abbey.Don't neglect the simpler calmer atmosphere of the cloisters. Also remember that this is a working church and services can take priority over tourists at times.

Impressive. Cant come to London and not spend an hour here. As you approach the excitement builds up. Its sight is awe striking. Beautiful architecture fit for Great Britain! Truly Stunning. Take a tour inside, its completely worth it!

Eerie But Very Cool!. I did not realize what Westmister Abbey was until I was there - a lot of people were buried here. The headsets that guide the tour provide a lot of information about the Abbey. The only downside for me was that you cannot take photos. I was also here during Remembrance Day and the yard outside was full of little crosses and poppies - it was a beautiful memorial.
The Most Important Building in London. The Christian Evensong service held around 5pm (check their website) is something to experience, especially when the boys choir is singing.

Too much money for so little. Westmister Abbey is a post gothic building with little interest regarding arquitecture.The thumbs of the English kings, could be of some interest for Brits and historians, but for the public in general, they do nothing offer. Not the sculptures, neither the coffins.I do not recommend paying 20 £ almost 30€ for visiting nothing interesting.
Pretty Amazing. For me, the highlight of this attraction is seeing Elizabeth I's tomb. And Poets Corner. It's an amazing piece of British History.

Stunning. I believe there is an entrance fee but I was lucky enough to visit here twice for free because of my job, so I can't comment on visiting as a tourist. However, I just want to say that the place is stunning - not as big as I originally thought it would be though. The detail throughout is something to behold and I would like to go back at some point and get a guided tour and hear more about the history of the place. It's a piece of London's history, so worth a visit! Funnily enough it's very close to Westminster station!
Beautiful sight. Worth a visit. Beautiful building. Silent and Heritage. Use a tour pass to get free entrance. Must visit this historical building.

Dedicate at least an hour to this special place. Great audio guide that helps connect what you see to the history and takes you on an easy walk around the Abbey. My son (23) and I enjoyed the tour. He enjoys history and listened to everything on the audio guide. A must see in London.

1000 years of history. Westminster Abbey has the tombs of many famous kings , queens such as Elizabeth I , monuments to statesmen, writers, actors, soldiers. It is so full from top to bottom that it is hard to take it all in. However if you are interested in important people in UK history and beyond , it is certainly stunning. Admission is expensive and my consolation is that it's supporting the church in maintaining this pilgrimage site for so many. There is a cafe we weren't able to visit and nice shops we were. Apparently you can visit for free during services , but visitors at those times cannot tour the many tombs and memorials. Get there early as the line is long even then. The staff is friendly and helpful. You are able to wander and staff are available for questions and info in different spots.

Its history is too much to fathom - amazing. Trying to capture and appreciate all of the history is like trying to capture the magnitude of the Grand Canyon on your pocket camera. The history is astonishing, the beauty immense. The included audio guide is helpful.Westminster Abbey certainly deserves its place as one of the biggest highlights in London, a city with many highlights.
History at its most beautiful.. Yes, it is an expensive entrance fee, but it was stunningly beautiful and historic, and worth the price, even in retrospect.

An impressive sight. Wanted to see first hand the grandeur of this majestic abbey, where royal weddings/funerals have taken place .Did not take the tour $$ through it, but we did attend a sunday service, which was amazing, with a boy choir. A must see when in London

Westminster Abbey - well worth visiting. Westminster Abbey is remarkable - it is worth visiting this 700 year old building. You can tour the Abbey at your own pace with an audio tour. Public transport is very close (bus and tube) and the Abbey is near other London attractions e.g. Downing Street, Houses of Parliament.

Over 1000 years of history.. Almost everybody who was anybody in the last thousand years was buried or married here. One could spend hours looking around and not be bored. The entrance fee is almost 20 pounds but if you attend a service you can see quite a lot of it. I believe they have services there almost every day. In a great location just across from Westminster Bridge, Parliament, and Big Ben. Worth a trip to see at any time you visit London. Maps at the door to point out the most important things to see in the Abby.
The sense of awe and a sense of history. We went with a walking tour and found that visit helpful and insightful. We were able to join in a service and that was quite a joy

Worth the Visit. We debated whether or not to pay the 20pds to go in to Westminster Abbey but are so glad we did. There is SO much history in this building. It's incredible to think of all of the major historical events that have taken place here and the historical figures who are buried here...Isaac Newton, Chaucer, Mary Queen of Scots, St. Edward the Confessor and countless more. It truly is a remarkable place.
A must do. Ask about attending Evensong. Listening to the choir of young boys and men and the organ will be a lasting memory of the Abbey. It was like being with the angels.

Pricey Entrance Fee but well worth it with a guided tour. It was pricey to get in and you cannot do a tour on a Sunday as it is not open for tours then being a church. The guided tours are great and very informative, I really enjoyed seeing Westminster Abbey.
Indrukwekkend. No one could not be impressed by Westminster Abby. The outside is allready very nice but the inside is above imagenation.

WOW!!. This is a beautiful church inside and out. Princess Diana's funeral as well as Prince William and Princess Kate's Wedding were held here. No pictures are allowed inside. We did not do the audio tour which I believe is free with your ticket. I mainly went to see Henry VII's Lady Chapel and the resting places of those involved in the Wars of the Roses and the Tudor Age, but I enjoyed the rest as well. Across the street from Parliament and Big Ben. Minutes from Westminster Bridge.
Must see in london. So many amazing tombs and such great history here beautiful cathedral architecture and you also can attend services here if you wish. Love it

Always a priority stop for me. I've been lucky enough to visit London on several occasions and the Abbey is a spot I always come back to. This was the first time however I had my kids with me and was delighted at how interested they were. There is a kids map and worksheet we were given at the entrance which guided them around to significant locations in the Abbey and prompted them to ask a lot of questions. There is so much history here, and I hope that one day I'll be able to return again.
Atmosphere and History. Westminster Abbey always moves me. It is one of the most incredible monuments to history in the world.

Your in London, you have to go to the Abbey. When traveling in London, seeing Westminster Abbey is a must. Yes, it is mostly tourist, but that is what we are, right? It is worth it. Go by cab (the best way to travel around London) and walk in. It is beautiful, with stained glass and under your feet are the famous and infamous dead. You can step on Cromwell, my idea of fun or just take a moment to take in the beauty of it.
Historic church. This is church holds so much history and is an excellent example of gothic architecture. Admission costs 20 pounds pp, so not cheap, but definitely worth a visit.

OMG, Go inside to walk amongst the Kings and Queens. Have been to London many times before and like others have walked past the abbey many times. This time we took a walking tour and was amazed by how much we didn't know about the who, what, and where of Westminster Abbey.As Americans, our own history can date back 300-380 years, not so in England. Here you will walk in and around the stones of former Kings and Queens of England exceeding the USA by far. Just an amazing place to visit. I highly recommend a walking tour like London Walks. Extremely knowledgeable.

Abbey . Westminster Abbey is usually open to visitors from Monday to Saturday throughout the year. On Sundays and religious holidays such as Easter and Christmas, the Abbey is open for worship only. All are welcome and it is free to attend services.Westminster Abbey is in the heart of London - next to Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. Closest tube stations are St James' Park and Westminster.

So much history in one building, must-see in London. This is a wonderful place out of time, so old and crammed with amazing things to contemplate at every turn. More than a thousand years old and the site of every coronation in British history since William in 1066... absolutely mind-blowing. The free audio guide (narrated by none other than the estimable Jeremy Irons) is free and provides deep insights into the notable sights along the way. Many many influential people are buried here, including kings and queens, composers (Purcell, Handel), writers (Dickens, Tennyson), scientists (Newton, Darwin), and many other British nationals who have shaped our world in ways we cannot imagine. Step back in time and open your mind to a thousand years of history, unfathomable yet accessible.

Just another big church. 20£ to get in, just to see a church is steep. Yes, it's big, and it is beautiful but similar to all other big churches. Biggest difference is that it's also a burial site for many notorieties. You can skip this.

A must-see place in London. I visited the Abbey in October. I went in the afternoon on a Friday. I had to wait about 45 minutes in the line to enter but the wait was well worth it. I used an audio guide that was well-narrated by actor Jeremy Irons. You just follow the stops which correspond to audioguide and hear about the immense history of the abbey. I ended up spending about three hours in the abbey. I recommend you take your time and not let the other visitors hasten your pace. I did eat at the Cellarium Cafe and Terrace. The food and service were excellent. The abbey shop has an excellent collection of religious souvenirs to choose from.

Breathtaking place to visit - all kings and queens were crowned there. It is amazing to be there where most of the kings and queens of Uk were crowned or got married. Though it is not free to visit one can try attenting the evensong (at 17 pm during weekdays) when the entrance is free. But be on time (no late entry is accepted) and prepare to spend an hour inside - an hour of prayers and chorus singing. It is an unique experience!

Incredible. If you go in London, you simply cannot miss the Westminster Abbey. This place is so rich in history, I still can’t believe it! Take your time and don’t forget to take the free audio guide.

Years of history in one place.. It's a fantastic landmark so make sure you visit next time you're in London. Once you enter, get the free audio guide as it will provide lots of information about its history. There is so much to see and it took me almost 2 hours to finish my tour. Unfortunately, photography is not permitted.

Not worth the admission. One of the most historically significant churches in the world, Westminster Abbey has been the site of many British monarch's coronation, wedding, and burials. Maybe that is why the admission price is so high: £20 per adult.While the Gothic-style architecture was certainly impressive, it was not as unique as other impressive Gothic-style churches in Europe that are free to enter like the Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris to justify the high price. Aside from its historical significance, I think the Abbey's selling point is that it's the burial site for not only the British royalty and aristocrats but also famous individuals like Issac Newton and Charles Darwin, so if you get fazed by cemeteries in general, this may not be your cup of tea. Otherwise, this is the place you will get as close to these notable figures without a time machine!I personally did not believe the church was worth the admission, as the exterior was more impressive and iconic than the interior. Unless you already have the London Pass, you can safely pass up going inside if you have and will be going to other churches in Europe.---tl;dr version:1) Impressive but not entirely unique architecture to justify high cost2) Burial site for many notable figures - good or bad depending on how you handle dead people

Beyond Words. The history overwhelms you and the scale of the cathedral is breathtaking. The number of kings, queens poets, and famous British citizens whose graves or monuments fill almost every space not available for circulation or worship
Great building. Good audio tour. No photos permitted.. Is £20 per person good value to see a building with so much history? Maybe. Shame about no photos though

Fantastic. I have visited the Abbey many times, and will most likely visit it again. Make sure to use the audio guide they provide for free, it will provide you with lots of information. There is so much to see in there, you could probably spend a couple of hours in there. It was very interesting to see the wall by Poets Corner that shows what the whole church looked like in Medival times. Very friendly and polite staff too.

Evensong Service. I went to the Evensong service and loved it. I've never been to a service like this one, as I belong to a much different church denomination back in the States. The choir was unbelievable. The staff was very strict about the no pictures/phones/etc policy, which I understood and appreciated so that the service was uninterrupted.
What a history. Great historical religious building, serene atmosphere, good functioning audio guide and worthwhile a visit. Not cheap but worth every pound.

A lot to see, adults like, kids suffer through it. Enjoyed seeing the famous people "buried" there, the audio tour was very helpful. I've never seen tanks and machine guns in stained glass. The ceiling of the Lady's chapel is amazing.

Beyond Impressive . On this, my 2nd visit, I convinced my husband to join me. As a serious historian, he could not have been more impressed. We could have spent days here, but had limited time to visit. We'll be back!
Fantastic blend of history and architecture. This is a must see in London. A place where you find scientists buried with poets and authors and Royalty!

Beautiful architecture. My review of Westminster Abbey is limited to it's exterior architecture as I didn't have the change to visit it from the inside.
Nevertheless, it is a beautiful gothic church full of history. Its two towers rise and are quite impressive.
One of London's great monuments.
Grand!!. I really thought this was just another church but boy was I wrong. Inside you'll see various structures that will blow you away. Must go!

Expensive but worth the visit!. See the grave of Charles Darwin and Sir Isaac Newton.
It is a essential piece of history when you visit London
I have enjoyed my stay here

One of the best cathedrals to see in the UK. Have visited a number of times, and it always impresses. Going on a Sunday to coincide with the service is a way of avoiding the entrance charge (which is high)

A beautiful place to worship and of history!. This is a most beautiful church, both inside and outside. But must admit, I had a "difficult" time having to pay to enter a church. (Something about that did not sit well with me.) Yet, the funds help to maintain this iconic English landmark.We did purchase their audio guide, and it helped with our tour. We also checked online for the day's tours and prices that were available. Both buying your ticket in person and online are the same amount. We noticed that not all areas are wheelchair accessible either. The staff is most helpful as you approach them with questions. Make time to check out the many royal tombs that are located here. Amazing history. We took the time to sit and take in the splendor and history of this church. Don't forget to look up, and see the ceiling detail. Note that not all items of interest are royal in nature. "Poets Corner" is for numerous artists, musicians, and writers. The coronation chair on display is amazing to see. As with all other London "attractions" there is a nice gift shop to browse in as you leave.
Very nice. I enjoyed the stain glass window and walking around to all the history that is in here. Mary Queen of Scott's, Henry V tombs all very nice
Good Place to visit. Westminster Abbey is good place to visit. You need to buy the ticket to see inside. It is easily accessible and not requires lot of time.

Spectacular . . . tombs . . . famous people . . . crowds!. We visited Westminster Abbey on a Saturday morning. We travelled to Westminster by tube from Paddington. When we emerged from the underground station, the entire area around the Houses of Parliament, Parliament Square and Westminster Abbey was absolutely crammed with people.When we made our way to the visitor entrance to Westminster Abbey, there was a very long queue of visitors waiting to gain admission. As we had London Passes, we were able to gain express admission and thereby just walk straight in. At the entrance, we were issued with our audio guides for our self-guided tour. The audio guide takes the visitor to about 22 different points of interest inside the abbey and around its environs. Included in the points of interest are a number of small chapels which contain the tombs of various eminent people.The interior of the abbey is absolutely stunning. The audio guide provides a very good insight into the various points of interest. During our visit, many parts of the abbey were very crowded with people which made it a bit difficult to dwell in any one spot for too long. It may have been better to visit on a weekday rather than on the weekend.After we had completed our tour of the abbey, we visited the abbey’s souvenir and gift shop which is located just next to the abbey. The shop was well stocked with a great range of good quality merchandise.Our visit to Westminster Abbey was a remarkable and very enjoyable experience. A visit to the abbey is highly recommended!

Baeutiful. We didn't go inside the abbey but it is still impressive from the outside, as with all Londonderry attractions it is getting expensive to visit, entry is included on London pass but we didn't have time to go back to the abbey, early closing times means weekday visiting is a must
Perfect History. You will not believe what you are looking at when you visit this amazing place...even Darwin is buried here...Absolutely fascinating

A great experience. Pre-booked tickets so in very quickly.
The architecture of the Abbey is fantastic. The fan-vaulted ceiling is absolutely beautiful. There are so many important memorials to past monarchs which give so much history to think about. The audio guide was very useful.

finally got there. Having tried to visit on several previous occasions we booked on line in advance.we turn up with a very large queue just before 10 we spoke to a member of staff who took us to the fast track side & we were in.The head sets are a must you can quite easily miss seeing thing without them. We wander round at our own pace & really enjoyed the visit,
Fantasti Buidling. So worth a visit. Like the audio guide, lots of tombs to view of departed Kings and Queens. Forgot we had so many. Liked the prayers on the hour, good feel.
Absolute must see!. Definitely must see in London! Nice building right next to the houses of parliament in Westminster, only 20 pounds to get in!

Well worth the entry fee. I was not sure it would be worth the price to get in so I waited for a couple of years before going in. It is amazing to say the least. Once in, it is fantastic and very big. It seems to go on and on. So much to see and I spent more than 5 hours here. The afternoon tea is very nice and I had mine with a glass of champagne.

The second of my favorite attractions. A must see. Lots of kings, queens, royalty and English favorites buried there from Charles Dickens to Bronte sisters to Jane Austin. This is where Diana and Kate Middleton were married. Very interesting place with lots of history. Would visit again.

The past was there.. When I got in the Abbey, I was surprised and fascinated by the beauty of the place. The past was there to affirm the greatness of the Abbey. Beautiful abbey!!!. Beautiful and gothic abbey. It is a little bit expensive, but worth it!Very close to Big Ben, if you are there you should visit!
must visit. We visit in the morning and then come back 5pm for to pray. It is so special place . We visit every time that we come to London. So peaceful!

Don't Miss It!. Westminster Abbey is beautiful and definitely worth the visit. It does have an entrance fee but if you have the London Pass then it is included. Walk along the sanctuary and view the crypts, the artwork and styles of the past. This is an active church and services are still held so you are asked to be quiet but many talk softly. The floor tiles also cover crypts and you can names and dates marching back through time. This is my favorite in London and you get a real feel of the age of the monarchy just by walking the time-worn floor through the church. There is a gift shop just outside the doors. Impressive!
Remarkable place. Well worth a visit the place is steeped into history just the though that people have visited this place for hundreds of years put's the place into a different perspective.

Westminster Abbey .. Of course !. Do not miss, forget, skip, postpone ... a visit to Westminter Abbey and it surroundings. No photo or video allowed inside. Will take you about 2 hours to visit it. You will learn a lot about the royals over the centuries

Historic gem. My wife and I visited London in the summer during August. We stayed in the Westminster area and saw most of the attractions inn the area. The Abbey is situated just across the Westminster bridge from the eye, very centrality located.
Go to a Church Service!. The tour was good but being a part of one of their services was a wonderful spiritual experience that you must have if you see this landmark.

Lovely walk around. Some of my favor people are buried there. So much history. If you take you time you will really enjoy this. Don't think you can pop in for 5 minutes. Go slow and see all the great stuff.
Nice urban area. It is a very animated and nice area.The Westminster Abbey bldg is remarkable.It really deserves its well reputation.

Morning prayer . Sitting listening to the choir singing matines knowing it has been done like this for 1000 years, send chills down your spine. The falsetto voices of the male choir is amazing and rejoice with the souls in the prayers. Episcopalians as well as others will be familiar with the liturgy.

Beautiful, definitely go in off season!. My husband and I toured the abbey on a Monday in November, and we were very glad we did. It was still quite busy and we can't imagine being able to see much of the Abbey in peak tourist season. We also used the '2 for 1' discount eligible for National Rail travellers which made the visit much better value.The Abbey itself is just stunning and I loved being able to see the place I had seen so often broadcast for special royal occasions. It was also quite awe inspiring to see so many memorials and tombs. The free audio guide was also very helpful and I would recommend utilising it. We would highly recommend this site to those in the off season, even more so for those eligible for a discount. If you are a true history buff or of a faith persuasion I would say the entry fee is worth it. It is definitely not a cheap attraction but I understand why a church would have this entry fee in place.

Beautiful architecture. Westiminster Abbey is not the most beautiful church in the world, but a visit to it is mandatory at least once in a lifetime, even if it is just to contemplate its beautiful architecture and huge nave.Visiting the place is more like visiting a mausoleum for the monarchy and very important people. Of course it still have regular services and masses, but the great highlight for the tourists is the history behind (or should I say below) its foundations. The place serves as a tomb for several kings, queens and member of the monarchy. The good part is that they offer a free audio guide, and without it, your visit will be somewhat boring, unless you just want to see where the Royal Members get married or get their coronation.
terrific. It is so beautiful and outstanding. The structure is wonderful. It is so huge and lots of people were there to appreciate it.

Magnificent. Again a favorite place to visit when I am in London. Hard to relate how amazing the architecture is on this building. If first time visitor, take tour to get layout. Allow plenty of time to explore afterward. Don't miss the basement museum that has all of the funeral effigies from 300 years ago. Kids will like this, kind of spooky to see the wax heads and clothing. Take plenty of photos inside and out. This place will take your breath away.

Must visit. Definitely visit this historical church. All royal Coronation happened here. Also Prince Williams and Kate got married here. In addition, they have a graveyard for most royal and famous people e.g., Darwin, Newton, etc..
Thanks service for scouting and guiding. Great day had by all, just a shame nowhere to mingle and share time with friends colleagues afterwards

A beautiful building. It seems expensive compared to being able to go into many of the iconic churches in Europe for free, but it was worth paying to get the chance to see around the amazing interior. There's so much history in the building that we ended up spending quite a while taking in all the audio guide had to tell us.

HISTORICAL ABBEY. Fantastic Cathedral - Abbey. Walking through British history is awesome! Good to see Queen Mary (1) and Queen Elizabeth (1)(Henry 8ths daughters) who were opposed to each other in life, now lying together in peace.
Just gorgeous. Its a spectacular building and a piece or history. A must see along with Big Ben just a few steps over.

Great History of Britain above and below the Westminster Abbey!. I wanted to visit this place since the time I read the book Da Vinci Code by Dan Brown. Westminister Abbey is the most famous Cathedral in London. Most famous personalities of Britain such as Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Dickens, Ernest Rutherford, Neville Chamberlain, Rudyard Kipling, Geoffrey Chaucer and many more are buried in this Abbey. It has hosted 38 coronations - beginning in 1066 with William the Conqueror and 16 royal weddings, the latest being that of Prince William and Kate Middleton in 2011. Important places in the Abbey are the Poets' Corner, The Westminster Museum and Chapter house. Westminster Abbey Shop sells souvenirs. Westminster Abbey is located at beside the House of Parliament. The nearest underground station is Westminster and St. James's Park.Entrance Fees are 20 GBP for Adults, 17 GBP for seniors and students and children 6 to16 (free for children less than 5 years old).The Abbey is open to visitors on weekdays and Saturdays from 9.30-13.30 in winter months and 9.30-15.30On Sunday the abbey is open only for those attending a service.
history. what a beautiful place with so much history and amazing stained glass windows.i just loved this place.to think how so many people have passed through this building.wow
Well worth a visit. A visit to the abbey is a must the great architecture is a must see and learning it's history was fascinating a must do if visiting London

Westminster Abbey is a treasure. Westminster Abbey is a treasure. Take time to do the tour. Pity no photos are allowed; and they do not have a DVD tour. Based upon the 3000+ tombs in the abbey, it almost seems you are touring a cemetery, but a truly incredible one. Download Rick Steve’s walking tour guide and listen as you walk thru. Not only is their an incredible amount of detail, but much of British political history is captured here. A truly magnificent site and one that has been here since 970 AD!

Historic WestminsterAbbey 😃😃. Historic. Beautiful architecture, intricate designs, lovely Vicarage, calming garden really peaceful. A real privilege to have set foot on its grounds. Come and attend the Evensong so you could hear the choir singing angelically. Experience the Abbey.
amazing interior. A must seetomb of the unknown warrior very poignant especially in November. Fantastic history and architecture

Evensong in Westminster Abbey. I had the opportunity to come for Evensong in Westminster Abbey. It was very spiritual, once-in-a-life moment, very inspiring. I am not a native English speaker, but it was just great to be there, to listen the music and to pray to the God.

Walking through history . It is breathtaking to walk through a site with so much history. The self guided tour is interesting and there are short guided tours that the attendants give. They all seem very knowledgeable and multilingual.

Different Than You Might Expect. While I have visited many of Europe's great cathedrals, this visit is very different. First, it costs quite a bit to enter, so it's not a pop in, pop out attraction or one to which you would return, unless it was for Evensong or for another service. It should be said that you never have to pay to worship here. Second, there are a LOT of people, so the visit is very organized. You will have a difficult time just wandering about unless you want to say "excuse me" a lot and be in the way. The audioguide is a must to get the most out of the place, and it will guide you through. You'll fall in with the parade of visitors who step over and around (and sometimes sadly on) the graves and memorials of many a famous person. The guide will help you identify these people as well as explain the history of the building and the chapels that you will see. Given the crowds and the volume of things to see, this is not a site to squeeze into your itinerary. Leave enough time. In spite of the guided visit, they have done a good job of keeping the church a church rather than converting it into a museum or tourist attraction. Most people are respectful about the noise level, and every 30 minutes or so, there is an invitation to stop for prayer. As well, regular services such as the noon eucharist DO go on, and you can attend easily. If you are visiting this place as a baptized Christian or if you have an interest in the Christian faith, I would highly recommend participation. There are also clergy and lay ministers available for prayer or to talk with about spiritual matters and concerns simply for the asking. London is chock full of attractions, but I would recommend taking your time here, not only to make the most of your tour but to take advantage of the spiritual resources available at the Abbey. Amos, while the church visit takes a long time,the peace of the cloisters is not to be missed.

Worth for your trip. When I arrived at the Abbey, I did't know that there was an entry fee of GPB20 so I decided to pay to see what is actually inside. After enter the Abbey, no photograph is allowed which help me to concentrate on the history of the Kings and Queens buried at the Abbey. Definitely worth to go. No Cantonese guide provided so if you are Cantonese speakers, please choose Putonghua for your language choice or English.
Gorgeous Architecture. Just a lovely place to visit! So much history and a beautiful setting. Can get busy at times so go at an off time to really enjoy the specialness of the place.
Fascinating. I am so glad that we were able to fit this into our day! There was so much history in this building! You could spend hours here. it wasnt too crowded off season.
Love this place. This one of the places, where you can spend a day, so much to see. Love it and wish had more time. Don't forget the chapel!

Spectacular. . This is a must see place in London. Westminster Abbey is the heart and soul of London and British history. The architecture is spectacular but the history is even more meaningful. The Abbey is inextricably linked to English history for more than 1000 years.
Amazingly haunting!. Do not miss this attraction when you are in London. The beauty both inside and out is breathtaking. Inside the stories and history is haunting.
Beautiful. The Gothic architecture is amazing. The history of the church and the notable events that have occurred here is very interesting. A must see. Wait time isn't long even if the line is long.

Beautiful and historic church. Westminster Abbey is a large and beautiful gothic church, graced with the coronation of many a monarch as well as their graves, and graves of other famous people. The entry ticket includes a free audio guide, although you could also pay 5 pounds for a 60-90min guided tour (which I did and thought was informative, as I didn't have the patience to listen through audioguide). The church didn't feel as vast I had envisaged. Sure, the nave has a tall ceiling, but the length of it is broken by the Quire, which splits it into two sections, as far as the viewer on the ground was concerned. Unfortunately they didn't let us take photos, which I never understood why (St Peter's Basilica, a far more spectacular and significant church, allows photography indoors). Also, the outside isn't particularly impressive. Nevertheless, it's worth a visit simply for all the history within its walls.

Evensong-Amazing experience. Be sure to attend evensong. It is an amazing event. Choir sings and organ plays beautiful music. We went in the day after Paris bombings and it was so peaceful to worship there. It is also free to attend.

A London must-do. No trip to London can be complete without a tour of Westminster Abbey. And do yourself a solid by signing up for the professionally led tour. You will then have special access to parts of the Abbey that general tourists will not see. It is one of the best deals in town.
Great place. I loved it here very interesting and its very historical place,there are a few places to eat and to have coffee
Historical significance. A London gem.We didn't pay for the tour but the Abbey is incredible just to look at from every angle and appreciate the history

In the presence of greatness. Westminister Abbey has surveyed 700 years of English histiory. It is in the heart of London. Over a millkion guests visit each year..Kings, poets and vagabonds in habit it. Heroes of scholarship and science such as Isaac Newton have found a resting place in Westminister Abbey..
Beautiful Church. Westminster Abbey is beautiful and full of history. It is a fully functioning church with amazing organ sound.

Strolled through and enjoyed the Abbey.. We did not do the organised tour but chose to walk through on our own. The history and seeing the resting places of so many monarchs was amazing. The stained glass windows and intricate interior surpasses anything that can be found built today. Only sour note was not being able to take photos.

Evensong early evening weekdays.. As a fully functioning Anglican Church, welcoming all comers and offering the highest standard of organ and choral music, this is an experience that is difficult to match and in a setting second to none.
love this place. what's not to like .History, heritage, and peace in what can be a noisy busy fast pace society. sometimes it is good to pause and contemplate

Not to be missed. Took my parents to visit here as its one of my favourite places.Highly recommend arriving early and booking a verger guided tour. My 3rd visit and I still learnt a lot from our guide. Allow at least 3 hours to visit. Well worth going to an evensong service later in you day. A beautiful experience and I felt very welcomed.

Absolutely gorgeous. My husband and I purchased tickets online to visit Westminster Abbey. It was good that we did as those of us who had the e tickets were the only ones that were able to skip the long line that had formed even before the Abbey opening. The Abbey is gorgeous, the grounds are gorgeous and the catacombs though sad, were interesting to see. The small cafe is something to visit as well.
Nice example. Take the time to tour the Abbey and appreciate not only the architecture but the history associated with it.

MINDBLOWING. I've just visited Westminster Abbey for the first time, I was stunned at this place. If you're in two minds whether to go or not, don't hesitate, just go! All the history, architecture, politics, music and magic of British history in one amazing place! Audio-guides keep you moving, but you can go totally at your own pace. Westminster Abbey, The Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster. This ancient church is a magnificent building. Long gone is the soot that covered it for so many years. The Abbey has been the coronation church since 1066 and is the final resting place of seventeen monarchs. The present church, begun by Henry III in 1245, is one of the most important Gothic buildings in the country, with the medieval shrine of an Anglo-Saxon saint, Edward the Confessor, still at its heart.Though many talented people are buried or commemorated in the Abbey, there are too many marble statues of long-forgotten men who mean little to most people today. The church would benefit from their removal to more appropriate venues.
Amazing church. Been there for the sunday mass. The church was beautiful and full with history. Art and old heritage of london. I love to be here and looking forward to be here again.
Beautiful. This is a breath taking view. It was amazing to see. However, it is quite pricey if you want to go in

Very moving place for remembrance on Armistice Day. . Went to pay my respects to some old comrades that are no longer with us. Very moving and humbling place to remember lost comrades, friends and fellow soldiers. Such history and ceremony here at Westminster Abbey. A real Jewel in the crown of London.
Great visit to westminster. Really enjoyed our trip to Westminster. It's well worth taking the guided tour, lost of interesting things to be told on the tour.

History Lives Here. When you get here there looks like a long line but it moved very well. I don't think we waited even 1/2 an hour. Once you walk inside, you are walking into history. When I see it on TV again it will not look the same. You need a good 3 hours to see everything. Extremely interesting. If you have a London Pass admission is free. Don't miss this.

Amazing repository of British and world leaders, thinkers, and artist!. This was the only place that my younger daughter wanted to see during our trip to London. I found the entire place amazing the people buried there are men and women that we have heard about over years. It has impressive architecture, cravings, and inscriptions. The only drawback is the long lines in the month of August. Patience is required, but the inside is worth it!

My 2nd visit, just as awe-inspiring!. The history and sheer beauty of Westminster Abbey makes it an absolute must-do when visiting London. We stood in line for about an hour or so, but the line moved quickly and it was a pleasant day. Bonus: we got to hear Big Ben toll noon as we waited. The architecture is stunning and the interior is simply breath-taking! No photography allowed, unfortunately. Seems like they could allow "No Flash" photography as it's done at Notre Dame.
History. Being part of history and walking in the steps that many have done in the past. Very interesting to see the various people buried there of various walks of lives.

A Church with History. We enjoyed our time exploring Westminster Abbey and wanted to visit some specific grave sites inside the church. The stewards were most helpful and we were able to find the graves of William Wilberforce and Kings and Queens that we were interested in. The staff was extremely helpful and the beauty of the building was relaxing to look through too. There was a lot to see here and we had a nice morning looking through the building. Make sure you check the time tables for your visit. Because it is an active church, availability can change from day to day.

Huge contrast to Spanish Cathedrals in the Western Hemisphere. I LOVE old churches and have visited some great ones recently. Mexico City, Granada Nicaragua, and the second oldest in the Americas in Puerto Rico. This is a different deal altogether. First, it is MASSIVE. Set back from green lawns, it stretches a block and towers above the street. Old granite stones accentuate the majesty.Loved it!
Amazing. Amazing to walk through & see all the history...guided tour is easy to follow. Beautiful architecture!
A must see in London.. Absolutely breathtaking! Make sure to take the £5 guided tour. The guide takes you places in the abbey where the regular media guide doesn't allow you to go.
Step back in time. The abbey is full of history. Take the time to talk with the guides within the church, and they will share interesting stories from the past.

Use 2 for 1. At this time of year you are greeted outside by the poppies laid in Remembrance, its worth taking a few minutes to look at these and remember the fallen.The queue also wasn't too long, only about 5 minutes wait however, that did include people bailing out of the queue - don't know why.The entrance fee is £20 per person, we used 2 for 1 which made it better value but you do need to download the voucher and show network rail tickets so its not available if you are a tourist staying in London (not the Abbey's fault). The audio guide is very informative and, of course, included in the price. If the Abbey wasn't included in the 2 for 1 we wouldn't have gone; £20 pp is a bit steep.Photography is restricted, there are areas outside of the main Abbey where photos are allowed.Currently the museum is closed as it is going to be re-sited, we couldn't find the café and the toilets have been moved outside to a Port-a-Cabin (there was an enormous queue of young school kids waiting to use it - lucky it wasn't raining at the time!) The College Garden is only open three days in the middle of the week so we couldn't see that either. My gripe here is that we paid the same as when the Abbey was fully up and running, yet not all the facilities were available to us.The tour route is well thought out and the commentary, as before, is informative. We'd just missed one of the guided tours so I'd suggest that you look at their website and time your visit as I'm sure the guides are very good from what we overheard.We'll probably go back in a few years to see the new museum but will use 2 for 1 again.
This is a must see!. The chandeliers inside the abby are so amazing, the church is iconic and mezmerising! Princess Di touched this sacred ground which make it so precious to the London citizens

Must see!. Westminster Abbey was by far my favorite. It will bring you to tears with its beauty & history. If you are trying to find the best place to experience then this is it. The line was long at the entrance but it moved quickly.
Historically famous church. Worth the admission price, lots of amazing architecture and history. There was plenty of information provided and ours was quite the educational experience.

Impressive church. I hadn't been to Westminster Abbey in at least 40 years when I returned this past week. I followed the audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons and his mellifluous voice and learned a lot. I don't usually visit churches because, frankly, I'm tired of them, but This church was worth it.
Amazing. Loved the experience and gift shop has great deals too. I came back to USA watched Kate's wedding to experience it again
Visit to Westminster Abbey. Take your time. Have been here 5 times and see and hear something new each time. Go early to miss the crowds.

Amazing!. This was on the top of my list for London! I was not disappointed! I could have spent the whole day, had my family agreed. So many historical people are there,I even found some of my husbands relatives! My daughter and I were anointed...a real blessing! If we return, I'm spending the day!!!
Wonderful. Visiting the Abbey first is a terrific means to getting an overview of the history of London. Fabulous tour. Many wonderful opportunities.
a bit boring. we thought it be cool but eventually it got a bit boring yet it still was cool seeing all those old graves inside .
Great visit. The abbey is really interesting - we had no idea who had been laid to rest there...lots to see and we would really recommend a visit

What is with the no pictures. This of course is a must see.. I have been many times, dating back to when entry was free. My whinge is not with the 20 pound entry fee but with the absurd obsession of the docents and staff who seem to spend most of their time in this place of reverence shouting at people enforcing the "no picture" rule. I understand the no selfie stick rule common in museums, I understand the no-flash rule. but no pictures at all why? there is probably not a single artifact in the Abbey that is not findable on the web so copyright is not an issue, and no flash imagery wont damage anything so whats the problem? My pictures are generally personal, moments of memory or experience which cannot be found in stock photography. We visited a day or two after memorial day, I was lectured aggressively by a grey cassocked employee when I tried to take a picture of two quite venerable ladies holding hands and looking down at the poppy adorned memorial to the unknown soldier and sharing some ancient memory. Later a white haired docent became quite histrionic when she caught me reading! my iPhone as I uncovered the background of the relatively new stained glass window in Poets Corner. She thought I was taking pictures. My final dressing down came in QE 1's mausoleum when I tried to document the lack of hands on the little metal statues that are mounted on fence around her place of rest. I asked a couple of the docents.. the best they could come up with is that the "dean forbids it". It really is silly though, in the current world taking pictures is part of life and of the social world in which we live, leave the signs up just please stop screaming at people just because they want to document some personal moment in a placed steeped in history

Beautiful Building, rip off entrance fee. Being of the age when I can remember visiting most of London's landmarks for free I am appalled how so many of them charge £17+ prohibiting many of us who visited the Abbey on Armistice Day 2015 to pray inside after walking around the magnificent display of poppies outside.

A truely historic and memorable venue visit. The Westminster Abbey is a church built over the graves of famous people such as Sir Issac Newton and also had memorial plaques in ground for others. During tour, a minister offered prayer for the current humanitarian disaster which was very touching. It felt like it was really worth visiting.

Fantastic. Great place, worth more than the price of admission. Plus has Jeremy Irons doing audio tour (recommend very much) - slightly surreal experience of having a tour narrated by Scar. Beautiful building and many great names buried there. Two queues. One for advanced ticket holders and one for cash payers, Go in the cash line. Moves way quicker and not that much of a difference.
Historical church. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful church with plenty of atmosphere. It's so peaceful you could stay there all day. Definitely worth going to

No photos. Sadly you cannot take any photos inside, but it was well worth the trip anyway. I'll have many memories of this place. It was so grand and for me out a lot into perspective of how things were conducted in the day and it's connection to the Tower of London and the kings and queens of the past and present. Very stunning!

worth queuing for. When my daughter and I visited London this was on my wish list and I'm so glad I was able to go in and have a look round. The architecture is magnificent. You get audio phones to listen to the history of the abbey. It is truly beautiful and worth a visit

Tourist Trap. A little over-hyped if you ask me, relying too much on being a tourist attraction and not enough as a religious institution. Poor visitor experience all-round even down to the Café serving less than average tea.

Great Gothic Church.. This church is significant for coronations and a burial site for many famous people. Another must see in London and situated close to many other attractions including the adjacent St Margaret's Church. This is a big part of English history.
amazing abbey. this is a must do attraction. the amount of history in this abbey is unbelievable. the architecture is amazing as well. it is worth waiting in the ques.

1000 years of History. What else to say than here you could visit 1000 years of history? Explore this increddible Abbey and walk along the tombs of several Kings and Queens or Statemen, every Epitaph leads you into the past of this Church where Ceremonies took place to install the Monarch or lead them to funeral.

A wonderful place to visit. This a very special and historic place to visit. There is a great sense of British history in every corner and private chapels. Poets corner is particularly wonderful and the ancient coronation chair is a poignant sight.You must go and spend time here as it is one of the most historic and inspiring sites in London. Marvellous !!!

Must see!. The Abbey is closed to visitors on Sunday so we decided to attend the 11:15 Sung Eucharist service. I don't feel it appropriate to comment on a church service other than to say that the setting was awe-inspiring. If you want to visit but Sunday is your only day to do so, attend one of the many services. Be sure to dig deep when the plate is passed as you are saving the cost of admission the rest of the week

Take Time. This wonderful building is all about Time . Buy a booklet ; take a tour ; stop for tea and cake ; go round again ... alone . Let your imagination run wild ! Give yourself a good few hours . ( yes : there are toilets ) You won't realise how long you've been there imagining other times , other periods in history , other lives . Expensive , but SO well worth it .

History, Art and Theology Lovers Must See. Westminster Abbey has a rich history. Many kings and queens were coronated here and many are buried here. It's a gorgeous, gorgeous church. We didn't buy tickets in advance. The line moves pretty quickly, it's very affordable and it comes with a free audio tour. Highly recommend.
Stunning. Your trip would not be complete without a visit to the cafe tucked at the back. Special offers for breakfast, afternoon teas and Sunday lunch is a must. The belly of pork is to die for.

A Visit to the Abbey. This is a must see for any tourist visiting London - there is so much history and beautiful architecture! The tour (audio assisted) is well laid out and very informative! Wish we could have spent another hour or so exploring!

Amazing . This is an amazing piece of history spanning centuries of our history. It's interactive, and the staff along the way are very helpful. You're able to see a great deal in the abbey, and even experience services

Actually here, in April 2014. Oh my goodness! We took our first "selfie" in front of this gorgeous place. Make it your first stop or second.
FYI: There is an park bathroom right across the street. Mind you,, it is a pay to enter only facility. Get and keep change-- you will not regret it.🚽🚻💱💲💲💲

Amazing cathedral. Once again I found another cathedral to visit. I just love it! This one just oozes history, with beautiful architechure. History is all around, and you can see everyone from Elizabeth I to Shakespeare and more.

Do not miss. London has so much to offer visitors that it is impossible to get to see everything in a short time span, but Westminster Abbey is one of those must see places. We had the advantage of a fast track pass for admission, but even so the lineup was not all that long. Once inside this magnificent buildings, one is awe struck by the surroundings, the history, the traditions of this iconic church. Headsets are provided and they offer everyone a guided tour in a language of choice, giving intimate details about this ancient abbey,
Spooky. Grand construction, amazing architecture but I couldn't get rid of the feeling that I am surrounder with tombs. I had a feeling that someone is watching me all the time.
At least once!. Westminster Abbey, a place you must go to at least once! The audio tour was excellent, very informative and easy to handle. Thank you for having an actor recording the information.

Amazing History. Make sure you have enough time to go through this remarkable Abbey. At one point in the journey I looked down and at my feet was a memorial to the remarkable HOWARD WALTER FLOREY- born in my home town of Adelaide. It is nearly impossible to take in the full impact of the history of this place [like many monuments and significant buildings around the world], of the historical events that have taken place within their walls. Take some time and have a good look around. While it is a good experience for kids, I suggest that you would need more time than kids would be capable of giving.

Awe inspriring and peacefull. When you visit Westminster Abbey you can't help but feel God's presence here and the history that surrounds it and my most favorite part was that Prince William & Princess Kare were married here!
