Palace of Westminster..!!. the center of London..do NOT MISS seeing this amazing place…home to some of the best travel pictures in everyones trip portfolio.. and everywhere around it is a amazing angle to shoot…Id highly recommend just sitting across from the Palace on the opposite side of the Thames river and have lunch and just soak it in..AMAZING place… and if you have a day… walk down the opposite side to the London bridge… theres a great trail going right along the Thames river leading there… an AMAZING walk.. takes awhile and much to see.. and some great pubs along the way...

Worth the money!. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to the Abbey. The tombs of British Kings and Queens are everywhere and there is so much history to experience as you walk up the aisles. The audio guide was informative and I learned a lot in my 3 hours of exploring. I would highly recommend the Abbey for a visit.

Finally made it!!. On my 4th trip to London I finally made it to Westmister Abbey. The experience was so neat. I was walking the same steps, Henry, Elizabeth, Edward and great Monarchs had in the past. I could imaging Elizabeth Woodville and her children huddled waiting to learn their fate as English history would be forever changed.

Poor Rating b/c of Customer Service, not the Abbey Itself. I had purchased tickets ahead of my trip, at $30 per ticket. The day I requested tickets for stated that the Abbey would be closing at 2:30pm for a special event. Upon arriving at the Abbey at 12pm on the day of my tickets, we were told the Abbey was closed. Unable to reschedule my visit, I contacted the Abbey upon my return to request a refund, only to be denied. Additionally, they insisted that the website stated a 12pm closing. This in fact was NOT the case when I booked. As a frequent traveler, I am very careful when booking anything and this is one important detail I would NOT have overlooked. Additionally, when I pressed the representative to please reconsider providing a refund, I was ignored completely. It' s a shame that this is the experience that will stick with me whenever I think of Westminster Abbey. I am sure the inside is lovely and well worth the visit, but sadly I will never know and can say that their customer service is lacking!!!!!

History on Review. Before going, check the website to ensure you don't run into the Battle of Agincourt commemoration or such, and have to reschedule your day. They have certain hours which may be restrictive to your schedule. Take the tour w/ the Audio Guide in hand and be prepared to be amazed and overwhelmed. English history and its players are all here. What an amazing church as well as museum. Go early when they open, and avoid standing in line outside; take care of your restroom needs before arriving as there is renovation of the loo now; be prepared to learn alot of history and culture. One of London's best!!

A fab historical trip. If you know of British history and want to experience the reality of it, then West Minister Abbey should be your choice. It marvels with so much history of the British monarchs and other prominent individuals such as Charles Darwin etc. Upon arrival in to the Abbey we sat down to experience the splendour of the Abbey only to realise a priest was taking a number of people on tour. We tagged along, listened to the history and were even allowed in to areas the public couldn’t go in to. Had a fantastic day. If you like history then £20 isn’t a steep price to pay, you’ll remember your trip for the rest of your life.
Phenomenal, Must See, Take Time.. This was incredible, this was one of the most enjoyed of all the historic attractions. Just amazing, this is truly a MUST SEE, MUST Experience.

Marvellous. We have seen this from the outside three times and it is always impressive>Seems to attract Americans in particular.We have only been able to go in once and marvel at the beauty because once it had filming going on and on another occasion it was a closed service.

Truly beautiful. It's absolutely beautiful and a real treat to visit if you love the arts as there are many famous names inside this beautiful building. A beautiful dedication to William Shakespeare interestingly with the Bronte Sisters nearby. So much beauty and the audio guide is great as well. A shame photos are not allowed but well worth the admission price.
Abbey of Greats. The Abbey is immense, despite the crowds it is still a great Church and a memorial to the famous politicians, musicians, poets, painters, writers and giants of the Armed Services

A Step Back into British History. Although the entrance fee is pretty steep, its worth it to see this venerable old cathedral, the coronation site and burial place of innumerable British monarchs. A great many of Britain's finest statesmen, scientists, poets, and other luminaries are entombed here too, including the agnostic Charles Darwin! My only complaint is that you are not allowed to take photographs inside. There doesn't seem to be any good reason for this rule (as far as I can see) except that visitors are probably more apt to buy a picture book or post cards in the gift shop as a result!
My teenager daughters favorite in London. This was a family favorite but especially my two teen daughters loved. Full of history its just simply beautiful.

Evensong. We decided to go to Evensong and it was so worth it. Get in line early and you may be able to sit with the choir. The music was amazing and the service lovely. We toured the Abbey on another day and that was interesting but the Evensong was the best experience.

A beautiful and historic place, but too expensive. By US standards the price was was brutal. 15%nSenior Discount £17GBP, about $29 US. Other than that, we enjoyed visiting this grand & beautiful church & monastery. It pales in comparison, however, to St Peters in Rome, or El Duomo in Florence, which are free. In fact, I objected to the cost of all the historical sites in London. (The Tower-£24.5GBP-$40US for example.). Only the British seem to soak the tourist. Washington DC, on the other hand, shares all our treasures at no cost.

A great immersion of culture.. Westminster Abbey was one of the best highlights of my trip to London. Granted it took an hour and a half to get in, but my was it worth it. The building itself is beautiful and bold so architecture gurus are sure to be happy. Inside are a huge collection of historical artifacts and stories and they provide an audio guide for those independent people. The audio tour is a bit lengthy and a little sporadic and it can get cramped between some of the artifacts and blocked-off areas when busy. Would recommend for people with a respect and love of history, and not for any people who have short attention spans.
Must See.. One of the Grandeur of London to see in person. Feel the rich english history. Trip to London aint complete without yourself in a photo with Westminster Abbey

A must see. Stating the obvious here, Westminster Abbey must be at the top of your list for historical sites in London. Get there early - opening is at 10.00am if I remember and plan to spend several hours+.
A last minute addition to our trip.. We had some time left the last day of our trip so we went to Westminster Abbey. Not a well organized tour. We didn't know there were so many tombs in it.

An amazing place.. I found Westminster Abbey to be an amazing place to visit. I learnt a lot but I didn't feel like I was being bombarded. All the staff were lovely, the audio tour is fantastic and the experience was one I'll never forget.
Excellent visit. Excellent visit. Good audio presentation. Wish I knew more about history. Well worth a visit. Lots to see.
Bucket list!. I had goosebumps when visiting here. Over 900 years of history. Tombs of many kings, authors and celebrities. Worth the wait.

Very good. Went mid afternoon so missed the worst of the crowds and queued for 15 mins only. It is a walk through British history and a who's who of the great and the good. It is of course a place of worship and to be respected for that. Definitely worth a visit, particularly on the 2 for 1 offers.

BigBen! London Big Bus! London Taxi! . Not the first time visited this place but each and every time when I travel to UK, I will pay a visit at Westminster Abbey. Each and everytime will be amazed and inspired by the scenic view and the breeze by the river. Please spend more time here, relax yourself and enjoy the view of London =)

Full of history and amazing architecture. I finally experienced Westminster, enjoying an evening of evensong with the the wonderful sounds of the organ and angelic voices of the choristers. It is an experience one should have when visiting London. You can normally attend evensong at 6 pm during the week and I have no doubt it will be a real treat during the Christmas season.
London must see. Everyone must go here when in London. We were lucky enough to attend a service there which was a treat. Rent the headset as it is well worth the money

nice place. Even though I wished we spent more time but I had not had chance, It is nice but I think I cannot any useful information here. Probably I started as the Abbey Road-You know Beatles, then ı had to stop,sorry

Perhaps the most historic site in London. Westminster Abbey is the one place I *ALWAYS* visit when in London -- and I always find something new to marvel at. I believe every monarch (except two) was crowned here since the Abbey opened. To wander around and see the people laid to rest here ... from Chaucer to Charles Darwin, Oliver Cromwell to Sir Laurence Olivier. The art here (meaning the sculptures on top the crypts) are incredible -- beautiful, strange, and moving.Even if you have only half a day in London, to me this is the one place that can't be missed.

Lots of History. So Much to see and learn, advisably you need to schedule at least 3 hours if you want to just glide through the abbey, I learned a lot of history about UK, was well worth it with an London Pass
A must see. Absolutely amazing. Definitely worth to queue. We stood in a silent wonder under monumental ceilings and felt whole history and man craft.

Historic. I have been here several times in the past and its always interesting, historic and very moving. My only disappointment is that I checked online before my visit as I had always wanted to go to St. Margaret's Church next door was told that it was open so went around the Abbey first only to then be told that St. Margaret's Church was shut due to a service. What is the point of going online to check if the information is not then given. I don't think I will ever get into that church as every time I have been its been shut for one reason or another.

A large burial ground. Well laid out audio tour of the cathedral. So many tombs and crypts and many in latin. It is not designed for seeing the alter by a large number of people, so that was an interesting concept and design.

Absolutely exquisite. When you visit, it is easy to see why Westminster Abbey is so iconic. Every piece of statuary, and each window, and every stone that makes up this magnificent building is priceless. It is so amazing to see how the wearing of the stones evidence the thousands of others who, down the centuries, have walked the aisles of the abbey and marvelled at its glory. The Lady Chapel of Henry VII is particularly amazing. The environment is serene, majestic and holy. The fact that the British government does not support the abbey astounds me, and I was quite happy to pay for entry to help maintain this magnificent architectural masterpiece.

Very poor value for money!. When we were there the Abbey was under serious reconstruction and the prices for a family were exorbitant. We queued for 40 minutes and inside it was very disappointing .I would not recommend this to any tourists , just take nice shots of the architecture from outside and save yourself a fortune!

Beautiful. It is a beautiful attraction, but it's also very interesting to hear and touch the history behind everything. I would have like to been able to spend a bit more time exploring it! It's impossible to see everything in a couple of hours.

Absolutely stunning. . Having visited Notre Dame a couple years ago I thought I had seen the most beautiful church ever. Well I was wrong. This place is breathtaking and the history that goes along with it is remarkable. We did the self guided radio tour which was £20 per person. Kind of expensive, but well worth it.
National Treasure.. If you are of English extraction or love English history. This is the place to have all those names from the past come together in one place.

Incredible tour if you like history!. Don't miss the chance to see and feel an amazing part of the U.K. History and also a world wide history. Don't forget the audio guide and enjoy the tour. Kings, queens, princess, writers, philosophers, all of them having their history buried in that place. Even being full of tombs and mausoleum, the energy is amazing.

Do not miss their beautiful piece of history!. A definite must visit! Like so many places it is filled with history and it is hard to take it all in so plan to take your time. Once you get to the end, it is not possible to circle back to revisit things so it is important to do that as you go along. We had intended to visit in the morning but found incredibly long line ups of tour groups so went back in the afternoon and the line ups were much smaller!
Always an interesting experience. Toured Westminster Abbey again after a break of several years. Very interesting way of learning some of the history of Great Britain.
fascinating. Wait to get in but worth it. Second time coming here and I would go again. Poets corner is my fav part, as so many of the literary people I admire are buried there.

iconic and historic, if rather pricey!. My first visit to the interior of this iconic building even though I have spent most of my life living near London. At £20 a head (some concessions available) it is not a cheap activity but the price does include an audio guide, narrated, if I am not mistaken, by Jeremy Irons! This was interesting and informative. You can see the fabulous interior, of course, plus a number of monarchs' tombs, the coronation chair, and many plaques and memorials, including in the famous Poets' Corner.There is a gift shop and coffee shop (with waiter service so they add a service charge, watch out for that) and you can also view the cloisters, gardens and a little museum. I imagine it's fairly grim in the summer when it's really busy but, out of season, it was quiet and you could get some impression of it as a working church.Definitely worth a visit but, at the price, probably a one-off for most, so make the most of it!

Crowds make exploring this place tedious!. Beautiful architecture that I could have spent hours marvelling at. However, it was too crowded to make me want to explore this place more. Hence, I didn't bother to pay to enter the main cathedral as there were huge groups of tourists everywhere and a line to get in. Went to one of the side chapels that's free, and it was an interesting historical sight. A must-see, but be prepared to battle the noisy crowds!

No question, this is one of the key places when in London. The line today was non-existant, we got there at 10am and walked right up to pay and were rather shocked by how few people were around. The history is outstanding and the audio guide is well worth the trouble...it comes with admission so it's a no-brainer IMHO.I always like the Chapter House and this time the small cloister was open along with the gardens in the back, most people miss them as they just follow the cloister around to the coronation chair and the shop, but if they are open, after you exit the Chapter house and go left around the cloister, at the first corner you will be able to go strait past the museum and around another corner to the left. These were the highlights of our visit, so nice. Also, keep an eye out for the resident cat in the garden!
More Museum than Church . A must see on any London Trip. A headset is included in the price of admission. Many famous graves and memorial plaques. Darwin and Newton lay feet apart.

Magnificantly historical. No visit to London would be complete with a visit to the Westminister esp if you are a fan of Tudor history. Here you will find the tombs of Queen Elizabeth 1 and Queen Mary (her sister). This is the place where the Kings and Queens are crowned- (look for the Stone of Scone). One of the most touching things about the place is the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Go just go!
Nice architecture. Great architecture to visit. Be blown away by the majestic feel and it is a great attraction in London worth a visit.

Stunning and soaked in history. First time visiting the abbey and must say was absolutely fascinating.Stunning building and so much history, its almost impossible to take it all in. Every name inscribed you see is a well recognised name with an interesting story. As an atheist I didn't pay too much attention to the religious aspect of the building so can't comment from that perspective, but from an historical perspective you must visit if you hold any interest in history.The price of entry was £20 each, but for the opportunity to see what you do, its worth every single penny.We arrived at 0935, 5 minutes after doors opened and the queue was already 100 people plus, luckily booked tickets online so avoided the queue and was still fairly quiet inside. By the time we left several hours later the queue was half way around Parliament Square.All in all, forget the price, for what you see its totally irrelevant. Get there early and book tickets in advance.A must see.

Famous Icon of London not to be missed. It was really beautiful and majestic when you really get to see the interior of the Westminster Abbey. I was captivated by the architecture and you will be busy spotting the tomb of well renowned British personalities, like Charles Dickens or Issac Newton. Unfortunate that we are not allowed to take photos in the Abbey. I came with the London Pass to skip the queue. Can be crowded but otherwise it was an enjoyable experience. The audio guide is free and gave interesting anecdotes on the lives of the remarkable personalities buried there. There are plenty of seats to gawk at this beautiful building. You would not have been to London if you do not visit the Abbey!
Fantastic. This is my third visit to Westminster Abbey and my most wonderful because Itook a guided tour and learn so much of the history the minster, the city and the nation!!

Go to a service to avoid entry charge. I personally don't think you should have to pay to visit a church, which is why I always visit during one of the many services. The only problem are the wardens and docents, who can be obnoxious to guests who linger about before or after services. They're really rude at times. I realize many of those who show up during services are there to be tourists and not worshippers, but it's still a church and you really never know why someone walks in the great west doors. My tip is to visit the cloisters, which is free and barely visited by the thousands who pay to see the interior of the abbey.

Take time to study about this place BEFORE going there!. Here are my tips and comments about this tour:- the audio guide is very helpful - take some time in advance of your tour to do some research on what you can expect to see here... I think this will make your tour much more enjoyable- before you go, review a list of those who are buried here in case you want to be sure not to skip over someone's grave that you would like to see- I did find David Livingstone's grave on the floor but I almost missed it and I can't recall if the audio guide even mentioned him or not.- we are a family that likes to take our time and read and learn as much as we can on a tour, so if you are the same way then I would allow extra time so you do not feel rushed- we went in the late afternoon and only had a 15 minute wait, but it was on a weekdayI hope this is helpful to you!

Great Experience. it is nice to go to a church that full of history, but go there early as the line not as long.it is a great little church but not only a church, it also had a lot of well know people who buried under the abbey. Kate and William also got married here in the Abbey. behind the Abbey, has a huge garden, little museum and a british oldest door. this place is huge and worth a visit.

Overwhelming collection of history and dead kings. As the spiritual heart of the British Empire, you have to see this place to appreciate the length, breadth and depth of their history. So many monuments, they seem to be piled atop each other. Kings here. Queens there. Dukes, Bishops, poets, scientists all have graves or memorials here. use the audio guide or you'll get lost! Read up on British history so you know who you are looking at.

Beautiful!. Westminster Abbey is a gorgeous building, I was in awe when walking around. Unfortunately, without doing some research beforehand, we turned up on a Sunday when the doors aren't open to view inside. A let down was that the grounds didn't seem to be well kept and there was construction lying around messily. Not sure if this was just a poorly timed visit or if it is like this year round?

Beautiful. Historic. Must-Tour. You've seen it on TV for weddings and funerals...but the scope and prominence of Westminster Abbey must be experienced in person. Do the free audio tour...the information is so interesting. Truly amazing piece of British architecture.

Grand Scale History. What an amazing place. You only see it during royal weddings and such, but it's so much more. Be sure to pick up the free audio guide as it helps you to catch things you probably wouldn't see.

Amazing. Westminster Abbey is difficult to review because words just can't do it justice. The abbey is beautiful. The history contained within it's walls is just amazing. Again, I can't come up with words to do it justice. Just go. You won't regret it.
Beautiful!. Beautiful church with an amazing history and lots of exciting memorials and tombs to look at, would definitely recommend a visit!

This place is huge!. Westminster Abbey just seems to go on forever! It is full of crypts and memorials for famous people and several church altars. Don't forget to look up at the amazing vaulted ceilings

Majestic. early morning is the best time to view Westminster Abbey before all the tourists buses come a calling,just to wander around the Abbey to take in the History is something to behold, do not miss the chance to visit.

Loved it. I visited this beautiful place twice -- once to take a tour, and once to attend a Sunday morning service. Both were incredible!The tour was a bit crowded, which is to be expected during a summer afternoon. I used my London Pass, which allowed me to fast track the entrance. There is an audioguide included with the entry, and it's narrated by Jeremy Irons who is suited perfectly for the job. I wished I could take pictures inside, because the Abbey is filled to the brim with wonderful things I wanted to remember.Sunday morning service was less crowded and absolutely fantastic. By a stroke of luck, my friend and I were ushered to sit directly behind the choir. The hour-long service was almost entirely sung and simply gorgeous.

Impressive. The Abbey was huge and impressive, so many different things to see. One does get a little tired of reading the inscriptions though. Definitely good to use the audio guide that they give you for free at the beginning of the tour, I would have missed out a lot if not for the guide.

Impressive and full of surprises. You think you know something about English history from school, then you visit this church and realize how little you know. The age of many of the memorials and chapels inside leave you in awe. It's a beautiful church and it goes on and on. Make sure you get the audio guide or use their app to get all the information on the chapels and memorials you are looking at. Well worth the wait in the line outside.

Great Experience. We were lucky to get tickets to attend the service commemorating the 600th Anniversary of the Battle of Agincourt.It was a great experience to be able to actually attend a services, rather than just being a tourist looking around. The choir and the organ music was great, and coming out of the Abbey to the sound of the bells ringing out was memorable.
Interesting place but expensive. A fascinating place to visit but it isn't cheap. A true piece of British history though with many famous people buried.
Beautiful. Just as you imagined it to be.The shop is not overpriced and a good place to get souvenirs to bring home.

A wonderful experience. I have visited the Abbey many times as a tourist and the whole building is wonderful, just packed with history and associations. Recently, I went back on a Sunday for Choral Communion. Unlike many other big churches/cathedrals it reserves Sunday entirely for worship and both the building is closed to tourists and also the shop outside. This creates an absolute oasis of serenity minus mobile phones, selfie sticks and all the rigmarole of tourist life. Even when the fabulous boy choristers are on holiday the adult men put up a fine vocal performance the lifts the spirits. Hats off to the Abbey for keeping Sunday special

Beyond words. This was my first tour inside the Abbey and it's well worth the admission. I have been to multiple churches in Europe but the Abbey is stunning. The enormity of the space, the history, the beauty and the meaning is all truly very powerful. We utilized the audio tour guide which was extremely helpful to tour the space and learn the ancient history and see the grandeur. You can move through at your own pace which is good. Don't let the lines to get in scare you, it moves very quickly. A definite if coming to London. I would love to bring my kids back here with me!

Good to do. You really can't not go to Westminster Abbey - but expect crowds as everyone goes!!!! We had a London Pass so skipped the cues. The audio tour was good and we could self pace ourselves. Amazing experience and well pleased I've been - amazing to be where Kings and Queens have been over the centuries.

Historic House of Worship. We decided to visit because it was included on our London Pass. There is a separate queue for pass holders but it a little hard to find at first - once we found the right one though the line moved quickly. As this is a working church, visitors are not allowed to take photos, but to be quite honest it was so busy during our visit, it would have been difficult to get good photos anyway. We enjoyed listening to the audio guide while touring around. There is of course, several gift shops on the grounds so visitors can purchase both religious type goods and London souvenirs. I chose to buy some postcards of my favourite parts of the Abbey and they were not overly expensive.

A beautiful place to spend a couple of hours. I was there just a few minutes before it opened and the line had about 10 people in front of me but moved very quickly. The price includes an audio guide which enhanced the visit. The amount of history that is in this location is astounding and the architecture is beautiful! It's a lovely and peaceful place to escape from the loudness and crowds in London. I highly recommend seeing it.

Beautiful, historic, and a must to see. After watching the royal wedding a few years ago it was wonderful to be able to see in person this stunningly beautiful and historic church. We visited with a private guide and it was great to go with a local who knows the church so well. The architectural and details are a sight to behold, and as a working church it was just lovely to be asked to stop for a moment at 10 am for a prayer -- a regular occurence deserving of respect and courtesy. Take your time here - there are members of the royal family interred here, as well as Britains unmarked grave for the unknown soldier. Great names are memorialized here and some buried here. An interesting tidbit -- the scene in the DaVinci code at the memorial to Sir Isaac Newton was not in fact filmed here (photography is not allowed inside the church) but in the cathedral at Lincolnshire. Walk the cloisters and read the names of those who came before us. It is moving. We caught a climpse of young students of the Westminster Boys Choir, who board and are schooled on the abbey grounds. It was neat to see them in their uniforms and cloaks. If you have questions there are volunteers positioned throughout the abbey, and they like to answer questions so don't be afraid of them.
Another London Must-see. We missed the tour since it ends at 3:30 but returned for evening song services, which was just wonderful.

Absolutely fantastic. Our visit was on a Friday morning ca 10:00hrs. Anything later and queues build up. Entry was £20,00 per adult. You are free to roam at will, an audio guide is provided by Abbey staff. If you know British history you will love Westminster Abbey. I think most foreigners are a trifle overwhelmed and do not realise or appreciate amongst whom they are wandering. Some of the areas can get quite crowded. Allow 2 hours at least for the abbey alone. A very good shop is on site.

Beautiful Church with so much history. First, the audio which comes with the ticket is great and worth using. I fills in all the history and you're walking through the Abbey. The diversity of architecture, build over the centuries, is the best I've seen in Europe. But the history of uses and who is buried there is also marvelous. I arrived 20 minutes before they opened and there were still 100 people in front of me in line. It was our last day, so I didn't have the time, but several people including our tour guide from the day before, said the live tour is great.

A must if you're in London!!. I was pleasantly surprised by the value for money this attraction gives you. I always thought that what you 'saw on TV' with the Royal Family weddings etc. was it....but there is so much more you don't or haven't seen!Take the free audio tour round the building and grounds and you'll not be disappointing....informative, precise and very interesting. The tombs and crypts beyond the alter are fantastic....here lies all the Kings and Queens of England (and Scotland!) and the gentry are also trying to out-style each other with their memorials which make for a marble-tastic experience!!3 hours is needed if you listen to the tour and take your time which makes this great value for money.

Historical big beauty... It is must to visit Westminster Abbey from inside to witness the real magnitude and beauty. It is really wonderful place. Visit to this place is must if you are touring London City. Easily accessible by Public Transport.

Highlight of our trip. Amazing walk through history....with the voice of Jeremy Irons on the auditory guide. Seriously. Who better to talk with such gravitas!All those hours in History class make such much more sense. The artistry, the magnificence, the unbelievable lineage and the grandeur simply boggle the mind.The queue was not long nor the crowd cumbersome, and we we here at half term break so there were a lot of kids. Definitely a must see.

Not just another church!. Wow! The Abbey is really special. The line goes quickly, so don't be discouraged. The ticket price includes a wonderful audio guide which gives enough information, but not so much that you feel overwhelmed. The audio guide takes you by all the important stops. There are also helpful folks around who are eager to give you more information if you'd like.  We were there in the early afternoon of a weekday. We didn't feel rushed or pushed along by crowds.We ate in the crypt cafe. We got there just as the lunch time crowds were subsiding and had a very pleasant meal.
Westminster Abbey . My favorite building in London. So full of history. You can feel the reverence there. Well worth the time and $.

It is Big and it is overwelming!. The 1st time I visited Westminster Abbey we did a long & thorough tour. When we returned to London this year, I just had to see it again. It is free with the London Pass.

Westminster Abbey - London. A must see for any visitor. Allow at least a couple of hours to really enjoy and take in the attraction in detail. Get a guided tour if available on the day so the experience will be even more enjoyable.
Westminster Abbey. This is a must see. The history here is mind blowing. Take your time and don't forget it's a working Church so don't plan on visiting on Sundays! No photos inside permitted.

Beautiful architrecture. Make a booking on the Internet so that you can go to the front of the queue of people. Allow 2 hrs for your visit as there is such a lot to see, too many to mention.
Well worth a visit.
breathtaking. gorgeous! such in important part of royal history, so much in depth knowledge. definitely use the free audio guide!

Westminster Abby. You dont have to be protestantic to love this beautiful church just in the opposide to the Parlament. A true must see, in- and outside just wonderful. but next time i'll take a guided tour... so many quesstions are still open. :)

A real gem. A very well preserved piece of history.
We saw the huge line even at the first morning hours and decided to book online. Then we entered directly gaining at least one hour.
The abbey is magnificient and the free audio guides a nice bonus

English History, in one place. We took the audio guided tour of Westminster Abbey and loved it! This building has little pieces (and buried bodies) of almost all of British history in it! The café was remarkably good. I got the added bonus of arriving in time for an Anglican Church service - as an Episcopalian that was quite a treat!
Breathtaking. Took my wife's breath away seeing all the unique architecture and mosaics. Felt like we were stepping into history.

This is a must see. There was a long queue to get in but it went quickly and was worth the wait. The abbey is an iconic building and easy to get to via public transit. We had lunch in the café. Service was great and the menu had a good variety of choices. Be prepared to spend at least two hours in the abbey. St. Margaret's church and the Jewel Tower are very close by and worth a visit

Awe Inspiring.. This for me was the highlight of our trip to London. I've never experienced the profound sense of history and my connection to it as I did here. Westminster Abbey would be my first stop on any future visit to London and I'd plan to stay the entire day.
Been there, check!. Just another church, one can say. But this church is extrordinary and enormous. Wonderful architecture.

Overwhelming and awe inspiring.. This is a magnificent gothic cathedral even without it's famous inhabitants. The fact that you are paying respects to Chaucer, Newton, Watt, Hayden, all the way up to and including Olivier offers an unparalleled experience. Throw in every king and queen since Edward the Confessor and a few PM's and nobles and the moving "unknown soldier" and you have the epicenter of western culture. My only gripe is that you are not allowed to take photographs. I'm not sure why but it's excruciating not to be able to. This is a unique experience and I'm so glad we chose it in our limited time in London. I'll remember it for the rest of my life.

Way too expensive. The Abbey is a great place to go and there is no doubting that there is a lot of history but the price to get in was eye watering. Huge queues and frosty guards did not help to convince me that I had made the right choice but once inside it is really impressive. Great to see but not worth the money.
Beautiful old place. A must stop for anyone visiting London! Take your time and explore all the nooks and crannies throughout the Abbey.
Beautiful. A must see while in London. A part of British history that must be included to have a full tour of this great city.
Great Service. We are not Catholic but we really enjoyed the Sunday Service. We later came back for the tour. If you love history, this is a must.

Oh, yes, you must. Unless you are illiterate or don't care a whit about history, you gotta go. Yes it's expensive, the lines are long, you can't take pics, and personally I have seen a LOT of churches in my lifetime. But it's gorgeous, hugely moving, full of those who have peopled and contributed at the utmost levels to English/western history, literature and science. Absolutely mind-boggling. Didn't get to certain parts that were closed, but can't imagine that could in any way rival this glorious place.

Westminster abbey visit. Beware the 20 GBP entry fee and long queue, or attend the morning service for 30 mins at 1230 pm and see it all free after the service so you are able to wander after communion service
Great!. Westminster Abbey is beautiful and the history inside it is incredible. I highly recommend to visit this place during your stay in London.
Aw inspiring. Filled with so much history and beauty. We attended a free evensong service. Very beautiful service. I loved watching the little boys sing so earnestly.
Poor show. An absolutely fantastic part of history to see but a bit over priced and some staff were very rood. If the staff were not so arrogant it would have made big difference to our visit.
Very opulant. It's a beautiful place with a lot of history. Good to do some reading up before you go. It has a lot of famous tombs. Give your self about an hour. No photos allowed inside.

First visit & not disappointed. Me & my daughter visited today & it was everything I thought it would be & more. It was a lovely experience if somewhat spoilt by children running around & parents oblivious to their childs behaviour! The guides were brilliant & very informative. The cafe is reasonably priced but some of the staff need to learn to SMILE ! ! A gorgeous day out get there early though to avoid the queues!It was amazing to see our countries past Sovereigns in such fabulous surroundings, will be back again ! !

A magnificent insight into history. Terrific commentary; amazing history. A few areas were difficult to negotiate with entry and exit through the same door and people just milling about. A clear path to follow would make it better.
Very impressing. It's a very beautiful, impressing church. The only problem in my opinion is that if you decide not to take the audio guide there are no explenations anywhere...

Royal Wedding Church. One of most important British Church in history. The place where the latest Royal Wedding ceremony of Prince William and Kate Middleton had been held. It is necessary to know the mass schedule before visit.
Evensong. Beautiful piece of history but the best was the event called Evensong. Held at 5pm throughout the weekdays (check the schedule). 45 minute sermon mostly done in song.
Moving. A place that will bring home many thoughts and feelings to one and all. The history, the sights are something to be enjoyed and felt.

Gorgeous. We waited in line for about 20 minutes to get into the Abbey. Not a big deal, I've seen much worse. Once inside you are handed a talking guide, and it came in pretty handy as it's a self guided tour. The inside of the Abbey is breathtaking, no other way to describe it. The entire tour took about 2 hours and I bet we could have stayed longer, there is so much to see. Well worth a trip and just as beautiful as I imagined it would be.
lunch. we enjoyed the quaint atomosphere, good selection, a bit pricey but all in all a good place to grab a quick bite

Interesting view. The Westminster Abbey is a nice landmark. However its only open for tours at certain hours. We unfortunately missed the tours a few times due to timing. At 20 pounds per person can definitely get expensive depending on how big your family is.
HISTORY. You can't get a better history lesson, do the self guided audio tour. Did I say HISTORY? Oh my, boundless.
Amazing. Just near to Westminster, this is a must see. You need sufficient time at this, photos are not allowed. take help of the audio guide if you wish. I got long ques may be due to weekend.
The abbey. Love the architecture and design, first time i visited the place was surprised to see Newton was burried there.
Westminster Abby. Must place in London. Have visited several times and never tire of it. Tour guide helps you appreciate the history.

Remarkable beauty!. I find this remarkable landmark well maintained. However when I went there was numerous amounts of trash. I don't think there is ever a down time for visitors to see it. Literally thousands of people every hour up till the latest hour.

So much history here.. Don't forget to explore the gardens in the Abbey. Take about 3 hours to thoroughly see everything inside and out.
A wonderful experience!

Very impressed with this site. Well worth a look for churchies. Free entry with the London pass. The audio provided in several languages was really good and helped understand and explain the history in a really organise and well explained manner. One of the best church tours I have done and the different rooms of the church vary considerably in style and use. Spent nearly three hours here and could have spent more. Minimum two hours required.

Greatness.. In gravitas and grace, one enters this edifice to stand in the stoic strength and majesty of the human soul, heart and life embodied through many centuries of history, hewn in stone, and crafted in glass and airy testament in the composition of architecture, prayer, theology and history which is presented to our world as Westminster Abbey. From the beloved Poet's Corner to the graves of Queens Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots, standing in an intimacy across the ages which they were unable to realize in their then historic lives, the Abbey stands as an edifice of prayer and practice, aspiration and life of the human race, and as a sentinel of the pillar the British are for us all. One of the truly great places of our human family and world. The docents are especially excellent.

Real History. Westminster Abbey is one of those places that you have to visit. Beautiful, fascinating and full of memorials to some of the great figures of the arts, sciences, literature, politics .... They give you an audio guide which is really useful, leading you around the main attractions of the abbey
One of those bucket list places. Amazingly beautiful place so steeped in history with helpful guides that answered our questions completely.

Perfect way to spend a morning!. We purchased vouchers for our tickets online in advance through VisitBritian.com, and that made a huge difference in our wait time in the que at the entrance. We were able to use the much shorter "online ticket" line, and it was discounted, and cheaper. We also chose to be here when the Abbey opened so our wait was only about 5 minutes to get in.The Abbey is magnificent; history, Gothic architecture, tombs, crypts, and memorials abound, leading you on a walk of over a thousand years of British history. The various chapels are lovely. Be sure to take advantage of the audio tour provided by the Abbey. It is very well presented, voiced by Jeremy Iron, and the player is very easy to use. It took us about two hours to make our way completely through, and there are two very nice gift shops and a lovely restaurant on the premises (we had breakfast at the restaurant and it was very reasonably priced and really delicious.)

The history here is amazing. Get there early, the line up by 12:00 was very long. We were there by 10 and went straight in. You will spend about 2 hours in there, following along with the audio tour. The only negative is that no pictures were allowed, but it was a fascinating tour. This is a must see.

Simply amazing. I am fairly used to seeing the Abbey on television: royal weddings, funerals etc, but even that did not prepare me for the splendour of it in the flesh. It is a wonderfully ornate place with an eerie spritiuality about it, which genuinely makes one feel that are in a place of God. The names on the plaques, tombs etc around the place are humbling.

So Much History in one place!. Such a beautiful building containing so much history. In addition to house of worship it is the final resting spot of so many Kings and Queens of England. Well worth the visit, but watch your valuables as it's very close quarters at times.
Xxx. Quite sad knowing princess diana was married here and she is not with us anymore I just had to see this building. Its definatly a lovely building a must see

Amazing historical perspective..... Despite visiting London a number of times since, I hadn't been in the Abbey for 36 years, since my first visit to London, so decided to go inside again this visit and refresh my memory, despite the cost!Booking online is the way to go - avoids waiting in long lines and is often a bit cheaper. The accumulation of English history in this 'church' is just stunning, as is the statuary and other decorations within - you could spend hours just wandering from nook to nook reading and absorbing the information on well-known historical figures.Most disappointing to not be able to take photographs inside (even without flash) but I do understand why - the jostling of the incredible crowds for the best viewpoints would be intolerable!Spent some time talking to a visiting minister from the US and she was most informative about current activities in the Abbey and then I watched as she led prayers shortly after.... a most rewarding few hours.Don't forget to visit the small museum and old chapel with the restored frescos out in the cloisters - also very rewarding and you can take pictures out there!

Fantastic. Beautiful grounds and church with much more history to offer than I had originally expected. We all really loved this. The audio was easy to follow with good flow and provided great information. The church was gorgeous and the additional rooms were awesome. At the end of the audio tour you were led to the area where the various artist were interned and that was quite peaceful actually. A great tour - must do.
Go!. I love churches. There are so many graves here. Lord Byron was not buried here because of his terrible reputation. This is a must-see.

Service at Westminster. Instead of paying the entry fee during business hours, I went to a service at Westminster Abbey on a Friday evening, which was free and open to the public. It was wonderful to experience the abbey as a functioning place, not just a tourist attraction. However, it's a must see in London!

A must see!. A beautiful historical landmark that is a must-tour in London even if you're not religious at all. I wish they allowed photography, the inside is so amazing, but I understand why they don't. Take an hour or two to follow along with the audio guide (included with admission) and they even have a decent afternoon tea in the abbey restaurant for afters.

Reminiscing the royal wedding.... Always wanted to go to the Westminster Abbey but it is so expensive to go in, £40 for adult, so decided not to do it.But went to a smaller chapel next to it, St. Margaret where I did sat inside and had a short prayer time.And I stood outside the door where the last royal wedding was held for Prince William and Princess Kate, cannot help remember what a beautiful wedding it was.

Reminiscing the royal wedding.... Always wanted to go to the Westminster Abbey but it is so expensive to go in, £40 for adult, so decided not to do it.But went to a smaller chapel next to it, St. Margaret where I did sat inside and had a short prayer time.And I stood outside the door where the last royal wedding was held for Prince William and Princess Kate, cannot help remember what a beautiful wedding it was.

go for evensong for a good service. We chose to go for evensong as its free (we gave a offering) which gives you the chance to experience the cathedral and a good worship service. The service goes for 40 minutes. You dont get a opportunity to look around (you need to pay to do this during the day) but you can see a lot from your seat. We arrived early and so were able to sit in the choir stalls which was a nice bonus.

Had To Go. I used to go past the abbey most days on my way to and from work and had seen it on the TV several times. I just had to go and see what it was actually like inside. Lots of history the audio guide is good..not bad but overall not as good as I had expecred
Historic London. Any old original London, is worth a visit.The more known, like the Abbey, have extra interests.And all now for free........

Incredible!. Very well maintained. Lots of history inside. The church is loaded with the history of the country. Kings and queens have been coroneted here throughout history. Royal weddings are held here. This church still has services here. A very popular attraction. A must see if visiting London.

Westminster. A must see for anyone visiting London. We had a Private Blue Badge Tour Guide Tim Martin well worth it as his knowledge of The Abby is amazing. So much history we really enjoyed the things we learnt about.

See 1000 years of history. Great attraction to see over 1000 years of English history. Used our London pass for no wait entry. Spent 2 hours with audio tour seeing resting places of historical kings and queens. Disappointed that no photos allowed. But top attraction and don't miss.

Amazing!!. How do you go to London and not see Westminster Abbey! It is quite simply amazing, do take the time to walk around the outside, see as much of this as you can as there is something to see at every turn and angle. They do have hours for tourists, otherwise you can attend service. I missed Sunday (Latin) mass and wish I had been able to experience attending in this magnificent place.

Known for who is buried there. Well worth the price. Comes with an audio guide that Jeremy Irons narrates. See the graves/memorials of Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Handel, Keats, Lewis Carroll and many English kings and queens. See the coronation chair of kings and queens. No photos allowed of this beautiful Abby.
Beyond compare!. While in Great Britain we toured many cathedrals and abbeys, but Westminster is in a class of its own. Huge spaces, amazing history and architecture that will make you feel small.

Interesting. This place is very interesting. You will find Newton burried in there. Also, many other kings and queens tomb inside. The entry is free during Wednesday for daily services, please check their website for more information

Beautiful and awe inspiring. I am not by nature a very religious person, but it is difficult not to feel the power of this place. The architecture is glorious, the massive number of historical figures buried here is astounding. It can get pretty busy, but the audio guide (done by Jeremy Irons) was very good at walking you through the structure and hitting all the high points.

So good it gets a bit crowded. We were glad we had booked in advance as even in October there was a long wait to get in and it was a bit crowded in the tighter areas . An amazing amount to see definitely not to be missed even at the price.
worth the trip. I enjoyed doing the brass rubbings, they came out really well and make a goof souvenir. This is good for a rainy day visit.

Gorgeous but expensive. Such a stunning and breathtaking cathedral, the detail is unbelievable. Hundreds of famous dead kings, queens, etc are buried here and you can see all the tombs. However, it's 20 pounds to get in, which I think is extremly pricey. I'm glad I saw it, but it's one of those things you only need to see once, in my opinion.

Iconic Must. A trip to London wouldn't be complete without a stop at the Abbey. Beautiful architecture with a really well organized audio guide and helpful staff- If you have question they will find the answer. I would recommend getting there early since the line can get long fast.

Can't surpass the history inside. It's worth the wait to go in and see all the history inside. Not only is this the place where most Royals are wed, but there are so many graves of the world's important people--kings, queens, scientists, world leaders---from the 1200s onward. I find something new each time I visit.

A historic and culturally rich burial site. So much history and culture packed into this place! The entry is £20 for adults and it comes with an audio tour device. Each of the stops marked in the Abbey will be explained in detail via the audio device. Here you get so see the burial sites of Issac Newton and Queen Elizabeth I; to name a few of the prominent people. A memorial dedicated to Shakespeare built with such intricacy can also be seen.
it was an architectural marvel!!!. it was very worth to see it, but do buy ticket online for fastest entering, even faster than London pass!!!

Must see. Everyone should see the Abbey. We had to visit several times to find a short line...sometimes they are too long. The admission and audio guide is included w/ London Pass. The chapels are a bit confusing re: the audio description and the map. One unfortunate experience was needing to use a woman's restroom. I was directed to a trailer with portable toilets outside the Abbey. Men and women were all sharing the facility and several men left the doors open. It was disgusting. I later found out there was a washroom right next to the cafe and guard did not tell me about it...instead insisting I go outside. It distracted from my overall experience of seeing the beautiful Abbey. sorry.

one ticked off the bucket list. having had surgery recently, I struggle with standing for any amount of time. A volunteer, kindly helped me to a seat while my husband queued, they were all so helpful. The Abby it self was just perfect. having read about the Tudors , Stewarts and Pantagents for so many years I was blown away to go to their resting places at long last. Although the abbey was busy it was very well organised and every one kept moving. great job, and thanks for all the help and consideration.

Historical must-see but you need a strategy to deal with the crowd. As English churches go, it is majestic but in a gothic, rather than the more beautiful Central European baroque, style. Looks aside, it is a must-visit for the pure history contained within its walls. Trouble is, every other tourist in London also wants to see it, and that will be your greatest challenge. Without professing to know all the options, you seem to have a basic choice of either visiting independently (and relying on the audio guide), or going as part of a tour group. Visiting independently, your initial challenge will be getting in the place and swallowing the fairly high entry fee. The line to get in can be long, like a block long.If you go with a tour group, there is a seperate entrance for groups and you avoid the long line. Choose your tour carefully though, as some charge more than others and the quality of guides varies (any guide really has to know his English history to be credible in such a place so full of history ranging over the centuries).We went with London Walking Tours, which at only £8-10 per person, combined with a small discount on the Abbey's entry fee, is an economical tour with guides qualified under London's Tourism Body. Our guide was excellent, so excellent that when we were inside the Abbey and the guide was giving her spiel on something, some people not on the tour would stop their audioguides and listen to her instead. The tour gives you a little less than 2hrs in the abbey, and you can stay longer after the tour ends if you wish. There is a lot to see in the Abbey and it really was funny seeing the independent visitors wandering around the Abbey like zombies listening to their audio device (no doubt getting value out of it but looking funny in the process). The advantage of a person-type guide is that they focus you into the really significant objects/places/people in the Abbey, giving you historical background on some so that you can understand why they are significant. Of course, you are at the mercy of the guide's competence and diligence, so that's why it's important to choose wisely.IN SUMMARY, it's a real lesson in English history, so try to understand what you are seeing either via a person-type guide or the audio guide. Have a strategy to avoid the long line to get in.

Westminster Abbey. What a fabulous building. So steeped in history. We went for an impromptu afternoon visit. I advise anyone to buy tickets online and avoid queues! It's the same price - £20 per adult and £17 for seniors. We spent about half an hour in the queue which wasn't too long but I wish we'd thought ahead. There are free audio guides, which are a must. We decided to explore under our own steam so we weren't pressured to move on, but we did tag on to some of the tour groups to listen to interesting facts and backgrounds. We spent about 4 hours in the abbey and could have wandered around for longer but it was closing time and a service, which we could have attended, was about to begin. A fabulous visit, well worth it.

Amazing, must-see!. I didn't quite know what to expect here, but it turned out to be one of the best places we visited in London. It's a shame they don't allow photography because it's really gorgeous. Although, that does solve the selfie stick problem. This is one of those rare places where the audio tour is actually interesting -- highly recommended.

A must-see for all visitors. Westminster Abbey is one of the historical checkpoints of any tourist's trip to London. It's just steps from Parliament and Big Ben, and easily accessible by the tube or any other form of public transportation.

The history and beauty is stunning. There is so much history within Westminster Abby and the building itself, you have to experience it yourself. The Kings, Queens, authors and others that are encrypted there, some from the 1200's, is beyond description. The building itself is very beautiful. It is a must see and go early before the crowds hit. If you get tickets ahead of time, entry is faster and easier than buying tickets on site.
History of England is Captured Here. An amazing visit. The history of England is captured within it's walls dating back hundreds of years.

Worth a visit. I had no idea there were so many famous historical figures laid to rest in Westminster Abbey! Very good tour. Kids got a quiz sheet but it was very hard! Kept them occupied as it took a bit of time to wander round each area.

Intricate part of the fabric and history of London. I have visited Westminster Abbey two times. Once on my own time table where I had several hours to really see the Abbey and once on a tour in which I was allotted 1.5 hrs to see all that was there. If you are on a tour and just want to say you have been to the Abbey then, see it on a tour. But if you really was to see this beautiful abbey in detail and remember some of the wonderful history, then you must go on your own and spend some real time here. I brought teenage boys this trip and to be honest, it was a been there-done that type of thing that they checked off on their list. But the abbey is worth the time to really immerse yourself to the vast history, glory and gore of this wonderful building.
Impressive. We only visited on the outside and we allready thought that sight was impressive. Really beautiful building. The neighbourhood is surrounded by beautiful buildings.

A must do. I haven't been to London for sightseeing in over 15 years, but I did this back then and it's just as good today. All the Church's now charge so that is a change for me since they didn't before, but Westminster is well worth it. It's audio guided and is fantastic. It's a must see in London.

Not to be missed!. Visit this historical site and literally be struck in awe. There are simply no words... and nothing else to compare it to. Step back in history and just soak in the atmosphere. One of the absolute "must-do" things on any trip to London!Tip: Be sure to pick up the free audio player to listen to as you go through - that way you can just relax and enjoy the sculptures and architecture while listening instead of having to read the plaques.

Beautiful Westminster Abbey. We visited this beautiful building in September. It is filled with beautiful architectural design, statues, paintings andso nuch history. Walking along with our audio guides, with so much information on times past. So many important Kings ,Queens, royals, poets, authors and many others areburied here.It was so amazing! Time here flew so fast . Definetly would recommend sèeing Westminster Abbey, a quick tip though, buy your tickets on line to skip the queues. We just walked in and saved hours! A beautiful and magestic place, just loved it .

Visit to Westminster Abbey. Visited the beautiful Westminster Abbey and I wasn't disappointed. Its the most amazing, peaceful place. We made sure we got there right on opening time of 9.30am which was a good idea. It gets very busy between 11:30 - 3:00pm. It 's very easy to get to, right near Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament and we took the tube (train) as we found it very easy to navigate around London. Definately a must see attraction if visiting London.

It was closed for refurbishment. All I can suggest for this sight is to call ahead and make sure they are open and available. I am not a fan of paying to enter a church, but I would have been interested in doing so had the Abbey been open. The building looked nice, but it was covered in tarps and scaffolds.

Alive with English history. That this church was begun almost 1000 years ago is almost incredible. Yet to see it and learn about it was also incredible. Greatly enjoyed our visit to this venerable place.

Save money but still enjoy. it is lovely from outside. the wait to get in for a tour was quite long and expensive. While i cannot comment on the tour we did attend Evensong which is done most nights at 5pm. it is free to the public. you can walk in and sit down. lasts about an hour and there are a few prayers and the chorus sings which was AMAZING! if you just want to see the inside and hear some singing this is for you. If you want to take it slow look around and learn a lot then I'd recommend taking the tour. no photos inside anytime FYI
On My Bucket List. This attraction is covered by a London Pass. I've heard about it for years. It is quite impressive. The history and the number of people buried there are unbelievable.

European Church is Not to Be Missed. Westminster Abbey is one of those landmarks you should not pass up. Not only have many royals and famous Brits been here, but it is also a very grand and beautiful church to visit in its own right. I remember seeing famous names on the floor and walls of the Abbey as burial markers. I remember seeing a famous authors name on one of the markers, Yates or Keats I think. It is just awe inspiring to think of those that passed through the doors over the centuries. And many royals were married here as well. You look at the well worn floor and wonder who walked in the very steps beneath your feet.Also when I went near 2000, they did rubbings of the headstones. Don't know if they still do that, but it was interesting.
Wow! Visit when boys choir sings.. One of the best church views in London. Really artistic sculptures and plaques. Boys choir is THE RECOMMENDATION.

Took my breathe away. I was not expecting this Place to be so full of wonder. Words leave one inadequate to describe the beauty of it. There are places of pomp and spaces for shadows..as well, as a working abbey still used today. Go...just go.
Impressive!. Iconic world sight, nice to be in front of such history. Right next to Big Ben and St.James' Park, short walk to Piccadilly Square.

In awe of all those intricate details!!. I went to Westminster Cathedral in July of this year.I had not booked any tickets beforehand. The line to enter seemed long, but I was inside the Abby before I knew it! When I entered the Abby, a gentleman asked me what country I was from, said good morning to me in Dutch, but unfortunately couldn't give me a headset in Dutch.I took the English one, which was fine, the narration was done by Jeremy Irons, who has a great voice!There are so many important and well known people buried here that it is easy to overlook them. When I started my narration it took me through an aisle, where I did see Mr. Darwin's plaque on the wall. Which I would've missed if I hadn't looked up in time.The beauty of the narration is, that you can stop and start it at will and it has extra you can listen to, by punching in a different number.So when I sat down to take it all in, I could continue whenever I wanted to.It was truly breathtaking, amazing tombs, ceilings and woodwork have been carved in the days of old...actually it is too much to take in! I will have to go back there again!As to the admission fee, it might be a steep one, but absolutely well worth it!
Amazing place, amazing history, wonderful choir!. Visit the Abbey mid afternoon and stay on for Evensong. Stunning music and choir in glorious surroundings.

a place for kings. Lovely abbey,which was finished in 1065.Its some decorations looks like the SAINT CHAPELLE de PARIS decorations.Here in 1066 was crowned GUILLAME LE CONQUEUR AS KING of ENGLAND.the fee is 20 pounds.

Well worth it. For those saying it is overpriced it is included in the excellent London Pass which on our recent trip to Lindon saved us a ton of money. We visitd many Churches and Abbeys on our recent trip to Europe and this was probably one of our two favorites. So much history and we thought the staff was helpful.
Outstanding . Attending mass was one of the highlights. If you are a Catholic abd it interests you, try to check on schedules as it is just wonderful. Definitely a must-see.

Historic but overpriced. Visited to take in a little of the huge history of the place. Very interesting and certainly packed with plenty to see, but felt it was overpriced even for London. Also very disappointed that photographs were not allowed - and the policy enforced by plenty of loitering guides ready to pounce at the mere hint of getting a camera out (I wasn't but couldn't even open my bag to get something else out!)

Thoroughly enjoyable!. Upon entering, you are sent around on a logical path and not rushed in any way. Considering how many thousands of tourists wander through, it's amazing how pristine and beautifully kept up it is. Thoroughly enjoyed my time there as I imagined it probably has not changed much in the hundreds of years it has been around.

Highlight of London, most interesting church in English speaking world. Just spent 1 full week in London seeing the sights. This was my only "cant miss" of the tourist attractions. The building is beautiful and the history of the place is almost overwhelming. The audio guide is included with the price of admission and is excellent.

Great peace of history. If you are visiting London defiantly save some time to visit Westminster Abbey. The entrance is around 20 pounds or you can go for free with your London Pass. At the entrance they give you free audio guide which is really helpful. My advice is to plan at least 1:30h-2h for it because there is a lot of things to see.

Beautiful church... Not so beautiful lines..... If you have time to spare on your trip it's worth the visit however if you are limited in time y can walk around the outside at no cost and then hit the gift shop which has some really interesting goodies to bring home... Ones that you won't find elsewhere....

The Abbey is a must do in London. We took in two services while in London. One was the evening service on Sunday and the second was Wednesday night. Both took about 30 minutes and were worth making time for. If you have time, get there before hand to take the tour.

Don't miss the Verger-guided Tour. From other Trip Advisor reviews, I knew we wanted to take advantage of the opportunity for a Verger Tour, and I was not disappointed.The Verger who led our tour was very knowledgeable. I found him entertaining and well-paced. The tours take you into a couple of spaces not accessible if you are not on the tours; also, it was really helpful to have him tell about the coronation ceremonies, and where everyone sat for royal weddings. He explained where the Queen and other dignitaries would sit during services. One interesting note (which applies to Westminster and other churches in England): Coming from the U.S., it was fascinating to see military memorials inside the churches. Separation of church and state is so significant for us, it just surprised me over and over to see this.One other note that impressed me: In every abbey we visited (and we went to several), including Westminster, they stopped every hour or so to welcome visitors and ask for a silence while they said a brief prayer. It reminded us that we were in a house of worship. Very meaningful and centering.I would highly recommend these tours and a visit to Westminster Abbey.

Wonderful history in this building; memorials and graves of so many people who have influenced our history; great music. We attended the evensong service, which featured wonderful singing. Also toured the Abbey. I knew that William the Conquerer was crowned there on Christmas Day in 1066, and this is just one important event that took place in this building.

amazing experience !. We were lucky enough to have Sunday worship here. It was amazing experience. It seems always full of tourists around this church, but make sure to have experience to go inside and sit for a while.
Good to attend Evensong there. One can enter Westminster without fee and enjoy a quiet time there by attending Evensong, which my husband and I did and avoided the crowds of tourists that way.
Beautiful architecture. It´s beautiful. It´s next to Big Ben and Trafalgar Square. Just go. Pay the 18 pounds and enjoy reliving your visit when you see British period movies.

A must see!!. Lots of history inside! So be sure to spend some time touring the cathedral. I took the Verger tour which proved to be a great decision. The verger shared an amazing amount of information and history, along with witty stories from her experience at Prince Williams's wedding! And the best part? I got to go to parts of the cathedral that aren't allowed normally!
Awesome You! Let's Tell the World. Our visit met all of our expectations. It was truly a great day! Well maintained and a pleasant environment.

A must see!. I enjoyed all of my stops in Lobdon, but Wedtminister Abbey is a must see! Don't be turned off by the huge line as they keep it moving. We waited 30 minutes and the line was down the courtyard an wrapped about 1/2 way around the street. The combination of history, religion, art, and architecture makes this a mind blowing attraction. The audio guide and the prescribed flow offsets the problems a crowd will usually cause. If I could only see one attraction in London this is the one. Do not miss it!

London Pass paid off. We were there first thing in the morning, and there was still a huge lineup for tickets. It really paid off to have our London Passes, which allowed us to bypass the long line, and just walk in. From the first moment that I entered the church, I was thrilled with everything that I saw. There is such a rich sense of history everywhere that you walk inside this church. The AV was also very useful and informative. Use the map to keep track of where you are, and which AV section to listen to. We were a little disappointed that you cannot take photos inside, but contented ourselves with seeing and remembering the fascinating contents, from the stained glass windows, the Grave of the Unknown Warrior, the Coronation spot, to the tombs of many famous people.

If you don't mind paying. It has everything you've heard about but at a cost, when C of E is so rich and other national treasures in London (gallery/museums etc) are free it's a surprise to be told to pay to visit the national cathedral
Beautiful!. We thought this was totally worth the money to get in. They do not allow photography which is actually kind of relieving. You'll love just strolling and looking at this beautiful place!

A must see in London!. We loved our visit to the Abbey. The audio guide is narrated by Jeremy Irons and it was very helpful at explaining all the nuances and details we might have overlooked. So much to see. While we were there the choir sang which was an unexpected delight. Absolutely beautiful inside.

A perfect example of history and architecture. I visited the Abbey on a day trip into London it really has the wow factor on entering. Fantastic architecture awe inspiring paintings and statues. Fantastically decorated ceilings well worth a visit a real step into the past when things were built to last

An informative visit. Took us a good two hours to go around the Abbey. Some very interesting history and a good audio guide that we downloaded onto our phones before arrival (you do get free audio guides if you don't want to use your phone). Amazing to see some c13th centuary items there and also impressive architecture.
All English History.... we enjoyed the glorious architecture of the Abbey, and the famous names of the people buried there made my heart beat faster...
Awe Inspring and Historic. A must see when in London. It leaves a lasting impression of English history. Plan plenty of time to see it all. The London Pass gets you through a shorter line
in awe. The most amazing spiritual inspiring location and despite the people peaceful a must see. Take the time to read the tributes of those that carved out history
Beautiful. Although crowded this was a highlight. Beautiful place. With little twists and turns in the rooms. Poets corner is inspiring.

Most Amazing Church Ive seen outside of Italy. This seriously was a surprise to me, having no prior knowledge of the Abbey. It was really the most opulent and amazing church I've seen outside of italy. The memorial plaques and artistry where amazing, its a shame you can't take pictures inside. The outside does no justice to the artistry of the insides.Downside is it is kind of a pricey visit.
Historic. This was an amazing visit, a little surprised by the expense (20#), need to take your time as there are so many interesting aspects to the Abby.

A beautiful landmark..... expensive and wouldn't be my top priority.. I wanted to see Westminster Abbey on my last day in London. I had seen it on TV so many times ...and thought it would be something id cherish. It was expensive, the audio tour was a bit boring and lacked warmth. The british people are so witty and full of great stories- the audio tours dull the experience. If you can - get a tour with a guide - in a group. This may have made my tour more memorable and fun.

Must See. A very lovely abbey to visit, and the self guided tour was very informative. Would recommend that you double check the times as the internet advised it was opened Thurs. mornings, however when we got there a sign was posted that it would not open till the afternoon.

Santuary of over 1000 years history!!. This continually operating church and burial place of the royal monarchy, famous people, poets, and writers and grave of unmarked soldier is worth a visit. Just the fact that it predates many establishments and was established at London's early beginnings denotes a miracle in the making!! Make this a stop in your travels...you will be impressed!!

fantastic abbey but give the shop and cafe a miss.. We were very lucky with our visit to the abbey. Arrived around 2pm weekday and queued for about 5 minutes. Well worth the £20 fee as it goes towards the upkeep and maintenance of this beautiful, historic, timeless building. We found the automated guide to be helpful and interesting, so well worth doing. Also an opportunity to light a candle for your loved ones and write a small prayer for them was special. As others have said the history of this immense place is quite extraordinary and to see all the buriel chambers housing kings and queens from hundreds of years ago was outstanding. The whole experience puts into context that this is not just a place where William and Kate married, they are only the tiniest part of it`s history. Make it a must to see the Lady Chapel, it`s really special.A final word is to say `avoid the tea room at all costs`. It was dreadful, disorganised, rude and unhelpful staff. Serving overpriced, stale cake and luke warm drinks....yuk, in a completely out of sink, modern setting that bore no resemblance to the gothic beauty of Westminster Abbey. Such a shame as they really let the side down. The shop wasn`t anything special either, very touristy and expensive.

Amazing. the whole tour was very moving and amazing at the same time , we had the audio guide to help us explore the abbey which was a great help.The only downside were the toilets which were outside in a portacabin which wasn't very clean , i hope they are not there for long or are upgraded.

Sooo beautiful!. When travelling, I always want to see a couple of holy places, and in London I always go here! And I mean it, every time, since the Abbey is so beautiful, you can feel (and see!) the history havering around the Place. Remember, they also organize fantastic concerts there, I stongly recommend you to have a look at the web-pages if you are lucky enough to be in London at that time - beyond this world, i guarantee

Remember, remember. Visiting Westminster Abbey is like looking into the mirror of one's past . . . one's heritage. So many of the individuals who made lasting contributions to our culture and society are there. We suggest you arrive early to avoid the mid-day/afternoon crowds and return late afternoon for the 5pm service (you can sit in the back and leave early if you need to). To fully appreciate the place, you need to hear people sing in it. Also make time for the museum.

Nice visit, a bit expensive for a church. Westminster Abbey was a nice visit, the line looked quite long but only took about half an hour. The entry price of 20 pounds per person was a bit expensive, considering most churches have free entry. Inside it was beautiful, and the audio guide that was provided was very helpful. We walked through the Abbey and listened to almost all of the audio notes, so we learned quite a bit. Seeing where so many kings and queens of history were wed, inaugurated, and buried, was really interesting, and definitely worth a visit. A final note is that there are no photos allowed inside the Abbey, so leave your camera at home.

Special.. It is lovely to go into an ancient building that has a dark interior. The abbey has been allowed to look it's age and everything from the worn flagstones to the marble monuments, to the high altar, to Poets Corner, has a famous name attached. Royal weddings and State funerals have been held here among its ghosts. It is huge and simply splendid in that quiet, subdued, British way. Not a place for children as there are too many distractions for the adults.

Much more than I expected!. We toured this place expecting it to just be a big old church. We were astounded at the history found inside and how big it really is. The audio tour really brings the history to the forefront and explains so much! Without it we would have missed lots. Give yourself lots of time to visit this place for the first time. We underestimated and rushed through the last half of the tour. We enjoyed so much its worth a do-over during our next trip.
