I See Dead People!. I loved Westminster Abbey. I was particularly struck by the fact that this active house of worship is also a crypt. I knew that many, many people were buried beneath the floor but somehow was not prepared for all the tombs in the midst of where worshippers congregate. That past and present exist so three-dimensionally in the same space. Yet it is not spooky -- at least not during the day. ;-> The funerary art is wonderful to behold as well as the magnificent architecture. The slides in art history class just didn't do it justice. The soaring vaulted ceilings, the panapoly of English history, the faith and dedication it took to build such an edifice at a time when high tech was pretty much a lever and a pulley are truly awe-inspiring. Okay, having said all that: if you aren't doing London Pass or purchasing your tickets ahead of time, pay with a credit card. A docent from the Abbey came down the extremely long line of people waiting to get in to re-direct any one who had pre-purchased tickets and then asked if anyone was paying with a credit card. We did and had virtually no wait to get in. The tour (both the docents moving you through the line and setting you up with the audio guide and the audio guide itself) is so well organized that you can take it all in and appreciate the surroundings in spite of the crowds. And Jeremy Irons' narration made for easy listening. If it is open during your visit, check out the Abbey garden. It is a quiet oasis in an extremely tourist packed part of London. Also be sure to check out the little museum which explains a fair amount about the burial rites of the rich and royal back in the day. If you stand in the right spot when you exit, you should be able to snap a shot with Westminster (Abbey and some spires of the Palace) as well as Saint Margaret's church and Big Ben. We got all sorts of amazing shots with multiple iconic landmarks in them.
The top 3 best and must place to visit in London. It sums up everything about England. The history and atmosphere consumes you. Burial place of some kings & queens and almost 1000 years old.

Beautiful. Wasn't planning to check it out from the inside but ended up here on a rainy day. I'm glad I did. The place is stunning and the amount of history in there can be overwhelming at times. The audio guide is quite helpful and gives you an insight on various spots/graves in the abbey. No photos allowed which I was disappointed with initially but given the amount of tourists it was a good idea since it kept the crowds moving
Very Majestic. Westminster Abbey was worth the admission price. It was great to see the architectural beauty and splendour as well as better understand some of the history.

Amazing experience !. Amazing experience learning about the history of London ! The audio guides are fantastic and very helpful... There were a bit too many people in there but its a tourist attraction so it is expected. Amazing !

Wonderful Westminster. We booked our tickets online and arrived about 11.00 am, after the first crowds had gone through. This made it very quick to get in, no queuing. Absolutely dripping in history. The Cloisters are also lovely and worth walking through.

Spiritual, Beautiful, Not to be missed.... Westminster Abbey!. Put this on the top of your list along with Windsor Castle as a must see! Also... go early as if there is a special event they will stop allowing visitors in as early as 1:30 and if you are in line waiting they will close even if you have been waiting in line. Westminister Abbey will touch your heart with it's history or Royals who have been married there. Who had their funerals held there. To see the names of those buried there. It is a gorgeous building that you will marvel at. The building itself takes your breath away. To think they built it without all the modern equipment we have in today's world is in itself mind blowing! Take your time as you go through Westminster Abbey so you don't miss anything. If you are blessed that day perhaps a choir will be singing in preparation for an upcoming ceremony or service. It is amazing if they are. Truly my favorite attraction in London. So very spiritual. I always light a candle and pray for those I know who are fighting cancer or have needs when visiting any church or cathedral in the UK or Europe or anywhere in the world! It just feels right and good to do so! But somehow lighting a candle and praying in Westminster Abbey just seems so very special.

Impressive inside and out. This is probably the most important church in England, filled with history. It is very beautiful both outside and inside. I visited around 13:00 on a weekday, and there was a long line at the entrance, probably the longest I encountered during my week in London. However, it moved along rather quickly. Entrance wasn't cheap - 20 pounds, but I think it's worth it. An audio guide is included in the price. I found it easy to operate, and the commentary interesting. You're not allowed to take pictures inside, which I thought actually enhanced the experience - you focus more on what you see, rather than finding the perfect "Kodak moment".
Beautiful! London Must See. Very Beautiful Abbey just be cautious and be sure you have time because of the long queue but totally worth it!
Fascinating. It leaves you breathless. Wow. Totally worth the pay. Such a beauty inside, shared with complementary audio guides dictated by Bill Bryson. 10/10

Must see. This is a must see place in London.. Especially since you get to see Big Ben at the same time. You can get a great view from the London Eye. It is also good viewing at night while it is lit up.
Excellent. Brilliant. Great value for money. Glad it wasn't the height of the season as it was very busy but must be hectic in high summer!

Amazing architecture. This is a must see spot. Lines move very quickly. Audio guides are very helpful and easy to follow along in the Abbey but a tour with a guide is best if possible. If you can attend a service it will be the highlight of your trip. A must see when you are in London.

Highlight of London's Medieval architecture. One of England's and the worlds most beautiful Cathedrals. This is where the Kings and Queens of England are crowned and where Kate and William were married .Well worth the money.The best way of experiencing the cathedral is to go to a service which is free. Go to a Sunday service or choral evensong and listen to the boys,singing like angels!

Squeezing in history. There were 2 must see churches on my list for our September trip to London with the family. Time was tight so I asked a bus tour guide which he would recommend out of St Paul's and Westminster Abbey (formerly called St Peter's - from where the saying 'Rob Peter to pay Paul when building St Paul's!). After a long pause he said Westminster but was clearly torn between the 2. Our family was also challenged over this question after visiting both. St Paul's was a wonderful refuge from the Tower of London crowds and rain and offers incredible domes and a whispering wall but Westminster offers amazing history. To view the tombs of kings and queens, poets and writers, explorers and military and naval greats is very humbling. To walk down the nave where Prince William married Catherine was a treat and the arched ceilings are beautiful to behold. Lovers of King Henry VIII will appreciate viewing the tombs of his father, 2 daughters (Elizabeth I lying on top, of course) and courtiers made famous in history fiction and non-fiction books. We visited on a wet day around 11am and although there were no crowds to enter the abbey, the crowds in the church made the visit less private, rushed and crushed. Perhaps try first thing in the morning or listen to the organ play on Sunday afternoon when there is no entry fee. This is a must see for lovers of history, royalty, poets, writers, musicians etc. A tour might be the go, or an audio tour but try to choose a quieter time of day than we did.

Don't miss this. The waiting line moved fairly quickly so don't be put off by a long waiting line. The audio guides are very helpful as you move along at your pace. I have been to London several times but this was my first time here. I regret that I didn't come here sooner - it is a top notch site - the religious ceremony going on while we were there added to the experience. I highly recommend this.

Incredible History and Present. We had bought tickets online before heading to London.Despite a late start to the day (I guess I can blame my wife) we were able to be escorted to front on line with our reservations.We were able to get on the 11:00 verger tour with Benjamin which was one of the best informative and enjoyable tours we have ever taken. This 90 minute tour for an additional 5 pounds should be done by all. It certainly puts 1,000 + years of history into perspective.After the tour we talked with Benjamin and we decided to come back for the 5 o'clock EvenSong mass which was an incredible experience. I would recommend for all and our mass lasted to one hour and twenty minutes and was the true highlight of our week in London!
An Essential Stop. Westminster Abbey is a must-see attraction. Beautiful inside and outside, with so much history. Recommend paying a little extra for the guided tour.

Past and present history comes to life in this spiritual place. We weren't expecting to be so moved but this place was one of the highlights of our trip. So much history and reverence in this monumental place of worship. I wanted to go back right after we left. Great!

Better than I expected. I visited Westminster Abbey on a London Pass, so I got in without futher payment and with fast track entry. I was expecting to be quite interested, but I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. DO NOT miss the free audio guide, it is read by Jeremy Irons and hearing it made being there 1000 times better. There is a nice feel to the place, even for an athiest like myself.

Wonderful. This was much better than I was expecting and the free audio commentary narrated by Jeremy Irons was a treat. The building simply oozes calm and is very beautiful. The huge building easliy absorbs the number of tourists so it feels private inside.One gets the feel of a place of worship not a showplace

If you go anywhere you go here. Brilliant. Rain or shine. So much to see and take in it is possible to miss stuff. Take your time, listen to the guides and see all the historical deathbeds. I loved it

Fantastic Abbey-don't miss!. Fantastic Abbey! Our tour was greatly enhanced by the 90 minute Verger tour. This allowed us entrance into the Shrine, in addition, the Royal Tombs, the Cloisters, Poet's corner, and the Nave. Guide was informative, entertaining, insightful. The size of group is limited, which allowed an intimate tour experience. Wonderful!
a must see. What a beautiful building. A must for anyone visiting London. We was there for a service of thanksgiving, the choir and the acoustics in there was unbelievable.

Beautiful in every aspect. Would just say money well spent. This building and the tour guide on handset just so informative. Just truly remarkable and fabulous building. The Shard of its time if not better.

Westminster Abbey - A British Historic Treasure. This historic attraction is included with a London Pass, which we would highly recommend for any London visitor! For those interested in learning more about the London pass, feel free to ask us, or you can simply check their website out, it is very informative.This was an attraction which we were highly anticipating, it did not disappoint in the slightest. There is so much to see here, allow at least 4 hours if not more for your visit, please do not rush threw it.The Tour – we were pleasantly surprised that because we had the London Pass, we were ‘fast tracked’ for entry into the abbey (perk appreciated because the line-ups here are always very long). This is probably one of 5 most popular visitor attractions in London.To quote many of our British friends “we were gobsmacked’, an expression used to describe beauty and astonishment. After entering the abbey lobby, we were offered as part of the tour an audio guide to inform us as the visitor the details and history of what our eyes were about to witness. As we entered the abbey itself we were indeed ‘gobsmacked’, it took our breath from our lips! The senses are almost ‘overwhelmed’ by the richest of the depth of the history experienced here. The magnificence of the gorgeous stain glass windows, the architecture, the historic efficacies, the tombs, and the rich history of centuries is without a doubt ‘a memory for which can never be forgotten’! Do not miss this opportunity to see this historic place; it was life-changing experience to see this abbey! It would be difficult for even the most gifted poet to put into words the visual treasures of this abbey. Gift Shops – there was a great variety of items in the gift shop for purchase. You can go to the Westminster Abbey Gift Shop online, to compare pricing and selection of items available. We did this before visiting the abbey so we knew in advance what to expect. We found there was no difference from the online pricing to that found with the actual gift shop.

Westminster Abby Everything You Ever Expected. It's soooo big that you can't explain it all. You move from one area to the next and you can quickly be overcome by the enormity of it. Take your time, spend time learning about some English history, and take in the beauty that surrounds you.

Too crowded but totally worth it!. Westminster Abbey is one of the must-see in London, not only for its incredible history but also for the amazing architecture it offers. It's true, there are always (always!) thousands of tourist queuing up to enter, but don't give it up just because of it. What you'll find inside is one of the best example of architecture that will make you wonder why the hell why don't try to emulate it instead of building stuff in "modern" ways? The Lady Chapel in particular is pretty amazing - the ceiling is a masterpiece! Moreover, you'll see and admire some of the most important kings' tombs, last but not least Elizabeth I's one. The symmetry with Mary of Scotland's one give to the place a weird but very fascinating climate. Don't forget to visit the Coronation Chair, and try to think about how many kings and queens in England's history have sat on it - it gives the shivers! The Chapter House is hard to stand thinking of how it was damaged in the Blitz (I'm half German, I really felt ashamed of it) but the glass walls are amazing!Try to see all of it, because it is totally worth it!Also, check out the time for the Evensongs, they'll leave you astounded!

Seeped in grandeur and history!. The entrance fee is around 20 pounds, and the lines can be long. I purchased a London Pass - and Westminster Abbey is one of the 66 attractions you can see using the Pass. There is also a "Fast Track" entrance for Westminster Abbey, so you enter through another door. I also took the advice from Rick Steve's travel guide to go during the lunch hour, when it's not as crowded. I got in pretty quick. By about an hour & 1/2 - it started getting crowded inside. I spent about 2 hours altogether. They hand out audio guides, which are extremely helpful. This allows you to move at your own pace. They do have guided tours, as well. This is a gorgeous place of worship, and so much history is tied to this place. As in many of the places I visited in London, you can not take photos. They do have a gift shop where you can purchase books and postcards, and such. If you enjoy architecture, and history and grandeur - you should definitely visit.

Absolutely beautiful!. Everyone that you have read about (practically) in your English history class is buried here. You will regret that you didn't pay attention a little better. Beautiful cathedral.

Nice to see. Don't know about the inside. What can I say. It's free to walk by. And for free, it's worth seeing. I didn't go inside because I've seen my share of churches. There's other buildings nearby to check out so it's good as part of a walking tour.

Amazing architecture central london. This is a must see when you come to London. Big Ben is right next to it and just walking around it is all you need to appreciate it. I still look at it in wonder every time I pass this building

Average because I did not pay to go inside. I went by Westminster Abbey on my final day in London. After a week of being nickeled and dimed (an American slang of being charged for EVERYTHING), I just walked outside of Westminster and did not pay to go inside. I did go into the gift shop and paid money for a Will and Kate Wedding book. I labeled average as I really didn't experience the inside and I think it's overpriced. I don't know how the landmarks in London expect people to afford their admission fees. Ok, so you don't have to be free like the Smithsonian in US, but you should figure out how to link admission fees across London attractions.

A must see. The line may have looked long but moved quite fast. If you think the outside is impressive you have to see the inside. The phrases amazing, phenomenal, and extraordinary do not even begin to cover it The only negative was photography is not allowed Leave plenty of time even if you just want a quick walk through. Could easily spend most of the day here

Plan in advance. Careful preparation offers the best experience. The Abbey is frequently closed to tourists. Reservations must be made a day in advance. If you have not booked to "fast track" a day ahead, even holding a "London Pass" requires a long queue. "Verger tours" led by Abbey vergers take you to places other cannot go, costs an extra 5 pounds, which can be purchased after entering the Abbey. This tour is highly recommended and offered several times during tourist days. Check in advance for Verger tour times, and be prompt! Otherwise, you will have only an audio guide option. Allow 2-3 hours for a complete visit to the Abbey.Lastly, for a spiritual experience, take advantage of 9:00am prayers in a small side chapel. Praying is free!

Don't miss Westminster. Thugh there is a pretty stiff fee to visit the Abby it is well worth it. The history involved can't be beat and to "see" all of the crypts of the famous writers to scientists is awesome. The alley is spectacularly beautiful and a trip to London is not complete without a tour here.

Incredible. What a treat to see Westminster Abbey! It's a remarkable, historic place, and exceeded our expectations. More is being discovered there, even weeks ago! We arrived in the morning, and were lucky enough to participate in a mass, which was an honor. A beautiful, special place. The Abbey is free with a London Pass.

Absolutely beautiful.. This is an extraordinary church. The tour is self guided and easy to use at your own pace. It will take you about 1 1/2 hours to see it fully. Go early as the lines are long later.

Totally Beautiful!. We arrived at the venue around 3pm, the notice outside said that the last group was let in at 3.30pm. We had to queue outside as we didn't have a ticket. I would advise pre-booking your ticket as I saw people go straight in with a ticket.They did let everyone in the queue in, so the 3.30pm notice isn't completely accurate.The inside of the Abbey is completely awe inspiring. There is so much to see and it is beautiful. Th wait in the rain was well worth it, so was the £20 entry fee.The only thing I was disappointed by was that there was a ban on taking photos.
Amazing.. If u are in London dont miss this place. Full if history and its so beautiful inside. Buy ypur tickets online to avoid the lines.
Peaceful, cosmic and in awe. Westminster Abbey felt so quiet and surreal. Can do nothing more than offer reverence and visit in awe. The history was educational. A must visit.

Travel in Time. Very touristy but a lot of fun! We didn't do the audio tour as we just wanted to take everything in and not be stuck to a phone like device. If we had questions there were plenty of people around to ask and to tell us the background stories. Well worth your time!

Beautiful. Westminster Abbey was so beautiful, really enjoyed going through it, and well worth the wait. We tried to go first thing in the morning, but the line was around the corner already, so if you plan to go when it opens, get there early. I wish photos were allowed on the inside, but a must see either way!
Plan two hours, you cannot take pictures!. You will need to plan at least two hours to go through this audio guided tour. It is totally worth it! They do not allow you to take pictures at all .

Fantastic - a must-see for London. Wow never imagined so much history in one place. The audio guide is comprehensive and you will have a creak in tour neck having to look up so much. Worth taking the stairs, a lot of steps, to the top to admire the panoramic views. Well worth a visit - set aside a few hours to really enjoy it!

Well worth a visit. We went on a wet Monday afternoon so queue wasn't too bad. Once inside there's lots to see and all the information is on the personal audio player you're given when entering. We spent two hours inside but could've stayed longer if we hadn't felt hungry. Folks travelling by train should note there's a 2 for 1 offer on until April.

Abbey tour. While being far from a religious person, I found The Abbey to be a wonderful experience built with magnificent architecture, abounding in history and a feeling of aura. To be able to walk through the many areas and have the audio guide explaining in detail the historical facts about this place was amazing. While the outside looks fantastic, the inside is also quite remarkable. A tour certainly worth doing and well priced.

Magnificent. I really enjoyed this and found it really moving. It is an amazing experience which I will treasure. I must make mention of one of the helpers that pulled us aside at the exit to stop and actually look right down to the end and beyond the alter. A must see place

Worth a Visit. Fantastic peace of history, loved seeing the tombs of the Kings & Queens such as Elizabeth 1 with Mary beneath her.
Poets corner and tomb of unknown soldier.

Most Impressive Place in the World . . . Now With Memorial to C.S. Lewis!. At the time of this review, Westminster Abbey is rated on TripAdvisor as the 23rd best tourist destination in London. It currently ranks well behind The British Museum at #1, the Churchill War Rooms at #5, The Tower of London at #10 and the Bomber Command Memorial at #20 (really?)THIS IS PATENTLY ABSURD!There are countless great sights in London, but none better than Westminster Abbey. In fact, I consider it to be the single most impressive sight I have ever seen anywhere that I have visited--and that was before the C.S. Lewis memorial was placed! (Authors note: I have never been to Jerusalem.) Do not miss this truly astounding destination.

No crowds on Sunday morning!. Here's a novel idea! Why not attend the Sunday morning service in the Abbey. Check on-line for exact times. Mostly tourists attending, but not crowded at all. If you arrive early you might actually be seated with the men's choir in the quire! We were and it was a truly memorable experience to be surrounded by those wonderful singers! Plus we heard an excellent sermon! Westminster Abbey isn't just a museum, it's a working church. We met the sweetest little old lady who attends church every Sunday at the Abbey.

Utterly Fantastic. I absolutely loved touring the Abbey. I didn't expect it to be as stunning, history soaked and amazing as it was. For a place that is a tourist attraction, it still felt very spiritual and holy to me. I'm actually really glad they stop you from using your camera because if you were busy taking pictures you'd really miss out on the essence of this place. I am also very glad they included the audio-guide with the ticket admission, because some places don't. I found the quality of the audio-guide to be very good. It really educated me on some of the meaning of the monuments within the Abbey. It expanded on the little knowledge I knew before visiting, which is extra value for money really. Because it was all so amazing, it is hard to pick a favourite part or highlight. I loved it all!Here's a tip though, I went in the second week of September and got there a bit early at 8.50 (it opens at 9.30) and there was no one there. It was great for me because I had time to get myself a coffee and have a good look around at the building exterior and admire that. So when the time for other visitors came to line up, and the ticket assistants separated us into separate lines, I was one of the first inside. Oh, and if you buy your ticket online from the Abbey website, you get in before the London Pass holders.
Well worth a visit!!. I really enjoyed the architecture and history. We listened to the audio tour. Loved it!! Allow about 2 hours.

Well worth a guided tour visit. We visited Westminster Abbey with a tour group and learnt so much more about this Abbey than if we'd been alone. Crowds of people and no photography allowed inside the actual Abbey. Very interesting and amazing place to visit. Also a gift shop.

Too expensive - Student discount worhtless! - Rude staff. We read on the price board at the entrance that they offer a discount for students. We are students and have an ID card to prove it. The guy at the ticket desk was completely rude and wouldn't accept our picture student IDs because of some strange rule. We had other picture IDs and the pictures were current. Our student IDs worked all over London except this church. And the guy was so incredible rude. We still went in because our friend really wanted to see inside. But we were disappointed by the attraction itself and the way they operate in general. Not the way a church should be IMHO.

Awesome, just plain awesome. We had to stand in a pretty long queue to get inside, but it moved faster than we expected and the wait was very worthwhile. Westminster Abbey is just plain awesome. Being unable to use my camera inside was almost too much to bear. Since there’s just too much to see in one trip, or even two, we’ll be back again the first chance we get.Addendum: Waiting in the admissions queue gave me time to more closely look at and photograph the decades-long exterior cleaning project currently underway. There seemed to be no rhyme or reason for the patchwork pattern of the cleaning. .
History and Landmark. Great pice of worthy history, but leave plenty of time to stand in a very long queue. Also you cannot use your camera inside which is a real letdown.
EVERYONE's buried here!. This is just the coolest place in London...of zillions of cool places. If you're into history, literature, architecture, walking where THEY walked, you must see it.
Must see. one word: love! By far one of my favorite places that I have visited. The building has been well maintained and it is just stunning

Amazing Westminster Abby. OMGAmazingI took a £5 tour and soooo worth it Much better that the do it yourself listen to tourWe got to go into areas that other tourists can't And the guide was great not to much info that you get brain numb Takes 90 minutes but goes very quicklyThe Abby itself was amazing so mind blowing with who has been there and who has been married, buried and had funerals thereCertainly worth a look
Fantastic abbey. A truly must visit attraction when visiting London so much history and things to see try buying tickets ahead to avoid delays in queuing and try go around the abbey gardens if open

A Stunning & Beautiful Place. While at London one must see such a stunning & beautiful place. Artistic carving with colorful window glasses, statues, figures etc are just awesome. Many people with great history are remembered & buried here, but felt uneasy to walk over the buried.
A Must. Amazing architecture. A beautiful abbey. Well worth seeing. Slightly disappointing that no photography was allowed inside.

Plan for crowds. Here's what you need to do to get the most out of your visit. Pick a rainy weekday afternoon when the lines are likely to be the shortest, and call ahead to confirm the times of the guided verger tours. These tours take you where the public is not invited and are usually scheduled for 2 and 2:30. While they cost an extra 5 pounds, they are worth every penny as the vergers are abbey staff and really know their stuff. Their role in managing ceremonies also means that your guide may be one of the royal wedding clips on Youtube, which kids get a kick out of.

Beautiful!. So beautiful, does not disappoint. Extravagant. Better than imaginable. No pics inside though. So much history. Definitely a must see. The though in my mind when inside was "this just might be the most beautiful thing I've ever seen."

So Beautiful. We really enjoyed our trip to the Abbey. It was so very very beautiful and the history was absolutely fascinating. We explored every inch, listened to every recording, and loved every second. The day we visited, the gardens we also open for viewing and they were beautiful as well. I would definitely recommend buying tickets prior to arriving, as it did speed up entering. We also decided to take a small break in the cafe to enjoy some breakfast and were not disappointment with the meals or service, despite being located at a tourist attraction. One should also stop by either of the gift shops as well. We had the best luck finding nice souvenirs here.

Stunning place with so much presence and history. So glad we went into the abbeyWe were blown away with history in one place and the people that are remember and buried in there. I challenge anyone to not get emotion at the grave of the unknown solider and seeing the great doors were we last saw Diana x

A must-see London attraction. Westminster Abbey is one of those things you just have to do while in London. It's not a cheap attraction, but most of them are not. It is included in The London Pass which we had, so we put it on our list of must do places to see. It is very big and filled with history. There are MANY people buried and/or memorialized here. So much that it felt more like a sacred burial ground than active place of worship. The optional audio guides are quite good and don't drag the tour out like those at other places. The audio guides are included with admission and are available in multiple languages. If you are hungry after, check out the café on the grounds. They offer full afternoon tea and a variety of other small plates.
Unique. Incredible. The tombs side is not so delighting but the rich of arquithecture and the work in the cealings are incredible.
Even song. Was ok, went on for a long time. Benefit was getting to see inside the abbey for free. The abbey is stunning!

Simply Awsome. Having lived in London many years ago, I was blase about Westminster Abbey. This visit, I decided to re-visit and was simply "blown away" by the history. Experience it, immerse yourself in it. I can't think of anywhere on the planet, with perhaps the exception of St Peters in Rome, that is so steeped in history

Beautiful music. We did not take a tour here but instead attended an Evensong service and a free organ concert. The Evensong service was outstanding, especially if you like sacred choral music. We really enjoyed attending a service in a church but also realize it is much more to many. We did not want to pay the admission, which you don't have to do if you attend a worship service. However, you are not allowed to tour the church.

Must-see when you are in London. We managed to visit this incredible place during several hours of flight layover. The price was very high in comparison to any other churches in Europe, but it was worth the money. The audio-guides were included into the price, there was a great amount of stories to listen to.
Finaloy got in!. We enjoyed a wonderful morning esperiencing the history of Britain through the statues and burial markers

The most intetesting building in London!!. Very intetesting tour around the abbey with plenty of detail about Edward the Confessor and the other English kings who are buried there. The your was excellent and very good value. Poets Corner was interesting and full of new information to us. If you only visit one place in London then this should be it. Very highly recommended.
Lovely Cathedral. We went for Evensong, which was a lovely experience. The Abbey is gorgeous inside and out, and it was nice to see the monuments to important historical figures.

Wonderful Must See. A necessary stop in any London visit. The tremendous sense of history here is overwhelming. I only wish they permitted photographs. Look for the plaque commemorating Winston Churchill when you enter, it is easy to miss.
Nice. Glad I came. A must visit. The architecture and detail was exquisite. Loved that I got to be where there are coronations and weddings of the royal family!
Nations national church?. What can I say that hasn't been said before, visited as a child but still find it interesting as we are seeing these great people of our country's past
gorgeous place. this is a must see, its gorgeous inside. Ive never seen anything like it. If you can, take the time to go inside and look

Expensive, but worth every penny. The Westminster Abbey is the best London has to offer. Some lanes and a little bit expensive. But worth every single penny! Take the audio tour, but do not rely ONLY in the tour. Enjoy all the monuments. It is the richest place I have ever been on terms of history and art.

Incredible History- Must See!. Come to Westminster Abbey to see centuries of history- from the coronations, tombs of Kings and Queens, burials of numerous famous people, spectacular Gothic architecture, etc.. It's definitely a must- see attraction. My only complaints are the ban on photography and the very steep admission fee. It's unnecessary since most of the major Cathedrals across Europe don't impose this. It wasn't a deal breaker for me, and I did sneak a few photos inside. I enjoyed the audio tour- also be aware that it gets very crowded inside.
Beautiful.... It was a beautiful church, there was a bit of a line to get in, but really cool inside and the history of it all was amazing...Verdict: Check it out for sure...
Amazing site. The church is inspiring and reminded me of notre dame. It is interesting that architecture is so close from place to place. It is definitely a place you must see when in London!

Beautiful and majestic trip into history.. Fascinating place where so many historical figures were laid to rest. The grandeur was fantastic. I truly felt the history and enjoyed this huge monument. Quite overwhelming.

Vist . Just back from a day around London land marks.went to the abbey and spent nearly 3 hours going around well worth the money and audio guide great.but I do wish you could take photographs inside.i know it's a church but went to 2 others today and they were fine about it. Very pleased with the trip and had a lovely time.
Beautiful . I went inside for a mass service. This is a major historical monument for the British faith and many of the great poets, musicians and scientists of the country rest inside. Superb.

Really Enjoyed. Really enjoyed our visit. the audio tour is very good and like the fact they don't allow pictures. No one getting in the way of your view so you can enjoy the grandeur of this building. Beautiful paintings and statuary. A lot to take in so allow a lot of time.

LOVED IT!. I loved Westminster Abbey! So much history! It is more gorgeous than I even imagined. Even if you aren't a history fan, if you have followed any recent royal events (William and Kate's wedding, Diana's funeral) you will recognize this beauty. Tons of memorials and interesting facts. The audio tour was very helpful, informative and easy to use. FYI - You cannot takes pictures inside.

Very Grand and Worth a Visit. Ticket includes a free audio tour which makes it easy to navigate. Takes about 40 - 90 minutes to complete. No photos and videos are allowed which is great, so you can just absorb the greatness of this chapel. It is nice to visit if you have time and is quite interesting. Note it does close quite early around 3.30pm. Easy to get to via the tube.

So much history!!!. Overwhelming. I began my visit attempting to read all the memorials and give them each their due, but quickly realized how enormous the Abbey is and how many memorials there are and had to abandon my original plan and be more selective about which I spent time on. The self guided audio tour had some good information, but I somehow got off track and it was a bit difficult to get back on. Regardless, there was an overwhelming amount of history to try to absorb here. It's all very beautiful, and as an American, the time span covered is so far beyond what we are used to it's amazing. One thing I realized as I was standing in the area where royal weddings have been conducted was that it's a beautiful place, but you are actually surrounded by hundreds if not thousands of dead people, so I'm not sure that's the ideal wedding spot. They are in the walls, in sarcophagi scattered around the entire structure, and underfoot in the floor. Well worth the time and expense to visit though!
Don't miss this if visiting London. The lines were a little long getting in about a 30-40 minute wait, but worth the wait once you get inside. The audio guide is very helpful
Wonderful Building. It was a very lovely building to visit on a rainy day in London. Not a big fan of the cost to enter or not being allowed to take photos.
Don't miss this. No to be missed while visiting London because it is a unique and overwhelming place. 1000 year of history brought together, like nowhere else to be find.
perfect place. impressive. Be careful, pictures are not allowed inside. Maybe you can sneak in some picture or other likeDownside: always crowded.
I fall in love. so beautiful and peaceful place. nice pieces of art statues and paints. it has ticket even I dont agree but is something amzing to see
Don't miss it. This is truly a magnificent place. Both of history and religion. The audio tour, which is part of admission, is excellent. Don't skip this one.

Other minsters offer more, but none can match its historical significance. Well, I confused Westminster Abbey with Westminster in my reviews and so will do a repeat here. Westminster Abbey is most noteworthy for its history and being the final resting place for English Monarchs. It is also where the relatively rare coronation of English kings and queens take place. There are marvelous chambers in the Abbey where you will find the crypt of Queen Elizabeth I (with her sister Mary tellingly buried underneath her) among others. As might be expected there are magnificent stain glass windows, but I was more impressed with the enormous pipe organ and fantastic seating areas for the various choirs (the boys choir apparently has its own school on the premises). Exhibits include the accouterments used for coronation ceremonies. A visit is much more constrained than for other Abbeys such as the ones at Bath or Yorkminster, since you can't take pictures and there is no tower climb, but other than that it is a London must see if you haven't experienced it before.

Superb Verger Tour. Arrived in the afternoon and was very lucky to get tickets for the Verger tour. I know other reviewers take exception to the entrance fee, but it is worth it, and do pay the extra 5 pounds to do the guided tour. Our guide was exceptional at getting us through the crowds to see some special features of the Abbey and was terrific at answering our few questions. I asked why Oliver Cromwell has an engraved stone in the floor, and he relished answering the question and supplied fascinating details. Truly a Must See in London. We used our London Pass.

History at its finest! . A must not miss visit if you are interested in history and historical facts. The final resting place of many of the Kings, Queens and other notable historic figures from the last 1000 years of British History. The iconic setting for Coronations, Funerals, Royal Weddings and of course an everyday place of worship too. It is worth taking the audio guide and spending time listening to the important historical fact given. Of course don't forget to spend time in Poets Corner and stand in awe of the number of famous people either enshrined or commemorated in the Abbey.

Our favourite tourist attraction in London so far. Westminster Abby is beautiful, the history is overwhelming. The entrance line took about 15 minutes, not too bad. Entrance fee is quiet expensive around $62 Australian dollars for one adult and one child...but this did include an audio head set that enabled us to tour the building at our own pace and choose what information we wanted to listen too. It is a very well organised and interesting attraction, expensive for a church visit but worth the money to see such a beautiful old place. You can't take photos inside the church,
Beautiful church!. Beautiful church and a must see if you're a fan of the British royals. Most of the time it's very busy, but worth the wait!
Evensong. In addition to being awed by the architecture of this holy and historic abbey, I was deeply moved by the Evensong performance.

Evening Service. ...beautiful! . Westminster Abbey is magnificent, whether you just walk around outside or enter the building. We attended an Evensong service which was open to all, it IS a fully operational church. The service was very lovely, very regal even.Upon the closing of the service the famous bells peal for a few minutes and the sound is thrilling to say the least!

Not to be missed.. I can’t imagine visiting London and not experiencing Westminster Abbey. Not only is it a magnificent structure, there is a tremendous amount of history there. I recommend taking the audio tour which is included in the admission cost. We went about 3 PM and stayed till closing at 4:30. Went for a quick snack and returned at 5 PM for the evensong service which was lovely. It lasts about 30 minutes and is a service that is sung. What a nice way to sit quietly and absorb the grandeur of this amazing church.

Magnificent. This is truly a very special place of worship and history. The guides were very patient and helpful despite the number large of people marveling the grandeur and many chapels. We had the privilege of attending an Evensong service with Admission of Choristers after all the tourists had left. This is beautiful place where royal weddings and coronations have taken place for centuries.

Westminster Abbey. The abbey was really stunning and you could see all the Latin inscriptions. There was a choirs singing from the Westminster Abbey school and after we looked round you can go to the cafe in which they have great food!!

Where kings come to rest. This is another iconic landmark in London and a must see in my opinion. The cathedral is nicely decorated inside and the audio guide offers helpful insights on the history of this place.I particularly liked the small chapel at the and and the small garden with the perfectly cut grass. As we visited during a sunny day, the contrast of colors was amazing!This attraction was also on the London Pass so it made it a bit easier to go inside.

Magnificent . Westminster Abbey is truly breathtaking. There is so much to explore, and the free audio guides are great. We had to wait in line outside (in the rain) for security and then we were ushered to a separate lane to walk in through since we had the London Passes. There was no wait there and I think regular payments had a short wait. There were so many small chapels and alcoves that I would have loved to explore and enjoy listening to the audio guide. Unfortunately, we had to just get in and out so as to get our 2 year old back to the hotel for a nap. I would love to return to Westminster Abbey, possibly by myself. I believe the regular admission price was £20 or £22, and this is well worth it, especially if you have enough time to really enjoy it. We were there less than one hour, I could easily enjoy spending 2 hours there if it was possible for me.There is also a cafe that serves afternoon tea, but we weren't able to find it. Maybe next time!

Very Crowded. Small queue but still took 20 minutes or so to get in. Audio guides available and reasonably helpful. However, speaking to the individual Abbey guides was superb. Asked one lady about actual burials in the Abbey and she told us who was eligible, and, picking up our Scottish accents, where to find memorials to Mary Queen of Scots. Unfortunately several coach parties were being guided round the small side chapels and the crowds. Not the best value for money. Plus, the toilets are undergoing refurbishment and we were redirected to an outside Portacabin which was disgusting. Expected better from one of Londons top tourist attractions

British History everywhere you look in a beautiful building. History in the stones everywhere you look you see the name of someone who has had an impact on our nation's history. Last came here as a child remembered it as amazing and it is the same as an adult. You see it all the time on TV but it is SO much more impressive when you are there.Even thought it was busy it still had a great atmosphere of peace.The stewards are so helpful. Audio Guide great. Food in the café was the best I have had in an "attraction" for a long time and good value for money.Prebook your ticket online to avoid the queues

Magnificent - Recommended. The majesty of this place must be experienced first hand to be appreciated. History and ceremony is embedded in every crevice and nave. This is as much a lesson in the history and politics of the UK as much as a visit to the church.Warnings though. (1) Get there early. After reading other notes on TA we arrived about 3/4 hour before hand. The queue was already formed. There are 2 queues, one for ticket purchase (moved OK) and the other for pre-paid (moved fast). So (2) the 2nd recommendation is to pre-purchase online and print the ticket. And (3) be careful of pick pockets.The audio tour was excellent, albeit a little hard to align to the locations at the start.Price was reasonable at about GBP 20 each adult.We also had a late breakfast at the cafe downstairs which has (time of publishing) a 2:1 breakfast. Worthwhile and nice.
One of the best Attractions. A must, This is where Lady Di's funeral services were held, Also , So interesting , the many tombs. Plus tomb of unknown soldier, So historic.

Beautiful visit.. Very interesting Westminster Abbey is one of the world’s great churches, with a history stretching back over a thousand years and an essential part of any trip to London.Buy your tickets on line and include other attractions. Don't go on Sunday as it isn't open. Like many religious building there is a dress code Westminster Abbey is a Church and a place of daily worship, so visitors are asked to respect this, and to show sensitivity in the way they are dressed, clothing are modest, and that gentlemen remove their hats while in Church. The staff or Abbey Marshals (in red gowns) and honorary stewards (at Sunday services) are always pleased to help you with any assistance you may require, and answer question we found them pleasant. No photograph or mobile phones are allowed in the Abbey, but you can take photo's in the Cloisters and College Garden which are open on Sundays.Take the audio tour as there is to much to tell you but it is so interesting and a must to visit.

Amazing and Inspiring. Westminster Abbey is everything that we thought it would be. For a combination of sheer beauty and history, it cannot be topped. We were overwhelmed with how many historical names we recognized - with so many floor and wall burial places, we had to remind ourselves to look up at the beautiful windows. Being Americans, we found a couple of interesting surprises. For example, Major John Andre is buried there as an English hero of the conflict in the colonies. On our side of the Atlantic, he was a spy who worked with Benedict Arnold during the American Revolution. We were responsible for putting him in the crypt! It's all in your perspective. When visiting London, don't miss Westminster Abbey.

Absolutely beautiful!. I've seen the Abbey on tv before, but nothing compares to experiencing it in person. There's just something about being in a place where people have been worshipping God for hundreds and hundreds of years.

Brilliant Building - Jaw Dropping. I'm not really one for history but this visit took my breath away. There are no cameras allowed in the Abbey so make sure you memorise it all! The building is very elegant and reminded me a lot of the Vatican City. The audio guide given to you at the start is a fantastic aid and tells you a great deal as you walk around. There are frequent prayers and services as you walk and you really feel like a part of the history.

Another Must See. Whether you are interested in churches or history or not - Westminster Abbey cannot fail to impress. If you have the time take a guided tour (head phones or with a guide) it's always more rewarding to have more information on what you are looking at.

Absolute MUST SEE!. My absolute favorite part of London. So much history here!! The audio guide tour is very informative and does a splendid job of taking you through the abbey. The abbey itself is absolutely stunning. I could spend hours here wandering through all the chapels and cloisters. We bought out tickets ahead of time online and it certainly saved us a lot of time not having to wait in the line at the door for tickets.

An interesting place of history. An incredible monument to history. The Abbey is more of a crypt with so many historical persons interred here. Well worth the visit although a bit expensive and the queue for tickets can be very long so get there early.

Very touristy. Booking on line will save you 30 minutes of queues. But is it worth it, the interior is so crowded it lacks that sense of austerity that you get in the European cathedrals. Going up into the dome also gives you access to the exterior and an excellent view of London.

Must See History. Westminster Abbey is must see history, as well as must see architecture style. There are few buildings I go into and am in awe, but this is one of them.This is a museum so it takes awhile to see everything.

Historically Fantastic. We'd travelled from our home in Spain for a sightseeing holiday in London. We'd been looking forward to revisiting the Abbey for the first time in 30+ years .After queing for a short while we reached the entrance. My wife is waiting for a knee operation and the problem had suddenly got worse over the previous couple of days and she said to the guy at the entrance that she did'nt think she could manage to walk around the Abbey. She was'nt offered the use of a wheelchair and she asked if there was somewhere for her to sit whilst I 'did the Abbey'. She was directed to St Margarets church , which is about 100 metres from the Abbey. When i entered the Abbey the first thing I noticed were a row of chairs before the attendants checked my ticket, but by this time my wife had hobbled her way to St Margarets, also wheelchairs were available..Another big moan is the entry charge of 20 quid ( 17 for students and pensioners ) to visit despite the fact that the Church of England is one of the wealthiest landowners in the Uk .At the time of our visit there were no toilets available ( due to building work ) within the Abbey .This is an absolute joke considering how many people visit every day. Thats the end of the negatives .From a historical and architectural perspective this place is hard to beat, you find yourself immersed in the history of our counrty.

Wonderful church full of history!. A highlight of our trip. So full of history and tombs of famous people! We used the audio guide and were so glad we did. It really enriches the experience. I actually purchased tickets ahead of time but was not needed as there was no line. Plan to spend about two hours minimum as there is so much to see and they did have a concert going on while we were there.
Classic. Westminster Abbey was a beautiful building with a quant park right beside it. The buildings are very gorgeous and worth the trip to go see them.

Expensive. Having spent a day in London and going on a river sight-seeing cruise from Westminster, the Abbey was a obvious choice when we disembarked. It is very beautiful but also very expensive, even taking into account London pricing. The average price for a adult ticket is £20.00 per person and if you want the guided tour, it's an extra £17.00 per person! - to really understand it's history, the tour is really a necessity. Everything is included in the price, including their magnificent gardens, but for me, I had better value at the other attractions we visited. I appreciate that they have no official funding, it's purely visiting tourists that help maintain costs, but as I have already said £37.00 for one person if you include the guided tour was overpriced.

Incredible opportunity to view history in person. Gorgeous.. We used our skip the line pass to avoid the ticket lines. The audio tour was helpful. It was quite crowded, but we were able to see everything with no problem.
Walking over Charles Darwin.. Who would not love wandering around in this place? Beautiful and interesting to walk and stop and sit for a minute, too.

Amazing!. Outstanding visit especially for Americans whose history does not go back this far. Arrived a little before opening time and purchased tickets in advance, so no wait. Definitely becomes more crowded as time passes.

Outstanding, Amazing. Just amazing. Excellent Audioguide. Incredible sculptures throughout, incredible woodwork. Most amazing of all was seeing the actual Abbey in real time that you have only seen on TV. The history, the pomp, the richness of the interior, will leave you in awe. I just wish they would have allowed picture taking, but I can understand why they don't. This is a do not miss.

Breathtaking building.... Pay the entrance fee and prepare to be amazed. I was a bit dismayed with the cost at first but this is a truly amazing building. Take the self guided tour and spend a couple hours just wandering.

One of my Favorite Places. Meet Queen Victoria like you've never known her; see the actual dresses worn by Princess Di, Queen Elizabeth and Princess Anne; hear about the history of this beautiful home. One of my favorite things we did in England

Undergoing construction. Unfortunately it is currently undergoing construction I was not able to take in the exterior in all of its glory. The lines are very long, so heads up. Possibly go early so you can reduce wait times.

Monumental!. I booked on-line the day before, which was supposed to give me priority entry. However, upon showing my ticket to 2 different staff members I was directed to a queue which was for both pre-paid customers and those who had just turned up on the day. So I ended up waiting for 15 minutes. I suppose I can't really complain about 15 minutes. Disappointed that photography is not allowed - surely this wouldn't be a problem provided it's done with I-Pods etc which have no flash. The place is so full of monuments etc that it's overwhelming. Gift shop could do with stocking photos of all tombs so that people can buy mementos of items which interest them - the guide books don't do the place justice.

The Abbey is the Best!. What can one say about Westminster Abbey that has not been said a thousand times before! The history of the place is overwhelming and it is truly an awe-inspiring sight. We go back every time we are in England, and we are never disappointed.
Gorgeous building. Very big and grand. We came here on rememberance day and there were poppy displays everywhere with fallen hero names on little wooden crosses. Really lovely to see. :)

WOW. Words cannot express the beauty,majesty and history of the abbey. Be sure to take a tour as you get to go a couple of places you can't on a self guided tour. Our tour was led by a verger who brought life to the abbey. Your neck gets tired moving from side to side to look at everything. A must do while in London.

Wow. What can I say? The audio guide is great. The history of this place just blew me away .
It is a definite must do. And allow plenty of time to look at everything, including the cloisters and the museum.
Beautiful. As beautiful as expected. Only wish I would have heard the choir. We did have the London Pass so that gave us a "fast pass" inside without waiting in the long line.

The sculptures are surprising. I had no idea of the beauty of the sculptures in the abbey, the detail is stunning. We also appreciated that there is a minute of quiet on the hour for prayer. Very touching.

Worth the wait in the queue. . Amazing place.. Wind was very chilli while waiting in line.. but it was well worth it.. History here is incredible and everything has been beautifully preserved. We loved it.

Centuries of people watching. Have been here a few times now and it never disappoints. So much history in one beautiful building. Will keep going back. Avoid the queues and get a pass. Audio commentary very informative. Go for a stroll across the bridge afterwards to get a better view of the Thames and London. Good sandwich shops down the lanes.

Lovely. Lovely views. Lots to see and very interesting. We took a group of special needs students there as they were performing songsthey had been practising at school. They loved it. The public loved it. The staff were very helpful. If your visiting london do go and visit

Beautiful ~ Must see when visiting London!. Westminster Abbey was one of the attractions I loved visiting the most during our time in London. Photography inside of the church is not allowed. The queue was incredibly long when we arrived shortly after it had opened but fortunately we had purchased the London Pass so we were able to skip the line, pick-up our audio guides and begin our tour. It was overwhelming being surrounded by so much history. Be sure to take your time taking in all the beauty that Westminster Abbey has to offer! They don't make such beautiful tombs / statues anymore and the detailed work is so incredible.

Trip to see the kings n queens of old. Shame they don't allow photography but this place is highly recommended as a must see sight. Seeing the artwork inside along with the tombs of kings n other prominent figures was just humbling. Take a time to sit and view the art work on top of the church as well as visit the Abbey gardens for some peace and tranquility. You just might hear Big Ben chiming while you sit there in silence.

Tea and Crompets anyone?. Awesome architecture, the structure of this building has so much character especially being thousands of years old. The history from Winston Churchill to Mary Queen of Scotland is enough to make you trip here worth it.

Not value for money. It was a rainy Monday afternoon so we thought it would be good to go to Westminster Cathedral. We arrived at 2.30 to be told that the Cathedral would close in one hour and yet the full £20 admission fee would still be payable. Come on Cathedral staff, get real, how much can anyone see in an hour. We had planned to spend the afternoon there, as it was we turned around and went elsewhere.

History & Beauty in one place. This offered so much more than I was expecting! Plan on spending some time and learning and seeing all the royalty and family lines buried here. Enjoy the history of the red carpet alcove where the royals are married and crowned. This place was amazing and note they do not allow inside pictures.

Nice to see. If you have time, go visit this Church. It is unbearably congested with artifacts, EVERYWHERE, so when you enter please take a free audio guide. The place is the burial site for Queen Elizabeth and her half sister Mary Queen of Scots. For me, this was the highlight. No photography is allowed in the chapel, and should take about 2 hours to complete :)

Visit. Well, it's big, has a lot of historic characters buried there (including Black Prince) but it is mostly its arches that draw attention. As in most places, they ask you to take off your hat; funny, only after I visited they asked in the end. It is a bit pricey, though.

Awe Inspiring. It's hard to describe the feeling of awe that comes over you when you visit. Plan ahead because on our trip to London in 2014 it was closed for an event. This year we bought tickets before we left. It's truly awe inspiring. There are so many famous people buried there, among them Queen Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots.

Beautiful building but queue-chaos. Because Webminster Abbey was closed on saturday and sunday we had to visit on monday. We arrived at about 09.25 but the queue was already long (just before the street further on). After standing a long time we heard that we could get in a second queue because we had the London Pass (we were at first directed into the long queue after asking). We still had to wait about 20 minutes before entering. Only 10 people could go in at the time because of the check and scanning the pass. We found the queue very chaotic. Maybe Webminster Abbey could split the queue. The queue starting at the left for everybody without the online-ticket or London Pass and a queue starting at the right for people with the online-ticket of London Pass. The bulding inside was very beautiful and was worth the price. But we wanted to drink something and heard a member of the staff saying that the café was closed. There was no sign with this information.

Meet Sir Isaac Newton and Lewis Carroll (author of Alice in Wonderland) and Coronation Chair here!. To me as a non-religious tourist, it was more of a huge amazing lovely piece of architecture and a cemetery of many of my favorite people such as:Isaac Newton, Dirac, Faraday and Maxwell as well as Charles Dickens, Lewis Carroll and others :-)

Westminster Abbey..Still the King of England Treasures. This was the highlight of my personal trip while in London..To see the resting places of Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots, many of our favorite Poets, the incredible rear altar dedicated to the RAF in WW II was breathtaking. To realize that the project had begun almost a thousand years ago and many kings and queens had walked there as well as Winston Churchill was thrilling.

A must see in London. A must when in London, I fully enjoyed visiting here. Definitely not for little kids, I don't think they would really enjoy it. We had to wait in the rain for a while to get in, but I felt it was worth it. I love the history here, the architecture and all. You can do an audio tour, which I wish we had done. We walked here, everything is very close to Westminster Abbey. You can't miss this when in London, it's a must see. If you have time, you can grab a cup of tea and scone in The Cellarium Cafe and Terrace, it's a must!

Beautiful view. The Westminster Abbey was built in 1958 - a heritage building with character. The environment is quiet and peaceful. You can have a great view of the Fraser Valley. I especially like the colorful dahlia garden.

Beautiful Architecture . The abbey is wonderful to see and hear the history of. How it was rebuilt using stone and who all is buries there. Also on special days you might see some dignitaries. Nice to walk around. Or you can get a tour that goes inside to see all of the artwork. Either way, you won't be disappointed.

Crowded and Expensive. Visited on a particularly wet afternoon which may have resulted in the large number of visitors escaping the weather.You are asked to pay 20GBP entry but get access to a free audio guide device.To be honest I did not get any sense of spirituality or tranquility at all with all the crowds of mainly overseas tourists.The majority of the abbey is basically stone tombs in side chapels and it is not clear why they so expressly forbid photography. I would have found it useful to have photographed a number of the tombs to examine in peace later.If you are looking for a place for quiet contemplation or even a solace from the city DON'T come here - there are many smaller and more peaceful churches in London.The central location and the fame of the Abbey make this a tourist trap which the church authorities milk by charging the high entrance price.They claim you can enter free for worship, but that is the last thing I would like to do at this church as stated above.I have visited other great English cathedrals such as Salisbury and Liverpool and found them to be more pleasurable visits.The Abbey contains the tombs of the great and good (and bad) from centuries of British history, and this is fascinating as it is the only place of its kind, but it is difficult to appreciate or even enjoy the experience with the huge number of visitors.

Lovely church. This building is exquisite, and even though it's expensive, the tour is worth it. People who wish to attend a religious service can do so in the daily Evensong for free, which is a lovely experience.
Beautiful and touching church. It was really interesting to see Westminster Abbey and hear the introduction about Westminster Abbey. Time "flows" there.

expensive but worth it. Yes its an expensive attraction but when I think of what people pay to go to madame tussads,........ I would rather pay to visit here!Its a beautiful place. The outside is grand and opulent and I adore walking up towards it taking photographs,The interior is just as impressive. So many people, royalty, poets etc have been laid to rest here.Although I see many people taking interior photographs I find that sort of behaviour a little crass and disrespectful.
Hall of fame tombs. Fascinating to visit! Half of Britain's brightest and best are buried there, plus it's a beautiful building.

A 'must see' for first time London visitors.. Touring the Abbey is a 'must' for a first time London visitor...it is unfortunate you cannot take photos inside the church as it is very beautiful with 'hundreds' of tombs...many of famous people...especially in 'Poet's Corner'.Make sure to tour the Cloisters before leaving the Abbey...right after 'Poet's Corner where you turn your audio guide in.The gardens were closed on the day of my visit this year, but I have visited them on earlier trips and they are beautiful as well.This place will get very busy (more so when it is raining) so tour early.

Buy the London Pass first!. There's over 7000 reviews already...I'll just say this is the most expensive church in the world to visit and not worth the full price £20...but before you visit...BUY THE LONDON PASS!!!!! I only bought the 1 Day pass for £49($77ish), not cheap, but worth it! Get it at the Tourist Information desk at the airport or the booth near Leicester SquareThe CHUN P Power-Cardio-One Day Tour of London:£20 10am-11am Westminster Abbey£18 11:15am-12:15pm Churchill War Rooms...5 minute walk away from Westminster£18 Thames River Cruise...5 minute walk to the dock, grab a quick take away lunch at Tesco, which will be on your left. Eat on the boat while trying to admire the Thames's not-so-great scenery...£24.50 1:30-3:30 Tower of London...have a coffee or tea break afterwards.£9 4:00pm-Close Tower Bridge...this doesn't take long to visit, maybe 30-45 minutes.£89.50 TOTALTotal Savings £89.50 - £49 = £40.50($62ish)That's what makes this attraction worth the money at almost half off the price.If you have more time and for a bit more £££££ you could buy the 2 or 3 day pass to see Windsor Castle(£19.20) and Kensington Palace(£17.50) for more savings.

A humbling tour. At the beginning of the tour you are given a headset and audio guide and are allowed to walk the Abbey as you please. This is partially a downfall as some areas are very crowded with rooms having tiny entrances. The audio tour allows a quiet walk through the Abbey which is filled with amazing history. The Abbey was a must do for us and I am glad we came in the morning so that we could take our time. Please remember there is absolutely NO photography allowed in the Abbey.

Don't miss. Absolutely incredible. Everyone from poets to Queen Elizabeth I are here. I suggest booking online through the Westminster Abbey's website so you don't have to wait in lines, nor have to be there at a precise day---you have the entire day to drop in. Audio guides are included which add depth.

Beautiful piece of history. This is a MUST do in London! We did the audio walking tour and the walking tour from the Rick Steves book. Very cool part of history and is absolutely beautiful. My husband and I both really loved this part of our trip!

wonderful place to see. Amazing St.Margaret's church is right on the premises (free of charge). Excellent location, and it was truly amazing to see where some of histories most influential people are buried. Can't take pictures indoors, but outdoors is fair game. Go in the morning to avoid the long line-ups.

A must visit. This was the second time we've visited and this was much better than first as we did the guided tour. Benjamin our Verger guide was humorous, knowledgeable, witty and engaging and well worth an extra 5 pounds. It was a terrific experience.
Historic. A very historic and old church, located in an interesting area for walking and sightseeing. A must see indeed.

A British icon with MUCH more than meets the eye!. A world-wide icon that you MUST see! I have been there tens of times and still learn something new every time I go. Tours are every day BUT you have to be careful about Sundays. Check their web page calendar to make sure you are able to tour on the day of worship and other holidays which you may not know about. There are two ways to see it. Either a do it yourself audio tour OR a verger guided tour. I would HEARTILY recommend the guided tour. You get to see places that all others are not allowed to. While this is a church, it has over 6,000 people buried underneath all of whom you'd recognize! MAJOR players! Not only that, but the history, intertangled stories of Kings and Queens, and the Gothic architecture you get to see behind the scenes make this very worthwhile of your time.GO!

Waste of Time. A bit disappointed.Do'nt try visiting it on Sundau it's partly or totally closed. When finally visited on a week day was a bit disappointed. Though its vast size there isn't much to see. Not one of the most interesting sites of London

Overwhelmingly wonderful. So much history everywhere. Definitely need to plan as much time as you can to see everything. We were there on Sept 16 2015 after spending the morning at The Horse Guards Parade near the palace. Unfortunately the traffic and weather slowed us down so was only able to tour for a couple of hours. Can't wait to return to WesminaterAbbey

Nice, not worth it for the money. If you can go in during church time to see the service and look at it that way (no pictures allowed during that time) that's definitely better as the cost is definitely not worth it. It's no Italian church! So if you can get in for free, worth the time, otherwise skip out. Go into the mini church right beside it as it's free and also pretty.

A Must Visit on any trip to London. The place where history is made! Westminster's will fascinate you from it's architecture to it's history. Whether you no a little or a lot about England and London, you'll recognize something in the abbey.

Incredible. Those of us who live in Canada aren't used to visiting churches or other buildings as old as Westminster Abbey. It's totally amazing! There is so much history here from the graves of former kings and queens to the names and graves in Poet's Corner. This and the Tower of London are must-sees for anyone visiting London.

Great for history, prefer St Pauls for atmosphere. OK, firstly the admission fee - get real people this building would take a LOT to maintain and there are a lot of staff around to assist you - this has to be paid for.If you are a history buff this is an amazing place - my wife loved it. Parts of it date back 100s of years and it really is the state church of England and reflects the history of England and its monarchs.While there was a moment of prayer on the hour and services being conducted during the day I still find St Pauls to be more inspirational and conducive to both sightseeing and prayerful reflection.
Stunning . This church is amazing. We were there for a service and it was so lovely. The choir was phenomenal and made me think of the royal wedding. Touring about was fantastic. Love love love

Filled with history, but not for me. Westminster Abbey was at Broad Sanctuary (Road?) in the City of Westminster. There were several funerals and burials of kings, royal family, as well as famous people like Sir Issac Newton, Charles Darwin, and etc. Admission to the Abbey is GBP 20 for adult, with an audio guide. Free, With London Pass, you can attend free (already included in the pass). The place was filled with history and events. But, for me; London had other wonders to offer which suited me more.
Beautiful and historical. A very historical place. The audio guide provides a very detailed and insightful aspect of the abbey. Long queues expected during peak seasons

beautiful and full of history. the entrance is by no chance cheap (20 pound! unless you're going for a prayer in which case it's free) but you do get value for the money.everyone who goes in gets a player device which lets you hear about the different areas and things found around the abbey. it walks you through the route inside while explaining what you're seeing, and there's a lot to see.the number of tombs inside is staggering, and to think what great events happened in this historic place make it even more unique. it has great statues, painted glass, and mainly a lot of stories.

Brigalow1. If you got kids and you want them to learn history this is the place it's not what I expected. The guided microphones were awesome you just followed the numbers it was awesome. Just to read the names from history alone was incredible.We also had a meal at the shop and the food was fresh and tasty.I have to admit I learnt a lot just soaking up the history.

WONDERFUL. What a beautiful and wonderful place to visit!! We waited in a short line to get in; reasonable fee. There are not enough wonderful adjectives to describe the Abbey!! It's very interesting and well worth a stop during a London visit. It was very meaningful.

Not What I Was Expecting But Still Pleased. Nothing like Cathedrals in the USA. The Abbey is a Lot of graves of very famous people and monarchs. The church part was smaller than I expected especially after seeing the wedding of Prince William and Kate. But the history and architecture were amazing. I am very glad we went!

Chills at Westminster. This is another place that I can't imagine missing on a trip to London. It is so crowded, however, that go in the very early opening times or an hour or so before closing. I know they are dead, but to touch the tombstones of some of the most famous historical characters in the world still sends chills down your back. Ask to see the 18th Century graffiti on some of the windows and even the throne. Little boys will be boys and the local school boys carved their names wherever they could get away with it.
Wonderful. Excellent historical church with lots to see. Free audio guide with the London pass was very helpful.

Try St Paul's instead. We had visited St Pauls on our last visit to London a few months ago and found it very inspiring. I’m afraid I could not say the same about the Abbey. A small leaflet is issued and free audio guides are available but I prefer to have a written general guide as I find audio detracts from the experience. Unfortunately none were available until you get to the shop at the end of your tour, which defeats the object of the exercise. Because of this we did miss the significance of a couple of things. I did expect it to be quite busy (10 am) but not the vast shuffling groups of students and tourists which we encountered. For me there was no sense of awe that one usually finds in any cathedral and apart from the short prayer announcement at 11 am, no sense either that this was a living church. This is a very marked contrast to St Pauls, where history and the present are mingled. The Abbey is basically a museum, overwhelming you with tombs and memorials to the great and the (sometimes not so) good, not a place of worship. I was unimpressed by the sight of one of the ushers openly touching up her makeup in the Lady Chapel. The price of entry I found to be way over the top (Seniors £17 each)That said, I particularly enjoyed the Lady Chapel ,the tombs of the early monarchs and the Coronation Chair. Overall I am glad that I visited but felt that the lack of written information very disappointing
Beautiful Beautiful Beautiful. One if the best Abbeys in the world. Even unbelievers must be charmed by the abbey. It's so great :)

Magnificent Architecture, Fabulous History. This magnificent building is steeped in history. The tombs of Royalty and famous people can be found within this building. The gothic architecture is amazing to behold and the soaring ceilings are breathtaking. Well worth the visit.
The beauty. Haven't been inside but the church looks amazing. Close to other atractions. If you wanna go inside there's a lot of things you'll see but it will cost you abut 20 pounds.

An architectural wonder. We didn't go into the Abbey, we decided to avoid the queue and ticket price and view it from outside. It really is spectacular, we felt that it was still well worth a visit, even without going inside.

SPECTACULAR!!. This is a truly wonderful place - the Abbey Vergers are very friendly and are on hand to answer questions. You need a good couple of hours to explore everywhere and visit the gardens. My favourite bit was seeing the coronation chair and thinking about all the people who have sat in it!! There is also a lovely coffee shop that sells delicious scones. Will definitely go back.

So much history…Don't miss it!. Wow.. I had no idea this pace had so much history, yes the obvious but so much more. As you walk in the door they give you an audio guide (included in your fee, or London Pass) which is very helpful. It was incredibly busy but everyone was friendly and all there to enjoy and take in the scene. Such beauty, worth seeing and worth taking your time to walk through.

One if the best Abbeys in the world.. A must for any visitor to Zlondon. Shane about the high admission charge. So much to see and do. Great place to sit and relax in the cool on a hot day. Be prepared for queues when you arrive.
Rememrable . I was there with my grandma my cousins and we saw an organ concert by a famous concert organist. It was so beautiful
So enjoyable.. Totally enjoyable. Great history, a self guided audio tour makes it an individual experience not to be missed.

Visit to the Abbey. We visited the Abbey on a Saturday morning. We arrived shortly after opening and quickly got tickets and entered before the crowds arrived shortly after. It's a big place with a lot of history. Well worth visiting.
Great stop for history buffs. The number of famous people laid to rest in this church is amazing; I was impressed with the tombs of Darwin and Newton as well as the poets corner.
So much history. The architecture alone is amazing. Everywhere something to see. So much history with all of the grave markers.
