Shiver up your spine. Been twice and would go again. The history is too much to take in, a pity you can't take photos. If I had the time I would allocate at least half a day to explore properly. The likes of Oliver Cromwell, Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin are buried here

Great visit. This was our third visit to Westminster Abbey and was just as interesting as the first two. The audio guide was very helpful as we wound our way through the Abbey. We also visited the gardens for the first time, which are only open on certain days. We took our time and enjoyed the visit greatly.

An active, architecturally gorgeous and historical church. This is such a beautiful church with gorgeous architecture. I was honored to participate in part of a regular service being conducted. There is so much history in the church with many royals and great figures of science and literature buried there. Aew inspiring

Worth It. I was a bit taken aback when I found out how expensive admission was to the abbey, but that was soon put out of my mind when I saw just how spectacular it is. Pictures do no justice, the central nave is absolutely magnificent, and Henry VII's chapel is a wonder to behold, too.And that's just the aesthetic side. Historically, the abbey is mindblowing. The amount of monarchs and influential people buried within one building is overwhelming.I don't regret paying admission for such an amazing visit.

Stunning. My husband and I visited Westminster Abbey during our honeymoon last month and we don't know what else to say other than: it was stunning. What a spectacular church with an interesting and engaging tour. It only would have been better if some of the closed rooms and places were open to the tours and if we had a live tour guide. Also, it would've been nice to have been able to take pictures to show our friends and family back home! Overall, what an incredibly beautiful place.

Historically amazing...not to be missed !. The Ladies Chapel is particularly impressive and just sitting in the nave imagining all the historical figures who have walked down the aisle...Be sure not to miss the museum it'definitely worth a visit . I found the audio guide helpful but wanted more information particularly relating to the additional tombs in the Ladies Chapel.

a great rainy day place to visit!!. we decided to go to Westminster Abbey on our own and do the walking tour with audio provided as part of the admission. that turned out to be perfect . the tour was well done the Abbey was fascinating . it was a rainy day and a perfect thing to do when the sun was hiding.

Jeremy Irons!. Thoroughly enjoyed listening to Jeremy Irons describing all the different points of interest within the abbey. The abbey contains numerous tombs, memorials and little chapels that are beautifully created.

Westminster Abbey is a very special place!. This is a very special and historically important site. I've seen a couple of times and have never tired of see the majesty, beauty and significance of this abbey. We received a free audio tour and found it to be extremely useful as we walked around. It's just amazing to think about of the important and historically significant people and events that have graced this place. We purchased the tickets on-line and visited the abbey first thing on a Monday morning - there was already quite a long line but we were able to get in immediately without going into the queue.

Great for a rainy day. The church floor is covered with burial plots, you will be walking on top graves. Once you get over that you'll enjoy the tour. When you enter get the headset and listen to the tour as you make your way through the church. This is an active church, there are services throughout the day, check the website for this information and plan your trip accordingly. While inside there is NO photography. We spent several hours inside viewing the many different burial plots, be aware that there is little room to sit and rest, unless the chairs are out for services. If you're hungry, stop at the cafe attached to the Abbey. They serve lunch and desserts. Stop by and have a coffee or tea to warm up on a cold drizzly afternoon.The church is close to the Westminster Underground stop.

A Must see attraction in London. The most beautiful building. Well worth a visit when in London.Filled with sculpture, paintings & history. Staff are very knowledgeable & friendly. Takes longer to look around than you anticipate as loads to see.

A national treasure. This truly is a not-to-be-missed experience. So much history here - it captures triumphs and tragedies of a nation in a beautiful setting - kings, poets, unknown soldiers. The architecture is stunning.

Beautiful place and you never know what you'll find.... Expensive place to visit, but worth the trip. There are few places (The Tower of London being one other) that have so much history in one location. Be sure to see the RAF Chapel and the temporary resting place of Oliver Cromwell, all the way at the front of the chapel, along with the resting place of most of the famous kings and queens. Be on the lookout for interesting non-royal graves, too. Besides luminaries like Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin, there are also inspirational graves such as the Unknown Soldier, the organist section and, if you keep an eye out, you can find one of the Abbey's plumbers. A great time.
No access to the inside. Was an impressive building from the outside. Our tour group did not go into the abbey.I don't know if any groups are allowed in. It was a disappointment.
Even more impressive than expected. High high ceilings, sombre interior and pervading sense of history. This Abbey is not just a church but an historical landmark.

beautiful place respect it. it is best if you can go at the evening time to listening a even song, you need to leave a camera away then, but it is only good, you can really be and listen and there are no millions of selfie people around.

Stunning, and the organ is beautiful to hear.. A must. I recommend the organ recitals on Sundays (5pm I think, but check the website). The music will be excellent, and played by a very highly regarded musician.

Well worth the time and a must do in London!. Beautiful & rich in history. To really appreciate the Abbey, take the audio tour if you're unable to book the Guided Tour or the Verger Tour. The Abbey is stunning at every turn. However, photography is not allowed inside. Therefore the Souvenir Guide is worth buying. There is also a good restaurant, the Cellarium within the Abbey for a good lunch.The ticket queue can be rather long. To skip the queue, pre-book your tour online or visit with the London Pass.
Historically magnificent. Went back again ...love the history and the Beauty of it . Guides are great and it is easy to revisit again

Don't miss this "art gallery" in a cathedral. It's like an art museum in a cathedral. Thank heaven you can't take pictures or no one would ever move along. It is very crowded. The free audio tour is helpful. I would not miss this exhibit. The first day we went there was a large line and we learned you could book and pay online and skip the line. So we came back the second day and there was hardly any line!

Evensong. Evensong is on most days at 5pm. We arrived about 4.30 and there was already a queue. They are quite strict about where you can go so don't expect to be able to walk around freely. We were told where to sit and luckily had very good seats near the choir. The service was a lovely experience.
Take your time. Just lovely, walking around with Jeremy Irons telling us about the abbey. Quite pricy to get in though. Need at least an hour or more to appreciate this beautiful building.

Amazing. Was very high on our visit list and we were not disappointed. It is included in the London Pass. The Abby is probably about 80% accessible. A tremendous amount of history is in the building and it should not be missed. The wardens are very knowledgeable and helpful.
Evensong in the Abbey. Attended Evensong service and actually sang with the choir! A great experience. The Abbey is beautiful inside.
Well worth the time. Very inspiring place to visit. Was not able to book a Verger tour, but the audio tour is well worth the purchase.

A must do!. Of course you must see this beautiful historic place of worship.Rich in history.All I kept thinking was Diana's funeral was here as was Will and Kate's wedding.A kind women that took our tickets explained to me how it was set up for the wedding.Do rent the audio tape for a full idea of all of the history within the walls.Many famous people are buried here.Take your time,it is a beautiful site.You can also see the Coronation Throne!

Jaw-dropping, gasping, eye-opening beauty and history everywhere!. This was my first time to Westminster Abbey as well as my other 4 friends who traveled to London with me. I just don't even know where to begin about this stunning and beautiful abbey. The history alone is amazing and every corner you turn, alights your senses and your mind with experiences that you will never forget. The only downside was we could not take photos inside, and with hopes that a DVD would be for sale in the gift shop at the end of our stay, we were even more disappointed to find they had no DVD of the interior of the Abbey or the history for sale. :( It's such an enormous place it would take years to go through it bit by bit to acknowledge everything there. It's indeed a magical, serene and exquisite place that must be seen when you visit London. 20 GBP per person to get in, children are discounted... but worth every penny. I'm still playing pictures in my mind of the Abbey... it's stolen my heart.

Interesting Experience. Interesting experience I would encourage first time tourists to try out. Extremely detailed and historic church was holding service while visitors walk around. Only bummer is no photos inside.

Worth an afternoon. Allow plenty of time for this piece of history. Well worth an afternoon. I would recommend getting the guidebook. You will miss so much otherwise plus it has great photos. Photography is allowed at certain times (no flash), but you may hit a time when it is not so having the booklet is a wonderful souvenir.

An awesome place. This is a truly awe inspiring place. The soaring arches are such an amazing sight as you walk through the nave. An audio tour is a must if you are to fully appreciate the history spread throughout the Abbey.

A definite must see. The line is discouraging to see at first but it moves very quickly. I see no reason to pay extra to get in ahead. Plan to spend at least a couple of hours inside with your audio guide because there is more to see than is possible to digest on just one visit. We were fortunate to get there during a noon service. There are guides everywhere and NO PHOTOS. I am torn because I do like taking photos but it is so refreshing not to have people standing around snapping pictures and ignoring the magnificence of the experience. It forces one to really pay attention to what one is seeing. It is beautiful; it is inspiring.
Make time to visit. This was a wonderful place to visit. I would highly recommended you make time to include a visit here.

Allow plenty of time!. We had a guided tour of Westminster Abbey and it was amazing. We visited on a grey and leaden day so unfortunately the colours of the Abbey were a bit muted, but there was so much to see. I really recommend having a guided tour as you would miss so much otherwise. Unfortunately you could not take photos inside (which isn't allowed anywhere there are oils on canvas paintings) but there are plenty of places to purchase photos if you want. It wasn't particularly crowded on the day we visited so there was plenty of space to move around the smaller areas of the Abbey. Highly recommend a tour.
Very expensive and crouded. We had to wait on the line for the tickets for 15 minutes20£ - A family of 5 people Each makes it almost impossibleVery important historic place

Unparalleled History. Where else can you walk where Kings and Queens have walked for centuries. Feel shivers down your spine as you come face to face with resting places of historical people you have studied at school all of your life. It is really an awe inspiring experience.

Highlight of the trip to London! . Wow, what an incredible building. It's astonishing to think that people were able to build something like this without the help of modern tools. Make the time to see this place the line may seem long but it goes very quickly. Make sure to get the audio tour as there are a ton of historical tidbits that you should know to really understand the grandeur of this church and it's relevance to the British crown. Admission was around £20 a person and you can expect to spend more than an hour inside if you get the audio tour.
What a holy place!. It's at the heart of London, along with Big Ben and Parliament Building. Even watching from outside is fairly enough.

Historic Building Filled With Memories Of Weddings and Funerals. Take care and walk slow and take in every view of this historic church. Every step is stepped in history (historic figures are buried under your feet). The coronation chair to the right of the entrance waits for the sad passing of the monarch so that the torch can be handed to the next head of state. The detail in stone is amazing and the height is overwhelming. Many wedding and funeral has taken place here and many were televised to the world for all to see. Take a moment and breakaway from the British Red Phone Booths and learn of this historic church.

mass with chorus. I missed the regular opening hours and was in luck as on Thursday they were having a mass with chorus (not a full mass as there was no communion). The only drawback is of course you were not allowed to wonder around, but I managed to see a bit of the interior after the 60 min mass. I wish their hours of operation were a bit longer.

A wonderful historic building!. There is so much history here, it is unbelievable. It is just amazing to see all the historical figures and the stunning architecture; you need a few hours to really soak in the atmosphere of the abbey. The audio commentary really brought everything to life. It is such a pity that you can’t take any pictures. I had just bought a Union Jack umbrella and realized when I was about to leave the abbey that I did not have it. One of the assistants led us all the way back to where I thought I laid it down, and there it was on the floor. He then took us all the way back to the exit, he was so very helpful. You can really get caught up in the history of the abbey and spend hours just absorbing everything around you.
A special visit. On our Ruby Wedding Day we attended the choral matins in Westminster Abbey. Magical! Sat in the quire stalls and enjoyed the service and occasion immensely.

Memorable. Visiting Westminister Abbey was a joy, to witness the history within the walls was something I'll remember always. The crowds are a bit of a challenge buts it's managed really well. I hope to visit again, perhaps with a guide.
!Very helpful staff. Wonderful historic site!! If you have ancestors buried there, ask the staff. They will help you find them.

The Abbey is a must-see living pageant of British history.. Westminster Abbey is one of the world’s great churches, with a history stretching back over a thousand years and an essential part of any trip to London. It is in the heart of London - next to Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament.

Absolutely Beautiful!. First site my daughter and I saw in London. Very impressive and set the tone for seeing London. I liked the acoustiguide audio tour. To think of seeing the Abbey where so many historical events took place...just incredible.
Highlight of Trip. This was a wonderful experience. Make sure you go to a service. Allow time to really see everything; it's worth the time. A London Pass will get you in via a shorter line.

Westminster Abbey top of the List.. Westminster Abbey was like stepping into a past that was replete with Royal Weddings Royal Funerals, Coronation and great figures of history rolled into one. The Audio tour is a must. No photographs are permitted inside the Abbey itself which is a bonus given the high number of selfies that are taken at every other historical attraction but once you enter the Cloisters and other sections of the Abbey precincts photography is permitted. The first thing that struck me was how small Westminster Abbey is. It is not a large Church at all! Canterbury, Salisbury, York Minster are much larger but Westminster Abbey is rich in tradition and history'- the tombs of Edward the Confessor and the greats of English Literature as well as those of the Benedictine Monks whose Abbey Church it once was, Kings and Queens of England are all there. For those who are familiar with Latin and Middle English, the Abbey is a treasure trove. The Funeral effigies of several Kings and Queens of England are on display in what would have been one of the Monastery work places. Did you know that Queen Elizabeth1 was less than 5 feet tall and very tiny? The Coronation Chair is in an alcove beside the Great West Door. Combine a trip to the Abbey with a visit to St Margaret's Church which is in the same precinct of Westminster. A visit to Westminster Abbey should be top priority especially if you love history. If you time your visit well, you may be fortunate to hear the Westminster Choir sing Evensong.
WALK through TIME. Close to the center of all the all the government buildings, the history and the link to English history is fabulous and one who is a history buff will love this site and church
Easy entrance. Easy entrance and not a long wait to get inside. Download the app to phone to listen to information about different areas. Can take photos once outside main building.
just ok. its a nice church but couldnt really connect with it for some reason, and the explanation wasnt intersting enough for me to listen to.

A walk through history. If there is any church to visit in London, I would go to this one as it has the most historical significance with the number of coronation events and burials of kings, queens, notable scientists, authors, soldiers etc. Worth the price of admission.
Not impressed with the restaurant here though despite the kids eat free.
Beautiful Abbey. What a beautiful sanctuary, lots to see. The rooms were to die for, we spent two hours there, need at least 3-4 to see and appreciate the Abbey.
Something you can't miss. It's absolutely mandatory to visit this place. For all the reasons. You will not regret. Thank you so much!
Evensong ... a special option .... Evemsong ... magnificnt! Too late to meander through the Abbey? Evensong is a special spiritual option.

So much to see at Westminster Abbey. So much art and history packed into one place -- it's overwhelming to try to see it all. Don't miss the Ladies' Chapel which has the tomb of Elizabeth 1 on one side -- buried side by side with her half-sister, Bloody Mary -- and poor Mary Queen of Scots on the other side, who was beheaded by her cousin Elizabeth 1. Other tombs of artists and writers, as well as priceless artwork. IF you have the London Pass, you get to skip the line!

Westminster Abbey, stunning!!. Wasn't intending to go to the abbey but went in because it was pouring with rain, so glad we did. I have never been to a place where so many famous people down the centuries are buried. Incredibly interesting. The tomb of the Unknown Warrior very moving.Visited with my husband and two older teenage sons who both thouroughly enjoyed it. Good audio tour and plenty of people around to ask questions. So glad it was raining or would have missed out on a very special visit!!,

One the Greatest Churches. You definitely want to have the London Pass to avoid the line ups.Once in you will be amazed by how big this church is and to know that it was build in 1065 and it is still here for us to admire and walk in this magnificent Gothic architecture building that has been the site for coronation of kings and queens since 1066 and the place for wedding and funerals of the Royals, it is again a place to take in and walk slow so you don't miss any of the wonderful monuments and stain glass wonders.

Wonderfull, a must see place.. What a spectacular cathedral. Just sublime architecture and tons of history. Loved the fact that the place isn't just a museum, it's actually a working church with daily services. Also it has this lovely welcoming atmosphere. Make sure you have plenty of time to spend because there is so much to see and many stories to be heard. We missed Scientists' Corner because we were there just before closing time. Got to experience Poets' Corner though. To stand there among Lord Byron, P.B. Shelley and the other great names was just stunning.This cathedral is a must see for everyone interested in history or architecture. Definately worth the admission.

MUST SEE SIGHT IN LONDON. If you are visiting London, do go to see Westminster Abbey. So much to see, it's a fascinating history of Britain in one building which dates back to its origins in 960AD. So many tombs of Kings and Queens, soldiers, sailors, poets and authors. Wonderful architecture and stained glass windows
Beautiful so don't miss it!. A must see if you are in London! A lot of historical significance and also the glamour of royalty weddings.

Disappointing. This is nothing more than a glorified memorial (and mausoleum) for famous folks of British history. Not really much of a church by my standards. The most interesting part is outside near the gift shop where 20th Century "saints" including Kolbe, Bonhoffer and King are recognized.

Must see if you are in and around London!!. What a wonderful experience...hearing the choir sing, seeing the many, many famous historical figures that are buried here, a beautiful structure and part of history!!!

Absolutely amazing . The abbey is unbelievable. It's so beautiful, so awe inspiring, totally worth the ticket price (which is a bit too expensive, though). Too bad you can't take pictures, cause the souvenirs can't quite catch the unbelievably powerful feeling you get admiring this beautiful church. (I suggest getting to the abbey before the opening time, I got there about 15 minutes after and there was already a long queue, and the chapels were quite crowded)

Stunningly, Historically Amazing!. This was stop one on our second day in London. We allotted about 1.5 hours here (we were using a London Pass) but that is not nearly enough time to absorb the magnitude of this site. Spectacular is an understatement. The sense of British and world history seeps pervasively through every step. We both came away knowing we'd not nearly spent enough time exploring the abbey.

Visit for free . I feel a bit guilty in reviewing a church... Anyway, if you actually go to a service then you can visit for free. We went to evening song and really enjoyed the fantastic choir. Please be respectful. If you go to a service then remember that people are there to worship!

Don't miss it!. Another "must to see" in London. Lots of history inside, we enjoyed it with the London Pass. You can't visit all the Churches in London, for sure, but try to take a look of it! Worth a visit!

Worth waking up early!. This is a must see. Regardless what religion we practice, this cathedral is a living history book with all the late greats laid to rest here. I found myself appreciating all the various histories I have come across about the British Empire even more after touring this cathedral.

Do the tour--and go to Evensong!. Wonderful! I would put this on your London must-do list. Of course, the outside of the Abbey (including views, within the area, of the Houses of Parliament, Big Ben, and the London Eye) are simply stunning. But it’s the inside that is amazing; it is absolutely worth the price of admission, and I would also recommend buying the small guide to the Abbey, which goes deeper into the history of each section. The entire Abbey is fantastic—highlights for me were the Coronation Chair, the graves of and memorials to many famous English church musicians, Poet’s Corner (with graves and memorials of many authors of famous English texts), and, of course, the Henry VII chapel, with its stunning ceiling made of hand-carved stone. What a marvel of early human achievement; I’m not sure modern architects could figure it out! After visiting the main Abbey, it’s also worth spending time in the cloisters on the side, which reveal some of the most ancient parts of the building and all of London.At the Abbey I was particularly struck by the sense of history mixed with vibrant, current life. This does not feel like a dusty museum; it feels like a living institution, vital to the nation in which it stands and still devoted to daily worship, education, and spiritual life.Along those lines, if you have the opportunity to attend Evensong, do. I attended on a Tuesday evening on which the service was sung by the lay vicars; they were a superb choir and the repertoire (traditional English church music—Byrd, Tallis, etc.) was perfect for the setting. Particularly gorgeous were the sung responses to the prayers. Evensong takes place in the quire; if you arrive early, you can sit in one of the wooden stalls (if you arrive later, they set up folding chairs next to the quire, which is perfectly suitable).I’d put this on the must-do-list for London. Of lesser consequence is the store, which is quite well done as tourist shops go—great postcards and various souvenirs, along with a wonderful CD collection (from the Abbey’s choirs and organ) and jewelry collection.

A must seen in London!. Amazing. Nothing can compare to the experience here. It is a must see for your trip to London. The history you will see and the stunning beautiful architecture is worth every quid to get in. Spot on!

So much history . This abbey is simply stunning! It's ancient history and vaults of ages gone by, plus the sculpture and stained glass windows combine history, majesty and monarchy. Amazing! Then there's the modern history knowing that Princess Diana and The Queen Mother lay there before being interred. There are times of brief prayer called, so that the spiritual is also strongly present. The cafe is delightful as well.

See the Abbey interior for free with the Sunday organ recital. Entrance into Westminster Abbey is quite pricey. However, there is a free organ recital on Sunday evenings that allows you to listen to lovely music while observing the beautiful interior of the Abbey. It lasts for 30 minutes and the line begins about 30 minutes before the start. You don’t get to walk around and get a tour like you would with paid entrance, but you can still see the interior, stained glass windows, art, etc. Plus, the music is excellent – and free!

Westminster Abbey. We do not regularly travel to the UK but we make a point of visiting the Abbey. For century's it has played an integral part in Englands history and is well worth a visit. It does become a bit crowded during the holidays so be prepared. They were busy with maintenance and cleaning during our visit ,but still worth the effort as it was mainly on the outside that the renovation and cleaning was being done. One should remember that it is a church and behave accordingly.

Amazing and not to be rushed through. Set aside a couple of hours to do it justice.. Although you may have a small wait in the queue, unless you have a past, we have always found the queue moves very quickly and you are soon inside this beautiful and famous building. Electronic guides are available (free) and give an amazing amount of information and history. One could spend several hours in here as it is so beautiful and there are so many graves and memorials to many famous people and the electronic guide explains about a lot of them. Such a beautiful and historic building. Excellent shop at the end of the visit with some excellent non run-of-the mill souvenirs. Also a tea and coffee shop but did not have time to check this out.

Stunning and beautiful. You will often go to a church, cathedral or humble chapel on a foreign visit. If you're in London Westminster Abbey is a must see. The church is the Monarchs church, therefore a Dean not Archbishop presides over the community on behalf of the King or Queen. It's all but a thousand years old, full of historic tombs and gravestones and beautiful wooden carving. If you're lucky enough to hear the choir practicing then you will think your hearing angels sing.
Historical place to see!. It's a must see in London! Love the history behind it. You can see a lot of great things there. The bridge has the best view of London Eye!

Very moving . My wife and I chose to do the tour and really enjoyed it. It was great that the church tries to involve you. We were able to light a candle and write a prayer, and everyone was offered to stay for communion/ attend a mass. A lot of history. And beautiful views of the church gardens, be sure to check them out before leaving.

Famous Landmark. The building exterior was under construction/renovation. Didn't tour the interior. There was long line waiting. The building/architecture is beautiful. The detail of the work is very impressive!! I heard no picture is allowed inside. And purchase your ticket in advance to avoid waiting in line to get the tickets.There are many things to see in that area so prepared at least whole day there. Please wear comfortable shoes because lots of walking in London.
Go for a service. If you are a Christian a service here is a must do. We participated in a service whose traditions go back 1000 years. Amazing.

Step through time and see the final rest place of a thousand years worth of England's royalty. Truly awe inspiring architecture, sculptures and art. Tour through a thousand years of British history as you walk past the final resting places of notables such as Mary Queen of Scots, Edward the Confessor, Issac Newton, Charles Darwin and Charles Dickens.
Not just another church. If you have interest in English history or literature, as you tour around you will find it interesting to see who has been buried in Westminster Abbey.

Probably the best attraction in London. Probably the best attraction in London, where you can see history and glory, religion and tradition with an amazing cultural landmark. This a real evidence for the great culture of the British people. We strolled around the monuments and the tombs for hours. It is most recommended to focus on several famous figures and thier stories. You can also pick in interesting exhibit while you are there and find its story on Wikipedia online which makes it great!Don't miss the inner garden and the museum as well.

Iconic landmark associated with memorable moments in Britain's history. Very moving to see the gorgeous architecture in this iconic house of worship. Lots of English notables are buried here, including Elizabeth I and her sister Mary. Can be crowded in the middle of the day, so recommend viewing first thing in the morning or mid-afternoon.
Stunning church. Stunning building of worship. Self guided tour very interesting and informative. Takes longer than you think

Amazing property. Tours of this facility are conducted by handheld audio guides which allow you to process through the facility at your own pace. You should allow 2-3 hours to cover the property. It is a very interesting site; full of history.

As Interesting a Cathedral as you well find.. I never would have expected our family of 4 to spend three hours in Westminster Abbey but we did. The audio tour was a great aid in making the trip worthwhile. So many kings and queens and notable others have been buried or married there that it is too numerous to list. Besides that the church is beautiful.

Great but expensive. I have visited the Abbey several times and it is definitely worth a look around. Poets corner, the tomb of the unknown soldier and the tombs of the various kings and queens are all excellent. The architecture of the Abbey always leaves me in awe. I do think that the entry fee has gotten a little extortionate over the last few years.

For every tourist. Remarkable artwork inside. A must see, especially for a first-time visitor to London. You could spend hours viewing all the historical monuments inside, or go through quickly for a small taste of the rich history of the city. Either way, absolutely stunning place to take a look inside.

Doesn't Fail To Disappoint Even on Second Visit!. We have just completed our second trip to Westminster Abby, as enjoyable as the first. Amazing how much there was still to take in. Can throughly recommend to all London visitors

Give Yourself a Few Hours. We took a tour of the Abbey with 'London Walks'. Highly recommended way to see it. The tour guide was great and we were able to walk right in through the group/VIP entrance. Give yourself a few hours if you want to really see everything. It was very crowded with no sense of direction - people going every which way, pushing into each other, etc. My only recommendation would be more directional signage, and a lot of patience.

History. What an amazing Abbey. Full of royal history. You can do a guided tour but we chose to walk around at our own place. Magnificent! However I did feel the entrance fee was a it high. The queues looked long but it didn't take long to get in.

Great half-day excursion.. Westminster Abbey is incredible. Never in one place will you experience as much history, religion, and royalty in such a short period of time. Chaucer, Handel, Sir Isaac Newton, C.S. Lewis, and many more are buried here. This is a must of musts. 17 pound fee. 2-3 hours needed.

Stunning. The line to get in moves quickly and the audio tour was very informative. The abbey's architecture was stunning both inside and out. Would love to come back and do a private tour if possible.

Beautiful music at Evensong. A must-see during any visit to London. If you attend a service the admission fee is waived. Attend an evensong and you'll be treated to beautiful choral music while you gaze at this gorgeous historic cathedral. A moving experience.

The Abbey. This attraction was one of my favorites in London. I was impressed how old this church is and the history behind it. I never new that this was a burial place for so many kings and queens of state. this made it really educational for my wife and i. This was worth waiting for.

Wonderful visit. Westminster Abbey is interesting both from an historic as well as religious perspective. I chose to pay the extra 5GBP to participate in the Verger led tour. It was a great decision as you are granted access to areas that are normally not open to the general public and here many interesting and personal details about the operation of the Abbey. Be sure to look around the grounds. In the Cloisters area I found the Pyx Chamber dating back to around 1070. Very simple and amazing.

Home to so much of British History. There is so much to see and take in from the last resting place of famous people to the sites of famous events. The audio guide is a great way to make sure you don't miss the really important parts. But if you do your homework ahead of time you can map out your own tour and see everything including what is not part of the audio tour.Weekdays are best but it will be crowded with tours on many days in the summer.

Beautiful and serene. The audio guide is good. It takes you through the Abbey in a methodical manner. Lots of British monarchs and famous people are buried there. You will miss a lot if you do not take the audio tour. I strongly recommend it.

Awesome. A tremendous walk through history. It was really awe-inspiring to see the memorials of so many famous people. I especially was enthralled by the poets corner and the prime ministers. Definitely a must-visit.

Too crowded, not too well managed. Very crowded on a Saturday morning. Mostly with huge tour groups who don't really seem to want to be there. The price of admission includes an audio tour. This is rather a bad idea, because it means that all of these tourists insist on going to see everything on the audio tour and ignoring everything else. If you want to have a look at something that is on the audio tour, it is overcrowded with foreign tourists. If you want to see something not on the tour, maybe one of the more obscure graves--Prime Minister Gladstone, Stephenson (of Stephenson's Rocket), C.S. Lewis--again you can't because the foreign tourists are all walking over it, ignoring it. They have it all roped off so you have to see everything in the order they want you to see it. You can't say "Okay, this bit is crowded right now, I will come back to it later" because it is impossible to avoid the direction of traffic the crowds are funneled in. I ended up unhooking a velvet rope when none of the vergers were looking to go back to an "earlier" part of the cathedral. I have never been in any other European cathedral where I wasn't free to wander around.They do say a formal prayer every hour, this seems to be an attempt to remind the crowds that this is actually a place of worship. Then there are small short prayer services in more isolated parts of the cathedral. I joined one at the shrine (i.e. tomb) of St. Edward the Confessor that lasted about 15 minutes.I came here both because I love the history, and I love the sacred religious heritage. I really couldn't figure out what the vast majority of the rest of the crowd were doing there.
Do not miss this place. Very serene place to visit despite the packs of people that visit everyday. I will definitely visit again when I am in London.
Full 0f History. I never knew this place have such interesting history. Lucky I did not miss it. Good to see the Coronation Chair for the first time ever.

Step too the side for a surprise haven. Yes it's a great place for tourists, it's a bit of a tourist trap. If you get time walk behind the abbey into the school courtyard. At one end there's an open area (opposite side from parliament) and you'll see a barrier with a guard for cars.. Don't worry he's not there to annoy or stop pedestrians. Just stroll on past, through the archway and you will find yourself in a tranquil and delightful enclosed square.

THE ABBEY. From my point of vue,it's the first thing to visit in London.You'll find there the whole history of England - the Coronation Chair,the tomb of Elizabeth 1st,of Henry the 7th,a monument to Newton,Shakespeare looking at Lawrence Olivier's tomb stone .And you hear it all from Jeremy Irons...

Westminster Abbey. The line was very short to get in that day. We did not purchase tickets in advance and that worked out ok. We did not rent the audio service. I think next time I will. There is so much inside the Abbey to see.

Historical Abbey. This ediface is impressive adjacent to the Houses of Parliament and the Tower of Big Ben. Inside is impressive as well with the many graves of famous Brits. Poets, authors and royalty as well a military heroes

Not to be missed!. When you pay to get in you're allowed to take photos, but not when you're there to worship--you won't be allowed in if you have a camera. The abbey is stunning and worth the price, but I also suggest going to evensong so you can hear the famous boys choir sing!

One of the most beautiful churches I have been. The abbey is so beautiful and elegant inside and outside. It is so interesting to see the tombs of famous writers with all the details, statues, symbols. We went to a religious service at 5 pm and we were in awe listening to the beautiful voices of the (professional) chorus surrounded by such amazing setting. We were almost levitating!

Amazing!. I don't know a lot about British history, so I didn't really think much was going on outside of Will and Kate's wedding a few years ago... But, boy, did I wish I paid attention in history class! I was flabbergasted with the amount of history, and important people's tombs in this building. I was really in a place of British royalty and history. I do recommend not bypassing the audio tours, and if you really want to take your time to seriously allot at least 2 hours to this place. (Also I felt that when I used the bathroom it would've been the same one Posh Spice used at the royal wedding...)

Worth seeing once. I have mixed feelings about Westminster Abbey. On one hand, the history and sheer magnitude of the building are practically overwhelming. On the other hand, the tour and information presented are nearly 100% related to the notable dead people buried inside. I didn't realize that the experience would be somewhat akin to visiting an indoor cemetery, but that's how it seemed. I'm glad we saw it once, but probably wouldn't go back.

A big Tomb with a church. so much of British history surrounded by tombs of important people, especially kings and queens. A setting for important ceremonies nowadays and a piece of gothic architecture to admire.
Awesome. A must see in London. This place was amazing, much more history inside it than I realized. My favorite place in London
Beuatiful stained glass windows. Icon of London. Must go inside to see the huge stained glass window. great history too. must on your lsit of places to visit in London especially on a grey rainy day

Historical. This is one of my favorite places to visit when in London. So much history!!! It is such a beautiful place and just amazing to see the historical figures that are buried here. Need a half day, to a day to really take it all in properly. Has to be on the list of places to see when in London.
Westminster Abbey. So so much history! Something everyone should visit. Even attended a service there. Would love to go back.

beautiful experience. The Westminster Abbey is a "must see" point in London.If you are travelling from outside of UK it is a special experience to visit this church and also a worship.I think it is much more better to participate on a worship than just enter as a tourist to the abbey. They are also prepared with many helpful brochure to be able to follow the worship.

Amazing place. I've seen my fair share of cathedrals and abbeys on my travels - and this one is among the most interesting ones for sure. The architecture is stunning and the history captivating. Unfortunately, I didn't get there in time for a guided tour, but even with only the audio commentary it was very interesting. A nice stroll through the gardens after and tea and scones at the cafe made for a great morning in London.

in England's green and pleasant land.... Took our American friends to Westminster Abbey and they were rightly amazed at the history and significance of this great abbey. We are so lucky to have so much to offer the world and sometimes we forget how much we offer the world.

Interesting Place of Great Historical Significance. We toured though Westminister Abbey with a private tour guide (we took a London Walks walking tour) and thus avoided the very long line to get into the Abbey. The building was fascinating and full of history, which was made more vivid by our accomplished guide.

Amazing!. Beautiful! Soak up the history (see who's interred there and be amazed) and amazing architecture. Definitely worth visiting. The entrance fee is a bit steep but trust me, it's worth it.
However, if you're not into art, culture or history, skip it and just have a look from the outside ;)

no interior tour great for taking PHOTOS. we walked around the outside and in the inside part that surrounded the interior ~ something to see for sure but then we tried to have TEA at the café ~ and the hostess waitress was so rude to us that we left and the next day had TEA AT HARROD's ~ on the TERRACE def do that if you have a chance the BEST !

I come in silence and surrender. The history itself is jaw-dropping and silencing. I wish there'd been small doors we could wriggle and wend through, I'm sure they're there. Set aside time for a walking or audio tour as well as some peace to watch the ghosts float through the sunlight.
Amazed. We toured Westminster Abby and were quite amazed with the architecture along with the history associated with it.

Evensong - Simply wonderful. You must go to Evensong to feel the true tradition of English worship and music. If you are lucky you may get a seat in the choir. I have always refused to pay to visit the Abbey but a donation of the same entrance fee is merited not only to protect this glorious monument but to express gratitude for the unique experience. Visitors can also show their respect by observing silence in this Sacred place of Worship.
Stunning. A stunning gothic cathedral, huge and full of history. A celebration of its county's grandeur: kings, queens but also pets, scientists, sailors. Dont' miss it
A beautiful church with amazing history. You cannot visit london without visiting Westminster Abbey. While we saw a lot of Churches in Europe, none have the same history (and crypts) as this

History on a grand scale. The guide to Westminster Abbey is hugely useful in understanding the building, and the various staff around the building were very helpful. To a Brit who has seen these sort of places it was excellent; to my American niece it was mind blowing. Avoid the toilets if possible.

Disappointed. Disappointed by staff attitude. We have visited the abbey many times and appreciate that to survive there is sneed to charge entrance fees. We are retired police and military, on this occasion all we wanted was to pay our respects to the Unknown Warrior... We had been in London all day and had no desire to see the abbey again... The aggressive and rude 'cannon' on the door would n or let us in to this area which after all is just inside the main entrance... Disappointed that the authorities will not allow genuine people access to this monument without charging us £34 to do so.. The extortionate fee is one thing but rude aggressive staff is totally unacceptable.

An experience of the soul of being English!. The best way to see the abbey if you cannot pay the entrance fee is to attend evensong. Then you can experience the abbey in all its glory as a place of worship. Wonderful. A must for any tourist or overseas visitor who wishes to experience the uniqueness of English culture.

All of British history from Mediaeval to modern in one place. Took the guided tour with one of the deanery staff, only costs an extra fiver over the twenty you pay to get in, well worth it. You get a two hour personal tour and get to go to some areas not open to the general public, included the tomb of Henry V and Edward the confessor.A great way to spend a morning if you are interested in British History.Definately take the guided tour, not just the audio tour.

Awsome display of history. It seems to have more statues than the British Museum! The building is impressive enough even if it were empty. It's certainly not. Makes you wonder where all the sculptors have gone. It's so full of history and the audio guide, which is free once you've paid to enter is a must. If you don't have time for the British Museum, just do the Abbey and you'll be happy.

Westminster Abbey. You can spend hours in Westminster Abbey. The audio provided is very good. The history of the weddings, burials, and coronations is wonderful. Be sure to read up on or watch some of the programs about the Kings and Queens of England so you can appreciate all that is there. Among those buried there, other than Kings and Queens, are Geoffrey Chaucer, Isaac Newton, Oliver Cromwell, Charles Darwin...to name a few.

Of Kings and poets. This was our third trip here and we see something new each time. Visiting the resting spots of poets and kings brings history alive. The intersection outside is worth a visit by itself just to take in the view

Superb walk through time. I went in to see the royal tombs and poets corner. But there is so much more. The soaring ceilings, intriguing carvings -the details produced by meticulous human endeavour are just superb. The staff are cheerful and helpful. There are lots of free tours which I dipped in and out of. I came out feeling 'wasn't that just wonderful?'

Quintessentially English. This abbey, next to Parliament, houses more UK history that you can shake a stick at! Whether you know it from watching royal weddings, or you're more interested in centuries past, this church has something for everyone!

You've got to do this at least once!. I got tickets for Christmas and it was easy to get in (no queuing) and using the audio tour we could get the background on the key areas of interest. I think it's well worth a visit and something everyone should do at least once to appreciate the history.

Very disappointing. We wished to go into Westminster Abbey but at £20 for adult entrance we decided against it. To have to pay to go into a church seems wrong. We would happily make a donation but £40 was too steep to part with for walking around a building.
Mind Blowing. Took the official tour and well worth it. Very knowledgeable and informative a great day wort every penny.

It is a must in London. This is a beautiful church. The architecture, the labor that they put in to it is amazing. Tip: Get there around 4:30 pm and you will be treated to a beautiful mass and choir. It is close to the Parliament complex, and if you are riding the train, get off at the Victoria stop. This church is the central church for England and Wales, and it is the church for the royal weddings. There is no fee to get in. You can pay an guided tour if you want.
Another must see in London (my home town). Attended an Evensong to celebrate Singapore's 50th Anniversary of Independence in early August 2015. Exceptional visit to a fantastic and historic place.

Wonderful Place to visit. We decided to come here for a morning due to the heavy rain. I wasn't expecting much but i was pleasantly surprise, it was well organised and layout was good (if not very busy). The audio tour was excellent and very informative. If just a shame we went on a Monday when the Gardens are closed.
Awesome Gardens and fountains. This is a must see while traveling in London. What great history and views. Great gardens and fountains.

Very Historical with the Crown. Get there early, the lines get very long and they barely move. When it closes at 5, it closes whether you're waiting in line or not. Its located next to Parliment & Big Ben.

The gem in Westminster. If your a historian, it goes without saying you have to visit. If your not, or your just a fan of the recent marriage, or who may be buried in many of the tombs, you cannot ship this if your time permits. We used our London Pass for entry on a Saturday. Get there early, I would suggest an hour before the gates open. There is a dedicated "fast entry" line for London Pass holders unlike other sites. So this is where the Pass really comes in handy. You are afforded no photography inside so keep that in mind. Our self guided audio tour lasted about 2 hours, but you could go quicker or well longer based on your preference. They have a cafe and gift shop inside. When you're done you are literally across the street from Westminster Pier, Parlament, Big Ben and the River Thames. Such a great area not to miss is Westminster.

A time to be born and a time to die. This is a one-of-a-kind. This Royal church is at once so English and so universal. It shelters almost one thousand years of Catholic and especially Anglican church history and yet contains a statue of Martin Luther King as well as Russian Orthodox icons. It is stunning as tradition and as promise. It is beautiful and inspiring.
Arrive early. This is a fascinating stop with a lot to take in. It gets crowded so buy a London Pass to skip some of the wait. It gets hot in the summer, so plan to arrive early.

Captivating and inspiring - the story of Britain.. Never got in the abbey in four previous visits so we were hoping it would live up to the expectations. Needn't have worried - it really is a magnificent experience. If you want to purvey a carefully constructed national identity then come here to commemorate poets, soldiers, saints, explorers and kings. Take it all in - there are few places like this anywhere else, it's definitely one of Europe's top historical venues.

Expensive beauty. The Abbey is clearly a beautiful place, steeped in history, with many historical figures buried in the Abbey itself. However it must be said that at £20 per adult it is one of the most expensive sites we have been to.
History about the Crown. as a History lover, I loved this place. The guided tour about coronation history is amazing. And the Abbey is just beautiful. It worth every penny.

Don't Miss the downtown abbey. This is a London must see. So much history is contained in one building that it can be overwhelming. The narration on the headsets by Jeremy Irons is excellent and questions can be asked of the helpful docents. If you think you have a relative buried there they will check for you. Admission is reasonable.

Too busy. When paying money to go in to somewhere like this you would expect them to have a limit as to the amount of people allowed in at one time. If they do have said limit then it seriously needs rethinking.My partner and I, having never been before were really excited. Upon arrival that excitement soon turned in to disappointment due to the amount of people inside. I'm sure the Abbey is lovely but, being unable to see anything due to the mass of people inside I am unable to comment on this. We pretty much paid £40 just to be crushed by other people and stuck in long queues. Very disappointing.
Another place you must go. I could probably say that you can't miss this and that, but in London you should not miss anything, and Westminster Abbey it's one of those places

Blown Away. It is always humbling to visit Westminster Abbey and I was able to take my boys to also witness this historic and remarkable cathedral. Plan to spend some time here to really appreciate all the history and the sites. It does get crowded.
Westminster Abbey. This was an humbling, sacred experience. I wish I had been able to attend a worship service during my visit. Rich with history concentrated in one venue! loved it.

Beautiful!. Wesminster Abbey is a must do in London (especially because is so close to many Landmarks). If you can see it at night (as with many London monuments) you should it is especially beautiful.

A famous place for many reasons. It was amazing to visit Westminster Abbey. The entire building is larger than we imagined, although the main sanctuary was smaller than it appeared on television. The ancient tombs and monuments inside were very interesting. We were disappointed that we could not take pictures inside--but we respect the reasons for that restriction. It was very touching when the loud speaker requested a few minutes of silence throughout the building as a passage was read and a song was sung. It was a good reminder that this is a house of worship, and not just an attraction.

Big place MASSIVE RIP OFF. We visited London for the day on an organised coach party and we had some time spare so we went to the Abbey. It cost us £20 EACH to get in and the ticket only lasts for the day. We did not have enough time to do the whole abbey. This is such a RIP OFF. UK residents should have free entry or at least your ticket should last for 12 months as most places do now. We have been to some of the biggest religious places in the world and paid NOTHING to enter, it is a place of worship for 'gods' sake! No wonder the C of E are one of the most richest organisations in the world.

Awe-inspiring, huge cathedral. It was busy when we visited, but there were plenty of volunteers in red outfits to help us. During our visit, they asked people to stop and either pray or meditate for one minute on a subject the announcer suggested. This was so much better than in other churches where they keep repeating "silence" over a speaker. As tourists, we should respect these holy places with our silence, but when our visit is continually interrupted by someone on a speaker reminding us, it is actually disruptive. Westminster's approach reminded us that we were in a holy place, and the purpose of being in the church is to pray. It is a beautiful place, with so much history--don't miss it!

Cool architecture and the gargoyles are watching you!. Such a great place to look at but had just been to the Dommos in Italy so I think my expectation level was so high. With so much to see in London and we had so much fun for 3 days that this just fell lower on our like list.

Don't miss Westminster Abbey!. . Westminster Abbey is rated one of the top attractions in London and for good reason. I was very impressed by the architecture and history.. The ticket line was long, however, it moved quickly The audio guide and staff members were very helpful. If you are visiting London for the first time, I would put this venue near the top of your list of things to do.

Awesome seeing the burial places for famous people. We spent several hours enjoying the beautiful sculptures, historic crypts, architecture and the phenomenal preservation of history. It was interesting seeing the church of royal weddings and coronations. We ate lunch there and the risotto was fabulous!
Excellent Attraction.. So much history it is difficult to take it in. A little difficult for disabled people to get into some areas but most things are doable.

It's amazing - pricey but worth it . I went with my 11 year old. It was £20 for me and £9 for 5 a 16 year olds. You get a lot. Audio guides are included. The history the amazing building the tombs - Kings and queens are buried here. Shakespeare is buried here, thousands of people at buried here. So many wonderful stories. I would most likely skip it if my kids were younger or at least go in alone. Between this and the tower I need to re-watch some movies on this period.
Just go allready. For Christ sake, you don't go here and your in London your brain dead. Too much history/architecture/sculptural interest to bother mentioning.

Amazing Architecture and History Behind This Place. It's amazing to see a building that has so much rich history in it. The architecture and design of the church is simply amazing. The admission price is a bit heavy but worth it.

Amazing visit!. We had no idea the history that is contained in this church! The Audio guide really helped provide historical and cultural info. Definitely plan to go if you are in London. Fascinating walk though British royal history and we learned so much.A long line to get in mostly regarding security(even though we were there before the doors opened). We had a London Pass to cover the entry fee and had a separate line for entry from the ticket sales.

If You Have Only a Day or Two. Don't miss a visit to Westminster Abbey. The history found in that one place is staggering. Do yourself a favor and take the audio tour. It's well done and will help point out features you might otherwise miss due to the crowd shuffling you about.

Memorable Visit in July. Visiting the Abbey was one of the highlights of our London trip. It was far more grand, beautiful and fascinating that we imagined. There is simply too much history to absorb during a brief visit, but reading in advance of our trip made it more meaningful and I am still reading about it now that I am home again. It was very crowded in London in July, and the Abbey was no exception. We bought our tickets online before we left home, which was a great timesaver, and we arrived as soon as the Abbey opened, and were able to enjoy it before the tour buses started arriving around 10 or 11.

Lovely visit - take the audio guide!. This was a great site worth visiting, as it was quite large and included int he London Pass. We used the audio guide which really added value to our visit, and taught us a lot about the history of the place.

Attend mass. I attended the mass here with the Mayor of Westminster. I didn't know that before hand. Only saw soldiers lined up outside the church. At the end of the service, Her Lady shook hand with all the visitors. The church choir is amazing.

Start early and spare sufficient time if you're a History junkie!. Visited the Abbey at 9.30am (which is when they open) and it was the best decision ever. There were less than 15 people inside and with the free-audio guide I could spend a lot of time inside without being pushed around. Closed for visits on Sunday.

A memorial to virtually all of English history. How can one visit London without paying respects to the many that are buried and/or memorialized here? So much history in such a wonderful place. The electronic guides are helpful but it is also fun to randomly walk from famous name to famous name.
So much to see!
Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey is a must see for anyone going to London...the old stately buildings are very nostalgic of Old London.

Worth the Effort. We enjoyed the Abbey twice during our visit by attending the early Sunday services then taking the full tour on Monday.
Outstanding.
Used our 3 day London pass.
Skip the tour companies and go at your own pace.
The Abbey can easily occupy your attention for 3+ hours.
Amazing place. . Lucky enough to be there at noon time when a service is preformed everyday. The Abbey is amazing. The history is unbelievable.

Centuried old Cathedral. While on a tour of London, we stopped at Westminster Abbey. It's as stunning as the pictures describe.We elected not to go in as the queues were terrible and it was a spur of the moment to stop there

Not much to say. To be honest I didn't enter so I can't tell you if it is beautiful inside. Outside I can say is an beautiful piece of history. The people that I know they said is amazing inside but for the huge amount of money you need to pay for you to enter they prefer St. Pauls Cathedral (again I just speak in behalf of others).The only advise I can give is first just try to find some deals in the internet like gropoun.co.uk because some time they have some cool discounts and at list you can enjoy the outside view how is amazing and in the left side of the abbey you have a small church that is absolutely incredible and its free, one of the most beautiful churches I ever been. Please go their is free and you probably going to enjoy more than the abbey and have a lot of history attach too.

Amazing magical. The fellowship at a service filled with strangers were not strangers during the service at all. . Your trip is not complete if you don't attend service walk slowly during your stay drink in all the beauty . I love London but Westminster Abbey is my special place just for me time it's just magical
Well worth a visit. Worth a visit to the Abbey. Relaxing place to sit and think of how lucky we are to be in London and see such wonderful places from centuries ago.

Fascinating.. Westminster Abbey had so much to discover! The architecture is beautiful, and the atmosphere does feel very reverent- a nice break from the busy chaos of London's streets. Swimming through the crowds got frustrating at times, especially as there were a lot of slow-moving tour groups to navigate around. Also note that there is no photography allowed- I would've loved some interior photos to show friends and family back home, but it did force me to put the camera down and appreciate my surroundings more. Other than those two cons, it was an interesting and enlightening visit that I'd recommend to anyone!
Do not miss this high point!. Very impressive architecture and full of history and wonders. So many famous people are buried there.

Arrive early!!!!. We loved walking through the abbey and seeing all the history. I don;t like history or museums, but the church history here was very cool. I was surprised by the number of people buried there and the huge amount of things to see. I originally just though it would be another old church to tour, but was pleasantly surprised at how great it was. Do arrive early before opening so the line is not too long and it is not too crowded inside.

Awfull experience . The Abbey is fantastic, but the staff is angry and agressive. I had to answer my phone (which was on buzzer only) a couple of times, and was approached by a man with a red cape. He accussed me of having taken photos inside the Abbey. He demanded to see my phone and my photos. I denied since my photos is a private matter. Je was Them veru agressive
Beautiful!!. Loved it. What I really liked was the history associated with it and its calmness. Its architecture was a sight to behold.
Church service at the cathedral.. We went in late July, later in the evening on a Thursday. We were able to attend service at the Cathedral. It was amazing.

Resting place of many historic figures. Was really impressed with all we had to see though I was a little disappointed that we did not get to see a number of things that where pictured in a flyer. Loved the medieval contribution to this church. Would be best to go at a quieter time as very over crowed and rather expensive which would mean many would miss out and being a church it doesn't gel with me being a house of god.
Stunning.. Stunning! So full of history.....loved every twist and turn! So much to see and take in, do not miss while you are in London!

A world Treasure!. One of the greatest historical sites anywhere, I've visited the Abbey many times. On this occasion we joined a "London Walks" tour which is a good way to avoid the lines at the general entrance. On a cool rain with unusually heavy rain, the Abbey was packed with people. Our guide did an admirable job of moving our group of 12 past the highlights of the Abbey and then providing us with helpful advice on what we could see on our own afterwards. The Abbey is a world treasure-not to be missed even if you only have a couple of days in London.

Fabulous church. Such a beautiful site. The church is divided into several sections of smaller chapels containing lovely tombs, statues and stained glass windows. The audio guide is wonderful and is narrated by Jeremy Irons! The admission cost is 20 Pounds ($43.80Aus). No photos allowed. The large open chapel of Henry VII is breathtaking with georgeous knight banners hanging from the ceiling. A small museum is in the corridor on the left, as you exit, and contains some very interesting burial effigies. A gift shop adjoins the church.
Why ? . It is historical place and worth the visit but u have to pay around 20 pound but in sundays it is free for people to pray and worship god . And the fast track line took 50 min 😩
Do it once, then go to St Pauls.. Beautiful building, a massive amount of history, but very busy I found which prevents you from really taking it in and reading the tombs and information plaques.

Beautiful, rich with history. Also crowded.. I love Westminster Abbey, and would suggest it to anyone traveling to London. Pick up an audioguide or follow a Rick Steves guided tour (I swear by them!) and you'll get so much out of it. Plan to spend at least an hour there.It's very, very crowded there, so travelers may find it difficult to sit and reflect. The best part are the walkways around the courtyard-- less people, great architecture, and a true feeling of being back in time. Bathrooms are lacking-- long lines outside for portable toilets. Fee is expensive (I paid $117 for four people).

Don't miss it!. Everything happens in this amazing abbey. royal marriages, buryals and coronations, it's a famous film location, resting site of many scientists, poets and philosophers.Arrive early and buy your tickets on the Internet, because it's always crowded.
Worth the architecture. Little bit pricey but the architecture is worth commending . Full of history and most enjoyable when in groups.

Impressive church and it's on the London Pass!!. We took the DLR from Greenwich, to the tube, to the Westminster station. As you get off the station, right there in front of you is where Big Ben is housed, House of Parliament, and Westminster Abbey. It is a sight you cannot describe. I took so many pictures of that sun coming up over those building that everyone is going to be sick seeing it. We walked on to Westminster to utilize our London Pass. We were fast tracked in, and on our way with the audio guide. I encourage people to get this audio guide because it was extremely informative, and very user friendly. The map they provide also assist with the guided tour nicely. There are no photographs allowed in the Abbey. It is so overwhelming with all the people around you, and looking in every direction (including down) that it can be over stimulating. The architecture if phenomenon and just takes your breath away. Knowing that so many famous people have stood where you are at, that so many royalty – including monarchs – have gotten married there that the history alone is just humbling. All the tombs of famous people like – Lewis Carrol, Chaucer, Queen Mary of Scotts, Queen Elizabeth I, William Bennet, and there’s a poet’s corner commemorating several incredible authors of our time. There is a list of all the famous people buried there on the Abbey’s website.

Expensive to See. We were keen to see Westminster Abbey. A big cathedral with beautiful architecture outside. A huge line of people waiting to get in. Tickets were 20 Pounds to get in which is horrendous when all other cathedrals I've visited are FREE.

Loved the experience !!!. This is a must see.. It was a amazing tour loved every bit of the tour. And as it was a audio tour I was able to go at my own pace.. There is so much history it was amazing to see.

Where you realize the Greatness of Great Britain memory. It is enough to say that Queen Elisabeth I, King Henry V, Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Laurence Olivier are here, as well as Poets Corner with Milton and Longfellow. The Throne of the Edward the Confessor is also there and many other not to be missed points.The main point for me is that the Westminster Abbey is in the row, not only British heritage but the whole world. So, I strongly recommend to go there and salute the contemporary world great ancestors Sincerely Yours,Artur
Beautiful architecture! . Lovely building to take pictures of! Obviously the history of the building is what's most interesting about it. Worth a visit nice way to spend some time.
Impressive place!. Except the price, the Westminster Abbey is a beautiful cathedral. For me, the most impressive place was the Isaac Newton tomb.
Weekend break to London.. Visited Saturday 22nd August 2015, beautiful building, worth seeing if just for the architecture, full of history and most enjoyable.

Rather pricey entrance fee for a Church!. Though Westminster Abbey might rank as a bastion and a reference point in the history of the Church of England, charging 20£ per person is a rather pricey option for a tourist who comes to London . As everyone knows, London in 2015 is a very expensive city and tourists who come to London,alone or with friends and family, irrelevant of their income, spend proportionately a substantial amount of their money on food, transportation, shopping, museums.Now,in all sincerity and with all due respect to the beauty of Westminster Abbey,neither Notre Dame...Sacre Cœur in Paris, nor any of the Basilicas in Rome come close to "imposing" on a visitor such a high 20£ entrance fee.In a time and age where religion should be available to anyone who seeks it and who seeks to visit masterpieces of Religious History and Art, charging 20£ is simply "a bit too much".

Terrific, take your time there. We took the kids to the Abbey. What are terrific way to take a stroll through history, literature, the sciences, etc. You could spend many hours there talking about the many known people buried there not to mention the royalty crowned there. A must-see!
Very interesting. One of England's finest religious buildings well worth the visit. Stepped in history you need to see it to believe.
The Power of ancient architecture. It's imponent. Each meter has a symbol of history and religion. Loved to see the tumule of Elizabeth I "the golden age queen". Fantastic.

Visit the Abbey and attend a service. This is a beautiful cathedral and I am sure you will want to visit it. I suggest that you visit the cathedral by attending one of their Sunday services. You not only get a chance to see the interior of the cathedral, but you get to participate in the service. They are very welcoming to all faiths. We attended the Sunday 10:00 Matins. This is an hour long service sung by an outstanding choir mixed with some short sermons. We got there about twenty minutes early and, much to our surprise, got a seat in the Choir section next to the singers and close to the speakers. It was a memorable and moving experience.This is what we consider to be religious tourism and we have done it all over the world. You not only get to enter the church at no cost but you get to participate. It really worked out well here. It is so much better than chasing around taking photos in a crowded church.

The place where British monarchs are coronated. I have visited this place inside. Lots of kings' tombs as well as tombs of well-known poets, composers and scientists - Hendel, Newton, etc. Also, this is the place were you can see the coronation throne of British kings and queens.

A History Lesson. A history lesson about England, Britain and The Church! It's not cheap but its well worth it. Get an audio guide, it's a must for this beautiful Abbey, you will walk past some amazingly interesting things if you don't have an Audio guide. The Architecture is beautiful. See the seat that every King and Queen to have ruled has been ordained on, since the 10th century! Like I said a history lesson!

Under construction . It is nearby to many things, including transport and other attractions. When I went it was under construction so there were huge sections of it which were covered up, which was a little disappointing. I didn't go inside as there was a fee, however it is free to view the outside of it and there is a church right next door which was free.
Ancient Church. Its unique church famous for royal wedding. We visited since it is covered in London pass otherwise found little costly. Audio guide provided there was usefull.

A MUST-GO!. You cannot go to London without going to Westminster Abbey. The centuries of history within the walls of this Gothic Cathedral are not to be missed. If you are a person of history, science, and the humanities this place will astound you as you take in the architecture and view the many memorials of the great souls that fill this church. Go on a weekday when it first opens in the morning and you will find it less crowded. Get a London Pass and the entrance fee is included.

Hope you have patience. . Even with the London Pass, it was about a 45 minute wait to get in. Tons of people inside made it hard to get around. They prohibit picture taking inside, which is a huge bummer, but plenty of people were doing it anyway. We had no idea it was a virtual cemetery surrounding the main Abbey. Loaded with history and very interesting. I would definitely recommend it, but bring your patience with you! It's possible that it was just a busy time of year that we visited.

No Other Place Like It In The World!. Have visited it 2 previous time, but don 't think I could ever see everything. Always learn some I didn't learn previously. So much awesome history here! Can not believe how many historical figures are buried there! Don't know why, but I remember the Poet's Corner more from the past visits! Please don't miss a visit to this!

Wonderful- Where kings and queens are made and the royal wedding take place. It is majestic and beautiful inside. The inside layout and decor is interesting. See the chair and throne of England where royal is made. Espically good for those not bringing small children.

Lovely and intersting. A lovely old church with lots of history. I found the tombs and memorials to be fascinating, but it is debatable whether the crowds and the price make it worth it.I purchased an inexpensive walking tour of the Abbey from London Walks which was also supposed to save me something on the admission. I didn't realize that it only knocked about a pound off the entrance fee, and for the price reduction, the Abbey doesn't give you one of the audio guide gadgets. So I guess it depends on whether you prefer fixed pace with a live tour guide that you can ask questions of or a program that you can listen to at your own pace.But you need either the audio guide or a live guide in order to appreciate what you are seeing.It did seem that at the price they were charging, they could provide better facilities than the unisex bathroom in the trailer outside.Bottom line, it's crowded and over-priced but probably a must-see if you have any interest at all in British history.
Blew my mind. This is totally worth it. The tour is very complete and extensive and from all the churches I've been it's the one that allows so close access to everything.

Impressive but Boring. How can you visit London and not visit Westminster? It's one of those tourist traps everybody is familiar with back home. However, the hefty entrance fee might be cause for second thoughts. I'm a Christian and love the church, but all the tombs within the beautiful architecture seemed a bit worldly and self gratifying. Would not recommend

England's Most Important Gothic Cathedral. This was my 3rd visit to Westminster Abbey. Being inside a magnificent Gothic cathedral whose construction began in the 1200s and took a few hundred years, never ceases to amaze me. What wonderful architecture men built without the high tech engineering tools of today, and built to last centuries! This Cathedral was a setting for many of England's coronations, royal weddings and royal burials. The unique feature of this Gothic Cathedral is the number of important English persons buried or memorialised here, including Edward the Confessor, Ann of Cleves, Mary I, Elizabeth I, Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, Goeffrey Chaucer, Rudyard Kipling. I find it fun to look for names of persons I remember from history or literature.
Excellent. This place is amazing....History all around with audio guides available but the price...is a bit expensive...
Expensive but extensive. There was quite a bit of detail in the audio tour. Plan to take at least an hour if not more. The entrance was about 20 pounds per person.

Double standards. Went here with my daughter. Shocked at entry fee price. A minister stood up in the pulpit, told us all to be quiet then delivered a pompous speech about how the abbey was all about Christianity. Ok then, give me my thirty quid back! Go via the sanctuary arch at the side of the abbey then you can visit the cloister and chapter house for free. These are the best parts as the abbey itself is a strange place stuffed with tombs, and thousands of jostling tourists. They actually have collection boxes inside, I noticed these appeared to be empty, presumably nobody had any change left. Here's another idea, fix the toilets!

Worth It. I was hesitant when I saw the price of admission. Once we got inside, I forgot the price. It came with one of the audio guide gadgets so we could get info on some of the sites inside the building. It was very informative. I was truly awed by the grandeur of the place. The art and sculptures were amazing. The rest of our group wasn't interested in 'boring' stuff so they didn't come with us and I definitely wouldn't bring children on this.
