It is a church and the atmosphere is a bit somber (there are tombs everywhere). The beauty and history of the place was breathtaking.

Thousand years of history in one place. Books are written about this site. A thousand years of history is inside. You must go inside to absorb the meaning and grandure. Kings, Queens, poets and many famous people are honored here. If you can only visit one place while in London, this is the place.

Worth a look. Lots of history we took the Audio tour, got there early line was not too bad alternatively get there late lines are quite quick to get in I was told by a chap that had been there before, give your self at least 2 hrs to take it in.
Awe-inspiring Visit. Beautiful space for pagentry! Full of lovely art! Take time to walk around in every nook as there is much to be discovered and appreciated.
Gothic masterpiece.. Excellent Gothic design, well preserved and maintained. It is a burial ground of several dozens of famous historical figures.

Simply and amazing place. As impressive as Westminster Abbey is on the outside, it's even more impressive on the inside. Touring this landmark takes you on a walk through history from monks to monarchs. Yes, it was crowded, and the London Pass did help getting in. Follow the audio tour, study and admire the artwork and appreciate the efforts that have survived centuries. Since it is still a church at the root, I understand the prohibition on photography.

Awe-inspiring church. There are no words to do this justice. It was as amazing as I'd hoped. One thing that surprised me was that there are no pictures allowed, so take this into consideration when planning souvenirs. ;) Also, there's a tour guide path, but you are also free to go out of line. We wanted to see Poets' Corner first, and a docent escorted us right to it.

More than I expected. I've been here twice. The first time, I just wandered around noting all the historical tombs. It is a beautiful place, and I enjoyed it. The second time I came, I came with a purpose....I discovered that several ancestors of mine are interred here. I recommend doing a little reading about those who are buried here before going. I think it helps one understand the historical significance of this place. The second time, I spent no less than 2 hours wandering in and out of all the little chapels. It is nothing short of mind blowing to see all the intricate carved details of the sculptures and the ornate design of England's past monarchs' effigies. The guides are extremely helpful, and were genuinely excited that I brought bits and pieces of my family tree for reference. They all had extensive knowledge of each person, and even made note that I resemble a few effigies. They were wonderful. I have to admit that I walked around a good part of the day looking up with my mouth dropped open in utter amazement. This place is well preserved, and to know you are walking amongst some of the most powerful and notable people in history, and that you are standing in the very place that history was founded upon and the very place that marriages were held that changed the course of history is almost overwhelming. Do a little homework. Ask questions. Reflect on the signifigance. :) and also please note: pictures are not allowed...and if you attempt to take them, you will be swiftly corrected.
Wonderful tour. I'd been years ago but the audio tour ( included in the price of admission)was a wonderful addition and helped understand what we were seeing

Absolutely beautiful. Words can't even describe how amazing this location is. If sight seeing in London, you cannot miss Westminster! We went on a Wednesday when they are open late. I had read in advance this is the best way to avoid lines, but we didn't have to worry. We were there in late March, before the heavy tourist season and walked right in. If you are able to go outside of the summer, I would definitely recommend that. Not just for this location, but anywhere in London. We did not encounter lines anywhere we went.

Tourist Friendly. The price includes the audio guide. It takes about 2 hours to walk through the building and listen to the guide. I was told I couldn't take pictures which was disappointing. Good to see the structure is kept in good condition.@instabuilt

Because you just have to experience it.. It's Westminster Abbey, you just have to experience the aura and wonder of this place.Get there early, wait in line, take the guided tour, then hang out and imagine all the history and emotion that went through these doors.

Overpriced and crowded. The signs forbidding cameras were very small and placed on poles about chest high. It was so crowded we didn't see them and we weren't given a map when we came in. My daughter had her cell phone in her hand and was treated rudely by a man wearing a clerical collar and red robe. He yelled at her telling her to put it away. We just left. As we were leaving we saw people taking photos. I'm not sure if the man was having a bad day but his behavior is just not acceptable.

MUST SEE. we didn't buy tickets in advance and showed up in the middle of july... aka SUPER BUSY. the line was wrapped around the block (beyond the fence)... we were a little concerned and you might be too, but DON'T be...the line moves quickly!! i was trying to tell my cousin...oh maybe it isn't that cool inside and she was like no we are definitely going in...and i was SOOO glad we did. get the free audio guide.

Impressive beyond words. Westminster Abbey is impressive beyond words. The visit takes you for a walk down England's history. It houses the tombs of some of our greatest and well known kings and queens and others and also commemorations to some of the country's greatest figures from the arts, literature, science and engineering. There is an admission charge of £20, but less for concessionaries, children and families. You can queue for a few minutes to gain admission so choose a quiet time to visit if you can. Opening times vary, but it is generally open from 9.30am to 3.30pm most days. Spend at least 3 hours there to do justice to the visit. If visiting London it should be at the top of your list of attractions! It really is fantastic!

Peaceful even with the crowds. Be sure to get there early to avoid the longest lines. Even first thing you'll be waiting for a while. So many wonderful spaces on the tour but be sure to save some time at the end for the Poets Corner and the gardens. Just an aside, you basically have to leave the Abbey to find a bathroom so try to take care of that beforehand!
Westminster Abbey quick lines. Interesting place to visit, lots of history. Less crowds about 10:00 am no need to buy advance tickets. Lines move fast.
Must see. One of the great tourist locations in the world. Stand amongst the great people in history, and where history was made. If you don't go you will regret it.

Wonderful for all ages. If you love your history come here. It's not just about religion it's our monarchy as well. Informative and exciting.
I am a Westminster resident so we can go for free with your ress card. Make sure you look around and read everything or you may miss something exciting.
The staff are friendly and more than willing yo help!!!

Awe-inspiring. I hadn't visited Westminster Abbey since I was a child, so i had no real memory of what it was like inside. I found it peaceful (in spite of the crowds - it does get busy!), and the architecture will take your breath away, especially the fan vaulted ceiling in the Lady Chapel. Nowhere else on earth can you literally stand beside kings and Queens - Elizabeth I, Bloody Mary, Mary Queen of Scots, Edward the Confessor and countless more are buried here, along with commemorations of a real "Who's Who" of the great & good. It feels like you are literally touching & breathing the history of Britain. I'd recommend booking online, for ease & speed of entry. Also download the app and free audio guide (voiced in the English version by Jeremy Irons - wonderful!) to your phone, and take your own headphones - otherwise noise from other people's audio guides is a real intrusion to your peace & tranquillity. A once-in-a-lifetime experience, truly memorable.

Very inspiring place to visit.. What ever you do get the London Pass and Museum pass.. this will save you a 2 hour wait in line to buy tickets. Go on line . It's worth it. This is an amazing space and beautiful both inside and out. Again little kids will get bored quickly but even middle school kids will be in awe of this space. IT is accessible but warm.. We were there in Aug. and it was HOT and sooo crowded. Go early I think it opens at 9:00 best time.

Wonderful visit during the musical prayer service.. I happened upon Westminster Abbey shortly before 5 PM. I was not aware of the prayer and music service taking place every day at 5 PM. Entry is free.A perfect way to see Westminster Abbey and enjoy the wonderful singing and music in the Abbey.

Worth the wait and the Money!. Ok so I'm not a world traveler, but this was Breath taking and a one of a kind! So much history and rich culture of England that you do not want to miss. Everyone and their dog is buried here. A truly must see

Lovely visit. It was lovely visit, please go there early as there was a line even the abbey was not even opened. Free audio guide is included and it's very informative for most of the tomb, must visit if you are in London!

Magnificent. As old and with as mush history as this place had, it is a MUST see of your in town. It's as magnificent inside as you see on TV and so much more. This history is everywhere and if you can take the time, you should explore every nook as you never know what or who you will find.

Incredible Experience. The whole of British History since 1066 under one roof. Absolutely stunning stained glass windows. Excellent and clear audio recording of the main features on individual devices. We also had the bonus of listening to a brass band concert in the Cloisters which was a perfect way to enjoy a summer's afternoon.
A UK tourist classic. Brilliant place to visit, wonderful building oozing with history. Had a lovely afternoon tea too (particularly impressed by the selection of excellent tea)!

Don't go via Westminster Bridge. After battling across Westminster Bridge against gambling opportunities every few yards as tourists are asked to guess which cup hides the ball for £20 a throw before being fleeced of their money; my friends and I arrived at Westminster Abbey to see that the admission charge is £20 per head. Such irony!I am pleased to see so many positive reviews of inside the Abbey but if you do go avoid the Bridge!

The Abbey itself is beautiful. We didn't go inside because it was so busy, queues were very long. We also thought it was a bit expensive. The Abbey is so beautiful, we were happy to photograph the outside and visit the souvenir shop. The souvenir shop had a huge range but like the entry ticket to the Abbey was a little expensive and similar items could be purchased elsewhere for less.

History under your feet. In here you can experience some of the most interesting stories about the people who help shape England, Europe and the World. You can choose to have the experience narrated by Jeremy Irons, highly recommended.
Lovely!!. The audio guides were very informative. A lovely abbey with a Huge amount of history mixed in. It is located near the Churchhill war room so you can combine these together in 1 day.

So fascinating!! My favorite tourist attraction in London!. Truly breathtaking! I had no i idea Shakespeare, Charles Darwin, and many other famous authors scientists, King and Queens and notable people were buried in this church. It is a must see!!

Wow!. What can you say about Westminster Abbey but WOW. Beautiful church, with stunning architecture. Audio tour gave so much information. Just beautiful to be in such a lovely old church with so much history. And being a fan of the monarchy, standing on those sites was kind of exciting for me. Did this as part of the London Pass, so were able to skip the lines and go right in.

Amazing!!!. Beautiful glass paintings, ceiling design and every single handcrafted details of statues, shrines and monuments show the England history :-) Full respect on how beautifully everything is preserved and presented!With the worship, it made me felt so peacefully and calmly.

Take one of the London Walks tours of Westminster - you skip the long line. We went in with one of the London Walks tours. You skip the long line and pay the reduced group rate entrance fee. Plus you get the London Walk guide to tell you what you're looking at. Check London Walks website

Go early to avoid the queues. Take the audio tour which explains the abbey in full rather than just walking around at your leisure. Does get busy therefore would recommend to get there early... a worth while attaction

Magnificent. Waited on a short line in the pouring rain. The attendant was nice and tried to get as many people in under cover as he could but the ticket takers were incredibly slow. This was an expensive site, but at least it included the audio guides. Some of the explanations were a bit too long for a few smaller more contained areas so created a bottle neck while people stopped to listen.Pretty amazing to see the resting place of Newton and Darwin and the poet's Corner where so many authors were commemorated. The building was beautiful...and busy. There were plenty of attendants throughout in case you had questions. Well organized. On the way out, someone started playing the organ - so haunting and amazing to be there with that music.You can't use the restrooms in the cafe unless you buy food, so the alternative is to go outside to some temporary bathrooms.
Worship at Westminster Abbey. If you wish to visit Abbey but do not want to pay 18 pounds, you could go there for the worship free (18:00 daily)

History Comes to Life. A must see in London as the Abbey is so closely aligned with the history of England. The audio tour comes with the admission but go ahead and take the guided tour as you will go in parts of the Abbey where the general public is not allowed to go.
Its good but costly. It takes approximately more than an hour. The architecture is very good, but we found it too be a little pricey.

Stunning building. It may not be the biggest abbey in Europe but it has to be one of the most beautiful opulent abbeys. The history of royal marriages and burials is far reaching. Kids will be bored so make a game and see if they can spot the hidden markings on walls etc.

Significant English History in the Beautiful Abbey. Westminster Abbey is one of the most important Gothic buildings in England. It is the place where many of the ‘significant’ people in English history are buried – Geoffrey Chaucer is buried in Poet’s Corner, Charles Dickens, Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin are also buried here. There are many others (hundreds), they are the ones I can remember. The Abbey has been the place of royal coronations since 1066 and seventeen past royals lie entombed here in the Abbey. Of course, more recently Prince William and Kate were married here (as well as Prince Andrew, Princess Anne, Margaret and the Queen less so recently). Twenty pounds is an expensive entrance fee but you are seeing significant history here and the audio is one of the best I’ve come across on my travels. It was very crowded when we went but still didn’t feel as cramped or disorderly as the Italian churches we visited. Westminster Abbey, sitting along side the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben is one of the truly iconic images of London. Unmissable.

Stunning. A must see when you go to London. Very touristy, but worth it. Most people relate Westminster to where Prince William and Princess Kate were married, but it is so much more. So many famous people buried there and the architecture is stunning.

Too much money. I have been to churches all over the world ,including St. Peter's in the Vatican and have never been asked to pay 25$ pp to enter . This is ridiculous and we refused to submit to this . Take pictures outside and save your hard earned money.

Let Jeremy Irons take you around the abbey. Wonderful tour of a wonderful place. Worth the money, although it is pricy. If you can't afford the tour, note that evensong is free. You can't wander, but you do get to go in. The narration on the headsets is by Jeremy Irons. He keeps the crowd moving and quiet. He is interesting, but doesn't go on too long. And did I say it is Jeremy Irons? We returned for evensong, which was lovely (and you need not be of the faith to enjoy it). We fully enjoyed our visits.

Great people in British history. Fast getting in thanks to London Pass 9audio guide is included). Too bad can't take pictures but I can understand why. Just too many people inside but it's summertime. Staff were very attentive to visitors whenever they have questions and available. Restrooms/ public loos a bit of a walk from the abbey. My son didn't bother coming back inside since he had to return the audioguide when he went to the restroom.

Great experience for history lovers. If you’re expecting any religious experiences in the Abbey, you may be disappointed as the place is packed with tourists. But if you consider Westminster Abbey as a kind of Museum devoted to the British history – you are not going to find any better! The graves and monuments of great Britons (and not only Britons) are telling you the great story of the Nation that changed the world forever. Excellent experience but only for those who come there with some knowledge of British history.

Astonishing. Impressive, majestic, expensive, unforgettable: it is worth the 20 pound admittance ticket and the queue. A gem of architecture, statues, tombs, history, special atmosphere will open to you as soon as you enter this magnificent building.Unmissable.

Take the time to go here!. So much history in one building. I was amazed at all the famous people who had been buried there. I recommend getting the audio guides as they give great information about each place in the abbey.
London Walks. I took a London Walks tour of Westminster Abbey and had fun and learned so much about England and her peopel

It was closed on Sunday, but we loved looking around the grounds and admiring the architecture. We wandered down to the area and were disappointed that we missed mass and the Abbey was closed. We really did enjoy wandering the grounds and enjoyed the architecture and views and gardens surrounding.

Resting place for so many people. Pretty good visit. There is a lot of history there as there is a lot of people resting there. More than I expected.
Visit goes smoothly even with lots of people.

A great place to visit. Worth the cost to visit. Steeped in history Westminster Abbey is a must to see. The audio tour was outstanding and the crowd control exceptional. Choose the day to visit as some areas are not always accessible. We visited on a Wednesday. Overall a great experience which opened our eyes to the history of the Abbey and the various kings and queens it commemorates, and other famous people.
Historic building. Did not go in, but impressive to walk by. Wandered aroundthe area and visited Westminster Abbey, Horse Guards parade, cenotaph,downing street

If you like artistic cementeries.... I've always wanted to visit the Abbey, so much history and personalities have walked on these floors!! I liked this place more than I thought but I also disliked it more than I thought and here is why.. I loved the historic, artistic, one of a kind place in which so many great decisions were given and taken by the bones buried in this place. Just feeling the energy from such leaders enchants you into a world of endless curiosity and once you are out you want to head to your books to find out more. Why would you hate it? As old as it is, and as important as it is, it is not a well maintained place, too dark, dusty, a cemetery converted into a world class landmark, and a little bit pricey for what you get. I have mixed feelings about it to be honest (as you can read) I would say, if you have the extra £20 and the extra day, go in, otherwise spend the £ mindfully in a delicious burger at burger and lobster. Mmmm yummii!

Amazing! Get a tour guide!. The architecture and history here is so overwhelming. The wait in line on Monday AM was only 25 minutes or so. If possible, go on the guided tour. I was dissappointed the rest of my group wanted to just go off on our own. I heard a guide describing different areas and it is mind blowing what they go into detail about. The audio they provide with the maps are also very informative. I was in awe of everything.

Awesome History. This is an absolute must see. I highly recommend investing in a London Pass which gives you admission to most of the popular attractions. This way you also bypass most lines. Otherwise, admission is 20 pounds.You are provided with an audio tour. It is breathtaking to walk amidst hundreds of years of history. My favourites were the tombs of Queen Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots in the Lady Chapel. Also, Poet's Corner, where Robert Browning, T. S. Eliot, Rudyard Kipling, Oscar Wilde and Dickens are buried, to name but a few.It was also thrilling to walk the aisle when Prince William and Kate walked to their wedding and Diana's funeral was held.

A trip down Britain's history. We recently visited the Abbey with my Ameriacn cousins - my first trip for over 30 years. Whilst access to some areas is no longer pemitted the guided tiour via headphones is well worth it and included in the entry fee.So many of our monarchs are buried here and when one adds the memorials in Statesmen's Corner, Scientist's Corner and Poets Corner you get a great insight into a colourful history.The architecture is inspiring and keep looking about you to take it all in.

Humbling Experience. Being an Anglican faithful, I was honoured to visit Westminister Abbey. It is a humbling experience and makes you appreciate more the sacrificies that were made in preserving the faith.

Get there early-impressive and crowded. This certainly is worth seeing and make sure to pick up the audio tour. Gorgeous and a great history lesson. Don't bother coming with small children - will be very boring.

evening song.. A must do in London! Go to Eveningsong for the best Choral performance! We could have stayed all night for this amazing service. The choir was like listening to angels sing and the Cathedral was unbelievable.

Of great historical interest due many important persons here. Besides seen the tombs/shrines for many great queens and kings, dating back 800+ years ago, it was also interesting to seek and find memorials for the many great minds of every discipline.
Utterly jaw dropping. To think of how old this is. To think of the many historic events held there. The guides are helpful and the inside is jaw dropping.

Absolutely stunning!!. Westminster Abbey is a must see in London! I suggest going early before the lines start getting too long. I believe it cost 20 pounds to get in, and you get a audio walking guide, which is really nice. There is so much history in this beautiful cathedral. One of my favorite was seeing the grave of the unknown soldier. So moving!

Awesome Tour. I've taken the tour twice now because I love it. My favorite parts are Poets' Corner and the tomb of Mary & Elizabeth.The tour of Westminster Abbey is a bit expensive, but I obviously feel like it is worth the price since I've taken it twice. The ticketed entrance is on the side, not the famous front. There are two lines: one is for those with a London Pass, the other is usually going down the sidewalk toward the Parliament buildings. The line moves pretty quickly, though.Included with the tour is an excellent audio guide. It has explanations for much of the history and items in the sanctuary. There are other areas/buildings that you can explore outside the sanctuary, but make sure you exit through the sanctuary in order to see the coronation chair.There is a cafe (and restrooms? I've never used them) on the premises. There is a gift shop that can be accessed from the outside without taking a tour. You will find it to the right of the famous front facade.

Don't miss out. Visited during a weekday in March. Short wait to enter. Audio tour was an excellent way to tour the Abbey. Go at your own pace and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. Make sure to stop by the café for tea and scones.

Great Historiical Site to See. Though some of the exterior was under renovation, we all still loved seeing this amazing sight. Plus, you are very close walking distance to the London Eye, which is another great to-do in London. I'm afraid of heights so I almost didn't go but hotel receptionist told me I would love it and she was right. Amazing views you don't get to see otherwise.

Beautiful!. We had our London pass and this was free with audio guide. If not you would pay 20GBP per person. It is a fascinating structure. Even if one is not religious, the building, the architecture, the history is incredible. Poets Corner, the Coronation throne, gardens, cloisters, memorials, chapels, sculptures make for a wonderful visit. We spent about 3 hours here and we could have spent more time here.

Westminster Abbey. We were too late to take a tour inside so were only able to see the cathedral from the outside. Even still, the architecture is incredible and its a must see in London. Will have to book a tour ahead of time on the next visit!

dont miss. Worth the rather long wait on line to see this magnificent piece of history. Be prepared..it can be crowded. Just go with the flow. Download the audio tour in advance on your phone to skip their large clunky recorded devices. No photos allowed.
Worth a visit. Slightly less busy than some of London's other iconic attractions but breathtaking and well worth it.

Worth the visit. On my last trip, our condo we rented was only a few blocks away so we passed by almost daily. Usually lines to get in, depending on the time of day and what season you go. We were there in September, so still a lot of tourists waiting in line. Worth the wait I will say, it doesn’t get much better than walking into Westminster. Not to mention the history behind such a place, definitely a must while in London.

Go for a service!. The heart of the Abbey is its worship life. Attending a choral evensong, as we did recently, is an unforgettable experience...turning what could seem to be a museum into the church that it properly is. Just listening to the echo of the choir as an anthem ends is a little taste of heaven! There is no charge for attending services at the Abbey.

Expensive but Amazing. Unfortunately too expensive for our family of 4 to go into but so pleased that we could kill two birds with one stone by attending a beautiful and moving Evensong Service and enter the Abbey. There are daily services held here which we would recommend. The stewards are quick (and a little rude) to push everyone out the door after the service. There is so much history here which is amazing. A beautiful place to visit.

Shocking prices!. We actually didn't go in because it was so expensive! £20 each! So we just took photos. I was really looking forward to seeing so many remarkable tombs of the great and the good so it was very disappointing. Good job we didn't come just for this!

Excellent...... ....... and well worth visiting. You will need the best part of a full day to see this attraction. So much history it really is fabulous, especially if you're British. Make sure you utilise the recorded guide/headphones.... extremely worthwhile and you move around at your pace, Must do if in London

Its worth a visit justto say you have been. Day trip to London and a visit was on the cards, its easy to get lost in time with these sort of historical places and time just flies past. would recommend a visit.

Timeless heritage. The Abbey is just so much of London that one cannot miss seeing it, ideally internally as well as externally.Simply amazing....and unbelievably beautiful, it can only touch you.There is an admission charge for entry, but even though some may feel it is high or unnecessary, remember that ancient buildings such as the Abbey require huge amounts of funding just to keep them standing, let alone open.It is a masterpiece and an accessible one. Its a MUST see.

A Place of Kings, and Queens, and others of signifigance. I was a little set back at the cost of admission to this church. Over $30 per person. Ouch. The much more expansive British Museum was free, but I guess you gotta know the church is going to burn you. That said, walking by, or over the resting place of so many that you have heard/read about all your life was a most interesting experience.

A Must See!. Westminster Abbey is a must see while visiting London. I suggest you buy your tickets ahead of time to avoid the long lines. We bought our tickets online and were able to skip ahead, which was incredibly useful on a very busy day. The audio guides were also helpful since there is a lot to know about the Abbey. We enjoyed our time there for sure!

Evensong service. The service was just enough for me on this first visit. It kept me from an additional expense and allowed me to view the stained glass, I must learn how that escaped Henry VIII's destructive measures, at sunset! Many statues cluttered the nave in which I was seated like a museum archive. The music was magnificent and I saw Sir Issac Newton's tomb on my way out.

Awesome Experience. I was in awe of the people who are buried within the Abbey. From my very favorite English queen (Elizabeth I) to authors the likes of Dickens and Chaucer. The art and architecture is absolutely stunning. The audio guides were both helpful and informative.

Get and Use the Audio Guide. We went on a rainy day afternoon and there was no queue at all which surprised us. The audio guides are free, get one and use it. I cannot imagine navigating this enormous place without one. We spent about two hours. Fascinating history, architecture, and crypts.

Awe Inspiring!. Even though it is a pricey place to visit, Westminster Abbey is worth every penny (or GBP). Plan on spending at least a couple of hours exploring this beautiful and ancient Abbey. It was a most enjoyable morning.

Amazing building. Westminster Abbey is an amazing building full of history and beauty. Luckily I did not have to queue for long to get in and I did think that £17 entrance for a senior was a little expensive, but it is a must see in London.

Londons greatest Abbey. Every one going to London should visit Westminster Abbey. It is truly a magnificent building & is very close to the Houses of Parliament & the Clock tower The correct name for what most people call Big Ben which in fact the name of the movement that runs the magnificent clocks in the Clock Tower. As for the stunning Westminster Abbey it is amazing to see some of the greats of England's past who were buried there. And the other reason is I was christened there so please do not miss it on your great trip to truly one of the worlds greatest cities.

A Historic Visit !!!. A cathedral to visit and a must see on a trip to London. Feel the presence of past royal events, Kate & William's wedding, The Queen's Coronation and her wedding and all else that has been there. The architecture is stunning. The vaulted ceiling is outstanding. Best time to visit is in the AM and mid week. No photos allowed but see it all with just your eyes. A great gift shop is available. Go and enjoy this famous and historic place. The London Pass is accepted here.

Majestic and moving. The feelings of awe start at the queue...well worth the standing on line. Use the time to look up and absorb the majestic abutments and spire. Inside - take the time to look into all the nooks ans crannies. Better still - go on a London Walks tour of the Cathedral to get more of the underlying stories.This ancient building never gets old. I keep coming back every time I'm in the area.
An all day stop. What an amazing Abbey. So much history and so much to see. Bring your walking shoes and take your time. You can be here all day. Take the tour.

Wow!. Beautiful buildings - the tour (solo with headset & map), was perfect! What an amazing place. We waited in line about 20 minutes and with all the people going inside, you expected it to be more congested. It wasn't - it was so spacious that you never felt crowded at all. Truly gorgeous!

A must-see. I have visited Westminster Abbey on three occasions. In the middle of January, it is a nice retreat from the cold weather and noisy traffic outside. Famous for royal weddings, the Abbey is a pretty cathedral. It is located in a busy area surrounded by other monuments. One of the teenagers travelling in my group this year needed to be taken to a nearby hospital while she was in the Abbey and the Abbey staff were so helpful. They provided a wheelchair and flagged a taxi on the busy road outside.

lovely. visited here while visiting london. we hadn't planned to go in however we had some spare time. we did not expect to have to queue for half an hour but it was something i wanted to see so we did. the entrance fee was quite expensive i would rather have a lower fee then the option to donate money at the end of the visit. while inside i found it quite peaceful and calming considering how busy it was but everyone seemed to respect the fact it was a religious venue and to be quiet. what i did not like is everyone going around with the audio tour things as they just seemed to get in peoples way when they stopped to listen to what it was saying i thing guidebooks are a better option. also after seeing pictures and watching events on the tv using the abbey as the location such as they royal wedding it was not what i was expecting inside such as all the barriers us and the hideous glass box around the main exit door which was the door used for the wedding entrance it just made the place look awful and takes away the beauty that is the historical abbey but i did enjoy my visit and would go back but maybe at a less busy time to avoid the queues and all the people using the awful audio guides. i also did not think having a cafe or a restaurant was needed especially where they were located as it seems disrespetful(near all the tombs in the crypt)
Great View. Their is lots of history and a great place to see, but can be extremely crowded and hard to see some parts of it.

Iconic with a lot of history.. Out of all the places in the Westminster area, this is probably one that everyone should go to. The Abbey itself is beautiful and the history associated with it is also incredible. There is plenty of history here and I would recommend that you download the phone app so you can listen to the history as narrated by Jeremy Irons. Make sure to go to all the little gardens all around the Abbey as they are also a site to see.
Spectacular . Walking thru history. Use the headset to guide you're your. lf your interested there is services to go too. So much history and beauty.

Chock full of history. Westminster Abbey is a must see attraction in London. It is a beautiful building full of history and culture. Do not overlook the museum, which is attached to the Abbey. It contains a number of effigies of famous people including Admiral Nelson and Charles II. The Abbey also has a restaurant which serves excellent food.

History & Architecture. A worthwhile tour to take in the architecture of this old building along with the history that goes with it. Was quite busy would recommend going early to try and avoid the queues.
A must see. If you think about it, it's a church and crypt. It feels like you are walking on dead people. But the architecture is breathtaking. Well worth the wait in line to get in

Awesome but some unannounced closing. We made two visits trying to get in to Westminster Abbey. Both times there were special events going on which were not preannounced anywhere. We were not able to enter. Luckily, we had been in many years before. Even just from the outside, it's very awesome and majestic. Try to go early for slightly less of a huge crowd.

Poet's Corner! . The Abbey is architecturally stunning, with its great arches and stained glass windows. The Royals and related buried in the Abbey's floor and the shrines and fence guarded graves are something to see. No pics allowed, so be sure to visit the gift shop for some postcards.

History and Tradition Abound!. Of course one expects Westminster Abbey to be gorgeous and impressive, but I'm happy to say that this landmark delivers the full weight of English tradition and then some. We were dazzled by the architecture, impressed by the history, and delighted by the care and attention to detail that makes this a wonderful site to visit. We went on a London Walks tour of Westminster Abbey, and do recommend a guided tour if it's your first time. Or even if it's your hundredth and you've never had a guided tour! It's full of history in every nook and cranny, and so worth your time and attention. We also recommend attending a Sunday service to experience the best of Westminster.

tourist trail. We were too late to get in as we arrived just before closing time and the queue was huge. But even from the outside it is very impressive and you walk where the great and the good walk when you see them on tv

Too Massive to Take in During One Visit. We arrived ticketless and at first joined the wrong queue. There is a separate queue for London Pass Holders and ours had run out. Once sorted out the line moved quickly but as always, get there early as Westminster is so very popular. We opted for the free audio tour as opposed to the guided tours. During a previous off season the guided tours made sense but with the crowds it was better to move at your own pace. I met a local vicar who gave me some great background on certain things, a very nice man who spends a week at The Abbey offering the daily prayers. There is so much to see that you can get overwhelmed but take your time and take it all in.We had a nice breakfast(actually elevensies) at their restaurant and it's a nice break
Historical Church. Anyone who visits London needs to visit Westminster Abbey. The site is well preserved and still a working church.Be prepared to stand in long ques.
Fascinating Place. I don’t have words to describe the feeling of standing in front of Westminster Abbey. Very nice building and the area surrounding that place is fascinating.

Most impressive!. I know I say this a lot in my reviews but get here Early!!! You want to be able to enjoy the well done audio guide and see everything before the swarms of people make it impossible. We used the London pass and arrived 15 minutes before opening time and the cue was already quite long. The history, architecture, and structure is incredible. The building is not terribly stroller friendly and especially when seeing the side chapels, my spouse and I rotated going in to see everything. Besides that, this is a must see!!

Historic gen. Full of so much history. If you have any interest in English royal history this is probably the number 1 place to visit. The atmosphere, architecture and obviously the contents are all incredible. Recommend reading up before hand to make the most of your visit.

Westminster Abbey; a must to visit.. I have twice attended memorial services in this mighty, historical building with it's perfect acoustics. So patriotic to hold the tomb of the unknown warrior and that alone makes one's heart swell with pride and tinged with great sorrow too for all those who fell in war. The imposing organ which seems to fill every corner and high ceiling rafter. It is an honour to visit and to attend a service in a religious building so steeped in history.
Amazing. Breathtaking. I can't really find much more words to describe this place. Shame no pictures were allowed to be taken.

Much too crowded, but needs to be seen.... Long waiting lines; be very early or after 16 hours. Booking via internet gets you into the shorter line, this helps! Expensive, but one needs to have seen it: history lessons with the shrines for the enemy-queens Elizabeth I. and Mary Stuart on opposite sides, memorials for dozens of famous poets and composers. Church feel is quite reduced due to the crowds everywhere, but then : you came for this, did you not ?? Relax afterwards in one of the nearby parks !

Worth the Time and Money. Westminster Abbey is one of my favourite spots in London. I always take a seat and reflect on the centuries of monumental events that have occurred within the walls of WA. Even though WA is busy and expensive, it is worth the time and money.

This is where the kings and queens are buried. You get a guide that will explain to you who is in each tomb and memorial. It is quite interesting, specially to see where Mary and Elizabeth are buried.
Amazing history. When visited very much people so look only outside, lot of history, famous people burried there, worth to visit if have time for queue

In the presence of the greats.. What an amazing place to visit - so many famous people buried here it's quite awe inspiring to stand in front of so many of my Science and Music idols. The audio tour is very informative but I think a more detailed guidebook on some of the tombs would be interesting and informative, even for an additional fee if necessary.

Entrance fees need review. Well, i must confess that i saw this place numerous times when it was still free to enter many years ago. i was shocked to see the entrance fees charged in this wonderfull place nowadays. With all the respect this is a simple tourist "robbery" and It's time someone will consider again this procedure, unless this is a way to filter the numbers of visitors in this place.

Disappointing visit. This was the third time I had visited WA....and by far the worst. The admission fee is scandalous. If you travel with children, make sure you have proof of their age as the person at the ticket window will check. It cost us nearly $100 US for five of us to visit. There were too many people allowed in at anyone time as well.

British history condensed. Firstly, don't queue! Book online, in high summer it will save you at least 1 to 2 hours.Secondly, use the guide handsets. It will give the main headlines, signage could be better but overall take your time once you are in. TIP, make notes of names and dates that you see, the t'interweb, will answer your curiosity, there is a website detailing every memorial in the place, so your trip can extend for weeks after you get home.Summary, don't be put off by the queues, just plan it better.
Pre-book direct the day before. At £20 to get in per person, and a 20 minute queue It had a lot of work to do 2 hours later and an amazing slice of history later I was most impressed.

Lovely place to visit. Nice place to visit although we thought the £20 entrance fee was a little steep we enjoyed our visit.
Lots of historical things to see and free audio guide is very good.

Westminster. Westminster is very beautiful. We did not get audio guide, but I would definitely recommend getting one. A lot of the crips are in Latin. It was still very interesting to see, but I would have like to know what I was seeing. Westminster is a must when visiting London!

Go for a service- you won't regret it!. I've wanted to go for a really long time but I have an objection as a point of principle to paying to go in churches (am happy to make a donation).We looked into things and found that there are regular services which you can attend for free. When you attend the service- which I found beautiful and spiritual- you don't get a chance to wander around and see things at your leisure, so if you are interested in having a really good look then you should pay to go and take your time.However, for me just being in the building was enough- it is an absolutely stunning space and you could feel the air thick with history and tradition. We weren't shepherded in and out at great pace so we were able to properly admire the beauty all around us.

For history buffs. We skipped the long wait line by using an excellent guide (from Context Travel). An amazing structure, especially the side chapels- but crazy crowded. No photos - a rule openly ignored, by many rude people. My teen told me he was "historied out", by the end of our visit. Take the tube there - it lets you out right in front of "Big Ben", and the abbey is less than a five minute walk from there.

Take a Tour. We happened into the Abbey at 1:45 PM, and there was going to be a guided tour at 2 PM limited to 20 people. We signed up for the tour at a cost of an additional 5 pounds per person! It was worth it and then some. The tour gave us an overview of the Abbey and let us wander to areas off limits to the general ticket holders. The sexton that gave the tour was full of facts and fun and even kept the children in the tour involved. Tour was to last 45 minutes, but lasted almost an hour and 15 minutes.

Must see but expensive. Oddly, the museums in London are all free but the churches charge you a lot! It is a great place to see the tombs of so many famous people buried. The church itself, although huge, was not as impressive in the architecture of St Pauls- that was awe-inspiring and beautiful.

This is MUST SEE attraction!. This should be on your "must see" list for London! The poet's corner was one of my favorite parts of the Abbey. Being able to see where brides have walked and queens were crowned was amazing!
Outside nice. Long line to get inside. Buy on line and get in special line. Next time. I will tell more then. Outside is very nice.
Magnificent!. The abbey is majestic, a lot of history in one place.A little overcrowed,we visited over the summer so it was totally expected. However is totally worth it.
Feel the history. While its in the touristic center, the moment you enter you feel the history that this place is host to. It can feel a bit crowded at peak times but most certainly worth a visit.
Family vacation. Could only see it from the outside on our tour. Get tickets ahead of time. Looked like the wait time was minimal.
Literally melted into the tombs.. If you are a British history buff then this is the place. The image of Elizabeth in her tomb practically made me melt into the stone.

the abbey is worth the trip and more.... been there almost 20 years ago and returned now. everything is still well taken care of, it is a pleasure to visit and to see everything that is there. if the weather is going to be dreadful the abbey is a good place to go but it may be a little crowded then.

Ya gotta do it, but..... If you're in London, and you've never been to Westminster Abbey, you've got to do it. But the traffic through there is rivalled only by the crowds in front of the Mona Lisa at the Louvre, or, well -- everywhere in Beijing!Seriously -- I looked down at the worn stone stairs and thresholds, and thought to myself: how are these going to withstand this kind of punishment? Centuries of the footsteps of Royals and pilgrims have left their mark; but 21st century tourists may be their undoing.

London break. Fascinating. If you go to the abbey be prepared for a wait to get in. We got in on our 3rd time! Was very surprised by the size of the actual abbey, lots of side chapels which then meant that the main aisle wasn't as large as it is shown on TV. Beautiful though.

Nice. It is worth a visit when in London. A worship place with history of centuries. Beautiful structure in the Westminster area. There is 20 GBP entry ticket. Had a chance to walk around and was a good experience.

A must in London. What a fascinating abbey . If you are a history buff this is a must. It is the best cemetery in the world, a real who's who are buried in that abbey, quit incredible. Three hours are needed to do it justice and the cafe offers reasonable food at the end

A must see when in London. The Abbey itself is beautiful. It is very helpful to have the audio guide to go through the building itself. A must see when you go to London. You have to follow a path to visit the church you cannot really walk around where you want to go - I believe they do this to heard people in and out as it can get very busy. We went early in the morning and did not have to wait to long in line.My only negative point would be that as you walk through you visit a series of small enclaves which houses several caskets but there is no indication who these people are - the audio tour points out a few which if they had lists or some indication of who is in these rooms would make the tour more interesting.There are a number of attendants standing around that you can ask questions to but they are mostly there for crowd control. They are very friendly and helpful.
NICE. Good one time experience. Lines were long, london pass helped. We finished it in one hour. We had kids with us too

A rare opportunity. Though there was a long que dur to summer holidays, I still got a chance to get in just before the last admission time. I though Westminster was only just a place to hold some ceremony but I was wrong. Who know Queen Elizabeth I and Queen Mary, the two iconic rivals were both laying there in the opposite room? And now you got a chance to see not only their tumb but also others historical person's.With the beautiful decorations inside the Westminster, everyone should at least get inside once.

Words can't describe . I've always wanted to visit Westminster Abbey after seeing The Duke & Duchess of Cambridge's wedding & wow today I went & it did not disappoint,what a stunning building with lots of history behind it, I can not describe or put into words how beautiful it is inside, I was able to see the Warriors grave & physically walk the whole aisle of the abbey exploring the bits behind the church like where kings & queens lie, also the coronation chair,Although you enter a different door to enter the abbey you exit via the normal door Stunning
English History - Awesome!. Not to be missed in London - you step back in time, and are awed by the tombs and memorials to kings, queens, scientists, and literary giants.

Stunning but Pricey. The Abby is grand in all respects but I do have a problem with paying E20. to enter a place of worship. If it fits your budget go for it and enjoy. If you are a starving student skip the interior.

History, Kings, Queens and the Medal of Honor. There is so much history and there are so many notable people buried here that this place must come alive with ghosts after midnight. Almost everywhere you step there is a grave with the markings worn down from the many of visitors who come here each day/year/decade. Excellent information guides with long coats/smocks are located at various points around the facility to answer your questions. Beside the main great halls of the Abbey there are side chapels with tombs and another era of British royalty and intrigue. We went in a counterclockwise direction and wound up in the famous English writers wing at the end (a must-see). Again, watch your step or you will tramp on old and new authors that seem to go so well with this facility. Also, the British equivalent of the US Tomb of the Unknown Soldier is located in one of the halls, surrounded with flowers. Unlike the US, that honors its Unknown with a military site and guards, the British Unknown is recognized in this religious facility. My wife and I were almost the last folks to leave and I mentioned to one of the info guides about this fact and he asked me to come with him, behind the exit ribbon to the tomb. He pointed out a pillar next to the tomb that had the US Medal of Honor on it that was presented to their Unknown at the same time that our Unknown was recognized with the British equivalent some years ago. What a memorable gesture. We were truly moved by the whole Abbey...not sure youngsters could make it through it all.
Could stay all day!. I could stay here all day! There's so much to see and every time you turn around there's something else interesting to see. Get the London Pass and skip the line!
Overpriced....... Enjoyed my visit, but find aspects overpriced, can't take photos, but have to buy souvenirs to keep...
Beautiful Historic Site!. The self-paced audio tour was very effective. This is a must-see location especially if you like to study the history of England and religion.
Breath taking!. Get the headsets to learn about the history. Kings, Queens and tombs! Its absolutely amazing! We got the london pass and skipped the line

Feast for the eye. Westminster Abbey is on the top of most visitor's lists for good reason. The architecture, stained glass, sculptures, and carvings are stunning to be sure. The audio guide leads you through each area and addition to the Abbey, tying each in time and to the crown that built them. Don't miss Poet's Corner at the end of the tour.

Amazing architecture and monuments to historic figures of UK. Westminster Abbey holds an amazing collection of memorials for famous people from the last 800 years of British history. Kings and queens of course, priests and cardinals and prime ministers, but also famous figures from science, arts, music, and culture. Beautiful architecture, amazing side galleries, a must-see when visiting.

Well worth a visit. Beautiful abbey in the heart of London with so much history. We used the audio guides and really enjoyed them. My teenage daughter and I spent longer than we expected here. It was very interesting.

One of the Great Sites of Britain. A truly amazing and inspirational place.We had actually come for a church service, so for an hour were able to absorb the atmosphere of this most historic of churches.Walking to our pew we passed by (and over) the graves and memorials to many British Prime Ministers and famous British musicians.Lovely church service, excellent singing by the choir, stewards all very friendly and helpful.

Westminster Abbey is a place of history, spirit, and spendor.. The Abby is a place of worship like no other. The décor and history put you in a time where royalty reigned supreme. The headset leads you through the impressive structure giving you details of what happened when/where and why the sections exist.

Gloomy. Gotta say I was really disappointed. It's more cemetery than church. So if you're looking for an impressive, take-your-breath-away cathedral . . . this isn't it. If you want to see lots and lots and lots of crypts then you'll love it. Highlight was seeing where Mary Queen of Scots was buried and her sister Elizabeth.
Must do in London. Loved the history and feel of this beautiful and iconic place. A must do while in London. Go on a day when the gardens are open for a complete visit.

Nice self guided tour that is respectful of the fact you are in an operational church. Audio guide was provided that provided history, and went into more depth if you wanted it. No photos were allowed inside, and they asked you to stop and be quiet when there were services or prayers in progress. Made you remember it was more than a tourist site.
A must see. Westminster Abby is a must see for any traveler to London. Not only is the Abby beautiful but it is full of history. I have been several times and never tire of visiting.

The best Abby to visit. This Abby is a must couldn't buy express passes to se this Abby as the don't charge an entry fee the line was long but quich moving. Audi available and the ceilings are to die for plus Princess Diana was married there.

Amazing. I was very surprised at the amount of old things in this church. Lots of dead Kings and Queens in boxes. Lots of stuff dedicated to the mythical God the British call 'God'. Very pretty place.

Pricey, but full of History. 20 pounds seemed like a lot of money to pay for entrance and you cannot take any pictures inside the Abbey. However, the history associated with Westminster Abbey is very impressive. Do not forget to get the audio tour. if you do not have the audio, it is very difficult to determine exactly what you are looking at. It was a bit crowded, but definitely a "must see" when you visit London.
Crowded. Quite crowded, but well worth waiting in line to get in. Make sure you pick up the free audio guide!

History Overload. This place was much more amazing than I anticipated! There was more history in that building than I have experienced in my entire life! It's much more than where the royals get married! The only reason I marked it down a star is because I felt like it was very expensive when there wasn't even a tour guide to explain the rooms and answer questions.

Beautiful church! Buy tickets online before you go!. We visited in early July. The church is beautiful. When you consider how old the church is, the architecture is fascinating. Be sure to book tickets online in advance so you can skip the lines. There is no photography inside but you are allowed to take pictures while walking through the cloisters.

One of the most interesting Cathedrals there are. It's amazing and worth every penny (But I agree it should be cheaper than 20 Pounds) - because its much more than any cathedral you might been to in Europe. Full of statues of , well, not saints, but people who changed England and changed the world - poets, artists, generals - they are here in fabulous statues, carvings and memorials. It's a real shame you can't take any pictures inside.Came at the opening in the morning, and there was some queue, but we didn't wait longer than a 2-3 minutes. I heard it gets worse later on. Took an interesting guided tour.The premise itself is impressive both from the inside as well from the outside, as can be seen in the pics.There is also a nice cafeteria inside the building, recommended for a relaxation since the atmosphere is very much church-like with arched ceilings etc.FYI, they have brochures and guides in Polish, but not in Romanian...

I didn't think I would like, but..... Westminster Abbey is a place not to be missed when visiting London. I tend to have issues with the whole idea of royalty, so I was not thinking I would appreciate this place that much. But it was on my wife's list of must see things in our short stay in London. So yes, there are lots of kings and queens buried there, and their histories are quite varied and interesting (for some reason I'm digging Mary Queen of Scots) but there is a whole lot more. Upon learning about some of the brilliant minds that are also either buried or memorialized there (Darwin, Newton, etc.), it was a truly awesome experience. The entrance price is reasonable (compared to the Eye, for example), and they provide a self-guided tour playback device that provides great information and at no additional charge. If you like places of worship, it is a must see, and even if you don't you will probably still like it. We went early on a busy Saturday, and got in before the lines got too long. You can easily spend 2 hours inside the Abbey, but if you attempt to read everything you might need days.

My favourite place in London!. I could've spent a whole day here, but only to really let the history sink in. It won't take nearly that long to get through. Do yourself a favour and pay the extra to visit Poet's Corner and the cloisters. For an English literature nut like me, this was like Mecca to me. And I still have my brass rubbing "art" from the cloisters.

Full of History!. Beautiful church filled with history (many royals have been laid to rest inside). Well worth the 1.5 hours we spent inside listening to the free audioguide. Make sure to go early to avoid the crowds!

Worth the Lines for the History.. This was the third or fourth time for us to go to Westminster Abby. We usually buy the London Pass so we get to bypass a very long line. The history of the Abby is outstanding. Also, as a Christian I enjoy the sacredness of the building. If you have a chance to attend an Evensong service ,you will be impressed with the quiet and beauty of the moment.
A definite must-do. The visit is well worth the steep price. There is so much history to see. Make sure to book on e beforehand as there is always extremely busy.

Awe inspiring (except for one thing). It truly stuck awe in my family and me. It is beautiful and accomplishes the Gothic goal of making you look to the heavens. The audio tour is a must, and the hourly breaks for prayer were a great reminder of the building's real purpose. The one thing that I didn't like was the restriction against pictures. Every other cathedral and site I visited in Ireland and the UK is fine with pictures (some say no flash, and that is ok), but this restriction really seemed more of a ploy to get you to buy the books in the gift shop than to preserve anything.

Fascinating church. We booked our tickets online so we could skip the ticket purchase line up. We were worried about visiting around mid-day on Saturday (we had timed entry tickets to the Parliament Buildings nearby that morning, so that is how it worked out). However, we did not feel that we waited a long time. Audio guides provide a lot of information and it is a church that you will need interpretation to get the full effect. The church is essentially a building of tombs, unlike many other churches that you will visit, it is chock-a-block. It almost felt more like a museum than a church. My educational background is English language and literature, so of course I loved poet's corner. The coronation chair is a star attraction. You will also see the oldest door in England, dating back to 1050. So much history, so much to take in. Fascinating visit.
Guided tour worth the money. Take the guided tour if you can, it's pricey but we had a terrific guide and it made the history of the abbey really come alive.

A key landmark of British history. Firstly let me say; get here early as this 'attraction' can get very busy. Also, keep your camera's stowed as there are no photo's inside.It was amazing to see in person a cathedral that has so much historical significance for the monarchy and Britain in general. The walkways are clearly marked and they will lead you past the various points of interest in the cathedral. Also, be sure to pick up an audio guide as the narration by Jeremy Irons is quite informative. You will see the tombs and markers of Kings, Lords and other people of significance for their time. You will be in the place where Royal weddings and funerals have been held along with the Queen's Coronation. You can even see the Coronation throne.As you would expect, the cathedral is quite large and you really need to allow a couple of hours to see it properly. I also had a London Pass and was able to bypass the queue, which was nice.

Very crowded but worth it. Westminster Abbey is stunning. We went at 930am when it opened and there was a short line that didn't talk long to get to the front of. However, the Abbey was full and crowded in a matter of minutes. Be ready to be elbow-to-elbow with everyone else as you walk around to see the sights. There are also a number of guided tours going on at one time that "get in the way" of seeing different things. Definitely listen to the audio guide - it is full of interesting information. So many important people are buried here and there is so much history to learn about. It's a must see but expensive at 20 pounds per person.

Inspiring Awesome Church. There is so much history here. It is a grand place. I attended the formal opening of the Law Year. An amazing and unforgettable ceremony. This is what the British are best at - tradition, pomp and ceremony.

So worth it. Yes it is expensive and yes you may have to line up (get there early and you won't) but it is a must see in London. Give yourself a good 2-3 hours if you want to see it properly and get the free headset. Truly lovely experience and much more history then I knew!

Enjoy. I visited Westminster Abbey with my wife indenting to visit the Abbey itself, I was slightly disgusted by an entrance charge £5 per person. In the end we visited (Westminster Abbey Choir School) situated at Dean's Yard and this was without exception the best decision we had made all day ... if your put off with the considerable commercialization of Westminster Abbey then your in for a very inspiring treat by visiting Dean's Yard. ENJOY!!

You can feel the history.... Westminster Abbey is not just a historical landmark; it is first and foremost a sanctuary and a tomb for some of the world's most influential figures. The thing that separates Westminster Abbey from other cathedrals in Europe is the respect they pay to those who were lain to rest in the Abbey as well as those currently worshiping during services. While other countries use their historic churches to shove as many unruly tourists through the doors as possible, set up souvenir depots at every corner, and allow selfies with ongoing worshipers, Westminster takes the higher ground. Because cell phones, cameras, and other tourists grub hub is strictly forbidden inside, it allows visitors to take in all the stunning architecture and historical influence the Abbey has to offer and actually feel something (other than a selfie stick across the head). My biggest regret was not knowing enough about all those former figures who rest in the Abbey. I won't make the same mistake again. For those who do want Westminster Abbey souvenirs, there is a gift outside adjacent to the entrance.

Breath taking. The Abbey is amazing. We were given audio guides when we entered together with a map which was a great way of learning about the abbey and its history as you could move along at your own pace. It was July and obviously very busy but we still managed to see all the points on the guide. Definitely a "must see" when in the capital.

Breath-Taking. Well worth a visit. The art and history of the Abbey is stunning. Everybody visiting London should go to the Abbey. If for nothing else then to say that you walked down the same aisle as royalty do when they get married.
Stunning views of the old world.. A must see while in London. Easy to get to and well worth the time. It is a beautiful old church and close to Parliament.
Awesome !. Do not go to London without seeing inside this stunning Abbey ! If you think the outside is beautiful then go inside and experience real beauty.

Beauty and a Lot of Tombs. Westminster Abbey is remarkably beautiful with a rich history and incredible architecture that comes with a great audio tour. The Lady Chapel is breathtaking and the church itself is stunning. Besides the architecture, there are mostly just a whole lot of tombs which after a while can make one feel a bit strange being surrounded by the graves of around twenty or so people at any given time.

Stunning. This is one of the few locations that I've found breathtaking - literally. Coffins piled high on top of each other, centuries (millenia?) of history lying strewn about like a cluttered attic. The spirits of great men and women jostling each other for position. The building itself is impressive, expanded upon over the centuries. The residents are a roster of who's who in British History, the curios and relics lying about have started wars. It's expensive, crowded, and worth it. Make it a full day trip and take the time to really learn about this fascinating personal church of the English kings and queens.

Where to begin.... I love Westminster Abbey. The history, the tour, it's location to other sights in London, and the restaurants within walking distance. One of the few places where I've been borderline speechless as I walked around listening to the guide and soaking in the whole experience. If I ever go to London again then I will definitely stop by Westminster Abbey again.

Awe inspiring. There is so much to see everywhere you look. Get the audio guide, it's a great help in making sense of it all. You are surrounded by history, don't forget to look down too. Don't forget this is also a place of worship, take a moment to sit and reflect.
Great Time. This is another must see in London. There is a lot of history here and a great audio guide. Make sure to buy tickets in advance online. Totally worth skipping the line.
Mind boggling work of craftsmen.. Get in the London Pass line by 9:15 to gain quicker entry. It was stunning! The audio guide adds a lot.
Culturally significant icon of English history. The history in this beautiful cathedral is astonishing, as is the art and architecture. We spent a morning and could have stayed longer.

PAY THE ENTRY FEE. The entry fee is steep. 18 pounds/20 pounds. Yes....high. But, plan the fee into your travel budget. If you only go in once it is worth the price of admission. This 1000 year old abbey church, originally a Catholic Benedictine abbey now Anglican since Henry VIII is steeped to the rafters in British history. Every corner is jammed with something to notice. Take a guided tour. After it you can walk around again on your own.As a Canadian the abbey has strong ties for us. Here our kings and queens have been crowned. Our first prime minister, Sir John MacDonald has a stall and name plate in the chapel of the Order of The Bath. Many British explorers who help map Canada in the 17 and 1800s are buried here. Gen James Wolfe who captured Canada from France in the battle of the Plains of Abraham at Quebec is commemorated here.Other memorials and tombs are a who's who in the exploration of the world and the development and growth of the British Empire and the Commonwealth.But, it is fascinating for anyone really. The tomb of Elizabeth I is to be seen next to Queen Mary of Scots whom Elizabeth had beheaded.So, pay the fee. Visit one of the world's most interesting and impressive places. It is well worth it.
Magnificent abbey. Great attraction, good audio guides, learnt so much, was not hurried around so plenty of time to read and take in the magnificent venue

Not religious, and that doesn't matter. . Rightly up there with all the other icons (lol) and another must.
Poet's corner of course, but many other famous and interesting people.
Asked to stop at 11 am while the vicar said a prayer, which was short and moving.
And the coronation chair. :-)

Simply amazing. I visited Westminster Abbey at the height of the summer season when it was inevitably VERY busy and VERY crowded. This often made it difficult to move around as the space around some of the monuments can be quite restricted and at times this was very frustrating when views were blocked. This didn't detract from the magnificence of Westminster Abbey itself or the feeling of awe generated by walking amongst the resting places of so many great (and not so great) historical figures and monarchs. I recommend availing of the free audio guides when you enter the abbey as they contain a lot of interesting and relevant information. Also, the English guide is narrated by Jeremy Irons who is a wonderful guide! :)I was particularly interested in the tombs of the monarchs and in Westminster Abbey you can see those of Edward the Confessor (partially hidden), Edward I, Henry III, Henry V, Henry VII, Elizabeth I and Mary I (buried together) and Mary Queen of Scots amongst others. In the chamber containing Elizabeth I and Mary I you can also see the urn containing bones believed (but certainly not proven) to be the princes in the Tower (Edward V and Richard, Duke of York). It was placed there by Charles II when the bones were discovered at the Tower of London in 1674 and Charles decided that they must be the lost princes.You can also view the coronation chair as you exit Westminster Abbey and the famous painting of Richard II.Also worth checking out is the museum which contains funeral effigies of a number of kings and queens.After all that walking around, the Cellarium cafe offers some excellent coffee and muffins.Also worth seeing is the church next door to Westminster Abbey where Walter Raleigh is buried.Westminster Abbey is easily accessible by bus and by tube and is well signposted. The cost of entry is £20 but concessions for senior citizens and students (student card necessary) are available reducing the entry fee to £17. If you want to really take your time over viewing the many magnificent monuments and tombs in relative comfort I recommend not visiting during holiday seasons if possible.

Do not miss!. Westminster Abbey is awesome. So much history and crypts with the abbey. The architecture is amazing. You can not take photos inside but you can on the grounds. They have Britain"s oldest door (see my pic). The London Pass offers free entrance and skip the line however even the skip the line is a line...LOL So very popular.

Amazing to finally see in person!. We saw this our first day in London -- used the London Pass and got right in without waiting on line. Used the audio tour as there was not another verger tour for 2 hours. Audio tour was wonderful and the Abbey did not disappoint! A must see in London especially if you are a history buff!

Crowded. Very busy. Good guided tours.. I started queuing at 9.30 am so was one of the first to arrive. The Abbey quickly became very crowded and it was difficult to see anything or to stand and stare so that you could fully appreciate all the craftsmanship within the Abbey. I decided to go on a guided tour (an extra £5 on top of the £20 entry fee) so that I could get a fuller picture of the Abbey's history. The audio guides are free and excellent but everyone stops to see the same thing making the viewing experience difficult. I was there during the peak holiday period. The guided tour lasted 90 minutes and was led by an Abbey verger. It was interesting and informative and we were able to visit the shrine of Edward the Confessor which is not open to the general public. I thought it was money well spent. I could easily have spent the whole day at the abbey, but had a family to meet. You need an interest in history and culture to fully enjoy and appreciate the Abbey. (My teenagers visited the London Eye whilst I toured the Abbey!)

Completely worth every penny . Always wanted to go see the abbey, it was absolutely gorgeous. Seeing memorials and actual graves of famous writers, soldiers, monarchs, painters and poets by my own leisure and learning about the historic value of the church was just phenomenal. The architecture and the serenity just added to the wonderful experience. I really would go again.
A must to see. If you enjoy history, this is the place to go. So amazing to walk in a place where royalty has been for 500 years.

Centuries of History Under One Roof. Talk about an impressive building. The outside had a lot of scaffolding on the sides but the front was visible. The inside is so impressive. There is hardly a space that doesnt have something on it. Between all the royals and other British famous people buried here to all the ornate decorations this place is a visual wonder. It is really hard with the crowds to truly appreciate this masterpiece. Definitely a must to visit on any London tourist trip. Was a long line to get in but it moved pretty quickly.

Beautiful Church Steeped in History. Centrally located; Beautiful Ecclesiastical Building Steeped in the History of this Country. But to be asked to pay an "admission fee" for a working Church? I was a bit shocked. I appreciate it costs a lot to run and I am more than happy to make a "voluntary donation" but, for me, they have gone too far.

A "must see" in London.. Very good audio tour guide. So much history! Go early to avoid crowds. Next door to Parliment and short walk to Trafalgar Square and Churchill's war room bunker. Red Lion Pub good place for lunch.

What a building. A full day out at probably the most historically packed place in London, if not the UK. Everywhere you look, there is something fantastic to see. As well as walk in the footsteps of the Royal weddings. The grave of the unknown warrior is very moving. On entry, there are free audio devices which really bring the place to life as well show video clips. The staff are very friendly and informative too. An absolute must see.

Spend the money!. 18 pounds seems a bit expensive, but this attraction is worth every pence! A guided tour is great, but the audio guide is also very helpful. Don't miss the exhibition hall behind the Abbey and the chapel.
Impressive. This is a must see in London, the history in this place is just a little bit longer than the lines to get in though. But brave the lines you won't be dissapointed.

A bit pricey but worth the money. The tickets for adults and concessions are expensive (£20 full price and £17 for concessions) but it includes a free audio guide and handout. The inside is stunning with high ceiling and beautiful windows. Looking around you'll find the graves or memorials for many famous Brits; Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Sir Isaac Newton as well as members of (the historical ) royal family to name a few.

So much history; so little time!. This is a place that a traveler can return to over and over again. It is chock full of history and familiar or semi-familiar names. We loved the tomb of the unknown soldier from WWI. The rectangular stone, flush with the floor, was surrounded all around the perimeter by12 inches of tightly packed red poppies. This created a beautiful frame and was so evocative of the many soles who perished during this catastrophic world conflict. Do not miss the 'poet's corner.'

Consider Attending a Service to Get a Better Taste of the Abbey's Significance. This is a beautiful church full of royal history. Its exterior is gorgeous but if you have the opportunity, go inside. I was persuaded by a friend to attend an Evensong service here and am now glad that I did. Even if it's not your thing (Evensong is a boy's choir), it is a great way to see the church's interior free of charge. The service is around 30 minutes long and is an interesting way to see this amazing piece of historical architecture. I'd recommend it even if you aren't Catholic or religious in general.

A must see in London. We spent over two hours Visiting Westminster Abbey today, listening to the audio that guided us through all the tombs and chapels. The place is very impressive, and I could not help but think of the Movie " a night at the museum" expecting Robin Williams to appear as our tour finished towards closing time. A recommendation, is to attend the 5 pm evensong service open to all but limited to 800'people. The service is 45 min. Long, is free, and allows you to get a flavor of the majesty of this place if you do not want to pay the 20£ admission fee. Start lining up around 4.10 pm around the side of the abbey. If you are too late, you will be seated where you will hear the service and choral singing, but not see the participants of the evensong service. The potapotties are located at the end of the self guided audio tour.

Breathtaking. The majesty, history and splendour of this place will blow you away. It was so impressive words can't describe it. To think this place has been used for worship for more than 1000 years is truly wonderful.

Stand in Awe! (No pictures allowed inside). Westminster Abbey: where kings and queens have been coronated since 1066, where William and Kate got married, where many of England's greats (kings, queens, nobles) have been laid to rest (Elizabeth I, Mary, etc.)Stand in awe of it's majesty and historical significance. Pretty crowded when we went. No pictures inside
History For Sure-April 2014. We never made it inside, but the building is absolutely spectacular on the outside. All the history in this very location is astounding.
