Not to be missed. I was only in London for one day, but I was not about to miss Westminster Abbey. It was crowded, but I felt like I could still see what I wanted to see and take my time. Wear comfortable shoes because the floors are very uneven. The audio tour is free (yay!), but the same information is available on an app that you can download on your cell phone and listen on your own earbuds. There is no way for them to give you details on every tomb you'll pass by, so keep your eyes open. Everywhere you look (and step), there is another monarch, or important person buried. Another note: get your ticket online before you go. If you have your tickets, you can skip the line and go right in. Someday, maybe I'll get the chance to attend a service there.

A must see for any visitor to London. Westminster Abbey is one of those historical sites that everyone should see on a visit to London. It is the burial place for hundreds of famous people (royalty, authors, explorers, etc.) from British history. It is completely amazing inside; the size and intricacy of the detail requires plenty of time to enjoy it and seek out the little oddities that always seem to hide inside the little chapels and nooks in the cathedrals. If you can be there during a choir practice or a service, you will be moved by the way the sound carries throughout the building.
A place with medieval spirit and long history of people. Visit is definitely worth the money for entry as inside you can feel a great part of English history walking the path of individual "sights".
Good. A must to see after the Parlement when you are in London. It is part of London history and a nice place to visit

Great historical context. Wow! I am so glad we took the time to stop by Westminster Abby. I wish we were allowed to take photo's in the church. No photos, no hats. Seeing where the kings and queen was amazing.

Probably one of those things you should see here. It is primarily what you have been lead to expect: tombs and monuments to a lot of historic names, most of whom you haven't heard of. However what will likely surprise you (at least it did me) was the majesty and expanse of the environment --- this place has a 'ceiling' that rivals that of St Peters and there are so many crypts, statues and plaques crammed in here that you wonder how there will be room for anyone else. Once you get over the creepy feeling of walking on someone's gravesite, you will just have visual overload on all the things to try to take in. I'd say get the audio tour if for nothing else than to help you focus your attentions --- it seems to cover a sizeable percentage of the more recognizable figures in the facility. At 20 pounds per person (~US$30/pp as of today's exchange rate) it feels a bit pricey, however I'm sure it takes a lot of money to keep this place maintained and just face it: you're in London. You're going to be spending some pounds while you're here and at the end of the day, this is one of those things that you would probably regret leaving this city and not seeing.

Westminster Abbey - A London Treasure. Westminster Abbey is grand and regal. Many royal services have been preformed here and dates back to 960 AD when Benedictine Monks settled in the area. Don't forget to look up when you're in the Abbey. The painting and sconces are a wonderment. You will also find many famous names that have been buried in the Abbey. Audio guides are available in 12 different languages inside the Abbey. There's the Royal Tombs, Poet's Corner, the Cloisters and the Nave to see inside. The coronation chair of King Edward I is also at the Abbey. Take a look inside Lady Chapel for a truly splendid medieval experience.

Westminster Memories. Really enjoyed the beauty and magnificence of Westminster Abbey. Just to picture Princess Diana and Prince Charles walking down that aisle for their wedding ceremony is stirring. There are so much intricate carvings and such within the abbey and we were fortunate enough to hear the choir practicing with such angelic voices, and the quality of the acoustics were remarkable. You can obtain a audio guide which is most helpful.

Full of History and Splendour.. The Abbey was everything I thought it would be, full of history, architecturally stunning and an extremely interesting place to visit. This was somewhere I had wanted to visit for a long time and I was not disappointed. There was lots to see and you were given an audio guide to explain where things were and the story behind each stop. I would recommend that if you intend to visit you book up online beforehand. When we got to the Abbey there was a very long queue but because we had pre-booked we were able to walk straight in. Also, there were an enormous amount of people visiting because of the summer holidays (particularly foreign visitors) so it might be better to visit at a less busy time of the year.

beautiful, but..... I was very keen to visit this beautiful Abbey, steeped in history. However I feel the entry cost of £20 per adult is extortionate and more than we could justify paying. However, I would have paid £10 as obviously the upkeep of the Abbey is important and maybe wealthy tourists, judging by the long queues, are happy to pay it.

Amazing historic cathedral. did you know famous poets and Saints are buried in the walls and floors of this historic cathedral. It is as if time has stood still...buy the book about " who is buried where"... So giant and ornate..if you only see one cathedral in Europe see this one!!
Amazing building. This is London! The towers of the Abbey are a must. The building by itself is wordless, loved it! It was a perfect day. We did the Thames cruise and made a stop at the abbey.

Well worth the entrance fee.. We had been thinking about visiting Westminster Abbey on several London visits,well I am glad that we finally made it to this monument to world history.There is just so much to take in as you walk through this ancient building,and the amount of tombs to the departed is beyond compare.If its a big day out,with lots of twists & turns, Westminster Abbey is the place to spend several hours of your time while in London.Summing up,just the perfect big day out that works out at real value for money considering the amount of time for your tour.A must see.

A wonderful part of our visit to the U.K.. Beautiful, historical, a total must see when in London. This was one of my favorite locations. To see the actual objects of history that I had only read about before was just amazing. My only regret was I was not able to attend an actual service, but I plan to go back someday.

Super Gorgeous. Beautiful Abbey (of course)! I was lucky enough to get in while the queue were relatively short. So many to see, great graves to admire, and beautiful architectures / ornaments / etc etc

The most important building in the English Speaking world.. This was the highlight of many highlights I enjoyed in London! What an amazing building and what an wonderful centre of English history. The Abbey demands more than a visit of a few hours. It is awe inspiring and I felt a little overwhelmed by the sheer scope of its history. Westminster Abbey should be the primary location for any visitor. After absorbing its importance to London, to England and to the rest of the English Speaking world, then move on to other sites in this great city.

A Jewel For Tudor History Buffs!. A 'must see' for literary/history/architecture enthusiasts. It seems a little pricey on arrival but, for the above content and two hours of viewing interesting artefacts (excluding the cloisters and the museum) worth the money. Recorded commentary was informative albeit rather brief in places. Translation of some of the latin inscriptions on the more important tombs would be very helpful.

Stunning!. There is no where like this. Buy your ticket ahead of time to reduce your wait time. Definitely get and use the audio guide (it's free with admission). It's a bummer you can't take pictures, but no one would move if you were allowed to take pics! To get the sheer number of visitors through the Abbey, I guess it's necessary to prohibit photography. We enjoyed the whole place, especially Poet's Corner. The coronation chair was a pleasant surprise, too.

Westminster. Take the audio tour, it's worth it. Poet's Corner was awe-inspiring. One interesting thing of note, there are "grave" markers for some NOT buried there, or once buried there and removed. And the Abbey itself is remarkably beautiful.

Beautiful inside - stunning. This place is beautiful inside. I didn't have to wait too long for in the queues to get in. It can be very busy but it is so beautiful inside - there are audio guides you can get in your own language and a leaflet which shows you all the key things of interest. Every hour, they hold a moment for prayer which was lovely just to sit and be a part off. No photos are allowed which is understandable as it is a working church and a sacred place. definitely a must see if you like history, architecture and places like this. Worth seeing - it is part of our culture here in the UK

Awe-inspiring. Only had the opportunity to see the Evensong. It was as magical as I thought it would be. Their voices are beautiful and it was very inspiring. Please be respectful and remember that it is also a type of service. However, definitely take the time to go in where you can actually inspect every detail of each tomb and stained glass windows. You won't regret it.

Let's put it this way.... If you don't get chills from standing at the graves of Newton, Darwin, Elizabeth I, etc., then you might as well go directly to a pub, get excruciatingly drunk, and ponder your lack of perspective. The abbey is an absolutely fantastic experience, and no visitor will go without coming across something (and someone) that will provoke gasps. My recommendation: on your first stroll through the abbey, DO NOT use any sort of guide. I'm serious. The traffic flow is clear, so just make your way around. Look. Read. Think. Stumble across names you now...Newton, et al. When you're done and already thoroughly amazed by the experience, then go get a tour book or something like that. Repeat the stroll. Enjoy the majesty of the place...and don't forget, right before the exit, peer to the left for a clear view of the Coronation Chair (aka, King Edward's Chair). We saw the "Stone of Destiny" at Edinburgh Castle, so seeing the chair made for a holistic moment. Entry into the abbey isn't cheap. But it's worth it. Go!

the intricate works of the craftsmen at the time. so much to see at Westminster Abbey. All the little chapels and nooks and crannies. Also the intricate work by the craftsmen was amazing. it was a lot to take in in a few hours and I have to look back over my pictures to remember it all. the paintings and sculptures , lots of them very delicate

One of the highlights of my London trip. Overall it was such a beautiful church with a rich history of England featured inside. There was a true emotional feeling associated with the Abbey. I do not practice religion and found it to be a very special and amazing place.I went to Westminster abbey after purchasing the London Pass. Whilst I do not agree with them charging so much to get inside, it was still a highlight of London for me.

Overwhelmingly beautiful. We were in London on a Sunday so we decided to attend the Evensong. It was a beautiful experience. I wish I had time to take the tour during the week, but I just couldn't fit it in.

Westminster Abbey. A little pricey, but so much history in the Abbey and you can stay pretty much as long as it is open. It takes a while to see it all, so taking the tour would be the best choice. Downside - the bathrooms are small and not very nice - use elsewhere before getting there.
Loads of History!. Beautiful place, definately a must see! We attended Evensong, which began at 17.00. I would encourage everyone to do this...it's free, but also the choir is wornderful.

Absolutely a must see. Westminster Abbey is a MUST see for all families. My husband downloaded the tour guide on our smartphones & we were able to complete a very in depth tour on our own. Be advised it closes at 3:30 & is NOT open on Sundays!
Dickens, Newton, Darwin.... Do the tour with the audio guide. Come early in the day and not on a weekend to minimize the crowd size.

Disgusting. Christ banished traders from the church, and now in 21st century we have people charging outrageous sum of money to enter in the house of the Lord. When I visit a church I usually make a donation because I understand that they have upkeep to pay, but I won't give a penny to those scoundrels.

Could have been more interesting. I think the crowds take away from this place. So many people jam into areas and hard to move around. Might go back for a service or on a tour and see what I think. It's a must see just be ready for crowds in the summer

Words can't describe how beautiful this church is !. This church was absolutely amazing. I got in free with the london pass but I would have gladly paid the price if I didn't. Too bad we couldn't take pictures. This is a must see when coming to London. I enjoyed saying a prayer and lighting a candle. All the history in this church made me feel so lucky to be in England.
Historical. Attending evening song an benediction was memorable and enchanting. It brought the books and movies to life for me.

Amazing Cathedral. The medieval architecture is very impressive. There are many famous people interred in the floor and in crypts. The only negative is that you can't take photos. It is understandable due to large crowds and everyone trying to take photos of themselves.

A Must See. We used our London Pass and skipped the long lines. Also, some of our tour group bought tickets at the hotel and could skip the line. The audio guide is a must to understand all the history. Very well done and so beautiful. We ate lunch in the cafe and it was good. Keep in mind that food is very expensive in London.
Very busy. Shame that some of the abbey was covered in tarpaulin but I suppose work has to be done. Long queues to get in so we just looked at the outside.
Abbey. This was a great cathedral to go inside but lots of people and queues?? Would like to have come earlier to avoid the middle of the day crowd. Easy to get to and great walks in all directions.

Beautiful!!!. Beautiful!!! I had to keep telling myself that I was surrounded by history. The inside is absolutely gorgeous. I only wish you could take pictures. Walking around and you see where England's Kings and Queens are buried is actually awe inspiring. The Coronation Chair is at the end. Look up on line when the bells of Westminster will be rung and do not miss it! We were there on a day, but at St. James Park, and we could still hear them. It was very beautiful.

More money! Morey money!. You have to go there. This is where Wills and Kate were married. They even have their wedding picture on the Abbey brochure. Yes, many Kings and Queens buried here. And Charles Dickens, Issac Newton, Laurence Olivier, Charles Darwin, and other people whom you probably never heard of, but they did have the money and power to have large statue placed in the Abbey proclaiming their glory, etc.. Yes, all these attractions are quite expensive, but this is worth seeing.

Highway robbery. The place is certainly of some historic value, but it is shocking that they charge 20 pounds for visitors to step inside - without permission to take photographs.There are plenty of sites that are at least as relevant as this one in the city, without the downside of exploring tourists. As if the Church needed even more money.

Awesome! Definitely a "must do.". The only bad thing about Westminster Abbey is that you can't take any pictures. But it was so awesome seeing all the tombs of the famous kings and queens such as Queen Elizabeth and Mary Queen of Scots. Jeremy Irons narrates the free audio which you absolutely MUST get in order to learn about everything. It was really cool. I

Great for history lovers. Westminster Abbey is a great place to visit for tourists of all ages. The line is usually not too long, and a free audio guide is included in the admission fee. The audio guide is nice because it allows each person to move at their own pace, and it also gives a very informative background on each item you see displayed in Westminster Abbey. It is also quite interesting to see the actual coronation chair and learn about all the different monarchs that have ruled England. If you research further, you can find the times that the chapel is in session, and you can come watch or participate if you wish. Young children may become bored, as there is not much to keep them occupied, but the great thing about a self-paced tour is you can leave whenever you wish.

Surprisingly Interesting. This was one of the stops i was told we must do. I didnt know much about the Abbey other than it's use for the Royal Family. I wasnt looking forward to touring yet another church. However i'm glad i didnt make an issue about going because it was an amazing, eyeopening experience.First i was unaware of all the people who are buried within the church. It was odd since i have never been in a church where people have been buried within the church. Besides awe, it gave the place more of an aura of respect. You are not just walking through a church (where respect levels may vary based on your personal religious beliefs) but you were also walking around a graveyard, something that i feel makes most more somber and respectful. The included audio guide was great, as was they way the church is somewhat sectioned off to guide you through it, yet you can go through at your own pace. While there they had a mass which you were able to attend. I personally had a great experience with one of the volunteers. While seeing the tomb of the unknown soldier I noticed a plaque on a column with a ribbon. It was a US Metal of Honor, presented from the US to the UK tomb of the unknown soldier. While explaining what it was and how slim the chances are we would ever be so close, literately within inches, of a real metal of honor in our lifetime to my friend. An elderly gentleman came up behind us and said " you two must be Americans". He then shared with us some stories about his experience as a kid during ww2 and his posting in southeast Asia a couple years after the war ended. It was a great experience and one that i will always remember.Speaking of the war, there are still signs of the damage from the wars that personally really hammered home just how old this place was and how much history/change it has seen through the years. For history buffs i would recommend planning a day just to tour this place. I was there for only about 3-4 hours and still had to rush through and skip some because of time. Non history buffs i would say 2-3 hours to really see everything.
Beautiful. This is one the most beautiful cathedrals in Europe. Many interesting people have been entombed here as well. A must see!
Dream come true. What an awesome place to visit. So may historic figures buried here. Beautiful abbey. It was a humbling experience. Recommend to anyone. Just a wonderful place to visit. Loved it.
Enduring interest. Spent hours and hours here. So many stories and points of interest. Fascinating. Loved the cloisters and many small chapels
Westminster Abbey. everything about Westminster Abbey is fantastic and very informative volunteers are very friendly and willing to give any assistance required

Worth it!. The price for entrance is rather steep, but the audioguide is then free (and handed out just beyond the entrance in the middle of the floor, very convenient). I've been to Westminster Abbey before but the audioguide helped a lot - and this time I got to see it from my teenager's eyes (she was wowed). It is a wonderful combination of history, religion, art and architecture, with a dash of royal interest thrown in. Even though you may only be there for an hour or so, spend the money and go. It's such a quintessential and beautiful piece of London's history.
Thoroughly enjoyable. good audio tour guide - lets you look around at your own pace. Beautiful place. Nice cafe to visit after the tour.

Fabulous experience. This amazing old abbey is SO full of history and it was fabulous to wander through with the audio guide listening to Jeremy Irons telling us all the interesting facts. I was blown away being right next to the kings and queens tombs... so fascinating. A must see for any visitor.

Westminster Abbey. Impressive. Good audio tour is included in your entrance. Be sure to see the older parts of the abbey and tour the gardens (only open certain days). Note, you cannot take pictures inside any Anglican churches we visited in England. See the coronation chair! Definitely worth a visit.

A must-see for all visitors. As my title states, Westminster Abbey is a must-see for any and all visitors to London. I am not a religious person, so this was not the draw for me. I was there primarily for the beauty of architecture and historical value that the Abbey presents. The thing that surprised me most is that although photographs are prohibited, just about everything is hands-on. I took a few moments and spoke with one of the very friendly and knowledgable staff about the reasoning for this as we visited Sistine Chapel and the Vatican and it was quite the opposite. I was told that as the Abbey is the property of the Queen, she holds the copyright to all of the contents and has not given permission for pictures. Additionally, with the advent of "selfie sticks" and "go-pro" cameras they didn't want to have anyone climbing on the tombs. The reason for the hands-on is that the Abbey is a working church and holds services every day so the decision is to allow parishioners and those interested to touch if the spirit guided them. Made sense to me.

Beautiful inside and out...a little pricey to get in...no photos allowed. It was a little pricey to get in but very beautiful on the inside. Sadly no pictures allowed which I never understand. Interesting to see who all is buried here. Lots of little nooks to explore.

Benjamin is an excellent guide.. We didn't book on line and consequently had a few minutes queue, not a problem usually but it was pouring with rain so I spent my time getting wet and wishing I'd booked on line!Verger guided tours are available at £5 ahead and well worth it in my opinion, as you get a humorous guide (Benjamin) and get to see extras including Saint Edwards tomb (not available to tourist ticket). Children's activity sheet was entertaining for the adults as well as our 11 year old.

Loved visiting 'English History' at Westminster Abbey.. So much history to ponder while walking through the Abbey. We loved seeing all the burial caskets, famous British authors, musicians, kings, queens, etc. We also liked the memorial to all the aviators who died during the Battle of Britain. We enjoyed lunch at the 'Cellarium Cafe' that used to store food and drink for the monks. this was one of the highlights of our trip to London.

English history. good value for money because if you have all day you could spend it in here especially if you love royal history and burial sites, lovely building just to sit and admire if you so choose.Like all London sites very busy expect to queue and be jostled by fellow tourists

Very informative and a lot to see.. We took the audio-guide and it was very informative. There is a lot to see and it was very interesting too.It is just too bad we cannot take pictures of all the wonders we discovered inside.Don't rush too much or you will miss a lot.

London-Crete Vacation. Enormous! We had time to get out of cab and walk around for pictures which I loved. There is a great little store for the Abbey to shop if you like. Lots of people were there during the afternoon and we couldn't park long, so be aware of the crowds.

Loved it! Just make sure to get there early and ask which line to go to! . We loved Westminster Abbey! We have been to London several times and never made the time to enter, usually just passing by and seeing insanely long lines and that was enough for us. This time, we bought tickets online before our arrival, printed them out and got there before opening time and waited along with lots of other people however we were at an advantage.... Many of those waiting in line had the London Pass or needed to purchase tickets so we actually ended up being the very first to enter the Abbey that day! Awesome!!!! Be sure to ask the Folks in green robes at the entrance which line you're supposed to be in...it isn't clearly marked in any way...I think that also helped us with the getting in first part. :-)We also had our 9 year old son with us and it was SO special. There is a little scavenger hunt along with the audio guide for the children and it really kept his attention...and is free! At the end they get chocolate for completing the hunt! What made the visit so special was the wonderful man working for the Abbey who took the time to speak with my son and he actually got the chance to go into the roped off area where the choir boys sing! The man spent probably 20 minutes with us answering questions and we left feeling so grateful for the experience.Make the effort to go here but plan in advance!

Family Vacation.. This was part of our tour. It was beautiful, and large. We did not go inside but the amount of people around the building was many. Driving by was great. And hearing the history about the building from our tour guide was good.

Rich with History. Westminster Abbey is a must see if you want to get a sense of England's rich royal history in a nut shell. The audio guide is a must and is very informative. The building itself is spectacular.The admission is expensive, but is covered with the London City pass and the pass does allow you to skip the lines. It does get very busy inside the building so pack your patience.

No quite a church for me. This is place were all is around tombs and their history. No what I look from a church. We did the reservation online and actually got there easy. Noon is a good time, less crowded.

History Comes Alive. English History comes alive at Westminster Abbey, a high gothic cathedral which is seat of the Anglican religion. It dates to the 10th century. Buy "skip the line tickets". Easy to do on the Cathedral website. (I continually stress buying these tickets for ANY major attraction. Why waste time standing in long lines? The audio guide is a must here. No photographing allowed. Staff are quite helpful and willing to answer most questionsHighlights include the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier,the Tombs of Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots and Poets Cornet. The Quire and High Altar are must sees as well.

Gorgeous. The Abbey is a fabulous place to devote to 3+ hours of your time to. The Entrance fee is a tad expensive but it also includes a free audio guided tour which is very helpful in navigating the place. The monuments and art inside are very gorgeous and the history behind it is just as interesting. My favorite sights include the tomb of Elizabeth I and Richard II plus the poet's corner and the coronation chair with the portrait of Richard II. Worth your visit if you love history and architecture.
Awesome ticket-punch. Iconic stop on your London experience. A must-do to say that you have "seen" London. Beautiful chapel and excellent experience.

Royalty at its extreme. We went to this Abbey expecting to stay for a short while. However, we ended up staying for three hours and a bit. The sculptures are beyond amazing and worth pay attention to their details. The abbey is particularly useful for kids studying british history as they can see the tombs of all the previous kings. Make sure you follow the audio guide for and visit the museum at the end.

Stepping stones of the past. The surprise for me, during the time in London, was how cherished peoples' lives are, even after death. Reading inscriptions about the men and women throughout the centuries was moving and inspirational. I don't get the same feeling in the USA. Not the reverence for life, and life after death.

Abbeys. Westminster Abbey is a large building across the road from the houses of parliament. It does not look that great from the outside, but superb inside. It is a bit expensive to get in and there can be long queues to get in, but worth it if you are not in a hurry.

The center of English history.. If can only visit one church in London, visit Westminster Abbey. A great interior, filled with many, many historically significant memorials--and the location for so many significant events over centuries.

Loved the Docents. Best part of my visit was chatting with the docents. They truly love their work and they are genuinely glad to answer questions and help you appreciate the building. There are many docents available and are easy to find; they're wearing lovely academic-looking robes. WA is chock full of monuments of those famous and once-were-famous. You get a sense of who was/is important and beloved to those in power over the centuries.

Westminster Abbey is Amazing. We had just 4 days in London so we just had time for the highlights, and I'm glad we included Westminster Abbey. The line was a bit long (it was early July) but moved quickly. The audio tour was very interesting, but it gets pretty detailed so don't be afraid to skip some of the details and move on. Make sure to go slow enough to look everywhere as you don't want to miss the burial stones of famous people. Keep quiet and let the history of the place wash over you.
Extraordinary Cathedral. You have to go inside and take it in. It is a stunning interior. Unbelievable in its size and details.
Must see. There was an art festival with lots of locals in the park across from Westminster Abbey. Great location to stay and play

Very beautiful. I enjoyed the self guided walking tour very much. There was so much history and I found it interesting. I was a bit confused about where huge masses of people sit for church here bc there just seems to be small chapels all over and not one large alter for a massive gathering like at Notre Dame. But, it was definitely worth the visit, but get the London Pass or plan to wait in line for at least an hour (like we did).

Another London Must See. Our London Pass allowed us to "jump the line" which, at opening hour, was very long. The Abbey is all you imagine it to be. The audioguide is excellent and guides you through the Abbey in about 90 minutes. No photographs are allowed in the Abbey.

Visit to London. While in London, we went to visit Westminster Abbey. There was a long line but it moved along quickly. To appreciate Westminster you have to have an appreciation for history. While crowded you can move along at your own pace as you get a handset that links with all the sites. It's worth the time and costs and I would certainly visit while touring London.
Westminster Abbey. Beautiful place to visit but try to schedule your visit in an off tourist season. The crowds in the Summer make it difficult to enjoy and see everything.
Historical and Inspirational. Self-paced audio tour available allows you to memorialize greats from the past, such as Charles Darwin, Sir Issac Newton, and many more!

amazing. if possible pre book as the line to enter can b long and when its hot take drinks once Inside the history really unfolds and i felt very honoured to have tread the same passage of so many historical figures i will advice to pre book any visits to all attractions as saves time and money as can get 3 4 2 visits when done over the net

Magnificent church excellent history. Use the London Pass to jump to the head of the queue and remember that you're entering an active place of worship - dress appropriately, take your hat off, and leave your cameras and cell phones off. Wander through the main chapels where British Royalty have commemorated life's major events for centuries. Many of the smaller chapels are the final resting place for the famous providing a fascinating glimpse of the long history of the British people. The walls and floors are so covered with burial stones and commemorative plaques that one can linger for hours and must take care of where one walks. Naturally the Poets Corner is a must see while the tranquility of the inner courtyard cloisters is serene. Imagine yourself in the audience of coronations, weddings and funerals and take those memories home with you to bring intimacy to the next televised event from this famous landmark.

Beautiful - don't skip the audio tour. We went in late June and it was just packed. I'd been there years before and didn't think I'd need the audio guide so we skipped that line. Really regretted it because there is very little signage. The tombs and statues are amazing and you want to know what you're looking at. We ate in the restaurant and it was quite good. Wish I had more energy and it wasn't so crowded.

Beautiful! A MUST SEE!. A very beautiful church! A must see in London! I suggest you buy tickets online before you go! There is a line for ONLINE tickets and one for those purchasing them that day! The line for online tickets was always shorter than the buying that day! You need to purchase them about 24-48 hours in advance!

MUST See. This would have to be at the top of my list of things I've seen in London. The Abbey is breathtakingly beautiful and has so much history! The free audio guides are great and allow you to move at your own pace. Make sure you visit the museum before you go, it's worth it! I would also recommend buying tickets online and at least a day in advance or you'll be waiting in a huge line!

Don't miss visiting Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey has so much history and is one of the top places to visit in London. It is and a beautiful structure that is known world wide. I highly recommend that you visit this facility. Check tour times prior to your visit

A must-see but crowded with tombs. Westminster is very beautiful, if crowded with dead people, famous dead people, but still crowded. Can't do much about that now! ;) Hard to see the soaring magnificence. We used the pre-recorded tour (free!) and it was very good!

A must visit. All visitors to London must visit the Abbey at least once. The burial place of kings, poets, and statesmen. The only "complaint" is that the admission price is constantly rising. It seems that they rise more than once per year. The lines are also extremely long. Purchase tickets online for a small discount and a slightly shorter line.

Stunning architecture. This is a beautiful structure and well worth visiting. It's beauty can be viewed from various angles and it photographs well. You might want to visit it on a week day because Saturday is quite busy in the Westminster area,

A Must-See. Beautiful abbey. We paid a little extra (5 pounds each) and took a small group tour (maybe 15 people total) with a staff member. Much more personalized than the free audio tour; I highly recommend it.
Amazing!. Such a historical building. I felt like walk thru the path of British history. Though it's a long walk, but worth it.
Going there again. I did not go there for a long time and I just loved watching it again and feeling the peace inside it. For first time travelers I would certainly recommend it.

A must see in London. I considered Westminster Abbey a must-see even before ever being to London simply because in my mind it kept a testimony of british history so important to the whole of Europe and of the world.I wasn't wrong, I am by no means an expert on British history but seing all those graves really gives one a perspective on how important and present monarchy has been in British history. More so that in any other country.To understand better England this Abbey is a good step forward, and it is a powerful and beautiful reminder of how many important men Britain has produced and how many important tasks they accomplished.A humbling experience for a 30 year old as myself who has often read of these men in histroy books, marveling at their victories without realising that many of them had my age when they accomplished such things.Aside from all this it is a pleasure to see this architecture and the hundreds of details, statues, engravings inside the Abbey, and although the Abbey in itself is not very big (at least comparing it to the basilicas w have in Rome) it is really a wonderfulsight inside and out. Again an A+ for the organisation.All this said I must be honest, I do believe that £30 is a bit much specially compared with the fact that museums are free. It was quite an expensive visti for the both of us, it was my first time in London and I had to see it, but let's say that if I do get back next year I am not sure I would spend that kind of money again.

Fabulous. Great! So much history here. Beautiful too. The windows and the crypts are artwork in themselves. Spent several hours walking around reading and just looking. Surprised that Charles Darwin is buried here.

A must see. If you only had one day in London I would do the Tower of London and Westminster Abbey. This place is amazing. A thousand years of history in one location. The free audio tour is a nice touch as it would be difficult to do without it. Once inside you can do the tour in an hour. Stop and have lunch or a snack in the small but nice cafe. The food was quite good. Definitely a place worth seeing at least once.

Must see when in London. Westminster Abbey is loaded with so much history! 1 of my favorites! Highly recommend the guided tour. It does cost 5£ but it was enjoyable. On this tour we were able to go into areas not readily accessible to other tourists. There are also audio guides available. There's so much to see, take your time. As like all the other sites in London, very crowded so bring your patience.

Historical Must See. This was a great palace to go and visit. There is a slight cost and photos are not allowed to be taken inside the Abbey. But it has so much history that it is well worth the cost and time.
nice. We visited this church as we were touring London and got the history of the church. Some famous families have been married there. Worth checking out.

A Don't Miss London Sight. Although we had to fight the summer crowds, Westminster Abbey was a highlight of our London trip. Hearing the history of the abbey and all the people buried or memorialized there was a real treat for us- and would be for anyone who loves history.

Visit During a Worship Service. The beauty of Westminster Abbey's history and architecture is undeniable. We were lucky enough to be in town and visited during a worship service (open to the public), and it was one of the highlights of the trip. It is a short service, and because it is a high tourist stop they have a service agenda that makes it very easy to follow along and understand the flow of the service. It was one of my favorite things we did in London.

Huge, crowded and very expensive. I visited Rome in the Spring and let's be fair: The catholic churches are more braggening and impressive. I think Westminster Abbey only holds The Lady Chappel that can compete in beauty.However it does make it interesting that so many famous persons is buried or have their memorandum here. It's worth a visit - but not as impressive than I expected
Awe inspiring, but expensive.. Simply amazing! Beautiful buiding, lots of famous people buried there. This is a must see, but is also quite expensive.
Spent Hours Here. Even though there was a 20 minute wait, the two hour visit made it worth it. Teenagers loved reading the stories about the people buried there.
British history in every brick. There is no other building steeped in so much history. It's an iconic landmark that is a must if you are visiting London and a must if you love history

Beautiful 1000 year old church. Westminster Abbey has been here for almost 1000 years and is still beautiful. As the coronation church of Queen Elizabeth II and the wedding venue for Prince William and Cate Middleton, the Abbey is nothing short of breathtaking. There can be long queue lines, so I would greatly recommend looking at The London Pass which allows you to skip the queue.

Wonderful stop while you are in London!. We stopped here and were able to get in. What a marveloous place with so much history! The pastors perform an hourly prayer here, and did so while we were inside. The architecture and ceilings are awesome! It has many things to see, so plan on about 90 minutes to see it all. Definitely worth seeing a piece of history!

Living History. Get audio guides to direct your path and provide information to enhance the viewing. Plan on at least an hour to reflect on the history of this place and the numerous centuries of well-known people who are buried or honored here in every dimension of life--war, peace, literature, art, music....ALL!

Long Lines. If you go in July, expect long lines and 20 pounds to enter. When you are in Westminster Abbey you are not allowed to take any pictures. This was disappointing after paying such a high fee to enter a church.

History of a church. If you have any interest in the reformation and how the modern day British church formed, it's all here. Make sure you stop at each spot on the map and listen to the audio. Any lover of history will learn something new and simply be fascinated.

Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit. This incredible Abbey is beautiful and worth the entrance fee and time spent in the queue. There is an audio guide that is included in your fee. There are also a couple of volunteer and paid staff members to help answer any burning questions you might have. One of the most significant places in the history of the country. There is a hall with banners, crests and mantles of a number of current Knights of the Order of the Bath which was definitely one of the impressive highlights.
A Longon must-see. The architecture is amazing and there is so much history here. A definite must-see while in London. You need to allow a bit of time because there is so much to see.

Westminster abbey. We went on a Sunday when visiting was not allowed
Enjoyed the organ recital and sunday worship service

So interesting!. So much history. It was wonderful to stroll at your leisure and take in all the interesting sights. I remember watching the royal weddings and it was amazing being in the exact same place. It was also interesting seeing all the statues and listening to things you learned about in school.
EMOTIONAL. If you get the tickets online, you enter the first, even before London Pass. The app guide is perfect.

Get the London Pass. We used to London Pass to bypass the ticket queue.
Plan to spend two hours at least because if you rush this you will miss some very very interesting points of interest.
We also attended a Sunday service.
Excellent.

Unique and Exceptional, Unforgettable, Not to be missed, Too busy and crowded. Westminster Abbey is incredible and leaves you moved by its beauty and historical significance. Disappointing that no photos are allowed and the ones in the gift shop are uninspired and predictable. The magic for me of taking a photo is in bringing home a photo that captures something of significance to me. The place was incredibly crowded . While most staff were kind and friendly the security guard on the front was rude and gave me the wrong advice twice (I asked him where people with online tickets were to line up and he pointed me to a long line up for people who didn't have tickets were to go. When I double checked he sent me back there again. We were later pulled from the long queue by other staff and allowed to enter because we already had online tickets. We encountered the same guard and he was rude again (July 20 at about 10:00). Having said all of the above, the Abbey is one of a kind and it should not be missed. I think they should work on crowd management and weed out the grumpy staff.

Verger tour of the Abbey.. The verger, which are the lay assistants to the abbey's various administrative and tourist related duties, gave a decent tour of the abbey. It includes access into the tomb area of Edward the Confessor and related persons that isn't available to people who haven't paid the 5 pound tour fee. However, I suspect that the taped tour gives much greater information overall.

Westminster Abbey is great. As the song says... "Take me to church!". Westminster Abbey is absolutely on the A-list of things to see in London. It's full of history and is impressive. You'll be very happy to see all that it has to offer. Make sure you get the audio guide to listen to the various recordings as you make your way around the Abbey. They do offer guided tours that seemed pretty good, but we preferred to do it ourselves by walking around at our own pace. While Notre Dame in Paris is impressive, this was actually even more interesting. If you want to experience the rich history of England in a gigantic and beautiful space such as this, make sure you visit Westminster Abbey. It's right by Big Ben, Parliament and the Winston Churchill museum. You can also head on over to the Thames River and jump on the tour boat and take a ride up to The Tower of London and Tower Bridge. By the way, this is included in the London Pass. If you're looking to do all of the key tourist sites in London, it's crazy not to get the London Pass. They do charge a hefty admission here if you don't have the pass. You'll save plenty of money.

A must. This historically important sight in London is a must see. Make this the first stop of your day and get there early. In fact, get a London Pass to get in. This place is a Who's Who of historical figures buried here. The architecture is amazing and the audio tour is narrated by Jeremy Irons. Definitely get that and get your history lesson for the day.

A Walk Through English History. Totally impressed with the history you see all around you at Westminster. There are opportunities to hear the choir during On Sundays... Check times. My daughter was interested in seeing the tombs of Queen Elizabeth I, Rudyard Kipling, Lewis Carol and others. The ornate statues and tombs are quite fascinating. If you get the London Pass, you can avoid the long lines.

Book the Tour. Kids should do the map.. We went and did not book the tour. We tried to follow the group but were cut off when they could enter places we could not. If we had known ahead of time, we would have booked it. However, we LOVED being here. Our sons got the kids map, this made them excited to be there. They hunted and searched for all of the quests on the sheet. At the end they received a large chocolate token!
Awesome architecture located right by the cathedral!. Massive building located right by the Abbey; steeped in history and deeply connected to the Royalty of England.

History and beauty. It is all there, dead kings, dead poets and anyone who made or shaped history. Darwin; Laurence Olivier; Franklin, Henry; Mary Queen of Scots; Lawrence of Arabia. The Lady Elizabeth Nightingale monument is especially amazing.

Majestic!. The architecture and art work of the building is just majestic and impressive. Really beautiful and a wonderful piece of art. Must visit no matter it is your first time or a repeat visitor. Will be there again on my next trip to London!

Amazing historical experience. Firstly we walked around the Abbey to take in buttresses and all the other features we had read about. Entering the Abbey you follow a set walk way which takes you through all the wonderful views and aspects including the many famous tombs of kings and queens. The nave, windows, architecture and the tomb of king Edward the Confessor are amazing. Also the cloisters are very appealing. A must visit when in London.

Expensive stop to visit God.. Cant believe they charge to visit churches in England. The line is endless, even for those with London Pass. Service schedule is random so not easy to sneak in for free during service. A shame that you have to pay to get into a church.

Must see when in London. My husband isnt to fussed on Churches/Cathedrals and even he was impressed! It truly is such a beautiful place and a must seeIf you're going to see one church, be sure to see this oneJust a note - no photography inside... you can get caught up in the beauty as soon as you walk in and not notice the signs :)
Impressive. Allow twice as much time as you originally planned. Every nook holds a new amazing story. The guided tour was excellent

Overwhelming. . In a great city full of icon and unforgettable places to see, this stood out for me. All European cities gave great, majestic cathedrals, historic government buildings and great museums. But the graves and memorials of a virtual Who's Who of British history from spy John Andre, Benedict Arnold's co-conspirator to Charles Darwin to every British Monarch was spellbinding as I read name-after-name.It is located in easy walking distance of almost every famous landmark in the old city from Big Ben to the London Bridge and one of those places you want to visit again and again.

Beautiful Church with so much history. My family and I (kids 9 & 11) all enjoyed our visit to Westminster Abbey. I recommend the audio guide because there is a lot of information. With the kids we went through faster and it took us an hour. You could stay longer but that was perfect for them.
Rude staff. The Abbey is a beautiful and amazing building. However, the staff are officious, rude and arrogant. The way they speak to members of the public is shocking.

Great. Fantastic for History geeks. There are many famous people buried here including Elizabeth 1, Henry 7th, Charles Dickens etc The architecture of the inside of the building is beautiful. I really enjoyed my visit and I would visit again.

beautiful singing. We attended evensong at the abbey one Thursday evening in July. We joined a queue by the entrance near to the shop at 4.15pm. At 4.30 we were allowed in to the abbey and assisted to seats by the verger. It was a wonderful service. The choir were on vacation and the singing was carried out by a visiting choir from Abbeygate College. They were a credit to their school as the singing was beautiful.It was lovely to be given the opportunity to visit the abbey for a service . It is such a beautiful building.

So much more than expected. The line took maybe 30 minutes to get through. I didn't know much about it, other than what I saw in the news. It was enormous! You could easily spend 2 or more hours in there. I think we made it through in an hour. The history, the graves, the statues, the various rooms, simply incredible.

Remarkable architecture. You'll pass by Westminster often if you're visiting London & it's easy to look at the other buildings all around. But this is a truly beautiful building that should be appreciated on its own. The history, of course, is remarkable. But the architecture on its own is worth being on your "must see" list. Beautiful.
What an amazing monument. we are quite impressed with Westminister Abbey. What an amazing art, incredible it is. if you are visiting London, it is a must to see.

Just because it's "The Abbey". Let's be honest... as far as European Cathedrals go, Westminster Abbey falls toward the lower end of the "impressive" scale. Many of her sister cathedrals provide more jaw-dropping offerings than does this abbey. To boot, there's a somewhat hefty (for a church) cover charge and pictures are forbidden (that's why we're there!).All that aside, what this abbey offers is an amazing glimpse into the history of the British Empire. Over a thousand years of monarchs have been crowned and married in this building, not to mention some MAJOR notables who lay buried on the property (I got a kick out of Darwin's gravestone myself). For that reason alone, it's a must see for visitors.

Beautiful. Grab guided tour sets. This was a beautiful place. We probably enjoyed it because we knew about it from the royal weddings etc. unfortunately you are unable to take photos. I bought my tickets online and was lined up with people with London pass. Lady came out and took us out of line to the front. It was good listening to information on audio guides. Enjoyed literary corner the most as knew these people. You could wonder around and go into all the crypts of past kings and queens. Rooms were small and sometimes hard to get into due to the amount of people. Price to get in isn't cheap, but worth it to preserve the history.
Amazing!. I wasn't sure how our kids would feel about this tour, but they loved it! We used the provided audio tours, and enjoyed the history grandeur and artistry of the Abbey.

Awesome. Cool inside the abbey on a very hot day. A snapshot of history which was breathtakingly magnificent.Despite crowds there was still a feeling of reverence which is missing from some of the cathedrals we have visited. Well worth waiting in the long queue for although we were too close to closing time to be able to spend as much time as we would have liked. Quite expensive to enter but worth it if you have plenty of time.

Nobodys not allowed..... Physically awesome, culturally imposing and world famous even before "The Da Vinci Code", the Abbey should not be missed. Seemingly, anyone who's ever been somebody in English history/culture is either interred here or is at least memorialized in one form or another. It's not too expensive to get in and the free ear phones are a must to guide you and to explain some of the highlights. Don't rush, there are wonders, views and history all around you. We arrived @ 3 PM, suffered through a short line at entry, and departed near closing (@ 5 PM?) fully impressed by it all!

One of London's main attractions. Westminster Abbey holds 90% of England's history. The lines can be long for entry, but they move fairly quickly. This is a "must see" for anyone who likes history and is in London!

Awesome. It is unique church with lot of history. It is the place where royal wedding took place. It is a bit costly. I had a London Pass which includes Abbey's entry. Do not forget to take audio guide. You'll know a lot about it's history. It's a wonderful place to be.

Grandeur and history meet. Even though I came with two sixteen year old girls, they could appreciate this grand edifice and amazing stories that it holds. I could have stayed longer since this a really historical and beautiful place. The people who work there are informative and pleasant. Must see!

History all around. It is a history lovers dream. With so many great morsels packed into one. Lines can be long but i found it worth the waitI also paid for the audio guide and was please with what I learnt.
Wow. This was our first sight we visited in London. We were amazed in the size. It's huge! We did the self guided tour. It was very information. Its a must see.

Very interesting self-guided tour. Lots of great history, interesting stories, and lots of dead people. My wife and I got the self-guided audio tour and it was great. Yes, it is pricey but how often do you expect to do this? We went on a Monday morning and the line moved fairly quickly.

Beautiful Swans. The Queen's backyard is full of interesting things. It's a shame she can't actually enjoy it herself. Having a guide really made us appreciate it. Without an educated guide you are basically just walking around in another park like environment.

Amazing!. Simply amazing! Seemed that everyone had the audio pack. Be sure to get one. As with any major attraction in London, best to arrive early. And the fast entry with the London Pass really was handy.

Westminster Abbey. This is a beautiful Abbey and it's huge. Allow a couple of hours to go through and see everything, there are many side chapels etc tucked away inside as well. You can get a free audio guide which I recommend getting so you know what you're looking at.It was £20 to get in, which is a bit steep but if you have room in your budget for it, it's worth going in.Toilets are in the Abbey but from what I could see and heard it was unisex and not really clean, so make of that what you will.There was long lines to get in but as long as it was, we got in within 15-20min. There was a guide patrolling the lines to move people through if you had a London Pass, so maybe look into those if you have no patience for lining up. We went in early July 2015 so peak season with lots of tourists.Overall though highly recommend visiting.
nice. one of the main and important places to visit if you have time or if it is not the first time in London,since you need few hours for it

It's a must see, but it's also expensive. Travelled in July 2015 with myself and older teens/young adults. It's expensive. About GBP 20 per person although if you can manage to organize yourself into a family package it works out a bit cheaper per person. Allow at least a couple of hours. We took the audio tour that comes free with the purchase price and would highly recommend it, as it is informative and gives you options for "extras" that provide more information. Westminster Abbey is crowded in July. We went an hour before it closed for admission and had to wait in line to enter.With all that said, it is a "must do": so much British history, from medieval to modern is represented here.

Amazing. One of the most breathtaking cathedrals in the world. Plan for at least 2 hours and be sure to check for event closures. Be sure to pick up an audio unit for your tour, though there are guides inside who are more than helpful.

Do not miss Evensong . I often visit religious houses and I do firmly believe that it's best to visit such places during times of worship - evensong will not disappoint.Arrive 30 mins before service to ensure good seats and it lasts no longer than 45 mins.The choir are excellent.A lovely place to gather ones thoughts after a busy day in the city.
Asitwas 2015. Everything, British history at its best. Very busy but able to observe and reflect on the building. Long queues and thousands of tourists but this is London afterall.

Don't Forget the Audio Guide!. I'll have to go back to Westminster Abbey about 10 times before I'll feel like I've really seen it. There has been so much crammed in there over the centuries that you can overlook so much.The nave is breathtaking, and not to be missed. But, all the little side chapels and rooms are very interesting. Make sure that you grab the little Audio Tour phones upon entering. My friend and I neglected this, and it was a mistake. There are very few signs explaining everything, and without the guide we didn't know what we were looking at most of the time. Most of it was written in Latin (which I only speak a little), and very worn with time. The price of admission is rather steep, but it's something you cannot miss when visiting London!

Wowzers. This place is pretty interesting. Really nice to look at. Free audio guides so you understand what you look at. Ridiculous 20 pounds to get in though. Can't take pictures or wear a hat so make sure you look good without a hat that day.

Stunning. This is a must see in London. It is very beautiful. They offer an audio tour, which is a very helpful guide. Be prepared for long lines. And you are not permitted to enter after 3:30 so provide yourself enough time to go through the line.

very dark....almost creepy. A cool respite despite the heat of early July in London 2015. It was nice but busy. Lots of space for a disabled traveler to sit for awhile. Rooms kept very dark, no air cond. but doors open for a breeze.

Loads to see, plan at least half a day. The Abbey was much larger than expected and just filled with statues, lovely pieces of architecture and much more. Unfortunately, I had a flight to catch and could only spend an hour here which was much too short. I will definitely visit again. If you are interested in details, I believe that you can easily spend at least 3 hours here.It was a great advantage having fast track entry with the London Pass, that saved some time so that I could admire the interior rather than the line outside. The only thing that was disturbing though was that you're not allowed to take pictures inside. I do understand that a lot of flashes lighting up is not desirable but with no flash should be allowed.
Far to expensive to go in. Just way to expensive. I think the entrace was about 20 pound per person. If it was 5 pounds or something it would be a fair price. This was just to much. too bad.

In the wrong place at the wrong time.. The only thing I found about Westminster was the poor Toilet facilities... maybe my friends and I were looking in the wrong place, but a queue of us were ushered in to crummy unisex facilities .... I was shocked.. after all, we had been charged a fee to enter a place of Worship... surely many of the thousands of people that go to visit need to use a loo.
Breathtaking & Beeyootiful. Breathtaking & Beeyootiful. Full of history and really really nice architecture. One of the many places to visit. Do make it a must visit!

20 quid to get into a Church is an outrage. I queued up for about five minutes and then saw the price. £20 to go into church. I left in outrage. I'm sorry but when you consider the Science, Natural History and Imperial War Museums are all free entry it's just ridiculous that they are charging that much to go into a church. As a Christian I object to having to pay to enter a place of worship no matter how famous it is. I went to see Billy Elliot the same evening and I actually paid 50p less for that than I would have had to pay to get into Westminster Abbey.
A piece of history. Overall, I would say it is worth visiting. I just don;t think spending money or too much time is needed.
A Spiritual Experience. Not only is it a place steeped in history. It is also a deeply spiritual experience to visit the Abbey.

Huge scale of history. This is not my first time in London and I have always wanted to come inside but never had the time to spare.Amazing inside the marbles and statues alone are something else.Surprised how quiet it was on a Tuesday afternoon.Stayed for much longer than planned and missed a shop in Selfridges, didn't mind a bit.The history is quite palpable and I felt lucky to be able to spend some time here.Highly recommended.

Old and interesting.. So interesting! So old! The audio commentary was very good. To the point but if you wanted to know more you could access extra information. Visit early in the day as, apparently, it gets busier as the day goes on. The cafe is good for coffee but didn't eat there so can't comment.

Simply beautiful. An amazing, old and beautiful Abbey situated in Weatminster.If you love old Architecture ( like I do ) and its contain yu have to go there.I think there are buried there important kings of the England History.

Amazing!. Absolutely loved Westminster Abbey. Before visiting, I did not realize how much history was inside. Kings and Queens buried there and plenty more. I would definitely recommend spending the time to go through the included audio tour.

Felt like a Royal.. Westminster is a unique Church with so much history. Westminster has been the most important religious home for the Royal Family for many decades. There are so many beautiful things to see. If you are lucky try to attend when the Boys Choir is performing. It is spell binding. The location is close to many other attractions, House of Parliament, Churchill's Underground Museum , and across the bridge is the London Eye..

Another must see!!. NOTE: If there is a disabled person in your party, be sure to bring proof. A disabled person and a caregiver both get free admission.This is another must see, do not go to London and miss this! I would have to say this is the one attraction we are extremely happy we saw! Don't forget to look for Isaac Newton and Darwin's tomes.

London 2015 Vacation. Westminster Abbey is an amazing place, so much history in one beautiful Abbey. My children really liked it as well, it is very educational for all. The thought that you are in a place that was built over 800 years ago is awe inspiring. I recommend anyone who has not seen it, take the time to visit.
Westminster Abbey. Absolutely breathtaking, immersed in history and one of the most beautifully designed Cathedral I've been to.

Awestruck. And visited for FREE.. Visited London with my teenaged daughter and enjoyed all the sites at our leisure. Took the "tube", which was so easy, convenient and inexpensive. We planned to tour inside Westminster Abbey but arrived at 4:15pm and found that tours not only cost a bit more than we wanted to spend, but they closed at 3:30pm to prepare for "Evening Song." What's "Evening Song?", I asked. Evening mass. Which happens at 5pm every evening. And as a religious service, it is free. This is a highlight, folks. Trust me.So we waited in line for about 15 minutes. The advised that no photography was allowed, as it is a full, hour long religious service. They checked our bags and seated us inside.The service was glorious. Words cannot describe the ethereal sound of the choir (all males) as they processed into the cathedral. It brought tears to my eyes.The service itself was fairly brief, about 1 hour, and included a mix of songs sung by the magnificent choir, prayers and readings. On the day we attended, one of the readings was done by a foreign diplomat, which was kind of interesting, also.They did usher us out (gently & slowly) at the end of mass, leaving ample time to meander about just a bit and snap a few inconspicuous photos. Docents chastise you if they hear the click of a camera, so use your cell discreetly if you are inclined to photograph the cathedral before or after Evening Song.And again "Evening Song" is religous services at 5pm daily, and it is free entry.
Don't miss this!. Unbelievable history and fascinating architecture. It is a must see. Don't miss this one. There is a substantial entry fee but worth every pence!

Westminster Abbey. You simply should not visit London without including Westminster Abbey. You can experience centuries of Coronations, Weddings, & Funerals in this marvelous Abbey. The historical information about Westminster during WWII is quite amazing. Don't miss Westminster Abbey!

The best of London!. Amazing building and a throwback in time! An absolute must do when in London! Do not miss it. Incredible history... the list of kings, queens, nobleman, etc buried here is surprising. Take the audio tour and hear the history that happened right where you are standing. The jaw dropping scale of the building is worth the visit.

Immersed in history. No wait at all but check the hours of opening, especially in the off season. The audio tour is easy to follow and very informative. The scope of the Abbey itself and the figures who have passed through (not to mention the ones who have been lain to rest) there truly leaves you speechless!

Couldn't Visit - Too Expensive. I'm used to touring continental Europe, where cathedrals and churches rarely ever charge entry. As a lover of churches, I was very much looking forward to visiting Westminster Abbey - unfortunately when we arrived, we learned that the entrance fee was very expensive (about 20 pounds), which, as a student, I cannot afford. I was very disappointed. The outside of the Abbey is beautiful, however.

The Abbey. Not to be missed; there is so much history here--and not just British History! People such as Charles Darwin, Sir Robert Walpole, W.H. Auden, Robert Burns, etc. An amazing place; though we all felt a bit strange walking across peoples' tombs. You can also attend services here on Sundays when it is not open to the public for tourism, only for services. Crowded, but worth it!
too costly to enter. shame they charge so much very few people going in not surprised, a british establishment the brits cannot afford

Well worth a visit. The Abby is a classic site in London and should be visited.The audio guide, which is included in the entry price is well worth using. There is lots to see and a lot of information. There queue was quite long when we got there, but the wait was not that long, maybe 20 minutes. There are plenty of staff on hand to answer questions.
Beautiful outside. Thinkig about a curch a was a bit disappointed of getting to know that you have to pay to enter it...it is beautiful outside but i think everyone should be free of enter and prey

Don't miss evensong!. We toured the Abbey on a Wednesday, late. There is no evensong on Wednesdays, so the Abbey stays open later. Incredible, and the audio guides are so helpful. We decided to go back on a Monday for evensong. An incredible experience.
Audio tour is a necesity. Even with the crowds, this abbey impressed me. If you come to London you must do this. The staff are very helpful as well. However, no pics are allowed.

Magical. Westminster Abbey was so magical. The feeling you get while walking thru listening to the history was so spiritual and humbling. The architecture was unbelievable. Truly my favorite tour of our stay in London.

Worth the Time. The queue for London Pass holders was significantly shorter than those waiting to purchase tickets. The audio guides are interesting but every man in a red robe that helped us was extraordinarily friendly and knowledgeable. It is just amazing the rooms (Chapels) all around the building, the tombs, the architecture, the mosaic on the alter is fascinating. Worth the time to go inside an walk through the audio tour.
Beautiful. This beautiful little church is well worth a visit just to see the history steeped in her and to see where the Royals go.

Must see. We did a guided tour, an extra 5 pounds per person but well worth it. Lots of history only someone can relay versus a iPod. Took 35 minutes in rain to get to front, not a big deal. Lots of history, we spent 2 hours and probably could have spent another hour but had more to see.

Need the audio tour to better understand the effect.. Manny many people. We got there rights before it opened. LOng long line ups on one side prepaid tickets and London pass holders, on the other line up people who needed to pay. Interesting and a Lott of history, but lots of or ople
Great historic cathedral. Westminster abbey is a great historic church to visit, with brilliant architecture. There is a fee and it Opens every day for visiting except Sunday.

Pictures can not capture the beauty. Such a beautiful old church. It was hard to capture the beauty in a photo. Unfortunately we visited it on a Saturday so it was very crowded but it is a must see. They are doing some repairs on one side of the church but it didn't take away from it's beauty. Very historic.
Beautiful and inspirational. We attended an Evensong Service, open to the public, and it was wonderful just to be sitting in this majestic church. Afterwards the pealing of the bells was magnificent!
Since 1042. It is impressive to be in a place that has stood for nearly a thousand years and that has seen such history. The building, the carvings and the statuary are magnificent

One of Eurpe's Greatest Cathedral because of its Contents. Sure, there are more beautiful cathedrals in Europe, but the historical contents of Westminster place it among Europe's finest. The interior contains elegant elements, including the choir and Henry VII's chapel. More importantly, the church contians the graves and tombs of kings, poets, heretics, politicians, and political figures. It's crowded at all times but it's worth a visit. Try a "hot dog" from the vendor to the right as you leave the cathedral.

One of my all time favorite places to visit.. There's just so much history here that you can't possibly be sorry to wait in line and pay 20 pounds to visit. Just imagine all the royalty and others who have passed through those doors.

Beautiful. The church was beautiful. We took a small group tour with a Verger who took us to some of the areas of the church that were off-limits to the public. He gave us a ton of background about the building and some of the many historical and impactful events that took place there.It was also fun to search for famous names buried at the Abbey as well!
Fantastic. Wow such an amazing feeling of history. I loved being there and seeing, in person, all those areas I've seen on TV.

Historic, beautiful building. Very cool to see the tombs of many past rulers and notable figures as well as the place of royal coronations. Interestingly the Abbey is still in use and as such, is used for worship services that anyone can attend and in fact one was going on while I toured. My favorite part was the lady chapel. Admission includes an audio guide that provides information as you work your way through. There is also a small museum off the courtyard of the abbey with many interesting artifacts from the building's past. Also there are no photos allowed in the abbey

Awesome jaw dropping. The most famous of all the landmarks - this being the well known venuev for the Royal,events is clearly not to miss on anyone's list . The beauty of this place brings back an era of the Royalty not seen elsewhere . The witness to the Royal household's major historical transitions to modernity . Worth the visit . The location is excellent .

churches. There are so many beautiful churches,you cannot take pi cyures inside. If they see your camera or phone is on they will come up and tell you to put them away.when I posted the pi c on my Facebook which for this rttip I put on Public so friends and family who don't have Facebook could see them.I just postedbtake your pick Diana wa either married or buried from one of these. They are beautiful architecture is fantastic . History is amazing Al from British tours made it so much more interesting with dates and facts and his enthusiasm for the historical and majesty make you feel like going back in time. He just doesn't point out things he gives the history and names.

Must see in London!. Westminster Abbey is beautiful from the outside but the inside leaves you almost at a loss for words. Thousands of people are buried in the abbey, including many famous folks. The line to get in can be long so be prepared for a bit of a wait. The abbey does get quite crowded so you might have to wait your turn to get a closer look at some things. The audio guide, narrated by Jeremy Irons, provides a lot of interesting information about the abbey and is worth the time to get. You can also download the audio guide on your phone and listen to it that way. I highly suggest going into the abbey rather than just viewing the outside. There is so much history!

Beautiful, Historic and A Place NOT to Miss if in London. This was one of the highlights of my trip to London. I love the history of the monarchy and seeing where many of the well-know royalty had their coronations as well as their burial was truly fascinating. I loved the self-guided tour which was on a phone and included video as well. Able to roam around and repeat spots if wanted to.

Iconic Part of British History. Save time and get a London Pass. I wish we had. The audio tour is not well organized. It does not start on part 1 until you have walked halfway across the building. My wife kept getting lost on the appropriate recording for specific areas.

Very Good Experience. I can't believe I come to London so often and I've never been here. I also can't believe that so many people are buried here either! Definitely a great place to see at least once in your lifetime. The audio set they give you gives so much information about the Abbey and the people buried there, a lot to take in! I think we spent about two hours here to properly take everything in. I would recommend buying tickets online before you go because there was no queue at all for online purchases (or the city pass holders), yet there was a huge queue for those who were buying on the day! They also do student discount.

Check out the Evensong service. If you are going to do the tour, make sure you purchase tickets in advance. The line can be long. We wanted to check out the Evensong service and got there about 45 minutes before the scheduled time, queued up with the others and ended up in the second pew, It's a great way to see the Abbey while the choir sings its magic, and it's entirely free. The service was about 45 minutes long. Highly recommend.

Take some time to take in history. This is one of the awe-inspiring attraction in London. Once entered you are invited to look at history, because the sculptures on the walls, writings, all tells us about the time when the church seemingly had a lot of power, just as Parliament, a few yards across the street, do today. And then too, where we were standing, on the graves of some of the so-called martyrs. And the pipe organ and the stained glass, tells more than words.Many in the audience were moved to express their feelings in prayer. For me, i did not have enough time to soak up all the history that was on offer. I glanced over it telling myself that i want to come again.

A must see . Have always heard about this place on the news so was a place I was always going to visit when in London. The first thing that strikes you is how big it is, but once inside the history and architecture of the church is fascinating. Audio guides are provided on entry which means you can take the tour at your own pace. Would definitely recommend.

A little history in a beautiful abbey. Get there early to avoid a long queue, although it does move quickly. Westminster abbey is surreal and interesting. A place of worship, as well as a tomb. The history which is associated with it, is just awe inspiring. I must have gone on a good day as everyone that went around was respectful. The free audio guide was informative, but keep an eye on where you are, i stopped to look at something, then got confused where i should be on the guide. People may say the ticket price is a bit steep, but to help preserve the abbey, its worth it.

Amazing environment and history. The experience here was great for all of us - from grandparents, teens and young kids. The amount of links to history is incredible. One tip - we were really glad to have our London pass and skip the queue.
The Pilgrimage Site of London. There is really nothing I can add to the description of this magnificent place. Any visitor with even a small amount of interest in history must stop here.

Westminster. This is worth the trip!
A lot of history to see and absorb, get a guide its well worth it.
We used Blue Badge.

Average. If you like history, don`t miss it. Otherwise, it is a magnificent but austere building that gave me chills: an active place of worship and a burial site, all in one. More beautiful from the outside. St Paul`s is thousand times better in every aspect of it.

Go to Mass. I went to an afternoon Service and it was so worth it! I got to see everything, without paying the entrance fee, and enjoyed being with other locals. However, I did not enjoy the fact that the other tourists were walking around the designated service area, which was not in the main area but on the backside, and everyone had there headphones blasting the audio tour so loudly, it was distracting and rude.

Loved it. Went one evening for an Anglican mass and then another for a guided tour. It is amazing to see this thousand year old structure containing the remains of many people including sir Isaac Newton, sir Lawrence Olivier, Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Queen Elizabeth I, and many more. Definitely a must see.
