I've given four stars on the basis that it's Westminster Abbey but as a visitor attraction it leaves much to be desired.

Astounding. I love this place! It is a beautiful architectural specimen and the ornate interior is mind boggling. But what sets it apart for me is the myriad of tombs and shrines for both royalty and those who have made contributions to history. I could spend hours in here, if I were left to my own devices!

A Must See. Westminster Abbey is spectacular as a cathedral, a burial site of kings and queens and statesmen, a memorial for poets and other members of the arts, and a gorgeous structure. This and St Pauls are the top 2 cathedrals to see in London.

Amazing building, outstanding history. Few buildings can boast the historical significance of this place. The audio tour (is that Jeremy Irons?) Is really helpful and kids can do a scavenger hunt. From the architecture to the graves and memorials, people from everywhere can appreciate this building and all it contains. Spend a good amount of time here to learn all you can.
1000 years of history. Living church with museum ambiance, not to be missed. Use the excellent audio guide, otherwise difficult to tell what you're looking at

Emotional!. One of the most beautiful place in the world, very emotional! The architecture is splendid, and it's an historical place where every detail, every tomb is particular. You have to go there!

Royal cemetery. Great disappointment after all the great expectation from reading up history. All I saw was tomb after tomb of former kings and queens. Perhaps, because they don't mean much to me, a non-English.
Should be free. £20 entry fee is absurd. Most London attractions are free and should remain that way. The church is wealthy enough
Take a stroll through the Abby . We took a stroll through the Abby to Big Ben it was pleasant if you have extra I'd say take a walk through hundreds of years of history
Worth a Visit. Wonderful architecture from outside and inside. Tombs from royals dated from over hundred years. Unfortunately no photos are allowed inside.

Beautiful, must see. It was so beautiful and it was wonderful to have the audio listen to while touring here. The lines to get in do get long so it's best to visit first thing in the morning. It took us about 1 1/2 hrs to go through and see everything here.
WOW. so muuch history. you get a self guided tour and it walks you through it. amazing, they dont let you take pictures. We were here for like 2-3 hours.

Beautiful and historic, although tough on younger audiences.... Westminster Abbey is definitely one of the "must do" attractions upon visiting London, especially for a first time visitor, but it's something I felt that only appeals to those not traveling with young children. Be prepared for un-friendly staff, large groups passing through and a very expensive visitor fee.
Perfection. This is by far (and I visited a lot) one of the most beautiful masterpieces of art I have ever seen. It's wonderful even for non religious people. Definitely visit it.
Breathtaking. This is a part of history not to be missed. Walk the paths of the greats of British history as well as the ordinary people.
Massive Complex. Put on your walking shoes as this place is massive to walk around but just as big historically. Get there early before the crowds jam up the area. The tube stops are all nearby.

A MUST for Architecture Fans. The building is amazing. You will see a lot of additions to the original Abbey but you can still the beauty of the original lines. There is tons of history with a very good audio tour. Pricey but worth it.

Always a lovely place to visit.. I have visited the Abbey many times over the last 20 years and if this your first visit to London you must see it. However, if you are a frequent traveler, try and go during a service to experience the music and the surroundings, but skip the line and all the tourists. Each year the admission has gone up and the lines have gotten longer. I was visiting with students so I went in, but it was so crowded that visiting most of the areas felt like a battle, not a visit. Go early or late - but not during the heart of the day.
A must see. Train station is just there so really easy to get to and great to see the history, lots of people though and very busy

Amazingly beautiful!. Westminster is fascinating and beautiful! I do recommend getting there early. We arrived about 10 minutes and had to stand in a short line, but later in the day the line outside and the crowds inside were much, much worse. Also, I highly recommend paying the extra 5 pounds for the verger tour. I learned so much more than from the audio tour and it was much more engaging. Also, on the verger tour, you are allowed to go into the shrine to see the tomb of Edward the Confessor and several other British monarchs. We spent almost 5 hours here. There is literally history at every step! The cafe was also nice - enjoyed a nice lunch and then went back to exploring the abbey. This was quite possibly my favorite place in London. The only negative is that you are not allowed to take photos inside the abbey (which I totally understand). Fortunately, they have several nice books for purchase which capture the beauty of the abbey.

Step back in time. We arrived at about 2pm and the line of people really wasn't to bad, maybe a half an hour wait on a Wednesday. The line finishes just inside the door. There was something about pre-booking online with no line of people, might be worth investigating?Make sure you pick up your head set which is included in the price, so many people seem to just 'wander' around. There is really not a lot of written info so they are a must. Plenty of seats around so you can sit and listen it can be quite tiring walking very slowly.I was a bit disappointed that you are not allowed to take photo's inside, and you can't do it on the sly either as there a lot of security people around. It is very busy inside and some of the chapels that you will go in are very small it's just something you have to put up with.If you walk around the cloisters this is counted as being 'outside' so you can take photo's and you will come across a tea room also serving light lunches and they have toilets here.

A building of great interest.. This is an essential part of English architectural history - a series of religious buildings were set on this site from 624, with an Abbey and monastery founded in 960. The present gothic building - construction of which started in 1245 - was concluded 1517. Since that time several additions added to the grandeur - particularly the towers constructed under the supervision of Hawkesmoor between 1722 and 1745. If you like old buildings, this one is for you.
great piece of history. Spent an entire afternoon looking at graves and the tour. Lots to see and do here-- and lots to learn. Be prepared to spend the majority of a day here.
Pricey. The abbey is gorgeous from the outside. However, they charge for admission and the lines are long. We didn't feel it was worth the wait, but it may be for others.

Essential to any London visit. Simply a must visit for anyone interested in British history. I especially enjoyed the Poet's corner for my love of literature. However, lines can get long and there are lots of people so it can be quite crowded. Don't let this discourage you though, its well worth the visit!
Must see - attend a service if you can. Beautiful to see in person. Highly recommend attending a service where you can really absorb the majesty of the church and hear the choir!

Beauiful. Westminster Abbey is one of the most beautiful churches I've ever seen! It grand and magical. It has an amazing story. If you go to London you have to visit it. You have to pay to enterbut it's worth it! Go early in the morning so you avoid the crowd.

Beautiful Sites and Sounds. My family was in London this past week and had to see the notorious Westminster Abbey. We walked around the abbey and marveled at the beautiful architecture. That evening we attended a free organ concert that we all greatly enjoyed. Halfway through the concert the sun streamed through the stained glass. Absolutely beautiful. Wish I could have taken pictures inside, but I will always remember the lovely sites and sounds.

A walk through British history. Westminster Abbey is one of those places where you just feel like you need to visit. There is a great audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons to keep you informed. But in actuality, this is an ornate cemetary of sorts. The majority of the sites are mausoleums and statuary placed to memorialize monarchs and other celebrated Britons. But it is a beautiful abbey that walks you through much of British history all the way up to Prince William's and Catherine's wedding.
Simply beautiful. A combination of history, architecture, art and faith. We could go to a church service and was a unique experience.
Historic and awe inspiring.. Stepping into Westminster Abbey is like stepping back in time. Beautiful and filled with history, it is a must see in London.

History within your reach!. If you're a history buff you're going to love Westminster Abbey, littered with the tombs of the famous and royals going back many hundreds of years. But why no photos??? When I've visited in the past photos were allowed.
Amazing!. We weren't sure what to expect, but found the Westminster Abbey to be a beautiful, historic, informative place to visit. A definite must for a trip to London!
A beautiful church with a grand history. Very beautiful church with magnificent architecture, monuments, and art work. Air-conditioned. This is a place of worship, but a must see.

Queens and Kings oh my!. I can't believe I saw Queen Elizabeth I's tomb. Queen Mary, King Edward I, and various other King Henrys and Richards. You can only see King Edwad I's tour on the paid tour, but it's worth it to hear the stories of the Abbey firsthand. I also attended evensong so I could hear the choir and pipe organ. They were breathtaking.

Amazing!. This is such a phenomenally beautiful and significant church. A must see in London. Go early to get in without as much of a crowd. Also do thew audio tour which is free and helps explain a lot of the tombs and relationships between the royalty. Also get your tickets on-line. The line is shorter to enter. Don't miss the Tomb of Elizabeth and Mary such a beautiful chapel. I've never seen one in white before. Also Poets Corner is fun to find your favorite. We saw Charlotte and Emily Bronte to name a few.

MUST SEE IN LONDON. Huge set of buildings that are now an operating church that is used by the royal family for weddings, funerals etc. Many famous people are buried in the abbey including kings and queens. A lot of history. Be aware there are usually two rather long lines of people waiting to get in. One is for people who need to purchase tickets, the other is people with tour groups and passes. Also, they are not open on Sundays.

See it while you're there. I only saw this from the outside but architecturally it is quite impressive and just the thought of Will and Kate getting married there is intriguing enough at least for me... :D It's right next to Big Ben so might as well combine them and the palace too of course.

Pricey, but a Must-See. I was initially turned off by the price (which could definitely be lowered), having visited other churches for free, but the amount of history contained within and the beautiful architecture makes for a great visit. Definitely something to include on your London to-do list.

Expensive but worth it. At GBP20 a head, this is an expensive attraction but it remains a must-see nonetheless. Even though we visited away from peak season and on a weekday, the place was packed which inevitably detracts slightly.I have to confess to being slightly annoyed at the ban on photography which is rigorously enforced. That's particularly when everyone's already completely distracted by their audio guides.Don't expect quiet contemplation, but as a condensed dose of English history, it takes some beating.
Beautiful. The line was short, the staff knowledgable and helpful and the audio tour was good and easy to adjust to your own interests.
Real Gems Of British Architecture !. Great view in sunny day! not get chance to go inside. but also you can get nice view of it from London eye.

A Royal Display but Pricey.... One of the traditional royal places of London, the "Abbey" is not only a good display of english monarchy history but also a full time Church. Because of that, the visitor schedule its quite strict with regular masses everyday. Lots to see inside, from royal tombs to the coronation chairs. The downfall might be the hefty price (20 pounds) but includes a free audio guide. If you are willing to meet the price its something different to do.

Loved the experience. At first it was a little disconcerting that we had to pay to enter when we have visited churches in other countries and did not have to pay to see them. That said the experience was very good with the audio sets really helping with the interpretation of the site. The value was there for the money. We would have liked to take some pictures but respect the reasons why it is not allowed.

Step back in history. I love Westminster Abbey! I've visited three times and it never ceases to amaze me. The architecture is so detailed and the history of the cathedral is mind boggling. Do not miss going here if you ever make it to London. It is a must see. Though the price to get in is a bit steep in my opinion. I recommend going early in the day or sometime during the year that isn't tourist season to avoid ridiculous lines and crowds.

A must visit historic church.. Westminster Abbey is a London Icon and one of the top sights, a must see, during your visit. It has so much history you could easily spend hours absorbing all there is to see. A guided tour is a good idea but leave your camera at your hotel, no photos. I suggest purchasing a guide book which has plenty of photos as well as a review of what you will or have seen.

Wonderful. Wonderful. You can visit Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots, Charles Darwin, and Lord Byron all in the same place. If you're going to London, don't miss this place.If you're looking for something to do, go to Evensong at 5pm. Get there early, though, because there's a line. Its very cool to being in the Abbey after hours, and if you're at the beginning of the line, you can sit in the Quire (choir) and be surrounded by the Westminster singers.

Exquisite Abbey!. Absolutely beautiful abbey, with soaring Gothic architecture. The site of many royal weddings and graves. Services were being conducted as we were there. Only disappointment was that they do not allow indoor photography!

Beautiful and full of history. This was one of my favorite places that we visited in London. The architecture is so amazing inside and outside. I loved seeing Poet's Corner and the ancient coronation throne. It can get pretty crowded at peak hours, so you may want to visit early.

Best part of London. Paid the extra £5 for the verger led tour and wasn't disappointed. This tour left me in awe and wonder. So informative and full of such wonderful history! A must see for anyone coming to London!

Formal, beautiful evensong service. I visited the Abbey for the Evensong service on a June evening. As the ushers reminded those of us in queue waiting to go inside, this is not a tourist event, but as a Christian I found it to be beautiful service in this elegant & grand church. We were ushered inside a few minutes before the start time and sat in chairs on either side of the central nave. Early birds got to sit in the pews next to the choir seating. The service lasted about 46 minutes and there was no late entry or early exit. The service itself was very formal with much flourish. The message was a simple reading of a few passages, but the songs were uplifting and enjoyable. We were given a program and participated in response. Overall, it was enjoyable.

Holiday viist. Follow strict timings for visitors.. A place to remember all the great legends , Laureates,Royalties, heroes of country..each n every step n statues reminds you of great people who contributed for the welfare of the country..different tombs of kings n queens give brief history of each era. Centre of Abbey n coronation chair are worth seeing..recorded guides are available.. Minimum one hour to see the entire abbey..

Amazing Church. Many of your favorite poets are buried here along with royalty. It is still a working church. I loved the architecture, and the history. It was disappointing that no pictures were allowed.

A must see in London. Loved the guided audio tour, so much to see. Could have spent more time here and toured it slowly. Even my kids, 10 and 13, enjoyed this tour. Amazing amount of history in 1 place.

Beautiful. This was on our LondonPass and part of our must see list. Glad we went - beautiful. The intricate designs and awesome architecture are beautiful and it was cool how some stone walking paths are worn from the many feet walking on them through the ages. Great gift shop, too.
Great place.. It's a place that gives u thrills down u spine. So special . Just too look and take everything in.It's a place that everyone should go and see. Really churchie if u know what I mean.

Closed on Sunday. Unless you attend the services or evening song you won't be able to go inside the Abbey on Sunday, but ironically the gift shop is open to all comers :) We were there of course on Sunday.

Wow, a must do!. Have been here many times. Most recent visit in June. A fabulous place of impressive architecture, history, and culture. We go every time we are in London and never regret it. Along with St. Paul's, this is a must do for anyone traveling to London.

Audio Tours have enhanced this experience. Upon visiting the Abbey after a 10+ year gap, I was impressed with the audio tour offered. I felt a much deeper appreciation for all the nuances, tombs and depth of who all is buried in this stunning cathedral. I happened to be touring on a Thursday when the gardens were open and that was a pleasant surprise and worth seeing. The Abbey is a must see even on the most packed London visits.

World famous and worth a visit. The guides and leaflets you get inside are very informative and the scale of the place is astounding. This is the kind of place where it makes me very angry when all people want to do is stand there, get in people's way and take photos! The postcards you can buy are of much better quality than anything they could take with their oversized phones and it would mean they weren't clogging up the flow of visitors! That said, it's a beautiful place, really easily accessible by bus or tube, and it does make you feel like you really have seen a world famous spiritual place.

Vergers are heaven sent!. Have been to Westminster Abbey a dozen times. But this time, we took the Verger tour. Benjamin was an angel. Made the 90 minutes fly by with an entertaining mix of history, architecture, royal life and faith. Buy your entry tickets online the night before your visit and avoid the long lines. You pay the five pounds for the Verger tour after you enter the Abbey.

Stunning and well worth it!. This is by far, the most historical building you can see in downtown London. You must pay to get inside, however it's well worth it. Everyone in history (mostly) is buried here. I highlight recommend seeing this treasure.
Beautiful. Great place to visit, both inside and out. You can spend a lot of time here discovering things you didn't even know about. Even my English hosts were wowed!

A Must See!. Westminster Abby is a must see for all visitors going to London. It is spectacular with its beautiful stained glass windows, artwork, and architecture. There are over 3,000 people buried at Westminster. It is the resting spot of Henry the VII and Elisabeth of York. Walking through this Abby gives the visitor a good understanding of the history and beauty of London.

Expensive to Visit - Long Queues!. One of the most photographed in the world!It is the finest of all of England’s Cathedrals but it is expensive to visit as a tourist. It is also where monarchs are crowned and other state occasions such as funerals and weddings take place.We considered the admission fee too expensive in the first place but also we thought to do something else than line behind the long endless queue. I remember from our previous visit some years back it was crazy in there. It seems at times you are moved quickly through some parts and crowds wanting to see the Abbey can be huge at times. There is always pressure from the staff to move people on to avoid congestion and this is not nice at all.

If you just want to get inside, go to Evening Prayer. If you really just want to get inside and don’t care about who is buried there, spend 45 minutes and attend an Evening Prayer. You will save yourself £20 (as they don’t charge you to attend a service) and have 45 minutes to sit and admire this amazing building. I have attended an Evening Prayer and paid for entrance and to be honest, I think the Evening Prayer is the best route. Save the £20 (outrageous!) entrance fee and go to a pub for a good dinner afterwards.

Pretty. Pretty and historical very close to Westminster and Trafalgar Square so these areas are often viewed together when traveling. You can to my knowledge attend a service at Westminster abbey but mobile phone should be off etc... November time /Year through - there are often poppies or memorials to victims around the abbey gardens

A superb guided tour. I visited Westminster Abbey some years ago and used the audio facility. On this second occasion, I was determined to join a guided tour and it was truly a superb performance by the guide. Despite the crowds, he was able to select just the right spots when almost free to give a splendid presentation of the innumerable historical treasures that the Abbey contains. I have the highest praise for the guided tour.
What a magnificent place to visit. The abbey is as impressive as we had heard. The architecture is stunning and the burials and memorials provide a great view of England's history.
ok. my husband had never been, so it was good for him, as i come from london , been many times, not cheap, when i was a child used to just put sonmthing in box. but if never been worth a visit

Chuck load of history. Came here as part of London walk tour. Manage to avoid the long queue and enter from a separate queue. The guided tour through is very informative about its history and current past events happening in the abbey.

Beautiful Church. We lined up at 9 AM for a 9:30 opening. It took us about 20 minutes to get in after it opened. The line grew quickly prior to the opening and this was in May. The church was exceptional, but there is a steep price. It cost 37 pounds for two of us. At the current exchange rate that was about $60.

Great for history buffs. Wonderful walking tour with free audio. Each area holds a past king or queen, plus many other notable people. Great architecture and archives. Definitely worth the admission price and is covered under the London pass
Across from the Parliament and Big Ben.. Make sure to go in - resting place of Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Dickens and so many famous poets. Also is a beautiful church.

One of my favourite monuments. Westminster Abbey was one of my favourite monuments to visit while in London.The architecture is grandiose and the craftsmanship on display is exquisite. There are many details that catch one's attention but it's difficult to take our eyes off the ceiling at the Henry VII Chapel. The audio-guide is very well done. Clear, informative, and concise, it contributed to a certain degree for how much I enjoyed my visit.
Add To Your Tour List. So much history (unlike the U.S.) that you almost can't believe time that long ago. Very well maintained and staff to answer all of your questions, no matter how many.

Amazing Gothic Architecture. We arrived early afternoon to a moderate queue. Although this is not an official London Pass skip-the-line destination, we were taken quickly through a separate entrance. The audio guide featuring British actor Jeremy Irons is excellent and provides rich history of the many sights within the Abbey. Don't miss the Cloisters at the end of the tour. Allow at least two hours for your visit.

Gorgeous church though difficult to navigate. Westminster Abbey is chock full of history in every nook and cranny.You can see the burial spots of some of the most famous monarchs, authors, poets, scientists, etc in English history, not to mention the coronation throne that dates back centuries. There is also the gorgeous Gothic architecture. The only real problem is that when it's crowded it can be very difficult to see many of the special things. There's nothing that can be done about that, short of turning the whole church into a giant queue, but it is a legitimate issue when you're trying to see a certain tomb or appreciation some of the beauty around you. With crowds pushing from every direction it can be difficult to enjoy, especially if you're of the shorter variety. Also, I hated that no photography was allowed inside the church. I understand no flash but it was a shame to have no pictures from my visit.

A Glimpse into British History. We were surprised at how much there was to see and how well presented it was. There were staff and volunteers around to answer questions and make suggestions. The audio tour was excellent. We had no idea how much the Abby provided. We had a lovely lunch in their cafeteria and it was very good.

Free entry for wheelchair users. Great service. Once we approached the church, we were friendly greeted by an employee who pointed us in the right direction. Because you can't access everything in the Abbey with a wheelchair, they will give you a free ticket. Overall there is still enough to see with the wheelchair. The carer will also receive a free ticket. Very good service!

Truly the most beautiful building in London. . From the moment you see the building from the outside to entering and taking in the whole experience. ... One can stand and sit amazed at the sheer architecture of this place.

HISTORY UNRAVELLED. This is an amazing structure worth a visit and also an excellent place to know a lot of history provided you are not on a city tour and can spare close to 3 hours for it. Guided tours are available and this place is crowded too. We did not participate in the services The architecture of this place is a treat for eyes..

Everything that I imagined it would be!. It was amazing! The architecture, the painting, the statues, it is all magnificent! You cannot take pictures inside, but you can take pictures outside. There is a great little food stand, just outside of the Abbey. It sells big hotdogs with all the fixing. They also sell some good desserts. Don't go to London without seeing Westminster Abbey and the Westminster Chapel, right down the street.

I still pinch myself...was I really there?. The history, the abbey takes hours to see properly....mass is happening as you tour...to actually see the tombs of past queens, Kings...your mind just cannot absorb it all...the ceilings will take your breath away....IT IS ENGLAND!!...how or why could you not visit!!
Do not miss this. I have been here many times but because of the size of it you see something new every time. Beautiful building so rich in history.
Massive Church. Lots of history, lots to see. Busy place. Very impressive architecture. Just imagine all the royalty that has been married or buried from this church. Amazing.
See it if you have time. Westminster Abbey is an incredibly impressive and historic building. I would recommend taking the self-guided tour to anyone who likes history or architecture.

Just awesome in every way. Absolutely worth the time. A beautiful church steeped in history. Truly thought-provoking and inspiring to see all the "resident" entombed and remembered there. Get there at 09:30 to avoid extensive lineup. We only waited about 10 minutes.

Amazing Structure and History!. Westminster Abbey is a historical marvel which covers a millennium of monarchs. Plan to spend a complete day if you can soak up this much material. A minimum of four hours is needed for a quick once-through. Those who wish to participate in the services are treated to wonderful choral music as well!Those who are interested in the building and architecture will not be disappointed. Quite a feat for the tools of the day!!

#1 Attraction in London. Visited two weeks ago and it is absolutely beautiful! They are doing construction on the outside so a section of the abbey is covered. It is also a bit pricey and you are not allowed to take photographs inside but it is totally worth it. The architecture is amazing and there is so much history within those walls. I would recommend to everyone and anyone.

Full of crypts. We came down to have a look at the houses of parliament then decided to have a look around here. Slightly surprised it cost £40 for two adults but then I guess thats cheap for London? Great place full of history and was surprised at just how many crypts and tombs were contained within just about every good or great person from down the ages seems to be buried here! We didnt use the audio tour and were content to just bimble around and take in the sites. If you love history would recommend.
beautiful. A must see, very beautiful inside and out. Stained glass windows. No rush, you can take as long as you like to see everything.

Brief visit. I attended the Abbey to meet a VIP. I enjoyed the visit and spent a brief time in the MP's area adjacent to the Thames. I already had lunch but enjoyed a cake and some tea. My only comment is that the place could benefit from a few less Tory, Labour and LibDem MP's.#56
History lessons come alive.. I squeezed a visit to this historic Abbey in between meetings. It was a wonderful way to decompress- quiet, rich and meaningful.

Wonderful and inspiring. Try to get there when the Abbey first opens in the morning. Fewer crowds, smaller line. I think there might have been 20 people in line ahead of me before the doors opened. Take your time and use the audio headset. There is so much history in this building, it is amazing.

A must do in London. The historical items inside are amazing, just spectacular, absolutely worth the cost and one attraction everyone should do once. Definitely take the audio tour with Jeremy Irons, he has the perfect voice for this sort of tour and it allows you to move around at your own pace. Don't bother with the service though, it's nothing more than what you'd get in a regular church.
beautiful place with history. if you like history and great moment, it is the place to go. Kings are part of this church and you can feel it. take your time and enjoy the architecture

Absolutely Amazing!. We did the self guided tour. It is an amazing building with tons of history and the bones of many a monarch. It was far better than I expected. I highly recommend the self guided tour. One of the best self guided tours I've been on.

Recommend the Verger Tour. It costs a bit extra, but we highly recommend the Verger Tour. Benjamin was our guide and he was nothing short of AMAZING. We did part of the audio guide while waiting for our guided tour to begin and, in comparison, the guided tour offered a much better introduction to the building & history of the abbey, as well as how it functions and is used today. Our group threw a variety of questions at Benjamin and he unfailingly had a detailed and helpful answer. Tour also offered access to Edward the Confessor's Chapel, which is generally closed to visitors except for certain prayer hours. Suggest you plan approximately 3 hours for your visit.
Rich in history. That's a site very rich in history and culture. A must see in London if you want to get anything historical. Plan a few hours to visit.
History surrounds you.. This Abbey has seen society's great moments and moments to be forgotten. Every step is an event. Kings, Queens and Paupers have been its patrons.

A concertrated dose of British history. Everything from the chair that monarchs sit for receiving the crown to the graves of most of the illustrious Brits. An excellent cafe and shop. There is an absolute prohibition on photography as if this was going to hurt the scenery. These prohibitions are totally absurd and a relic of the past. It's not like the place was going to go broke if people don't buy souvenir booklets. Aside from this, it's a fascinating place to visit: where all of the royal , deaths, marriages and coronations are celebrated.

Enjoyable Visit, but a little on the pricey side. Had a lovely visit to Westminster Abbey during our visit to London. Having the audio tour included is a definite plus. Being able to know the history and background while you experience the Abbey was a nice touch, but it is a little expensive (20 GBP) to visit. And keep in mind that it is still an active, functional church so they still hold mass even if you happen to be in the middle of your tourist visit! For me, it was worth the visit.

The highlight of our visit. Our group made this our 1st stop in London, and it proved to be our best as well. The recorded story was most helpful, as one was able to explore countless chapels, niches and displays. The Poet's Corner was awesome. Seeing some video clips of coronations gave us some more recent context as well. A sight that every visitor to London should take in.

A Great Abbey. My husband and I are happy that we visited the abbey. The sights within are incomparable and even though we had to wait in line to get in it was well worth it. The architecture was unsurpassed and it was incredible to see where the British monarchs are crowned!

TAKE THE TOUR. I saw so many people just walking in and not knowing anything about the history. If you are there TAKE THE TOUR. You will learn so much about its history, and some special surprises about people who are buried there!

Make sure you know the secret word if you're visiting in the evening!. I came for the free visit in the evening. The line/queue was very long that evening. When you get the front, the man will ask, "What are you here for?" If you say to "visit," they will kick you out of the line. You HAVE to say that you're here for the service. I saw a tourist family (who probably didn't speak good English) who were so confused because the man let other people inside and not them. I felt bad for them. I wish the staff at the entrance would be more compassionate and just let everyone in for service!
Ancient abbey. Fascinating abbey easy to get around quite large free to London pass holders unlike St. Paul's along with many other venues including the Tower of London and dozens of others

Must see for all visitors . Westminster Abbey is a gem due to historical significance, all the luminaries buried there, the beautiful architecture and evening choir service at 5:00 pm! Go in the afternoon and stay for the evening service! Cathedral organ is impressive and grand.
Be Carful of the Floor. Beautiful so much to see. Caution the floor is very slippery and uneven, have good shoes and avoid the crowds as not to trip and fall. Well worth it!

Enjoyable visit. We visited Westminster Abbey for the evensong and it was a wonderful ceremony. We sat a few seats away from the young boys in the choir, do it was a very special. The order of service was very well done and overall an impressive service. Many people are unaware that entry is free if you are attending a service. Digest you line up early to get a good seat.
Everyone should do this at least once. There is so much history here, it's hard to take it all in at once. Beautiful architecture and an awe inspiring experience.

Takes Your Breath Away. What a wonderful place to visit, there is so much to see. To actually stand next to the tomb that Elizabeth I and her half sister Mary shared was very sad as Elizabeth had Mary executed and obviously regretted it ( read the message that Elizabeth had engraved on the tomb ). You must visit here when you visit London.

Had Communion @ Westminster Abbey. On our trip to London to see the Electric Light Orchestra we visited Westminster Abbey. It was very beautiful and it was quite crowded. My wife and I both wanted to have Communion and she was a little concerned it was too busy. It was absolutely no issue.We walked around and saw the rich history and as 12:00 came close we worked our way over to where the service was to be performed. It was about 20 minutes long. Just the simple Protestant service. No singing. We are Lutheran and the service was very similar to the our own. It was very special to me and would encourage anyone for a special connection to God to experience this event.

Lovely walk. Heritage, art, architecture, gardens, restaurants, people, Thames, knick knacks- you will find everything here, including the iconic london landmarks. A must do thing even if you cannot do anything else during your visit.

An essential visit to the cultural heart of England. I had been to the Abbey when holiday-working as a travel courier and guide in the late 60's, but thought to see it again. In my day as a courier, there were no tickets, no entry charges, no queues, no entry times, no nothing - you just went! I had expected to be asked for a voluntary donation, but not to be charged £17 for entry to our national church !!! What was the story about Jesus throwing the money-lenders out of the Temple? We sure know where they went, don't we...? Having said that, it's still one of the few places in London where you can see 1000 years of history jammed into one site. The complimentary audio-guides are fantastic, too. Was it worth the money? Yes, actually...
Right Near Big Ben. and a piece of English history, although you need only 15 minutes to experience it, just sit there and thing about Royal weddings etc

Totally worth it. If you are visiting London for the first time, Westminster Abbey needs to be on the list of the top 5 things to see. Do not miss this. It has an exponential wow factor. It combines politics, religion and history and a lot of it, all in one space. There is an informational audio tour that comes with the entrance fee of 20 pounds. There is so much to take in! Do some homework ahead of time and read about the history so you have some awareness of the significance of this Abbey. Pretty much a guarantee you will be awed and surprised. No photography allowed though-- this was the only down side to the visit.

Beautiful cathedral. It was beautiful. I would of given it a 5 star but didn't due to no photography allowed. We were to services on a Sunday evening. Interesting plus we were at evensong and the choir is wonderful.
Interesting but not the best. Not for children unless on a school trip. Good for someone who likes history and C of E and Catholic historical religion

Wander through history. I visited Westminster Abbey using the London Pass; it's right across from the picturesque Big Ben and Parliament. Upon entry, you can get a map and a recorded tour to guided you through the Abbey. Since there were a lot of attractions I wanted to see that day, I decided to skip the automated tour and walk through on my own. You can spend as much or as little time there as you desire. Westminster is a beautiful church and is the final resting place for many well known Brits. I loved that there was a special activity pamphlet for children.

Expensive but worth it. I found it to be very expensive, don't buy guide book as I didn't use it ( I was a little annoyed at myself for wasting valuable money) didn't use it as entry fee includes audio guide, which was a pleasant surprise. Abbey is so impressive your mind boggles, my son loved the audio guide as it was short and sweet as easy to follow, he learnt more in an hour than he would reading a guide. Put aside a good hour and a half. No photos in abbey which is totally understandable. Staff did look a bit over it but you get that at some places, I suppose they don't like visitors but we bring good money to the country so I really don't understand. Shop staff short with you etc. all I all the abbey is worth a visit.

With the history of Westminster Abbey, you can't miss it!. Westminster Abbey is a MUST in London! It is absolutely fascinating. The audio tour is great and the history is so rich. Everything is beautiful and the staff is very attentive. Be sure to get there a few hours before closing to ensure you get in (lines can be long!) and that you have plenty of time to see everything. The audio tour is long but well worth it. Amazing history!

Beautiful . You must see this attraction .. Located just across the Westminister tube station, with the Houses of Parliament and a Westminister as well as the Big Ben adjoining it.The Abbey is beautiful with beautiful stained glass within.It evokes a feeling of peace .The attraction is covered by the London pass. It would take 90- 120 minutes for a thorough visit.. An audio guide is available which is free with the London pass . You can follow this with the Thames river cruise or see the Churchill rooms and Trafalgar Square
great history. brilliant way to learn history.they even had a treasure hunt for children. long queue for toilets though.

A place of history and glory. Westminster Abbey is another must visit place in London. This is the burial chaplel of St. Edward the Confessor, whose tomb on the main altar can't be touched, and many of the English monarchs. Henry VII, Mary I and Elizabeth I are interred here as well as Mary Stuart. The Plantagenets occupy a good section as well. Then there is poet's corner and many famous statesmen, scientists and even Lord Laurence Olivier. On the hour there is silence for prayer to remind everyone that you are in an active church. Queen Victoria was married here as well as the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. This is a truly amazing site.

Outstanding and child friendly!. How can you not be impressed just to walk in and look around? They involved the children with a scavenger hunt form right at the start. As we were standing in the choir stall area, a vicar came and let our granddaughters sit in the stalls. He explained to them why only boys usually sit there and all about monks. They will remember that all their lives!

Amazing Historic site. There are so many historical attractions to see in London, and I'm glad we chose this one. Just to see all the historic graves of so many historic figures is just amazing. The architecture and stained glass is just breathtaking. My only complaint is that there is absolutely no photography inside. Disappointing because there are so so many amazing things to see. Plus they didn't offer many postcards to purchase either. I wanted a memento of some of the graves, especially Louis Carroll's,

Very historical and beautiful.. We loved looking for the tombs of Elizabeth the 1st and the bones of the two princes who were murdered by Richard the III. Also many writers are buried there.Get a London pass so ou don't spend a fortune visiting these things. It was crowded even early at 11am.

History buffs heaven. The Abbey is a font of wonderment. I waited only 20 minutes to enter & the audio guide was excellent - voiced by the incomparable Jeremy Irons. My favourite is the tomb of Elizabeth 1 whose tomb is above her sister's Mary. You feel history surrounding you every step of the way.

A must visit despite the cost. No one who appreciates out inherited culture should miss this experience of standing in a place where so much of our history has transpired. Sure it's pricey but consider the upkeep on such a place. The soaring nave, the peaceful chapels of the kings and queens, the bombed out windows from WW II, the inclusion of artists, authors, and scientists, the memorable tomb of the unknown - it is a patchwork quilt of important passages.

Attend the Evensong on Sunday. We did not tour the Abbey, but arrived just in time for the Evensong at 3pm on Sunday. This was definitely a unique (free) experience to sit in this church, where prayer has been offered for over a thousand years. The service always includes one or more psalms and is sung by the church’s choir.If you plan to attend the Evensong concert make sure to arrive early as space is limited. Photography, filming and sound recording are not allowed in the Abbey at any time during the service. Also is not allowed to tour the church. Entrance is free of charge.

Stunning and Breathtaking. The Abbey is not to be missed. It was fascinating. I could have stayed for hours. I wanted to stay for Mass however, the rest of the family did not. Needless to say, I was disappointed since it would have been a rare opportunity. I will go again if ever in London and stay for Mass !!!!!!!
A Stunning Abbey *v*. You'll see Kings, queens, soldiers, poets, priests, heroes of British history and the well-known people since 11th century until 21st century. charming!
Historic church. Very interesting visit to Westminster Abbey with excellent narration of section descriptions. Spans the history of Britain. A place of rest for royalty, scientists, poets,and artists

Music lovers dream come true. Wondered around for a while during a service and was directed to a door that lead outside. I walked towards a courtyard where I heard the cathedral boys choristers rehearsing for the service. I must admit I'm a sucker when I hear exceptional harmonies sung by the Westminster boys. Highlight of my day was standing outside their rehearsal room. Moving.
Must see. A must see for visitors to London for the first time. Quite expensive but you've got to go in once. Not open every day so check first.

On a bright day its beautiful inside. Westminster Abbey is unique, as a private royal church it has been filled with a lot of tombs royal and royal favourites (which seems a bit dark and creepy on a grey day). The most beautiful bit is the Lady Chapel, with its amazing ceiling. I would recommend going for mass or even song so you can hear the choir and acoustics - and entrance is free. The audio guide is really helpful - as are the tours. Avoid the crowds if you can.

An iconic sight in the heart of London. No trip to London is complete without seeing Westminster and the Houses of Parliament. This famous building is one of the most photographed in the world, and resonates history throughout. Inside there are famous monuments and tombs alongside interesting architectural features. My only nitpick lies in the price of admission for adults which is at an expensive £18 per head (tourists often think in dollars and think they are getting a steal). That being said, I live in London and rarely visit but when I do with friends from out of town they always enjoy going in for an hour or so.

Fascinating place... I visited Westminster abbey with a friend. We took advantage of the free audioguide which was very interesting and useful.The architecture is amazing. We enjoyed a walk in the westminster gardens which is only open tuesday, wednesday and thursday. We then had a tasty afternoon tea in the Cellarium cafe. Westminster Abbey is well worth a visit.
So much history. Incredible experience. The history here grabs you and does not let go. The Kings and queens of England and the fact it continues is so cool.

An amazing amount of history.. This church has been where many shared their best times of their life and also where many have been celebrated for a life well lived. I have watched events that were in this church on television and was amazed at how little space there really is for people to be to attend a wedding our funeral. They have really nice audio guides that help tell some of the many stories that are within these walls.

ROYALS. Church of England as they call it. We went in because we got curious of the intricate details of the outside of the church, amazingly inside is very rich of history. Like wow!!! Most of the royalties are actually celebrating life, marriage and death there. So if you want to know more about the King Henry etc. Go there.
Must See in London. I was in awe of this wonderful church that In had read about in the US for many years. Loved taking time and exploring the entire Abbey. Rich in History.

Brilliant verger-led tour. I went to Westminster Abbey with 5 friends. We paid online for our entrance. I saw on the website that there are verger-led tours available on the day for an additional £5. We arrived at 10.30am to buy our tickets for the 11.00 tour. There are audio guides available for free but we thought it would be more interesting to have a verger explain the history of the abbey to us. Each verger-led tour has 20 places. The verger arrived promptly at 11.00, we had Benjamin, an incredibly knowleageable guide and very funny too. We were all amazed at his ability to keep us entertained whilst at the same time giving such an informative tour. At the end of the tour he also showed us the museum. Seeing so many tombs of legendary monarchs was wonderful; Elizabeth I, Edward the Confessor to name just two. We had lunch in the cellarium cafe, this was tasty and waiter service. I can recommend paying the extra £5 for a verger-led tour to make the most of your visit to Westminster Abbey.

Beautiful abbey with so much history. We were almost put off by the long queue during the bank holiday. Our perseverance paid off. The carvings, stained glass, the ceiling, and every detail of this gothic style abbey are just magnificent. The audio guide gave so much information for me to remember. Luckily there is no History test at the end of our visit.Must see.
Must Go Here. This historic place of worship represents so much English history it cannot be missed. Many notable historic figures are interred here.

Stately Abbey with an abundance of history. The Abbey is a must for all visitors. It has such history around it, it gives a sense of pride going through the walkways. The leadlight windows are amazing.

A mesmerizing place in which even just the ceiling is absolutely magnificent!. A must see London attraction (a UNESCO World Heritage site) steeped in history. It's like a symbol of strength for the Nation (it survived the London bombings of WWII immaculately) and also of continuation, as many monarchs rest here spanning a period of 1000yrs. There are over three thousand people buried in the Abbey: notable among these is the Unknown Warrior, whose grave (close to the west door) has become a place of pilgrimage and Heads of State, who visit the country, invariably come to lay a wreath at this grave.The Abbey has been the setting for every Coronation since 1066 and for numerous other royal occasions, including sixteen royal weddings (the last one being the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's in April 2011). Today it is still a church dedicated to regular worship and to the celebration of great national events. It also houses the Westminster Abbey Choir and the choir's school. with an extensive repertoire that ranges from early sixteenth century polyphony to the very most recent commissions. The Abbey contains the most important collection of monumental sculpture anywhere in the country with 600 monuments and wall mounted tablets: the famous Coronation Chair that was made for King Edward I in 1300 circa and that enclosed the famous Stone of Scone (brought over fm Scotland) is just one of those. You'll most likely hv to queue around St.Margaret's Church in order to get in on most days, but it's generally fast moving. Tours take 1.5hrs, but if you really want to take it all in and give yrself time and dedicate attention to the antique artworks and tombs I think 2-3hrs is more realistic.Audio-guides are included in the price of yr entry and are very informative, besides being recorded with the incredibly manly and yet soothing voice of British actor Jeremy Irons: you won't want to hand it back!!
Incredible. This is what I consider a Must See. Gorgeous architecture, beautiful works of art, amazing history. Audio tours point out all the interesting artifacts,
Restful if quieter. A breathtaking attraction well worth an extended visit to admire its wealth of sights to seeTake your time and if possible listen to the choir

Amazing collection of history. The Westminster Abby is full of history. Walking through the audio tour is like a tour through hundreds of years of history. That said I think the admission fees are a bit pricey. 20 pounds for an adult and a whole three pounds off for a senior is not a bargain rate! And after that high fee you are not allowed to take pictures. I am glad I did visit the Abby but I would not do it again.

Really interesting, definitely take the audio tour and take your time!. Entry into the abbey isn't cheap at 20.00 per adult. However there are no other places I have every been that has had so many points of interest in one place. From Kings and Queens to Poets, writers, scientists, everywhere you look there are points of interest. The building is breathtaking and it is worth taking a seat when you can and looking up and around, so many people were rushing around but it is so worth sitting and taking it all in.The staff were friendly and knowledgeable and all in all it was a fantastic experience and well worth the money!

History!. Be sure to allow yourself plenty of time for your visit. Look up, down and sideways so that you don't miss anything! Memorials and plaques about for everyone famous. It is awe-inspiring as you pass through the choir remembering the various weddings and funerals that you have witnessed on television. Again, be sure to look down and allow plenty of time. Great little cafe too! To die for mushroom soup!
Breathtaking. Morning visit best time to avoid bus tourist traffic. A must see visit for anyone visiting London. So much history here. Also great Sushi restaurant nearby.

My favourite place in London. The architecture, art and history of this place is incredible. I am not religious so that aspect did nothing for me. Still, this place has and continues to have a rich history that is truly unique. Well worth the £20 to visit.

So Overcrowded in June. It would have been fabulous but for the serious over-crowding of tourists in the abbey. It is crazy inside there. We went for 930am opening time & still it was so overcrowded. The audio tour was ok. Still lots of information missing. We got in quickly arriving at 920am. But the abbey which is beautiful soon became so overcrowded you squeezed through the chapels. Significantly more stewarding is required to ensure single file through the chapels.I didnt take in as much of the abbey sights as I would if it was a crowd light tour. I would like to return well outside of tourist main season.

Not just your average church. We live in Germany where there is a historic church around every corner, so I figured it would be just another church. It was pretty interesting though with the stories on the guided tour. Price is steep, but we had the London Pass and it was free with that.
Nice for a quick bite!. Convenient location but slight school room atmosphere, tasty sandwiches and cakes but would not recommend for anything more formal.

Evensong Worship. Heavenly worship experience! We arrived to queue about 4:00-4:15. Doors opened at 4:30 then we are ushered in and were fortunate enough to be seated in the choir loft right next to the 30 boys academy choir. I cannot describe just how beautifully God was glorified by the 8 parts sung by 30 boys with perfect pitch and harmony sung to His Glory. This became in an instant the highlight of our Anniversary trip to London.

Worth the visit. This Chruch is something very special and sacred place, when you enter you will know you are somewhere special. I do think 20 pounds is a lot to pay to enter a church, but the upkeep must cost a fortune, so it makes sense.
historic. What a lovely historic place . Full of history and heritage .phots do not do it justice , in side was remarkable

Step back in time. When i visit Westminster Abbey i am in effect, time travelling. I go back many moons and this i love. Monuments and statues adorn the entire building which has stood on Thorney Island for many many centuries. Any history lover will lose themselves in this unique inimitable place and to be able to see the tomb of England's greatest Queen, Elizabeth I leaves one with goose bumps on their arms. A true must if you need history to get through your life such as i do.

Unbelievable experience. This was a highlight of our visit to London. We had the London Pass so we were able to gain Fast-track entry, probably saving some 90 minutes of wait time. Get the London Pass if Westminster Abbey as well as other popular sites are on your list of things to do. The Abbey houses tombs and monument stones to just about anyone who was anyone in England during the past 400-500 years. Royalty, authors, poets, statesmen, etc. are all commemorated in this beautifully ornate building. You can tour at your own pace and there is much to see. You could probably spent 60-90 minutes in the Abbey. The adjacent grounds (the Cloisters) are also beautiful to visit. To stand in front monuments for such authors as Charles Dickens, T.S. Eliot, Alfred Lord Tennyson, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, etc. is awe inspiring. Don't miss a visit to Westminster Abbey. You will never forget the experience!

Our favorite visceral experience.... This Abbey is beyond my description. You must experience it yourself. It is the most amazing architectural achievement we have ever encountered. (Others may think this honor falls to St. Paul's)

WOW. This is awesome in every way & should be a must. In spite of the crowds it is well organised and so much to see that at least 2 hrs should be the minimum time here. This is British History at it`s best, regardless of your nationality.

Must see in a lifetime. Wow. Words cannot express the awesomeness of this place. If there is one place in the world one must see in a lifetime this is it.I am baffled why this is not at the top of the list. Maybe it's the upset visitors who felt £20 was a rip off. Please ignore the low reviews and see this magnificent place.This is a sacred place and should not be viewed as a tourist attraction. It is the resting place for kings and queens. You will be humbled by its awe from the first step you take inside. Words cannot describe it and if I try it will be an injustice. See it and you won't be disappointed .

Still in the Temple. There's not much you can tell me about how much it costs to run and maintain an old building but I still find it offensive to be charged to go into a church. It is, of course, a magnificent building and stuffed full of British history from kings to commoners. Take you time and explore thoroughly. You'll be amazed at what you find in the side chapels. And my favourite - the tomb of Edward the Confessor. Not every day you come across a head of state who was a saint is it?
A great spot to visit. Amazing history of the Church of England. Its the who's who's list of famous English people buried in the cathedral.

Awesome, Expensive but crowded & NO PICTURES. Westminster Abby is a more beautiful than it looked on TV during William & Kate’s wedding. You have the opportunity to roam through the entire Abby and the audio guided tour is very descriptive and has numerous anecdotal descriptions and stories that are fascinating. To stand where kings and queens and famous poets once stood (or are buried) make you feel quite humble and yet excited. The entire facility is extremely well kept. The only negatives are that it is very, very crowded and they do not allow photography at all inside. For thirty bucks a person, I expected to be able to take pictures inside.

Beautiful. If you can attend the sung mass. It gives one time to pause and understand what the significance of the structure is. I absolutely loved just sitting and absorbing the amount of work that went into creating this masterpiece.

A bit pricey but worth it. I had always wanted to visit Westminster Abbey to see where the Royals had been crowned, married, and buried for centuries. You can see the graves of everyone from Queen Elizabeth I and Queen Mary to Laurence Olivier and Charles Dickens. As a literature and history fan/student, I loved seeing the Tudor graves, Mary, Queen of Scots, and Sir Isaac Newton. It was also really cool to see where some of my favourite authors were buried (Poet's Corner). The Abbey itself is beautiful. The stone carvings and architecture are incredible and worth seeing in person. The price of admission was kind of shocking, to be honest. But after my tour, I felt that it had been worth it for such a lovely experience and for keeping the Abbey in good shape for future generations.

A must see for all walks of life.. A beautiful must see structure. Everyone who visits London needs to,see this amazing building, regardless of your religious beliefs. The architecture transcends all religions and is just pure amazing beauty.

An Inspirational and Historic Landmark. Much has been written about visiting the Abbey so I will add only a few key points. First, buy your tickets online so you can by pass the long line to purchase tickets. Second, take the Verger tour if you can arrange it. I do not know if this can be arranged in advance, but it was clearly worth the additional 5 pounds. I would recommend spending additional time with the audio equipment either before or after the Verger tour to see everything at your own pace. I wish we had the time to hear the choir in the early evening.

AMAZING.. No footage of any royal wedding does this location any justice. This is such a beautiful abbey that has so much more than you could ever think is inside. Definitely worth the wait. We got to the entry 45mins before the doors open and was worth the wait because the time they opened their was around the corner. It was nice to see the abbey without the large birds of crowds as well.
Sacred place. A very sacred place, you feel all this energy and sacredness when inside, so mane famous people buried there. Definitely worth visiting.

Not to be missed - Matins at Westminster Abbey. What a wonderful hour long choral service it was on Trinity Sunday 31 May, at Westminster Abbey. The sermon on the Trinity given by Canon Jane Sinclair was excellent and made the Christian doctrine that God exists as a unity of three distinct persons so much more understandable. I felt privileged, to shake her hand at the end of the service.A visit to this very historic building was awesome not only for its architecture but for the burial site of the kings, queens, statesmen and other famous people.There are no photos allowed but the gift shop has wonderful pictorial and historical books both large and small.

Attend a service for full appreciation. Westminster Abbey is a working cathedral and is best appreciated in worship or in an attitude of reverence. As stated by other reviewers, the Abbey has daily services and I highly recommend attending one of these services. I visited the Abbey for Sunday morning service and was intrigued yet humbled by the pomp and circumstance of the service. Arrive early as people are seated 30 minutes to and hour prior to the service.There is no charge to attend a service, but the church will pass a collection plate. Also, all of the daily services are listed on the Abbey's website.

Worth the entry fee!. It's a little annoying that the UK charges money to enter its cathedrals and churches, but Westminster is worth it. If you are a British poets fan, then you'll definitely love it. Many of the greats are entombed in the Poets Corner, which is really interesting to see.

Hugh crowds. Westminster Abbey is probably one of the most beautiful cathedrals I have ever had the pleasure of seeing! The Nave and Quire are so incredibly ornate! It is truly amazing to know that since 1066 the Abbey has been where the Royals of England have been coronated and continue to be so! The many tombs and monuments of past Royalty, dignitaries, and scholars within are humbling. The crowds here can be very large and overwhelming for small children.
Superb!. The audio guide was really well made - so you can understand what are you seeing. Loved idea of 1 minute of prayer every hour to remind this is a real functional church.

A Walk back in Time. This should be one of the first places that you visit during your stay in London. Get there a few minutes before it opens and there will be little waiting. It is covered by the London Pass. Once inside, you will be awed by the history-kings, queens, poets, statesmen, inventors are all buried here. It can be overwhelming but there are priests and nuns who are willing to answer questions and guide you in the right direction. Remember no photos allowed.

Only in England.... On my London trip, I was occasionally joined by a friend who happened to be travelling there at the same time. My friend noticed a trend in England: you could have the most amazing attraction or monument, visited by millions of tourists, and then in some corner you'd have a pile of trash, or a really badly-colored wall, or exposed electric wires, or something that makes the site's maintenance look very unprofessional.The Westminster Abbey is an extreme example, which has all of these elements. Large parts of the abbey's walls which are supposed to be bare stone, are painted with many layers of cheap paint, including some ceilings. The stones at your level are often filthy and blackened by human touch. There are exposed electric wires going right on top of some memorial plaques. And this is one of the most-visited tourist sites in the world. It really takes away from the experience.Other than that, the abbey is not bad. It's interesting as a church, and of course for the main interest—being the burial place of many key people in history, such as Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin and Winston Churchill. On the other hand, the place is so crowded that you can't properly stop at many tombstones, and you're likely to miss many important ones if you don't look for them specifically/ask the staff.It's probably worth a visit once if you're in London (prepare for long lines), but don't hold your breath. You certainly won't see the amazing theoretical splendor of the abbey as portrayed in movies like The Da Vinci Code.

Beautiful and informative.. Went in on a Saturday. There were lots of people but it wasn't terribly crowded and people kept moving. Plenty of room to see and explore. The audio guides were very useful.

Attend an Evensong service. Highly recommend going to an Evensong service here in the afternoons, either on Saturday or Sunday. You get free entry into the cathedral, and get to witness a beautiful boys choir perform! Very stiff, but it's an experience. A lot of standing and sitting, just like Catholics love :)
Great day out.. Westminster Abbey well worth a visit. All the religion and regalia of our Abbey.Very interesting to look round and see who is buried there and the History that goes with the place.

Plan your visit carefully and you will have a marvellous time!. First of all, I am a 'local' to Westminster Abbey, and I visit the Abbey to attend services on a regular basis. With this in mind, I would advise the following when planning your visit: 1) Try and get on a tour very early in the morning, as early as possible, as the crowds through most of the year (March to October) are very busy. If you can visit in the winter months, so much the better. 2) When on tour, of all that is to see in the Abbey, there are obvious highlights such as Poet's Corner and the Royal Tombs. However, for me the highlight is entering the King Henry VII Chapel, with its stalls and banners for the Knights of the Bath. If this doesn't take your breath away, nothing else will. 3) Please do attend a service at the Abbey, ideally the Evensong service usually at 3.0pm. Entrance to the services is free. Just say you are attending the service at the door and you will be shown a seat in the Quire. Here you will hear the world famous Abbey Choir, and listen to the equally famous 110 stops Harrison & Harrison Organ. It is only when the crowds are gone and you are listening to the service, that the magic of this ancient Royal Abbey church truly reveals itself, and is highly recommended.
Enjoyed. There is an admission fee but the earphone audio players were very good and allowed us to go at our own pace. Photos were not allowed .
Too long a wait to get in and way too expensive!. The title says it all really. Yes, they've got to deal with the hordes of tourists but 20 quid a head entry? You're kidding aren't you?

Impressive. This is one of the world's most famous churches. I have seen a number of top rated, included Notre Dame, but this one is probably my favorite. Numerous kings and queens are buried here, as well as, notables like Charles Dickens, Chaucer and the British Unknown Soldier. The architecture is overwhelming. A must see while in London.

Poet's Corner A Highlight. Touched by Poet's Corner and to see Jane Austen and the Bronte sisters acknowledged here. Friendly staff, informative audio guide. Wonderful to visit and learn more of the history, and to see people who have contributed so much to society recognised alongside royalty.

Wow!! British history in - well, a bit more than a nutshell!!. Wow! What a magnificent monument, fantastic architecture, epic history throughout this ancient edifice.Our first visit, and was not disappointed. My wife & a friend tried to get in last year, but the queue was so large, they gave up.Not this time!!! Get here early, we did, before 9 am, had a little wander to Big Ben, heard the chimes and queued up. only 20 to 30 in queue. 5 minutes we were in.Collect a portable listening guide, when you enter, it's free, and helps you make sense of it all. And if your early, you're not banging elbows with hordes of tourists!Famous monarchs, authors, poets, statesmen buried here.Amazing place, well worth it.
Stunning. Amazing building and fab to see, as you walk towards the immense building you are blown away. Worth a visit

Amazing History. Very Interesting Church. Lots of history to absorb. If you go on a Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday the gardens are also open to the public. After doing the audio tour it was very nice to sit and relax for a while in the garden before joining the throngs of tourists that flock to the Westminster area of London
Beautiful. This is a very grand Abbey and quite beautiful. We enjoyed our tour as there is so much to see and learn while inside the Abbey. Don't miss this stop on your London tour.

Fascinating, but simply not worth the cost. The building itself is incredibly interesting to look at, and there is a great deal of history here both in the building itself as well as the people buried in it. However, I just can't see it as being worth the price of admission, and this is reflected in my rating - the 20 pound fee just seems excessive, at least to me.

So Much History in One Place. Audio guide comes with admission fee. You can avoid the long lines with a London Pass. We spent about 2 hours here and found it to be worth the.time We enjoyed all of the history & seeing the coronation chair.
outstanding. This is an amazing place with so much to look at. Well worth £20 entry fee. Staff really knowledgable. Tombs and memorials really fascinating.
Beautiful place. There is so much history packed in the it is a definite must see while in London. The dates on some of the people laid to rest there are incredibly old.

So many famous names!. It would be easy to spend hours just finding all the famous names on tombstones and commemorative plaques. Seeing the place where Elizabeth 1 is laid was amazing and the abbey itself is absolutely stunning.

Place of Interest for History Buffs and Romantics. This stunning gothic church and UNESCO World Heritage site is a must see for history buffs. Many famous names are part of the rich history of Westminster Abbey, from royals to scientists, poets and aristocrats. If you are a romantic, you will want to see this church where Katherine Middleton and Prince William were married in 2011.This church is also one of the background locations in Phillipa Gregory's book, "The White Queen". So if you read the book or followed the TV series, you will enjoy this place.Tip: If you need a break, the cafe near the gift shop serves really good tea and scones for a reasonable price.

Wonderful place, terrible experience. I would have loved to see the interior of Westminster Abbey. Unfortunately all I saw were the masses of other visitors jostling and pushing. This place has really got to sort out how it times visits. 5 stars for the building but 1 star for the visit
Magnificent!. I had been to Westminster before, but I so enjoyed the audio guides that were available. It was so easy to follow the guide and to understand the history of where we were standing.

was good. was vert large was worth going and seeing the abbey if your in London go and look at the outside and no go in the inside and its pretty cool to thing that the royal family got married in somewhere where you are now walking

Excellen tourist place. Westminster Abbey is an iconic medieval structure and the site of many historic royal and national events, from coronations and weddings to burials and even deaths. Centrally located in London, Westminster Abbey was first constructed in the eleventh century by King Edward the Confessor, a Saxon king who dedicated this new church to St Peter. Wonderful thing to see. Did not like the line to wait for 1 hour to enter the place.

Splendiferous. This is a must see if you are in London. The architecture and history in this abbey are astounding. You can marvel at beautiful masonry, bright stain glass masterpieces, and learn about thousands of years of British history. They offered a Audio tour (narrated by Jeremy Irons) which I thought was a superb idea because it was very informtive, entertaining, and kept the interior more reverent because you did not have a tour guide shouting explinations. I think this was one of the best places we saw in London.

A bit over priced for what you see. Whenever i'm in London i have tried to go to the Abbey but this time i bought the tickets on line and it was great because i didn't have to be on the line to get in. Except for the banners room which is really colorful i was a bit disappointed specially because i had visited the Westminster Cathedral where you don't have to pay anything and have really enjoyed it. But if you are in history there is plenty of very important people buried in the Abbey and the tombs are grand. The cloister is really nice.

Beautiful, familiar church. I took the the self guided tour of Westminster Abbey. The audio guide was fantastic, and provided lots of great information of the history of the Abbey. The stained glass was gorgeous, and it was cool to walk through the areas of the Abbey that are so familiar from watching events on television. It's also worth going to a service at the church, even if it's not your denomination. It's very moving.

Hidden in plain sight. This building compasses all that is wondrous about English history The treasures the names the events ; it once housed cattle and the poorest in our land and as time past has hosted the weddings of royals. It's a must do visit

Not so Good.... I really enjoy visiting old cathedrals and abbeys. Wherever I am staying, I map out the cathedrals and abbeys I can likely get to on my trip. Since I was staying in Wiltshire, it was a short trip to London to visit Westminster Abbey. Sorry to say the experience was rather impersonal after visiting Hereford, Wells, Salisbury and Winchester. Surely the monuments, burials, and the cosmati pavement are worth a visit, but the experience compared to other cathedrals/abbeys leaves something to be desired. One person in our party probably summed up the experience quite well: the other places we visited were loved by a dedicated staff of volunteers, at Westminster Abbey people are just doing a job.Though it is worth a look, I realize in the other cathedrals/abbeys the "feeling" of the place is much more to my liking and adds to my enjoyment.

A History Lesson unlike any Classroom. Breath taking......With Jeremy Irons as my guide via head set Westminster came alive, three fascinating hours, I could have spent more, of a tale of why and how England, this tiny island, was able to dominate 3/4 of the earth for two centuries

It will definitely leave you awed. If you haven't been living under a stone, the Westminster Abbey will definitely leave you awed. The grand interiors a treat for the eyes. And the graves of people like Sir Issac Newton, Charles Darwin and Alfred Lord Tennyson will leave you spellbound. A definite must-visit if you happen to travel to London.

So much history!. Beautiful church with so much history! We got there early so that we could sign up for the Verger tour. Unfortunately, the church opens at 9:30am and the first tour was at 10:30, so we ended up doing the self-guided tour. It was done very well. The church is incredible. I loved the literary corner. Museum was not worth it though.
Great view. We had the best day of our live in London to see all the sides. So much history in this city, and nice shop as well. We def. Come back here again

Must see. The Westminster abbey tends to get crowded and this could hamper your experience of the place. However, the audio guides are fantastic. The staff are always ready to answer any questions you have and they always add that extra bit of information that brings the place alive.The prayer service is wonderful as well.

A place of pilgrimage. I've been to Westminster Abbey three times now, and I never fail to enjoy it. The most recent time, in early June 2015, we arrived before opening to stand in line, and it was well worth it. The crowd was very minimal, and at times we were completely alone in parts of the abbey. It was almost magical, and added greatly to the experience. I did not bother with an audio guide because I already know much about the abbey. To be in the presence of kings and queens and statesmen and nobles and poets and writers - it is incomparable for any person of English descent. To pay homage to Elizabeth I, Henry VII, and so on ... you need to visit Westminster Abbey at least once in your life. The more, the better, in my opinion.And do not miss out on the Abbey museum! It opens at 10:30am, while the Abbey opens at 9:30am, but the museum is wonderful. It's a small collection of various things like royal wax effigies and extant costumes for them, and a very old altar piece, and more. It is one of my favorite parts.

Breathtaking!. Awesome and breathtaking. So much to absorb. The audio tour was great and it walked you through the parts of the building. Got to be part of the moment of prayer which was beautiful. Can't take photos inside.

Most Historic Place on Earth?. You will get much more out of Westminster Abbey if you have some familiarity with the history of the British monarchy. The TV show "Monarchy" with David Starkey is a good start (we watched on Netflix). At Westminster Abbey, we took the paid, guided tour and the audioguide tour. The paid tour is well worth five pounds, if for no other reason than gaining access to the normally-blocked-off tombs of Edward the Confessor, Henry III, Edward I, Edward III, and Richard II - truly some of the most noteworthy British kings of all time.
