After the 1.5 hour guided tour, we got free audioguides and took that tour as well. Each tour covered many subjects that the other did not; there was only mild overlap.If you appreciate history, dig royal weddings, or are Anglican/Church of England, Westminster Abbey is ground zero. My only regret was that we couldn't spend more time there.
Amazing..... This is a very interesting church that left us in awe. We loved looking at the various tombs and learning about the history of who were in them.
Lots of history. I am a history buff and I enjoyed my visit to the Abbey. They give you a playback device so you can learn about many of the tombs, etc.

The Sheer Size is Incredible, and the Architecture is Amazing. Great old beautiful old building, and should be on the list of things to see when visiting London, fairly close to Big Ben, and easy walk to get there. The workmanship both outside and inside is totally overwhelming. Besides being a great monument, and the last resting place of many past Kings and Heroes. Amazing what could be built by hand so many years ago.

Beautiful evening service and organ recital. This is the must see of London. So much history and a reverence to the building and the lives that are represented there. I attended an organ recital and evening service my first evening into London. It was a huge highlight if my trip to London.

Overwhelming to the senses in a good way. History abounds, kings and queens, etc buried all throughout the Abbey, starting from 1052. My mind was overcome with the magnitude of it all. Such incredible history and information. I was like a sponge.

Great scavenger hunt for kids pls Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin buried here!. How cool is that? Plus they have a great scavenger hunt to keep the kids interested. We didn't get to finish but they still got a big chocolate gold coin at the end. Interesting for adult and for kids.

Beautiful!. We used our London passes to get into the Abbey. No line either way on a Tuesday. The guided audio tour was very informative and in the soothing voice of Jeremy Irons. You can't take pictures so be prepared to soak it up!

A magnificent building dedicated to God. No visit to London would be complete without seeing Westminster Abbey this magnificent Cathedral Building, built by the last anointed Saxon King, Edward the Confessor. The workmanship both outside and inside is totally overwhelming. Besides being a great monument, and the last resting place of many past Kings and Heroes, it still has that feeling where you can be close to God
Awesome and majestic. The great cathedral of England for eons now. This is the spiritual center of the great English people for a millennia. This is a must-tour for a first-time visitor!

Church Service- Singing. We attended church service at the 11:15 am and it was 90 minutes long including communion. The choir sang and it was such a beautiful time of worship. They do practice open communion, if you take communion in your won church you can participate here. The building is spectacular! You cannot tour the Abbey on Sundays, just worship. Highly recommend it.

beautiful building and amazing history. Having seen it so many times on TV we decided to go and visit it which we were glad we did. The building it beautiful with a fantastic history. The audio guide to go round with provided a lot if interesting additional information.

Beautiful and Historical . I did not want to pay to go inside. So, I went to the evening service that happens every night called Evensong. If you want to see every stone and take in a lot more history you may want to pay to go in. But I was crunched for time so I went to the Evensong which happens 5:00 every night for free so I can at least see inside. It was worth it. The person in front will ask if you are there for service and you say "yes" and the they warn you it's an hour but it's really about 40 mins.it was great. Heard the choir which was beautiful. And we got to sit quietly for a bit and look around as we sat for service. Make sure you get there about 20 minutes prior b/c there is a line to get in and you don't want to get shut out.

A surreal experience. Westminster Abbey was absolutely stunning. There were 5 people in our party: 2 adults and 3 children under the age of sixteen, and every one of us enjoyed our visit here. We took the audio tour, which was thorough and informational, and ended up spending hours soaking up the rich history and beauty of the Abbey. Our trip to London would not have been complete if we hadn't visited Westminster Abbey.
Must See - Be sure to Use the Hand Sets for the Tour. Tour at your own pace using the Hand Set - Many languages provided for those visiting. So much history and amazing architecture.

Book a guided tour. Fantastic mine of hidden gems. Try to book a guided tour for £5. Well worth it - good value for over an hours worth of fantastic information. Many of the great and the good of Britain are buried and/or commemorated there.

Beautiful. Even as a non Christian I found myself humbled and saying a silent prayer when visiting the Abbey. We didn't want to leave but stayed until closing when we were forced out (by the incredibly friendly staff) :)
Amazing!. Definitely worth paying to go inside, fascinating history and amazing place to explore. Very helpful handheld radio guides too.
A must do when in London.. Incredible beauty and history. Breathtaking rooms and icons/windows. Plan several hours to take in all this fabulous site has to offer.
The best way to see the Abbey. Knowledge guides take you in a side entrance (no long waits in line). The tour lasted about 1.5 hours...well worth the money.

Too much to see at the one time. I had not been to Westminster Abbey for 43 years so revisiting was like seeing it for the first time. We had just missed out on doing the guided tour so we used the audio guides which were supplied as part of the entrance fee and were excellent. However, there was just so much to see. You are not allowed to take photos inside which is a bit disappointing as there are so memorable things which I know I will forgot about by tomorrow. The staff are friendly, and there are extra toilets in the restaurant too if the queue is too long in other places. At lunch time it gets very busy at the restaurants around the Abbey, we decided to go back two underground stations and found seats and good food without any problems. Otherwise, you can walk around for hours, trying to find food and spoil your day.

Blown away. Having been reading more about the history of England I was blown away by the contents of the Abbey - hundreds of years worth. Kings queens, various chapels, poets etc. Try to go on a Tuesday when you will have access to the cloisters and museum and can see the death masks of various monarchs. The Abbey is definitely worth the admission price and I can't wait to go back again. Audio guides are available. There is often a queue outside but don't be put off because it moves pretty quickly. There is a one-way system in the Abbey which works well. You could probably see the essentials in an hour but I would recommend a longer visit.
poets corner is awsome. a nice experience but a little lengthy and the constant stopping for prayer was a little annoying but is is worth the visit

Expensive. This is costly but a solution is to arrive a half hour before evensong say 4.30 and get in for free! There is also a free organ recital every Sunday afternoon 5.45 p.m. There is much to see and it is worth paying to see Henry VII chapel and the shrine but to be honest it gets very crowded and noisy. I am told the new cafe is good. The loos are near Poet's corner. Choir and organ always excellent!

An absolute must-see for any english history or literature buff. Although at first you might feel like 18 pounds is a bit steep to enter a house of worship, the Abbey keeps you mesmerised and captivated throughout the duration of your visit. The audio guide (with narration by Jeremy Irons) is included in the admission fee and allows you to move at your own pace. If you're even the slightest bit interested or even intrigued by English history and / or literature / poetry, this place is a treat. We took about 2 hours to see the place but one could easily spend a lot longer. Poet's corner, Henry VII's Chapel, the coronation chair and the cloisters are just some of the highlights. Also, spend some time in the smaller chapels in the abbey - some of the sculptures are truly amazing.

Great tour of Westminster. Excellent tour of the Palace of Westminster on a Saturday afternoon. Security entering the Palace was quick and friendly. Lunch in the cafe was good and relatively reasonable. The tour was fascinating taking us into the Commons and other parts of Westminster that you only see on tv. Our tour guide was friendly and very informative. Glad we booked this as our first tour on our London vacation.

A great tourist location. All tourists visiting London must visit Big Ben and Westminster Abbey, located just across the road from Big Ben and the houses of Parliament, it is accessible from Westminster Underground station, great photo opportunities
Indoor cemetery more than an abbey. Very interesting to walk around but pickpockets everywhere. Place was bigger than I thought, really no line on any london attractions in early june

Can't express how beautiful this abbey is!!. Whether you're religious or not, the Westminster Abbey is stunning to all with its ornate architecture. It's so cool to see the tombs of all the kings and royalty throughout the years buried inside the abbey! For sure take advantage of the audio tour. I learned so much, but I found it entertaining and cool that JEREMY IRONS was the narrator! And no judgement if you slowly walk down the aisle through the church like you're Princess Kate. If you are in London, this is a MUST SEE, and you can get a pic of the parliament building since it's right across the street. You could go through it in an hour, but my family and I took more time because we were so amazed and went to have tea and scones in the little cafe.

See the tombs and memorials to many English notables. Love Poet's Corner...probably one of my favorite places in all London. The beauty of the church combined with the reminders of England's contribution to cultural and political history makes this a great place to spend some time

church service. organizedcan come as you are: polo, jeans, and tennis shoes due to being on holidayprogram helps you through each step of the service: beginners welcome!the guards had to keep telling people that church was in service because they were coming in to try to take pictures while people where worshiping...so I can see why people are writing that the staff can be a bit cold...however, being in the quiet and meaningful service we were thankful for the staff keeping it quiet and peaceful...tricky line to walk for the staff at WA I am sure.

Crowds? Of course. But it's Just Wonderful!. British History fans must visit Westminster Abbey. You don't know where to look: at the architecture, the underfoot resting places of so many famous people, or just absorb the atmosphere. We took advantage of our London Card for free admission and got there 15 minutes before opening. There were long lines, which had shortened by the time we left an hour later. It's everything you hope it will be. It's a MUST on a London sightseeing trip.
Majestic!. This is worth the effort. Go early, there will be lines. So much history here! Also, check to make sure it is open on the day you intend to go. They do use the abbey for church functions.
Amazing!. It had been years since I last visited Westminster Abbey, so I was excited to revisit this very famous place. It didn't disappoint. Well worth a visit.

Wonderful History. Westminster Abbey is one of the most wonderful and historical places in England and indeed in the world. The building itself is a fine example of ancient architecture. All the Kings and Queens of England have had their coronations there.But most interesting are the buriel sites,monarchs, prime ministers, poets and playwrights are all buried here. Because there is so much to see it is best to get a map of the Abbey before going in. Photography is not allowed. It is best to go early in the day because otherwise the queue can be quite long.

Visted on vacation. The line was long (looked like maybe a wait of hours) but we were told it moved fast, and sure enough we were able to enter in less than 20 minutes. This is a must see (20 pounds). It will take about an hour and a half.

Beautiful abbey, rude attendants. The architecture is simply wonderful - what else can you say about such a British icon? Enjoyed the experience except for one thing. We explored the abbey as part of a uni tour group with a certified Blue Badge guide. Despite her nearly 10-year experience with London tours, the attendants in the abbey were unnecessarily rude to her and acted like they owned the abbey. They spoke to us as though we were a group of primary school students, not young adults. If not for this, the experience would have been perfect.

Nice but not worth the cost. i have an issue high prices to see a church. They did a very nice job with this fabulous church in selling out. It is a house of worship, not a museum. Shame on them for going commercial.

Wonderful Westminster. This trip included Westminster and we showed up at late afternoon on a lovely day. The afternoon sun made for better pictures than last time, but there was a line and the attending employees were telling us and everyone behind us that waiting was futile, we wont get in. Never shaken, we went for it and made it through. The Abbey is a stone wonder and really built around "The Confessor's" tomb. Yes, many Royals are buried here and this building is spectacular and history bound, but at its heart it still a functioning ode to England, it's people and God. See Poets Corner and all the famous resting places(The Confessors tomb) is off limits due to a fragile floor. The Coronation Chair is now behind glass and everything is as I remembered it, old and venerable. We did feel a bit rushed as it was towards closing and they were sealing off sections as people filed through. Still we love this church and always admire the past here. There is no entry discount vouchers, though London Passers and students are obliged. There is no photos here sadly ( we have many from when you could, and much video, but that was then). Westminster Abbey should be seen by all at least once in your lives.

Westminster Cathedral, a must for all lovers of history and tradition. Wonderful, awe inspiring and historical building. Witness to the past and England's monarchical magnificence, the Lady Chapel is exquisite and the Poets Corner bears the memory of so many wonderful literary figures whilst the tomb of the Unknown Soldier is so moving. To be close to the mortal remains of those such as Purcell and Handel is an outstandingly memorable experience.

4th visit always interesting. For various reasons this was my 4th visit to Westminter Abby in 5 trips to London. It has always been interesting and the included audio commentary in various languages makes it interesting.

Worth Seeing Once. Westminster Abbey was one of the London attractions I had always dreamed of seeing. While being there was amazing, parts of the Abbey were smaller than I had imagined from seeing it on television. I am glad I saw it, at a 20 pound admission fee, I likely wouldn't go back.

Beautiful landmark. I have no idea how this was built in the year it was and how amazing that all the graves are in there, its an amazing, spooky at times, but definitely mind blowing experience to go into it. A definite must!

A Must Visit Despite the Entrance Fee. A London landmark we have often been past but never been in before. We started with a light lunch in the excellent Abbey Cellarium Cafe - quite hard to find off Dean's Yard but well worth seeking out - and then to join a short queue for the Abbey itself.A|lthough we qualified for a concessionary entrance fee, it still cost £34 for the two of us. Although we know it is the the only source of income for a building with what must be tremendous upkeep costs, it still seemed a lot to pay to enter a house of worship for only an hour or two. But there is plenty to see. The internal architecture is much more interesting and spectacular than the exterior and the place is absolutely full of tombs and plaques.It's quite impossible to take it all in on one visit so a return, despite the cost, is very much on the cards. As might be expected the Abbey was full of tourists and once or twice we got caught up with largish groups with a guide which made progress quite difficult as in places, they tend to create a blockage. We didn't take up the offer of the audio guide which was probably a mistake. Photography is not allowed which seems a shame as no such restriction applies in many similar buildings, especially abroad, although I accept that it can be intrusive for other visitors. There is a set route round so that you are sure of seeing everything but, other than trying to return against the flow which would be quite difficult, there is no means of retracing your steps to have another look.

Worth a go!. Great place to visit, especially to see the place where Prince Wiliam and Catherine got married and also to pay respects to the legendary iconic people of the modern world such as Sir Issac Newton.

Evensong. We went to Evensong, which was well attended. Though plenty of room for everyone.We were each given a dated order of service, which you are able to keep. The service lasted an hour, there are large screens to follow the service on, for those who have side seats.  The service was uplifting, the choir was lovely, and most of all, you feel you are part of the Minsters thousand years of history.

A royal and historic stop in London that is worth the time.. Waiting in line for a tour of this majestic and royal cathedral is worth it. You never know who you might see or what you might see- I saw a great motto "Every sinner has a future and every saint has a past" on the back of a jacket while waiting in line. The majority of the facility is handicap accessible. As a historian and someone that enjoys seeing the engineering feats of the past I was thoroughly impressed.

Great, but get there early. Really impressive and historical, so worth the visit. However, definitely buy your tickets in advance and get there before opening to get in line. The first group of people get to enjoy the abbey largely alone, and the remainder of the day is mobbed with people.

Amazing. It is a payed entrance, includes in London pass. Well worth visiting. Come inside, get your audio tour (includes in ticket) and follow it. The whole history of British royalty. Intriguing and exiting. Must see.

Awesome place, but very expensive. Westminnster Abbey is very impressive.The price to get into is about 20 pounds and this is really expensive.TIPP:go inside for a holy comunion or the chorals. you get a free entry but you are not allowed to see everything.

Walk where William the Conqueror was crowned. The ticket is pricey because Westminster Abbey isn't state-supported, but it's well worth it. So many kings and queens buried here, kings and queens crowned here, tragedies commemorated.... the air is thick with the years and events that make up the country's history. In a word - unmissable.

Westminster Abbey - always well worth a visit to this place of worship and tradition. Expect huge crowds but don't skip a visit to Westminster Abbey. We bought a one-day London Pass and stopped here first - opens at 9:30 a.m. I don't think the Fast Track part worked though --long lines for those with that feature as well! It was wall-to-wall people inside, but still awe-inspiring and highly recommended. Be sure to visit Poet's Corner and stand in front of (and on top of!) the graves and markers of all the beloved poets.

Brilliant. Absolutely worth visiting . We didn't have to queue as we arrived just before it closed on a Saturday for evensong practise. As we walked around we suddenly heard this wonderful music and were invited to sit down and listen to the choir rehearsing - how lucky were we?! ?Only went to take our visitors out and about and are so glad we did.

Congestion of centuries. My first visit to the Abbey many years ago was flabbergasting. I nearly cried at the Gothic beauty and spectacle. But I'm jaded by 3-4 visits since and would rather go to St. Paul's. Poets' Corner, the gorgeous chapels, the tombs of monarchs, the shrine of Edward the Confessor are still thrilling and uncanny. The building is still magnificent. I don't even mind the hip-to-haunch crowding of fellow tourists. But the Rococco clutter wears you out. The longer the epitaph and the more numerous the weeping-angel statues, the less significant the honoree. Too many monuments are more about imperialism and hereditary privilege than virtue or service. But go anyway. You can't not go. Put my grumbling out of your head, study the Abbey's web site and install its app, brush up your English history, pick a date that's not a bank holiday, and go.
Just passing by..... Went to London as a City break and this was something we aimed to see, well worth a visit for tourists, still not as good as St James Church, Louth.
Incredible!. With friends and family, we took a London Walks tour. This was reasonably priced when you considered that we missed the lines at the entrance. The guide was very good.

London's church. Westminster Abbey is the colloquial name of the Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster, a gothic palace become a UNESCO World Heritage place. It is the church for the Royal weddings. A must to see.Tube stop: Westminster.

Awesome exterior . Just looking from the outside gives you an impression of how magnificent this site is. The guides are really helpful and go out of their way to make your visit memorable. Remember- no internal photography
A Walk through History. We didn't have enough time to walk and look at everything. Wonderful peaceful experience. Will go back for many more times.
Must see. Total "Wow" factor inside.. Can't believe we missed this Abbey the last 3 trips to London. It was probably closed or the line was too long. Absolutely blew me away. Wow.
Evensong is to recommend!. Just such a thing as David Livingstone is buried in the church makes it worth a visit. A place where history literally are.
Great. This abbey is just unique...sorry that now is not free to get in..I understand the cost to maintain it, but if you like to see this kind of building ...go for it and visit it.

Breathtaking!. Westminster Abbey is probably one of the most beautiful places I have even seen. I did the tour and it was just unbelievable! So much history and it's soooo beautiful! It was definitely one of my favorite attractions in London. I also had the chance to pray in the chapel which was an unforgettable experience. It's definitely a must visit when in London!

A celebration of Christianity. Christianity, human accomplishment and monarchy. Regardless of your thoughts on the latter, the former too are present everywhere your eyes gaze. A tour through time and through inspired architecture. An incredible experience.

Walk into history. The Abbey is a magnificient place to start understanding and appreciating English history , arts and even literature. It emcopasses a cluster of many centuries of great monarchs, authors, artists, etc. Describing the interior in words is almost impossible. One must experience it to understand it . A must for any visitor. Should not be missed !!
Splendid. A splendid historic site with so much to see. Expect long lines with little freedom of movement but it's s must see for visitors.

Look Back to a Wonderful History Of The Church of England and It History. We visited Westminster Abby and toured the Abby with the audio guide since the guided thorns were booked. They agreed at the end that we could return the next day and were scheduled for the first thing for the first tour. It was delightful. Our guide Benjamin Sheppard was terrific. Ask for him.

A little piece of history. This place has so much history. Grab your headphones and take the tour. There are lines to get inside and it's pretty busy once you are in. You can't take photos inside, but there are postcards you can buy if you want to have something to remember it by.

History and beautiful architecture!. The whole Westminster area is absolutely stunning, and so rich in history -- deeply rich in history!! Be sure to take the tour and visit the gift shops for some very unique presents to take back home!

Westminister Abbey. I love a big cathedral. There are a lot of rooms to get through so plan to spend 2-3 hours if you want to stop and really take it all in. It was fun to look for famous writers & scientists graves. You actually have to walk on those who are buried in the floor. Go when the choir is practicing. Their voices are so beautiful and it adds to the ambiance.

Can't miss this one. This is certainly a don't miss attraction for history buffs. We could have spent more hours there, but it closed earlier than we'd expected. Do check the entry times so you are aware.

So much more than you could ever imagine.... I was not prepared for just how wonderful my trip to the Abbey was going to be! I was lucky enough to go with work and hence we received a private evening tour without tourists. The ambience, history and grandeur of the place is second to none. The tour guide was fantastic and honestly I felt like I was at the latest royal wedding. A great visit, great attraction!

westminster Abbey History,HIstorry. Nothing to dislike. History full of pomp and circumstance like no other. Tombs of the famous and kings and queens., Stained glass windows,Crypts of royal and famous.Time to pray.leave over 1.5 hours.

Just Ok. The price to get in was a little steep and the Abbey was very crowded. You do get a free Audio guide with entry which we did appreciate, though we probably would have enjoyed a Verger led tour more. There is a lot of history here and the Lady's chapel was particularly pretty as were the small gardens outside. Wanted to eat in the cafe, but there was a long slow moving line to be seated so we left. I would probably skip the tour and attend Evensong if I wanted to see the inside on future trips.
Wonderful!. No trip to London is complete without this tour! Take the audio guide tour and buy the book. There is so much to see--allow enough time to soak it all in.

Fantastic!. Loved this experience and could have spent days here. If you like history, this is a must-see. As with most popular tourist attractions, it's crowded, but the history is well worth the crowd.
London. We were there on a Sunday so there were no tours, however we were able to go in after the service and listen to an organ concert. I t was beautiful.
Abbey Tour. I took a tour years ago and now with the audio tour system it is a lot better to get the information. I wish it wasn't so crowded but there are a lot of tight spaces.
Wow!. Really loved this place. I had to line up in the rain to get in but it was well worth it. Good value and lots to see.

Unbelievable. The Abbey us a must see in London. It is impossible to describe the interior.It must be seen to be believed. The beauty of the structure and the many famous people buried here make it a memorable experience. History buffs will be overwhelmed.
William and Kate getting married here made it interesting for my daughter.. Schools need to visit these places to bring these places to life. It doesnt feel the same reading from a book.

Breathtaking...and crowded!. We went early in the morning, lining up when the first opened and it was super crowded even then. It is a beautiful place and you should go at least once, but way, way too crowded. And you can't take pictures either. You kind of just waddle and squeeze around like everyone else. But I still loved it!
A walk through history. Enjoyed the self guided tour of this historic site, can be very crowded at times, the building is magnificent and the history is every where

This is a don't miss!!. The Abbey is amazing! Start at the Nave, up to the shrine of St Edward, to Henry VII's Lady Chapel, onto to Poet's Corner to see where Chaucer, Jane Austen, Lord Tennyson, the Bronte Sisters, Robert Browning, Lord Byron, Laurence Olivier and hundreds more are entombed. View the alter where Will and Kate were married, the ornate marble floor where Diana and the Queen lie in state, the coronation chair, ornate figures carved in brass and gold adorn the top of the tombs, with figures of children surrounding the tomb. See the burial tombs of King Henry III, Mary Queen of Scot, Queen Victoria and many King Edwards.

One of our trip's highlights without a doubt. My husband and I went to London for our honeymoon and had the BEST time. One of the places that we neglected to do much research on was Westminster Abbey, only because we knew we wanted to see it regardless. When we both walked into this place, we were floored. The tombs, altars, stained glass, individual shrines, and statues are unbelievable. We actually enjoyed this more than the British Museum in this regard. To be in such a momentous place seeing the tombs,markers of Isaac Newton, Florence Nightingale, Chopin, the Bronte sisters, Jane Austen, kings and queens, and others was mind-blowing. Such a unique treasure. Don't miss out on this place. The phone audio guides provided in various languages are neat and guide you through the abbey from location to location using numbers. We were also lucky enough to hear the organ and choir practicing while we were there. It gave me chills.

Spectacular Cathedral. After having visited many cathedrals around the world, my husband and I finally had the opportunity to go inside Westminster Abbey. It is by far, the most spectacular cathedral we have ever seen. The beauty of the sculptures and the architecture are amazing and should not be missed!

Visit the religious services (Evensong). I have visited the Evensong at 5pm. The tickets are really expanive so I chose this way to visit the Abbey. It was a beautiful 1 hour service, I heard the famous choir and also had time to walk around in the abbey. And it was free!

Amazing! Don't miss that one!. If you think: "to go, or not to go" (almost like Shakespeare's "to be or not to be) I say YES, TO GO, What an impressive cathedral! You'll appreciate the Monarchy much more after you see how much they tried to keep tradition. A choice of few languages tour around was amazing, including music tracks to feel the times better. Loved it! Probably not for kids, who might get bored, but history lovers, do not hesitate. Worth every penny!

Thousand-year-old Gothic-styled Building Used By Famous People. Location: Next to House of Parliament and Big Ben.Train: Westminster Station.When I was there early May 2015, the North entrance of Westminster Abbey was under renovation. However, it did not deter me from visiting this beautiful place. I first saw Westminster Abbey was on television when Princess Diana had her funeral in year 1997, and later Prince William's wedding in year 2011. This place looks like a place for the royal family for coronation, wedding, and funeral.Inside of this building is very grand and has a classic Gothic design. I was really amazed and impressive with its grandeur architectural design. One thing to note, there is Martin Luther King's sculpture just on top of the West Entrance door arch. Try to spot it if you can.Charles Darwin, Issac Newton and J.J. Thomson, alongside with many past British monarchs were buried in this abbey.
Love the history. When in London don't miss Westminster Abbey. The history is amazing. If possible buy tickets in advance, otherwise there may be a line to get in.

Wow amazing history!. My wife and I stopped to visit and had no idea how much history was there to discover! The place is filled with tombs of royalty as well as other famous Brits. Definitely worth the visit.
Fabulous. A must see in London! We waited in line about 30 minutes on a Monday morning. Very interesting to walk through and see all the art and the graves of many famous people.

Very worth 45 minute power walk.. Statues over entrance tell a great story. Poets corner is incredible place. Especially if cloning ever works. Make sure you have smart phone and Internet service before entering because you will generate 30 must find out questions while touring inside.

A great place to see Darwin's tomb and, if possible, avoid stepping on it. Entrance fee is 20 pounds for adults. The queue took for us half an hour to get inside – I definitely expect it to take longer during the high season. No pictures are allowed inside.The place itself is wonderful, with a lot of things to see – architecture, tombs, monuments, the coronation chair. You will discover the tombs of Darwin, James Watt, Sir Isaac Newton and many others. However the disturbing aspect for me at least is that since all these famous people and brilliant minds are buried in the floor, you’re stepping on them as you walk by and it doesn’t feel like a very Christian thing to do. I also feel that Darwin should’ve been buried anywhere else but in a church, where his tombstone only says his name and doesn’t do him justice.

Worth the time and steep ticket price. We visited Westminster Abbey at the end of May 2015. The line was very long but we got in after just 15-20min.The entrance fee is 20 pounds but I hated the fact that you were not allowed to take any pictures, because there is a lot you would like to photograph.Apart from the beauty of the cathedral itself, there are a lot of interesting things to see: Britain's oldest door (1050), the tombs of Isaac Newton, Charles Dickens, Charles Darwin, Thomas Watt, Rudyard Kipling and many more.Prices in the shop are quite high but that is all too common for London.

This one is a must-see. If you visit London, I strongly suggest that you visit Westminster Abbey. The Abbey admirably reflects many centuries of British history -- the greats are buried here.The architecture is stunning, especially the Henry VII Lady Chapel with its pendant fan vault ceiling.The price of admission, £18 to £20 per person, is high, but it includes a very good audio tour. I think it's worth every penny.

well worth a visit. its breathtaking from the moment you walk through the doors there is a lot to see you get to light a candle as well for 30p for those you lost well worth the money and well worth the visit get there early though

Did you know?. As this is a must visit spot, let me share some cool facts: the abbey is the place to be married or buried! Not you but royally speaking. The abbey changes with the times too - you can see a statue of MLK right u front and center . Pretty cool and way to go London! Now get on over and learn some more!

Exceeded our expectations . If you want to get a ten year old to complain, suggest touring a 1000 year old church. This changed though as we entered and they offered a kids self-guided hunt for all manner of symbols and items in the church. This kept the kids busy and we enjoyed the abbey at the same pace. They enjoyed it, we enjoyed it - a win:win.I find the abbey expensive to visit, but what in London isn't? Well worth it. Plan for two hours in the Abbey and also some time on the grounds and in the smaller church.

Westminster Abbey. This was on our list of to do's, it was without a doubt the most beautiful experience. We arrived just before 3.30pm when it closed but once inside were not rushed, the audio set was a real bonus

Tradition Religion and Glory. No place more than this one must be seen during a Visit in London.The price gives you access to the complete building with the support of an audio guiding system. The walk through the history of England -960 to 2011 with all the Tombs of famous people, the coronation chair, the Poet Corner , the wonderful Chapter house, teh relaxing cloister garden, The Henry VII's lady Chapel bring to every visitor a high load of emotions; The Queen Elisabeth coronation happened here 1953 and poor Lady Diana last funeral mass also . The Audio guide gives you so many details that capture your attention for hours, and if need many kind people are here to advise and answer any question.

Amazing. After visiting London many times we had never managed to visit Westminster Abbey. We booked on line and walked straight into the Abbey without having to queue which was great. The experience was truly majestic so much history. Really worth taking advantage of the (free) audio tapes to get the full stories. The staff were also very informative. One of the highlights from our 2 days break, highly recommended. but book on line with the Abbey to save a little money.
Beautiful and interesting.. It is other of the places in London you probably will visit. I think ticket prices are higher I expected. Anyway, it is an interesting place to visit.

So Much History, Great Site to Visit. Really enjoyed the visit to Westminster Abbey. So much history, it was as my college history textbook opened up as we walked through the Abbey. A beautiful building chock full of a thousand years of British history. Don't miss the Abbey on your visit to London.

beautiful. being one of the most expensive tourist attractions in London (18-20 pounds), those on a thigter budget may prefer visiting the abbey on daily service hours, when entry is free. althoug I think the free audio guide, and the chance to visit the chapels and wonder around the abbey was well worth paying for.

Got to do it, Its worth every penny. Get a museum pass for all your London museum visits, saves time and money. This was a wonderful visit and you must visit if its your first time in London. We enjoyed all the museums, but this is one of our favorites. All London's Church's and Museums are a must do. They are beautiful and full of history.

Incredible building!. Absolutely stunning! We did the audio tour which was very interesting and easy to follow. It was quite crowded the day we were there, but the crowds flowed well. I found it very interesting to see everyone that was buried in there too.
Beautiful. Very crowded, even on a weekday, but it was a really lovely church. A lot of history to see, and the inside of the church is beautiful. The free audio guide is quite helpful as well.

Great Verger tour with Benjamin!. After paying the entry fee, for an additional 5 pounds, the tour led by our Verger-guide, Benjamin, was most definitely worth it! He spent about two and a half hours with our small group. Besides gaining access to parts of the Abbey not available to the general public, his witty comments made the tour one of the highlights of our trip to London. I most definitely recommend taking one of the Verger tours.

Less than Expected. The Abbey is beautiful, and there is a lot of interesting information about it inside, however I wasn't as wowed by it as I thought it would be. Still worth a look, grab a set of headphones inside to make the most of your visit!
Abbey. The atmosphere is just first class. Just imagine the weddings which took place there. As if you are in a different world.

Its was Ok. Interesting place FULL of English history however, over crowded and once again spoilt by the number of people pushing and crowding into small and not very well lite places - typically poorly organised London mainstream tourist attractions - I am very impressed by the overall history - just can not imagine doing it again as it was not a pleasant restful experience more like dodgem cars at the fair - take care B&M

Ancient edifice. We arrive just before it opened and were greeted by huge queues. we had purchased London passes and this was its first test. The London pass queue was fairly small in comparison and we were inside after about 10 minutes. The size and the various alcoves and tombs of the Kings was very interesting. Well worth the visit.
Brilliant makes you proud to live here. Wow wow wow go and visit it's great an amazing place great commentary lots and lots to see makes you proud that we have things like this in the uk

A must see in London. This is the grand daddy of British history. If you do nothing at all you have to go visit the abbey. There is a fee to get in but line is very minimal. There are monuments for every British famous person you can think of from Jane Austin to Shakespeare. I did not know queen Elizabeth I and Mary, queen of Scots were buried here in equally majestic graves and exactly opposite of each other.  You can see the alter where every British royalty gets married or their coronation location. I could have spent hours just standing there and admiring the organ. Very easy to navigate, no pictures allowed, but if you like history or like architecture this is a must see.

Remember Us. Westminster possesses the spiritual mystique one might expect from a religious site, though I found myself more humbled by the seemingly endless grave markers within the building than any symbol of faith. Which, as a history lover, made it more compelling. The Abbey was very crowded when we visited and pictures aren't allowed, but no one seems to mind stepping aside to permit the next person a view or to pass by those who are especially intrigued by a particular setting. The Cellarium Cafe, however, I wouldn't recommend stopping at. It's pretty and a nice break in the midst of the day, but the food's expensive and not worth for the extra quid.

If you do not want to stand in line or pay a large admittance fee, visit the cloister for free. Westminster Abbey was built between 1245 and 1517 in French Gothic and perpendicular Gothic styles. Its cloister preserves some Romanesque features of an 11th century abbey built on the site by Edward I “the Confessor.”I am not a big fan of paying an admission charge to visit a church and consider a £ 20 entrance fee for the Abbey out of all proportions. However, the cloister is free to visit. You can enter the cloister from the Dean’s Yard that is situated behind the adjoining building.When entering the cloister, you will receive a yellow laminated card you must show. At the back of this is a map of the cloister, just in case you lose your way walking around the cloister. The rib-vaulted Gothic cloister was reconstructed after a fire destroyed the original one in 1285.From the cloister there is a view of the south façade of the Abbey with its flying buttresses and Gothic windows. The cloister also gives access to the Chapter House where Henry III’s Great Council and the Commons met until 1395. The Chapter House is accessed through a beautiful archway in which you can find what is considered Britain’s oldest door from the 1050s. The octagonal structure was constructed in 1245 and preserves its original tiled floor and very beautiful murals.The cloister also provides access to the Pyx Chamber, the Abbey’s treasury chamber. The Romanesque chamber dates from the late 11th Century. The name derives from the wooden chest holding coins that were used to judge newly minted coins and that was kept in the chamber. From the cloister, you can also access the Abbey’s museum. Among its exhibits are replicas of the crown jewels used during the rehearsals of the coronation.When I visited on a Saturday morning, it was not very crowded. After visiting it, I saw the long queue of people waiting to enter the Abbey itself. So, if you do not like to stand in line to see a church or the tombs of famous people or if you are not too keen on parting with a considerable amount of money to do so but want to see some of the Westminster Abbey, this may be a nice alternative.In no way am I suggesting you should not visit the Westminster Abbey. If this is that one time you are here and you can afford it, don't deny yourself the opporunity to visit this famous and beautiful Abbey. Even then, don't forget to visit the cloister. I recommend a visiting time of less than an hour. This is more than enough time to visit the cloister and the elements mentioned here. A visit of the Abbey itself may require considerable more time.

Worth a Visit. Beautiful and historic. Take advantage of advanced sale tickets now available on-line on abbey website that allow you instant entry instead of waiting in a very long queue to purchase tickets and enter on day of visit.

Great but needs more organizing. Amazing place to visit. I go there every time I go to the UK. But ufortunatelu it has high entry fees and it's a mess trying to go around the place. They have so many people going around that you cannot see some of the tombs for crowds standing on them etc. there has to be a way of organizing large crowds so that everyone gets to see these wonderful icons. Also I feel it's a bit disrespectful that people are allowed to stand on the tombs.

Loved every minute. This was a very crowded place to visit, but I loved it. The history is amazing and I could have spent hours walking around. Unfortunately, we just didn't have that kind of time on this trip. I highly recommend this to anyone. Tip: Get a London Pass. We got to wait in a different and much shorter line because we had a London Pass for our entry. Saved a lot of time.

Amazing history and mind-blowing architecture. Being inside the amazing cathedral knowing the history of its numerous events that took place (coronations, weddings etc) was surreal. The whole building is full of opulence, wonderful intricate details and just sheer grandness.

Beautiful!. Loved visiting Westminster Abbey on my visit. I wish I would have taken a guided tour, but the self guided tour was good as well. Visited just after lunch and didn't have to wait in line (we had the London Pass).
Awesome. Beautiful church full of rich and interesting history. I would highly recommend it. Also, if you have a London pass you can skip the line.

What's not to like? But plan!. It's Westminster Abbey! Iconic. So, you should see it. It's a good idea to do a little research and find out if and when you can go into the cathedral, especially on a Sunday. Also, maybe you can catch a daily choir concert. It's a different way to experience this -- sitting and enjoying the music and architecture.

History, architecture and verger tour. I suggest to start the experience by circling the abbey from outside, to see the gorgeous architectural details.It also gives you a chance to appreciate the surroundings: St. Margaret church, Parliament buildings, various statues and monuments, sundial that quotes Shakespeare.The entrance with London Pass is quicker (since there is a separated line and all is needed is to scan the Pass instead of dealing with money). Arriving at the opening we had to wait only around 20 minutes at the queue which I think was absolutely ok for such a popular attraction.Near the entry you can book a verger tour for additional 5 pounds. I highly recommend it! Verger tour was one of the reasons our visit was so successful. It is 90 minutes tour full of history, humor and fascinating information. Audio guide is good (I used it after the tour to visit areas not included in the tour) but verger tour is amazing!We also entered some areas normally closed for visitors.I suggest to plan at least 3-4 hours at the abbey.After verger tour we wondered around with audio guide and after 4 hours the decision to leave in order to see other places at Westminster didn't come easy.I also suggest to read about relevant historical figures (monarchs, writers) prior to the visit.You will find the visit more interesting.You will note many curious facts: Queen Elizabeth I is buried across Mary Queen of Scots and shares the grave with here half sister Queen Mary I, Princes from the Tower are buried here as well as their sister Elizabeth of York and people who might be suspected in their death (Henry VII, his mother Margaret Beaufort and Anne Neville the wife of Richard III)...

tour and evensong. Westminster Abbey was wonderful. I had never seen anything like it. Lot of famous people throughout history are buried there. the tour costs 20 pounds for adults, 17 for seniors. The church service featuring the Boys choir, called evensong was free. Imagine, people have been worshipping our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ in that same place for over a 1000 years!! Wonderful! Well worth it.
Would go again..... I would definitely go to Westminster Abbey the next time I'm in London. It was fairly expensive to get in, and very crowded, but well worth it.

Blown away. I was not expect ion this attraction to impress me so much. The beauty of this building is mind blowing and we had no idea about off the kings and queens hurried there right in the Abby. Unfortunately no photos allowed. If you want there is a mass you can participate in.

Exceeded my expectations!. Westminster Abbey had been on my Bucket List, so I had planned our trip to London to make sure we included it. It was so worth it. Words can't describe the experience of walking through the cathedral that has been the backdrop to so many iconic weddings and funerals. So many amazing figures in history are housed in their final resting places here. The audioguide points out all the major things you want to see. I also used the Rick Steves guide as well. Well worth the price of admission. We went first thing in the morning and it wasn't too crowded.

Make the time to attend a service and here the choir!. It is important to know that on Saturday - you need to be in the abbey by 3:30 pm as they clear the church for the 5:00 pm service. We got in just before 3:30 pm and stayed so we could get in line for the 5:00 pm service. Don't leave the abbey - if you want to stay! They will let you get in line. Folks start lining up around 4:30 pm for the 5:00 service. We were able to sit in the pews which are right next to the choir. There is limited seating and they direct you were to sit. It is an amazing experience.
eye opener. what a fantastic place to visit !! 1000 years of history condensed into an afternoon - in a very good way. the admission fee is not cheap - but, it is worth it !!

Impressive. hundred years of history - spirituality - architecture and arts. And not to forget: famous people side by side in their thumbs. with London Pass we had no waiting times due to priority lane - perfect

A tip about the audio tour. I won't reiterate what a wonderful place this is. However, if you go on busy days the audio tour seems shorter- we saw many areas that should have had a description that were not on the recording. My son found that if you punch in "99", you get to hear more audio concerning the Cloister Garden and other areas to the south. Leave it to a curious 12 yo to find a way to hack the tour!

Well worth the time it takes to walk it's halls!. After chatting briefly with one of the very charming volunteers, and acquiring a self-guided tour sound track - we took off along the route exploring all the different displays and memorials located within it's walls. The Black stone for the servicemen who died during the war was touching! We found it very interesting to see names we remember from history in school - fascinating to see the history residing there!

Completely Impressive 1000-year-old abbey. Westminster Abbey is the quintessential cathedral. It's huge, beautiful, and filled with memorials and gravestones for both Abbey personnel of ages past and famous persons. The restaurants are fine. There is a substantial charge for admission, and you can book tickets online before you travel; they will mail the tickets to you. We did this, and it worked out fine. Just a caveat, however: There are other enormous and ancient abbeys in the UK that are much less crowded and just as beautiful.

Words Cannot Describe!. This was my favorite spot in London! I had no idea that it was an indoor cemetery of England's royalty and other important historical figures. The tombs are the most magnificent pieces I had ever seen in my life. The history is amazing! The self guided audio tour is wonderful and full of facts. A must see when visiting London!

Wheelchair accessibility. Fascinating historical site, definitely worth a visit.The Abbey is relatively wheelchair friendly. Accessible toilets difficult to find without the help of a guide. With most of the attractions buried in the floor, for once reading everything is easy.Entry fee by donation for wheelies. Others pay an entry fee.

Beautiful Abbey. If you think the outside of this Abbey is beautiful you must spend the time and money to visit inside. The audio tour provides some wonderful information about the building, history and people buried in the abbey. It's a shame you can't take photos inside but they wouldn't do it justice anyway.

History all around you. What an amazing place!!!. You must go see this place. It is so beautiful and there is so much history there. You should not miss this site. I wish we would have done a tour with the guides available there. Make time to spend in this beautiful place.

Westminster Abbey. The Abbey is one of the most amazing buildings in London. But on this trip it was closed for repairs. But I must say from my last trip to the Abbey I was able to go inside.You wouldn't believe what the inside looks like I can't even begin to tell you. The first time I walked through the door's I was in awe. I couldn't believe what I was looking at, The inside is so amazingly beautiful it brought tears to my eyes.

History was never like this at school!. We went round the abbey with an audio guide and learnt so much we did not know before! Saw tmbs and monuments to so many famous people and read epitaphs and stories about them. Saw the coronation chair and the tomb of the unknown warrior completely surrounded by poppies. The fresh flowers at the altar and the quire were lovely. Food in the cellarium cafe was very good if pricey!

AMAZING!. My only disappointment was that photography is not allowed inside. But I don't think I'll ever forget how beautiful it is inside. From coronations, to funerals, to royal weddings....so much amazing history. I loved the Poets corner as well. Do not miss the chance to take a tour of the Abbey if you are in London!

Wonderful!. This is a magnificent structure, architecturally breath taking. I love reading the words that family members chose to inscribe on the tombs of their loved ones. I spent hours, reading each (with the exception of those on Latin) and loved just being in this magnificent cathedral. This is where each new King or Queen has their coronation and where they are all buried. It is so worth the price of admission.

Beautiful. A must visit when in London. If there is a long line come back at another time. It Is beautiful inside and it takes a while to see the entire church. Inside we took the self-guided tour and it was more than adequate. That way we could spend more time in areas that we found more exciting.

Surreal Place. Oh My goodness, seeing the graves and statues of so many I've read about in history was amazing. Men like William Wilberforce who helped abolish the slave trade in Britain, Isaac Watts, Isaac Newton, etc., etc. It was really an experience! We were also there on VE Day the 70th anniversary. It was a privilege to take part in a special memorial of honouring words, prayer, and blessing at the tomb of the unknown soldier. I want to go back and spend more time here.
Dont miss it from the inside. The amount of history and the great achievements in this church is facsinating...its one of the best and most beautiful places ive visited in london

Beautiful History. Such great history & beautiful architecture. I recommend taking the tour with the audio guide because there's so much to learn but it only took about an hour & it's free with admission. It was truly awe inspiring to be where so many kings & queens were crowned & where so many influential people are laid to rest. It is walking distance from the Westminster tube station & the house of Parliament. Highly recommend a visit!

A Verger Led Tour. If you are in London and want to see the Abbey a Verger Led Tour is the best way to do so. Verger-led tours of the Abbey are available, in English, for individuals or family groups only (and not for larger parties or school visits). They start at the North Door, last for approximately 90 minutes and include a tour of the Shrine (containing the tomb of Saint Edward the Confessor), the Royal Tombs, Poets' Corner, the Cloisters and the Nave. I took one with some visitors last summer and it is the only way to do it. I think it cost £5 more on top of price of entry and you have to call ahead and book it but it's well worth it. You will get access to areas that you wouldn't if you toured by yourself. You will also get more information and your journey through the Abbey will be shorter than if you did it by yourself. Highly recommend it.

WESTMINSTER ABBEY, LONDON. Guided tours and self-guided tours available. I highly recommend guided tour - discounts for seniors. Tour guides usually meet with tour groups just outside Westminster tube station for collection of fees and issuing of group I.D. badges. Excellent information is provided about this stunningly beautiful and historic Abbey which is open to the public all days except during Royal occasions. The Memorial to the Unknown Soldier is very moving as is every facet of the interior and exterior of this grand structure. The Charter Room is a " must see" . Conveniently located near Big Ben and Westminster Palace (Houses of Parliament) - I recommend also entering St. Margaret's Church beside the Abbey - visitors are welcome, however, photography within St. Margaret's is forbidden.
The Best part of our visit!. Not only was going through the Abbey amazing, looking at the tombs of famous royalty, but we stayed for Evensong and sat with the choir. Once in a life time opportunity.

Important church and tourist icon.. the crowds are frightful. Go early or late in the day. Go to a service. It is free. You get to sit near something historic. My last visit was near the prime ministers. Enjoy the building doing what it was designed for. If the Queen is going stand on the corner near St Margaret's. The royal cars will be so close you can almost get in.

A must see in spite of the queue and the steep price. Everyone must already know what an absolute must this church is. Incredibly beautiful and historic, with a clear, helpful, helpful audio guide. We went in the afternoon and stayed for evensong, a lovely and restful way to spend the end of our sightseeing day.
Beautiful and awe inspiring. The beauty of the cathedral along with all the history inside, makes the tour so worth it! Small chapels and large, each with a story to tell. A Must see!

Beautiful and interesting. This was one of my favourite parts of London - the abbey itself is absolutely gorgeous with huge stained glass windows, and elaborately sculpted tombstones all over. It's also a functional church so often there are sermons going on while you walk through. Also the free audio guide that came with admission provided a lot of interesting historical details (using Jeremy Iron's voice!) about the tombs and the abbey itself. We also had afternoon tea in the café, which was lovely.

A church.... I wish we could have gone into the abbey but due to a communion going on it was closed off for the time that we had available to see it. Just from the look inside from outside though I'd say it's worth the time to look into going.

Beautiful. Took my aged father to see the wonderful sights of the Capital, Westminster Abbey is a great place to visit for history old and new and plenty of places to sit and rest for the older visitor

If you like history and churches this is your place. I loved this place - for the history, the atmosphere, and the ability to explore so many areas at my own pace. This is a "working church" and they have services on Sunday (when they are closed for tours) and at other times during the week when they invite non-members to attend. I am so into old churches and Westminster Abbey did not disappoint. Be sure and check the hours before you go to give you enough time to explore and be amazed

Worth the wait. This is a living church....so we had to wait for several hours in the rain before we could get inside. A ceremony was being held in the church which we had not expected It is best in most cases to go early. There are many people waiting for tickets in long lines and many others that have purchased tickets ahead of time. The Abbey is an amazing historic treasure.

Well worth a visit. Very moving to see the grave of the Unknown Soldier and to take in all of the history of the Abbey and it was interesting to see that so many of our famous authors were laid to rest or remembered in Poets Corner.

England's History in 1 Place. This place was one of the most memorable ones from all the cities and places I'd ever visited. I think everyone knows this place and what it's famous for, but to me it felt like the place where I could feel the British History and culture that I was able to touch. The building itself is so beautiful inside and outside, and the sound of church singing was about to make me cry, because it was so clear and melodic. Also, I could visit the places where the famous British were buried, the places and people I had been telling my students about. I think this is the strongest place of London fo rme. I might forget the hotel where I was staying or the pub I had beer at, but if I ever have a chance, I'll re-visit Westminster Abbey at my next visit to London.
Try to make the Evensong. A revenant way to enjoy the Abbey, beautiful music in the perfect setting surrounded by the royalty of England
Beautiful Church. This is an absolutely georgeous church. We enjoyed exploring the different parts of the chapel and shopping at the gift shop outside.

A visit to the Abbey. We had a fairly nice visit to Westminster Abbey. The audio tour provided great information and I enjoyed hearing about the history. With that being said, my partner and I were ready to leave mid-way through. We got the jidst and were done getting elbowed by folks trying to get a better view of so and so's grave marker. Although crowded, I am still glad that we got a chance to visit the Abbey as it was a beautiful and historic site to see!

£20 to get in and nowhere to queue in the rain. A poor show: if you are going to charge £20 to go in a church, even if it is probably the world's most historic, you need to provide some sort of shelter for those trying to get in; as the weathermen cocked up yet again; as a result we and numerous others gave up, so you lost loads of revenue as a result; worst still the groups entrance was deserted and unused; this was not very sensible of you. Is there a cafe etc? I have no idea and I do not care. I bought a brochure from the abbey shop instead and used it to remember when it was free to get in, as a church should be.

superb. We prepurchased tickets for Abbey. Be careful to be on time.The audio guide was fabulous - stacked full of information & extra content. I even got to hear a recording of the pipe organ (ok by me as I couldn't hear it live). Seemed that they regulated how many people entered at a time. So things didn't seem too crowded. You could tour in your own time. We ended up spending approx 90 minutes.The actual architecture & history is mind-blowing (for 1st time visitor to Europe). Also nice to be able to experience the abbey as a church - time and spacefor his.The Cloisters & museum after the main buildig is also excellent.

Gorgeous. Really enjoyed touring the Abbey. We used the audio guide, which was quite helpful as we strolled around. It's so beautiful inside...so, so beautiful. I feel as though it's a must see. We arrived on a Monday around 11, and did have to wait in quite a line, in the rain. I had planned on getting there earlier to try and avoid a line, but we had just arrived in London the day before and apparently needed to sleep in. We did walk past later that afternoon, and there was only a short line to get in. The rain had cleared by then, so maybe mid afternoon is a good time to visit.

Awsome!. We were fortunate to attend an afternoon choir service at this historical church. It was beautiful, magnificent, and it was difficult to realize all the history that has taken place there. One bad feature is that you cannot take pictures of the inside of the church.

Something to see. A must see if in London - inside a homage to their past Kings and queens, great architecture and just a very religious experience. Also an area where some of the great English poets lie.

Amazing Landmark. An essential piece of history. We climbed the stairs to the second level, but the arrival of a large contingent of high school students on a field trip put us off climbing the last section. The audio tour is excellent. We were fortunate to attend a prayer service near Edward the Confessor s altar, usually roped off, with about 10 other visitors and the thought of all that history under our toes was amazing. I loved the poets corner and lingered on a bench to read all the inscriptions. There are lots of marbLe monuments to old soldiers both in the cathedral and throughout London, so be ready.

A step into history. A must see. We went around 2:30 pm, crowd was light. There is a fee. An audio guide is included in this fee.This is where kings and queens are married, buried and crowned. Famous poets and writers lie along with Britians tomb of the unknown soldier.The architecture is superb and it is absolutely a magnificent cathedral. Highly recommended.
Verger Tour Westminster Abbey. If you are touring W.A. pay the extra 5 pounds and do the guided Verger Tour. You go to some places not available on your own. As always, excellent and informative!

Well worth a visit . Amazing architecture inside, definitely a must see. So much history. I had seen Westminster Abbey on television but nothing compares to seeing it in real life. Staff were really helpful and knowledgeable too. Photos not allowed inside. Audio guides and maps included in ticket price. £20 full price for an adult paying on the day. Free entry for those with a London Pass.

Allow plenty of time to do justice. Queue can be quite long but moved very fast when l was there, but they did walk through the line asking for anyone that had booked online so if u can always book online. Audio guide was excellent but l also took the guided verger tour, this was only 5 pound and gave you access to an area off limits to the public, for this alone l would add the tour on. A communion service is also offered twice a day, always nice to partake of this in the abbey, you do not have to take communion you can have a blessing or just stay in your seat if you wish. Another good thing to do is put a card in the box near the candles to be read out during the service for a prayer for someone. To really get the full experience you can also attend Evensong, just check the days in advance when this is on. You can do all or none of these but l found them all to be well worth the experience depending on how much time u have, if you just do the Audio guide allow around the 2 hours . Nice cafe and there is also the usual gift shop. Amazing history and well worth attending if you have time

A Must See. It was quite an experience standing at the front of Westminster Abby and imagining Kate Middleton walking down the isle to marry Prince William. So many famous people are buried there and the architecture is amazing. It was awesome to see Newton's tomb and the tomb of the young Lady Jane who of course was beheaded there. There is a real feeling of magestry. Take the time to experience it.

Lovely and such history!. This was my second visit to Westminster and I will mostly go a again during future trips to London. The architecture and stained glass are beyond beautiful. There is also much historical significance to this site and that seems to permeate the air.

Fab View. The climb to the top can be a bit tiring, however stop off at the half way point and enjoy the internal views of the abby from the whisper gallery. The views from the top are amazing on a clear day. Highlight of my visit was having the opportunity to listen to a visiting choir.

Beautiful and unique. A must see when in London. So beautiful and so much to see. Very different form European churches. If you book online - you'll probably wait less in line. Don't worry if you haven't downloaded the guide app - they give free audio-guides in all languages for free. Unfortunately, photos are now allowed.
Legendary Visit!. Always wanted to be here with a little extra time on watch, this time it happened. A landmark worth note!

Very Historial and Insightful. Westminster Abbey is filled with information and insights about past and current Kings and Queens. I would recommend having the London Pass as the que isn't as long. A good day's outing.
Outstanding. Well worth a visit. Only downside if there is one, it's a bit like IKEA. Once you enter, you have to walk right around before you find the exit.

Amazing design to look in London. The Westminster Abbey as one of the most famous landscapes in London deserves you to spend time having a look. It is near the Big Ben as well, parliament buildings, and not far away from the Buckingham Palace. :)

Beautiful. I felt it was a bit expensive to pay that much money to visit the Abbey and so, I bought the London Pass which is including it (With 3x 20pounds attractions, you're already in your money). The pass also gives you a fast track which is great. Inside was quite wonderful but I hadn't seen any English abbeys yet and so, maybe I was a bit deceived. Still lots of interesting stuff and I think it is a must do if you are interested by the Monarchy and that you have followed a coronation.
An overpriced must.. If you are in London, you must go, but I think it's a bit pricey. The exterior architecture should garner some time. It's beautiful.
Wow. History buffs will find their happy place! If you walk in and just think if everything that has happened here, you'll get chills.
Beautiful. I had never seen so many graves in a church! It's nice to keep searching for specific graves and analysing the people's graves profiles.
Excellent, well worth the short wait to cue.. The sites and history was fascinating and really interesting. It surpassed my expectations. We would've liked to have been able to take photo's.

A must. Westminster Abbey is one of London's most famous landmarks and definitely something you don't want to miss. You can buy audio guides which make the experience a lot more interesting and informative. The abbey is spectacular inside and out and filled with history. I wouldn't really recommend for families with young children who might miss the greater significance, but still a great and affordable place to visit!

Breathtaking (If you don't go you're crazy). The history that has occurred here should be reason enough to visits. It's not just where the Royal Wedding happened, it's where Isaac Newton is buried and where the Tomb of the unknown soldier is located. There's no way you can come to London and not visit here.

Very special. I make a point to visit Westminster Abbey each time I get to London. There's just a special feeling there. More than a religious experience, it's just one of the great witnesses in the history of a greatnation.

A very beautiful cathedral.. It is a very beautiful cathderal. A masterpiece of Gothic architecture.It has its influence on other cathderals made in Europe.They majestic site is really inviting.The inclusion of Dr Martin Luthar King adds to progressive attitude of church.liked it very much.pleas find the timings before going .they stop entry in late afternoon.One can spe. Sometime on lawn outside if there is sun.

A must see experience. This is definitely an attraction you should find some time to visit. A mobil audioplayer to get all the information you need, then you are set for a good time, and lots of information.

Beautiful Cloisters and College Gardens - Photography Allowed (for personal use). We visited the Westminster Abbey last Sunday afternoon and visited the Dean's Courtyard, College Garden and Cloisters. It was peaceful, inspiring, and charming. We managed to take some beautiful pictures to help bring back memory. See photos uploaded.

Wonderful and a must visit!. You are about to enter this magnificent great building - the traditional place of coronation and burial site for English and, later, British monarchs and there have been at least 16 royal weddings at the abbey. This is an amazing place that everyone should see. At least once in their life. When I walked around and understood that under my feets it was written Charles Darwin I stood still for a very long time. This is somerhing very special.

Memorable place to visit. I wasn't sure whether I would really enjoy visiting here or not, but was so glad I did go! While the building itself is awe inspiring, what impressed me more than anything was being surrounded by so much history. The tombs of so many people I've only ever read about were within touching distance. It's incredible to be able to walk around somewhere so old and which has been used by so many distinguished people. It was an experience I'll never forget and would love to go again at some time. We visited the Cellar Cafe at lunchtime and enjoyed delicious soup. The staff were very friendly and helpful and the toilets were also very clean. My only criticism would be that its a pity there werent toilets available somewhere other than at the end of the tour. I kept hoping I would find some before then, but I never did!!

Westminster Abbey is one of the key landmarks. Its like the royal church and all related to the monarchy. The coronation of the kings and queens of United Kingdom happens here. The church is very beautiful and full of history, The radio guided tour is good and worth the money.

Go, even if crowded. The Abbey is quintessential London. The history of this place, and all the people buried there, plus the amazing architecture features, will make you feel like stepping into a sacred ground.

beautiful but.... dont like that you cannot take pictures. i understand its a place or burial and worship, but sometimes you just want pictures to treasure the moment a little longer. the coronation chair was very beautiful and great to see.

beautiful communion service. What a wonderful way to pause in the middle of sightseeing and reflect in this peaceful setting. Check the website for times (we went at 12:30pm). We tagged this on to our visit to the London Eye and Big Ben, both nearby. They welcome everyone to attend the service (free) and for communion anyone who attends communion in their own church (you don't have to be Anglican)

A must visit at least once. Absolutely beautiful Protestant church with rich history related to English royal weddings, coronations of kings and queens as well as famous people buried there. Enter through great north door with ticket booths located just inside. Please note opening and closing times in advance. Closes mid afternoon. Receive free guided audio tour in various languages after purchase of entry.

Neat. Learned a lot from audio tour. Missed some of the tombs account of the crowd. They were also preparing for the Queens visit that Sunday, so some parts off limits. Coronation chair impressive. A must to see if you come here. Nice statues in the square outside.

Incredible history. Loved the density of amazing things to see. Can't believe so many historical figures are buried in one place (Elizabeth I, Geoffrey Chaucer, Winston Churchill, etc.). It's hard to take it all in, in just one visit. The musical service was likewise incredible.

historical and beautiful church. lots of graves in the church, too bad no photos allowed inside the church but it has all the history you can find in england. whats nice is that you can rent a recording where you can just listen about interesting points of history of the church and take your time strolling.

Impressive. I have been here 4/5 times and every time I discover new things, its very impressive with all the Kings and Queens berried there, I strongly recommend you go there if you like history.
Bernies World Wide Travel Experience

Very good place to visit. I think is a place which really worth the time and the money, there is a lot of history about England, Kings, Queens, artists, cientists. Make sure you get the audioguide, it really worth to have the explanation of every single part of this magnific place.

Holy of holy,s. The trip to Westminster Abbey was on the same day as our trip to the London Eye. The Abbey is amazing experiance whe you consider both the religious and historical significance of the site. The only down side was the crowds of which we were two but at times it was difficult to see the tombs and religious artefacts that were to be seen. Having said all that it is still a place that I would recommend for a visit. Not a place perhaps for small children as it can be a bit boring for them.

Awesome. Come to the birthplace and resting place of British kings and queens, take in the architecture, the stunning masonry, the wealth of the great and the good of this magnificent country. Most of all feel the history seep from the pews and find your god amongst all of the pomp and pageantry. Audio guide helpful but not as good as it used to be, docents brilliant.

A Must See. See where Kings and Queens have been crowned, and just about every major Britishnevent held. It's a spectacular building in every way, but allow formplentybofmtime during peak tourists seasons, as it can get very busy. Get off the tube at Westminster.

History. This abbey is beautiful. It is fascinating to see so much preserved history all in one location, not to mention the final resting places of people we have heard of who lived several hundred years ago.

Unbelievable. Inside is magnificent and all the people buried (over 3000) is unbelievable, walking around the names are impressive.Try to find the painted on window, during WW2 the Abby was hit but they did not have the materials to repair the widow, so they just painted it on the outside wall

Wonderful Landmark. A lovely landmark but a bit expensive. There is so much history located in the Abbey but at £18 is does come accross as high. I recall, not os many years ago that it was free to go round. The only cost was for a guide. I suppose these buildings require a lot of maintenance and hence the cost. Similar landmarks around the world are of the same and so I reckon it is just a sign that the poor tourist has to take on more of the cost. There is no need for a tourist tax if this is the level of charge.
You will feel like you stepped back in time. I thoroughly enjoyed Westminster Abbey, when you're inside, you will feel the history envelope you. Get the audio guide.

Breathtaking!. The structure is overwhelmingly large. Such history! Across the street is the House of Parliament and Big Ben. Fine craftsmanship in the architecture of this church. It is unreal! Cannot wait to see it again.

Outstanding- living, breathing history. I have been numerous time to visit the Abbey. Each time I am awestruck by the majesty and the story behind it as well as the fact history is still being made within its walls through royal weddings and funerals.
