I find the Abbey better organized for visitors since my last trip. The free audiophones make for a smoother transition throughout the building. All the major tombs and sights are pointed out. Of course, the secret is to order your ticket in advance and be there at the opening before the tour buses arrive. I was able spend some time alone with Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots and study their resting places and remember their tangled lives without being herded and pushed through by the crowd. I had forgotten how lovely the Lady Chapel is. I would suggest also reading up a bit on English history before you go, to be able to get all the kings and queens in context. A must-do, must-see when in London.

How to treat a customer like a complete moron.. I posted a glowing review of this place (7 February 2015) and will now ask Tripadvisor to remove it. I totally agree with the reviewers Rab365 (May 17 2015) and Darwinbeagle (May 16 2015).I considered an interior visit (£20 per person) and heard that this place was included in the National Rail '2-for-1' offer but when we went up to London could not find it included in that offer in the National Rail Booklet with its vouchers, so we went somewhere else instead.I sent a message to Westminster Abbey asking why this was. Someone there eventually bothered to reply, several weeks later. They informed me that the Abbey was indeed included in the offer (so why wasn't it in the rail booklet?) and 'the scheme runs until 15th April'. The message was sent to me on 11th April, so a fat lot of good that was!!!What a pity I cannot award ZERO stars.This is undoubtedly a great and historically important building but if the Christian Dean and Chapter who run it (who undoubtedly know a thing or two about some writings of 2000 and more years ago but precious little about service to the paying guest in the modern day) can treat you in such an incompetent manner perhaps it is time that such a nationally and internationally important edifice was taken over and managed by another organisation or even by the Government.I would be very interested to see if they bother to respond to this as I know they read all these reviews.If you pay the money and go inside you'll almost certainly enjoy it, but why not just admire the magnificent exterior (as I do now) and visit one or more of the many other visitor attractions in this area instead? St. Margaret's Church is beside this and is well worth the effort.You can attend services in the Abbey (there are 28 each week) and this is one way you could at least see part of the interior without paying the steep admission fee, which is too high for those with limited means.

Ten quid to enter, and shut at lunch time!. I thought I had better have another look, so I got off the train at Westminster and walked around to the entrance. There at the gate were two men telling heaps of people, "Closed till 1.30." So I'm off.Three things I like here are : - Poets Corner, and the fact that Queen Elizabeth the First ended up in the same tomb as her cousin Queen Mary of Scotland, the lady she had beheaded. You can almost hear them discussing this 'little' decision. And lastly, has anyone any idea of just how many people are buried here? As I walked around, I could hardly put a foot down without treading on someones grave.Brian. from Perth. W. Australia.

Amazing Architecture with Famous Crypts-A Historic, Yet Creepy, Experience. I cannot bring myself to give this any less of a rating than excellent, just for the architecture alone and out of respect for those buried there; however, it was a really creepy experience for me. It gave me the heebie jeebies, walking around while looking at all of the crypts, especially the ones that looked like early Madame Tussauds sculpture renditions of those who have passed away. My husband wasn't fazed by the "death art" at all.

Hmmm; not sure how I feel.. The theme that I'm getting in London is that you can't take pictures inside historic places. That's a drag. I get the whole church environment and mass burial site but most people coming here are tourists, we pay to get in, and it'd be nice to take pictures. While it's definitely beautiful, I found the whole idea of it weird. I did appreciate the audio tour though. It was nice to learn some new things. Oh, if you prepay for your tickets, as for the "special" line. It's not clearly marked but there was no waiting in that line. After getting through the wrong line, I was sent to the prepaid line.

Not just a church - more of a history lesson. It is an active church but when you tour it, you are transported into history. It was like being in a time machine. You could pick a year and find a section of the abbey that had meaning during that period. Loved walking on Charles Darwin. Yes - you must look up, down and around to take it all in.

WONDERFUL PLACE. If you want to do the tour then you have to pay an entrance fee of around £20 but if you tell them that you just want to light a candle(which is what I wanted to do) then they let you in to do it free of charge

Breathtaking. I was absolutely in awe when I entered the Abbey. It's spectacular and a definite must see if you are in London. The audio tour guides were very good to listen to. Very informative and easy to follow.

Westminster Abbey. Huge church on huge grounds. Plenty of crowds but be patient. It's worth the wait. It was cool being here and seeing the things with my own eyes that I saw on TV such as the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II and the wedding of Prince William to Katherine. Walk around and explore. It's more than a church, it's a history museum as well.
A must see in London. I believe the history of this Abbey is incredible. The self guided tour gives you a great insight as to its history

Place of great reverence . It's been the site of many monumental and historic events for many centuries. From crowning of monarchs to being the actual burial ground of many figures. Yet it remains a religious place of serenity and worship with prayers and evensongs daily. Worth a visit to step inside and take in the magnificence around you.

Beautiful. the history also the tombs also a must is the crypt. The tombs are of very well known names throughout history and the architecture. There is just a pleasant atmosphere wherever you are within the walls.

Beware possible long queues even if pre-booked. Took 90 minutes to queue to get in! Assumed having pre-booked tickets we would be straight in. Many agitated visitors walked away as their 'plans' did not give them time to wait. Audio tour very basic. Recommend full guide book for a better understanding. Only limited toilet facilities inside (another 10 minute queue - good job I wasn't desperate). Staff managed inside numbers well however. Not overly crowded inside, which was probably part of the problem with the queue outside. RECOMMEND you get there early i.e. just before official opening time to minimise waiting. Museum worth a visit.

Architecture, History and the Unique. Enjoyed so many things about the Abbey. The cloisters, the tombs, the art, the architecture, and the recent additions in the Poets Corner. There are many medieval memorials and tombs in the Abbey...which are ornate and really cool with regard to British history. The church, itself, is just lovely...with so many different alcoves and rooms. It is a must see on any London visit.

A Must See. We went to the Abbey our first evening in town and we all agreed it was even better than we expected. The complimentary audio guide was fantastic and really helped us navigate. It's something everyone really should see.
Great historical building. many things to learn abt the abbey, definitely a must see when in london. Get the london pass to get in the fast lane. It is an attraction included in the London pass

Get the real Westminster Abbey Experience. Rather than pay to get into the cathedral we attended one of many free services as our time was limited and we were there on a Sunday. The down side is that you can't take pictures at all when you are inside (at least not so they can see you!), but the up side is you can worship in the abbey. We went to a free organ recital which was incredible. The main thing we noticed about the church was how much of it was for the glory of man....the kings, the queens..... Didn't seem to be much about Christ or the disciples. However, it is a beautiful cathedral. My favorite picture is after the service as we are outside leaving the abbey, the priest comes out in his red robes and is shooing everyone away as it's time for the choral matins. Most churches are trying to get people to come in, but not Westminster Abbey.

Don't expect to take photos. Was a little disappointed we could not take photos but the experience was wonderful. I would recommend taking a guided tour- we did not have time but bobbed in and out of a tour happening around us and found it much better as we got the story of the graves. It is a beautiful structure well preserved and loved. We did not have time to see St Margarets this time but take a day to really check this area out.

Breathtaking!. A serene feeling when you enter the Abby. Home of the tombs of England's greats from Kings and Queens and even Darwin and Newton. The place where Williams and Kate got married and Diana's funeral was held. A handheld recorded guided tour with a reasonably entrance fee. Arrive early as it fills up fast, if you are there around noon the Arch Bishop leads a prayer. A must see for sure!

Awesome. The service we received was excellent (I was accompanying a wheelchair user and we were treated like royalty - nothing was too much trouble) So much history in the Abbey and beautiful setting. Definitely worth a visit

Worth every penny!. Loved our visit to the Abbey. Worth the entrance fee. Give yourself at least a couple hours to go through. You get a personal hand held audio guide to the abbey also which was neat for added info to what you're viewing.
good for taking photo. i didn't enter the church. just looking around in the front park. it has beautiful park actually. worth for taking picture though, no more

Exciting. The building was huge but we only took a picture stop - definitely great to see the construction and style of architecture was interesting - if you have more time - it would make a special stop

Love it!. My mother and I got there before the Abbey opened and the line was already very long. However they had the sign saying "30 minute wait from here" and it only took half that time. The Abbey itself is wonderful and the audio guide is great too. Glad I was there ten years earlier to get pics on the inside, because they don't allow photography anymore. I absolutely love the coronation chair because it is not what you would expect. It's not a grand gold and jewell encrusted chair. It's really old and wooded and still has carvings from the schoolboys of yesteryear. Totally cool.
Beautiful. Although it was expensive, it was truly beautiful and worth seeing for its grandeur and amazing history. This Is a very interesting place to visit, and definitely recommend to others.
Spiritual and beautiful!. We had a private guide, Richard Rath, who was able to get us in quickly and was incredibly knowledgeable. I would highly recommend a guide.

Collins London. This is a MUST on everyone's list to things to do & see in London. Again the audio tour provided allows one to see and absorb at one's one pace. A truly remarkable edifice! Be sure to catch tea or a light lunch at the Cellarium- great food & atmosphere!
Beautiful. Amazing place with lots of history, ashamed that you can't take pictures considering you have to pay to enter. Not really a bad thing but would love to show pictures to friends and family

Sensational. It's a pity you aren't allowed to take pictures inside because the Abbey is beyond beautiful inside. The history of the place is breathtaking, and you often find yourself coming across the tombs of people who literally defined modern civilization, such as Isaac Newton and Queen Elizabeth I. The audio tour is detailed and worth it, and you should really spend a half day here to enjoy it fully. Outstanding museum with priceless historical relics. Don't miss this attraction if you come to London.

A very expensive visit to a church. We were extremely disappointed in the cost to visit Westminster Abbey. Considering a church is meant to be a place where one can find solace and peace, it is certainly not available to the common man. I believe that Westminster Abbey has become a very profitable money making scheme to ensure only the rich and famous will ever find peace within its walls.

Well Worth the Trip. The history is incredible. As a technologist, I stood in awe at the tomb of Sir Issac Newton, Lord Kelvin, Michael Faraday, and James ClerkMaxwell! These guys changed how we view the world.. Take your time, listen, to the audio guide, and read the plaques. Don't rush.

Just Beautiful. You would be amazed how many historical people are burried here. They do such a nice job for Rememberance Day here. This was the first place I ever visited on my first trip to London many years ago. I always find myself coming back here!

Breathtaking. We explored with the London Pass- they give you free recorders that tell you about each section of the Abbey (really interesting). Loved the atmosphere, the tombs, and the history of the self-guided tour.

Total rip-off. We went to Westminster Abbey to see the tombs of Sir Isac Newton and Charles Darwin. The price for entry: 19 pounds. We left, disgusted. Shame on the Church of England for such a rip-off.

History made beautiful. The external part is worth the trip but the inside is even more impressive. Combined with the history it makes for a combination not found often. There is an Evensong service on Saturday evening at 5:00 which lasts an hour and people start lining up at 4:00 for it so be early.

Well worth your time. The audio guide is wonderful - it adds much to your visit. Go early and avoid the lines. Also, if needed, they will lend you a wheelchair for anyone who may want it. This is perfect for elderly - because there are not many places to sit along the way and they won't miss anything. Also - be sure to go to an Evensong at 4:30 - it's free and will be one of the most beautiful experiences you have. People start lining up around 4 at the side gate - check the times and information online before you go

Well worth the money. This looks like an expensive visit and I think that it probably could be if you were not into your British history. If you wanted to "Do" Westminster Abbey you could in half an hour looking but not seeing. We spent over 3 hours and had an amazing, interesting time so the £20.00 entrance fee gave great value for money. My partner is an archaeologist with an interest in medieval belt and horse harness buckles (yes we left our anoraks outside) and the information gained from the period statues and memorials is with her for ever. When I went as a child some 35 years ago certain parts of the Abbey had a separate charge, now one fee gives access to all.

Do the Tour AND a Service. The Abby is not opened that much, check the dates and buy your tickets in advance. The audio guide is average. Plan on reading a guide book or pay for a guided tour. The Abby is steeped in history and art and easily a two hour visit if you want to soak it in. Still, unless you attend a service, you are missing the full experience. Queue up early (4:20 for a 5PM service) for the "Evening Song" service. The choir is worth the wait and the actual service is about 45 minutes.

The attraction is ok but it's strange that you cannot . take pictures inside. The church is very beautiful and is a testament to The history of UK and London. The layout is unstructured and it's confusing to find your way around in the church if you are not using the tour phones. Happy to have been there but is not visiting for a second time.

Yikes.... While impressive on the outside, I found the place to be cluttered and just a creepy place to be on the inside. A lot of people entombed in there, too. Plus, it was quite expensive to go inside. But, it's one of those "must sees" while in London. Still, I could've done with just seeing it from the outside. I would've saved money and skipped on the creepiness factor. The time would've been better spent seeing one of the many other attractions in the great city of London.

Fabulous. fabulous, the history here is only second to the tower of London. To see this active house of worship. To what where kings and queens have. To see were marriages and funerals have taken place and to visit the final resting places of the Kings and Queens.
Steeped in history.. Very expensive, overflowing with tourist but still a must see while in London. Staff friendly and helpful, we enjoyed Westminster Abbey very much.

Totally worth it!. We visited on a very crowded Wednesday and even though it was quite busy, the visit was well worth all the stepped on toes. Be sure to get the audio guide otherwise you will be missing out on much of the history. This abbey is well worth the admission price. We also enjoyed visiting the cloister gardens and were able to take some lovely pictures. This was my third time visiting Westminster Abbey and if I ever make it back to London, I will be going again.

Historic Church. This is a historic church and one must pay to enter. The lines move quickly. This is where coronations, royal weddings and royal funerals take place. Sir Isaac Newton, general Oliver Cromwell and several kings are all buried here. Princess Kate and William got married here. Princess Diana's funeral took place here. The place is huge and impressive. Need not make a separate trip, you could combine it with a visit to the Parliament square.Worth visiting.
Not just a church. So many kings and queens, along with famous others throughout the years are buried here. I enjoyed the audio guide.

Worth the admission price. We were in 2 minds as to whether or not to come here due to the cost but decided to give it a go and were pleased we did. It was the most expensive of all the churches we visited during our recent UK/Europe trip (in fact most of the other ones were free), however it was by far the most impressive. The audio guide was very informative and an added bonus for us was the Children's Trail which kept our 2 children (11 and 13) occupied and interested. There is so much to see here - graves of many monarchs, Poet's Corner, grave of the unknown warrior, the coronation chair etc. - and the architecture is beautiful. We spent much longer here than we'd intended but it was definitely a highlight of our stay in London.We queued for about 20 minutes to get in but I noticed that the Pre-pay/London Pass queue was also very long - but maybe it was quicker-moving.

Westminster Abbey - a Memorable Visit. Westminster Abbey was a highlight in our visit to London and well worth the admission price and the time we spent there. Before we began our tour, we went into the Dean's Courtyard to a small restaurant for lunch. During the tour, we had audio guides which were very helpful. Westminster Abbey has been the place where royalty has been crowned, married, and buried since 1066. The architecture of the building is incredible. We saw the exact spots where Queen Elizabeth II was crowned and where Prince William married Kate Middleton. The Lady Chapel has beautiful stained glass windows and an incredible ceiling. We saw many tombs of kings and queens and others important in English history. Particularly interesting was Poet's Corner. in this section were plaques and memorials honoring the great English poets and writers: Dickens, Shakespeare, Tennyson, and so many more. There is also an Air Force chapel. The stained glass window has religious figures in it along with pilots and parachutes. It is a tribute to WWII flyers. Our audio guides led us through each part of the Abbey explaining each section as we went.After our tour and after an ice cream break, we went back for the Evenson service and are so glad we did. The church had been cleared of tourists. Worshippers were led in and seated for the service. Evensong lasted about an hour and was beautifully done. This is such an historic place and we thoroughly enjoyed seeing it.

Beautiful with Amazing History. The size itself is overwhelming and the historical contents are more than you can handle in one day. Get a sense of the highlights of what you want to see before you go in or you could wander around and miss a lot. We had a private guide, who again, took us to the highlights and told us all the cool stories so we knew what we were seeing. Definitely recommend guided tour. Get there early!
westminster abbeya lo. A lovely abbey not to far from the river with lots of history. Quiet and peaceful. In the heart of London.
Worth the wait!. I don't really visit churches, espcially if I'm not travelling, but WA is so stunning and full of history that's it's definitely worth the ques! Still a bit pricey tho...

Must See. Everyone friendly and helpful. Meander at your own pace with the free audio guide. A feast for your eyes, so much history but never loosing the fact you are in a wonderful place of worship. Gardens open on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays. A very popular attraction.

Useful Audio Guide During Westminster Abbey Visit. I arrived at 9:30 am on a Tuesday in April at Westminster Abbey for a visit by myself. There was a short line-up to get it. The line moved quickly and it only took 5 minutes to get to the ticket window. I paid £20 by credit card for entry and I got an audio guide which was very useful. I just followed the sign numbers in the Abbey and entered the appropriate code into the audio guide for a very good commentary. I finished my visit by 11 am.The Abbey does get crowded but it was manageable to walk around without too much inconvenience. No photography is allowed inside the Abbey. There is so much history inside.

A beautiful building with a long history. While it may be surrounded by other buildings and it might not be the largest abbey, it is still well worth a visit.The history pours out of every stone and there is so much to take in. It was extremely crowded and the queue was quite long but it was still worth the effort.I must admit I also really enjoyed sitting for a few minutes in the little church just outside the entrance of the Abbey. St Margaret's is a beautiful little church and was a pleasing quiet relief after the crowds and noise outside.

Exceptional beauty and history. Such an amazing combination of beauty and history. I had pretty low expectations and was blown away! We did the headphone guided tour and it was fantastic! So interesting and you really need to experience it yourself. The highlight for me was standing in the spot where Guy Fawkes was tried!

Expensive, beautiful interior, some odd contradictions. It will cost you a decent amount of pounds. Those British institutions love your money. It's funny, because the tour in the National Cathedral in Washington DC is donation only, and so are the museums in NYC. The architecture is stunning interior and exterior. They have a very detailed walking tour with headset inside. Many areas tell you not to take photos, though I took them anyway....just be discreet. The largest contradiction is that Charles Darwin, cofounder of Evolution and also probably an atheist, is buried inside the Abbey....which is Christian in origin. Maybe he did not realize he would be buried there. Ha ha.
Must See. Came here on a 2for1 voucher and it is amazing inside, you will walk on the tomb of Charles Darwin without realising! Definately see if you can

Get the London Pass & Cannon Verger Tour. My wife and I just did our first trip to London and after we left, this was one of our favorites. Beautiful church and such a rich history. Must do if you've never been. My advice would be to get the London Pass. We got there early but the line was wrapped around the building to get in. Those with a London Pass were able to skip the line completely. Having that pass would have saved us about an hour waiting to get in. Other thing I would recommend is getting the Cannon Verger's guided tour of the facility. David Mott did ours and he was fantastic! Really made the experience even more special. Only 5 extra pounds per person and totally worth it.

A Beautiful Edifice of Life and Death. How many royal weddings and coronations have taken place in Westminster Abbey? How many Kings and queens and famous Brits are buried here or commemorated? I don't know the answer, but within this edifice of life and death are the names of many famous people I recognize. Whether viewing this beautiful church from the outside or walking within its hallowed walls, I felt a sense of awe and inspiration toward all who have gone before me. To name a few: Mary, Queen of Scots, Sir Isaac Newton, George Frederick Handel, Charles Darwin, David Livingstone, Charles Dickens, Rudyard Kipling, Alfred Lord Tennyson. Their placement comes to mind, but no photos were allowed. Though royalty and notables ended up here, I couldn't help but think of having in common our mortality yet the hope of eternity.Take time to experience a thousand years of history, a daily place of worship, magnificent architecture and a treasure house of paintings, stained glass, pavements and artifacts. Visit Westminster Abbey!

Breathtaking!. Westminster Abbey is absolutely gorgeous. The architecture, art, the windows, everything. The tour itself is very interesting and they did a really good job with the audio guide. We thought about paying for the guided tour, but I think we got a really good understanding of the history and the artifacts from the audio tour. We truly enjoyed our visit and would definitely return again given the opportunity.

My mother was in awe. I did not know that Westminster Abbey is also a great burial spot. Very informative and lots to see inside. Long queues to get in, and it was not "peak" season, but good to see. Love the audio guides that you take along to hear about the different things, without having to be in a tour.

Amazing. I thought that this would be a quick 1 hour or so but there is so much to see and so much history. You are provided with an audio that allows you to self discover or you can join a tour. This is a must see place to visit! It took around 3 hours to go through the abbey and take in the atmosphere and architecure - including Britain's oldest door.

A National Treasure. Having not visited the Abbet since I was a small child and being a history buff I wanted to see where so many events had happened and so many famous people are buried or commemorated.We pre-booked the tickets and entered through a dedicated entrance with no queuing involved.The staff were friendly and helpful.We had the free audio headphones and wandered about at a leisurely pace taking in the marvellous atmosphere and the wonderful architecture.If you know anything of British history and have not visited the Abbey be prepared to be amazed at the nearly 1200 years of the country's story almost ingrained into the building.If you know nothing of British history it is well to take a brief overview to enhance your visit, but if this is not your scene still go and you'll still enjoy yourself.It is a working church and prayers and services may take place during your visit but it will not interfere with the tourism aspect of visitors.Would heartily recommend a visit.

Worth the visit. Just do it. That's all I can say. If not for the art, then the architecture, or the history, or the cultural importance. There are so many reasons to visit. If you have any questions, the staff and docents are so helpful. I asked them to a of questions and they answered all of them.

Incredible. What a truly amazing place, as a Brit living in the US it was so incredible to visit and show our children and explain our cultural and religious heritage. You are literally walking in the footsteps of our kings and queens.

Beautiful!. The gated gardens are spectacular. The details in the building are amazing. The grounds are immaculate. The atmosphere is excitable. My partner and I never went inside but were duly impressed by the outside alone!
A must do. You can't go to London and not visit the Abbey.You are given audio guides for the visit, which makes it worth as you travel through history as you walk.

Pay the resting giants a visit!. I loved it, and would probably have listened to and enjoyed the audioguide if we hadn't brought the children. They were 8 and 12 at the time and since we are from Sweden, they had not yet heard of all the history and famous people connected with the WA.Its both humbling and thrilling that all these monarchs rest there, along with famous scientists and artists.

So much history..... ... More than 1000 years of it. It has more thousands of memorials to kings, queens and other nobles. There is even a poets corner where great literary figures are honored. Great medieval architecture and the gothic ceilings are awesome.

Superlatives only here. This building is unique in every way. The history is quite astounding. From the Monarchs that have been crowned there through to all of the personalities that are interred there. I am a scientist and was very moved when I sat on a step beside Sir Isaac Newton's tomb. There is something for everyone, be it scientific, literary or musical interests that you have. It is a Who's who of famous people over the last 1000 years. The Abbey has a hefty entrance fee but it is a small price to pay for the mother of all history lessons. Coffee shop, toilets and gift shop are all very good.

My Fav place so far. I could have spent hours in here. Its filled with so much history and coming from a relatively new country this was just amazing and beautiful. The self pace tour guides made things simple and allowed me to take my time though this place of royal history.

Founder of YMCA.... Sir George Williams.... Westminster Abbey has a wonderful Stained Glass Window to Honour Sir George Williams, Founder of YMCA, believe it or not, its true, he founded it over 150 years ago, I have researched it.. Also, in Russell Square there is a plaque with his name on... Well worth visiting for historic reasons...

Centuries of Religion. Just think, this Abbey was standing and used for worship centuries before America was discovered. The tombs of the famous are amazing, but perhaps clearer notices of who the tombs are for might help, not everyone speaks ancient Latin or medieval frenchJust be aware that the queues can be long

Incredible architecture. Not being religious, I didn't have much vested interest in going to see Westminster Abbey. I wanted to see it for it's architecture and history more than anything. They offer digital audio guides included in the admission price, but I decided to forgo that option, and just let my eyes soak in everything around me. The only downfall of the entire thing was the fact the line for admittance was incredible long, but it also was a Saturday that we were there. No fault of the church at all.It's worth seeing at least once.

Glorious. Go early, be prepared to wallow in centuries of YOUR history. It's an incredible place. Be sure to go into every nook and cranny, you won't be disappointed. The gift shop is also well worth the visit.
Probably fantastic but the odd opening hours were frustrating.. Can't really rate this attraction but do be mindful of the odd opening hours and expect the unexpected.

Fascinating. We are not really church touring types, but this is really worth a visit and the audio guide is well done. The crowd moves quickly, and were respectful for the most part. And you can see Darwin and Newton's tomb. It was a lovely way to spend the afternoon. Oh, and the staff were pleasant and helpful in re-directing us when we went looking for Newton's tomb.

Simply Beautiful. Pictures do not do this icon justice. The whole setting is perfect. Sitting right on the Thames with Westminster Cathedral and Big Ben adjoining it it is a must see while in London. The history just oozes through this whole area as you are transported to Royal Times in merry ole England!
pricey. I loved Westminster Abbey but it is very expensive! The crypt was amazing!!! But It's not at the top of my "must see" list
Gorgeous inside and out.. Hope to get back to London sometime and take my mom here! Such amazing history here. Listen to the 'stuff you missed in history class' podcast about Westminster Abbey

Stunning church!. My husband and I visited Westminster Abbey recently on a trip to London. It was well worth the admission fee. We took an audio tour and enjoyed learning about the history. (Warning: if you are weirded out by crypts or tombs, this is NOT for you!) It is a stunning church and worth a visit, even if you're in town for a short time.

Incredible to see. Amazing to visit with the history surrounding this monument.Take a tour if you can as you get a better in site in the history of the building.It's a beautifully designed building and very much worth the visit.

Awe-inspiring. This is truly a must-see in London. Buy your ticket ahead of time online so you don't have to wait in the ticket buying line, as this place gets very busy quickly. I cannot describe in words the feeling you get entering this ancient house of worship. It is beautiful and majestic, everything a cathedral should be. I also like and respect the fact they ask everyone to stop for a moment (every hour) for silent prayer or reflection, as this is an active house of worship. Please, go! It will soothe your soul.

A great historical monument. Having paid for my concessionary ticket at the door I was impressed by the sheer size and grandeur of the location as well as the historical significance of the place. As well as containing the numerous memorials to the great figures of British history this is the final resting place of many sovereigns and other great figures. The wonderfully dignified setting of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier is moving as is the small but beautifully designed RAF Chapel. The construction of the Abbey - especially the vaulted ceilings and flying buttresses - is a subject worthy of study in its own right. A visit to this site can be cherished as a truly treasured memory.

Westminister Abbey...Your Soul will be refreshed After a visit inside !. The Abbey (WA) --- what more is to be said about such an ICON of London ? IF you know anything about English history, this is a must see site. Consider looking at this SANCTUARY from its religious origins. Take time to read about its history (as you will be in a very important neighborhood of London). So why consider the RELIGOUS origins of the Abbey ? Because even TODAY there are services conducted by the Church of England, here. Bases upon my multiple personal visits, I recommend you plan your trip so that you spend an hour that overlaps during a weekday Choral Evensong OR a Sunday Choral Worship service. These traditions of the Anglican communion are visible now CENTURIES, later and practiced in a way that brings glory to God. This is NOT a review to suggest changing whatever your religious beliefs might be --- but just listening to the choral music of English masters will refresh your soul...Remember: WA is still used for official events, so plan ahead if you are from out of town to not be disappointed if it is closed for such official events. Afterwards, Pop into the Abbey's bookstore-----appropriately priced and NICE things for sale!

I Was in Awe. I was honestly in awe the minute I entered the building and my mouth gaped for at least the first 20 minutes. It was beyond belief. The combination of history and tradition and art and reverence all at once was overwhelming. Every single inch of this place is ornately decorated, detailed, and meaningful. To stand in the middle of it and remember and recognize recent history...Princess Diana's funeral, Kate and William's wedding, and even the footage of Elizabeth's coronation...awestruck. The staff here were also wonderful. And the audio guide tour was well done. I really didn't even want to leave. Some practicalities...we went soon after they opened for the day during the week, and there were no lines or crowds. There was plenty of room for everyone inside to move about and see what they wanted to see. Be sure to go outside and see the cloisters and the gardens as well if they are open when you are there.

Awesome to behold!. It is a dream Cathedral packed to the rafters with so many of the dead. The audio tour accompaniment is more than adequate. You cannot take pictures inside! You will find things here that you will never see the likes of anywhere else. Its an outstanding and beautiful place! Don't miss this....

A Must See. Westminster Abbey is one of the imperative places to visit in London. Yes, it is costlyto get in (GBP 20 p.p.), but it is worth it. Burial site of so many Royals. Wedding siteand Coronation site of even more Royals. Magnificent place to walk around and geta sense of British history & greatness.
Westminster with Friends. Great to see Westminster Abbey again and to share with our friends who had never been to England. Always drawn to the tomb of one of sciences greatest - Sir Isaac Newton.

BEAUTIFUL FASCINATING. NOT TO BE MISSED. This was our third visit to London and something keeps drawing us back to Westminster Abbey. This time we signed up for a tour with London Walks and we learned so much more about the church, it's history and traditions as well as the people who are buried and memorialized there. It is a wonderful experience just being there.Add this too your to do list in london

Wonderful history under a single roof. Went there recently, because we hadn't been there in several years. A busy Saturday a.m., but the line to get in moved quickly. The price to get in has gone up a bit - £34 for two seniors - but worth the cost of admission. Can't say enough about the history that is found inside, everything from Queen Elizabeth I's grave - lying on top of Mary Queen of Scott's in the same crypt - to those of the monks that died in the plague in the 14th century. You walk over their gravestone while walking over some of the passageways. The docents who are to be found everywhere clad in their long robes are great, friendly and able to add a bit extra to your experience if you have any questions. Overall a "must see" if you have never been.

Highlight of my trip. This was the highlight of my two days in London. I loved the history and beauty here. Worth every penny! So many famous historians buried here and if not, their names are mentioned and referred to. Felt history come alive. Well worth the visit.

Tip for avoiding high-priced ticket. Westminster Abbey is beautiful, but it's EXPENSIVE! ($30 USD/person when I was there) A way to avoid the high ticket price... attend one of the free evensongs. They're offered pretty much every day. If you get there early they have you line up inside the abbey, so you can look around. You obviously can't explore the various chapels or use the audio guide, but you'll at least get to these the inside. As a side note, the evensong itself is just eh. I recommend the evensong at St. Paul's much more highly.

Not to be missed!. Years ago, entering the Abbey, either to visit or to pray, was free. Now, to get into it (and St. Paul's) you have to pay--which is offensive to me. One shouldn't have to pay to get inside God's house .But you do and, frankly, it's worth the price FOR ONE VISIT. Just wandering around Poet's Corner and even going down to the vaults (a must), the Abbey leaves a lasting impression on you. If you don't want to pay to go inside God's house, feel free to wander around the outside (and don't forget to visit the gift shop--it's free to enter!).

In Awe!!. This abbey will give you a sense of history like few other places in London. The architecture, along with a who's who of famous people buried here simply is overwhelming. It's crowded, but then again who can blame the thousands of people who pass through here every day, so wanting to experience this magnificent place

Awestruck. This is by far the most interesting and awesome attraction in London. Walk amongst the tombs of kings and queens past, spectacular architecture. Stand ad contemplate the tomb of the unknown soldier. We walked around the well organised and audio accompanied tour in total awe at the splendour and history that fills this special place....A must for all London visitors......
Great Historical Site. Loved this visit. So much history and your entry gets you an audio which is easy to use and full of great information. Would advise that you go early as it does get crowded.
Top 3 site to visit. Beautiful very informative at your own pace with the audio guide - which was very clear and easy to use - not to be missed !
Historical. An amazing, beautiful structure with tons of history. It is very interesting to read the stones of past kings and queens, poets and statesmen buried throughout the abbey.

Best London historical site. I've dreamed of seeing Westminster Abbey, and not because Kate and William were married there! We arrived too late for the guided tour, but attended an Evensong service. It was primarily music which lasted an hour and we were seated between the "quire" (choir) and the alter- where the Queen sat for the royal wedding.It was amazing enough to attend that, but I returned for the self-guided audio tour which included the crypts behind the alter (lots to see!) including QE I, Mary Queen of Scots, etc. Incredible history. Next time I will take tour led by tour guide because I'm a history buff.

Must See When Visiting London. Westminster Abbey is a large, mainly Gothic church in the City of Westminster. It is over 700 years old and is located in central London, in close proximity to Big Ben and The Thames River. It is one of the most notable religious buildings in England and has been the traditional place of coronation and burial site for English and, now, British monarchs. The building is no longer an abbey or a cathedral, having instead the status of a 'Royal Peculiar' – a church responsible directly to the Sovereign.Daily worship services are held at Westminster Abbey. Services are open to the public. The abbey is open to tour on most days from 9:30 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Self-guided tour tickets are 20 pounds per adult, this includes an audio guide. The history that Westminster Abbey holds is engrossing and the architecture is quite spectacular. Of particular interest are the Cloisters, Lady Chapel, High Altar, the beautiful stained glass windows, the choir, and the Poets Corner. No pictures are allowed inside, but we were able to capture the beauty of open areas and the architectural majesty. It takes several hours to appreciate the abbey. Expensive, but time and money well spent.

Can't be Missed !!. If you are in Great Britain you must visit London. When you are in London you must visit Westminster Abbey as a one-stop-shop to get a perspective on the country's history. A little reading prior to the visit, the audio guide and an EARLY start make for a great experience. Wander around and look up, down and don'[t be in a rush. Do not miss it!

No wonder it's jam packed!. Fascinating visit - so much history, so much detail. Your mind is blown away. The hordes of visitors visiting at the same time as us certainly took some of the pleasure away, but I guess it's the same the whole world over.

Westminster Abbey. It is expensive. But as you walk inside and follow the audio guide (included in price!) you get to admire the beauty and the history of the place and appreciate it. It was the only attraction with an audio guide included in the ticket and that is a plus! Took us about 1 1/2 hour to complete the tour.

Definitely Worth a Visit. Westminster Abbey is spectacular. Definitely do the tour with the audio guide as it is very fascinating. Not only is it a major church, but it is a museum and a burial place for kings and queens and other famous individuals.
westminster abbey. interesting place the tiles on the floor are well worth a look lot of stairs in tower bit, sometimes enactment people their, check on info site

Breathtaking. The outside of the Abbey is stunning but the interior is breathtaking. If you love history this is a dream destination. We had a guided tour with blue badge guide Conrad who was so knowledgeable about the Abbey happy to answer any questions and made our trip a real joy. If you are in London this is one place you really shouldn't miss.
So worthwhile!. Sure its pricey...i about 18 pound...but its full of do much history and beauty. The audio guide (included in admission price) wasreally good too

History immerses you here. Well organised access, but get there early to avoid queues in good weather. However once you're in it's an easy one ribbon walking tour. Use the audio device to get the most out of it.The exterior was astounding detailed architecture, well preserved. Inside it's a mixture of a Middle Ages cathedral, Coronation venue and mausoleum. British history and it's most significant people are there.This is an absolute MUST for a London visit.Use the London Card for best $ value.

Must see in London. Westminster Abbey is awe inspiring in many ways. From the historical significance to the architectural grandeur and beauty it is a must see in London. Get there early or get "skip the line" passes as the wait can be long otherwise.

Impressive with amazing history. My partner and I did Westminster as part of the London Pass. We skipped the line and went straight through. We were greeted by lovely staff and given an audio guide and map. The inside is breath taking to say the least. My partner originally had no interest in visiting, however he has no rated this as his highlight on his 5week trip of Europe! We were amazed by the architecture and the history and were surprised at the people who are buried there. This is a must do!

Excellent for History buffs. Westminster Abbey is just swimming in history, so it's kind of a must-see for anybody who is really fascinated by that sort of the thing. The Abbey itself is impressive and beautiful, but the real intrigue comes from all the kings and queens who are buried there. To walk past the tomb of Queen Elizabeth or Victoria is just incredible, or to walk past those of Kings from 700 years ago is amazing. The fact that coronations, royal weddings and funerals have taken place here is also quite awe-inspiring. The entry fee can seem steep, but it's reasonable for the sheer sense of history in the place. If you're on a budget but you love history, come here. If you just want impressive churches, maybe head over to St Paul's. Ideally, see both!
A must do in London. This is a must do in London, take your time, get there early or get your ticket in advance. Well spend time.

Breathtaking. My goodness, this place is impressive! Yes, it costs a fee to get in, but that fee includes an excellent audio guide and access to as many places as are open at that time. Plus – come on, people. The abbey doesn’t get any funding from anyone but the visitors (which I find confusing), so all the restoration and upkeep is paid for by you!The only thing that made me sad is that pictures are not allowed within the Abbey. I understand it, I think, but it would have been nice to be able to have pictures of some of the plaques within Poet’s Corner, or some of the awesome stained-glass windows dotting the walls. I gladly would have paid a “photo pass” fee to have that privilege.We were both immediately struck not only by the architecture – soaring ceilings, marble and granite and gilt covering almost everything, intricate carvings everywhere you looked – but by the history as well. Yes, it’s a theme that I keep coming back to – so much history! Tombs for kings and queens, memorials for poets and artists and musicians, paintings that were created 700 years ago, floors that are just as old, stain glass windows that partially survived the years and WWII, it just didn’t end. Every nook held a piece of London’s history. Every room had a story. And most things were displayed in an easy-to-understand-and-follow kind of way.The Abbey does tend to get crowded, so I would recommend going early, if at all possible. We got there about half an hour after they opened their doors, and it was just starting to get stifling. By the time we left, the crowd index was insanely high.I love that you’re allowed to walk at your pace, and to take your time in viewing all the history surrounding you. It’s amazing to me the things they have on display – that they were recovered, that they’re in such fine condition, that they leave them within touching distance of some of the more oblivious tourists…I’d say it took us about two and a half hours to get through everything, what with the audio tour and fighting the crowds. There were a few things closed that day – the gardens and the little cloister, to be specific – but there’s still plenty to see.

Westminster Abbey. Just outside the Westminster station is the London parliament building along with the Big Ben on the banks of the River Thames. The best time to visit the place is during Christmas when the entire building is lighted up. The best view of the Parliament building can he had from the London eye.

Stunning!. Not to be missed if you're visiting London and absolutely gorgeous architecture and so very rich in culture and history. From here you are paces from Big Ben, The Houses of Parliament, Westminster Bridge, The Thames, St James' Park and Dowing Street, Whitehall etc. and all eminently doable on foot. Go see!

Beautiful church. Beautiful church with lots of great history. Very restricted hours so plan accordingly to visit inside. The outside is quite stunning, so even if you can't make it in, it's worth to visit the outside.

Westminster, must see in London. Westminster is wonderful, so many interesting facts, you can find the tomb of Elisabeth I and Shakespeare, besides the other famous people from England. Enjoy a slow visit, with all the time to read each information on the tomb, you may be surprised. After the visit, stop by the cafeteria/restaurant in the Abbey for a tea or lunch with wine.
Must-do Tour. Buy your ticket on line before going and skip the line. The inside of the Abbey is a must see. So much history. Helpful and knowledgeable staff. Free audio guides with your ticket.

What an amazing place!. Loved all the history. Got goosebumps seeing where royal coronation and weddings have taken place. Burial site of numerous royalty and other VIP persons behind the altar, it goes back another mile!
Beautiful Church and Tombs. How beautiful to tour through this church were English royalty was married were entombed. This church is like no other......No picture taking allowed

Resting Place of Great People. I never fail to be moved by the beautiful monuments within this incredible church. But on this visit, we took more time, and set our own pace.By the time we had seen the museum and Chapter House (and I can still recall walking in felt booties on the medieval tiles), we needed the "refectory." Quite a charming little restaurant.Also, I was pleased to find British and European goods for sale in the gift shop....

Great for families!. We visited Westminster Abbey with three kids ages 6, 9 and 10. The scavenger hunt and reward at the end were WONDERFUL for the children. We had a great time exploring this beautiful abbey. A highlight for us was the Coronation Chair.

Lots to see. I'm the heart of London this wonderful building houses the tombs of so many historical figuresIt's best to go early in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the crowdsI had an audio tour but another time I would go on a guided tour to make the most of the visit
Living history. Beautiful abbey maintained to high standards. Has immense historic importance and continues to host key royal events.

A walk back through time. A must, must, must see. So much history, so many famous people buried there, a wonderful audio tour to bring it all together AND a special treasure hunt for children, this Abbey is well worth the visit. The tour will only take 1-2 hours (get tickets early or online) but will give you so much information. The list of monarchs, scientists, writers and composers et al buried there is a veritable 'who's who' of western civilization.

Whether whisking around in a couple of hours, or lingering for full effect this is a fantastic venue.. It's not the cheapest venue in London but if you take your time and look at all the history on display it provides an experience that is both rich and fulfilling taking the visitor through over 1000 years of British history , and the excellent audio tour is included in the price. The Abbey has manywell-known spots, you can tell these because the bulk of your fellow visitors will congregate there, but there are areas in which fewer visitors linger which have plenty to offer. I found that some of the side chapels, especially in the older part of the Abbey were very atmospheric and bore the marks of previous users over the millennia. The Chapter House and Museum are some other less popular areas of note, the former having some of the finest and ancient of carvings and paintings in English history and the latter as well as being in one of the oldest parts of the Abbey has a fascinating display of items from royal funerals. I love this place, and whilst you can do the visit in around 90 minutes would recommend that you slow down and value the sense of history and occasion the Abbey offers

You should not miss this. The Abbey contains the graves of a multitude of famous people, including Charles Darwin, Issac Newton, and more kings and queens than I could count. There is an area known as poets corner with many names that you will recognize. It will take a couple hours to tour this site, and I think the audio guide is indispensable. We had a meal in the restaurant, it was very busy, but the food was tasty, reasonably priced and there were many items to choose from.They have the royal coronation chair here. Fortunately, we visited before the summer tourist season was underway, and we had the London Pass, so we avoided any lines at the front gate and walked right up to the ticket desk through a separate entrance. It was busy, but not crowded.

The Abbey. I did not do a tour. It was late and we were walking past the Abbey and I was talking to my daughter saying it was a pity we missed the Abbey. The Priest standing at the gate overheard me and he invited us in to a mass. It was beautiful with a full choir and the tears just rolled. I loved it! Thanks you so much - what an atmosphere.

Please be respectful and trying not to walk on the tombs. This is an amazing church with so much history and so much to see... however both my mother an I were a little weirded out by the fact that we walking on the graves of those would had passed. It felt so disrespectful to walk on those grave and in some cases the writing engraved into the tombstone had been worn down due to millions walking over it. It sad because history was literally fading under our feet. Other than that amazing museum

Impressive. Perhaps you must wait long to get in, but once you're in, you can enjoy the immensity of the cathedral, you can reliving the history, see where Kate and William were married, where the queen has been crowned, listen to the explanation from the audio tour of this historic awe-inspiring place of worship. When you go on tues-, wednes- or thursday, you can also visit the college garden where you can find blissful tranquility.

Very unchristian. Had access to the Chancery through English Heritage but was told this would not give us access to the Abbey itself. Not a problem as had been before. Unfortunately twice whilst looking for the exit we opened a door leading into the Abbey and were treated as criminals for trying to enter. The second time my husband, who is slightly deaf, didn't hear the yelled instructions to go back and I thought they were going to rugby tackle him to get him out. We are used to going to Christian churches around the world and to Buddhist temples where we have been made to feel welcome but our experience at Westminster Abbey made us understand why churches in Britain are emptying.

History surrounds you!. So much history in one place. Every footstep has a story beneath, above or beside it. I was completely taken by the magnitude of what this building encompassed. I dont think you will ever see this level of craftmanship ever again. You will need most of the day to really absorb the history and stories Westminster contains. I will visit again.

Fantastic ABBY!. so far Westminster Abbey is my favourite. It has not only amazing architecture, stunning stained glass window The ceiling in the Lady Chapel alone is worth the admission.Don't let this Abbey pass you by, stop for a quick look on your walk around London, you wont be disappointed.

The very beautiful Westminster Abbey. We did the self guided tour with the info-phone....you press a button corresponding the the exhibit your looking at and you get a small bit of info.The Abbey is spectacular in structure and steeped in history...so many things to list including the tomb of Mary queen of Scots, Elizabeth I,poets corner the grave of the unknown soldier and of course...the Coronation Chair.The layout of the Abbey self tour is so well structured and organised so as not to miss anything at all.Of all the things you choose to " leave til your next visit" don't let this be it...this is a most beautiful place and so worth the entrance fee.

Paying my respects to Sir Isaac newton and Charles Darwin. Westminster Abbey is a recommended place to visit while you're having trip in London. This is a church, which has been standing for almost one-thousand years. It has great Gothic architecture and interior design. I visited this place on August 2014, and the queue line to enter the church was really long due to the summer vacation period. The regular admission fee to enter the church is quite pricey (£ 20.00 !). Fortunately, I am still a (graduate) student, so at that time I presented my student card and got £ 3.00 discount (luckily). When I entered, there were some people who offered free audio guide, which was very useful to learn the history of this church if you travel alone without any tour guide.My sole intention to visit this place was to pay my respects to my most favorite scientist of all time: Sir Isaac Newton (I am definitely a nerd), who was buried here few century ago. I became aware of his burial place from a famous passage in "The Da Vinci Code": "In London lies a knight a Pope interredHis labour's fruit a Holy wrath incurredYou seek the orb that ought be on his tombIt speaks of Rosy flesh and seeded womb "I later found out that there were many famous British scientists buried here as well, i.e. Charles Darwin, Sir. J.J. Thomson, Ernest Rutherford, and also memorials dedicated to many famous British scientists who was buried elsewhere, i.e. Lord kelvin (William Thompson), Paul A.M. Dirac, Michael Faraday, James Clerk Maxwell, James Prescott Joule. However, since this is basically a church, taking photographs are not allowed. I didn't aware of that in the beginning, and I took some pictures inside the church. Later some security personnel approached and told me that I should stop taking pictures. They explained that since Westminster Abbey is basically a church, so taking pictures (with generates sound and flash) may disturb other visitors experience who may come to Abbey for worshiping purpose. So, please be aware of this situation before you buy the admission ticket. For me, I may say that the experience inside the Abbey is worth the admission fee.

Absolute Must when visiting London. So much History in one place! The ceiling in the Lady Chapel alone is worth the admission. We decided to take the self guided tour, and it was wonderful! This Gothic abbey is the symbol of everything Britain has stood for and stands for, where most of its rulers were crowned and where many lie buried.The Tomb of feuding half-sisters , ironically buried in the same tomb, Catholic Mary I and Protestant Elizabeth I, was my favorite. You can also see the Shrine of Edward the Confessor, and the Coronation chair. Let's not forget the Poets corner.

A Must see in London. One of my favorite places to see while in London was Westminster Abbey. This was my 2nd visit (other in 2009). If you love history and tradition and beautiful architecture take time to see this in London- give yourself 2-3 hours if you love to read everything. Get the audio tour

Fantastic.. This abbey is so steeped in history that I hardly know where to start. It contains the tomb of England's sainted king, Edward the Confessor. Henry v, of Agincourt fame is there along with Edwards I and III, Richard II, Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots, and so many more royal personages. Alongside all of these are magnificent tombs to the rich and famous of former times, many with effigies or other memorial statuary. Then there's the coronation chair, the wonderful Cosmati mosaic floor, the tomb of the unknown soldier and the magnificent vaulted ceiling. The 10' tall Waterford glass chandeliers look only a fraction of their true size when viewed against that vast Gothic height. Poet's corner boasts memorials to all the great names of English literature, though not all are actually buried there. Geoffrey Chaucer is and his monument was the first in that area of the abbey.This only touches the surface of what's to see at Westminster Abbey. Give yourself plenty of time, and for a really magical experience wait on for Evensong. Also, I took the verger's tour which casts an extra £5. Well worth the money.

Loved it, and the audio tour.. Just look up. WOW. There is so much history here. Where to begin.Okay, so the line was REALLY long, but it moved at a good clip and we waited only about 20min on a dreary Saturday around noon. Bags searched, tickets purchased and audio tour phones retrieved in short order. I was worried that there would be no room to see anything with the volume of people in here. I was wrong. In addition, there were many placed to sit and rest between stops if you wanted. The details of the audio tour made this visit for me. I learned so much, I started to question the sanity of the ruling class of this country. Sheesh!The rest room situation is a little odd. There are maybe 5 or 6 water closets out back with one attendant making sure everyone stays in line. There is no men's room or ladies room. They are all for both, so it truly is first come first relieved. Again, the line move quick enough, and the attendant seemed to be paying attention enough to resupply as needed. While the set-up is different, it works. As long as guys remember to lift the seat. Ladies shouldn't have to put up with men. There are no photos in the Abbey at all. A teen took one and one of the ushers came over and verbally lit him up. She shamed him so much I thought he might cry. They didn't toss him out, but she threatened to, and even threatened to toss out his whole family as well. My son jokingly said that you CAN take photos, but only one!You need to visit.
History at it best. I watched the wedding of Prince William and Kate on TV and it never crossed my mind that I would have visited this church. An incredible architecture, especially the details.
Church. Amazing services held here. I found that the church service was quick which was a relief for a historical church, probably around 35-40 minutes.

Monument to the history of Briatain. I have visited London on countless occasions and finally managed to visit the Abbey. We were down for a weekend break and the highlight was a visit here. Everything, with the exception of poets corner, is over the top with opulence and I suppose that is the point. The great of Britain's history are here, so their monuments have to reflect that. It's an amazing place, the sense of history almost overwhelms you.

astonishing historical architecture. the 18 pounds entrance was quite expensive but it was all worth it in the end. and since photography was not allowed, we had more time appreciating this historical masterpiece. our favorite was the back site which looked like a cappella.

Magnificent church and a very large cemetery. The church is mammoth and beautiful. Actually, I would call it cavernous! It is where the Royals marry and many are buried here; in addition to poets, authors and anyone famous in history. There are so many grave stones in the floor, in private areas etc that I thought it a bit unnerving. You can view the area where the coronations take place and the chair that is used. The Abbey was begun in 1245 by Henry III and because it was used for coronations, it survived Henry VIII's onslaught on Britain's monastery like buildings.
Loved it. Saw so much, the history is just incredible but we would have like to have been able to take pictures.

All the great and the good are here.. To see the resting place of the kings and queens of England and the memorials of so many famous people is amazing. The architecture is magnificent and the history fascinating. As you enter you are given an audio guide which is excellent. For me the highlight of the abbey is the stunning Lady Chapel with the tombs of Elizabeth I, Bloody Mary, Mary Queen of the Scots and Henry VII. The staff are really good, full of information and willing to show you things you might have missedI wish I could give the abbey 5/5 but some the chapels were a bit dark and dingy and it is a pity that St Edward's chapel with the tombs of Edward the Confessor, Richard II, Henry V and other kings cannot be viewed.

Only rating a 3...are you surprised. I looked forward to my visit of this famous institution used by the Royal family for many solemn and stately occasions.As I approached the Abbey itself, the architecture was a statement to the genius of man. Following the signs to the visitors' entrance I was greeted at the entrance by a hot dog stand (?!) and a large sign that said it would cost me almost $30 Cdn to get inside.I was taken aback by the commercialization of something that should be accessible to anyone! And yes, I am keenly aware of the challenges to these institutions with today's high costs. So, that being said, I can only give it an average rating!

Enjoyable and breathtaking. One of the best self guides in London. I enjoyed every bit of it, being able to understand England's rich history, able to see the coronation area etc.And also lots of tombs here, kings and queens etc. Helpful staff, we had to feed our child (he was hungry) and food were not allowed in the area. They offered us a small private chapel for us to feed our son, which was generous.

British great people sleep here.. Great people whom Churchill, Princess Diana, anyone know sleep here.
So that they watch British people from here‼️

Must do the Audio Tour!. What an amazing place for family of all ages, who love the self guided audio tour. Plenty of staff to pleasantly answer any questions. Must do for everyone who loves the history of kings, queens, writers, etc.

Amazing. as a family we have wanted to visit the Abbey for some time, and on a previous visit to London, had been helpfully informed by staff at the Abbey to allow plenty of time to see everything.So we arrived before lunch on a Saturday and whilst there was a short wait to get in there was no issues.The price for 3 of us was fair, and the feee audio guide was excellent.You are guided around listening to commentary, and there is plenty of Abbey staff to help answer questions. Everyone we spoke to was very knowledgeable and friendly, and seemed to have their own favourite bit to talk about.There is so much history in one building, you could easily spend a few hours wandering around.There was lots of people visiting at the same time, but we didn't feel rushed, or pushed etc at any point.Don't miss the cloisters area, and the oldest door in England, and of course the Coronation Chair.
It´s like a dream. It´s in good conservation and very big, when I saw on TV I thought is a little abbey but really amazing place, make difference between others that I´ve already visited.
Lovely. Didnt go inside due to time limitations, but another breathtaking part of London which is a must see.

History comes alive. This place is very special in many ways. Aside from its major religious significance, it is incredible the see the tombs of all the historical figures on this site. You also can almost picture the coronations, weddings, funerals of major historical figures and royals.This is a must see attraction.

Excellent. We visited the abbey as a family of 4 2 adults,2 kids.There is so much interest in this building, you can easily whittle away hours.the kids aged 10 and 8 were very interested to.this was top value for money in my opinion, unlike other London attraction...London eye / dungeons etc.Superb...would recommend and revisit if in London.

Coronation Church since 1066. In 960 Benedictine monks settled on this site and since 1066 has been the Coronation church and 17 monarchs are buried here.There is no charge for entry for services -if you want to look around this amazing building then it's £20 adult /£17 concession/ Child (6-16) £9.We easily spent nearly four hours here -we took the guided tour which cost an extra £5.00 -or you can take the free audio guide (or both )The abbey has been the scene of funerals - to name just a few - Edward VI 1553 - Henry V 1442 - Elizabeth I 1603 - Victoria 1901 . The scene of weddings - Elizabeth II 1947-Prince William 2011 and Princess Anne 1973 even as far back as Henry I who was married in the abbey in November 1100.The abbey has also been the scene for Coronations.Most memorable for us was the Lady Chapel, the Tombs, Poet's Corner -in fact everything !!The abbey is not available on the 2-4-1 National Railway Deal -but is still worth the cost of the admission

Just Wonderful. I am sure there are millions of reviews of Westminster Abbey - so all I want to say is that although it is expensive it is truly worth a visit.So much history in one place and such a beautiful building - everyone should visit it at least once.Just wonderful.

One of the "must do" of London, but pricey and crowded. Westminster Abbey is a unique collection of history. Not only is the building itself historic, having been the site of many royal coronations and weddings, but it has become a tribute and monument to some of the most influential (and in some cases controversial) people in English history. You can't turn a corner and not bump into a name that comes straight out of your history book. Memorials and/or graves of Newton? Darwin? Chaucer? Kings and queens? Check, check, check, and check. Add to that the splendid beauty of the cathedral and it is no wonder why this site is so popular and a "must do" for visitors. But with the popularity comes some problems. The queue and crowds were crazy, with lots of pushing and shoving through the many tight spaces throughout the building. Over the years the constant stream of visitors have also caused deterioration of many of the monuments and statues inside. This damage goes back hundreds of years, and adds a layer of... charm? history? not sure what to call it, but even the coronation chair has been heavily abused over the years, but it still gets called into service, engravings of childhood initials included! But that's part of Westminster. That's history. A few things to note about your visit. Expect crowds, and there are lots of tight spaces. So be prepared. Also download the tour app for your phone (it is free) and use headphones to carve off some personal "space". I used noise cancelling headphones and it really helped isolate my experience, even though I was in the middle of a sea of people. Visit the undercroft as well - it is included in the tour and has some interesting relics as well. Minus one star because of the 20 pound entry fee. Ouch!

Beautiful building but no pictures. We really enjoyed our trip to the Abby but we're disappointed that you cannot take pictures. We have elderly family that are unable to travel and I would have loved to have shared pictures of the experience with them. The admission price allows you a free audio tour that was very informative and helped to guide your time at the Abby. The building is beautiful and it was awesome to see all of the history inside.

A walk through history. A very interesting and informative walk through the Abbey helped by the audio guides provided on entry. The building was a wonder to observe, the roof and monuments were fantastic and steeped in history. Now when something is televised from there I can relate to it much better.

A time for quiet introspection, in awe of the Abbey. History is preserved to perfection in the Abbey. The kids enjoyed navigating at their own pace with the help of the audio guide. I enjoyed the time for quiet introspection, peace and appreciation.

Wow.... What an amazing... i have been here many, many times over the years, and i will still keep going... its an amazing Abbey with so much history.... it's a must for everyone...... while in there, just take a moment to look around... and look at all the beautiful things that this Abbey has...

Majestic. Walking into Westminster Abbey is a dream now fulfilled. The gothic design of this grand old dame of London sets it apart, in a league of its own. £20 is a small price to pay considering the Abbey receives no funding from church, state or crown. The work they do is a testament. The most beautiful building I've seen in my life.

Classic London tourist stop. Like Notre Dame in Paris it's one of the classic European cathedrals that you have to go to. Kind of pricey for what it is but you do get a free and very informative audio tour.

Excellent History Experience. We got here a little after opening and wasn't too much of a line. I didn't realize that there was a separate entrance for London Pass holders until we were in but since there wasn't a line that was ok. We were on a wait list for the abbey led tours that only allow 20 people. HIGHLY recommend you do that as only a select few people get to go into the old St. Edwards chapel and this is how you get in. It was worth the 5 pounds/person cost. We ended up doing the tour and then leaving because you could get in later the same day and it was getting crowded. That was a smart move because when we got there later in the afternoon it was after the school groups had left. Much calmer to visit and see things. We visited during lent so they were doing prayer every hour (not sure if that is year round). I just wish we could have taken photos inside the abbey but totally understand the reluctance to do that.

Fantastic Interior Art and Historical Abbey. We spent good 3hours in this wonderful church, the audio tour system provided as part of the entrance ticket was so helpful to learn about the Abbey history and the historical events seen at the church including the marriage of Prince Charles. It was amazing experience to walk around the varies chapels while enjoying the audio commentary.

The history is unbelieveable. If you have the chance to go on a rainy weekday morning in December you will have one of the greatest experiences. I went on a day when I was virtually alone and it was magical. I spent hours really looking at everything and felt that I had experienced something private and precious. My advise is look up! So many lovely vistas. I

Use the credit card entrance if you don't already have a ticket!. We walked up to the abbey to see a huge line. There was another entrance next to the main entrance with a man standing by it. I overheard him tell someone else it was for credit cards and people who already had tickets. We went right in and paid with a credit card. The other line easily had 50 people in it. It was about 20 pounds for adults and 10 for children. My teenager actually liked seeing the abbey and found all the tombs and garden interesting. A beautiful attraction and functioning church. I'm sure the services and organ and choir practices would be amazing. There are guided and self tours available. Everyone enjoyed the visit.

Beautiful! But very busy. . What a gorgeous landmark. Inside and out! The detail in architecture is stunning, The glass work is beautiful, and of course it is rich with history. The only downside is that everyone insists on having an audio guide so if you opt out and want to take your time taking in the sites you'll be jostled along with the droning sound of multiple electronic languages while everyone pushes along to the next "number". Also, if you plan to visit do keep in mind this is still a place of worship, and if they ask you to be still and observe a moment of silence, do it. Put the audio on pause and respect the customs. Also, if you must entertain your children with electronic devices such as phones or handheld games be courteous and turn the volume off. If it weren't for the disrespectful and over abundant tourists this would be a six star attraction! Gorgeous!

Wow what an Abbey. This Church was more spectacular than expected. It was loaded with old artifacts, effigies, etc. The audio guide was not easy to use or follow and the walkways were poorly marked. But still an amazing building and work of art.

Blue Badge guides are the best. We were a big group of students and faculty and undertook the Abbey tour with Blue Badge guide Paul. Paul added wit and was enthusiastic about the tour around Abbey. History came alive with him. His knowledge and eagerness was infectious and we enjoyed every minute with him. Particularly impressive is the fan vaulting and timber work in the choir stalls. It would be helpful for all to brush up on History of England before heading for the Abbey for a lot of facts and information to fall in place. Be prepared for a fair bit of walking around.

Excellent Walk Through History. This is a very popular spot. There appears to be 2 lines that move into the abbey. When you get there it is a walk through a covered cemetery. There are some famous folks buried there like Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin. They have a free audio guide to guide you. It is a very ornate place with great architecture and stained glass. You would do well to arrive early. The London Pass does not get you in any quicker... the quae is ticket purchase and entry. Recommend at least 90 min inside.

History and Grandeur. I went to the 7am prayer meeting. It was a small affair and it consisted of the Church of England responsive reading. On the way out I lingered a bit to see all the history and grandeur of the Abby, but I didn't linger too long because the doorman had been adamant that to linger and browse I had to come back at 9am and buy a ticket. Still, It was well worth seeing either as a worshipper or as a tourist.

Great church . I come from Rome so every time I go and visit a church I tend to make a paragon with St Peter Church which I consider one of the most beautiful place for worship in there World. Westminster may not be at the same level St Peter is but still it is a great place to visit and one which make you feel the History. Everything is so well kept, the monuments so magnificent that you almost lose the sense of time while you are inside this church.
