I would recommend to allow at least one full hour inside the church and to actively use the guide which is provided at the beginning of the tour. Everyone wishing to see Westminster must be aware that the queueing time can be overwhelming but the wait is really worth it. the cost is at around 18 pounds

Do The Verger Tour!. We booked a day in advance to do the verger led tour in March. Our guide was Benjamin and he was incredible. Benjamin's knowledge, wit, and charisma made seeing Westminster Abbey even better. Seeing where QE2 sits ( and touching the pillow) was just cool. So much history (coronations, weddings, funerals)...Westminster is a "must do" while in London. Book that verger tour!!!!

This is one pilgrimage not to be missed in London. This awe-inspiring structure is just one of these wonders in London that no one should ever miss. Not only is the architecture superb, the history and its association with some of the greatest events taken place then and now is simply mind-boggling. Even if the tickets are quite expensive, it is still worth it.
beautiful. A must do though a little expensive as most of London. Don't miss it. And also check out Big Ben and Houses of Parliament nearby.

Beautiful but pricey. Westminister Abbey is breathtaking. Beautiful, ornate, and a step back in time. The information provided on the tour is interesting to all ages. The Lady Chapel is awesome. There are restroom facilities but they are quite cramped and only a few stalls. My one complaint is the cost of admission. With so many cathedrals in Europe, I am surprised that Westminister charges such a high admission price. It is surely worth it once. However I found myself wondering how much it would be if you had a large family. None of the other cathedrals charge such a high rate. If you're in London, of course you must go - just be prepared that your admission is a bit steep (in comparison to other cathedrals).

Submerse yourself in British History. Apart from the architectural splendour of this great building the historical significance is overwhelming. Many great British statesment and women and interned here along with many members of the royal household including Mary Queen of Scotts and others. The magnitude is out-standing. This magnificent Abbey has been the preffered place of marriage for a nimber of the British Royals. It's history is deep and varied.Visit the Abbey museum for an even greater historical experience. There are plenty of staff to assist in your questions. The Abbey also features a eatery and shop. The courtyard is adjacent to the choristers school. A great way to spend a few hours and adjacent to the Houses of Parliament.

Bit Pricey. While Westminster Abbey is definitely something to see, I don't think it was worth paying for the audio tour. It was hard to see everything inside because it was so crowded (even first thing in the morning when I went) and you aren't allowed to take pictures. I felt that I saw more of it watching the royal wedding on TV than I did on the tour. Go take pictures outside, but save your money for something else!

Jaw-Dropping Experience. One of the main reasons I wanted to visit London. There are no words to truly describe how amazing this Gothic church is. If you know anything about European history, you will probably appreciate it more. I was left speechless when I had finished walking through Westminster Abbey. I have visited many churches in Europe and this was by far the best one I have ever been to. Get the audio guide when you arrive and take your time to really 'see' everything.
Wonderful. Interesting and informative in an amazing historical space . The audio guides are excellent as are the tours. I had visited many years ago and was even more impressed this time!

Awesome Place!!!. It was a tiring but worthy exploration of London's historical sites. I just felt that we should have carefully checked the efficient and friendly rail system of London to go to this site esp. in the Westminster Abbey. We walked from Waterloo Station going to Westminster Abbey instead of taking the Westminster Station. But walking from Waterloo Station, we were able to see London Eye, Big Ben and have pictures there before going to Westminster Abbey.Inside the Westminster Abbey, you'll see a lot of interesting pieces of historical facts about UK. The King and Queen, Knights, Saints, Coat of Arms and other amazing medieval stuff. Truly awesome historical place in the London.By the way, don't ever miss to go to Westminster Abbey Shop. Great shop to buy souvenirs.

Expensive and you can't take photos, but the Lady Chapel is stunning.. Firstly, the Lady Chapel is stunning and well worth visiting, but I resent having to pay £20 to visit one of our 'National treasures' - St Paul's is much better value (and they do 2 for 1)! Lots of tombs and memorials, but you are shepherded along and it is busy - I think it is overpriced but I appreciate that the cost of upkeep is staggering. Personally, I would rather pay less for admission and give a donation or spend money in the Abbey Shop.The advertised 'Fast Track' if you buy tickets on-line beforehand does not really work. We ended up queuing for 30mins in the queue along with people paying by credit card (the queue for paying by cash was longer) so don't bother booking ahead, just use your credit card, it's the same queue.I was very disappointed that photography was not allowed. Like most people, I like to take personal photos of what interests me, and then share them with friends and family. How can you show how good somewhere is if you can't show them a photo? Yes, there is the opportunity to buy postcards at the Abbey Shop, but I want my own photo-memories, not someone else's. Please, Westminster Abbey, follow the example of St Pauls and charge visitors for a photo pass (£2, I think) - more revenue for the Abbey and more memories for visitors (and the chance that the photos they take will entice more visitors).Having said all that, the Lady Chapel is truly stunning - wonderful architecture and visually stunning. It is probably worth the admission fee for this on its own.

Are you kidding, no one told me this was this big.. $40.00 each seemed a bit rough but when will I be back? So I took a gamble. This Abbey is amazing and I had no idea how big, how historic and how amazing it is.

Awe Inspiring. I've been to Westminster Abbey twice now, and it's still one of the most amazing things I have ever seen! If you love architecture, history, and art, then this must be a stop if you're visiting London. This cathedral is gorgeous! The stained glass, the ancient architecture, the tombs of famous kings, queens, musicians, artists, authors, prime ministers, etc. are here, and it is awe inspiring to stand in front of these giants in history. Some of these tombs are 800 years old! They provide audio guide that has loads of information for visitors. At the very end of the tour, you even get to see King Edward's Chair; the chair that has been used in every coronation of an English/British monarch since Edward II! This is definitely a 'must see' on any London trip.

The Most Expensive Abbey Built - Probably. As the title suggested, it was a GORGEOUS and HOLY place to visit. We leant tons about the history of England with the visit; was certainly memorable to myself and although I am an athiest, I would recommend this to all of my friends. Enough is said!

History and WEDDINGS!. Famous people are buried here, and it where Kate and William were married. Lots of history here. Next door is St/ Margaret Church too, wich is worth a visit. The Catholic Church is opposite.

Definitely worth a visit. Much hype to visit the venue where william and kate held their wedding but Westminster abbey is much more than that. Lots tombs of the royal and personally love the poets' corner And the RAF chapel to honor their service

Breathtaking. Inside and out the Abbey is absolutely magnificent. Do not pay attention to long lines, as the place is very much worth a visit. It is a good idea to start your London exploration from here.

Just Amazing!. So much history here. So beautiful and amazing. The outside is just as beautiful as the inside. Dont let this Abbey pass you by, stop for a quick look on your walk around London, you wont be disappointed.

A bit of history to start with!. I was visiting London with three first-timers, and we decided to go to the Abbey as none of us had been there before. We had 2for1 attraction vouchers, which was great as full price seemed a bit too much afterwards.The Abbey is nice - full of history, interesting facts from the past, ancient tombs and a very special atmosphere. Audio guide system is good, but unfortunately there was (and probably will always be) some people unable to pay attention to anything else but the magical voice in their ear. A place worth visiting, yes. Would I go there again? No. Make most of it and go there after lunch or full English brekkie, as it will take time to explore everything there is to see. There is a café, but it's well overpriced and their food is quite a disaster.

amazed. This was one of my favorite places. The outside of the Abbey was just beautiful and the inside was even more so! I was so amazed at everything I saw inside and wish I could have taken pictures to remember everything. Price was a little high, but it was well worth it.

History first and foremost. I can remember the first time I visited Westminster Abbey I wasn't sure about it as I felt it was more of a graveyard than a church. On returning, this time I came to terms with the fantastic array of English history that is memorialized in its floors and walls. From the musicians to the poets to the great figures in English public life. How could one not visit the Abbey?

HIghlight of the Trip!. Absolutely amazing. At times it was overwhelming how much to there was to look at in the Abbey. Definitely pick up the audio guide....Jeremy Irons was the narrator. The negative is that it is rather expensive to take the tour, but once you get past that, you will be glad you visited. The tombs ae absolutely amazing. If you like History, pay the admission fee and enjoy....you will be glad you did. This really is a wonder of the world!

Nice to see- no pictures. It is wonderful to see, but in the main church area, you cannot take pictures. It is breathtaking and cool to be in the room where William and Kate got married. Devote an hour.
As beautiful as you would expect. Crowds flock to this lovely abbey and it is apparent why they do. This is a "must see" on your trip.

Plan to visit while in London. This tour is a little expensive, but the history it contains is unbelievable. You can't possible see it all. This monuments and stones are in every nook and cranny. The final resting place of the famous are all here. The audio tour is very complete and is easy to undertand

A must see in London!. This is not just a church, it is also a burial ground for many famous/important people. We did the audio guide and were very glad we did....many interesting facts. We also ate the the cafe here which was good, but a little pricey.

Even Song. We attended the Even Song service and it was so beautiful! My family and I sat in the front row of the Nave and were awed by the boy's choir and pageantry. So much history in one place...you are literally surrounded by the people who shaped England and so much of our world. Attending Even Song was my favorite experience during our trip to London...I will never forget it.

Super value. As part of the 2for 1 deal on the train tickets I decided to use the voucher and I'm so glad I did. There's lot to see and learn especially about Henry V111. Phenomanel site seeing and architecture.

Interesting but pricey. I visited here on a guided London walk today. It was a very interesting and historic place to see. I really enjoy London walks as they are good value for money (especially if you get a two for one offer with the rail card deal) & the guides are all execellent. However I was disappointed with the expensive price to actually get in to see the abbey. There is a lot of British and religious history in the place and there is much to see. But it seems more like a museum than a place of worship. Now I know maintaining a historic place of worship costs money as I work in one but with the millions that visit annually does it really need to charge 20£ and ask for donations? Westminster Cathedral up the road has no entry charges. Neither does Southwark cathedral. Please consider lowering the entry fee. Are there other ways to raise revenue? Concerts? Art events? Exhibitions? I did enjoy the visit but I would be reluctant to become a regular visitor.

wonderful staff, fantastic tour and full of history.. A fantastic site - many monuments and tombs, the latter most interesting ones being from the Tudors, plus the earlier Edward I, Henry III and Henry V. With the tour guide, you get close up to Edward the Confessor's tomb. Many major scientists too - Darwin and Newton included. Would highly recommend the Verger tour , 90 minutes for £5, very informative indeed. My guide was Benjamin, who was excellent - knowledgeable, entertaining and good fun. His presentation was top class, a real credit to the site. Don't overlook the amazing architecture , especially the fan vaulting in the area where Henry VII is buried, and the chapter house with its medieval wall paintings. Yes, an excellent site indeed.
Expensive but worth a visit. At £20 each I did find this venue somewhat expensive, but it was definitely worth a visit for the history and intricate architecture.

My 2nd favorite in London. I've visited a lot of churches and so far Westminster Abbey is my favorite. It has not only amazing architecture, stunning stained glass window but you will walk among the tomb of royals. For free entrance, go there during Sunday Mass :) entrance fee 18 pound

Take the time and enjoy this site.. Do your homework ahead of time and learn as much about this fantastic place before you step foot in it. Get there early - and plan on around 3 hours minimum. The Lady's Chapel is astonishing. They'll let you use your camera in the Chapter house. Enjoy!

the history in this place is amazing. We visited westminster abbey and the church was unbelievable. the architecture alone is mind blowing. then you start looking at all the royalty from throughout history who are buried here. its a must do. the hop on hop off bus stops here so make sure you do it.

Very beautiful, full of history.. Westminster Abbey is another place in London that is a must see. We went in September 2014 and spent a couple of hours wandering around the interior, marvelling at the beauty and the history of the building. The best way to visit is to pre book your tickets and then you can avoid the long lines. There are audio guides available, which I suggest you get as they offer a lot of information and point out focal points you may otherwise miss. There are many famous people buried there or their ashes, people such as Jane Austen, Mary Queen of Scott's, Rudyard Kipling, Charles Dickens, Tennyson, and many many more. There is also a tomb for "The Unknown Soldier" where the Queen laid a wreath. This is to honour all the men and women who have died serving their country. We also found a tomb for a person who when we worked out the date of his death was 152years old. We wondered if we had read it wrong and so asked one of the many helpers of the Abbey, and he was happy to give us some information. He said that Thomas Parr was supposedly 152 years and 9 months old when he died. We soon had a lot of people gathered around to hear the tale of Thomas Parr's life and death. Westminster Abbey is full of history and definitely worth spending a few hours looking around.

Great visit. A little bummed you can't take photos, but other than that, this is a wonderful tourist attraction, filled with nook upon nook of history, stories and beauty. There might be (quite) a line outside, but it does move. Try going to a mass, if possible.

Well worth a a long visit. Really wonderful & well worth spending several hours seeing! With a free audio guide (narrated by no less than Jeremy Irons) you will find it hard to leave this amazing place, with its long list of kings & queens, lords & ladies all residing in the hereafter, along with celebrated poets & other lucky souls who made "the A list.” It should be mentioned that a sense of reverence is appreciated while visiting, as it a much revered place of worship & where the royals go to be married & eventually, buried. The only negative I notated was that not enough sites were covered (really numbered) on the audio guide & you are left scratching your head whilst trying to work out "who is in that very regal looking burial chamber over there?” Being American I also loved the little chapel (there are many inside this BIG chapel) dedicated to the RAF & from what I recall WWII flyers, including U.S. who are memorialized in the beautiful stained glass, within it.

Love this abbey. You can take a Verger led tour for a small fee, I would definitely recommend a Verger tour because you get to go places where you can't by just wandering around, and it's so informative, interesting and funny.

Busy, but beautiful...not surprising!. Yes, it is one of the most highly visited tourist attractions of London...but it's for good reason.After five years of living in London, I finally made it inside Westminster Abbey. Why did I not go before? Well, I'm a bit lazy and lines make me feel even less inclined to do, well, anything. The day we went, Westminster had all of the usual lines, but my friend's Mom visiting from the US guilt-tripped us into going with her...and I didn't regret it for a second.It is an absolutely stunning building on the inside and there are so many nooks and crannies and bits to explore. I would have no hesitation to return again even if it is to see the exact same things I say before, but I would be elated if I could attend a service of any kind there.A bit of a wait, but a wonderful London experience.

Disappointed. Understandably, Westminster Abbey is a must see when in London. Our stay was short so we were very disappointed when we went to visit, and found that it was closed for a service that was being held. The Abbey, of course, has a purpose that is greater than being open for sightseers; however we were a bit disappointed. Wish us better luck the next time we are in town!

Mind blowing history lesson. The building is amazing in itself, but the the history that has taken place there is incredible. The graves of Elizabeth I, Issac Newton, Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, the list goes on and on... Not to be missed.
Westminster Abbey. Buyingthe London Pass was a good idea and we could get a special entry and by pass the serpentine queue. A magnicient structure. Has lot of history and well preserved.

Busy, but very interesting. We visited Westminster Abbey with my parents and my 11 year old daughter. There is a GBP 16 / adult charge - which is fairly steep but is comparable to St. Paul's Cathedral. There was a reduced price for kids and seniors.The Abbey remains a practicing religious building and visitors are expected to respect this. In addition, no photography is allowed. There is a security check at entry and a number of personnel inside the Abbey.A audio guide is available. We didn't take this - we purchased a guidebook on entry. However, there is a lot to take in and the audio guide may have been better. That said - there is probably too much for the general visitor to see everything. If you have a specific interest in art or religious history, etc. you may need a longer or multiple visits.The Abbey is set up such that there is an assigned route to be followed. It is not too obvious but is intended to ease congestion in some areas. The Abbey gets very busy with some larger school and college groups.Overall a very interesting and historical building.

Beyond Amazing History. We loved the beauty and history here. We also very much appreciated how they went out of their way to create a children's activity sheet; it became a fun hunt for the whole family!

Loads of history and architecture at your own pace. I cannot believe that I lived in London for just over 2 years and never visited. This trip I decided to remedy this and am very glad I did. The self paced audio guide that is included as part of the admission is excellent and provides as much information as anyone could want. The fact that you can walk around at your own pace and stop to absorb the atmosphere when you feel like it was brilliant. The staff were very engaged and happy to answer any questions. There is so much to see, it is easy to spend several hours without even realising it. If you have time, Devonshire tea in the cafe is also good value and very yummy. Finally, the small gift shop has some interesting and reasonably priced souvenirs, particularly cds.

The most extraordinary building I ever visited. This place is absolutely amazing! The architecture, the details, the history...It was worth every pence! The only downfall was that they don't let u take pictures. The rest, flawless!

Interesting and Inspiring. Although this stop was not available on the 2-4-1 deal with the National Rail service while we were there, we paid the price and loved every moment we toured the Abbey. So much history there and the audio guides were very helpful as we explored the Abbey. Be sure to visit the Cellarium for their cream tea. Delicious!

An extraordinary trip through western history. A visit to the Abbey is a tour of the birth of western civilization itself. Take a listening device, go slowly, look carefully, spend time at each and every room and space and hallway - each is dripping with history. You can attend mass too, if you wish. It should take you hours and yes, while it is not inexpensive, it is ideal for a family with older kids who are ready to look, listen and learn in an awe-inspiring environment.

Worth the Visit. Although there were hundreds present in the Abbey, it was humbling to stand at the entrance where so much English history has occurred, to gaze at the architecture, and to Be Still and Know That God is present.

THE VISIT. Been past here many times on the bus. Got of this time went straight in no queuing about 11.30 am. Very quite inside perfect it was a Wednesday morning . Picked up a mobile audio machine they are free, very helpful. If it's quite you can play it back and see the item again. Staff are very helpful . did not eat there so no comments on the café. As a senior citizen I paid £17.00 well worth it A tip if you miss anything go backwards and key in the relevant number I also wear a hearing aid but no problem with the audio

Organ concert. I've been to Westminster Abbey for a free organ concert, which takes place ones a month. I arrived almost 2 h prior to beginning and was ca. 8 in line. In 10 min I noticed, that behind my back another 30 people are waiting, so it was good time to start waiting.Approximately 15 min before concert they open the gate and after short bag inspection let attendants in.The procedure is very quick, and also after the concert you aren't allowed to stay any longer, the stuff push everybody out as quickly as possible. Honestly, they looked quite angry to the people, who managed to enter for free this over-priced sight)The concert was great, apart from music I enjoyed the feeling of warm, light and very beautiful space around me, while outside in the cold wind it began raining.

One of the best sites in London. An amazing tour with a self guided audio. Crowds can be a problem so try to come early int he day or the late afternoon. There is history in every step - poets corner, crypts of kings and queens, majestic stained glass. Would recommend buying tickets in advance or on line to avoid the lines.

Best sight in London. Not to be missed because of all the history within these walls. Even my 14 year old son enjoyed it very much. Should be done early in the morning to avoid the crowds because there are narrow passages around the most important tombs. A must see in London.

Historic and architecturally interesting. Undoubtedly one of the best of its kind but I draw the line at paying really excessive amounts - approx 28 euros (£20 UK ) per person to enter any form of religious building. it seems mercenary. In my opinion, a church is somewhere you go to pray and give thanks to your God - not a tourist attraction.

Never tire seeing this ornate and historic abbey. We booked our tickets online and it was wonderful not waiting in line to enter. The ticket was for anytime during the day which made it nice. It was disappointing to not be able to take photographs. There were plenty of people monitoring to see that no one sneaked a photo.Audio guides are complimentary.The abbey was built in 1065. It was interesting to just admire the beautiful stained glass and the intricate architecture. The coronation area had unique mosaic tile. The chair itself was very old and was nothing special except for the history attached to it.The side chapels and tombs were unbelievably unique. Also, the tombs of the English kings were massive. The poets corner had Charles Dickens, Handel, and Lewis Carroll's plaques and memorials.The gift shop is quite large and has something for everyone. It was rather crowded in the abbey so be prepared to follow the crowds through the areas. Yes, it is pricey but I feel it is well worth the money.

Appalling cost. £20 for entry is an abomination. My wife and I are backpackers, and although we're on a budget we do normally just fork out for the cost of admission to places, or donate when it's free. We left immediately. Disappointing.

the price disgusting. My wife and I went through the security only to find out it was £20 each to get in and walked back out. Popped over the road into the Methodist centre what a pleasure to visit no fees lovely caffe very nice building and left £5 in the collection box. Enough said

Fascinating and worth the price. I almost didn't visit Westminster Abbey because after visiting several churches, I felt a bit over it, and the cost (20 pounds) seemed quite steep, but I had some time free and couldn't resist the beauty of the building from the outside. Now, having been there, I'm so glad I did go see it. And that cost covers the excellent audio guide, unlike many other places which charge extra for this. I had read that it's good to go early in the day as there can be queues at other times, but I only had one family in front of me when I lined up for tickets, so I got in quickly. There were a fair few people inside but it wasn't overly crowded and very easy to see everything. I was a little disappointed you can't take photos inside, but given it is a working church, it is understandable. And once inside, the history of the place is just amazing. I spent about an hour and a half there and if I'd had more time, could have spent much longer marvelling over the memorials and the beauty of the place.

Beautiful Church and museum. This Abbey is still used for services and houses an amazing amount of tombs and monuments of very famous people. We used the acoustiguide audio tour and enjoyed all of the historical information given regarding this church. Photography is not permitted inside the church.

The history lessons from school all became relevant as saw graves of so many monarchs. Such an impressive building. Beautiful stone work, huge ornate ceilings and then the opportunity to see shrines /stones/graves of so many of this country's monarchs and famous people. The poets corner was equally educational and was such a touching sign of respect to those whose works live on even today. It was rather expensive to enter but I am so pleased I have seen the building and will not forget the experience.

Westminster Abbey - Excellent but Expensive. There are few places on earth like Westminster Abbey for sheer history. There is simply too much to see in one visit and here in lies part of the problem. Receiving no government funding the Abbey has to stand on it's own two feet and that mean the entry fee is expensive (like many of London's famous attractions). At £20 per head (£17 concessions) and family tickets at £45 (family of 4) you certainly get your monies worth to be sure, but it is a lot of money and more people would be able to view this marvellous place if it were cheaper. This is no fault of the Abbey.....and i will leave the politics there.On top of your ticket however it is worth getting the Verger guided tour. I have been many times but for the sake of the family i happily tagged along. Two very quick hours later i was still enthralled by the really excellent guided tour (and i really hate guided tours).The bonus is you get into some areas that general ticket holders do not.For those who do not want the guided tour the language ear phones are available in many languages and seemed well received.Reminder that this is a working Abbey so it is closed on Sundays and best to check there are no major national events going on before you plan your visit. In addition Saturdays are very busy. You can book tickets in advance and i found this to be a good idea.Still it is the Abbey and worth seeing once in your life time.

Very interesting. For anyone interested in English history this visit encapsulates all that is noteworthy. The Abbey, with its own history spanning over a millenium, marks the last resting places of many Kings (and Queens) of England, and famous poets, authors, politicians, explorers, scientists and others who have contributed to the development of the country and its civilisation, especially in the last 500 years, are all remembered here. A must for every tourist genuinely interested in the changing culture of England over the ages.

Beautiful Place. My husband and I visited here during a 3 day trip to London and the entry was included as part of our London pass. We had to queue for a short while to get in and they do a bag check at the door. Once in you can pick up a free electronic guide and listen to the history which comes in many languages. We are not big on history facts etc and just enjoyed walking ourselves round taking in the beauty of the building and it was interesting to see the chair used in all of the coronations since the 1300's. Beautiful place to go and see whilst in London.

A unique place. Incredible church with an amazing history. Unfortunately we didn't have time to do an audio tour and didn't really do the building justice. As it is £20 per person to enter you should allow enough time to do a proper tour.
Family visit to the capital. Well organised, very interesting, a must for all tourists ! So amazing to see were all the history of politics in Westminster focus.

bring down the price so it can be enjoyed by all !. Excellent visit. Audio guide a must ( or tour) or you could miss some best bits. wonderful place to visit . The only thing is the price , i feel you may be pricing some people out of history. Same as St Pauls, come on guys, there is cafe / gift shop, and the amount of visitors that pass through the doors,,, bring down the price to make it accessible for everyone. We would love to bring the children back to see it, London is expensive enough to access and stay ,,,, It is a holy place after all. At this rate my children will have to be very very rich to visit their capital and see the places they learn about at school ! Every one should be able to enjoy
Absolute must see. This is a beautiful church packed full or religious and civil history. A must see with included audio tour. Not cheap at 20 pounds, but worth it.

Kings and queens history galore.. This is the church absolute must see of the churches in London. It is so historical with all of the rich history of kings and queens. Do not miss visiting this location.

A walk through history. We were very lucky to take the guided tour by one the marvellous verger's who made the whole place come alive. So much information given and so unbelievably interesting ending up in poet's corner. I have been before and walked around alone, but it is well worth having the guide.

Pricey but brilliant . At £20 I thought this was a lot of money to look around a church, that said the radio tour ( using the voice of Jeremy irons) was brilliant and very informative showing you what to look out for and really make the most of your visit.

Off season for a quiet tour. Took a tour and enjoyed this so much more than wandering around by myself. So many of the Kings and Queens are there in their highly decorated tombs with true to life effigies on top of the tomb. Take the tour off season and there are no crowds and no noise. Very peaceful on the right day.

Amazing. This is an amazing building, almost like a museum. I recommend to take the verger led tour which cost only extra 5£, but there are also audio guides available if the tours are full. Try to get there as early as you can, because it can get super busy. Whilst in the area you might want to visit churchill war rooms our houses of parliament.

Beautiful. I'm really not interested in churches, or the history behind them, but I visited here because it was included in the London Pass. We got in, had a free audio guide, and map, and wandered around. The inside was spectacular, and the map/guide takes you through in a certain order, which is good as you're not just left to look at everything in no order (which might be a bit overwhelming as it's huge). The guide talks you through the different areas inside the church, and the history. There are many burial sites and plaques plus a lot of information behind them. I got a bit bored, purely because I wasn't really interested in it (I really just wanted to go in and look), but it was good to be able to learn about what has happened in the church, the history etc. Definitely wouldn't have payed to get in.
The Abbey Tour. Spent Saturday morning doing this tour - give it a couple of hours as there's lots to see - enjoyed it all - well worth seeing.

Everything we'd hoped for. Yes, we waited in a long line (despite arriving at opening time) but our tour of Westminster Abbey was well worth it. Lots to see, and it was interesting to play "spot the monument" for everyone from scientists to statesmen to royals to artists and writers. We enjoyed a lovely spot of tea in the cafe as well. If you're lucky, you can time your visit to enter some of the regularly locked areas as well.

Pricey but worth it. 20 pounds per head is decidedly steep, but it includes the audio guide and there is a lot to see inside. Rather than recite all the points/graves you could hit, let me just say that the Lady's Chapel, about midway through the visit, is a spectacular work of art - luminous, ornate, and in my view utterly without equal anywhere. It is visually more stunning than the Sistine (though lacking the Michelangelo ceiling), and more uplifting than Sainte Chapelle (though its stained glass is much more modest). This by itself is worth the admission.
Amazing cathedral. Wonderful to visit this magnificent abbey and to reflect upon the lives of the people buried here. Highly recommended.

Scene of many historical events. It is many years since I first brought my children here. Then, entrance was free. Today, we paid £120 (£40 per family with 2 adults and one child) for our group of 9. Audio guides are included in the fee. Fortunately, it is worthwhile going in to gaze at the site of some of England's important historical events. Coronations have been taking place here for hundreds of years. Funerals of noteworthy personalities have been held here. Oliver Cromwell's body was dug up 2 years after he was buried, decapitated and hung. He is no longer here.The most beautiful part is the Lady's Chapel with its white stone carved ceilings. The Quire where the choir sings is also interesting with its carved wooden panels. When it was a Benedictine abbey, this is where they would sing their prayers 7 times a day. There are royalty buried here, butit is the Poets' Corner that appeals to most visitors. Here, you will find the graves of Charles Dickens, the Austens, Tennyson, Lord Byron and lots more.We all enjoyed our visit, including my nephew who's only 8 years old. This is definitely something that the whole family can appreciate.

SO interesting!. I never knew that there were so many tombs here. It was fascinating to learn just how many important people made this their final resting place. The architecture is phenomenal, and the audio tour was great. If you like history, this place has plenty to spare. It's surprisingly serene...even though on any given day there are hundreds of people there. It is certainly worth a look.

Highest Recommendation and Rating. Westminster Abbey was by far the most impressive attraction we visited in London. There is a fee of 20 pounds to enter, but the value far exceeded the price. Take the guided tour to fully experience the vast history and sacred setting of this wonderful cathedral. Highest recommendation. Not to be missed!!

Historically Interesting Experience. Going to Westminster Abbey is like going to a place of worship, a history lesson, and a cemetery full of famous people, all at the same time. From multiple kings and queens of England (Edward I, Elizabeth I, others) to poets and writers, to scientists like Darwin and Isaac Newton, there is a lot to see here. The audio tour is done well and the Abbey is worth the price of admission.

History Condensed. My 17 year old daughter and I travelled to London recently and Westminster Abbey was a must see for both of us. While I lived in the UK and had visited many times, this was her first time there and she was not disappointed. We skipped the guided tour this time (I would recommend it for first time visitors and those wanting access to additional parts of the Abbey that are off limits for non-tour visitors), but we're able to take part in prayers at the shrine of Edward the Confessor which we both enjoyed. I know that the cost of entrance is high, but we thought it was worth it. I consider the Abbey a must see when in London.

Amazing. The most expected sight during our visit in London, and it did not disappoint me. The Abbey is soo beautiful. It was such an amazing experience just to be there, We were lucky enough that the Royal Family attended the Commonwealth Service in the Abbey on 9th March, so we could see them arriving. :) It is not allowed to make any photographs inside, which I totally understand but despite of this fact it would have been great to make only one photo as a memory. The security man at the entrance was funny, we arrived before the opening hours, and when the time came (9:25) he was asking, whether we are ready and excited like it was a concert. :) An experience I will never forget, so much worth every penny! :)

Amazing. Although you have to queue to get in this is somewhere really worth going to. Entry is £20 but includes a really good audio tour of the Abbey and visits to various other parts of the site. One of the highlights was actually using the dorway where royalty etc enter for the big occasions. Also seeing first hand loads of historic tombs which we had previously only ever seen in pictures. What a great experience.

Interesting. Welcoming and at £20 per person not cheap. The human guides are brilliant and the recording of Jeremy Iron's grating and catatonic voice on the electronic device supplied as part of the entrance fee did not detract from the amazing history of this building. Toilets for the public/unwashed are terrible - not at all the fault of the chap with the horrible job of keeping them topped up with lavatory paper and doing his best with a poor facility. Bite the bullet and install some single sex up market portaloos outside adjacent to current facilities. The fact they're unisex just adds to the unpleasant experience. Have a feeling visiting dignitaries will be accommodated elsewhere...!? Get this sorted and you'll improve the working environment of your staff and provide a positive visitor experience.

A Sight to Behold. When visiting London going into the Abbey is a must - it may not be as grand as its neighbour, the Houses of Parliament, on the outside but the inside is simply stunning! Trace the footsteps of Royals as you walk down the aisle - how overwhelming it must have been especially for the brides!!!! No need to pre-book as it is the same cost at the door. If you're an OAP, take I.D or you won't get discount!
Connects the past with the future. Must visit. Loved this place. You go through England's majestic history and it's future. Staff is helpful and friendly. A must visit attraction!

Awe inspiring.. We visited the Abbey this week and spent some hours looking at the Church, the memorials and the Royal Tombs. It was not busy and there was plenty of room to linger at strategic points. Visitors enter at the North door just by the front door of St Margaret's (in itself an interesting place). Entrance fees are a bit steep but not bad if you remember how much it costs to keep the building in good repair - £20 adult (only £10 at York Minster and Durham is free but donations welcome), £17 concession for students and old people like us. Free if you live in Westminster, and it seems that Parish Churches can get free passes for their members.Included is an audio guide which is not too verbose and quite adequate.The Royal Tombs are indeed awe inspiring, from St Edward right up to the Tudors. Later regal burials are marked by simple engraved tiles in the floor and are very easy to miss.The Lady Chapel is incredibly beautiful and houses the first Tudor King, who built it!, and his wife.But there are other interesting things too see at the end of the Abbey itself, not least the architecturally stunning Chapter House with medieval tiled floor, the lovely gardens, and the quirky little museum with many death effigies. A recently opened undercroft restaurant serves excellent if very expensive food. Soup and a sandwich costs an arm and a leg but you can see prices before you go in. We stayed on for Choral Evensong, sublime. Of course, if you just want to go to a service (Evensong at 5 every day, not always sung) no entrance fee. But if you want to sit in the Quire for Evensong it is as well to join the queue at the Great West Door at least 30mins early. There are also free organ recitals on a Sunday (see website).There are toilets off the South Transept (Poets' Corner) and next to the restaurant.

One of the worlds greatest attractions.. A little dubious when we we first arrived as there were huge queue. No need to worry though it is superbly organised and you never feel there are too many people in the place.Audio guide is excellent and gives lots of wonderful details.I was amused when visiting the tomb of Elizabeth1 and Mary Queen of Scots.Mary's was the grandest of the two and wondered if James1st who had his mother interred there was getting his vengence.A wonderful visit and the foods good too.

Take the time to absorb it's history. Beautiful church that's not to be missed. With paid admission you are given audio guides. Listen to every section of the Abbey, you'll be amazed at who's buried there. Poets corner is sectioned for the creators of art, music and writing. Other sections have inventors, heros and of course Kings and Queens. The outside is also nice to see, the Abbey's garden against the structure of the building is picture perfect.

History Lesson & Working Church. Lovingly cared for soaring building with plaques, tombs, and monuments of so many great human beings, especially the poets, scientists, and statesmen. My eyes kept tearing up. Truly a place to uplift the human spirit and connect with the divine.

Truly awesome. Westminster Abbey is one of the most historic buildings in Britain and a visit here is a truly incredible experience. It can be a bit crowded but it still retains a rather serene atmosphere in which you can ponder all of the royal events and historic moments which have taken place in these hallowed halls. The Henry VII chapel is the real highlight; the rest of the building can't compete. The Museum didn't really add much to the visit for me: some of the effigies of Kings and Queens past were interesting to see but the rest of the collection wasn't worth a look. My only criticism is that some of the audio guide commentary is very brief and there is not much - if any - information given about the various people buried in the floor/memorialized along the walls as you walk from the entrance to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and up the Nave. This area includes Prime Ministers, statesmen, explorers, military figures and others yet you would miss them entirely if you were not carefully looking where you were standing.

History abounds here. I'm probably the only person who was so uneducated about Westminster Abbey. I thought we would stop by for a few minutes, take a few pictures, and head to our next destination. I had no idea what history and treasures were inside! If you like history or royalty at all you simply have to visit Westminster Abbey. There are amazing tombs and not just of royalty. There are famous musicians, philosophers, and poets too. Be sure to set aside plenty of time as the line to get in can be long and our tour took about two hours.

A wealth of history not to be missed!. Gothic architecture, high vaulted ceilings and stained glass windows, coupled with a long, rich history and many notable royal, noble and other prominent burials, make Westminster Abbey a must-see. Don't miss it!

When in London, it's a place not a place to miss. If you are interested in History you have to visit Westminster Abbey, it's full of it. I thought it was expensive at £20 a ticket, but you do get a very good audio tour and there are plenty of guides around to ask questions...and you will. Make sure you visit everything, every corner has a story to tell and listen to the audio.

Just Stunning. What a beautiful building and just steeped in history. Entry costs £20 for adults with the usual concessions for children, seniors etc. Well worth the money as you get an audio guide with entry fee. Take your time to soak up the atmosphere and listen to the commentaries. You can also book a guided tour. All in all just a wonderful experience and one which we would like to repeat. British history at its very best. Highly recommended.

A One Off. We've been meaning to go round the Abbey for many years and finally got round to it. It is the most remarkable place that you should visit once in your lifetime---but only once as the £20 entry fee is way over the top
Quite possibly the most beautiful building I've ever been in. The title of the review speaks for itself, I loved this building. The architecture was amazing, a must see for anyone traveling to London

Wonderful Experience. We had passed the Abbey many times and finally made it inside. We spent a wonderful few hours admiring the architecture and the atmosphere. The audio guide was very useful but we felt that there were other areas and objects that needed labels and we were left wondering what they were.It was wonderful to see the tomb of see Elizabeth 1 and other tombs of famous people we all read about at school.

Good. It is very old. Lots and lots of history. Epitaphs for sure of a lot of famous people ...... They might be buried there also but i am slightly confused about that.....that is because of the sheet number of famous people interred here...... Whether it be kings n queens, poets, scientists, politicians, you name it. The fascinating ones for me were those of newton and darwin. The other fascinating bit of history is the chair on which the english monarchs have always been crowned. The church is very nice otherwise, very grand. There is an entry fee but that comes with the audio guide. The cloisters are pretty nice and relaxing. A must visit in London but only for those who have a sense of history.

splended building. We visited the Abbey some years ago just before sarah Ferguson and Prince Andrew married in there, So had a little time to kill in London so ventured again, although the price is a bit expensive now. After saying that its a must to see if visiting London. Its a magnificent building which oozes history from every crevice. there is plenty to see such as the poets corner the tomb of Mary Queen of Scots, and the beautiful ceilings.I suggest you visit their web site for a more in depth explanation to what to look out forWe hope you enjoy your visit as much as we did.http://www.westminster-abbey.org/

Wonderful Westminster Abbey. I love this place despite the ridiculous cost of entry, and the staff who think that they're too good to dealing with the plebs. These factors aside, Westminster Abbey is a joy. It oozes history from every stone, it fascinates, amazes, and should be on the itinerary of every visitor to the Capital. From Queen Elizabeth I's grand tomb, to Anne of Cleves tiny niche, this building is British history encapsulated in ancient stone.

A must see on a visit to London. I have travelled to London many times over the years but had never visited Westminster Abbey until a few weeks ago and then realised what I had been missing. Wonderful architecture and sense of history. Quite an amazing place. My favourite bits - the ceilings, the tomb of Mary Queen of Scots, and Poets Corner. We arrived just after 10am on a weekday morning and the queue was not very long, took just over five minutes to get to the entrance. I did think that the entrance fee of £20 was a lot (£17 for seniors). However it does include a free audio guide that you collect once you are in. We took around 1 1/2 hours to go round but I am sure it could easily take longer if you linger.

Landmark Visit. On my bucket list for years, this iconic Abbey is central to our nation's collective memory. Memorials and sanctuaries abound in remembrance of the great, the good and sometimes the not so good. All are described on the audio-guide included with the entrance fee.After a brief bag search we quickly passed into the abbey. We had paid on-line and so our e-ticket was scanned. We picked up a very easy to use hand-held electronic voice guide with Jeremy Irons to emphasise the depth and wealth of history of this building.My most memorable moment was being alone in a side chapel with the tomb and thus remains of Queen Elizabeth First and her older sister Queen Mary.School parties abound, just wait for each wave to pass; or, go in early.Yes, it is very expensive, but worth it.

Amazing place to spend hours . I was here on Wednesday I had a great day.On entering I thought £20 is a bit steep for this sort of attraction and was gutted to find photos weren't allowed - yrs there's some postcards in gift shop but not of the things I wanted. I had hoped that like Carlisle cathedral you could buy a permit to take pics...First time around wasn't great as I hadn't been given one of the audio handsets but a member of staff sorted me out and I started again, next time i might prefer an actual tour.Highlights were - seeing where the coronation and royal wedding took place, mary queen of scots, poets corner, memorial to baden Powell and the oldest door in Britain. Liked I could light a candle. The place is steeped in history and the ceilings are just amazing I spent a few hours and could have spent longer. Special mention to the toilet attendant - what a lovely man :) Will return. Please consider if there are any suitable places for pics inside :)

BEAUTIFUL!. Westminster Abbey is absolutely gorgeous and rich with history. It's close to other landmarks and offers up a memorable experience. The attention to detail is beyond belief throughout. I say it's a most go! For more details and reviews of more London sights check out my blog:
http://thewannabegypsy.blogspot.com/2015/02/london-oh-sights-to-see-certainly.html

Hands down the best attraction in London. Came here with the London pass, but would pay the fee to enter without hesitation. Amazing to see the intricacy of all the tombs of past kings and queens. They give you a free audio guide which tells the fascinating stories surrounding some of the people buried there. The level of detail in everything they have done is amazing and just looking up at the ceilings or stained glass is a site to behold. Have done almost every major attraction but nothing compares to this. You know you are a part of history while you are inside.

Remarkable people there!. Not only a beautiful cathedral, but also a graveyard where remarkable people were buried. At the entrance, you can get an audio guide to help you during your visit. The audio guide provides some details that you can't notice without it (for instance, a whole on a wall of the cathedral, made during the London Blitz (1940-1941) You have to travel inside on a fixed path - and you can't come back. So, walk slowly, paying attention to every plate - on the wall and on the ground! Lots of historic characters there and you may miss an important person every time. So, if you love history, spend 2 to 3 hours in Westminster Abbey. In my case, I was really interested in Isaac Newton's tomb. Darwin and Shakespeare are not buried there, but there are some tributes to them. Visit every single chamber so that you don't miss an important king or queen.

An architectural feast for the eyes. The history of this building makes a trip to this landmark a neccesity. The arhitecture and stories that it holds are almost overwhelming. I was a bit shocked by the price when I went but got a student discount since I was there studying. I highly recommend this as a stop on anyone's trip to London. You must go early when it first opens to avoid long lines and being overcrowded.

The fee to enter is outrageous so we did not go in. We were appalled that there was a $40 AUD(20 pound) per adult fee to enter. We chose not to. Even our children were shocked at the charge. We had already been to Notre Dame and St Peters so we just decided to have a pic outside.

Awe Inspiring - you must visit. Visited with my partner whilst on a long weekend to London. At £20 per head its not cheap but is well worth it and if you travel to London by East Coast Trains you can download a "2 for 1" voucher which makes it really good value. Its not just about religion - its much more than that. The architecture and the history were both amazing. You get an audio guide (narrated by Jeremy Irons) included in you entrance fee and this really enhanced our visit.

A visit to the Abbey. Having worked in London for many years I thought it was time to visit this National institution. I was galled at having to pay the £20 a head entrance fee to visit a place of worship. But went ahead and did it anyway. The building has stunning architecture throughout. There were graves of Kings and Queen's and many famous people like Charles Darwin and Issac Newton. Audio tour was included in the price and this was well narrated by the actor Jeremy Irons. The tour took approximately 2.5 hours to see and read most things. There is a lot of British history yo absorb but well worth the visit if you can afford it.

Breathtaking. I visited the abbey with Mary from london walks. As this was a paid tour the fee for entry to the abbey was discounted. The history is staggering and the abbey is beautiful, I particularly loved the Henry VII addition - the fanned ceiling - a similar ceiling can be found in Bath Abbey as well. From the coronation chair to the tomb of the unknown soldier this is one spot you should absolutely make time for on your trip, and if you can, pair it with a guide from London walks.

Full of interesting architecture and history. Went here with the children and thought it would be a bit of a quick visit but 2 hours later I was still engrossed. It is a beautiful building and so many famous people are buried there including surprisingly Darwin and Oliver Cromwell!My daughter did the question sheet driven on my the lure of a chocolate coin she completed it all which made us explore and learn a great deal.The audio guide is excellent.Definitely worth a visit for the architecture and the history.

Amazing Building. An amazing piece of architecture with so much history. This church is truly magnificent. The lineups are very long to get in. It is quite beautiful at night with Big Ben right near by. Don't miss the small chapel right beside the main church - worth a look to.
Beautiful Church. There were a lot of interesting artifacts from around the middle ages. So many Kings and Queens as well as famous people were buried there. The church was magnificent.

Grand Gothic Structure. The historical 10th century Grand Gothic structure is awesome to see as it mesmerize in its style and skill. It is the place where the Royal weddings take place and every tourist to London should not miss this wonderful place for he can carry the memory of this architecture. Its blissful and serene atmosphere is worth to realise and feel

Worth every penny of the entrance charge. Having visited Westminster abbey as a child I had forgotten how much there is to see and take in. The audio guide is fascinating although I would have liked even more detail in a written guide to supplement further what you hear. I saw some children completing a quiz sheet on the tour which I thought was a great way to get them interested in all the fascinating details of the Abbey. A must see if in London...

Great historical experience. A beautiful place full of history - take the time to read and visit all the sites within the cathedral, and don't miss the small, but interesting, abbey museum located in the basement.

A must for history buffs. Westminster Abbey is a must for all history buffs. It's a tad expensive (£20 per adult) but admission comes with an audio guide, which is quite useful. The building itself its impressive, but even more impressive is the way Britain chose to honour her royal family, soldiers, writers, poets, actors, scientists, and politicians by immortalizing them in this magnificent cathedral. Tips: 1) go before noon and on weekdays to avoid soul-crushing lines. 2) Don't miss the small museum tucked inside the gift shop. Lots of fascinating artifacts.

Our highlight of London. If this is worth visiting to you (and yes, it is), then you should DEFINITELY book a verger tour. Make plans to go early in the morning, have a nice lunch in the area or visit other attractions, and then make sure you go back later for Evensong to catch the choir. If you appreciate this type of singing, it will be a moving evening for you ... especially if you're among the first 20 or so in line and get to sit with the choir. Incredible experience.

Not to be missed. What can you say about this most Iconic landmark? When in London, it is a must see. A most incredible place. The walk about audio is really helpful and comes with the admission. We had the London Pass which worked out great. After a full day of Churchill War Rooms, etc. we just wore out and unfortunately were not able to really do it all. We are going back in June and will finish the job.

Beautiful. At £20 for adult entry, it seems a bit expensive, but the price is well worth paying, you get an audio guide included which is superb. The Abbey is iconic for so many reasons - it's age and history, the number of royals, rich and famous people buried and commemorated there, the royal coronations, weddings and funerals and of course the tomb of the unknown soldier - very moving...It's simply breathtaking in it's scale and even more so when you consider the times when it was built and the quality of the craftsmanship - it would never happen today! It was very busy when we went, but it was still easy to get around and view all the main areas. The Lady Chapel was my favourite. It's a whole huge slice of English history that's hard to match.

A sight at a price. Architecturally, Westminster Abbey is very impressive. Artistically and historically as well. However, if you aren't a big fan of those subjects, then it might not be worth the $30 cost of admission. There are some notable graves here that almost everyone will recognize. Definitely accept the free audio tour.

Great Building, but inflated entrance fee. I would say that this is a must for tourists and would have give five stars, but the fee they change is far too high, when you compare with churches in other countries, particularly Italy. To take a family of four in, you need to take out a small mortgage and this surely cannot be right for an iconic church building. If other countries and religions can charge much less, or even nothing, then Westminster Abbey should also reduce their charges. They may end up getting more people, although I guess tourists on holiday with money to spend will think nothing of the cost, but UK citizens on a day out with their family, certainly would

a Walk through British History. As a Building I do not rate this as one of the best Cathedral-type places to visit in the UK. But that is well compensated by the sheer amount of history on display going back generations.
impressive icon. Fantastic architecture and history, the Abbey is really impressive and beautiful. Well worth a visit to see the grandeur of the venue of so many royal weddings etc.

Wow!. Breathtaking ground and historical monuments. Such a calming and peaceful place to just walk and see. Even in the middle of the city, it feels as if it's in the middle of no where. It's kind of like Harry Potter.

Amazing. The place was closed to tourists, however I had come for a special reason and I was fully expecting to be turned away as were all the tourists. However, as soon as I gave my reason I was immediately allowed entry and was even warmly welcomed. I did what I want to do in the abbey and left. I had thought there would be a problem. I can't give my special reason for visiting as others may try it but the Abbey was so welcoming of the fact I came and allowed me in to do what I had come to do. So, to the abbey staff thank you. You made my day and what a great place majestic holly beautiful and in my case emotional place. Thank you for treating me as a person.
must see. This is a must see if you ever find yourself in London. It was beautiful and magical and more than you can imagine. So much history in those walls.

Brilliant. Visited with Hubby & daughter specifically for her to see the resting place of Queen Elizabeth the first. £40.00 entrance fee with free audio guides and mapBeing a stroppy teen she went off on her own, annoyed I had given her an audio guide. Afterwards she said she was not that impressed because she could not find the cues for the audio guide and there was no translation for the latin inscriptions on many of the tombs and also mumbled something about the "vanity of the church" !??Anyway that aside my husband and I thought it was brilliant, amazed at how many ofthe British greats were there, Kings, Queens, prime minsters, poets, explorers, inventors and military and clock makers and moreSmugly we were able to inform our stroppy teen afterwards that if she had chosen to stay with us, we could have highlighted these great people to her and explained their accomplishments...we both said we would go back and do it again.....tip: dont forget to look at the floor and read !!

Majestic!. Westminster Abbey is a must-see on any trip to London, especially if it is your first time there. This church is full of history, and the audio-guided tour is extremely informative. The Abbey is stunning and vast. The choir music is peaceful and beautiful to listen to.

Not to be missed. Visited in the afternoon on 13.02 and were therefore very lucky to miss the nomad queues to gain entry. If you are in London and have the chance to visit the Abbey go for it as it is a wonderful experience. The history and atmosphere are incredible as is the feeling of serenity. We were lucky to participate at the prayer service in Edwards chapel which was lovely. For anyone travelling to London by train entry to the Abbey is now again covered by the British Rail two for one voucher offer which means two can visit for £20 instead of the normal £20 each.

I finally get it. I am a Londoner, I walk past the Abbey and other historical monuments on an almost daily basis. I have never once gone inside this fabulous landmark. Today- I did. I waited in line for half an hour, alomg with other anxious tourists who were all thinking- " how much longer?" We were the 9O'Clock starters at the front of the line, but still had to wait until 9:30 am for the Marshalls to let us in. But, it is worth going as early as you can manage.Yes, £20 is a lot of money anywhere in Europe to see a historical site. But the audio guide is free, and handed to you by a friendly volunteer at the door. There is a clear route to follow, I didn't realise at first, I thought some of the area was roped off, but you get to see it all, in order, in all it's glory. It really is amazing. The tomb of Elizabeth the First! A portrait of Richard the Second!Wonderful Cloisters outside.I think, one of the most important places in the World.

Take the guided tour. I took the guided tour with my girlfriend. Well worth the price. Our guide was very knowledgeable and took the time to answer all questions. It's well worth the visit as the rich history of the place is breathtaking.

Much to see. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful place to visit. There is something for all ages. The Rose Window is fantastic as are the other beautiful stained windows. There are numerous monuments, burials, statues and memorials. The Coronation Chair is also in the Abbey. The gardens are lovely and very peaceful. You are able to take an audio tour by yourself, a verger tour for individual, family or small groups or a guided tour for large groups. There is a food outlet, and also shops where you can purchase various postcards, books, gifts plus souvenirs. Westminster Abbey is near Big Ben and can be reached by using the Hop on Hop off buses or a short walk from Westminster Rail Station.

Surprisingly a lot to see. Spent hours looking all over. So many kings and queens amongst total 3000 people interned. Tombstones and monuments beautiful and that ceiling. Wow. Gardens were peaceful and worth a visit. Do Verger tour for £5. Very worthwhile.

Didn't have time for the guided tour, but it was spectacular!. On this particular trip to the UK, we skipped all the guided tours, and just wandered through most attractions on our own.Westminster Abbey was no exception to this method of "see as much as we can in the time we have available." Beautiful space - no photography allowed, but I saw MANY people taking photos anyway (we didn't, but we're generally rule-followers). Seeing the coronation chair was pretty awesome, as was knowing we were in the space where Princess Diana's funeral was held.The facility is stunning, and the guides/docents helpful (almost TOO helpful) - except they disparaged us for not taking one of the hand-held self-guided tour audio devices. That actually made me a bit irritated. I know what I want to do and how I want to see/learn! :) Next time (if we actually go back there) I *might* take the audio tour, but gah - the GERMS on those things! They're just dumped back into a basket and then handed to the next person.Allow at least an hour for a quick walk-through - or at least 3 hours for a full guided-tour experience.

Fascinating insight into British history. First of all I will say that I considered the entry fee of £20 to be quite high, although this does include an optional audio guide at no extra cost.However, if you are prepared to pay it you will get a wonderfully detailed narrated tour of one of Britain's most iconic and historic buildings and it is certainly worth a visit.If you have any interest in the history of the monarchy, this is the place to go.

Stunning. This place has been on my bucket list for a good number of years and finally got to visit it last weekend. My only disappointment was that you can see it, you cant get close to Edward the confessors tomb, but totally understand and respect the reason. This place is the place to go if you want to know, see, touch and smell British history. It is highly recommended.
Take the guided tour!. Dripping with history in a beautiful setting, the guided tour provided extra access and great information. The tour was well-worth the price.

Amazing. We went unsure of what to expect but were surpised and amazed at what could be found there. From the sculptures, to the tombs of royalty and the famous, there was so much to view. The audio guide was excellent, and easy to use. The architecture was stunning.
Loved it. We got 2 for 1 with the national rail offer. We did the audio tour and loved it. The abbey is very impressive and the history inside is mind blowing. Really enjoyed looking around.
Tours recommended . If you're a history person, get the audio guide and take a guided tour as well. You get very different - and awesome - information from both of them.

History yes, architecture not so much.. Love cathedral architecture but this one is so full of monuments to people that its difficult to get a clear view of the inside of the building. If you are a history buff (with 20 pounds to spare) you will enjoy the audio tour but there is so much inside that there is no way for the tour to cover it all. Do check out the 14 century paintings in the Chapter House.Personally I prefer the look of a cathedral like York Minster or even St. Paul's. They aren't so crammed full of marginal history, monuments to rich people who didn't want anyone to forget them.

Amazing!. We visited Westminster Abbey during the summer holidays. The Abbey has always been something on our list to visit and we went to see the grave of the Unknown Soldier (this was also in keeping with what our children were learning at school). Very helpful and knowledgeable staff and plenty to see and learn. Fascinating to see the history inside and the graves of previous monarchs. Nice restaurant for something to eat as well and a small shop for the kids to buy something to take home! Toilet facilities were not the cleanest (which was surprising to us).

Always wonderful. This was my third visit to the Abbey. It's wonderful and easy to fill on 2 hours taking in the history and beauty. The admission covers an extremely good audio tour. The queues were small as it was freezing. They can be extremely long in warmer months so beware

Well worth the visit. Plan on getting here early as the line for admission could be long, particularly if the weather is nice. Your admission price includes a very informative audio guide that lets you explore at your own pace. It will take at least about 1-2 hours to visit and listen to most of the audio guide. This is a site that is well worth the price of admission.

Overpriced . Whilst there is no denying that this is a fabulous building I feel the £20 per person admission charge is excessive. I appreciate that a building of this calibre needs constant maintenance but the price is counterproductive in that it deters visitors (I saw several walk away once the cost became clear). The audio guide was extremely good but the whole visit worth £20? Definitely not.

Picturesque cathedral. We were truly fascinated by this sight,single admission is 20GBP,however they offer also family discount and student tickets, this is the must see even if you are not a fan of GB history,only downsize-you are not allowed to take any photo, audio tour guide possible in many languages

Belittled by architecture. Westminster Abbey is one of those places you gotta see if you're in London. Is it worth the 18 pound fee? Probably not. For those who are not into history or architecture is a big cathedral. Again is a self guided tour with an audio (if you can choose the English one as is Jeremy Irons' voice and that's definitely a plus) I know it's very difficult to fit the whole story without making the tour too long, but in my case at the end of it i found myself wanting more. History can be a hell of a story but in westminster's case is just little tips of what happened or about the people who's buried there. Enjoyable, yes... but i was honestly left with a sense of... not enough.

Full of beauty and history!. The amount of history you see in this church is unbelievable! Make sure to get the audioguide, narrated by Jeremy Irons. It really helps you to understand every corner, every little chapel and tumb inside of the abbey. Simply amazing!

Outstanding day. As a local walking past it frequently, I never thought of visiting Westminster Abbey. Pricey entrance fee nearly put me off, but my wife and I had a great time. So much to see we spent three hours in there and learned so much. A truly historic site filled with nationally important memories of great people and events. A great day out!

Truly Amazing!. I really enjoyed our trip here. The tour was absolutely incredible and I learned quite a bit and began to piece together a little more British history after also visiting the Tower of London.

One off my bucket list. Have intended to visit here for many years and finally took the opportunity. Even so, I was unprepared for the splendour, intricacy of many of the sculptures and the sheer density of memorials. The audio tour is excellent and it took me a good two hours to go round on my own. When I visited, (early afternoon on a December Wednesday) there was no queue and it wasn't too busy inside. I had plenty time to linger at the most impressive tombs (Queen Elizabeth and Mary Queen of Scots). Expensive? Yes, but I'll probably not visit again so as a one off, it's not. But I do think some sort of application scheme could be devised for those for whom the cost is genuinely prohibitive.

Beautiful historic church. This is one of the most wonderful places to visit in London. They give you (with the admission price) hand-held phones with commentary and photos and you can take your own time going thru the cathedral. The memorial to the unknown soldier and Poet's Corner are only two of the most impressive sights in the building. Well worth a visit to this historic church.

Outrageously overpriced and no photos allowed. Westminster Abbey is one of the most expensive attractions in London, so if you are on a tight budget then this is not for you. No discounts are offered, queues are huge and no photos are allowed once inside. If you choose to go in, entry is £20 and you will get to see where every British monarch (except two) have been crowned since William the Conqueror. Alternatively if you want to save your money and see just the equally spectacular outside, head through the arch into Dean's Yard where you can sit and admire it from a tranquil lawn not many know about.If you want to see the inside for free you should attend evensong which is held most days at 5pm. Entry is via the main Great West Gate. You will need to let the guards know that you wish to attend. You won't be able to wander about much once inside but will give you a taste of what it is like.

Amazed.. Loved the architecture of it and it is a good place in the centre of London to gather your thoughts and relax and admire this creation. The structure is in such good condition after all these years.

magnificent. My husband and I visited Westminster Abbey this weekend. I'm not a religious person but wanted to visit due to the historical significance it has in British history. It was £20 per adult, which included a free audio tour. We got there on Saturday just as it opened. I would say we timed it perfectly as the queues were getting quite big as we left. The tour is an hour, then there are other places to visit afterwards. The highlights for me were the architecture of the building itself (it is beautiful), the tomb of Elizabeth I and the Coronation Chair. I would highly recommend visiting the abbey if one are interested in British history.

Unbelievable. This is one of the most amazing sites that you will ever see. It is beautiful to say the least. Take some time just to soak in the history. The recorded guided tour is great. We loved this stop. It is very busy so arrive early!!! Very Early!!!!

Must see!. Outstanding self guided tour thanks to the audio commentary provided. Not cheap but a small discount for 60+. Also for younger visitors. Not sure little ones would cope with the amount of time needed to see everything - or if they'd appreciate the history and architecture. But we did!

Best place to visit in London . This is the best place to visit by far in London... I wished I could spend the. When day there... And for sure I'll revisit this abbey next time I visit London... MUST VISIT...

Beautiful architecture. We only saw this one from the outside as it didn't fit into our backpacking budget!Even without entering I think this is worth a stroll around specially after you've come to take your photo in front of Big Ben.
Stunning. What a stunning structure! Worth a stop in to see! It's location is great on your way to other attractions. We were able to stop in and still make other tourist stops in the same day.

clasical british celebrities. In Westminster Abbey , it's full remembrances and burial places of really famous classical celebrities but i couldn't stop staring at all the arts and textures , its all fascinating ! each place has its own story . If you bring kids they might be a bit frightened because of the gothic architecture . You also get to see the Royal Throne ! It's also the place that Prince William and Kate middleton got married.

Living history. Need 2-4 hours for your visit. Lots to see and hear (from hand-held audio equipment). Very interesting for history and architecture buffs. Go when the crowds are less otherwise could get too crowded.

Put other things on a higher priority. Slightly disappointing for me. There is undoubtedly an interesting history here- many great things happened and are still in the abbey. But for outrageous price and the substandard audioguide I don't think it was worth it. For an alternative I would recommend. St. Paul's. It was also pricey, but more worth it's price.

Unbelievable, daunting, history and beauty unparalleled.. The only downside is the no photography rule...so buy a book as in a few short hours you will see more of history than you could begin to imagine. This building has to be the holy grail of western civilization and history. Look anywhere in any direction and someone that you have learned about is buried beside or beneath you. Case in point was a lady in front of us was told to look over to her left to see the final resting place of Charles Darwin and then advised that she was currently standing on Isaac Newton and so on and on. Then you move into the Royal tombs area and WOW you can actually feel the centuries and ghosts and all that goes with it. Mind boggling stuff. Of course, for the living, this is the real "Coronation" Street LOL.

Plan more time than you think you need. This place was much bigger and had so much more to see than I expected. I blocked out about 2 hours to see the cathedral and we were there 3 (and could have stayed more). If you're creeped out by tombs, you're going to be super creeped out here because they're everywhere, in the floor, in the walls, in the middle of the walkway. It was amazing. It was such an humbling experience to be there among the tombs of so many who worshipped there over the centuries.
Fabulous. The architecture, the history, the 'Unknown Soldiers' grave, the peacefulness even though it was quite busy. Not to be missed
