Take a Verger Guided Tour, Go to Evensong. Westminster Abbey is one of the most popular tourist attractions for a reason. If you are going during a busy time, I recommend getting there 15-20 minutes before opening time, otherwise you may face quite long queues. Call ahead and book a verger guided tour. It costs 5 gbp more than the general admission (which includes the audio guide). Only 20 people are allowed on each tour, and a verger personally takes you through the Abbey and explains things to you. You get to go places that you otherwise cannot with the audio guide (most notably, the shrine of Edward the Confessor, where Kate and William signed their marriage license after their wedding).The Abbey is quite large, and you cannot take photos inside. Plan for at least a few hours for a visit. There are so many famous and important people buried here that you will lose count. Also, I initally tried not to step on the graves of people, but quickly realized that it was physically impossible to do so, so don't worry about it when you are there. Sometimes the Abbey carries weird hours. If you can't get in for a tour, definitely go to a service, Evensong if you can. The Westminster boy's choir sings at many of these services, and they are quite impressive.

Great tour of Church & State. The ultimate confluence of Church and State exists at Westminster Abbey, where all the modern British Royals have been crowned and almost every British monarch and important citizen is buried. Its exterior is deceptively small; inside it is massive and incredible. Absolutely worth the visit. Drawback: you can't take pictures, which absolutely sucks and needs to be changed.

A few changes in 20 yrs... but it was good. First of all the is a fee to tour the Abbey now.. it is about 20 pounds/person. I really like that they have the audio recording tour with the number selection. I got a lot more out of it. 20 yrs ago we did not have any of that or a tour guide so I didn't really know some of who was there. They now have a Children's trail which is learning experience for kids. and all the the people there were very helpful and answered my 7 yr olds questions

Wasnt sure but really enjoyed it. I will state now I am not religious and didn't think I would like the abbey but my wife wanted to go so I tagged along.Once inside when you see all the fantastic memorials and graves of all the monarchs and people from all walks of history it blows you away.The tombs of the likes of Queen Elizabeth the first and Edward the Confessor it brings it home to you how important places like the abbey are and every generation should take the time to visit them, highly recommended

Absolutely stunning!. Took the Westerminster Abbey audio tour. Absolutely a must to go inside. In the Abbey precinct you can visit St. Margaret's Church, the Great and Little Cloisters, the Chapter House and museum and College Garden, which is the oldest garden in England. Unfortunately you cannot take photos inside but there are great photo opportunities outside.

Take a walk through history. The vastness of this experience must be adsorbed slowly.
Experience the tomb of the Duke of Wellington and Horatio Nelson.
On your journey through this icon you will visit memorials to the poets, Charles Darwin and the most recent addition Captain Arthur Phillip. A wonderful experience.
You can't argue with history.. So much history to soak up. It's amazing.The structure just takes your breath away. It gets so so so so busy, especially at the weekend so get out early to see it.
Must be seen. It's wonderful old Gothic architecture, full of history and peaceful atmosphere in London centre itself. It has seen many royal weddings and ceremonies. It must be entered inside!

Took the audio tour. Full of information and history.
Highly recommend to get in early to beat the crowds
There is an easy to follow tour and plenty to take in
Also see the wooden coronation throne!

Astonishing every time. With the wonderful architecture, and the tombs of the Kings and Queens of England, from Edward the Confessor to George 11 , not forgetting Poet's corner, the Abbey Audio tour is excellent and allows everyone to take in the tour at their own pace. The amazing Coronation chair , made in 1301 and used at every Coronation since, is also displayed in the Abbey.

The craftsmanship is breathtaking.. We have seen Westminster Abbey so many times on TV we thought it was time to visit. We arrived at 3.30. Just as they were closing ! The closing times vary but on certain weekdays it is 3.30! We squeezed in and we're told that the abbey closes at 4.30 so we had just one hour. An audio us included in the £18 entrance fee. That seemed quite expensive.the organ was playing for some of the time which was a beautiful sound and there was also music available on the audio which added to the atmosphere. The building is unbelievable beautiful. The masonry and the ceilings are out of this world. I was able to light a candle for a loved one which felt special. There are a lot of tombs! Poets corner is interesting to look around. Then outside are the cloisters and you can easily visualise its' origins as an abbey. You can see the spot where the coronations take place as well as the coronation chair itself. All very interesting. We did not take any children - they may find it interesting if they were doing kings and Queens at school ! They do a family ticket which seemed good value. One hour was just about enough time. Anyone can attend the services and so it is possible to visit the abbey without paying.

Very good. Enjoyed the tour on the audio devices provided, especially with Jeremy Iron's voice! Well done, nice circuit, and amazing Abbey. Helpful staff around for additional questions and a nice peaceful way to spend a couple of hours. Learned a lot of history, and you can learn as much, or as little as you like because you are in charge of your own tour. I occasionally found myself confused as to where I was supposed to be with respect to the audio tour, even when I was in control, but this was minor, and you could easily replay if you were in the wrong spot.Thanks!

A Highlight of my London Visit. The Verger's Tour, available for an additional 5 pounds, is well worth the cost if one wants to see more of the Abbey than the standard Audio Tour provides. Peter, the Verger who led my tour, was very knowledgable and went out of his way to answer questions. I chose the afternoon Verger's Tour and then stayed on for Evensong at 5:00pm. This was one of the highlights of my vacation in London!

Jaw-Dropping. The great churches and cathedrals of Europe were designed to astound and awe. Westminster Abbey does just that within moments of walking in.Aside from the spiritual nature of this place used for prayer for hundreds of years, it is a veritable who's-who of English history. Kings, queens, authors and scientists are buried (or at least memorialized) throughout the building's side chapels. Poet's Corner is a special place, with the likes of Shakespeare and Chaucer. One of the lesser-known but quite powerful corners is dedicated to the pilots who flew during the Battle of Britain.This is a must-do stop on a London visit. It is included on the London Pass.

Dripping in history. The history of England all in one place. Allow a good half a day to wander through, especially if you have an interest in English literature. If you do, head straight for Poet's Corner, you'll find all your old friends there. Downside - it's VERY expensive, much like most payable attractions in London. It is on the London Pass though, so if you have one, then it's free.

What's it like to be RICH ???. My Wife and I recently went to London for 3 days to see the sights and also walk down Memory Lane, we moved up to North Yorkshire 28 years ago and being 77 & 78 years old we thought it would be nice to revisit places that we haven't been to since that time and longer, My wife really wanted to go to The Abbey. BUT, we found out that it was £18 to go in, that's £36 for the two of us, that £36 represents 30% of my weekly income, all this to say a prayer. The last time we went together was shortly after we got married 56 years ago and it was FREE We found the price in a London Tourist Guide, We were Shocked...£16 each for St Pauls, £29.95 each for the Shard,£25 each for the Houses of Parliament Tour. Madame Taussards £30 each, and many of the other attractions that were affordable or FREE. London is for the RICH Tourists not for Low income Pensioners ..................Very disappointed, but we did enjoy the Tower of London The ONLY attraction we had the money for (£14 each off the internet)Some of these attractions belong to the people this country !!!

Stepping into history. Thats the only way I can describe my visit to this place. Every nook and corner is steeped in history. And probably every step you take you will be stepping on the remains of someone famous of long ago. At the tombs of the famous queens all I could feel was awe. You cannot come to london and not come here.

We loved it. Great history and made us feel like we were in a very special place. We took our 8 month old and it was baby, stroller friendly. To be so close to Darwin and Newton, created spiritual feelings. I recommend getting the London Pass, it helped us skip the lines and maximize our 5 days in London.

A Real Step Back in History. A must see when in London! The step back in time is truly awesome, and to see the graves, crypts, etc. of some of the most famous names in history is really awe inspiring.
Fantastic!. My husband and enjoyed completed the audio tour and found it very informative. The Abbey is very beautiful and steeped in centuries of tradition. A must for any visit to London.

Beautiful but Underwhelmed. We came here for Evensong and that was honestly all we needed. While the outside of it and history is so rich and beautiful, we were very underwhelmed with the inside. It seemed so crowded and...just not what we expected. Evensong was wonderful and it was all we needed. We didn't need to come back.

A Lot of History in One Place. This could be the best place to go to get a sense or the history of England. Incredible number of English greats buried or remember here. The greats of english history or buried here as well as being place where so much history has been made over the centuries. The whole area is beautiful with statues and memorials. It is well worth the time to take the tour and get more of the details of the history in this Abbey. It is small area and with a lot of tourists it is difficult to get around. I enjoyed the Poet's Corner as have a special interest in Chaucer. You can probably get to see all that is of interest in about an hour, so does not take too long. Using the the audio tour is also a good choice. Be sure to go to the Abbey Museum and see the exhibit of the clothing made for the Kings and Queens and the mannequins they used. Very interesting. Also, the Abbey shop has good selection of souvenirs and interesting items to buy. Downstairs of the shop you can get some nice tapestries.
History and more history. Loved the historical background and the beauty and holiness of the building. Recommend the Vergers tour. Try to end your visit around 5 p.m. for Evensong (not Weds)

Westminster Abbey. Beautiful gothic cathedral/Abbey, incredible relics, graves and stained glass windows. The only downside is the fact it costs nearly $30 US to enter (you can get in for free if you are there for worship, but I didn't see anyone doing that). It seems a bit pricey, I recall it being only about half that price a few years ago. I understand the need for upkeep, but the price is becoming prohibitive and turning many away from a truly iconic landmark in England.My average review is due to the price, not the content, which is magnificent...I hate to see others turn away from such a treasure due to the cost.

Visit Westminster Twice!. Visit twice. My sister and I visited Westminster Abbey for Evensong. It was extremely worth it and such an amazing opportunity. I would highly recommend it. Get there early in order to get good seats! However, when you attend Evensong visitors are not allowed to explore the Abbey, being that they are attending a religious ceremony. I recommend going to visit at another time to experience and explore the Abbey. I regret not going back to check it out, it is exquisite!

A place of wonders and respect. A neo-Byzantine style cathedral, covering an area of about 5,000 m2 makes it a fascinating construction. It makes you wonder how such a construction was built in the early 19th century.
The cathedral was opened in 1903.
Would love to visit the place again if I find the time when in London and dedicate more time to explore this marvel.

Sunday service in Westminster Cathedral. I visited with some American friends who were on vacation, and was so glad I did, as the building inside is spectacular and full of history as you would expect. The service was beautiful and there were confirmations taking place during this time also. To see, and more importantly hear the choristers in full voice was very special indeed. You will need to arrive early and queue as there is always a high demand for the seats. No charge is made for entrance to the service as it is an act of worship. I highly recommend that if you have the time to experience this then its not to be missed, and one you wont forget.

Evening Song at Westminster Abbey. This is a must see. Evening Song is done i believe at 4 pm and its the Westminster Abbey Choir singing a short mass. It is by far the most spiritual thing i have ever seen and heard. You sit with the choir it is truly the high light of my trip. Plan on going again this year!!

Dont expect a student discount. Only reason for not giving a 5 star review is because of the sour faced indian lady working here who did not accept my australian murdoch university student id card as suficient proof of id for being a student and insisted on charging me full price. Otherwise a beautiful abbey with many wonderful tombs and ornate carvings. Definitely had the experience tainted by the woman working here though.

Longest Line in London!. Do not be deterred by the longest line in London! I am not a history buff, but I spent my life as an English teacher, so I was fascinated by the Poets' Corner. My family, however, is much more interested in English history, and enjoyed tremendously the tales associated with the royalty buried there. Do use the taped tour....easy to use and narrated beautiful by Jeremy Irons.Loved it - and that long line moves quickly!
Beautiful but too expensive. We would have loved to go inside but the £18 ticket put us off. Amazing building, definitely a must see even if it is from the outside.

Informative, interesting and beautiful. We decided to visit Westminster Abbey on a whim after a day of sight seeing. We arrived at about four in the afternoon as the sun was going down. The architecture on the outside of the building is stunning and it truly is a design feat. Once inside I highly recommend taking an audio tour, it is very interesting and gives a brief history on some significant burial sites. After this we stayed for the 5pm service. This is a very humbling experience, it is amazing to think how much history is held in one building! Worth a visit!

Stunning historic site. We visited on a cold January afternoon when there were very few tourists and were able to look around freely and take time to read many of the inscriptions. It is very beautiful, steeped in history and atmospheric. An excellent chance to recall England's Kings and Queens as well as seeing an astonishing array of plaques commemorating famous people.

Great attraction with wonderful history. I was shown the main areas of the abbey by my guide Adolph who helpfully gave me insight into a number of interesting historical stories on the Abbey, including Ben Jonson being buried upright to save costs and Oliver Cromwell being dug up and beheaded.The Abbey is smaller than you imagine and in some areas quite crowded but it's steeped in the history of the UK and is the last resting place of so many iconic figures.The exhibition area with its desk masks and mummified figures is both ghastly and fascinating!

Awesome Evensong. We did not have time to tour the abbey but we were able to attend evensong. Even though it was a visiting choir, the music was wonderful and the whole service brought me great peace.

Too much...but a must see. If you go over Christmas, try to get in to hear the choir sing. The tickets are free, but are given out by lottery in the fall and are snatched up immediately. We started going to the website every day to see if there were any tickets surrendered, and within 3 days we had two tickets and were able to witness something very few can. Just beautiful.The abbey itself is amazing....layer upon layer of tombs and memorials. If you are easily overwhelmed, you may not want to visit. The audioguide was quite helpful.

Expensive for a visit .... Was it worth it? No, not after being in there. But unfortunately it is probable one of the must visit places.At £18-00 per head (Like €50-00 for a coulpe) it is a very expensive visit - and all you can do is walk around it inside. You can hire an audio guide, but we didn't see these till nearly finished (the crowd entering may have hidden them from our view when we went in. The lady at the ticket entrance didn't point it oiut to us either. Most places wnat to get an extra bob or two by having the audio guide, but after the entrance few I would possible not have paid for it anyway. This was not my first time in London, but it was the first time I gave into temptation to enter this sight. I will never have to do it again. And wouldn't have done it in the first place if I knew how dissapointing it would be.You will recognise a few of the names on the tomes and stones on the floors and walls, Newton, Livingstone, the Queens and Kings gone by. I would expect that the audio guide may have made it a better experience, but the entrance fee is so high it should be included in the entrance.I think it was said on the very poor leaflet that was given to me at entrance (and it was not a history guide) that thousands visit each day - so at £18 a head x 1000 equals £18000-00 a day good money if you can get it.....Not worth the visit (at that price) but unfortunately its a place that is on everyones list.
Must See. First time in London? Second, Third? No matter how many times you come to London, visiting Westminster Abbey is a must.
One of my Favorite. I so loved seeing Westminster Abbey. We went there on December 28, 2015 for a service with the choir. It was one of my favorite things I did in London.

Good interesting tour but no Photos??. you need about 2 hours to do a full tour of here. Its a big beautiful place and a must see if your in London. full of history but I don't understand y you cant take some pics.

17pounds are you kidding me!?. This is one magnificent building, full of history. We went there during reminisce and all those poppy flowers and setting at the lawn was great but when we wished to enter and see it from inside we were unpleasantly surprised, a 17 pounds for entering a church, just for get inside, no souvenirs to take with you, no guided tour, just entrance fee. I know London is expensive but almost all of attractions are free entrance or maximum 7-8 pounds for some exhibitions, I'm sorry but 17 pounds is too much for that.

Worth the price and the wait.. The first time I was in London I skipped the Abbey because I didn't want to pay the fee, but this time I did and I'm so glad I did. The entrance fee gives you access to the audio guide - pick one up and enjoy. There is so much history inside this one building. It was an amazing experience. Be warned - you are not allowed to take pictures inside. I'm not really sure why rule is necessary, but it seems to be a theme with English churches.

You have to visit this. Westminster Abbey is something you need to visit. I was there in early January so the crowds were thin. It's amazing to wander around a place that's that old with that much history.

WOW!!!!!!!!!!!!. The best sight that we visited in London. I literally walked around with my jaw hanging open. Make sure that you get one of the audio guides as it really lets you know exactly what your looking at and brings you around in a good circuit. Don't miss it!!!!!!!

Great place, even if it's another church. If you have to visit one church head here. It's the place of kings, poets, musicians anyone and everyone that has meant something in England. My kids listened intently to the wonderful recordings that lead you through. Worth the wait and the price. It's beautiful, educational and a must amongst all the things to do in London.

So much more than expected. We visited early morning in December, no queues and using our London Pass as part of visits to many other sights balances the cost.This Abbey surprised after seeing it on TV (Royal wedding) as you did not get a sense of everything else it houses. Go around the Cloisters to Chapter House, visit Poets corner, the grave of the unknown warrior, the Coronation Chair and the 5 small chapels off Lady Chapel (home of the Order of Bath) and as you walk look down to see the incredibly famous people buried beneath you. The all boy choir sings every week day, in this setting it's unrivalled. Free organ recitals are held Sundays 5:45 pm.

Expensive entrance fee. Beautiful building would have loved to go inside but at 18 pounds per person thought it was too expensive. Got some beautiful pictures of the exterior though. Worth a visit if you can justify the money.
Must do for history buffs!. The audio tour was surprisingly comprehensive and the Abbey's history and permanent residents are de rigeur for any fan of history, British or otherwise.

long lines. Beautiful building but if you're not that type of person who intrest is the hisotary you don't need to go in. The lines are always long and the ticket price is quite high and there's nothing speacial inside.

Awesome - do your homework first!. The Abbey is absolutely beautiful and the historical significance of the abbey is incredible. I did not do sufficient research before my visit and found out afterwards that I missed seeing a number of things that I regretted. People like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, and Geoffrey Chaucer are all buried hear, along with most of the old kings and queens of England. I have never been a huge history buff, but the names of these famous people all resting at the same place is incredible. The exterior of the abbey is beautiful and the inside is even more wonderful. The beautiful columns and arched ceilings are magnificent, and every trip to London should include a visit to Westminster Abbey!

wonderful abbey, wonderful atmosphere. We have been in Westminster Abbey several times, it was the first time we attended a service...how special, we felt privileged to be there, a wonderful choir and a moment of silence for yourself

Oozing With History. Our family toured Westminster Abbey as part of a Verger Tour. The Verger Tour allowed us to skip the long line for admission, you can make your appointment by calling in advance as directed by the Westminster Abbey website. There is an extra fee but it is more than worth it for the experience and to preserve your time for touring other sites. You'll love hearing the history of the Abbey and the stories of the coronations, weddings, burials in this historic church. Our Verger fully engaged the young ones in our tour group and told many stories with a great sense of humor. A must see!

A loss of words to describe.... Westminster Abbey was an "experience" not a tourist attraction as many would think. (I did prior to my visit.) It is hard to wrap your head around the architecture, considering the time period it was built in, much less the historic events and individuals that have graced the interior walls of this building over history. Beyond the historical learning this tour will provide is the surprising "spiritual feeling" that you will begin to experience once you enter into the main sanctuary. If you are religious, you will want to spend time in the private pray sanctuary. It will take you to a place of solitude like most of us have never been to before. Of all the tourist locations in London, if you could only see one, this would be the one I would recommend!

Incredible history but payment in a holy place. Fantastic incredible history, atmosphere but why the high charges to visit if you have to charge be reasonable because you are precluding people in poverty who might get something religious or otherwise from a vist. I do not believe (personal view) that a charge should be made by a holy place... Remember our Lord and the money lenders in the temple. If you can afford its prices you should go, if not I do feel sorry for you having to miss out because of exorbitant cost.
Loved the Choir. Went in for an evening service, specifically for the Choir. A unique experience which is a little more that a typical tourist rush through the Abbey.

Wow. I'll start by saying that this is literally one of the two places I've visited on Earth that have made my jaw drop with amazement. The other was visiting La Grand Place in Brussels.It's definitely recommended that if you're going to London and plan to visit a few places, check out the London Pass. It will save you some valuable coin!Seeing this place on TV is one thing, but being there and taking in the history of it all is quite another. The number of historical figures that are buried within the walls/floors is astounding, as is the attention to detail in the church itself. Just the fact that so many famous events occurred there is hard to comprehend when trying to take it all in.We didn't do the audio tour, which I'm sure was full of valuable information, but even still we spent a good hour in there just looking. It was well worth visiting. More than well worth visiting. Someone else described it as iconic, and I would agree.

Must see!. Westminster Abby is absolutely beautiful and I was shocked to find that they have multiple services each day that are open to the public. Sadly, you're not supposed to take pictures inside, but it is absolutely beautiful and the acoustics are awesome. Warning: they burn very strong incense-like stuff during the service which caused my allergies to act up. I wouldn't go to a service if your asthma is really sensitive.

Iconic . We visited here whilst we were conducting a whistle stop tour of London. I can't imagine somebody staying in London without coming to Westminster Abbey. It just oozes history. From walking around the outside taking in the Gothic architecture to exploring all the information regarding what has gone on throughout history inside you really could lose yourself for a few hours here!
Must see. This was a personal goal to see. Amazing architecture and awe inspiring. The tombs were incredible to see.
Must see in London. Did the typical audio tour here in December. Beautiful cathedral with a ton of history. Highly recommend!

History..one of the London must see places. Either you´re religious or not, take a guided tour on Westminter Abbey, with a good guide (I recommend the the Verger Tour). Cheap and without one guide you´ll not take full advantage of your visit. Advise: guided tours are, usually fully booked, so, book on the previous day, or even sooner. No photos allowed.Having done this, ...just enjoy one of the most beautiful Churches you can visit in the world. If possible, plan your visit, in order to have time to visit, also, the Houses of Parliement (on the other side), the London Eye (on the other side of the Thames)

No Photo!!!!!!!. The place is wonderful, of course, but the idea of not allowing photos is archaic. Go to the free British Museum and you can take as many amateur photos as you like. However, in the Abbey they have many staff running around chastising visitors for taking pictures. Make you feel sinful!These days everyone has a camera in their phone and they take pictures anyway. I don't see how it is any disrespect. Quite the opposite.18 £ not to take pictures?Otherwise, it is a worthwhile place to visit. Newton's grave is in the middle area. It was fun to see all the physicists' graves like Maxwell, Dirac, Joule, Herschel etc. They wouldn't mind photos.
Beautiful. The architecture is worth seeing. Also, take advantage of the audio guide (free with the London Pass). Provides really interesting history you won't get by just walking around.

Excellent! Get in line early. We got to Westminster about 30 minutes before it opened, and the line was already long. We were very glad we got there in the AM, it seemed to be less crowded. Take your time in the Abbey, its totally worth it. So much history. Make sure to get a free audio guide, it was well worth it!

Verger tour is a must. This was our 3rd visit to the Abbey and each time we've taken the Verger tour with Ben. His knowledge of the Abbey's history and his presentation skills are fantastic. The building is magnificent and the number of historical figures buried or represented there is astounding. The cost of the tour is only £5 more than the entry fee and is the best value. There are only a few tours per day and limited to 20 people per tour, so best to call a day ahead of your visit to the information desk and get on the list. You still need to wait in line and buy an entry ticket so arrive well in advance of your tour starting time.In addition to the insights of the Verger guides, you get access to the choir stalls and the chapel of Edward the Confessor. These are very memorable.If you are touring London, don't miss Westminster Abbey. If you visit the Abbey, don't miss the Verger tour.

One of the world's holy places. There is the Pantheon in Rome, Notre Dame in Paris, or St. Patrick's in New York, but none really compare to the sense of true awe that is Westminster Abbey. This is the place of coronations and marriage, funerals and average Sunday Christian Worship of the Who's Who of England. Not as large as St. Paul's, it is big on the names on its stones. Here is a chance to walk among the wise and famous. We suggest taking a tour as the best way of seeing it, although everywhere you turn there is glimpse into the glorious past. Even an atheist will sense that this church is special. No photos, lots of people, do not be rushed.

One of the Grand Dames of London. This historic Anglican Church contains the actual bodies or memorials to so many of the greats of British History. It is so large that it is hard to gage where you are physically within the church at any given time. The Gothic architecture is, however, truly glorious.

Impressive. We arrived fairly early, which was a good thing as the line was long when we left. What surprised us was the fee, which we thought was quite steep to visit the insude of a cathedral. Notre Dame in Paris is free. However, the tour of the Abbey was worth it. We alrleady knew of the many notables besides royalty who were buried there, but were still awed by the sight of so many who were honored and/or buried there. We were glad we took the time to take the tour.

Beautiful!. This is a beautiful, historical treat! So much to see & learn about the history of the church, monarchy & hardships suffered through the ages. It is also a place of great beauty & peace. The audio guide was really helpful & informative & the architecture of the building is stunning - well worth a visit.

wooow. All I can say Is that its marvelous the altar, main floor, court yard, the tombs are all incredible I suggest getting a London pass once you get to the airport or get here early because the line will extend around the block come noon.( if you get the pass you can go here, tower of London, I believe the London eye and the ferry ride down the thames)

Beautiful building full of history!. Our family enjoyed visiting Westminster Abbey. It is a beautiful building and many famous historical figures are buried here. The audio guide was good. Go early to beat the crowds. This is one of the must-see sights of London.

Well worth the price of the entrance ticket. If i were you I'd recommend going on a guided tour around here (londonwalks does a great one).I was gobsmacked at the history and how big this place was. Cant believe it took me 7 years of living in London to visit but now is in my top 5 recommendations of places to go.Top 3 in terms of ones you have to pay for.

interesting but little bit expensive. my wife and I visited he abbey in December, we spent about two hours there. It was interesting at first but later it was repeated and becomes less interestingfew things:1. little but expensive 19 pound2. the audio guide is good

It's one of must to see list. if you are a history maniac, you gotta to visit Westminster Abbey. It's not just a church. It's full of history 8read: England's history). What I wasn't expecting, it was such an honor to find out that Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin were buried inside the church. Yes the great "Isaac Newton" with his "apple" discovery. and it's the church for Coronation Day and Wedding Day for the Royal Family. The entrance ticket is a little bit expensive for about 18 Pounds. Well I guess, they need the money for the maintenance.
Who's who of England . That's who's buried here. Many interesting tombs, plaques, history all here. Come early as the queue starts bf it opens. There's a lot to c here so make it thru the key points.

Stunning - both inside and out.. This is probably one of the most stunning buildings in the entire UK.While the Abbey is simply beautiful beyond words, the entrance ticket at apx. 30US$ leaves you with a very bitter taste. Seriously? Does the Royal family really need all the tourists' cash to keep the Abbey in tip-top shape? Hardly.Still, once you get over the crazy fee, enjoying the inside of the Abbey is very easy.Simply put - it's a true gem and it can give a fair fight to bigger churches and cathedrals around the world.Even if you decided not to get in, take your time in appreciating the Abbey from the outside, instead.Highly recommended!

Magnificient and full of 'little' stories. Architecture, History, Science, Litterature, you choose your reason for visiting. Including Robert Langdon trail. Our family saw, The Tudors, Elizabeth on screen, we wanted to see the real places. This is an amazing place. Audio guide is available. Photos are not permitted inside (too bad). Saw the Christmas decoration to give an extra dimension to the place. To be seen, possibly more than once.

Wonderful Building. This is one of the best places to visit in the UK. It's steeped in history and occasion. It might be full of tourists but it's easy to close your mind to the clamour and feel of the great atmosphere. Always worth a visit, every time!!

Stunning. I absolutely love Westminster Abbey. It is beautiful, full of history and has gives you this feeling that you are part of something more. I would recommend getting there two hours before it clothes, 1 hour to stand in line and 1 hour to tour the Abbey.

Few Places More Beautiful & Fascinating. We all enjoyed this headset self-guided tour. Fascinating and overwhelming to consider all that has transpired within these walls. An absolute must-see for any tourist in London.

Tip for buying tickets inline. Truly amazing place. A must do in London.A bit tedious for a younger child but there's lots to look at and a children's activity book to try to keep their attention.If you buy tickets online from Visit Britain make sure you print the voucher. They will not accept it on your phone or tablet's screen.If you forget to print your voucher then there is a Snappy Snaps a 10 minute walk up Victoria Street. You can email it to them and they'll print it for a small fee.A bit ridiculous in this day and age that they require the voucher to be printed but there you go!

A monument full of history. Westminster Abbey is full of history. There was a long queue but worth it. The audio tour can be very useful. Unfortunately, you are not allowed to take pictures. Westminster Abbey is a full functioning church and it would not be appropriate to take pictures anyway. However, you may take pictures of the cloisters.

Get there early!. Westminster Abbey is gorgeous and worth the wait if you are into seeing old churches and religious artifacts. The line gets long pretty early--we showed up at 11am and it was already curving around the block--so try and get there when it opens. To the left of the doors is a beautiful chapel (St. Margaret's) which is free. It's darling and worth a walk around after heading in to Westminster Abbey.

Lifeless. A gallery of rogues are buried here. It was such a disappointment to me. None of the light and spiritual energy you feel at St. Paul's Cathedral or Notre Dame in Paris. I'm from the UK and I have to also say the staff that confronted us here were surly and downright rude, making us stand in line in a pouring rain. No politesse, no class, no compassion, no respect. Go somewhere where you will feel the joy and conviviality of the British people but please, please skip this godless lifeless tomb.

Just amazing!. This was my third visit to Westminster Abbey over the past 20 years, and it was just as fabulous this time as before. The history, the beauty, the feeling of being almost overwhelmed by the splendor is hard to describe. Take advantage of the recorded audio tour -- it's included with the admission and is very informative; not fully comprehensive, but a nice overview. Don't miss it.

One Place Not To Miss in London. By far, the most interesting place in London. So many famous people buried there and the building itself is beyond marvelous. It is so big it is hard to imagine people actually building it. So many events have happened there too, over the centuries, that you feel like you might have been to them. I wanted to stay longer than our tour lasted, but maybe next time we're in London.

history and more history :). This is a must in London. It is covered by the London Pass (recommended). Get the audio tour which it comes with your ticket and walk through many years of history - it is very well organized. Coronation of the Queen and the wedding of Kate and William took place here. It was worth it! Too bad you cant take pictures inside but I enjoyed learning about the history of England.

The most overwhelming historical monument in London or perhaps any other city. I've been to the Vatican, been to Venice, been to the Forbidden City - but it's still Westminster Abbey which retains the single most powerful impression on me as an amateur historian. It's simply overwhelming, too much, to fully grasp the enormity of the history and the importance of this particular building, from the actual events that have taken place there which are too many to list, to the royalty actually buried there under your feet, to the poets and novelists who proudly take their place among the monarchs. It's not so much a 'church' as a living, breathing testament to the history - both tragic and glorious - of Britain. Yes, it's expensive to get in, but surely worth every penny, and as others have said, if you go at Evensong you get even more of an impression of the Abbey's ongoing importance.

Spectacular!. My boyfriend and I were lucky enough to attend Christmas Eve mass at the Abbey, and it was an experience that I will never forget! The event was ticketed and sold out quite quickly, and we were so excited to have been a part of the mass. The sheer size of the abbey is breathtaking. It is absolutely immense...not your average parish. It terms of the history, you can't even begin to imagine the events that place has seen. Not only has it hosted hundreds of coronations, weddings, and funerals, but it also serves as the burial site of some of the most influential minds of the past hundreds of years. It is an absolute must see, I cannot stress that enough! The earlier you go, the better to avoid the crowds. Keep in mind too that it is only open for services on Sunday, although seeing the abbey for its main use is a wonderful way to get the full experience.Happy travels!

Classical gem. Pro tip - no photography inside. Yeah, it costs some money to visit (duh). But can you imagine the upkeep costs? Pro tip - get the audio guide and you can wander around or follow a tour path and learn all about the fascinating history. So many cool things to see here: religious artifacts, awesome crypts, architecture, etc. A must visit for London, it's worth every penny to experience.

History and beauty - all in one place and worth the admission price. Really recommend you do this. It costs about 18 pound to get in but it is really worth it. Do the audio because it is free and it really gives a great history lesson. You can feel like you have walked in the footsteps of Kate and Wills as they got married - plus been there for the coronation of the Queen. It is actually much smaller than you might expect - but because of the history it takes about an hour to do it justice. Of all the tours that cost in London - this was my favourite.

Midnight Mass. I attended the first eucharist of christmas at the Abbey which was a lovely experience. I arrived at 10.35, shortly after the doors opened. There was a very large queue but the Abbey staff (all very pleasant and welcoming) were organised about getting us inside quickly. Once (free) tickets were checked, seating inside was unallocated (apart from the choir reserved for VIPs). We sat in the nave which seemed to be favoured by most of the congregation. However, I understand from friends who had been before that the sound of the choir is actually better balanced with the organ if you sit in the transept (and choosing the transept also gives you the chance to walk through and see more of this stunning church). Bear in mind that there is no public transport in London late on Christmas Eve. You may be able to get there by bus or tube, but it's a walk or taxi home (unless you have a car and there is easy parking nearby on Christmas Eve at this time). In summary, the service was very nice, the choir is fantastic, the church itself is just amazing, and it was very nice that all the clergy were outside at the end to greet the vast congregation. I'm not religious at all, but I must say I left with a very good impression of the Church of England. Well done Westminster Abbey.

See it for free.. It is a beautiful abbey,but, very expensive to get into and depending on the time of the year,extremely busy. So,if you are on a budget I recommend going to Evensong or Sunday Services. You can still the beauty of the church,relax and listen to some amazing choral music. Downside is no photographs.

A rich experience. The Abbey had so many things in there that you would want to go through it again but with a price. We had to guided tour with headphones and it was very fascinating to hear about the different sections of the Abbey. No pictures allowed but it's understandable.
Excellent . The audio tour was well done. Just a really cool place to wall around. Shame that photography is not allowed, but I guess that's to be expected.

History-lovers' paradise!. There's so much to see here. It is a little pricey to get in, but worth it if you have the time to spare. Resist the temptation to follow the audio guide religiously and take a good look around. There's something for everyone!

Take the verger tour. We enjoy the self-guided tour with headphones, but you really should take the guided tour with a Verger. Interestingly, I've had the same Verger, "Benjamin" for both of my tours, 10 years apart. It very much adds meaning and lets the history of the place sink in.

FLOWER DISPLAY. I visited here with a friend whilst the flower show was on display inside it was a fabulous experience with the lovely scent of flowers to add to the atmosphere. I really enjoyable visit beautiful suitable all ages.

Fascinated. The gothic church was first on my 'to do' list. I was mesmerized by the entire history, weddings, burials... Darwin, Shakespeare, Milton...the list is endless. One should really spend time inside it. Impressive and traditional. Loved the history of the coronations, the walk around the entire abbey, the view from outside, everything basically.

HIstory, Timeless...and more History. This place is a mind blower. I believe there are over 3,000 people buried at Westminster. Including King's of England from many many centuries ago (like 1300's!). Famous authors, Queens, Prince and Princesses...it's all here. The line may look longish, but it moves rather quickly actually. I think anyone in London should see it. It's pretty wild to see all the history. Entry includes free audio guide.
A real masterpiece of London. One of the most important and full of history place in London, a real masterpiece in this beautiful city. Other words would be wasted.
Fantastic Architectural Building!. Great Building, fantastic architecture and always busy!! Shame we didnt get to do the tour due to restricted opening hours!
Not to be missed.. One of the highlights of our trip to London. The architecture, the history, the weddings I have seen, and to finally be here! Take you time, take the otur! It's worth it!

ABSOLUTELY FACINATING. Westminster Abbey is a huge Gothic church in Westminster, London, and located near to the Palace of Westminster. It is one of the most notable religious buildings in the UK and the traditional place of English coronations and also a significant burial site for national figures. Without a doubt the Abbey is impressive - the architecture is beautiful and it’s just dripping in history which makes it even more enthralling. My wife and I visited the Abbey (despite the inordinate cost to get it! - £18 per person) and found it very special. There is so much history and the commentary on the Abbey-provided audio guide was extremely useful. The audio tour is very detailed and tells everything you would ever want to know. You are not allowed to take photographs whilst in the Abbey, which is unfortunate but, perhaps, understandable. All-in-all a wonderful, iconic place to walk around and absolutely fascinating – and, remember, it’s still a working place of worship, with services everyday.

A wonderful place any time of year. This is one of the "must see's" of London not only for it's history, it's royal weddings, tombstones and stories but for the architecture and structure itself; you could stand anywhere on site look up and be awestruck. And the weather plays no part as , for me, the colder and duller it is the more atmospheric it is. If you're planning a journey always check that there's no ceremony or Royal visit on your day which happens frequently and will mean much of the Abbey is closed before, during and just after each visit. I taught at Westminster Abbey for many years so I got to experience the Abbey on a weekly basis (hence my warning about closures during events) and I can honestly say that every single time I arrived I'd notice something new, something different something I'd not noticed before. It's fascinating every time you'll visit but one visit simply won't be enough.

Worth seeing, pay attention to hours. The Abbey closes early so be aware of the hours.
Beautiful, historic and somber place.
The amount of history in this place is awesome!

Tips for the best Westminster Abbey experience. Westminster Abbey is an absolute must-see for any art, architecture or history lover. Here are my tips for your first Westminster Abbey experience:- Don't rush through the first section of the Abbey because you won't be coming back to it later. You buy your tickets at the North entrance, walk inside and immediately you're given an audio guide. The first chapter of the audio guide kind of rushes you into the nave. But make sure to take your time in the first part of the Abbey because it has some amazing art and you won't return to it later in your self-guided tour. Dictate your own pace through the abbey - don't let the audio guide rush you through.- The Abbey is pretty expensive to visit (£18 per person) but well worth the price. If you absolutely cannot pay the £18, you can still see the beautiful nave by going to a service or one of the Abbey's many free events. In addition to doing the audio tour, I went to a 30 minute organ recital on Sunday night (check the online schedule) and it was excellent! Hearing such a masterful musician play the world class instrument inside the beautiful and resonant space was well worth my time! Make sure and queue up outside the abbey at the west entrance 30+ minutes in advance.- To warn you – there is no photography or recording inside the abbey. Photography is allowed in the cloisters and garden.- Plan on allowing yourself at least 1.5 hours to look around.

An Essential visit for a London trip. i went on a weekday and arrived about 11 so maybe that's way there were only a few people ahead of me in the queue. There's great photos to take outside of the amazing Gothic architecture but it's a shame that as with so many historic buildings that you cannot take pictures inside as there are so many monuments and structures to remember. There is a specific route to take around the building ( all ground floor) with a hand held audio guide included although I'm the type that could have done with extra literature on many of the tombs and plaques as I enjoy history. Toilets are towards the end of the route but the many staff will open up the cordons to let you through if like me you can't wait that long ! Don't forget that this is a place of worship so quietness is encouraged as services do take place as you are slowly drifting along. I will definitely be revisiting once I have researched more about Henry III, ELizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots etc

Westminster Abbey. I was really excited to see Westminster Abbey because of my interest in Queen Elizabeth I, and because it was where Princess Diana's funeral was held. It was very interesting to walk around. I did an audio tour so that I could wander around the abbey at my own pace. I was also excited to see Charles Dickens' grave. It was also the location for the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's wedding.Photos are not allowed inside the Abbey.

Recommended to visit. Go during a weekday preferably not during summer because the queue is outrageous. I only managed to get in on my second trip during autumn. I wasn't disappointed. Do get the audio guide because it will help you learn about the history and each chapel's significance. It is a very beautiful and grand church, you will enjoy the visit.

Beautiful Peaceful Experience. We had a peaceful experience this Church was so amazing a wonderful beautiful place the stained glass windows the masterful wood work . Take the audio tour it's free you can take your time enjoy all the wonderful history you will love this Church !

Fantastic!. I am so glad I finally got the chance to visit inside Westminster Abbey. There is much to see and I recommend you get a headset for more information. If I didn't have one, there is no way I would have know who was buried there and their significance. The staff members were very helpful as well. One of them noticed my William & Mary college hooded sweatshirt and told me where I could find where both monarchs are buried.

Beautiful.. This attraction was very, very crowded, however, everything in London was very crowded. So worth the wait. We had 2 kids between the ages of 10 and 17 and they also liked it. So much to see!

Expensive to see but worth the history within its doors. We visited London in March and one of the first places we decided to visit was Westminster Abbey. It is NOT cheap to get into. However, the history inside its walls makes it worth it including the historical figures interred there. It is a magnificent structure architecturally and there is so much to take in it can be overwhelming. I remember seeing this Abbey on television during Princess Diana's funeral service and couldn't help but remember that as we entered its doors. It has seen many happy and sad occasions and if its walls could talk what a story they could tell.

Worth a little wait, lots of history.. Wow! What a place to see. I loved Westminster Abby. I got there about an hour prior to opening and only had a small line prior my arrival. Maybe 50 people. By opening time, the line stretched around the block. My first bit of advice, GET THERE EARLY! Lots kings and queens buried here. So much history. It's just amazing and like going back in a time warp. My only negatives is that no photography or video allowed inside. There is security everywhere and they watch people with cameras pretty closely. Don't know what happens if you get caught. Once the crowds build inside, it's kind of hard to take pictures anyway because there are so many people in the way. Allot about 3-4 hours to see it all. £18.00 or about $25.00 for admission and for me it was worth every penny. If you like history, it's a must see.

Historic monument . westminster abbey a beautiful building with a rich history. Take your time to see it and study its architecture. The audio system that they provide is very informative and will guide you through all parts of the abbey.

Despite the ridiculous fee, it’s still worth it. Westminster Abbey is a must see for anyone in London. The original building was established in the 11th century by King Edward the Confessor although has been changed over the centuries. It is built in a gothic style and for anyone who has visited other famous England cathedrals (ie Salisbury, York Minster etc) you will find it externally quite underwhelming. However, despite what you think it is certainly worth the ridiculous 17 pound fee to get in. Internally it possesses some of Englands greatest treasures, as well as the resting places of its most famous & influential including most monaches from Henry III to George II, Sir Issac Newton, Charles Darwin , Dickens, etc. There is no photo’s allowed inside, which to be honest is probably a good thing. It does get quite crowded, although people push through at a decent rate. There is normally a queue outside, although once again this pushes by at a reasonable pace. It’s a ‘must do’ for anyone in London, regardless of whether you have been to other famous England cathedrals before. Given yourself 2-2.5 hours.

Came for evensong service. Westminster Abbey is very beautiful architecturally and it is, without doubt, filled with a LOT of significant history and many important figures have been buried here. I came for evensong services and was honestly a little underwhelmed. It was a nice service, but I thought the evensong at St. Paul's Cathedral was much more beautiful. HOWEVER, the Abbey itself is breathtaking and is definitely a must-see--whether you take the guided tour or you just come for evensong services. The next time that I'm in London, I will definitely take the guided tour to get the full experience.

So peaceful and meditative.. Walking through The Abbey was a very special way to spend an hour. There is so much history and having Jeremy Irons providing the commentary on the self- guided audio was delightful.I returned later in the week to participant in Holy Communion which was the highlight of my 5 days in London. The service was only 30 minutes and even though in such a large church with onlookers it was very easy to get into a reflective and prayerful state to participate in the holy sacrament. Tip 1: the self-guided audio tour is free so just do it.Tip 2: if your are a believer attend Holy Communion. It is very special and will be a moment I remember for a long time.

Massive place of worship. Westminster Abbey has to be on your "things to do " if you go to London. It's huge. it was great to actually visit the place where all the ceremonies take place. Although we didn't go in due to time schedule, the walk around the perimeter was just as good. Be prepared to que if want to go in though.
This is great fun!. It's really fun to walk around and see all the memorials of the rich and famous. If you are from the USA, we simply don't have these kinds of churches.

The hieght of English history. The queue was long before it opened but it was worth the wait to get in. Imagining all that had transpired in this building over the centuries was incredible. I felt from an architectural standpoint it was not as impressive as Ely Cathedral or St. Paul's not to mention the ones in Italy BUT there is no denying the providence and significance of this structure. Worth a visit for sure.

Schedule time for security line. We made reservations for the verger guided tour of Westminster Abbey and arrived about 35 minutes before the tour was scheduled but the security line took 50 minutes to get through. So the tour was long gone by the time we got through the line. We had called ahead of time and told that the line would only take about 15 minutes. This was in late November--so not the big tourist season. My advice is if you want to take a guided tour arrive way ahead of time. They do have hand-held recorded guides which are very nice. The cathedral is of course absolutely magnificent.

History becomes reality. I wasn't thrilled at the idea of visiting as I thought it would be dark and dull. Quite the opposite! It is well lit and the staff are very welcoming and helpful. We went straight to the front of a very long queue thanks to having granny with us aged 90! You need stamina to get the best out of this visit. We skimmed over much of it just gawping at the amazing number of plaques and burial spots of lots of historical figures...Darwin, Gladstone, Kings and queens etc. the most moving part for me was the tomb of the unknown soldier. I loved the words on the tomb. However, the tomb that really amazed me was that of Elizabeth 1st. Her face is actually her likeness as it was taken from her death mask.The stained glass is fantastic and you can stop for prayers/ silent reflection at various times. The hand held interactive commentary was very useful although Jeremy Irons' voice did start to grate after a while. When one of the guides found out it was our first visit and that granny had a special birthday - he spent time showing us some personal photos of the wedding cake sent to all the cathedral staff after Kate and Will's wedding...a lovely touch.The loos are fab and the café was fine - although it is underground. Hot chocolate was good.I was initially irritated that I couldn't take photos - but then relieved as it meant you had to really look at everything and absorb the atmosphere instead of clicking away. I would not have liked it to be any more crowded - so go early. Also save up! Cost us £66 for 4 and that was despite a student pass and a senior ticket ( ouch!)
Great. Listening to Jeremy irons on the commentary was a great way to experience the history of the abbey. Well worth a visit. Takes about 60-90minutes

Beautiful, but no pictures.. The Westminster Abbey is beautiful from both the inside and out. The audio tour is very detailed and tells you more than you would ever want to know. Personally I think the entry fee is very high at 18 euro. Although there is much to see, if I pay that much I feel I should be entitled to take pictures, but there are ZERO pictures allowed once you enter.

Abbey of Sorrows. Spent two to three hours visiting the tombs of kings and queens of England and other lords & ladies. Spent more time at the shrine of Edward the Confessor , found this to be a peaceful and spiritual episode. But the old and decaying tombs with ancient graffiti scraped on their shiny worn stone induced nothing but melancholy in me.Odd to view the tombs of Mary Tudor and her half sister Elizabeth 1 side by side in death , as in life they differed fundamentally in religious outlook. If you have an interest in the history of Britain, you will find this a fascinating place, my only negative is the fact that in the side chapels so little written information on the lesser titled lords & ladies, it would help because few of us can read the Latin inscriptions.

Interesting. Myself and the missus went for a wander around the halls etc of the abbey (mass was on so couldnt get in to the abbey itself). Found it to be very interesting reading all teh headstones og the people that are interred there. Reminds me of Hogwarts

Verger tour made this fantastic!. Just after our paid entry, we noticed that for an extra 5 pounds each, we could go on a tour conducted by one of the Abbey's Vergers. This delightful man made the tour one of the most enjoyable, entertaining and informative tours I have ever been on. Not only this, but the calm and friendly manner in which he told people (either on his tour or not) 1.to put the lens cap on their camera, turn off their mobile phone - because photos weren't allowed; or2 while people ( hanger ons) might like to join the tour, this group was full but others were welcome to join another group by going and signing up; and3 responded/ assisted others as required as "our group" weaved our way through the Abbey.A the end of the whole entertaining 90 minutes my companion "suggested" to our delightful leader that she may have seen him before......... At the end of the last Royal Wedding after the official TV broadcast had finished, the cameras continued rolling and there the cameras found a verger doing cartwheels down the aisle. Was it our man? "Yes! Because everything had gone so perfectly" and he "felt like showing how happy he was."In summary, a wonderful visit to Westminister Abbey made perfect by the verger tour.

Beyond expectations. We popped in for a quick look around and left almost 2 hours later! The Abbey is huge, with so much to see. We did the audio guide tour which was fascinating. We were blown away by the size and beauty of the Abbey as a whole and amazed by the history contained within its walls. Of course the building looked quite different actually being there to photos and television coverage I've seen, being far more impressive and beautiful in reality. The gardens and cloisters would be lovely to explore further on a warm day. Although there were a large number of visitors, our viewing wasn't affected. Make sure you see this beautiful church.

Impressive but too Crowded.. Without a doubt the Abbey is impressive! The Gothic architecture is beautiful and the abbey is dripping in history which makes it even more fascinating. But photos are not permitted which was very disappointing. Another major drawback to visiting the Abbey was the crowds. It was so packed with people, that at times it was impossible to appreciate what the Abbey had to offer!

Very worthwhile visit. I am a born and bred Londoner and hadn't been to The Abbey for many years ,so had a trip recently. There was a short queue but weep organised. An audio machine is included in the price and is well worth taking. The age of some of the tombs is staggering and Poets corner fascinating for the variety of names.I would highly recommend this London site.
MUST VISIT. The ceiling of the Lady Chapel is absolutely magnificent. It's take my breath away. Highly recommended visit!

Absolute stunning . Loved the choral session at Westminster Abbey. The architecture has been spectacular, and I really loved the historical value of the place!! Would recommend it to everyone visiting London or the Big Ben.
Very interesting - inspirational setting!. I never knew that the Abbey had chapels all around it and the history is immense - well worth a visit !

Absolutely Worth It. A couple of weeks ago, I had the opportunity to go inside Westminster Abbey with my sister. As soon as I stepped in, I knew I had made the right decision. While Westminster Abbey looks breathtaking from the outside, the inside is even more incredible. For me, it was mind-boggling to see the graves of the likes of Isaac Newton and Charles Dickens. Not to mention how cool it was to see the place where Prince William and Kate Middleton got married, and where Princess Diana's funeral was. I highly recommend buying a ticket and touring the inside--if you go later in the evening it will only take you about an hour and a half to get through it all (5:00 is a good time on a weekday). You can avoid the crowds that way. I also recommend picking up the free audio guide, because it takes you on a complete tour of Westminster Abbey, and informs you of a variety of interesting facts. The coolest part of the tour is at the end, where the Coronation Chair is on display. Hard to imagine so many royals have been crowned on that exact chair.

Well worth it. For this time of year I would suggest going mid week & arriving mid afternoon, no crowds. Of course there are people; its London after all. But you still need to allow a good 3+ hours. Magnificent Abby architecturally & seeing the crypts of Edward the Long Shanks as well as Mary Queen of Scotts and the almost overlooked Anne of Cleves was moving.

Absolutely Gorgeous!. If I could make one recommended stop while you are in London, this would be it. Whether you love history, architecture, churches, or beauty in general, this is a sight to be seen. If you want to go inside you will want to check the hours in advance as they are limited, but there were many people quite happy to simply behold exterior. I would highly recommend walking the neighborhood when you are done as there are several other attractions close by- it's well worth it!

Gorgeous even with jet lag. This was my husband and I's first stop after arriving from the U.S. on our first ever transatlantic flight. We were exhausted, grumpy, disoriented, and hungry and we still were awed and inspired by this incredible abbey. Every room is gorgeous, every step laced with history. I only wish we had come on a day when we didn't feel like zombies so we could truly appreciate everything this place has to offer. If we return to London, this will definitely be a stop once again.

Stunning to see and visit. As you enter the Abbey you are welcomed in person. You get a free audio tour. I paid 5 pounds extra to go on a Verger guided tour (available twice a day). It was fun, and took 90 minutes, but if you want to spend less time or more time, then the audio tour is best. No photos are allowed in the Abbey, but you can take them in the cloisters which are the next step. It is worthwhile to go there as there are memorials to Halley, Cook and so on. The shop is really good.
Amazing. One of the most beautiful churches in the world. An amazing building with incredible works of art which is also a walk through British history.

Must see....absolutely incredible!. Simply amazing from start to finish. The luminaries from history buried here makes visiting worthwhile. The beautiful architecture is breath taking. I am certain that visit here is a must and will top your list of "glad we went here" while in London.

Expensive...but worth it?!. Extremely interesting and FILLED with history, but also somewhat limited in scope and extremely expensive when compared to the other landmarks! Definitely has to be on the docket for a visit to London though!

Gives you a different feel..... The building houses the country's rich heritage, amazing architecture and loads of historical stories. You can opt to take a self-guided tour or follow their tour guide. There are many interesting icons, that you will be amazed with.No photography though therefore your best memory is what you see...Opening hours are subjected to change, so it's advisable to check the website.Two famous scientist is commemorated there too, but a Singaporean, another prominent figure there is Sir Stamford Raffles.Worth visiting the place...

The Verger tour is worth the extra cost!. I visited Westminster Abbey six years ago and didn't take the verger tour. I regretted it so was determined to do it this trip. This tour is 90 minutes and cost an additional 5 pounds on top of the entrance fee, but you learn more on the tour and get to go a few more places that you are not allowed access to unless on the tour.

Guide was terrible. In additional to a hefty entrance fee I paid an extra 5BP for a 'verger' guide. She had been a guide for a little over one year. I expected that, like a high quality museum - i.e. the Metropolitan in NYC - the guides took a course on the Abbey, knew all about it, passed a test, then became a guide (verger) This woman was hopeless, It was pathetic to watch he unable to answer the most rudimentary questions about this place. After the 'tour' was over, I went to one of the vicars and asked him a few questions which were beautifully answered. Ridiculous and annoying. Otherwise, of course the Abbey would get 5 stars.
Expensive but supreme. Absolutely amazing!! Kings and queens tombs as well as all the british poets and writers' you can think of. Simply mesmerizing

Visit twice -- once to tour, once to attend a service. Westminster Abbey offers visitors two completely different experiences; try to take in both. The tour is a fascinating timeline of British history, politics, music, and literature told through the Abbey's monuments. After you've done that, return again to attend one of the daily sung worship services. It's when the Abbey is serving its intended purpose -- as a place of worship -- that it really comes to life. On this visit, we attended the daily 5pm Choral Evensong. The monuments are largely off-limits before and after services so it doesn't replace the tour experience, it complements it. If you're fortunate enough to be in London in mid-October, the annual Edwardtide National Pilgrimage is the ultimate way to experience the Abbey from a spiritual perspective. You approach the visit as a pilgrim rather than a tourist. It's well worth it if you ever have the opportunity to attend. You can find details on the Abbey web site.
Is it worth the money though?. Interesting but not as good as St Pauls cathedral. Not sure it's worth the money. Some history but nothing spectacular.

Verger tour is a Must for History Buffs. With your entrance ticket to Westminster, you get a free audioguide, which is very generous because a lot of other places make you pay extra for that. Surprisingly, Westminster seemed smaller than I thought, but that didn't take away from the grandeur of it. It was relatively crowded, but not unmanageable. The Verger tour was an additional fee (I think 5£). The group was myself, my husband and another person. So we definitely had a very individualized tour. At first, I thought we were moving so fast through the church, but he told us that with our ticket, we could go back through, even with an audioguide. The nice thing about the tour is that it is very informative. We saw a lot of interesting architectural features that we wouldn't have seen on our own. We also heard his personal stories about the royal wedding and other events he's been a part of. The best part was getting access to Edward the Confessor's tomb, which the general admission ticket doesn't let you see.

Absolutely breathtaking!. Amazing sculptures and monuments! This is a MUST SEE in London! My favorite part was the literary area!I was a bit amazed that the Coronation Chair was so... umm... blah? I mean - I certainly would have thought that it would have been much more ornate.

EVERYONE SHOULD VISIT HERE. This is a really fascinating way of spending a day. When you have entered at the North door, you take a handset and a map leaflet. Follow the numbers carefully and take your time.This is far far more than religion, it is part of the heritage of one of the greatest nations on earth. Certainly you will visit an incredibly beautiful building that took hundreds of years to build, treading some worn steps that were trodden over 1000 years ago. You will realise the scale and extent of British history that is far too great to describe here.This is utterly inspirational and should be compulsory for everyone!

A Must See When In London. Nice to appreciate in person what you see on the television during important ceremonies. The building architecture is amazing as is the endless list of historical people buried there. Some of the tombs are quite spectacular and go back a long long way. Nice to see a variety of languages catered for in the available information headsets so most visitors and tourists are covered. Definitely one of the must do attractions when visiting London and so close to the other Westminster sights which can take up your day quite easily

Loads of History. Impressive building and thank goodness they give you an audio tour as there is so much to see. Look for the numbers and listen closely. I loved the small things, like how warn out the stone steps are from hundreds of years worth of feet walking along, or the exquisite details on the tombs.

Lots of amazing history!. If you're a huge history nerd like myself then Westminster Abbey is heaven. So many amazing historical figures buried there. The guide was great & very informative. I highly recommemd visiting it if you're in London.

Westminster Abbey. Took off on our own to tour Westminster Abbey in a small group. The line was long but moved steadily. Once inside, was given a headset to listen to and travel throughout the area according to the map. Beautiful sculptures and artifacts. Christian service was on a regular basis so you could take advantage of the worship while on tour.

Exhilarating experience-must go place. Churches never sound like much fun, but Westminster Abbey is a treasure cove full of interesting information and the list of famous people that have been buried here is immense-Charles Darwin, Jane Austen, many of the Kings and Queens of Britain to name but a few. You need at least two hours to complete the full circuit of the Church properly, but when we were there the queue pretty smoothly and it was the summer holidays so I'm sure on a regular, cold day in December the queue will be rather short. Be prepared though-inside it's amazing!

Breathtaking. Westminster Abbey is right up there with some of the best churches in the world. It is beautiful and ornate and has so much history in it! The only thing that is bad is you can't take pictures inside.
Awesome!. Westminster Abbey is breathtaking! Amazing architecture, unbelievable upkeep, incredible history. The staff were very friendly and helpful.

Expensive, but excellent. Surprisingly interesting. I'm not a lover of churches or museums, in fact I dislike being in many churches. However this one is so richly filled with history. It's a one-off. Do go, you won't be disappointed.

Majestic Place!. Beautiful architecture, just across the street from the Parliament Buildings. This is the place where every King/Queen has been crowned since 1066. A lot of famous people have been buried or comemorated here, like Jane Austin, Geoffrey Chauser, Winston Churchill & Charles Darwin to name a few. You need 2-3 hours for this site since there seems to be lineups to get in and it's quite large. Also, I recommend you take the audio tour otherwise you will feel lost. You cannot take any pictures inside the Abbey but there are several great souvenir books to choose from in the gift shop. Great place to visit.

Believe it or not, it was a great visit for kids!. The Abbey has done a great job including kids in the visit. They have a kids scavenger hunt where they receive a prize in the end. It allowed for a wonderful visit for mom and dad and the kids were excited to learn about the Abbey and all its history.

Awe inspiring architecture and history. Don't miss Evensong. Whatever else you do in London, you must go to Westminster Abbey. And you need to pay for the tour, worth every dime.For sheer historical importance and sense of awe, nothing compares.Read the placques on the walls and get a sense of the sacrifice and scope of the British empire. See the tombs and reflect on over a thousand years of history.And then stay for Evensong and contemplate the divine and your place in the cosmos.
Westminster Abbey. a treasure , very historical & lovelyi like so much we take many photos therea piece of gold under the sun .....................................

Breathtaking. Majestic, unbelievable, absolutely stunning.I had seen it on the news so many times that I couldn't believe my eyes when I was finally there. It is one of the "must-visit" places in London. The history of the place is fascinating. I strongly recommend to purchase the audio guide.

Dont Miss this!. Westminster Abbey, located near the Houses of Parliament, is more a historical site than a religious site. Since 1066 every royal coronation, with the exception of Edward V and Edward VIII has taken place in this church.

Beautiful site. My family and I visited London in November 2014 and enjoyed seeing the major sites including Westminster Abbey. The architecture is quite beautiful. We did not have a tour due to time constraints but will do so when we return to the area in the future.

Absolutely Fascinating. I guess I was a bit uncultured on what the Westminster Abbey was...I thought it was just a large cathedral. I was blown away by the crypts and burials inside. Absolutely incredible to be in a place where kings and queens from a 1000 years ago rest in peace. Some other very famous people are buried there. Won't say who, you have to go to find out yourself. Well worth the time and cost, which was not that expensive considering.

Highly recommend. Being able to see Westminster Abbey in person was a dream come true for me. To be there in person where so much history has been played out was such a special experience. The complimentary audio guides were very nice to have too as it not only told what the history was and what rooms where what, but also acted as a sort of map as well. The Abbey is such an awe inspiring place and the bells are beautiful with the prayer at the top of the hour. To be able to actually be inside the chapel where HRH Prince William got married to Princess Kate was such a neat experience. Having gotten up at 4am to see their wedding on TV and later to be standing in the same place was amazing! My favorite place of all however, was the Poet's Corner, especially the C.S. Lewis memorial stone. As an avid reader of the classics, it meant so much to me to be able to see all of these memorials to the great classical writers whom I have read, but C.S. Lewis' stone was extra special for me. It was also so neat to be able to see the actual real Coronation Chair of the Royal Family! Pictures aren't allowed and it is rather expensive to go in, but visiting Westminster Abbey and seeing so much history and famous names was definitely a wonderful experience and I highly recommend it.

Vergers tour really informative and amusing. Lots of interesting history and amusing anecdotes in a beautiful building. The café/restaurant was an unexpected treat. We had lunch but may have to go back to try the all day tea

Not to be missed! . We arrived via the Westminster underground station on Saturday afternoon. The crowd of people was incredible. We admired Big Ben, took some pictures and made our way to the Abbey. After some directions from a local policeman we found our way there. Our hope was to attend the 3 pm evensong service. The tour costs 18 pounds but the services are free, so we informed the people at the gate we were there for the service and they welcomed us in. We entered the great West door about 2:45 and followed the rest of those there to do the same. Evensong is primarily a choir based service.
