It was inspiring and moving and lasted approximately 45 minutes. We sat, worshipped and appreciated the incredible surroundings. After the service was over we were able to take our time in walking through and out of this amazing place.

Amazing place and such history. We went here shortly after the Duke & Duchess of Cambridge's wedding a a few months ago. Very moving and beautiful - take time to explore it all as there is much to see.

Amazing place. I'd wanted to visit the Abbey for years. The entrance price (£18 per adult) was probably the acceptable rate for a major London tourist attraction but it seemed a little on the high side - just my opinion. The Abbey is such a serene, peaceful place. Not being a religious person I still found it fascinating what a history it has. The audio tour - voiced by Jeremy Irons - is very informative and enhance the visit. I had chance to explore every nook and cranny just to absorb the place.Am so glad I visited - just an amazing place to be.

Awe inspiring. This is a beautiful example of old english architecture from english literature the selfguided tour with headphones is wonderful as you can go as fast as you wish hundreds of years of history in these walls the tombs are amazing
So very beautiful. We were here for the veteran days weekend, and the display was outstanding.Have been here before bu this was breath taking.

Beautiful and Interesting. What a piece of history. It's very cool to realize who is buried there and what important events happen there. The headset guide was excellent. We found out later that Hyde Park and Kensington Park once belonged to the abbey.

Wonderful!. This is a very airy, quiet, bright and pleasant place! Beautiful very old building, where atmosphere is kind and friendly. I walked in as a tourist to see and feel this is Abbey, to communicate with the Universe (God) and stayed for liturgy. It was a wonderful experience! Thanks so much!Unfortunately, taking pictures is prohibited, but I treat this with understanding.

A day through history. Westminster Abbey is spectacular and breathtaking. It is a building filled with history but also operational as a place of worship. The tourists walking around are quiet and respectful, it really does help that you cannot take any photos, it adds to the reverence of the place. We got a free audio guide which could be listened to via speakers rather than headphones which was pleasant. The ability to be able to walk around to each chapel, see the age and beauty of some of the tombs was great. For the Tudors historians amongst us, the Lady Chapel is outstanding. To see the tombs of Mary I and Elizabeth I together, together in death if not in life, Henry VI and Elizabeth of York, Mary Queen of Scots and Margaret Beautfort is like seeing history right in front of you. Henry VIII is not buried here, he is buried at St. George's Chapel at Windsor Castle. For the literati amongst us, Poets Corner is an interesting slice of history!Definitely worth the money and the visit!

Very Interesting Visit. The visit is amazing! We went with two friends and it feels incredible to be where so many important people are buried. In the middle of the visist it was a church service with organ music with choir by Handel, really beautiful.

Absolutely magnificent.. After spending a month in London and visiting many, many fantastic sites, we were amazed at how awesome this place was! Expecting a long wait to get in, we queued for less than 10 minutes before arriving at admission. During the queue, visitors are sorted into those paying by credit card and those paying cash. The audio guide which was easy to use and very clear, guides you right through the abbey, explaining everything. Difficult to properly convey the incredible richness of history here, the coronations, the beautiful tombs, cloisters, the resting places of so many monarchs and other famous people. It did get a tad congested in some areas, eg near The Lady Chapel, but it is to be expected. Lovers of history, put this place at the top of your "must see" list.

Awe Inspiring!. Visited the abbey on Nov 11 - remembrance day. Did the self guided tour which was wonderful. The guides at the abbey are very happy to answer questions and seem passionate about all that is around them. We went to an evensong service (3:45pm, I think every day) it was perfect to hear the choir sing and sit amongst such amazing art and history. There is a cafe in the abbey, a busy place - for good reason, tea and pastries were delicious. In my opinion, a MUST SEE while in London!

Truely Beautiful. This was a highlight of my trip to London. Westminster Abbey is just so beautiful and amazing!! We used the London pass and did not have to wait in a line to get in. Was an amazing experience I'll never forget!

Interesting & well guided. We were given free tickets through our London pass & also had an audio guide. Was a very interesting walk through the abbey. The tombs, alters, choir chambers & monarchy seat were all impressive and it was just amazing to walk where many monarchs had walked before on some of the most important days of their lives - some over 100's of years previous!
Wow!. Verger guide tour was worth it, very informative, got to go places others did not. Worship service on Sunday was beautiful!

2000 years of history in 90 minutes. This was the highpoint of our visit to London. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful cathedral and so much more! The entrance isn't cheap but once you are inside I highly recommend spending the extra 5 pounds for the guided tour. This gives you personal impressions of the history buried (literally) in the abbey. From William and Conqueror to William and Kate, the history of England is right there in the building. The private tour also has exclusive access to some places including the high altar and the very important tomb of St Edward the Confessor. Arrive early - the queue moves quickly.

A must-see!!. If you have any appreciation at all for history, then you must visit Westminster Abbey the next time you're in London. We spent about 5 hours here, but I could have stayed all day. Listen to the audio tour, stay for Communion, and come back for an evening organ recital. You will not regret it.

Impressive burial places for so many pioneers. In addition to his architecture and historical importance, I am impressed by the famous pioneers buried in the church, giving me an opportunity to pay respect to Newton, Maxwell, Shakespeare, Handel. I also took the chance to make my pray, even though I am non-religious, for the awe of the place. Well worth the waiting in line.
Jolly Old England. Historic, majestic. Great audio tour. Too bad you can't take photos, but I understand it damages the treasures.

Where the upper crust is buried. This is an amazing place with all the tombs of so many famous Englishmen. There is a special corner for famous literary figures. To me, the most interesting thing was the extremely ornate tombs of people that we never heard of but were friends of the royalty and were buried here. The audio guide is very thorough. Unfortunately, no picture taking is allowed.

Beautiful!!. Kind of pricey, but we had the London Pass. It was gorgeous!! You cannot take pictures, so you should probably buy the book in the gift shop. I didn't realize the amount of people buried there, truly amazing. The ceiling and the amount of things to look at are incredible. We went around 2pm and had time to finish. The times open are somewhat limited.
Great Place to visit in London. ...come and see where William and Kate got married......see the grand church.....the history of this building is great
Stunning. So so so beautiful! Definitely worth going for an actual service so you can go inside and get the whole feeling. It is beautifully crafted and worth a visit.
A total 5 star experience. Can't miss this amazing church and all the history inside it. Too much to absorb on one visit - so try to go back if you have time.

Expensive, but well worth a visit. If you want to see tomb of Edward the Confessor you must take the verger's tour - an extra £5. He was very interesting and knowledgeable, taking about one and half hours. You were then free to wander round on your own with or without the audio guide. The price to enter the abbey is too high and no photography is allowed. Well worth a visit - the tomb of the unknown soldier and the Coronation Chair are here. Other tombas are in King Henry VII's chapel.

Field of Remembrance. We had no idea that a field of remembrance had been installed around the Abbey every year since 1928. Small areas were pegged out and named after all the regiments that fought in the two world wars. You could buy a small wooden cross and write the name of a soldier and when he served and then peg it into the ground in the appropriate "field". A team of volunteers were hammering in the thousands of crosses that symbolised all the lives laid down. Really, we found this as moving as the ceramic poppies at the Tower.

THE Place for British Royal History. OK, when did the British corner the market on kings and queens? Apparently about a 1,000 years ago. At least you'll come away with that impression after a visit to Westminster Abbey. With the French having trashed their royal tombs St. Denis during the Revolution, Westminster Abbey stands as the greatest collection of historical figures in Europe.This is History with a capital H. All the greats of English and later British royal history are bured here, as well as many notable historical leaders. The church is magnificent, but there are scores of great cathedrals all across Europe (including the above-mentioned St. Denis, the first great Gothic cathedral). But none of them has the breadth of historical sweep that you will find here. Kings and queens have been crowned here, then interred when their reigns were over. And in places like the Poets Corner, notable writers are buried or memorialized as well (not everyone who has a stone in the floor or walls of the Corner is in fact buried in Westminster Abbey). I definitely recommend the self-guided audio tour. It takes you to all the highlights (Queen Elizabeth I's tomb, the Poet's Corner, Chaucer's tomb), and lets you go at your own pace. While not cheap (nothing in London is), it's good value-for-money. And be sure to stay away on Sundays when the Abbey is an active, working church and tourists are kept out.

Fantastic experience. Although a bit expensive to enter and a bit of a wait, this was definitely worth it, especially when you learn how your entry fee contributes to the running of the Abbey. For a history-enthusiast like myself, this was almost too much to take in at once. The audio guides they give out (included in the entry fee) are brilliant and really gives back to your visiting experience. To be able to see the tombs of the old kings like Edward III and Henry V, as well as the Tudors, from Margaret Beaufort to Elizabeth I and her nemesis Mary Stuart was great, but the Abbey with the beautiful architecture and setting is worth a visit in itself.

Beautiful place!. What an amazing historic building!So much to see as you wander around! Only downside is you can't take photographs and you all have to walk in the same direction, so occasionally miss things to see!Will be returning to see what I missed!Arrive early, it gets very busy with long queues outside to get in.
Beautiful church. The church is beautiful an full of history!! Close to other sites and worth the trip!! The cost is 18 pounds but it help keep up the church so we didn't mind.

Serenity.simplicity quiet reflection.. On arriving at the gates you have a sense of being within the presence of the Lord and the Men and Women who are remembered within the walls. I enjoyed seeing all the different parts of the Abbey and then going down the minister's and out into the grounds at the rear. This was a privilege that I was glad to do.Have been to services, but never visited as just a visitor. This is another must do for any visitor to London.

I've done a lot of audio tours and this was one of the best. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed myself here. This is one of the attractions included in the London Pass, so I put in on our itinerary as an "oh, we might as well, I guess" kind of thing. It was fantastic. The audio guide was GREAT, I learned a lot, I loved that we could get up close to everything, the atmosphere was incredible and I was almost overwhelmed by the feeling of awe I experienced. I'm sad that I couldn't take any pictures (seriously, they are seriously strict about the no pictures policy), but my memories of this place are awesome enough to make up for that.

Awesome and Reverent - all in One. Went to Saturday mid-afternoon evensong service. In this service the choir sings the service. Add to this appropriate organ music and you can't help but feel a little "British" and can imagine the Royal Wedding.No matter your religious preference the place is a one of a kind and and the music is wonderful. God Bless the Queen!!
The history is amazing!. Don't miss this one!Visit the chapel of Edward the Confessor (in the Cathedral) at the daily 11am prayer meeting if you are religious or not!

Beautiful Architecture. It was closed when we got to the area but the exterior of the Church as gorgeous. The columns and structure were a sight to see. Maybe next time we'll be lucky enough to go inside. Must-see!

Incredible. I visited Westminster Abbey, and will always remember my trip. Constructed hundreds of years ago, this building is still used by religious officials for services and prayers, in addition to being a tourist attraction. Every hour, a prayer is offered to the general public. There is so much history in Westminster Abbey, it is truly incredible. My favorite thing about it is how close you get to the actual artifacts. Nowhere else can you be right next to memorials of queens, priests, kings, researchers, and literary geniuses, ranging from Queen Elizabeth I to Charles Darwin. The most unique part of the self-guided tour was to see the wooden throne that is used for the induction ceremony of every new king or queen.
Such beautiful architecture. The Gothic, and Gothic revivalist architecture used places such as these is stunning in a way! I recommend stopping by here when in London!

Wonderful. My first time here. Be sure to check the times of the Vergers tour. It is £5 extra but really, really worth it. It is a very comprehensive tour (90 minutes) and was truly excellent. It is limited in number and you are allowed to sit in the choir and also visit the tomb of Edward the Confessor. You also get the benefit of the wisdom of one of the Vergers. A wonderful and beautiful church steeped in history. Simplemagnificent.

full of history!. Many important ppl are burried There (eg darwin, newton)..Take ur time in the abbey its huge & worth the visit as it is full of history! the only thing i didnt like abt it is that u have to pay to enter. Church should be free of charge

Awesome Abbey. They have guided tours and you can use the recorders, so much history, Kings, Queens, Statesmen, the craftsmen that built these sculptures were truly gifted, the celling amazing it could take 2-3 hours just going around, then there is the bells the sound was fab. I would advise a morning tour so you can take your time going around the Abbey.

Westminster Abbey Tour. We didn't have to queue very long and used the tour recorders to walk round the place. It was so interesting to see all the peoples names buried there from kings and queens to poets and writers

Must see for history buffs. Visited in Oct 2014. Included on the London Pas, expensive otherwise but a must-see. I enjoyed to audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons and it provided a lot of informative information as I walked around the Abbey. I got lost a couple of times trying to follow along with the audio, but was able to get back on track. It's hard to believe when you are standing on the grave markers of so many famous people and it can be a bit overwhelming trying to find everyone of interest who is buried there. The altar is beautiful and the audio tour provides a detailed description. Make sure to see the coronation chair at the end of the tour.

Wow what a Church. There is a lots of bones in that church. Not being disrespectful just a lot of history in one location. We spent a couple of hours in the main building, reading and listening to the church sounds. Prayer here and there as would go on with a working church.

Amazing. An amazing place to visit. Knowing that so many royal weddings and funerals have been here just makes it more xciting to visit here. The graves and markers inside will mistify you for hours. Make sure you visit the abbey that isn't an abby. Lol

Beautiful. What a lovely church just a stones throw away from Big Ben. The entrance gardens were lovely, full of remembrance for those fallen in the war. Some famous people from the past buried inside the abbey and lots of history to take in. Worth a visit.

Definitely worth a visit. To me this is one of the places in London truly worth a visit. If you are at least somewhat interested in history you will not miss this one. You do it at your own pace. Self-guided audio tours in multiple languages are available. It is not a free attraction and will cost you around 15 pounds. Some might say that it is a bit steep for "a tour of a cemetery", but when you think of the concentration of British history in one place you would probably be willing to overlook the price. You will learn about the history of the Abbey, why a church is actually called an Abbey, and also will get a very informative and interesting narration about all the British kings and queens, as well as other dignitaries buried there. Don't forget to admire the architecture. Highly recommend, but not to those who would expect Madame Tussaude's type of attraction. Probably not for very young kids either.

THE church to see in London. Westminster Abbey is THE church to visit in London and England. Famous for its tombs (from poets to scientists, kings and queens), its rather french gothic style it is not only a masterpiece of architecture but bears a century long history. The only negative point is that it is not allowed anymore to take any pictures. The first time I visited in 1996, at least on one evening in a week picture taking was allowed. The official reasoning that it destroys the arts is SCIENTIFICALLY wrong and false (provided one doesn't use flash, and nowadays everybody should know how to switch flashlights off).The audioguide is for free and pretty informative. Unfortunately you cannot go inside without an entrance fee. Even 10 years ago you could at least enter the nave up to the very first altar to have a glimps into the church, in case the price is too high for your taste. Pictures below are from this year, interior pictures are from 1996 when it was allowed to take photographs, so the quality might be low, but it still might give you an impression why you should visit this place.

Awesome as ever. Visiting Westminster Abbey is a unique blend of splendid worship and heritage,I've been privileged to visit many times in the past 45 years, and always seem to discover something "new." Having the Coronation Chair more prominently displayed near the great west dooris a great improvement over it's being tucked away as it had been behind St. Edward's Chapel;and now adjacent to the portrait of Richard II - said to be one of the earliest actual likenesses of an English monarch from life, is an inspired move.We attended an organ recital - perfect acoustics and atmosphere for such an occasion.Having just returned from Africa, we noted our seats in the nave were just by thegrave of David Livingston, reminding us that this is a vital link of past and present.So much more--- well worth spending time both in worship and re-discovering thevast heritage this site preserves.Evensong and organ recitals are FREE, but of course limited to the area in which they take place, and appropriate etiquette is observed. Daytime visits have a schedule of fees, withconsideration for seniors, groups, etc. See the website for details.

may be the best-looking church in England. Having visited several churches in England, I felt churches were just the same and decided not to visit any more churches. When passing by Westminster Abbey on a boring afternoon, I glanced at this famous building and found there was not a long queue at the entrance. I was glad and decided to go inside and take a look. I expected that it took only five minutes to walk around, but I was totally wrong. This abbey was quite large and numerous sculptures were inside. The density of sculptures, I would say, was the highest among all the churches in England. I felt my eyes were jammed with artworks. After seeing all the mesmerising sculptures, I found I had spent 40 minutes inside this abbey.

The burial place of poets and royalty. The Abbey is many things to many people: A place of worship, a place of burial, and a place of remembrance. The architecture is stunning – as you would expect from a church approaching almost a 1,000 years in age – and if you think the outside is impressive… Well, regardless of your religious affiliation, everyone should enter a Gothic cathedral at least once in their lives.Before entering, you’ll get to experience the solemn queue up to the ticket booth. The cost may seem a little high up front, but it’s worth it. They do happen to have a military discount if you ask (student rate) and are eligible. Once inside, you’re handed a map and a fairly high tech audio guide that comes with the entry price. From there, you listen to the sweet, sultry voice of Jeremy Irons as you follow the solemn queue on a winding path through the Abbey. At a few stops the audio guide, which has a little LCD screen, can also show short videos.I was visiting to see the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, but the Abbey is also known for honouring national figures such as scientists, poets, generals, Prime Ministers, as well as past Kings and Queens. Notables buried or commemorated within Westminster are the likes of Darwin, Newton, Chaucer, Dickens, and for the Canadians: General James Wolfe (tomb only – he’s buried elsewhere). Many of the tombs are quiet elaborate, and some are surprising to even be present ie. Mary, Queen of Scots. Cromwell only has a marker, as he spent three years interred before being dug up and “parted out.”I would budget at least 2 hours to work – 3 hours is better – your way through the Abbey. No photography is permitted within the church, which is understandable. Most of that time will be spent following the solemn queue, which bottle necks in a few areas – unavoidable with the design of the church and the crowds it receives. I don't think they planned for so many visitors back in 1245 AD. Once you’ve exited the main hall of the cathedral, there’s still the Westminster Abbey Museum to visit, as well as some of the surrounding gardens. Surprisingly, this is one of the few places where you won’t “exit through the gift shop.” To reach it, you exit through the west door, head outside the fencing and turn left. Can’t miss it. It also means that you can visit the shop without having to pay for admission. Finally, for those looking to worship without the tour, the church is still a church (surprise, surprise) and runs posted services. This option is free of the mandatory entrance fee during the “tourist hours,” but if you must absolutely, positively say a prayer outside of these service times you’ll be required to pay for entry.

closed to visitors. Not sure why, but we could not get in, unless we wanted to attend a religious service. The gift shop was nice, so was the beleaguered guard outside who patiently explained to everyone about the closing.
Wonderfull piece of history. The visit to the abbey is quite well organised and the abbey is really beautiful, unfornately it is a bit expensive

Nice photo stop, but there are more interesting things in London, Part II.. I feel the same about Westminster Abbey that I do for the Parliament building... I've been to London a few times before and I feel a walk of the area for photos is worthy of a fine morning or afternoon as long as there is enough light to take photos, but I won't stay too long. Your time is better enjoyed in Museum (most of which are free by the way) or in Pubs if that's your thing. The city has a lot to offer, but if you're adamant about a walk of the AbbeyI wouldn't mind to do this but every time I get here it's either crowded or closing, so I don't bother, also I do have issues with the admission fee at £18 for adults... maybe it's worth it... but I don't know... most of the museums have much more to offer and are free (but ask for donations.) This one is your call. I'm not that interested in most religious places, but the Abbey is exceptional, so if you know the history and it appeals to you. Go for it!I will say this, your best photo op is from across the street near the bank. That's the full view of the front as long as there are no cars or people in the way... you might have to wait a bit for that perfect shot, but it'll come... if you're patient.Enjoy!

A 'must see' for appreciating British history and present day culture. Westminster Abbey is an absolutely wonderful place of worship and is so much more than this - a 700 year old treasure of the nation which has so much history and fame associated with it. Here visitors will find architectural beauty and am amazing 'pageant' of remembrance of great British lives. Some 3000 people have been buried here and there are over 600 monuments and memorials to kings, queens, statemen, poets, priests and so on. Poets' Corner is wonderful where one is reminded of the greatest poests the nation has produced from Chaucer onwards in history. Anyone interested in British Royalty will also have so much to appreciate. All coronations are held here and the Abbey has hosted no less than 16 Royal weddings. There is a fee for entry and one can pay for a guided tour. Both are well worthwhile. I have been here several times and would never tire of the grandeaur and historic associations of the Abbey.

Don't miss this. We had to queue and then pay 18 pounds each but it was well worth it. The Abbey receives no government funding and I am sure it costs a fortune to keep the buildings open. The audio guide is free as is the opportunity to find a place for a quiet prayer. I liked the short announcement on each hour and the prayer for peace. The high point for me was seeing Poets corner and the burial place of Elizabeth the first. This is a step back in time and a great opportunity to see the rest place or commemoration plaques for many famous people. We ate in the cafe and had the afternoon tea which I would give a miss to. The scones were hard.

A piece of history: A London must see. Loved touring this piece of history. Bear in mind, no photos inside. I actually liked this, in crowded attractions, people taking hundreds of photos normally makes things move slower. It was refreshing to have no cameras. Our group cannot get over how knowledgable the staff and volunteers were. Make sure to talk to them, ask questions, you'll learn so much and won't regret it. We went on the London Pass and didn't pay entry. The attraction was great, but the price seems a tad high. Having said that, I'll pay the price of admission each time we have a house guest visitng. It's a must see in London

Breathtaking and unlike any church I've visited. More like a museum. Lots to see and read.. I was expecting a church a large church fit for a queen. I was not expecting it to be so large inside and I didn't expect it to be so vast in history. It holds tombs of some of the worlds most fascinating people! Check online for times and fees. I wish I could have attended a mass there it is free and they have them everyday (per schedule outside of church.) Visit Abbey during week to avoid crowds. Not a place for small children. Free audio guides in entrance, very nice touch!People that work there extremely informative. We had lunch at cafe it was actually quite pleasant! They have a small museum inside through cloisters. I felt this church was quite unique and very different from churches in other parts of Europe.

A Walk Through British History. Walking through Westminster is like walking through British history. It is the final resting place of many kings and queens, from Edward the Confessor to Henry III, Henry V, Henry VII, Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots. Chaucer, Darwin, Newton, Dickens, Handel, Olivier and many, many more of the greatest cultural and historical figures of all time are interred here. Many more are honored with memorials. Poet's Corner is an unforgettable and moving experience for anyone with a literary bent.The audio tour provides some excellent commentary. There is so much to see, one visit won't be sufficient to do it justice. Be sure to check out the museum located in one of the oldest areas of the abbey. It contains royal effigies and artifacts.Photographs, unfortunately, are not permitted and the crowds can be tedious, but don't let that dissuade you. You haven't begun to experience London in all of its ancient mystery until you visit Westminster Abbey.

Couple. Amazing state of the art. Landmark of the royals: queen coronation,wedding and funeral. This can be visited by walking ,bus and boat tour. Good site to take a picture overlooking the known Big Ben clock. It is a must to see a part of London Tour.

Pretty close to God!. just happened to bail on a London bus tour Xmas morning. I walked over and entered the abbey. Timing was happy accident as ushers kept waving me into the main cathedral where christmas service was about to begin. The entire experience was out of this world as I was seated in raised gilded gold pews directly beside the youth choir. The abbey experience is one I'll never forget. Incredible history and architecture.

A fascinating experience.. As I stepped over Charles Darwins grave marker and then stood before that of Isaac Newton I understood something of the importance of this place. Fascinating walk thru history.

Service - 5 stars/Tourist hours -1.5 stars. I hate to write this because my husband and I had extraordinarily high hopes for Westminster Abbey. It was all tee'd up to be a true highlight for us. We are not particularly religious, but we love visiting churches. We love the architecture, the vaulting, the windows, everything. We visited 9 churches while were in England (in 10 days!). On a previous trip to Rome I visited more than 25 churches. We don't get "church'd out."Despite our love for churches, Westminster Abbey was both a hit and a miss.The good:The Sunday evening organ concert was sublime. My husband is a musician, and one of his favorite things to do in Europe is hear organ concerts in different churches. You see, every organ is different. Many are built for a specific church with specific acoustics, and it's interesting to hear the differences between them. So we made a point to go to the organ concert one Sunday evening, and it was just incredible. The organist did a wonderful job, and the church staff made sure that the people visiting were there for the concert - not there to tour the Abbey. Did we get to walk around afterwards? No. But we got to be still in that place for about 45 minutes and just meditate and take it all in. Bonus: it's also free.The bad: We visited a second time a few days later, intending on it being our "tourist visit" to walk around. We made the mistake of visiting it after a tour of Parliament (which we LOVED, by the way), so we weren't first in line. By the time we got there it was absolutely mobbed with people... many of whom were trying to sneak a photograph here and there (photography is not allowed), and of course we got jostled around by multiple tour groups. It was crammed to the brim.It's also "busy" in terms of the number of plaques, monuments, markers, etc. you see. Let's be clear - many of these are grave markers. But many are not. Churchill, for instance, is not buried there. Yet, he has this massive marker at the entrance of the Abbey. Jane Austen is also not buried there. But she has a marker in Poet's Corner. How many people visit Westminster Abbey and think they saw where Jane Austen was buried? After we left, my husband called it "the basement of the realm." It seemed to fit - if you're British and you're famous, your name will be on a plaque somewhere. In a way, it rather took away from the solemnity that we typically experience when visiting European churches. Between that and the mob of people, we were just turned off.So in conclusion: this is Westminster Abbey. Of course you have to visit. But I would also encourage a visit to some other churches in and around London. Of the 9 we visited during tourist hours, Westminster Abbey was actually our least favorite. Our favorite was probably Winchester Cathedral, closely followed by Canterbury Cathedral. Those places are truly awe-inspiring and manage to welcome tourists without losing their purpose.
our favourite. This was our favourite attraction in London. As Canadians there was a real link to our history. As tourists it is fascinating.

Beutiful. A beatiful building inside out, and it is very hard to describe this exquisite place I am lost of words, I regret not going to this grand church before, for some reason I have explored the whole attractions in this area, the London Eye, London Aquarium, London Dungeons, maybe because they are well advertised and never felt the need to visit this stunning Abbey. I guess I was lucky today as I went with my son's school trip for The First World War Remembrance Day, and what an experience it was, the Westminister education center staff were amazing, they taught us about the First World War, showed us a short documentary, and a soldier shared his expereince, we then went on a tour, and then prayed at the Grave of the Unknown Warrior, the service was amazing. It is expencive to visit the Abby the charge for an adult is £18.00 but worth every penny, I have not paid the fee to visit the Abbey but I will not hesitate going again and paying double the fee after my visit today so I can spend more time on my own or with my husband to see this amazing Abbey. It is a must see place is absolutley amazing. Every thing is astonishing and impressive and the employees are very helpful and ready to answer any question, a great holly and rich place to visit.

Sublime. There is very little to say that would do justice to Westminster Abbey. Exquisite, fascinating and majestic come close, but still fall a bit short. The Lady Chapel is breathtakingly beautiful. The admission fee includes an excellent self guided audio tour, and there are Abbey employees everywhere ready to answer questions and provide more detailed information than the audio guide (and they WILL most definitely notice if you attempt to photograph anything...spare yourself a genuine scolding and avoid it!) Every hour, a prayer is offered, a lovely touch, reminding visitors that the Abbey is still in use as a church. As such, it is closed on Sundays. We spent a leisurely two and a half hours here, but we did read every sign, see every chapel, every statue, every interesting bit of architecture, so that's probably longer than many would find necessary.

Beautiful. Absolutely beautiful building! Located near Big Ben, so if you're going there, you might as well check out Westminster Abbey too. Even if you're not interested in going inside, it does look absolutely amazing from the outside too!

More than just a church!. The Wesminster Abbey is a must while visiting London. Make sure you take the audio guide, it will make your visit worth while!Everything is astonishing, impressive and a great way to learn even more about its history. Being from Quebec City, I was personally impressed by Wolfe's statue.....the man who won the battle of the Plains of Abraham!Loving the Royal family and Prince William, it was exciting to walk down the same path William and Kate walked on their wedding day!!!

Stunning Sunday Service. We went for the 10am Sunday service and it was stunning. We were seated between the choir and the organ and WOW!!! Most of the service is sung and the message was short and succinct, I didn't feel it was preachy at all - more of a life lesson. They take a voluntary collection.We also stayed a bit afterwards for tea and scones in the cafe. Glorious sunday morning!

Worth while visiting. A holy sanctuary where you can visit for free if you are going for mass. Otherwise it's over 18GBP to visit.There are lovely organ concerts you can attend in the evening too. You just have to line-up an hour before to make sure you get a seat. Those are free too. Enjoy. The acoustic is great.
Westminster Abbey. Beautiful. Definitely worth visiting! Best time to visit is during weekday when the queue is not too bad.

Not Just a Church!. The Westminster Abbey is a must see. I would recommend the free audio tour guide because it is full of great information and fun facts that allowed me to understand what I was looking at. I don't think I would have enjoyed it as much with out listening to the audio guide because there is a lot more to the Westminster Abbey other then just being a church.

Surrounded By History. So much to see here! Do yourself a favor and spend the extra $5 for the verger tour. That's the only way to get into the shrine of St Edward the Confessor. While we were there, the verger pointed out that surrounding his shrine are the tombs of King Edward I & Queen Eleanor of Castile, King Edward III & Queen Philippa, King Richard II & Queen Anne of Bohemia and also Henry III. I'll never forget that moment, eyes tearing up, realizing I was now surrounded by the historical figures I had read so much about. Equally touching for me was visiting the tomb of Queen Elizabeth I, another figure I love to read about.
A fantastic Church. A fantastic church absolutely beautiful If you are in to churches then this is one you must not miss

Crowning Glory !!!!. On a long weekend visit to London with my family (2 adults & a teenage daughter) this was a place that was not planned as part of our itinerary and it was a last minute thing and so glad that we did visit this landmark in London. For anyone who has never visited this monumental religious attraction of London, then what are you waiting for. It is such an impressive building from when you first see it in the distance but it has so much more to offer when you are inside. The price was reasonable especially for a family and we all agreed that is so worth every penny spent. All of us were in awe at actually standing next to Kings, Queens, Prime MInisters, Poets, & Knights as well as many other famous names that we all recognise. The Abbey is so grand and anyone who says they did not enjoy it must be from a different planet. So much of our British history in one place is well worth the money and definitely a place we would all go back too.

Check - check - check!. If you are planning a visit DO check their website as to whether they will be open to visitors. This is a place of worship and naturally that takes precedence over tourists. The opening times are variable for each day but the website is very clear and you can check months in advance. And if it's closed for general visiting then why not attend an Evensong service (some days at 3pm and some days at 5pm). Lineup at the west door for this if that's your choice (and it's FREE). Either way - you won't regret this wonderful place!

Audio guide a must. lots to see in the Abbey. The guides in the Abbey were very helpful. The church is still very much a place of worship despite all the visitors. Loads of history and small interesting chapels.
Great spot. Loved the audio tour. We found it very informative. So much history. Be ready to take your time and learn so much.

Absolutely stunning!. Westminster Abbey is a must see while visiting London. Went mid-day and did not stand in line long. Took leisurely tour around the inside and although it does get crowded, it is well worth it. Be sure to check hours it is open/closed before going. It does have shortened hours compared to many other places to visit.

Great attraction!. A very interesting attraction! Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton were buried here. Kings and queens, poets and writers are also buried here. Coronations of kings and queens are also held here. A historic and interesting place. A must see if you're in London.

Another World Heritage Site. You can not go wrong by planning an itinerary around World Heritage sites. Westminster abbey will not disappoint. The abbey's history dates back to 960 although its current form is from the 1260's.

surprised. I recently went to Westminster Abbey at my husbands suggestion with our two kids. I was expecting to be bored looking at high ceilings and stained glass windows (seen a few in my time). So I was amazed to find how much history has been packed in to those walls and the audio guide was great, not too long and droning, just a good amount of info to keep me interested. The size was impressive but it was how it was sectioned in to so many different areas that really worked for me, meaning that we had to keep moving on to explore each bit. I just spent three days in London doing different things, but this was definitely the highlight of my trip.

Should not be Missed, but Problems with Audio Guide. This is where London started and certainly should not be missed. During high season, I would probably recommend some sort of skip the line tickets. Being October, we only waited about 20 minutes. We did not take the tour and instead got an audio guide as well as the pamphlet with a map. I have to say that this is probably one of the worst maps and audio guides I have used. We really had a hard time figuring our where we were since numbering appeared to be hit or miss or hidden altogether. Sir Isaac Newtown's burial place is not even marked or discussed - really! Had we taken our own tour book with us we probably would have had a better tour. There are a lot of red-robed personnel about to answer questions. Some or these people are better than others. But, all in all don't miss it.
Great experince. Had a lovely time visiting the Abbey. Would put this on my list of places to see in London for all those who enjoy historical buildings.

Westminster Abbey. If you love history, statues, beautiful architecture and don't care if you can't take photos you should go. Take your time and look everywhere including down, don't let the crowds push you along, take your time and absorb it all. The staff are friendly, informative and helpful. If you have a London City Pass you will miss the long line getting in. Plan to spend a 1/2 day to get a chance to see it all.I wouldn't recommend taking small children. The only reason I gave 4 not 5 is because you can't take photos.

Don't do a DIY at Westminster Abbey. I recently did a tour of the Abbey with the fantastic Original London Walks Company. Always well organised, very knowledgeable and reasonably priced. This was not exception and did not disappoint. Far better than queuing for an age and then just listening to a recorded commentary.
Stunning . Well worth a visit ... it is a beautiful place, filled with so much history !! Audio tour is a must so you don't miss anything . The only downside was no pictures !
Historical. They dont build churches like these anymore. We got there late and missed the tour but we were able to get in on the evening song service. What a neat old building.

Lovely but beware of closing times. This is a must see. Pictures taken from the outside are very good but if you wanted to venture inside beware they are CLOSED ON SATURDAYS & CLOSED AT 3.30PM on weekdays.
We came on Friday at 3.30pm and do could not get in as all as could not come again on Saturday since it is closed.

I Actually Liked the Less Spectacular Areas the Most. If you walk along the nave, take a seat and look up, you are treated to a spectacular view. I definitely thought about how they could build such a thing. But I actually liked some of the rougher areas more. The little chapels that surround the main areas are interesting, providing context and history to the church's existence. And the cloister area, once you finish the tour and are on your way out felt like the most peaceful part of the building.Arrived around 1:30 on a Tuesday afternoon and it was easy to get in, there being only a couple groups paying in front of me. I would go for the audio tour, since it walks you through the building in a good pattern, while hitting you with some of the history and letting you know why certain things are where they are. They make you walk through a gift shop on your exit, but it's up to you to shop. I didn't.

A BEAUTIFUL EXPERIENCE!. I attended a church service at Westminster Abbey on a Sunday morning. I can only describe it as one of the most beautiful things I have ever experienced! The setting, the music, the message - it set the tone for the rest of my day, if not my life. By all means, attend a service if you can fit it into your schedule.

Historical & Spectacular!. We visited Westminster Abbey on a guided walking tour (through Walks.com) which I think is one of the best ways to explore the abbey. The guided tour charged a fee (I think it was 9 pounds) for the tour and they gave a discount on the entry ticket. I would highly recommend visiting this historical Abbey with a guide, as you get to learn so much about this spectacular building (through a very knowledgeable guide rather than listening to a portable audio guide) and you get to skip the very very long queue (around 10.30am on a Monday morning) into the abbey. If you are in London, a visit to this church should be at the top of your list.

Much better than I expected. I was originally put off by the price but my husband wasn't so we went in. No queues at 11am, nice staff and a big Wow! From the minute we went in. I was overawed at seeing the burial place of the Tudor kings and queens. I would also recommend the museum, it is not too big and has models and effigies so you can see what the Monarchs really looked like; check out the family likenesses. One weak area was the cafe, poorly organised, no customer care and a bit too expensive.

A beautiful abbey. Visited first thing 10am very minimal queue approx 15min wait...Once inside it almost took my breath away!your given an audio guide (language of your choice) a map telling you the route round to take the Abbey and along the way you press the numbers that correspond with the numbers on the boards... extremely informative and thoroughly interesting.This abbey is amazing take time to look around especially at the ceiling i found it amazing... the whole tour took us about 90mins tops.Definitely recommend :-)

Historically Brilliant. This is an amazing historical tour of England's history through the lens of burial sites and memorials. To step near the burial site of Kings and Queens is fantastic and a little eerie. Sadly, there are many entombed at the Abbey who deny Christianity, so there is also a Political arm to this place that is for me disturbing...but well worth the visit...be sure to visit the gardens...And if you are Clergy you can get in for free with up to 4 guests...just be sure to have documentation or e-mail them before you visit to make arrangements.

Spectacular building. I visited Westminster Abbey in Nov 2013. There was still a line to enter the building however, I did not think that it was long wait. I felt the fee to enter was reasonable. The interior of the building was a spectacular as the exterior.Overall I felt viewing Westminster Abbey was well worth the time and money.

Great history and architecture, but London Pass fast pass NOT allowed. The Abbey itself is beautiful, but it was so very crowded, and the Abbey people said that the fast pass feature of the London Pass was NOT available. That is not what the London Pass materials state. Anyway, we ended up in a very long line despite having the bloody London Pass, so beware that that could happen to you. The audio tour is a must because you would miss so much of the significance of certain areas without it. The Nightingale monument is breathtaking and the unknown soldier marker is moving. If you can get close enough, the floor of the high alter is an incredible mosaic of precious gems and minerals. Also, Cromwell is buried in one of the rooms, but his stomne marker was turned around so one would not know that! I only overheard that little tidbit from one of the guided tours. Photos not allowed, except in the courtyard at the end and ithe nearby chapel after you get through the rest of the Abbey.

A must see - entrance on London Pass. Full of British history from Kings and Queens coronations, statesmen and soldiers, poets, priests, heroes and villains - it is all there. A thousand years of British History. A magnificent piece of architecture in itself. Allow a couple of hours at least to experience this gem. We got access via our London Pass and skipped the queues.

Amazing place. This place encapsulates so much British history, with so many kings and queens buried here, so many references to british prime ministers and famous people in British history. A amazing building with a amazing history so historic,seems a shame it is so busy since it is a house of God but a amazing place to spend a day if you have the time British or not.
A Must Do.... I only wish I could have spent more time. We were fortunate to have been there when the choir started rehersing with the organ.

Beautiful. We did the audio self guided tour and it was very informative, interesting and well worth the money. The abbey is very beautiful and the tour helps explain the history and architecture of the building very well. I loved it!

The fanciest Gothic Cathedral we've seen. We've been to many cathedrals and this is the fanciest. The exterior is something and the interior beats it hands down. An absolute must see. Well worth the cost.

Didnt have to pay so it was an even better visit. I was lucky to get a free trip as part of my work. It was a fabulous visit and I would certainly go again. Pros: A lovely building from both the outside and inside. If you like Victorian Gothic you will love this place. Excellent guides very knowledgeable . A great chance to see where the pomp and ceremony goes on for the State opening of parliament and to see how the seat of government works. Beautiful architecture with gold everywhere. Cons: long queues even though we had prebooked a tour, a lot of security but understandable given what goes on these days. We couldnt see the Houses of Commons as parliament was in session. However depending when you go if the house is in recess you get to see inside the Commons. I think it may be quite expensive to visit but well worth it if you are in London . No photographs so you have to rely on memory .
A "Must See". This was such an amazing experience. To be within arms length of Kings, Queens, Poets, and more was truly awe inspiring.

Worship here!. We decided to skip the guided tours and attended for evensong (it is free to attend worship). This was seriously one of the best moments of my life. The church is beautiful and radiates of pomp and circumstance, and the boys' choir is out of this world. I left feeling uplifted, calm and happy. Even if you aren't religious, this could have a seriously good effect on your mental wellbeing.
Better on the outside. Definitely better on the outside. It's very expensive (£18!!). May be good if your interested in seeing tombs or just to tick off the list.

Amazing. A trip to London would not be complete without a visit to Westminster Abbey. The shear magnificence of the structure is breathtaking. To think one can walk where world history occured is mind-boggling.

Stunning!. Me and my teenage son visited here during a 3 day visit to London. The queue outside looks worse than it is, we found it moved quite quickly. It is expensive to visit (£18 adult, £15 concession, free for under 11s) but well worth it. Lots to see and a free audio guide is included in the entry cost.I am not a religious person but it made me feel a bit emotional. Every part of it is really stunning. My teenage son, who wasn't as interested in visiting as me was filled with awe, and eager to see everything. We both agreed it was our favourite place while visiting London.The only downside is you are not allowed to take photographs, but do not let that put you off. We bought the guide which is full of pictures and information. It has taken pride of place in my son's room.If you are in London, visiting Westminster Abbey should be your number 1 place to visit!

Beautiful. Words cannot describe Westminster abbey I was just in awe with the beauty of this Cathedral no you could not take pictures it would have felt disrespectful any way and a camera would not capture how you felt when you were there, You could sit for hours just looking at the beautiful windows. Plenty of history with a easy to work audio tour. A must see.

Westminister. There has been a cathedral on this site for over 1000 years. It is awe inspiring and very beautiful. It is the resting place of many famous individuals including Shakespeare, John Donne, Jane Austen, and many of England's former Kings and Queens. It is still used for coronations and royal marriages. It is one of the top historical sites in London and if you want to see it go as early as possible to avoid the crowds.

We went Sunday. It was church, not tours.. We had planned to tour the Abbey Sat, but it didn't work out. We walked by it Sunday and they were letting people in the side door. I thought they were having choir practice, but it was actually for a service. They let people in for the service without charge, but don't want you to take pictures inside.

Nice to see. I was passing by and had my London Pass with me, so I decided to visit it. It's a place of great history, with a lot of nice stuff to see and hear. The audio guide is quite nice. Well worth the visit.

Was one of our favorites!. This was definitely on the top of the list of things that we did. Lot and LOTS of people buried in the Abbey. No photos allowed inside so that was a bummer. You get an audio guide and get to go at your own pace. Tons of history and things to see inside. I would definitely not miss going again when I return.

Top sight. Where else can you see the tombs of Elizabeth the Great, Bloody Mary, Mary Queen of Scots, Henry V, Richard II, Chaucer, Darwin, Newton and many more. This is where the English Kings and Queens are crowned and it is a fabulous sight to see.

Worth the Cost. People, people...you are in London visiting a building that is more than 700 years old! We were there on a European tour (our first) and visiting the absolutely stunning Westminster Abbey was the highlight of our trip. If you don't want to spend a little money then don't go, but if you do go, don't complain about the cost. We had saved up for two years to take this trip and did not mind spending money for sights such as this. The building is breath taking and the history is unbelievable. The audio tour told us everything we wanted to know about this beautiful piece of London's history. We would definitely go again if we get a chance to return.

Immersed In History. Trying to avoid all the crowds, we booked our tickets online – 18.00 pounds each – and waited by the gate of the Abbey at least an hour before it was open. With time it did get crowded, though not as much as it would in any other time of the day. Once we set foot in the Abbey, we were excited to be surrounded with so much history, knowing so many greats have been part of it. Ever since its beginning, in the 10th century, the Abbey has been the place of coronations, commemorations, burials, and weddings, the first coronation being that of King Edward the Confessor. We saw many statues, memorial tables, and tombs, including the ones of Queen Elizabeth I, Mary I, Mary II, Edward III, Henry V, among others. Along with the royals, there can be found tombs and statues of many famous musicians, mathematicians, philanthropists, sailors, admirals, historians, writers, poets, architects, scientists, priests, and politicians. We were especially fascinated by the whole Poets Corner, thrilled to find so much literary grandeur in one place. Starting from memorial tablets of Jane Austen, the Brontë sisters, Edmund Spenser, William Tyndale, WH Auden, Keats, and Shelley; the statues of Shakespeare, Samuel Butler, Coleridge, and William Blake; the memorial stones of CS Lewis, George Eliot, Lord Byron, John Dryden, Lewis Carroll, and TS Eliot; the stained glass windows of Alexander Pope, Christopher Marlowe, Elizabeth Gaskell, John Milton, and Oscar Wilde; and the graves of Ben Jonson, Charles Dickens, Geoffrey Chaucer, Lord Tennyson, Robert and Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Rudyard Kipling, Samuel Johnson, and Thomas Hardy. Among the tombs of other historic people, we were able to see those of David Livingstone, Lord Kelvin, Handel, Henry Purcell, and the famous scientists Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin. We also found the memorial stones and tablets of famous people, such as Oliver Cromwell, Winston Churchill and Franklin Roosevelt. It was touching to see many of the memorials of people who lost their lives in the two World Wars, whose bravery hasn’t been forgotten. We enjoyed our visit and we recommend it to all history lovers.

A Beautiful & Historic Church!. Westminster Abbey is a lovely place to visit. Steeped in history, it is also the final resting place for many Kings & Queens as well as other famous people. It is open to the public, so plan your trip for a time when there is no function taken place and get to visit the inside. Most definitely worth a visit!
So much to see. We just look going thru old buildings, and Westminster Abbey is one of the best. Just beautiful. It was well worth it.

Do Not Miss This. This is absolutely breathtaking. The audio guide that is included with the entrance fee is very informative. Hearing Jeremy Irons narrate to you as you take in the impressive beauty of this massive building is worth the entrance fee. Photographs are not allowed, and a photograph would never be able to do it justice. We went late in the day, so there was virtually no line, and the crowds were small. That made for an intimate experience. Getting such a late start, however, caused us to miss seeing the Museum or the gardens. Walking among the tombs of Kings and Queens as well as notable literary figures was incredibly surreal. This still remains one of my favorite experiences during my trip to London. It is certainly one I will be repeating!

A place you can never forget!. Besides the history and the beauty and reverence of this magnificent building, the voice of Jeremy Irons giving the walking tour was worth the $22 US price of admission. Walking thru history, seeing the 500+ Yr old tombs of Kings and Queens, the famous Poets Corner, the gravestones of Lewis Carrol and so many other famous names the world over made this one of our favorite visits. I would do it all day for a Jeremy Irons personal guide!

British History - Wherever You Step (On). We arrived early on a weekday morning and there was already a fairly long line to enter. We had tried to visit two days earlier, but there was an unscheduled event at the church that prevented us from entering. It did take us almost 20 minutes before we are able to get in. The moral is to arrive early and probably on a weekday rather than a weekend. At £18 a person (£15 for children/seniors), it is quite expensive for a "church" visit. You also get a really good audio tour in your fee. Guided tours are also available. Remember, no photos are allowed, though I'm not sure if I would want to take photos with all the memorials/graves.The abbey itself is smaller than St. Paul's Cathedral, but the sheer number and significance of the Britons buried here overrides St. Paul's. What's interesting is that the entire church is in essence a big cemetery, where people are interred in the ground, in the church walls, and more. The architecture is beautiful, though it doesn't match the splendor of St. Paul's. There are some substantial other things to see other than the graves - there is a small museum and gardens area.But what makes the place special is it's the burial place of many of the significant figures in British (and in many cases, world) history. You see graves everywhere, every step (a famous individual could be buried beneath your feet) - just every foot that you walk. The gravesites, coffins, whatever - many are elaborately decorated. In fact, many are so old that their letterings have faded from years of people walking over a stone, etc. The figures are just significant in history. I was especially interested that many scientists were buried there, including major figures such as Darwin, Maxwell, and Newton. You also have your requisite kings and queens and the royal family, but you also have poets and other literary masters as well. The audio tour provides great history and facts as you tour separate sections of the church.

Steeoed in history. Great place to visit, especially on a rainy day. £18.00 adult admission fee but this includes a mobile phone type listening guide which you can dip in and out of at your leisure. Plenty of seats to take a moment and soak up the atmosphere and art. Highly recommended. I had to open my handbag for a security guard to take a look but this was done in a polite way.

A historical place to visit in London. I always liked to visit this place for its historical value. It contains the tombs of the famous and celebrities in the English and British history. My only disappointment this time was because no photos were allowed inside.

Take the verger tour!. we paid the extra for the tour - about £5 a head - and it was worth it. So much to see and it is best to be guided if you don't want to miss any of the many highlights. The sense of history is incredible.

Worth paying for. With so many great (and free) attractions in London, something that charges an admission fee needs to be really outstanding. Westminster Abbey delivers above and beyond. The place is an architectural marvel and literally dripping with history (royal weddings, funerals, coronations). The self guided tour is top notch.

Great time. We had not been to the Abbey since childhood so this was quite an experience. Arrived before 10.15 on a wet Monday morning to be faced with quite a long queue. This moved fairly quickly and the tickets office dealt with it very efficiently (they have concessionary admission charges).The Audio guide system is excellent (free) so just follow and listen. Some parts are busier than others so just be patient!!!Well worth a visit

A glimpse of history. It was awesome to see all the tombs of the past royals. I was a little dissapointed when at 12pm they asked everyone to stand still for a prayer and then turned it into a political message about the school education system! All in all though it was well worth a visit, it's such a shame you can't take photos though!

Don't miss this one!. This was a fantastic self guided tour. You are given headphones to listen to at your own pace. Well worth the time and money to tour this iconic cathedral. Upon entering the cathedral, you will be greeted with the beauty of another time. Don't skip this one while visiting London.

A must see - beautiful. This is an amazing place. Take time to sit and look up. Also take time to read the plaques - so many people buried here and some of the plaques tell quite a story. Go during weekdays to avoid crowds. Also, be sure to check the hours because they vary.

Regardless. Regardless if you are a religious person, or even believe in a supreme being, this is a must see. Honestly, it really is worth seeing and the inside is unreal. You may have seen the most recent royal wedding on tv, but you need to see this place in person. I was shocked to see that Darwin was buried there.

Beautiful. Awe-inspiring to visit the Poet's Corner and pay homage to the great writers and musicians interred there. The cathedral is stunning, and though likely always crowded, everyone was respectful and quiet.

Almost unbelievably beautiful national treasure. Construction of Westminster Abbey was begun by Henry III in 1245. It is no longer a cathedral, having lost that status in 1560. It is now quaintly described as a Royal Peculiar responsible directly to the British monarchs. The coronations of British kings and queens are traditionally performed at this great abbey located near the Houses of Parliament.I can think of only one fair description of the interior of Westminster Abbey in London - almost impossibly beautiful! The exterior of this Gothic building is magnificent but the glorious interior of this national treasure surpassed any expectations held by my wife Dianne and I. My wife loves Gothic cathedrals and we had visited Notre Dame in Paris, Cologne Cathedral, and the Frauenkirche in Munich but the astonishing beauty of the interior of Westminster Abbey simply took our breath away. In our opinion, the interiors of those famous French and German cathedrals cannot match the beauty of Westminster Abbey. It is impossible for me to convey an impression of that beauty here because photography is not permitted inside the great abbey, but excellent interior views can be found at the online home of Westminster Abbey under the heading "Abbey Treasures" at http://www.westminster-abbey.org/visit-us/abbey-treasuresInside the abbey, the Gothic sculptured stonework and carved woodwork is magnificent. The decoration of the interior by master craftsmen is superb. Statues of famous people from English history are to be found on every side, as well as the burial tombs of historically famous people. Unfortunately, we visited Westminster Abbey in July 2014 when most of Europe, Asia and North America appeared to be on holiday and visiting London. Despite the dense throng of visitors to the abbey in July, we thoroughly enjoyed our visit but promised ourselves that we would try to visit again in late September or the first half of October when everyone is back at work or school. Entry to the Abbey is from 9:30 to 15:30. The admission charge per adult is £18 and £8 for schoolchildren (11 to 18). Children under 11 are admitted without charge if accompanied by an adult. My wife and I entered without paying as one of the benefits of our London Pass. Taxis are conveniently parked outside the abbey.

Beautiful ...but get in line before 9am!. Enjoyjed the self guided audio tour of Wesminster Abbey - The inside of this building is absolutely breathtaking - So much history in one place - However, I would HIGHLY suggest getting there before 9am to get your place in line! Worth a small wait, but I would not wait for hours!

Don't miss it. Now my review may be prejudiced, as I saw Westminster Abbey (for the second time), with London Walks. To have someone point out what to notice, and why it's important, as well as giving the history, made this a fascinating visit, so I can't speak for people wanting to tour this by themselves. But the highlights were where the royal weddings occur, the tomb of the unknown soldier, the ceilings of Lady Chapel and Chapter House, and of course - all the important burials (and memorials). Be aware you can't take photos.
Must see!. Beautiful church with friendly and helpful staff throughout. Be sure to check opening times before you go! The Cellarium Cafe and Abbey shops were really nice as well.

Late afternoon blessing. This was not my 1st visit to the Abbey, but I did feel inclined to walk through it again. I did not use the headphones as I wasn't staying long, but I still happy that I made the effort to see it again. My favorite part was and is when the Vicor arrives at the podium to remind everyone that the Abbey is a house of worship first and foremost and asks everyone to join him in a brief universal prayer. Perfect moment. Also, be sure to light an candle and make a request for prayer. Although I am not religious myself, I found this a very comforting experience.

Better outside than inside. We really wanted to see were all the queens were crowned and the big wedding took place. The entrance fee it's enormous, like 18 ponds...for me that means a lot for only an entry...but we had some luck with the tour guide we took (it was a free walking tour) and he told us that at 15 PM there is a service and that the entrance it's free...so guess what...we went there at 14:45 and they asked us what we wanted to do...we told them (at the gates) that we want to hear the service so they took us inside.The inside of the abbey it's not so special..I was sure that it will blown my mind...but it really didn't. We took our seats (you have to stay down and the pictures are not allowed) and you are given some papers with the description of the service and all the song that will be played in case you want to sing with the choir. They say that it will take like 1 h...but it was no more than 40 minutes. The service was beautiful, the choir it's very good...so I am glad that I could take part in that...and in the same time see the abbey without paying 23 euro for the ticket.

Be prepared for the crowds.. This place is swarming with people and the queues are long if you want to go inside. The exterior of the building is amazing and I viewed it from the front and the sides. I can see why the Royal Wedding of William and Kate took place here. If you want to go inside and not have to pay then go at a Mass time on Sundays when it is free to enter.

Beautiful Westminster Abbey. This is such a beautiful cathedral. To see the tombs of the Kings and Queens of England going back 1000 years or more. There are right there, it's unbelievable. It cost money to get in, can't remember how much, but definitely worth it. The cathedral, the architecture, the stained glass, it's just wonderful.

Use the audio guide!. Without the audio guide, I would have gotten a lot less out of my visit! English guide is narrated by Jeremy Irons, not a bad voice to listen to, and it's really informative. Without it, you'll miss a lot of the interesting stories and legendary figures who make up the Abbey's fascinating history.

Outstanding Historical and Cultural Experience. The artistic and architecture experience is amazing. Adding the historical relevance from hundreds of years is even more overwhelming. Time very well spent.
Historic and wonderful. Visiting Westminister was amazing. The building is so interesting and goes on and on. Much history here.

A Must-See. A trip to London MUST include this cultural icon. What can I add that hasn't been already said... the history, the grandeur, the sheer overwhelming magnificence of the centuries old edifice... it takes your breath away. Be prepared for crowds. The self-tour audio-programs are very nice but you're not always on track and many many things aren't given descriptions - most likely for time. Be aware of your surroundings - because other people aren't - they're listening to their own audio device and paying no attention to right of way or bodies standing in their travel path. Grin and bear it.

Visit it on Sunday!. Great tip we used: visit it during the Sunday mess, it is free and really impressive. All the members of my family had broken into tears for no reason during it even though we are not religious, really beautiful and inspirational place.We also had coffee on its stairs after its closing and it was just an incredible feeling.

Paradise for the Medieval History Buff. Can't say much that hasn't already been said. However, I can provide some tips that may make the trip easier. Since the Abbey is closed on Sunday, Monday draws the most crowds. If your time is limited, you might want to look at a guide book or YouTube video to help you narrow down what is important and one of the many volunteers can point you in the right direction. The audio guides are very helpful by identifying some of the tombs, but you really need a detailed guidebook for background or for those not on the audio guide. Tudor fans should head for the Henry VII Lady Chapel to see the tombs of Elizabeth I and her sister "Bloody Mary" among others. The ceiling is fantastic. We enjoyed excellent scones and tea in the cafeteria near the Abbey Museum (which is also well-worth a visit.)If you want a decent seat to hear the choir sing Evensong, get on line outside the church by 2:30. This way, you should get a seat in one of the choir stalls or the first few rows.

Grand Design!!. The exterior of this fine building is imposing with it's height, magnificent stone walls, fine windows and intricately carved statues at elevated positions around the walls. However, the true splendour of this grand cathedral is not evident until entering this wonderful place of worship. The colour, adornments, finely carved marble & stone tombs are astounding. The high vaulted ceilings and the enormous dimensions of the church are breathtaking. We were fortunate to here the Abbey choir rehearsing which further enhanced the pleasure & enjoyment of our visit. There is much to see in this magnificent place and the audio guides are well prepared, allowing one to move around in an orderly manner at the desired pace.

Large indoor graveyard!. Lovely cathedral, but with around 3,500 known graves in it, this is the most interesting feature. Audioguides give some great history but are not always clear where you are going. Queued to get in but not for long.

Important historical sites in a spectacular historic church building. Full English history played before one's eyes when one enters this very important historic church! Here you find the graves of most of the major English personalities, whether they are writers or scientists. One is struck also by the medieval atmosphere and the impressive architecture behind this impressive building. Expect a lot of visitors, but the queue at the entrance tends to move at a fairly good speed ...

Wonderful. Have lived in London for years and never visited the Abbey before.The entrance fee is £18.00 and a short queue beforehand, but well worth it. Once you pass inside you collect your audio set which friendly staff provide in various languages and then you can wander around following the guided instructions via the audio set. Even though the Abbey is busy the place and layout is so well organised you just follow the flow even though it was busy you do not feel jostled or hurried. The Abbey dates back to Edward the Confessor in the 10th century and is full of history with many famous monarchs and people buried there in the various chapels. The architecture is wonderful and breath taking as to the scope and magnificence. Once the tour is complete you can visit the café and museum and don't forget a visit to the shop before leaving which is filled with a variety of goodies to buy.
Nota to miss. You can't miss Westminster abbey onde you're in London.It's huge and beautifull!Plan at least 2 hours to do a proper visit to the abbey.It's full of história!

Walk in the steps of history . . .. No matter HOW many times you have seen photos of this place, or seen it in movies or on TV there is NO substitute for standing in front of this majestic building and walking where kings, queens and royalty have walked for centuries. Walking down the main knave of the abbey and thinking about how Princess Diana must have felt as she walked down the aisle to marry Prince Charles. How Kate Middleton felt as she walked the same walk to marry Prince William - just gives you goose bumps. Beautiful in architecture and steeped in history - it's a MUST DO if you visit London!

Drowning in history. Westminster Abbey is basically the perfect representation of the rest of London: it's awfully expensive, it's too cluttered and cramped, the atmosphere is solemn, and the audio guide keeps politely telling the plebs to keep moving along. Save £18 and find a photo online (they're forbidden inside,) and you'll get a better view of the truly magnificent parts, without all the mismatched monuments crammed unceremoniously into an otherwise beautiful space.
Amazed. A must see when in London! Absolutely beautiful! Plan on at least two hours here, as there is SO much to see.

Moving experience!. The rich and diverse history that lies within Westminster Abbey combined with impressive Gothic Revival architecture is the perfect match to ensure a very moving experience.Once you enter this magnificent building you are overwhelmed by a sense of serenity as you take in the splendorous surroundings.The stained glass windows are absolutely breathtaking! Note that Big Ben and Buckingham Palace is a short walk from Westminster Abbey.Not to be missed!

Still Amazes Me. This is my second trip to the Abbey and was stilled awed by it. The weather in London the last week of September was well above normal making the Abbey very busy. Even with the crush of people it was still easy to navigate with the free audio tour. This was my Mother's first visit and she said that this was one of her favorite sites.

most important stop on your touring itinerary. We enjoyed seeing this so much! We happened to get here on the top of the hour so we were able to experience the prayer as we walked in the door. It was so incredible to be surrounded by so much history and beauty. Poets Corner was my favorite!

Don't miss this. I enjoyed every moment here quiet, peaceful and beautiful. I have never experience something so special. Every traveller to London must see.. the place is awesome you have to see it for yourself there is no perfect description for Westminster Abbey. This is Royal History at it's best!

A great history lesson!. Beautiful building full of history!! I could have stayed there all day reveling in the history of the people who walked on the very same stones as I. Very interesting stories of those buried there. It's mind boggling how old the building is!! I was delighted when I returned home to find out that I'm mostly British!! I must travel back to England and retrace my ancestors steps someday!

AMAZING!. Although you have to pay to get in, it is DEFINITELY worth it to pay a little extra for a guided tour! Our guide was so knowledgable and I really felt like I learned so much about royal history while I was at Westminster Abbey! ABSOLUTELY worth seeing even if you are only in London for a short period of time!

Macabre but beautiful. I hadn't realized that, to a large extent, English cathedrals are as much tombs as they are houses of worship. In the southeastern US we're taught to walk between graves and not on them, so, at first, I found the idea that I was walking over the departed to be disturbing. The history of the place soon won over and I became enthralled with the names of those resting there and the beauty of their memorials.

Best attraction in London. Of all of the attractions we visited, this was easily the best. We are not religious people, so that was not the reason. It is the amazing architecture, beauty and history that make it amazing. Just to stand there and see the beauty and imagine what it took to build it was amazing. It is close to the House of Parliament and Buckingham Palace so packaging those three makes a really nice day of sightseeing.
