No photos inside. We enjoyed our visit to Westminster Abbey. I'm not sure if a fee for Adults of £18.00 is entirely warranted, as this only included an audio tour. However, we enjoyed our visit and would encourage others to spend time in the Abbey. We had to wait outside for approximately 20 minutes before entering the Abbey.

Pickpocket's do work in this area. £44.00 (2 adults and 2 children)! That's quite a steep price for a family of four recalling that years ago we remember visiting for free...and at that time only the guided tour cost money. Seems odd for a place of worship to gouge tourists. So, we saw the outside took pictures of the grounds and decided to spend our money elsewhere.

A beautiful church with a most remarkable past. When I finally saw this church I was very taken by it, but my thoughts were less about the structure’s architecture and more about its remarkable past. Think of all those coronations, royal weddings and burials over the span of nearly eight centuries. Wow! I stared and stared, imagining what it must have been like in the Middle Ages when that very same building was in that very same place. Now THAT is some deep history!

5pm Evensong Service. This was a special treat...we had planned to visit but got there too late for the regular tour so they asked if we wanted to attend the service and we thought...why not. We were seated in the very front part of the abbey. The gave us a detailed program so we could follow along. It was a beautiful service allowed us to visit in a non-traditional way.

Hallowed ground. Always gives one pause to see the tombs and memorials of so many long gone, significant people who have built the world we live in. Also brings home the need for a good guide to separate the different Henrys and Elizabeths and Marys. Soaking up the atmosphere instead of focusing on every tomb is my solution to the visual overload. This is a London must see.

Absolute must-see!. The abbey has been crowning royals since 1066 and is the burial site for inumerous british famous historical figures, such as Queen Elizabeth I, Darwin, Newton, Faraday, Byron... It is also the site of the coronation chair and of beautiful gardens and cloisters. The building itself speaks of so much History, and the atmosphere of all the scientists, writers, politicians all around is overwhelming. Don't miss the audio-guide narrated by Jeremy Irons.

Better than expected!!. I didn't really know much about the Abbey going in, and when we saw the admission prices (I believe it was about 18 pounds each) we almost didn't go in. We were expecting just another old church with beautiful high ceilings, but didn't realize that the tombs of what seemed like most of the important royals over the years were in there! We got to see where the first queens Mary and Elizabeth are buried, and many of the older kings that I can't remember the names of. All in all, we were sooooo glad we got to see that bit of history!!

Iconic cathedral that has been around since 1066. How do you not enjoy something as old, famous, and historic as the Westminster Abbey? Not only has this cathedral witnessed every coronation except two since the battle of Hastings in 1066, it is the final resting ground of many famous people. And many more who aren't actually buried here have a memorial stone dedicated to them. For example, I didn't know that Sir Isaac Newton or Anne of Cleves were buried here. The tombs of Queen Elizabeth I, Mary I, and Mary Queen of Scotts are most impressive, as is the tomb of Edward the Confessor. The only way to see the area where Edward the Confessor is buried is to take the guided tour. I highly recommend the guided tour because you will see all the highlights in a small group. The tour guide has a way of clearing crowded areas so you can step right up and see various memorials and tombs.Unfortunately you can't take photographs, but the cathedral gets quite crowded and lingering photographers would probably make the congestion worse. Don't be discouraged if you see a long line waiting to get in. The line moves quickly. When we arrived the line was all the way down the sidewalk to the street but it probably only took 10 minutes to get to the entrance.

Disappointing . I have been to the Abbey numerous time since the early 70s. This latest visit was very disappointing. It was so crowded it was almost impossible to appreciate the beauty. There were also ropes set up to control the flow of visitors. This helped to contribute to congestion points within the Abbey. It was also sad to see that the chapter house now has a carpet covering the original tile floor with a small portion of the tiles exposed near the center. It used to be you had to take off your shoes and put on special foot wear to enter the chapter house. I am sure the change was made for conservation reasons but it was disappointing none the less. If you have not seen the Abbey, go see it. Just be prepared for very large crowds. If you have been before they started charging admissions, rethink your visit. It will not be the same as before.

Historical Monument. Its an amazing place where you can find a treasure-trove of paintings, stained glass, carvings and sculptures. Some of the most famous and influential personalities of London are commemorated. One of the most historic site in London, a must visit.

Awe Inspiring. If you see nothing else in London, Westminster Abbey is a must. It is so humbling to walk through those gorgeously crafted, enormous halls among what remains of some of the greatest artists, writers, and leaders of all time. It's a great reminder that "this too shall pass". Even our five-year-old had a great time.
Amazing. I am not a Church fan nor a history expert but the Abbey is a unique place. Architecture, design, history, ambience and monuments are a MUST! Take your time and enjoy it.

Take your time. I had always wanted to visit here and it didn't disappoint. With a self guided tour you can take as long as you like. You don't have to book, but go earlier in the morning and the cue will be less. We got there about 9.30 and the long line moved quickly and we were in within 30 minutes or so. Allow at least 1-2 hours to walk around. All indoors.
Just walked past. Just walked and also drove past whilst visiting Westminster abbey. This was sufficient for us. We also had lunch on the banks of the themes next to London eye, so looked at it then.
very good. Having just been to the Vatican I rate this church better than St Peters. Very interesting, plenty of room to walk around..easy to find. A must see attraction.

Unmissable. I'm neither a churchgoer nor a history enthusiast, but having attended Westminster Abbey twice I recommend that nobody miss it for the world.The building alone is a wondrous feat of majestic architecture, and what impresses outside serves to contain only greater treasures within. What makes the historical elements of the Abbey's luster so very captivating is how they materialise in the bones of British heroes and heroines lying so close to your fingertips as you traipse around the Abbey. You are brought into very really contact with some of the greatest figures of Britain's most prime and celebrated culturally identifying moments; Chaucer, Elizabeth I, Darwin, the Unknown Soldier... And until you are confronted with these figures in such immediacy as the Abbey offers, you've no idea just how capably moving they are. Aside from the figural history, the Abbey retains much charm as an operational place of Christian service - and this I say as a devout atheist. The church's appeal is simple in that it is raw; behind the veil of such awesome architecture is an admirably basic motivation: to continue a Christian tradition that has been conducted and evolved on this same site for countless centuries. And there is no better way to end one's visit to the Abbey than with tea and cakes at any number of the adorable cafes open around the site. Ask not what specific reasons there are for you to visit Westminster Abbey - ask what valid reasons you have to turn down the opportunity. Really, there can't be any.
If you have time. Expensive to get into. If you have time go and see it, don't make it a priority. Walked there from Buckingham Palace.
Majestic Abbey. The Abbey was so majestic. There is so much to see. Visit in the morning when the crowds are less and you can take your time.

Gorgeous Church!. On my last visit I wasn't able to tour this church because it was closing. However I made sure I got there this time. I was very impressed with this lovely church and it's architecture. The tombs and statues of famous writers, royalty, and actors were very interesting. The only turn-off to this church is the high entrance fee, although they did give you audio headphones at no extra cost. Otherwise, this was a beautiful attraction.

Heritage and Worship - what could be better.. Many times I have visited this wonderfulplace. Stayed for Evensong last night, 5pm. If you can listening to the choir and experience Traditional Choral Music,prayer and historical architecture. Wonderful!
Glorious Abbey. Don't miss it. High security required a bag check, but worth it. History everywhere! And a delightful tea in the Cellarium.

Excellent time spent. We went to Westminster Abbey and enjoyed this extremely interesting church. It is kind of odd, in some ways, to see the resting place of some of histories most notable personalities...from historic royalty to poets (Chaucer), musical composers (Handel) and authors, etc. It is a beautiful church and it was also interesting to see the "coronation chair" which, I believe, has been used for every coronation. A grand place to visit!

Greatest Collection Of Royal History Available.. I am a regular visitor to London and each time I go back I am drawn to the pageantry, history and Royal lineage that is ''Westminster Abbey''. There is no other attraction in London that brings all the great icons of history, authors, poets, Kings, Queens and statesmen together in such a way. You walk through all the history lessons and novels you have ever learnt or read about. There is no doubt that no country does the royal and pageantry bit so well as they do in the UK. But they do it so well. This is my 5th visit to the Abbey over the years and every time I go there I see something new. If I didn't have the 3 Day London Pass I doubt if I would have gone again because the queuing and the crowds do get a bit annoying. But I'm glad I did because the pass gets you to the head of the line and once you've been there before you have a better idea of what you want to see. Anybody who is anybody in British history is buried there and the architecture and the memories of coronations and weddings that have taken place even in my lifetime make it all the more interesting. Either go once, twice or even more because it is one of those experiences that will tick all the boxes and bring all your history lessons flooding back.

Too Much!. Too much to look at and so little time, we enjoyed the visit hear but you really can't be rushed because there is so much "dead and buried history" and along with the encreadable architecture of the building itself. Hard to take it all in, just hope you don't have to line up for the restroom as the line ups are long. Pre plan people.

History - at a high price!. The trip into the abbey was interesting and the audio guide was actually the best I've had before (Jeremy irons' narration) doesn't waffle on. The history of the place is super to learn about, and you see the resting places of many monarchs, writers and musicians etc. The price to get in seemed really high to me, but I'm glad we went in :). If you're tossing up between which cathedral to go in though I would choose St Paul's every time.

Architecturally Significant --- but so crowded!. Came here as a part of the London Pass. Westmister Abbey is an absolutely stunning gothic structure and beautiful to behold. The downside is that it's endlessly crowded and nearly impossible to navigate unless you're shoving through the crowd. Opted not to get the audioguide which left me irritated at everyone else who had them as they shuffled slowly along. Just wanted to drink in the beauty! Loved the ceiling and light fixtures - I could almost imagine the royal wedding too! Overall worth a visit - but I'm glad I had the London Pass, felt like I was getting a better value.

Just Amazing. This church is so beautiful and so steeped in history of royalty, leaders and cultural icons. Like many venues of this type, without a guide or at least an audio, you miss so much of the meaning that goes with the tombs, portraits, statues and the building architecture. Take your time and enjoy the experience. It's worth it.

VERY HISTORIC AND INSPIRING SITE. This was a very interesting place to visit in that many important historical figures are buried right in the church (kings, queens, authors, clergy, etc.). Of all the attractions we visited, this was by far the most crowded. Even though we went on a weekday (the weekend lines are horrendous) rather early (11 am),and there was no line to get in, it was slow-moving once inside and crowded in many of the smaller sanctuaries located within the abbey. But who can forgo seeing Queen Victoria's actual tomb and other incredibly historical burial sites of royals and other notable like Jane Austen? There is a nice gift shop adjacent to the church for your souvenir needs once you leave. The entry tickets included an audio tour but we were fortunate enough to come upon one of the guides who works in the abbey and he really complemented what the audio tour might have left out. Again, buy your entry tickets before you "cross the pond" as it does help with the lines when you arrive. Of all the attractions we visited, including Windsor Castle, Tower of London, and Buckingham Palace, this by far was the most crowded. On other days when we were on the bus to other sites and passed the church, you could see the throngs of people outside waiting to get in. Not sure a "good day and time" to visit Westminster, but we went on a weekday (Thursday) in the late morning and it wasn't too bad.

History Housed Within Grand Architecture. A trip to London is not complete without visiting Westminister Abbey. It is a grand edifice. Within its halls, walls, and floors are buried some of the great monarchs of Britain as well as many famous poets, musicians, and other notables. The sheer majesty of the location is overwhelming. A few suggestions follow:1. Arrive between 2:30 and 3:00 PM when entrance lines are shorter. The line can be frustrating as visitors are fumbling for cash and credit cards.2. The "audio tour" (free with admission) can be somewhat confusing and difficult to follow. Some "stations" on the audio tour are closer to each other than it would appear on the accompanying map.3. To fully enjoy the abbey, be sure to look up and down as well as straight ahead and side-to-side.4. Even though you have the audio tour, do not hesitate to ask questions of those who work there. They have stories and anecdotes that you won't find on the audio tour.5. Poet's Corner was a highlight for us! There you will see tombs and monuments to the people you learned about in school. Spend time there. Take out your smart phone and read summaries about people like Charles Dickens, Chuacer, Sir Laurence Olivier, John Masefield, and Alfred Lord Tennyson.6. My only criticisms are the traffic flow (which is inevitable in a site this important) and the audio tour (which could be a little more explicit in helping one to find the site being discussed).Go!! You must see Westminister Abbey! In our experience, it was less crowded in the afternoon.

A walk in history. If you have a desire to hang with famous people this is it. Well sure they're all dead but that a technicality. Here you walk in the midst of Darwin, Mary Queens of Scott's the list goes on with the most famous people of the eons. Architecturally the place is amazing and then to think your walking where the first Royal wedding was in 1100 AD. They have mass there regularly and if you want to say confession you can meet with a priest and do it there. There is one downside the bathrooms provided to visitors are atrocious. I told my husband had this been a car stop on a road trip we would have gotten back in the car and gone on down the road. Filthy, smelly and cramped. So go to the Abbey, just go empty.
Amazing.... A beautiful landmark with very informative guides. History at its best... grounds were kept immaculate.

History & Royalty. I spent 3 hours in this magnificent abbey where Elizabeth 1st and Mary 1st are buried. It is also the site of the Queen's coronation and the wedding venue of William & Kate. To walk among history is always humbling. But it is more so in Westminster Abbey where to walk, look and read of English royal history made me wish I could have lived just for a little while in the era of Elizabeth, Mary and Henry VIII. Or have seen the Queen's coronation or the royal wedding. As this was not possible then a trip down history lane in the Abbey is the next best thing.

cellarium cafe review. During our visit to the Abbey,we decided to go to the Cellarium cafe for 2 cups of coffee-What a mistake! We noticed that the every thing was very expensive.Many people were waiting to be served. Although there seemed to be a number of staff wandering around nobody seemed to be doing anything.Eventually we got served but instead of dealing with orders immediately the waitress was busy doing other jobs so was not handing in the orders to be made up. Long Wait again. Coffees came but I think we must have been on rations as got short measure.When we went to pay, there was no one there to help us. We nearly felt like walking out.What a shock! They were adding a service charge on top of the already expensive coffee-What service?. The old set up in the cloisters was much better as they served lovely soup,coffee and muffins-reasonably priced.

Avoid the cost of the tour and still have a great experience.. We had planned a walking tour of the Westminster area, which started almost in front of the Abbey. It was there that our guide mentioned that rather than paying for the Westminster Abbey tour that we come back for the evening Evensong service (check the website for exact times). Which is exactly what we did.The walking tour in the day offered great history of the building and architecture, the service in the evening, gave us the opportunity to sit in the same area as the Royal family!It's a beautiful structure worth every penny of whatever tour you do take!
Westminster Abbey. Lovely, historic tour. Great tour guides. Tour guide directed us where we could go to sit in with the choir. Evensong was AMAZING!

Beautiful but expensive. 18£ is quite a bit for an unguided tour- the audio tour is great though. Of course the abbey is beautiful and the enormous amount of history is both overwhelming and exhilarating. If you can afford it, a must do.

Grand place with long history. The line was very long and it took me one hour to get in but of course it's worth the wait. The inside is very impressive with a lot of history. Make sure to get the audio guide because there are a lot to see and learn. You need hours to see every chapels. I believe photographing is not allowed. I did not have any pictures and this make me confused about everything and all of the details i saw. Guess if I need to see again, I have to pay another visit.

Beautiful. Beautiful cathedral. The tour is worth the extra money, the tour guide did a good job showing us around and explaining everyone who was buried at the Abbey. With the tour you are also able to go up to the tomb of Edward the Confessor, which you can't do otherwise.

Costly and crowded. Jamb full of monuments, tombs of all sorts of famous monarchs and non-royals etc. Is it worth seeing the graves of Edward III, Mary I etc.?Charles Darwin, Lawrence Olivier, Handel are buried there.

Westminster Abbey. A highlight of our London stay. The Abbey is in the shadow of Big Ben. It is stunning and the people staffing the Abbey for tour assistance were so friendly and helpful. After the Abbey you are perfectly located to tour Parliament, walk across Westminster bridge and take a spin on the London Eye. Leave plenty of time for touring the Abbey- its fantastic.

Very grand & very crowded. Westminster Abbey is, of course, a very beautiful piece of architecture and an important part of British history. However, the crowds made it very difficult to appreciate. The experience was rather like being in a cattle chute. It does seem a bit cheeky to take the money and then also impose Christian prayers over the public address system.

Wow!. The free audio tour is very helpful to appreciate this place. In addition to being the nation's Coronation church since 1066, it also the burial and memorial place for many historical figures from the last thousand years of British history. There is a senior rate. To avoid long lines, get there when it opens-9:30? I would allow about 1.5 hours to enjoy the visit.

£18 to visit a place of worship, how very unchristian!. I have wanted to tour the Abbey for many years and can understand churches asking for donations from visitors, but a charge of £18 to visit a place of worship is simply scandalous, (and even if you pay this outrageous sum you're not allowed to take photographs). I would love to know from the clergy how they can possibly justify this obscene money grabbing spectacle to take place in the very heart of the nations capital, but notice that they tend not to respond to other reviews posted here. I'm sure the interior is spectacular, but I would advise everybody not to support this disgraceful exploitation of a place of worship.

Impressive momument. This is an impressive monument . Inside you will get a glimpse of England's past. Ther aree a lot of people inside at all times i think. With London offer 2for1 we only paid one ticket per 2 persons.

Not what I thought. Perhaps it was because of an exhusting day of seeing sites, but we were a bit disappointed. It is indeed beautiful. The line was very long to enter and inside was shoulder to shoulder. Very famous people are buried inside, but you had to fight the crowdes to even get a peak. There is a lot to see so I would suggest you allow at least 3 hours to see all the high points.
Wonderful. If you have any interest in the history of London or England this is a must-see. A spectacular building with changes made and tombs added by monarchs over the last thousand years.

Excellent visit. Amazing visit to the Abbey, it's majestic and historic and enjoyed this visit and highly recommend you visit while you are in town. It's easy to get to on the tube and you can then walk and see many other attractions in the Westminster area.

How can you get married in a Cemetery!. Although spooky,this place blew me apart to see who was laid to rest in there. Newton, Shakespeare,Dickens, Olivier,Darwin and Churchill....just a few amongst the non-Royals. The Church itself and the history is well worth a visit.

Perhaps I had too high an expectation. At 28 BP for two people, I thought this was rather pricey for a 1.5 hour experience. It was very busy and difficult to navigate the crowds. The audio program was decent and corresponding numbers to the guide were relatively easy to find.

Beautiful Visit. This is another attraction that was covered on our London Pass so we were able to skip the line and walk right in and recieve our audio guides. This place is so big and there are so many tombs and so much history that I'm sure I missed at least half of it on just one visit. It would be overwhelming to try and see it all at once. But the audio guides were great at hitting a lot of the highlights. Give yourself a couple of hours at least, to get through the audio tour. Also, remember to not take pics inside as it is a place of worship. It is nice to stop and light a candle and have a quiet moment, even if you aren't Christian.

Don't miss this. We liked everything. The beauty of the church, the way the tour was laid out (yes it was crowded but the flow was good), the audio tourguides, the cafe. So glad we did it. Good value. Better restroom facilities would send it over the top.

Not to be missed. A truly amazing place. It was busy but not to the point of queues so we had plenty of time to wander around and take in this incredible place, so much history. Another tick off my bucket list.

Interesting place for its history and architecture. So much history at this place, and such a significant symbol to the royal family. We've seen it on TV many times, now we can say we have been there. Didn't realize that so many kings and queens and royal family members were buried here. Now I am really interested in brushing up on my European history.As one of the top attractions in London, it's always crowded and the queue can be long. We used London Pass and got in without any line up. After visiting the Abbey, we went out to Parliament Square across the street to get a nice view of the Big Ben.

Worth the cost. We paid the full entry price and would say it was worth it. To stand and visit the place where many of our monarchs are buried was a great experience. The audio guides are free and again worth it.Would recommend anyone to go!

London's Top Attraction. Westminster Abbey is one of the most interesting and awe-inspiring attractions in the world, and no visit to London would be complete without seeing it. It's not a particularly impressive cathedral, but what makes it moving is the history contained within. Effectively everyone who was anyone over the last 1,000 years in British history is interned within. Admission also includes an audio-guide, which can provide some helpful information.

Westminster Abbey. okay, where else can you walk on Charles Dickens, Samuel Johnson, Lawrence Olivier, and William Shakespeare graves. I was naughty and slipped my hand in to touch Queen Elizabeth I grave effigy. sir Issac newton, (following Dan Brown again) Queen Elizabeth I and her half sister, Queen Mary I are buried together, hmmmm?? if you are a history buff, here we go!!!In the floor just inside the great west door, in the centre of the nave, is the tomb of The Unknown Warrior, an unidentified British soldier killed on a European battlefield during the First World War. He was buried in the Abbey on 11 November 1920. There are many graves in the floors of the Abbey, but this is the only grave on which it is forbidden to step.3,000+ are buried here, if you like history, place where they do the royal weddings and crown kings and queens, it is amazing

Everyone should visit here at least once in their life!. The Abbey is awe-inspiring - you can't help but be moved by it. Get there early to be there when the open the doors at 9:30. It makes no difference if you have a London Pass or not here - everyone is in the same line. Be sure and take the audio tour - it will point things out to you that you wouldn't notice otherwise. Even if it is crowded, there is enough room to move around with your audio tour - you can take your time and don't have to be rushed. Sit down if you have the opportunity and really absorb this magnificent place. If you think of all the personalities who have walked its halls and chapels, you might even feel a ghost brush by you.

Extreemly interesting. Not what I had expected. Far more interesting with much more to see than I expected. Guides were very helpful. Allow 3-5 hours for your visit. Only downside is that a lot of text is in Latin, with no translations available. A pity as a leaflet even for a small charge would be useful.

Absolutely stunning & historical building. Westminster Cathedral has an air of history, of historic occasions, but most of all the feeling of peace. I attended for an Organ recital, but was able to look around beforehand. The simply stunning architecture alone is enough to get you there. It is a totally moving and spiritual place to be.

Everyone (almost) was buried there!. Great place. One of those "don't miss" places. Saw Queen Elizabeth I's tomb which was important to me. Beautiful stories and sculptures as well as tombs. They permit tour guides inside which is unfortunate as the noise from them talking is ever-present.

A must. One of the must-visits in London. I didn't regret money and time spent there. though. Marvellous architecture, the famous ceiling is especially remarkable. Looking at the tombs and the memorials of kings and quues, writers and scientists, one could just feel the history. (I was also thoroughly impressed by the oldest door in England - this wonderful thingy just sits there). The audio guides in different languages contain loads of interesting information. The gift shop is also pretty nice.

Not To Be Missed.. You really can’t go back. On our Big Bus tour we chose not to stop, but just go on upon seeing the crowds. Knew it wouldn't be as good. We did Westminster last time in London. It was inspiring. On our last visit in the evening for a private tour, we were honored to participate in Evensong. One of our group actually was invited to play the organ! Inspiring. Hard to top that! So we chose not to stop. But. Everyone needs to see this icon of English history up close just once. Despite the crowds.

A must see. Check opening hours for tourists as there are dedicated times for praying only. We went on a Monday and it was very packed. Some rooms was just a human traffic jam. Entrance was pricey but being such a famous church, it was an absolute must see (no photos allowed). The free audio guide got boring after a while, but it was still interesting exploring all the different areas and finding out all the famous people buried there.

beautiful church. We attended service in this beautiful church. I felt this peaceful feeling of being close to the Lord. It was an amazing feeling to be able to worship here. No words can explain the power of this historical church. The church survived numerous centuries and many great people have walked through and worshiped here. Don't miss this church.

So much history. I visited this twice in two days. Yesterday, attended evensong which was a special time. The choir was wonderful, and the brief service was also well done. I suspect a lot were there for the singing — as a service this is not the time to look around the abbey.Went back today to see more of the abbey itself. The audio tour is very good, and time should be taken to explore everything. You'll never manage to read and/or identify all the people commemorated here, but it is worth looking beyond the obvious ones and being surprised.

Surprised that I liked it so much!. I had to pick one church to go to, Westminster or St. Paul's and I was not disappointed by Westminster. I took the regular audio, self guided tour which I liked. The Henry VII (Lady) Chapel was beautiful with its amazing ceiling. One of my favorite parts was actually where the Northumberland vault was located. There was a gentleman there who gave a quick history on the vault and his personal account of what happened the last time the vault was opened. It never failed to amaze me how much history is packed into one place.

Tour of London and British Isles cruise. In June I flew to London, England took tour of London saw Buckingham Palace, Thames River, the crown jewels and rode the London Eye with a view of London Parliament Big Bend. Went to Westminister Abbey walked isle where Kate and Prince were married. Absolutely wonderful experience. Boarded cruise ship toured Ireland Blarney stone and Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Paris, France. The experience was absolutely great also Seine River in Paris the Eiffel tower. Things I never thought I would see in my lifetime. The experience was just outstanding and a great time. I would definitely recommend it to anyone going abroad is quite an experience. I went with a group so I was with people on my own would have been scary but great time and great people

Wow. Amazing. Now this is old. First built in 1000. Current structure relatively new dating to 1240 or so. The audio guides are either great or a little long but if you just walked around gazing at the structure it would be worth the price of admission.

Must see experience. I was last in London 40 years ago - Westminster Abbey is the one place that I could not get out of mind. This time around did not disappoint. It's historic - it's beautiful - it's holy. What an amazing experience - a wealth of English history lies in this place. Allow time to fully explore.

Sunday morning service. The abbey is open to visitors for the Sunday service at 11:15 and also for evensongs. The men and boys' choir offers a different sung high mass each week, and summers offer visiting choirs an opportunity to perform. Voices ring and echo off the high vaulted ceilings, and the organ peals away in performances that lure me into feeling I'm at a recital rather than a mass. The plummy tones of the clergy offer prayers and homilies granting either time for reflection or time to regard the splendid architecture. Sitting in poets' corner or statesman's corner is for visitors always a memorable experience, but after mass, the ushers will try to herd visitors out so the next service can begin. After mass, have a bite at the spacious modern cafe, and wonder what the monks might have dined on in ages past. Then visit the wonderful little museum, where Lord Nelson and William and Mary figures are dressed in their own clothes, and old vestments and memorabilia sit in glass cases. You can buy a CD or bookmark at the museum shop.Nearby is a small enclosed garden, but you just get to peer in from a gate.

Don't leave London without paying your respects.. I have been to Westminster Abbey several times and you can get in free if you have a London pass which you can order online before your trip over. There are so many monarchs and famous people buried there. Our family is related to Sir Isaac Newton, so it's kind of cool to actually be related to someone there. The audio guides they provide help in telling you about each section of the Abbey. The Abbey is not too far from big Ben if you have trouble finding it.

Must see spooky place full of History. Its Gothic & spooky! No 2 ways about it - even in the middle of the afternoon! If I got locked in that place in the night _ I would die of a fright just thinking that I am there - even before looking around!! But I loved it - Its so full of history - crammed infact. The priests are pretty scarry too - especially if they see you with a camera in the church. They will tap you on your shoulder & wag a finger & give you a nasty look as if you were stealing the charity money. Yeah - so no cameras inside please.They are there as well - Queen Elizabeth & her sister Queen Mary ( Bloody Mary) , I wish they had given chess board teeth Elizabeth some name as well - because these 2 daughters of King Henry VIII upped their father in the killing spree for heresay & this & that. Off with their heads! King Henry VIII was definetly a hard act to follow - well , never underestimet your children especially women- Woman Power! Wow! Thats one of facts that you will feel & that the final irony was that however poles apart the 2 Sisters were , there in the Abbey they lie next to each other. Not to forget what nasty thing happened with Cromwell - or rather his remains - Vengeful & Macabre. You need to know what happened ? Visit the abbey or read up British History ladsWhat crypts there are? Some for the truly great - Isaac Newton - made more popular by Dan Brown in his Da Vinci Code as one of the puzzles were cracked by the missing orb about his statue. The humble crpyt for an unknown soldier. This was one of the first times I suddenly realised that while I walk in the Abbey, I am actually walking over the interred places of some long dead people from some influencial familes centuries ago. So unless you can pirrot like a ballet dancer - take that thought off your head that you are walking over deadbodies- or dust- or bones or whatever is left.The coronation chair in which all the Monarchs of England sat till date. Its not a comfortable seat but its pretty old & has had many a royal backsides on it from a long time esp when they were stiff & steady for Coronations.There is a poets corner & well known poets will be seen there interred, Chaucer I recollect was one. Chapels inside the Abbey is for the Monarchy.Even the current Regina _ Queen Elizabeth. Not to forget the weddings - most royal ones were held here - including Prince Willima with Katherine.Once you step out there is a huge courtyard - where you can click pics & enjoy a tea. Souvenir shop is not really great. Along with the ticket there will be a free something for the kids, which will entice you to visit the souvenir store & stand in along queue. You get a chocolate coin (thats what I got) for all your wait- but try telling that to your kids. So skip the souvenier shop if you can. Psst ! you will get it cheaper at Camden!!

Amazing architecture. Another place visited with my london pass! A very worth while purchase.The architecture in west minster abbey is breath taking and the audio guide was very informative although at some parts it seemed to go on a little too long for my liking and I felt that I was just standing around listening to it rambling on.A truly breathtaking experience and I would really recommend a visit here while in London, whether you are religious or not it is definitely an experience you don't want to miss.The only thing that disappointed me being a tourist was that there was no photography allowed inside Westminster abbey :( how can a tourist and avid photographer travel to london and look at brilliant sights and not be able to capture those memories. Perhaps a no flash photography policy would be better than no photographs at all. Just an idea!!
Breathtaking!. Unfortunately, we were not able to go inside, but no matter. Even from only the outside, this is truly amazing.

A must see in London. I enjoy visiting churches but was amazed how beautiful the Abbey is. You may have to queue to get in and it can be busy but is well worth it. The audio guided tour gives you enough information without overwhelming you. Try to see the tomb of Queen Elizabeth 1st. The gardens are a lovely quiet area for a breather. Give yourself plenty of time to take in all the history and the special atmosphere of the Abbey.

Amazing, beautiful and creepy. The abbey is an amazing building filled with beautiful and creepy crypts. The carvings are incredible-true works of art. You could spend days seeing everything. Even my 13 yr. old liked it. Check out Florence Nightingale's- it's spooky. The audio tour was helpful but the headset could not be made small enough for my head so I had to hold it in place when I wanted to listen to something (annoying when you have other things to hold).

A must!!!. If you enjoy history and architecture Westminster Abbey is a great place to visit. The Abbey contains the final resting place of many historical figures including Kings, Queens and other important figures from England's history. The architecture is amazing and in my opinion rivals the Vatican.

Return visit. Have been looking forward to going back to Westminster for years and finally made it. Got my ticket quickly and inside was given audio guide. Was glad to see they did not charge for the audio guide at Westminster. Enjoyed it this time as I knew more what I wanted to spend time really learning about. Some areas were closed for renovations but I understand that. Enjoyed my visit.

What a beautiful site. We visited Westminster Abbey on March 19, 2014 and stayed inside for four hours. There is so much to see that you do not want to be rushed. We were fortunate to be inside during the eucharist and participated in the communion. So much history, so much beauty. This is a must see, just don't rush.

One of the prettiest churches I've visited!. and trust me, I've visited a lot. The outside of the church is beautiful, with its carved angels and saints and the edgy tower tops but the inside is like an art museum. There's an abundance of fine, marble statues, as well paintings and other works of art. The queue outside is long but once you get inside, it's all worth because of how amazing it looks! Don't miss it :)P.S If I remember correctly, photographs inside the church are not allowed.
Nice on the outside.... .....too bad London decided to cash in on the tourism and started charging to go inside these old places. Almost £18 to go into the Abbey? I'll admire it from the front.
This gothic church is a must see. I was in awe of how beautiful this church was from the inside. So much to see and admire. It can get very crowded and long lines can form.

Rude attendant and guard. A lady visitor standing in front of me asked about fast entry offered by London Pass and the guard and attendant treated her in an incredibly rude way. When she expressed her disappointment that she wouldn't be able to enter after standing in queue for 30 minutes (well, who wouldn't be disappointed?), the guard started to yell at her(!!), repeatedly saying "Nobody asked you to wait in line!" (!!) Tourists are here to visit and enjoy, not to deal with bad attitudes. Plus there are so many other wonderful attractions in London that are either free or have less crowd.
Amazing. Ornate and awe inspiring. Didn't realize so many kings and queens were inturned there. The audio tour was helpful.

Simply a must see. If you like history and culture,this is for you.You are given a radio with narration by Jeremy Irons to guide you around.You can simply breath in the history.So many stunning artefacts and of course the alter where the royal wedding took place.If you go to London,you have wasted a trip if you dont go

Best Church in England. It is one of the most beautiful churchs I have ever visited. With a mostly gothic architecture and amazing interior decoration, if you like visiting religious sites, churchs or cathedrals, this is very worth your time. Not only being the coronation site for british monarchs and royal weddings but also the burial site. Very interesting building and audio guide available for a richer experience during the visit.
A must see. It is as wonderful as you have heard, nice audio tour with lots of history and amazing amount of statues and history to see.
Love the history here. I love all the fun facts that come with the audio tour and the richness in all the details in the abbey. Must see!

Incredible History. What can you say about Westminster Abbey that has not been said? We had a London Pass and so our wait time was nonexistent. We were marched right in under 30 seconds. From there we picked up and audio tour, which was very helpful. The abbey was quite crowded and the going was slow, but it allowed time for processing all of the graves that you were passing, and even then we missed two that we had come to see. My 15 year old son was skeptical and was, basically, dragged by his parent, but agrees that to see over twenty previous sovereigns of the British Isles in one place is rather awe inspiring. Elizabeth's grave alone is worth the trip.
A must see. This is surely on the 'must see' list of any visitor to London. Especially those interested in British HistoryEnjoyable experience.
One of the highlights.... The history and architecture were fabulous. Give yourself plenty of time to listen to the audio and thoroughly explore the abbey.

Spectacular Architecture Cool Welcome. Westminster Abbey - an historical "Royal Peculiar" church under direct authority of the British Crown is a spectacular and not to be missed sight in London. There is a charge to visit the interior spaces and photography is not allowed. Pictures and other things may be purchased in the Abbey shop. Check the Abbey web site before going as the building may be closed for special services or other state occasions. The critically acclaimed Abbey choir of men and boys is not to be missed. There are many opportunities on Sundays during the choir term to attend a choral service. Evensong- a late afternoon choral service is sung almost every day. Again check the Abbey web site for times and dates. In summer these services may be sung by visiting choirs. My biggest criticism of Westminster Abbey is the less than friendly attitude of it's vergers and clergy. They are cold and unwelcoming treating visitors like school children or interlopers.

Amazing inside and out!. The line was out of the gate when we arrived but it didn't take us long to get inside. The architecture is just beautiful. Audio guides are free once inside and there is plenty to see and learn. You can be in there as little or as long as you like. Seeing all the Kings and Queens was really fascinating and tombs of people like Isaac Newton and the unknown soldier are there. I think we loved this church so much because it contains so much history and so many important people. Definitely worth checking out. Oh and there is no photography allowed inside!

A spiritual experience.. On Sunday June 16 2014 we attended the service at the Abbey.You simply go to the door they direct you to and then follow the guides to the sanctuary. They fill the "Choir" first so if you get there early you can get a real front row seat. It seemed like most of those in attendance were tourists. The Church of England is like the Episcopal church in the USA. They give you a program with everything you need on it. The Priest gave an excellent message. Afterwords we went to the cafe in the church and had a pastry and coffee and then went to the gift shop.

This place smells of history.. There's not a lot to say about this place that hasn't already been said. Historically it's world class. Kings and Queens lie here from the centuries. The religious aspects are fantastic too.

The home of england history. It is a place where you can understand the whole history of this country, you will see the place where all the kings and queens were burried and get the knowledge about princes and princesses of all areas of england, a very nice ear pieces to listen to the explanations of each thing you see in every place you enter, its also the place where the late princess Diana wedding ceremony was held.

Beautiful building. I would recommend getting here first thing in the morning as it is a very popular spot. There are only 2 pay desks so it takes quite a while at times to get into the Abbey. There was a dedicated London Pass queue.Once inside you are given an audio guide and you can take your time wandering around. It is a truly magnificent building and there is so much to see. The tombs of people you have read about in History are there for you to look upon and remember what you know about them.The tomb of the Unknown soldier is a moving sight with the poppies all around it. Make sure you look at the Coronation Chair which is behind glass doors, just before you leave the Abbey.A place not to be missed.

Very Historical. The first time to visit was in 1960 and it hasn't changed much. Then I toured in later years to do the De Vinci Code walk through which was very interesting. On this visit I had to come back again and see the structure, review the history and stories. The stain glass is still beautiful as ever.

British Culture, History, and Music. What a thrill it was to experience an organ concert in this magnificent church prior to our actual visit the next day! There was so much to absorb in the short time that we had in spite of an audio guide that provided us with as much information as possible. Whether you admire the architecture, the great rose window, the portraits, the sculptures, the Cosmati floor in front of the alter, the 1297 Coronation Chair, still used, or the stunning organ, one of the largest in Europe, you could still feel the history of the Coronations and other historical events that took place here. I rarely spend time looking at graves, but the range, both in age such as Chaucer to the variety of the significant artists such as Handel interred here required me to pause and pay tribute.

Amazing architecture and history. I am a bit torn with my visit here. I loved the architecture, the history, and respect the fact this is burial site for many prominent individuals. I hate the fact you can't photograph ANYTHING inside the the building. It's nearly impossible to remember everything inside as there is so much to take in. The audio guide is helpful navigating but it gets overwhelming quickly. It is crowded; very crowed during it's peak and makes moving around challenging. However, it is well worth a visit, with the no photography and crowds caveat in mind. Recommended.
Absolutely incredible! Except.... For the price of entry, and you can't take any pictures? Really? The memorials/tombs within are absolutely breathtaking! The story lines and history are wonderful.

Amazing building but.... £18 is very steep to walk around a very crowded, albeit magnificent, church for an hour. (With that many people, you will not want to stay for longer.) For the same money you can fill the entire day at Windsor Castle or Hampton Court Palace which are both equally splendid.

Highlight of our London visit.. Without a doubt one of the best experiences on our London trip! Stunning architecture and overwhelming historical/religious significance. There's a reason it's a "must see" for any trip to London!

Don't miss it in London. I had no idea of the British history before. After spending one and a half hour with the verger at Westminster Abbey, I am now interested to know more. The place is just historical and cultural. I am so impressed with the stories of it. The background and the history of it are just far more interesting. Of course, the architecture is amazing too. And if you do not know much about the history stuff like me too, I highly recommended you to take the verger tour. The guide was funny and informative. Love it for sure.

Just like in the movies. I was lucky enough to have had sunny weather and it was great. Westminster's Gothic style was really quite special. Really liked just looking in it. There is a park nearby, which you can read a book or relax and just stare at Big Ben and the buildings. The Bobby's at the front seemed friendly enough. I didn't actually go inside.

Absolute highlight. We attended evensong at 3.15pm August 2014. It was without a doubt one of the best experiences I have ever had. To be in this wonderful Abbey so enriched in history. We were treated with courtesy and respect. The service was mostly in song by the Westminster Abbey choir. There is a fee to enter during the week but no fee to attend the Sunday services.

Wonderful. We spent a fabulous afternoon in Westminster Abbey. The ticket price is a bit steep, as is everything in London, but includes an audio tour. The staff was hugely helpful, the premises very well maintained, and the museum and grounds are bonuses. Be sure to head into the Dean's Yard, it's a nice, quiet stroll surrounded by lovely buildings.

One of the Must-Sees. Westminster Abbey is one of those obligatory things to see in London. But there's a reason for that. Many reasons, actually.The architecture is mind-boggling, the place is overflowing in history, from being a site of coronations to the tombs of British heroes, the history of thr varioua monarchs and war heroes. The services are excellent as well.It's not perfect. The lines are long and it isn't cheap. But it's worth the wait and the cost, without a doubt.

Fantastic. A must see when in London... this is a magnifiscent building with lots of history. Visit early in the morning as the lines get long during the day. within walking distance from St. James Court hotel. Also, just across the road from the Cathedral is Big Ben!!!! and the river and the London EYE.

Surprising, and beautiful. First of all - decide what you are here in London to do. If you are in London to learn about the rich history of the country, then this is definitely a place you should visit. If you are in London to explore the city and just see the main historical sites, then I wouldn't necessarily recommend it. As far as tours goes, I felt like it was a little bit on the pricier side, but I was pleased to find that a guided tour listening device is provided. After all, you are in a Church, (and you can sit in for a service if you'd like). I went with my boyfriend and we both enjoyed it. I do think that children might be a little bored and might not understand the full capacity of what they are seeing.The entirety of Westminster Abbey is really large - the overall tour, listening to everything and fully taking everything in actually took almost two full hours. Inside the Church is hundreds upon hundred of memorials and tombs for the rich, famous and important people of England. From the Kings and Queens of England to Charles Darwin! It is amazing how much they've stored in there, and how beautiful it really is!I managed to get this tour in the morning, drop by the National Gallery and the Museum of Natural History in one day. On a rainy day, it is a great in door activity and the Houses of Parliament is right across the street.

Impressive. We were only able to walk around Westminster Abbey (it was closed) but it was very impressive and what a great part of the history of England. I would suggest checking the times it is open so you can go inside!! It was worth seeing while in London!!

Great tour, but no ability to roam.. The price of admission was very expensive, but it's an amazing sight to see; I wouldn't have missed it. The audio tour was really well done and it allows you to see the church at your pace. The tour kept quiet overall in the church was nice, as it kept the serene feel one would expect.My one complaint is that if you want to go back to see something again, you don't have the luxury of walking back; you presumably have to go though the whole queue again and if you're short for time, this really detracts from the experience. At about $32 CAD to get in, I'd like the ability go back to re-see what I need in a timely fashion. Absolutely avoid the bathrooms at all cost. They're unisex, in poor condition and unclean.

Grim tourist trap. Of course, Westminster Abbey is a fabulous place, crammed with monuments and the history of this country but I've named this review as I have because it's a ghastly experience, over-priced, over-crowded and over-policed by rude attendants (well, to be fair, they're only rude to people who try to take forbidden photos - but is there a credible reason why photography is forbidden? When tourists pay £18 a head to go round, they're entitled to expect to be allowed to do what tourists do.) In contrast, one of the Volunteers, asked where a particular window was, kindly looked it up in his book and then conducted us there even though it was at the opposite end of the Abbey from where we were when we enquired. It is difficult to move around. Some of the aisles are quite narrow and people are lingering, listening to the commentary on their audio-guides, or - in groups - to their guides. Of course, too, many memorials are on slabs set into the floor so people back into you looking at them. One has to go once in one's life, I suppose, but it will cost and won't be easy.

An amazing attraction for all ages of tourists. Recently visited here on a holiday in Oxfordshire we took a train into London for the day. Despite visiting London many times we have never visited the Abbey before . What an amazing tourist attraction in every aspect. We took advantage of the audio tour - a must if you want to get everything out of your visit. However, in comparison to other Cathedrals around the country, it is a shame that you are unable to take your own photos, although I appreciate why this rule applies.

History, ancestral and Architectural treat. My husband and I spent whole day here fro morning till evensong.This was a great historical journey, seeing tomb Queen Elizabeth 1, Edward the Confessor. and seeing statue and burial place of William Pitt, the Elder. My late mother was a direct descendant of Chatham Pitt.Architecture was stunning. We decided to savour the atmosphere of this majestic place.Great little café. It is a must if you love Gothic architecture and history.

Breathtaking. Walking through history... do the tour as they take you up to the shrine of Edward the Confessor... It was amazing to be standing at the foot of so many royals graves including Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots

Awe inspiring. We qued up at the abbey and the line moved rather quickly. The audio tour was included with admission . What a great piece of history with kings, queens, poets and politicians all memorialized. Do not miss the coronation chair.

Bought history alive. As much as it is a place of worship, it is a treasure trove of history.Get there early as people que in very long lines to get in.You are given a hand held audio so you can go around at your own pace.So many well known names are layed to rest there and be sure to spend some times in poets corner.

Wow ... Beautiful!. The Abbey was breathtaking! We listened to the audio guided tour. It was overwhelming (in a good way) learning about all of the history, people married and buried at The Abbey. I understand it but wished that we could have taken photos inside, but I do understand and respect why they prefer no photos. After the tour inside, you are able to take photos on the back lawn that gives a full view shot of the church, it's pretty amazing! 100% worth going. Also, I bought the London Pass which gives you the Fast Track entry, so glad we had this since the normal line wrapped the building. The London Pass saved us so much money and waiting time!

Fab day. Visited here with my daughter , last visit was many years ago ,seeped in history . No rushing see at your leisure . Famous tombs .. Little chapels tucked away ,Queens carnation chair . Fantastic day all round . Headsets complimentary . Areas to sit and take in all it's splendour .. Will most defiantly visit again ..

A fantastic sense of history.. Upon entering the abbey, you are immediately cloaked in history. Almost an overload of the senses. See the tombs of long gone kings and queens along with dignitaries. Well worth the price of admittance but somewhat spoiled by the jostling crowds. Best to arrive early.

Beautiful Gothic Building - and our GUIDE was tremendous !. It seems everyone thinks the price of the tickets is high - makes one wonder how much it costs in upkeep for this lovely building. We splurged - and took a Verger guided tour. WELL WORTH the MONEY! We got our tickets ordered BEFORE we arrived, so very short line. Our guide was so interesting and really loved her participation in our tour. She seemed to give us secrets that others did not know..... We truly learned a lot about our history. (The only downside is the lack of decent (or any) restroom facilities.) DO NOT MISS THIS wonderful experience.... it is history that you have read about since you began to read....

Must see, but plan ahead. Heed the guidebooks; go early or go late. We arrived around 10:45 am on a sunny Tuesday in August and the daunting line was around the corner and all the way down the block across from the Houses of Parliament. But it moved quickly (nice photos of Big Ben while you are in the queue) and we were in the Abbey by 11:15. There are discounts for seniors and students, so ticket purchases go quicker if you know the number and type of tickets you want. Headsets are included in the admission price and provide excellent detail on the history, tombs, and architecture. You can take your time wandering around. There is so much history here in one place, it's a must see for anyone. We also toured the garden and the museum, and left at 1:30 pm. There are restrooms near Poet’s Corner and in the restaurant, but you’ll need your ticket to exit and return. When we were there, they decided it was too crowded and they weren’t letting anyone else use the restaurant restrooms.

Great place to see history. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful cathedral but also houses memorials to many of Britain's finest leaders, writers, and scientists, many of whom are buried right there. Don't miss the tomb of the unknown soldier, Isaac Newton memorial, and poet's corner. Make sure you don't miss the Cloisters, The Lady Chapel, the oldest door in Britain, and the Abbey Garden. Arrive around 9:00 AM to be one of the first in line for the 9:30 opening. Closed to tourists on Sundays.

History of England in one place. I enjoyed the all the history in this one place, unfortunately my nieces 15 and 16 were bored after 2 hours I could have stayed there for hours. I do highly recommend getting the audio tour it comes with the admission price (GBP $ 18.00). The audio tour was very helpful. We had about a 45 min wait to get in. If you are traveling with anyone under 18 the admission is less.

Mass was great!. We bought the London Pass and I thought that was necessary to see Westminster Abby, however when I arrived at 5pm they told us that the venue was now closed and that they were starting mass…….which is what we wanted anyway! So they politely said (please put away the London pass, we don’t want to know about it) and we were able to get in and sit through mass. It was great! They had a visiting choir from the states which made the whole experience even better.

Amazing sense of history. Westminster Abbey is a tourist staple for any London visitor, and rightly so. It is an ancient, beautiful place full of the resting places of the most famous Brits. Although there are the tombs of royalty and artists, there are other, equally beautiful memorials, amazing architecture, and fascinating pieces of history. There's simply too much to take in - and unfortunately you can't take photos so you're likely to get overwhelmed with it all. Always worth a visit for the history lover.

An amazing historic space. Truly amazing. So much history in one place. Get there early as lines are long and the place gets very crowded as there is no timed entry. The adults LOVED it and the kids (14 & 12) while they didn't hate it, were a little bored. I am a royal family fan so it was really exciting for me to see this place in person.

Worth the time. Easy access but long lines, about 40 minutes on a Saturday afternoon. Audioguide is a must. Interesting architecture and history with many famous corpses in residence. One of the few places in London I'd visit again. Cafe was pricey but not outrageous and food was suprisingly good.

History and beauty. My husband told me this was a must. Poet's corner one of my favorite sections by far (though they need to add Tolkien monument!). The amount of history in this one place is enough to blow your mind. The audio tour (free with admission) is very soothing...mix of music and commentary.

Not quite the gem we expected!. We visited Westminster Abbey on a weekend away to London and although the Abbey was a very impressive sight and steeped in history, the entry price was exorbitant at £18.00 each. The signage was a little confusing and the staff were quite snooty and unhelpful. The worst aspect was the toilets which were absolutely disgusting! Half of them were out of order and those that were working were filthy and had no toilet tissue. We found this to be quite unacceptable considering the entrance fee. We were embarrassed to be British as the majority of visitors were from overseas and were expressing their disgust quite vocally. We found Lincoln cathedral and York Minster to be much better attractions and better value for money.

Amazing Abbey and Communion too!. Visited Westminster Abbey today and paid 15£ as a senior. No pictures are allowed but the beautiful historical sights will forever be imprinted on my mind. We were there for 3 plus hours and could easily do more. The entrance fee included the audio tour which is really necessary to know what you're looking at. We were there for a prayer for peace over the intercom system. Then at noon we attended a mass in the Abbey and received Communion. The mass was almost identical to a Catholic Mass but this was the Church of England but very similar. After the audio tour was over as we left we walked by the museum and spent some time there and we also went into an art exhibit in a room of stained glass windows and one of the staff explained the stained glass to us which was fantastic because there were so many nuances we would have missed. Can't recommend going to the Abbey enough. If I was here longer I'd make a second trip!

Excellent educative visit though ticket is over priced.. We were in two minds, to pay the GBP 15 apiece,(which was the rate for seniors) or just admire it from outside. The ticket is definitely over priced. It should be around half the price. Then decided to go. After all, we had spent a lot in coming to London. It was an excellent piece of history which we saw, but more for the Britishers or those of the British descent for herein lie graves and memorials of past English monarchy and nobility. A smattering of graves of other luminaries like Oliver Cromwell and Charles Darwin including Lister can also be spotted. It was interesting to see the graves of Elizabeth I and Mary of Scots on opposite shrines. Lovely architecture. The statues and wall stained glass windows were a marvel. The wooden pews and central alter were beautifully carved. Quite marvelous. Regretfully, photography was not allowed. But, the free audio guide is a must. You must take it. The visit is worthless without it. Take it and walk by at a measured pace so that you can fully enjoy the experience.... expensive as it is.While we were there, the 12.30 mass was taking place. The topic of the day was the barbarism which was taking place in the middle east and there was a plea for harmony amongst the various sects and religions. All in all, a good educative visit.

More Than You Expect... Amazing!. Until you actually go into Westminster Abbey, descriptions cannot actually describe what an amazing place this is. Steeped in History, Royalty, Beauty, Architecture and presence you may have heard some of the stories of famous kings, English legends and the word-renowned buried within the Abbey itself. But it doesn't do justice to say one or two famous names and leave it at that.The list of influential persons buried under the floors, walls, and in the crypts here is a literal "who's who" of significant matters and English as well as other National Heritage. Each with stunning displays in varying beauty memorialized in marble inscriptions to classical and ornate statuary spanning the ages.Isaac Newton, Shakespeare, Churchill, to Queens and Kings of England's greatest and most trying times. Poets to playwrights the Abbey is an amazing treasure trove worth exploring and honoring.There is a fabulous audio tour (excellent and most appropriate English narrators, but I won't give the secret away) included with your ticket purchase which you must do: as listening to it explains the beauty and origins of the Abbey ( from humble monastery to it's gothic grandeur), it's ornate individual chapels to the entombment of famous and important dignitaries. The latter which will astound you as to how many persons are contained within the Abbey to this day.Don't forget to stop into the small museum area as well as the cloisters, and college gardens if you are lucky enough to visit on a day the gardens are open (I think M-W but check.)Well worth your time and definitely a must do when visiting London. There truly is no other place like it, and Westminster Abbey is rightly deserves to be called a historical wonder.

A must visit in London .... Westminster Abbey is place of royal coronations, weddings, funerals and other occasions ... and it's interior and exterior architecture is beautiful. Go early or late ... the crowds can be big.

Such a beautiful place to visit. Westminster is right across from El Big Ben, get there early, and make sure it open the day you want to visit. You can easily spend 1/2 to all day just in this areas attractions. Check out the eye, and the venues around there too.I found taking B&W pics and Sepia really come out perfect.

Breathtaking. I've seen many photos and videos of Westminster Abbey before I visited (to be honest, I can thank the Royal Wedding for that), but nothing could prepare me for the true glory of seeing the church in person. Words can't describe the feeling you get when you first walk in, so I'm not even going to try. I just want to say - if there is one "must see" attraction in London, this is it.

Cemetery of Kings. We had the London Pass so didn't have to pay which was good as churches should be free. The abbey like most big churches was beautiful and grand. This one though had many royals and famous figures buried here. It wasn't too busy inside and the audio guide was pretty good. The queues to get in were pretty long but moved quickly. Once inside probably took less than an hour to see everything.

Simply amazing.. I was deeply moved at the abbey. There is so much history that a repeat visit is definitely required. To stand next to the tomb of Elizabeth 1st is an amazing moment. Allow plenty of time and if visiting the city I would recommend purchasing the London pass to fast track entry plus you can also visit other attractions in the area. Photos not permitted and audio guide very helpful. Can get very crowded especially in the small chapels.

History buffs will love this!. Visiting Westminster Abbey was a priority for me when visiting London. I was not disappointed. The abbey itself is a beautiful building with great architecture and is the tomb to many famous figures over British history, including Mary, queen of Scots and Elizabeth I. I would not miss it if you are planning a visit to London!
Full of History. Well worth the cost of admittance though more like a museum to me than a church for worship. However the history inside the building is wonderful if you love history.

Awesome. We did this with the inside tour in 1994 when it was easier to get in before 911 and the restrictions. Now we just walked around with the tour guide on the outside and got some of the history which we didn't get in 94. Just see outside again after all these years brought back memories and we saw things we didn't see the first time. The inside is also outstanding as I remember.

Just Excellent. I have visited Westminster Abbey twice. Absolutely amazing. Recommended to take the audio tour. Will make you travel in other century and walk through the history.Even with the number of people visiting is huge you can fell that place is peaceful (take a sit for a few minutes in order to have this feeling) Its pitty that you are not allowed to take photos. Ticket is expensive but worth. It’s a must to visit.
Don't muss it. Amazing place to visit. Go with time and listen to audio tour. Well worth it!Familiarize yourself with the Abbey before your visit. Beautiful grounds!

Almost a Cemetery. The Abbey was much older appearing than I expected although it was very exhilarating. I felt like I was walking through a cemetery in which many of the most famous historic figures were buried. There were tombs below and to the right and left of us. I think I should visit it again now knowing what to expect.

Amazing. The building itself, both inside and outside is just something to see. The individual guided tour was nice. You get to move along at your own pace and listen to a recording about what you are seeing. There were so many little details to look at.

Westminster Abbey, London England. Absolutely stunning! I felt so humbled entering this beautiful place as I thought of all those who had come before me through the Abbey's mighty doors. I also loved slowly walking around and looking for all of the wonderful great writers and equally famous poets who are buried in this most sacred place. It was a little eerie, though when I thought about the dead, who's spirits watch over the special events that periodically take place there. I would encourage you to take an audio guide as it explains so much about this amazing cathedral! Believe me, you don't want to miss a thing!

Don't miss this one. We were so glad we had the London Pass so we by passed the long lines. This was so interesting to see so much history in one place. The headset tour was very informative! Beautiful place.

Sunday Service. Hi I did not go to the Abbey as a tourist but to visit a place of Worship. On a Sunday you may attend free of charge the religious services and even take holy communion it is truly a wonderful experience.

Historical Inspiration. One of the most inspiring sites I have ever visited, Westminster Abbey is crammed with historical events and past heroes and other celebrities. In addition, it is breathtakingly beautiful. A visit here puts several years of history into perspective.
Stunning. Absolutely loved Westminster Abbey. It is breathtaking!! My group got lost in there for hours and I still don't think we saw everything there is to see.

Pricey but worth it. It's £18 to enter, but it's lovely inside, and you get an audio guide included. So many historical figures buried here and have passed through the doors it's amazing to think about

YOU MUST TAKE THE AUDIO GUIDE. Stunning!!!! Get in line and enjoy the anticipation of being inside one of the grandest cathedrals in the world. I did not take an audio guide but my wife did and it does make all the difference as there is hundreds of years of history to see (and they are free). Not to mention all the small alcoves and apses located along the way that house the remains of Kings and Queens. The architecture is breathtaking. Stick this on the top of the list for sites to visit,

Beautiful. It is an amazing place. We had a London pass so we didn't wait at the entrance more than 10 minutes. Anyway, the Abbey is fabulous on the outside. But, also, the inside is breathtaking. An historical place that deserves a visit.

Breathtaking. I'd been to visit Westminster Abbey several times without going inside. Finally managed to get there early enough that there was only a short queue so I didn't have to wait too long. From the moment I walked inside I was absolutely breathtaken. It is so very beautiful and majestic inside. The architecture of the building itself is simply stunning and the incredible monuments it houses are incredible, especially the tomb of the unknown soldier. I loved my experience here and highly recommend it to all who visit London.

Walking through and on history. I tend to avoid visiting churches when on holidays but I was really pleased that I changed tact and went to Westminster Abbey. Apart from the amazing architecture it has amazing history. I doubt that there is anywhere else where you can witness such a breadth of Anglo-Saxon history. Our three boys loved the quiz and it was very educational for them, they loved the free chocolate coin at the end just as much.A very pleasant surprise and I would recommend a few hours (at least) at Westminster Abbey.
Beautiful. Love the layout of the visit and the audio guide is a must. Very well narrated. So much historical item in one place. They abbey is just beautiful by itself.

Quiet time amidst the bustle of London. We were blessed to be able to attend a Mass service at 5pm on a Monday, very impromptu as it was not planned in our schedule. Awseome choir of very young boys gave us goose bumps. The architecture is beyond belief. When we think old buildings in the US, we think 150 years. In London, they think 1500 years old! Very moving and inspiring service in a fantastic setting.

A Magnificent Cathedral. This is one of my favourite cathedrals I ever visited. Go early because it closes at 3:30. There is a good, free audio guide for Westminster Abbey. It really added a lot to our visit - the stories behind the people are one of the things that make Westminster so interesting. It's right across the street and to the right from the Westminster underground stop.Westminster Abbey is very close (easy walking distance) to Big Ben, Churchill's War Rooms and St. James's Park - all are worth a visit. That makes this a great underground stop for a day but it is quite a crowded area, with loads of people stopping to take lots of photos.The lineup can be deceiving, it moves quickly. Also, it is not cheap to get in. About £17 if I remember right. The crowd inside was quite subdued and respectful - there are a few of the side chapels that are quite claustrophobic but well worth the time to explore them. Watch out for raised bits on the floor as you enter some of the side chapels. You might not see them because you will be staring at the amazing ceilings! There are so many monuments and memorials in this cathedral that you really are tripping over them. There is a lot of gold, very ornate ceilings, and so much of interest. Poet's corner was really nice, with all the memorials to Shakespeare and lots of others. This is a magnificent cathedral and, unfortunately, you are not permitted to take photos inside.Don't miss the coronation chair at the end of the tour.

Magnificent. I have always wanted to visit Westminster Abbey but never thought it would be worth paying the entrance fee on the door. So when we got the London Pass Cards, it was my number one thing to visit. We got fast track entry and surprisingly we were given free audio guides. As soon as you walk into the Abbey, you feel like you have moved back in time. It is just a magnificent place. Everyone should visit and experience it for themselves. Every single corner of the building is full of history. Make sure you take an audio guide, otherwise you will have no clue what to look out for. Take your time and explore it fully. It is worth every penny you pay, but I would recommend getting the London Pass Cards as you go in for free and with fast track. The queues for normal entry are always very long and the adult ticket is around £18.50

Magnificient! (Pity you are not allowed to take photos.). When we visited, there was a lengthy queue, but it was worth waiting. It is a magnificent attraction, a major piece of British history beautifully preserved. The audio guide is superbly executed; it lets you walk through the chapels in your own pace. I am not a technical talent but it was very easy to navigate and also to select from the additional multimedia content. The English version is narrated by Jeremy Irons, the Hungarian version also uses well known voices from national TV which we found an advantage. The attendants are very helpful. It is difficult to understand why you are not allowed to take photos at all (not only the use of flash was prohibited).

Not to be missed. We made a mistake by not budgeting enough time to spend here. We were hurrying through but had to slow down given the overwhelming amount of history to absorb. Don't make the same mistake we did and give yourself several hours to appreciate everything that has gone on here and the astonishing achievements of the incredible people buried in Westminster Abbey.

Amazing!. When I visited a few months back I went with one friend for a day out sightseeing at he had never been to London before. I decided to take him to Westminster abbey and even I was overwhelmed with the sights and things to do there and I've been before! Great sights and things to do as well as a McDonald's nearby so food isn't a issue. Only 4 dots not 5 simply because the London Eye is ludicrously expensive and the queues are enormous.
