Apart from that you could spend a good couple of hours there

Very nice from outside, but SO expensive to go in. We did not expect to see the very expensive entry price for Westminster Abbey. We decided to not go in after all - it's a CHURCH after all- why should it cost so much to get in? We did eat at the Cellarium downstairs in the basement which was very nice - good food and a distinctive atmosphere.

Closer to God. Beyond input controls, beyond that constantly back and forth inside the abbey visitors, can not not admire the greatness of this place of worship, close history between its walls is impressive and worth visiting .... no matter how much it costs ...Depends on the mood of everyone, calling everyone ... but you can not bow to the greatness of human genius ... who designed and built this great ...

Stone Cold. My husband and I were so excited at the thought of attending a worship service and free organ concert at Westminster Abbey on Sun Aug 17, while we were visiting London Aug 16-22. But surprisingly, it was not a good experience from the moment we were ushered in until the minute we left. No one was friendly or even polite. In fact, I understand that positively NO pictures are allowed inside the Abbey, but the workers were beyond MILITANT about it, constantly pacing back and forth, eyeing the crowd and barking "NO cell phones!" and "NO photographs!" at anyone remotely looking as if they were reaching for a cell phone or a camera throughout our visit! It was actually ridiculous and quite unpleasant. So, although the stone work inside the Abbey is beautiful in its own way and the church itself is of course an iconic masterpiece, steeped in history, the actions and attitude of the staff who work in the Abbey undermine and overwhelm any positive experience we could have otherwise had there during our visit. The organ concert was excellent and obviously, the organ itself was exquisite as the sound enveloped every corner of the interior space. But, other than that, we were left feeling exceptionally cold. Even the sermon message surprised me, as it was wholly secularized and politicized, having nothing to do with God. Although I did light a candle and pray for the Lord's peace on our world on my way out, this experience was not at all what I anticipated, considering it is a functioning church and therefore a house of God. It certainly wasn't warm or welcoming as one would reasonably think a house of God would be. But, considering its history, I suppose it's still worth a visit as a tourist attraction, and maybe paying the entrance fee and going during tourist hours is better than going when we did for the free organ concert and evening worship service on Sunday (with NO choir or communion, by the way). That said, if you are only going to visit one church in London, I'd strongly recommend skipping this one and going to St. Paul's Cathedral instead!! It's a far more warm and welcoming environment with friendly staff, both for tourists and worshipers alike!! No comparison!!

Breathtaking historical monument. Arrived shortly after 2:00 on the Saturday of the August Bank Holiday weekend and joined the queue at the Great North Door. It moved pretty quickly. Bags were checked before entering the payment area (£18 for an adult including a map). Friendly Abbey staff on hand to greet you and to provide an audio guide (included in the price). Unless you are on a guided tour then this is a must as there is limited information around the cathedral. The audio guide is narrated by Jeremy Irons and provides a lot of information as you follow the route on the map. Even with the number of people visiting this is a fairly peaceful place. Take a seat near the nave / quire and take it all in. A real ‘wow’ moment and made me feel overcome with joy. It always amazes me to think of the number of people who have visited this very spot over the centuries. The architecture is breathtaking, the history fascinating and the tombs / monuments incredible. Don’t forget to visit the Abbey Museum, Chapter House, Pyx Chamber and Cloisters (all included in the price). Refreshments available in the Cellarium Cafe. Whether you are religious or not this is a must-see whilst in London. No photography or filming allowed. Visit the informative website for further details.

Evensong at Westminster Abbey. We attended Evensong last night and it was well worth the experience. The Choral Evensong is an Anglican religious service conducted primarily by the officiant and the Abbey's (or a nearby Abbey's) choir, however, all are welcomed to attend. While I sat/stood and listened to the choir, I marveled at the history around me and it's awe inspiring for anyone with any interest in history.There is no fee associated with the religious service. Just line up along the West Gate (that's the gate in all the photos of the Abbey). When we went, ppl queued up at 4 pm, for the 5:00 p.m. service. Just be aware that you will not be able to roam around the Abbey. It's a religious gathering after all. Do go early though, and you may find yourself seated behind the choir, which is also quite a treat, considering you're probably using a bench previously occupied by some nobility.My wife and I attended with the understanding that we're participating in a tradition that's lasted several centuries, in one of the world's great religious sites. Besides, you'll probably recognize the Lord's Prayer, so your heresy is marginalized.

Verger tour a must. There is over 900 years of history here and while the audio tour is free....pop for the extra 5 pounds and take the guided tour. You also get to see parts that are not open to the general public. It is an amazing way to view this wonderful building and see its history...a must see attraction but so worth the extra quid to have a human lead you around. *** we got the royal wedding cartwheeling verger as a guide...he was hysterical

The corner stone of English history. This amazing stone and marble edifice to the glory of God, is packed with history going back almost 1000 years, most of our Kings and Queens were crowned here, and most are still here is there gilt and marble tombs, which are so life like [in fact as I viewed the tomb of Queen Elizabeth the First, I am sure I heard a voice say "hallo sailor"] also most of our poets and writers are mentioned there and of course the glorious tomb of the Unknown Soldier. If its your first time in London you owe it to yourself to see the ,Corner Stone of English History

Breathtaking history. So much history in one place. The tombs and monuments to Kings and Queens, The Unknown Soldier, and to many greats of history (Newton, Darwin, Florey, Handel, Clementi). To be in a place that has seen so many Coronations, Weddings, Thanksgiving services and Funerals. I was also very fortunate to be able to attend one of the free Organ recitals in the Abbey - to hear the organ magnificent in hallowed halls. Westminster Abbey is an absolute must for any trip to London!

perfect for the whole family!. I love history. My 11 year old son - not so much. We had been to London before and intentionally not done the Westminster Abbey tour due to attention span. This time (again - 11 year old son and 13 year old daughter), we chose to do the tour. But - instead of the lengthy audio tour - did the 45? minute verger (in-person tour guide who works for the abbey) tour. It was just right! Amazing history - spoon fed to you with humor and just the right amount of detail. We would all go back in a heartbeat! (Btw - I also use a scooter due to poor walking and the verger could not have been more thoughtful.) LOVE the Abbey - LOVE the verger tour!!

This is one tour that you don't want to miss!. I didn't really know what to expect from the tour. I thought it would be cool to visit the place the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were married. I had no idea that I would be completely blown away. Westminster Abbey is magnificent. It is breathtaking, almost makes you want to weep, just taking it all in. This was definitely one of my favorite places to visit in London, and would go back again for sure. We did the audio tour, and that was a bit hard to follow. I think it would be worth doing a guided tour next time.

One of a kind. One of the most amazing churches I have ever visited. It's a must visit when in London. I know London has many complimentary sites but the 18£ are well spent. For the less superficial visitor this site really can take some time since it's somewhat separated into different sections. Also has an outside part and gift shop.

Missed Judge Time Needed. Having visited London many times, I had always just walked past Westminster Abbey and taken a photo, this time we had a lot more time so I allocated several hours to have a good look around. We were there during school holidays (mid August) and there was a 40 minute queue to get in at 10:00am when we arrived although later in the day the queues were longer.There is a lot to see and two hours was not long enough having said that if crowd numbers were smaller taking photos would have been easier and quicker and some of the ante rooms would be easier to access. If you are not interested in reading the inscriptions and are not using the audio guide two hour may be enough. Mu advice, arrive at opening time, allow 3 hours and get the free audio guide.

Beautiful. If you are big into the royal family or British history, this would be a must but the lines are very long, so if you are not that much into it I would skip it and just admire it from the outside.

Arrive Early!. Westminster Abbey is a popular destination for those traveling to London and for good reason. It's rich history, architecture, and religious significance draw thousands a day. Lines are very long but move quickly. I would suggest getting here early in the day. A map and audio guide is included with the admission price. The audio guide is informative and read by Jeremy Irons. Follow the map and numbers closely to get the most out of the experience.

Crowds made it less enjoyable. Wonderful, although very expensive audio tour. Great history in this place but it was so crowded with tourists that you have to stand in various lines to get into the individual crypts etc.

Glad we went.... As many other reviewers have commented, it is expensive at £18 per person, but is a price you would probably expect to pay in London. The Abbey is well worth a visit, with so much history and fantastic architecture. The queue to get into the Abbey is long, but don't let this put you off, as it does move quickly. Although I would not return, I am glad I went, and is one of those places you have to see once. One thing I would not recommend is the Abbey Cafe, which is very over priced. It feels it does not know if it is a cafe or a restaurant. There is waiter service, and even a pot of tea is £3 pp, and it was one of the worse tasting teas I've had. Glad we didn't eat there, and we were even automatically charged a service charge for a cup of tea!However, all in all the Abbey is well worth a visit.

Fantastic and olistic!!!. Id really enjoyed this amazing place and country..english traditional church and very big...Its important to live also the architectural and spiritual side of a big capital like london.

A must see in London, but pricey. One of the sites on most people's visit list when they come to London. Lots of famous people, lots of royalty. The downside is that the price is a bit up there and you can't take any pictures inside. Also there is usually a pretty long line to get in. Still a must see though.

Westminster Abbey - great experience. It was amazing to see so much history in such a beautiful place. Easy access even though you cannot purchase advance tickets. Well worth the money - something I will always remember.

Beautiful piece of English history. There are plenty of reviews complaining about how expensive this attraction is, and it really is. Unfortunately though the majority of the 'top sites' in London are the same and whilst I certainly don't condone it it should come as no surprise. And Westminster Abbey most certainly is one of London's best attractions.Whilst queuing you can see the architecture of the Abbey, it's beautifully crafted and even the hour you'll no doubt be waiting won't be enough to appreciate it all. There's so much history in this building I'd advise anyone to make full use of an audio guide and after queuing for so long don't be in a rush to leave, stay and soak up a keystone of English heritage and culture. If you're in London this has to be done, regardless of the cost or it would be like going to Rome and not visiting the Vatican.

Lovely to attend service but experience marred by rude staff. Attended Sunday morning sung matins service yesterday morning. Three other Christian friends and I were attending as they were visiting me in London for the weekend. We were very excited at attending a service in the Abbey. However, the whole experience was made disappointing by how rude the stewarding staff were, which is why I've downgraded the rating to Poor.On entering the Abbey, I pointed out the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier to the teenager who was with us. The steward nearby said (in a very rude tone of voice) "You can look at that later, you need to go and sit down". Now I understand that they need to keep people moving, but he could have simply said "Would you mind going to your seat, please - you'll have the opportunity to look at the tomb on your way out" or similar, and the tone of his voice was, frankly, disgraceful. Further down, two other stewards were too busy chatting to each other to welcome people. Not one of the stewards welcomed us with a smile.So, all in all - the service was a lovely experience, but I think whoever has oversight of the staff needs to have words about customer service. I was aghast at the unfriendliness of the welcome to a Christian church and would expect far more.

another must-see attraction, but no photos. You probably already know why you would want to go -- the history, the royal connections, the famous people headstones, etc. It's not cheap and the line (in July) was long, but it moved along and there is a lot to see and no one rushing you inside.My one complaint would be with all the "No Photography" signs everywhere. Of course, they are be expected--after all it's an active church and a crowded tourist attraction. However, you might be led to expect that there are plenty of beautiful post cards to offset this restriction. Unfortunately, the post card selection is very limited and features the exterior (where you can take you own photos) while many of the interior views you might want are not available on post cards at all. Thus, you're limited to how well you can recall the views, or you can wait for another royal wedding, funeral, or coronation.

Worst Money-Grab in Europe. It's a great place, but it is now priced for rich tourists only. SHAMEFUL. Will keep many (most!) people away who simply cannot afford it. Thanks, London. Very, very disappointed.

Disgraceful commercializing of London's most historic church. This is a review not so much of Westminster Abbey -- whose awe-inspiring importance as an ecclesiastical building can hardly be overstated -- as of what those responsible for its operation have reduced it to: one of London's most grasping and user-unfriendly tourist sites. A logical analogy might be made with St. Peter's in Rome, where - despite the pressure of even greater crowds -- entry is still free and staff more or less amiable. By contrast, the entrance fees (£18) to Westminster Abbey are extortionate and many of the staff condescending and surly. It now operates like a living allegorical embodiment of the money changers in the Temple, although those responsible for its reduction to the crassest commercialism seem to have no recognition of the irony of what they have made of it. One would have thought that the senior churchmen responsible for its operations would have recognized that excluding on economic grounds much of the population of Britain, and employing staff many of whom are short-tempered, condescending and sometimes downright rude in their attempts to hurry through the building as quickly as possible patrons who have paid handsomely for the privilege of being there, are betrayals of the trust placed in them in their roles as guardians of what is arguably the most important and historic public building in England. The Dean and Chapter should be ashamed of having allowed things to come to this sorry pass. Much the same might be said of the similar surrender of St. Paul's Cathedral to economic opportunism.

Impressive. My partner and I both had London passes which allows you to fast track entry to this attraction which was great as the line was very long. Once you enter it's very impressive make sure you get a free audio guide to listen to while going around.

A must visit when in London. I will say that the price to get into the abbey is a bit steep and although I do understand the reasons I also understand that some people are not happy about it. I knew what the price was so was quite happy to pay it. I see it as the best way to raise the funds needed for the up keep of the abbey, and you do get an audio guide in with the price, which at a lot of other places you would have to pay extra for. I went fairly early as I knew I would need a few hours there. although the queue was quite long it was fast moving. Once inside the splendour of the place is outstanding. the history architecture, stained glass windows, artefacts and atmosphere is fantastic. You need to take your time find places to stand out of the way of other people and take it all in. You can not help but be overwhelmed with all you see and hear from all the different people who are buried there to the Coronation chair and poets corner. The audio guide is excellent and very informative and the abbey staff who are there to help you and answer questions are also very helpful and informative. One thing I will say is the café is vey stylish but not the best and very expensive.

Interesting. I didn't really know what to expect when I entered Westminster Abbey (I expected it to be just another church I suppose) but I was pleasantly surprised. The audio guide was very interesting and told a lot about all the people buried in Westminster Abbey. With the London Pass we didn't need to queue so that was very nice as well.

Unrivalled history. There is so much history here, it really is mind boggling. There is heaps to see and look at, let alone just sitting down and taking in the atmosphere.A must-see. I was quite happy to pay the price, although it is quite steep.

The Westminster Abbey. A must see if you've any inclination/appreciation for history, architecture, and relative artifacts found in religious venues. Take all the time you can as this experience begs for your studied attention. You'll be simply overwhelmed with the names of the buried and/or occasions such as weddings, etc., and with Jeremy Irons as your commentator on the very effective audio tour, you're in very good hands.

Expensive. While I understand that this is an important place to visit on the tour of London and I especially understand the need for churches to pay for their upkeep in difficult times (believe me, I really do!), but I was taken aback to reach the end of a moderately fast moving queue to find that the required admission fee was £18, €22.49, $29.84 US! Now the history in the building is worth taking the time to appreciate, the beauty of the stained glass is worth bathing in the light of, poets corner would stir the heart of even those who do not read great literature and poetry BUT £18 to shuffle along in a vast swathe of people standing on the inscriptions you are trying to read, hoards talking over any opportunity for reflection and crowds moving through any opportunity for the possibility of appreciating the holy aspect of the building make this a tough £18. The "free" audio tour with the dulcet tones of Jeremy Irons does something to soothe the soul but even the chapel set aside for private prayer was disrupted by the loud tourist who came on "harrumphed" at the setting and then failed to shut the door when she left- this didn't help find any sense of the spiritual in the midst of the madness. If you are looking for historical England you will find it, if you are looking for a sense of the holy in a cathedral of the Church of England you may need to search elsewhere.

There is a cheaper way to see the Abbey.. The Abbey is worth a visit just to see the structure itself,but, if you wanting to see the inside you can go during services as the Abbey is still a working church. Just don't be a jerk and leave mid-service. The choir is lovely and if you are really lucky you can listen to the boys choir. If you are wanting to pay to go in...it is not a cheap venture,stuffed to the gils with people...go EARLY and avoid the long lines.

Will return every time in London!. I really love this place. I have been to London many times and always try to come back. Took my kids for the first time, and it was a great history lesson for them. In the past I have gone to a service, which I highly recommend. It is always full of tourists, so if you don't go to a service, you are likely to NOT get a spiritual experience here. The audio tour is very good - I like listening to Jeremy Irons' voice.All of the tombs give you a great opportunity to share with kids what the people have contributed to science, literature, music, etc. Before London we were in Normandy, so my son liked seeing the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and the Churchill memorial.When you leave the grounds, make sure to go across the street to Parliament Square and admire the statues.If you have small kids, be warned that the bathroom experience is not great.

Absolutely fantastic!. This was an outstanding site. The audio tour was fabulous, the assistants/docents were always helpful and responsive. I did not realize how many statues were here commemorating various Brits (and FDR). Many had such sweet sentiments. I'd have to put this on the list of sites NOT TO BE MISSED, even if in London only for a few days. It wasn't that high on my priorities before the trip, but it is after.

Very cool. This and the statesroom tour of Buckingham palace were our fave tours. Very powerful to see the tombs of different kings and royalty through the years, it's a lot to take in as there is a lot packed in here, the line does move fast even though it seems crazy long.

Take plenty of time. HUGE LINES. WORTH EVERY MINUTE! Not to be missed, incredible history. Beautiful inside and out. The only downside is there are about six(no kidding) unisex bathrooms . So don't wait to go! Also had trouble following the audio tour. But truly loved this place. You could spend the day there!
Awesome. Simple awesome. History, history, history, and people, people, people. See and listen to the decades and centuries of stories that has made England what it is today. Simply amazing.

Not my cup of tea. After waiting for long time to enter the cathedral ,it was packed with people .I just found this cathedral just too busy with various tombs and so forth ,I understand the importance of it and how many nobles have been buried here ,but it didn't have that wow or spiritual uplifting vibe for me

Great Tour! The line moves fast!. We arrived here early afternoon and was a little concerned about the long line but it moved quickly. The cost of admission includes an audio guide which is program to your language of choice. This truly made the experience personalized. You are able to pause and go back to different areas with corresponding numbers on the audio. Of course the abbey was crowded, hey this is holiday time and with the audio I was able to go at my own pace and focus on the things that interested me the most. I only wished I had done more reading about the Abbey before we visited as there is so much to see and process. Very memorable experience.

Worth the wait. We had to wait in line nearly 45 minutes, but it was worth the time. I'm not usually into visiting all the cathedrals, but this is one definitely to check out. Get the audio guide and walk along to explore all of the tombs of significant Brits. It was really fascinating and there is so much history under one roof. Loved the altar floor that is from the 12th century. The crowds are a bit much, so mentally prepare yourself.

Free audio tour makes this a winner!. I visited the Abbey back in 1990 before there were docents, audio guides, and a ban of photography. Went back with my teen boys forcing them to go as it is a must see in London. The line was long but moved swiftly. I think the fee was cash only so make sure you have it on you after waiting in line.Once inside, go straight to the free audio guide. Then you can relax and listen to Jeremy Irons soothingly teach you about British history and the Abbey. The flexibility of being able to go to different areas and hit the corresponding number on the audio player was terrific when it was so crowded with tour groups as you could skip sections and come back rather than be forced to follow an order. Don't miss Poet's corner at the end. Truly amazing history. Note: we did this after the Tower of London which helped my teens put the royalty in perspective as we had heard about the various Tudor royals at the Tower and then saw their burial sites at the Abbey.

Fantastic. Although I had to wait more than an hour to get my tickets and enter, it was certainly worth the wait. It contains some amazing parts of history. I was imagining what it was like to be standing there when some of the events happened. The tombs of the kings and queens and others are all so beautiful. So may intricate details. I do wish they could help preserve the slabs over tombs in the floors as the writing has all been completely worn off of many of them.
history ..breath taking. Must visit when in london . tickets are expensive but worth a visit for those who are intrested in hisotry

Perfectly Gothic. Westminster Abbey is just a stone's throw from the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben, and so, even if you're not that interested in churches, it is well worth taking the tube/bus to Westminster and having a look around the area. The Abbey is a perfect example of Gothic architecture and very striking for for its appearance and history.

Takes your breath away. As part of our London Pass, we could tour the "Abbey" and skip the lines…well worth it during summer months.
An audio guide is provided and gives a ton of info. The history in the Abbey is amazing. From coronations to dignitaries buried there is unforgettable! No pictures allowed inside.
Omg. Must see, experience for every one. Jaw dropping, so much history, if your in to history and monarchy, it will take your breath away

Beuatiful and interesting. Great visit. Amazing history and insight into kings and queens of england buried inside. I recommend you use the free speak headsets which talks to you about the history as you walk through.

Too many people buried in Abbey. After queing for an hour, i thought the entrance fee of £34 for myself and my 2 daughters was really expensive. The Abbey is a beautiful building and I loved the artitecture. The tomb of the unknown soldier is very moving. However there are so many people buried here that it felt like a grave yard. You walk over them and in all,of the side chapels someone or many paople have been buried so that the chapels are lost. I wondered as a christian why these people are buried inside the Abbey? Poets? Musicians? Historic military people? Why inside the Abbey? Old monarchs are also buried and they just added to the 'graveyard' feeling. It comes across as a celebration of he great and the good and powerful.,rather than a place of worship. If it was not for the tomb of the unlnown soldier I would say it is not a "must-see" in London.St Pauls is so much more impressive cathedral. Be prepared for crowds, walking in a one way system, using the audio guide - I did not find it held my attention. It did not feel like a palce of prayer.

Amazing. Simply and Beautifully Amazing.. Included in the London Pass. My husband and I are serious history and Museum junkies, so when we saw that we could tour this monument on our first day in London, we absolutely took the opportunity. Such a beautiful and historical building, where Kings and Queens have been enthroned, wed, and buried, and where the vaults of Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Elizabeth I, and Mary Queen of Scots, among many others, are kept. And the tour is voiced over by Jeremy Irons, how cool is that?And we had tea and breakfast in the little cafe housed within the walls. So neat.

TRULY AMAZING. This was an experience i will never forget,it was beautiful and magnificent, so much history, tour guide,all former kings and queens of England, absolutely magnificent, it was like going back in time, truly an amazing experience.

Audio Guide by Jermey Irons! So much to see inside. So many famous people buried here from King Henry IV and Queen Elizabeth 1 to Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton.It's truly spectacular and the line goes quickly!

Gothic. We opted out of viewing the interior of the Abbey this time around as time was short and we had other priorities. The exterior is Gothic to which I am just not naturally drawn. It was impressive and grand. I was glad we visited. They have a nice gift shop accessible from the exterior of which we did take advantage. We were able to get a gift for someone back home who is rather enamored with the whole royalty business. The line to get into the abbey was indeed long so it is something to consider when making your plans to visit.

A must do. The length of the queue nearly stopped me seeing the abbey. The line moved quite quickly and once inside you could move through at your own pace with great audio. The abbey personnel were easily identifiable in their coloured robes were very helpful with any questions you may have.

LOTS OF HISTORY. We skipped the queue using our London pass which wasn't that long any way, If your into English monarchy and history, then you will love Westminster Abby, we got the audio guides which were fantastic, they gave a you a lot of information about all the English Kings and Queens that were buried there, Queen Elizabeth 1 and many more, I really enjoyed the experience and so did my teenage kids.

Favorite Attraction in London. I loved Westminster Abbey! It was great that the audio tour was included in the cost and we learned a lot. The enormous space was very crowded so having your own audio tour was great opposed to a led tour group. I honestly did not know what to expect upon arrival. It was wonderful to see the location of the Royal Wedding and learn about the choir and knights. This would also be the spot to see the graves and memorials of so many important people (and there are A LOT of people buried here) including Charles Darwin, George Handel, St. Edward, Charles Dickens just to name a very few.

Important fact about visiting the cathedral. Are you aware that you can skip the line , for at least 60 minutes ?Buy your London pass, skip the line up and enter through the right side of the line up.Stop by the book store and look at the pictures of wedding of TRH The Duke and Duchness of Cambridge. The place looks very different with the red carpet, the choirs on both sides and flowers all around.Enjoy the tour and vote for me if you find this review helpful.

Beautiful Cathedral. Westminister Abbey is a very old and really beautiful Cathedral. It has very much details and a lot of History of the Royal house of England. I would really recommend visiting the abbey if you like beautiful churches with a lot of history.

A lot of dead people. I was expecting a lot more before coming here. The line outside was very long, but thankfully passed along quickly. It was rather pricey and to be honest I don't think it was worth it. The building was beautiful but not completely breath-taking. St. Paul's is FAR more beautiful than this. It was smaller than I expected and is just full of dead people. We didn't want an audio guide but quite frankly without it there's not really a point as you have no clue who's tomb you're looking at. Most people seemed to be so-and-so's brother's niece, but since all the inscriptions are in Latin or Old English so it takes a bit of decoding. A few important people are here, and poet's corner is neat but that's about it. Overall disappointed. Could've done without going in really. If you're a history buff this would be more interesting.
Abbey. So, so beautiful , a must to do and so much more than we expected. It has so much history you could spend all day there.

Impressive cathedral. I think this is the most impressive building in London...it's so old and wonderfully designed. Also, the atmosphere is unique and the audioguide is doing the job! Worth a visit! Advice: buy a LondonPass and avoid the HUGE queue!

Serious detail here. This is one you cant miss. The detail of construction here is unbelievable, not to mention the amount of history here. It costs 18 pounds to get in, not cheap, but you have to do it once. Enjoy.

The history sucks you in!. It's a very busy attraction, and you will have decent queues, and you can't take pictures, but there is so much history within the Minster's walls that it should be most travelers' lists. The audio tour greatly helps in appreciating what you're seeing.Even if you're not someone who usually visits churches, it's not just the architecture here that deserves a visit, but the thousand years of royal history.

A great experience. We enjoyed visiting the Abbey and really liked the audio guide. Such an amazing piece of history and so many things to see and discover, that it may take you more that 2h to visit. Do take the time, if you have it. It might be a bit crowded, but it is to be expected (we went there in August).
Wonderful !. The abbey is absolutely amazing.. it has a unique atmosphere..and illustrates a lot of history.. like all Westminster.. A must-go in London for certain.

I'd go again . I spent more than half a day here on my trip. It was much more than I'd ever imagined it to be. Catch the choir if possible. I was lucky enough to. And if you go to the mass you can skip paying for entry. But some sections close a little earlier than others, so keep an eye on the timings. Definitely worth a visit.

A walk through history. Whilst once free, the entrance fee is now £18 (but the London Pass includes this). Huge and historical, the names on the floor is a real "who's who" of Britain history and it's a chance to walk in the footsteps of royalty.Judging the number of different languages on this warm and very crowded Saturday morning this is very popular with the foreign tourists. Best to avoid the holiday season if you want to see everything here and check the web site as there's different opening times throughout the week.

From William the Conqueror to William and Kate. Take a walk through history in this wonderful abbey church. William the Conqueror was crowned here in 1066 and William and Kate were married here in 2011. Mediaeval historyaplenty and wonderful tombs of kings and queens. You will also get to walk on the gravesof some illustrious people. The exception is, of course, that of The Unknown Soldier honouredhere for all those who fought and when we visited it was surrounded by poppies. There is a Science corner and a poets' corner which also includes famous writers.Do not forget to look at the wonderful architecture including the beautiful ceilings of the Perpendicular.The Cellarium café supplied the Benedictine monks with bread and ale.and now supplies its many visitors with light meals, sandwiches and cakesThe abbey is always busy and in August expect to queue for at least an hour.The cost is £15 concessions and £18 There s a free acoustiguide available in the northtransept. We paid £5 extra for a guided tour and it was worth every penny. The vergersare a great source of information and can, of course, answer questions unlike the audiotour. You also get to visit the St Edward Chapel which other tourists do not get to see.Photography is not allowed but there is a shop with some wonderful souvenirs including postcards.The abbey is very close to The Houses of Parliament and both can be visited in a day if that is all the time you have. You could spend several days in both of them and stillwant to come back for more...

steeped in history. Really enjoyed our trip to Westminster Abbey. So much history and burials from the 5th Century until the late 20th Century. The connection with the Royal family is impressive ( even though I am not a great fan of monarchies in the 21st Century) . That being said, you must be impressed by the history and sheer age of the building. Well worth a visit.

Amazing. Simply said: Amazing! If in London for the first time, make sure you visit the Westminster area coming up from the tube at the Westminster station. Coming up from the station you have the great view to the Houses of Parliament and the park. You if time it right, you might get a chance to hear the bells of the Westminster Abbey. Another option would be to take the tube to the Waterloo and cross the bridge. This option is better as it offers great photo ops with a great deal in the background. Once at the Westminster Abbey, take your time to explore - get the map and the audio guide and follow them. So much history at such a small place. Visit the Cloisters and the gardens. Light a candle. Hear a prayer. During our visit (both not religious persons) there was no mass, but a priest took a moment and said the most beautiful words about our loved ones, the departed and spreading love and being respectful to one another and going the best we can. To hear such nice words in such an amazing place at the right time, brought tears to my eyes.

Can't go to London without seeing Westminster. Wow, I don't generally like walking around looking at churches. This isn't exactly a church. Amazing to see all the royal's tombs. Sir Isaac Newton. The poets corner with so many literary giants. We found it funny how so many tombs/graves and in the floor and everyone just walks on them. Tradition

Wonderful. Well worth the entrance fee. I was surprised at the tombs you can view really close of past Kings and Queens and the history in there is amazing. I must have spent 3 hours in there. Staff are really helpful on friendly. Even on a busy day it's still worth a visit. Definitely part of the 'must do' experience in London

Staggering History and Reverence. One thousand years of history and worship enveloped in this magnificent building creates a visible link from the past to today. Every step brings you near or on top of the most famous people that you have read about in school. We attended Evensong and watching the ancient ceremony with fellow worshipers was inspiring. We entered/toured the Abbey in the afternoon and then at about 4:30 crossed over to the entrance for the Evening services. That put us first in line for the services on the inside while others were lining up outside. It costs to tour the Abbey but the services are free.

Breathtakingly beautiful. If you have the chance to visit London this site is a must! The views of the church are breathtaking. Just sitting in the pews and close your eyes and then open them to the true beauty of what this place has to offer. The lines can get a bit long but with the London Pass I was able to by pass the line and get a free audio guide. Once you're in the cathedral make sure to light a candle on the prayer table and submit a prayer. Once in a lifetime experience.

Church service. You can attend a church service at Westminster Abbey. Ask the guard at the gate for the times. I believe they are at 5PM and the one at 12:30PM is also Holy Communion. OMG. My niece and I had Holy Communion at Westminster Abbey. I was overwhelmed with tears! Must do for any believer...

Westminster Abbey. As we had already paid a rather high fee to see St. Paul's Cathedral, we decided to attend the 5:00 evening song so that we could see the famous abbey for free. You need to arrive a little before the service begin (or, if you get in early enough, you can sit in the choir section). You have to tell the guard that you are there for the services, and he will let you through without charge. I loved looking around at the beautiful architecture and enjoyed the lovely service. We were seated on hard chairs that are probably set up for service daily as they aren't permanent fixtures, and we were packed in tightly. It wasn't the most comfortable service ever, but it was easy to see and hear everything. I really would have loved to explore the abbey for hours, but I was really over paying ~$50 for my husband and I to tour London attractions.The only real complaint I have with the churches in England is their double standard. If you are going to charge a (rather high) fee for admittance, you really lose a little bit of your credibility of calling it a sacred ground and therefore banning photos. Profiting off a religious ground and not even allowing pictures is a little shady.
Abbey. Churches and cathedrals are not my cup of tea,but yet again another attraction that should be on your london's bucket list for first timers.

Absolutely breathtaking!!. What could I seriously say that hasn't already been said before? This is one of the most beautiful and overwhelming buildings I've ever seen. The architecture is absolutely stunning and it's simply amazing that this building has been standing for hundreds and hundreds of years. Even more impressive is the sheer number and importance of the people buried within its walls. To stand near the graves of Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, Charles Dickens, and Geoffrey Chaucer was a feeling that I shall never ever forget. If you're in London for a short trip and are wondering which places you should see, Westminster Abbey should be your #1!

Great for history. I have been a couple of times with different people and the reaction is always the same. Make sure you use the audio guide, you learn so much! Poets corner is great, I have spent a lot of time reading everything on the walls and floor here
Pretty Outside View. I didn't go inside, but the outside view was great. The line is a little long, but I went near lunch time. Be sure you go early enough so you can avoid most of the lines.

Westminster Abbey - A top attraction in London. Westminster Abbey is a UNESCO World Heritage Site founded in London around the year 960AD. This is one of the most important sights in the country and a place that is well worth including on your must-see list of attractions. This is the sight of English coronations, weddings and funerals processions for the monarchy for the past millennium. It is also the resting place of many important figures throughout British history, probably the most remarkable collection of tombs in the English speaking world. Entry price is a bit steep at (£18.00 per adult and £8.00 per child) but entry includes a very good audio guide, narrated by Jeremy Irons, that helps you identify important tombs and understand other things you are seeing. There is also a handheld brochure map that you can use to help navigate your way around the abbey and grounds. Do make sure you pick this up once inside. In addition to the many important tombs and other interesting things to see, the abbey itself is a gothic masterpiece, with a attractive nave, vaulted arches, stained glass windows and other classic gothic architecture that provides the perfect medieval feel for this attraction. While visiting, try to make time to also see St Margaret's Church in the courtyard, the Abbey Museum, lovely Chapel House and Cloister. There is also a Abbey Garden that you can visit, the Cellarium Cafe found in a 14th century store room and gift shop at Westminster Abbey as well. Altogether, you can easily spend 1.5 - 2.5 hours here if you use the audio guide visit the rest of the abbey grounds leisurely. Tip: A great way to visit Westminster is to arrive around 8.50 am in the morning, allowing you to hear Big Ben sound off at 9am. Then, you can make your way over to Westminster Abbey to queue for the opening at 9.30am.If you are in a group, one member can stand in the queue, while the rest of your party walk across the street to Parliament Square to see the statues of important historical figures found there or you can walk around the abbey to admire the Gothic architectural exterior of the abbey. Then it will be time to enter Westminster Abbey at 9.30am to begin your visit.

My favorite site. You can get lost in thought while taking this tour. You'd be surprised at who is buried with in these walls. It's a museum and active Church. You have to see it to appreciate the attention to detail and beauty. You will forget that you are basically inside of an indoor cemetery. The building is grand.

Stunning. We were able to attend a service at Westminster Abbey. It was a lovely service, but the pipe organ was phenomenal. That, along with the architecture, of course, were the highlights for me. The side of Westminster Abbey that seems to be most often shown in photographs looks quite different from the rest of the church. I enjoyed exploring the other sides of the church as well, so be sure to walk around outside too!

A Heavenly and Royal Connection. I walked up to it in awe of its majestic beauty! It is a well known and famous landmark in London. Many royal events have taken place here over the years. More recently, my friends (smile) Prince William and Kate the Duchess of Cambridge got married here. I visited here on my birthday, July 22nd which happens to also be little Prince George's birthday (their son) that he shares with me I might add (smile). As I walking toward the entrance, the bells were chiming loudly and it lasted for quite some time. I wonder if they were recognizing Little George's birthday oh and of course mine. I didn't have to wait long as I was using the London Pass which had a fast track entry. The inside was just breathtaking as well. So many famous people from history coming from all walks of life are buried here. I was walking in the footsteps of them and the royals who have visited there. The courtyard and gardens are also impressive. The greenery surrounds you and it is so serene in the midst of all of the visitors. As I was leaving, I heard angelic voices. It was the choir practicing upstairs. I stood there and just listened for a few moments taking it all in. I then recorded a few moments of it and got a little teary-eyed. It is a must see on so many levels! You must make it a part of your visit to London. If you are using the London Pass, your admission is included. If not, there is a fee and it is worth every penny. I highly recommend it to everyone reading this. Plan on spending about 2-3 hours there. You will walk away with a better understanding of all of the beauty and peace these cathedrals have to offer.

Westminster Abbey. My favorite place to visit in London! Simply incredible. So many characters of significance to Anglo-American history (and Western history in general) are memorialized there...stunning. If one is of faith, try to attend an Anglican mass there--after all, Westminster is still, above all, a working church. The audio guide device works well. No photos allowed, but there are plenty of sources for images. The staff are very helpful and knowledgeable. Easy to get to...right by Parliament. Must see!!
Stunning. It's well worth the money to go inside. There are handheld audio tours so you can see the points of interest at your own pace. They have a very nice gift shop too.

Must See. Westminster Abbey should be on everyone's bucket list! It is breath taking! The only let down is that they do not let you take pictures due to copy right (yeah, that's right, copy right laws!) I was told you can, however, go on-line and pay a fee to get the right to use your camera, but it was too late for me.

How can you review your spiritual life?. You can't talk in a trivial way about such a profoundly important place in Britain's spiritual life.Kings and Queens have been crowned here since 1066. Of course tourists walk around here like vultures with their cameras constantly snapping but underneath all the tourist razzmatazz is a deeply spiritual place and if you attend a service here instead on being a tourist you will experience the true spirit of the Abbey. The sound of the world class Westminster Boys Choir will send chills up your spine their voices are like angels singing.As you gaze upon the main alter there is a golden haze around the alter the points toward the spiritual...

Gorgeous!!!. We were very lucky to arrive on a day where a protest was happening in the Westminster area which kept all the tourists away. We've been here before when the line to get in is quite long but due to the influx of protesters there was no line this day. Anyone who appreciates Abbeys and Churches and such will find this particular one GORGEOUS. Couple that with the historical significance and a history, architecture buff will be in heaven. I only wish I could have taken pictures but alas, they don't let you ... or at least they ask you not to.

Westminster Abbey without pictures!. Westminster was one of our destination attractions this trip and we were not disappointed. Well, maybe a little disappointed that we couldn't take pictures. The sheer number of famous and not so famous people buried and memorialized is astounding. The audio guide is worth the small fee. The periodic pause for commemoration and prayer by the Abbey minister reminds you that this is, after all, a church. Searching for, and finding, your favorite dead person is a treat and often surprising. Charles Darwin has one small likeness and a plain slab! And it's next to Isaac Newton's much grander memorial.The size of the place spreads the crowds out to a tolerable distribution. Some areas get crowded because of the narrow one way in - same way out traffic flow.All in all, it is still a must see for anyone interested in the history of our world.

Upscale Royal Graveyard. They pack so many crypts and memorials to the royals and famous into this cathedral, you wonder how they can still perform religious services any more. The price of admission includes rental of an recorded audio tour with headphones which is a must to make sense of everything. Big Ben, Whitehall and a park with statues of peace-makers from around the world are nearby.

No Line. No line at 2:00 P.M. To the landmark Westminster Abbey. We paid an extra £5 and took the verger lead tour. Our verger was enthusiastic and funny making the beautiful old building come to life with history and personalities that graced the walls. Our verger had been present for the wedding of Will and Kate and the funerals of lady Di and the Queen Mum. He shared stories from events. I feel forever connected to the place now that I've sat in the quire and stood at the foot of the high altar where so many historical events have and will occur. The tour took us behind the high altar where Kate and Will signed their marriage certificate before exiting the church. The knights' chapel with all their colorful banners and coat of arms contrast with the deep dark wooden chairs and sky high ceilings carries you back in time. It's the resting place of many kings and queens, poets and writers, scientists and the who's who of centuries. Names like Sir Isaac Newton, Mary Queen of Scots, and Rudyard Kipling link this cathedral to the notables of history gone by. Walk through the towering arches and let this landmark take you back to the distant and not so distant past. Westminster Abbey is a must see!

Overpriced and Over-rated, but can you miss it?. This was my second time at Westminster Abbey, and I remembered being a little unimpressed the first time. I gave it the benefit of a doubt ten years later, but was still unimpressed. The space is gorgeous, definitely, and there is so much rich and amazing history here. However, it is extremely crowded and over priced. I have been to cathedrals all over Europe and Westminster is pretty 'standard' in terms of architecture. I'm certain you can find just as amazing, if not more spectacular, quieter cathedrals throughout the country. If cathedral architecture is your thing, head out to smaller centres. If you want to learn about England's monarchy and see some historic tombs, go to Westminster. After visiting for the second time, I realized that its historic burials are really the main attraction (but most of the time you cannot get close enough to the actual tombs because of crowds). If you have the money and the time you shouldn't skip it altogether. However, if you are on a limited budget, do not worry about skipping this place to save a bit of cash.

Great Place to Visit with Audio Guides. The Westminster Abbey had so much more history than I had previously realized. The audio tours were very good and are very well organized.The only downfall is that within the Abbey itself, there is no photography - a little bit of a bummer, but it made me focus more on the guide stops within the Abbey more.We were there for a couple hours walking around, listening to the audio guide.

Very Impressive. From an architectural perspective, the Westminster Abby is an very Impressive architecture, if you love history it is filled with that. All of the kings and queens are buried there, you can get a free gadget where you can listen to the various historical information, i.e. who is buried where and the history associated with those kings and queens. There is also the “the Poets corner” where many of the great literally icons are buried and represented. For the younger generation, this is where Princess Diana’s funeral took place and for the even younger generation, this where of course, we witness Prince Williams Wedding, With all the history associated with the Abby, I found it to be less of a spiritual experience then maybe I would expect.

Visit with London Pass. London Pass offer a fast track entry to visit the abbey which is a bonus especially during this summer holiday where there was a lot of visitor. This abbey is a little too crowded for me. Nevertheless, the building itseld was impressive and of course the audio guide is very useful.

So beautiful wish we could have taken pictures inside. Beautiful church with lots of interesting history to it. Too bad you are not allow to take photos inside because the interiors are amazing. Well-organized clearly marked self-tour inside. We greatly enjoyed this site.

Every bit as grand as you think it is. We had the London Pass, so we did not have to wait in the long line that formed to visit Westminster Abbey, we had express entry. We were there when the Abbey first opened on a Thursday. We used the audio guide that came with the tour ticket. It was interesting, but a little long. There is no photography inside Westminster Abbey. There were lots of people there, but it didn't feel crowded. If we had to wait to look at something it was only a moment or two. There are many people from members of the royal family, nobility, famous writers, actors, scientists, and many others buried or commemorated there. Westminster Abbey is very ornate and beautiful. We greatly enjoyed our visit there.

Go early and be prepared to pay.. It gets quite crowded...I happened to walk by and just ended up in the line...managed to be one of the last people to be admitted. The cost was pretty high (18 pounds per adult). I'd been there before, so being able to see new additions to it was interesting. History buffs will certainly enjoy it.
Fabulous. Loved seeing this beautiful historic place. Great service and gave us fantastic Royal Navy discount. Beautiful Even song and atmosphere

Go early in the morning. Even if you go early in the morning, there is a big line to enter. With the London pass, the line was shorter, but we still had to wait 15min. the church itself is impressive, but the audioguide tour was a little long. Some places in the church were very crowded.Don't go on Sunday. It's closed for service.

Take the Verger-Led Tour. In a word: "incredible". This was our first time visiting Westminster Abbey and it was one of the highlights of our four days spent in London last month. We opted for the 90 minute Verger-led tour and couldn't have been happier with that choice. There is so much history/information to take in at Westminster Abbey and this tour allowed us to see the highlights with lots of great information provider by our enthusiastic and knowledgable Verger. Although the entrance fee itself was a bit pricey, we thought the Verger-led tour at just £5 (above the admission fee) per person was a great value for the money. If you take the tour, allow extra time to explore on your own afterward to get the full experience at this absolutely incredible place.

Famous Kings and Queens. A must see in London. Amazing to see this absolutely stunning gothic design up close. The details are truly amazing, and we loved finding bats in the design. We used the London Pass and walked right in with no wait or fee. My teens loved the inside of the Abbey, and finding Isaac Newton's tomb. The history is just overwhelming. Take your time in finding all of the majestic tombs. It is quite an experience to be in the church,where many funerals and wedding have taken place. It was our favorite place to visit in London. We stopped for lunch in the Abbey's restaurant, and it was a relaxing atmosphere upstairs to enjoy tea and sandwiches.

Beautiful - Get there early!. My husband and I started our first day in London exploring Westminster Abbey. There is no doubt, this is a beautiful building. We arrived about an hour and a half early and there was no line. We explored the area and had a great time taking pictures until a line started forming about 45 minutes before it was supposed to be open. Once the line began forming, we jumped in. The line was allowed to enter the gates and wait outside the door to that Abbey once the opening time arrived. We were however left waiting there for another 30 minutes before anyone was let in as there was a service going longer than had been planned. Be prepared for unexpected wait times!Tips:- Arrive at least an hour before opening and get in line. The line is actually around back, we had a hard time finding it.- There is no way to buy tickets ahead of time. You can however buy a London City Pass, and that will get you in here. - There was a separate line for those with a London City Pass. This line was much shorter. - The audio tour is great if you have the time, and budget, for it.- There are no pictures allowed inside. - I found that one of the buildings serves an afternoon tea, I did not get to partake in this, but I would love to the next time I go. - There is a store that can be accessed at any time and you don't have to tour the Abbey to go in. - I believe there were restrooms on site.In summation, this building is beautiful, full of history, and worth a stop. Make sure to get there early and plan in enough wiggle room for unexpected waits.

Beautiful, but pricey.. Westminister Abbey is something you've got to see while in London. It's a lovely church, and it looks even better in person. I was shocked that you had to pay to get in, though. It was £18 for an adult ticket, and £8 for a kid's ticket. The audio guide was very informative, but VERY long, and it had too many unnecessary details for my taste. My kids were bored to tears, but maybe the experience is more suitable for older teens and adults. The staff members were helpful and knowledgable and the church was very pretty. NOTE: Photography is not permitted inside.

I only wanted to say a prayer!. As a Christian living in England I had just heard of the death of a friend and asked to go in just to pray, even a side chapel, I didnt want to visit the Abbey but I was refused admission! I was advised to go to the church next door but this was "closing" and again I was refused admission even to say a quick prayer.I have been in as a tourist before but think the £18 admission charge is disgraceful.

amazing. I liked the dimension of the abbey, the fact that audio guides are free (entrance is paid though) and available in European Portuguese, I liked the memorial to Isaac Newton, the huge number of historical people buried and/or remembered there (kings, queens, dukes, Jane Austen, Geoffrey Chaucer...). It is a must see for everyone, specially history lovers.

Not What I Expected. I had expectations of this cathedral from what I saw on television but I was disappointed. It was hard to imagine where the weddings, funerals had taken place. It was interesting though to see the tombs and coronation chair. While the lineup was long it didn't take long to go through.

Worth the wait. We had about a 45 minute wait to get in (the line is quite long but does move fairly fast) but once in it is truly amazing. The size of the building alone, and the extent of the important figures memorialized there, are both overwhelming. Audio guide is very informative and you get a sense of the sweep of British history, although as an American I get a bit confused about which king came when.I should note, however, that the kids were significantly less interested. We took about 2 hours going through (it was very crowded so can get quite slow in spots) but the kids (10 and 14) were mostly "done" after about 30 minutes. [By way of contrast, these same kids spent 2 hours in the Churchill War Rooms which held their interest the entire time.] So if you're taking children then balancing this with something more "fun" for them may be necessary, and it would probably be best to do this early in the morning.

Steeped in history. Queued for 25 minutes to get in - absolutely worth the wait!ProsSo. Much. History! The audio guide is very good and gives additional information as well as the standard tour. Stunning church to be inside. So beautiful. There are spots where you can sit to one side and take it all in. There are plenty of guides in red or green gowns around to help should you need it. Great shop at the end of the tour.Cons It's busy! The café wasn't great - my order was wrong; there was a bit of kitchen towel in my daughter's meal. Staff were excellent Howe er and offered complimentary tea/coffee and 20% off the final bill. I'd eat elsewhere if I were you though.Overall - the Abbey is not to be missed!

London icon. You really have to do this once. The history and majesty of the place is stunning. Some parts are quite beautiful, although centuries of additions have obscured as much as enhanced. There is also a very nice little restaurant, that seems like a oasis after you've walked your feet off. The abbey is something I've wanted to see nearly all my life, and I'm glad I did, but I probably wouldn't need to do it twice. Although, attending evensong might be pretty amazing.
Well worth a visit. Rather long queue to get in so I'd advise booking in advance. But once in there is a huge amount to see and the audio guides are excellent.

A must see in London!. Wonderful old cathedral filled with rich history. Definitely a must see in London. Line was long to get in but moved quickly. Did an audio tour and it was very good. Crypt underneath was very fascinating. The original coronation chair that every King or Queen for last 800 years has been crowned in was a highlight as was the rest of the Royal history inside.

Incredible. You have to pay to get into the Abby, however, if you take a part of the 12.00 mass you get in for free which is the steps we took. Absolutely incredible structure and is very interesting to view the tombs of many famous Brits.
Memorable. Highlight is of course Poet's Corner. But numerous other dignitaries buried there as well. Spent longer than I expected, but well worth it. Would do it again.

Possibly my favorite place in London. A stunning church and so much history within its walls. I am continually amazed at how welcoming the clergy here are- they show their visitors great respect and on both my visits have made me feel like a member of their ministry (but not in a creepy "we're trying to convert you way). These are truly people of God- their love for their ministry and their cathedral is evident and they do a great job sharing it.

Wonderful. The Abbey was a wonderful experience. It was a bit pricey for a church but well worth it. Photography is not allowed in the Abbey. We had a wonderful time despite it, We had a wonderful lunch after our visit, right outside the Abbey at the cafe. It was a delicious afternoon tea.

Incredible ornamentation. The architecture from outside and in is amazing. The design of everything inside is incredible. The cost is a bit steep if you are not a big fan of British or religious history.

Stunning building and the resting place of so many great people.. Being non-religious myself, I can take a certain pleasure in simply coming here to revel in the irony that such people as Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin are now being remembered and honoured in a religious institution. There is plenty here for science, history and literature nerds -myself identifying as the latter two. The lines are intimidating but move quickly and are well worth it. Arrive early to beat the crowds, and please for the love of whomever it may be, skip the Cellarium.

What a building, from the outside!. I couldn't justify £18 to get in when everyman and his dog was there lined up for at least 100 metres. The crowds were enormous and there is no opportunity to take photos inside so with my time limited I wondered around and marvelled at the buildings breathtaking beauty from the outside. It is an outstanding gothic building, simply huge, and makes you question the ingenuity of medieval times. Even just looking from the outside is worth the effort.

Loved it, another must see.. We used the audio guides for the tour and they provided a detailed account of the history of the abbey. Beautiful gothic architecture on the outside and the history of the abbey is so amazing. Even younger people will enjoy the stories of the weddings and coronations which took place here.

Jaw dropping. We were a family of 4- Mom,Dad and 2 teen boys. All were amazed. Not only is the abbey breathtaking but the total accumulation of history is mind boggling. Use the audio guide for sure to get the most out of the visit. An amazing place to make history real and tangible from 100s of years ago to simply a few months. Lovely.

Beautiful place with wonderful history. Loved visiting Westminster Abbey. Gorgeous sanctuary with amazing history. Make sure to visit the tombs throughout the church. So many historical figures laid to rest here. Would recommend to anyone visiting London.

Westminster Abbey is a must see.. Breathtaking in its grandeur and steeped in history. We queued for about half an hour at 10am which was not too bad. Cost was 18 pounds per adult and 15 for seniors. I would recommend the use of the free audio tour so you know what you are looking at as well as the history behind it.

The beauty of Gothic architecture. We waited in the queue for almost an hour, but it was definitely worth it. Even from outside you can admire the beauty and majesty of the Gothic era. The high arcades, the vaults, ... it really takes you back in time and makes you wonder about the genius behind it.It's forbidden to take pictures once inside, but that's ok, it gives you more time to amaze your eyes with its majestic rise and details. You can see tombs of people like Newton & Darwin. There's no personal guide, but they give you an iPhone with a preprogrammed tour, and this will lead you on your journey. You can even see the tomb of Queen Elizabeth and her rival Mary queen of Scots. At some point it gives you shivers in the back. I Suggest you read a little bit more about those 2 ladies before visiting the Abbey.We spent 2 hours there but it surely deserves more. It was truly awesome !! It's a must-see when you are in London.

Skip the audio tour- do the Verger led tour. I did the verger led tour around the Abbey. Verger Benjamin was outstanding! He knew everything, engaged everyone in the group from children doing the children's trail to the adults and gave very clear directions and told us when we were standing on someone famous. Best part of the tour was being able to go behind the rood screen into the actual shrine of St Edward where the general public are not allowed to go. You definitely need to allow several hours to see the whole building.

Evening Song. Walking through Westminster Abbey my children and I talked about the kings, queens, heroes and all around historical figures that created history in those walls. We almost missed having the opportunity to see the Abbey because we arrive 15 minutes too late for visitor hours (our mistake and trying to see everything within a 4 day trip). However, we lucked out and had the opportunity to see the Choir perform the evening song. It turned out being a full mass (my husband and I enjoyed the atmosphere and seeing the pageantry of the mass, but my kids thought I tricked them into going to mass during vacation). In the end we all enjoyed the music and the small tour of the abbey.
Breathtaking Architecture. We only waked the grounds and took pictures. Everything in London is beautiful, but this building is simply amazing.

Busy but Impressive. Had to queue for about half an hour to enter and the entry price is a little high, but overall it was worth it.Beautiful architecture and more tombs and plaques of the great and the good than you can imagine; really impressive.Try and go a quiet time because there were too many people inside to fully enjoy.
a trip through history. Take time to read the plaques and listen to the excellent audio guide (free). Not inexpensive entry, but worth it for the chance to be steeped in English history.

Don't pay the 18 Pounds to get in... Attend the 5pm service and it's free. Don't pay the 18 Pound entrance fee to get in the Abbey. If you attend the 5pm church service offered daily, it's free. But so much history in the Abbey. You can't take photos inside, but just looking at all the historical, famous, and political figures buried at the abbey is just amazing. If you admire history, this is one place you want to go. A must see!

A must for History Lovers. Truly awesome. The Gothic architecture is breathtaking, it is like the Palace of Westminster, one of the most beautiful buildings I have ever seen. 1,000 years of history covering Royal Marriages, burials and Worship. Poets Corner - has burials from Chaucer, Tennyson through to Dickens. There is seating here to rest and absorb the atmosphere and read all the famous names. If you are a history buff you will be in your element. Go early - opening time - as the queues can be horrendous. I recommend the audio guides. It is a bit pricey for a family but worth it. It can be busy in the tomb area particularly near Edward the Confessor but we were ahead of the crowds and had no problem. It is dimly lit which adds to the reverence of the place but watch out for the occasional uneven flag stone and small steps. The beautiful vaulted ceiling, tiled floor, pews and heraldry let you know you are about to walk down one of the most famous aisles in the world - most recently walked by William & Kate & now us! There is just too much to mention - all positive. Beware - the coffee concessions are to be avoided as a real rip off - expensive - sneaky cups full of froth no coffee. They are a concession in the walkway/quad that rely on the fact that queues are too long to go back to complain. This negative is minor to what is a brilliant day out. You won't be disappointed. Very highly recommended.

history is amazing. loved the history here. Take a guided tour to full appreciate everything that has happened here. Reading about this place would take all week, so do yourself a favor and pay for the tour,

Beautiful place to visit. Visited with two children. We all liked the interactive guides and the self guided tours using those are brilliant - enough information set out in a clear manner but crisp enough to keep children engaged. Highlights for me were Darwin's grave, poet's corner and the tombs of Elisabeth I, Mary and Mary queen of Scots along with the absolutely stunning architecture. Unfortunately we missed the cafe, though the shop is very good and much less expensive than other attractions for "London" merchandise and nice historical replica items- e.g quill pens. I highly recommend visiting (thug it has taken me 4 annual trips to London to get this far)
Nice place to visit. I recommend you to get the audio box, it explains about the tombs, monuments and everything. I personally thought the tickets were expensive, but worth the visit.

English history - feel a part of it. Visiting Westminster Abbey is always quite exciting and always has been. I first visited the Abbey in the early 80s and have been back ever since. The last visit was with my daughter who had never been to the Abbey before, although she has been to London frequently since she was born. She really enjoyed the history that can be discovered in every corner. Imagining what events have taken place in this building just takes your breath away. The tombs of former kings and queens are well worth a visit, if you are interested in British history.

Dear Abbey. Westminster Abbey provides Audio boxes in various languages to guide you through the facility. It is a very interesting tour and it is amazing to stand in front of the tombs of many very important historic people

Beautiful place. This is really interesting place to visit. There is a great deal of pomp and circumstance here. Buried famous British people right inside. There is a picture of the latest royal wedding. Not a place to miss on a trip to London

Very beautiful from the outside, not worth going inside.. The outside is one of the most amazing building I have ever seen. Although the inside is also nice it's finished very quickly, not worth paying that amount to see something for a few minutes.

Final Resting Place of Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin!. The significance of Westminster Abbey is that almost every important figure in English history has left their mark in this Gothic monastery church: many monarchs are buried here and there are monuments to historical figures who have made significant contributions to culture, literature and science, such as William Shakespeare, Charles Dickens, Sir Issac Newton and Charles Darwin. If you had read Dan Brown's novel, The Da Vinci Code, you wlll also remember that Westminster Abbey is the setting of a climactic scene in the novel—another compelling reason you should visit this intriguing place.
Wow. It was so beautiful and hearing about the kings and queens of the past was amazing. The building is so beautifully breathtaking.

Awe Inspiring. Although there was a long queue, the wait was not very long and well worth it. Handheld audio guides are available and quite helpful; you can choose to hear additional info. All staff were very friendly and seemed eager to answer questions.One gentleman who had been with the Abbey for many years invited my husband to sit with him and gave great additional insight. Upon learning my Mr had been in the military, he made sure we didn't miss any of the tributes to Americans that we may have missed. Although I do not consider myself to be highly spiritual, I was quite awestruck. The amount of history at your feet (literally) and fingertips is immeasurable, not to mention the breathtaking architecture. You can easily spend several hours before you realize it. The surrounding area is also wonderful with the Houses of Parliament and Big Ben outside one entrance and Parliament Square Park at the other.

Worth a visit. The first I've been to Westminster Abbey was many many years ago and I noticed that a lot has changed since those days. Whilst I found the admittance fee quite high (in my opinion one should not have to pay to get in to a place of worship), one was able to get an audio guide to walk around the Abbey on his own pace. There were no audio guides available several years ago (or at least I can not remember it). There are plenty to see and many famous writers and actors etc reputable people were buried here. The abbey gets very crowded at times so get in early to avoid it.

Walking ON History. Westminster Abbey was a well worth it visit on a recent trip to London with a group of my students. It was one of the first major sites we visited and reinforced how much amazing history there is in London/England, and how passionate the locals are about it. We hired a guide for the day to take us here and to the Tower through Walks.com (Simon) and he was fantastic - knew EVERYTHING. There may have been a point towards the end where the students felt on overload. Every corner, stone, tomb direction and location, colour and crest seemed to have great meaning. It was incredible. Seeing tombs of some of the greats in music, literature and (for me the best) science was just awe-inspiring. A must see destination. Highly recommend an audio guide or personal guide if you can make it happen.

Expensive visit to a Cathedral. We didn't go in because there was a very long line, and it was expensive and we would not have enough time to justify the fee. However, my sister went in the evening before us, went to a service and paid no fee…she actually was at what she believed to be a choir practice but then turned out to be an entire sung mass. Its a good way to avoid the entrance fee, beat the crowds and get some time for prayer and reflection.

SUNDAY NIGHT SERVICE AT WESTMINSTER ABBEY. Last time we visited London, the Royal Wedding of William & Kate had taken place a week before so the queues for Westminster Abbey were way longer than normal.This time we did intend to visit the entire Abbey but happened to be passing as the Sunday Evening service was about to begin, so thought that would be a nice way of seeing the Abbey.We loved the service, which lasted just over 30 minutes, but sadly it meant we did not see the entire Abbey as we would have done as visitors.We’d already planned our following day, so never returned to see the rest.However, what we did see was stunning, and it was very special to be part of one of the services. Another time we’ll return to see it all in its magnificence.
Honored to be here. First timers and amazed. What a beautiful place. Don't skimp on time here - there is plenty to absorb.

A Portal into Time. I didn't, at first, think this was something for kids, I was wrong! Also, if you have a bag, bring it! You get pulled out of line then you can automatically go inside. You see architecture no where in the world you can go. You just have to go!!!

The first time visiting this wonderful Abbey. Despite living in the UK for a (ehem) long time, I had never visited the Abbey before. The Abbey was very crowded when we arrived, but there was no queue when we left at 2:30pm, doors close at 3:30pm.We arrived about 11:30am and there was a long queue, which moved quickly. We had time to queue and for one of us to get food, eat it while chatting and then go in.The audio guides are included in your entrance fee and do give helpful information.It is an amazing building, standing in the quire, do look up, the ceiling is impossibly high, the feeling of being close to God.
