Don't Miss Walking ON History. You literally walk on tombstones of the rich and famous. Its really sad as all that walking is eroding the readings on the stones. Eerily Medival, evensong still takes place. Grab the recording to hear info. Talk to the guides around they have lots of info also. Interesting to see past Kings laying there. Victoria and Albert can be see at Windsor. Margaret Rose is buried there with her parents Queen Mother and King George 6. Small cafe I think was in the basement. I love history and this is amazing - but wish they would try to preserve the tomb writings on the floor. Once they are gone - the experience will not be the same.

A London Must See!. We were thrilled to be able to visit Westminster Abbey! As Americans we simply do not have such rich history in our country. It was a privilege to be able to walk where royals have walked, to see where the famous and "stinking rich" have been laid to rest. The beauty of the building is incredible! We had a private guide which I believe enhanced our experience tremendously. We'll never forget being there!

A must see in London!. Got in early and beat the long lines and crowds. A little pricey but the audio guide is a must! The history inside the cathedral is unbelievable. Very impressed!P. MartiniSydney, Australia

THE Must Do in London. Westminster Abbey is not only an architectural and artistic wonder, but INCREDIBLY rich in history. The resting place for many kings and queens as well as famous inventors, poets, writers, and more. The place where coronations and royal weddings occur. Amazing!!

A Must See!. By far Westminster Abbey was my favorite in all of London. We did the audio tour which can be a bit of a challenge on busy days but was worth the effort. You will need to exercise patience because some of the chapels are very small and there are always a lot of people. In order to get a good view of everything you will need to take your time. Here you see the Tombs of Edward the Confessor, Queen Elizabeth I and Mary I and many others as well as the Coronation Chair. In current times most of us remember Westminster Abbey as the place that William & Kate were married. It's such a beautiful solemn place. The history and architecture alone are reason to visit.

A Gothic Masterpiece where Monarchs and Great Minds Rested. I went to this place this afternoon.Built by generations, the abbey is a masterpiece of gothic architecture. I can say no other cathedral in the world can offer you the same amount of amaze that Westminster Abbey does, including la Saint Chapelle. For art historians and architects, this place is a Jerusalem for them to go on pilgrimage.Have been in love with history, I really liked the history the abbey offered. Cromwell (not really but come on let's not argue this here) a lot of kings and queens rested in peace in this very place. Through the audio guide, visitors can learn a lot about them and their stories. Lord Byron, Isaac Newton, Lord Tennyson, Shakespeare, Wilfred Owen, Lewis Carroll were either buried or had their monument erected for them here. For literature students and researchers, this place makes their dreams come true.Generally speaking, this is a great attraction. You can pick up a free audio guide here as well. I don't get it why some people chose to pay some 20 pounds just to walk around this place without an audio guide and learn nothing.

So much history for one building. I didn't know it but the monarchs are crowned there, married there, and their funeral is usually held there. Queen Elizabeth was crowned and married there. Charles and Diana were married there, William and Kate were married there. As well as famous people buried or memorialized there. Made me appreciate why the British are so attached to the "Royal Family". Their histories are intertwined. We have a President for 4-8yrs but we don't "watch him grow up". They literally watch the royal family for all the important things in their lives. And we have.....the Kardashians :-P
Amazing. We loved touring Westminster Abbey. The cost included an audio tour which I highly recommend. We loved touring and it was definitely worth the money!

Here and Gone. This major attraction features the resting place and memorials to a who's who of British royalty, as well as those known in government, literature, the arts ,sciences, etc. The architecture is well worth seeing, and being the most famed in Britain, is a must-see. Queues outside move along, but you may spend 20 min or so until you enter

Amazing!. Each time I visit I amstill blown away. You must visit the abbey on a visit to London. The London Pass covers fast pass entry, so no wait. The architecture, reliquaries, tombs, stained glass, its overwhelming. Get the audioguide.

Medieval Beauty. Westminster Abbey is a masterpiece of Medieval Architecture. As you approach this Medieval Beauty you begin to notice all the small details. The architecture can be compared to the great Gothic styles of Paris . The flying buttresses help to support the weight of the structure. The interior of the Abbey is equally impressive. Though I was surprised at the size. I thought the interior was much smaller than it looks on TV. I watched the weddings of both Princess Diana and Kate Middleton and the Abbey looked so much bigger on TV. The Abbey is quite beautiful inside. Many of the previous monarchs are buried at the Abbey as well as national heroes like Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin. We enjoyed walking in the gardens and the museum was very interesting. We attended the Noon mass in the Abbey which was a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the day.

The Abbey at it's Best. Ten years ago, by accident , we discovered the real Westminster Abbey after the sightseers had left. I was taking photos and wondered why some people were refused entry and others were admitted. Standing near the Keeper of the Gate I discovered the password "Evensong" and what a world it revealed. Being seated in the body of the Abbey we heard the Abbey's Boys Choir in full voice which was amplified by the acoustics of this wonderful place of worship. In the service itself we witnessed the Church of England at it's very best. The following year we went again and as others were rejected we whispered the password and the Gatekeeper quietly said "Certainly, you know where to go". This time it was slightly different and we were seated at the back of the Choir Box immediately behind seven members of the Men's Choir an experience that still remains crystal clear in our minds. Fast forward to Friday 6 June just gone and we are back again at 4.45pm for the 5.00pm Evensong service. However, things have changed no password needed just join the 20 metre line but the experience is still the same, magnificent. If Evensong at Westminster Abbey doesn't bring you closer to God it will certainly make you ask questions of yourself and what you can do better. England and it's Church in all their glory.

Huge, Beautiful & Worth a Few Hours. I know its a church, but I hate when I go to a beautiful site and am told I can't take pictures inside. That's right, you can't take pictures inside.Its still worth though going in and spending a few hours. It was smaller than I thought it would be, but it had way more in the way of history inside than I thought ti would. They offer up great audio guides that are helpful.The tombs inside have names everyone would recognize which makes it more interesting for all ages.We had the London Pass which was great in bypassing the lines to get in.I checked 2-3 hours, but I'd count on the high side of that and even more.

I stop in every time I'm in London. To me, Westminster Abbey is the essence of England: the history, the architecture, the . . . HISTORY! I've been there so many times, but I can't resist going back. Most recently, I was exhausted and not really in the mood to stop and do the tour again, but I ignored my aching feet and just went. Yes, the line to get in was long, but it actually moved quite quickly (I had a book to read while waiting, also). The entry price was a bit steep, but hey, it's English history! And you get a free audio tour narrated by Jeremy irons! (The English language tour was narrated by him, anyway.) I mean, Jeremy Irons? Would you want anybody else to narrate this tour? I get choked up every time I see the tomb of the unknown soldier. I can't believe I'm standing so close to Laurence Olivier (just watch "Wuthering Heights" and you'll know what I mean). And the coronation chair! Yes, I will revisit Westminster Abbey every single time I go to London, for the rest of my life. To me, Westminster Abbey IS England.

Worth a Second Visit. We visited Westminster Abbey twice. The first time we just enjoyed the beauty of the place. The second time we came back and enjoyed an organ recital by the organist at the Abbey. What a talented organist and what a splendid organ. Much better acoustics than St. Paul's. We did not take a tour, but we will next time.

Pay the 5 pounds Extra for a Personal Tour!. We loved our tour of the Abbey. Rather than do the audio tour which comes with the standard entry fee, we paid 5 pounds more per person to get a guided tour by one of the abbey staff members. This was WELL worth the money. The tour was 90 minutes and allows you to go to places in the abbey that are off limits to the general public. The tour was engaging and very intersting and went by extrememly fast. Would recommend this to anyone over the audio option.

Cool place to visit especially with a guide. We went there on a tour and I was surprised at how large it is...much more to see than what you might view on TV during Royal events. It is full of interesting history, so I highly recommend a guided tour. Very worthwhile.

A Record Of English History. If a person ever made history in England, Royalty, The Arts, Science, or Politics, they are either buried here or at least they are mentioned with a plaque. It is amazing how many names you are familiar with and who actually had a direct affect on our lives. A very reverent place. A must see more than once.

Didn't go inside. Westminster Abbey doesn't offer advance admission tickets. That means you have to wait in a huge line to buy tickets and enter unless you are the first one there in the morning. Not worth it in my opinion. I'd rather explore other parts of the city than stand in a long line. It's also a little ridiculous that the admission price is so high.

Incredible history. 5 yrs ago I missed getting into the Abbey because of their hours and a wedding. This time I made it and I wasn't disappointed. The coronation site of kings and queens as well as the burial site of many of them and a host of dignitaries. Who can stand by the graves of Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, George Frederick Handel and scores of others and not be moved. The Coronation Chair awaits the next monarch.

Weddings!. I'm not really into history, but I do know a few kings and queens were coronated here. Not forgetting the 2 big weddings during my time - Charles and Diana and William and Kate. Was in London only for the day, so did not queue and pay to get in. Just hung around outside for quick photo-op.
Fascinating Monument. It's without any doubt one of the most fascinating attractions in London. You will appreciate every single detail. a must visit.

Beautiful. Plan on being at the North side close to opening. WE didn't wait more than 10 minutes and were first on line. Stunning. Read up on all that are buried in the abbey. Really eye opening. Was so happy we decided to go there.

Verger tour comes recommended. Yes, it is expensive. It's a bit... weird that christian buildings like Westminster Abbey and Saint Paul's are so expensive, while National Gallery, British Museum, Imperial War Museum and the British library are free. Was it worth it? Yes, I think it was. We even paid 5 pound extra per person to do the verger tour. That one comes highly recommended. We had verger Ben and he did a great job. Lots of great background information, brought us to places others couldn't come, a joke every now and then. Perfect.All in all this building is fascinating, and one can spend hours in there exploring.
A must see. Beautiful architecture and in the midst of other London attractions, such as Westminster Abbey and the Thames.
A must see for all history buffs. Take time to read the walls and floor plaques, as you simply have no idea who you are walking over or past. So many famous people in such a small area.

Everyone says it's a must see, and everyone is right.. Really beautiful with a stunning history. I could have stayed here for hours- every nook and cranny has pieces of history. Be sure to light a candle and say a prayer- a truly moving experience. My only complaint was that it was hot and crowded, but that cannot be stopped on a hot summer day. And it was totally worth it.

A must see while in London. My wife and I began our honeymoon in London. We spent a few hours in Westminster Abbey, and it was truly profound. Yes, there is a decent price associated with visiting the Abbey, but it was well worth the money. Every guest gets an audio guide in whichever language they desire. Jeremy Irons narrated the English version that we used. The tour of the Abbey can be done at almost any pace. For us, though, we moved somewhat slowly so we could see all the details, and enjoy the history that Westminster Abbey represented. While we were there, there Westminster choir performed a few songs. That made our experience even better. If you are a history buff, someone who enjoys the religious side of life, or someone who sees all the major attractions wherever you go, then Westminster Abbey should be on your list of things to do!

Absolutely awestruck. Though the admission is steep (18£ per person), we don't regret a single pence of it! The free audioguide was narrated by Jeremy Irons, and the suggested walking tour takes you to all the major sites in the abbey. All of the high points, especially the tombs of Elizabeth I and Edward I, left us awestruck. All of the staff were incredibly kind and informative. If you're visiting during the high season, as we were, be prepared for quite a long line -- it took us about 30 minutes to get through it, but it was worth the wait.

The first church of England. This is absolutely worth a visit. Tombs of saints, kings, poets, authors, and scientists. The gothic interior of the Abbey is breathtaking, not to mention that it is the site of the coronation. It is a bit expensive to get in, but is included with the London Card, so if you pre purchase that prior to the trip, admission is included.

Fantastic Audio Tour Jeremy Irons!. I spent 4 days in London, and this was the highlight of the tour. Seriously, the highlight. Was there a long line? Absolutely. It wrapped all the way around the corner, but it moved fast. Very fast. Was it expensive? Yep. The cost for adults was 18 pounds (around $33) and 8 pounds (about $14) for kids. Both fees were worth every penny. I was traveling with 19 teenage students, and I required them to see the inside of Westminister Abbey because it's seen the coronation of every British monarch since William the Conquerer! This is history!I can't recommend the audio tour enough. If I didn't have the audio tour, I would have had no clue what I was looking at. The audio tour is excellent. It takes you from the entrance and all the way through the abbey. It is informative and perfromed by Jeremy Irons, a.k.a. Scar from The Lion King. So, Scar will educate you all about almost a thousand years of the British Monarchy. Well, William the Conquerer was technically French, but in 1066 after the Norman Conquest of England, he was the monarch who changed England and the English language forever.As you meander through the abbey (it takes about an hour and a half), Scar will enlighten you about the tomb of Elizabeth I, her sister Mary, and loads of other members of the who's who of British Monarchy interred at the abbey. Again, Queen Elizabeth I, the Virgin Queen, the greatest monarch who ever lived, is entombed in this abbey. Queen Elizabeth I, who defeated the Spanish Armada! And if the Renaissance isn't your bag, Elizabeth II was coronated here, as was her father George VI, AND Prince William and Kate Middleton were married here!And Poet's Corner? Fantastic. It was everything I thought it would be and more. You'll recognize the names of dozens of authors who are either buried here or have monuments dedicated to their memories. Brilliant! The audio guide will provide you with details about the most notable tombs, and since it's the end of the tour, you can take a walk around and enjoy the waft of literary history for the remainder of your visit.There's a lovely gift shop at the exit, and if you look closely, you can check out St. Margaret's Church which is on the property, but you might miss it if you aren't looking for it.So from the first tomb of Charles Darwin, to the lovely gardens at the end of the tour, this is a "must see" in London. Don't be afraid of the crowds or the pricey entrance fee. You're in London to see the most important attractions. The student tour we were on did not include this on the itinerary, so we ditched the tour and went on our own. I would do it again because this is one of the most important attractions in London for all visitors to experience.

Fabulous. This was really a great place to visit. There is wonderful history to learn about and the architecture will blow you away. The audio devices are very helpful and this is an excellent place to visit in London.

Crazy expensive!. It is £18 per person to get into the church and the line was wrapped all around the street corner. It seemed much too expensive to is to go in so we took pictures outside. The church is gorgeous and well maintained. Very beautiful but I don't think it should cost any money to go into a church. Norte Dome in Paris is free and it's a spectacular church.

dissapointing. As we were on a coach trip we had limited time, the ques outside the abbey were enormous, and the admission price was a bit high and s a result we felt it best not to wait as there was a risk of missing the coach, we did however visit St Margarets church in the abbey grounds.

Respect for history. It was absolutely stunning. The architecture was amazing and paying homage to so many people who transformed the world. Not only the kings and queens of the past, but historical figures such as scientists (Sir Isaac Newton), poets and musicians. A must see. London Pass was huge bonus as you by-pass lines.

Spectacular!!!. Wow, this was a beautiful cathedral. I can't not recommend enough to have a visit at the Abby. What a beautiful design and intricate work on the inside and outside all throughout. Really peaceful and serene and simply a beauty.!!

Rip of. Having to wait two hours to see the Abby and then having to pay a lot of money to go into a church is a rip of was very disappointed that one had to pay to go into a church England cashing in on the fact that prince William got married there totally not worth the money

Just ok. Westminster Abbey is definitly very beautiful and has a rich history. Honestly I thought it was very pricy and not enough was seen to equal the value of the ticket. Sure it was neat to see poets corner where the great authors are memorialized but the place was packed and hot. Overall just take pictures from the outside.

Absolutely brilliant visit. Everything just worked here...staff were great and very helpful...audio guide was fantastic...showed me how little I know about English royalty. I really enjoyed Poets Corner and the famous tombs of Kings and Queens of England interred in the Abbey. Get there early because it fills up very, very, very quickly in peak season

Pricey but interesting. Long queues but a gem of a visit at the end. Think they're rather milking their allure with such a hefty entry price - but there was at least a very very friendly and courteous welcome (unlike St Paul's).The audio tour is great - so good in fact you find shoals of people wandering almost mindlessly listening to it. So prepare for distracted tourists bumping into each other or standing on you (you'll do it too!) My only negatives are that it assumes a great deal of English history awareness already... And without that it was about a lot of very old names flung together without much context. If I hadn't seen The Tudors & Reign on the tv, my GCSE in History wasn't enough - and it pains me that such dramatisations were of vital use!I would also have liked to see more about the recent royal wedding. A sense of the occasion - as to be honest - that's my only awareness if Westminster, and would have given me more of a connection. Maybe walk us down the aisle with Kate and Will and explain what they'd have seen or what little, in fact, those in the service might have seen but how it would have felt. Overall considering I was reluctant to do anything so religious - I was pleasantly surprised, though the price still felt quite steep.

Memorable!. Loved everything about Westminster Abbey. The architecture, the history, the self-guided tour were amazing. This was one of the highlights of our entire trip! The line gets a little long but it is so worth it!

Not a big fan of churchs, however; I enjoyed the abby. Its a spectacular cathedral, full of history, and the graves of hundreds of famous Englishman. Disappointing archaic rules with regards to photography.

Westminster Abbey - A Must See in London. Beautiful WESTMINSTER Abbey sits next to Parliament in London. We bought tickets at the door and used the audio devices provided with the price of admission. The device was easy to operate and provided useful information as we moved from one section to another. We went later in the afternoon and we could not get into St. Margaret's Church. We did get to see the Cloisters but we had to hurry as they were closing. I would advise you to go earlier in the day.

Amazing! . The abbey is beautiful and has so much history associated with it. Also the kids audioguide is really good, we chose that one instead of the adult version and found it added alot to the history. It was super crowded with a long line so if you can skip I would recommend it (especially with kids)

A Fascinating Abbey Full of History. Walking around and exploring the sights of Westminster Abbey is remarkable. The experience is truly incredible and so much history to take in. Fascinating place to visit!

Well worth your time...if you like history.. My wife, a history teacher, and I took a Verger led tour. We bought tickets at the Abbey without prior reservations. Our guide was very informative and I learned a great deal during the tour. My wife, if course, could have led about three quarters of the tour from memory. I did stump her on Sir Robert Peel but then I'm a retired police officer.The Abbey is beautiful. Unfortunately, but understandably so, photography is not allowed inside the Abbey.The tour lasted about two hours but went by much faster.

Fascinating Place. There were plenty of history in the Abbey. The Kings and Queens that were buried there certainly made us more interested in the history. However, we found that the others buried there especially the gentries were a bit odd. They had very elaborate and sometimes weird tombs and most of them we didn't even know who they were. Must say, it was well worth a visit.

An amazing experience. We went to the abbey in the afternoon, not realising that visiting hours had stopped. However, there was an 'evensong' service beginning at 5pm (I'm pretty sure) which was just as we arrived. This was an amazing experience as we were able to experience the ABBEY IN ACTION, complete with a full choir, biblical readings and the traditional ceremonial procession. A must-do for any Christians as well as anyone who wants to witness or be apart of the service. Truly more amazing than walking through the abbey during visiting hours.

A must see!. I hear many people complaining about the price of entry fees to various sites, including this one. We purchased the London Pass and saved big. It got us into Westminster and via fast track which lets you skip the lines. The abbey is amazingly beautiful. Such great history. You can not take pictures, which was disappointing, but nevertheless well worth a visit!

Take your time.... If you like cathedrals and churches and buildings like that, you have to visit Westminster Abbey. I felt very special when I walked past (over) tombs of famous writers, poets and scientists.

It's a must see!. I have been fortune enough to be the matron of honour at a wedding here and most recently attend the christening of my cousin at the Lady Chapel. Every time I go here it takes my breath away. This really is an incredible building - there is so much to see and so much history, you feel as though you are in another century!Take time when you visit Westminster Abbey - and if you can time it to hear the organ practice then you will treat yourself to another great delight! During the week is better, and if possible not during school holidays - but if that's the only time you can get there then bite the bullet and face the crowds, it's definitely worth it!

Very beautiful. Westminster Abbey is amazing! Beautiful, reverent, we absolutely loved visiting. During our visit a worship service was being held, which we attended and took communion. A highlight of our trip to London, Westminster Abbey is one of the most beautiful churches un Europe. Highly recommend a visit.
Sacred space. I am not a Christian but there is a sense of awe as you walk into this building. It is simply spectacular. Stunning space.

Make sure to meander back and see the Abbey gardens. On the summer day we selected there was a bit of a queue, just about 15 minutes worth after joining the line after 1pm. It appears having a London Pass can save you a few minutes with it’s own designated entrance. We spent three hours in total taking the audio tour, then down to the museum and down the corridor to explore the outdoor gardens past the abbey. Judging by the lack of visitors outside, this space is often missed by visitors, because it isn’t well marked. Follow the corridor past the museum/store and around the corner to the left. Great views of the Parliament towers and Union Jack can be seen along with the charming gardens of its residents. This is a must do for history buffs as you imagine if these walls could talk.

Unbelievable. The size and scale of this one time royal place is simply mind blowing. It's gothic architecture is stunning. The location on the Thames only makes it more spectacular. It is in a busy part of town with a lot of tourists but you have to see it with your own eyes. You can get some great photos from the opposite side of the river, there's a walkway that's much less crowded than the park in front. Also, the sun sets behind the palace from there.
Just beautiful. Such an amazing church. We had a terrific time visiting this amazing gothic church. Our favorite was the Lady Chapel, don't miss that.

Must See in London. Don't miss this. There is so much to see. Rent the audio and, if you have children, ask about the children's tour. They have special audio and a worksheet for kids that keeps them engaged while you take it all in. If they complete the worksheet they get chocolate at the end. Poets' corner, Coronation Chair, and so much more. It's a beautiful place that must be seen by all.

Wonderful Site. Westminster Abbey is well worth the visit. We paid the extra 5 pounds per person for the verger tour. Absolutely wonderful! We were able to go into parts of the Abbey others were not. We learned so much about the coronations and the queen's visits and royal family activities there. The Abbey is loaded with history - monarchs, scientists, writers, etc. Fascinating structure! We were not able to buy tickets on line, but the line moved quickly even though it was wrapped well out onto the street when we arrived.

Worth seeing if you get in for free. The £20 entry is too much, as you can also see it for free every day at 5 pm, during the service. However, you will have to stay for the entire service, which is about 45 min long, but it is really enchanting hearing the choir sing with the great acoustic of the Abbey. As I had only seen it on TV before, I really wanted to see it for myself if it was that majestic and it is indeed!
Westminister. Interesting, historical, architecturally beautiful. The audio provided gave enough information that a private tour was not necessary.

Have to be on your list of places to visit!. Amazing cathedral, gorgeous from the outside and breath-taking on the inside. So much history and beautfiul stained glass windows. You need to give yourself 2-3hours to enjoy this cathedral and you won't regret. I managed to catch the choir and with that in the background as you're looking around the building, it gets quite over-whelming in a good way.

Great piece of history to see in 2-3 hours. Over 1000 years of British history with monuments and burials to the great and the good of Great Britain.At £18 per adult the price is high compared to other Cathedrals and Abbeys in the UK but I guess this is London prices!Worth a visit though, the interactive hand-held guide was useful and informative and there is no rush, just walk around at your own pace and admire the architecture and history.

If you only have time to do one church, this is it.. Too much history here to miss. From the elaborate crypts of the numerous bygone monarchs, to the place where current royalty are crowned and married, it's just too important to bypass. The architecture and interior adornment alone would be worth it without the rich history. But my favorite feature was the Battle Of Britain Memorial stained glass window in the Royal Air Force Chapel in the rear of the interior. The stained glass window, by Hugh Easton, contains the badges of the fighter squadrons that took part in the Battle.In four panels are shown visions which symbolise the Redemption. In one a squadron leader kneels before the Virgin Mary and the Christ Child. Below this she is represented in her sorrow with the dead Christ across her knees (a symbol of the sacrifice of the mothers and widows of those who died in the conflict). On the opposite side a panel shows a sergeant pilot kneeling before the Cruficifixion (a symbol of the sacrifice of the pilot himself). Lastly, above this, is the Resurrection seen by a pilot officer (representing the pilots' triumph). Seraphim, with six wings and with hands outstretched to paradise, are shown in the top row of the window. In the central section are the Royal Arms, the badge of the Fleet Air Arm and the badge and motto of the RAF "Per Ardua ad Astra" (Through struggle to the Stars). Extremely moving.

Great from the outside. We arrived later than planned and didn't have time to go inside. From the outside, it is, of course, gorgeous and beautifully maintained. The area around it is likewise very nice. In the crowded tourist area, there are many shops and restaurants, but get away just a little and you find peaceful parks with the locals.

Ridiculous entry price. Well worth à visit but entry price is exorbitant especially for à place of worship. Too expensive to visit both St Paul's and Westminster Abbey with à group of 19 adults. Disappointed it is not more accessible financially.
You must visit!. Great historical attraction you must visit while in London! Great way to pass away 2-3 hours. Enjoy and Highly recommended.

Surprisingly good. A great placeto visit and different to other churches and cathedrals. I would rate it as a must see in London.So much history to see there. So many memorials to great people. Much more to see than you expect.We visited on a Monday in late June, arriving at opening time, we got in fairly quickly, crowded but it was comfortable to move around. The audio guide is very good.

Choir. We came and saw a mass with a Choir which was fantastic and better yet we didn't have to pay. I do think that it is exorbitant what they ask for the tickets but there is always a line so the price seems right for the average tourist. Inside the abbey is somewhat underwhelming, I have seen much more beautiful churches/cathedrals from this time elsewhere in Europe.

Best decision!. I decided to visit West Minister Abbey on a little free time while taking a course over winter break and it was one of my best decisions of the trip! I ended going alone, but I think it worked out better this way. It isn't a place to go with several friends and discuss history; it was well worth it to walk around admire the beauty and learn through the audio guide. I think if you spend the time to immerse yourself in the beauty and history you won't need to worry about things like...you can't take photos inside. Yep, bummer, but understandable. I plan to go back to visit the Abbey when I return to London with my husband in the future!

Love it!. It is so much larger inside than you realize because there were additions throughout the centuries. There is so much history within these walls that it was simply breath-taking. There are people laid to rest here and memorials to there's from around the world. Young children would probably not enjoy the length of time it would take for adults to fully take in everything the Abbey has to offer. The public can attend the services though so you could just see the sanctuary that way. No photography is permitted but free audio guide is.

Take the Time. I saw a lot of cathedrals on my recent trip to the UK but Westminster Abbey isn't just another cathedral. It is a bit expensive and you do need to check their website to make sure they're open when you're there but take the time it really is worth it. The audio tour really helps and tells some amazing stories. My favorites are Mary Queen of Scots, Mary and Elizabeth, and Oliver Cromwell. There are a number of greats buried there. It's truly amazing! We spent about 2 hours there and felt satisfied.

Must-see historic Abbey. The Abbey is a must-see in London with it's incredible history, magnificent architecture and beautiful statues, memorials, stained glass windows etc., all in a working church. Really appreciate that they include an audio guide with the entry fee and that you can see everything at your own pace. We went on a Tuesday, fairly early in the morning and it was moderately busy. When you think about the events that have taken place in this church over the past 1000+ years, it is truly amazing.

Looks different than it does on television...and yes the lines are long. I've seen a coronation in Westminster Abbey on television - it looks very different walking through the abbey - much smaller and packed full, full, full of memorials and monuments...it is really quite overwhelming. A history lesson in just a couple of hours. It is fun trying to find the memorials and monuments to famous scientists, statesmen...and of course, poet's corner. The lines are long. We arrived about 9:48 in the morning and there was already quite a line but got in shortly after 10. I missed it my first trip to London, glad I went this time.

A fancy burial ground. I can understand how some previous reviewers struggle to recall the visit - photography is not permitted in this place.Westminster Abbey is the resting place of monarchs, poets and scientists. Essentially, a big and splendid burial ground. It's also where the coronations and royal weddings take place, so yeah. It's very hard to say much more about it.There is a museum inside with statues of past monarchs, but it's hard to appreciate unless you're a big fan of the British Royal lineage. Disappointed not to see George VI in the group.Come on a Tuesday/Wednesday/Thursday, when the gardens are open.The queues to get in can get quite scary but we got a quick entry with our London Pass.

Attests to the importance of Great Brittan in Western Civilization. As a student of history, and lately British history, This was thrilling. We had just been to the National Gallery on Trafalgar Square and I was totally worn out, but this place brought me back to life! I recognized the statue of William Wiberforce immediately. And there was William Pitt, the Older and the Younger. The Ladies Chapel....oh gosh, Queen Elizabeth I lays on top of her sister Queen Mary. The monument to the Royal Air Force was wonderful..."we band of brothers". Sir Laurence Olivier's monument lays right below the statue of William Shakespeare. Atlee, Allenby, Austen, Bonhoeffer, Booth and John Bunyan....and on it goes. Personal hand held tour that you carry with you and punch in the number for the narration....with the price of admission. And every hour visitors are asked to stop what they are doing an pray for a minute or two....lest we forget that this is a church. Very inspiring to me. Oliver Cromwell, Sir Francis Drake and Samuel Johnson...I would recommend some time on You Tube researching British history. Movies like Elizabeth I with Kate Blanchett, and Amazing Grace with Ioan Gruffurd and Benedict Cumberpatch are a good start.We couldn't do all that we wanted to do, it was impossible in the short time we were there, but I am so glad that I made this a priority.

Living History. Westminster Abbey was one of the highlights of our days in London. The abbey itself would have been worth the money, but throw in 29 the tombs of 29 kings and queens, and the place comes alive with history. I had seen the coronation of QE2, the marriages of Charles and Dianna, and William and Kate on television, but standing where they stood made it all seem much more real and relevant. The abbey is one of the most beautiful churches in the world. When you go to London, don't miss going to Westminster Abbey.

Don't Miss. The Abbey is beautiful, historic and fascinating. Even had lunch there and it was acceptable. Awed with the famous people buried there. Also attended Evensong - young boy's choir - beautiful and peaceful.
Awe inspiring. The grandeur and history contained here is truly beyond words. It's a must-see when visiting London (but buy a London Pass to avoid the queue that stretches seemingly forever)

Breathtaking. How can someone not be awestruck by the architecture, history, and beauty of the Westminster Abbey? The intricate details of the structure - both inside and out - are simply breathtaking. One is humbled by it and the events that happened here throughout history.We spent about two hours touring this masterpiece, but it would take at least a day and probably more to fully appreciate all it has to offer.This was the highlight of our entire stay in London. It is definitely a must see.

Absolutely gorgeous!. We visited many different cathedrals in London and this was our favorite. The church is absolutely beautiful. We really enjoyed listening to the audio tapes because we learned so much about the history in Westminster Abby.

A must see at a reasonable price. We arrived shortly after opening and were concerned that the line was a bit long but I am so glad we stayed because it was absolutely beautiful.It took us 20 minutes to actually get in after paying and picking up the self guided audio. I suggest that you make a point in getting the audio and listening to all of the information. I also got the book but walking and listening to the history truly made it a wonderful experience.I am a Tudor fan so I was glad that I could take as much time admiring the tombs and just absorbing as much as I could.I was disappointed with the Darwin tomb. I was expecting something a bit more ornate but I think that's just bias on my part because there were even smaller notations for some big name literary figures.I was glad we didn't put a time limit on our visit because we really got to enjoy ourselves.

The highlight of our London trip. What an amazing temple. Awe inspiring architecture, incredible statues intriguing history. Absolutely astonishing beauty of the Virgin Mary Chapel. You mustn't miss it.

Waste of time. Two times while in London last week i tried to visit the abbey. First it was blocked off becasue of a political protest. Then again we went there but all the doors were locked. No reason was given for the closure and no time of reopening was given either. I was hoping to visit this historic place but both attemps were a waste of time. Don't bother visiting. Just google some pictures.

I cant even remember it. I wanted to rate this 2 stars but 2 stars is poor. It is not poor but disappointing. I just got back from my trip to London and while writing reviews of what we saw, I can barely remember anything about Westminster Abbey. I know they had an audio tour and my wife said it was confusing. She did say to me don't you remember how beautiful the church was. I must say no. The one nice thing is that we had the London Pass which gave us a fast track in so we did not have to wait on the long lines to get in.

My favorite church / cathedral - so very much to see. Every corner of Westminster Abbey has something to see. The sculptures and stonework are amazing. The entry fee is a bit high but was included on our London Pass... making it so very worthwhile. The London Pass also helped us with expedited entry, though the lines to get in were not very long on the day we visited. I think the entry fee keeps the lines a bit shorter here than at other attractions in London but is still very worth the price (to me). I am sure to see this attraction on every visit to London - it even impressed my 17 year old son who is hard to impress! Use the audio guide and a map to tour the cathedral at your own pace. Some places are a bit small to get into and out of and you have to wait for others to leave a chamber or chapel before you can enter. Many of England's monarchy and political history is contained here.

Don't Miss!. A must see while in London. We did the audio self guided tour and enjoyed a relaxing tour of the entire building. We also returned for an Evensong which was a joy to hear the organ and choir.
Amazing!!!. I was really impressed with the beauty of this iconic London sight. It was definitely one of my faves. The self-guided audio tour was great.Highly Recommended.

Why. To be perfectly honest it's been a few years since I have entered The abbey , as we were visiting London with friends and my wife's friend had never been in the abbey we said we take her for a look round this fantastic abbey in the heart of London . When we got there not much of a que so we went to join the end , the down side being the entrance fee of £17.50 each DISSGUSTING we did,nt bother and we was,nt the only ones . The Church of England must be one of the richest organisations in the land , you should never have to pay to enter a church make a donation by all means after all it is a house of GOD

Abbey History ..all I think is Da Vinci Code. Quite an expensive place to go, luckily I had a NUS student card the woman in the ticket office was very snotty as I pulled out first my University student card which had just expired. I quickly pulled out my valid one. My attitude and my fiance who had forgotten his student card were a bit annoyed by the way we had been treated.Upon entering the Abbey one word..wow..a stunning building brimmed with history, no guides but an audio guide voiced by jeremy irons..awesome.I would recommend this for a visit but go towards the end of the day about an hour before closing so you don't get stuck in a massive queue.It's an experience.

Great - but better if you can get inside.. The downside to this attraction is that you cannot pre-book because they limit entries to reduce the crowds. We stayed in the queue for a while then gave up as we'd seen it before and bought a book instead. Other main attractions overcome this problem by allocating times to their bookings and this would certainly have made a difference for us. For all of that, it's still a great place.
Must see!. Westminster Abbey is another iconic London sight not to be missed. We chose the self-guided audio tour, but a guided tour would have been nice.

A fascinating respository of history. Again - been around about 1,000 years through various phases. The interesting part is the 3200 souls interred there; not all famous though must be prominent. From kings and queens to Newton and Shakespeare. Very interesting and well worth the visit if you are interested in English history and architecture - a truly beautiful building.

Wow!. Just seeing some of the memorials and markers for those buried there was worth the visit. Definitely avail yourself of an audio tour of this majestic cathedral (not to be confused with Westminster Cathedral).

Not what I expected.. I went to the abbey using my London Pass, so I'm glad that I did not pay for it. Granted, I'm not Christian, but I was interested to see the abbey from within. Upon entrance and purchase of a ticket it is possible to take an audio guide for free and tour the abbey. Each part is given a number that corresponds to a number in the guide. In my opinion, the experience was rather dull and was over within the hour. I walked around and was impressed with the insides, but not overly much. I think this attraction is suited to either Christians who wish to join the mass at such an iconic abbey, or to those who are interested in the general and specific history that surrounds it. All in all, if it was not through the pass I would have been rather angry at the price that I would have had to pay for it. And that, I suppose, says it all.

Lots of history in this place. Be sure to visit this place to understand more how brits think. I was with a £9 walk tour and felt it was just great. A lot of info about the place and the stories involving it

History History History. Spent almost two hours at Westminster Abbey. You can not take pictures inside this historic sight, you probably would be there for 5 hours if you did. From kings, queens, poets, writers, musicians and others are either buried in the church or honored for their works. Use the audio tour to help you through the walking of this historical building.
Incredible history. What a wonderful place to review some of English history. To walk where Queen Elizabeth was married and crowned queen and where Kate and William were married....wow.

Not your typical church. I am not sure what I expected from Westminster Abbey but what I experienced was not it. Although a very old cathedral, it is broken up into many different sections. It is rich with history and contains quite a few dead bodies. To me is was more of a graveyard than a church. Lots of former monarchy are buried in the Abbey as well as many famous poets, musicians, etc. from Handel to Shakespeare. Definitely do the audio tour so you can have a little more context of what you are seeing. It is worth the trip. Allow yourself some time as there is a good bit to see.

very impressive. Unfortunately we only allowed ourselves about an hour to tour the Abbey- I think it would take two hours to take a cursory look at everything that is there but if I make it back there I plan to allow several hours to look at all the memorials for prominent Britons (including the American transplants TS Eliot and Henry James) and royalty would take several hours.
Special. Nice little visit. Spent around 40 mins inside. It's where the queen had her coronation. Lots of kings and queens burials. Magnificent building.

Remembrance Day at Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey is beautiful all year round.However, I find it particularly impressive in November for Remembrance Day when they set up a field of poppies from legions around the world.I highly recommend a visit in November!

splendid. We went to see the place . The first day we reached the place at 4.30 pm and were cdisappointed to know that it has closed . Disappointed we came back the next day and were truly amazed by the beauty of the place.The architecture and interiors are breath takingly beautiful. We spent a lot of time inside enjoying the beauty of the place.

My highlight of London. I was mesmerized and deeply moved while here and will say that one should not miss this historic and spiritual wonder. I could have easily spent 6 hours here but it can be fully experienced in 3 hours. If you are interested in history then you should study a bit before visiting.

Go later for smaller queues. Incredible attraction with knowledgeable and friendly staff. Good catering facilities deserving of a wider audience.Beware, so busy in the mornings you might not be able to see all that you wish.

Too Famous. We had a very good tour here. Too crowded to be heard without our vox earpieces. That was a spoiler as it deserves quiet and the children ( not ours) were ill behaved here as usual. Among the great churches of the world ,of course, but there were actually better cathedrals in other places, just less famous.
Tombs tombs everywhere. It is an amazing church with you'd abounding. As you walk thru the Abby you are impressed in the feeling of great history and respect
Beautiful. Beautiful views, pricey souvenirs, but hey, it's London. Go early in the morning to avoid the long lines or if you have the London Pass, you get right in.

Don't miss Edwardtide!. The place is always worth a visit, and especially on Edwardtide, the feast of St. Edward the Confessor, when the Abbey is closed for tourist visits, but open for pilgrimage, allowing you to enjoy the whole Abbey in a more peaceful setting, praying at the Shrine of St Edward, and - why not? - enjoy the prayerful music and singing at Evensong! [N.B. There is normally a fee for tourist visits, but the Abbey is free for those coming for liturgies, and days of pilgrimage, such as the Edwardtide Pilgrimage].

Wow. What history and beauty?. Worst part was we couldn't take pictures but what a tour. The architecture was worth the price but then the tombs of many kings and queens and their stories. Also seeing where so many coronations have taken place including the coronation chair. I thought it was well organized.

Worth the Visit. We found it very interesting that in London the museums are free but to visit, but not the churches. But a visit to the Abbey was worth the money. The tour is well planned and the audio tour is very easy to use. So much history with the church, and we were surprised to find how many writers were buried there. Of course there are great stories involving mysteries and scandals. The architecture is beautiful.

Great attraction, but admission is high. I went to Westminster Abbey during an all day layover at Hethrow Airport. I was somewhat taken aback that there was an 18 Pound admission fee, complete with admission ticket, to see the inside of the abbey. I just wanted to walk through. There was an audio self guided tour available, but I just walked through on my own. While on one hand I am happy to support the abbey, the price seemed a little steep to just walk through, and a freewill offering with a suggested amount would have been more palatable. In general, if you are going to go inside, dedicate some time so you can see everything and get your money's worth. If you just want to look inside, and see the coronation throne on the way in, save the money and go for a worship service. Also, photography in the abbey is prohibited, shutterbugs be forewarned.

THEASE HALLOWED WALLS. I attended a remembrance service at the Abbey last year, but not what you would expect I was there for the 75 year remembrance of Kristallnacht 1938 The Abbey is great well worth a visit the building its self is spectacular. so as this was a service no admission fee for me.
Must See in London. Very Beautiful church, located right by the Parliament. There is a fee to get in, but is totally worth it.

Attend Evensong. We attended a choral Evensong service instead of paying admission to tour. It was a beautiful service but you are not able to walk around except to be seated. I understood that being admitted was for the service only but I was appalled that at several points during the service, people stood up and left! As you enter, ushers explain that you are attending a service. Tours close at around 3:30 on days when services are conducted. Visitors receive a program to follow along. Our children attended and several other families had their children as well.The Abbey is beautiful and it is an amazing experience to be in a place that represents so much history and recent royal events too. I would like to tour more and hope to return on another visit to see the famous burials.

Delightful tour. We took the audio tour at the Abbey and couldn't have been happier. You can take your time and take in the sites or rush through if you'd like. Seeing Sir Isaac Newton's tomb was a highlight especially since my husband is a huge science nerd.

History is alive. There is so much to see here. The the tombs of Queens Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots. The altar where kings and queens were crowned, married or funerals (Diana, William and Kate). Not to be missed.

Does not disappoint. Westminster is such a wonderful testament of history. I've been to London three times and I finally had the time to go inside. They have a lovely walk-through audio tour. Make sure you have three hours. Don't rush it.
Historic. It just felt good to view church where historic events took place such as weddings of kings and princes and where some are buried
Nice Place!. It is just a beautiful place to visit, you were not allowed to take photos which was a little disappointing.

You can't miss it!. What an amazing place, with so much history under one roof. Just fascinating, and so many features that have you awed by their age, historical significance and/or the skill with which they were made and preserved. Not being a religious person I was unfazed by the apparent lack of respect being given to a sacred place, but I can appreciate some believers might be upset. I didn't find the staff or attendants helpful or friendly, but maybe they are unhappy with their place of worship being turned into a financial venture more than a church. Overall, I loved my visit and would do it again.

Touring Westminster Abbey, London. We initially didn't tour the interior of Westminster Abbey, thinking the admission was a little too pricey, especially when they don't allow photos. But after hearing several friends and tour guides admonish us for not going inside, we added it to our itinerary on our last day in London, and were so glad we did. Yes, it is pricey, but with such amazing views and history, we though it was well worth it! Just to stand at the final resting place of so many famous people (like one of our favorite authors, Charles Dickens), was pretty awe-inspiring! And it left us wanting to learn more about the early history of England and some of the permanent occupants of Westminster Abbey, which is also a good thing. We aren't usually big fans of audio guides, but found the ones at Westminster Abbey, which are included in your admission fee, to be helpful and worthwhile.

Palm Sunday service. We normally go to St. Paul's for the service but this year we decided to try Westminster abbey, a superb service and a truly magnificent building. If you are in London on Palm Sunday I can highly recommend this wonderful and moving service

Gorgeous Abbey. Although I have seen this beautiful abbey on tv, seeing it in person is awe inspiring. Every time I have been to London, I have gone to the pray service in the chapel at 7:30am. There is no fee to get in at that time. We also thoroughly enjoyed listening to the evensong. ( also free to the public)
History. Full of beauty and history with volunteer docents ready to answer any questions.Lots of walking on very hard surface. Lots to see, really need much more than a day to absorb all.

Best place I have visited . Westminster Abbey is absolutely awe inspiring. There is so much to see in this masterpiece. My visit was very different from the regular person, as I know someone who works there. We saw all the people you read about in books and learn about in school - poets, musicians, political figures, scientists l, etc. It is my favourite place on earth. If you're visiting London it should be your top place to visit. It's easy to get to and there's a restaurant with great treats.

Very Historical and Educational Attraction. You have seen this palace several times on TV during royal weddings and funerals. Seeing it on TV doesn't do it justice. It is a magnificent place. Charles Dickens, Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin's crypts are here.Buying your tickets on the day of your visit is cheaper.
Beautiful . A majestic abbey steeped in English history.. Audio guide and map to guide you round the abbey.. A beautiful place to visit but vastly overpriced.

A must see attraction!. I was very pleased with what I saw there. It is the most impressive cathedral I have ever visited. It is full of architectural masterpieces. There is also an electronic portable device (like a mobile phone) which tells you information about every corner of the cathedral.I don't know what more to say. It is just amazing and I definitely recommend it!

Westminster Abbey. Stunning, breathtaking, 1000 years of history on a concentrated and mostly unchanged spot... Still visible, you can touch and inhale History... Another impression: how more effective these capable and selected weatlhy English(wo)men were to aspire for eternity and set a death-resistent commemorative to themselves in statues, etc... (resembling the Egyptian Pharaophs and their Mummies...)A smart choice is to pre-purchase a London Pass for each of your family member (may not be cheaper than buying the individual tickets but surely more visitor friendly - with this you can SKIP the frighteningly long queues and spend your limited time not in queues but enjoying the sights themselves you came for.NB - Audio-guides are available in Hungarian as - don't miss them, very informative.- Many of the inner chapels are NOT accessible for wheelchair users - lot's of steps all over the place.- The Cloister gardens are open on Tue-Thursd only.- Excellent bookstore at the end of the Abbey.- Beware - closed on Sundays!Enjoy:-)

Homage to the dead. While rife with history and grandeur, my partner and I were left empty here. After seeing many beautiful cathedrals and churches of varying stature and beauty, Westminster Abbey was under-whelming. Dark, very little spoke to us of the spiritual values that are supposedly the cornerstone of Christian churches... built to the glory of God. Instead, we both felt that this was a monument to the glory of the dead. Certainly, there were interesting dead people here. And monuments to others who were buried nearby. But... sigh... an expensive cemetery. The tourism industry really has sucked away whatever spirit this place had. Don't get me wrong. There is incredible beauty to be found here. And the history is very rich. I'm just telling you what my partner and I came away with.

A Magnificent Experience that Touchs the Soul and the Intellect. As a Sixteenth Century historian specializing in the Tudors, I am extremely biased about this wonderful building. I first visited this site in 1975 and together with the Tower it inspired me to become an historian. In 2009, I returned to the Abbey for the first time since then. When I first entered such hallowed ground, I broke down in tears of joy and of reverence. It's a relatively small space but packed with great sites that tell the history of this great country. I always head for Elizabeth 1's tomb. As David T said in an earlier review, take your time and just breath it in. Forget those audio guides -- they detract more than add to your experience. Last year during my visit with Elizabeth 1, I stepped back to observe the other visitors. A young man was so glued to his audio guide that he quickly walked past her tomb without ever looking at it. What an incredibly sad waste of time and effort! Walk slowly into each room and carefully read the inscriptions on the tombs. They reveal much about the Medieval/Renaissance attitude toward life and death, our place in the universe and man's relationship with God. Also take time to study the magnificent funereal art and what it reveals about the inhabitants. If you can, attend one of the prayer services for Edward the Confessor. For one thing, it's the only way to see the tomb and also it's a lovely experience which only takes about 5 minutes, but 5 minutes well spent. Also, as David said, make sure you look down at the floor or you'll miss something quiet wonderful, such as the tombs of King Edward VI, Henry VII"s son, who is buried in front of his grandfather's extremely lavish tomb, and also Barbara Villiers, Charles II's favorite mistress. Once you've finished your tour, walk out into the cloister area. There's a small museum there which is worth a few minutes. I noticed last year that they replaced the lovely little eatery with a higher priced restaurant. I'm not sure it's the worth the extra money, but I'll let you all be the judge of that. You must also visit the site dedicated to the Unknown Soldier from WWII. It is quite moving in its simplicity. Once outside, definitely take in the garden in back. It's a lovely place to sit and reflect on your experience which I'm sure you'll enjoy. Also, you can see Parliament looming up before you, yet another grand site. I have always been somewhat disappointed in the gift shop which acceptable for post cards and music recordings, but that's about it. The book selection isn't nearly at good as at the Tower. That said, the Abbey is one of the great sites well worth visiting numerous times. I can't wait for my next visit in late August. Maybe I'll run into some of you there.

Great audio tour. Again using our London Pass, we got entry to this iconic church steeped in history. Hard to do justice in a short review; the Abbey is so full of amazing sights and history. The audio tour is first class. Allows you to really enjoy the places of greatest interest.

Of COURSE you have to go..... Take your time and go slowly. The details are amazing. Be sure to look up at the walls, the ceiling, and the stained glass but also do not forget to look down at the stones commemorating some of England's most famous people. Not just Kings and Queens mind you, but also famous men of science (Issac Newton, Lord Kelvin) Prime Ministers (though you should know that Churchill is resting elsewhere) Poets and authors. It is well worth the trip, but try to go mid-week to avoid the weekend crowds.

Beautiful piece of history. We enjoyed our visit to the Abbey very much. It is such a historical & beautiful church. We took the audio guide & were very pleased with that decision. It offered pieces of information that probably would have been missed without it. We decided to go towards the end of the day before they closed rather than trying to beat the crowds in the morning. We were happy with that decision because we never felt crowded or rushed during our visit. This is definitely a must see when in London.

Quite a Sight. I didn't know too much about this before going but I had heard a lot about it and wanted to cross it off my London List. Turns out, this was absolutely fantastic. I didn't do a guided tour as I liked going at my own pace and the audio device was fantastic! You're not allowed to take pictures inside but sometimes, it's great to put the personal electronics away and just take it all in :)

Westminster Abbey London England. This place is huge, crowded and filled with amazing British history. I do genealogy and have traced a few royal lines and those connected with it. I wish I had my family records because this place is a virtual who's who and I recognized many of the names. The last time I was there the Abbey had a memorial flame for Princess Diana, but there is nothing there now for her. I asked about our (meaning those of us from America) last king - where was his burial. It was still on the black and white floor but I couldn't get to it because of the number of visitors on tour this day. They have audio tours so that keeps the crowds moving forward. There is a gift shop that sells postcards and other trinkets.Allow several hours and be there before the last entry of the day. While wheelchairs can come into the Abbey, there are some areas on the tours where there is no way possible for a wheelchair or walker to pass through or climb stairs. Canes would be appropriate. But the rest of the Abbey can be viewed and enjoyed.

Definitely worth visiting. I agree with most of the other reviewers that the place can be crowded, but you can always find a quiet corner to take in everything, at least in some parts of the abbey. Lots of history, literally the who's who of the country's famous people rest here and obviously most of the royal family; we were surprised to find that even Isaac Newton was interred here. The audio guide is fairly comprehensive and allows you to move at your own pace. The admission ticket at 18 pounds is not cheap, but can be afforded at least once for all the history of the place.
Beautiful and Great History. Our visit to Westminster Abbey was excellent. It is an amazing place with so much history. Worth a visit.

Even better than you envisoned. We took the audio tour. (They had them in multiple languages.) Our tour in English was narrated by the outstanding actor Jeremy Irons. We were in the Abbey for 2 or 3 hours... there are so many chapels and so much to see. At the end you can see the Coronation Chair which is in a secure spot as it is an important antique. It goes back many centuries yet is still used when a new British monarch is crowned. The only downside is that this is a very popular attraction and very crowded in June.

Take the Verger-led tour and hope your guide is David Mott. It's an extra 5 pounds but well, well worth it. Hopefully, the other Vergers are as excellent as David Mott. I took the tour this morning and was thoroughly impressed with Mr. Mott. A quick Google search indicates at least 4 other reviews mentioning him by name. Extremely knowledgeable -- there are approx 3500 people buried on the Abbey's grounds, many beneath the floor of the building itself, and I'd guess he knows all of them. The oldest part of the grounds date from the 11th century, although most of the Abbey itself is from the 14th. Not just royals buried there either, Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Chaucer, and David Livingstone being amongst the riff-raff. Of note, if you have access to video of Kate and William's wedding, Mr. Mott can be seen escorting Princes William and Harry from the Chapel that was used as their holding room.
Must See Once. A lot of history in this abbey, but also very crowded. Good to see at least one in your life. No photos are allowed since it is a church. Allow one hour for visit.

Most see, just amazing. I was there for the second time, and I was still amazed. There are so much to see, even a day would not be enough. The Abbey itself is wonderful, huge, and very impressive. Unfortunately probably for these reasons it was crowded, and the queu was long. But totally worth it. There is free audio guide, which is very good, and the tour is really well organized. I can recommend for everyone.
A treasure!. What can I say about this beautiful structure with all of its amazing historical contents. It speaks for itself. The audio tour is informative.

Must see but crowded!. We got there at opening and the crowds were heavy. I was in a (loaned from Westminster) wheelchair and we paid extra for the "verger lead tour". It was too loud to hear him most of the time, so I can't recommended. The verger was very good, when we could hear him. The crowds were a challenge while being in a (loaner) wheelchair. Wheelchairs can't go everywhere. There is SO much to see here, take your time. I agree with others about making sure they haven't closed because of special event. Check the website listed on tripadvisor. There a plenty of FAKE websites. You can only buy tickets the day of your visit at the door.

Harry Potter Central. You can't fault it really . Vaulted Halls , stone gargoyles, the spot on which the condemned king stood - its only seconded by the Tower of London ( though considerably younger) in terms of a weighty sense of history and ceremonial . You may even catch a fleeting glimpse of a Minister of State rushing away down a corridor maybe chuntering oh my ears and whiskers. It's THE consummately British affair and the home of democracy with excellent tearooms that hark back to Edwardian grandeur. But as a dedicated republican there are too many shades of the boys boarding school in its atmosphere for me - but I guess it's a privilege to be there - and WHERE would we be without it! Harry would be at home!

Breathtaking. Quite expensive to visit make sure you have your student cards on you (thats if you are one)On entering you are given a headset with jeremy irons doing the commentary seeing the famous graves of Issac Newton and elizabeth the 1st and mary queen of scots and most of the royal family and many other people made me get goosebumps but the architecture of this building s stunning Would definitely visit againNo photos are allowed to be taken inside here

Incredible.... Visited the Abbey in mid June with my wife,we have been to London several times before but had never been inside the building until now.
£18 each may sound like a lot of money but it is well worth it,so much history in one location,fantastic....

Check when it's Open!. We went on Sunday! WHOOPS. But we were treated to Sunday bells which was nice. Make sure to check when you are able to enter beforehand. My biggest regret in London was not being to get in! Very Busy.

Check the schedule before going. When visiting the Westminster Abbey, make sure to check on their operating hours since there are some days that they're closed or only till 3pm. Some of my friends told me that they never went it, they only took photos outside. Please don't let this happen because there's so much to see inside. I think it's also good to go in the afternoon (less crowd) on my experience. Some people told me about the long lines, but when we get there in the afternoon around 2pm, there were none. There's also the Royal effigies in the Westminster Abbey Museum which opens till 4pm.

Thousand Years Of History. This is a site you must visit when in London. Enter from the side entrance opposite the Houses of Parliament. Be prepared to have your bags searched. Unlike most churches and cathedrals in the UK you are asked to pay an entry fee. Immediately on entry, pick up a free audio recording machine in almost any language that will travel you around the cathedral using numbers and symbols. You will see the remains of Kings and Queens from Edward the Confessor to Queen Mary and from the tomb of Handel to Dylan Thomas. Look out for the voluntary helpers in their blue, red or green gowns. They are very knowledgeable and extremely helpful and patient. Take your time, take in the history and the atmosphere. Try the café in the cellars - extremely good sandwiches, afternoon cream tea, cakes and buns. Expensive, but very well worth it. Toilet facilities are hard to find. Use the facilities next to the café, despite it being for café users only.

Full of history. This was an incredible tour. We did the free audio tour and it was great at explaining everything you saw. There was so much to see, that you could miss a lot if it isn't pointed out to you. It was absolutely gorgeous.

Beautiful Church. Very beautiful church with lots of history attached to it. Make sure you are approprietly dressed if you wish to visit inside and there are lots of periods where outside guests cannot visit but it is a sight not to be missed if you enjoy churches.

Don't miss this!. This church is so beautiful. I thought I would be bored, but was pleasantly surprised. The architecture is remarkable and the paintings as well. There are so many tombs to visit. Queen Mary I and Queen Elizabeth I are both entombed here along with Mary, Queen of Scots, Henry VII, Margaret Beaufort (his mother), Elizabeth York (his wife). It was interesting to find Charles Darwin buried not only in a church but such a notable one as well. The only drawback is picture taking is not allowed.

a lovely church.. it is a gothic church in the city of westminster,london located close to the palace of westminster.its quite beautiful.it has been the traditional place for coronations and a burial site for the english n later the british monarchs.many royal weddings too have taken place here,the most recent being the wedding of prince william and kate middleton in 2011.though we dint get to visit from inside the exterior too was great.one can get a good view of it from 'the london eye' too.

Amazing. This is an amazing site. We toured around the grounds and the massive church is beautiful. The history associated with it is wonderful. I could have stayed there for a couple of days just to take it all in.

must visit while you are in London. Simply amazing. you can't find another place like this with some many history of UK. I night visit it again next time since definitely missed some. Too bad that they don't allow picture inside.

Another not to be missed London attraction . Okay I know it's just really one big O giant church but it has a lot of cool things in it that are not to be missed. The architecture and beauty of the building is really incredible. Not to mention the beautiful tombstones and Graves including that of Henry 11 Winston Churchill and believe it or not Charles Darwin. It is a beautiful as the store place in the little side attractions like the monuments to the Saints and the nights Templars are really something you to see at least once-in-a-lifetime. Plus you can light a candle to your favorite saint etc. We also really enjoy the cool and interesting gift shop. It is very centrally located near Parliament big Ben etc. and be a great port of a walking tour in that part of London. The headsets provided adequate historical background and knowledge of the building in my opinion. We did not take the stairways up for the scenic views. Let me also Holly recommend the little food court that was right outside of the exit of the building. We all got hot dogs and waffles with ice cream etc. there and everything we had to eat was great and actually reasonable. I don't remember the cost of this cause it was portable London pass and I believe that we actually had a quick entrance to this using the pass. In any event the lines were not bad at all here. We spent about an hour and a half to two hours which seemed adequate for this attraction although you could easily spend the whole day in this beautiful building. But with teenagers an hour and a half was plenty. It is not as cool as the Tower of London but the matter what it says on here I would rate it is one of the top attractions in the city.

Jaw dropping. This place is just beautiful...I cannot believe it is still standing and so gorgeous after all these years of war and peace. There are so many famous people buried there....and so many famous people were married there.....I had no idea. The architecture is astounding. Take time to really take it all in......you will never forget it.
Beautiful. This is such a beautiful place to see. So glad I was able to see it. Went later afternoon and there was not a line at all! Walked right in
Just beautiful. Just beautiful certainly worth a visit, you were not allowed to take photos which was a little disappointing.

Impresive (and free with mass service Sunday). We went to enjoy the chorus at 11:15 am and were able to sightsee the insight (crowning chair and say hi to the priest that married prince Williams). I even saw someone else sneaking a picture shot.

Its one of those places. I must admit at baulking at the price of entry on a previous vist to London.I gave in to Mrs JB on our return, and whilst i think it is still expensive, really enjoyed the whole experience. Thought the audio guide was very good, with plenty of information on each aspect of the journey through the countless years of history. Didnt quite realise the intricate web that a lot of the famous people had spun through various countries-seemed each town or country we visited on our travels had some connection to Westminster. Pop in, spend a morning or afternoon, and immerse yourself in not only the architecture, but the history that surrounds.

Historial Westminster Abbey. Plan to allow plenty of time to visit Westminster Abbey because it is always very crowded. Hiring a personal guide is a great way to get a lot of history and they can get you in and out through the crowds. They are real pros! What I liked about a personal guide was that they have stories that are not on the self-guided devices! One thing I missed on my first visit to the Abbey in 1998 but I did not miss this time was the Stone of Scone. It is located in the back of the Abbey and it is a MUST that you learn it's history and what happened with it at the time of Queen Elizabeth's coronation.Unfortunately photography is not allowed in the Abbey so do purchase one of the nice books that describes the history of the Abbey and provides great pictures of important tombs of interest. You may also light a prayer candle and ask for a prayer intention. The prayer intentions are picked up every few hours and the intentions are prayed for by the Abbey's priests.

Just beautiful!. This church is truly amazing and beautiful. Unreal how many famous people are buried here and have been married here. The architecture is beautiful. We had the London Pass so we didn't have to stand in line long. Well worth a visit.

Westminster Abbey. I was last here over 20 years ago when I lived in London and this special place remains the most fascinating place in the City of Westminster. When I was last here there was no entrance fee so I wondered whether a visit would be worthwhile for small children (for whom there's no charge). It was! While it no longer offers brass rubbings for them, it has created a unique workbook for children which sets up a kind of treasure hunt, asking them to complete questions about the people honored there, about the number of lions and other animals they're able to identify, and about the various monarchs enshrined in the various chapels and gravestones. For example, one of the questions asked was what happened to Oliver Cromwell, which they will learn from the free audiphone tours provided (Cromwell was buried there but later removed by Charles II, beheaded posthumously and left in the streets to rot). My children loved the exercise and they were rewarded with a large chocolate coin in the gift shop at the end of our visit. They especially enjoyed Poet's Corner, seeing the graves of Charles Dickens, Lewis Carroll and other authors they already appreciate. A high point for them was an informal tea in the Abbey's cafe, with light sandwiches, cakes, cookies and hot chocolate! They were not bored for a second and we were there for almost three hours. They actually enjoyed this experience more than the London Eye and the changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace. So for short stays with children in London make sure Westminster Abbey is high on your list.

Worth the trip. This is a beautiful place and with a lot of information. The audioguides were great and everyone was very friendly and helpful. It is a large place, unfortunately, no photography was allowed, so we have only pictures of the outside.
