Make your way here for Evensong. PRO TIP: Visit the cathedral during Evensong. The service is friendly, beautiful, and FREE. You won't feel pressured to sing or participate, but it is a great way to see the amazing building without the crowds or entrance fee. Definitely worth the visit

My favourite attraction in London.. I went to London last January with the boyfriend for a week. Westminster Abbey was my favourite attraction (probably tied with Les Misérables and the London Eye). I love historic sites more than museums. This one is pretty unique. A millennium of history awaits you in there, and the audio guide (available in French for us) is extremely well conceived. We spent a couple of hours there and I would have taken more. Really fascinating. And in January, as for most things in London, there was no line at all. Joy!

Probably a good place to visit if you love history. The lines are long, the place is crowded, but people seem to want to visit it and be able to say they were there. This isn't my cup of tea. But we got pictures of the outside.

My favourite sight in Zl Indonesia ( so far ...). Excellent. . Humbling to see so many names In history , from so many walks in life. Makes you proud to be British . As a Scot , found the story of Mary Queen of Scots body came to be there very interesting. You come away wanting to know more ...At £18 expensive , but unmissable . Free entry with forces I.D. Staff really friendly , and knowledgeable . Did this visit to tick a box to say I d been. . Did not expect to be so interested .

Amazing experience. Westminster is an absolutely incredible place. There is so much to see here. It is simply breathtaking. We also attended Evensong, and it was a wonderful experience. Not to be missed!I will return again on my next visit to London.

Breathtaking. Situated just off Westminster Bridge (Big Ben) this is a place you have to visit even if you are not religious, you will be amazed at the architecture and skill of the stonemasons of old.Included in the admission fee is an audio tour which gives you excellent information and guides you through the abbey, there is so much to see that you should allow 2-3 hours for your visit

So Much History. You cannot walk slow enough to take in everything within Westminster Abbey. An extraordinary amount of history in one place. Breathtaking statues, history within every corner, and worth every second. The Authors' area was very interesting. The volunteers are so friendly and love to answer any questions. I was very surprised to see an inconspicuous stone there for Anne of Cleves -- the only wife of Henry VIII to be at Westminster.Take your time and enjoy.

One of the must do experiences in London. Westminster Abbey is the UK in a nutshell. It's where kings and queens are crowned and where the great and the good of a nation are buried or memorialised. Its old and its cold and its full of tourists. But the Henry VII chapel is truly breathtaking. This is the quickest way to get a handle on what makes the British tick! It's worth the effort.

Breathtaking. Worth the wait and expense! Absolutely breathtaking, although I wish I could have taken a photo or two, photography strictly not allowed. Sir Isaac Newton's tomb was beautiful, as was the whole place! Cant wait to go back on my next visit to the UK.
Westminster Abbey. To walk in and absorb the beauty of this grand place. To imagine the weddings, coronations that have taken place here was breath taking. Most beautiful place I've seen.

Westminster Abbey a Must See. Despite having to pay 18 pounds for entrance, it is well worth the price if you are looking to see a lot of famous names either buried there are memorialized there, as well as talking to the fantastic volunteer staff. It is a beautiful church to be sure and if you are into "name following", then it's an added bonus.Names like Sir Isaac Newton, Faraday and Kelvin are all buried at the church. For geeks like us? Well if our children were with us they would have been "shooing" away visitors that dare to walk over their names. That, by the way is impossible to do....they must have every square inch of floor with someone buried underneath.What a joy to see. Also, do yourself a favor and if you are there and need a bite to eat, do so in their restaurant. Reasonably priced, very good sized sandwiches and at tentative wait staff.

Soak in the History. It is not the largest, glitziest, or architecturaly interesting, but the history of the place is overwhelming, similar to St. Peter's in Rome. Newton, Darwin, Tennyson, Kipling, etc. We also did a service. A worthy sight for the first time London Visitors
Beautiful. Just view from outside. Very very long "Q" so didn't get to go in. Be prepare for at least an hour "Q" time.

Highly recommend the Verger-led Tour. After originally reconsidering our visit to the Abbey after seeing the line out the front, we were definitely glad we waited it out. We opted for the verger-led tour and enjoyed having Alice show us around. The church is rich in history and is impressive on many levels. I would definitely recommend going earlier in the day and paying a little extra for the verger tour as it is worth it.

Simply breathtaking. Westminster Abbey is a must see if you're in London. The building is amazing, and you could easily spend hours just looking at the architecture, sculptures, and such. I would highly recommend using the audio tour that's included in the price of admission, as there aren't explanatory signs such as you would see in a museum. We did not take part in a Verger tour, but I would be interested in doing so - there's just so much to see that I'm sure we missed some interesting items. It does get rather crowded, so getting there early (before opening time to queue) is highly recommended. Also, since it is a place of worship, they are closed for tours on Sunday, as they have services there (which I believe are open to the public).

Regal place of history. Definitely wait in line and pay the entrance fee and don't forget to pick up the audio tour headphone. Incredible amount of history, so much different than the images you have seen on TV and in print. Loved every minute of it, I had to buy several books in the gift shop so I could review it all.
Beautiful and Solemn. Beautiful architecture, great history. Great place to quietly reflect or pay respects to those buried there.

Very pretty- bring proof of age for teens.. Liked the audio guide. Enjoyed the history that the audio guide shared. Adults are 18 pounds and if I recall correctly my son's ticket was 8 pounds, but they did ask me for proof of age.

Hard to miss this one. If in London, it's one of those must see places. You can knock out at least three other sites near by in a few hours. Subway station near by. I just think it's amazing to have so much history around you. Put on your list when visiting London. (westminster).

Lovely, Lovely!. What can one say? Westminster Abbey is lovely. I suggest you schedule your visit around a Verger Tour. We didn't. We used the audio tour. It was OK, but it's just so vast and there is so much to take in that you get a little lost. I think it would be easier to take in if you had a real person telling you about it. It's certainly worth a trip. The line to get in moves very quickly so don't be discouraged if it seems long. You will get in pretty fast. It's lovely.

Lots to see here. I would firstly say that if you have young children under 12 the audio tour is far too long. There are 20 different audio points throughout the abbey. Each is full of interesting information sp as an adult it's well worth taking the time to listen. Could I suggest a children's audio like an abridged version. Despite this we enjoyed the experience greatly. Literally everyone who is anyone is buried here...the queen Mother to Dylan Thomas. The leaflet provided gives details of key past events and info regarding services which all are welcome. The only downside are the toilets. These are situated on an outbuilding round the back. They are unisex and few were open. I would buy a coffee at tge cafe to use their toilets. But all in all a good destination

Stunning and magnificient!. What an amazing piece of architecture with so much history. A definite must to see in London. We didn't have to wait long in the queue, about 10 minutes and we didn't have fast track tickets! The audio to walk around with is very informative as there is so much to see and understand. Tombs of Queen Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots, amongst many many more. The stained glass is beautiful and the ornate ceilings magnificent.
Must see..... Beautiful, definately a must see on your visit to london, liked the audio guide device with details explainations

Beautiful Experience. Beautiful experience! Yes, it is crowded but definitely manageable. Loved the accompanying audio device that is handed out in the entrance. Wonderful help and explanation as you make your way through. It is definitely a London must see.

Must See ...... You can't go to London without seeing Westminster Abbey. Take a guided tour and hear about all of the stories, see all of the unique places that you can't get to using a handset, and get the personal touch of an experienced guide. It's well worth the money.
Very beautiful church. Our family found it to be a great church and very beautiful. Get there early because crowds can occur

A must see. Abbey is the highlight and must see of any visit to London. Audio tour is well designed. Personal tours also provide you with a more detailed tour and some personal stories from the guides.

Wow! A must see in London.. Westminster Abbey was my favorite site to see while in London. The amount of history in this building and on the grounds is amazing. So many historical figures and buried here from Darwin to Queen Elizabeth I. The architecture is beautiful. We were there on a weekend so it was very crowded but it was well worth the wait. It took us 3 hours to go through the Abbey and we were going through it quite fast. You could easily spend a half of a day at the Abbey.

INTERESTING TO SEE ONCE, BUT NO PHOTOS NO VIDEOS AND MANY PEOPLE.... My wife and I spent 5 days in London with a London Pass card. As this card is giving you free access to many attractions, including Westminster Abbey, we took this chance to visit it. So, my first advice, before to enter and if you have good weather, make outdoor photos of Westminster Abbey immediately !!! Because weather conditions in London are changing so fast that you can have sun when entering and rain when going out... You can get an audio guide in your mother tongue, but expect many people all around you watching and standing at the same place as you during all your visit ! I did not use it and I think it was much better, as I could move where I wanted and when I wanted, because not everything that you will see will interest you for sure...We took some photos outside but it was not authorized inside. Generally speaking, we saw it once, but no chance that we want to see it again ! It was more than enough with one visit. Mostly you will see tombs and a lot of sculpture with written things about people you have hardly even heard about, sorry but it was not that interesting to my eyes...Well, good luck if you want to visit this place and enjoy your day there ;-)I will soon post some photos, as seen from outdoor only.otterboris
Plan for a long visit. A must see in London. Do arrive early if you need tickets and ask for English before you pay as they ran out of audio guides.

So much history.... So much history has been made here with coronations, weddings, and funerals that this is a must see in London. THey don't allow pictures so make sure you allow plenty of time to take it all in so you can remember it all for later. The highlight was seeing Elizabeth I crypt and the coronation chair.
Must See in London. A must see in London. The history of the place alone is worth the visit but the beautiful architecture and sights within are a treasure not to be missed

Enjoyed it. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit here. We had downloaded the Westminster app, so we didn't have to waste time getting an audio guide. We were also there during the noon service, which was very moving. Thankfully the other tourists were few and quiet during the service.
Had tea in the cafe in the basement, which was ok.

Wonderful Historic Visit. I almost didn't visit because I'm a student on a budget, and at $30CAD it's quite expensive. But, I'm glad I went in. It was near closing time (they allow the last people to come in at 3:30pm, closes one hour after) so it wasn't super full of people which was nice. Once inside I was greeted by a friendly staff member who informed me of the free audio tour. I took it and it was super informative and I learned a lot that I didn't expect to.I'm really glad I went, just wish it wasn't quite as expensive.

If your a tourist, add this to the list. This site is a treasure hunt full of history nuggets. We kept digging and and unearthing gems of the past. 5 extra points to the one who finds Isaac Newton's grave. Do a bit of reading prior to your visit and the experience will be greatly enhanced. So long as your here, make the effort and do the tour. Well worth the price of admission.

So much history!. I have visited Westminster Abbey a few times and my last visit will be my last. There were too many people inside to allow me to view anything at my leisure and I was thankful I had already seen many of the areas on display. Westminster Abbey is a must-see for all visitors to London and is full of so much interesting history. It is a pity that on my last visit, all I could do was shuffle along in a queue! I found the nearest exit and escaped!

NOT MEANT TO SEE...... When planning my 4-week visit of Great Britain, I allocated 4 days of the first week to visit my top 10 attractions of London, WESTMINSTER ABBEY being one of them. I even purchased a London Pass to expedite my visits of these 10 attractions. It was not meant to be seen, not meant to be inside. My attempts to see its inside for 4 days were futile. Either the cathedral was closed for service (Holy Week Celebrations) or just closed at the end of the day. Please see attached pictures. Note that there is entrance fee to this church. I admired the beauty of its facade, the other buildings next to it and the park near its location as well as its rich history. Perhaps, next time I visit London, it would be open to the public and me.

Fantastic visit. This is a costly visit if you take the whole family and you've got young kids who aren't yet into this kind of thing. It is otherwise a great place to visit - my 12 year old loved it. The audio guide is excellent and free. The restaurant is costly but there are plenty of other places to eat close by. Enjoy!

History at your feet. Used our London Pass portion at the Abbey, which is worths it's weight in gold.This wonderfully historic place is busy as it should be.. We all should see the history in the stones, chairs, shoot the flags. There is a reason why there are so many US citizens at the Abbey, we just don't have this amount of history yet.

Oh what history!. We bought the London pass and skipping the lines was worth it! The audio tour was great and standing where Kate and William have stood for their wedding and seeing the queen's chair for coronation was incredible. The building was beautiful! What a great day!

Breathtaking but crowded. The Abbey normally opens at 9:30am during the week and charges £18.00 for an adult. We had purchased a London Pass (a savings if you are seeing some of the more common tourist sites in London). The Westminster Abbey was included on the London Pass and gave us a Fast Track option so we were able to bypass the busy ticket lines when we arrived. We were there in the mid-afternoon and it was extremely crowded. There is a free audioguide available which has good information on it. Remember, no photography or video is allowed inside Westminster Abbey which is a bit sad because it is so incredibly gorgeous inside. There is a gift shop available though that had souvenir books and postcards available.Even if you are not a history buff, your jaw will drop at the architectural splendor instead this gorgeous building. Give yourself several hours to see all of it, especially if you do not arrive early and face bigger crowds.

Wonderful. What a gorgeous place to visit. So much to see within the abbey - the most humbling bit to see is the tomb of the unknown soldier....lump in throat for me as I paused for thought at it. Only downside is the cost to get in but cost goes to the upkeep

Very Old, Very Interesting. The abbey is a wonderful church full of history and dead people. Take the time to read the head stones of many famous names. Also take the walk that Kate took when she married William.

An Impressive Building and Site with Hefty Fee. The building is impressive. The history is obvious. Upon entry, the site seems more tourist attraction than religious site with hefty entrance fee, free audioguide included and the extended entry area. We still felt like it was a must see place. The memories will last longer than the pain in our wallet. If the price is too much for you, services can be attended for free.

Just beautiful. I was her in May and whilst i am not religeous nor am i a seasoned traveller, this was the most beautiful building that I have ever seen. It simply took my breath away. As an Australian I had to keep reminding my self that this was built before Cook got to Australia.I found the outside far more breathtaking than the inside but the inside is just as awsome.The only disapointing thing about this place is that you cannot take any pictures inside. Some of the memorials inside are just spectacular. I suggest that you put you mobile on camera, there were lots of people using their phones to sneak pictures. I didnot pay for a tour as I would have had to wait a fair while but if I had my time again I would have waited.

Christmas service very special. What a glorious place, full of history and ceremony! The tour is a must, but if you are in London at Christmas, it is well worth it to plan to attend the service. Reserve tickets in advance, through the website.

Better time and experience. Be willing to wonder of the beaten track. Walk into cloister garden. Wander the halls of historic building. Go beyond the superficial. Attend a Sunday service. Feel with your mind the surroundings and appreciate the history.

Westminister Abbey mjust be seen. This is where notables are buried from Charles Darwin, Chaucer, Sir Isaac Newton and Cromwell.Of course it is a church as well. Going back to about 1080, it has been home to many royal weddings, funerals and other royal events.The architecture is worth the visit.

Late Afternoon Visit Combined with "Evensong" Service. This is one of the most amazing (historically significant) churches that is an absolute "must see". As luck would have it, we arrived at this attraction in the late afternoon and as a result, the crowds weren't bad....and after our tour, they were lining up outside for the evensong so we decided to attend. The evensong was amazing in that it reminded us that this is a "real" place of worship...and thankfully, we were not struck by lightening in the process :)

Bursting with history. A visit to London would be incomplete without checking out Westminster Abbey. Dripping with historical splendor on the exterior, the interior welcomes you with warmth and brilliance. A wonderful building and a must see for anyone seeking beauty, history, science, and grace.

One of the premier London attractions. Even if you have only a passing interest in history Westminster will enthral you. Even if historic architecture doesn't grab your attention, this place will. This is not so much a lesson as an immersion in the history of England. You can see this old wooden chair which has been the coronation throne since 1066. The actual burial places of some of history's best known figures. This is a place which holds the attention from start to finish. It holds a central place in the history of England and is an attraction that I will go back to any time I am in London.

A must see when in London. Beautiful church with amazing history. The audio tour is a great way to see everything and hear about the highlights in the midst of all the crowds. Audio tour has video highlight of some areas not always accessible. Go early before the queues build.

westminster abbey. Stunning visually inside and out. Visited with my 11 year old daughter and was worried that she might get bored. No need, the staff and volunteers make alot of effort to engage peoples interestno matter how old they are. For the younger visitors there are handouts for them to find certain points of interest around the abbey. I would allow 2 hours at least for your visit and be prepared for queues as it is very popular. The gift shop situated at the exit has plenty of souvenirs for youngand old alike. Definitely worth while.

Spectacular tour through English history. We spent a worthwhile 2 hours touring Westminster Abbey. Make sure you get a headset, as the audio guided tours are excellent. While somewhat crowded, you can get around easily and see the entire cathedral. This is an absolute must, especially if you are interested in history.
Historical church. This abbey has a lovely architecture, its Gothic structure reminds me the Notre Dame Cathedral. An abbey very used by the kings in the past

It is a church or a monument to the monarchy?. I was a little disappointed in Westminster Abbey. Perhaps it was due to having gone to St. Paul's Cathedral first. St. Paul's was clear on it's mission as a church. Sadly, based on the talk by the tour guide, Westminster seems more about being a tomb with the graves of many famous people as well an edifice to glorify the monarchy. You could quickly lose sight of the fact that it is a church. With all the tombs, the nave is very cluttered and, frankly, takes away from the majesty of the building. That being said, the building is so rich with history and is indeed impressive architecturally that it is a must see in London.
a must see. a lot of great history, see all of the tombs and get the audio guide and go through it in detail, worth every bit of the time. Entrance is on the side, exit is in the front.

Historical but crowded. This is a very crowded museum/cathedral even in the off season (May). This is probably a must see because of the history of the place, but I really did not enjoy it. There are hundreds of tombs and i just did not find it very interesting to the death mask of Queen Victoria. I could not see the architecture very well because so many people were in the way. I think it is one of those places that you should go because kings and queens were married, crowned, and buried here... but I think I would have been just as happy to spend more time at another London attraction.

Worth seeing!!. This was by far one of my favorites on the trip. You could just feel history oozing from this abbey. Gothic architecture at its best. We had fast track tickets which was great cause there was already a long line when we arrived which was early morning. Audio guides came with the tickets but I passed. Not my thing. No photos allowed inside which is understandable. Nice little gift shop.

Sunday Eucharist Service. Even though I have visited London several times and make a point of touring Westminster Abbey each time, I never attended a service. This trip provided that opportunity and it was beautiful and moving. I recommend it for the general experience alone plus all of the other pleasures you will enjoy when participating within the walls of such history.

History Lesson at the Abbey. We had planned to go to Westminster Abbey and since it was a rainy day, it was perfect to be indoors. The line was not too long and it was easy access. The tour can be done by handset or a tour guide. We chose to wait for the guide. Our guide was such fun. He was a wealth of information and told us so much history about the Abbey. We thoroughly enjoyed it!

The history and building - truly exceptionsl. This is one of the real icons of history. the building is spectacular and the resting places of the famous just took me back. It was a well spent afternoon that had me spellbound the entire time. I ma not sure how well young ones would enjoy the Abbey but for adults its a real treat
westminster abbey. Steeped in history a must for all ages.A wonderful building and a must see if you visit London.Only drawback is you cannot take photographs

Must Stop. One of the most famous churches in Christian and Western European history. It is a must see for anyone making a trip to London. The bad thing is that it is so expensive. I believe it's worth it if you are a history buff. However, if you don't want to fork out the cash then you could attend a service for free.

Very Nice. It is a nice old church with a lot of history tied to it. Just looking at the church means less than the history. I would think if in London that anyone who likes history at all would want to see this.

British History. The history here is mind boggling. For over a thousand years the coronation of Kings and Queens and the resting place of many of them is impressive. Definitely a must do in London. We were with a tour group that was on the move fairly quick because we were trying to get a lot in on a day tour. But we did have plenty of time at The Abbey. Indeed take you time, a lot to see.

Very Impressive. While the queue was long it did not take us long to enter, the entrance fee is not cheap but it is a very important and historical site. The audio headsets give a comprehensive commentary of everything to see and there is a lot!! It covers England's history from kings to noted commoners. As well as the monuments the architecture is also outstanding as it is one of the great buildings from the Gothic era.

Wow. The place is beautiful, beautiful statues, beautiful carvings, different patterns. They also offer audio guides, (not sure how it's called) so when you go around the place it's like you're taking a tour. It's also amazing that everything is made entirely by hand, all those small details. No wonder it took centuries to build it.

Incredible! A must do when in London.. Beautiful abbey. Cannot properly express how moving it is to walk amongst the tombs of historical figures you have only read about. Mary Queen of Scots, Isaac Newton, Queen Elizabeth, Charles Darwin...the list goes on and on.

You'll be in awe. Get there early. You'll be amazed that the Coronation Chair looks so shabby. You'll also be in awe that you're walking on the graves of Isaac Newton, Lawrence Olivier, and Charles Dickens. Oh if those walks could talk.

Worth the Visit. We visited Westminster Abbey on our first day in London. When we arrived there was a long line to get in to purchase our tickets, although the line moved very quickly. The Abbey closes to visitors one hour before they close, so people should keep this in mind when planning their visit. Once inside the Abbey, the cost of your ticket includes the headsets, so you can spend as much time as you want during your visit. This was a site that was high on our list of things to do and we were not disappointed. Although you are not allowed to take pictures inside the Abbey, there are plenty of places you can purchase post cards and/or books about the Abbey. We would definitely recommend this attraction when in London.

Shame there is no photography allowed. We had to try a few times before we got to see this attraction. On one of our attempts, they were late opening. We had been in a huge queue and with still no sign of the doors opening - the longer we waited, the longer the queue became - so we cut our losses and went elsewhere. On our third attempt, we finally got in. The entry fee is quite high (36 pound) - but you get an audio tour - and there are staff to ask questions of. It is an amazing place - but hard to remember - because you cant take photos. Photos become the memories of our holidays - so it is a shame to forget such splendour.We particularly enjoyed the gardens - where you can take photos.

A must see in London. Beauty, history, religion and lots of tombs! The line to get in moves quickly, better if you have cash. The audio tour is great and winds you throughout the Abbey. It's worth the crowded aisles to slip into the side naves and follow the tour. Sit for a bit and listen to the recording of the organ. I understand that evensong is wonderful.

A Historical Delight and Architectural Wonder. Westminster Abbey is well-worth its ticket price of €18.00. If you are a history buff - particularly Tudor era - and/or an architectural enthusiast, you will absolutely love this beautiful abbey. The cathedral ceilings are beyond impressive; it is such a shame pictures are not allowed, because looking up, the views are simply breathtaking. The crypts and tombs through out are sombering, capped off with some of history's most notorious figures - Isaac Newton, Henry VII, "Bloody Mary," and Elizabeth I to name just a few. Make sure to take them up on the audio tour offer; it is the best way to understand what you are looking at and get the often very interesting backstory. If you love to explore, experience history and respect beautiful architecture, make sure to set aside at least 2 hours to enjoy Westminster. We were there for over four!

Impressive. We finally visited Westminster Abbey. The long history of this church, combined with the history of the English monarchy is impressive. The audio tour was helpfull and the drink afterwards in the café great.

Amazing Church. Just the history alone was worth seeing. The church has been standing for over 700 years. It was quite beautiful and the audio tour was very informative. The only negative to the tour is you cant take pictures in the main part of the church which for 18 pounds you should be allowed to do so in some areas. There is quite a bit of history from the grave sites of Darwin and Kings to the oldest door in London possibly built in 1050. Would very much recommend seeing the church.

worth the money and time. it was quite expensive for entry. can't remember how much. I was thinking it was a lot to just look around a big church. I was pleasantly surprised you got a audio guide included and lots of great people to tell you about the abbey. It was like a history of england in one building crypts and memorials to hundreds of english historical people. beautiful architecture. we spent several hours I would have stayed longer if we had the time.

Amazing experience!. This was an amazing place to visit - and it was so well worth it to take the private tour. Walking down the same aisle as royalty and standing at the altar of royal coronations, as well as walking on the graves and seeing the monuments of such famous people in history. That was incredible. Take your time and see it all, especially on the private tour.

A Visually Stunning and Historical Experience. Westminster Abbey was a marvel to see! So much history to take in. Bear in mind however that they do NOT allow photographs inside the Church. The fee for an adult admission is £18.00, but my wife and I bypassed the line using the London Pass (which is totally worth the money for all the attractions it's good for). We visited at the right time because the Abbey was due to close for the following 2 days of our trip for a Royal ceremony. So, just a head's up, be sure to check that the Abbey is open for the public as it can close for private events at any time and DO check the hours of operation because certain areas and exhibits close at different times. The cloisters, college garden, and St. Margaret's church are free to visit, but do not grant entry to the main Church.The architecture was stunning and the craftsmanship on the many tombs was fascinating. Many historical figures from great writers to Royalty are buried there and others have memorials there. In the first hall there is a place where you can write down and leave a prayer or light a candle for a loved one. I lit a candle in memory of my late mother. I would have left a prayer, but the pencils provided were broken. The Abbey provided a free audio tour handheld device narrated by Jeremy Irons, but was also available in several other languages if necessary. It can get crowded, so be prepared to exercise a little patience while maneuvering through the different rooms and halls. There are members of staff on hand to answer questions and give historical information as well.So, if you are touring London, be sure to see this spectacular piece of history, but just be sure to check in advance that it's open to the public the day you visit or you could be sorely disappointed. I heard many, many people throughout my trip talking in passing about "going to the Abbey tomorrow", but we had to tell them it was closed for a few days for a private event.

Its a must!. If you are in London, you must visit Westminster Abbey; it s such a splendid place, full of history. Although there are lots of tourists, you don t have to wait more than 2-5 min to get your ticket.

My history. I have avoided this one for so many years believing I knew what it was and what made it great, now I do know. The famous people and the greats of all time, maybe not all to everyone's taste but the architecture and the atmosphere that eulogy "if only these stones could talk" and well over hearing a conversation between one of the guides and some American lads and lasses when in front of the commonwealth benches " say, there's Canada and Australia, where our seat?" Answer came, "sorry its the commonwealth of nations, you could always apply and I would love to see the amusement on the Queens face" me too, America where's that or thet!Ho ho the cousins, think before you leap, Scotland beware and be brave whatever you do, we do not distinguish you to be separate even when you may be, don't be strangers in any case.

The history of England all in one place. This is a must visit for anyone who loves British history and wants to see the final resting place of kings, queens, poets, dignitaries and prime ministers. It is truly hallowed grounds and you can't help but feel like you are walking through time surrounded by the likes of Queen Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots, Edward the Confessor, etc. Only drawback are the crowds and the disappointment that photography is NOT allowed.

Worth a visit but a bit expensive!. We've been meaning to visit the abbey for years but were very surprised at the high entrance fee.Nevertheless, it was good to have a good look round at this beautiful building.The Lady Chapel is especially gorgeous.It was a pity you couldn't really see the Cosmati pavement properly. I guess another viewing of the Time Team program is on the cards!The building seemed smaller than it appears on tv due to clever filming I suppose.The audio guide was quite good but a bit plodding .The toilets need urgent attention!!!We walked out of The Cellarium because the service and laissez faire attitude of the staff was unacceptable. Waiting 15 mins to order and then another 20 mins for a cup of tea in a half empty cafe was ridiculous.

worth a visit. If you have a good few hours to spare take a wander around here. It is a beautiful building steeped in a lot of history. The audio guide is excellent and can take you back in time. My favourite (favourite is not the right word) was the lost warriors grave, very poignant, and emotional. I admit to shedding a tear.

Go to Evensong. It's free.. So if you want to take pictures of the Abbey and tour, then pay to get in. Otherwise, they hold service every evening at 5 PM. You'll be able to go inside, attend a service, and it's free. The grounds there are very hallowed. My husband and I felt this as we waited for service to begin. The Boys Choir sounds amazing. If you've never been to an Anglican service, it's very much like a Catholic mass. If you've not been to mass, there is a lot of call and response and standing up and sitting down. Lol. It's a wonderful place, and it should not be missed. I plan on taking a proper tour the next time.

Rent the audio guide. Fantastic! We thought we'd had our fill of cathedrals -- Italian, Spanish, French -- but this one was part of the London Pass so why not! We went during the week in April (off season?) and the regular waiting line was perhaps 1.5 hours or more. The London Pass Express line was 15 minutes. We would not have visited otherwise. The audio tour made it MUCH more interesting. There were lots of people but we never felt crowded. Not as grand as many cathedrals but many interesting nooks and crannies and the history -- all the coronations since William the Conquerer have taken place here -- was marvelous. But you need the audioguide to not miss some of that. Ah but we in America would take a hint and start building more places like this -- I'm a Buddhist so am not suggesting places of worship necessarily -- to enjoy over the millenia and fewer nuclear-powered subs and aircraft carriers, we'd all be better off.
So much history. Take the time to soak in the history. Many people buried here and honored here... The architecture is amazing and this is must while in London!

Best Tour of the Weekend. We visited Westminster Abbey and were thrilled. We spent an extra 5 pounds each to take the Verger tour. This was so much better than an audio tour. Our tour guide was so informative we thought we had an encyclopedia with us! He took us into areas that we would not otherwise have been able to see. This tour was not rushed and all our questions were answered in detail showing the expert knowledge of the guide. If you go and don't spend the extra 5 pounds for the tour, you will come away disappointed!
Awesome Place. It was absolutely Beautiful full of history and the inside will leave you breathless. Will recommend as a must to visit!!

Oh So Gorgeous. I'm a fan of English history; and after all the TV; i.e., The Tudors and The White Queen, it was wonderful to see where so many of them are buried. The church is magnificent and a must do while in London. Fantastic. Take your time and see it all.

Stepped into British History. Apart from the majestic architecture and stained glass, Westminster Abbey is steeped in history; from the burial places of monarchs and famous British pioneers to the tomb of the Unknown Soldier and the RAF memorial. The excellent audio guide, included in the (rather expensive) entrance fee, allows you to go at your own pace, but we spent most time in the Quire, where the Coronation and wedding ceremonies take place, and the Lady Chapel, which were both quite magnificent. The Abbey staff were excellent in answering our questions – even rather obscure ones with the help of their colleagues and available documentation, although it's a pity that no photography is permitted. This is a must see for anybody interested in British history and the monarchy.
Spectacular. One of the most spectacular gothic architecture - I may say its more beautiful than Notre Dame du Paris - and full of history. Worth every penny

Must-see, marvelous. We went last Friday to Westminster Abbey, I've been in London for 10 months now but was waiting to use my London Pass to go as it's very expensive to enter in an abbey.... (£18). It is really woth the price, it's so huge, the inside is fantastic, beautiful. There are so many things to learn inside, and think about the weddings, the people who were there, it's great. It's a must see in London. The architecture is marvelous, it's awesome. I can't discribe ! Just go !There are also audioguides inside you don't have to pay more to have them. It's really interesting it explains a lot about each parts/chapels of the abbey. It's really helpful(The fee to access the abbey is used to keep it as beautiful as it is)

Notable, Important, Interesting Must Visit. This is an important stop when in London, it is one of the most notable religious buildings in London. It is the place of coronation, burial site for Britain's monarchs (you will be amazed at the dates you come across on the), the elite and national figures such as Isaac Newton...incredible & we were surprised to see Charles Darwin...WOW. Weddings are also held here, last one William and Kate, so it is quite notable and very interesting. The poets corner is amazing, there are so many names you will recognize memorialized in this nook. It seems disrespectful to walk over these markers but there is no where else to walk to get from place to place to explore all the British history in the abbey. It was not particularly crowded the day we went which was lovely and they have an audio tours which are quite helpful in pointing out the various markers and explaining the different parts of the abbey. In our opinion it is a must visit.

Too expensive. A really expensive ticket for a church. And to add to your insult they don't allow you to take pictures inside. The church as such is beautiful but I feel the price they are asking is too much.

Breathtaking!. Words cannot express the feelings I had while touring Westminster Abbey. I was choked up and unable to speak for most of my visit. The grandeur of the architecture and the history contained within the abbey are overwhelming to experience. My understanding is that you cannot purchase tickets in advance. I had purchased tickets for all other major attractions online but could not do so for the abbey. (There was a fast track queue for those who had a London Pass.) My husband and I arrived about 30 minutes before opening, and there was already quite a line.Because the experience is so overwhelming, I would suggest doing research before going, so that you know in advance what to expect. You can go to the Westminster Abbey website and actually download the audio tour (narrated by Jeremy Irons). I listened to the tour 2 or 3 times before going, and I was still overwhelmed and missed things. You will be so busy gawking, listening to the tour and trying to keep on track, and being pushed along by the crowds that you will miss a lot. I wish that I had purchased the official guidebook at the gift shop (about 5 pounds) a day or two in advance of my tour, so that I could have further prepared myself for the tour. For the money, the guidebook is a great souvenir (especially since you can't take pictures anywhere in the abbey).I went back a few days later to attend a 5:00 Evensong service. The service is free, of course, and if you get there early, you might be lucky enough to sit in the quire. I was seated right across the aisle from the choir. The service was moving and so beautiful.

Overwhelming. The size, the history, and the beauty of Westminster is absolutely overwhelming. So glad to have finally visited, it didn't disappoint. The list of important people buried here is unbelievable. The audiotour is essential, and part of the admission fee. I really can't add much that hasn't already been said. But it is absolutely worthwhile and extremely impressive.

Outstanding architecture, important to see. At the very least you should walk around the abbey while you are in the area seeing other attractions like the Parliament buildings and the London Eye. The building is immaculate and very beautiful! If you fancy going inside, the history alone is compelling. What has happened at this location alone makes you feel like you are basking in history. I recommend a tour, or the head set, so that you get the most out of the experience.

Beautifully moving. Finally made it to Westminster Abbey on our last trip. I love old churches because I love to think about the art, the architecture, the history that has happened in them. This one is definitely at the top of my list for favorites. There's no getting away from the history, which if fabulous. What I loved the most though is that it's a working church and the clergy made a point of not losing their faith among all of the tourists. Although I didn't know it, we were there in time to participate in their daily Eucharist service. I think it was at 12:30. I loved feeling taking the sacrament there and thinking about all of the lives that have been touched by that place throughout the centuries.

Walk in Royal Footsteps. For GBP18.00 per adult, you are walking in the footsteps of the Royal Family and many of those celebrities that have attended royal weddings in this church. It is a huge place with exceptional architecture and colours through the artists impressions of kings and queens alike. You will marvel at the high ceilings and the stone tombs that lay before you. It's a crowded atmosphere, so make your way around the scheduled path but be sure to take in as much as possible and take your time. Flash photography is allowed, but get your settings right to capture the intense colours.

Mind-blowing. I am not one who knows all that much about British history, but one trip to Westminster Abbey has totally sparked my interest. The monuments, tombs, art, and architecture are all incredible. The individual walking tour with audio was great too because you could travel at your own pace and were trying to listen to a tour guide speak over other tour guides.

There is no reason not too come..... I arrived around 9:00am and the Abbey didn't open until 9:30am, which turned out to be a blessing (pardon the pun) as I got ahead of the crowds. You need the audio, which is free, and plenty of time. Well worth it but get there early.

Beautiful. Beautiful architecture. It was my favorite part of my London trip. Very expensive to enter. Very strange that you have to pay to go inside a religious building. The audio tour is worth it though. Amazing to be walking amongst the tombs of some of England's most famous nobility.

Westminster Abbey. I would only go to this once. It was what I expected...a lot of tombs. It was cool to see where Will and Kate got married and if you are a fan of the movie Young Victoria, you see where her coronation was. This was covered with the London Pass, which we found helpful.

English History & Architecture at its Most Lovely. My 14 year old son and I are Anglophiles, so it came as no surprise that Westminster Abbey was a hit for us. We happened to go on an extremely crowded day, as the Abbey was closed for a church ceremony until 1:30. I recommend you check its schedule/website before visiting. Despite the crowds, it was a delightful visit thanks to a decent audioguide (included with admission) and a millennia of history to peruse. Poet's Corner was a highlight of the visit. The cloister was a lovely & restful outdoor space to be enjoyed, as well.

crowded but accessable. a must see. the robed staff keeps everything moving along. they are super friendly and helpful. the free audio guide is excellent and super helpful in guiding you though the Abbey.
British History. It is so full of history that you might miss some of it. Audioguide is very good and included with visit. A must when in London.

Second visit. This was my 2nd visit to the Abbey. The first time I took the tour (expensive and feels rushed even after hours in line). This time we went to Evensong. That's what I would recommend- figuring out when they will have a service or organ recital so you can go and enjoy the church, the organs, the preachers, and the people. Plus attending a service is free so you can leave a small donation for the church without paying exhorbitant entrance fees as the tour groups do. A beautiful interior with an amazing history-- if you opt out of the tour be sure to have a guide book and read up on the abbey before your visit so you can fully enjoy the interior. Know that if you attend a service you will walk through the cathedral to get to the service area but will not have access to every statue, every nook and cranny so if you have the time to stand in line for hours and the money to spend on the tour it may be worth it to pay for a visit if you are interested in seeing a particular person buried in the church or exploring its entirety.No photos allowed of the interior- whether you pay for a tour or not.

1000 years of history. This place has been the site of Royal Coronations and burials since 1066! You will recognize many of the names on the plaques and grave stones from your history books in this church from literature to science. Another must see in the city of London.

Fabulous. Westminster abbey is a piece of art itself. It is a very beautiful building, rich of history and one of the most famous places of the world. It is museum as well. There you will find people like Isaac Newton! If you go on Christmas it is even better because you can listen to a beautiful choir and watch to a centenarian Anglican ceremony.

The history in this place, damn!. My friends and I stood in line for a little while, but they are very efficient so even if the line looks long, don't fret, it moves quickly. No pictures are allowed inside, so keep that in mind. The history in this place is AMAZING! Tons of people I've never heard of are buried here, but they must have been important to have a place among so many people I did know about. We didn't take the audio tour because we wanted to have conversations among ourselves, however, our conversations were all questions about who people were. Therefore, get the audio tour and I imagine you'll leave there with an even greater knowledge of why it is such an amazing place. Lastly, you're going to be walking on people's grave sites, but apparently they wanted it that way so don't feel too weird about it. It's the Cathedral's own fault for making you feel weird. And now the last point for reals, don't miss out on the King and Queen's that are buried here. Amazing costs went in to their place in the Cathedral. One other tip, it's still a church and you can wait in line to attend a service there, free of charge. Enjoy your trip!
beautiful. It is both charming and uniquely beautiful and amazingly wonderful to imagine the history and pageantry that is especially British.

A London Must-See. Westminster Abbey is this immaculate building that captures you when you stand in front of it. It stands as a symbol of Henry VII and his incredible influences on the country and the church. The history of Westminster Abbey is extensive. I could take an entire class dedicated to this subject alone. The church was built and added onto for years. The history of the architecture is important to the abbey’s creation.The abbey was built in the middle of the English Gothic era. Some say it is a perfect example of this era. The English Gothic area lasted over 400 years. Westminster Abbey continuously grew and changed during this time. Westminster Abbey is one of England’s largest examples of English Gothic architecture. Henry III started building the Abbey in 1245. He was especially fond of Saint Edward the Confessor and built the Abbey as a shrine to him.Westminster Abbey’s largest distinguishing feature as English gothic is the pointed arches. This is a key gothic feature. The elaborate details in the arches is another important detail. The abbey is extremely detailed and elaborate. Additionally, the Abbey has many lancet windows, which are thin, narrow windows that line the Abbey’s nave. The nave is the main area or middle of the church.Overall, Westminster Abbey is this massive church that not only illustrates the English Gothic architecture era of its time, but the influence of the church in England.

Impressive. Wow - this place is impressive.There is a lot to see in here, and the free audio tour enhances the experience. You'll need at least a couple of hours to take it all in, and to see all the alcoves. It's an amazing place filled with a lot of history.Tip - if you buy the London Pass, you get Fast Track and free entry to Westminster Abbey which means you bypass any lines waiting to get in.

Top Attraction. The Abbey is breathtaking beautiful and the history in it is also breathtaking. it's completely worth the line. When we got in line, the sign said 30 minutes, but it was way less than 30 minutes. Make sure you take your time walking through it and find all the amazing tombs. It's a bit surreal! The Abbey wasn't crowded when we were there so we had no problem walking around at our own pace. However, I can see how a large crowd would make it very difficult to walk around and fully take all the sites. If you're going during high season, I highly suggest that you go early to avoid the crowds. The site is truly fabulous and definitely worth a trip and the ticket price.

Yes, It's Beautiful and Historic .... But at 18 pounds (with a modest discount for students ... and this is the only place where they asked for (and carefully scrutinized) proof of student status for my student-daughter) it's horribly overpriced. While many other costly sites at least offer 2 for 1 admissions, this one does not, making it, by far, the most expensive site on our itinerary. We visited several other churches and cathedrals, and I was more than happy to drop a few pounds into the donation box, but this place is just extortionate.Once inside, the included audioguide offers some basic historical information on some of the chapels and monuments, but if it's not on the audioguide, there is no information at all to tell you what you are looking at or who the people are under all those grave stones or in those tombs. For that, apparently you have to go to the gift shop and buy a guidebook... (And once you've exited to the gift shop, I'm not sure you can get back in.)

Magnificent but over crowded venue. You can't escape the incredible sense of history but we felt that £18.75 was a little high priced for this yep of venue. There were easily 5000 people touring when we were there. So at some points you are shoulder to shoulder as you try and view the many artifacts this huge church has to offer. We found the audio guide devices quite useful but several of the check point numbers were missing around the church so it created a lack of coherence and flow as you attempted to tour. Found the volunteers in green robes to be helpful and charming. There is a maddening no photography policy although pretty well everyone was ignoring this rule. Guess they're not making enough on the admission charged so they need you to buy the photo booklets as well and not have you take your own pictures. The sense of history remains powerful but if you are looking for a spiritual experience you can pretty forget it here as there are just too many visitors. All in all though it remains something the visitor to London still must see.
Really enjoyable, have been back again since.. Throughly enjoyed wondering around and seeing all of the history. Well laid out and friendly staff. Very interesting to see it all.

A lot of history. While aesthetically I prefer St Paul's, the amount of history associated with Westminster Abbey does warrant its own visit. It can get busy and bottlenecks in narrow places (of which there are plenty) so you need to be patient at times. The audio guide is informative and paced well.Also as others have pointed out no photos are permitted inside. Overall it is a fascinating place but if you are pressed for time I personally wouldn't make this a top level priority.

History writ vary, very large - wow!. We have seen a lot of magnificent cathedrals, abbeys and the like. Westminster is in our top 3 or so because of the amazing collection of people interred there, and not just the usual kings and queens. Poets corner is a fantastic place to pause and reflect on the great writers and poets who have gone before. Indeed, add in Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, the Unamed Soldier, Handel, Mary Queen of Scots, Edward the Confessor, etc, etc, etc then you get the idea. They all seem to speak to you as you stroll around. It is good they provide an audio guide as part of the entrance fee because otherwise it is steep frankly. The magnificent gothic ceilings in some of the chapels and main areas are breathtaking. Because of its popularity it gets crowded which spoils it a bit and it is not a cavernous space like the Cathederal at Sevilla, Spain where you can escape and draw solace. Nevertheless it is an amazing old Abbey that is a must see if you are a history buff. Make sure you check opening times though to avoid disappointment, and wonder around the adjacent Deans Yard to see how the other half live! Guys, you really should allow respectful photography inside, that is a but mean by other comparisons.

Stunning. It took an hour in the line/queue to get into Westminster Abbey, but it was well worth the wait - the Abbey is stunning. The audio tour is informative, and the history contained in the Abbey fascinating. The craftsmanship in the Lady Chapel is stunning. What a fantastic place to visit - it is a must see.

A must-visit in London. On all of my six visits to Britain I have always gone to The Abbey. This time I went twice, one to do the tour again and also to Evensong. If you are unable to afford the tour at least go to Evensong. You need to take your time because there is so much to see and take in. The personal commentary devices are excellent. Als make sure you see the 11th century Pyx Chamber and the Chapter House with its 13th century floor tiles which come under the care and guardianship of 'English Heritage'. There is also a circa 1050 door which is probably the oldest in England. The museum is also worth seeing.

Very Historic & Beautiful. The place is so beautiful to wonder around and take it all in. There are many nooks and crannies to visit. Just keep wondering. Plan to spend 1- 2 hours. There is no photography inside the Abbey itself but once outside the Abbey proper, you're allowed to take pictures and there are a few nice shots to take. We went on a Monday afternoon and there was no wait to get in but it was busy inside. We'd passed it a few times on the weekend and it was lined up. There is a mild security check on the way in, just a peek in any purses or bags.

Don't miss this. I had no idea the amount of famous and historical figures that are entombed here. Darwin, Handel, Queen Elizabeth! Not just is the architecture amazing, the history is too. No photos inside, though!

It is so beautiful. Everybody has seen the outside of this place (in the movies, in the TV, in internet) but see it in the inside is so beautiful. Again, they have worship times, so be very respectful and you cannot take pictures inside at any time. The tombs of different kings, queens, poets, etc. are numerous and there the tombs of very famous people. The inside garden is a gem.

Interesting Experience!. Visited the Westminister Abbey in April 2014 and joined the guided tour for an additional 3 pounds. 1st impression of the exterior, looks similar to Notre Dame in Paris on the inside totally different. The interior layout, the seats and the many famous tombs inside. Wow! A pity is no taking of pictures inside. The tour was worth the additional price, its a small group guided tour. You hear stories on the history of the Abbey, the people whom are buried here, the royal wedding, the cornation and you get to visit parts of the Abbey that is not open to visitors not on the tour. You will gain more knowledge, getting pointed to things you may not notice on your own. Although entrance is expensive but it's definately worth the visit!

Lots of history. Over 1000 years old, this Abbey has witnessed a great share of English history and today is the burial place of monarchs and other important English people. The church is usually crowded with tourists and the opening times can change without notice so it can be difficult to tour the facility. Overall, a great historical monument and one that should be seen as part of the history of London and indeed Britain.

Resting place of kings and queens. Do you realized who is buried here? OMGosh! We saw the elaborate crypts of many queens and kinds over centuries. What a beautiful place! AND the place where they were crowned! A must see.

History, Architecture and grandeur!. The queues may be long but the wait and entry fee is worth it.I don't like paying to visit religious establishments but this one is special in many ways. Just remember that the monarchs of England have been Crowned here since the year 1066! Many are buried in the Abbey as well as 10's of other famous people commemorated by plaques and statues on the walls and floors ( e.g. Winston Churchill)The building itself is stunning, how did they do that all those years ago without the modern day technology?Take your time on this visit, there's no rush and you're not hurried to get out. The audio tour is very informative at no extra cost in a variety of languages.

A beautiful historic Abbey. While the entry fee is expensive, a tour of this historic church should not be missed while on vacation in London. The audio guide provides much relevant information. I was especially fascinated by poets corner, so named because of the poets, playwrights, and writers that are buried and commemorated there.

Wonderful. This is a lovely church and a wonderful, historical experience. Get there when it opens as the queues are long every day. Be sure to note the hours -- they open later on Fridays. Take advantage of the free audio tour and roam the facilities. Take time to sit and just take it all in. There is so much history and the staff is wonderful and helpful. Don't miss the Coronation Chari on your way out!

Free Entry. The best part about this for me is that you are able to get in for free and attend service!! This is one of the most beautiful buildings in the world and if you want to do a tour, yes there's a price BUT service is free for the public as well as a few other events like choir and organ recitals. You're in the main sanctuary you are just not allowed to take pictures inside.

Worth It!. This is just a must see. There is so much history here--even if you're not into royals.If you don't know a lot about Westminster, rent one of the audio tour devices--it is worth it. I particularly liked the Poet's corner and was surprised that Charles Darwin is buried here. The coronation chair is worth a look.

Historically significant, worth visiting.. Steeped in ceremony and historical significance, this is a destination not to be missed on any trip to London. Take time to appreciate the architecture, stained glass windows, and the tombs and markers of those who have gone before. Helpful and knowledgable staff available to answer questions. Don't get overwhelmed and expect to see everything in one trip. You will see something amazing every time you visit. Nice gift shop too.

Evensong. Evensong is a great way to get into the abbey for free. It is an hour long service with choir and readings. However, as you enter, they herd you in and you don't have a lot of time to walk around and look at the details.I would definitely try to get their early, however, so as you can see the choir. We were angled away so that we could only see the singing on the TV screen. It was definitely less engaging. We were struggling to stay awake given the long day of museum crawls. Don't be fooled by the placard outside the Abbey with the Evensong times. They advertised it as 3:00pm but their website had the accurate time, 5:00pm. It's also a bit hard to find. The entrance is not the main entrance, but through a gate near the street vendors on the right hand side. Even then, there was no advertisement for it. There were people who were outside the gate taking pictures as if they couldn't get in. We approached the gate, and they asked us what we were there for. We said Evensong, and they let us in. Sort of like a secret password...

Amazing to be where history is made. The Abby is beautiful - stunning architecture, historical pageantry and ceremony all reflected around you. The audio is really very well done and allows you to do the tour at your own pace, very helpful and knowledgeable staff available throughout who are happy to answer questions and share their knowledge and stories. It is quite something to see history before you. Well worth the visit. I recommend you buy your tickets I advance online if you can. Saves a 30 minute wait in line.

Pricey but worth it for history buffs. I went ahead and paid the 17 pounds to go in. Quite expensive, I thought. I was the only one not bothering with the little headphone tour, so those people certainly got more out of the experience than I did. However, it is amazing and gorgeous and simply huge. Give yourself some time to really wander around in there and look at stuff. It's a church so no pictures and they are serious about it. Worth 1-2 hours of your time. I only dinged them because it really was rather expensive.

Fascinating but go early!. As one of the most visited places in London, you can expect a great tour. The audio tour is fantastic, as narrated by Jeremy Irons. I've been here twice, once with and once without the audio tour, and the tour (free of charge) makes the visit much more interesting. Because of how popular this attraction is, I recommend going as close to opening time as possible to help avoid massive crowds of people who visit every day. As well, make sure you research when it is open and closed. Occasionally there are events that can shut the site to visitors, so look it up before you go. Overall a great piece of history to visit in London.

History galore. Second visit and would visit again. The abbey is so full of history, but has architectural splendor as well. Truely one of the most impressive churches in the world. Take your time and listen to everything in the audio guide - you will learn so much. Afterwards wander around the cloister - feels like you're stepping back in time.

Beautiful!!!. I had been there many years ago, but I found it more awesome this time, I had forgotten how beautiful and impressive this place is. My mother was in awe expression all the time. We wished to had more time to see it because if you really want to learn about it you really need a couple of hours over there. When we arrived there was a long queue but we were really happy to have the fast track for this one from the Londonpass. Impressive, the history in it, even if you don´t care about history, visually it´s really a good experience. Don´t miss it at all if you are in London!
Wow.... this is an awe inspiring place. Well worth the effort to wander through. There was so much to see and soak in, make sure to give yourself enough time!

Great stop for a break. One of the most impressive churches in UK & Europe. Very beautiful. Visitors, both wanting to pay respects or just have a peek of the inside, are allowed in but do be respectful.Once you're satisfied looking inside, have a lounge on the open green lawn outside and rest your feet from the long day's walk. It was the beginning of spring and particularly sunny on the day of my visit so there were a lot of people hanging out and enjoying the sun. If you have a snack/drink with you don't forget to clean up after yourself.
westminster. Really loved Westminster Abbey, History abounds, definitely a must see when your in London. Central and easy to find amazing architecture.

One of the most fascinating places on earth. I highly recommend paying a little extra for a tour lead by a church verger. I can't put into words how magnificent this place is. A few hours is not enough to digest all of the history offered here. Over 3,000 bodies laid to rest here, from British royalty, famous scientists, musicians, artists and authors from the last 900 years or so. The surroundings are gorgeous. Every where you look is a feast for the eyes. No picture taking allowed, so just enjoy the tour as it's happening. You might want to stay after the tour to see things that were missed, as the tour can't possibly cover everything there is to know.

Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey was closing early on the day that I visited so I nearly decided that it was not worth paying the entrance fee since I would have less than an hour. I am so glad that I changed my mind and went inside. It was amazing! I used one of the audio guides that was provided for free and while I was rushed the guide was very informative. Next time I will allow time for one of the guided tours.

Broke my heart. The visit to Westminster Abbey was extremely emotional for me. I was heart broken to see people shuffle through the church, stumbling over crypts, names, history, people without thinking twice about who these individuals were right under their feet. It really bothered me to see the names, dates and text worn off the crypts due to the foot traffic through the church. I was bothered by this. It seemed really disrespectful to me and made me want to know more about the history of each tomb. In the bookstore I found several books that gave insight on the individuals & made me realize that the church has hundreds if not thousands of years of records - so the information that may appear to be "lost" may have visually been removed but it has not disappeared forever. I hope the church improves the exhibit and how the visitors flow through the church. There has to be a better way to respect the sites and preserve the scripts on the tombs.

What a awesome gothic church !. And now I finally arrived at the threshold of what portrayed the long and rich with turbulent events,history of England, the Westminster Abbey. It is located in the City of Westminster, whole region that occupies the area, leaning on the left coast of river Thames between the Lambeth Bridge on the south and Westminster Bridge on the north.To the east from this gorgeous gothic building is the Palace of Westminster or Parliament Building which outlines in the dawn or in the dusk, we had seen so many times in old britain or holywood movies.This church was the traditional place of the coronation and the burial of England and later British monarchs. If we look back in the past, we can say that coronations started from the 1066 year, since William the Conqueror, the old Norman ruler.I entered naturally inside the Abbey, and remained stupefied for quite a time, perceiving the magnificent nave of the church, the King Edward's Chair, a very nice early middle age paintings, a recumbent effigy or likeness lying in repose, the cloisters and garth, the great number of inscriptions on the walls of the halls and on the monuments.That was the genuine top of the cake of my sojourn in London.
Must do this!. Westminster Abby and Windsor Castle were by far my two favorite things to do in London. Be sure to go during the week. Walked right in.

Only saw the Outside. Could not go inside - church was closed to visitors. Probably just as well as they now charge a fee to enter the church - I was there in 1976 and there was no cost to gain entry at that time - so I was rather disappointed.

Absolutely Gotta Visit - even for under 30's. I thought this would just be another "thing that someone said I should visit" attraction, especially as I am not overly knowledgeable about British history - but happy to say I was surprised by this. Amazing architecture, and a lot of inscriptions throughout the halls and monuments telling you stories. Wasn't too expensive, and the cue was nothing to complain about - you could probably spend quite a few hours here if you wanted but I think we did it in around 1.5 hours.

Absolutely Breathtaking. Westmister Abbey was on my MUST SEE list when I traveled to London last week. I've seen it on TV a ton of times, and I am a HUGE Royal Family fan. I first attempted to visit the Abbey on a Saturday afternoon---the line was around the block!!! I was devastated, as this was my only chance to see it because we had other things planned for the rest of my short stay. I decided I would wake up super early the morning I was leaving and be first on line. Visiting hours start at 9:30....I arrived at 8:30 and there was nobody there. I decided to take a walk to Starbucks to grab a coffee and muffin, and when I came back, there were 3 people in line. YAY! The doors opened right at 9:30 and after paying an 18 lb. fee, you were led into the Abbey and given a little electronic tour guide that looked like a phone. Wherever there was a sign with headphones, you'd input the number on that sign and it would give you a whole background on that particular area. Amazing. The Abbey itself...though it is quite large, it looks much smaller than what it looks like on TV. Especially the organ screen and the choir area. So much smaller and intimate. And it is so much more than just the church you see on TV. The tour will take you about an hour. Behind the alter are a bunch of different chapels and tombs...including Elizabeth I and King James and Shakespere. The architecture and detail of these chapels and tombs are absolutely breathtaking and quite moving. Also Note: No photography. I'm usually one to sneak a pic on my phone anyhow..but I just felt so disrespectful and wrong doing so....and NOBODY was taking pics...plus they have people watching you. In the Abbey shop they sell lots of pictures and post cards of the inside of the Abbey, so I bought some to remember some of the architecture. There are also the cloisters to visit and gardens which were also beautiful. At the end of your abbey tour, by the front glass doors, there is the coronation chair which I was excited to see. Also the tomb of the unknown soldier, surrounded by poppies...just so moving. If there's one place to see in London while you are there...arrive early to the Abbey and take a tour....you will not regret it!!

Westminster Abbey. ABSOLUTELY breathtaking! Was disappointed it was no longer covered by the London Attractions Pass, but they gave us a 10% discount, and I am SO GLAD we went. Saw the tombs of Charles Darwin and Sir Isaac Newton, among many others. Amazing!

Great experience - the staff is amazing. We had fast track London Pass tickets which was great as we were in 10 minutes. The staff of the abbey is lovely and great, very helpful and always have a nice word. We used the digital guide - available several languages. After the visit we tried the coffee shop and had an afternoon tea there: very tasty and the staff very professional and smiley despite being very busy.

Worthwhile but expensive.. The Abbey is an impressive and incredibly interesting building. Staff were polite and the free audio tour engaging. We had to wait for about 30 minutes in the rain before getting in and this points to the two areas in which the abbey could improve – the option of timed tickets might be beneficial and the ticket prices are extortionate. I have a real problem paying to go into a church and £18 per adult is an awful lot – they even had the cheek to ask for a donation on the way out! A family ticket for 2 adults and 2 children will set you back £44. The audio tour is quite quickly paced, probably to keep people moving, so you need to make sure that you take some time and enjoy the surroundings at your pace.

Fantastic second visit!. We recently visited Westminster Abbey for the second time, and we were so glad we went. The entry fee is quite expensive, but definitely worth it. Though very busy inside, we were able to take in more of this amazing abbey this visit, though I'm sure you would find something new and interesting every time you went!

1000 years of history. We rather balked at the 18 pound entry fee, but Westminster Abbey says it gets no govt funding, so we coughed up. Are we glad we did? Yes, yes, yes. The church is a Gothic gem, but it's the history associated with it that really glued us to the place for well over an hour. It's the burial place of most of the kings and queens of England, and so many musicians, actors and writers are either buried there or have memorial plaques. This is a walk around the best of England's royal and cultural history...from Edward the Confessor to Charles Dickens, Geoffrey Chaucer, Handel, various prime ministers, many of the nobility...please don't miss this! Tip: if you go on Wednesday, the abbey is open till 6.30pm, other days it closes at 3.30pm.

Something about the place just makes the depths of your soul resonate with awe that is both sublime and serene.. I've been a fan of England's royal history ever since I first read about Henry VIII as a nine year-old and visiting places like Westminster Abbey have been my dream ever since then. I finally got to visit the place about a week ago. I arrived an hour before it opened and simply seeing its magnificent edifice before me as I walked up the street was enough to inspire awe within me. I would strongly suggest going here early so you can take photos and still be at the front of the line since the queues rapidly from about a few minutes prior to opening time. The entrance fee of GBP18 might be a bit steep, considering that most museums and galleries in London offer free admission, but since this goes towards the upkeep of such a hallowed place, I didn't mind in the slightest.The Abbey was founded in 960 and is well over a thousand years old, and this hits you the moment you set foot within its walls. Countless monarchs have been crowned here ever since William the Conqueror's own coronation after The Conquest, and about seventeen of them are buried here too. I could have wept with reverence when I was before the tombs of Elizabeth I (my favorite monarch), Mary I, Mary Queen of Scots, Margaret Beaufort, Anne Neville, Henry VII, and Elizabeth of York as I have been reading about them for most of my life and standing before their graves is the closest that one will ever get to actually meeting them. Bear in mind that you can't take photographs inside the Abbey, but I surmise that this was a mercy since you are forced to truly focus on the astounding sights that are before you. Many other dignitaries are buried here as well, such as Isaac Newton and the great Laurence Olivier, with memorials set up for literary luminaries like Jane Austen, the Bronte sisters, and William Shakespeare, of course. Finally, no visit is complete without stopping before The Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, a memorial to the numerous and nameless soldiers who fought and died for God, King, and Country during the War.One last tip: If I'm not mistaken, somewhere in Poets' Corner is a niche in the wall, which opens up into a small chapel/prayer room. I was able to spend a few quite minutes there in silent prayer and thanksgiving and I don't recall the last time I felt such profound peace within my soul in that little space.I heard the Abbey Choir's Evensong is also quite an experience, so I will endeavor to witness that on my next trip to London.

Sung Eucharist and Organ Concert. I was most grateful to have been seated in the quire for Sunday's sung Eucharist. Although this magnificent structure appears rather large on television, it is actually smaller and more intimate in within the confines of the quire and the main altar. To have heard the choir sing and participate in this service was most uplifting. In the afternoon, I attended an organ concert. These concerts are offered most Sunday afternoons. This time, I was seated outside the quire.

Heart of England. It's a breath taking historical place with more than lots to see. The audio tour guides you throughout the different corners in staged stations. Pity that photos are not allowed in there.

Words can't express. My whole life (I am 36) I have seen Westminster Abby on TV. All I can tell you is seeing it in person was nothing short of breathtaking.
