We went late in the afternoon, around 3:00 I think. We walked around the Abby and as we were finishing we heard the boys choir practicing! Their angelic voices were so beautiful. I could tell they were setting up for service so I asked if we were allowed to stay. The wonderful gentleman said the best place to wait is here inside, because once you go outside you have to wait in the general line outside. So we waiting for well over an hour before we were let in. To our surprise, the families of the boys choir were escorted in first to take their seats behind the boys (in the beautiful red velvet chairs you have all seen the dignitaries sitting in on the TV).....well, there were 4 seats left open in that area so WE GOT TO SIT THERE!!!!! the moment they started to sing I was overcome with emotion. I sobbed a majority of the time. It was truly a once in a lifetime experience and in my top 3 best days of my life!

A real 'prize' of England. If visiting London, head here first.... Wonderful, atmospheric, stunning gem! Definitely not to be missed if you are in London. This is probably why around a million people flock here every year-and it is wise to be prepared to queue. There is so much to see here. It was founded in 960 and the Coronations of a myriad of Monarchs happened here. Oh if the walls could talk! :-) It is a treasure trove of memorable sights. Literally hundreds of monuments and memorials. Seventeen Monarchs have their resting place here. It is also, with all of this, simply a beautiful, breath-taking place. Westminster Abbey is a working, usable church and holds 28 services a week. All are welcomed to these and the widely renowned choir are amazing...Parts of the interior are dim so if you have limited sight, that may be significant. Good but not exclusive access for the less mobile, but if you are a fulltime wheelchair user, speak to staff, as free entry may be possible.Entry at £18 for adults (unless attending a service), may appear expensive, but oh...what an experience!
Breathtaking. A beautiful treasure! We were there in the middle of the week in October and the crowds were very light. It was a short walk from our hotel. A must see!
Beautiful. The audio tour was excellent. With 2 young teens in tow, this held their interest. We went on a Wednesday and it wasn't crowded.
Heard evensong. Evensong sung by the men and boys' choirs was awesome. If you get a chance to be there for evensong, it's truly a memorable experience. The voice and acoustics sound heavenly.

Impressive, though expensive. The inside is quite impressive with all the tombs and ornaments. A must see as it's not comparable with most churches. Although, it's ridiculous to ask for a £18 entrance fee... Personnel is very rude and the English politeness seemed far away. It should be part of your visit, but if you wanna place your bets, put your money on St Paul's Cathedral.

Best place we visited in london. Blown away at what we saw inside here and kudos for having Jeremy irons voice the audio. Every step reveals something new to see that will make you appreciate how it is so we'll preserved after all these years. Go here and enjoy

Not sure why I like looking at all these tombs but I do it every visit .. The Abbey is 700 years old . Every monarch during that time has been coronated here . How could you not be impressed . How could you not love to see the tombs of a Isaac Newton , Charles Dickens , Kings and Queens galore , Geoffrey Chaucer and Lawrence Olivier . All in the same room .

Awesome from start to finish. I last visited the Abbey some 30 years ago so I thought I would refresh my memories and visit again with my wife. When I first visited, there were no queues to gain access and it was free! Of course in the 21st century things have changed considerably, the Abbey though as not changed for centuries. The audio guides that you are given at the entrance are totally fantastic, as they give you such a fascinating commentary as you walk a set route. The history within the abbey takes your breath away, Kings, Queens, Lords and Ladies are all featured as you make your way around. I thought I may have come away thinking that it might not have been worth queuing for near on 45 minutes and also the admission price, but no, I was absolutely awe struck by the visit, it was well worth it, and left me with some great memories.

A must see!. Whenever in London you should definitely pay Westminster Abbey a visit. The church is a specteculare view and contains so much history. Didn't have the chance to enter the church due to a tight time schedule but most definitely will next time I'm in London. The outside is beautiful.

Highly recommended. The guided tour offers a real insight into these iconic buildings.. Everyone in the world is familiar with these buildings, but you must go inside and learn about the history of the place and see how it operates as a living organism of government. This is a must to see in London, and a guided tour is highly recommended!

Historical Gem. Westminster Abbey is a must when visiting London, the audio tour brings history to life, and the views inside and in outside in parliament square are amazing. Love the Nelson Mandela statue.

Actually this is 5 star except for the no photo policy. Great audio tour . Fascinating subject matter . Though they could find a way to let old people like me sit down more . I also am unhappy with the no photo policy , unless there is some Dort of security reason . The walk through take 1-1 1/2 hours . I would have liked to take a bit longer but if I can't sit down I can't dawdle .

Wow!!. Please do not miss visiting Westminster Abbey ! It is so grand and beautiful, and full of so much history. Pick up a self guided phone and wander around. We used our London Pass and skipped the long line.

Westminster Abbey. There is a fee for the church and well worth it. Go thru the very steps that Kate and William walked when they wed. Very lovely to see and experience. The line is a bit longer than most attractions, but well worth it. They close sometime in the afternoon, so make sure you're not waiting on line when they close as you will have to come back. They offer a family deal, so grab that if you are in a group.

Witnessing history.... This is an impressive site. I compare it to the Am Dom Cathedral in Cologne, though it seems Westminster has more history to it. Do not forget to pick up an information device to guide you through the tour.

Sanctuary indeed. I was really taken by Westminster Abbey. It's a beautiful church with an actual history. I really liked the fact they don't allow you to take photos, I detest people who do that in churches especially when it's forbidden. The welcome is also nice, there are a lot of people working in the abbey that speak multiple languages and you can get a guide with the common languages. I had mine in English and I got to admit, it adds a bit extra when you have your history tour narrated by Jeremy Irons. A big plus from that! Abbey itself is beautiful and so full of Western history that it is quite unbelievable. Well worth the visit!

Step into wonder..... Westminster Abbey dates to 1075 if I remember correctly. Honestly, I has so much history crammed into my brain there today, it's a wonder my head didn't explode. They have a great, free audio tour. No pictures allowed inside, which was very sad, but your camera could never capture what wonders you will behold. This place has scale, history...everything...
Amazing. Westminster Abbey is just amazing. It is huge but appears smaller because of the choir box in the middle. The burial chambers inside the Abbey are truely fascinating.

Incredible trip into history!. Truly awe inspiring and really left me speechless. Would highly recommend a visit here for any history buff or someone who loves cathedrals. Hard to take it all in. Simply beautiful.

Timed tickets would improve it. I wish they used timed tickets here, as the Abbey got very crowded and difficult to negotiate. I was feeling very stressed, which made the experience not quite as nice as I was hoping for.The Abbey is very beautiful and we enjoyed reading the plaques and memorials. The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier was just as profound and sad as the one at home in Canberra. We enjoyed the commentary by Jeremy Irons on the audio guide. Overall, this is a great place to visit, one of the must see's in London. Do get there early, as there is a queue later in the day, and check opening times before you go.
Audio tour is awesome!. Do yourself a favor and get the audio guide. It'll explain everything in (sometimes excruciating) detail but you'll get a full sense of the Abbey and it's purpose.

So much people, so much history!. It was a very incredible visit, seeing the Tombs of many great people and the venue of the Royal wedding. There were lots of people, but that was not surprising as everyone would love to visit.

The Best of London. This structure easily becomes the must-see attraction. The detail and size of the site is amazing, and cannot be captured on photographs. Rich in history, quality and detail- please note it is hard to get a place inside, and crowds around the area are enormous.

history history and again history. Westminster Abbey is impressive. Large, full of history and for the regular tourist is an amazing experience. Don't miss it! Do not let yourself discouraged of the long queues, there is something you will encounter in every major attraction in London. But this one in particular, it's really worth it! Anyway, prepare yourself with patience and be ready to be amazed of what you will find inside! The visit including the time needed for tickets/entrance will be around 2h30'-3h30'. But you will not be disappointed!

Gorgeous church!!. Westminster Abbey is lovely and full of more information than one human can take in in just a single afternoon! We went an hour before closing time and had to race through. It would have been nice to have had more time!

Absolutely Incredible!. The Abbey was absolutely incredible! The artistry is truly magnificent and very impressive. It's really hard to describe the centuries of hard work and craftsmanship that have gone into this historic church. I really enjoyed seeing the tombs and memorials of past royalty. My wife especially loved the Poets Corner, home to Chaucer, Elliot, Kipling, Austen, Dickens, and many many more. No trip to London is complete without visiting Westminster Abbey, even at £18 a person.Read my other reviews, complete with pictures:Search "The Barbecue Fiend"

Very busy, get there first thing in the morning.. To see the place where so many great minds and historical people lay was an awestruck experience. It was great to pay respects to those who have changed the course of our history, from Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Henry VII, Elizabeth I and Mary I and Edward the Confessor. The tours are a great way to see the Abbey as you don't get lost and double back or miss important sites and it's great to be a part of a larger pack, as you don't get shunted around so much by the amount of tourists they cram in there. One thing that really got me annoyed though, was the amount of tourists taking photos. It may just be my belief that you don't disrespect the dead, but I thought people cramming into the enclaves to take photos of the tombs was wrong- Westminster Abbey has signs posted telling people not to take photos but it seems most don't listen (it was the same in Notre Dame in Paris when we visited a week later). But that is personal opinion only. Overall the experience was awe inspiring and a fantastic way to start our history day in London.

No words. Incredible. A must see for London. We went on a Sunday, and happened to be there forty minutes before a service. We waited, and ended up being seated in the front for a beautiful service. This was free, and well worth the wait! My favorite memory from London.

Iconic London Landmark. Well, tourist attractions don't come much more iconic than Westminster Abbey - as the queue snaking round the corner demonstrated. Nevertheless we were inside within 25 minutes so not too bad - & well worth the wait & price of admission.The Abbey dates back over a thousand years & is an architectural triumph which you can't fail to be impressed by. Tombs of Queen Elizabeth 1st & Queen Mary to name but a few. Name plaques to honour all manner of well known & not so well known & some fascinating funeral effigies in the basement. There's also the famous Coronation Chair which has been used for all coronations since the 13th century (I think!). A visit to the Abbey is to walk the path of the great & mighty.Lunch a tad expensive but, hey, this is Westminster Abey after all & the food & service were excellent.There's also free entry to the adjoining St Margarets Church - where Winson Churchill was married - which is also well worth a visit.Of course you can also take in the Houses of Parliament, Big Ben & Westminster Bridge all of which are only seconds away & all of which are mightily impressive
Love everything about this building.... Loved it... walk around the feel the energy, this place is should be on your list of places to see while in London

Worshipful. We didn't actually take the tour/pay admission, but just attended evensong one day. The building was lovely and it was a great experience to worship God in a different way than I am used to. We especially loved the choir. It was also fun to be in the area, see the houses of parliament while eating crepes from a crepe stand.

It was okay.... Steeped in history and a traditional must-see site for any traveler going to London, expectations are high for visitors. This is reflected in the price of admission, which was 18 L per adult, or 36 L for family of two adults and one child. Many other attractions in London have free admission. Self administered audio guides are provided for a circuit around the Abbey to view all the highlights. Going early at the opening hour of 930 am gives one a hint at how popular and potentially crowded the Abbey can get. London Pass holders can gain access without waiting in the queue which can be quite lengthy as the day wears on. The many venues within the Abbey are interesting but not compelling. Finding the various names of the many well known individuals buried here was not easy. Photographs are NOT allowed within the Abbey. The incredible range of nobles and historical figures over the past 900 years is impressive but a little monotonous. Historical information on the many individuals on site is not readily available which takes away from the informative potential of any visit. The structure, grounds, and monuments are certainly unique and worthwhile to study in person. However, I came away underwhelmed by the experience.

Kings, queens and poets.. Although quite expensive you will be informed about some of our most important characters both with royal blood and people of note including Keats and Churchill. Our rich heritage lends itself to some great stories spoken by Jeremy Ions. The audio guides actually work very well and give some great information. The only downside was I wasn't allowed to take photographs.
Beautiful. Very beautiful abbey, well situated if you want to see Big Ben and London Eye. I recommend his visit.

Beautiful abbey, but go for the history.. My husband and I arrived around mid-day on a Friday and while there were tourists everywhere we only waited a few minutes in line. We opted to use the audio guides included in the ticket price - you receive a map with the audio guide that shows you what numbers to enter for each area. We probably spent a little over an hour following the map/audio guide.There is so much history! The guide points out notable tombs for numerous kings/queens/important people. There are tombs which are hundreds of years old - I think King Edward the 1st was the oldest we saw. Sometimes you do have to look around a little to figure out what the guide is talking about, but we didn't have too much trouble. I found Poet's Corner especially interesting because the average person can recognize many of the names.You can get close enough to touch nearly all the tombs, but that doesn't mean you should. We were saddened to see where people had scratched words into some of the stonework, these are tombs people!. Note that some of the Viking "graffiti" around the abbey, so be on the lookout for that. Another pet peeve of mine was people standing in small walkways, keep walking until there's space to stand and stare without stopping everyone behind you.

Historical Abbey. I took my grandmother to visit and was a well worthwhile visit. We arrived at 11 and had about a 20 minute queue outside; glad we had good weather that day. The audio guide and map provided is excellent, very informative and easy to use. Inside the nave is very impressive and the audio tour is easy to follow. Plenty seats are provided and my grandmother found the abbey very accessible to walk around. I would recommend at least 1 hour and half to visit, as the abbey if full of interesting historical information. The only thing I could criticise is price, which is expensive for some at £18.

Quite small. Upon arriving at westminster abbey my original thought was it wasn't that large, considering a lot of royals get married there. It is however a beautiful building and has a small gift shop to the side.

The church where the monarchs have been crowned since 1066. It's an architectural masterpiece full of history and culture. I can't imagine visiting this place without a tour guide. The abbey is massive, and there's so much to cover in such a short period of time. It was originally built as a monastery by St. Edward The Confessor and was later rebuilt in the Gothic style by King Henry III. The abbey that we see today is so much more than a place of worship. It's also the place for Royal coronations, weddings, and burials. As you walk though the abbey, you'll see memorials and burial sites of famous monarchs, poets, scientists, musicians, prime ministers, and actors. The Poets' Corner in the south transept of the abbey has names such as Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Robert Browning, Charles Dickens, George Frideric Handel, and Sir Laurence Olivier. You'll see beautiful architecture all around you from the cloisters to the cathedral. You don't have to be religious to enjoy it. It's worth a visit for it's historic and symbolic value. My only regret is not being able to spend more time here. Don't miss this experience.

Lovely Visit. The staff inside were very knowledgeable and helpful. The tour is given on an audio guide. The place is full of history and if you have questions just ask the staff. You cannot take photos inside but its well worth the visit.

Well worth your time. Arrived there at 9:00am and were the second people in line for the 9:30 opening. Be aware that there is no photography allowed within the abbey itself. The architecture and stained glass is amazing. A must-see while in London.
Not to be missed!. The history! I enjoyed the audio guide, but there were also volunteers there who could give more information and answer questions.

Lovely visit. I totally enjoyed my visit to Westminster abbey. The place has so much history its overwhelming. You could spend all day in the abbey. The audio guide really helps keep you navigating the massive church. Loved the visit.

Amazing Architecture, Audio a little boring after a while. There is so much glory in the building inside and out. I haven't seen a nicer church in my life. The audio tour is nice but gets boring after a while. So many famous English peoples' coffins in this place. Great for anyone liking architecture and history. Come on Sunday morning or in the mornings to avoid the ques.

Beautiful. A bit pricey but worth the visit. We visited St. Paul's Cathedral first and weren't sure we'd do another church but definitely glad we didn't miss Westminster Abbey. It was amazingly beautiful with interesting stories and so many incredible people in history there.

Go inside and take a guided tour with a Verger it was great!. We had a London Pass and were able to skip the que. When we arrived there was a tour we could purchase with a member of the church. This was excellent! We were given so much information and were able to go to areas that are not available to the general public. We even were able to sit in the Quire and in the area behind the main sanctuary. It was so worth it and one of my favorites. It did take about an hour and a half.
visited at last.. would recommend booking a verger tour ( £3 each).we were a small group so could hear everything he said.he took us to places not on the normal route excellent value.

Beautiful building, dull audio tour. I'm a sucker for an audio tour and, generally, I like them. Unfortunately, the audio tour (included in admission) at Westminster Abbey is incredibly dull. It doesn't seem to highlight the most interesting stops - e.g. It says to look out for Newton's tombstone, but then doesn't tell you where it might be. The usher stationed there looked exhausted when we asked him to point it out.The building, however, doesn't disappoint. The cloisters out the back are also beautiful. It may also be worth noting for some visitors that it's not very wheelchair/limited mobility friendly but all visitors can see most of the main sites within the Abbey.

Fantastic morning. I love all churches and historic houses but this was worth the money a truly wonderful history lesson. I would recommend getting the audio thing as a lot of the inscriptions are in Latin. Lots of thing to see, and plenty of help with knowledgeable staff.
Y.. Must see in london. The audio guide is clear and useful. A very impressive architectual design. We enjoyed the hour and a half tour in the abby

Mobbed and like a mausoleum. But wonderful guides and volunteers.. It is a very long time since I visited the abbey and it may well be ages before I go back. It is expensive and, while I do not object in any way to paying to enter any church merely to look and admire rather than worship, I do resent paying "top dollar" and then have to jostle with mobs of visitors and then missing the Coronation Chair because it is boxed up to protect it from work going on around it. When that happens, the ticket price should be reduced.It is a grand building but there are more beautiful cathedrals and abbeys. It resembles a mausoleum for the great, the rich, the influential of nearly 1000 years and many of the lasting memorials are grim beyond belief. Kings and queens are squeezed in where there is space and that leaves little space for the mobs to contemplate their lives and their impact on our history and to see their last resting places. Poets Corner is also a resting place for the living as it accommodates lots of folding chairs in rows for the weary tourist. It is not a pretty sight and and that is a shame as the volunteers and guides are willing, informative, knowledgeable and, despite the masses (of tourists), pleasant. Our history is lost, hidden and forgotten in such a clutter. Only the human contact with the wonderful volunteers at the great west door made this tolerable for me.

Only Outside. I did not take the tour as you cannot take pictures inside anyways and I didn't want to spend the money. However, the outside of the Abbey is gorgeous and HUGE! It is amazing to see the beauty of the way they used to build things.

Favorite Place in the World (next to home). I am a Christian from the States. I love to tour the older churches and cathedrals throughout Europe. I've been to Notre Dame, Winchester Cathedral, St Paul's, St Michael's, a mosque in the Turkish side of Nicosia Cyprus, the oldest church in Larnaca, Cyprus (founded by Lazarus - yes, THAT Lazarus). and on and on, including cathedrals/churches in Belgium, Netherlands, Sweden, Finland. My first time in London, in 2000, I had only a Sunday to be a tourist, and decided to attend a service as the only way to see the inside of the Abbey. It was amazing - as a christian service, as a choir/organ treat, and as a historical monument. The deaconess (?) seated me in the Quire itself, and I just had shivers and awe from the sense of reverence and of history, and the beauty of the choir/organ. Whenever I am in London now, I make Sunday services at the Abbey; I feel such a sense of reverence I can only think of the Holy Spirit. Passing through London again just now - and off to services there.

Amazing history, but no photos inside. The history of Westminster Abbey just oozes from the walls. The audio guide is very interesting, and allows you to choose which areas you want to hear about (although the path through the Abbey is one-way and you are not allowed to go back). We saw an amazing variety, from the tombs of Charles Darwin and Queen Elizabeth I, to the memorial to the Royal Air Force with some bomb damage to the Abbey preserved. There was a huge line when we arrived, but it moved quickly and while you are in line you get some great views of Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. An hour or two is probably enough, but this is one of those can't-miss sights if you want to say that you've seen London. The only drawback is that as it is a functioning church, you are not allowed to take photos inside, but this also means that you pay a little more attention to what you are experiencing instead of just trying to get a great photo.

Beyond Beauty. We have wanted to visit here for a long time. Unfortunately we got there quite late and couldn't take the time needed for this trip, but that does mean we have to go back one day, and we definitely will.Westminster Abbey is truly magnificent, the staff are extremely friendly, helpful and knowledgeable. Our son had a quiz sheet to work through which points the children to important parts to see and is great for them. The entrance fee feels a little steep, but under 11's go free. We will definitely go back, need hours there to take it all in. Shame we couldn't take photos inside.

Brings London and British history together. We really enjoyed our visit to Westminster Abbey. As Americans, we have some knowledge of events in English history and this place ties a lot of those in. Here you can see the grave of Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots and also see the place of coronations, funerals, and weddings. The guide there not only answered a question about Sir Isaac Newton's grave location but also walked us there and explained the meanings of his memorial. The Lady's chapel was one the most beautiful things we saw on our trip. This place should be a must on any tour of London.

Excellent Verger Tour, Stunning Sight. What a beautiful and interesting place to visit! There are so many nooks and crannies and such historical significance in this Abbey that I would highly recommend the Verger tour. Our guide, Ben, was excellent! He personalized the tour in a way that was special for everyone, and told the story of Westminster in such a way it was fun and enjoyable even though you were learning a tonne! I would recommend seeing Westminster Abbey after the Tower of London because it helps to continue the timeline of history and we had a better frame of reference after the Tower. We used our London Pass which allowed us to beat the line up (also highly recommend). Go early to take advantage of the day.

Steeped in history. Westminster Abbey is a must visit site in London. It spans many centuries of British history with the impressive tombs of Queen Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scots and the Unknown soldier among others. The Coronation Chair, Poets corner, the cloisters and gardens are well worth a visit.You need to get there before last admissions at 1530 and the lovely gardens are only open on certain days.Entry is expensive at £18.00 per person but the audio is included in the price and well worth using for a good insight into the Abbey.

Best Cathedral I've Ever Visited. There is so much to see in Westminster, it is almost mind-numbing. There is an admission charge and the family admission only covers one child (children under 11 are free). The audio guide is very well done and is included in the admission price; don't skip it. The sense of history in Westminster is amazing. Tombs of famous people and beautiful architecture. Because of limited time in our schedule, we almost skipped this. It would have been a huge mistake. Make this a priority visit in London. It is right next to Parliament and Big Ben and a short walk from Buckingham Palace, the Churchill War Rooms and the Cavalry Museum. Even my kids, who are not big history buffs, were awed by this visit.

Beautiful but expensive. I love the history here. My daughter and I used the audio guide and she enjoyed immensely. I don't think it was worth £18 but she got in free and really wanted to see it. Wish they'd consider allowing pictures!
A must see. Amazing history and recommend paying the few extra pounds for the vigour tour guide as it gets you to areas otherwise blocked off to tourists.

Wonderful history and architecture.. Always a must see when in London, a visit to the Abbey never fails to impress one. Every visit is special and you find and see something not found before. The magnificent architecture leaves one stunned as you take in the height of the roof, the design and intrices of the ceilings in the various chapels. The whole history of England, indeed the UK, is here with the final resting places of countless Kings, Queens, dignitaries and luminaries from all walks of life. Poet’s Corner is a must – just to revel in the monuments and burial sites of such diverse groups of artists. A bit like visiting Musicians Corner in the Central Cemetery of Vienna. It is worth reading up some of the tourist guides of the Abbey prior visiting so that you don’t miss too much. A nice little café/restaurant is now on site where you can recharge the batteries before further exploration. Compared to St. Paul’s, there appear to be more monuments and tombs and the design of the building is of a more grandiose scale. Like St Paul’s it does reveal the military history of England with so many of the famous persons celebrated and laid to rest. So much of the stonework, dating back centuries, is of such beautiful craftsmanship and skill that it is a delight to explore the side chapels and crypts. Again, like St. Paul’s, it is a working Church and your visit may have to work around Church commitments. The famous Choir area is a treat to see as we are all familiar with these places after various Royal weddings and funerals over our lifetime. You are not permitted to take photos or videos.

First visit for 20 years. Advice - get there early, take the audio tour. Well done. A "granny's attic" of a place - beautiful marble memorials very close together, which they probably weren't originally. Coronation throne away for repair. Touched by the memorials to the infant pricesses. Even royalty has its sorrows. Note: Closing times vary, we missed our first attempt by 3 minutes, but early the next day (Wednesday) was fine, no queues. The guides are splendid. Well informed, and courteous. A bit "memory lane" for me, and, as a "fully paid up" (ie baptised and confirmed) member of the Church of England, was rather disquieted to have to pay so much to enter what is, in fact the central church of my religion, (moneychangers and temple sprang to mind) Still I suppose it has to be maintained, and the wear and tear on such ancient monuments must be considerable.I have always enjoyed visiting it, and still do.

Eye-wateringly admission charge but fully justified. The sad thing about visiting the Abbey is that it is only frequented by overseas visitors. The man handing out the audio guides was taken aback when I said that I lived in London. Why is so little done to attract UK visitors? Anyway said audio guide gives succinct information but there are plenty of guides to assist enquiries or prevent use of cameras. There is so much to absorb here that even as a British person with a tenuous grip of domestic history one feels that you are treading water just to keep ahead. Beautiful, mesmerising, overpowering and empowering. Be better if the balance between worship the essential revenue generation extracted from the tourist were brought together so that those who just want to "do" the Abbey appreciate the whole reason it is there rather than just marvelling at history
love the architecture. I loved the burials , the sculptures and ceilings. it´s like be transported to another world, and to another times.
Beautiful Church. Its filled with history and just such a beautiful place to see, you are taken through the history very well and is simply put out.

Humbling. What a beautiful church. To walk where kings and Queens had walked and got crowned. To see the burial sites of Queens and Kings and writers and statesman. Unfortunately you can't take photos even without a flash. One of my favorite characters is buried in the Abbey (Sir Lord Thomas Cochran from the Master and Commander series).

All England's history in one place. We must have been blessed. No queuing to get in. No huuuuge groups of tourists. My daughter, a history undergrad was most keen to visit QE1 monument which we did with time to really take it all in. We were in the abbey at the right time to take prayers at Edward the confessors chapel very special it felt too. It is a very cluttered building with family monuments obscuring other monuments. Resembling at times an architectural salvagers if that isn't too impertinent to mention. All the same a very special place. Would've stayed for lunch but the prices were pretty hefty not in keeping with a religious place. Look at Durham cathedrals refectory for example

Amazing - A favorite in London. Westminster Abbey is beautiful and well worth a visit. It is beautiful, loaded with history, and not commercialized at all. You are provided a self guided audio tour for free and it is handy. One of my favorite stops in London. On the way, I also recommend you stop in to see Churchills War Room. It is the bunker were he and his team worked from in WWII and it is very well preserved.

Oozing History. The majority of England's Kings and Queens are buried here and I find it incredible that I can stand next to the tomb of Edward 1, Henry V, Elizabeth 1 etc, etc. Also not to be missed are the fantastic ceilings, architecture and engraved windows. Right down to damage caused in WW2.Still a place of worship and reflection if you like history this must be the best time line for the last 900 years.The staff are very knowledgeable.

Amazing, a must-see attraction!. We waited less than 5 minutes to get in and then spent about 2 hours walking around viewing this amazing Abbey. We took the advice of other reviewers and got the audio tour (free) and I would highly recommend this since otherwise it would be easy to get lost and overwhelmed in such a huge area. The staff were also super helpful in answering any questions we had.

amazing place.. A bit costly to sight see at £15-£18 but considering what you get for your money it's got to be worth it.There isn't enough room here to list it - just go and do it. Alternatively, do what we did and went to on of the 5pm daily services, which are free! these also occur at St Paul's every evening as well. During the day, pop across the road to the Methodist Central Hall and try the Wesley Cafe n the basement Good food at a sensible price lovely seating and a good place to recharge !!

Breathtaking!. This is one of the most beautiful churches I have ever been to and I found it such worthwhile visit. Upon your arrival you will receive an audio box for a self guided tour. I never realized that Isaac Newton was buried here and it's a bit strange to see so many graves throughout the church. The smaller chapels are interesting and be sure to look at the ceilings in all the smaller rooms…each are gorgeous. You an walk down the same aisle as Princess Catherine and can sit in prayer. Be sure to check the times as a lot of people in our group went later in the day and missed it. We went around 11 AM during the week and got right in. You can also visit the cafe on the grounds for an English Tea Service!

Wow. Anyone who is a sucker for history and architecture should take the time to visit Westminster Abbey. A truly beautiful structure that is absolutely full of history and well worth the time to visit.

I'm Sure It's Amazing, If You Can Get In!. If you are travelling in the low season like we did, be sure to check dates and times available for the attractions you want to see....on the day of. We tried on a Tuesday to go into the Westminster Abbey, we got there at 5pm and it was too late. We went back the next afternoon, earlier but not early enough. We asked about going back the following morning, and were told that it was closed to the public for the entire day.
Wonderful!. I've waited many years to see the Abbey and I was not disappointed. It's daunting to think of how many have passed through this ancient building. I was humbled.

Unmissable. As a born again history fan, this place was heavenly, paradise in fact. The ancient tombs and memorials are of course unique, and awe inspiring, as is the cathedral architecture. The history which this building has shared and witnessed is almost tangible. Unfortunately it is obviously a site favoured by many tourist groups and it was quite crowded even in the month of March.

enjoy. we have been meaning to visit the Abbey for sometime but have been put off by the £18 each price tag. It was my 50th birthday trip so we bit the bullet and were surprised by the short queue to get in . First impression was its a bit small compared to the other cathedral/ minster/ Abbey buildings we have visited.We plodded on , in the end it was a hotch potch of areas cramped at times and a lot of waiting for your fellow tourists o vacate an area before you can have your turn. Historically interesting but I would put Canterbury Cathedral, York Minster The Hagia Sophia , The Blue mosque, Westminster Cathedral in front of it.

A must see attraction. This was our the first activity on our 3rd day in London. We went here on a London pass, so we didn't have to go through the long queue of people buying tickets. The London pass includes a audio guide that will guide you as you go along the tour inside the abbey. People are not allowed to take pictures inside, this is to preserve the sanctity of the abbey. There are many famous people that are buried inside they abbey. It is really large, and there are lots of places to explore. Sometimes, there are guided tours offered. We were trying to keep a schedule, so we only went through the highlights of the place. I will go here again if given the chance, so that I can learn more about the place.

Magestic...literally!!!. Used since the time of William the Conquerer (1066) to crown every king and queen in Britain (except two) through to the current Queen...and no wonder. We used the audio guide (voice over by Jeremy Irons), which covered everything in as much detail as we wanted, but the Abbey also offers free tours for those who prefer the more personal touch. Simpy, the Abbey is spectacular. This is a 'must see' for anyone who visits London because of the incredible history, the architectural brilliance and the amazing beauty.

Priceless experience. The outside is so intricate. Amazing that every piece has a different face. Unfortunately we had to much to see in London in 3 days to really expire stop and stay here. We did not do the audio tour, if you do have time they have a sheet for kids to do as they walk around. Most places in London have this which was nice to keep our son interested. I enjoyed the saying around CS Lewis' memory plaque on the floor. The Handel statue and the numerous king and queen tombs. My favorite part was outside we saw an older part that dates back to the Norman days where they stored the money they compared all money to. Very interesting. One of my favorite things I did in London.

Better than I could have imagined. We went to Westminster Abbey with not a lot of expectations. We just hadn't really researched it much so didn't really have a lot of thoughts on visiting. Once inside, though, our minds were blown! It was one of the most beautiful places I have ever been, and I've been a few places. I loved the audio guide tour as well. It had great information and you didn't have to wait around for a group of people to move on to the next area. Westminster Abbey is an absolute must, in my book!
Marvelous church. This church holds so much history. It is well worth a visit. Many celebrities are buried here, for example Darwin.

Grand, historic and beautiful. My husband and I visited the Abbey on a quick 2 day break in London. I expected it to be grand, and I was not disappointed. Thanks to my lack of research, I was surprised to see that it is the burial place of hundreds, who are memorialized with huge statues mounted over their crypts. Now I have to admit, I am a graveyard gazer. I love to look at ancient graves and imagine the lives of those buried beneath my feet. But this takes it to an entire new level. I greatly enjoyed standing at the burial site of folks I have read about in history books. Maybe that's macabre, but, that's me.We also had the opportunity to take communion in the abbey. My husband and I are non denominational Christians, and my husband is a former Catholic. The service was very reverent and lovely, and I am glad we attended. Though I don't normally care about the building in which to worship, I have to admit that the abbey inspired some deep worship.I also have to admit that I got a kick out of walking down the aisle where royalty was crowned and married. It was fun to see pictures of Prince William walking in the exact place I stood. If you enjoy the history of the British royals, even a little bit, I think you will enjoy the abbey.

Sunday Sung Eucharist Service well worth going to. We explored the outside of the Abbey and learned much of its history as part of a Westminster walking tour. Somewhat put off by the high admission cost, we decided to go to the Sung Eucharist service on Sunday morning (no fee when attending a worship service, but no additional sightseeing permitted). It was wonderful. We were seated in Poet's Corner. They have large video screens placed so you can see full service and choir even though some of nave not visible from our pews. The music (boy's choir plus men's choir) was glorious; the service interesting and thoughtful. Got to see much of Poet's Corner during service (Chaucer memorial and window, Dryden memorial was at end of our row; Robert Adams stone was at my feet, Shakespear memorial nearby, and more). And we saw much of church on the way out, including the beautiful windows, many famous memorial stones, (Sir Isaac Newton's , Winston Churchill's, Noel Coward's and others), tomb of the unknown soldier, coronation throne, etc. Did not get to see tombs of the royals, but that was offset by opportunity to enjoy the abbey in use as a living churh, and to hear the choir. I would recommend attending the service even it there was a change; it was even better that there was not.

Oozing with history.. Despite our London Pass we still had to wait for an hour in the queue. We really enjoyed it once we were in there. The history that goes back centuries is awesome. allow yourself a good 3 hours if you want to do it justice.I didn't find the toilets if they were there. We had to go all the way back to the underground 200m away and pay 50p for the privilege.

Amazing. Cued up for 40mins to enter, even though it was free with my London Pass. Inside was amazing and the audio guide was well done. A pity you can't take photos inside though. Spent a couple of hours in here and it was an amazing glimpse at history and a number of 'famous' people (royals especially). Worthwhile doing if you get the chance.

to expensive by far. At the end of the day this is a church. One that i always thought of as part of my heritage . I don't mind contributing to the upkeep of any of our country's treasures but £18 ---- I thought it was a joke. One of the staff in an attraction opposite told me the price was increased after the royal wedding !!!! I didn't go in. Instead i went to the other end of the street to the catholic cathedral where i was able to go into the tower to see great views of london, had a lovely welcome, a nice meal, and left a donation towards the upkeep. Gave a star for the outside view.

Such a beautiful historical place.. Got in free with my London Pass and it was awesome!! Can't take any pictures inside but its great to see all the history and knowing that I walked the same steps as royalty had was pretty terrific. Really worth the visit!
worth a visit. very interesting, you will spend alot of time in here. costly but worth it. there is a free audio guide available, use it. its great.

Well worth visiting. Loved visiting the Abbey, it is such a beautiful building , the audio tour supplied was very interesting and informative. I Would have given 5 stars, but think the entrance fee expensive.
Beautiful, big, pricey, no photos allowed. A beautiful piece of history definitely worth seeing, but a bit too pricey and I don't quite understand why you aren't allowed to take any photos inside.
Beautiful!. This is a beautiful church and well worth going through. The audio tour was definitely worthwhile. You cannot take photos inside.

Beautiful Church!. Soak it all in and take the audio tour and you will not be disappointed. There is a lot to take in so take your time and remember it is a church. Poet's Corner was especially fascinating for me. The only thing is you can not take pictures inside the church. Buy postcards if you want pictures. They are serious about that. Nice shop. Must see stop when in London!
must see!. Beautiful - but watch the schedule. They are closed for visitation Sunday and Monday. Otherwise, great place to visit, gorgeous church. A must see in London for sure.

Walk where the famous do. this was an excellent couple of hours, where you can picture all the royal weddings, funerals etc. that they put on the television as well as seeing where the famouse queens and kings of our country have been buried. The craftmanship here is fabulous and for us was a must do visit on our trip

Fantastic - a must see. As with every tourist attraction in London admittance isn't cheep, but the sights, and history make the price well worth it. Make sure to get the audio guide, and take your time. My wife and I went this last September and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. It was made more difficult given she was 6 months pregnant, but they have ample seating for those who need to rest. I'm a sucker for all things war history, so my favorite thing to do was read the epitaphs of military officers to catch a glimpse of what their life with like, and what action/adventures they partook in. All in all is a celebration of life, and British history all in one place.

Best organized audio tour ever. Westminster Abbey is an amazing place with a ton of history, but to top it off it has the best self-guided audio tour I have ever encountered. The tour is free, or more exactly included in the price of admission, and it provides good coverage with many opportunities to go into more depth. Our family decided this was the best attraction in London.

Interesting and well presented. Interesting, well presented self-guided tour including easy to follow and comprehensive audio guide (included in admission price). Lovely building architecture and much history to discover.

Beautiful. After months in London I finally made it inside the Abby and was not disappointed. It is simply breath taking. I went on a Sunday to one of the morning services to get a different experience. The outside of the church is beautiful and it's more beautiful and grand on the inside. It should be on every ones itinerary, my only regret is not coming in sooner.

Inspiring . 1000 years of history in this incredible building. A jewel in the crown of London's historical heritage. So much to see. Download the app for an audio assisted tour. Go to evensong for a most magical choral and angelic experience or simply wander through, over and between eons of history of royalty, artists, poets and composers. The scene of royal weddings, funerals and coronations. Westminster Abbey is a most amazing experience. Go visit!

Beauty in history. Beautiful stained glass windows, just a beautiful church all around. Very old and goes hand in hand with England's dark history and yet beautiful at the same time. I am a very big Queen Elizabeth I historian and to see her Sarcophagus was fascinating. What humor to know she was placed right next Queen Mary her rival sibling. Many, many more Royals and the tomb of the unknown soldier. To see the alter where Princess Diana lay in state before her burial was emotional. If you think about it, it's truly amazing that should you be a Royal and to be married at Westminster Abbey your ENTIRE family is there including the ones from many, many generations ago. To see how the all the Royals were related was very interesting
Amazing place. One of the most beautiful church interiors with interesting history and perfect audio guide narrated by Jeremy Irons. :)

Amazing place full of History. We went for the Organ Concert, which is scheduled for every sunday at 5.45pm and it is free of charge. It was incredible. We sat in the choir área and we felt we were living part of the History.A must see!

Happy with Abbey. We were a bit taken aback with the entry fee to Westminster Abbey ... it is expensive. But with a self-guided audio tour and a couple of hours to spare we did enjoy the experience. It is a spectacular place and the history captured within these four walls runs very deep.
Interesting. I visited with my family, and we had a nice time looking around the cathedral and seeing some graves of some famous people.

A must to see. To discover the Abby with the audio guide is a great experience. They don't allow photos what you could think it is a pity, but the truth is you can really pay attention and enjoy the visit. The building is fabulous and you can easily spend a great 2 hours visit as it is not cheap.

What more could you want?!?!. This was a SPECTACULAR visit. You MUST leave yourself at least 3 hours to do the tour if you really want to do it justice. It was wonderful that an audio guided tour was included in the cost of admission as I can't imagine having wandered through without it. The staff was very helpful in pointing out things you may have missed or couldn't find. Though it was somewhat overwhelming to realize you were literally stepping across graves, the history and beauty was truly inspiring! Recommend going around later in the afternoon and then sticking around for the Evensong in the evening.

Worth the long line.. Be prepared for the long line to get into Westminster Abbey. We got there about 30 minutes after opening and there were 2 lines that stretched from the entrance to the street. We had to wait about 15 minutes. It's sooo worth it. Such a beautiful, breath-taking sight. Definitely need to get the audioguide to get the full appreciation. The aisleways are a little narrow which is challenging for those pushing strollers or wheelchairs. Also, some of the rooms get a little claustophobic and hot with the crowds.

beautiful. beautiful place to walk round. Doesn't take long so nice just to catch the underground for a quick visit. Wouldn't go back because nothing really to do there but looks good on my photos and lovely place to look at
One of the "must see" places in London. Do not skip this one! Do the tour, and don't skip the audio tour part of it. There is so much history including tombs with many names you will recognize.

Overwhelming. This isn't a quick visit, if you want to take it all in. It's mesmerizing to have the history of the UK in one place. All the great cultural heroes are memorialized here. If there's a line outside, it's worth waiting for.

Beautiful - but expect long queues!. Definitely worth visiting. In fact it should be on your top 10 locations to visit in London. Expect long queues and crowds, even when you are inside. We hired one of the audio guides which explains a lot about the building, which is rich in history and beauty. The guide even describes to you where the famous people like Shakespeare are buried.

Culture tour. Not been to the Abbey before and had mixed reviews from friends.But it is truly a gem to visit with a fantastic array of english history through the ages.Marvellous,will be back to London just to go and see what I missed last time.

Bit pricey. After a bit of a queue (25 mins) friendly welcome by security at entrance & ticket office. Entrance bit pricey at £18 each. You do get a good individual audio headset to use that had a wealth of information but unless you walk round really slowly it's unlikely you will be there more than an hour. We noticed people who had queued near to us leaving around the same time so I don't think we rushed round. Great to see inside - its been on our to do list for a while & glad we visited. It's just not cheap!
Beautiful building. One of the highlights of London, beautiful example of Medieval architecture with a brilliant history

Stunning and fascinating! (but please sort out the toilets). This is an absolute must-see for anyone with the slightest hint of interest in British history - it is all covered here. From kings and queens to poets and musicians, the great and good of Great Britain are buried and/or celebrated at Westminster Abbey. The seamless architecture is visually striking and in itself good enough reason to warrant a visit.My one gripe is that the toilets were in an appalling condition. This is wholly unjustifiable given the extortionate adult ticket price of £18. That said, this is a London attraction not to be missed!

Dream Come True. Words cannot even describe the grandeur, solemnity, beauty, peace, and historic value of this church. It is a must-see for any London visitor, and I am chagrined that it's not ranked within the top five attractions for the city. If you are not awed by the Gothic architecture, surely you will be impressed by the names of great people who are buried here. Within this church you will find the last resting place of kings and queens, lords and ladies, great poets, scientists, generals, clergy -- Elizabeth I, Mary Tudor, Mary Queen of Scots, Henry V, Henry VII, Charles Darwin, Sir Isaac Newton, Oliver Cromwell, Chaucer, to just name a few -- and memorials to many other influential and prominent figures of British history. The Abbey is also the home to the Coronation Throne.You can rush through the church in an hour if you skip various chapels. However, for a satisfactory visit, budget at least two hours or more if you're a big history buff or fan of British literature as I am. When we visited last weekend, it was 18£ per adult to visit the Abbey, which is very expensive (but London is one of the most expensive cities in the world to visit). You will be provided with an audio guide (offered in many different languages), which highlights the history of the abbey and of the people interred there.Photographs are not allowed inside the church itself.If you have the time, I would highly recommend attending an Evensong or Sunday morning service, which are free.
Amazing!. The Cathedral is stunning! The ticket is a bit expensive but the audioguided tour is included in the price.

Attended evening service at 6:30 pm. We attended the 6:30 pm evening service at the Abbey. It was very dark inside the Abbey and cold. I think most of the Abbey was partitioned off. I was not impressed with how the inside of the Abbey looked. I think I would feel differently if I went during daylight hours. Next time I will go during the day and will take a tour.

Historically interesting but . . .. So much history and very much worth a visit although the entrance fee is rather steep. There are several guided tours each day for which you have to pay extra otherwise you are stuck with a walkie talkie device which kills a lot of the interest and atmosphere after a while. Ended up not using it for very long. Please London - keep "real" tour guides as they bring the history alive, unlike listening to Jeremy Irons commentary! Unlike many historical attractions in London, I think this will be my one and only visit.
Very Interesting and Wonderful place. It was a lovely place with so much History and the Guides were Brilliant . So much to see and do and it was spotlessly clean.

Wow !. Location: The closest tube stops to the Abbey are Westminster (Circle, District & Jubilee Lines) and St. James Park (Circle and District Lines). The Abbey is a short walk from these tube stops, providing lovely scenic routes along the way. Westminster is a pretty area within London, so the quick walk will be pleasant.The Abbey is a focal point within Westminster, situated extremely close to the Houses of Parliament, Big Ben, the London Eye, the Churchill War Rooms and Buckingham Palace. This area is dominated by government and business aspects of London city life, however it is nonetheless a nice area to walk through and explore.The Abbey:I could not have imagined the beauty and prestige of Westminster Abbey before I actually experienced the real thing. The Abbey holds more than 1000 years of British history. It showcases the prestige of British royalty, including the crypts and memorials to 17 monarchs. Also, it holds the remains and memory of infamous civilians, including Charles Darwin. The Abbey also houses the final resting places for the children of King Henry VIII, notably Queen Elizabeth I, Mary I and Edward VI. At every turn, you will find stunningly carved legacies of infamous individuals.Highlights of the Abbey: The High Alter is the heart of the Abbey. It contains a stunning mosaic and religious artefacts that date back to the 17th century. In front of the High Alter, the 13th century marble floor gleams with stunning colours and patterns. Also, there are 3 medieval tombs just off to the north of the High Alter.The Lady Chapel:This part of the Abbey was my favourite aspect. It was established in the early 16th century and is the last “great masterpiece of English architecture”. The fan-vaulted roof, carved statuettes and beautiful stained glass express the grandeur of this chapel. Here, Elizabeth 1 and Mary 1 reside in their competing tombs. The Lady Chapel is exquisitely ornate and detailed. It is a beautiful part of the Abbey, and definitely a must-see.The Poet’s CornerThis part of the Abbey is entirely dedicated to famed British poets, writers, etc. This part of the Abbey contains enormous hand-crafted monuments made from beautiful white marble. There is a large shrine to Shakespeare, which is a highlight of Poet’s corner. You will also see stunningly grand monuments to Tennyson and Charles Dickens, just to name a few.Other Highlights:The Shrine to Edward the Confessor, the Cloisters, Grand Organ, the Nave, Pyx Chamber and Saint Faith’s Chapel.Service:There is a free audio guide that is narrated by Jeremy Irons. At times, it is drawn out and a little dull. However, it provides extensive knowledge and information regarding the history, architecture and legacy of Westminster Abbey. The various guides and volunteers around the Abbey are a great help. They are knowledgeable, engaging and pleasant. Their information was much appreciated and their manner extremely kind. Guided tours are also available.The only downfall of my visit was the no photography permitted. I understand this is a place of worship, but it is also an infamous icon within London. I believe the high fee of entry should enable the use of cameras. Overall:I doubt my review could caption the beauty and grandeur of Westminster Abbey. It is definitely a must-see attraction with London, for the religious and non-religious.

Truly Glorious. ABBEY: Beautiful architecture and statues. Interesting history and tombs. TOUR: Lines can be long to purchase tour tickets. I paid a few extra pounds for a nice guide book (I think it is worth it). Tour is audio, every informative. Abbey can be crowded with tourists at times. On occasion, I had to wait to enter chapels, etc., because they are small and can only have 5 or 10 people in it at a time. Nice gift store. NOTE: Be sure the Abbey is open. I have been there twice when it was closed to private events.

Beautiful. A beautiful building with so much history within its walls- from being the resting place of Elizabeth 1 to being the scene of many Royal Weddings. The Abbey is seen on TV often so it was wonderful to step inside- and also to see the bits that are not shown. It was busy but people are well controlled, there are guides on hand and it still seems a peaceful place. The audio guide was very informative. We had afternoon tea which, although not cheap, was not overly expensive and very tasty.

Awe inspiring. Truly as stunningly beautiful as you can possibly imagine. Even my husband, with his questioning belief, was amazed and touched by the architecture and history within the Abbey. The grave of the unknown soldier brought tears to my eyes. Many of memorials that had birth days in the previous weeks had wreaths of remembrance from historical societies and/or military societies. So uplifting to see so many great and accomplished people that shaped our remembered so profoundly. Was confused about Darwin's inclusion. Didn't think a Church would ever be that broadminded especially in 1882!

Holy holy holy. Beautiful, beautiful! Get the audio guide as it explains all the highlights here. I love churches especially gothic and everything in this lovely building is a feast for your eyes. Tour every nook and cranny there are interesting facts and history galore. As we were looking at the place where the coronation seat is placed a choir of young men came in singing, perfection. I would never go to London without seeing this fantastic place, no matter the price. Pay and feel great that you are part of preserving this beautiful piece of history.

Worth the Wait. I finally made it to a tour of Westminster Abby on my third trip to London. What an amazing experience. This self guided audio tour through the halls of history is a must do. It is well done and easy follow but not for children. Absolutely gorgeous inside and out the Abbey is well worth the entrance fee. I would highly recommend this and hope to visit again on my next visit to London.

More impressive than I thought. Church was more impressive than I thought it would be. Yes, its very big, but also intricate and beautiful. Disapointed in 2 areas. First, church opened 15 minutes latter than advertised time and entry location was moved in the morning. Also, don't mind paying a decent fee to get in. But like so much of the UK price is simply too much. I hate to say it, but it really seems that much of Britain is over greedy compared to the rest of the world. Not sure why.

Top Site in London. Must see if you have the time in London. Spent hours walking around and enjoying the history. Self-guided audio tour does an excellent job explaining the history. The staff is friendly and very helpful.

Ridiculous price.. We did want to visit, however the admission fee for two senior citizens was £32 which we were disgusted with. This is after all a place of God. The sign did say that it was free to pray, however we decided that as they were not making us welcome we would not bother.
Really worth a look!. One of those classic 'must see' destinations in the world. Very expensive but there is a lot to see.

Lovely Sunday Service. I wanted to see the Abbey but didn't want to play the price to get in. I went to my first evening service last Sunday and now intend to keep going for the duration of my school year here in London. I'm not a very religious person but the Abbey, despite having so much history, was very welcoming to all and made everyone feel as though they've been coming for ages (despite the bag checks at the entrance). I dressed up but there were definitely tourists in jeans and sweatshirts (so don't be turned off if you didn't pack your "Sunday best"). It felt very powerful to be praying in such a place packed with history. It was also nice to contemplate while looking at the beautiful scenery that is Westminster Abbey!Look for the service schedule either on their website or on the info boards in front of the entrances

Go see this!. Amazing just amazing! Worth going to again! Take the audio tour for this and you need at least 3hrs to take it all in. There is so much history in this place. It's worth your time and money for sure. It's in our top 5 list of things to see in London.

Amazing!. I knew about the price but didn't matter to me. It's an amazing place of history. Amazing to see where royalty has been buried along with other people of significance. Almost didn't go because some said the price wasn't worth it, but glad I went. Well worth the price!

enjoy it!. How to get in for free?Come to worship! During the evensong everyone gets to join them for free. And it is really great.First, they tell you where to sit. Then you find a laminated piece of paper with all the instructions and prayers on it. During the ceremony you'll have to stand up and sit down a couple of times, but you do not kneel. You listen to the beautiful voices of the choir members. At the end you have a few minutes to meditate and think about anything you want: your life, your ups and downs, etc.For those who don't visit church very often it must be a relaxing and enjoying event. Moreover, the architecture is exceptional.

Great place of interesting history. We enjoyed visiting Westminster Abbey and seeing the historical significance. Allow at least 2 hours to explore. Recommend using the audio tour. No photos allowed inside the Abbey. Don't miss the outside portions of the Abbey on your tour.

Makes you proud to be British. On arrival we were quite shocked by the £18.00 entrance fee. But to be fair it is a tourist attraction and you are told that they receive no funding from the Government and thankfully it is money well spent. You get a great free audio guide voiced by Jeremy Irons which takes you around the entire abbey and to be able to see the graves of most of our monarchs is an incredible experience and the Coronation Chair is really impressive too.

great history but expensive to see. finally got a chance to see the inside of the abbey after all the times i walked past, and the inside was pretty impressive!! we were lucky that we went early as the queue was huge by the time we came out. the audio guide you get is great and retells the amazing history of the place. i really enjoyed seeing the history of the abbey and the famous graves.i was lucky that my work covered the entry for us as i think that nearly £60 for the three of us is too much, as good as it is i think it could be cheaper and i wouldn't have paid it myself.

Expensive. Really beautiful with lots of history. I do think it is expensive though and maybe reduced rate for British citizens as I know people who just won't pay to go in which is a shame. Apart from the price it's a must if into history .

Incredibly beautiful history. I took the self-guided recording tour so which was a convenient way to understand the highlights. I enjoyed it very much. I could write everything I saw and it wouldn't begin to describe my experience. The history is overwhelming. Just do it, you won't regret it!
Marvelous!. We took a tour with self-guided recordings so we don't miss a thing, we enjoyed every minute! it is truly a lesson of history and tradition! Recommend the visit!

1000 years of history in one place - take verger tour!. Westminster Abbey is truly a London gem, a worldwide gem in fact. It's hard to write a review, because there aren't many places that offer this depth of history. The graves and commemorations of kings and queens lie a stones throw from great writers, poets, musicians abc scientists. It truly is the story of Britain for the last 1000 years. The building is also stunning, maybe not as ornate or spectacular as some basilicas, but beautiful all the same. I would strongly advise the verger tour, it only costs £3 more than standard entry and for that you get a 90 minute guided tour and also a chance to see the shrine of Edward the Confessor which I don't believe is accessible to those not on the tour. I much prefer to be guided by a person than an audio guide and it isn't much extra to pay. You book a place by phoning the day before, groups are limited to 12, so you get a nice intimate experience. Which brings me to the cost and the reason I'm not giving 5 stars. I know the Abbey is self funding and I know London is an expensive city, but for me £18 entry is just a little too expensive. I actually went on my own as my husband wouldn't have a huge amount of interest in it and we felt it was too much money for him to just keep me company. If it were even a couple of pounds cheaper, that would be something. But even though it's expensive, it is worth it for any history buff. Definitely a must visit when in London.

Absolutely marvelous!. Such a wonderful tour of the Abbey with self-guided recordings (a little difficult at first to match up the recording with the section we were seeing, but I eventually matched them up). The Abbey was beautiful with such rich history and tradition. The cost of the entrance fee was definitely worth it!

The choral is just amazing!. The only time I was at the Abbey was for an Evensong, that takes place everyday at 5pm. That was simply one of the best experiences I've had in my life. The choral is amazing and was hard for not cry when I listened for the very first time.Good: you don't have to pay for attend the Evensong.Bad: is forbidden take pictures or film, as well as visit the other parts of the Abbey.Go, go, go! One of the best London experiences you may have.

Liked it more than Harry Potter Tour!!!. Well worth visiting. We spent longer here than at the Harry Potter Warner Bros Tour it was that good. Fascinating history. Excellent audio guide too. Give yourself plenty of time, we took 3 hours but still felt rushed to read everything because it was crowded.

What words can describe the magnificence?!!. It took several hours to tour this breathtaking structure so rich in history, art and honor then by evening I returned to attend a Catholic Mass and hear the Westminster Choir sing - such a beautiful it brought tears to my eyes!

Amazing British History. I have visited the Abbey at least a half dozen times and I never tire of it. I always take the verger tour. For £3 you get 1 1/2 hours of history and information and anecdotes. Plus you get to visit the shrine of Edward the Confessor -- something off limits to the public. The Cellarium Cafe has lovely food. The gardens and cloisters are beautiful. They even have summer concerts in the gardens. I can't say enough good things about this place. A must see in London!!!
Well worth the visit. An amazing building with a lot of well known people buried here. Highly suggested that you take the audio tour which is included within the admission price.

Westminster Abbey is a Must see!!. Take your time when visiting. Look everywhere, read everything. It is full of history and if you paid attention in history class you will recognize plenty of people resting here. Enjoy this one, I did.

Loved the History. Having been to London multiple times and shied away from visiting Westminster cathedral based on the price of entry, I decided to bite the bullet and do it this time, and I did not regret it. I really really enjoyed it. I understand it may not be for everyone, but I am really interested in the history of the English monarchy, so I found it really pretty fascinating. The Lady Chapel was a highlight for me, just breathtaking the intricate work put in to the ceiling!

Historical gem. Whilst a little on the expensive side entry includes a audio tour and map. The cathedral is smaller than expected (St Pauls and Lincoln are superior as buildings) but the monuments and hostory are fantastic. Recommended

Great attraction - especially the audio tour. Really enjoyed going round the Abbey for the first time in 25 years. The audio tour read by Jeremy Irons is excellent and full of details that make the history of the Abbey come alive.

A MUST!. Ok, lots of comments on cost, but if you are a seeing several sights get a London Pass as that will make the sites more affordable. Second, do not pay for a commercial tour of this site. Go to the Abbey and take a tour by one of the vicars (I might have thier title wrong, but it was something like a pastor). My recollection is that they are offered twice a day they are fantastic. This is a marvel of history and architecture not to be missed. Enjoy!

Excellent.. As a Londoner it was quite shameful I had never visited. The Abbey is an amazing place for British History with numerous sites of interest that are worth the entry price. Despite not being allowed to take photos the place will stay in your mind. Thoroughly recommend going if you are a tourist.
Worth the price. This is pricey but well worth the price- you can't visit London and not go here. So much history and quite beautiful!

Probably a bit too expensive. Having been to quite a lot of London's major attractions on previous visits we decided to visit Westminster Abbey this time. The detail of the building & interior itself is something you have to see for yourself, amazing. You get an audio guide to help you know what's what when you're walking round plus there are Abbey guides there too although I got the feeling they were just there to make sure you don't take any photos!! I'm glad we went & have ticked it off the list but feel that £18 was a bit on the steep side, £10 would be more appropriate I feel. If you like history though there is plenty of it here.

BEAUTIFUL! Just gorgeous!. This was my second time visiting Westminster Abbey and this time was SO MUCH BETTER! For one, my husband was with me, but we also used the audio devices and really listened to what we were looking at. It made everything more meaningful. The history in this place is just mind-blowing. I'm obsessed with everything Royal, so I enjoyed walking through and remembering where Will and Kate were during the Royal Wedding. They were setting up for Christmas services, so there was lots of BBC equipment everywhere, but that was fine, we still enjoyed our visit!

A way to avoid the overpriced ticket: choir. If you don't wanna spend 18 pounds to visit the Westminster Abbey, just check what time the choir take place and go. Not only you will see the Abbey from the inside without paying, but also you will have a delightful experience listening to the choir. Try to arrive earlier than the actual scheduled time, so you can be at really good seat to admire it.

Expensive!. 18 pounds per person. But I wanted to see it - see the graves of Elizabeth I and Dickens and Chaucer and CS Lewis and Mary, Queen of Scots and Mary II. Just to be in a place so steeped in history was amazing. But I feel for anyone trying to see London on a budget.

Thoroughly enjoyed as a family. We visited as a family (2 girls aged 10 and 7) recently and we were thoroughly entranced. The children were given a question and answer sheet, clipboard and pencil with a promise of a chocolate surprise at the end. This kept them busy and also enriched our experience as well. I have to say the volunteers and Abbey officials were magnificent they gave us much information and help along the way. There is also a free audio tour for the grown ups and this gives lots of information as well. Just so much history everywhere you look. We spent about 3 hours in the Abbey altogether. I found it fascinating to realise all of the famous people that are buried within.Do not miss it.

Impressive and humbling monument. Westminster Abbey is one of the most magnificent monuments. The architecture is amazing a testament to the gothic masters. Each niche is more spectacular than the next. The tombs are beautiful, soulful, fascinating. The organ is sonorous and awe inspiring. Every famous author, poet, playwright and person of importance in British arts is entombed and/or memorialized .A really remarkable and informative place to give one a feel for the traditions of historic England.

Extremely interesting London landmark !. What a fantastic place to visit. If you are in London -Westminster Abbey is a must see. It is a beautiful place and there is so much history. The audio tour brings it all to life and explains the main features of the Abbey. It is overwhelming the architecture and the amount of history that lies within the Abbey. It is a little on the expensive side, however, you can easily lose 3 hours on a visit there. It also has a very good cafe for just a drink or a full meal-perfect to give your feet a rest after or during your tour of the Abbey!

BEAUTIFUL ABBY. One of the most beautiful churches I have visited. Very moving experience. Waited in line in the rain for an hour. Had a London pass and still had to wait in line. Worth the wait in the cold rain.

Breathtaking and Interesting. I was fascinated by this church. The architecture is indescribable. You can feel the history within its walls. The many bodies that lie below its floors of people who hold a place in history either as being famous or infamous. The many alcoves that are places of prayer and memorial add to the spirituality of this church.

Beautiful architecture. Enjoyed seeing the Queen's celebration of 60 years.. We were unable to tour the Abbey due to the Queen's celebration of 60 years of her coronation. We did get to see the guests leave from the church. The grounds are beautiful. I would definitely go back the next time we visit London. A must see for everyone.

Unbelievable beauty and history. Definitely a must see in London. Entry is a bit steep (£18) each but the free audio guide was extremely informative and it was nice to be able to progress through at your own pace. No photos allowed but postcards available in the shop. Plus it was better to concentrate fully on what was there rather than focussing on taking photos. Overall, an amazing experience.

Historical, overwhelming, choir amazing..... Again, not to be missed... we did Parliament tour and then Westminster Abbey and went back an different day for St James park and Churchill War Rooms.. so much history in this amazing city....

Beautiful and historically fascinating. I visited Westminster Abbey when I was in London 20 years ago and again this time. Each time, I found the church itself quite beautiful. The really amazing thing there, however, is the history - all of the figures buried there and all of the history that happened there. It is one of my favorite sites in London.

Westminster Abbey Verger Tour. I can't imagine visiting Westminster Abbey without doing the Verger Tour. The extra 3 GBP cost is minimal but you get to see and hear about things not available elsewhere. This was a highlight for us on our recent visit to London.
Beautiful. The best experience is to attend a service. There's a service called EVENSONG, the entire service was song by their choir that sits with you. Amazing

Very Helpful Staff. I am a wheelchair user and I visited Westminster Abbey on Saturday.
