The staff at the Abbey were excellent from the security man at the front door who opened the cordon rope for me and opened the main doors to make it easy for me to enter to the lady on the admissions desk who did not charge me for my entry nor did she charge my partner. The Abbey is a fantastic spiritual place and is truly beautiful it blows your mind to think how the craftsmen who built the abbey with primitive tools could produce such a lasting and wonderful place. The Abbey guilds are very approachable and helped me a great deal during my visit. As a wheelchair user the Abbey posed no problem at all and would recommend a visit, you will not regret it.

England history shines here. Whe you are visiting abbey, you feel almost as the time stopped here. The interiors, relics, tombs, artifacts give you a feeling of full submersion in to the times of Englands glorious past. It is one of not too many places on the face of earth where you almost feel as if some ancient king or warrior would just come by you from the nearest column. Incredible, beautiful and very dramatic place.The coronation chair is simply... ohhhhh....Aside of this... Yes, you will have to deal with dreadful ( just like in all UK ) staff selling entrance tickets, embarracing you with their rude behaviour of primadonnas bored by stupid visitors, as well as with insane entrance fees. It is just to spice your visit and make you feel robbed , LOL. Also, just like in many other places you won't be able to take a pictures. Common, what would happen to the stone interiors of the abbey or the tombs if I take a picture of them ? Are they going to collapse or what ?

Amazingly beautiful and spiritual visit. Just the thought of the 1000 years of worship on this spot is amazing, then the beautiful architecture and sculptures, then the famous poets corner, etc... My daughter and I had the privilege of attending a worship service. We were seated in the side chairs and the service was lovely (identical to an Episcopalian service in the states). Afterward, we walked slowly out, viewing the fact that CSLewis' memorial had been right behind us where we sat. FUN to think we went to church with CSLewis, in a way. :-) We then had brunch in the little cafe...and that was delicious. The shop had lovely items. You cannot tour the church on Sunday, but any Christian would enjoy attending a worship service there, and if you walk out slowly, you see much. :-)

A great way to learn Engish history. Well worth the 18 L entry fee, which gives you the right to an audiovisual device that guides you through the abbey at your own pace. My 18 old son and I went there at 3 pm on a friday (last entry is 3 30pm) so we were also spared the usual large crowds.

Incredible History. This is another London attraction that deserves at least half-a-day, if not a whole day, to explore, visit, and admire.While the audioguide was at times a tad brief, and could have provided greater color and depth, it is still a must-have if you are to see, hear, and understand everything that is going on. It really is a place that should be experienced, and the history and significance of this Abbey cannot be surpassed - only Winchester Cathedral or St. Paul's Cathedral could match what this place offers.

Self paced. The audio tour gives a excellent overview if the Abbey, no photos are allowed. Some parts of it tend to close early (we did visit in the winter), so it is good to check what these are as we were disappointed not to be able to see parts of the Abbey

Come early - and visit this place!. One of the best sites we saw on a recent trip to London. Well worth the short wait in line, but do know that it closes earlier than you would think.You are not allowed to take pictures, so be sure to come when you are ready to take in some amazing architecture and history. The audio guide is quite helpful and allows you to really learn more about some of the items in the Abbey.Spend about 1 hour here walking around and touring the grounds - its definitely worth it and a respite from the noisy attractions across the river.

Airy hallways, beautiful interior, amazing choir. I loved the church service I attended here- it was just by chance I'm not religious at all but I highly recommend staying for the singing and to be in this church where so many important events have taken place. Beautiful.

Do visit the Abbey museum. All that can be said, has been said about this glorious church. We paid extra for a tour ,only three pounds, which gave us entry to the Confessor's chapel. Do visit the Abbey museum, it won't take too long and gives a different perspective to funeral practices

Get there early. This closes early, so plan to get there early if you want to get in. The first time we went it was already closed by 3pm. It closes even earlier some days. No pictures allowed inside.

Well worth the time and money for the tour. This was not really planned to do more than walk inside but we chose to take the tour...Its self paced with a free audio guide with price of tour. Took us maybe hour and half two hours max and we were really in no hurry so could be done quicker if one chooses. Lots of kings and queens buried in the church as well as some very famous literary writers and poets. The facility is beautiful if all you wanted to see was the splendor of the church or take in the fact of the recent Royal Wedding and how all that took place, a small museum off to the side with some artifacts and wardrobes worn by late king and queens as well as of course a gift shop. They do have a "tea room" cafe with bites to eat, we did not take the time to experience that, so can't really comment on that, but the tour was worth the small fee they charged (sorry can't remember price) around 16 pounds maybe. But felt like it was an enjoyable experience. Take in as much as you can or buy a postcard or picture book of the inside, picture taking inside the church is prohibited. They are very stricked about it and workers are everywhere even when you try to sneak a picture you will get caught everytime...I did anyway even when trying to be discreet about it.

First tourist attraction I'd ever visited. Many years ago, possibly 2009 I visited Westminster Abbey. I was completely blown away by the size of it. I purchased many postcards to keep the memories alive as no photographs are to be taken.
Simply Amazing!. With Big ben, Westminster abbey and London Eye just there, makes it an amazing place to visit. It is mesmerising.
The best so far. For the first time I had really hard time for not being allowed to take any pictures. The abbey is breathtaking, amazing and worth the visit. Take your time.

Medieval Pavement Fit for a King. I recommend a beeline over to the the Muniments Room to view the stunning geometric pavement. Cosmati work is a form of precisely cut inlay stonework, named for a Roman family of skilled artisans. The main design theme is four-around-one, known as a 'quincunx', and is one of the quintessential designs of Cosmatesque work. (Think floors at St. Marks in Venice) It has a mysterious history, and thirty-eight kings and queens have been crowned upon it. Prince William and Catherine's wedding also took place here. You can't walk on the pavement, but do stand up close, stay for more than passing glance to really take in all the colours and intricacy. It was recently restored by the Getty Foundation. Worth a visit!

Walk in the Footsteps of History. Westminster Abbey is a MUST see. Stand above the final resting places of some of the most important people in history: Charles Darwin, Geoffrey Chaucer, and Charles Dickens to name a few. Gaze at the Monument to Sir Isaac Newton (as seen in the movie ‘The Da Vinci Code’). View the location in which Kings and Queens have been crowned since the 1200’s, or where Prince William married Catherine Middleton.The importance and history of the Abbey can overwhelm you. Take your time walking thru the Abbey using the free Audio-guides. The only downside, no photography allowed.

Westminster Abbey. This church is so beautiful! I was in such awe of this place and the history that goes with it. There are a lot of royals and nobles buried here. Among those that are buried are Sir Issac Newton, Charles Dickens, and Charles Darwin. It was truly amazing to walk down the isle that Kate Middleton walked down on her wedding day!! To enter the abbey it costs about 18 pounds and they provide an audio tour to listen along while you walk. I was a little heart broken that they don't allow pictures inside. Overall, I was very impressed and happy to have had this experience!!

Breathtaking!. It's really a vision to take in Big Ben and West Minster Abbey from South Bank in London and slowly make your way over the bridge towards it, it becomes a vision and makes for some great photos. Westminster Abbey was beautiful and if your a Royal Wedding fan make sure to take in the RW plaque out the front!

Pure Magnificence!. We have been 2-3 times a year to visit London and each time try and do some place of interest...this one outshines so many. Yes, It's expensive c£17 a head but worth every penny. You are given very comprehensive audio kits and these have the capacity to expand with even more information should you want by pressing the appropriate buttons/very easy to use.There was no sense of urgency to hurry round and there was an atmosphere of Splendour and Magnificence, awe and beauty and a deeply religous building complete with profound history.This place will appeal to everyone, the world over.

Beautiful Church. An amazing building and provides many, many great photo opportunities can be had from the outside given there is a park in front of the building, it will give you different angles to take photos from.
Felt like a royal wedding. Walking down the aisle gave me goose bumps. The old crypts are fascinating. So much history. Be sure to see the Coronation Chair on your way out.

Very impressive. The £18 entree fee is little high, but when you're a student you can get a discount of £3. Still, a little expensive but, when you're into history, architecture and religion well worth the price.The audio guide is included in the price (won't say free...) and in any language. In English you have Jeremy Irons who's informing you. Take your time, it's needed. There is so much to see!Only minus I found, it's a real pitty it's not allowed to take pictures. The people in green or red robes are friendly when they see people still trying to take a photo. The priests... they are kind of rude in the way of telling you this! And it's such a pity it's not allowed to take a photo! I'm studying history and saw so many things I'd like to take pictures of. Is it such a big no-no to take a picture? In the Vatican, any church you can take pictures, why not here?For the rest, well worth it !
seen with friends. Discovered things never knew. But as a British Tax payer why does it cost me same as a foreigner?? very expensive to get in but very well organised

One of London's (many) must see attractions. The Abbey is (of course) dripping with history. Worth spending two to three hours walking about. Many monarchs and other notable people interred there and the architecture is fabulous. This is my fourth visit - and I'll be back.

Grand yet personal, gothic, stunning.. Whether you are interested in religion, architecture, art, history, or all of the foregoing, this is a place of wonder. It is grand yet not overpowering; there are family chapels and areas dedicated to the great and good, poets' corner, royal burials, Winston Churchill is buried here. The vaulting of the ceiling is both a remarkable feat of engineering, but also delicately lace like and geometric. It is wonderful to see the use of fine marbles and gold and paints but equally fascinating to walk in the footsteps of our ancestors over well worn hollowed chapel door thresholds where millions have passed over generations, many of them very famous. Following the route of royal processions, be they weddings or funerals or the like, being able to stand within a couple of feet of a king or queen in their tomb, for example Elizabeth I, wow!Mustn't be missed.

History coming to life. Since retiring I decided to visit the attractions I never seemed to have time for when I was working. This was on my list to do. Visited on the 3rd January and the line to get in extended the length of St Margerets church and beyond. Lucky there was a gap in the rain. However the line moved quickly separating at the entrance if you were paying cash or card. £15 to get in , concession rate. OK for one person , but would soon mount up for couples or families. Once inside, it's packed with people, I would worry if I had a young child with me. Saying that, if you have any interest in the history of this country everything is there to see. Just about everyone you have ever read or heard about is there at your fingertips. The carvings on the headstones are magnificent and touching,look for the one to a Mrs Livingstone from her husband. He is shown preparing to fight off the grim reaper coming for his wife, very dramatic. I was there over 3 hours and I'm sure only touched the surface of this magnificent building and it's contents. One minor point, it is a working Church with services at regular intervals. When you are asked to respect this by standing still for a moment please do it.

a place full of history. we were lucky and did not stayed in line: it was december and quite late in the afternoon. The place is amazing. The building itself is beautifull anywhere you look. We were lucky also to catch a choire rehersal wich was fantastic. The bad part, for me, was after some points is was just too much history and could not follow the audioguide anymore.

Another London Must See- but not 5 stars. Westminster Abby is Westminster Abby. There are 18 English monarchs buried there so.....you gotta go. Did I mention Chaucer, Dickens, and Tennyson all there too. It is beautiful and immaculate and wonderful....from the outside. The inside is slightly more expensive than I would have liked and VERY VERY VERY busy. People everywhere squeezing into each nook and cranny you can find. I hate that over the centuries people have rubbed their hands on everything and have worn down treasures made of wood and stone. Also don't think that you will find a quiet place to sit and reflect. It doesn't exist in Westminster Abby. Not so much a complaint but just something to know, it seems like everyone and their mom is buried there. Plumber for the Abby in the 1600s, sure, you get a plaque. One last thing, make sure you are in the correct line. There is a cash only line and a credit card line. Both will be long. Be sure to visit all the gift shops. The best gifts I brought home from England came from the Abby. Unique glass jewelry and such. Now please dont think that I hated Westminster Abby. It is beautiful. I love that you cannot take photos because it keeps people moving AND it means that unlike Paris, you just have to remember this one, your mind is your only photograph. It is grand. It is tall. It is perfect. It is England. It is the Abby. Just go and realize that the lines will be long and that you will get bumped into.

Fascinating. The magnificence of the abbey cannot be captured in words or by pictures. Has to be seen to be understood. The marshals around the abbey are also very helpful and friendly in answering any questions you may have.

The line to get in was way, way, way long!. I can remember when you could just walk into the abbey and wander around. When we went in 2010 we were surprised at the charge to get in...and it was pretty hefty, we had never had to pay before. Guess we were spoiled by the previously facinating freeby that it once was. This time, the line went halfway around the building. I gave this five stars because it is, afterall, Westminster...but to tell you the truth, we were scared away by the line of people and the time it would take. Went to the Globe Theatre instead. If you don't mind standing in line for a couple of hours, it will be well worth your trouble. Also, didn't mention, it was way more crowded inside on our 2010 trip, more so than ever before! Hard to get back into some of the small places, plan to stand in other lines once inside. I also think it would be well-worth studying the significance of what you will see at Westminster before you stand in line. May not be worth it if you don't know the importance of what is there. It is not like a museum with a lot of explainations...but I do seem to remember an audio tour.

Awe inspiring. Museums are free in England, but there is a charge for churches. Although discount for a family of four is nice. Great, free self guided audio tour that thoroughly explained everything you were looking at. Be mindful that last entry is at 3:30. Give yourself an hour for the tour. Worth the trip to experience a part of history, the tombs are fascinating, the architecture is inspiring, and late in the day the choir was practicing so that was special.
It worth a visit, for sure!. The Westminster Abbey is the history itself! The visual is wonderful both inside and outside. It's crowded at any time, so be patient.(visited July/2012)

Great if You Like Famous Dead People. Westminster Abbey is always high on the list of things to see while in London. There were two lines just to get in based on how you paid (one line for cash, the other for credit) so make sure you check before standing in line. There is a party store on the corner with snacks so if you missed breakfast or are generally trying to get a head start on the day, stop in there, get a snack and eat it while in line (personal note, getting some spare batteries for your camera would seem like a good idea at first but there is no photography on the inside so don't stress it). Many major events in recent British history have taken place inside but the attraction for me were all the graves, crypts, and memorials to some very famous deceased individuals. It is hallowed ground and tough to imagine that so many tourists step on Isaac Newton's grave every single day. The audio tour is helpful as it does point you to some famous people and places you might otherwise walk past. It will be crowded but is most crowded in areas emphasized on the audio tour so if you don't like the crowds, you might want to walk past the crowd and listen off to the side.Overall, I'd recommend visiting the British Museum and the Tower of London before coming here but if you can get past the crowds (or perhaps around them) and the entrance fee (not cheap, that's for sure), you'll enjoy seeing some pretty famous names and knowing that their remains are closer to you than ever before.

Worth while visiting.. First time we visited the church,a lot of veterans prayed.That was a day for victims of World War 2.The next day we visited again.This time we could enter the church.It was true that the fee was expensive,but once you enter,you will forget the fee,I bet.Magnificent sculptures,a lot of famous kings' tombs,majestic atomosphere;all these will make you feel sacred kings' spirits living there!When you visit London,you cannot avoid visiting this church.I strongly reccommend you to pay a visit,even though you are German or French.

A must see sight. We never visited Westminster Abbey when we lived in London for over 10 years but recently went on trip back from Sydney. It is one of the most amazing places to visit in London with a huge amount of history packed in.

A special place in the Heart of London. This was my third visit to the Abbey - I paid to go in and walk around as well as attending an Easter Day service during the same trip to London. I love the history of the building and it's fascinating to see the tombs of so many famous people. I would happily pay to go back on each trip to London.

Too busy on inside but lovely on outside. I stood in quite a queue to get in there . This is just my opinion but the abbey inside was too busy in terms of tombs etc.I do understand that this is important church in London and many people do get buried here.I loved the outside though
A little disappointing. In person, there was nothing special about the Abbey. The building across the road near Big Ben was more impressive! Still I was glad I got to see it and take a photo of it.

Favorite London Attraction. Westminster Abbey is full of history! The Abbey itself is visually stunning, but the history inside is what drew me in. The Abbey is amazing, and I could have stayed all day. So many weddings, coronations, and funerals have taken place here throughout the last few centuries, yes, centuries. Seeing the Royal Coronation Chair was pretty special, as was learning that Darwin, Jane Austen, Bronte Sisters, Chaucer, Dickens, and Isaac Newton, were all interred here. My most favorite place in all of London.

worth the visit inside. If you have the London Pass, admission is included, otherwise it is worth a visit inside here even though the admission is expensive. It is a self-guided audio visit that guides you along. Lot of history inside here as tombs of famous historical people are buried here. You need to take a moment and stop at the center of the abbey to admire the gigantic size of this abbey and the familiar scenes of events that have taken place here- the last one being Prince William and Kate Middleton's wedding in April 2011. Before leaving the Abbey on your left, check out the Coronation Chair behind the display glass enclosure. If you have time, do come back on an evening (except. Wed.) when there is an Evensong scheduled at 5p.m. for an hour. Admission is free. You may enjoy listening to the choiristes sing and the ambience of the surroundings and acoustics in the abbey. It is 1st come, 1st served but there are plenty of chairs. You may leave as you wish before the end of the program as long as it is not disruptive. Nice experience to hear the singing.

Beautiful. Toured the Abbey recently while in London. There is an admission fee and included in that is the audio tour. I recommend using this since it gives you all kind of information while looking around. It took us about an hour but you could easily stay longer. It's fascinating to be inside knowing some of it's history. We really enjoyed it!
Serene and historical. The chapel, the chance to pay homage of fav scientists and writers like Darwin, brontes, and more. The memorial flags for martyrs outside was sweet.

Check out the Evening Service!. On our first night in London, we went to check out the evening service at Westminster Abbey. It’s a great way to see the inside of the church without paying the outrageous tourist fee. Services occur daily at 5PM and last for less than an hour. You need to go to the other entrance (not the main tourist one) and let the guards know that you would like to attend the service. You are provided with a program and then ushered into the sanctuary. It turned out that there was no choir for the service – apparently they only have a choir on certain days of the week. Regardless, the service was very nice. Neither my husband nor I are Anglican, but the program was very clear and walked you through the service (including when to sit and stand) in detail. We will definitely be back (preferably for Evensong) on our next trip to London!

Beautiful and impressive. We went to Westminster Abbey two times on a recent visit to London. For one, we toured the Abbey. The audio tour makes the experience much better....definitely worth doing. Our youngest child did a chilld activity and loved it (he got a big chocolate coin at the end). There is so much to see here. Make sure that you leave enough time to see everything. We also went to Christmas sung mass here. It was really lovely and the boys choir was amazing.

Breathtaking. Stepping into the Abbey immediately takes you back in time and on an extensive tour of history. It is a good idea to use the audio tour; easy to use and multilingual. Take your time and enjoy the architecture and revel in the history. Truly an incredible place to see.

Burial places of Great Kings and Queens. I was quite surprised that there were so many of the Monarchy buried here! I knew it was a great Cathedral, but did not know of the tombs within the walls. It is such a beautiful place with so much history as well. Seeing the original parts of the Cathedral was such an experience! The self-guided tour allows you to take as much time as you need to experience the grandeur and the history. Absolutely lovely!

Historic England at its finest. After the half hour queue we stepped right into the historical abbey. Reasonably priced and provided with an insightful audio guide included in the price. Makes you want to get into the history books and read up more on our heritage.

Somewhat disappointed. Yes, it is beautiful (although not as much as St. Paul's) and yes, it does have quite a historic pedigree. My issue is it felt more like a museum to me than an actual cathedral. Otherwise it was good to see the place where so many historic English (both royal and non-royal) were buried.

Full of history and presence of great minds of England. The audio tour was very informative and interesting. W.Abbey houses the tombs as well as monuments of many important figures in the world (Newton, Darwins, Shakespears, Q. Elizabeth I, King(s) Edward etc). The church structure is beautiful with mosaic ceiling and highly decorative chapel.The only minus is the steep pricing of 18 GBP per person. But like St Paul, the audio comes for free.

Breathtaking, please don't miss this!!. Westminster Abbey will forever be in my heart as the most beautiful place I've ever been to; it's absolutely breathtaking and deserves to be way higher on the attraction list than in the 40s. I'm also a history lover which explains why I loved this place so much as well. It's absolutely amazing, you get to see where some of the most amazing people in history are buried from Queen Elizabeth I to Jane Austen, the list goes on and on. It's like a church mixed with a museum.. You get to see the church components in all their beauty as well as many historical artifacts dating back 1000 years such as the royal throne that almost every monarch in English history has been crowned on. You can learn about the coronation process, view clothing from the time period, the whole thing is just amazing and definitely worth the money. The only downside is that you can't take pictures inside but still well worth it. Please go!!

deep in history. we had a hire car, parking was very expensive i guess you would expect
that in the area, enjoyed hyde park ,and winter wonderland

Very beautiful and a must see attraction.. Next to Big Ben is this historical place which you should definately visit. We were lucky enough to attend a Christmas choir.
Be aware, no photos allowed inside the Abbey but outside you can take as many as you want! There is also a souvenir shop outside the Abbey. Tube stations are close to the area.

Christmas Day Service. We went for the Christmas morning service this year for the first time and it was wonderful. Though it is televised, I wouldn't have missed seeing it in real life for anything. A lovely service in a grand building, with a beautiful choir.

Such history. Be prepared to spend at least a couple of hours . Unfortunates, no photos. Just amazing how many are buried there. I won't tell you why, but be ready for a surprise when you see the Royal Throne on which English rulers have been crowned since 1066. Best to visit in the fall to avoid the really huge crowds of summer. The actual chapel is smaller than it appears on TV. The visit is a little pricey, but worth it and try to get the tickets online if available to save time in line. A must see.
Must see. Place this at the top of your list. Words will never do it justice. Lots of tourists, but you're supplied with a self-guide recorder that allows you to go through at your own pace.

A Must See. Every one who visits London must go and see this church. The church is incredible and let's not forget the history behind it. One gets to appreciate this fantastic church the more you walk around. The only surprising fact for me was that the church is smaller than what it was made to see during Kate's and William's wedding. But overall, must see!

Pricey but worth it... When I first saw the entrance fee (17 pounds) I was a little put off but shelled out the money and went in anyway. It was well worth it as the Abbey is a true beauty! Photographs are not allowed inside but I think that allows you to soak up the surrounds uninterrupted. Audio tours are available in multiple languages and are filled with useful information. If you love amazing architecture and european history, this is for you!

Westminster Abbey. So much history! We were lucky enough to have a friend who works here to give us a private touring, but the public tours look fantastic, as well. Ironically, Darwin's tomb held my interest the most.

Crowning glory.... This building, close to the Houses of Parliament, is one of the most important in the UK. Site of coronations (that of HM The Queen took place here in 1953), it is the final resting place of umpteen former Monarchs. It has also been the setting for countless royal weddings, funerals and the greatest national ceremonies. The architecture is stunning, especially bearing in mind that it dates from the thirteenth century and there is superb statuary, stained glass and innumerable treasures to please the eye.

Disappointing for its services . Great place to look at but disappointing. Why? The service is horrible for the shops and dinning area. As a tourist who has been to many places around the world, I feel greatly disappointed. If is expensive and the service is rude. I feel that there is no need to pay. I get the fact that there should be renovation and stuff like that. However the government should do the funding. Ehh!! Would not come back again.

Do NOT miss this. We love history and this Abbey is loaded with it. I can't add much to all the rave reviews BUT.... You might time your visit around 3 PM on a day when they conduct the Evensong service. You can confirm on their website. Get the audio guide and visit the amazing displays. Make sure to spend most time in the side altars behind the main one. This is where the most interesting stuff is, so don't get too caught up in the front areas. Then Evensong starts at 5 and the lineup begins around 4:30. The Boys Choir adds an awesome element to this wonderful experience. It's about a 50 minute ceremony and worth it.

A travel in history. A great place to visit. You can see centuries of human history there where some of the prominent persons of england (and human) history were buried as Sir Isaac Newton, Shakespeare and Darwin. Where most of Kings and Queens were crowned. The visit is self audio guided (included in price) in different languages (portuguese too). There are plenty places to rest during the visit and bar to eat and drink.

Lots to see. . This place is amazing. We did the self paced tours with a friend and her family (including two children ages 7 and 10). The abbey provided scavenger hunt forms for the children, with the lure of a chocolate coin at the end. For us adults, we were given portable speakers and followed the tour around the abbey. There is so much to see. The architecture in and of itself is amazing, then the history, the monuments and everything else is just icing on the cake. My only suggestion: wear VERY comfortable shoes. Those tenth century floors aren't made for my delicate feet haha.

Walking through History.. The size, history, statues, paintings, marble. Shakespeare's grave, so many others. The final resting places of kings, queens. This is a place that speaks to you if you will take your time and read, listen, and observe. I would go back again. There is so much to see, three hours did not do it justice.

Westminster Abbey. Join the queue, pay the admission fee and prepare to be absolutely amazed! An audio tour is provided and the voice of Jeremy Irons guides you through this wonderful experience. A great audio guide as it explains each point of interest in a documented and factual way rather than other audio guides do in that pantomine type way. Historic, beautiful and a "must see" on your visit to London. I agree with another reviewer that if you revisited Westminter Abbey several timesyou would still find and amazing things to see and learn. Excellent. Highly recommended

Love this church. Myself and my partner have been to the Abbey several times, each time we go we always manage to see something different, we love the architecture and the history of this church and the tombs of kings & queens past. Def worth the visit.

History plus ..... This place is utterly breath taking at certain points in the day from at outside and at certain points throughout the tour inside. It cost 18 pound to enter and an audio guide is provided. I was fortunate that there were few people around at 2pm just before Christmas. At some points in the tour it could get tight when crowded.For me the audio guide was too superficial but that might just be my special interest in history.The staff interactions were mixed. A few are downright snooty and cranky (long day perhaps) however most were polite and helpful. On this occasion the choir for Evensong was indescribable to listen too when sitting in the Quire. You need to be in the front of the line for this seating privilege. It is worth waiting for the experience of this. Do ask staff about where to wait in line. We just remained in there at the end of our visit but otherwise be outiside the church at 4.30 or a bit before if you can for the best seating.(check the time for Evensong I think it is 3pm on a Saturday). Whilst most things do have a routine this is sometimes altered for special purposes.Remember you cannot take photos but if you have a relative buried there they not only tell you where they are but will allow a supervised photograph as long as you ask the person in the red cape/cloak (sorry I am sure this has a special name). Do try and give yourself enough time for this experience.

if you're christian go to a church service there. we went to a Sunday 11:15am sung Eucharist service. there are four services daily, they are free. there was a lovely presence of God, the sense of history is awesome reading the names of the statues/tombs/plaques and the choir voices fill the 5 storey space

My favorite place in London. The history and beauty of Westminster Abbey cannot be over-stated. The self-guided audio tour is easy to use and very interesting/informative. Given the amazing artifacts and artwork it contains, the abbey remains remarkably accessible and really lets you experience the sweep of history and royalty on a more personal level. Not to be missed in London!

Worth a Visit. We went here because we could not get onto a tour of Parliament, but we were glad we did. It's full of history (of course) and the audio tour and map given out on entry makes it far more than just a walk around a big church ! Having watched 'The White Queen' on TV some of the tombs names were instantly recognisable and the story behind them. Yes it cost to get in but doesn't everything these days ? The only disappointment is that you are not allowed to take photos, other than that it was a very interesting couple of hours.

Fascinating History of our Country. I had never been to the Abbey before. I spent 3 hourse there and did the guided tour. It is a capsule of the great history of our country covering Royalty Science Literature and Church Architecture. Engrossing and absorbing. Why did I wait so long to visit? So glad to have been there at last. Well worth the entrance fee.
Stunning. If you're religious you should pay and take a look inside the church! But leave some money to buy souvenirs in their shop, It´s more expensive but there is beautiful magnets!

Very interesting. It looked loads smaller than on telly but was so beautiful inside. Quite expensive to get in £18 i.e. Lincoln Cathedral is a donation of £3 but was really pleased as if you took your time there is lots to look at. Nice follow on from Houses of Parliament.

Breathtaking. Beautiful all round, lived up to expectations. To stand by the tombs of our great kings and queens is just mind blowing, couldn't quite believe it. Architecture is absolutely out of this world and really a great sight to behold. Highly recommended.

Sadly lacking in Christian spirit. this week I was in London and I attended the evening prayers in WESTMINSTER ABBEY, we were sheaparded through into the seats (that were roped off and segregated as if we were the visiting side in a difficult derby football match) on at least 3 occasions we were asked if we had a ticket. I felt uncomfortable and not welcome in a Christian place of worship and pilgrimage that has been accessible for over a thousand years. At the end of the service (which was not performed with a Chior; and this appears to be the norm for about 50% of the time). I asked to use the toilets and was told no; if I did not have a ticket (£18 per adult ) it was suggest that I go to the local conference centre or the local pub (both of which are aware and do not welcome such suggestions). During the service there were tourists making noise around the edges of the roped enclosure. No attempt was made to address this by the lay clarks who appear to be no more than cassocked security. I wonder if Christ would be welcome in this building as the spirit of Christmas and the holy spirit is sadly lacking. I'm sure the money lenders of the city would be more welcome than the homeless, needy and naked of the streets of london. I understand the requirement to pay for the upkeep but if the original reason for the building is just paid lip service to they would be better handing the keys over to the NT and stop kidding themself that it is a place of pilgrimage or worship.
walk by and wave :P. we passed by this place at night so it was closed but its a real eye candy to see at night . worth a visit if you are in the area

Definitely worth a visit. Inside Westminster Abbey is fascinating! There is so much history and being there was really special. No photos are allowed but the audio guide kept me occupied as it is very thorough. A memorable experience, a must visit when you're in London!
Service. Go and check out a service at this church, make sure the choir is singing, it will blow you away you'll walk out with chills

special seasonal service. attended Evensong and were transported to a place of peace, serenity adn love. We were invited to attend as the evenign fell and the ights went on. about an hour long and free to all
beautiful. Loved this cathedral but a little disappointed we could not take photos, but I understand why. The audio information is thorough and the history is incredible.

Enjoyable Building. Westminster is a great place to visit. You can pay to tour the building, or come in free for one of the Abbey's services. There are audio tours available, and it makes a great little outing for the attractions in the area.

Must Do/Take a Tour!. Loved our time spent at Westminster Abbey. Would recommend doing one of the self-guided tours. Learned a lot about the building and all of the historic events that have taken place there. Also one of the best gift shops we found in the city...got many unique souvenirs.

amazing history and stood in awe. Everyone should visit this place of history. To stand by the tombs of our monarchy including Queen Elizabeth 1was incredible. The audio guide is excellent and provides enough detail and you have option of more detail if required.

A living Church with a millennium of history. Westminster Abbey is a great place to visit at any time of year. You may have to queue to get in and there is an admission fee which includes an audio guide in your preferred language. Staff are more than helpful and you can also experience worship at certain times.It is wonderful to see where the Kings and Queens of England lie at rest as well as all the other people who are buried there. You can see the Coronation Chair dating back to the time of William the Conqueror. The tour is taken at your own pace and therefore you can stop and savour the moment as well as appreciate the awe inspiring architecture. Plenty of toilets if the need arises.A great experience even if you've been before.
beautiful. The carved memorials and the tombs of famous people were marvellous. We spent a good couple of hours here

Beautiful Church, Lots of History. This is a beautiful church with lots of British history. Most notable are all of the people who are buried here, and those who were married and crowned here. You can't take pictures inside but you get a nice audio guide included with your admission fee.

Wonderful experience. Yes, you pay to enter but given the history of the pick pockets along with preserving the sanctity of the church, I am okay with no photos and the price of entry. The price of admission includes the audio and that was very nice to have available. We didn't find it over crowded but most places weren't as we were there over the week of US Thanksgiving. They have plenty of staff on hand to answer questions. There was a Wednesday service when we were present although we did not sit for it. I love the history so I found it wonderful.

A wonderful visit. We were in town to go to the theatre and walking from victoria over Westminster Bridge we had enough time to make an impromptu visit to the abbey. The staff were all very friendly and had a sense of humour. It was busy but you could go along at your own pace and never felt rushed. The free audio guide really helped to understand the history but there is so much to take in, we really need to go again. We had seen it so many times on tv but it was amazing to see it for real. I was blown away by just how many famous people are buried or remembered there, every where you looked there was another. The hourly prayer was very touching and it was special to be there for that.

Pricey Entrance - Crowded Church. Westminster Abbey is much more than just a church. In fact, it didn't even feel like a church at all, just another tourist attraction. After seeing many other beautiful, historic churches and cathederals in Germany and Rome, Westminster Abbey was very underwhelming for a number of reasons.First off, the cost. I understand that as a tourist attraction costs can run up. But this does not excuse the rather pricey entrance fee. The included audio guide is nice, but I would much rather have a smaller fee and the option of purchasing an audio guide, or better yet an actual person. Secondly, the crowds! We went in the "off season" in November, and it was still difficult to get around and see things due to crowding around the audio guide points. The church itself was very crowded feeling as well. There were so many memorials everywhere that, to me, it detracted from the church itself and made it feel messy.

Making it fun for kids!. I don't think I can add much to the other reviews in terms of the quality of the experience, so I wanted to post about how they make it interesting and fun for kids! If your kids are like mine, they burn out on touring sites pretty quickly. Westminster has figured out how to do it right! Upon entering we were greeted by a lovely gentleman who inquired if our kids would like to do the kids program.We said yes, as it was free of charge. They were given scavenger hunt sheets and pencils and were rewarded at the end (with chocolate) for playing. Again, if your kids are anything like mine, they were "all in" at the mention of a prize in the form of chocolate. The result? They lingered longer and listened to the audio for answers, something that is uncommon for a 5 and 8 year old to do. They learned and absorbed more of the history and significance of the church.The benefit, is that by making it a game, my husband and I got to linger longer too and made it more of an interactive whole family experience.If you are going with kids and want to have some fun, find someone in a green jacket and ask to play!

To get a Feel of this Place, Do the Evensong. An amazing church, but to catch the spiritual feel of the place, I recommend taking in the Evensong - taking in the accapella singing in the old building.
Be careful when you visit the place, it is often closed and there can be long lines - but it is worth it if you plan ahead.

Very beautiful and interesting. I visited here on a recent trip to London and this is an attraction to see. The church is very large and the architecture is beautiful. There is a great deal of history associated with this church. It is usually busy and you do need to check the schedule to see what times it will be open each day. They do have the audio guides you an use that tell more detail about areas of the church. They bury many Kings here along with some famous people like Charles Dickens, Charles Darwin ,etc.

Extraordinary display of who's who in uk history. Had been before many years ago and thought that we would give it another go.It is beautiful however not architecturally the most impressive or most imposing. What it certainly has above all pother cathedrals is an extraordinary number of the great and the good in Uk history from Edward the confessor upwards.We were offered the family ticket which effectively meant our son was free.Did not try the cafe looked a bit small but the shops had a good selection of all sorts.You do have to queue to get in but the queue on a saturday morning was only around 15 minutes or so.
Quite amazing. Visited in late November when it wasn't very busy. Very beautiful abbey, rich in architecture & history.I loved it, my 17 year old daughter also enjoyed it, my 15 year old son less so.

A Breathtaking Experience!. 50 of us from our village church attended Westminster Abbey on an autumn evening for a 'Parish Prayer Pilgrimage'. We were welcomedt by Canon Jane at the grave of the Unknown Warrior, then proceeded down The Nave and were shown the Screen, the Quire (where the choir sit), the High Altar, the Shrine of St Edward the Confessor (not always open to the public), the Lady Chapel (with it's magnificent ceiling), Poets' Corner, and culminating in St Faith's Chapel. At each point there was a detailed explanation of the point of interest and appropriate prayers were said. In St Faith's Chapel we took part in a candle lit Compline service which was very moving. We left the Abbey via the Cloisters and were greeted by a cool London night filled with a warm feeling of having been somewhere special..

Expensive but worth the money. My personal opinion was that £16 was more than acceptable for what was simply a stunning visual experience rich in history, and if this is what you are into they I would say you will share the same opinion. We visited on a Saturday and although very busy it did not sour the experience in any way. They have plenty of seats scattered around if you feel the need for a rest or to just simply admire your surroundings.My only gripe is the strict no photography rule which seemed to be Enforced with clergyman and guides running at you as though to subject you to a rugby tackle at any sign of a photo being taken, or even a camera with a lens cap off. Not really sure of why they have this rule other than to keep people moving, however at £16 each I feel this was a little unfair and unnecessary. You are forced to spend further money from the gift shop to take any lasting images away with you, this is the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars.

A Glamorous Anglican Cathedral. I was lucky that there weren't any long queues to be seen. I recently visited Westminster Abbey with my friend last July, 2013. The Houses of Parliament and Big Ben are simply gorgeous in both day & night and from every point of view. Westminster Palace is the seat of British government and includes the famous Clock Tower Big Ben. It dates from the 13th century, and holds the tombs of almost all kings and queens of England. Westminster Abbey is also used for coronations. Many of tourists take photos from the Westminster Bridge or the opposite bank of the Thames. If you are lucky enough to get inside then the level of detail is awesome and holy. I recommend to anyone travelling to the London (UK) to visit Westminster Abbey.

the ABBEY ON A SUNDAY. We wanted to see the Abbey but when we arrived it was closed to normal tours due to being Sunday so we decided to joint the locals and spend an hour in Eucharist, and not being a religious person i really enjoyed the ceremony ,with readings from the old testament to sermons by chaplains and then the choir singing and remembering Charles and Dianne plus many royals all were part of this magnificent church with Gothic painting,sculptures and breath taking stained glass windows,if you have the time and don't leave during the sermon like some of the other tourist did..very rude..its well worth sitting listening and enjoying English history and saying you have been there!

A must visit. If you are in London then you must visit Westminster Abbey. As some have pointed out it might not be the cheapest place to visit (£18 per adult) but once inside it is worth the entrance cost as there is so much to see. You could spend most of the day there if you looked at everything in detail! It is a very difficult place to review as probably every single person will get something different from their visit. The statues, monuments and architecture are wonderful with a free audio guide available in many languages but not essential to use, we didn't. You will also see many plaques in the various "corners" - poets, politicians, musicians, scientists etc. We went there on a Monday morning in November and it was busy but not annoyingly full (it is closed for tourists on Sundays). Before leaving take a look at the cloisters and the small museum which has some interesting things including the rehearsal crown, orb etc. for the Coronation. Sadly the garden is closed on a Monday. There is no photography allowed in the Abbey itself but you can take photos in the area outside. Don't miss the coronation chair near the main exit. A very enoyable, pleasant and extremely interesting place to visit.

Loved the afternoon Evensong service. Hard to believe the size of the Church and the details throughout. The 3:00 P. M. service was a joy to attend. Many staff members were all around and very helpful with questions. Hope to return very soon. No fee was charged to attend the service (a collection was taken) but we were told there is a fee outside the services.

Expensive for what you get. It is expensive to get in, (£18 per adult) and there is a strict no photography policy. Kids under 11 are able to have a quiz/treasure hunt which is nice, but far too long (four A4 pages!!). This can get, as one of my group stated 'really boring'. You can, however swap your clipboard for a large coin chocolate at the Abbey shop (located outside). Nice to see, but I don't feel a burning need to return again.

An extraordinary place. Simply put a trip advisor review is not sufficient to do this place justice. Anyone who has an interest in the world beyond reality TV and Twitter will find this place fascinating and humbling. The history, and the Kings, Queens, scientists, musicians, authors and poets buried are quite overwhelming and the architecture is stunning. The free audio guide is good; for each part of the abbey described you can have the choice of a quick explanation or more detail if you're interested. I thought the entry price was a bit steep to begin with, but by the time I left had absolutely no objection to the £18 ticket price. I can imagine it must be very busy at time and think this would detract from the overall experience so my top tip is to go on a quite mid week morning.

Stunning history. As a certified history geek, I was in awe from the moment I walked in. I spent quite a bit of time just sitting in a chair soaking in where I was. The Kings and Queens who'd been crowned here since 1066! The authors and scientists buried here. It was to much to take in. The guided audio tour is awesome, but a bit confusing at points. Overall? I could spend days here with local historians and be in heaven! Truly a must see!

A must see when visiting London!. We were there for the Rememberance Day memorial which was quite busy and very beautiful. I would take a good 4 hours to visit this location to get the full benefit of each part of the premises. The head phones they give you on the way in are great and the time should be taken to visit each speaker point. The only downer was that we were told that no photos could be taken while in the Abbey (which I do understand the reasoning of).

Expensive attraction. Visited the Abbey on a Saturday afternoon. Large queue and long wait to get in.Vey expensive admission fee.While the architecture is beautiful, it was not worth the fee.Other far better less expensive and free attractions in London.Would not recommend you pay to go into the Abbey - just enjoy from outside

Westminster Abbey, WOW!. We visited this absolutely amazing church during our December 2012 trip to Europe. What an amazing trip through the ages. LOVED all the history behind every corner! Definitely worth the visit.

Hands down, the best abbey I've ever seen.. While it pained me to pay to enter a church, the audio guide offered a wealth of information about the abbey and the people to whom it pays tribute. It was great to learn so much about British history and see the location where so much had taken place.

3 £ tour well worth it. This was our second visit to Westminister Abbey. Even though we were there early in the morning it was very crowded. We did not want to miss anything, so we decided to take the Verger tour. It was well worth the money! There were only 12 people in our group. Our guide was outstanding. She took us in parts of the Abbey that the general public is not usually allowed. She was very knowledgable and gave great insight into the history of the Abbey. After the tour we were allowed to tour the Abbey on our own. There are audio guides available for of charge, but the Verger Tour was so much better! Consider this tour in addition to your own walk through visit!

Very famous, very crowded historical building ........ The Westminster Abbey is a very famous, but also a very crowded touristic building with historical values. Unfortunately due to the lack of time and the long queuing, we did not have enough time to have the entire tour inside. Nevertheless, we have been here at least :-)

Great attraction but expensive. Three of us ventured into London to visit Westminster Abbey. Entrance was £15 each as 60+ visitors. Entrance is via the North Gate and on the way we passed the garden with all of the poppy tributes for Remembrance Day.We had to queue for a few minutes to pay and then entered the abbey and collected our audio guides that are available in several languages. The equipment is quite light and easy to use. There are options to listen to more in-depth descriptions available on many of the audio stations. Jeremy Irons is the narrator and his diction is easy to listen to and understand. There are guides in red robes to answer any questions to you may have.The Abbey is not as large as one would expect. In fact it is smaller than several other English and French Cathedrals, although I suppose this is to be expected as it is in the centre of one of the most populous cities in the world.The things to see are primarily related to English history, including tombs of many kings and queens, memorials to rich and/or famous Britons and also Poets Corner. The building itself is well worth seeing.After the abbey itself, one can visit the beautiful Chapter House and a very interesting museum.Our visit took over 90 minutes and was to us worth the money we paid.

In the Heart of it all. Really this is just a church. They do keep it open for the public but there isn't a lot here. Nonetheless, it is a beautiful building and it is located in the heart of it all making it easy to snap a few photos of the old church. It is right across the street from Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament so take a few photos while you are there.

Historically significant and stunning architecture. I suggest taking both the grounds and interior tours. The architecture is really stunning, the artwork is impressive and the history is noteworthy. The grounds are impressive! The tours are on the steep side but worth it. The later in the day you go the longer the lines get so plan accordingly.

Westminster abbey -Rememberance Day. Visiting over the Rememberance Day weekend is an extra special time to go. Field in front of the abbey is filled with small wooden crosses to commemorate all the British soldiers that have given there lives for their country, so many crosses, it makes you pause to think.

As impressive as I remembered. I very much wanted to see the abby when my family and I were in London, as I had been as a teenager and loved it. My husband and three year old son were as taken with it as I had been, and spent quite a while exploring and listening to the audio guide. My visit was unfortunately cut a bit short, because my 10 month old was evidently not as interested in English history as the rest of his family! But I still had the chance to appreciate the beauty of the architecture and be impressed by the history. It is very crowded, and it's important to check the hours of operation before going (we arrived at about 2 pm on a Wednesday, I believe, only to discover that they close early that day.) Some advice to anyone travelling with a baby: bring a baby carrier! We were very thankful to have brought ours, as the crowds would have made the stroller a impossible (not to mention, several areas are not wheel chair or stroller accessible) Still, despite the cost and the crowds, I found the visit to be worthwhile.

fantastic. magical experience.I enjoyed every moment sent in London.I love this city and I highly recommend non touristic tours in Shoredich area. Abbaye de Westminster is nice place to learn about Gothic period in UK and you can jump to Paris to compare it with Notre Dame. Go! Go !

A must see while in London. We visited Westminster Abbey and the visit was made more enjoyable because we downloaded the tour on our iPhones. You have to pay to get in, but it was worth it. Most places are free in London. The church is beautiful and filled with rich history. A must see if you visit London.

Hard to say.... We arrived around noon. There were two lines (one for cash, one for credit) of about equal length outside, and neither line was really moving. We estimated that it would take at least two hours to get in, and the abbey closed at three. I had a sprained foot and it hurt to stand, so we opted to tour the outside, a beautiful blend of old and new, and to explore the square across the street. Although I would have liked to see the inside, Canterbury Cathedral, Salisbury Cathedral, and York Minster will have to do. If you go, go very early.

Fantastic church - but at a cost. The church is fantastic,both from the architectural point of view and from the historical significance. The audioguide is also great, with Jeremy Irons taking us through the church. However, 18 pounds is a rather steep admission, and then you're not even allowed to take photographs. I understand that flash can damage the artworks, but banning all photography.Still; it's a place you have to see. Just fork out the money and go there!

Evensong service was profound. We're not very religious but evensong service was very moving. You are seated in the Abbey's ancient pews. The sermon was predictably dry but the sound of choir echoing through that massive hall was angelic. If you're an American Episcopalian, this is a must-do experience.

History up, down and...under your feet?. To experience Westminster Abbey one almost has to go back in a time capsule. Everywhere you look someone famous is buried, unburied, or remembered with a plaque on the wall or floor. This is must see with a tour guide. As you cross the street to enter the abbey it hits you-so many English monarchs were married and buried here...many reburied, but their coffins remain. Worth every penny!

Go to an Evensong service - just amazing. I went to an Evensong service during the week and then went back the next day to tour the Abbey. The Evensong service was beautiful and a memory I will never forget. As for the tour, I lined up at 9:30 when it opened and got in around 9:45. They have an excellent audio guide here as well and the maps are easy to follow. I don't think you'll ever not find a crowd, so you just need to manage around the tour groups who have guides walking them through. It is a gorgeous place full of history and is a must-see when in London.

Should be top of your London visits. Although living within a relatively short distance from London and having visited The Abbey on several occasions I had never been to an actual service before.We attended a choral evensong and I cannot describe what a wonderful experience this is – quite awe-inspiring in fact and with a superb choir.This is something when in London that no-one should miss out.We were also able to have a look around and felt quite humbled by the magnificence of this piece of great architecture.

Great history. Had a great time, children enjoyed the treasure hunt and the chocolate coin reward at the end. Although we had the handsets there were places where I still didn't find all the information. A magnificent place with so much history.

Magnificent. The audio tour took us around and indicated all the famous people and the history of this marvellous building. We visited on 9/11 so the minute of prayer and silence was very poignant. We actually had the best coffee and muffin of the holiday from a little stall just outside before our visit!

So much on offer if you take the time to look around. Having seen this on the TV for years I took my kids and showed them the inside of this wonderful piece of history on a wet and windy afternoon. We all used the handsets to listen to the commentary and we all learned so much. The kids had great fun finding all the monuments to the people they knew, especially the literary greats, and really made their Tudor history come alive. The guides were approachable and informative and the whole building is a delight. Shame we all had to cram through the, rather small, shop to get out though. The man at the ticket desk said to wait until the afternoon to come as the Abbey is much quieter and hence you don't have to queue so much.

Busy Busy. This place was extremely busy inside. The wait lines were extremely long. However, I got in with a group and got immediate entrance through the back. It was one of the most beautiful places I have ever been. This is a most visit when going to London.

Wanted to take pictures. Another place I went to 30 years ago. I don't recall if there was an entry fee back then. There is today. There is a self-guided audio tour that tells you a lot about the place and who is buried there. Scientists corner, poets corner, so many names we know and love. I found some of the history of the royals there to be interesting as well. My biggest disappointment other than not being able to take pictures was for how little respect others had for the tombs there, touching them, leaning on them, pulling on pieces. Mostly children not being watched by their parents, but some adults too.Otherwise, a very quiet, contemplative, informative visit that I thoroughly enjoyed.
Expensive. Expensive and long long queues.Once inside you see all the tombs of kings and queens over the ages. Also famous people like admiral Nelson is entombed here.

Expensive and you can't take pictures. This atraction is too much expensive for that it shows. The interior of the church is beatiful and the main altar is very impresive. You can find the tombs ( marble in the floor) of very important people and some impresive tombs. But i visited the san paul cathedral and is much better than the abbey. Sincerely, i recommend it only if you bought the london pass. Don't pay the entrance don't worth it.

Dissapointed Far too Expensive. Spending a day in London visiting different sites. Tried westmister Abbey entrance fee £18 each.Far too expensive so didnt bother, they are loosing a lot of local visitors due to the price which is seems to be aimed at overseas visitors who will pay itDissapointed.

Expensive and no photos allowed!. Very excessive price but that didn't deter a crowd. Absolutely stunning inside but unfortunately you can't take pictures and believe me they have a ton of staff following you to make sure you don't sneak a pic! I get the No Flash policy but No Pictures after you've gouged me for 18 quid to get in? Boo!

Walk on Darwin's grave. Long lines to get in, expensive to visit, most churches in the rest of Europe are free to visit. However, once inside the history that has been preserved was mind boggling. Tombs and monuments as far back as the 10th century.
Don't miss the coronation chair. I had no idea.....

So much history!. Westminster Abbey is truly rich with history! It was fascinating (and a bit overwhelming) to see so much in one place. I would recommend going when you can take a couple of hours and really take your time. The audio guides are a great source of information. Unfortunately, my husband and I were wrangling our toddlers, and they didn't much enjoy the Abbey; also, we went shortly before closing time, so we really had to rush through and missed out on a lot.
Evening Song!!. We were lucky enough to go to a service at 3 on a Sunday afternoon. Being in the historical church and listening to the choir was surreal!!
magnificent. Even though not going inside the church because too crowded, I believe this is the most wonderful place I have ever visited. Really and truly magnificent.

Put This on Your List to See. Wow. It is everything and more. The smartest thing we did was have a guide that was very knowledgeable. He showed us all of the main highlights and everything we wanted to see. You could get lost in this place for days.

Probably 3 and half stars. Crowded, no pictures, confusing, but a must see. Third visit to the Abby in 40 years. Worse each time. The entrance fee is £18.00 but you will get an free audio guide with poor headphones for the price. Unfortunately, you can not take pictures inside. I used the free downloaded audioguide from Rick Steves and listened to it on my iphone. Steves' guide is probably less stuffy than the one the Abby gives you. The inside strikes me as a "a gaudy monument to posthumous vanity" rather than a sacred space. The combination of memorials to the dead combined with the crush of tourists made the experience less than satisfying. That said, it was great to see my favorite, the memorials and tombs of great scientists Newton, Darwin, Thompson, Rutherford, Lyle, Joule, Maxwell, Stokes, and Lister as well as those of many famous British writers and poets. I especially like the small stained glass window represented Oscar Wilde given the difficulty he faced in the light of Christian beliefs.

truely magnificent. This is much more than just a church its beautiful buidling both inside and out. You get an audio guide included in admission price. We found this really good and enjoyable. You can listen to as much or as little of the guide as you like. Also you cannot take pics inside Westminster abbey.

The place that touched me the deepest!. The most amazing place I visited in London. The history, the atmosphere, everything was fantastic. This is a must see! Not a place I will be able to forget for the rest of my life!

Gorgeous Architecture!. My husband is a huge history buff, as am I. But while I can spend an hour or so in a historical landmark, he can spend hours upon hours, until all enjoyment of a particulat spot is lost to me. Not so with Westminster Abbey.The architecture is absolutely gorgeous. The minute you step inside, you're completely enveloped by history. There is just so much to see, that one visit is definitely not enough. Unfortunately, pictures aren't allowed inside, so, your own memories will have to suffice. Also, be sure to pick up one of the audio guides! It's really informative and it's narrated by Jeremy Irons, which is really awesome. The guide also makes sure you don't miss the must-see spots inside the abbey.The souvenir shop is also really, really great, so, be sure to stop there on your way out.

Expensive, cluttered - potential has been squandered. I was there a few hours ago. 18 pounds to access this tourist place. If the managers could remove about 90% of the clutter, it would gain in gravitas. But right now, it seems more like the hall of the rich and famous, rather than the pantheon of the UK's best known and most important historical characters. If you're not buried there, then somehow, you get a plaque put up instead. TOO MUCH!

Impressive Church and history. We did not take the audio device to listen to the history and displays, wish we did, otherwise to hard to follow. The interior of this Abbey is huge and the history surrounding it impressive, at times felt like being in a large tomb with all these great people, the history and architecture is awesome. A MOST on any visit to London.Not too many options for a washroom, plan carefully. Photos not allowed in church.

Remarkable. Westminster Abbey is such a memorable place to visit. Unfortunately you are not allowed to take pictures within. I recommend bring a pair of headphones to use with the provided radio style audio tour.

Audiotour is key to this experience. You can go at your own pace and listen to as much or as little as you like but do not miss the Chapter house and the cloisters! This is a must see for tourists in London.

Memorable, moving; a unique living, spiritual and historical site.. This was my first visit - being born in London I've not done the tourist trail - but it won't be my last. We were almost put off at the entrance by the fees of £18 per adult but there are generous concessions available.There is a free audio guide which we didn't use, wanting to discover the place for ourselves. We were very pleasantly surprised that this is a living place of worship - live prayers are made hourly over the public address system and each person is invited to stand still to join in. We also attended a very short but moving service at the shrine of Edward the Confessor, a memorable and worthwhile experience. (This is where Kate and Wills signed the register, if you are into that kind of thing. There is also a very good view down the Abbey through a peep hole. ) As well as these prayers, there are various services throughout the day, details of which are on the reverse of your ticket. Most people showed respect for the no photography rule which is impressive considering the historic nature of the place with the many tombs of the great and the good to see (and a contrast to the disrespect shown in, for example, San Marco, Venice).I love reading inscriptions with phrases such as:HE DYED FVILER OF FAITH THEN OF FEARS, FUILER OF RESOLUCON THEN OF PAIENES, FVILER OF HONOVR THEN OF DAYESas well as the modern memorials you may see in the cloisters. One of the most moving tombs is that of the Unknown Warrior.Outside are figures of twentieth century martyrs - this isn't a place about the past but a site which has deep historical foundations for its modern worship and is very much a place where Catholics and Protestants may join together in prayer.The place is just packed with history, fame and symbolism as well as worship. There is a cafe for refreshment when Abbey Overload rears its head.

Fantastic sights rip off cafe. What a fantastic place. I cannot praise it enough but this was spoilt by a rip off cafeteria. Don't get me wrong the service was good and the produce was good it was the bill that was wrong. The bill arrived with service charge already added then underneath this it said service charge optional. Which is it? I feel very sorry for visitors who paid this service charge unknowingly then left a tip. Not good if you are a visitor but good if you collect tips. Westminster abbey please stop automatically adding a service charge if we as visitors feel that we have had good service we will tip
got to do it. please use the free audio guides. absolutely invaluable. visit lasted over 2 hours there was so much to do and see - even at £15.00 pp.

Expensive but worth the time. My group arrived early before opening time with the intention that the lines wouldn't be bad. Well, we were so wrong. The line was quite long and we were waiting for quite a while in the rain, even on a weekday. Once we got inside it was worth the wait because there was so much to see. I definitely recommend the guided audio tour because it really helped me understand what actually happened in there. There is so much history in the Abbey and I'm glad I got the chance to experience going in it.

Breathless. this is where most of the kings and queens since 1066 have had their coronation, and indeed most are also buried here, prince william and kate married here, but one thing i will say, its a lot smaller than you think, worth a visit? i would say a big fat Yes

A Must See in London. Westminster Abbey is not to be missed when visiting London. As with the Tower, history comes to life as you tour the Abbey. The waiting line or queue wasn't too long when we visited, and it moved very quickly. Standing in line actually gives you time to take in the architecture--the detail is astounding. Once inside, you're given an audio device. You can pace your tour, either listening to the pre-programmed audio which leads you through major attractions, or you can wander on your own and simply press the numbers on the device that correspond to the numbers on the space you're looking at. Either way, it's a magnificent place to visit, almost overwhelming inits majesty. We spent about 1 1/2 hours there, but you could certainly spent the better part of a day. The Abbey has religious services daily and all are welcome. There is a restaurant sponsored by the Abbey on the grounds, but we didn't visit. Still, good to know if you're there at lunchtime or for tea.

Worth the entrance fee. Full of history, this church is definitely a great place to visit. The entrance fee comes with an audio guide which points out all the little spots in the Abbey where people has been buried or where the Queen had her coronation. Worth the trip indeed.

Amazing and Insanely Crowded. My boyfriend and I visited Westminster Abbey with our London Pass. We arrived about thirty minutes prior to opening and joined a long queue. Mercifully the queue moved quickly as soon as the doors opened.I can't imagine that the abbey is never not busy, but once the large tour groups began to arrive (about an hour into opening) it was chaos. Hands down, this was the busiest and most congested place that we visited in London.The abbey has a great audio tour. It's filled with information. Tip- when using it, pick a quiet spot and stand still, look at the object after. There were so many people using the audio tours and not paying attention. I was constantly having other visitors bumping into me. The floor is uneven in many places, so in general, pay close attention to your surroundings.The Abbey itself is amazing and awe-inspiring. It is so ornate that it is quite an overwhelming experience.We were let down a bit as we didn't realize that a lot of the famous names on the "tombs" are not actually buried at the Abbey. Some very famous people are, but a lot are not. It's not very clear who is and who isn't. I wish that I had read up on the Abbey prior to visiting and knew what to expect.Overall, this is a London must-do. Go prepared to deal with the crowds and allow yourself two hours to full explore the abbey.Like my review? Check out my blog!

Really beautiful church with so much history. I love the beautiful style that the Abbey was built in. It's very impressive but also has a warmth to it.So many famous historical figures lived out critical moments here and so many are burried or honoured here. The audio guide is definitely full of useful information.

Very Interesting & Very Crowded. Everyone must see Westminster Abbey. I especially liked the fact that they honored Winston Churchill in one of the floor slabs. He is such a hero to England and essentially to the world due to his contributions during World War II. It is a beautiful church with very unique architecture and paintings. We probably should have gotten a guide for this site.

Expensive. I cant believe they charge 18 pounds, yes 18 pounds for entry. Inside is great and great to see, but I do not think it is worth that much. The lines to get in were long (about 30 mins) and that was a week day. I was disappointed as other main attractions in other countries (Notre Dame) are free as were others in the UK.

Locked out. I'll start of by saying I never got to go inside Westminster. I had only a few days in London, and I didn't get around to the Abbey until my last day in town.Unfortunately, when we got to the doors, there was a sign saying the Abbey was closed for a private function until later in the day. I had other things I wanted to see and knew I wouldn't have time to go visit those places and then make it back in time before Westminster closed for the day - so I left the Abbey saddened that I couldn't see in the inside of this famous church.The outside of the church was lovely, and I can only imagine that the inside is beautiful as well. Too bad I'll never know now, as I likely won't be able to visit the city again.

Inspiring. Spectacular and wonderful historic abbey. Be careful to check times and dates for tours and also check times of services. Beautiful and quiet and full of history and peace. May be long lines but worth the wait. Perhaps go in the late afternoon for shorter lines.
Amazing Experience!. The abbey celebrates the very best of England's contributions to world science, literature and culture.

go in for free or pay for entry?. We were a bit shocked by the 18 pound fee to enter the Abbey. We arrived as it opened as instructed by our tour book, but I think it backfired, as it was a long enough opening line that the first 15 minutes were crowded until we thinned out. The audio guide (included in admission) is essential. Speak to the staff who are stationed throughout the abbey; they are incredibly helpful and loved to share their knowledge.It is basically an enormous mausoleum, so if you are not interested in the history of the inhabitants, and in spending several hours in contemplation, then I recommend yo come for a service. We did both. We attended a 5 p.m. choir service (not at 3:30 as the permanent sign indicated). Line up early and if you are among the first 25 or so visitors (I mean worshipers!) you can sit in the choir seats. We almost made it into the choir seats so had a fron row seat on folding chairs on either side of the high altar. If you are not near the front you will not see the choir and I think would be disappointed, but you would still be able to contemplate the abbey and exit through the choir area. It is free to attend a service and you see the nave, choir, north transept, stained glass windows, and high alter. Ushers prevent exploration.
