The service features two readings, a couple of prayers, call and response, etc. It lasted about 50 minutes. The high Commissioner from Uganda and her staff attended and she read one of the readings.

Can't miss this. Get the london pass and skip the lines which I am sure are long in summer time. Audio guide lets you self pace. No photography inside which makes sense afterwards. Try to go when you can visit gardens and other sites attached as these are nice and a great place to sit and relax.

Use the Audio Guide. . It's easy to go in, stare at the ceiling, get bored and leave. Use the Audio guide and let it explain what it is in front of you. Helps to appreciate the place. Plan about an hour. Don't miss poets corner and the coronation chair. Also of note, they are continuing to bury people there. Glancing at dates on the tombs and noticed 1986 and such. Interesting.

breathtaking. You must go see Westminster Abbey. Absolutely amazingly beautiful. If you don't want to pay for the visit (about 30$), go for evensong at 5pm. You can't walk around during the service but you have a bit of time at the end to see the place. Good way to relax in the shade for 45 minutes at the end of your day and enjoy one of the most amazing churches.

Outstanding Tour. While visiting my son studying in London, we decided to take in some sights including Westminster Abbey. We went as part of The London Pass (which I HIGHLY recommend). The Abbey was very crowded but we went anyway and decided to book a private tour for an extra 3 pounds (worth every penny). We were a group of 15-20 and our tour guide was outstanding. We saw parts of the Abbey that otherwise wouldn't have seen and received more information and insight on this exquisite piece of history in an hour and a half than I could have ever imagined. The Abbey is so expansive and impressive I highly recommend this as one of your stops in London. It's a magnificent work of architecture not to be missed.

Spectacular. This site has multiple buildings on it used for various purposes it seems with some of those changing over time. I don't know much about abbeys, but I do know the building referred to as Westminster Abbey, is architecturally and aesthetically spectacular, both on the outside and the inside. It is also incredible to see what it contains inside and the work that has gone into the construction and ornamentation. One of the most beautiful and awesome church buildings I think I have seen anywhere, if not the most beautiful and the most interesting attraction I saw in London. I also think it is as close as one can get to understanding who the significant people might have been who are entombed here, whether they be royal, religious or neither or whatever. The feeling of being in the vicinity of these tombs is difficult to describe, perhaps a bit eerie? It's certainly moving though and worth experiencing, in my opinion. I was surprised with the secular aspect to some of the attractions within. The distinction between monarchy, state and religion appears to me to be blurred, with a lot of the stories, facts and attractions here, which is fascinating and at times peculiar. Tracing and interpreting these 3 areas as they evolve over time would seem a complex exercise. This is no criticism of the attraction, as I imagine this is a representation of real life as it has and was unfolding.I really loved the various buildings' doors and window treatments, as I did the Norman style (I'm to understand) ground floor hallways and rounded arches, which are wonderfully ancient and mysterious looking. The final aspect of this attraction which is worth praising are the gardens. These are really superb, not just for the roses or trellises or espaliered apples, but for the really old and large shade-providing trees. These trees create a very cosy sense of place and space, a microcosm, between the buildings. The spiky chain to stop people entering a small courtyard is a 'nice' touch. I had to carefully climb over it at the request of boys (boarding school pupils?) playing basketball in the next courtyard to fetch their rogue basketball which landed in the garden next to me. And the ball finials and pruned trees within the garden are delightful. I could happily sit here for a couple of hours with a book and a cup of tea and perhaps a crash helmet (a joke!) Beautifully presented attraction highly recommended. With all of these types of attractions, for those with limited mobility, I would recommend buying a ticket beforehand or requesting to go to front of line. From memory though, the line moved reasonably quickly and there is some seating available, if needed, if you ask. Well worth the entrance fee and I am so glad I chose to see this amazing place.

You can't deny the history but it would be nice to have a better explanation.... Westminster Abbey costs a phenomenal £18 (£15 for concessions) to enter and, in the process of trying to balance the desire to be a place of worship with being a national monument, it fails at both, sadly. I am sure you can enter if you simply want to worship, but I am not sure I would fancy that with hundreds of people walking past you to look at the tombs of kings, queens, politicians and poets (other famous churches have side chapels for worshippers, which seems to work better, and use the body of the church exclusively for services at set times). The entry fee clearly pitches the place as one of the must-sees for visitors to London but the lack of signage and explanation of what you are looking at lets it down severely on that front, too.You will need a good two hours to walk around and admire the monuments. History oozes from every pore, with the Abbey having been dedicated in 1065 and the present church dating from 1245. The Lady Chapel must have one of the finest examples of a fan-vaulted ceiling in the world. Numerous Kings and Queens from The Plantagenet and Tudor Houses are buried in elaborate tombs, including Queen Elizabeth I and her rival, Mary Queen of Scots. Not surprisingly, there are numerous stairs, so the building is not easily negotiated by those who use wheelchairs.The entry price includes a tape recorded tour, narrated by Jeremy Irons. I had not realised he was so good at speaking different languages... But it only provides snapshots of information and leaves you with more questions than it answers. It is also one of the old-fashioned kind that you have to hold up to your ear, so quite uncomfortable after a while. You can pay an additional £3 for a tour led by a guide, although they are at fixed times and so you would wise to check on line first if you favour this approach.Given a total admission price of possibly £21, it is surprising that the Abbey still has so many donation boxes and it is rather distasteful that you literally have to leave the building via the gift shop! Yes, I know it costs a lot to maintain such an historic building, but the majority of merchandise on sale seemed to have little, if any, connection to the Abbey. (If you like jewellery, on the other hand, you'll be in seventh heaven!) I would recommend the restaurant, though. Soup with bread, fish and chips, and two soft drinks came to £25 including service. While the price was average, the quality of the food was good and the service friendly.Strangely, the loos by the restaurant were clearly labelled for patrons of the cafe only. So I am not sure what those who are "just visiting" have to do and the "free" plan handed to you on arrival makes no mention of lavatory or baby changing facilities.There are lots of stewards on duty, who I assumed were volunteers. They need to guard against being overly intrusive. While some people might have found them friendly, I got a bit fed up being asked if I spoke English every few minutes as another came up to me!Given the history and the time you need to walk around, £18 is not unreasonable. But as the Abbey is pitching for the tourist market, in which there is no shame whatsoever, PLEASE make it more educational and improve the information available - there is no shame in that, either!

Westminster Abbey is Phenomenal. My husband and I were swept up by the 1,000 year history of this site. Incredible visiting the tombs of so many historic figures (i;e, Chaucer, Darwin, Newton, Mary Queen of Scots, Elizabeth I). impossible to adequately describe the majesty, the architecture and the powerful experience of stepping back into time. Viewing the 700 yr old coronation chair, possibly the oldest piece of furniture in England, was a wonder. The Abbey's small gardens are not to be missed, especially the College Garden, said to be the oldest garden in England (look up and see another view of Big Ben). Allow at least 2-3 hrs to take it in. Our visit to Westminster Abbey was positively unforgettable.

I was having a cow.....nearly literally.. When I went into Westminster Abbey, I was flipping out. The 18 pound price mark is a pittance for the absolute and pure majesty of the whole place. I had barely walked 20 metres before I saw the graves of William Wilberforce, Ralph Vaughan Williams, Isaac Newton, Sir Edward Elgar, and PM David Lloyd George. I cannot truly describe the feelings of awe at this church. There are no words in any language to feel the honour to walk among the graves of the men and women who have made this world more beautiful and more wise. The soaring columns and floating ceilings, hundreds of feet up, cannot contain it all. Walking on, I saw the graves and memorials of Winston Churchill, David Livingston, Edward the I, William Shakespeare, and George Frideric Handel. Pretty much everyone worth remembering in history is either memorialized or buried here. If you go to NO other place in London, go here. Parliament and Buckingham Palace have one PM and one Queen; this place has about a million of each.

Extra class!!!. Definitely worth every pound!The cathedral is so beautiful I couldn't believe it. the illumination works perfectly with the interior you can literally feel the piety of the place. It has very interesting history so do not miss it and discover every level of experience it can provide.You can take audio-guide for free with your ticket and elevate your experience to the new heights. The English one is narrated by Jeremy Irons which is a A+ voice match for this holy place.

Interesting visit. It is hard to be in London and not see Westminster Abbey, however, at 18 �� it is a bit pricey for an audio tour of an old church. Lots of grave sights and chapels. A coronation chair that looks as old as advertised. Go and visit with a stop in the pew with a prayer and save yourself 18 ��!

LONDON VACATION. Of all the attractions we visitied, both in London and Paris, Westminster Abby was the most spectacular. I actually got goosebumps in here because of all the history. Being able to see the beauty of this church was beyond my expectations. I was awestruck with all of the ancient tombs of England's kings, queens, dukes, actors, poets, writers, , etc......I could have, and should have, spent 2-3 days exploring and seeing all of the majesty and history in this magnigicent historical place.I only wish we could have taken pictures in here but cameras are not permitted.If you visit London and see nothing else, see Westminster Abby.I was blessed to have been able to see this.

Beautiful and fascinating. Really enjoyed the visit, lots of history. As an engineer, enjoyed Isaac Newton's tomb. The poet's corner is awesome. Loved the monument for Shakespeare. There is also a decent, if overpriced (what isn't in London!) restaurant in the crypt.

Love the Abbey. This was probably my favorite spot in London. The Abbey is absolutely georgous, and the history is incredible. There is so much detail in architecture and to think this was all done with none of the modern day tools is amazing. The Nave is beautiful!! Just behind the high alter at the end of the Nave is the Shrine of St. Edward the Confessor which is encmpassed with many other tombs (henry III, edward I, edward III etc) and beyond that and on the way to the Henry VIIs lady Chapel are so many other tombs but the Chapel itself is amazing with a vaulted roof with carved pendants. there are statues and creasts throughout...just so much history. I will say much more interesting for older kids and adults, my 5 and 7 yr old were bored.

beautiful. its well worth the money,as everything in london if you pre book it is not that expensive.very impressive,so ornate.beautiful ceiling,everywhere you step there is a story at your feet.many people are buried under the floor and there are memorials to famous british people from scientists to poets everywhere.very interesting,im glad i took the time to visit.stroll around the streets outside,a very pretty area of london.great architecture.
Exquisite. The architecture of this building is amazing but it sure is hard to get into. The weekend hours were almost prohibitive.

Not worth the price. 18 pounds is too much to ask for it, really. I've found st pauls to be more impressive, and it is even cheaper. If you can go on sunday, you might be able to see a bit of it for free. Otherwise, I would skip this.

Not to be missed. Visited on a Friday at 2.45pm and did not have to queue. Perhaps we were just lucky but it wasn't crowded and we could walk and see everything without having to wait our turn. The sun shone and the light through the stained glass windows was magical.
London. First visit here,very impressed,entered with London |Pass,it is quite amazing,to think how old it is,I would recommend anyone visiting London to see this.

'Transported''. Our visit was to attend the installation of a new Canon of Westminster so it centred around worship at Evensong and hospitality afterwards; therefore, my visit falls into a different category of the more usual visits by the many tourists.Having been a member of the Chapter of another cathedral with the highest standards and expectations for music in worship, Westminster meets the very highest of expectations. This all reminds us of the key component—the Abbey’s corporate life—that enables everything else to happen. The hospitality, from the welcome at the door, to being guided to where the worship would take place and through to being bid farewell happen with practice, training, commitment and attention to detail. Through that, Westminster Abbey models the core element of its Benedictine foundation: a spirituality of looking to the ‘other’.

Worth doing the tour. We recently took the walking tour of the Abbey. The main advantage was we did not have to stand in line for ages to get tickets and admission and the tour guide was well informed. This is the only way to conveniently see the Abbey in tourist season. We booked the day before through our hotel and while I can not remember the exact cost it was inexpensive given what we would pay for tickets anyway.

Overwhelming. We had only 4 days in London, and Westminster Abbey was on the B list which, thankfully, made its way to our itinerary! Agree with going early to avoid lines, but, no matter the lines just go! Difficult for the 9 year old after an hour or so but I could have stayed all day as could my teenaged son and husband. 2 (+/-) hours are best. You are overcome with the sense of history as so many important people are memorialized here. The audio guides provide a lovely tour. My favorite historical site in the city.

take the verger lead tour. We visited early in the morning, shortly after the posted opening time. There were already lines forming. There are 2 different lines, one for cash transactions and one for credit. The cash line moves much quicker, as is logical, since there is less processing going on with each transaction. We paid the $3/person extra for the verger led tour and could not have been happier in doing so. Our verger spoke with passion for the subject and his knowledge of the Abbey was incredible. We were taken into several places that the general public could not go at that time without being on the tour, behind the alter and in the choir boxes. The tour was about an hour and a half and I feel that it gave me a greater appreciation of the history there. I learned so much about the history of the Abbey, the kings and queens buried there as well as the traditions that are still being followed today. If you prefer, like I do, a live talking human being who you can interact with, as opposed to a headset then take the verger led tour. For the extra 3 bucks you won't be disappointed. Check the Abbey's website as there are specific times each day that the tours are held so you'll want to plan your trip accordingly. They max each tour at 25 people and there is no advance reservation. We were lucky and had a group of about 10 which was perfect.

Holy overload of English history, Batman. My father and I visited Westminster Abbey during our trip to London and were wowed by every aspect of it. We went through the cash line (way quicker!) and were surprised to find that the abbey wasn't that crowded, even on a Saturday. The three extra pounds for the tour were well worth it - Alice, our verger guide, knew her stuff very well and answered all of our questions. From what we sampled of the audio guide (narrated by the dulcet tones of Jeremy Irons), it also seemed to be top-notch. We took a look around the church of St. Margaret's afterwards, which, while certainly not essential, contained more monuments and lovely architecture with almost no crowd factor.

Spectacular; but frustrating for photographers. There is so much to see here I could spend an entire day shooting just the windows. Well, you won't have to worry about that; they don't allow photography - ANYWHERE in the Abbey; just the grounds & the cloisters. So save your batteries, cap your lenses and let your senses be overwhelmed with the beauty of this place. You don't need to be religious to appreciate the incredible talents that went into creating the beauty of the woodwork, the frescos, the stained glass or the sculptures. You've heard of being moved to tears by beauty? Westminster Abbey will pull the heartstrings of anyone who appreciates art even in the smallest way.

One Visit not Enough. Unless you are really well read or come with an excellent guide then please use the free audio units. Take you time to take it all in. Plenty of places to sit and rest during the tour and although some of the areas get confusing as to what it what number, with the help of the free map then you get a better picture of all that is there.We did the whole in about 3 hours and we then stayed for 30 mins to eat in their restaurant and oh dear me - small, dry sandwiches. A chef who thought that French Fries were wedges and practically sneered at us when we queried it and threw the meal down.The 'private' toilets for customer use only were filthy with faeces and dripping blood in the ladies. Two of the 4 hand basins out of order. NOT good enough. will not use again in our next Abbey visit.

Westminster Abbey - my favorite church. Architecture, history, worship; whatever your reason for a visit, it is well worth it.The abbey is incredible. It has a special feeling for me, I can feel all those centuries of prayers. There is so much to see, from the tomb of the unknown soldier to the modern martyrs and the 12th century Chapter House. I love evensong at the abbey, I have had the priviledge of sitting in the quire. It is worth arranging your day. The Abbey schedule is available on-line.Say a prayer, light a candle or visit the memorials of the famous.Well woth your time.

Breathtaking. Most amazing building. I’ve seen this so many times on TV but to see it up close and really breathe it in was amazing. The littlest design features can sometimes take your breath away. Very close to Big Ben and well worth the extra time spent to look around inside.

Lots of dead people. Stood in line for about 20 minutes (there are 2 lines: one for cash, one for credit card. The cash line moves much faster!) Upon entering, we picked up headphones for the audio tour, which manages to cram hundreds of years of history into a nice easy to follow tour. It was maneuverable while the crowds were few, but by the time we left, we could hardly move-- so arrive early! Lots of royal history inside as we'll as burial grounds for many English poets & authors. However, I found the memorials of past kings & queens fascinating, as well as the tomb of the unknown soldier. We bypassed the cloisters, as per Rick Steves...and used the unmarked, free & empty loo (outside the door in Poets Corner).
Must see. Beautiful place. Not a busy place, but you must see this to appreciate the history. Close to Big Ben and across the street from the London Eye

Overwelming and impressive. As a U.S. citizen experiencing such a monumental church with centuries of history can be overwhelming. Initially, we hadn't planned on viewing the interior of this major attraction--delighted we did. Go early since lines form early. Also, pay the extra 3 pounds apiece for the guided tour-well worth it.

Lady's Chapel a Must See!. Beautiful Abbey and worth a visit. Suggest going early in the a.m. when it opens, otherwise you'll experience long lines. We went at 9:30 a.m. and got right in with our London Pass. This was a real time saver for many exhibits in the area. Our favorite room was the Lady's Chapel. Gorgeous ceilings and lighting. Stunning room. Worth a visit for sure.

Evensong at Westminister. Highlight of my trip was attending choral evensong at Westminister Abbey. Being in that beautiful church and the magnificent sound of the boys choir, this must be what heaven is like!

One of the best things we did.... I agree with many of the other reviews. This is a destination not to be missed. If you can get on one of the tours, you will learn so much more. They do not allow photography inside the Abbey, and they will come over to you and ask you to please put your camera away (we witnessed this). Photography is allowed outside the building. Seeing the tombs of royalty, great authors and just standing in the exact spot where the coronation of kings and queens occurred was a thrill.

walking amongst kings and queens. .awe inspiring visit to an amazing abbey. beyond my wildest dreams. where history and the here and now meet. want to thank verger ben so much for his imformative tour and the beautiful breakfast we had in the café. all in all a wonderful few hours spent in the presence of kings and queens wow!

A must do/see. This place had such splendour and religiousness to it, amazing to think of all the Royal marriages, coronations & funerals that has taken place inside over the hundreds of yearsThe amazing tombs of all the dead Royal Monarchs from down the centuries were very eerie and fascinating to study. The tomb that interested me the most was the combined tomb of half sisters Queen Mary I & Queen Elizabeth I- Henry IIIV's daughters!

The most important church in England. Westminster Abbey is the place where many royals have been married, crowned and mourned. No trip to London is complete without a visit to this hallowed place where so much has happened. There are so many familiar and famous people memorialized here. It's a stunning church with an amazing history. A must see site in London. Easy to get to.

For the amount you will pay, not worth it :(. Unless, you want to say you've been there, skip it. It was nice to see the church that royalty has used for marriage for the past 1000 years or so, but that's all. I have seen the Gothic church in Palma, Spain and it was far more impressive.

Westminster Wonderful. An absolutely stunning piece of Gothic architecture synonymous with London and the whole British Empire. This masterpiece is awe-inspiring and overflowing with a thousand years of our history.The admission price is steep (and has risen noticeably since last year) but it is totally worth the investment of time and money. And, true, the monies are re-invested in the obvious upkeep but the price does include a significant audio tour (as does St.Paul's). If you have to question the admission then you had better save your time and just do a walking tour of the area. An alternative to this is the LONDON PASS which we purchased in Canada prior to our trip and we got in to Westminster for free, and had a FASTTRAK which allowed us to by-pass the line-up.Whatever your background, if you travel to London and are truly interested in the culture and historical impact on the world of this nation you would not even question the cost of a one hour dinner to spend three hours in these hallowed halls.And if you REALLY use your imagination, on the way out you can imagine standing beside the Coronation Chair with Queen Elizabeth at her investiture, and THEN, in the doorway where Pipa Middleton's physiology overshadowed a royal wedding! HIGHLY WORTH IT!!!Unfortunately, no inside photography.

A Must. The first time visited was in the 70's. Much of London was grimy from the coal smoke and when they cleaned the buidings off it was a new place. I don't know when the "rubbings" began but I spent some time in the courtyard doing one carfully and contemplating the place. Going back since then I've looked for the individual markers of historic figures buried there. - including an ancestor.

Must attend a service if possible. It has been a dream of mine to attend a service in Westminster Abbey, to experience the solemnity first hand and to drink in the history whilst being part of it. Services are free so if possible, organise your trip accordingly. It is truly majestic and awe-inspiring, and we felt revitalised after our visit. Big Ben next door is great to see as it is so iconic, and walking from Westminster into the centre of London (Piccadilly and Oxford Street) is very easy and a great way to explore the centre of London.

Services Are Free. If you attend service you can not only see the abbey you can hear the choir and listen to some fantastic speaking voices talking about religion. . . Much like they did in the 1100s. If you are not into religious services you can imagine a coronation or royal wedding but either way it is an amazing experience to be in the abbey as a participant and not just a tourist.

Westminster Abbey. wonderful trip back in time, the tombstones or graves of famous people who shaped England's including Kings and Queens from yesteryears, a lot of history is in this Abbey. one of the more worthwhile visits. loved it! if you want to enjoy this Abbey, sit and just take in the sights, the stained glassed windows and the size of this Abbey, it was beautiful and you could almost feel there was a prescence of the ancestors who carved their names and staked their lives for their country. ten out of ten

Great piece of history. Even more expensive than St Pauls cathedral - now 18 pounds. High entrance prices especially poke in the eye when it comes to the places of worship as usually churches are free to visit. I understand that it requires renovation and staff payment but such high price does not seem right.Anyway the place is a must visit when in London. big slice of history of England and its rulers. Audioguide is great leading you through the church and its chapels. Impressive from the inside and from the outside. Be prepared to spend some time in a queue for tickets. No photos allowed inside the church.
great. I didn;t get to go inside, but I liked the architecture from the outsideIt is a famous landmark of London and definitely a must visit

A must see. A tourist in London must see it. Full of story it is difficult to move quickly when there are so many burial plates or memorials of so many highly renown people. The ticket is pretty expensive £18 and there is so much to see that you really need to plan for at least spend 2 hours.

Not To Be Missed! Magnificent!. Westminster Abbey has been the British Coronation Church since 1066. King Edward's Chair is the throne on which the British King or Queen sits as the crown is placed on their heads. Seventeen monarchs have their final resting place in the Abbey. Historically, the first Benedictine Monks were brought to Westminster about 960 AD. No part of their church remains as King Edward The Confessor built a new Abbey on the same site. This Abbey was consecrated on 28 December 1065. The Poet's Corner located in the South Transept has a lovely rose window. Underneath this window are two medieval carvings. It is interesting to note that this area was not known as Poet's Corner until the 16th Century when a tomb was erected to Geoffrey Chaucer who had been "laid to rest" there not because of his "Canterbury Tales" but because had held the office of "Clerk of Works." When Edmund Spenser was "laid to rest" in the same area, a new tradition was established. Charles Dickens, Rudyard Kipling, Thomas Hardy, Alfred Lord Tennyson, Robert Browning, and John Dryden are among the poets buried in this area. Composer George Frederic Handel is buried in Poet's Corner as is actor Laurence Olivier. Many monuments pay tribute to other writers who are buried in other locations. Some of those include Jane Austen, William Wordsworth, Henry W. Longfellow, William Shakespeare, T.S. Eliot, John Milton, John Keats, George Eliot, Henry James, Thomas Gray, Percy Shelley, Sir Noel Coward, and others. There is a wonderful museum, library and monument rooms, lovely gardens, chapels, and a gift shop. It was nice to note that the tomb which was receiving the most attention during my visit was the "Unknown Warrior." Audio Guides are available. No photography.

Very well shown off!. Unlike other London attractions I feel like Westminster has got it down for the tourists! The queue isn't massive, they are organised with the purchasing of tickets and have a very well done system of the tour headphones. The way around is well signposted even if you chose not to use the headphones. I highly recommend it though because you can tour at your own pace and its really nice learning everything in more detail.I also suggest learning a little about the people buried there before you visit too. Some people (not naming nationalities) had no idea who they were and I feel it could have perhaps taken away from the experience because it was exciting for me to be that close to such huge people from history!

Awesome - history beyond compare!. Upon entering the Abbey, we were overwhelmed with a sense of the historical importance of Westminster to not only the Commonwealth, but indeed the world. Here you walk in the footsteps of kings, queens, and heads of state; as well as on and past the graves of some of the most prominent and influential people in history. To have the opportunity to stand on the site of the Grave of the Unknown Soldier, or to view the Padre's Flag, gives one the feeling of having truly connected with some of history's most poignant times and events. I should mention that everyone involved in the tour, from the security guard who welcomed our toddler with a smile and comment on his beautiful eyes, to the abbot who held him while pointing out the seat which is reserved for the monarch or her designee only, to the tour guides who took the time to show us the location of some of the lesser known artifacts, everyone at Westminster made our visit truly memorable. Even if the lines are long, it is worth the visit. Enjoy!

History-revisited. Very interesting. A very famous place in London full of activities in modern times and always in the news. I did not know what to expect when I went in. A big surprise and great impression after what I have seen. I was wondering "is it a little Vatican outside Rome but in Central London?" It is full of British history over the years. Isaac Newton, Cromwell, Livingstone, Dickens, Lord Byron, a lot of the Royals and many more are there to share history with you. Highly recommended to visit.

A compulsory visit while in London. There are so many fabulous places to visit in London and many of them are free so while the entrance fee is expensive, I think I would regret not paying it as this is an absolute must see. It can be crowded at times but I think you have to expect that. In my opinion the audio tour is adequate and it does say that if you have any questions you can always ask one of the volunteers.

expensive but worth it. if you love history and art this is an amazing place to visit. The visit needs at least 2 to 3 hours to explore the abbey. The abbey is huge and the audio guide is needed to fully appreciate what you are seeing.

A must-see:). Beautiful and historical. The audio guide is excellent. We got there about 20mins before the abbey opened and were admitted in about 5-10minutes, so queues were fine. They let a LOT of people inside at once

Heavenly place. I had the joy of being at Westminster Abbey to attend a special service to celebrate Namibia's Day of Independence. Sitting in the stalls next to the choir and to share evensong was breath-taking. The choir's voices were outstanding ... and I could gaze at the architecture of almost 800 years.Tourists witnessed this event too, so maybe keep an eye out for services.I have been many times to Westminster but as with so many of England's other historic cathedrals ..... Having visited Salisbury many times, Winchester and others, a cathedral tour must be a glorious experience.

Steeped in History. This is a must do site. While entrance fees at £18 are not cheap, the history embraces you like few other places. You literally walk over the burial sites (or in some cases monuments to) of Dickens, Lord Byron, Darwin, Livingstone and many other famous people, not to mention the many Royals.The included audio guide is adequate and provides enough detail to keep crowds moving from site to site at a reasonable pace.You can view the Coronation chair used for every Coronation since 1066. The children in the choir even go to a school of their own.Crowds can be large at times. We went mid afternoon and there was only a small queue to get in.
Save 19 pounds and go inside . That is a place where you MUST visit... So save around 20 pounds to go inside... Breathtaking history and jawdropping structure

Organ recital at 5:45 pm on Sundays.. We have visited Westminster Abbey on two other occasions and were delighted to stumble upon organ recitals conducted there on Sundays. After waiting 30 minutes in the driving rain our patience was rewarded with a brief but rewarding recital played on the Abbey's organ in one of England's most treasured and iconic venues. Be sure to look for recitals if your in that area of London on a Sunday evening.

History is hard to ignore. The history in the abbey is hard to ignore no matter how over-crowded. However, why is there no fast pass entrance for London Pass holders? The entrance fee is included with the London Pass but we still waited in line for over an hour just to get in. Which of course is always a problem when you travel in July. Besides all that we still enjoyed the beauty and history.

Abbey left us wondering. This is a magnificent structure filled with history of the most interesting nature. It was however a very frustrating visit for us. We had really looked forward to it and paid £18 each to do the audio tour. Frankly it was inadequate and the accompanying leaflet/map as useful as a chocolate teapot. So many of the important contents have no information to see. These include royal tombs. You are left wondering whose tomb it is, knowing it must be someone important by the grandeur and the crowns on their heads. The audio tour starts well guiding you along through the great and good of their day including Wilberforce, Newton and Darwin then spends a lot of time on just a few areas e.g. chancel and Royal tombs such as Edward and Henry VII. There are many significant royals buried there who hardly get a mention. I nearly missed the coronation throne by the exit! The volunteers are welcoming and helpful if somewhat apologetic about the inadequate information. There were a few security guards posted about inside and one helpfully answered some of our queries about whose tombs were in the chapels beside the main king Henry's. This person told us the information signs had been removed which used to be provided for visitors when the current Dean took office. I felt the Abbey is excluding a lot of people with the tour cost yet so much of the history of our and other nations is represented in some way here. If the information provided had been comprehensive and tombs etc clearly marked with information signs I would not have left with feelings of frustration and disappointment.

Full of history, a must visit whilst in London. We visited Westminster Abbey last weekend, it was fascinating. You will be blown away by the number of historical figures that are buried there or for whom there are memorial plaques. It's a huge tourist attraction, so get there early, even if you have to queue it is well worth the visit. There is a ban on photos inside the abbey which is a shame, but seems to be the norm as the same applies in St. Paul's Cathedral. At £18 entrance fee for adults is quite expensive, so check out the London Pass before you visit London.

A must see site. In London, this is one of the historical sites that must be visited. It has everything that one expects and looks better in real life than on the television. There is a lot to explore and the audio guides provide an amazing amount of information. This also allows visitors to go through the building at their own pace. Entrance fees are quite expensive for this type of attraction. Also, it is very crowded. This makes it somewhat difficult to see things at times and lessens the enjoyment and overall feel of the place. That said, a trip to London must include Westminster Abbey.
A must see in London. It was crowded and hard to find a place for reflection, but it's a must see on any trip to London. Well worth paying for.

Do the Verger Tour!. We did the Verger Tour, which was very informative. We also got to see things roped off to the general public. A couple issues though: The queue to get in had a line for credit cards, and a line for cash. London Pass users got to use either line, so we chose the much shorter cash line. Despite every sign and guide book saying it opened at 9:30, the line did not move until ten (or maybe it was ten and ten-thirty. Either way, the line didn't move until 30 minutes after the posted opening time). However, the credit line seemed to be moving well before the cash line, which seemed unfair to me.
Beautiful!. I loved Westminster Abbey. It was breathtaking and the audioguide was very helpful. I would love to go again!

A Herd of Cattle. Wow! This was a beautiful place if you like to be in a herd of cattle! You can't really see alot because there are so many people in there at one time. I don't know if its like that all day but when we went it was so crowded! Once again, no photos! London attractions are notorious for no photos! That is one of the pleasures of going on vacations, looking back at your pictures. All of these places have different excuses for no photos, but why don't they just say it, we want you to buy our books! It is worth a visit if you can stand the crowds!
great tour. Worth the time and money. Excellent audioguide. I think narrated by Jeremy Irons! Busy inside, as expected.

So Much History. We visited the Abbey with our Blue Badge Guide. This is not my first trip to the Abbey but it was the most meaningful. She was able to explain the history of the Abbey as well as pointing out the many tombs, we saw the coronation chair which was very interesting, it is obviously old, 600 years old and in its original state. I find it cool that the statues at the main entrance include Martin Luther King. A more modern group of individuals than I am used too. Appreciate the tombs in all of their grandeur. Spend time on the outside areas including some of the oldest areas where the walk ways are behind the main door. Also to the right where the Minster School is, we were lucky enough to see the choir boys heading to school. Don't miss the Knights of Westminster section with the flags, helmets, and name plates on the very interesting seats. Walk inside the amazing outside of this grand building is not enough.

Majestic place. Westminster Abbey is one of the highlights that you could come accross on your visit to London. This place breaths with history of many centuries, so many important events in the history of UK took place here. Several members of nobility or men of literature and science are buried here. Very monumental gothic style architecture. Audio guide here is very good and helps you to perfectly orientate in the building.
I revisit every time I can. So much history in one small location. You feel as if you visited a few centuries in an hour or two. I have been over twenty times but still look forward to my next visit.

Beautiful Church. I visited on a Monday in September 2013. It was very crowded I was surprised that it cost $18 per person to go in the church and no pictures. Notre Dame was free and you could take pictures. Be prepared for crowds , but also be prepared to be awed. Unbelievable art and stained glass windows. The history alone was overwhelming. Wouldn't have missed it on my trip to London.

Westminster Abbey. Was expecting to queue but got there on a Tuesday morning about half past ten and we walked straight in, having said that, it was extremely busy and sometimes a little difficult to get around due to the amount of people that were also looking around. I found the Abbey fascinating, disappointed that you cannot take any photographs as would have been a lovely memento.

Absolutely lovely. I only had a few days in London, and this was on my list of "must sees" things while I was there. I really enjoy history and was particularly looking forward to spending time here. It was a drizzly day whn we visited but it was worth the walk and the wait for entry. Since I'm from the U.S., we just don't have churches like this in America. The ceilings, the stained glass, the tombs, the coronation chair, the art.....it was just breath taking. We really enjoyed visiting Poet's Corner. Photography isn't allowed in the Abbey, but they have nice guide books for purchase. It was an amazing place to stop and pray. I think If I am ever lucky enough to go back, I would do one of the guided tours. We heard tidbits as we did our own wandering but learned a lot from the guides.

Time your visit well. Westminster Abbey is a magnificent building housing the graves and epitaphs of numerous prominent citizens of the British Empire, from royalty, to Isaac Newton, to David Livingstone, to Charles Darwin. You must literally watch your step as - before you know bit - you will find yourself standing on a monument to a notable!The Abbey is big and there are many areas to visit - be sure to make use of the audio guides which are available upon entry. The guide gives loads of interesting information about the various events held here over the centuries (coronations, funerals, etc.), the architecture and meaning of various symbols.If you time your visit right, the "hidden gem of the Abbey" - the Abbey gardens - are definitely worth a visit, more so in summer time when you may be lucky enough to attend a live orchestra performance while relaxing on the lawns of the Abbey school, basically in the shadows of the Houses of Parliament.

Must Sees - Henry VII's Lady Chapel & Tomb of Edward the Confessor. Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster, normally called Westminster Abbey, is a famous landmark in London, UK. Its origin can be traced back to as early as 604 AD, but there is no evidence of this building. Edward the Confessor (1042-1066) had an idea to have a palace with a large monastery and an abbey church suitable for royal functions and burials. King Henry III (1207-1272) played a noticeable contribution to the church by spending lots of money to rebuild the entire church in the new Gothic style starting in 1245. The rebuilding was halted after his death, and it took another 250 years for the completion of nave at Westminster. In 1745 the west towers were completed, and the building we see today was finished. The Abbey today still plays an important role to the people of UK and a place of worship. The Kings and Queens continue to be crowned here and have their funerals here. On September 6, 1997 the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, was held at the Abbey. Some Royal weddings also held at the Abbey, including Prince William's wedding on April 29, 2011.Westminster Abbey is in the heart of London, not so far from Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. You can take London Underground (Tube) to Westminster or St James’s Park station or regular red London buses will take you near the Abbey entrances. Every year it attracts over one million visitors. It always has long queue at the entrance. You can pay by cash or credit card for £18.00 per adult, which includes a free audio guide tour. Once you get into the Abbey, you can see the nave, stained glass, crystal chandeliers and the grave of the unknown warrior. There are two must sees inside the Abbey - Henry VII's Lady Chapel and Tomb of Edward the Confessor. The Henry VII’s amazing chapel is so unique for its spectacular fan-vaulted roof and its carved pendants. I just could not believe how they could find the way to construct it. The Great Cloister, St Catherine's Chapel Garden and College Garden are the only locations that you can take photos inside the Westminster Abbey. It will be more valuable for the visit if you learn the history of UK before the visit.

Must see when in London. For those who likes history, beautiful architecture this is an amazing historical attraction. Recommend the guide tour as there is so much to see and cannot go everywhere on your own. A lot of memorial Poet Corner is the highlight of the tour. The garden worthed the tour outside There is a lot of historical significance Royalty and saint are buried in the Abbey The staff and the guides are very respectful A must see when in London At the end we were invited back to hear the Boy Choir which we could not attend So next time

Absolutely Beautiful!!. Don't miss out seeing this beautiful amazing church. So much history, beauty, what a work of art....such talented people who built and designed it. The ceilings are marvels in themselves...just gorgeous!!! Your eyes don't know where to look first there is so much beauty!! You are given hand held audio devices with head phones that talk about everything in the church. They worked great. Learned so much. Stood on the very spot where Kate stood with her father before she began her walk to marry Prince William and then walked down the center aisle like she did. Fantastic!! There is a sense of sacred respect while walking around and everyone seems to feel it. It was a wonderful experience my husband and I wouldn't have missed for the world! You won't be disappointed....promise!!

Amazed!. The self guided audio tour was excellent. There was a good size crowd but for the most part the it did not slow down the tour. We were surprised to find out how many famous non-Royals are buried there. Definitely worth the price of admission.

Amazing. If you like history, beautiful architecture, art, royalty, churches, poets, authors... Any or all of them... Then Westminster Abbey is definitely for you. It was our first stop in London and we were glad we made it so.

Guided your in the abbey. A really beautiful church. Visited the church togethed with my child (10), joined a guided tour. Hard a LOT about dead kings and Queens, but unfortunately not as much about the church itselves as I had expected. But I like history, so it was OK for me, but a bit booring and difficult to follow for my child. The tour lastes 1,5 hours. Cheap history lecture!

Fantastic historical attraction. The Abbey is an absolute must see in London. The day we went the line was not very long, only ten minutes and then it was a very quick ticket purchase and we were in. Everyone walks around very respectfully as I think we were all in awe of the age of the structure and the historical significance of it's the contents. I was with my teen daughters so they were thrilled to be walking where not only many kings and queens had walked, but where Kate and William were married. Lovely that something so old can still be so contemporary. It think in that regard it speaks to so many and therefore is a must when visiting London.

Great for those who love history!!. Great Abbey, too confusing, a lot of tombs you loose track. Artists corner attractive with Shakespeare and Dickens. You can find Queen Mary and Elizabeth I but keep your eyes open or you will miss it :(Not as great as advertised, others around the world are better preserved.

Well worth a visit. What a beautiful interesting place. Audio guide books available as part of entry fee were very informative. So much history, pomp and circumstance to experience. you need at least 2 hours for your visit depending on how busy it is and it may be worth checking visiting hours before going as last entry is 1530.Very good cafe and shop

Unexpected Awe. My 27 year old daughter and I went to Evensong at Westminster Abby on our last day of our 8 day trip in the UK. We were both tired, bracing ourselves for 10 hour trans-Atlantic flight by to JFK. We got back to the hotel a little early and had enough time for an afternoon of attraction. By this time to move both becoming short on cash. Over the past eight days we saw and were expectedly awed by the crown jewels, Edinburgh Castle and St. George's Hall, at Windsor. We decided to attend the 4:30 PM Evensong Service at Westminster Abbey. This ancient Christian service can be traced back at least 1000 years in English history. This worship service was one of the most unexpectedly awe-inspiring events of our trip. Once again, it showed me that many times the best things in life are free.

Must see. Don't let crowds keep you from enjoying this incredible and beautiful place. Allow enough time to visit the Poet's Corner. Each hour one of the rectors offers a prayer. It is a must see to understand British history and culture.

Don't loose your family.. The Abbey is full of history and it takes time to absorb, so don't think it's an hour or two. There are memorials to people from 16c, Poet's corner, marble statues of kings, queens and the two young princes, the wooden throne that has been used since early times. The crowds are large and many tour groups, so be prepared to be shoved out of the way, get your own back by walking between the photographer and their subject when outside! (naughty) Be prepared to queue to enter and beware of pickpockets. The odd thing is that no photography is allowed, yet in Notre Dame in Paris, which is equally old and famous, it is allowed and it's free!

A little advance planning maximizes your visit. Before you visit Westminster Abbey, check online for open/close times for the day you plan to go so that you can maximize your investment by seeing it all! I especially enjoyed the gardens and right now there is a special photo exhibit on Queen Elizabeth’s Coronation to celebrate her Diamond Jubilee at the Chapter House/Pyx Chamber. These and the Gardens were closed closed on the day/time that I had first planned to visit and I am glad that I changed my itinerary as it is worth the time all by itself with gorgeous tiles, stained glass windows and ancient frescos. The inside of the Abbey is overwhelming, hard to know where to look so be sure to grab the audio guide . . . you can always turn it off if you don’t like it but I found it very helpful to navigate the space. And while you cannot take pictures inside, there is still so much beyond the doors and into the complex. Even if you don’t plan to spend the entrance fee, the exterior architecture and grounds make this destination stroll worthy. Walk all the way around, you won’t be sorry. Big Ben and Parliament are just across the street!

Awe Inspiring. This place is magical. I went for my birthday. I had a london pass so i got in for free. So rich is history and tradition. Such a beautiful place to visit. I wish I could have taken photos

Beautiful. Westminster Abbey is so beautiful, inside and out.I've never been despite only living an hour away, but the interior of it blew me away.I didn't realise there were so many famous tombs in there, it was fascinating to walk around looking at the floor as you were going trying to find Isaac Newton, Thomas Hardy and Charles Dickens obviously just to name a few.The tombs for all the Kings and Queens of England were there also, with some bishops also. There didn't seem to be an empty space in there which wasn't covered in a memorium. An absolutle must see in London, especially if you're in London for a trip from abroad it's fantastic...albeit a little expensive at £18 per adult but it is worth it.

worth the money!. This was also included on the London pass. I had no idea what I was in for when we werw waiting in line. It was a good hour and a half tour that included a self guided audio tour. The abbey is absolutely beautiful and it was so cool to learn about all the history that happened there. It was a little crowded but that didn't take away from the visit.

Visually stunning with an outstanding audio tour... a MUST SEE in London!. My wife & I toured the Abbey on Monday morning 8/26. The entrance lines were long, but moved quickly. Having London Passes let us avoid the line for tickets, but we still waited to enter - well worth it!The interior of the Abbey is huge & stunning, but the outstanding one-way audio tour (included with the price of admission) takes you to numerous fascinating sites at your own pace. The audio vignettes about famous figures were endlessly engaging... History came alive.... Special sculptural exhibits for people like Sir Isaac Newton & Shakespeare were remarkable. The "Poets Corner" was fun.... The exhibit of the now-humble throne that's been used for all coronations since 1066 in the Abbey was one of many, many unusual sights.By all means visit the Abbey & take the audio tour.

Illuminating and interesting. My husband and I booked a live tour of the abbey on our recent visit to London and it was great.The minister (yes) who gave us the tour was extremely knowledgeable as to the kings and queens of England and it's history as a whole. By booking a live guided tour you get to visit places others do not get to see in the abbey. Tis is a fascinating look into the royal and regal history of England. Definitely worth the time.

Beautiful. Very historic and beautiful. Many of the royal family have been married here. A short walk from Big Ben. Walk around the outside to take pics. Steep price to go inside and no picture taking inside either.

Westminster Abbey - a must see when in London. It is hard to provide a review of Westminster Abbey with such few words and do it any justice, but when you are in London you MUST see this wonderful Abbey. It has over 1,000 years of history and has been the church where 17 monarchs have been entombed since 1066 (same year as the Battle of Hastings). Not only will you find the monarchs that have the church as their final resting place, but many other famous people are also buried there. Plan on at least an hour to view the church, and if possible, attend the Evensong and get to the front of the line so you can sit in the wooden seating area that offers the best acoustics.

Very amazing place. Westminster Abbey is beautiful inside and out. It is very convenient to the Houses of Parliament and St. Margarete's Church. The audio-guide to the Abbey was extremely helpful and educational. Amazing history and amazing artwork...definitely see the gardens too.

A must see in London!. So much history! First of all, the abbey is an absolutely beautiful building architecturally. Then you walk inside and not only see the beautiful art and architecture, but all of the history of the building. The tombs of the monarchs, the coronation chair, etc. All amazing! There are tombs of other famous English men and women at your feet, so make sure you look up, down, and all around as you walk through!

Learning and seeing history of london. 3x now I have walked down West minister just to see learn and take pictures. I cannot get enough of it. I will go again to learn more of the history of London and its great old fine buildings. Am reading more about them too. As I read what I read becomes life because of what I have already seen

Obligatory but pricey. Westminster Abbey is so important to the history of all English-speaking peoples that a visit while in London is absolutely mandatory. The tombs of the monarchs, the Coronation Chair, Poets' Corner ... How can you not go?Two major drawbacks. One is the admission price: £18. The other is that photographs are absolutely prohibited.The staff is extremely friendly and helpful. I inquired about a particular monument (Major John André, the spy executed by the Americans for receiving the plans to West Point from Benedict Arnold). I asked one of the guides, and he escorted me into an area normally off limits to see it.

This is where history happens!. I've always wanted see Westminister Abby, it holds hundreds of years a of history within its walls and is witness to so many past and present events. Just standing outside in the line you get to see the stone work and amazing structure of this building. The line to purchase tickets is shorter and faster if you have cash, just walk past all the people in line for credit cards and go to the other side of the doors. Once inside grab a hand held guide and map and your own your way. It was busy but so worth it make sure to stop and see the tomb of Elizabeth and Mary, look of the floor when you start your tour for Sir Isaac Newton, at the end make sure you stop and see the coronation chair and stop by the Queens coronation as well. This is a stop not to be missed and just a stone throw from Big Ben.

A London "must see" that is well worth it. The Bottom Line: A "must see" London attraction. The Great: Westminster is a focal point of British history and a must-see attraction if you are visiting London. As you would expect, there are the typical breathtaking ceilings and other cathedral standards. What you may not expect are the many shrines around the Nave that have a variety of buried monarchs and impressive statues and other relics. There is also a room in the "back" (from the main entrance) that features heraldry of various families and individuals who have achieved deeds of note. And of course, the graves of those famous enough to end up in Westminster (but not famous enough for their own room) -- are literally everywhere. The Mediocre: Skip the cafe unless you have a logistical need to eat there. Average food and a boring menu (even for the UK) make it not worthwhile. The Expected: Very crowded.

It's worth to see if it's your first time.. Like many of the churches we saw while in Europe this was a very beautiful church. All the history and glamor that you know about it is true. We saw this attraction using the London Pass so I don't know how much the regular price is, but was worth seeing. If this is your first trip to London don't miss out on this beauty!

Amazing. We were lucky with the crowds. Got there on a Saturday morning about 9:30 and almost walked right in. Less than 5 minutes in line. The inside of the abbey is even more breathtaking than the outside. It was still very crowded inside as some of the areas don't offer a lot of room to move around. The history of the abbey is truly hard to fathom. Every step is like a walk back through 1000 years of British history.

Very historically significant. Amazing place - definitely a must see while in London. Gorgeous building inside/out. So many historic figures entombed or remembered within. Allow a couple of hours. Cost is around $30 pp but if you care to go to a service usually at 5 p.m. - you can enter free. Check service dates/times.

Most astounding place on earth!. My review on this will be different from others. I was fortunate to meet a priest who offered to give me a free tour. We were able to bypass the line and we learned so much. This priest knew so much about everything and had the most amazing stories that we were fortunate to hear. Upon entering the abbey that's when you realize just how amazing the place is. We were just astounded at the rich history of such a place. We were told just about everything about the abbey. I had the rare opportunity to be shown the room where much of The Bible was translated! I even got to see places in the abbey that few have ever seen. The abbey itself is a huge burial ground for very important people in British society and it was great to see the likes of Noel Coward, Mary Queen of Scots, Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, to name a few!This is one if the few places in the world where you feel very different as a person!

One of the greatest we have seen!. Westminster Abbey is another (very expensive) must see while you are in London. My husband and I have traveled quite a bit around Europe and have seen many many many churches and Westminster Abbey is one of the greatest. The free audio guide made the entire tour worth it, definitely give it a listen and take your time at each one of the stops. I learned a lot more from the audio guide than I expected. The cost to get in is high (about 20 pounds per person) and the lines can get extremely long so go early and the cash line usually moves faster than the credit card one. Westminster Abbey is not only a beautiful place to visit, it is also extremely rich in history. Definitely a must see!

Long Line but Worth it. Not to be missed. The place where all British monarchs are crowned. And the resting place of many heroes of the British Empire. Very crowded. Take the self guided tour with recorded guide. No photos permitted, so buy what you want at the gift shoop.

Awesome-Spectacular-Huge. We were most impressed with this beautiful structure. Well worth the crowds. Amazing to think of the history that has occurred in this structure. It has a lovely cafe upstairs which we enjoyed in peace and quiet. It is hard for us from the U.S. to imagine a place that has participated in so much history. Very impressive.

Great history, but that's it. What makes the Westminster Abbey so special is it's fascinating history. But the architecture is rather less than more impressive as the one of other gothic cathedrals in Europe and even England (e.g. Canterbury Cathedral, where your in addition allowed to take pictures).

it's nice inside.. Upon entering you get the free audio guide. You scroll in there and the architecture is impressive. You can find the tombs of Isaac Newton and Darwin among many others who have contributed to England culture.Too bad you cannot take pictures....

I confess. I cried.. Westminster Abbey is a must for any visitor to London. The sense of history that pervades the place is absolutely amazing. To see the tombs of kings and queens, generals and admirals, that I had read and studied about throughout my life was amazingly affecting. I was not, however, prepared for Poets' Corner. I am an English teacher and I literally teared up when I found myself standing atop the marker for Geoffrey Chaucer, surrounded by Byron, and Milton and all the rest. I'm also enough of an Anglophile (British mother) to have be profoundly affected by seeing the throne on which Elizabeth II and many of her predecessors were crowned, as well as the choir stalls that I had seen so many times on television.

Just go!. Amazing beauty. Worth every cent to see all the details inside. You can't take photos inside, but you can purchase beautiful photo postcards in the gift store on the way out. Worth it because those photos are lovely just like the experience. The pipe organ is awesome - you can feel the base notes resonating in your chest! Try and time your visit with a time when the organ is being played.

History and Beauty. My daughter is a history buff, this was on her list. We had tried on our last visit but they closed. Check the hours before you go. Limited visiting hours, unless you go for mass on Sunday. I wanted to see the Abbey for its beauty and connection to the Royal Family, but found myself enjoying the tour and amazed by the amount of famous graves and crypts. Enjoyed the tour and the beauty of the church.
Love it. Love it! And it's also in the TV-show FRIENDS and that made the place so much funnier to visit. Since I'm young and prefer places that are known by that way. Lol

The grounds and outbuildings are the best part. You need a guided tour to really appreciate the history. There are so many aspects to the abbey that if you just go see the church you will think it is a mausoleum. The original chapel, the walled garden, the lawns and mini museum are just brilliant.

Great attraction but too crowded. I guess as its one of the iconic attractions in London it is going to be crowded. My sister and i went on a weekday in April and it was still crowded. I love history and that alone for me to see and walk the abbey was enough, but the charter house was closed and again the crowds didn't let you linger and enjoy the walk through. Perhaps they should be limiting the number of people they allow in at an one time. Not worth the price I think.

More of a mausoleum than a church. We'd heard about the splendor of Westminster Abbey so we decided to go. Twice we missed visiting due to their very limited visiting times. I've seen many cathedrals in Italy and I was a bit disappointed. More than half of the church is dedicated to crypts and graves. It's interesting from a historical perspective but I wouldn't go back. No pictures allowed of the fabulous stained glass windows.
A worthy visite. It is a bit expensive but you have to visite it. Lady's Chapelle is amazing and also the huge amount of famous people buried there

Favorite site. Amazing and beautiful. Don't miss it! I thought I would spend 20 minutes here and I was there for nearly 2 hours. Between the gothic architecture and the tons of interred remains of famous historical figures, there is plenty to see and learn.
Disappointing. Overall, overhyped experience: audio guides provide rudimentary historical context, and many group tours create overcrowded situations in tight spaces.

Great. This is extremely iimpressive in historical context but also the architecture. So many famous people buried here! You get a phone device that talks you thru the tour by number and you get to walk thru many areas. Not many ropes in the way. Take your time and enjoy, worth it!

My favorite in London. You have to see it, so much history, great place to learn about history of English Kingdom.Take audio tour and remember to bring some wipes to clean audio devise before you get it close to your face.

Magnificent Gothic Church. A trip to London would not be fulfilled unless you visit Westminster Abbey. Given it's history as a Benedictine Monastery and it's transformation to the current day, one can only marvel at the number of kings and queens entombed within plus the ornateness of the various crypts and the high altar. Very moving and the architecture truly wonderful.

Awed by ornate beauty!. We attended the "Evensong" service at Westminster Abbey during our stay in London. Evensong is a service sung almost entirely by the wonderful choir. When we entered the church my wife was stunned by the ornate beauty and even began to tear up. We were there for the service and the only cost is when they pass the collection plate. The Evensong services are usually in the evening but we were able to attend in the afternoon on a Sunday. As we left the church we marvelled at how old some of the tombs were. We even noticed the tomb of Sir Isaac Newton complete with a Sarcophafus or stone coffin that said he was buried there in 1727. The cathedral is truly beautiful as are the choir's voices, I would avoid the 18 pounds entrance fee and go to this instead. The service took a little over an hour.

Something Special. I am constantly amazed how these wonderful buildings were constructed hundreds of years ago. Really enjoyed the audio presentation around the abbey though once again a very busy and popular stop for tourists. Felt like we were walking in the steps of famous people.

A place so full of history.. What an experience. You need to allow plenty of time to explore Westminster Abbey so you have time to explore every nook and cranny the Abbey has to offer. There is no photographs allowed in the abbey but once in the cloisters you can take as many as you like. The Abbey is a must to do when visiting London.

A must see in London!. Westminster Abbey has a slight commercialized feeling in the entrance and its a bit hard to get past the £18 entrance fee, but once your really inside it's breathtaking. You don't feel rushed, you can take your time soaking in all the history. Sadly there are no photos allowed and you will get caught if you try to sneak.

A visit to Englands Kings, Queens and poets.. Westminster abby striked me as an important location in Englands history. The graves of the Kings and Queens of England show how important the abby is and has been to England for centuries.I specifically liked the audiotour wich gave lots of information about the abby, it's construction and the people that have their grave or Memorial in the abby.You actually learn something from it.So if you are interested in history, you should visit the abby.

Amazing. I cannot recommend this place enough, I was blown away by the amazing architecture. While visiting remember to look down to see all of the famous Britons who are buried or have memorial markers there. If you're in London I definitely recommend a visit.

Historic gem. Although not cheap (but that is London for you), for me this is a must do in London. It is one of those places steeped in history. Coronations, royal weddings and royal funerals as well as famous people being buried here. The free audio guide allows you to enjoy the art, church and the beautiful chapels at your own leisure and gives you all the info you need to appreciate its history.

A church and a museum.. The price of admission seems a bit expensive but the audio guide is included. While this is a church with on-going services I was suprised by the number of tributes to figures of distant and more recent history.

Majestic. This was one of the few things I wanted to see in London, and wasn't disappointed. I thought the entrance fee of £18 was expensive....until I got inside. The building itself is pretty awe inspiring..such a beautiful cathedral which holds so much history as well. The tomb of the unknown soldier is very poignant. No photos allowed, but great to just walk around and see the tombs of English Royalty, plus all the prominent thinkers dating back. There is just so much to see here. A really great experience.
Must see in London. Visit the Abbey on Sunday. You can join the services for free. I loved to listen the choir during the 3 pm Sunday Service

Amazing. One of the most impressive experienceIt is a lesson of history, full of emotionI've been in several other large and faimos cathedrals in Europe and USA but this was the best experience of this kind

Very interesting. We had cash (pounds) and the line was short to get in. The credit card line was quite long. Taking the self tour with the headset was really great. You went at your own pace and it gave a lot of detail.

Awesome!. Very neat place in London! Tons of history! An audio or guided tour is a must! Why walk through and not know what you are looking at? The lines were fairly long but we didn't wait long. Right line was for credit cards and left line was for cash... LondonPass holders can use either. Not much (anything) about the recent royal wedding on the audio guide, so it should be updated. I'm sure many go to the Abbey to see the site of the recent royal wedding! We had a great time at the Abbey and it was beautiful!
Certain ambiance. Really neat place. Went in and say though a bit of Sunday mass. Great building with a lot of history. A must see.
Westminster Abbey, London, England. A must see! Incredible history, tombs of major Monarchs. Be aware of your surroundings, very crowded and pick-pockets are very busy.

Do Use the Audio Guide. I was there in August 2013. Arrived early, around 9:30a and the line went down the sidewalk and well down the street. However, it moves quickly, so don't let that intimidate you. It took about 15 minutes to get inside. Once there, the audio guide made it all quite intimate and informative. The ancient history to see and study is remarkable and well worth taking the time to experience in this magnificent house of worship.

Impressive!. Beautiful building, lots of history there! A bit expensive, but worth it. Lots of important historic figures buried there - don't miss Sir Isaac Newton's tomb, right next to Darwin's! English audio guide narrated by Jeremy Irons - excellent!

Beautiful. Wow, so impressive. A must see. The free audio tour was a nice addition. The layout helped people move along from room to room. The alter is amazing. Many of the tombs are ornate and some date back to the 1200's.

Not to be missed. Westminster Abbey is a fascinating piece of architecture, as well as a most interesting review of History. The visit is very well organised with audio guides and clear indications. My two grandsons, aged 11 and 10, loved it and didn't miss a thing !The price of tickets for children and seniors is quite reasonable.

Centuries of history is buried here. Make sure you dedicate enough time to this place and it's better to be familiar with history of England. As there are buried kings and queens, along with scientists and some other famous figures. Such as Sir Isaac Newton, which I have the most respect among others.Also, use the provided audio guide and map when entering.

Beautiful building with so much history. So much history has occurred at Westminster Abbey. There are tombs of so many kings and queens. The carvings and statues in and around the building are beautiful. Definitely recommend this while in London.

EvenSong. We arrived late in the day, so we missed the tour opportunities. At the side of the building, people were entering. When we looked at the daily activities, noticed there was a service. This was beautiful to participate in. One of my unexpected highlights. We did walk around a little bit. It was beautiful. The gift shop offered a variety of items.
A unique chatedral.... Ticket is expensive, better to use London pass.I like the story of the king & queen of England...and their tombs are all over the place.
Must see in London. History lesson expanded. The atmosphere of standing on stones hundreds of years old and listening to Jeremy Irons was so culturely amazing. Loved it

Visit solo, but take a guided tour too!. We got there before midday and hesitated on whether to go for the guided tour (next one being at 2pm -2 hours later). We are glad we did both. We had the audible guide which was fine although some of the information minimal. However you can go at your own speed but you do miss things that the tour (only £3 p/p more) gives you. For example without the tour (from a witty Verger called Ben) we would have missed amongst other things 1) where the Abbey finished when Henry III ran out of money; 2) the marble casket where the bones of the Princes from the Tower are held; 3) Some of the Royal tombs (James 1st, William (III) and Mary plus the last King buried there (George II) 4) sitting in the Quire and seeing where HM sits 5) visiting Edward the Confessor's shrine and seeing where Kate & William signed the wedding register. Additionally we found out about the only tomb you cannot walk across the last body to be buried (now ashes) and who was the last interred. Worth every penny.

lots of history. My partner and I visited the abbey in June 3013 and had a great time. So much history and beautiful statues to see. I was surprised how many names I recognized on all of the stones. Worth a visit if you are in London even if you aren't religious.

Historical and Iconic. Westminster Abbey is one of London's must see attractions. As the audio guide states, the history of Westminster Abbey is the history of England. It was constructed in 1065: 27 kings and queens are buried within, along with the renown statesmen, poets, nobles. The building is so tall that chandeliers ten feet in height look small from the ground. Hours are M-F 9:30 to 4:30, Sat 9:30-2:30, closed on Sundays. The Underground stop is Westminster. The entrance is on east side of the Abbey. It is extremely crowded in the summer, and on Saturdays and Mondays. There are two lines, one for credit card, one for cash. The cash line moves much more quickly. The entrance fee is £18 for adults, and £32 per family (2 adults, 1 child). Children are under age 11 and are £11. We came with three children, ages 15, 11, and 9. However, because we did not bring their passports, we had to pay full price for all three kids, because (as the agent told us) they "looked big." Be prepared: bring passports. We ended up paying £68 for our family--- $100 to see Westminster Abbey.The audio tour, while good, can be difficult to understand with the background noise. We were literally moving in Brownian motion because it was so crowded: it was sometimes difficult to see the inscriptions beneath our feet. It is a hand-held guide with a mono earpiece insert. Because of the crowds, it was not possible to see any of the sights for more than a minute or two. The numbers that are referred to in the audio guide are also difficult to locate.Photography and video are forbidden inside the Abbey. Photography is allowed in the cloisters, a picturesque covered walk for monks linking Abbey buildings. Bathroom facilities are sadly inadequate. They are located in a small building outdoors near Poet's Corners. The ladies' bathroom was at least a 15 minute wait.

Historic and Sacred. It was everything I imagined. Beautiful, majestic, historic and inspiring. The tours are superb but you could also learn a great deal with the self guided audio tour. Be sure to allot enough time so you don't feel rushed and can take it all in. You'll be impressed with the vast amount of English history represented here. The tombs are really something to explore and give you a great sense of the traditions, culture, royalty and political presence regaled throughout the years. The cafe is good for a tea or light snack. Be sure to pick up something in the gift shop as a sweet reminder of the artistry of to beautiful masterpiece.

Don't miss this and use an audioguide.. Don't be put off by the long queue : it moves very fast.The interior of this abbey is magnificicent.Search for all the graves of famous kings, queens, scientists, writers etc.The audioguide is very good.We had scones in the restaurant and they were very good.Before we left, we heard part of a concert by the choir : very impressive.

Self-guided audio tour a must. The only reason I'm not rating this a 5 is because of the amount of people that were there. I've been before around the same time of year and it wasn't THAT busy. So it's just dumb luck. It's great, there is so much to learn and so much to see. It is awesome to see where such historical people have been laid to rest. It's beautiful and so rich with history. It's a MUST SEE. Maybe go first thing in the morning or last thing before it closes to avoid squeezing through everyone.
