Concert in the abbey gardens and Evening Prayer Service. We attended a lovely concert in the Abbey gardens music provided by the Merton Band who played a good selection of music from the Dambusters to Frank Sinatra it was a great afternoon there were plenty of refreshments all reasonably priced plenty of seating and tables to enjoy afternoon tea or bring your own picnic all free just a donation to the band fund .What a lovely relaxing afternoon .

Awesome. If you are someone who love history, then you are at right place. Keep at least 2 hours free to see this place as there is lot of information to imbibe. Self Audio tour is useful. London pass users do not need to purchase the ticket.

The stones sing with history. I consider the £18 entrance fee money well spent after I had taken the self-guided audio tour around this venerable edifice so it can be maintained in its splendour for future generations to enjoy. During my visit, I arrived at a far greater appreciation of British history which has inspired me to delve deeper into a subject that quite frankly bored me senseless at school. This is not just an English church, a Scottish Queen is buried here, and every country in the United Kingdom is represented in some shape or form. Kings, queens, statesmen, artists, poets, heroes and villains, they are all here, the embodiment of the centuries of history on our small island. To see the Coronation Chair, used to crown every monarch since William the Conqueror, sent tingles down my spine. One truly feels the deep presence of history here.The church wardens are eager to help and advise and share their knowledge of the Abbey, and there is even a fun interactive quiz sheet for younger children to feel involved. There are cafe and toilet facilities and a shop and you can easily spend a morning here.A must see for anyone coming to London on a visit.

Take The Verger Tour. When you visit Westminster Abbey - and you MUST - visit if you wish to understand London - be sure to take the Verger Tour for behind-the-scenes glimpses of the world's finest collection of medieval kings tombs dating back to the 12th century.

A true English Gem. Although payment is required, this is well worth a visit, so many famous people are buried there from the Kings, Queens,poets in poets corner to Admirals, Generals, Prime Ministers and of course the Unknown Warrior. The whole building is steeped in history and several hours are required to do it justice.

A must see - whatever the price. Yes, £18 is steep, the audio tour poor quality and which leaves a lot out - but if you can afford it do go if you have any interest in history. The queue for cash (rather than card payment) was much faster.The are so many that are not to be missed - the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, Henry VII, Elizabeth I and her cousin, who she executed, Mary Queen if Scots. But you will have your own checklist. It is worth researching the tombs you want to see. There is an A-Z list on the Abbey as well as other sites. I got bored with the superficial commentary so had to go back to find Henry V and Anne of Cleves.

Got a Certified Guide .. Great Tour. Locked ourselves into a certified London Attraction Tour Guide for the tour of Westminster Abbey.Best idea I have come up with in recent memoryThe guide (Steven) was able to make this tour informative without being too 'matter of fact'He was able to keep the 4 of us informed and engaged for 2 1/2 hours throughout the tour and we came away with a better understanding of what we were looking atIf you want to 'know' what your touring, get a certified guide.

Burial sight of Kings and Queens. Very impressed how this structure has survived over the years. Very beautiful and full of history. The audio guide is worth having. The audio gives you a nice overview of the different chapels.

Don't miss this!. We're not a religious family, but this was one of our favorite visits while in London! There is such an incredible amount of history. You must grab a device for the audio tour. The information it provides is fantastic. It was so much more than we expected. I honestly forget what we paid to enter, but whatever it was was worth every penny..... or pound!
Incredible structure. Again, I must say as I did with so many other structures. How did they build this thing? Buildings from yore go up and up and up. You just stand there and follow it to the sky.

definitely tour this attraction!. We went to Westminster Abbey at 4 p.m. and missed the last tour of the day (last tour entrance 3:30) but we stood in line for a half hour and got into Evensong at 5 p.m. for free. The inside of Westminster Abbey is phenomenal! The only part I didn't like was we weren't able to stop and look around, we were lead right into were Evensong (a church service) was performed, which is were the queens & kings are crowned and Prince William and Kate got married. I would highly suggest getting there in time for a tour, it costs 16 pounds.

Stunning architecture. Magnificent building - especially the Lady Chapel which came as a delightful surprise of airy and light after the soaring gothic of the main cathedral. Lovely irony - memorials to anti-church Robert Burns and Thomas Hardy in Poets' Corner !

Unexpected impressions. I do understand that this is out-of-to-be-discussed greatest memorial and sanctum place of London, but while being there I had feeling of cemetery but not Saint, Majestic and Historical place.Of course, too many merited persons were buried there - right, it should be. But in contrast to many other Temples with tombs inside (Holy Sepulcre in Jerusalem, Notre Dame de Paris, St.Vitus in Prague, St.John in Valetta) this one seemed to me to be free of sanctity. It is amazing but not heartfelt. Sorry, but it's my impression.

Too crowded.... I was excited to see this place; however, I found the Abbey too crowded both in the tourists that come into the church and its architecture that it took away all the enjoyment for me. No pictures are allowed inside.

Gorgeous. Loved walking throught the Abbey soaking up the history. Line ups can be long but move fast. Free audio giude worth grabbing, makes the stroll through far more interesting. Beautiful inside, worth a visit!

Amazing history matched by amazing entrance fee. There can be no doubting the important place that Westminster Abbey holds at the heart of the British establishment and the amazing feeling one gets when standing near the mortal remains of so many famous English kings and queens, as well as Mary Stuart and as numerous less well-known buy equally illustrious individuals. The whole place is steeped in history and tradition and clearly well worth the visit. My gripe is with the £18 entrance fee for all adults, which may be acceptable for foreign tourists but should be significantly reduced for UK taxpayers, and any children should go free. We had lunch in the adjacent Cellarium Cafe, which was a mixed bag: my wife's soup was excellent, if pricey, but it was impossible for me to have a plain scone, as the waiter regretfully told me that he would have to charge me the full whack for a cream tea, which includes 2 cream and jam laden scones and tea at £8. I settled for a pot of tea which at nearly £3 was exorbitant. Having visited Durham, St Albans, Lincoln, Norwich, Ely, Rippon and York cathedrals here in the UK, and numerous ones in Europe, Westminster Abbey left us less than enthusiastic, perhaps because of the expectations which were not fulfilled.

Abbey gets average rating..SHOCK!. looking forward to this one...waited only 3 mins in queue...good!Friendly security guard..good!£18 entrance fee...bad!Very crowded inside..g!Staff inside not so friendly...b!Very smug Jeremy Irons audio commentary..b!Everywhere OVERSTUFFED LIKE A HUGE JUNKSHOP...B!Gardens beautiful...not many people out there...g!Loved the cloisters...g!Could the gift shop be anymore expensive...b!A mixed visit...
Well worth a visit. Steeped in history with tombs of Kings, Queens, Statesmen and poets. Located beside Westminister Bridge, Big Ben and Government buildings. Lovely to stroll around outside too.

Go On Sunday, No Charge!. No one should visit London without going to Westminster Abbey. I recommend you go on Sunday and you can avoid the entry fee. This is place that no matter where you turn, one sees history through the graves and sculptors of those honored there, in a way only the United Kingdom can create. William Pitt, Sir Winston Churchill, William Shakespeare and Benjamin Disraeli along with many others buried here.I recommend you do go back on a weekday and pay the fee. You will need 2 to 3 trips to see it all and you will not regret it.
Tour of Westminster Abbey. This was an excellent tour. We really enjoyed it and learned a lot. So much history. We didn't know that there are so many famous people buried there.

A Must While Visiting London!. Visiting Westminster Abbey is something not to be missed. It's steeped in history, the architecture is stunning and the famous historical figures buried there is fascinating! Our family of four elected to pay the 3 pound fee to go on a Verger led tour within the Abbey and it's worth every penny to learn about the history from an employee of the Abbey -- there are not more than 20 people in a group and you also get access to places in the Abbey that general admission does not allow.

you had to PAY!!. I cant believe you have to pay to get into this place. Even Notre Damn cathedral in Paris is free!
Its a shame because these places are beautiful and everyone should get to see it. They must be raking it in!!

Evensong lovely way to enjoy Westminster abbey and its free. Make sure to research schedule but for the most part daily at 5pm. A mini mass (minus communion) mostly sung by the boys choir, however, occasionally a visiting choir replaces the boys. Just amazing. First fifty in line sit with the choir, the rest on folding chairs. A lot of kneeling and sitting during the service. On a Friday, we arrive at 4 and were first in line. The let us in at 4:30 and are queued inside till 5. The service is about an hour. Make sure to be dressed properly for entry.While you can see how beautiful the abbey is, you are restricted to the choir area. This was a highlight for me
May '13. Excellent spot and very interesting. Only problem is the audio tour isn't that easy to follow. Nice architecture too.

Worth a visit. A beautiful structure that is filled with history. There is a charge to visit. However, you can attend the afternoon prayer service with no charge on a weekday. It is closed on Sundays to touring. Since we were there on a Sunday, and wanted to see it, we found that there is a free organ recital in the late afternoons on Sunday. You wait on line and then gain free entrance to the Cathedral and also get to attend a pleasant organ recital. The Cathedral should definitely be visited on your trip to Londaon

Oh Dear. We would have loved to have visited this Abbey. It represents hundreds of years of our country's history. Unfortunately the queues were enormous and im afraid I object to paying an entrance fee to look around what is essentially a church. Wont be going here again until they change to a donation system (like the museums).

An amazing must do!. This is one of the most amazing places I have ever visited. If you are into history, literature, politics or just the famous this is the place to go. My 10 year old was just blown away with the view from the outside at the entrance! Both the 10 and 9 year old are fascinated by Queens and Kings so to see the tombs of some of the most famous made their day. There are so many tombs, burial plaques and memorials you are able to move a few feet without being intrigued. It is a little expensive but worth every penny.

Was too late for a tour.. Went to Westminster Abbey, arrived just a couple of minutes late for the last tour of the Abbey, was a shame, but outside looked stunning, walked around the grounds, even got a picture of the Abbey, shame I couldn't go inside.

Should've listened to Rick Steves. We should have heeded the advice in our guide book to go around lunchtime for shorter lines! We went first thing in the morning (and so did everyone else) and stood in a very long line, in the rain. We spent the whole morning inside though (there was so much to learn!) and when we got outside, around lunchtime, not only had the rain stopped, but the lines were indeed less than half the size of the morning rush. Completely worth it as a history and literature buff though.

Great place, no toilet.... The cathedrall is amazing and you really have a lot to see and learn. The only bad thing is that there isn't any bathroom in all the cathedrall (and the place is huge) and the only one at the exit, at the entry of a Cafe says for clients of the Cafe only and it invites you to go to a public bathroom opposite to the cathedrall where you don't have any directions to reach it and you have to pay to use it anyway.

Pricey but nicey. 18 quid to get in at the time of writing.I didn't want to buy shares in the place.... A great building with great history. Helpful staff, and we ate in the Abbey's cafe. Good, tasty food, and just the right portion size...If you want to hear the choir, get there 40 minutes before the service to queue up/get a decent seat.

British History Central. Westminster Abbey is a London landmark that should not be missed by those who like British royal history. Like most London tourist stops, the $20 entrance fee (give or take a few dollars depending on age or if you have a student discount) is a little steep, but it was worth it for me.There is a "free" (included in entrance fee) audio guide that takes you to points all throughout the abbey and explains the history and/or significance of that point. Following the guide gives you about a 2 hour tour of the abbey. It is unlike other European cathedrals or churches, which I wasn't expecting, with its cross shape and many nooks and little outlet rooms full of ornate memorials and tombs.

For those who like royal history. A must to see while in London. Audio guides in different languages available. Be prepared for crowds of people together with you so will not be easy to see every piece of abbey. Anyway really interesting to see. After 30-40 minutes you feel like visiting just famous cemetery getting tired of all royal details and descriptions. As for me 30 minutes were enough for brief acquainting with abbey. The main reason was to show this place to my kid who was first time in London.

Awesome Walk through British History. This must be the world's most significant gathering/memorial to the who's who of British history! Such a gathering of famous monarchs, poets, statesmen, inventors, scientists, artists etc is both staggering and breath-taking!If there is one famous church you may visit please make it this awe-inspiring treasure. The architecture is also spectacular and adds to the sheer grandeur of the place.The audio-tour is well worth the effort as it brings things to life as do the many, well-informed attendants scattered throughout the Abbey. They give generous added information when asked and are a credit to the place. It was also inspiring to hear the admiration and respect one man attendant had for the Royal Family.

Really? You need a recommendation to go to Westminster Abbey?. OK. Here goes. If you are anywhere near Westminster Abbey and skip it, you'll be doing yourself a disservice. Simple as that.The building itself is impressive and beautiful. But not more so than similar churches around Europe. If you've seen the Cathedral in Cologne or Il Duomo in Milan you'll find yourself shrugging your shoulders just a little.It's not the architecture that should draw you there. It's paying your respects to the great and good that are interred at the place. Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton, Auden and Carroll and so many others are there and it's just the right thing to stop by and say hi.And after you've done all that, go back to the nave and look for the largest and most conspicuous of all the graves. You will find a very large, very black square, right where you would expect to find the most important figure in all of English history. And right there you will find the tomb of the unknown solider. With no name and no rank, he was brought back from the killing fields of Europe to be buried with the highest honors that a grateful nation can bestow. Stop there for a second and bend your head.Keep in mind, regardless of what the guides and the website says, Westminster Abbey stops granting access a full hour before it closes and the lines are very long. Get there early.

Incredible history. It was awe inputting to go to s place that housed so many historical English events such as the coronations ,marriages and burials of famous and historical figures -- the architecture was amazing as well

Not bad. We had a nice experience at the Abbey. The queue was not that long although it was summer and our entrance was smooth. Its good to have a free audio guide included with the ticket price, although we thought the price was very expensive for what you get to see inside. There is a lot of history and culture and inspiring architecture. There is a lovely garden in the abbey too, very relaxing.It was very noisy inside however. Being at the Notredame Cathedral in Paris was a better experience, that cathedral was so quiet and gives you room to reflect, but this wasn't the case at the abbey.Considering the price, wouldn't very much recommend unless you are into these things, which I was, but my family wasn't.

Worth the Wait!. Our first attempt to visit the Abbey, we passed because of the huge line to get tickets. Next day, we were sure to get there earlier! Though pricey, a trip to the Abbey is just amazing--the history in this one building covers centuries of politics, science, art and literature. Just wish I could have taken photos--the post cards at the end were really a disappointment!

Great visit. We loved Westminster Abbey. They have a good audio tour included with your entrance fee. Very interesting and a beautiful place to see. We really wanted to book a verger led tour but couldn't . That would have been a great experience--we listened to one going on near us. Do that your if you can. The visit is worth the wait in line.

Beautiful Church. Long queues to get inside. Waited over an hour to get in. Very worth it to see this beautfull and iconic church. Disappointed that once inside we could not take any photos. I understand that services are being conducted throughout the day, but would have appreciated being able to take non flash photos.

Spectacular and so foreign. We arrived on a Monday about 40 minutes before the church opened and joined the lines of people waiting to get in. Had pleasant chats with fellow tourists from around the world. Arrive early since by the time we left, the church was packed!So foreign to our experiences as Americans--a state religion, burying important figures in a church, spending millions on gilt and impressive spectacles to impress others. A must see, but am glad I am an American where church and state aren't so interteined!

Inspiring experience. Rather than going on a tour, we attended the weekday evening Evensong service. This is a great way to experience Westminster Abbey. The service will largely feature choir singing, Old Testament and New Testament readings, and an affirmation of faith. It is a simple but meaningful experience. There is no charge and no offering but it is a service - not a visit or tour and the crowd, although full of tourists, honored and respected the service. The service begins at 5:00 pm but you need to get there 45 minutes to one hour early to get a good seat. Don't worry - it is worth the wait. You will feel renewed and inspired for the rest of the evening.

Staff rude. While in London we wanted to see all the sights. When we arrived at Westminster it was 3.25 and it was already being closed quite abruptly by staff. We had travelled quite a bit and it was disapointing

A Must do!. yes, there are lines (2 different ones for which payment method so be sure you are in the right one) but the lines go really fast. We lined up about 45 minutes before opening and there were already about 50-60 people in front of us. They opened a little before 9:30 and we got in and got our tickets by 9:32 (time stamp from the ticket itself). Beautiful inside, we got an audio tour which was a little long and boring but all in all, the inside is worth seeing.

go to the concert. We arrived in time to hear the free Sunday evening organ concert. Come early as there were people in line that didn't get in. No photos or recording while inside - bummer, but understandable. Too bad you can't take photos of the inside of the Abbey. You could photograph the section as we were herded out. If you miss the Sunday concert, its done again on Tues. for a fee.

big queues. wpuld have loved to have gone in here, very majestic but queues were quite long and didnt have time to see everything that london has to offer. when i go back this is the first place i will visit. very beautiful on the outside, cant even begin to imagine what the inside is really like, nothing like on the tv, i can guarantee this, what a sense of history.

An absolute must. Awesome.. This was a fabulous start to our 5 day stay in London. Well worth it. Glad we got there early, even then waited 20 minutes as the line was long, and it was school holidays. Had a free audio guide which was great. The history is palpable and it is truly magnificent. We were not slow but it still took about an hour and a half.

Well worth the queue!. 1) If the queue doesn't go out of the fenced area do take the time to wait - go early. 2) There is a LOT to see and some of it unfamiliar to non-Brits so do use the audio guide but fast forward too - you can! 3) Do ask the volunteers any question you wish, they are interested in helping you and for the entry price of £18 per adult you may as well take full advantage. 4) Do visit the cloisters and other areas around the main building and reserve a couple of hours minimum. 5) Do try and get to the Cellarium Cafe before noon - with little in the way of hostelries nearby, this is an excellent stop for sandwich or small lunch and much needed coffee. All in all every reason to be a popular tourist destination.

You have to see this!. Westminster Abbey is one of those must-do's in London. It is beautiful and overwhelming. The audio guide was great, and we spent so much time just wandering around marvelling. It is always busy in there, so be prepared to be a bit squished in certain areas, and we did this with the London Pass so skipped the main queue which was definitely a good thing! Lots to see and appreciate, just beautiful.

My favorite visit. Standing in Westminster I felt moved to a timeless place. There's so many iconic people buried here, kings, queens, along with the writers and leaders of the past, that you can't help but feel the weight of history as you move about. People are quiet, and there are moments of prayer and reflection periodically, both announced and private.

A lot of history. This place is amazing. Get here early by 9 am or so before the lines get too long. Try to get to one of the walks with a guide. If you can't the recorded guide was pretty good as well. It is very well organized.

Overwhelming. Even if we used the London pass to skip the long lines, there also was a queue for the pass.
Beautiful church, outside architecture is amazing, the history inside is overwhelming.
Everywhere you turn, there is a tomb of a notable figure from England's history.
The audio guide is very informative and easy to use.

A must see in London. So much history is here, and not only government and religious history. English poets, writers and other famous people are buried here.
Buy your tickets in advance and take a real tour.

Must see. This is absolutely fantastic place, every inch is full of history and included audiguide brings a lot of interesting information. If you have a possibility choose Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday and after abbey excursion you'll have a chance to walk in The Gardens of Westminster (they are open just on these days). You'll see trees planted in 1850! and in summer time at 12-30 band concerts are held in the Garden, so that could be a very good bonus to your lunch on the grass (you could bring it with you or buy here).

A Walk Through History and The Church. This amazing Cathedral oozes history and one could spend an entire day exploring the tombs, art and religious importance. The historical importance prior to the Reformation is outstanding. We were able to attend a brief prayer service at the oldest altar in the cathedral. We enjoyed having the Audio guide and took full advantage of exploring the grounds and taking tea in the Cellarium Café...the lemon tea Cake is quite lovely!

Better than I expected. We loved Westminster Abbey. We had read to be there early and that is the truth; the line builds quickly. There are two lines, one for cash and London Pass holders and the other for credit cards. The cash line seemed to move more quickly. The audio tour provided is excellent. It was very crowded so be prepared for that (at least in the summer). Our teenage daughters really enjoyed the Abbey as well.

History at your feet.. If you go to London, you MUST got to Westminster if you care anything at all about British history. We especially enjoyed the area (the Chapter House?) with the stained glass windows that were redone after being blown out during WWII. Their was a guide there who told us the story of the windows, that the woman who made them slipped in some "extras", scenes from WWII, including airplanes, soldiers and guns. He particularly pointed out one window and said he was told it was a picture of the Queen greeting the troops. My camera was able to capture the image up close and sure enough, it was as he had been told. He was thrilled to finally see it!

Breathtaking. A very stunning building and representation of fine architecture that can never be tested. The lands are beautiful, but the location of the entrance can be hard to find, but even without going inside can be well worth the trip up to see it.
Amazing. Royals and other famous figures are buried here. The Kings and Queens are inaugurated here and you can see exactly where it takes place. The audio tour is very helpful.

Worth the wait. The place is amazing. I can not imagine one building with more history packed into it. Tips: Get there early. Expect crowds. Leave at least 2 hours for a full tour. Don't rush. Savour it. Have your eyes open, everywhere you turn there is something of interest. Use your London Pass and save money. As with most places in London paying as you go is NOT Cheap. It would have cost us GBP42 to visit (two adults and two kids)Remember, this is a place of worship. Conduct yourself accordingly.

Finding the front can be confusing. There are many signs for Westminster Abbey, but finding the front can be a bit confusing because of how it's located. The first think you'll see is St. Margarets church and the Abbey is behind it. Follow the road where the Parliament is (so it's to your left) and the Abbey will be on your right.

A Cornerstone of English Christianity. From the 10th century onwards this magnificent Abbey has seen countless episodes of world changing history, from Edward the Confessor, Henry III and escaping Henry VIII and his wholesale destruction of the monastic tradition. We attended to visit various family monuments In the Abbey side chapels, however most visitors on that day seemed to consist of foreign tourists looking for Shakespeare ( most unaware of the other important memorials around them ). The staff on the entrance desk looked bored and uninterested whereas the chap handing out the headset guide ( narrated by Jeremy Irons ) was a little too familiar. All in all this is a must for visitors to Westminster, especially for English people who perhaps have not taken must interest in their heritage. £18 entrance for Adults, avoid the cramped and unfriendly cafe in the Cellars, not the best hospitality.

Loved it!. This was one of our favorite sights on our European vacation. We were disappointed that we couldn't go on one of the verger tours (they don't offer them for a 2 hour period near lunch), but the audio guide was very good. During summer expect to wait to get in. We showed up an hour after it opened and waited at least hour to get it in. There are two seperate lines, one for credit card and one for cash. Make sure you get in the correct one because signs weren't visable from the back of the line. The place was beautiful and absolutely facinating. We spent at least 2 hours once we were in and loved every minute.

evensong. couldn't afford the fee so decided to go for evensong instead. you cant go round at this time but it was amazing .. seated way up by the high altar .. 45 mins of pure joy .. large donation box as you walk out which we used but so many did not which was a shame as we all got in free of charge .. Don't be put off by the queues .. we arrived about 4.14pm and we queueing on the third street nearly back on the main road but thought we would give it a go .. needn't have worried 30 mins later looks like we all got in .. you wait down one side until choir practice has finished and then we were seated .. what we did see while waiting was fabulous .. all the composers buried there and much more .. cant praise it enough .. will go back at a later date with lots of money and have a proper look xx

Celebrity Grave Yard. Didn't queue for very long and was greeted by a very friendly priest. The place is steeped in history and a must visit if in the area. As my title suggests, the majority of the visit is spend wandering around the tombs of the great and good, a little bit creepy but intriguing nonetheless!

History by the bucket load.... In a nutshell; - you will queue, but its worth it- according to one member of abbey staff mondays are the busiest days, 7000 people visit!- cash and credit cards are different queues check you are in the right one- you can download the audio guide in advance to get your barings before you start and use it instead of the supplied headset- food in the cafe is very pricey, even by Londons standard- childrens trail is good- remember to look up as well as down!

Amazing - go to Evensong. I had a day visiting London and was really annoyed that I had left Westminster Abbey until last and it was shut. However, Evensong was on and so I went to that and so got in for free. Not idea as I couldn't look around properly but you got to see everything you needed to. It was awesome singing in the abbey too that's so full of history.

Timing is everything. We first got there about 9:30a and it looked to be about an hour wait to just get in the door. Went back around 3:00p and walked right in. Lot of info to digest. Wished I could be buried there or at least have a marker put in the floor.

Beautiful & Stunning. It was very busy when we went and the queue was approx 30 mins. I visited the abbey with my 4 children with different age ranges. The younger ones were occupied by the kids trail activity book they give free! This taught us a few things too. The abbey is stunning & so interesting. It took us about 1hr 30mins to go round. It was a little pricey but we felt for the history it is steeped in & just how beautiful it was the price was worth it. I'd recommend if anyone wants to know the history about kings & queens. But feel once you've been no need to return.

wow!! amazingly beautiful,huge and full of history!!. This was my 3rd trip to London and my first trip to Westminster Abbey. What a truly magnificent building! I was astounded by the sheer size of it especially how high the beautiful ceilings were inside,it took my breath away.I found the staff very welcoming and friendly.i really loved the little side chapels which housed the tombs of some of the famous kings and queens,ie elizabeth I. The architecture has to be seen as it is too truly breathtaking.A lovely long walk up "the aisle" where Prince William and Kate Middleton were married to the high altar was beautiful.You can feel the history of the abbey and imagine the coronations and royal weddings of the past. Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer DID NOT marry in Westminster Abbey,they married in St Pauls Cathedral.I couldn't believe i had never visited before,i can't wait to visit again.Children under 11 years admission is free which is great if you have a few children.A family ticket is round £36.00 .adults around £18.00 each.Money well spent for such a breathtaking place,I wanted to stay longer as there was so much more to see!!!

See all the famous people from British history buried there.. This was the second time I have visited and is a must for anyone visiting London. The history lies not only in the architecture, but in all the tombs and markers in it. Besides famous royalty, there are sections for authors, actors, ballet dancers. It is a who's who of British history. We hired a private guide who whisked us through a back entry and told us many, many of the stories behind the people in the tombs (how Cromwell's head was put on a spike and his bones distributed among the streets of London). It was also fascinating to see where the royal weddings and coronations took place. Definitely worth hiring a guide (we arranged one through our hotel) to hear all of the stories.

Incredibly detailed interior, audio guide great with details. Jeremy Irons voice on the audio guide is a nice touch. There are so so many monuments and graves and tombs in the abbey that it makes your head spin a bit, this is definately worth the line outside and visiting is a must. So ornate and costly to build but worth every penny. The gardens are also really pretty.

very expensive. It cost 18.00 an adult to get in which for a church is very expensive as alot normally free. Inside you are not allowed to take photo's which again is disappointing. Interesting to see everything inside but alot of money for the privilege of doing it.

Very good full of history. If you intend to visit Westminster Abbey I suggest as visit out of season. We visited in August, and there was a long queue to get in. However once inside and equipped with the audio guide, you could wander around the recommended way at you leisure listening to the commentary, and digest the history of this beautiful building.I felt the entry fee was a little high. Considering the RC Cathedral further up the road is free entry

how could you possibly miss this?. I have been there, every so often, since I was six years old. It was fascinating then, and is fascinating now. A few years ago I thought "been there, done that", and decided to skip the Abbey. While wondering around on foot, I found myself very close to it and decided that I couldn't just walk by. The impromptu visit was a reminder that there will always be something else to discover about it. This year I went again, with only one day in London. The visit was worth every moment.

One of my favourites. The first time I walked in to Westminster Abbey I was completely overwhelmed by how stunning it is. It was on the top of my 'to do again' list on my latest trip to London. It really is the most beautiful, wonderful building. There is so much to look at and learn about, I'm a big fan of English history, especially when it comes to the Royals so I think that makes it even more enjoyable for me - but there are plenty of other tombs and memorials celebrating some amazing people. The audio guide is good, I'd also recommend private tour if possible. I know this is something I'll be looking into next time. I was behind a family doing a guided tour and the man showing them around was great. I didn't spend quite as much time as I would have liked on this visit but it was really, really busy (much busier than my first visit) and I was just a little tired of being bumped into. You have to go at least once!
Odd shrine. I was surprised by Westminster Abbey. It was different seeing it for myself. I thought it was like a shrine to many past people of importance in English History.

More than a church. We saw churches in Germany, Austria, France, Belgium, Switzerland but this one surprise us by all the little details you have to see. You have to go in a specific way by folowing everybody but it worth the slowly flow because there is always tons of people visiting the church where Prince Charles and lady Diana got married. What mainly got my attention was all the little rooms where well known King and Queen are exposed in there close coffin. The height of the celling is awsome and when you look closely you have the impression that gold is shining on the ceilling buy we've been told that it is like crystal reflecting the lights that does that effect wow we were inpress. So if you have 2 hours to spent it fully worth the time to visit and go early in the morning to avoid the 2 hour wait line.

Spectacular. Pictures don't do it justice! The Abbey is spectacular! Being inside is almost a spiritual experience, you really can't help but think about how much history has happened in this building, from the Royal Wedding to coronations for the last 1000 years. The art and architecture inside is beautiful. The tombs of many notable historical figures are inside, like Charles Darwin, Winston Churchill, and Elizabeth I. Most of the tombs are beautiful. The audio guide was a little annoying, but still informative. The lines are really long pretty much all day. I would recommend arriving 15-30 mins before the Abbey opens (9:30 am when I was there) to be near the front of the line. You don't have to wait as long and the Abbey is less crowded inside. Definitely a must-see in London!

fall in love with it again and again.... I have visited Westminster 3 times! And every time I visit it I fall in love with it again and again… The history behind it, the glass work in the inside chapel, the tombs, everything there is so overwhelming it just leaves you speechless. The audio guide provided is very helpful and easy to follow with the map provided with it. It is like a time machine; takes you back in time. You can spend atleast 3 to 4 hours here. The first time I went here was the very next day of the royal wedding in 2011, and it was beautiful inside as the plants that were brought for the wedding were still there also got a chance to see the bridal bouquet that was kept near the tomb of the unknown soldier with the poppy flowers. The queue to get inside was a very long one but it was worth the wait.I would suggest you go there early, around 9 or 10 there is lesser crowd, make sure if you have only cash you are in the cash line and not the card line and vice versa. Tourists with London pass also have to be in the same queue there is no priority entrance with London pass in this site There is a senior citizen (over 60) discount as well. When I visited in July this year the entrance fee was 18 pounds and for senior citizen it was 15 pounds. You have to buy the ticket at the site unlike most attractions you cannot buy the tickets online. The abbey is closed for visitors on Sunday.

Magnificent architecture and stained glass. It was a dream come true to finally see this church for myself after having seen it on television on so many occasions, the last one being the Royal Wedding. The architecture and the stained glass are awe inspiring. So much history lives here. At the same time, it is very much an indoor cemetery, which is odd. We arrived before opening and there was already a line up. We chose the cash line, which moved quickly once the doors opened. We used the audio guides which were informative, easy to manipulate and useful to complete the children's trail. It took us at least two hours to complete the questionnaire with the kids and we could have stayed longer to do the entire audio tour. However, once we completed the children's trail, the kids had had enough and were looking forward to receiving their reward: a chocolate coin. I believe we got to see the most important areas and significant artifacts. The staff was also very helpful. But as other reviewers have mentioned, it was very crowded and this was sometimes frustrating when walking around. This is a definite must-do while in London. Try going early to avoid the crowds.

Beautiful - must see. I went to a Sunday morning service. It's incredible architecture in there. I think they have a couple services on Sunday that anyone can attend. Try to get there early so you can see the fantastic choir. Please don't wear shorts and a t shirt.

Historically significiant. Spectacular. An absolute most see and experience. So much history don't pass it up. This place was very high on my wife's list when we went to London. I now understand why. Loved the time I spent in this surreal place.

Expensive, but Worth It. The price of visiting Westminster Abbey has soared since I last visited 8 years ago. At over £20 per person, it's not a cheap outing, but I try to bear in mind that the abbey does not receive public funding and relies upon visitor support to continue running smoothly.Your admission price includes a self-guided tour that you can hold to your ear and a map of the abbey. Once inside, you have the opportunity to see the graves of Charles Darwin, Issac Newton, Geoffrey Chaucer, Elizabeth 1st, and many other monarchs. Cenotaphs honoring Shakespeare and other artists are found in Poet's Corner. Don't miss the stunning Lady Chapel built by Henry VII.It is important to note that the visiting hours are inconsistent, so be sure to check the opening times a few days before your visit to ensure that you won't miss out. Plan on spending a few hours for a detailed visit.

Captivating. One of the most interesting buildings I have ever visited, so much history in one place, yes it's fairly expensive, but worth it, the audio guide is great and simple to use and included in the admission price. fascinating to see the burial place of Elizabeth I and many others. If you like history you'll love it here.

Walk in Time - A Visit with the Past. Westminister Abbey is probably the quintessential London tourist attraction - so much history happened there - every coronation since the 11th Century, and many of the big English names are buried there too - Isaac Newton, Darwin, Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots, Chaucer - the list is endless! While not a big fan of viisting churches, this one seems to have surprises at every turn and kept my interest piqued through the time spent - if we weren't under a time crunch I could have stayed far longer!

Nice Visit. There is an entrance line for cash and another line for credit, so it’s helpful to have both payment options available so you can pick the shorter line. The day we visited the cash line was shorter and moved more quickly. The audio guide was really helpful for touring and it was easy to select the specific sections you wanted to listen to. The only downside on our visit was the crowds.

The most important gothic church. It is a wonderful church built almost 800 years ago,is full of very interesting chapels and artifacts.You can spend several hours and always find something special.You can almost see the pictures of many historic events before your eyes. The price is high,but don't hurry,take in what you see and enjoy.

Although didn't go inside, it's worth it outside. Beautiful building and surrounding area. The clock and the tower bridge can be seen when you are in the area. Just be careful when crossing the streets, traffic flows different from that of the US.

unbelievable history.. If you're visiting London, surely a visit here is on your "to do " list. Remarkable history. Friendly informed docents. If you show interest, they show even more knowledge. Take your time here: can easily spend half a day. For young kids they have ways to keep them entertained looking for itmes as the adults take it all in.
Sad. All I can say is there must be enough visitors willing to pay the extortionate entry [price that they don't need more! We certainly didn't pay for two pensioners and a child. Disappointed.

Fascinating and awe-inspiring. I watched the programme on tv about the abbey, so my husband took me there as part of my birthday present. We arrived early and did queue for a while, but it was worth the wait. We opted for a verger led tour and were so glad that we did. You can see parts of the abbey not open to other visitors and our guide (Ben) was excellent, both witty and well-informed. We felt that we would have liked to stay after our tour and take more time looking, but unfortunately were due somewhere else! However we went back to evensong and found it an uplifting and very special experience. You should allow most of a day if you want to see everything properly, so although the price seems high it is actually good value in terms of time spent and enjoyment. I don't know how anyone could fail to be moved by such a wonderful building, both as a piece of our heritage and a tribute to God.
Wonderful history. Long wait but worth it. Beautiful. We really did enjoy our journey here. Easy to get to from the tube. Worth the time and money really. No cameras and very peaceful.
Speachless. I cannot even put into words the spectacular sites and amazing history in Westminster Abbey. An absolute when visiting London.

So much history. We were blown away by the scale of Westminster Abbey. The lines were daunting when we arrived but after asking a helpful guard we got in the cash only line (credit card line moves much slower apparently) and were inside within 25 minutes using our London Passes. It's breathtaking to when you first walk inside and continues to impress all the way through. My wife has an ancestor who supposedly has a memorial statue inside, so we asked one of the volunteers who had a book and looked up his name for us, and sure enough he told us exactly where the statue was and we found it not far from the entrance. The included audio guide (narrated by Jeremy Irons!) is very informative and there is plenty to keep you busy for a good couple of hours. Seeing the tombs of previous monarchs is a particularly haunting experience. A must-see in London.

Simply amazing!. Can't believe I have never visited before! Westmiinster abbey is rich with history and the free audio guides are excellent (the english version is read by Jeremy Irons!). I would recommend a good 3 to 4 hr visit here as there is just so much to see. The history attached to Westminster Abbey is almost overwhelming from Edward the Confessor to the last royal wedding. My 10 year old daughter absolutely loved it and as her admisson was free was really good value for us. Just go, you'll love it.

History & More--A Must See. Be sure to take the time ( I spent almost 4 hours) in Westminster Abbey. Get there early and line up in the cash queue since it moves faster than the credit / debit card line. There is a wonderful audio guide included in the ticket price; take your time and wander around, sit in the pews and admire the architecture, ceiling and imagine yourself there for a wedding or other such ceremony. There is a museum, you can walk through the cloisters and have lunch or a cup of tea in the cafe. Westminster Abbey is a must see/visit London attraction for anyone interested in history and architecture.

gorgeous-long wait but worth it. very beautiful-very easy to follow and informative audio guide. 12 and 14 year old children enjoyed as much as we did. Long line for a Saturday morning but worth it-I suggest going to a tour when first opens at 9:30 in the morning-closing time is early afternoon. very pretty, very peaceful and no cameras!

Go to a piano recital if you can!. My husband and I stepped into Westminster Abbey due to rain just as a well-time piano concert was starting. What a wonderful serendipitous experience! We would've made a point to do this if we would've known what a nice relief from busy sightseeing it would be. If you can take a moment to rest your tired tourist feet and catch a recital, you won't regret it.

Beautiful. Fabulous building, a must see if visiting London however expect to pay high admission rates and a long que to get in! It costs about £20 for each adult and children go free. We got there at about 10am and the que on each side was about an hour long! It opens at 10 so go early to avoid the wait!

A FASCINATING EXPERIENCE. I could hardly drag myself away - the richness of the history on offer is a wonderful feast. As well as the large and very impressive tombs and monuments, there are also some more hidden gems - for instance, the fact that Anne of Cleves, despite having suffered the ignominy of rejection by Henry VIII, is the only one of his wives to be buried in this great cathedral. I would no doubt have found more fascinating detail had I had even more hours to spend there. Definitely worth a first, second, and third visit!

Breathtaking.. I cannot believe I was not here before. I should have visited this gem sooner. The stained glass windows are unreal, so many famous peoples graves are in this Abbey. Fantastic looking building in every way. I will have to go back again. Brilliant for the history and the expance of the building is like no other. One would have to go , again and again!

Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey was a real treat. I’ve walked by and photographed the exterior on previous trips to London, but until now have never entered. The architecture is amazing and the history and prominence of the place cannot escape you. Be sure to visit the adjoining “Church House” grounds and square.

Wow, such an amazing building. Couldn't wait to visit Westminster Abbey and I was not disappointed, it is such a beautiful building.The history involved is breathtaking.Used the audio guide for information on the best way to see most of the abbey and it was very good. Only bug bear was no audio info on Henry the fifth tomb and Eleanor of Castile also.If you love history, this is a must do.

A True Highlight. I was surprised by Westminster Abbey. I expected it would be packed iwth tourists and much like many other churches I've seen in my travels, but in fact, it was not remotely underwhelming. My friends and I were in London in April, just days before the wedding of Kate and Wills. We visited the Abbey towards the end of the day, just before closing time. There were no crowds--honestly it felt like we had the place to ourselves. There are soooooo many famous people buried here--you can hardly move around without stepping on some important persons grave. It really is facsinating. The staff was very helpful, polite, and friendly, as well. Do not miss this stop on your itin in London!

A must see. Beautiful.. This is an absolutely MUST SEE site. Unfortunately, we had to wait in line for approximately 2 hours before it opened but found free wifi from one of the buildings across the street. This building is beautiful and rich with history. Cannot imagine a visiting London and not stopping in for a visit. Definitely get the audiotour. Worth the few extra pounds. Allow enough time to visit the cloisters and surrounding grounds. I was on a 1 hour time limit once I entered the Abbey and it wasn't enough time. 2 hours should be more than enough.
historyhistoryhistory. tremendous amount of history here. take your time and enjoy taking in all the details here. this will be where charles or william will be coronated.

Don't expect a quick glimpse - this is such an historical wonder. You need some hours!. I first visited Westminster Abbey many years ago. I thought that I would just "pop in for a short reflection" on this trip. Well, some hours later I left "the building". Westminster Abbey has many areas. This building has stood for hundreds of years and Kings and Queens, knights, nobility and historical figures are buried or honoured here. This is a working church too. If your visit coincides with a church service, you are welcome to be a participant. At the conclusion of your viewing, you can eat a very tasty meal on the Terrace or in the main restaurant. So, if you are interested in British History, this is well worth a visit.

Walking through History. Awe inspiring visit to an Abbey that houses centuries of history. Get there early to que up for the opening. Crowds begin forming to que 30 minutes prior to entry. You cannot buy tickets ahead of time. A must see stop while in London.

Beautiful place to pray. The statues and memorials are impressive but what makes this place special is something that your ticket price can not buy.Evensong is not a concert or performance but something to join in with! Go to a service and engage with the real purpose of this wonderful building.Then light a candle, ask a verger to show you the way to Saint Faith's chapel and find a moment of solitude in a very busy abbey.You pay to go in as a tourist but go there to pray and it's free.
Beauty and history. Probably one of the most expensive visit in a church of any kind. But if you wan't to see that Landmark and walk into history...you pay. A major attraction, by all standards.

So much history!. This was fascinating. We went by the Abbey mid-day and there was a fairly good crowd. We arrived 1.5 hours before closing and walked right in. We had audio tours that explained the history inside. This was very interesting and a great experience for all of us.

Superb, must do when in London. Visiting this beautiful cathedral was an outstanding part of our London trip. It is so much more than a gorgeous church, rich in history and culture. We were staying nearby in Waterloo and had noted large line ups during the peak times. We elected to walk over early and be in line at just after 900 fro the 930 opening. Lines form at north doors. What a great decision! There were only about 20 persons there and lines are split depending on passes and modes of payment. By the time we entered there were two long lines........We had London Passes so were in the cash line. Once the doors opened it was quickly in with the pass and we were on the tour. The audio sets they provide free are great and run you through a lot of history. Very educational. We toured the entire Abbey and everything it had to offer. We noted that by 1030 the place was getting very busy and where we strolled alone an hour before among 10 people was now jammed up. We were very pleased with our decision to go early as it allowed for a quality visit. If you can, go first thing and you'll be rewarded. As I said in the title, this is a London must do. If you are in a time pinch, go early and you could easily see it in a couple hours without crowds. Enjoy!!

Awe inspiring. Visited on a saturday lunchtime, tip: pay by cash, queue was only 10 minutes, pay by card 30 minutes wait, Fantastic awe inspiring place, we all saw the royal wedding last year, stand & behold, lots to see & do & plenty to amuse the kids, not that expensive for the 2/3 hours enjoyment. Steeped in Royal history its a must visit,

A place in history. The grandeur and the history of this iconic building where kings and queens have been crowned and buried, just wonderful you can just feel the history of the place when you enter,as we went mid July it was very busy with long queues to get in so take plenty of water as it is a long wait.

Fantastic Kids questionnaire. Took the kids along to the Abbey, didn't use the Audio guide. Instead got the kids questionnaire and they loved it. Kept the kids busy for nearly two hours of our visit, seemed to take at least as long as the audio guide. At the end of the tour a completed questionnaire get the kids a massive chocolate coin from the gift shop. Pretty good value for free kids entry. Make sure you find a employee when you get there as I think that the stuff for the kids is a bit too easy to miss.Highlight for the Kids.
Absolutely beautiful. So many beautiful cathedrals around. This has to be one of my favorites. Just thinking of all the history there.

Book a Verger Tour. If you call the abbey two days prior to your visit you can book a Verger tour. We found this to be so informative and proved to be an easy way to catch the highlights of Westminster Abbey without being overwhelmed. What a wonderfull place! Don't miss. Even our teenagers enjoyed this tour.

The Abbey. 2 hours was enough time to see what was important. I loved seeing the tombs of Elizabeth I, Mary Queen of Scotts, and Bloody Mary, all in the same area. One Catholic, one Reformist and one beheaded. They must be rolling in their tombs. The Church was more of a burial ground than a Church but I still enjoyed the history.
Great place but skip evensong. This is a great place to visit, but if you go to evensong they usually do not have a choir and it is not very impressive.

Put it on your bucket list!. Yes there are queues but they move efficiently and this is worth it. The last 1000 years of British History are all there before you right up 'til now with the wedding of Will and Kate etc. The audio accompaniment works well and the whole experience is smoothly designed to help tourists appreciate what they are seeing. The Brits are very fortunate to have such a building in pristine condition like this and the rest of the world is also fortunate to be allowed to share.

Great audio tour. The audio tour is thorough without being monotonous. Amazing to be in a place so gorgeous and rich with history. Loved seeing Queen Elizabeth I's tomb. Went at around 12 on a Friday and was surprised that it wasn't too busy. Only took cards which was a bit of a bummer but the experience was worth it.

Took my breath away. There are almost no words to describe Westminster. The architecture alone is brilliant, but if those walls could talk... To walk the steps of past and current kings and queens and see some of their final resting places was beyond. The audio tour was a must. And the people inside were extremely nice and helpful and full of information. If you go, speak with them and you will get so much more out of your visit. I had accidently passed by Darwin and Isaac Newton and one of the guides was more than gracious to escort me back across the Abbey so I did not miss out.This was one of my favorite places in London.
A Cultural Peek. This reflects England and her history. Takes about 2 hours to do right and use the Audio guide and plan on early visit otherwise the ques are LONG. It closes at 3:30 so make plans.

Do it. Going to Westminster Abbey is most definitely an interesting experience. I don't know if I stared at the architecture or the grave names more. The architecture is just glorious, but the dead people that are housed here are definitely more celebrated than the architecture. Places such as the Poet's Corner and Sir Isaac Newtons grave site are crowded beyond belief and usually make the experience less enjoyable, but you can still have a good time here despite the crowd.
Breath-taking!. It really was! It was amazing to have seen the place were several mens and woman became kings and queens of a splendid nation. Really a must-see place!

Magical visit to Westminster Abbey. If you do anything when in London, you MUST visit Westminster Abbey. I arrived half an hour before opening to beat the queues, and got in very quickly. Make sure you pick up the audio commentary as this wil guide you around very successfully. It has jaw dropping history which gave me goosebumps, especially when you see the resting places of so many kings, queens and famous people. Of course the architecture is spectacular and make sure you get some pictures outside because photography is not permitted inside.

Great Cathedral Experience. As we wondered through London, my wife and I found ourselves at Westminster Abbey. It seemed to be a grand establishment with lots of history associated with it. Even though there was a costly price of admission, we decided to explore it further. We used the audio tour to guide us through the massive maze and plethora of monuments and tombs which lay within the walls of the abbey. Even though there were a lot of visitors, it is such a massive structure that there was enough room to facilitate a good flow of people. In the end, it was worth the cost of admission, but make certain that you have at least a couple of hours free to explore the abbey in its entirety.

Too Crowded to Enjoy Properly. Westminster Abbey is one of the most beautiful cathedrals in Europe. The fact that there are so many people buried there especially famous people makes it even more interesting. Just seeing the tomb of Queen Elizabeth was fascinating. I really love this place. However having said all that try to avoid this place in the heavy tourist summer months. It's not worth it. You can barely move amidst the crowd and you never get a feeling of solace and peacefulness that most churches and cathedrals naturally would bring to you. It's sort of sad in a way. It's like the temple must've looked when Jesus threw everybody out. So much noise and so little piece. I went there the last time in January and it was a completely different experience. If you've only got a few days to in London Maybe your time would be better spent somewhere else where you can thoroughly enjoy the experience. There are so many fabulous churches in London that are little visited and your time would be better spent finding some of those. You gotta love the history though!

More interested because of Royal wedding. Great to visit, very central walk. We went 30 minutes before opened and there must of been at least 150 people ahead of us. More narrow than imagined. Just intrigued as young royals wed there. St. Paul's cathedral was much grander, in my opinion. But certainly glad we went and tons to see around the area

Worth a visit. You have to pay to enter the Wesminster Abbey, but it's worth a visit. You get to see some interesting history and listen to a commentary about anything you see, but best of all, the commentary is by Jeremy Irons. No photography inside.

Loved it.. We loved this church. It is so rich in history and the people that memorialized of buried here are amazing. I loved the Newton burial. Well worth the long line to get in.I also loved the memorial to the service men and women from WW1 and WW2 in the little chapel. Plus the 9-11 dedication to the Americans.

Disappointed. After seeing the Abbey on TV so many times, I was so disappointed after touring it. It was to me, less a house of worship and peace, than an indoor graveyard. Yes the old tombs of kings and queens were interesting as was where famous people are buried, but the place, had to me, no feeling of sacredness.

Speechless. It's a very sacred place. A must visit for everyone. Did not enter the Abbey as it was quite expensive £18 per person. I'm awed by the architecture of the Abbey. Being around the abbey was already very satisfying and leaving me speechless. The Westminster Abbey is also just beside the Houses of Parliament and can be reached by the Jubilee Line at Westminster Station. A must visit.

Great spot with lots of history. We enjoyed our walk through westminster with an audio guide. It was interesting to see the more famous effegies scattered in all areas of the cathedral. I always wish that it was accepteable to take pictures in such great looking churches but can unsderstand why they choose not to let us. A must visit when in London.

AMAZING!!!!!!. Westminster is a very sacred and holy site housed in the grand ancient abbey. It is well worth the money. As you walk you can see the tombs or memorials of all the most important people in history from Darwin to the royal family throughout history. I highly recommend an adioguide. Westminster is like no other abbey or cathedral you will ever see - do not miss!

Very Historic. Lovely building is rich in history. The tombs of British kings and queens are here. The poet's corner is also filled with tombs and statues to many of history's greats. A trip to London would be incomplete without a visit to the Abbey.
Amazing place. Too many tourists on the weekend.. So much history. I enjoyed seeing on the graves of royalty. We went on a week day, we attempted to go on a weekend day, but too many people.

Long Lines to Get In; Make Sure To Get There Early. The lines are long to get in, but they are worth it. There are so many famous people and royals buried here that they are full up, and can't add anymore graves. The likes of different Kings and Queens are buried here, and even the Abbey's personal plumber is buried here. Things can get crowded, so go in the morning and spend up to 2 hrs in the Abbey. There's a great store to visit with many souvenirs and jewellery to buy.

Breathtaking!. (My) words fail to describe how beautiful and awe-inspiring this place is. Even with the crowds of people, this is place of serenity and beauty, and well worth the time (and the cost) to visit.

Better than expected!!. Spend the few extra pounds for the guided tour or you'll probably miss a lot of interesting aspects. Was so surprised to see Darwin is buried there - a must do on your trip to London!

A New Low for the Church - Alcoholic holy water!!!!. Half way through my touring of the Abbey, the religious service was about to commence. Three priests were blessing each other at the Alter in front of the quire with what I assumed to be holy water. As it was a very hot day for London (32deg) these priests must have been very thirsty indeed - sipping copious amounts of 'water' from their silver cups. Immediately when finished drinking they meticulously wiped them out. 'Very professional' I thought. Not much time had elapsed when one of these clergymen hurriedly walked past me, heading towards the Cloisters,absolutely REEKING of alcoholic spirit. He passed by so quickly that I didn't have time to berate him. How disgusting that so-called representatives of Christ can selfishly stoop so low! Christendom is near its end (Bible prophecy) and we are now starting to see its demise

A good one time visit.. We visited on June 26, 2013 mostly because my daughter really wanted to see Poet's Corner. The price was high so we wanted to take our time and look around, get out money's worth but it was very crowded. After entering, you follow the roped off section, all the way through. There is an audio guide and plenty to look at but you are pushed along with the crowd so sometimes you don't get to stop and really look at some things. My daughter and I took a few minutes to sit in the seats set up for visitors so that we could slow down the rushed process. By the time we made it to the end where Poet's Corner is located, we noticed many seats were set up in this area, on top of the names of the people. There are many tombs and statues that are absolutely worth seeing but no photographs are allowed. It looks very well taken care of but not as grand in some areas as the brochure makes it look. Overall we wouldn't go again but are glad we did visit.

Rude and unhelpful staff. My parents and I wanted to visit the Abbey to pray, not to use it as a tourist attraction. The website said that worshippers were welcome but when we tried to use the entrance for worshippers, we were sent back outside and told that we could only pray from 4pm that afternoon (3 hours away).We thought we would try and take in some of the Abbey's surroundings and make the most of the time we had there. We had read that there was free access to the Cloisters so we thought we'd see if there was an appropriate place to pray there. Unfortunately as we walked through, we were stopped by a very rude man who shouted at us and asked to see our tickets. We explained that we wanted to pray and that we understood the cloisters part was free. He told us that we were wrong, that they were not free other than when he made that decision. He then gave us a large green card and told us that we could enter the Cloisters but that we had to make sure the large card was visible so everyone else could see that we had not paid for entry. We went in at first but felt uncomfortable and embarrassed by how he had treated us. We decided that it was not appropriate to make worshippers feel like second class citizens in a house of worship and so we left. All in all, we were very disappointed to see that the Abbey is treated as a tourist attraction rather that for its intended purpose of prayer and worship. The staff were incredibly rude and it was humiliating to have to deal with those types of people in a house of worship. Very disheartening and very disappointing.

This is the place for royal wedding, coronations, and many other historical events. When we planed to visit London this was one of the places we had to go to. This is the place for royal wedding, coronations, and many other historical events. the audio guide goes through all the major points and make you think.
Extraordinary!. Do not miss! The audio tour is mandatory if you want to enjoy your visit and really get familiarized with this extraordinary building, its history and its legend.
Awesomeness! !!. Westminister Abbey is such a grand place...this building is well preserved and you just can't stop viewing the grandness!!
Cloisters. Didn't get to go inside the Abbey(lines too long) but reading the inscriptions on the plaques and graves around the Cloisters were history and beauty enough.

God's presence was palpable and the stunning architecture amazing!. Go here and take a private tour! It cost us each £3 and it was worth every pence! Our tour guide was very knowledgable and showed us sights that guests aren't permitted to see without a guide. We could have stayed the entire day there...alas, there were a zillion other sites to see and do in London!

Worth lining up for!. Arrived early on a Monday but still found the queues quite long! There were no signs to indicate the "cash" and "credit card" queues until we got close to the entrance.Once inside the views were incredible, and the audio guide was extremely well done. Don't forget to pick one up as we nearly missed a chunk of great commentary.My favourite was the Poet's Corner, acting as a memorial for the famous. I wish I was able to take some photos!

Breath taking. You obviously must wear pants, which being an American having never been in such a Holy Sanctuary, so after a quick change of clothes, we got to enter the most breathtaking place I had ever seen

Definitely a must to see. Last Wednesday , we arrived in the afternoon to visit the abbey, unfortunately it was closed. We tried again on the Saturday morning at around 10h00am . It was already crowded. There is 2 queues, one for cash only and the other one for credit card. Of course, the cash only line is quicker and we opted for this one. It took 15 minutes before we arrived at the admission. The cost is 18 pounds and they give you an audio guide offered in different languages. The building outside is very impressive but it is nothing compared to the inside. Wow , it's amazing the audio guide is well done, we learned a lot about the history . Whether you like history, religion or just a royal fan ,, you will enjoy this visit. You can't miss the unknown soldier memorial, the coronation chair , the magnificent alley which took William and Kate at their wedding. You will see where lots of monarchs, writers, poets, soldiers , etc are buried. Some chapels are just breathtaking. I always like to look of the ceilings , it is so beautiful. We spent 1h30 in the abbey, we could definitely spend more. The only negative thing that I can say, is that is it so crowded that you can not enjoyed fully of the abbey- we certainly missed things. But don't miss this visit because of the crowd- you will missed a good opportunity to visit part of British history

You may want to have a tour guide. I've been to London several times but never went inside the Westminster Abbey till this visit. We got there around 1 pm on Tuesday and had no line to get in. It is expensive, but after all it's a lot of work to maintain something that is over 800 years old. The architecture is breathtaking! As to the graves - some of them are mentioned in audio guide, a lot are not. You may want to have a tour guide if you really want to know whose grave is there. Do go on the days that the gardens are open (they are on Tuesdays). They are beautiful and very peaceful. The church itself was crowded, but not so much that you could not see anything. I guess going at 1 in the afternoon was the right choice. Overall I would definitely recommend going at least once!

Walking through the history of England. A lot of English monarchs, writers, poets, politicians have the honour to be buried here. It is highly recommended that you grab yourself an audioguide and discover the thousand years of history of this island country.

Beautiful. I was there around two hours before closing time and the lines didn't take too long. Inside, we followed the crowd around the entire abbey. I wish I could have taken photos! They were in the process of doing some restoration work, so that was interesting to see, plus the choir was practicing in a side room so we heard them. If you go on an hour, a priest will stop everyone for a moment of prayer. I liked that.

Absolutely breathtaking.. There are no words to describe how beautiful the Abbey is. It's so grand in scale, the detail of every square inch of the architecture is just stunning, and you cannot forget about the history. The Abbey was packed full of people, despite hot temperatures outside. My favorite tombs I saw were those of Geoffrey Chaucer (my favorite poet) and Queen Elizabeth I/Bloody Mary.

VERY expensive and crowded. We recently visited the Westminster Abbey. Although the church itself is very beautiful and full of history, I did not enjoy my visit there. The price, in my opinion, is too high---18 pounds per person. There were so, so many people there, I could barely see anything. Also, you cannot walk around the church in the manner that you choose. Instead, there is a roped off walkway that everyone must follow, meaning it is difficult to go back and see things. I was disappointed with my experience here.

Takes Away One's Breath. As history buff... and a lover of all things England - this was heaven on earth to me.The decorations and details... the tombs... the connection with the monarchy and history.I waited in line to take Holy Eucharist in the Shrine of Edward the Confessor...I'd plan to spend several hours in the Abbey.

Not to miss. But get there first thing! We were told by others in line that they had come several days (height of tourist season) and couldn't get in. So arrive about a half hour before it opens, North entrance. (Credit card to the right facing the doors, cash to the left). Great audio guide but the (people) guides inside are happy to answer your questions. Steeped in history, it's crowded insight (not just other tourists but chairs set up for services and all those memorials!) The tour booklet (extra charge) was also good. Consider lunch or tea in the cellar: good food and a nice way to spend some time there.
Gorgeous. You can't go to London without seeing Westminster Abbey. Gorgeous inside and out. I would only recommend you take a tour if possible as we did not and probably missed out on a lot.

Westminster Abbey a must-see. Don't let the lines stop you from visiting this wonderful site. We were engrossed in the history in every inch of this building. The volunteers were great and were fonts of incredibly detailed information about everything in the Abbey. Afterwards, stop by the café on site and have some really good food. The tea was excellent, as well

Closed when we arrived?. The signs indicated that the Abbey was closed when we arrived. But, upon closer inspection, we discovered that the Evensong Service was about to begin so the Abbey was closed to tourists. So, we decided to attend the service! I am so glad we did. The music was beautiful as was the service. After the service, we explored the Abbey. It is truly a wonder.

Breathtaking. We visited Westminister Abbey on our 1st day in London. Unfortunately, we were too late for the tour, but I happened to read in my Rick Steve's book that we could cue up on the side for the 5:00 pm Evening Song. We got ice cream, and cued up at 4:15, which was good b/c they opened the gate shortly after 4:30. It's free, and you get to attend an actual worship service. WOW! We got to hear the choir from Westminster school. This is the way to see Westminster Abbey. You can read the history online or in a book, but we really experienced the Abbey, and still got to walk through a bit on the way in and out. So inspiring! This was one of my highlights of our trip ~

Breathtaking, beautiful, a must see. This is a must see. The church is simply stunning and one of the most impressive buildings I've ever been inside. Not only is this building a must see because of its beauty, its history of being a crowning place of British Royalty and Royal weddings makes it one of attractions you must visit in London. I definitely recommend picking up an audio guide to learn about the church, taking your time walking around and taking in the atmosphere.

Fascinating. W.A is absolutely beautiful and steeped in history. The cost is very reasonable as there is so much to see and the upkeep would be huge. Fantastic audio guide to assist you as we'll. we really enjoyed visiting this amazing piece of history.

Pretty and impressive. This impressive Gothic church is very beautiful inside and outside. You will receive an audio guide (available in several languages​​) where you can hear about each compartment of the church. Besides the beauty, the atmosphere associated with British royalty (crowning place of kings and queens) makes this church one of attractions you must visit in London. Schedule your visit for early morning (around 9 am) and at the end go to the Buckingham Palace to see the changing of the guard that happens every day at 11 am.
Tremendous Historical and Religious Displays!. Long lines even early in the day but they moved quickly. Give yourself 2 hrs min to see everything. Not to be missed.
I want a re-do!. Westminster Abbey is fascinating, but even though we arrived early, it was so crowded that it was difficult to fully enjoy. I felt as if I missed some things.

A must on your trip to London. So much history! You cant come to London and not visit Westminster. I've only visited in winter so I cant comment on the lines that summer must present, but its definitely worth it. Get the audio-guide to explain everything to you

Westminster Abbey. One of my favourite places to visit on every trip to the UK - historically wonderful and a snapshot of British history - especially its kings and queens and other notables - and there are no restrictions on taking snapshots. However, check the hours before you go, since many overseas visitors were disappointed to find it closed early on Saturday,.and it is often closed for special events any day of the week. Take at least one hour to visit the abbey itself (if you are interested in British history) and give yourself another hour to visit the entire complex and other buildings including the historic green behind which is worth a walk, as are the cloisters and Chapter House. I did not notice this visit if you could still do brass rubbings, but if these are of interest the last time I was there you could buy paper and rubbing wax. There are plenty of washrooms in the complex and at least one place to eat and an Abbey gift shop.
