If you go at the latter end of the opening hours, things tend to be quieter than when the tour buses are out in full force.If you are staying at Gatwick - much cheaper option than staying in London and only a 30 minute high speed train ride away - the Abbey is really easy to reach from Victoria station which serves Gatwick. All you need is a "tube" ticket to Westminster or Embankment stations. Buy a tube ticket in combination with your rail ticket from Gatwick and you can save a LONG wait when you arrive in London! Getting to the Abbey and crossing the road can be very dangerous for foreigners (especially not familiar with the opposite side of driving - several groups of tourists had close calls on all of my last 3 visits since traffic moves FAST. Making a "run for it" is risky)..Access for wheelchairs in the Abbey is almost impossible, there are a few ramps but the best bet is to concentrate on the outside areas. Also, N. American visitors the underground has few elevators (it does after all date back to the Victorian era), many have brutal escalators and masses of steps..

Definitely go on the Vergers tour. Having brought the London Card, going the extra £4 to do the Vergers tour did not seem expensive - and I'm glad I did as it was definitely the best £4 I spent in London! The Verger was a great guide, being intimately connected with the Abbey, he knew all the stories, and was able to take us to places that the average tourist didn't see, including the tomb of Edward the Confessor. Very interesting and informative.

A MUST for any traveler. I've been fortunate to visit London several times, and each visit I try to attend an Evensong at Westminster Abbey. It's a fabulous experience to hear the superb Choir of Men and Boys, to hear the magnificent organ, and just to look in awe and wonder at the magnificent architecture of the building ... not to mention all the history that has taken place there, and will continue to take place. And if I'm fortunate to visit again in the future, you can bet I'll make every effort to attend another Evensong there. (Note: There is no fee for Evensong, but one must also realize this is a service, not a sight-seeing event.)

Evensong Commercialized. I had been to the Evensong at the Abbey several years ago when it was relatively unvisited. There were just a handful of people in attendence and the service was presented with no amplification. Just etherial voices in a huge space; one could almost believe that angels were singing in the rafters. . You could soak up the atmosphere while gazing at this magnificent structure. Imagine my dismay at the "cattle call" I experienced in May 6 years later. So many people funneled in to the apexes with voices clogging the airspace, televised and amplified, and people being seated 10 minutes after the service had started! Such a disappointment that it has been commercialized to attract and accommodate more tourists. Go for the experience, but don't expect angels.

Breathtaking. Visiting Westminster Abbey is a must. Just the outside alone is impressive, but the inside is awe-inspiring. The architecture is gorgeous. The history takes your breath away. Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, Queen Elizabeth I, Charles Dickens, and so many more are all buried here. Coronations and weddings, too. One of the most amazing places I have ever been.

West Minister Abbey - A British Beauty. West Minister Abbey is a must-see architectural beauty that is rich with British history; it hosts tombs of world class heroes like Charles Dickens and Charles Darwin together with a memorial for Isaac Newton. Make sure to read up a little history before you visit the Abbey. It will be much more significant to you in so many ways. The interior includes a statue of the Virgin Mary holding baby Jesus and the cloister (a rectangular open space surrounded by covered walks with open arcades on the inner side) leading to the College Gardens. The Abbey is walking distance from the Thames and a great way of spotting other great landmarks like our good old friend Big Ben. You are able to access the Abbey FREE with a Londen Pass (you might want to consider in getting yourself one). Alternatively you can pay daily rates between £8.00 (children) and £18.00 (adults).
absolutely lovely. This is one of the most impressive buildings that I have ever seen. If you are in London this is a must to visit

HISTORY IS BURIED HERE. If there is an outstanding figure in English History, chances are they are buried in Westminster Abby. Elizabeth I and Mary, a number of Numbered Henry's. and Poets corner brings back memories of those books you had to read in high school = well if you went to high school before the 80's

Excellent. Make sure you have pounds (money) to get in as there are two lines to get into the Abbey and the charge card line did not move too quickly. We paid cash and pretty much walked right in. Upon entering, you are given a electronic devise programmed to your respective language. This allows you to tour at your own pace, which is huge when you have time constraints. Unfortunately, they do not let you take pictures inside, so you might need money to buy a book in the gift shop that commemorates your visit.

Enchanting Experience. A historic place; and an enchanting experience! Make sure to order the audio guide; it helps out a lot to learn about the history of the place. It's not free admission so you'll have to pay for this attraction. I must say I felt I got my money worth more than St. Paul's Cathedral. Even if you don't go in, read about its history and take some pictures of the abbey from the outside. It's a trademark of London for sure.Note: It's always crowded and there's always a huge line for the tickets but it's still worth it.
Wonderful Just to Set Your Eyes on. The area in and around the Abbey is a little congested, but there is a lot to do there. The Abbey is breathtaking.

Beautiful and full of history. I enjoyed the audio tour that comes with adminission. I was surprised how much history is stored in each of the small rooms throughout the Abbey. The small rooms can be a bit of a pain as there's only a small doorway to enter and exit. 10 minute wait to buy tickets, we went on a Monday. Check the website before going to make sure it open when you plan on visiting. Overall I like the path that the tour lays out to handle the amount of visitors.

Great building. The place is awesome and the architecture is something to admire. Its a bit expensive and there arent many mora atracttions inside beside the tombs and the audio guide (free in several languages).

I was honestly surprised by this beautiful place. Westminster Abbey is so much more than I expected. I thought I would see a grand church, but it is so much more than that. We only went since we had the London Pass and really glad we did. Yes, you are charged to enter. I really didn't see anything wrong with this, it is like paying for a museum.The line was long and almost deterred us, we gave it 5 minutes and once it started it went very quickly. There are two lines one for cash and one for credit, make sure you are in the right one. Just ask someone standing in line.Once inside there are no pictures. There is an audio guide. We got one, but didn't use it on every thing inside. Another note, most people start looking and listening to the audio guide right from the beginning. This is probably the right way, but it is congested. We just quickly looked at the things and moved further up where it was not so crowded and started from there. There are many people buried there and you will be walking over them, you cannot help it. This place branches off into different wings which are older and hold more burials and interesting things, venture on to these wings.I don't know what else to say, but it is a beautiful place that didn't disappoint. I would recommend everyone see this place once. You can take as much or as little time as you want. I think we were there a little over an hour.

Beautiful, but very touristy. I visited St. Paul's Cathedral first, and while I wasn't intending to compare the two, Westminster felt very impersonal. To begin with the ticket lady was unfriendly. She refused to sell a family ticket to the family in front of me because they did not have anything to verify the ages of their adolescent children. They paid double what they had planned to get in. I showed her my student ID with a current picture on it, but it lacked a year, so she would not give me the student price. She was very strict. The crowds were massive, but the cathedral is well worth it, especially to see Issac Newton, Charles Darwin and Shakespeare's graves or monuments. The cafe and gift shop both were overpriced, and the cafe was out of many menu items, only sandwiches were left, so I went straight to dessert. The cake was marvelous!
Beautiful. We liked everything. Great architecture, beautiful interior. A very moving experience feeling the history.
A must see. If you are going to London, this is a must-see. Gorgeous and rich in history. My teenager liked it as well. Get the audio guide.

Huge line to go inside. Worth to wait tho.. Even if you arrive before they open you'll need to queue. But be aware: they have TWO different queues there, one for cash and another one for credit card. So the best choice is to bring both and join the smaller one! ;)

Lots to see, lots of people. Expect to wait to get in and make sure you are in the right line - there is one for cash and one for credit card and the line-ups are on either sides of the abbey. London Pass can go in either. The line-up was all the way to the road but only took about 20 minutes to get in.We used the audio guide (free) for the first time and it was well worth it. The commentary is done by Jeremy Irons who has a great voice and the commentary pieces aren't too long but very informative.Saw Darwin, Newton and Handel as well as a few kings and queens! St Paul's Cathedral wowed me more but this was certainly worth the time spent waiting and exploring.

This Has The Wow Factor. Even although it was free using the London Pass I was a little reluctant to visit after seeing St Pauls but this beats them all and had a big wow factor, I didn’t realise how big it was and what it contained. For once I listened to the audio and was taken in by it all – very impressed and if you only have time to visit one thing in London make sure this is it. There is the queue and the bag searches but the wait is worth it.

1000 years of British history within a city block.. We loved visiting Westminster Abbey. We booked a Verger tour and could not have been happier with that choice. David, our guide, was fantastic and knowledgeable. He took us behind the scenes on several occasions to visit sites that we could not visit without being on the tour. If I could offer you one recommendation, it would be to book this tour. He took us to all the important monuments/graves while explaining the history of the building and Britain. Our verger was part of Will and Kate's wedding and he related stories from that, also discussing aspects of the coronation ceremony. If there was only one day in London, this would be a site I would recommend visiting.
Beautiful. Had to stand in a queue but not too long. Meanwhile started looking at the beautiful outside of the building. Then the inside; simply amazing. Like going back in time.

Disgusting rip off. I saw two lines of people queuing to enter the Abbey and just assumed it was a busy day. As I drew closer, I saw signs saying cash only and credit cards only. They are charging people???!!! Absolutely disgraceful, it is a place of worship, not Disneyland. I did not enter and just took some photos of the exterior. Shame!!! Beyond belief!!!

Very enjoyable. Very crowded.. We got into Westminster Abbey with our London Passes. The line outside looked long, but took all of 10 minutes. And inside it was crowded, but fascinating.Entry includes an audio tour. This tour was quite thorough (in all we spent about 2 hours here), but allowed us to easily choose what to listen to, when we wanted. I felt that I was given access to every part of the Abbey I wanted to see, and was given information and told stories about these parts. My feet started to ache many points along the way, and I was almost always able to find a seat or a place to lean. Meaning, the site is aware of its visitors' needs, and is not stuffy about people leaning on the walls.Warning: The lines for the bathroom are long. Be sure to keep the printed ticket they give you as certain attractions within Westminster Abbey are technically outside of it and you'll need to show the ticket to get back in.Total bummer: No pictures allowed! I so wanted a picture in Poet's Corner but was unable to take one.
Loved it. Absolutely loved it here, being a Tudor fanatic I expected to! The free audio guide is fabulous, gives a really detailed tour. Highly recommend.

Tips Beyond Being a Tourist. Westminster Abbey is not just a tourist attraction - it is a sacred space hidden in the press of thousands of visitors a day. In Christian faith, there is the concept that the soul outlives the body. Here in Westminster Abbey you are surrounded by the physical remains of historical luminaries that include monarchs, poets, musicians, scientists & politicians who would have sought the divine in this space. If you want more than just the tourist experience on a weekday, here are some tips. At 3pm the shrine of Saint Edward is open to pilgrims who wish to join in the centuries old practice of prayer. This shrine is closed at other times unless you are in a tour group. It was during this time of special prayer that the priest remind us, "You are no longer merely visitors but have become pilgrims." Those who wish to pray for healing may do so in one of the prayer alcoves set in the shrine. There is also a time of prayer at 11am but the 3pm is recommended if you wish to remain for Evensong at 5pm (which ends by 6pm). Here is the reason: people begin to be ushered out of the abbey around 4pm. At that time, if you walk around the cloisters and make your way back to towards the nave, you may ask to line up for Evensong. It may seem a little much to have to wait 45-50 minutes for Evensong, but there is a reason for this. If you line up within the Abbey at this time, you will be at the front of the line (they seat you around 4:40pm). Those at the front of the line are seated in the Quire which is the area of wooden stalls between the organ and where the Abbey choir will sit. You may be a little further away from the High Altar but you will enjoy he marvelous experience being in the epicentre of the musical worship experience of the Abbey. If you arrive later, you may find yourself outside the Quire at the Transept or the Nave but it is still an inspiration to worship among the saints of both the present and the past.Whether you are of the Christian faith or not, you may find the experience of pilgrimage and worship nonetheless divine!

Came back again!. I could spend hours in here. In fact, i went once and loved it so much when I visited London again i made sure i came back. So much history, i get chills seeing the same black and white tiles that kings and queens walked down hundreds of years ago. The White Room is absolutley breathtaking. Tombs and memorials of historians and royalty alike. It is massive and every corner there is something new. I could feel the prescence of the past 500 years of royalty all around me. Would highly reccomend taking the tour they offer, we did not get to but you get to go up on the main altar and behind it and you cannot get there any other way but the tour!

Beauty. The gothic style building is stunning and a true landmark of London! The tower is magnificent and well kept! Shame it always seems to be scaffolded when i go but it's still wonderful to see. Always busy too

Tracing the footsteps of royalty!. I took the audio, self-guided tour and was captivated! The Abbey has such an amazing place in history. One thing I found very interesting about all of the churches in England and Ireland is the number of military people who were honored and oftentimes buried in the churches. Touring the Catholic Churches in the rest of Europe, they seem to only bury priests and their saints in the churches. The Brits also honor artists. One area of Westminster is called "Poets Corner" where the likes of Lord Byron, Charles Dickens, etc., are buried. Shakespeare is honored, but not buried there.It was very moving to stand in the place where the Kings and Queens have been crowned, as well as the spot where Princess Diana's casket rested during her funeral.The throne that has been used since the 1300's is the last thing you see before exiting. Not at all anti-climactic. Lots of beautiful architecture, amazing history, very much worth visiting. I would easily visit there again if I ever had the chance.

Do not miss. Get this as part of the London Pass. It is a must see. Yes, there is a line, but it moves fast and is worth the wait. The inside is beautiful and the architecture unbelievable. Be sure to stop and get the self guided headsets for your tour.

The pre-eminent Religious Building in England for over 1000 years. This is the Abbey where all Royal Coronations have taken / take place. It is gothic style architecture and it is a must see in London. It is also the burial place for Charles Dickens and other notable / historical individuals.We were there two weeks ago and planned our visit to attend the 5 pm evensong service, which is a boys / mens choir. Well worth it, but get there to line up early.It is an included attraction on the "London Pass"

Beautiful Church full of history. If you can, buy tickets in advance, the wait was a bit long. It was definitely worth the time spent in queue though, because the church was a rare beauty and the volume of history in the place was fascinating.

Nice Architecture. True, regardless of your beliefs, the architecture is worth a visit. We were mesmerised at the unique building and nice surroundings. The tranquility and serenity made our day. Try to visit where there's less people. However, I am not sure when will there be less people or tourist. Seems to have lots of visitors everyday.

must see. there is so much to the abbey; we could have spent several hours in here.... so many of the Royals are buried there~ with close visual access. it has quite a feel to it.. I would make more time for it next time~~

Beautiful and Historic. We have been on the tour of Westminster Abbey before, which is well worth the money. This time we just went for the Evensong service, which is a service done in song. This was absolutely beautiful! I would recommend getting there about an hour early, you will have to wait in line a bit, but it's worth it!
a wonderful sight for the eye. this is also one of the amazing buildings og London, it shines With its histoty. Magnificent views both inside and outside. Just amazing when you think og its age

A place for history lovers. Westminster Abbey was on my "must do" list for my three days in London. Not only did it not disappoint, my expectations were exceeded. If you love history, you will love Westminster Abbey. The greatness of the building itself was awe inspiring and then add to that the people whose tombs lie there. Give yourself plenty of time to wander and soak up the beauty and history of this magnificent place. Be sure to look up and around when inside to appreciate the architecture.The audio guide is very good - you collect them once inside the door. I would recommend also doing a little research on the Abbey and its occupants before visiting, just to have a little more knowledge on what you are experiencing.The rooms where Queen Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots lie are symmetrically placed each side of a central room and are quite small. A sign says to keep moving through these rooms, but there is a small space where you can stand aside and absorb the knowledge that you are in the same room as such historical figures.

Do Not Miss. Regardless of your views or beliefs, do not miss visiting Westminster Abbey. From standing outside and admiring the architecture to the moment we walked inside, we simply ran out of words to describe the experience. You can feel the history in the building, understand the inspiring heights of the ceiling, stained glass windows, the burial stones, chambers with kings and queens laid to rest. You simply run out of words and walk around in a quiet reserved manner trying to soak it all in.

Amazing History. The Abbey opens at 9:30 am every day (except Sundays when it is closed). At 10:30 there was a line. We waited in line about half an hour but it moved steadily. If the day is really sunny and warm, you may want to bring an umbrella to offer yourself shade. The one issue I had with entry into the abbey is that they seem to let in too many people at one time. I was in London the end of June, beginning of July (around the beginning of their tourist season) and it was already mayhem. I shudder to think of the crowds and lines that will be there in the next 2 months. It is well worth the visit! The history of that abbey is truly astounding! No pictures are allowed, which is a bummer, but you get over that pretty quickly as you are mesmerized at what the abbey beholds. Enjoy it. Take time to light a candle for someone. Try to appreciate the history of the abbey. Forget about the camera. Well worth the (high) price of admission.

Fantastic, wonderful, interesting.. We loved our visit to the Abbey. We had lunch in the Cellarium - wonderful! The visit itself was fantastic - it felt like living history. Tombs of Henry V and Edward, etc. Amazing. Definitely a MUST see.
Breaktaking. When you buy a ticket you automatically receive an audio explaining what you are looking it. It is worth it to hear the history of the Abbey.

Awe inspiring. This place has a very heavy feeling, the weight of alll the stone rests on the shoulders. Beautiful works of art, historic monuments and tombs and thankfully the religious theme was underplayed. A minutes prayer on the hour and the option to submit prayers at some candles sums it up. The location for the royals weddings, coronations and etc this place is a must see if in London. The price is £18 and is almost enough to make you turn back... don't!According to legend the catacombs (to which public do not have access) is where the religious artifacts are kept.

More than just another church on the European trail. I have visited some cathedrals, churches and abbeys over the past 2 years and this one blows them away! Yes, Notre Dame, The Vatican and Florence's Duomo - I did love them all though. This abbey is really a cemetery with everyone who is of note in British history. The cost of 18£, I believed was outrageous, until we discovered the abbey is not funded by the C of E or the government and is self funded. Regardless, it was a highlight of this trip!
awesome!. A definite must for the architecture, the beauty, the history, the tombs. I would love to see it without the crowds, but it is still worth the time and effort.
Amazing view. superb place to have afeel. We really njoyed our outing their at cerntral london, Very Close to london eye and thames river

The "must" attraction. Westminster Abbey is must attraction in London, but remember that it is a church as well.I were little supprised that entrance fee was 18 pounds (about 21 Euros). That is quite much.
Amazing!. Anyone who visits London must go here it was breath taking inside and out the history off the place was amazing and you get to see all the tombs and they also have a prayer service.

Westminster Abbey is fantastic. A family of 5 (21 year old, 18 year old, 12 year old) enjoyed it. The back temple/alter is so beautiful and decorative. The headset tour feeds you right through each place. Make sure to sit and pray for some time.

EVERYONE you know from English history is buried here!. Well, not quite, but it seems like it when you visit here. Even if you've read all about this place, if is awe-inspiring to be in the PRESENCE of such greatness. For us, it was full of things that surprised us - that the deadly enemies Catherine of Aragon and Elizabeth I are buried in a common grave; that the father of Henry VIII's extraordinary devotion to the Virgin Mary caused him to create the lovely Lady Chapel, with its delicate fan vaulting; that there first was an Anglo Saxon church on this spot before William the Conqueror started building this one - the list goes on and on. An amazing place, on every level possible.Get here before 3:30 PM, that's the last tour group admitted, since evensong services begin at 5 - or come me in through the side door for the service (this is a wonderful place to meditate or pray, and of course there is no fee for that!). We were lucky enough to hear the Westminster Boys' Choir rehearse (celestial!), one advantage of visiting in mid-afternoon.A walk down Whitehall after or before this visit is an added attraction, since the Abbey lies at its foot, and Trafalgar Square at its head. We practised walking before we went to London to get in shape - a good idea, as it turned out, because there is so much to see on foot that you would miss if you took the bus, let alone the underground.

Spend the extra money, take the tour. Yes, everything in London is expensive, so just go for the gusto and spend the extra money so you actually know what you are looking at. We took one of the tours with one of the vergers. He was extremely informative and could have given us endless English history lessons had he had the time. It was a little challenging to fight the tour "moochers" but the guide did his best letting people know we were "special." On the tour you get to visit the center chapel, not open to the general public, and get to see some of the more significant tombs up close. Try to get one of the later tours and you will get to hear the rehearsal for the evensong. It is truly heavenly.

Iconic but over-commercialised. The Abbey has become such a familiar sight on television and in the press, particularly in recent years and having seen it from the outside numerous times I was really keen to visit. As such, it was always going to be an interesting building to see and on that level, didn’t disappoint. The Abbey is open to worshippers for free use and there are daily services but for other visitors there is a “tourist” option. An easy to use audio guide in a number of languages is included in the entry charge, which takes visitors round 20 of the key points of interest and ensures people keep on the move in the same direction. There are also “optional extras” for those who want more detail, for example on the Coronation Chair and the Eucharist service. I was surprised at how different the Abbey looked inside from my expectations. For a start many of the camera shots are taken from high in the roof and give the impression of a vast open space whereas there are actually quite a number of divisions between different areas. The sheer volume of tombs and memorials is quite astounding and I was surprised at how little their placement seemed to have been planned as part of the whole – they appear to be squeezed in when a gap is perceived! The Lady Chapel is especially beautiful and it seems amazing that it has survived completely intact through the Reformation and all subsequent turmoil, and remained unblemished during the Blitz.So, undoubtedly there is much to appreciate. However, I always find that when visiting religious buildings and sites, part of what makes the experience special is the quietness and stillness that often remains inside. The Abbey is such a popular attraction that this was completely lost due to the number of people there. In addition, while I feel the entry fee is justified in light of the huge cost of running and maintaining such a building, I was quite uncomfortable with the presence of the Coffee and Gift Shops and particularly the fact that both were mentioned as “things you may wish to do at the end of your tour” on the audio guide, further emphasised with needing to leave through the Gift Shop. I just felt that both could have been a little more understated, perhaps located just outside, and do not feel this would have had too drastic an impact on their success. Finally, I felt that the staff I encountered appeared quite disinterested and were not especially welcoming, clearly feeling they were there to “do the job” as a transaction rather than greet and engage with visitors. It’s not something I would usually particularly notice so it must have been fairly marked.
Awesome. Historical buildings and sightseeing is not usually top of my todo lists but this place has jaw dropping history and architecture and a good system of explaining it to visitors

Historical and Reverent. Awe inspiring and beautiful. Impressed by the outstanding sites inside and out. Was simply impressed by those figures who are buried there. Wonderful to think of the history created here with the coronation and the wedding of William and Kate. Amazing!
A place with great meaning. So much has happened here that a visit cannot be disappointing. The crowds, however, test that notion to the limit.

Stand in "Greatness". Westminster Abbey was another absolutely must-see in London for us. The history and the beauty of the 700 year old Abbey is outstanding. We arrived early and there was hardly a queue to wait in. The audio guide that is included was very good and highlighted the important areas and antiquity of the Abbey. The difference between Westminster and St. Paul’s cathedral is remarkable. Both must be seen to be appreciated. Both are included in the London Pass which takes the cost down. Even without the Pass, I would consider this to be well worth the admission. Unfortunately, as in most important places, photographs are not allowed. The elaborate tombs of Elizabeth I, Mary I and Mary Queen of Scots, the Coronation Chair, Poet’s Corner and so many other special places. Very nice to be in the same place where Prince William and Kate were married.Next time will come back for an Evensong or service. Can't imagine how wonderful that would be!
So much history in one building!. Just standing looking at this building brings back all the memories of just being English. Marriages, coronations and funerals. Well worth visiting.

Great History. I love old churches and this one is distinguished for being the site of amazing history and the tombs of so many of the world's most famous individuals. Yes, the fees are high but you just spent several thousand dollars getting here so why complain about an entrance fee. Use a tour guide and get the most out of the place.

Day light Robbery. Just got back from visiting OUR capital city great time but £18 per person to go into Westminster Abbey, we decided not to bother bought a tea and looked at it from the outside very disappointing, smacks of just greed!

Astounding! Must see of London! . My favorite attraction in London! GO! Costs about 18 euros and you get an interactive tour with that. Very worth it! Gorgeous architecture and many famous people buried there.

Evensong at Westminster Abbey. We spent a few days in London and were on a walking tour. The tour guide mentioned the Evensong held on Thursday evenings at 5pm. We arrived about 15 minutes before 5pm and the man at the gate asked us why we were there. We told him we were there for the Evensong and in we went. We got a front row seat. The regular choir wasn't there but it was still magnificent. We were in there for about an hour and really enjoyed the service. There is no charge for the service and you are ushered out once it's done, but it was better than paying 18 Pounds each to see the inside of the Abbey. Check it out if you have a chance.

Not really a MUST see. My husband and I went with our two little kids (ages 5 and 1). There was no fee for the kids, but for adults it was 18 UK pounds each (kind of a lot in my opinion to go to Church!). Yes the building is impressive and there is a lot of history there, but to me, it was not really worth the admission fee. The kids obviously were not that interested in it, and if it hadn't been for my husband's insistence on having to see the place at least once, I would not have even bothered. It is a bit difficult to enjoy this attraction with little kids in tow, to kids, it must seem like a dull and dreary place. After an hour or so, we were all ready to go. Luckily Big Ben and Houses of Parliament are nearby so the walk is a nice scenic one with great views of surrounding sites.Nowhere decent nearby to eat though, so pack a little something with you or plan to eat after leaving the area.

Not worth the $$. Westminster Abbey was nice. It is a very nice church but I was put off by the high admission fee. I traveled in mid December and it wasn't very crowded but they still rushed you through the church.

Awe aspiring. Spent a bit of time looking around, so much to see, so much more then just the chapel, it is beautiful, but so are the other area's and the history... wow.
We actually got shown some of this stuff on a Photo walk and then we went back and got to have a better look around.

If you have one day in London- go here. So gorgeous and so much history. The people buried here itself is an unsurpassed memorial. Hard to impress the kids, but they couldn't believe it was The Isaac Newton in there...then cursed him for making their math so difficult. Darwin...and the list goes on. The Monarchs and their stories. Mary, Elizabeth. Poets/Artists. The architecture is breathtaking.If you have one day in London- go here.

This Is A "Have To" Visit When In London. Excellent!. We toured Westminster Abbey on this trip, our first visit to London and it's a "don't miss" for a first time trip. Magnificent history and church. Be sure to get the audio headset.

Magnificent. The Abbey is the burial place of many of my husband's ancestors. It's absolutely beautiful! Be prepared to spend quite awhile here as there are over 3000 tombs with so many interesting facts.

Gothic architecture. The Houses of parliament are definitely worth going too....easily accessible by the Westminster station on the Jubilee line they have an almost surreal quality about them. I higly recommend going again during the night when they are all lit up and you can marvel at the play of light and shadows on this beautiful buildings.No wonder that it is an Iconic landmark of London.
Must see. Wonderful history and beautiful church. Audio headset great help!!! So much history and beauty in this place! Ate in café and food was pretty good, just a little pricey.

amazing. so much history,very interesting a must do, if your a history geek,lots to see amazing .the handset tours are good and also staff on duty to ensure any questions you may have can be answered,staff try to ensure that everyone gets the information they ask for and more

A must see. We were just in London and what's a visit to London without a visit to Westminister Abbey. It's a must see! Old school London at it's best. It's well worth the price of admission. When you go inside they give you a handheld player that tells you about each step of the way. That's a very nice touch, other places charge you for the use. Without a doubt go there for a visit. They open at 9:30 but the line builds quickly. We got there by 9:10 and there was already a fairly good line ahead of us. Once it opened, the line went right in. You tour at your own pace so your not rushed. If I get back to London I will without and doubt go back for another visit. 900 years of history, amazing!!!

Amazing royal cathedral. This royal landmark is a must see for any one visiting London. The inside of the cathedral is impressive and there is lot to see. The audio guide was included in the ticket price and delivered very good information on the history of the cathedral. At times it may have been tiring to hold the audio guide in your hands, maybe a pair of headphones may have been more comfortable. I'm not sure I will be back to the Abbey next time I'm in London but for those who have never been there, I highly recommend this place. Please note that there is usually long queues to enter the abbey so expect 10-30 mins waiting outside in the queue. Another important thing is that there are 2 queues, one for cash payments and one for credit card. Choose the correct queue or you may be disappointed.

Impressive!. Audio tour is included in the price of admission, however it's a handheld set, which can get tiring. The audio tour was essential to our visit. We learned so much! We spent a lot of time looking at all the names of people who are buried here. Very interesting! Westminster Abbey is closed to tours on Sunday. We happened to be in that area on Sunday, so we were able to take outside photos with no people around. When we went back for our tour on Monday, there were people everywhere. There were 2 lines outside, one for cash admission and the other for credit cards.

Highlight in London. The Abbey was very high on our list for our first visit to London and we we not disappointed.Luckily, the queues were quite short at the time of our visit and we opted to pay the extra 3 pounds for the private verger tour. This tour, for no more than 12 people in each group, is conducted by an Abbey staff member (Ben in our case) and allows you to see up close some parts of the Abbey not available to those on the basic entry price and adds a personal touch to your time there.The tour was informative and entertaining and lasted about 90 mins.The history and architecture of this place are astounding even if you don't have a special interest in either subject.At the end of our tour a visiting choir sang just in front of the high altar.......breathtaking and a real bonus!Take anyone's advice, don't miss this wonder!

Gorgeous!!!! Audio was good, but it's tiring holding it.. I think this is a gorgeous place, so full of history. A bit off-putting for my young children, but I loved this place. The audio was useful, though I wish I don't have to hold the device, it was tiring. In comparison, audio device at the St. Paul cathedral was friendlier as it was a headphone. It was very crowded but our London pass allowed us to breeze through the entry. All in all, one of the nicest place i had been to London.

Royal Grandeur. This grand edifice where the royalty of England has been crowned since the days of William the Conqueror (1066) can be quite crowded and the entry lines long, particularly on a rainy day, but entry with a London Pass can speed it up a bit. Perhaps not the best place to take antsy young children, though.The names on the many tombstones and sculptures inside will often be very familiar but take a moment to just stand somewhere out of the swirl of people to admire the fine medieval Gothic arches and ceiling above.When ready to sit and have a spot of tea and a bit of nourishment, the Cellarium Café offers both under the low ceilings that used to cover the Abbey's brewery and bakery. The cloisters can also offer quiet repose even in the rain, as you stand under the eaves.

Worth fighting the crowds to see!. There is so much history packed into this pile, that it's hard to know where to start! My advice would be to TAKE YOUR TIME if you are an English history buff, because there's a lot to see. My favorite spot was the room where Elizabeth I and Queen Mary were buried. So much history in that space. I was genuinely moved. The Poet's Corner is another interesting spot - but heck, it's all interesting. I'd say go early in the morning if you want to avoid crowds.

Gorgeous royal cathedral. The free audio was key as there are many side chapels that need explanation. Very interesting history and breathtaking architecture. This is one of the main sites you must see while in London.

Wonderful Westminster. Situated beside Parliament, Westminster Abbey is a must-see while in the area. Whether you have a full tour or just go in for an Evensong service, the spirit of the magnificent cathedral will be with you always, and you know that you will have to return. The history in this house of worship is mind-boggling with its coronations, weddings, and funerals throughout the history of England. It will always be on my itinerary for London.

Must visit this amazing place!!. We visited Westminster Abbey expecting to see an historic church and found much more. The architecture inside and out is incredible. The historic significance (Kings Richard II and Henry 5th are entombed here) is amazing.

A wonderful time!. Westminster Abbey is a must do in London! The external architecture of the church is beautiful but the interior is even better. So must history is contained in this church that it is nearly overwhelming. Please, if you visit London take the time to go see Westminster Abbey! It won't disappoint!

Westminster Abbey. Double wow! What an experience. The recorded tour (narrated by Jeremy Irons - perfect) was very good. Just enough detail and the recording device allows you to repeat any part of the information at any time. It was a bit crowded but that's to be expected. The staff was outstanding. Very knowledgeable about the abbey (and other things in the area) and friendly. We were able to sit in on an afternoon church service and take communion. Chaplain Jennifer Petersen presided and greeted guests and chatted a bit afterwards. Quite and experience.

Free audio tour with entry fee.. When we planed to visit London this was one of the places we had to go to. This is the place for royal wedding, coronations, and many other historical events. the audio guide goes through all the major points and make you think. might be a quick for smaller kids but for any who love history there is a lot packed in this place. it is located right at a underground station so easy access
Very nice. This is a must-see in London and the audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons was quite informative. Steeped in rich history and educational and insightful - don't miss it!
A Historic Church. Excellent architecture located near to the parliament house. Must see and spend some time here. Very unique structure.

900 years of English history in 90 minutes. For first time visitors to London this might be the first attraction to see. For 3 pounds( about $4.50 American) take the guided tour by a staff member. Since almost every famous English person is either buried in the Abby or has a memorial there the tour is the easiest way to get your bearings about the Kings and Queens of England. Poets corner has almost every great English author, poet, writer, essayist, and playwriter represented there. Might be the best bargain in London for a historical site. The history you learn here on the tour helps you understand many of the other London sites.

When a 10 year old boy says he loved it. I know the world says this is a cant miss attraction you take it seriously but when a ten year old boy walks out and says he loved it, you have to pay attention. Ok stretch a little but it was fabulous. A great mixture of history, architectural splendor, religion making it a great stop. My highlights were the Coronation Chair, Poets Corner, and all of the stained glass. I took the time to listen to the audio tour and it did a great job adding the historical highlights.

Very.Very.Crowded.. Charging 18£ per person, I can understand why Westminster Abbey would want to shove in as many bustling Americans as possible. Unfortunately as soon as that happens, it loses its magic. Luckily there are beauties that will withstand such foot traffic- The delicate Lady Chapel, for instance. With its intricate almost lace-like ceilings and colourful stained-glass windows.

Steeped in history. This building is just fascinating, the people that have walked through the doors of this building and who are buried here is just unbelievable. For me, standing at the graves of Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton was mindblowing. Other people come for other reasons. The architecture is beautiful and the audioguide provides so many interesting facts and details as you make your way through the abbey. Highly recommend no matter what your thoughts are on religion, monarchy etc.

Jeremy Irons is the perfect tour guide. Needless to say Westminster Abbey is a gorgeous place steeped in history. What I had not expected was the excellent audio tour dictated by Jeremy Irons. What a treat to explore the Abbey with that voice in my ear!

amazing history. i liked the great picturesqueness of it all but sadly my timing was bad as it was late afternoon and did not want to waste the entrance money for a short visit. would love to visit again with more time in hand.
Best place to see the Royals!. Beautiful church - saw the Queen & Prince Phillip - later saw Prince Harry . Next to Big Ben - great photo ops

A 'Must See' in London. We visited Westminster Abbey on the last day of a short break in London. With hindsight, we should've been there earlier in the day, however only got there at about 10, so ad to queue, though the queens moved quickly and the security guard was good humoured. As noted by others, entry was expensive, but then this is a 'must see' location. Sadly, with 2 children, 7 and 2, we struggled with the audio guides and found the kids quiz a bit tough when the place s literally heaving with people.Every square inch is historic and people are directed round in one direction, occasionally interrupted by impromptu diversions and closures. Unfortunately, if you need to go back, it is not straightforward to do so, partly due to the sheer volume of people! We stopped mid tour to visit the refectory (pleasant, if expensive) and then again to go to the toilet (yes, there are toilets in Westminster Abbey, but they're not signposted as presumably they don't actually want people to use them...), which caused untold misery trying to get back into 'the flow' of tourists. There is lots to see however I think I have resigned myself to returning in a few years time with older children and more patience.

Just Amzaing. The self guided tour through the beautiful Abbey was just amazing. My wife and I really enjoyed the history and ambiance of this church. We loved the Newton shrine and Poet's corner. I would really recommend this to any person visiting London.What was crazy is we went the day after the 60 year coronation ceremony and the abbey was in great shape.

Glimpse of history in Westminster Abbey. Despite having seen many occasions on television from this church, the actual building was a surprise. I took the audio guide and enjoyed the melifluous tones of Jeremy Irons as I looked around. History seeps out of the walls and there is something of interest and historic significance round every corner.

Sausage factory. Get into the queue, shuffle in, get a brief glance at some important tombstones, shuffle out. Bit of a waste of time to be honest, there are just too many people for the experience to be spiritual or historical.I also find it ridiculous that you have to pay to enter a church.

Historic Attraction, Heart of London, Buy a London Pass to avoid long lines. I loved this attraction because of the history. Some of England's greatest are buried in this church and generations of Kings have been knighted and married in the church. To walk through this church is to talk a tour of England's past, very cool and I wouldn't miss it on a first time trip!

What a place !!!!. Been to London several times but somehow always missed it. This time I had decided that I won't miss this imposing structure. And I must say what a place to visit , full of history . Self guided was great , had all the important information of this majestic place. Some of the most important people in history have their tombs here. It is really an intriguing place.

Beautiful - favorite Church in London. After visiting other churches such as St. Paul's previously, I felt that the Abbey would be more of the same sights. I was totally blown away by the beauty and history of it however. It is breathtaking and though we weren't allowed to take pictures, the Abbey stands out in my mind even now. So beautiful and the self guided audio tour really helps to bring the place to life.

If you love history, you've got to go. I think my title says it all. Of course I agree with some of the negative posters that it is a steep price to pay to see the slice of history inside, but I do believe that it's well worth it to see the place where so much history has occurred and where so many historical people are either laid to rest or memorialized. Totally worth the money.

Did the self guided tour. Did the self guided tour yesterday, had a great time. The audio guide is great, easy to follow. Jeremy Iorns does a great job of the comentary.Abby it's self is a piece of living history.
Very cool but pricey at 18 £ a head. No pictures allowed. Glad we went but with little kids, i wouldnt reccomend paying entry fee As they grew bored quickly. Kids are free but adults are 18£

Awe-inspiring!. Long queues, but well worth the wait. My only gripe was "no photography" - surely they have "missed a trick" here as they could easily make a camera charge - I certainly would have been happy to pay this as I would have taken well over 200 pictures, given the choice.But, having said that, a wonderfully uplifting experience.
Worth every bit!!. Quite the church and so much to take in. I stayed for 2 hours and I wanted to stay longer. This place cannot be missed!!

Absolutely beautiful!. My family and I visited Westminster Abbey on a Sun. We were not aware that the abbey was closed to all visitors on Sundays but were lucky enough to be able to attend a church service there (and you get in for free). The inside of the abbey was absolutely beautiful. No matter how many times you have seen it in books or on TV, nothing beats seeing it for yourself! Fantastic experience! Would have loved to be able to explore it further.

1000 years history........ Visited this amazing place on a recent trip to London. We were total overwhelmed by the amount of history in one place. Henry III, Elizabeth I, Charles II, Oliver Cromwell, Handel, Disraeli, Churchill, 36 monarchs crowned. It's a history lesson in a building. Make sure you get an audio guide and set aside 4hrs and soak it all in.

Historical and sacred. An incredible place of worship. Full of history and terrific place to meditate and worship. Attend the evening vespers, sit in the high altar area and enjoy the evening services with the boy's choir. Be at the gate at 4:30 p.m. to get the best seats. Easy access by tube or bus.

Enjoyed the Verger-led tour & lunch at the Cellarium Cafe. I first learned about the Verger-led tours from the Westminster Abbey website. Needless to say, I was delighted when I arrived at the Abbey to discover a tour was ready to begin the minute that I had finished paying my entry fee. As a solo traveler, I enjoyed joining a very small group of other visitors (two couples and a few solo travelers like myself) who didn't mind paying a wee bit more to have a "live" guide. "Our" verger had a great personality and made our visit to the Abbey something very special. Afterwards, I had a wonderful lunch at the Cellarium Café. I was impressed by the unique selection of salads available on the menu. The Cellarium -- part of the 14th century fabric of Westminster Abbey -- is where the monks kept their stores of food and drink! Take time out to just sit, sip your tea, look at your surroundings, and imagine what life was like there so many years ago...

This is as good as it gets!. Westminster Abbey is the ultimate historical experience! A truly amazing place with more famous dead people buried underfoot than you could possibly imagine. Only bummer was the amount of people (uncomfortably so) and the constant noise of the hand held tour audio guides!

Amazing. Even though I had seen the Abbey on TV watching services it did not prepare me for what I would see in person. It is so much more interesting than I could imagine. The number of monuments and memorials really overwhelmed me. It was almost too much to absorb on a single visit. I'm sure I'll go back again in the future. We went in the morning and the lines were really long so we headed to a couple of different attractions first and headed back around lunch time and had no wait. It was crowded but didn't prevent us from spending time viewing the areas we wanted to spend time in. We did not stay for a service but would definitely do that in the future. Be sure to go to the garden and cloisters too. See it all!

Awe inspiring edifice. The abbey is legendary for a reason. Stepping inside is like stepping back in time. Except that it's narrated by Jeremy Irons (on the audio tour). I feel that the admission price is fair, especially for all the upkeep that is necessary to maintain this historic building. A word of advice: there are two lines to enter, one for cash and one for cards. Our admission price was included with the London Pass, so we could go in either. Luckily we chose the faster line: the cash line.

Refresh your History in this Beautiful Place, dedicated to God and Monarch!. The day before we had watched, on television, the celebration service in Westminster Abbey of the 60th Anniversary of the Queen's Coronation and then, of course, before that there had been the spectacular Wedding Service of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the sad funeral of the Princess of Wales! We had just left a tour of the Houses of Parliament and were a little shocked to have to join a long queue to enter the Abbey where the entrance fee for a family of adults is not insignificant at £18-00 a head. It was very crowded but the free audio tour, recorded by Jeremy Irons with just the right delivery, made for a comprehensive tour of the Abbey and was easy to follow. You can feel that you are in a Mausoleum of dead Kings, Queens, the aristocracy and the famous and you do need to bring yourself back to the fact that you are in a working Abbey, dedicated to serving God and the Monarch. A visit is a must in anyone's itinerary. We will return in the Winter months when it might not be so crowded. This will allow us the space to really appreciate the beautiful architecture and not feel pressured to keep moving so as not to be in the way of others.
Marvelous. Truly a marvelous, must see experience in London. The architecture, interior, and historical value of the interior monuments and tombs is extraordinary. Not to be missed.

The introduction of British History. Westminster Abbey was the first place that I visited in London. I'm so glad I did it although I waited for a long line to get in. The Abbey is not only beautiful architecturally, but also full of histories. You were load up information of British royalty, and famous people buried there after you walked though with the audio guide. After hours amazing tour, I really needed to sit down and tried Cellarium Café for lunch in the Abbey. Both food and service were average, not really compatible to the inspiring historical site.

Missed the tour but did evensong and it was wonderful. we missed getting on a tour of the abbey so went to evensong and it was wonderful. Boys choir and a short liturgy - what an astounding building. Should not miss on a trip to london

I was doubtful about this 'must do'. I was doubtful about this since there were so many other places I wanted to go in London.I was blown away. Beautiful. In between Darwin and Newton, there was Faraday and Maxwell. And the Poet's Corner: Dickens, Keats, Milton, etc. was impressive.

A great experience second time around. I had visited Westminster Abbey a few years ago, and the second experience was no less overwhelming. On this occasion, visitor admissions did not commence until 25 minutes after the advertised opening time, apparently because of a special event the previous day, so there was a crush when the doors opened.However, the majesty of the interior soon dispels any negative feelings. Being inside the cathedral is something one has to experience to fully appreciate. The history it contains is mind-boggling. One comment to London Pass cardholders - don't expect the suggested queue avoidance - it doesn't happen.

Beautiful. Looking at Wesminster takes your breath away. It is a beautiful structure with so much history. Lines are not very long, we went of a Friday afternoon, waited about 20 minutes to go in. The Abbey is big and you walk down the aisle as the first part of the self guided tour (a big treat for Royal Wedding watchers). They give you a cell phone type of device for the audible tour, but we did not get those. We walked around and I was surprised by the tombs that are all over the abbey. Kings and Queens including Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots. Also, there coronation chair is there dating back to King Richard and is used for every coronation. A must do on your London itinerary!

Everyone should see it once. To see the gardens and the grass so green you think it is fake and the brick wallways and walk over the graves of everyone who ever worked for the church back in the olden days and bural place of other historical figures, and to see where royal ceremonies take place.....priceless. To see the grave of the unknown soldier and where every leader of any country comes before actually doing any business...priceless. To see where Princess Diana was married and where the next leader of England will be crowed ...priceless. This is not just an attraction but history and beautiful history at that.

Historic. As a local one of the few places I'd never actually been in for one reason or another. After making a definate decision to go I'm glad we went. Fanatastic cathederal covering a huge amount of history. Audio guides free with admission tell a great story of the cathederal and the figures buried and/or memorialised within and well worth a visit tourist or not. Experience enhanced by knowing a bit of the history of the UK - specially the Plantagenet/Tudor periods and also knowing who some of the lesser figures are that are not mentioned in the guide.

Great place. Great time spent there. Really enjoyable. No queue when we went in late morning, surprisingly. Had an audio tour as we missed the Verger's Tour. The audio guide was really great and informative as we made our round around the Abbey. The Abbey was quite small compared to St. Paul's Cathedral so I spent about an hour and a half there. Great time, great place.

Impressive. We visited Westminster Abbey (2.00 ...Queue approx. 15 min) whilst in London for two days and really enjoyed walking around the entire abbey (took us about 2 hours).The abbey itself was impressive and so was the historical information.Prices for entry:Adult £18.00Concession £15.00Schoolchildren (11-18) £8.00Family £36.00 (2 adult plus 1) £44.00 (2 adult plus 2)If you are thinking of eating at the Cellarium Café I would suggest give it a miss.See review.

Fascinating history. I'm not terribly religious, so it takes a bit to get me into a church while on holiday. The Abbey is totally worth it though, for both the beauty of the building and also the history that goes along with it (particularly the crypt!). Allow a fair bit of time to walk through at a leisurely pace. Make sure you get the audio guide, and also get there early as it gets crowded later on.Entry is included as part of the London Pass, which we had.

Absolutely breath-taking Cathedral!. This Cathedral was built starting in the 1200's and the beauty and detail is unimaginable! We attended Even Song, which you should arrive between 4:30-5:00pm, and runs from 5:00 - approx 5:45pm. There is no charge, compared to touring it for approx. $25 per person in U.S. dollars (we had toured it before so we didn't want to pay again), so the Even Song worship service allowed us the opportunity to see it at no charge and we loved the service - the acoustics are amazing as they sing the scriptures. Truly a lovely experience! I highly recommend it!

My Favourite London Attraction. I'm a big history buff, so it shouldn't come as a surprise that I loved Westminster Abbey. What is surprising is that amongst all the other fantastic things to see and do in London, my visit here sticks out as my favourite. Just standing in the Abbey is awe inspiring and you do not have to be religious to appreciate the work that went into its construction. Like so many of the great churches in Europe, it harkens back to a time when the common man was illiterate, and he was inspired to experience God through visual form. The building is beautiful, but when you take into consideration the amazing events that have occurred inside its walls, along with the remarkable people either burried or commemorated, you're left gob-smacked with the intense relevance of the building to our understanding of modern Britain and the Commonwealth. Don't miss this!

Great for history buffs. I finally made here on my third trip to London and I'm so glad I did. The Abbey is beautiful and historic and a must-see for any history buff, especially those interested in British royalty, as the the Abbey is final resting place of Queen Elizabeth I and Queen Mary I. The included audio guide is extremely well done and interesting and I'd highly recommend taking your time to listen to the various information provided on it. I agree that the admission fee is too high, especially since no pictures are allowed. Otherwise, it is well worth the time to check out.

Perhaps only for those really keen to take a look inside. Westminster Abbey is a great landmark to visit, but the £15 price tag to enter seemed a little steep! Unless you are particularly interested in going into the Abbey I would say its not a most do. The views of the Abbey from the outside would be suffice. Like all London tourist attractions its very busy at any time, but for people who are religious and interested then you'd need to allow at least a couple of hours to get a good look around.

Beautifully awe inspiring.. A trip to London would not be complete without a visit to Westminster Abbey. Well organized for tourism visit by following a marked path aided by personal audio guide providing direction and information about all you will see. So much history here I can't possibly try to tell about it. Just go there and be amazed. A special treat is to attend an Evensong service given at 1700 on weekdays and 1500 Sat & Sun. You have to line up early at the gift shop gate to make sure you get in as they only allow a limited number of people to attend. They will tell you to be there by 1630 to assure getting in but I would recommend 1600 to be sure. We were first in line and actually got sit in the Choir with the Choir. Amazingly beautiful service completely in choir voice. The best part is it is free to attend. Do Not Miss It!!
Beautiful. This place is so beautiful & historic. The architecture is amazing. We walked here then to Parliament, Big Ben then the London a eye.

A walk thru history!. Kings and Queens and Poets and Writers and Composers and Scientists and Princesses and Statesmen ...and common people have celebrate life events and ceremonial events in these halls. Imagine hearing Handels Messiah echoing off the marble...Imagine Dianas funeral, or Williams marriage, or the coronation of Kings and Queens. What an emotional visit one can experience while taking in the splendor and grandeur of Westminster Abbey. It is an incredible place

Great building but £18 is a rip off. I would suggest you walk round this magnificent building. Approaching it from the courtyard at the back is stunning. World heritage site or not £18 is far too much especially as photos not permitted.

Wonderful part of our heritage. A visit to this building was on our list as we have never visited previously and thought it was about time we did. We were not disapponted as its a beautiful building cram packed with our history/heritage. Price at £18pp

Amazing. When you look at this place and to think about the history you have to pause and taking it all in.......Its a pitty how some churches are too commercialized. But its a nice place to check out when in London.

religious experience. the architecture is amzazing and the art involved in all of it is so awesome. the Abbey is so old and full of history that you should study it b4 coming, otherwise you will absolutely need the free audioguide

Go Don't make Excuses.. We have been to London many times, never been to the Abbey, there was always an excuse. It is a wonderful building, you do not have to be religious to appreciate the tradesmen & women along with influence and money to create such a spectacular result. It is worth lining up to see. "GO".

Well worth the time for a look around. Despite visiting London on numerous occasions over the years, I have never visited Westminster Abbey before, but I really enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone. It was very busy outside, but once inside the atmosphere is very calm. The audio tour is free and very good. The staff are also very helpful and friendly so don't be afraid to ask any questions. The history within that one building is truly stunning - amazing to see just how many key figures are buried there and over such a very long time.

Too expensive.. At £18 ($28) per person for admission we decided to skip this tour on our London visit. Once at Westminster previous ideas of grandure quickly evaporate. It is a tourist mill in the name of tradition and religion.

Don't miss it...and book a Verger Tour. Obviously a "must see" sight. We enjoyed our visit even more with a Verger Tour. (Vergers are volunteers who are like museum docents.)For only 3 pounds additional to the entrance fee, you get a fascinating 90-minute tour. The Verger was knowledgable about all sorts of interesting stories and facts about the Abbey.You can book a Verger Tour 2 days in advance by calling the Abbey phone number. The lines at the entrance were quite long. We had a London Pass which includes entrance to the Abbey and we did not have to wait on line. Be sure to check the Abbey schedule before you go because they are closed some days.We also had lunch at the restaurant at the Abbey. It was very nice and very convenient. You can find information about it on the Abbey website. You can also make a reservation. I DO recommend a reservation. They are very crowded at lunch with long lines. But with our reservation we were seated immediately.

Awe. Religious belief/non-belief is irrelevant. Westminster Abbey is an awe-inspiring experience for the architecture and history. It is difficult to visit and not think of the lives of the people who built the place, who prayed there and who are entombed there. Some people have complained about the high entry fee, they are correct, it is high and it is worth the price, especially if you want to take pictures. If you do not want to take pictures you can see the inside of the church by attending a prayer service.

A Must-See. This attraction was included in our London Pass. We found it very interesting. The audioguide was included with admission and was helpful. We were there on a Tuesday afternoon and it was extremely crowded. At certain points it was difficult to even manuever around the press of bodies, but everyone was polite - no pushing. The small museum beneath the abbey was also intriguing. I found Poet's Corner to be the most fascinating portion of the abbey.
Beautiful. A must see if you're visiting London. Very impressive! So much history, beautiful stain glass and just a magnificent building.

Soul Stirring!. The Abbey has something for many people ... history, architecture, religion and beauty! I am so happy to have had the opportunity to visit Westminster and see it for myself. The Abbey is completely gorgeous and those entombed there are truly men and women who shaped history. Mary, Queen of the Scots tomb is a beautiful memorial from a son who never knew her. Elizabeth I is buried with her sister Mary I and the audio tape has touching and interesting information about the sisters being together in death as they never were in life. Jeremy Irons narrates the audio guide and it is interesting and too overly informative ... for some that is a good thing but I wanted to know more. This is a must see for those heading to London ... spend the money and see this piece of history for yourself!
Family visit. An amazing building described beautifully by the audio guide.very busy so an early start vital. Take time to complete the tour.

So Much History!. There is so much history in this place. It it's a must see. Well worth the price of admission. Make sure to give at least three how's to fully appreciate everything this has to offer.

Very historical place. Loved my visit to Westminster Abbey. It is such a historical place and has so many memorials it is well worth a visit. I loved the way that they still make time for prayer during the visit. The handsets are great and give everyone a change to tour the building at their own pace. It is a bit on the expensive side to enter

beautiful - Must see. this place is just so awesome. it is so hard to believe that it was built in the 1300's - i just do not understand how the work was done back then. they have an extensive audio tour - which is neat it does tell a lot about the place. very interesting to realize how many dead people are actually buried in the abby - kind of creepy when you walk thru there and think about it. But this is a must see attraction when in London

Wow. Coming from Australia that has only been settled for 200 or so years, to visit a place like this was a real thrill. We were lucky that we struck a day were there were no long queue'sOnce inside we were blown away, the whole majesty, history and granduer of the place was amazingFor us a must visit
Really nice. Great architecture and history behind the Abbey. Though not really meant for kids. Had gone with kids 13 and 11 and they were extremely fidgety.

free organ recital on Sundays; evensong was awesome. on Apr 28th Sunday we wanted to attend the free organ recital from 5.45 but we got delayed... we had earlier attended the 4.45-5.15 organ recital at St paul's and getting out of westminster tube station overshot the abbey and walked on to the parliament houses... by the time we retraced our steps, the organ recital was over but we attended the evensong and listened to the lovely choir.. it was a great experience and all for free... next day we arrived at 9.20 but there were mile long queues for the cash as well as credit card lines... so we gave it a miss. we do regret we did not see the interiors in more detail
Try to go to evening song. Beautiful! Try to be there for the short mass with the choir Mon.-Fri. in the evening. You are not allowed to take pics at this time though.

Very crowded. I've visited here a few times, but hadn't been for a while. I was amazed at the long lines and crowds inside considering it was April. Hopefully weekdays would be better. Quite expensive now, too.

Great British history. If you want to understand British history in just a few hours, this is the place to start. The walking tour is well-documented with the electronic tour guide. You must pay attention or you could miss one of the key points of the tour, Poets Corner. They have a well-stockeed gift shop

History, but too expensive. Been to London many times but never here before. Yes it is grand and living history but at £18 it is just too expensive when compared to major churches and temples in other parts of the world. But I suppose that's London , everything is more , transport especially - it's a wonder so many people Come..... But they do , and judged on its own merits the abbey is a must see.

A walk through English history. So many famous kings, queens, poets, scientists, and other high achievers from the UK are buried here. See where royalty is crowned. My only detraction was that it seemed to be more about the famous people than God.

Excellent slice of British history, but watch out for the grumpy person in the ticket booth. I took a group of students to London last week. We had a wonderful visit to the abbey. It is very moving to see such sights as Elizabeth I's tomb, and British history is why we were in London. At the end of our visit we lost 2 people from the group (this all turned out well in the end). Everyone in the abbey was super helpful, and allowed us to exit and re-enter a few times as we looked for our people. The verger of the abbey even announced their names over the loud speakers...can you imagine having your name announced at Westminster Abbey? The only unhelpful person was a grumpy ticket booth person who took our tickets off us so we could not re-enter the abbey. In times of concern for other people it is off putting to encounter a mean person when everyone else was eager to be helpful.

Great couple of hours. We took the guided tour which for an extra £3 was a bargain. Wonderful to be amongst all that history. Very busy and apparently they can get 8000 visitors a day. Dont bother with the cafe. Overpriced and not very good coffee (tastes like machine coffee). The Abbey however is wonderful.

great tombs. We have been a few times,even when able to take pics.Sadly,no photos now(past few years).The Abbey is wondrously ancient and gives a sense of English history like no other place.We especially like Elizabeth the first's tomb.The stained glass is as good as it gets,and the vaulted archwork stunning.If one looks closely,you will see some curved buckling of some of the tall pilasters.The stone masons build them to accommodate this over time.Enjoy this church as we have,it is not to miss.If you cant pay to get in,there are ample outside shots,particularly the arched doorways.

Bit pricey. £18 for adultsI know its an ancient attraction and must cost a bucket load to maintain but still £18.Anyway the 4 of us have been meaning to go for years so now was the time. Very good greeting and directions. 'free' audio guide if you want.If you think its big from outside wait till you go in it is a rambling old place and you even get access to the garden - who knew!Has a café on way out but didn't try it as 15 minute wait and only wanted a coffee.

Beautiful History. If you are in London even for a day, you need to make the quick trip to the Westminster Abbey to walk through it and just take in the history! There are memorials to legends and kings and queens buried there. It is amazing!!

Still One of my London Favorites. I have been to London twice and enjoyed my visit to Westminster greatly both times!We visited this time about 1:30pm on a Wednesday. There are two lines to get into Westminster which are "Pay with Cash" and "Pay with Credit". If you have the London Pass, you can go in either line. Both lines were about the same length and only took us about two minutes.The tickets are £18 for adults, not sure the price for children. Once inside you receive an audioguide which is included with the ticket. The guide takes you on a nice path around the Abby. When I first came to Westminster I was 11 years old. My siblings (all younger) and I enjoyed having our own audioguides and still consider our visit to Westminster to be our favorite site in London.Tip: This might be an overall tip for London, but I would say that if you enjoy history or are hoping that your children learn a lot of history during your visit, do some prep work. So many Kings and Queens in English History have the same names. Try to find some sort of diagram or picture (like a family tree) to give your kids...or use yourself. This visual aid will help them remember what they have learned better.

Simply cannot be missed. There's little point to going to London if you miss Westminster Abbey. Despite the throngs of tourists, etc, it is an absolute must see. It is an incomprehensible journey through British history. To be standing over or in proximity to legendary figures: Darwin, Newton, Elizabeth I, St. Edward, etc, is hard to comprehend.I strongly suggest booking a guided tour. The audio tour only scratches the surface. We listened in on a couple of groups, and they were getting much more information.

So much History. Westminster Abbey is full of history. I did not realise that so many of Britains Kings & Queens are entombed here including Henry VIII, Elizabeth I, Queen Victoria to name a few as well as so many figures from the past Chaucer, D H Lawrence, Charles Dickens the list goes on.

A Must See in London. Westminster Abbey is a must see London attraction. The architecture is amazing and the many years of history are more than informative. There is a gift shop with truly unique items for sale. In addition I would recommend a visit to the Cellarium for breakfast....good atmosphere and very good food.

Makes one feel diminutive. To say anything other than this 'attraction' being excellent would be sacriligious. This is such an awe-inspiring beautiful place... oozing British history. We used the audioguide and it worked well to see us through. We especially loved the Lady's chapel.Sadly there was restoration work at the back of it so we didn't see all round. I was also quite taken with Poet's corner.This is a must see for all visitors to London.

Waited in queue longer than I spent inside. Westminster Abbey is quite pricey and you'll have to queue up for up to half an hour, but I suppose it is definitely unique and significant for its history.
great history. this place gives you such a sense of british history as soon as you enter the state occasions that have taken place really can be felt

Highlight of visit to Europe. This was without any question the highlight of our visit to Europe (essentially London and Paris). Having said that, our time at the Abbey was structured differently than most visitors and I can understand some of the negative comments. First this is a functioning church not just an attraction that is focused on tourist business so be prepared for changing hours, areas that might be inaccessible at time of your visit etc..Secondly yes there are crowds at times, there were long entry lines when we visited at mid morning but no lines at around 2pm or so when we walked by a few days later. TIP -there was a cash only line that was shorter that we availed of. The entry fee is around 18 pounds as noted in other reviews - we spent an extra 3 pounds for the guided tour and it has to be one of the best values ever- a highly informative and entertaining tour by an Abbey verger -highly recommended! Lastly if you are so inclined consider attending a service at the Abbey, there is no charge and it can be a moving experience. We attended matins (10 am service that is mainly sung) and the choir was in superb form and came back a couple of days later for the guided tour. Recommended.

Words can't describe... Simply amazing, words can't do justice. Get there early as it gets very crowded as the day progresses. You get an audio guide and it took about an hour to complete the self guided tour.

Abysmal visiting hours. I honestly can't review the inside of the Abbey as I was never able to get inside!! I arrived on a Monday afternoon at 3:40 p.m., only to learn they stopped letting visitors in at 3:30 p.m. When I returned several days later, I got there at 2:00 p.m. on a Wednesday.
