One sign stated that they were open until 6:00 p.m. After walking around to the exit door, the sign posted there said on Wednesdays, they stopped letting in visitors at 1:30 p.m. They need to check all the signs on the property and make sure they are accurate to avoid disappointment to others like I experienced. Now I don't know that I'll ever want to visit on my returns to London.

A must see place. A beautiful church with a lots of histories. The audio guide tells a lot of story about the church and who were buried there. I spent about 4 hours there, checking out every nooks and crannies. The heavy crowd can be distracting but the staffs were very helpful in answering questions! Impressive architecture.

an amazing place to visit. Westminster Abbey was one of the highlights of our 10 day visit to London. It is steeped in history. Every inch including the ground you walk on has an historic story to tell. Great self guided tour and guides posted all over to answer any questions you may have. A must to see when visiting London.

Amazing piece of British history, but a bit expensive. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful and breathtaking place, filled with the tombs and memorials for so many of Britain's leaders and monarchs. It was amazing to visit the place where many of Britain's monarchs were crowned (and to see where William and Kate got married!) But there are some downsides to visiting the abbey. Its £18 for an adult ticket and even though the lines to get in were quite short, the abbey was very crowded inside. You are given a free audio guide which helps to lead you around the abbey, but as you're viewing the sites and listening to the commentary, you are surrounded by dozens of other tourists doing the same, standing in the same spot. I would recommend going quite early on in the day if you would like to avoid the crowds, but its definitely worth a visit

Beautiful Gothic church, but very cold and unfriendly place.. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful Gothic cathedral in Parliament Square. It has soaring pillars which give the impression of great height. Some chapels are areas have ceilings consisting of beautiful fan vaulting. The fan vaulting, a late development in Gothic architecture, is probably the finest in the UK.The Abbey is the resting place for many great people. Among the tombs are the splendid tombs of some British monarchs, including Queen Elizabeth, and Mary. Poets’ corner contains the tombs of some of Britain’s great writers and poets – Geoffrey Chaucer and Charles Dickens to mention just two.The Abbey is a beautiful building, both inside and out. Do not forget to view the cloisters with the windows looking over the green secluded space, and some with hauntingly beautiful glass workThe cloisters lead out to the Dean’s yard, and other romantic and beautiful spaces in the heart of London. These areas can be accessed from outside without entering the Abbey, and it is worth exploring this beautiful heart of London.So, why do I rate this attraction so low? There are several major areas in which the attraction serious fails. In some cases the problem can be mitigated by forward planning, and initial preparation. However, other issues cannot be avoided, and need to be weighed up. I look at what these problems are below.1. It is essential to plan your visit. The Abbey shuts its doors early, and sometimes is shut for the preparation for events. It is essential to look on the internet to check up opening times. A morning visit is better than an afternoon one since the church shuts very early.2. The entrance cost is extremely high. The current rate is £18.00 per adult, with no concessions for elderly people.3. A lot of important sights are not available to visit. I visited when the rear of Lady Chapel was closed off for renovation. This meant that a lot of royal tombs were not accessible, and covered in plastic sheeting. This was not mentioned at the entrance when paying entry, nor mentioned on the internet. 4. The tomb of Edward the Confessor is inaccessible except at certain times for short periods. This is not mentioned at the entrance. It is possible to see it, but you must find out about access times, and ensure you can get in with the guide.5. There is very little information available. There are short notices about some of the items, but very little. There does not seem to be any form of annotated map with useful information. The visitor will need to obtain this information prior to entry. The Souvenir shop is situated outside the church, and I am not sure that they will allow re-entry.6. There are a lot of wardens, all pompously dressed. They appear to be trained to be unfriendly and unhelpful. I watched in amazement at the way that visitors entering to attend a service were strictly queued up, and had to wait in an orderly line to enter the service. 7. Photography is forbidden – and strictly policed. That is despite the fact that the visitor has paid a substantial amount of money to enter. I found my visit very wearisome. There are few places to sit down and meditate. It is a beautiful building, a very beautiful building. It is also a very cold and unfriendly place.

Crowds Ruined the Experience. Westminster Abbey was the number one place that I wanted to visit. It is a fantastic experience IF you are one who doesn't concern yourself with people constantly bumping into to you. For me, the overwhelming number of people in the Abbey, along with the $27 US cost to visit, seriously hurt my enjoyment. However, it is not to be missed if you can overlook these items. It's history and grandeur is unsurpassed.

Still very good. A free audio guide is a good thing. Lots of information and lots of people. The place is crowded. My last visit I scheduled to an early entrance and thus I beat the long lines. This time I tried to do the same but arrived 15 min late and had to queue to get in. There is nowadays a credit card queue and a separate cash queue. The place is still amazing. For some unexplainable reason there is a no photo policy. Having travelled around in Britain, London is the only place where I'm not allowed to take photos in churches. They claim it is for religious reasons/house of worship. Is there a special London religion...? Strange and very sad since the variation of book and postcards in the shop not nearly gives you the opportunity to buy your photos instead. Poor photos, to few photos and no proper photo book of the place. No photo policies without a good reason sets down my grade by one.

Expensive and crowded - but a historical must. At a whopping 18 UKP/adult, we almost decided against it, having to return a second time when we learned the attraction's strange hours. Still, both of us were glad we went in. Breathtaking historical value. The digital guides are the only way you'll learn a thing, so make sure you get one (no extra charge). We were wary at first with the rather boring voice (the guy who played Scar in Lion King ;) ), and the slow-moving crowds, but we quickly became entranced by how many famous people had been touched by the artifact. Takes a little patience to get through the lines and empty your wallet - but it's probably not one you want to cross of the priority list.

Majestic. Well worth the two trips it took us to finally get in! Make sure you find out opening/closing times - we didn't the first time and missed entering by a few minutes. Once inside (if you can ignore the crowd) the majesty of the place is almost overwhelming. The final resting place of so many great people, and to walk where they once trod is amazing. The architecture and stained glass are wonderful. Don't miss it!

Nice but too many people. This abbey is beautiful and there is much to see, but its too crowded and for the amount of things there are to see, the crowd makes it hard to take in a lot. It feels a bit rushed. But, I am someone who likes simplicity. It is a fascinating place to visit but the cost and crowd make it less enjoyable.

Long lines and costly but worth a visit for the history. The classic church nearby the parliament building is worth stopping into for those history buffs who can appreciate the kings buried within that go back to the 13th century. It's quite expensive to enter (18 pounds) but a remarkable part of world history.

Stunning, but the standard tour lacks information.. I went twice, first for the Sunday morning service, which was a treat. The choir is fantastic, of course, and the organ is a joy to listen to. Of course, being there for service means you don't get to look around at all. I went back on a weekday to join the hoards of tourists. The audio guide that is included in the admission is barely adequate. I feel like it tries to move you thru the site fairly quickly, giving you a little bit of interesting information here and there, but overall lacking details. There were other people there with their own private tour guide and I wish I would have known to find one for myself.

Never seen so many famous dead people. Not my first trip to Westminster Abbey but I always discover something new every time I visit. It can feel a little claustrophobic compared to St Paul's and you don't get the same ambiance, but lots to see maybe take a seat for a few minutes between chapels and tombs and try to get a feel for the history of this beautiful place.

Must see. A must see on your visit to London, a bit costly to walk in (18 pounds) so if you can afford it you should do it, if not you must at least take a look around the area.. You can see multiple sights there in one shot anyway such as Big Ben, Parliament and Buckingham Palace

wonderful piece of history. We missed the last tour of the day but were able to catch evensong (vespers service). We felt like we were in a piece of history. If you have the chance, vespers is a very inspiring and beautiful service. We definitely plan to go back for a full tour of a religious icon that has so much history!

So amazing. Will go back in a heartbeat. Amazing history and was able to go pray in the private area of Edward the confessor at the 3pm prayer. Only about 30 people a day get to do this- recommend highly for a spiritual event. Also while walking around in the outside courts pay attention to the ground with all the older gravestones - just amazing reading some of these.

historically interesting, but too many tombs. It was interesting as far as the significance of the Abbey in royal history, but the focus of much of the tour is the tombs and plaques to all the deceased. It got rather morbid. The Abbey is also rather dark. Lots of construction going on inside in one part.

Amazing place. I loved being here. Westminster is beautiful and the audio guide helped fill in the long history of the amazing place. Don't miss poet's corner and the cafe that serves good fresh food or tea for reasonable prices.
So much history and beauty. Attended an evensong I found the experience delightful. When you grasp all who have trod the church, you are overwhelmed.

Quire they were preparing her seat for the forthcoming services. Any English history buff will spend hours here! Take the Acustiguides offered and follow along as you go back in time of the English kings, William the Conqueror being the first king crowned there in 1066, and subsequent kings thereafter. Many famous historical people are buried there and memorials for others are placed all about. The Quire is a remarkable place.....so many aspects to it. Be sure to learn about the numerous people of note who have occupied the seats throughout history, and to this day. While we were there a priest told us they just heard Dame Margaret Thatcher had died, and by the time we arrived at the Quire the staff were preparing her seat for the services that would eventually follow. When we were almost ready to leave, a boys/mens choir began singing/chanting....it was so beautiful. Be sure to time your visit to take this in, such a peaceful time. Sitting in god's house listen to these "angels". To me, this is one of the "MUST SEE" places when in London, before many of the others, there is just so much to take in.

Very worthwhile!. While the crowds are very difficult to contend with, the Abbey is a must see. The audio tour is informative but we found it sometimes awkward to follow. The mass of people made it tiresome to move through the smaller rooms. The majesty of the Abbey make it all worthwhile! Highly recommend!

So many famous dead people. Charles Darwin, Isaac Newton, Shakspeare, Winston Churchill, Charles Dickes, and the list goes on and on. Breathtaking both outside and in. This attraction was at the top of my list for London sightseeing. Definitely not to be missed.

What a shame.... Firstly, Westminster Abbey is a fantastic place to visit and I would say a must see. Unfortunately, I have to agree with fellow reviewers that the staff could do with extensive training on Customer Service. Being British and proud of our vast heritage, I was ashamed at the rude manner of the so called 'guides' especially to those visiting from abroad. Please check the times of opening carefully as they will snatch the audio guides from your hands and shout until you leave. They could do with taking a leaf from the staff at the National Trust's book...Could do much better.

The Good and the Great. An amazing Abbey, full of so much history of The Good and the Great! The gardens are so peaceful, you forget about the hustle and bustle of Westminster and Bigben over the wall. Everyone is willing to help you with any question you have about the Abbey or the people entombed there.
Great in every aspect. Evensong at 5 pm, w ith chior on most days, not wednesdays. You don´t get the buildings history, but You get a glimpse of Heaven instead!

Worth the tour. The cost of the tour is worth every pound! We have been visiting European churches in France and Italy over the last couple of years and thought we could not be impressed any more. We were very wrong. The Abbey has a whole diffrent character than most of the other churches. The walking tour is a great way see the Abbey. You can take it at your own pace, listen to the enhanced details or speed through it if that is what you choose to do.

Expensive and Unfriendly. Despite the cost of 18 pounds for each adult which is very very expensive for a church, the staff is unbelievable unfriendly and very impolite. Girl in the ticket sales counter looks bored and make you fell that you are bothering her for being there, people in these positions should be well trained and understand that they are perhaps the most important "welcome card" of any business as they will get in touch with almost all the customers. The guy in the private tour was more interested to avoid people outside the group to listen the explanation than in the proper explanation of the areas making the whole group to fell uncomfortable with the situation and people outside the group embarrassed. So as a one of the most-see attraction in London the whole experience is not great which was also compared with other couple and groups visiting the Abbey, all having the same opinion. So unless you are prepared for the poor service and end up the tour feeling uncomfortable with less 18 pounds in your pocket go ahead with the tour, otherwise you can spend your time visiting for example the Westminster Cathedral which is free and beautiful or St. Paul Cathedral.
Stunning attraction. Amazing to see the coronation chair, make sure you take the audio tour as you are blown away by the famous people laid to rest on this glorious church .

This place deserves better. I have planned to visit this site on a weekday in order to find most of what there is about to see open for public access, such as Pyx Chamber, cloisters, gardens, etc. On the day, I found two very long queues, one for cash paying visitors, another for plastic cards. Took the cash queue, and traffic moved slowly but surely. Was done in about 10 minutes. So far so good. At the cash counter, I paid GBP18 which is hefty in comparison to other places, but I knew in advance of. However, upon entering the building, I was taken aback. Hoards of people filled the place with no one to guide them (except for those with an audio guide). At times, visitors would simply enter a nave without giving others inside time to exit so as to make more place for them. The abbey looked dark inside as well. Then the pyx chamber was closed. And so on.I suggest that access to the Abbey is made by advance booking only and by means of timed tickets (similar to Madame Tussauds), thus limiting the influx at any one time. Additionally, for the price a visitor is told to pay, he should find more ushers inside to guide the flow (to my knowledge I saw only a pair during the entire visit). Ultimately, if an area is advertised that it opens during a specific time-frame, than the administration should see that they stick to that.Would I recommend this place to family and friends? I'll them of my experience, and to save time and money and visit Hampton Court Palace Gardens instead
All I can say is WOW. This is a must see in London. The place is huge, and the history in unbelievable. Kings & Queens buried every where.

Just Ok. After a whirlwind tour through Europe, London was my last stop so after the magnificent churches I had already seen this one was just average. The history is there, but nothing that magnificent about the actual architecture. I would recommend this based on your actual interest in the history, less the actual structure. I now live in London and when I have visitors I always advise them to skip as there is much more to see in this city.

Glorious!. We spent several hours in Westminster Abbey. The admission was £18 for an adult, and once inside we paid £3 for the tour. It was excellent. The Verger told of the history and less well known bit and pieces of the Abbey. We got to sit in the Quire which is only allowed to people on the tour, and we got to go up into the private area of Edward The Confessor's shrine. All told, it was a superb visit, and I was in my element learning all about the history, the people and the royalty who are buried there and who are part of the British fabric of history.
Beautiful Building. The history, the architecture, the quietness. A wonderful haven in London and part of so many historic happenings.

Worth It. I loved Westminster Abbey, I went and did an audio tour, as well as attended Evensong on a Sunday, which I highly recommend regardless of your religious beliefs. Westminster is stunning and holds so much history, and is really a fascinating place to visit in London, Evensong was beautiful as well, and free to get into, though you need to get there early and be respectful that it is a church service, not for tourist show.

Amazing. One of the most amazing places I've ever been! Yo can see a lot of tombs of famous people an royalties.This is the place , where almost every Royal ceremony is happenig.Just stuning, I still feel the goosebumps!

A little too much everything. I will say that if you are in London, you should probably go to Westminster for a the history. Kings, queens, adventurers, poets, scientists are all burried here. Monarchs have been crowned, married and buried here for centuries. However, be prepared for crowds. The longest lines we faced of any site we visted where here. The inside is a jumble of statues that left me dizzy and overwhelmed by the pure chaos of the place. The guides and staff are pretty aloof and disinterested, but I can understand that when you see the crowds they deal with every day. My advice is go, be prepared for lines, crowds and pushing. Reward yourself with a pint in a quiet pub afterwards to recover.

No pictures allowed but great place to visit. Bank holiday Monday in London.....busy? No it wasn't to our amaze. Just walked to take pictures and to our delight no queues. Family ticket £36(2 adults and 1 child under 11). A must to see as it is an iconic history lesson and such amazing graves! Our daughter of 5 was very bored, but we really enjoyed it. A bit disappointed that no photos can be taken, but a kind of magical place. Look out for the oldest door in the world near the end of the tour...which I am sure gets missed. Nice staff and a pleasant experience.

A must for your visit to London. A great place to wander round looking at the memorials and graves of kings, queens and notable British people. When we went there there wasn't much atmosphere as there were hoards of people wandering round but it was still good.

Gorgeous. This church was beyond amazingly beautiful. We spent several hours there looking at the burial sites of the many famous people. The architecture was beautiful. You cannot take photos inside but it was lovely.

Beautiful. So compared to Italy and France I have to say that all London buildings have got nothing on them but I did like Westminster. Better than St Pauls and I went along thinking I would not like it as I had been disapointed by all the rest I had seen. Price was a bit steep? I felt everything was so was not suprised. Did like the free audio phone that you walked around with and got to know all about the place. I found this more interesting than St Pauls. The most suprising good thing were the toilets. How is that. I desperately needed to go, but there was a queue outside in the cold and snow to get to them. Both male and female together. As I was waiting in the queue all I could think of was I bet the royals don't have to do this. But once I got in, the bloody toilets were the warmest place to be. No wonder everyone took so long. Heated to the max. You could just sit there for a while to get warm again.

Be surrounded by history in an amazingly beautiful church. This is history. Not to be missed on a visit to London especially if you are an Anglophile like myself or if you are a monarchy buff. It is amazing to see where coronations and royal weddings have happened. Imagine standing not only where Queen Elizabeth I is buried but where she was crowned as well. The Abbey's employers are incredibly helpful and full of interesting information. I cannot wait to get back. It is absolutely worth a second visit

Incredible history lost in the crowd. Jammed with people, no posted historical information. We opted to join a Verger Tour. (Vergers are apparently internal staffers.) Bad mistake. Verger Peter was a cranky man who was highly annoyed by questions and Americans. Told us that we would set off alarms if we picked up one of the recorded tour devices (not true, but this allowed him to move faster by skipping a lot). Highly recommend that you avoid Verger Tours, especially the nasty Peter. He made a long-anticipated visit to this Abbey miserable and terribly disappointing.

Massive, Impressive and Costly. £15 pounds to get in (Senior) We opted for Westminster over St Pauls which also charged. I have been in Westminister Abbey before but did not remember going to places where I went this time. Nor do I remember paying. Therefore, this was a new experience. The earphone made the tour with valuable information being given. It was difficult to follow at times due to the crowd of people there. A map comes along with the handheld earphone which makes following a little easier. The Abbey is a must to see. Just be ready to see it with many, many, many other people. Also, when you get in line, be sure you are in the correct one. The day we were there, there were two lines, one for cash and one for credit cards. Try to time your visit to being there when the bells are pealing.

Amazing. I visited with the London Pass. Now I don't usually enjoy attractions like this, but from the moment I walked in I was in awe. The building itself is absolutely gorgeous. Everything is so detailed from the building to the tombs. It was very interesting walking around with the (FREE) audio guide. Was very happy about the free part because most other places you have to pay for them. Without the audio guide I don't think I would have enjoyed the experience as much because it tells you facts about the people who the tombs were built for and also why the tombs were made the way they were. After giving the audio guide back I wandered around for a while and went to the museum which wasn't worth my time at all. As you leave you see the Coronation Chair which is amazing to see with your own eyes because it's such a huge part of history. I just picked up something small to remember the experience at the gift shop which you conveniently need to exit through (same as most attractions though).

Expensive admission fees to see glorified coffins and graves. The place was way overpriced vis-à-vis other admission to similar cathedrals in Europe at 18 pounds. Hence I gave 2 stars compared to other places in Europe. Yes the place is historical with the tombs of English Kings and famous scientists but this is daylight robbery.The audio phones are okay and informative similar to those in continental Europe. Won't spent more than 45 minutes in the cathedral.Better to take pictures outside and move on to other attractions

Gets very crowded. The queues to get in moved fairly quickly but once inside it was very congested so it was difficult to really appreciate what this fabulous building has to offer. Definitely worth a visit but I would suggest that you go early

Get there early. £18 a ticket for a church always seems somewhat wrong. We arrived at approx 1030hrs on a saturday. By this time it was packed. I think it had the ability to be a truly fantastic experience but being treated like sheep in transport spoilt it. You are handed a audio guide device that is very informative. As long as you are not near noisy children you should be fine. My only major criticism would be that smaller areas such ad Elizabeth I tomb needs an Usher at the entrance to allow crowd control. Some visitors are on a mission and will not give way.

Mesmerizing!. Visiting Westminster Abby was one of the most amazing travel experiences I've ever had! You see the tombs of Elizabeth I, Bloody Mary, Mary Queen of Scots and numerous other historic monarchs, not to mention the tombs of Darwin and other famous scientists/thinkers/writers. There were so many things to look at it was a little overwhelming at first, but luckily the audio guide points you in the right direction.

Shame!. I was looking forwards to seeing the Abbey after travelling up to London for the first time in 25 years. The admission charge of £18 single stopped me in my tracks! The Abbey is my history and my heritage but this excessive charge amounts to institutional extortion. I will look at my church through new eyes from now on; shame on you!

This is a must see.. Astounding, crowded, historical, beautiful. Buy into a London Pass, it will make the cost of getting into this Abbey less. Do not eat in the cafe on site, it is expensive and the food is not that remarkable.

Beautiful but underwhelmed. From the outside, the Abbey is absolutely beautiful and everything you would hope and imagined it would be. However, the hoards of tourists with their audio guides and the congestion within the Abbey make for an unpleasant experience. We felt like we were constantly pushed through the Abbey to make way for more people, and while the architecture is beautiful, the memorials on the walls are distracting from the true beauty of the Abbey. Overall, if you're in London it's a must see, but be prepared to be underwhelmed.
Beautiful. Breathtaking and awe inspiring at once. Should not be missed if at all possible; easy to stop by after checking out Big Ben.
Beautiful. Beautiful Abbey - very informative staff, although a couple did look very bored!! The audio tour was very helpful, made it really interesting - loved the place,

Spectacular. What a stunning church it is. The high vaulted ceilings, the lovely icons and the intricate tombs are just amazing. I was blown away by how marvelous it is and would love to go back. The chapels are fascinating, especially thanks to the audio guide commentary by the deep tones of Jeremy Irons. My only criticism is that whilst we were in the garden the abbey closed for mass and they didn't leave any signs for an alternate exit. We eventually found our way out though.In the gift shop I asked if they had a postcard or picture of a particular statue that I liked (you can't take photos inside the abbey) which they didn't have but kindly told me that I could order a copy from their library. Very helpful indeed.

One beautiful cathedral!. Very well organized self directed tour (with personal audio device).MUCH grander and steeped in history than we realized. An absolute must if one visits London. Well worth the price of admission.
Westminster Abbey. Beautiful & a must-see. Remember that you can't see the inside on Sundays because of services so go on another day of the week to take full advantage of this historic landmark.

More amazing than we imagined.... We toured the Westminster Abbey as part of a family trip to London (2 adults and 2 teens). Seeing the Abbey from the outside was nice, but touring the inside was phenominal. The audio guides were helpful and allowed you to listen to additional details if you were so inclined. There was a lot of history inside of the Abbey. Most interesting to us was poets corner. The royal history was good too, but we don't have a good understanding of all the royal bloodlines to truely appreciate some of the tombs. Once inside the Abbey, the staff seemed to be very helpful. They were interacting with elementary age kids as it seems they were on some sort of "scavenger" hunt for information in the Abbey...probably to make sure the kids were engaged in the experience. Since we were not allowed to take pictures while inside, we bought a souvenir book at the Abbey shop afterwards. Highly recommend a tour if your schedule permits.

Audio tour was excellent. The audio tour gave many details about the people and their relations with others so it's a great place to start your tour of London. I can't believe there are so many sarcophagii in the Abbey. Seeing the Coronation Chair was a bonus. It's nice that such a historical place in history is open to the public. I would recommend the tour to others.

Lots of history here!. Westminster Abbey is well worth a visit, purely from an historical perspective. It wasn't our favorite place we visited... St. Paul's wins that award... but it was incredible in its own way. Well worth a stop.

History come alive. A living bit of history, headphones giving audio guided tour were very helpful. It was all just a bit overwhelming--lots of things to see below your feet (tombstones), at eye level and above as well as on the ceiling. The tomb of the unknown soldier brought me to tears. But the people, oh the people. There were soooo many people. People shuffling along, people standing in clumps and thinking about shuffling along. People that didn't seem to care standing in clumps and shuffling along. I wonder if they could set up appt times? I toured in April, typically not a vacation time but there were also lots and lots of school groups.

wonderful history. What a marvellous way to spend a few hours.we were captivated by the beautiful architecture and history of the abbey.we was amazed by the amount of famous people that are buried at the abbey. At first my partner thought that £18 entry fee was rather excessive but realised it was worth every penny, we was given a audio commentry which was very informative,very clear and well spoken (by jeremy irons ) a great place ! Well worth a visit and makes you realise the fabulous amount of history we have in this country.

Highlight of our trip. We didn't actually plan to see Westminster abbey, but it was snowing(yes, snowing in April) so, in order to find a warm shelter, we got tickets (£18 per ticket.$26-29 audio tour is included in the price) and got inside. It's a magnificent structure built in 10th century ( can't believe, they build this kind of building without crane) it's not just a church where kings and queens were coronated and married, also I learned, it's a resting place for royals, famous writers and poets (C.Dickens, C.Bronte) well-known composers and politicians. Definitely, check a museum of the abbey and cafe(We had a steak sandwich which was very good) it gets very crowded during the lunch, so better come before 12:15.

Stunning abbey. Westminster Abbey is absolutely stunning, both in terms of architecture and history. We spent half a day there, even our two children aged 8 and 10 were kept interested from beginning till end of the visit. The audio guides which are available in several languages are a good source of information. For children, there are fun assignment sheets that they can fill in, and after completing them, the children can bring the sheets to the gift shop where they will be rewarded with chocolates. There was a large group of tourists on the day we visited but the place is so large that you never felt crammed in or rushed. It is definitely worth a visit.

Amazing. What a spectacular and historical place. It is stunning inside and chock full of interesting history and many famous figures. Make sure to make use of the included audio guide which brings the place to life. I expected just another beautiful church and was pleasantly surprised to find it was much more. A definite must see when you visit London..

Go Inside. Pay the fee and go inside. Well worth it. Free audio tour in most languages will walk you through the church and point out the most popular graves. Felt a little irreverent walking on graves, but I guess that's to be expected.

pretty good. There is so much historyin this building. In this celebrity obsessed age it would be unbelievable to have so many celebrities in the same place. I love the way that Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots are as far apart as possible. The architecture is amazing, the stories fascinating, what more could you want in an English church (other than free entry

Stunning. Westminster Abbey will simply take your breath away as soon as you step inside. There is so much history contained within those walls. I wish you could take photographs inside as there were so many things to see. Definitely pick up your free audio guide to use as you are walking through the Abbey. These guides will help you see the history contained within the walls. You simply must go to Westminster Abbey if you are in London.

A lesson of British History. I highly recommend guided tour. It gives you an in depth account of the people buried here. As well, you get to go to some chapels closed to the general public. I can't recall how much was the cost but it was quite affordable.

Dream Come True. Going through Westminster Abbey for me, was like going back in time. I was especially thrilled to be escorted by one of the docents, to the burial site of one of my Ancestors, Thomas Shadwell, Poet Laureate to the Crown, in the 17th century. I was with my BFF/Soultwin, Jodi Tanner, and best friend, Bobby Farkas, which was a Good thing, because it was So Overwhelming to me, I actually had tears streaming down my face, and the docent told us that they don't normally allow photos taken inside, but since this was a 'Special' situation, we could take many photos.....Great....I was a pretty sight!The entire experience is So Etched in my memory, but the kindness, and thoughtfulness, of the British people, will forever make England a Special Favorite. If you plan to tour the countryside, make sure to research the selection of guides thoroughly.
Lovely church. Really beautiful building to see. Lots of wonderful details on the outside of the building and inside. Lovely area around the abbey to walk around and see the lovely gardens.

One of the great churches in England. To do justice to your visit, you must have a blue badge tour of this place. There is just too much that you may miss going through the Abbey. So much history and so many stories that need to be told - our tour guide was very informative and made the experience a much more enriching one.My only complaint is that they do NOT allow you to take pictures (even without a flash) or videotape inside the Abbey. Most of the other cathedrals allow this.

WOW - The magnitude and importance of this building just overwhelms you!. I am not a religious person but there is something about all the events and occasions that have been held or recognised in this place of worship that I found quite moving. To be able to walk around and encounter the exact spot where monarchs have been crowned - Stand where Princess Dianas coffin was placed- touch the tomb of Elizabeth the first and Mary Queen of Scotts - read memorial stones of Chaucer/ Shakespeare/Dickens. I really found it hard to take in as it feels so surreal. Add onto this the ornate carvings, the stained glass windows and the sheer architectural magnitude of the building itself and this is an awe inspiring visit that I would recommend.

Really great but why no photographing?. This is a must-see, really a great building oozing of history. The café was good too. But why is it that yoa are not allowed to take photographs? (or in S:t Pauls?).

The Holy and the Hallowed. I was a bit taken aback when I first walked in, surprised at how dark and small it seemed compared to my visions of Westminster Abbey on television. I quickly realized it was the lack of photo lighting and the high mounted camera angles that made the difference in the feel of the place. That understanding having taken place, I took the guided headset tour through the Cathedral. Listening well, I scoured alcoved altars all along the sides that were filled with the sarcophagi of the ruling class. A history of sinners and saints poured out from room to room, each with its own personality and its own story to be told.I became so enveloped in the history I heard and saw that when the call for morning pray rang out, it startled me. Taking off my headset and bowing my head I prayed along, only to open up my eyes to find I was praying over Chauser's marker on the floor. I didn't think that he would mind. So much to see, so many names familiar to us all, requiums for the greatest people the empire ever knew, there was so much to explore there. I could have spent much more time at Westminster Abbey than I had that day. It is on my list for a repeat visit the next time I'm in town

Catch a service with the Choir... Dedicated or Drive-by you will appreciate the beautiful sounds that this building has been capturing and amplifies for hundreds of years. Immerse yourself in the visual and structural beauty of the internal building as the harmonies lift you to a timeless place where hundreds of thousands before you have also traveled.

History. My wife and I visited for the first time since we were children. So much to see and learn. When you visit, as children, you sometimes miss so much. Once we had finished, we were also able to have a bite to eat in the café. Very good quality.

Steeped in history, beautiful choral music. We attended some of the evensong service on a Sunday. Although I am not religious, the Abbey welcomes all and so I didn't feel hypocritical watching the service just to listen to the beautiful choir. I was surprised to see they weren't wearing robes. Because the service was on, there were no tours, but we were able to walk around the courtyard in the middle to see the tombs. I would love to go back someday to spend more time here, every moment is well worth your time.

Gorgeous. Living history! It was beautiful inside and out, and the history was astonishing. Learning how the Abbey has evolved over time with the influence of royalty and notable historical figures was fascinating. Not to mention all of the wonderful things that still occur here - history is constantly being made. It makes history that much more tangible. It's really a highlight and I'm glad we came back to see it!
Well worth a visit. A great visit with lots of history and atmosphere. Easy to get to. A great experience which can be combined with looking at the Houses of Parliament next door.

Swept away by history. Westminster Abbey is maybe not the most obvious place to visit with two kids, when touring London, which is so rich in action-packed and more tantalizing attractions more aimed at the younger.But after having walked for just a short while in the cathedral itself and trying to communicate our meager knowledge, it was fascinating to see how it caught their interest. We opted out of the audio guides, as English is not out native language and it was more necessary to look at the things and try to explain than to listen to the by no doubt excellent audio-guide.Free maps and material for the kids are distributed by volunteers, easily recognizable in their green robes.You have to adhere to a certain route round the Abbey, which makes sense, as there a many people visiting the place.Personally I loved to see the different memorials - especially the one for Isaac Newton, but our oldest daughter who's an avid musician also easily spotted the memorials for composers she has been playing works by; Henry Purcell, George Frederich Händel, Edward Elgar, Benjamin Britten, and Muzio Clementi. Impressive that the names has caught on.This is indeed a place for grasping the history of what would become an icon of british royalty (all coronations have been here - eventually) and the Imperial dreams of a country.For the royalists of many countries, the central nave and the benches at the organ will most likely be remembered by anybody viewing the recent royal wedding on TV.The Abbey originates from 1042 and has a long history of additions and rebuilding, all this can be read somewhere else, but do see for yourself.Nearest tube station is Westminster, and you can the just as well have a look at Big Ben at the same time...

It Will Be A Trip Highlight. As I read through the reviews, it's all been said. Worth the admission, use the headset, and enjoy every minute. Being a history buff, this was one of the highlights of my trip. Do a little research beforehand. There's a lot to take in at the abbey. A little disappointed you can't take photos, but understandable. Don't miss it.
Knowledgeable and fanatic tour guider. Very good content in the recorded tour guide sound track, however, nothing can compare with the very knowledgable tour guider

Amazing amount of history in one building. We loved it. We loved everything, it must have more history in it than any other place i have ever visited, we were very happily surprised. The only downside is you cannot take photos inside, if its a money issue i would rather pay more and have the right to take photos than be expected to buy postcards etc. its a shame but still highly recomended.
Beautiful. Westminster Abbey absolutely oozes history. It is a must see for anyone that visits London. The number of world changing individuals who have been buried there is just incredible!
Beautiful. Use the head pieces so you can hear the great info!. It was so interesting seeing and hearing about the abbey. There is so much history inside and is well worth a visit

Quite spectacular. There was a line up to get in, which seemed to move quite slowly, even though were were two clerks on duty. Cost of entrance was Adults £18.00. i suppose this barely covers the maintenance for the facility! You can take a group tour for £15.00 or an audio heaphone free, which we did. I would have taken the tour but ....You can easily spend an hour or so and there is a fabulous bit of history to be learned. Well worth the venture!Cheers,Britishcanadianeh

Loved the History!. Have been aching to hit Westminster since reading 1000 years of English history and the abbey does not disappoint. To walk on the tombs of so many people, read the inscriptions and see the tombs of kings and queens is pretty awe-inspiring. The phone-track tour helper narrated by Jeremy Irons sure doesn't hurt either.

Highlight of our visit to London. We were fortunate to beat the crowds as it was before Easter and Spring break when we visited. Extraordinary! So much history in one place right up to recent years. Gives a real sense of the tradition that has made Britain what it is today. Leave yourself enough time as you don't want to rush through. It is expensive. We purchased a London 6 day pass and used it to enter and used audio guides to help us understand what we were experiencing. Highlight was hearing the choir and enjoying the outstanding acoustics.

Moving Experience. The admission charge is worth it. There is so much history to be found in this beautiful place. You will get an audio guide included in your admission charge so you can be guided around. There is plenty to see and take in. You can sit and pray and reflect. They offer "mini" services if you feel moved. Allow at least an hour and one half to complete your tour. Don't miss this landmark!

well worth the entrance fee. You need 2 hours or so to really appreciate all that is in Westminster Abbey. We happened to be in the Abbey when they announced the opportunity to attend a service in one of the small chapels. There were only 8 of us at the service. I felt very priviledged to receive an intimate service in the company of past kings.

abbey. I visted on my own,was a bit crowded,but worth every minute,really great building with all those king and queens buried inside it,loved the poets corner,coronation chair,the stained glass windows were awesome,worth a vist.

Awfully expensive, historical. It seemed pretty expensive to us, but it is a major attraction. Some of the majesty was lost due to the amount of tourists. It was amazing still though. Some of the tombs are just cool. It's a huge place, so you need time.
attended Evensong. unbelievable! heard the boy's choir sing and able to sit and enjoy the acoustics of the Abbey! Wish we had the chance to tour the entire Abbey, so much incredible history

A marvellous building rightly part of England's heritage. Westmister Abbey is as impressive inside as it looks from the outside. A marvellous building. Try and get there early as it gets busy. Spend time looking at the fascinating memorials to the good and great of England's past.

A must see!. Every time I go to London I make sure to go here. My first couple of visits were just self-guided tours, but on one of my more recent visits I decided to take the Verger's tour. It costs a few extra pounds but is well worth it! I would take it again in a heartbeat. It's so much more informative and you are allowed access to a few places you wouldn't be if just on your own. My most recent visit was during a school break (April)and the lines were incredibly long. I decided not to go in. Just something to keep in mind when you decide when to visit. I went once in November and no lines at all and very little crowd. I will continue to visit Westminster Abbey every chance I get. It's one of those places I don't think I'll ever tire of!
History you can relate to as a Canadian. Being from Canada and understanding the monarchy, it was simply amazing to be in the same place where our Kings and Queens have been coronated.
The price. It is too expensive to visit that. Around 18£ per adult. But from the outside, looks really beautiful.

Irreverence ...... It should go without saying that Westminster Abbey is an unquestionable 'MUST SEE' visitor attraction in London. I don't have the eloquence to describe the magnificence of the Abbey but suffice to say it gives one a very tangible connection to the key personalities of hundreds of years of European and World history. Ergo my following comment may appear irreverent and disrespectful but I can assure the reader that I am most sincere. I unreservedly I direct any visitor to the Cellerarium cafe within the Abbey precincts and further suggest you purchase a bowl of chips there - they are no less impressive than the surroundings. 'Don't know how much they were - coz a dear friend bought them for me - but they were memorable and delicious.We were asked to share a large (12 seat) table in the restaurant and we enjoyed chatting to several visitors in a most friendly and relaxed environment.

So much British history in one beautiful building--a must see!. Virtually all the greats are buried here, along with many obscure wealthy ones, and you will encounter familiar names from politics, history, literature and the performing arts. The building is huge and complex, with many chapels and shrines. Like the Duomo, one could visit every day for a year and keep encountering new things. A half day is what's needed to enjoy a Who'sWho.One caveat: The admission charge is high and seems out of place for a house of worship. Although everyone's money is welcome, the Christian message that goes out over the sound system at least hourly is undiluted for those of different faiths.

A place to witness history..... Many times you will find the place closed for services but check ..It is well worth a visit to witness the making of history...The great Royal and state occasions literally ooze through the stone work.Nearby is Central Hall Westminster .The great church of the \metodist faith ,which is me...!!..In the basement there is a cafeteria which is cheap and very few people know of it.One piece of useless information....Andrew Lloyd Webber' father was organist there for many years..

Too much to see!. This place is packed full of memorials and you could easily spend many hours just reading all the plaques. It is quite crowded so think about doing this first thing when they open. An audio guide is included in the admission. Also be sure to see the crypts. The only bathroom I found was down on that level along with a gift shop and cafe.

Worth the visit. Obviously its beautiful. What intrigued me was all the people buried there. I am not British so I was not familiar with many of them but there were so many known leaders, artists etc. it was interesting. Very crowded - and tight spaces - but manageable.

Peace and Serenity. Westminster Abbey and Evensong...Having missed out on the Evensong Boys Choir in our previous visit we made this a first port of call… after our meal at the pub located on the ground floor of our boutique hotel – bearing the name of The Sanctuary House Hotel. And after 7 hours of travelling which involved cabs, escalators, elevators, airplanes, more cabs… Sanctuary is just what we needed!Ah yes … Westminster Abbey … steeped in history and ceremony - rich in gold, colour, sculptures, columns, domes, porticos. Chandeliers hung like tear-drops from high-domed-ceilings. Stained glass windows paid homage to Saints and more. Baroque architecture lavished not just the exterior but the interior with complex shapes, extravagant ornaments, opulent paintings, and bold images.Yet the peace and serenity we felt within the cloistered walls left an indelible mark and followed us in our wake.

Easter Service.....Divine. I have been to the Abbey a million times. This is the first time I attended Easter service. I was convinced by my friends to attend the service. Divine and wonderful. Like watching history in motion. I am not the most spiritual but I enjoyed it. It was cold but wonderful. Led by a female reverend. Her words resonanated throughout the church. I may try service there again

History at every step. This is a place to go if you ever doubt your pride in the UK and especially England. There is history at every step and the building is just incredible. This is well worth a visit. The entry fee at £18 seems steep but what you get for the money is worth it. If you are a member of the armed forces you get in for free on production of your ID.
Beautiful church. Beautiful church. Impressive just to walk around. I believe you can do tours, but I didn't have time when I was there.

Guided tour is fabulous. Make sure you go early a get a spot booked on one of the verger guided tours of Westminster Abbey for the extra £3. The guided tour pushes you past the crowds and into the private areas of the Abbey. You can also then stay on for longer with the audio guide to see the items again, or focus on different areas of your choice.the guided tour really is amazing and well worth it, especially when they add in some of the personal stories of recent events such as the royal wedding.

Breathtaking. We've seen quite a few Cathedrals, Abbey's and Churches in our travels but Westminster's atmosphere is absolutely unique. Everywhere you look there's some piece of history staring back at you.We opted to do the 90 minute guided tour as this was our first visit and we were so pleased we did. As our guide said, 900 years of history in 90 minutes PHEW.You do rush thru, but you get to see areas of the Abbey that general visitors don't, so that in itself is worth it.Groups are a max of 20 people which is a good size, especially when the Abbey is busy.Our guide, Peter, involved the children who were in our group and helped them complete the kids guide/questionnaire.Sadly we didn't have time to go back and get the audio guide, and retrace our steps. To do this you really need a good few hours (tho we'll be back for sure).Sadly, but understandably you can not take photos so we bought a book at the shop as a momento (and of course, with many more explanations of things we didn't see)Highly recommended.

Highly Recommended!. We didn't really know what to expect - we only knew Westminster Abbey from a few coverages on TV - but once inside you almost literally feel yourself going back through many hundreds years of history for a variety of disciplines (science, royals, poets, ...). Recommend to take the guided tour and to visit the museum, too. Initially I found the the entrance fee quite high, but that feeling disappeared already after a few minutes. Impressive!

Fabulous. We saw the Abbey a few years ago. For this second trip, we paid a few pounds extra for the guided tour, which was 1.5 hours and within just 15 minutes, was clearly money well-spent. The Abbey is an amazing, overwhelming place full of history and interesting things to see and even better the second time because it was easier to focus on all the treasures. We spent about four hours here and enjoyed it thoroughly. Look for the oldest door in Britain.

Good Experience. Good place to visit, though very busy when we visited. I'm sure its much better and you get a much better experience of the place when its not so busy, but the staff are really helpful and the guided tour was really informative. Well worth a visit to see all the history. Beautiful place.
Must see. This is a must see in london. So many historical moments have taken place in this church that you cannot miss visiting while in town.

The guided tour shouldn't be missed.. For just a few pounds extra, we took the very informative guided tour. You have access to some off-limits areas and our verger was quite entertaining. Book your tour ahead.

Breath taking. Made 2 visits on a recent trip to London. First of all I attended the Easter Sunday morning service so had a peek at part of the Abbey for free. Then decided to go back the following afternoon with a friend and pay to go in. It was definitely worth the entrance fee and would visiit again on future trips.

A must!. Westminster Abbey is THE place to be visited.Marvellous from outside and once inside you get astonished with its architecture and history .At the entrance you are given an audio tape with your mother tongue language, which helps you to discover this amazing place.It is the place to feel the British culture.You are not allowed to take pics inside, but it is worthwhile.

Wonderful Place. We visited on Easter Monday - the negatives are it is really expensive - £18 per adult and also it was really busy. That aside, Westminster Abbey is fascinating, full of history and a must-see in London. You are not allowed to take photos inside - take all you can outside, the architecture is stunning.There are memorials just everywhere you walk, it is really full of history. The greatest people in the UK are buried here and have been for centuries - Prime Ministers, Kings and Queens and all the great and good. There are memorials to Darwin, Newton and the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior.The audio guides are excellent and give you a lot of information. We saw a vergers tour - we were too late to join it, but it sounded superb. If you have children, pick up a children's trail at the door, this is a good way to keep them involved.Poet's Corner was my favourite place - every literary name you can think of is here including Dickens, Hardy, Tennyson, Kipling and more. There is a statue of Shakespeare resting his hands on a pile of books and the tomb of Sir Laurence Olivier is beneath this.The entrance includes exploring the Cloisters and the museum. You can see the Coronation Chair on the way out -unfortunately covered up during our visit as it must be having work done on it. Since 1066 monarchs have been crowned seated on this chair in the Abbey.We went back again for Evensong at 5.00. This is wonderful and I highly recommend it. You need to queue at the gates from about 4.15 onwards, they let you in at 4.30. It gets really busy - we got there at 4.15 and got seats near the front. The music, atmosphere and Book of Common Prayer Service was a real highlight for me and unforgettable.

So much history here.. What a beautiful place, so full of history. The building is stunning. To see the names of so many great literary figures carved into the stones was a great experience. You cannot see London without a visit to Westminster Abbey!

if only it weren't so dear.... First, the bad news: £18 admission is outrageous, there are no two ways about it. An annual pass at £40 is clearly much better value if you'll make repeated visits, but it's still extortionate. And there are are still parts you won't get to see well or even at all. Plus the crowds, the sometimes unfriendly staff...On the other hand: there is much that is magnificent, fascinating or curious and services can be very fine.So your best bet, if you have time, is to visit a sung service and carefully ponder whether you want to return as a paying visitor.

No better place to be.... We were blessed to attend Evensong (evening church service) on Easter here, and it was terrific. The singing, organ music and sense of history here combined to make this an unforgettable experience! The abbey is beautiful at any time, so to be here on Easter was really special. But even if one is only able to come here during the week, this is still one of the top attractions in London, and one of the most beautiful churches anywhere in the world. I highly recommended a visit at any time!

Fantastic Journey through our heritage.. from the tomb of the unknown warrior to kings and queens to Darwin and Shakespeare . A visit through hundreds of years of this great countries history.The guides were most helpful ,well worth visiting . Also the coffee / tea rooms are some of the best we have been to.

Verger tours. It would be well worth the effort to plan ahead of time and reserve a spot on this tour. It was very well done and informative. We would highly recommend it for both religious individuals and history enthusiasts.

Stunning and historic. My husband and I have visited the Abbey twice, the first time attending service and the second taking the tour. Both experiences were well worth the time. Even though we visited during off peak tourist season, it was still very crowded. If you attend a service there you are not allowed to tour the tombs, but it is an amazing and historic feeling to know you are taking part in traditions that date back hundreds of years. When touring the Abbey, the audio guide is interesting and makes the experience much more fulfilling because otherwise you might miss some of the tombs sine many areas are overwhelming. Some of the tombs are also a bit difficult to fully see; there are protective gates around them which obstruct views (although they make sense to have!) The Lady Chapel and Poet's Corner were especially interesting to see. Attending service there was a very calming experience while touring it was a bit stressful due to so many people and student groups. Not to be missed, just decide which way you would like to experience it!

A must see in London. A must see in London. So much history and info that its difficult to absorb in 1-2 hours. I have 2 suggestions about visiting this place:1- I'll suggest u to read about this place (such as thru wikipedia) before visiting it, and to decide which parts / attractions are u more interestd in (such as ceiling of lady chapel and the coronation chair). If u will go unprepared, chances are there that u will miss something of ur interest. Atleast make a list of persons who are buried here (such as Newton, Darwin etc.) and u want to see their final resting place. 2- Do take a guided tour. The tour price (around 2-3 GBP) is much lesser than the entry ticket (around 18 GBP) that u have already paid for. This guided tour will take you to some places that are closed for general public and will make sure that in the limited time available, u get the most interesting and relevant info.The down side is that u cant take pictures inside the abbey, even without flash.

Well worth your time. The audioguide (included in admission price) is really helpful. The staff were very approachable and the place is an amazing mixture of social and church history. The cafe/restaurant is fine if a little cramped.

Too Crowded. My daughter and I visited on the Wednesday before Easter and that may have accounted for the crowds. We also arrived at opening. Unfortunately it was difficult to really enjoy each area as I felt swept up in a tide of people. The building itself is breath taking and I recommend using an audio guide to learn about all the history in the abbey. The staff located throughout the building were also more than willing to answer questions.My daughter visited last year and went in the afternoon. She said there were no crowds. With that in mind, I would recommend going in the afternoon instead of at opening.

Amazing!. The Abbey is a very serene place. The audio guide is a must. When you take off the headphones you realize how peaceful it is. There is so much history in one place. Would definitely like to go there again because there is so much to look at.

AMAZING and a must see in London. Wow! Such a beautiful experience so see a old building and the history in it. I loved every minute in here, and I'm not a massive history buff either.We visited on a Monday and arrived at 9am even though it opens at 9.30am. Glad we did, as we were at the front of the masses! As soon as we were inside we went to book the Verger Tour. I highly recommend this tour! It's an additional £3 but worth it. I found it informative and the Verger we had, Benjamin was amazing. Answered all questions from tourists and was extremely knowledgable about all the tombs and the history held here.We were really lucky and were able to visit other parts of Westminster Abbey that other tourist didn't have access too with this tour.  It was an amazing experience to visit all the different tombs and to learn about the lives of people here. We ended up spending 5 hours here and weren't bored! The audio guides are really helpful in getting around as well.Tips: get there early! It gets over run by schools and other tourists really quickly!Book a verger tour as soon as you get in. They can only take a certain number in each tour, not sure how many they run a day but you won't be disappointed. Be prepared that you can't take pictures once inside.

Verger-led tour. Westminster Abbey is wonderful. We went on the Tuesday before Easter & had wisely booked the 11am tour. There were queues to get in but not too long. The interior was packed. Our verger used his officialdom to good effect to guide us around BUT he spoke too quickly, was difficult to understand, was impatient, and sometimes rude when questioned about something he'd already said. I don't know what impression the overseas visitors went away with but i was quite embarrassed at times.
excellent childrens booklet. and excellent listening guide. a shame the cafe and cloisters were closed when we went, but the setting is wonderful. it is on the pricier side, so be prepared

Outstanding place. Westminster Abbey was an incredible place to visit. It is almost a thousand years old so the church had some remarkable architecture. It was so cool to see all the historical people's graves. I even got to stand on Isaac Newton's grave! The church also hosts services that you can go to. I enjoyed looking at the ceilings too.Overall, this is a must see in London
Bit Opressive. Architectually and engineering wise impressive. But very grey, dark and full of tombs. Poets corner was quite interesting though. Big lines prebook tickets. St.Pauls is much nicer.

Fantastic cathedral. It costs almost $30 per person to get in, but we thought it was worth it. So much history in one place. The audio guide is included and has a lot of info. It was very crowded when we went and there were a number of tour groups that packed some of the rooms. The sculpture and fixtures are incredible. The staff was very helpful in answering questions.

No pictures??. I was really excited to get to the Westminister Abbey but I was stopped at the entrance by a not so friendly security guy who told me that cameras was not allowed and needed to be handed over upon entrance. I carry a camera rig that's prettybig so I asked if they could guarantee me that nothing would happen to it while I was inside the Abbey which they couldn't. I asked if I could bring the cameras inside but hand over the memory cards and promise I didn't take any pictures - but still no go. Photographers - be advised!The audio tour however is good, but if you got a good guide book or a cell phone equipped with a guide app - no need for the tour. The Abbey it self is amazing and my best advise is not to rush your visit. Take some time to sit down, contemplate and just feel the atmosphere. Even though staff was less than friendly the place is a piece of history that should be on everyones "must do" in London
A WONDERFUL CATHEDRAL. A very good self guided audio visit. The interior is wonderful with its chorus, the king tombs, the high altar, the ceiling.

wow. Visited this wonder, you can feel gods prescence,so many people buried here, Edward the Confessor,Elizabeth the 1st, mary queen of scotts,Henry the 8TH ,S FATHER HENRY THE 7TH,, Charles Dickens, Geoffrey Chaucer,Handel,Anne of Cleves,Darwin,Isaac Newton,David Livingstone,,William Wilberforce and so on,VISIT THE ANCIENT CHAPTER HOUSE AND THERE,S A MUSEUM,it a great heritage of our country,the staff in green and red are very heplful, and there is a frre audio tour, DONT MISS WHEN YOU ARE IN LONDON.there is also a childrens trail when they finish they get free chocolate.

Highlight of our trip to London. A beautiful cathedral with fascinating links to the past, including the numerous tombs for British Kings and Queens. Very well organised audio tour that leads you round a particular route. Audio commentary was fairly concise but with options for further listening if so inclined. A welcoming atmosphere with audio introduction emphasising that you are welcome to ask for a chaplain to pray with you or to attend a service for which, of course, there is no formal charge. However, as we were doing the 'tourist thing', we were happy to contribute to what must the massive cost of upkeep for this historically fascinating and beautiful church.

A treasure!. At Westminster Abbey you do have to pay an entrance fee but included in that is a self guided audio tour. We were able to do this at our own pace. There are no photos allowed in most of the Abbey. You can also sign up to take a tour. There is a place to eat but we didn't eat there and there is a gift shop at the end of the tour.

An Amazing Cathedral!. The interior of this Cathedral is amazing there is always something that captures your eye and the best thing, at least for me, is that the place is filled with so much history. My only complaint is that i wish that they allowed photos to be taken inside, but it seems most places in Europe of the same stature doesn’t allow.

Great historical and architectual site. Stopped by here with my teens just to "check the box". We wound up staying for hours. I expected a great cathedral, but did not expect who was buried/memorialised within. My teens first noticed William Wilburforce's monument. Then Faraday and Isaac Newton's. On to the kings and queens with many other historical notables along the way. It was stunning. We opted not to take the audio tour guide (free of charge after admission price). If I return, I most definitely will.
Perfect. I've been to London a dozen times and I never tire of visiting Westminster. The history there is nearly overwhelming. The addition of the guided audio tours was very helpful.

Must-see, at least once.. This place is amazing. Yes, it's relatively expensive to get in (I think it was around 16 pounds p.p.). But totally worth it!The buildings themselves are magnificent. And when taking the free audiotour, you get more history than in an entire course (well, almost). Everything is impressive. There are no words to describe it.Also, don't think this has anything to do with religion. I am an atheist, and have taken this tour twice now; I love it. It's all about history, politics, architecture etc.Take at least half a day for this, as it is rather large. Also, try to pick a weekday if you can; the place can get horribly crowded, but on a Thursday in January we could easily manouver even the small rooms and passages.While you're here, have a drink/bite at the Cellarium Café!

pay the fee to go inside. The cost is worth the experience. The audio guide is included in the admission price. You will learn a lot of the history of the Abbey if you listen to the audio guide. Be patient, it is a bit crowded. No pictures are allowed, but I bought postcards in the gift shop as my "pictures". The Abbey is amazingly beautiful and moving.

impressive and a must. I love the architecture of the abbey. It's just awesome and gorgeous. Many kings and queens have been buried there as well as some poets and writers. The entrance fee is a bit steep, but well worth it as you gain entrance to the abbey, cloisters, museum and the use of an audio guide. The audio guide helps to understand the historical significance of many different parts of the abbey. I would definitely recommend a visit to the Westminster Abbey.

Wonderful Ornate Abbey - rich in history. Beautiful ornate abbey and a very definite must see on a trip to London. I do believe that everyone should see it, but I did not realize there were so many people buried in there. Not meaning any disrespect, but I felt it was more of a shrine or mosaliun for those with lots of money. The admission fee was pricey.

EXPENSIVE ABBEY. Whilst I enjoy splendid Architecture and wonder at the skill and effort of the builders who built such magnificent buildings without our modern machines and equipment it tingles a bit when I am asked to pay almost £17.00 to look around it. Nevertheless it is a place of great power and historical significance which, as an Englishman, I should not miss for the sake of a round of drinks.The cafe is also expensive and, if you have booked a our of the Houses of Parliament (which is next door and a good visit) wait and have your tea and crumpets there.

Amazing history. It was amazing to see Issac Newton and Handel's grave. What an historical church. Entrance fee includes tour headset which is nice. Also during your visit if on certain weekdays you can view the courtyard garden which was a treat.

Must see!. Great audio tour, amazing architecture and so much to see. Westminster Abbey is a must-see place when you are in London. Can get crowded so make sure you visit first thing morning. Entrance is free with London Card.
Pagentry, history and spirituality. The Abbey is beautiful, the audioguide (included in admission) is great, you can set your own pace and listen to as much or little as you like.

So disappointing. It was raining the day we went to see Westminster Abbey but it didn't get any better in the gloom and disarray of the inside and I agree with RustyMc_ATL it is more like a crypt than a church. Save the expensive £18 entry fee and go somewhere more inviting. The monuments and sculptures were all piled up in corners. It certainly didn't look like this when we saw the Royal Wedding. I wonder how much they paid entry fee?

History in front of your eyes. To go to London and not see Westminster Abbey is a mortal sin. It is amazing in every way. So many historical people are entombed there, that you could spend an entire day on that part alone. To see where Elizabeth I, Isaac Newton, John Milton, and a great assortment of kings, poets, statesmen and scientists rest for eternity is a moving experience. Be sure to be respectful, as the Abbey is a church, and they are pretty strict about such things as not wearing a hat inside (which I accidentally did and was asked to remove it). No pictures allowed.

Excellent value. I thought at first it was expensive but actually really good value and for the price that's £18.00 for one adult, you can use your ticket to return to one of the services. Very popular due to the Royal Wedding I guess. Very interesting and worth a look.

Not big but unrivaled in the UK for its History per square meter. I've been to more ornate cathedrals and abbey's but only st Marks in the Vatican can beat this place for its history. So much to see in here and your walking in the footsteps of kings and queens . The audio guide is very good , probably the best I've used anywhere .Thoroughly enjoyed our visit but really need a whole day to take it all in and do it justice. Entry however is a little pricey at £18 for adults.

Breathtaking. How is this not #1? It was absolutely amazing. It's nice from outside, but once you walk in... too bad they do not allow pictures to be taken. There is so much history, make sure you pay for an audio guide. Go earlier in the day, otherwise, it can get pretty busy. See it in the morning, then walk over to the Houses of Parliament.

Horrible. This is not a church it is a crypt. Visited 30 plus churches (many as old and many more ornate) across England, France, Switzerland and Luxenburg and this was the biggest disappointing of them all. Good thing it was off season and there was no line.

Amazing Place Full of History. This was our first time to tour Westminster Abbey and we were very impressed! The free audio guide is very helpful in explaining some of the sites. There are guides walking/standing around who are there to answer your questions or just to tell you more things. Do ask questions and do engage them because they are really friendly and knowledgeable! There is SO much to see and learn about! We spent at least 3 hours touring the main church and then we had lunch at the Cafe.It is very moving to walk on the same stones as all those have gone before us! This is a must see while in London. To avoid long lines outside and inside, try to get there early. We did and we had no trouble getting in and it was not that crowded inside the Abbey. This will be a better experience than if you are caught in long line ups!

Amazing.. Loved this, so much to look at and interesting for kids too. kids were given a sheet (history treasure hunt) and it kept them busy, at the end the got a giant chocolate coin when they handed in sheet at the shop (didn't matter if it was all filled out they didnt even check).

wonderful venue for music -- and food!. In addition to the other attractions of this historic site, the daily Evensong performances (except Wednesday), at 5pm, free and open to the public, are a marvel. Recently heard the all male choir (of some 20 members) perform very moving plainsong and an early-modern composition. The setting is quite intimate--there were no more than 150 attendees--and the setting is incomparable. Well worth the visit for music lovers!
An amazing church. Westminster Abbey is a church with such rich history. It is the site of kings, queens, poets, and other famous English men and women that have passed away and been buried there.

Always a favorite. We visit every time we are in London. There is so much here to see and take in. Highly recommend use of the free audio guide. If you get the chance, take the Verger led tour also. It costs a little bit more, but they are very informative and you get to go up into the Confessor Chapel. An enormous amount of history is in this place, plus some very wonderful architecture. Watch for the worn tiles and steps from the millions that have walked her before you. I suggest reading some of the history on their website before visiting. Then list out a few of the more unusual things to look for in your visit.

Amazing, have to see it belive the artifacts this church holds. I'm not one to tour museums or churches but this took my breathe away. Though I suggest go early there are long lines to go in and it's about 18 sterling to get in.

A little disappointed. This Abbey did not meet our expectation. Once you go in, it seems a little depressing - it is quite dark. I understand it's purpose is to hold important graves, but I really didn't feel the overall experience was worth the prices they were charging - £18 per person. I think if you are an aficionado of royal history and churches you might find it worth it, but otherwise we definitely found it a strange way to spend that much money. St Paul's was far more interesting/spectacular for us.

Church or Mausoleum?. This place struck me as more of a mausoluem than a church/place of worship. There are so many memorials crammed in here that almost every nook and crany is completely filled. I expected a beautiful cathedral and it may have been there, but it was overshadowed by the cemetery feel of the place.That being said, there certainly is a lot of history here, and the included audio tour presents a lot of information very well.The fact that no photos are permitted inside was annoying.

stunning building. spent the day at Westminster Abbey last week and thoroughly enjoyed it.the building was stunning and full off history off every turn,i thought it was lovely that on the hour they asked if u could just stand quietly whilst a very short prayer was said.even if u are not religious its still a very moving place,i would 100% recommend it,they also have a beautiful garden at the back off the Abbey which you can sit and have a packed lunch

"Hands down, best Abbey I've ever seen". Well what do you know. Joey from Friends was right...Me and my partner spent the previous Christmas in York and this took me back there. A wonderful, historical building it most definitely is. The audio guide (free) helped guide you around the splendid building. I really had no idea just what has gone in this building. There is a lot to take in. Given the weather was awful outside. I was quite happy to take my time and enjoy what was on offer.A real must on the "Things to do in London". I am not a religious person but even I was blown away. I would definitely re-visit.

Incredible and magnificent!. This place is just incredible and amazing! You will be in the presence of important historical figures ranging from Britain's monarchs to poets and scientists. I would suggest to join the verger tour. It is an extra £3 but it was worth it. You will be brought into areas that normal visitors would have no access to.
