You will be allowed to sit in the quire, and the most important part is that you will be allowed to go in St. Edward the Confessor's chapel and shrine. This is just behind the high altar and is not accessible to everyone.

Amazing Westminster. Fantastic, amazing to visit. English history under one amazing construction. Yu need to be prepared to spend at least a good 3 hours to look at all the amazing tombs. Henry VII lady chapel incredible. An english history lovers dream. Well worth the expensive addmission fee.

Beautiful and rich in history!. There are many famous people from history buried here. Take your time, use the audio guide, you might be surprised by what you learn. No photos are permitted inside. From the Royal Coronation Throne, to the mosaic floor at the alter, the Abbey is filled with history. Westminster Abbey has been the venue of Coronations, Royal Weddings, and State Funerals; but it is also a house of worship, so show some respect and enjoy your visit!

Incredible Historic Church. Yes, there is a reasonable fee to tour Westminster Abbey (covers costs & constant repairs). But where else does one get a glimpse into the vast history of not only the United Kingdom but also the heritage of any North American/Australian etc. whose ancestors came from the British Isles. Included with your ticket is an audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons. One of my favourite areas of the church is the poet's corner where so may famous poets, writers & musicians are buried or have a memorial ....Chaucer, Spenser, Longfellow, Milton, Shakespeare, Handel, Bronte to name a few. The church itself is stunning & the treasures beneath its roof are irreplaceable. On Sunday the church is only open to people attending the service. Visitors are welcome.

Our ticket into Westminster Abbey was. the 5:45 p.m. organ recital. As typical American tourists, we wanted to see more in London than time available, so the 30 minute organ recital fit into our tight schedule. Westminster Abbey is on all the walking tours, and is close to other can’t miss sights like the London Eye, Big Ben and Parliament, Westminster Bridge, St. James Park, Buckingham Palace, Whitehall, 10 Downing Street and Trafalgar Square, plus Westminster Underground Station and Westminster Millennium Pier (water taxis) are right there. We arrived at the front gate about 5:35, and told the staff member we were there for the recital (No tours on Sunday, as it should be). Arriving 10 minutes earlier would have been better just to sit in amazement in this beautiful building. The nave seating filled fast, but we found some places with the other 100+. The view of the interior for the organ recital is limited, but really, all seats are good; Everything was good. For 30 minutes we soaked in the music, the high interior walls and ceiling, the stained glass and the great names of history and Christendom……David Livingstone, William Wilberforce. One could go on and on. If unable to make the Monday-Saturday tours, the Sunday worship and hymn services and events are certainly acceptable alternatives. A visit to their website has most of the helps to plan your visit.

A London must see. I have no faith to speak of but this building took my breath away - We had a London Pass card so no Qs. The iPod audio guide that you get was excellent and easy to use. Simply stunning and I loved the Lady Chapel . Must see.

A National Treasure. Hard to believe we were in the presence of so many Kings and Queens of England. Oozes historic content from every corner and behind every pillar. Although it is most certainly on most tourist routes, it is an awesome experience, nicely interspersed with 1 minute of prayer on the hour and the amazing privileged of twice daily public prayer in the Shrine of Edward The Confessor
was marvelous, but expensive. marvelous building, unbelievable, but getting in was 18 pounds.Better visit a service, you can do that for free, and those services are just fantastic

Incredible. If I hadn't gotten free passes from my university, I probably would have skipped Westminster Abbey, but I'm so glad I had the opportunity to check it out! The inside was incredible, and a free audio tour is included with purchase of tickets, which was very helpful. Unfortunately, you can't take pictures inside, but it's a great way to spend a cloudy afternoon in London.

Amazing and highly recommended.. Amazing in every way. Everywhere you look, there is something very old and interesting. The place has an especially good vibe about it when compared to other churches we have visited. We went to the midday service and took communion which was special and refreshing for my wife and I. The only disappointment was that we could not take photos. Westminster Abbey exceeded my expectations and comes highly recommended.

An absolutely amazing experience!. Truth to be told, I went here in doubt, why? I had little time to visit London that day since I was gonna take a flight on the early morning the next day so did not wanted to be exhausted. When I exit the Westminster tube station, I had two choices, either enjoy the sunny day marveling at the Houses of Parliament for the last time or going to Westminster Abbey/Cathedral.I chose Westminster since I have heard its amazing, The entrance cost you 16pounds, which sounded a lil' too expensive for me, but when I entered the building, God allmighty, it is indeed amazingly beautiful and a very iconic and historic place in London, to be able to see kings and dukes tombs, the places on which famous writers rests remains its an unforgettable and unique moment. You must need at least 2 hours to enjoy the visit but feel free to spend more and more time, either inside or outside marveling at the facade!Great great place to visit, its absolutely a must in London, and of course, I did not regret choosing the abbey at all!

Not to be missed!. If you have any interest in history or architecture, the Abbey is a MUST DO on your trip to London. My first impression is that it was smaller than I imagined, but that is because there is so much inside. The different tombs and memorials are fascinating. Get the audio guide, it certainly helps you to know what you are looking at.

Poor Value. I was so excited about taking the children at half term to see the place where 'Kate and Wills' got married but I probably should have checked the website first. I always assumed places of worship were free to enter with donations gratefully received but was horrified to find it would have cost £34 for the 3 of us to step inside - so we didn't. Very disappointed!!

This is a must-see!. Westminster Abbey has been a highlight of my trips to London. Honestly, I haven't done the tour and paid the rate to go throughout the Abbey. I like to attend services or concerts in the way the Abbey actually still functions rather than as a tourist. It is also free this way! They have Evensong services where the Choirboys sing that are spectacular. The first time I went, it was a slow tourist time and we sat in the choir loft area facing the choir! Wow! The whole cathedral rang out with their sound! I have also gone and attended a regular service. The organist is amazing . . . the choir sings beautifully . . . and the homily is in English and understandable. My sons (teenagers) even enjoyed it. We had time to sit and absorb the history and essence of the church!

Massive Disappointment - Give It A Miss. Had been wowed by a visit to St Pauls Cathedral on previous visit to London so was expecting a similar experience at Westminster Abbey. What a massive let down. Not much more than a (large) collection of tombs, mainly to people I'd never heard of. With the extortionate prices charged to get in to a church, this has to be one of the biggest rip-offs anywhere in the world.

Organ recital on Sundays. I only had a brief visit to London and had to fit in some serious site seeing in a couple of days. Westminster Abbey is not open for tourism on Sundays as it has regular church services. They have a choir recital and an organ performance on Sundays that are free of charge. This is a brilliant bargain, as you get to see the abbey and listen to word class music all in one go, and it cost you nothing.
A must see in London!. A visit to Westminster Abbey is a must see in London! This is well worth the price of admission. The amazing history and tradition are not to be missed.

Amazing.... We booked a tour with Context Travel, which specializes in very small group tours led by very well-educated guides. The Abbey is a very interesting building, as it was built over a couple centuries, and has hundreds of memorials and graves. Learning the history of the monarchy, the stories of Mary, Queen of Scots and Elizabeth I, the history of Poet's Corner - all fascinating. Try to book at a time when you can get up into the Shrine of Edward the Confessor - amazingly quiet in the middle of the hubbub of this building. It is very expensive to get into, and it's too bad that photos cannot be taken, but given the age of the structure, that is understandable.

Wonderful few hours. I'll admit that I didn't want to visit Westminster Abbey. I was put off by the price and the preconception that it was "another bloody church" and I wouldn't enjoy it. My kids desperately wanted to visit so I relented.The last time I visited was circa 20 years previously when visitors were largely left to their devices to explore. Visitors today are given a handheld audio tour device which describes each of the key features. This massively enhanced my visit and made the tour so rewarding.My little one got a tresure hunt / quiz to complete which kept her fully entertained and was rewarded with chocolate at the end.All of the staff we met were enthusiastic and informatice and were a real source of information, and a source of entertainment for the kids.Overall - Massively exceeded my expectations!

London in February. We went to Westminster abbey during our February visit to london.as there were no school holidays in teh UK and Europe, there were not many visitors and we did not have to stand in a cue. the church is great and lots of famous people buried there, but after an hour it just gets to many.I believe this visit should be done in 2 days, otherwise it is just an overkill of information.

Stunning but expensive. The title says it all really. It is a wonderful place and it is breathtaking, but it is expensive. Be warned that you can't take photographs, which I think it is disappointing. The audio tour is ideal and very easy to follow.

The most quiet place in a whole world. Westminster abbey - very quiet and beautiful place in London, one of the biggest churches with good architecture for tourists and local citizens. We was in Westminster Abbey in November, when all Britain remembered about World War 2 and we saw many little fires on the ground near main entrance to Abbey.

Above expectations. Costly, but worth it IMO. Didn't think so looking from outside, where the building appeared to be rather unremarkable, even somewhat unattractive relative to the other great religious buildings of Europe. But the tour (we used only the audio guide) completely exceeded our expectations, and felt very much like a walk-through of English history. Highly recommended for fans of English history.

Honestly, I wasn't too astounded. Honestly, I wasn't too astounded by Westminster Abbey. If you're looking particularly for the architectural wow factor, there are other churches and abbeys you could visit. You're not allowed to take pictures, and the ticket price was somewhat steep.

A bit too expensive. Most cathedrals/churches I have ever visited were free of charge, here, you need to pay almost 20£ for a visit for one adult, that does include a free audio guide featuring Jeremy Irons's commentary, but I did feel it was a bit on the expensive side. The architecture is beautiful and there is a lot to see, and it was a surprise to see so many familiar names commemorated there, it was certainly an interesting experience.

Much better than expected. I have negative experiences with religious attractions. This church was a positive surprise. Very well organized tour with audio guide (I think even in Hungarian). Not too detailed but very comprehensive info. Attendants, church people all over not to control but to guide you. I left feeling well fed with knowledge (and with a snack in the nicely furnished cafe).

Humbling. I have been to London many, many times and this was my first visit, as an adult, to Westminster Abbey. It is expensive to get in but if my contribution helps us to retain such an iconic building then it's well worth it. I was totally unaware just how many people are buried there. Elizabeth 1st and Mary Tudor, also Mary Queen of Scots is there too and many other members of royalty. I was unaware that Geoffrey Chaucer was also buried there, which has encouraged me to buy a copy of Canterbury Tales. Charles Darwin and Isaac Newton too and numerous Prime Ministers. You are given an audio gizmo which is free and is very informative. I heard the choir practising for Choral evensong. They sounded heavenly, so moving, wonderful. It would have been worth the entrance fee just to listen to the singing. a most memorable visit!!!!!

Expensive but worth every penny!. A bit of a shock at £18 per adult but at least our 8 year old went for free so we were able to get a family saver ticket for 2 adults and our 15 year old for £36 in total which was better. However, there is so much to see inside and the audio guided tour is so well done. It's hard not to be moved by the tombs of the great and the good buried inside the abbey, together with the facts that nearly all of our monarchs have been crowned in this beautiful space since William the Conqueror, plus the recent wedding of William and Kate! I must also mention the cellar cafe where the four of us enjoyed a really tasty and good value lunch, made better by the fact hat when my husband happened to mention to the waitress that the homemade soup whilst being very tasty, was quite salty, fetched the manager, who said that she had tasted the soup and also found it to be salty, thanked us for the feedback and took the price of one soup off our bill! Excellent service I thought and the food really is good quality.

Go for the history.... If you have a choice...go in the winter when it isn't crowded. It is expensive at 15£ per adult. Having seen it on TV during royal weddings and funerals I expected it to be larger than it actually is. I enjoyed the audio guide and if for no other reason visit the Abbey to see the spectacular ceiling in Henry VII's Lady Chapel.Continue on to the Abbey gift store - they have one of the best buys - a tin bank in the shape of Big Ben and filled with 14 English teabags for 3£!
Awesome and beautiful. If you are interested in Great Britain's history and religion. This place is well worth a visit. My Mum & I visited on Saturday and it was packed.
The Abbey. Shrined in history, pomp and circumstance. What more could you ask for. A great historical place to visit and although pricey the money maintains this wonderful building.

Pricey and crowded - but still worth it. The audio guides are excellent - one of the staff not so much! But it was a good, punchy narrative which told you enough but not too much. We were there on a Tuesday morning, on a freezing winter day, outside school holidays, and it was still absolutely packed. I would not consider going here in a proper tourist season because it was about at the limit of what I would consider enjoyable. At £18 for two of us it was fine, but she turned 11 a few days later, and it would have been a lot more then - which would warrant reconsideration if time were tight.I got a real kick out of the history - Cromwell, Elizabeth and Mary, Mary Queen of Scots, Henry VII etc. Poet's Corner was good, although half of them are just plaques and not tombstones, so not quite the pantheon of tombstones I had expected. Compared to other historic churches (eg Winchester Cathedral), this felt more like a tourist attraction as it was so overrun, but still it was definitely worth seeing. My 10yo was not as impressed as I was, but there was enough to keep her interest. The cafe was a welcome respite afterwards, with very good food, and an excellent, simple but high quality children's menu.

Attend a service. I attended an evensong service at this church while I was in London, and it was a truly magical experience! I was there about half an hour ahead of time (the service begins at 5:00 p.m) and was offered a seat in the choir area. Admission to evensong services at Westminster abbey is free. The service itself was very beautiful and inspirational! The interior of the church is wonderful as well, too bad you're not allowed to take pictures.

Costy but summarizes London's / Great Britain's history well. Entrance fee is 15 pounds for students, 18 pounds for adults (if you don't want to spend this much but want to go in, think that entry to British Museum, National Gallery, Victoria & Albert Museum is free of charge and average the prices.)Inside you'll find a lot of tombs of kings, writers and poets from the 900s to 20th century. For me the most impressive parts were the chapel for the Royal Air Force with it's modern stained windows, a tomb where a statue of a skeleton steps out of the crypt to take the deceased wife and the ceiling of Henry VII chapel.If you visit London and you are interested in any historical background, visit the abbey once.

Take the Verger Tour!. Westminster Abby is wonderful , a magnificent old building filled with history We took the verger-led tour in January 2012 and thought it was fabulous ( it lasts 90 minutes and includes a tour of the Shrine , the Royal Tombs, Poets' Corner, the Cloisters and the Nave). Our verger was excellent and very entertaining and told us wonderful stories about the coronations, weddings, etc. I honestly think it is the best way to get the history of the Abbey
History at it's best. 2nd time visited but still had plenty to keep my attention. The recorded tour guide is good and very informatibe but I think if I go again I will do a Verger led tour

To expensive. We traveled by tube to visit this lovely Abbey only to decide not to enter. The cost of £18.00 each was extortionate. At the end of the day we should be encouraging people in to church not excluding the less well off.

I actually thought the parliament buliding was more impressive than Westminster. I actually was trying to find Westminster Abbey and I came across parliament and thought Westminster by mistake. Parliament was beautiful, but Westminster is also so beautiful as well. Its not somewhere you have to see, buts its definitely something you should see if you can.

Dripping with history - Britain at its best. This building is so full of history that you can feel it all around you.....it is difficult to take it all in. You may feel that is expensive....£18 per adult (discounts for 60+, students etc) but it is worth every penny.On entry you are handed an audio handset (in your language) so you can walk around at your leisure, see what you want, and have it explained to you by Jeremy Irons.For me the highlights were the tombs of Elizabeth the first and Edward the Confessor....there are many other monarchs and nobels there and overall the stones and memorials run into the thousands....and top of the tree the Coronation Chair and the grave of Sir Winston Churchill.The building itself is, of course, magnificent and the decorations etc breathtaking.One word - this needs a receptive and highly interested mind - I think taking small children should be done only with great forethought.Summary? Britain at its best.

Church makes money out of its minions. Just a church with fancy coffins. So disappointed not being able to take photos inside, not even without flash, after visiting churches all over the world who allow you to do this, I was very disappointed in this. after paying £18 admission I think they could have allowed this as it was off peak and it had very few visitors inside. I asked for permit but was turned down.

Steeped in historyand worth the price. A must when visitingLondon. To see for yourself the burial places of the Kings & Queens of England, Even if you are not religious the whole atmosphere is wonderful

lovely to see but £18.pp. we had a very enjoyable visit here, we found it most interesting and found the guided hand held radio tour very good and informative.we are uk residents and feel £18 each to enter a church is a lot of money and must be many people who miss out as its just too high, it would be better to allow uk residents to pay less by showing proof of residency and tourist pay the higher which many places do abroad.

Absolutely beautiful. Westminster Abbey is a must see when in London. Yes there are queues but thats just part of tourism. They have plenty of information available about the Abbey and the staff are happy to answer any queries. You aren't allowed to take photos inside - fair enough as it is still used everyday for services and worship. There is a gift shop that has plenty of all sorts of items and a cafe as well. Again went in on the London Pass so no additional cost. A really wonderful piece of Londons heritage.

This is definitely a place for history buffs. Words cannot describe how awe-inspiring this church is. I could not believe that I was there for 3.5 hours. A must see! The famous people who are entombed there and to actually see their names and tombs and even coffins. Just to know that the Monarchy has had marriages,coronations,burials in such a beautiful building is really amazing. And just a short distance away is Canada Park and Buckingham Palace. I can hardly wait to go back!

Choristers, History and Amazement!. An extremely amazing church full of historical tombs of many you have read about and many you have not. Being among so many of the "who's who" of history, standing where so much history as taken place, is somewhat of a surreal experience, to be experienced at least once in a lifetime.We went after 1:00 PM on a Monday in January and walked right in, received our audio guides, and spent 1 1/2 hour with absolutely no crowds or lines. It is a sobering, huge place of worship, with services possibly being held while you are there. (Don't expect it to be "entertaining".) It is beautiful in a haunting kind of way. Really makes you think of times gone by and their significance. (Would probably not be the best for children).We also attended the Evensong service. The service is at 5:00 pm weekdays. They ask everyone who toured the Abbey (and paid the admission fee) to leave by 3:30 pm and then allow those who want to attend the free Evensong to line up again, about 4:30 pm.Those first in line are asked to sit with the Choristers in the Abbey, (if there is space, after the parents of the Choristers are seated.) There were plenty of seats, however, not being early considerably limits the view of the proceedings, as you are off to the side of the main center aisle. The 45 minute service is definitely worth attending, whether you are religious or not, if just to hear the gloriously harmonious Chorister's voices echoing throughout the vaulted ceilings of the Abbey. There are instructions of what to do during the service (when to sit, when to stand). The High Commissioner of India spoke at the service we attended.You will only be able to view the perimeter tombs as you pass by upon entering and exiting for the Evensong service, but if you just want to see the main interior of the Abbey, without paying the entrance fee and viewing the major tombs and gaining additional information, this will do. Some have commented that they were abruptedly asked to leave after the service, but this is understandable as the Abbey is funded only by entrance fees. While worship is free, maintenance and upkeep is not. We noticed some areas of the Abbey could use a nice "refresh", but apparently, entrance fees are not sufficient to keep it pristine.Pictures are not allowed at any time, especially not during the service, as expressed "you are here to worship, right?" A subtle message to the tourist versus the worshiper! Amazingly worth it, free or paid!

If you're in London, you have to go. This is as good as it gets for history. Westminster Abbey is one of the foundations of the British Monarchy for both coronations and tombs. Absolutely fascinating.
Breathtaking. This is a must see. We even attended a church service and had communion. The architecture is breathtaking. You can spend hours here.
Photos!!!. What a shame that we can't have pics inside the Abbey, a place full of history, beautiful in architecture, the staff very kind.

full of history. They don't sell tickets online, and the ticketing queues are usually long, which deters a lot of tourists - a shame really because you will miss this great historic place if you go away. I usually go there early (but there is still a queue nevertheless). Make sure you check the Westminster Abbey website before you go because there are no tours when they have service in the church. The audio guide comes with the price of your ticket - use it, and you'll learn a lot about the place. If you listen to each section in the guide, you will be spending about an hour inside, which is well worth it. As in most all cathedrals, museum and castles in the UK, taking of pictures inside is not allowed. There are some areas, such as the corridor just as you step out of the abbey where you can take pictures.

Took husband this time!. Visited for the first time in 2006 and this year insisted that my husband come with me. He was fascinated by the graves of or memorials to scientists (Darwin, Sir Isaac Newton), royalty, literary greats (Chaucer) throughout the Cathedral. Just the sheer size of it impresses!
Great for history. Fantastic architecture. So much history and remarkably serene despite the tourists. Visit on and off with visitors from overseas. Never fails to impress

A must see. £18 entry seems quite steep, but to be honest it's worth it to go inside such an iconic place. We've been to many such places around Europe and further afield and this is one of the best for sure. Not as ornate as The Vatican but still somewhere you should go to at least once in your life, it is still quite jaw-dropping. Rather quiet on a cold January day but I imagine it's hellish busy in the summer. The most incredible roll-call of famous dead people you will ever see anywhere!

West Abby is famous for a reason. I usually don't read gravestones in old churches but this one is filled with so many names that I know that I couldn't remember them all. And the history and achitecture are amazing. This Abby is so historical.

Great. The abbey's architecture is gorgeous - it is awe-inspiring with stained glass windows and cathedral ceilings. The poet's corner is memorable and the many royal people buried here sharpens your sense of history. Because the place is so huge and impressive - you feel like there is a divine presence here!

Awe-inspiring, Historic & Beautiful. The abbey's architecture is gorgeous - it is awe-inspiring with stained glass windows and cathedral ceilings. The poet's corner is memorable and the many royal people buried here sharpens your sense of history. Because the place is so huge and impressive - you feel like there is a divine presence here!

A must see in London but maybe that's all. Hmmm, Westminster abbey is definitely an icon of London, and it is interesting to see the richly ornated interior and the fascinating history, well, with thousands of others, I should guess. Be prepared for a long queue outside. You feel something magical (and spooky) walking among all those tombs of famous people, but I did enjoy myself much more in other cathedrals that are more like a church rather than a graveyard if you know what I mean. Both St Pauls Cathedral and York Minster are more ambient IMO.

Evensong at 3pm!!!. I passed by the Abbey one afternoon and wanted to pop in to pray but was told that the Abbey was closed as they were preparing for Evensong. I queried why Evensong was not in the evening but the usher just pushed the gate closed on me and walked off. Rude, Rude, Rude.A church is public place, a place for quite solitude and prayer and I did not expect to be excluded by my own faith. In an age where Christianity is suffering ever decreasing numbers of worshipers, the staff and management at this site need to remember that the church is there for the congregation and not simply to provide the management a place to work. I'm disgusted and won't go there again.

Uplifting 'Evensong' in Royal Setting. For tourists in UK, 'evensongs' are evening worship services, usually mostly choral, featuring wonderfully inspirational hymns and voices in historic cathedral/church/chapel settings... often with attendee participation in songs, prayers, or both. At Westminster Abbey (site of 'Kate & William' nuptials), weekday 5.00pm evensongs are free to visitors (voluntary contributions welcome; this is not part of the pricey daily 'tours'). The Abbey's young 'Choristers' sang during our Monday evening visit... beautiful! And the High Commissioner for India read as part of the worship service. We were part of only 50-60 attendees since these church services, open to the public, are unpublicized, but held widely in the UK (We've attended like events in Oxford, Bath and villages). TIP: Go early for seating amid the singers; gates open at 4:30.

Walk amongst Kings, Queens and other Royal People. The Abbey itself is amazing for its beauty and scale. The side chapels where Kings, Queens and other famous people are buried are extensive and diverse in their sculpture, colour and significance. The amount of people interned there means you are constantly walking on stones marking the site of one burial or another. Recommend a visit.

Wow. The Westminster Abbey is a fantastic place to see and explore. The design of the building is amazing. You get a free audio guide which is very helpful and provides lots of interesting bits of history of the Abbey. A must see for anyone visiting London

try to get a guide. I could not work the audio recorder and was constantly looking in the wrong place at the wrong time. The audio guide was useful in that you could hear more about specific areas, but I found that the numbers on the objects were very poorly marked and I found myself lost several times. I guess I am not as technical as some people. I was the last to leave from my group and that was after I finally gave up and stopped the audio portion and instead just looked around. I dont know if actual tour quides were available as I was just ushered towards the audio tapes. Alot of history in this place. Charles Darwin was one of the famous names buried here. Lots of royalty as well. If you are using the audio tape plan on hearing everything plan to spend plenty of time. I lost my party and went outside to look for them by the outside gift store. A guard almost didnt let me back in, luckily I had my receipt. My friends totally missed the monk section and gift store. I think it wasnt on the audio tour and I had given up by then and was just wandering. Little costume museum at the inside gift store worth seeing.

Personally I was more impressed with St. Paul's cathedral. No one can dispute the history that Westminster Abbey is steeped in. Every step you take, corner you turn etc there lies either a grave or memorial to an historic English figure - be it King, Queen, playwright or even perhaps an unknown soldier. However, for some reason the experience left me feeling cold and underwhelmed. I'm not sure if it was owing to being busier than St Paul's, the poorer phone devices that you had to walk around with or another unknown factor. What is certain though is that St. Paul's will remain in my conscience a lot longer.

Not cheap-but worth it. I agree with a prevoius review that this not the cheapest place to visit, especially when the ticket only allows one visit (unlike St Pauls or the Queen's Gallery for example). That being said, this is a wonderful place and full of English history with something new at every turn. If you're there at 11.00 or 3.00 you may be lucky enough to get into Edward the Confessor's chapel and tomb which is closed off at all other times due to its age and fragility. Henry 7th's Lady Chapel is suberb and a must-see. The newly refurbished Cellarium restaurant is small but perfectly adequte with good food and friendly staff but is again on the expensive side. All in all a great way to spend a couple of hours.

Worth going with a guide.. We went with the guide and he was excellent. You learn so much more, and with humour (please don't electrify your verger!!) . This was the first time my son had visited and many years since I had and we learned so much in 90 minutes and saw all the main features. Yes it was a lot of money but the upkeep must be horrendous. We were reminded several times that everyone was welcome (for free) to the services. I was impressed that on the hour silence was asked for as a prayer was offered. This is a living church with the history of a nation.

History. Plan to spend a lot of time here. Around every corner there's something you heard of or learned in history class! My favorite part was the ceiling in the chapel of Henry VII. I've seen it in books but to see it for real-amazing and so beautiful fan vaulting. Some parts are closed off so you have to look from outside the room but you can still enjoy the view. We had lunch in the Cellarium at the Abbey. I had a Grilled Montgomery cheddar cheese with onion compote. Oh wow, was it good!

18 Pounds to get in?! Appalling!. If it's your first trip to London, I guess you have to do it. You won't be disappointed if you can get the memory of the entry fee you've just paid out of your mind, upon walking in. You are not allowed to take any photos inside the Abbey for that price, either.We have been into the Abbey several times over the years so just thought we'd visit again. It's such a historical place and associated with significant funerals (i.e. Princess Diana's) and recent royal weddings, among other things. Our boots came to a screeching halt and our eyes nearly came out on stalks when we saw the entry fee the Abbey now charges. Daylight robbery! They should be ashamed of themselves. We suddenly didn't feel the need to go in. However, there are many people who simply could not afford this. Maybe that's their aim. Keep the riff-raff out. You can visit the equally historical St. Margaret's next door, for free, however (or it's your choice to give a small donation).

I Never Leave London Without Visiting Westminster Abbey. The first time I went to Westminster Abbey I knew I would be back over and over. The audio tour is fantastic, the history is amazing, and I've bought so many things at the gift shop. Go on a week day and there's no line (except when it was 2 hours long after the Royal Wedding, but that hype is over). The cloisters and College Gardens are not to be missed, I could spend all day there. I hesitate to put that on tripadvisor because the reason they are special is because they are so peaceful. Not the best for kids or big groups, as it is an Abbey.

Amazing history and spectacle. Yes, there is a fee to enter the abbey but the ticket price supports maintaining this beautiful building. An audio guide is provided in multiple languages in the cost of admission. Very helpful for navigating all the smaller chapels. It really is worth taking time for the audio guide tour. All the famous inhabitants of the abbey are easier to find. The modern restrooms are located near the cafe. Tip: St. Stephen's Tavern is located near the abbey and Big Ben. Highly recommend this tavern.
So beautiful!. I was thrilled to be standing in such a historic place in London. I loved the architecture and spent much time photographing from various angles. The gift shop was quite nice too.

Central Tour of London. Westminster Abbey is close to Big Ben, altho I think it's called something else now with the Queen's Jubilee, Parliament buildings, Parliament Square, and the Eye. Unlike other places, like Notre Dame, there is a fee to go in. Depending on whether or not you like to see artifacts, etc... you may find the cost a bit steep. I didn't get the audio guide, altho a lot of people prefer it. I was with a friend who knew a lot, so I much prefer that, or if you have a tour book, then you probably could save money without the audio guide.It's similar to Paris' Notre Dame, and some may say Notre Dame is nicer to look at.If you are limited in time, I would suggest you see the other attractions in the area, but if you do have time, then this was definitely better than going into Buckingham Palace.

WOW & AMAZING - Westminster Abbey. This building will wow and amaze you. It is a church, tomb, coronation place, and cathedral all in one. I learned a lot of interesting tidbits while I was there, and you will too. I'm not a history fan much, but even I was pulled in with all the history there was in this abbey. One thing I did not know (amongst other things) was how much religion is wrapped up in the coronation ceremony. All I can say is that if you ever have an opportunity to go, do it. You will not be disappointed.

Beautiful site with lots of history.. The Abbey is beautiful and the history associated with all buried there amazing. The audio tour was done well and gets you through in an hour to an hour and a half. Don't be limited by the audio tour - make sure to look around. We were there during winter and definitely enjoyed not having a crowd.
Spectacular. One of the most spectacular abbey I've ever seen. But the admission fee is very expensive! Because you will not spend half day there, so half the present fee would be more appropriate!

£18!. I'm sorry but £18 for an adult and £15 for a student is disgraceful. Yes there is a lot of history in this building but frankly if you are visiting London, especially if you are on a budget, there are far more attractions mostly free which you should visit first. I was absolutely astonished that this was what they are charging for admission. I understand that the building requires funds for upkeep but there are limits. You should be ashamed of yourselves

Must Visit Attaction. If you have a London Pass, this is a must go to place. Take the river cruise and get off at Westminster pier to see the Big Ben and Parliament building. The architecture of the abbey is breathtaking and the history of the place as well as the tombs of Kings and Queens were very fascinating. Be sure to take along the audio guide as it explains very well the history of the place. The only minus was that photography was not allowed inside the abbey. It was very crowded when I visited on New Year's day.

History at its finest. I have to admit, I wasnt going to pay for admission into the Abbey, but I had a London Pass and I wanted to get my money's worth so we went inside. OH MAN - so glad I did. This place is amazing and all the history and people here - WOW WOW WOW. Plus, its a working church so we had a chance to stop for silent prayer and listen to a sermon. Man, just so interesting. Definitely come during the winter time. Lines are short, not a lot of people and you can spend as much time as you want studying and reading up on things. The audio/video guide has SO many extras so dont skip ahead. They also provide bathroom facilities which is nice. In London, finding a loo (that doesn't charge you) is like finding the Holy Grail. Bad joke? Well, its a great tour and even for someone not so into religion like myself I could still appreciate the history of the Abbey and admire its amazing craftmanship.

Awe-inspiring. Definitely a must-do on a trip to London. I highly recommend the Verger tour which is a couple extra pounds, but gives you lots of fantastic information, a quick sit in the quire and access to the Chapel of St Edward the Confessor. The architecture and the history are amazing and come together to provide an experience unlike anywhere else.

Very very good and well worth the admission. I visited on a cold January Saturday, so there was no queue for entry and I was able to follow the audio guide round at my own pace. It is, of course, a church, and visitors are expected to respect that fact. I had forgotten to remove my woollen bobble type hat and was politely asked to do so. Fair enough, no problem at all. The history of the UK is well depicted and the tombs of many Kings, Queens and other notaries are well placed for observation.There are many small side chapels which require a slight diversion from the guided route, but are not difficult to find. I was disappointed not to be allowed to take any photographs. I have previously visited York Minster where I was allowed to take photographs. The small cafe is very expensive service a little slow. I would suggest leaving eating or getting a tea or coffee until you have left the abbey.

History and a who's who of folks buried here. First off - it was a very easy walk from the Haymarket Hotel to here. If you can - take the Verger Guided Tour, worth a few extra pounds. Our tour guide was actually a member of the Royal Wedding a couple of years ago - had a fun story to tell us about all that. The architecture and history of the Abbey is simply amazing and seeing it all in person after only seeing it on TV was quite exciting. I would recommend getting there early in the day as lines do form early. The list of people buried here is truly a who's who and it simply astounded me seeing all this. Well worth taking a few hours of a day to go visit this.

Must See! Iconic Building. Westminster is a must see if your are visiting London. It is very close to Big Ben, and right across the street from the Parliament building. Stunning architecture, and if you can visit during evensong.

superb historic place but no photos!!!!. we visited the Westminster abbey on the morning there is much less people and it was superb there is even the grave of Charles Darwin and nobody talked about it!!anyway it was nice but unfortunately no photos were allowed insidethe price was quite expensive to look at few tombstones and a throne!!

Glorious!. You can feel the history and majesty of the Christian faith through the ages the minute you walk into the front door. Initially put off by the 18 pound fee (over $28 USD), I was more than happy to contribute to the upkeep of this treasure. Stay for Evensong at 5 PM. You will be blessed!

"I was glad ...". Visiting the Abbey Church of St Peter's in Westminster was one of those experiences that brought together a life's worth of images and sounds into the sharply focussed world of reality. I have seen images of Westminster all through my life via TV - royal weddings and funerals, the papal visit of Benedict XVI etc - and I tried to put my preconceived ideas aside and experience the place for what it is. It was not that difficult as it turned out.The first experience was that common feeling that the place was not as big as it had loomed in my imagination. The Abbey is not a small place, but it is not an overwhelming one either. It has very human dimensions. I'd stood outside in the early evening and walked around the West Door and along the north side to the Lady Chapel (Henry VII's stunning addition). The following day I joined London Walks on their guided tour of the Abbey. Why? I have read a lot of the history of the Abbey over the years, but I wanted to ensure that I got a wholistic approach and having enjoyed London Walks "Jack the Ripper" walk and been impressed with the expertise of Molly and Donald, I thought the Abbey walk would be of a similar quality. And so it was. Federa was my guide and she ably steered our group through the cloisters and the West End through the Church and in and out of the maze of monuments and memorials.Our introduction to the Abbey was rather long, but necessary to establish the context of the building and its purpose. St Peter's was founded as a Benedictine monastic house; it was never a diocesan church and the church itself was a monastic place of worship for over 500 years before the reforms of Henry VIII and all the reforms that followed him.The shrine of St Edward the Confessor surrounded by the tombs of many of the medieval monarchs was a major highlight as was the simply magnificent Lady Chapel of Henry VII that left me speechless. It is great that there is mirror placed in the centre of the chapel so you don't strain your neck looking upwards at the fan vaulting.Much of the sanctuary and choir (spelled "quire") is 19th century refurbishment but there is enough remnant material from the monastic church to get some impression of what the Abbey may have looked like. There are two wall paintings of St Thomas and the Risen Christ and St Christopher that survived the iconoclasm of the 16th and 17th centuries because they were hidden behind a memorial and there are the recovered and restored panels of the Revelation of St John in the Chapter House.On the hour one of the Abbey priests asks everyone to be still for a minute's silence for prayer or reflection, a gentle reminder that we are in a "working" church.I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. Federa was an excellent guide and answered my many questions with enthusiasm and a pride in this wonderful building. I know that many people find the entry price rather steep, but since the Abbey enjoys no government or church funding, it depends entirely on revenues it raises on its own. I would have loved to take my own photos inside, but I respect the need to raise funds through whatever means possible. That said, the gift shop could do a little more in creating a suitable selection of books on the history of the Abbey. Perhaps they were sold out, but I only saw a "coffee table" book of the Chapter House - beautiful, but not what I was looking for.Before you leave, make sure you take in the Abbey museum, the Chapter House and if possible, the smaller cloister.So, to use the words of Psalm 122 and the memory of Parry's great anthem so often heard in the Abbey, "I was glad when they said unto me, 'Let us go into the house of the Lord'".
Interesting place!. This attraction is a must to do in London. Very old and impressive architecture and the free audio guide have nice story's to tell.

Interesting and beautiful, full of history. Similar to many attractions in London, the Westminster Abbey entrance fee is a little expensive but it worth it. It's really quite beautiful inside and the history is interesting. You can get an audio guide and made which I think that you have to pay for as well but it is useful and interesting. There were a lot of people there when we went so its best to take your time to see and listen to what you like. The history and architecture and wonderful.

Stunning Architecture and full of historical significance.. This was an attraction that we missed out on during our first trip to London so it was at the top of the list for us to visit. This is one of the most magnificent architectural buildings around. Definitely worth the visit to see the stone work.The crowds were pretty thick though and a majority of my fellow tourists were quite rude and only concerned with what they were going to see and not caring what others might be trying to see. It also seems that over the years, the tourism has taken its toll. There are "grave markers" of a sort in the floor throughout the Abbey but many are worn away to a point that they are unreadable due to high volume of foot traffic. I went into this attraction expecting it to be somewhat quiet and reverent seeing that it is a church where services are still held, but that couldn't have been further from the truth. The majority of visitors seem to be noisy and uncaring of the fact that they are in a church. I suppose this isn't so much a drawback of the attraction as it is a simple disappointment in the people that visit it.I would definitely recommend this place even for the price. It is well worth it to try and find a time where the crowds are smaller and you can enjoy the Abbey and its rich history at a more leisurely pace.

Good but Expensive History Lesson. We were a family of four going here, which was pretty expensive. The tombs were exquisite and it was amazing to see all the famous people buried here. There are lovely stained glass windows. They do not allow photography and the gift shop which sold pictures of it was a mad house so I don't really remember much else of what was there. I just remember an altar and that there were some chairs to sit on and I think Dickens is buried here along with the royals. I think the royal tombs were quite nice. However, after a little less than an hour, my children and I were ready to leave. If price is an issue, then I would suggest coming here for Evensong instead of paying for admission. I think it is very worth seeing.

Evensong. Beautifully taken service. An oasis of calm and quiet in the middle of the city rush hour. The Choir sang beautifully and one was left wondering why there weren't more people there. We easily take for granted forget how fortunate we are to have our churches and places of worship in the UK...with such professional and approachable clergy.

Expensive but nice. It is a really nice building with such wonderful details. Inside you can find the graves of many well known people such as Sir Isaac Newton. However you need to pay 18£ to enter. That's quite expensive I think.

Amazing architecture and history!. My husband and I loved the amount of real history one could experience just walking through this beautiful church. Many famous people including royalty, scientists, poets, authors and musicians are buried here. The stained glass and architecture is breath taking.

Wow. Beautiful place with enormous history. We went to Evensong which was deeply moving. Take the tour and watch a replay of the Royal Wedding afterwards - it looks totally different when it is full of people.
Disappointed. Very disappointed to find it costs £16.00 per adult to go inside the Abbey. I feel this is an extortionate amount to charge, given that it is after all part of the Church of England.

Fabulous! Sooo Much to See. Hint, eat well before you go and give yourself several hours to go through it. Just about the time you think you have seen it all, there is another crypt or chapel around the corner. Remember to get the narrative. It is free with admission and Jeremy Irons does a fabulous job.

another piece of London history. can be crowded but recommend putting on a list of places to visit when in London, especially if it is a first visit. Along with the Cathedral and St Pauls. And both Tates.

Spectacular Place -- don't miss it. This Abbey is breathtakingly beautiful. This is not like any other religious site I've ever seen -- although, of course there are some similarities. One of the things I most liked is that many of the windows are clear, so there's quite a bit of natural light. I went early in the morning, to get in line before it opened, since I'd heard it was crowded during the holiday season. It opened about 30 minutes late, but then we went right in. It was nice to be able to see it before it became too crowded. Entry price includes a recorder which describes the various sights within the abbey. I believe you can buy a ticket online -- which allow you to skip the ticket line. I had lunch in their newly opened on-site restaurant. The food was delicious, and the service was pretty quick.

What a beautiful place. The staff was so helpful and the history of the place is overwhelming. Although it was extremely crowded, the staff managed to organize and helped with the flow of people. We even managed to pray a litte.
Excellent. Well worth it, incredible architecture and history and recommend this to anyone. Allow a couple of hours to see it all with the audio guide.

Amazing, but not the place for small children. The size of this place is quite expansive & is rich with history and information. This is definitely not the place for small children, as they are strict with the volume level of everyone in the Abbey. Also, because it is an active church, there are services sometimes occurring during your visit- definitely not the place for children under 12. Overall, the experience was amazing. The beauty of Westminster is unrivaled by any other cathedral or church I have been in. A definite must see!

So much to see..if you're interested in history. As a student I paid 13 pounds with a valid student ID card. I recommend that you take the audio tour to give yourself some info of the background to the Abbey. Don't forget to look for Newton, Joule, Jane Austen and Charles Dickens. However the tombs and memorials of the kings are much more intricate and amazing. The interior is absolutely majestic. It's pretty dark so watch your step and it could be quite crowded sometimes and so you will need to keep moving when in tight spaces and there aren't any shortages of those.

Marvellous tour. I can recommend every one who visits Westminster Abbey to take a guided tour with Ben. You get to see places nobody else gets to see and it all comes to life. He is a wonderful guide. And do stay for Evensong as well. Very atmospheric.

Book a verger tour. We have been to Westminster Abbey a number of times and always found it very interesting but going on a tour led by one of the vergers gave us so much more information and allowed us into areas not normally open to visitors. Well worth the extra £3 and can be booked the day before your visit.

Fascinating visit. Visited on a Saturday and felt it was pretty busy. The audio guide is very good and informative and it is just an amazing place to walk round and see all the history in front of you. Particularly powerful is standing by the altar where the coronations have taken place, coffins have been positioned and weddings been conducted! The abbey closes early on a Saturday which is worth remembering and whilst the tour and experience is fascinating I do consider £16 to be a very pricey admission fee!

Sadly disappointed. Sorry really not impressed, great history lesson and as a tourist attraction is a really great place to go perhaps, but somehow considering it is a working Abbey, that aspect of the buldings life almost seems to have been forgotten other than linking it to royal events. Where in the tour is there a space for people to explore their faith, or even really sit and pray quitely after all it is a wroking Abbey and not just a museum!
Beautiful. Definitely take time to go in to the church, and go early before the crowds show up and photo bomb all your pictures.

History. When you enter the Abbey you can sense the history of this building, going back to the Benedictine Monks and right upto the wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton. The paintings and stained glass windows are amazing, didn't realise how big it actually is. The entrance is pricey at £16 each for adults.

Favourite cathedral so far. We have been to a lot of cathedrals/abbeys across Europe/UK and this is our favourite so far. We spent almost three hours here and with the free audio guide, number of people there to assist and how beautifully kept the abbey is, we would not hesitate to pay £16 again.The most humbling part of this church is that it's a beautiful memorial of people from many walks of life who have shaped not only British but world history - from kings and queens, to writers, scientists and past bishops, we thoroughly enjoyed exploring them all.Definitely pick up the free audio guide as this gave a lot of additional insight and included videos if you wished. Don't be deterred by the lines - our line was to the street but it was no more than 15 minutes, especially if you're in the cash line.

£16 pounds for an adult to go in - disgusting!!!!. I would have been happy to pay a fee to go into the abbey but £16 is really disgustingly expensive especially for families and people who are on a tight budget.I know that the upkeep of the abbey must be expensive but I refuse to pay such a high price to go into a place of worship !!!
Lovely choral service. We went on a Sunday and attended a service - the Abbey is closed to visitors. Arrive early and get in to the choir stalls - magical.

Evensong at Westminster Abbey recommended. A great way of seeing a church, at least in my opinion, is to visit it when it is actually being in use. One way of seeing Westminster Abbey is by going to the so called Evensong. It is a one hour long service with beautiful choir song. Evensong is free of charge, but I would recommend getting there in good time so you can get seats in a good spot to be able to enjoy the beautiful church more, otherwise you risk having to stand up for the whole time.

one of the famous place to visit. you will be amazed by the statue and wall decoration of the abbey..the only thing I don't like is the place is too crowded, more like a market than an abbey when walking through.
expensive but beautiful. It's a gorgeous piece of architecture and is so full of history, it's brilliant. I find the price ridiculous though. I would give it 5 stars if it was cheaper.

I'm not into religion..... and I thought this would be a waste of £16. whatever pomp and ceremony might have gone here in the past, I didn't think I would appreciate it. I have to say I think the Abbey is a spectacular building, the availability of individual audio commentary is really helpful, it guides you round, and as you can start and stop it, you can pick and choose what to visit or revisit if you miss something.Turned out to be £16 well spent!

English history lesson & tradition combined. I thoroughly enjoyed our trip to the Abbey. Inside the Abbey are many commemorations and burials marked via stone pavements or through vaults. The free audio guides are extremely helpful. The Abbey's own description of "Kings, queens, statesmen and soldiers; poets, priests, heroes and villains - the Abbey is a must-see living pageant of British history." accurately sums the experience. It is expensive yet worth it. It is best not to take young kids in the Abbey as they will get bored and you will not enjoy the peaceful atmosphere that the Abbey provides.

This Abbey is a Daisy. One of lifes greatest pleasures is going to see an attraction that exceeds your expectations. We visited the Abbey on Remembrance Day, the beauty of the Abbey combined with the hearfelt sorrow of paying respect to the fallen soldiers of past battles was breathtaking in its simplicity. Take time to stroll to the street behind the Abbey and you will feel like you have stepped into 19th century London. The cobblestone lane intertwines with the living quarters of the Abbey staff with the students of a private school ( they dress in a type of harry potter uniform ), makes this attraction a must see.

An amazing piece of living British history!. We got an audioguide (included in the price) and we really enjoyed both the audioguide as well as the building. We were able to see all the graves and memorials. Absolutely amazing to see all of the graves of Britian's major historical figures under one roof. Really nothing like anything I have ever seen. Take your time and take opportunities to sit when you can. We all noticed that our feet were really aching by the end of our tour!! Plan in advance to make sure it will be open.

Christmas Eve service. We went to the Christmas Eve Lessons and Carols service (tickets required), and it was the highlight of our visit. If you can't go for a special service, go to Evensong. Services are free and give you a more vital feeling for the Abbey.

More like a 'Mini-Cathedral'. It lies just across the street from Parliament and appears like a mini-cathedral in design. Be sure to use the audio head set. Well worth it. The history, the explanations and commentary bring it to life and put things into perspective. Very glad that we went.
no foreigners. again, like big ben, if you are not from Brittan you are not allowed in to help control the number of tourists. Really nice building from the outside though!

My Favorite Cathedral. I was blown away by my visit to the Westminster Abbey this Spring! I did not realize how massive, and ornate, it would be.The Abby serves as a tomb, to many kings ,queens, and famous poets. I have always heard about, the Notre Dame Cathedral, to be so amazing, however, the Abbey, from the inside, was more interesting.

Left feeling bitterly disappointed when I should have felt uplifted.. Westminster Abbey is a magnificent structure, with a 1,000 year history. It is one of the UK's biggest symbols, and a place visited by millions of people from across the globe. Many famous people are buried there, from Kings and Queens of England, to famous writers, soldiers, artists and politicians. It should be a place you leave feeling inspired. But I left feeling dejected. It is nothing more than a commercial enterprise, but the authorities don't really want you there, they just want your money. You have to follow a one way system around the Abbey, there's no scope for casual wandering. Many areas are fenced off and off-limits to the general public. You can look, but please wipe your feet and don't linger too long is the message Westminster Abbey's authorities give out. I even had my sandwiches examined by an over officious security guard before I was allowed to enter.The Abbey could also do with a good scrub. One of England's most sacred sites, yet all those find tombs and plagues are covered in dust and grime. All the money the Church of England rakes in for the Abbey, yet they can't be bothered to send a few people around with dusters. It felt like nothing more than a commercial exercise, to allow the "little people" in to view their heritage, but not to allow them to fully appreciate it as they might want to aspire to be something better.The building a one of the most beautiful I have ever seen, and their are some magnificent pieces of artwork inside. But where St Paul's Cathedral gets it right, by having a clean, welcoming building, Westminster Abbey gets it very wrong by having a dirty, overly commercial unwelcoming attraction. They should remember that it is a place of worship, and that means being welcoming to all visitors, not just the "chosen ones" who can have full access to the whole of the Abbey.I'm actually quite sad that I have been so disappointed by my visit there. Westminster Abbey is always somewhere I have wanted to go, but it was a real let down.

Great time. Had to move through fast because of another scheduled event but was very impressive and the staff was awesome. One even took the time to show our daughter a roped off section. Great experience.

My favorite attraction in London. One of the most impressive buildings in all of England. Packed full of art, sculptures, tombs, and history, this abbey really gives you a feeling of spiritual presence. Even if you aren't a religious person and don't really enjoy visiting religious sites, this is one place you really shouldn't pass up. I went with my girlfriend at evensong (check the times, I think 4 or 5pm), and entrance is free if you go at that time. The short service was nice and the interior is beautiful. The only downside for some is there is no photography but in my opinion, this really helps preserve the appropriate atmosphere inside as opposed to Notre Dame in Paris and many others that are swarmed with tourists. I highly recommend taking a few hours to visit this spectacular place.

Great for history fans. Been there more than 20 years agp but my husband had never been so accompanied him again. Great that they have the audio aids now. It can be pretty creepy bur thete were plenty of visitors and guides around. Nice way to learn about English history and historical figures! Enjoyed it thoroughly even though it was my second visit!
Westminster Abbey. Simply gorgeous! It is a must if you haven't been there - it is a symbol of England after all. It is nothing like other churches or abbey!

Breathtaking!!. We only had a few hours to pass before we flew home and this was our first choice to visit! Unbelievable!! You're able to receive a audio self-guided tour which was very well done. As Scottish being our heritage it was amazing to see the tomb of the Queen of Scotland. I wish we only had been able to spend more time there. Money well spent!!

must see. I am not religious at all, but you should visit it at least from architectural point of view!It has lots of stuff inside. And it has audio guide in different languages, including Russian.But I think that admission is quite pricey!

Walk Where Kings Have Walked. To be in this place is to be in the presence of greatness. Not only is it the place of coronations and weddings, but it is also the burial place of many kings and other monarchs. There are also monuments and memorials to many famous Britons, including Jeffrey Chaucer and Isaac Newton, throughout the abbey. Also notable is the tomb of the unknown warrior, placed after WWI. Of the many graves on the floors, this is the only one upon which it is forbidden to step.Don't miss King Edward's chair, which has been used for every coronation since 1308. It's cool to just walk around and see the sights, take in the atmosphere, and know that this building has so many stories to tell.

Amazing but pricey. I was amazed at how well preserved the memorials and artefacts are, and the abbey stretches back more than you would think, so it is not a short tour. But the admission fees are astonishingly expensive, especially as it is a church of England! You wouldn't mind giving a donation, but a huge fee is not right.

Wow. What a wonderfull building, and what lovely staff employed there, they are so attentive and helpful. The audio guide is very good, as I had missed a guided tour,you can easily spend two hours here taking it all in,don't miss it on your trip to London

Experience a 'private' visit. My wife and I attended the evensong service at the Abbey. This takes place at 5pm each evening, after the church is 'closed' to visitors. Whilst you will not be able to wander around and see the 'tourist' aspects of this marvellous building, you will be able to experience it as an actual, everday, place of worship.The service lasts about 40 minutes and is a mixture of prayers, readings from the Old and New Testaments, alongside the excellent and very moving singing of the Abbey choir. Be aware that you are attending a religious service, so the appropriate decorum is expected and you must be there in advance of the beginning of the service; you can't just stroll in. The outer perimeter gates are closed before the service starts.Regardless of your faith, or indeed whether or not you are of any faith, this is something worth experiencing.

Not to be missed!. A visit to London is not complete without spending several hours at Westminster Abbey. It is one of the most beautiful churches and fascinating living history museums in all of Europe. Pay the 16 pounds admission (even if that means skipping another attraction), be a nerd and wear the audio tour headphones, browse through the gift shop and spend at least 2 hours enjoying!

Heaven for history buffs. There are more famous dead people in Westminster Abbey than just about anywhere else on earth. For some that fact will leave them cold, but for anyone with more than a passing interest in English history, it's brilliant. Just about every meter, there is a memorial to an illustrious artist, politician, soldier or churchman. The only complaint is that there is plenty of equipment strewn in odd places and even covering up some of the memorials.
absalutly excellent. the shop was excellent and the cathedral was so beautiful and i have nothing bad to say about it. i have nothing elise to say but it won't let me submit in till i have 100 words.

so much history. I was an English first timer to The Abbey and I loved it. As usual, tours available in every language to go at your own pace. The history just envelopes you as you pass through. Elizabeth the First still lording it over Bloody Mary. Anne of Cleves tucked in by Poets Corner whereas no sign of Katherine of Aragon, of course. To stand feet away from where William and Katherine married. It is a positive name-dropper's paradise. Above all this though is the edifice itself and the majesty of it all. I couldn't help but be moved. And proud.

A must do. Westminster Abbey is great. Steeped in history, most recently will and Kate's wedding. It is a beautiful church full of historical graves and memorials. The ticket price includes a fantastic audio tour making the visit even better. We spent ages exploring. Highly recommended!

A great history lesson of Royal family. The audio guided tour was splendid, explaining most of the tombs in the abbey together with the historical importance of each character. The architecture is splendid, with a mixture from several different periods (took a few hundred years to fully complete the whole building). You also can join their frequent praying session during the visit.

"Best of the Best" if you love English history. If I could only see one thing in England - this would be it -- the history and beauty within the Abbey staggers. I strongly recommend paying the additional 3 pounds (as of 2012) for the Verger led tour - being able to stand in the Chapel of St. Edward the Confessor, surrounded by Edward I, Edward II, Richard II and Henry V is an amazing experience.

Expensive but worth it!!!. I visited the abbey and thought that the Sixteen pound admission fee was a lot....after pondering this for about a minute, I thought I'd go in. Get the interactive audio guide which comes with admission, it's very informative. This was a mind blowing trip through time from about 1100 to the present day. With all of England's royalty and more, poets corner was simply incredible. The ambience of the abbey is incredible....a great place to go for pilgrims and history buffs alike....a cultural baptism! Absolutely superb!!!!
step into history. not just a pretty building to look at, taking a walk through it should definitely be a must on your to do list

A must see attraction. Far too much to take in on just one visit to The Abbey. The history is fascinating, word cannot describe its beautiful statues. Check website for opening hours before arriving, took me three attempts to get inside because they change opening hours daily .

Amazing.... I spent yesterday afternoon at Westminster abbey, including the 90 min verger tour. There are so many nooks and crannies in this awe inspiring building. The tour was the best 3 pounds I ever spent. Benjamin the verger guided us through parts we might have otherwise glossed over. Highly recommended!

Fascinating.. Not enough can be said about this site. It brings home how OLD England is, when you see the dates on the memorials and tombs within these walls. Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Handel...all there. Take advantage of the free handheld narrative devices. It's truly amazing the work that was done by builders/artisans hundreds of years ago. Walk the path that the kings, queens, princes, princesses have walked.

Well worth the entrance fee - time well spent!. I have visited Westminster Abbey several times - but not for over 10 years. On a recent visit to London my sisters and I decided to spend the afternoon at the Abbey - a great decision! The self guided tour is well worth the 16 pounds spent - the audio was great - and very informative. In addition 'volunteers' were available to assist as needed - we took advantage of this and they were knowledgeable and extremely helpful. One lady in particular shared some insight on the handling of the bouquet after the Royal Wedding a couple of years ago - a nice 'insider touch' she told us the relevance of the flowers used in the bouquet - simple and thoughtful. This is a piece of living history that touches all - those with ancestors from the UK as well as those who enjoy learning more about the lives and resting place of artists, writers and poets. Living in Chatham County in North Carolina I was particularly interested in the memorial to William Pitt - Earl of Chatham - who is still reflected in the name of the County.Plan to spend several hours visiting so that no detail is missed - it is time well spent

Astounding Abbey. Our first full day in London, we got on the tube by our flat and took it down to the Parliament buildings (came out right underneath Big Ben), and walked around the corner to Westminster Abbey. We knew we wanted to go to Westminster Abbey, although I really had no idea what it was like in there except for pictures of royal weddings. We spent quite a long time in there. It is really fascinating, although it was frustrating not to be able to take pictures. I highly recommend the free audio tour, because you can use it any time you come across something you are wondering about, but you can go at your own pace. I had to keep going back for my husband because he wanted to look at every single sculpture and was taking a very long time. It is an absolutely fascinating place, I highly recommend it - one of the best things we did in London.

Dead People Aplenty. I'm a minister and I'm super interested in church history and cathedrals and whatnot. So I thought, "Better go see Westminster Abbey"! Not only did I get "massive church" and "weird Christian tidbits" but crazy amounts of stories of lots of dead people - royals, celebrities, writers, actors, randoms and even cats. The place is huge and you'll be slowed down reading about all the interesting people and their ensuing demise. The architecture is magnificent and makes you wonder how people back in the day could be so creative and why our buildings and churches today look so incredibly drab. It was very cool to attend the small services they had - an experience that in and of itself isn't going to blow your spiritual mind, but something you shouldn't miss nonetheless. Even if you're not churchy or care about that side of things, it has enough to keep even little ones interested (meaning that YOU should be interested too). My only comment - there's like 2 restaurants anywhere within walking distance of this place, so don't come hungry and hope to find someone nearby!

History of England at its Best. In a prior trip to London I did not go inside the Abbey because of long lines.Well this time we got in line and the wait was reasonable. Not wanting to wait in line was definitely not a good excuse to miss the incredible inside of this MAGNIFICENT monument and witness the History of England and its people Dont miss the the visit inside and enjoy.. For History buffs and others...

History and lots of it. We arrived about an hour after the Abbey opened and there was only a very short queue to get in. We took a free audio guide but didn't really use it. There are lots of guides around to ask for advice, or to answer questions.There is so much history, so many memorials, it really probably needs more than one visit to take it all in. My favourite areas were the tomb of Elizabeth 1 and the Lady Chapel. My husband was fortunate enough to be able to enter the Shrine of Edward the Confessor - access to this only occurs during prayer times due to the delicate nature of the Shrine. The cafe "Cellarium" is well worth a visit - very fresh tasty food, great service, and (for London) unbelievably low prices.

A marvellous and unique Abbey. Truly amazing to see the tombs of monarchs from before the Tudors. To use my wife's quote "It's a giant collection of the rich and powerful's memorials". There is of course a bit more to it than that, the building and its adornments are truly magnificent.

Must See in London (My #2). My #2 must-see in London (behind only the Tower of London). I love that with admission you get an audio guide (rather than having to pay extra), which takes you around in about 50 mins. You can read the history and the things to see here on other reviews and other places. I'll only add that you MUST get the London Pass to see the town! Buy it online and save and then you can skip some lines and end up saving lots of money.I'll also add that I thought this gift shop was one of the better ones at the major London attractions. Usually a line on the main floor to check out--go to the back of the store and down a few short stairs. Mainly jewelry downstairs, but there is another register that had no line!
Amazing arquitecture!. I loved every bit of it! It really tells you about history! I loved to see the chair, where all the kings and queens get the crowns.

A Thorough Delight!. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Westminster Abbey. I visited on a Monday and arrived just before 9:30am when the Abbey opens to visitors. There were about 30 people in the line in front of me and it took me about 15 minutes to get in. Your ticket for admission includes a free audio guide. There is more than enough information in the audio guide and with things to see and pore over in the Abbey to last a good hour. I took almost 2 hours. Two highlights of the tour are the Lady Chapel and the history of English Coronation. The fact that I have a great deal of respect for Jeremy Irons' work only made the tour all that more special for me, he is the narrator in the audio guide, you see. I would encourage you not to hurry through this tour, this will allow you to soak in the splendor and quiet majesty of the Abbey. You will also begin to appreciate the fact that this place of worship has been in existence for centuries and continues to be an active, living and breathing sanctuary, it is not some theme park re-creation, but a real place where you can have a real encounter with history. Sir Isaac Newton is buried here. This is entirely amazing to me, and if this fact amazes you too, then you should definitely visit.To end on a more practical note. Some of the more interesting spots at Westminster don't appear to be wheelchair-ready. Please be sure to inquire before visiting if wheelchair access is required.

Unexpected. Having seen the building in photos and on tv I was surprised at how much smaller it seems when you're inside. I was also surprised by the memorials tucked in to every nook and cranny. It's definitely something you should see while in London, but admission is pretty pricey and it gets very crowded. The history and majesty are awe inspiring. Don't miss the cafe at the exit. Amazing salads and soups; afternoon tea too.
Didn't open on time. Enjoyed this, but wanted to note that it opened 15-30min later than listed time. Don't know if there was a problem the day I visited or not...

un-welcome. My family and I visited Westminster Abbey for the first time on Sunday morning, attending Matins.Unfortunately we got held up in traffic diversions and arrived at 10.15, so we had to sit in the Nave. Though sad to have arrived late and not be able to sit beyond the Quire, we very much enjoyed the last half hour of the service.However, the moment service finished - as the organ voluntary started, an usher asked everyone to start leaving. I took the opportunity to admire the stained glass windows and read the tombs around the side of the Nave. Whilst doing this I was asked by another usher to leave.While I was near the door a third usher even went as far as to touch my arm to guide me faster out of the door.
