All of this during the organ voluntary.One doesn't like to make a fuss in such a situation, but once outside the door I did make a comment to the final usher about being hurried out when the voluntary was still being played. At that moment the playing finished, and with what I can only describe as an insolent smirk the usher said 'well it's finished now', as he shut the door in my face.I appreciate that there is a further service at 11.15, but there was fully 25-30 minutes before that began. So there was no need to harry people out of the Nave.The whole experience was quite extraordinary: disrespectful, insensitive and to be blunt, very rude. And above all unworshipful.

Experience of a Lifetime. I've always wanted to see Westminster Abbey, and I've finally done it. However, I think that people should be allowed to take photos in the main bit - its just so amazing in there. It was great to see where William and Kate got married. Tons of interesting interesting monuments to see there. Great site to see and worth the visit.

Go to Evensong service at 5pm. If you line up prior to 4:30 when the gates open, you can get into the Abbey for a free evening service with the choir. It is lovely to absorb the atmosphere while listening to the boys' choir. Check when they are held, but I think they are on weekday evenings. Definitely a great experience. You have to line up at the end of the Abbey where the gift shop is. And once the service starts it lasts about 45 minutes.
Amazing Abbey. An experience not to be missed, no extra charge for the audio guide. So much history, an unforgettable experience, a real must do in London.

Too bad cant take pictures, but AMAZING destination. Come here to get your mind blown and feel overwhelmed in the presence of something bigger than yourself. Saw a ton of interesting monuments and memorials and tombs to famous larger than life figures. Thought the admission price of 16 pounds was a little steep, but that was before knew it came with a free audio guide :)Can't recommend it highly enough!

Westminster Abbey. London is filled with history but this is one of those iconic places that you just cannot miss when you visit. The architecture alone is enough for the price of admission. The ceiling is an amazing work of art and architecture. The opulence and magnificence of the tombs and the cathedral space appreciate just how great Britian was and its rich history. Either go early in the morning to avoid lines or try late in the afternoon mid-week. I went on a rainy day and there was virtually no one in line and the Abbey was not too packed with visitors. A nice touch is the audio narration in multiple languages.

Westminster Abbey superb visit. From entrance to exit just a great venue to visit for a hour or two. The interactive voice recording (by Jeremy Irons with his atmospheric voice) explained everything. Packed full of history and interest the abbey is a top 10 london attraction and must see.

Westminster Abbey. I can not say enough about this wonderful and amazing cathedral, the sense of history that it evokes is truly amazing, it makes you appreciate just how Great the Great in Great Britain was and is. When you view tombs and memorials of the monarchs, heroes and artists that we have produced though the ages it makes one proud to be British. We spent over four hours there and we want to go back. It's a must see for any visitor to London.

Wow – Amazing!. Westminster Abbey is located next to Big Ben in Westminster (near the Westminster Underground Tube station) so it is an easy attraction to find and visit. We (my wife and two other couples) went on a Thursday afternoon in September and did not wait at all to get in. This is my second visit to the Abbey and I did not wait the first time either (although I heard the line is long during peak times).  I am a history buff and did not visit the Abbey on my first couple of London visits as I thought it was just another old church. I could not have been more wrong. Westminster Abbey is an amazing place with an incredible history. Not only is it a large church but it is also the place of King and Queen Coronations and royal weddings and royal burials. On my first visit I paid for the audio guide tour so wanted to do a Verger led tour this time but these tours were not operating for some reason. I tried to call a week ahead and reserve a spot on a Verger tour but they only accept reservations the day before (since they do not always know in advance if the tours will be operating.) I was hoping to go on this tour as you get into some areas of the Abbey where the audio tour does not. We settled on the audio guide tour and still had a great time. The audio guide tour can be a little confusing as there are so many nooks and crannies in the Abbey that I was not always sure if I was supposed to takle an immediate left or right, or walk a few yards further and then turn (but I made it through).I really enjoyed everything but really enjoyed the medieval wooden coronation chair. All monarchs since about 1300 have been crowned on this chair except Queen Mary I. The chair was very interesting as it appeared to have graffiti on it (it’s amazing a wood chair survived this long). I also enjoyed King Henry VII’s chapel and the Poets Corner. Not only is King Henry VII and his wife buried in the chapel but so are his famous granddaughters Queens Elizabeth and Mary Tudor. In addition, most if the other Tudors are buried here. The Poets Corner is amazing as many famous people are buried in this area including Charles Dickens, Chaucer, composer Handel, Rudyard Kipling, actor Laurence Olivier, and poet Alfred “Charge of the Light Brigade” Tennyson.Westminster Abbey is amazing and is truly one of the must see attractions in London (especially if you are a history buff).

Oh what an Abbey!. Beautiful building, full of history, helpful volunteers and staff. We visited on a rainy July day but this added to the character of an Abbey with a long history. we loved walking through, seeing the stunning architecture and names we've only read about. A definite must see!
Great sight!. A massive piece of history in the UK and is for sure worth a walk through. If you've got a London Pass then entrance is free and this is an absolute must.
Huge!!. A nice tour via headsets and narrated by Jerome Irons, a lot to take in, beautiful building and the place where so much British History has happened. A must see!!
Nice attraction. 16 Pound admission fee, but if you think at other attractions in London, that cost even more, the price is okay.

Historic Abbey & resting place for many monarchs. In my opinion, Westminster Abbey is not as magnificant as St Paul's Cathedral, but has more history since it was built by King Henry III in 1245. It is the resting place for many monarchs. It does cost @$25 to enter, but considering the cost of upkeep it's probably worth paying it. Around some of the massive tombs, it is dimly lit (possibly to help preserve them), but it can get a little depressing. Be sure though to see the tomb of Queen Elizabeth I, and get a glimpse of the Shrine of Edward the Confessor who died in 1066.

Wonderful Abbey. This iconic church is simply known as "The Abbey" and really is an iconic church steeped in history. The self guided tour is very important as it traces the history of the tombs which are located around The Abbey. While one could argue the merits of paying an admittance fee the Abbey is truly one of the most important places of worship in the world and because of this and the history so well captured in the self guided tour it is well worth the admission price.The queues to enter also support this.Dont miss it in London

The history is staggering!. This is a must see, it always busy. Going to the back door near the gift shop for evensong, gets you in past the line, and at no charge. You can truly enjoy. One can go in to honor the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier as well for no charge, if you ask nicely.
Verger tour. So much history it is mind boggling. Please spend the 3 pounds to take the Verger tour - well worth the money. Evensong is worth staying for - the choir is spectacular.

Great self-guided tour. So Jeremy Irons, often a movie bad guy, is the voice of the self guided tour. Again, budget yourself a couple of hours for this one. As the tour is self paced, you can kind of race through some parts and spend more times at stops of particular interest to you. This was not something we planned. When walking from Buckingham Palace to the Thames, we stopped buy, debated a little and decided to go in and take the tour. It was one of the highlights of our trip. It would be a bit long for children. I don't think anyone under 13 would really appreciate the historical significance of the structure, the people who passed through there and the people who are burried there. For us, it was one of the most enjoyable touristy things we did in London. If you like history, don't miss it.

Worth the visit. The walk to the Abbey is such a joy and seeing Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament next door added to the enjoyment. The Abbey itself will not disappoint as it really is a beautiful and architectural wonder. It is amazing how many famous and creative people are buried inside. Walking up the centre isle, you cannot help but reminisce on the beautiful royal weddings. Give yourself a couple of hours at least and don't forget to take your camera

Umpteend visit. Each time I am in London , I never tire of this place like any other in London- The sheer beauty of this building makes one feel so grateful to be able to enjoy the architecture the solid stone work- I dont have words to describe my awe

Great!. Took the metro to Paddington station then took a train to Westminster Abby. It costs us around 30 pounds round trip for the two of us and took around 30-40 minutes each way and had to change trains once more right at the very end to get to Westminster.Having the audio guide is great but I'm a big fan of having an actual tour guide to ask when you have questions. We picked a gorgeous day and it was nice and sunny.We were even able to get our ticket stamped on the way out where you return the audio guide to validate your ticket for an entire year and since we live in Europe we know we'll definitely go again since the Church is closed on Sundays and we were unaware.

Take The Time For This Wonderful Place. The grounds of Abbey are free to enter and look around, take photos and really get the feel of the place. You can enter the Abbey for 16 Pounds ($28) for adults from 9:30am to 3:30pm most days. It is well worth going inside. Spend the money! Trust me it is very nice inside and brings back memories of Lady Di.

Truly Amazing. We like to travel in the fall and spring, when tourist crowds are not a problem.Seeing Westminster Abbey was truly amazing. It is so rich in history, from Royal Coronations, weddings, burials and memorials of Britian's most historic people.There is an audio tour that takes your through the Abbey. It is very well done and informative.We loved our morning at Westminster Abbey !!

Dark and dreary but historic. If you are a history buff it is a fascinating place to visit. It really is a cemetery and my family could not understand why anyone would want to be married in amongst the ancient coffins. Also amazing is how te decapitated Mary Queen of Scots lies there in an amazing tomb while the great Elizabeth 1st the 'virgin Queen' and Mary 1st nicknamed Bloody Mary could possibly be in the same tomb especially considering their troubled relationship. Sad to see the tomb of Elizabeth's great minister Cecil with it's carvings wearing smooth. Guards explained if no one pays for the upkeep of any of the engravings or inscriptions of the tombs they just fade away in time. How sad but I suppose it happens for commoners as well as the famous. My 21 year old daughter and 65 year old husband disliked the Abbey visit intensely saying they found it depressing and tedious. As a History teacher I found it fascinating.
amazing. what a place, what history beautiful,beautiful,beautiful.members of English Heritage get To go into the Chapter House for free.

Hadn't been in a long time. I like the Abbey, it's a must see. However, the price of admission is now quite steep at 16 pounds for an adult!!! I understand that upkeep is high, but it is a Royal Peculiar. Still a must see though. More things to see than when I first visited in the late 80s!

Feel the History. Have visited recently, opening times are on the website. I would recommend to get there for it opening as queues can be very long, especially in the summer months.As soon as you enter you can feel centuries of history seeped into the place. This isn't a place to be rushed,So much to see and take in.Audio and tour guides are available or you can wander round at your own pace.Poet's corner is fascinating, everywhere you look there are familiar names.The shrine of Edward the confessor is there too, as well as the coronation chair.One of the most interesting places is the Royal Tombs containing tombs of many kings and queens going as far back as 1272.There are over 600 monuments and wall tablets and over 3000 people are buried here.

Beautiful and peaceful. We went to the evensong service at Westminster Abbey. The service started at 3:00 that day, but we were told that the doors opened at 2:30 so we were there before 2:30. I recommend that you do that if you want to attend. The people who got there late weren't able to get good seats. You want seats right in front, preferably on the south side---that way you can still see the choir and also you can see the priest when he preaches and the officiator when he sings and conducts the service.The service lasts less than 1 hour. You're not allowed to tour the Abbey at that time---you have to attend the service and then leave, but we saw a lot just walking in and walking out. Lots of people's graves underneath you, lots of statues around.What a special place.

A Must see!. Right from walking in paying admission,you are absorbed with such history and the head set is narrated by Jeremy Irons,so much to see and spent about and hour 1/2 toruing inside.Just to see where William and Kate said their vows and where Diana's funeral was,you could almost feel like you were there.Gift shop also fabulous and bought lots!SO many kings and queens and lesser royal buried there as well.

A moment of glorious calm in the eye of a storm. I am probably the furthest thing from an Anglophile you can imagine, but this review may give you cause to doubt it.It was the day after the 2012 Olympics opened in London. We arrived in London exhausted, with a 13 hour stopover ahead of us. We took the pricey but excellent Heathrow Express in to Paddington and the Tube to Piccadilly. We surfaced in Trafalgar Square and over the course of an alternately rainy and sunny afternoon, made our way towards Westminster. The Abbey was closed but a notice on the gate mentioned that the choral evensong service (it was a Sunday) would begin at at 3 pm. Worshippers were invited to attend minus cameras. I am so glad we did. What a joy to enter this exquisite gothic structure, to sit in the choir, to immerse oneself in a harmonious swell of superb polyphony, ancient and modern. The acoustics were extraordinary. Around us a few Olympians had filtered in - their team colours showed they were from Poland and Canada – and they listened raptly as they prepared themselves for the great contest ahead. The very reverend John Hall, Dean of Westminster delivered the readings of scripture and verse in perfectly modulated tones. The choral responses soared. The lady bishop of Wimbledon gave the homily - a fact that pleased our feminist Catholic teenagers (and us) greatly. I was startled – despite my own Catholic traditions – by the extent of pomp and circumstance in a high Anglican service. After an hour, we filed out and strolled over to the Thames, rested and refreshed, physically and spiritually.
Awesome. Took grandkids - they felt surrounded by so much history. Amazing tour and helpful guides. So nice to actually be where we see on TV often.

Wonderful evensong. We attended evensong at the Abbey; what a wonderful experience. It's offered many days of the week, but not every day, at 5 p.m. The service is short--less than an hour--and the music is beautiful. Queue up ahead of time to ensure sitting as close to the choir as possible.

did this one on the London pass. i have an odd feeling to be charged for going into a religious edifice. This was included in the London pass so the odd feeling wasnt so odd when we used the pass . You can look up and be in awe of the beauty but make sure you look down to see what famous person you may be walking over as the Abbey has many historical figures buried in the floor. We enjoyed this visit and once again wish that we had read some history before we visited. We then had lunch in the Abbey and it was delicious and ok priced. The lunchroom offered a place to gather our strength for the walk towards the eyeenjoyed the visit

Take the 90-minute guided tour. You'll see more in that 90 minutes than you could on your own in twice the time, and you'll see parts that non-escorted visitors don't. Our verger (Benjamin) was very well-informed and clearly enjoyed presenting the tour. Avoid the audio tour - information is good but people shuffle along like radio-controlled sheep, shutting off their other senses as they listen.

Best stop in London!. This was by far the most exciting stop on my 3 day sightseeing extravaganza in London in July 2012. It is a truly amazing building and the audioguide was really interesting. I didn't realize that there was a guided tour that you could take, so I guess I have to go back now to try that! The audioguide did a great job of touring you through all the history. We spent about 2 hours, but I could have easily spent more time.

Just... wow.. Beautiful in every respect. I wouldn't say I'm very religious but you definitely feel something when you walk through these doors. The architecture is breathtaking, the stained glass, the tombs... Definitely on my top 10!

Pricey but worth it. Westminster Abbey is steeped in History. I loved seeing the burial places of so many kings and queens, and the church where so many monarchs wed and were crowned. The admission fee is a bit high, but I didn't mind it. We went on a rainy afternoon in June but the place wasn't crowded and we had no problem walking around and seeing everything, though there was a considerable line at the ticket office. The staff was very friendly and helpful. We liked the audio guides and thought they were very helpful, though a bit confusing at times. I particularly liked the fact that pictures aren't allowed inside - it maintains the reverence the place demands. Also every hour a prayer is offered inside the church, and the bishop (?) calls everyone to either join in or at least be silent in reverence while he offers a very brief prayer. I loved being able to pray in that place. It's a beautiful, amazing place.We did not eat there so I can't say anything about the restaurant.

Simply beautiful. Well worth a look. The atmosphere and history are palpable. When I visited I had to pay an entrance fee but it was worth it and the money doubtless goes to maintain this lovely building, which is the last resting place of so many worthy souls.

Breathtaking. Take your time at this attraction. Plan to spend about 2 hrs to take in the history of this remarkable site. It is a MUST see if you are in London. Tours are offered in many languages. No pictures allowed unfortunately. Go early, beat the crowd as it can get cramped inside, avoid weekend if possible.

Attended Service Here. i went here on a sunday. seeing the massive long line i was hesistant to wait but i was glad i did. i got to experience mass inside westminsiter abbey. i got to sit in the pews and it was just a surreal experience knowing who had been inside this place. the architecture from the outside was just as amazing and breathtaking. a must see if you are in london.

good but audio guide very disappointing. The cathedral is truly impressive. A must see if you are in London. I would love to come back to the cathedral again and do one of their guided tours. The audio guide was just too short on facts and left me frustrated that I was only getting an explanation for a small fraction of what was before me. Hint, get there at least an hour before one of the guided tours are to start, as the lines to get in are long and you must sign up for the guided tour once you have got your entry ticket.

Must see if you love history. Amazing sculptures, tombs and markers showcase the incredible history of this place. It is a living, breathing museum that is chock full of interesting findings no matter where you look. Take your time and use the audio guide to enjoy the details. It's worth it.
A must see for a first time visitor to London. This is a good place to put on your must see list (aka Bucket list) for a first time visitor to London England

Be SURE to take the guided tour!. The entry fee includes an audioguide, which most people seem to take. But for an additional 3 pounds, you can take the guided tour. Spend the money -- take this tour! The tour guides are members of the Abbey staff. They are called Vergens and are lay people, they are dressed in long black cassocks, so they look sort of priest-ly. They can take you to places inside the Abbey you cannot go with the audioguide. We went into the center of the Abbey, through a gate, up some creaky stairs and heard the story of Edward the Confessor, who began the building of this magnificent building in 1053 (or thereabouts). There is a tomb that you can kneel in; all very ancient and sacred feeling. The story of why Elizabeth 1 and Mary are buried together is fascinating. The history is so dense that without a guide, it would all be overwhelming. The line to get in was divided; one side for cash and one side for credit. The guide books say that you can only pay cash, so the credit might be new, but there was no wait at all on that side. The line to pay cash was LOONNNGGGGGG. And the tour is limited to about 20. At some point, the gentleman counted and discovered he had picked up a couple of strays. Even though we were wearing badges, identifying us a members of a tour, some people just joined us! He asked them, in the politest way possible, to leave our tour, as he could only accommodate 20. Very nice. He explained everything, took us everywhere; might have been the best tour in London, and that is saying a lot! He invited us to return for an Evensong service, to hear the choir sing. I did. What a wonderful experience. The building has great acoustics and there isn't anything more moving than a boy's choir in a stone building! I cannot thank the Abbey staff enough for this wonderful experience.

Interesting also for the children. We were very satisfied that there was a little quiz for the children to explore the cathedral during our visit. Unfortunately it was very difficult for them as they are quite small. Maybe it would be better to design two different questionnaires for small and older children.

Expensive, but worthwhile.. Walking around Westminster Abbey is like having a history lesson of England - all those royal connections, all those tombs, all that grandeur. It's incredible. It's expensive, but it's easily possible to spend two or three hours inside. The museum is a highlight - coming face to face with Henry VII was really something, and seeing the ring that Elizabeth I had given to Essex... a token of her favour, carved with her image ..... There are some cons though. It's busy, and 'the tour' is regimented. It's not possible to wander around at will, areas are roped off and the audio guide (included in the entrance fee) encourages the visitor to keep moving; the guide is good in as far as it goes - history in broad strokes - it concentrates on a few highlights and is far from comprehensive. Although Abbey staff were helpful when I asked questions, the experience seemed to be designed to get people round as quickly as possible. We wanted to have lunch in the Cellarium Cafe before starting our visit, little realising that having queued for our audio guides we could not take them into the cafe area. The Cellarium was expensive, service was a little abrupt, and the discretionary service charge was added to the bill without comment or explanation.
Romantic. Only viewed from the outside but so lovely so see in person where all those beautiful weddings and coronations have taken place throughout history

A great experience, despite the crowds. We visited Westminster Abbey on a rainy autumn day, so it was full of wet tourists (like us). The lineup to get in was long, but we chose the cash-only line, which moved quickly. Despite the crowds, it was tranquil and peaceful, and we spent much longer there than we expected. We learned a fair bit about the history of the British royal family and mainstream religious life in England. We also enjoyed a private meditation service in King Edward the Confessor's shrine and tomb, surrounded by kings and queens. This is offered twice a day and it is the only opportunity for visitors to visit the shrine. A great deal of time can be spent seeking out the resting places of luminaries such as Sir Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Charles Dickens, Rudyard Kipling, George Frederic Handel and Laurence Olivier. Many of the more recognizable names can be found in Poet’s Corner, which is at the end of the tour route. Admission is definitely costly, but it includes a detailed audio and video guide narrated by actor Jeremy Irons. There is a treasure hunt booklet for families to use to make the experience more exciting and educational for kids. Be sure to visit the Chapter House, full of beautiful stained glass, wall paintings, and the oldest door in Britain.

A wonderful tour through English history. Westminster Abbey is a major tourist attraction in London so it will be crowded most of the time.The audio guide which is included in the entrance fee and has many language options is exceptionally good with the normal guide channels but also it has music and video clips on other channels. It is well organised with enough Abbey personnel to keep the crowds moving. But most of all, it has seen history made in terms of coronations and royal weddings and contains tombs of kings, queens, poets, writers etc who shaped English history for the last 1000 years. A well presented attraction that leaves you a lot more knowledgeable and well worth the cost of entrance for 2 hours plus of interest and entertainment.
Historic place. If you are in London, this is one of you must-see places. Not only because it's magnificient in the outside, but also because of the historic meaning. Book a few hours for it!

A beautiful abbey church with an exceptional concentration of history. Entrance is by the north door, (if you chose to pay with a credit card the queue is on the right and is longer / slower than the cash queue on the left). There is an audio guide included in the charge, but for a little extra a personal guided tour by one of the abbey guides is best, especially if you seek those little gems that bring the whole place alive.The delicate tomb of Edward The Confessor (whose death lead indirectly to the Norman Invasion) maybe glimpsed, but is strictly controlled by prior arrangement.....definitely worth doing your research beforehand as it can be overwhelming. The buiulding and its adjoing cloisters and chapter house are truly wonderful, the stone work in particular is jaw dropping....then there is the whose who of who is there, out of over 3,000 dead candidates I chose Richard III wife Anne Neville who is remebered on the opposite side to Henry VII, Elizabeth and Mary Tudor, daughters of Henry VIII and Queens of England in turn but bitterly opposed on religious lines, they are buried side by side, not far from Mary Queen of Scots who was executed for treason after the discovery of the Babington plot.....Henry VII is there and so are plaques to soldiers prime ministers, poets etc., Cromwell was here until Charles II was so outraged that he had him dug up and hanged and beheaded (although already dead!) at Tyburn.....I wonder if there were any Irish volunteers for that task.... The abbey (which is not an abbey any more c/o Henry VIII) is generally open to visitors Monday to Friday, but check because it maybe closed for religious services. I am told that Mondays are notoriously busy because of build-up over the weekend. There were some building works when I was there but these were not very intrusive..... Is the entrance fee too expensive? Maybe to some but it rather depends how much you get out of your trip; good planning and prep will probably enhance your experience and value for money......
Part of our heritage!. This is history coming alive! A stunning building with a history that is unimaginable to someone who comes from a young country like New Zealand.
Pricey. Lovely from the outside, and this is all I saw because it is 16 pounds to enter. I suggest that unless you are very interested just be satisfied with its beautiful exterior

Don't bypass the audio tour (free with admission). I've visited Westminster Abby several times over the years, but only this last time did I take advantage of the free audio tour. Don't pass it up. You'll come away with a much better appreciation of the rich history and significance of this stunning Gothic cathedral.

Westminster. Wellof course we have all seen the marriages of Charles and Dianne , Will AND kate but to visit the Abby on an ordinary day is another story , many famous people have been laid to rest there like Sir Issaic Newton for one , it is very dark inside , much of it cover in wood , the walls and seats , the stained glass windows , it is quite beautiful , just around the corner from Big Ben and Parliment it makes for a very interesting day while visiting London

Evensong at the Abbey on Sunday. I was in London on business and my only window for sightseeing was on Sunday afternoon. Westminster Abbey is closed to tourists on Sunday, but all are welcome to attend the 3:00 Evensong service. You can wander in slowly to find a seat, getting a very good look at several of the Abbey's highlights. But best of all, you have a wonderful hour long service, which is virtually all music provided by the organ and the boys and men's choir. Truly a lovely way to spend a bit of time in London.

Everything that is London. Issac Newton and Darwin are forever entombed... the coronation throne (100's of years old) is here on display and it is still used today. The building and everything that is here and that it represents is all the reason you need to see it. The only thing I was dissapointed with is that you can't see the tomb of the first king buried in the abbey.
A definite London stop. One of the best Cathedrals I've seen in Europe. A lot of history so give enough time. The audio presentation is actually better than most.

Beautiful and Inspiring. Yes, the entrance fee is somewhat expensive, and no, photography is not allowed--something that momentarily annoyed me until I saw the crowds and wondered how much several thousand people trying to take photos would increase congestion.However, the Abbey is absolutely beautiful and you can actually feel the weight of the history that happened there. You could spend most of the day reading the inscriptions on the tombs and memorials for everyone from kings and queens to the Abbey's plumber. Very inspiring.

if you have time go, Its gorgeous and historic but if your only in England for a short time we found other churches mor. I cannot tell you how much I was looking forward to visiting Westminster Abby. We arrived 15 mins before opening on a Wednesday morning and lined up in a small que about 10 people long. At 10am the Abby opened and we were shuffled into the ticket line. The price per ticket is 19 pounds and that comes with an included audio guide. We wanted to take the guided tour with a real person but were told that it is an extra 5 pounds a person and the first tour of the day was totally booked. We decided to just do the audio tour which was one of those phone type things where you type in the number when you get to it and then hold it to your ear. That were fine and the guy giving them out was helpful in pointing us in the right direction to start. I enjoyed the information and found it easy to use but because everyone is forced to travel the same direction in an odd sort of parade spaces around the numbers got really cramped. Lots of school groups were there and people began to really pack in a jostle for spots to see the alter and graves of monarchs. At two different points school groups pushed past my husband and I and stood in front of graves to listen as one big group. We are both in are twenties physical fit and don’t mind crowds but found this crazy and very uncomfortable. After we finished the tour and walked through the outer gate to tour the grounds and gardens we were astounded by the huge numbers of people, tour groups and school groups who seemed to show up out of nowhere. They all seemed to be on their own private tours and were happy to push past independent travelers and cut lines to see the highlights of the Abby. What truly annoyed me was that the docents who are stationed everywhere did not seem to mind and when we asked them about it told us that the groups are such big ticket buyers they are accommodated. The Abby however is amazing the architecture is breathtaking and the small museum in the west crypt is very cool and has 6 or 7 wax effigies preserved from royal funerals of the 1800’s. The audio tour is average and provides good information but is rigidly laid out and in large crowds hard to follow. The docents are around at lots of peak locations and were very nice about answering questions or helping find a specific grave/monument. Overall I went to London really looking forward to visiting Westminster Abby and left with the feeling that; if you have time go, Its gorgeous and historic but if your only in England for a short time we found other churches more beautiful, less crowed and much friendlier even if less famous and with less buried monarchs.

Evening Organ Recital. We were able to catch a 30 minute evening organ recital here while we were in town for a short time. While we really weren't able to tour the entire Abbey, just being there listening to the organ was beautiful. Glad we were able to experience this on our trip.

Very impressive. Westminster AbbeyVery impressive! It’s not just a church, it’s the history of England and you’re standing where the people who made much of that history are buried. We got to see the resting place of a famous ancestor. I would have taken a lot of pictures but they don’t allow photography inside so I had to limit my efforts to the outside of the church. There is a nice gift shop which my wife made full use of. If you like visiting churches and historical sites while traveling then you will enjoy this.

One of the highlights of our trip. Such a beautiful cathedral, it really is a must see if you are in London.The architecture both inside and out is incredible, while the memorials and headstones are works of art in themselves...... They would give many a museum and art gallery a run for their money.It was crowded the day that we went, but we were still able to see everything quite comfortably and enjoy it in our own time.If you had any questions, there were plenty of volunteers on hand to answer them for you, and some had a few interesting stories to share. Such a shame that photography isn't allowed..... As a keen photographer, this was a little disappointing...... Especially as you consider that photography is allowed in the Louvre.

Heavenly Music in the Abbey. On a recent trip to London, my daughter wanted to visit Westminster Abbey; we found out the tickets were a little expensive, at 16 GBP or about $25. As we debated going in, we noticed church announcements of service times, organ recitals and evensong choir singing. All these were at no cost. We decided to go back later on in the day for the organ recital. What an excellent choice. We arrived about 5:15 to wait on line and entered the Abbey at 5:40. What a magnificent place. We sat in a side section surrounded by lovely stained glass, dramatic statues, and facing a beautiful altar. The organ recital began and the church was filled with gorgeous music. If you want a special treat, go to the Abbey on Sundays for the 5:45- 6:15 organ recital.

didn't even go in.... Look, the abbey is impressive from the outside. Clearly it's a great tourist attraction. After 4 weeks in France and Spain visiting churches that don't charge for entry, I thought the 16 pound entry fee per adult was ridiculous. Even with the sign outside the front that attempts to explain that the state, crown or government does not fund the abbey - I thought asking people to cough up that kind of money to get in was very steep indeed...so I did not go in. If you're happy to view from the outside though, it's good enough!

Evensong Service. As an Anglican, I wanted to attend a service at Westminster Abby and hear the amazing choir. We attended the 5pm Evensong service and were lucky enough to get to sit in the choir stalls! The choir was just out of this world, we were so pleased to be able to attend this service and thank God for a great and safe vacation. It was St. Luke's day and the bells were rung after the service which was so wonderful to experience.

Amazing to check out the tombs. The history connected with this place is astonishing. If you are the sort of person who enjoys cemeteries, you will love this place. Newton, Darwin, Shakespeare, Chaucer, and many others are buried here, and others are memorialized. Beautiful architecture as well.
royal weddding. very nice, but no pics allowed, it would be much more nice to have lasting memories on film, i can understand why no flash, but pics would be great, also no discount tickets available

Great history and architecture. What impressed me the most about Westminster Abbey was the number of artists and scientists buried or memorialized there: Charles Darwing, Isaac Newton, Rudyard Kipling, and dozens more. The building itself I found more impressive than Notre Dame in Paris, but not as much as St. Pauls Cathedral. What I didn't like is that pictures are not allowed and that there's an entry fee. Having to pay to enter a church just seems wrong. (Services are free).
Imposing.. Beautiful imposing abbey,just next to Big Ben.Great for pics wide angle.Must see when in London.Go there.
Westminster Cathedral. A little bit of History. Magnificent building to visit. We attended the ANZAC service to honour the service people of the past wars which was a great tribute.

Not To Be Missed. If you love gothic architecture, this is a must during your trip to London. The outside is impressive but this has one of the most impressive interiors of any church I've ever seen. The recorded tour on a personal player is very helpful and, unlike trying to listen to a live person during a tour, you can replay parts that you don't understand and do the tour at your own pace.

Stunning. I've seen the West side of this church from TV, newspapers, etc. And I never knew there existed a north side facade. I love the stunning architecture of the north facade of this church. One of the most beautiful church I've seen! I didn't enter the church though as it was pricey. Free admission would be good.

A must see in London. This is a must see in London. We purchased the London Pass at the airport and we probably didn't see enough to cover the cost of the pass in the two days we were in London. However, it was worth the cost to me to be able to fast track past the lines with the pass so recommend purchasing one if you don't like to wait in long lines. The Abbey doesn't allow photography and the staff will tell you to mind your bags due to pickpockets. There is a handheld tour device that you hold up to your ear to hear the stories of each area. They move you through the church at a nice even pace which allows you to see all you wish to see. Warning the Abbey is rather large and it is difficult to absorb it all in a few hours. The Coronation chair is there to view as well but is tucked in a corner so don't miss seeing where all the Kings and Queens were crowned.

Ok. This was ok, interesting and somewhat fascinating, but I overall didn't like it very much. You can get souvenirs here though and that made things somewhat better. But overall it's kinda grim and dark, and there's not too much that's interesting there

Beautiful and historic. Coranations, weddings and funerals of the Royal Family have been taking place here for centuries. Many kings and queens are buried here, along with a who's who of English poets. The abbey is stunning and the audio tour which comes with admission is informative. We had no lines on a Tuesday afternoon and the crowd inside was manageable. Entrance is £16, but I believe this is covered on The London Pass, so if you are planning to do a lot of sightseeing squeezed into a number of days, the pass would be worth it.

Beautiful. Even though we could not go inside because it was Sunday and closed just being outside was enough. I have heard so much of this place and now learning a little bit of its history was great.

Kings and Queens. The history here is mind blowing. You step into this huge cathedral and you are immediately thrown back in to time. Do the audio tour. Show up early. Kings tombs, queens tombs and others. It was pretty cool to see. I am a history buff so I really liked it. Oh....the bathrooms are bad or the at least the public ones.
Absolutley amazing. A beautiful Abbey. Such amazing history. The audio tour was very good and they had a printout of the audio for my deaf companion

History and holiness, the circle is unbroken. Wow, what history, and it's still a functioning church, a circular history that goes on! How good is that? If you don't go in, you are missing out on 90% of the experience of Westminster Abbey, even if there is a queue. Absolutely, go early, but they let a lot of people in at a time. So, even if there is a queue, you'll get in. Nothing can describe the history of the place and of all the people buried there. You have to go in. It is simply one of the "must see's" of London. You'll understand what I am saying after you've made the tour. Note: It's better than St. Paul's. As good as St. Paul's is, this is better. And it's a holy place too. Every hour on the hour, everyone in the building is asked to stop in their tracks and remain quiet while a one minute prayer is read over the address system from the pulpit. That's very neat.

Love history? Don't miss Westminster Abbey!. It can be pricey, but considering the depth, range and amount of English history found on this site, it's well worth the entry fee. The audio tour is excellent, though if you can join a tour with guide, I'd recommend this. Plan on spending a couple of hours - and don't miss the Lady Chapel, the Charter House (if open). Good coffee and refreshments available in the cloister area, which is peaceful even when bustling inside.

Beautifully done guided tour. The tour was great and was glad we got the guided tour that we did as it was so crowded that we could hardly see things and would have not have been able to explore and get all the info if we had done it on our own.
Westminster Abbey. Fantastic spot in London to go and see, beautiful architecture inside and out, visiting tours inside only Monday to Saturday. No visiting tours inside aloud on Sundays.
A must see in London!. The history of what has happend here is fascinating, and you cans see the resting place and monuments for the who's who of British royalty and poets.

Only saw the outside. My friends and and I didn't go in, but the outside of the Abbey was beautiful. The only reason we didn't go in was because of the line outside to get in. I would suggest going to the Abbey as early as possible to avoid the long line to get in.

Breathtaking!. Breathtaking doesn't even begin to cover it! The sheer size of the church and knowing it was built by human hands is just amazing. We had our two children (6 and 7) with us and spent about two hours here. We were approached shortly after we entered by someone who worked there offering the kids a "children's trail." It was like a scavenger hunt. It helped to focus our tour and kept it from being too overwhelming. My husband and I both had the audio tour which helped with supplemental information. My kids loved this place, we loved this place. It was beautiful and well worth the cost of admission. If you have questions, be sure to ask the many people stationed around the church. They were full of answers and loved to tell about the church. Oh, and when you are done the tour with children, be sure to stop in the gift shop and turn in the children's trail. The kids get a souvenir chocolate coin!

Beautiful.. Had a few hours to spare in London last November so visited the Abbey. I thought the admission price was a little steep, but afterwards I felt it was worth it to see inside this stunning Church. Highly recommended, so much to see and very educational. Perfect for a history nerd.

Amazing !!!!!. This is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen in my life!!! I was not expecting to be so moved by all the beauty and history that Westminster Abbey had to offer. Put this at the top of your places to see in London. You will not be disappointed. It is truly amazing!!!!

Beautiful Place !!!. I really enjoyed visiting this church. This is a treasure of significant importance in London history. It has a lot of chapels fill with architecture and sculptures. The week that I was in london rained a lot, don't forget your umbrella and coat you may need it. Hand held guide are provided to you at the entrance at no cost. It is a lot to see and read. I was there for about 1 !/2 hr and run out of time.You probable are going to need more time is quite big inside. It is near the Big Ben Tower.
Cold church. Old and cold sums it up best! Very ornate but have been in much better churches. Not worth the queue

Favourite place in London. We spent over 3 hours exploring the complex, there is so much to see! The nave is full of interesting tombs with its stories and the garden/cloister area is beautifully peaceful. A must visit place in London!

Breathtakingly Beautiful - Interesting - Educational. Westminster Abbey was one of the most breathtaking Churches I have ever seen. Words fail me ... just go ... and plan extra time to see and read all that is there! We ate lunch at the new restaurant and it was very good.

Day Trip. At first I thought the admission price was too high but I came out not disappointed. There is a lot to see and if you are there in time they open up the St Edwards Shrine for a brief prayer/viewing as it is so old.

Surprised by how much we enjoyed it. We knew that Westminster was a must do for London, but we were surprised at how much we enjoyed and appreciated it. A key to this was the handset we were provided with as we walked in the door (included in admission fee). The information was invaluable in guiding us through the abbey ensuring we caught the high points. I was particularly struck by the chapel of Henry VI which is breathtakingly beautiful. We also enjoyed poets' corner and were amazed by the number of British authors that are buried or memorialized in it. We were stunned by the plethora of graves and memorials--it would take many viisits to fully appreciate this aspect.Our first attempt to visit the Abbey failed as there was a special event taking place. However we learned that the website lists the events to which the pubic can get passes. The benefit of this is hearing the choir sing. The choir does sing frequently and it is worth timing your visit to hear them.

Spectacular even when crowded inside and wet outside. We waited until we could get in using a London Pass to save some money on entry fees - two years ago we had to pay to get in and wouldn't. We have a distant relative there and our goal was to find his statue - no mean feat among a sea of small and big creations. It's so big and such a vast monument to religion and history. Be prepared to move in a throng of people and don't forget to look down as well as up and sideways as there is as much to see on the floors as everywhere else. The guides are pretty helpful if you are searching for something or someone. Sit down and take it all in if you can.
Amazing history, at a price. The abbey is probably a must do, or close to it, while in London. Entry price is a bit steep, but I'm not visiting every week.
The detail. We didn't do the tour but we walked around and admired all the details. Get there around 9:30 so that you beat the crowd.

Beautiful church, but very crowded. It's easy to get a bit overwhelmed with history in London, and Westminster Abbey is probably the pinnacle of London history. There are so many tombs tucked into every nook and cranny of the church that it becomes impossible to focus on anything. I enjoyed seeing the tombs of Isaac Newton and other luminaries, but trying to appreciate the long history of the Abbey is tough when there are a thousand people pushing you down the aisle of the church. That's not the fault of the Abbey, but it's something to be aware of before you go. If there is such a thing as a "not busy" time at the Abbey, try to go then.

Unique gothic style architecture. Very unique gothic style and the vault ceilings are amazing pieces of artwork. There is nothing quite like it at other cathedrals/churches. There was something interesting to view at every corner.

Wish you could take pictures!. Westminster Abbey is one of the most beautiful places in London! I just wish they'd let you take photographs inside. The audio tour is wonderful, highly recommended. Just watch out for pickpockets inside!
Beautiful. It is as beautiful as it is historic. Although it was crowded and very slow moving, we enjoyed our tour of this incredible Abbey.

Day of worship, not tourist, Sunday. Did visit gift store and appreciated less congestion of tourists than the visit in June with the olympics and Wimbledon traffic. Could actually see the gift items and made purchases this time. Still appreciated the beauty of the buildings and scenery/

Tour and Evensong. With its excellent free audio guide, the tour offers a nice history lesson, at your own pace. I'm not much for guided tours moving along with a crowd, so the self-guided tours at so many of the sites around London were just my cup of tea (...and that's another review - tea at The Wolesley). You can actually feel the history of Westminster Abbey as you step inside. It's fun to get lost in the imagery of the stories of the artists, royalty, poets and writers. While it is certainly a typical tourist stop, it should be on your "don't miss" list along with St. Paul's which is entirely different and stunningly magnificent. The Evensong service at 5 pm is lovely - particularly if you get to hear the Abbey boys' choir. We ended up with a seat in the back with no view. While the music was great, it would've been nice to see faces to go with the voices. Recommend arriving early to get an up front seat.
Visit Inside. Impressive looking church. Don't just take photos outside. Pay the entrance fees and see where most of the royal families have been married in.

Profoundly Stimulating. Don't miss it. Westminister Abbey is a must to see when in London.I could feel the royality as soon as I walked into the doorA wonderful audio tour is free with paid admissionThe line moves quickly and once inside you are at your own paceGive yourself some time so you are not rushed, there is much to see.Enjoy!

Don't bother. Have tried to get in twice on the last two visits to the UK.... Both times, had to wait for hours in the queue and ended up giving up..... just as well as we didn't know there's an entry fee also...???!!! People... IT'S A CHURCH!!!!! Please don't charge people for wanting to light a candle and say a prayer!!! Now THAT is a disgrace....I don't whinge about queues really as I choose to do the tourist thing, but I won't pay for something which essentially is your religeous right to do.... won't be returning!!
Magic. The Palace of Westminster by it's proper name we visited the cloisters the library the abbey what a great experience worth every penny

Highlight of our trip to London... We arrived around 9:10 am and there was already a line up to get in but once it got going it moved along at a pretty good pace. I had goosebumps waiting to get in and as soon as you enter the door you see some of the statues and ceiling and it was incredible. We went with the Verger Tour and as far as I am concerned it was the only way to go, extra 3.00 pounds. They got you close to all the different areas and gave a little more information than the audio guide did. Unfortunately the area behind the altar was closed because of restoration work but we had a quick peek. I had a tear in my eye when I saw Elizabeth 1st crypt. The history, the people buried and remembered there is truly overwhelming, I loved the quire area and where the Knight of the Bath sit. Because this is a working church no photos, no cell phones and every hour a prayer is said. It was nice to see people of all faiths stop and take a moment to respect this. The tour takes about 90 minutes and then we went back to some of the areas to revisit. In total we spent about 3 hours there and we would definitely go back if we go to London again. There is so much that we overlooked we would have to go back.

Amazing. This place is really amazing. The day we went we were turned away in the morning due to a special service they were holding. It might be good to check before you go to make sure this doesn't happen to you. We came back at 1:30pm when they said it would be open again and the lines were LONG. We got in the cash line thinking it would move quicker then the credit card line. I think we made a good choice because we were through in no time. Don't let the line intimidate you as it will move rather quickly. Once in it was still very crowded and that is the only thing that bothered me. It was really hard to see some of the things we wanted to see due to the crowds. But I'm sure it had something to do with the fact that these people had done the same thing we had done and now the afternoon AND the morning crowds were seeing the Abbey all together. Oh well - it was worth it and I'm glad we were able to get in.

A Must See. Kings, Queens, Poets, and more. I wanted to see Westminster Abbey because I watched parts of the royal wedding and Princess Diana's funeral. It was amazing to see exactly where everything is and the history behind the building. There are some very famous people buried here.The coronation chair which you see as you exit is worth the price of admission.
What an unbelievable show of history.. The history within the Abbey is something that has to be seen to be believed. Very interesting and worthwhile.

The stone steps say it all. As you enter the Abbey, look down at the steps...they're worn away with over 1000 years of feet, including all the greats of English history. The burial chambers are amazing, but as a friend of mine remarked, if you want to see where Henry VIII is buried, it's not here...in case you want to see him, he's elsewhere.The poets and writers are everywhere, please don't stand on them! It's just marvellous to stand where kings have stood and look at the amazing old architecture. Today's designers could learn something about durability!Like entering a sacred place, which, of course, it is!

Awesome to see in person. This place is really cool to see in person, and BIG. Beware that there are two lines, cash to the left, and credit to the right. The line for credit moved swiftly, there were probably 100 people ahead of us, and only a 10-15 minute wait. The free audio guide was quite handy, and doesn't give lectures, just quick explanations of what you're looking at. Sadly you can't take pictures in here, but that's too be expected in any setting such as this.

Worth the 16pound admission. A wonderful site-audio tour is is included in the admission and this church is filled with historical graves. The chapel of st Edward the confessor is considered the jolliest site. There is prayer said on the hour. The gift shop is great and we ate at the cellarium-the cafe attached to the abbey which was delightful.All in all a wonderful day

....wasn't in. We came on the write time but there was some conference inside and we couldn't get in...we were very sorry but it was our own mistake....YOU NEED TO CHECK TIMETABLES BEFORE YOU GO THERE!!

walk in the steps of royalty...westminster abbey. audio tour sets a must (free) a lot of people working there to help with any questions...easy to just picture the royal weddings and funerals.......beautiful, beautiful...okay for all ages

DO not visit with a 1 year old!. It was great and there are so much to see. travelling with a pushchair didn't help and it got tiring after a while however the place is massive and GREAT! Staff is great however i would recommend a tour so you would know exactly what the place is about. Would re-visit not with my kid tough!

What an inside.westminster abbey. One of the best visits my wife and I have had in London.this is really an eye opener and well worth the money.the ushers inside are there to help and advise you and this they do ,and I mean really do.so much history to take in and it is really worth the visit.It takes about an hour.there are a few small shop stands inside and also a small garden,so don't delay go now.

evensong. We attended an Evensong service. The church itself is stunning, and the service was also very beautiful and intimate. I am glad we attended and think this was a unique way to visit the church.

"Very impressive...". I decided to visit the abbey for a number of reasons and was not deceived by the splendour of this magnificent edifice. A great number of British and English monarchs are buried there and one will see a diversity of architectural styles and its collection of tombs and monuments (Elizabeth I and Mary Tudor, Mary Queen of Scots, Shakespeare, the touching one of Florence Nightingale, etc...) and I would stongly recommend the audio guide for a better understanding of the importance of this site... Arrive early, and if coming from Victoria station walk about and have a look at the splendid Westminster Cathedral on your way there.

Worth it. Although it comes off as a bit cluttered, the Abbey is well worth the price and the time. If for nothing else, the architecture is simply breathtaking. After a while, it gets difficult to appreciate one crypt after another, but go and experience it. Skip the audio guide unless you are a hardcore history buff. It just distracted me from the experience (and gave me a sore neck).

A Wonderful Visit. Spoke to a guard on Saturday and found out that if you show up Sunday at 9:30 am you can attend services in this wonderful place. We did and it was a unbelievable experience. The choir performed right in front of us and the pagentry was great. A very moving experience without having to wait in line on a tour line for a hour and half. But no photos allowed! I had church service right where they have the coronations, etc. Maybe I sat right where The Queen sat before? LOL. Don't miss this!

Breathtaking.... Not only can you get lost in the amazement of the place, but the included audio tour also does a very good job of explaining every part of the church. I think we spent almost 2 hours there. My only complaints are that you cannot take photos which I understand to a point, but I don't see the harm in allowing photography without flash. I also had to use the restroom after waiting in a very long line to get in and the restrooms are all the way at the end of the tour and since the whole place is roped off so that people follow it in order, I was forced to speed walk the whole thing first and then go all the way back through to the beginning which was time consuming and difficult with the amount of people there.

More beautiful than pictures!. Beautiful architecture and windows plus interesting people buried here ~ made for a very interesting morning! I would def get there first thing in the morning, as the line was already long when we arrived about 10:30am.

Glorious!. We’ve all seen the images on TV during royal ceremonies, but seeing it in person takes it to a totally different level. Even the most jaded will be amazed and will love the sheer grandeur and elegance of this place. It is really nothing short of amazing. I can honestly say that I love The Abbey, and it is really something that you have to see when you’re in London. It will take you some time to go through this wonderful place. Primarily because The Abbey is much larger than one would think. The main hall is immense, and the outer courts are expansive. There is just so much to see. Also, nearly everyone who is anyone is buried there. The tombs are fascinating to see, and the details provided in the audio tour warrant you taking your time. The outside corridors surrounding the square is quite nice (and there are even tons of people buried there, also), and it’s an area where you can get something to eat and relax and also take some pictures. In closing, The Abbey embodies so much of British history, yet is a living place in that it is a working church and remains an important part of state functions today. With that in mind it would be a mistake to travel all the way to London and not see this magnificent place. Just go, and I promise you that you’ll be blown away!Hope this helps.

No photography? No cheering crowds then.. Sorry, but ban of photos inside is a bit much for shutterfreaks like me. Some of the medieval royal tombs look in desperate need for care as well. Otherwise - a unique experience, with a myriad of memorials to people ranging from local nobles and officials to the rivalling pair Mary & Elizabeth, Newton and Wilde. The cloisters are a good place to console yourself and your camera after the restrictions inside.
OMG!. OMG! I loved everything! Buy the audio! It is not expensive but It will make your visit worthwhile! It took me 4 hours. but I visited every single room and read everything. just couldn't stop!

AMAZING!. Being able to tour the Abbey was amazing. All the monuments and tombs you can see it just blows your mind. I even attended a mid-day service while visiting. I spent close to 2 hours just looking at everything. Its beautiful, stunning and breath taking.
Incredible. An amazing experience, so interesting and so much more in it than we thought. Fascinating! An absolute must do for anyone who visits london.

Fascinating place. Had wanted to visit here for many years-we were not disappointed. I didn't know it was filled with little rooms with tombs. Very interesting. Beautiful place. Easily can spend two-three hours here. We didn't see everything.

Audio Tour. The history and architecture are stunning. The audio tour is excellent - clear and easy to follow. A real bonus for us was when the organ began to play very softly. We arrived late in the day, and had to queue only for about 15 mins. As well as the audio, there were guides to help out with any questions, and my two companions (on a visit from USA) were well pleased with information from this source. The weather was good, so we walked from the National Galley in Trafalgar Square down Whitehall to the Abbey. In addition to Downing Street and Horse Guards Parade, there are some beautiful historic buildings along this stretch of road, together with ancient and modern statues, and the more widely known cenotaph.
days out in london. its unbelieveable how beautiful this abbey is could have sat in there all day well worth visiting and well worth the money
Overwhelming. Go early to avoid the crowds!! Amazing place with mind-boggling history - the audio tour is great!! Loved it.

A Must See. For anyone who enjoys History, architecture and a WOW experience, this is a must. Do your homework before going, to make the most of your interest during your visit. Easy to get to, you can walk from Waterloo if the weather is good. Cross over Westminster Bridge, to find it. Allow at least 2 hours minimum. Discover th remarkable history and beauty of the place
amazing history. Amazing history surrounding this lovely building as well .Amazing to think royals have been married at this catherderal

Worth visiting!. It's impressive and very well organized. The audio guide will provide a lot of information about the history. There are a lot of thumbs there including Elizabeth I, Mary from Scotland, Carrol Lewis, Haendel just to mention a few.

Has to be seen to be believed. You simply cannot describe it. You just have to see it for yourself. It is one of the most remarkable places I have ever seen. You are walking into history, back in time. I have never seen anything like it.

Beautiful architecture and so many famous tombs!. Didn't love the steep entry price (Notre Dame is free!), but the audio guide (narrated by Jeremy Irons!) is well worth it and the walking tour you get is amazing. Lovers of history will love this place. Sooo many famous folks are buried here: Kings, Queens, Scientists, Poets, Writers, Nobles, etc. Being at the resting place of Elizabeth I, Edward the Confessor, Sir Isaac Newton and Darwin was incredible. History Channel fans will love this one.

I Wanted To Like It But It Just Made Me Feel Sad. I had been looking forward to a trip to Westminster Abbey ever since my husband and I planned out our itinerary for our trip to London as neither of us had visited the Abbey before. I was sadly, and extremely, disappointed by the whole visit. It made me feel depressed.An air of "we don't want you in here" pervades the whole place. The staff are rude, unwelcoming and the entire staff body wandering round the building are unhelpful and unapproachable (which is odd considering all they seem to be doing is walking in circles doing nothing) and their attitude was distinctly of the variety that 'we're better than you little people and it's only because we have to let you in here that you are'.The whole place is dirty, the statues, plaques and plinths don't look like they've been cleaned in a long time (baring a very quick spruce up for the royal wedding) and there are cobwebs coming off of them. What exactly are the people running Westminster Abbey spending all their profits on? It's clearly not on conservation and cleaning! The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier was poignant and probably the only thing I can't fault.One of the jewels in Westminster Abbey is supposed to be the tombs of the monarchs they have buried there (such as Richard II, Henry V and Edward VI amongst others) but you only get to see a small part of each tomb because the rest is facing the shrine of Edward the Confessor. As for looking at the shrine of Edward the Confessor, a major religious pilgrimage for many people and an important historical pilgrimage for others, forget it. It's reserved for the privileged few and only open at certain, limited, times (to be slightly fair; I've since learned that the shrine is closed off so much at the moment because of work being done to the flooring around it but I could find no information about this while on my visit. I had to look at their website to find it out). What little joy I did get out of this place came from looking at the tombs of Queens Elizabeth and Mary something I've always wanted to do but even this was ruined by the high dirty metal railings surrounding it and it was really obscured. Also you don't get a long to look at anything in this building as there's too many other people around and as everyone's walking round the set out route from the guide book (and don't try and deviate from the given route as you'll get dirty looks from the staff!) you kind of get shoved along anyway.Poets corner was a little better but even that didn't exactly overjoy me as by the time I reached it I was so disheartened by the rest of the building. I also got the feeling it was overly crammed, haphazardly designed and generally disorganised. What a shame.We got in using our London Pass so thankfully didn't have to pay the extortionate £16 per adult entry fee. I won't be visiting again until major changes have taken place. The people running this place should be deeply ashamed and all the staff should all be retrained. Appalling.

Needed more time. We had a guided tour through Westminster Abbey while staying in London. Give yourself at least two hours to do it properly. It's fascinating to be able to see the abbey on television and then walk in the same steps as so many historical figures. The size and grandeur need to be experienced to be appreciated. Some of the customs behind the events held in the abbey were surprising and fascinating.

Our Favourite Place In London. There is so much history and architecture in Westminster Abbey that one could spend many hours here. Just seeing the location of the coronations, funerals and weddings that we have watched on TV was wonderful. This is the second time we have visited Westminster Abbey and would go back every time we visit London in future.
very impressive. we thought this was very breath takingfree audioguide with entry -go at your own pace.worth a look!

Absolutely loved visiting here. Of all places that I was due to visit in London, this was by far the best which was a huge surprise to me. I absolutely loved the walking tour and the indepth information that was given on the walk around. I was blown away by the whole think. Loved it... and would highly recommend it.
Another Must!. The Westminster Abbey is central to the life of the British nation which makes it essential to every visit to London.

Beautiful building but a bit creepy.. I desperately wanted to go to Westminster Abbey because I know it is the final resting place to some of the key people from the Tudor time in history. My husband and I finally got the chance to see the Abbey last week. I must say wow! The Abbey really is a beautiful building, the staff are extremely helpful and knowledgable. I got to see all the resting places I wanted but I must admit after awhile it did feel a bit creepy. There are just so many resting sites in the Abbey and I didn't really consider that before going. This being one of several holy places we had been to during our holiday it did get a bit weird that people were buried in them. I'm used to graveyards being outside and (I'm not trying to be disrespectful mentioning this) I found it hard to see how people could be respectful when most of the time you had to walk over the sites. But if you can get past that this building is a must see for it beauty and history.

Beautiful. The Abbey is a fantastic site in London. The history which surrounds the Abbey is so rich. We went with a group of 6 on a weekend late in the afternoon. We did not encounter any lines or long waiting times.

Definitely a must see in London.... I visited London recently on business and took a few extra days to do some exploring around London. At the top of my list of course was the Tower of London. Overall, London is VERY easy to get around via both the bus and metro. Although you will see much more of London if you take the bus, traffic can also be very congested, so for me my preference was to take the Metro. Public transportation in and around London is safe, efficient, easy and cheap.Having said all that. Westminster Abbey is right in the heart of London - across from Big Ben and Parliament and from what I recall in walking distance to the Churchill War Rooms, Downing Street, etc. Of all the sites I visited in London, I think this was perhaps my favorite. Westminster Abbey is just an architectural marvel - both from the outside and the inside. Its rather large, with so many different rooms to explore. Personally speaking, I love history - especially British history - and it was just such a cool experience to stand a few feet away from the tomb of Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary. There's quite a bit to see and well worth giving yourself every bit of 2 hours to explore. I really can't stress enough how much I enjoyed Westminster AbbeyDepending on the amount of time you have in London, it might not be a bad idea to get the London Pass. If you are staying 3-5 days, the pass becomes much more economical and essentially grants you 'free' pass to almost all attractions in London. Place your order for the London pass before you go and you will be able to either pick it up right there in central London or possibly have it mailed to you. It saved me quite a bit of money on the trip. You can find it quite easily with a google search. Also, buy a day or week pass to the metro - it covers both buses and the underground, and is fairly inexpensive. I was able to take the metro from the airport to the hotel. Cost me about 8 euro (for a day pass). The business associate I met up with at the hotel got a taxi from the airport. He spent 65 euro and it took him roughly the same amount of time to get to the hotel as it took me. Just some food for thought. They have an excellent (and safe) public transportation system.

One of the must see. This attraction is one of the must see when you are in London. Other nearby attractions are Houses of Parliament, Big Ben, London Eye, River Thames cruise and etc. Inside the Abbey is full of tombs and memorial of the Kings and Queens of England, great poets and etc. There's an audio guide provided at the entrance of the Abbey and you get to know more about the history through this audio guide. There's also tour given by the personnel working in the Abbey, you just need to look out for the schedule in front of the entrance. No photo taking is allowed inside the Abbey though.

way too expensive. It may be interesting if you're interested in these kind of stuff. I loved the building itself, staff is friendly etc. But i left after half an hours because It was not my kind of thing.
Interesting. The audio guide was a bit confusing but the tour was generally good. I'd like to go back at a quieter time to have a really good look agai. It was reasonably priced too
Church or playground?. Very overcrowded, overpriced and too few facilities. Nobody seemed to care that this is a place of worship and pilgrimage as well as a tourist attraction.

Hefty price tag, but a very cool historical site. The biggest knocks on this place are that it is quite expensive at 16 pounds to enter. In addition after charging you that much money they then tell you that you can't take photos inside. I would highly reccamend getting a London pass to help combat how expensive London and its sites can be, you get a 3 day pass that covers free admission into sites like tower of London, Westminster abbey, Churchill war rooms, st Paul's (each of these cost 15-17 pounds each). At westminster You get a free audio guide which allows you to explore the space at your own pace. It is very impressive and several kings as well and famous Englishman such as Darwin are buried. Stopping at this church is a must on your visit to London, just get a London pass to try and ease the blow to your wallet and take pictures at your own risk.
Hands down, best abbey I've ever seen!. So much historyin one place. Amazing architecture and scenery and the guides are extremely knowledgable. A great place to visit

Intricate building. This is an old, gothic, intricate building where Kate and William got married. It is beautiful inside. I attended an Evansong service at 5pm on a Wednesday (about 30-45 minutes) and did not have to pay entrance. Once inside, there are guides and priests ushering you to your seat for service, so there is no opportunity to look around. I’m sure they are aware many attend service just so they don’t have to pay to see the inside. Hearing the choir with the acoustics of the church was amazing. There are no photos allowed. Maybe it is different for paying visitors that are not there for service, I’m not sure. After service, they are quick to usher you out. I would go back to see St. Paul’s Cathedral before I would see Abbey again, personal opinion.

Beautiful!. The cathedral is massive! Allow plenty of time to see everything. We were a little short on time so we skipped parts of the audio tour but were still able to appreciate the beauty and history of the cathedral.

Rich historical experience. The audio guide really enhanced our experience of Westminster Abbey. It was fantastic to hear the stories behind all the tombs and memorials scattered throughout the Abbey. If you visit around midday you also have the option of sitting in on the 12.30 service.

Worthwhile seeing. We spent all morning at Westminster Abby. I found it awe inspiring. We got there early and found the line wasn't too long. As one writer mentioned check which line you should be on, there are two, one for cash and one for credit payment. The signs are near the door so you have to walk up first to see which line then walk back to join the queue. We had the audio guide and a map and I found this a good way to understand what you were looking at. It would also have been good to take the guided tour, although I dont think I fully was aware of this option at the time, and realised it later on. If I went again I would do the guided tour. I found it a fabulous place full of history, with its own special feeling. It wasn't too crowded when we were there, I mean it wasn't unbearably crowded. Dont miss going around the corner after you've finished viewing the Abbey to see the Houses of Parliament, Big Ben and Westminster Bridge.

Don't miss the free mass on sundays 3pm. Great historical church, but here's what I enjoyed more - attending the Evensong service on Sundays. Normally you pay a hefty fee to get in, but if you attend this mass, you can have a (partial) tour of the church for free, plus you get to hear the most hauntingly beautiful Gregorian chants. I forgot if it was 3pm or 6pm, please check on the website.Trust me it an hour well spent. I am not a Christian, I loved it, the mass can be enjoyed by people of all faith.Remember, you have to say you are there to attend the mass, otherwise you will not be allowed to enter!

Overwhelming. It is difficult to describe Westminster Abbey. The number of significant historical figures immortalized in this church is simply mind blowing. Everywhere you turn is yet another tomb or shrine of some extraordinary political, scientific, cultural or artistic legend. There are historical gems and revelations hidden and tucked away in every nook and cranny. The architecture and art is beautiful and inspiring but you don't get that sense of sacred space that other houses of worship evoke - however you do get a strong sense of walking on historical hallowed ground. Of course it is extremely crowded and you feel you are being hoarded through a tourist trap but that is to be expected. It is easy to overlook this and get lost in the ambiance.
On my top 10 list of things to visit while in London. Don't miss it. Many famous people have memorials or were buried there not to mention the coronations & weddings that took place there.
