What an incredible piece of history!. I couldn't get over just how many important historical people are buried inside the Abbey. Their "tombs" are magnificent, and carry such interesting stories. The Abbey itself is beautiful in every way. Be sure to get the hand held audio guide, so you can hear all of the stories behind each monument.

is it a church or a museum ?. I havent visited the Abbey in years,The building is still as beautiful.The history is still as remarkable,but I felt herded in and pushed around with no chance to stand and contemplate.I was glad my mother and her wheelchair missed this trip as it felt like a Saturday market day and wheelchair uses I saw stood no chance of viewing anythins effectiveley.

for history buffs. Well organized - although the audeo recording was limited, it did point out the highlights. I would recommend not limiying oneself to the tape but doing some extra exploring - oh, what sirprises await!

Not to be missed. This is a most see in London. A very nice area, full of history, architecture and modernity. I visited it twice: the first time on a rainy day, but I felt that I didnot get the appropriate chance to explore the area and to take photos. The second visit was worth it. At night it is also very special.
The cloisters. Didnt get time to go in Westminster abbey as it was closed for something but wandered around the cloisters, which were like a little scene from Harry Potter and were just beautiful.

Do the verger-guided tour. It's worth going just because so much of it is familiar from the royal wedding and other historic events. It's amazing how much history is packed in there, including all those buried there. I went on a verger-guided tour, and I highly recommend it. It's a few extra pounds, but very reasonable because you get to go in spots you can only see while accompanied by a verger. The place is definitely crowded, and do keep in mind it's a place of worship. They do stop for prayer for a moment every hour, and it's respectful to stand quietly during that moment. A helpful hint - when you approach the building, come up in front of the main entrance and make note which line you need to be in - cash or credit card (there is a sign right in front of the door). The cash seems to move faster.

Westminster cathedral!. Westminster Cathedral is a nice cathedral with lovely things in it.I only saw a part of it in the entrance but we decided not to go in because the prices were too dear, but besides that, the atmosphere was great!The only sad bit about it was that the back of the Cathedral was completely BLACK!

Awesome place. This is an awesome place, absolutely jam packed with loads of famous people, all dead of course! And the architecture and stained glass windows are wonderful. Bit pricey at £16.50 and we werre disappointed that we didn't have time to go and look in the museum nearby - would be better if opening hours a little longer, this was a very busy attraction. I would recommend the audio set -easy to use and very informative with added information -and it doesn't use horrible ear-phones you just rest it next to your ear.

An Iconic Must. The history and majesty of Westminster Abbey are brought to life by the atmosphere and audio guide which is provided. To step in the footsteps of so many is an amazing part of your journey through the abbey. We were also luck to see the photographic Jubilee tribute of Queen Elizabeth which was beautiful. Westminster Abbey is not 'just another church'.

Wonderful experience - go early. Beat the line ups and try to arrive before 10AM - we went in at 10 and when we left at 11:30 the lineup snaked around the building with multiple tour groups. 1-1.5hrs is plenty of time to walk the abbey and take in the architecture and history. The audio supplement is invaluable (despite the cheesy super-british accent). Once through the abbey, the Churchill war rooms, Big Ben, and the London Eye are all nearby and a short walk. It's easy to do them all in one afternoon (buy tickets in advance to avoid some of the lines), and finish with the London Eye - the kpmg transit boat dock is next to the Eye and a trip down the Thames costs about 6EU to Greenwich where you can hop on the blue line DLR that goes through Canary Wharf and brings you back into central London (Bank tube station)

Beautiful building but too busy - chapter house and pyx were amazing. We had to queue to get in so should've realised how busy inside would be! The queue did move fairly fast though. Entrance is quite steep - £32 for two adults (children under 11 are free).... First impressions inside the abbey is beautiful. You arent allowed ro take pictures though. We were given free audio guides which were ok, and the children were given quizzes to complete. To be honest I think that they ought to manage the numbers allowed in at one time as in some places it was ridiculous, we could barely move and definitely couldn't see! Other areas were less packed but very noisy! The children couldn't do a lot of the quiz as they couldn't get near the areas to find the relevant information. Once the abbey itself had been seen we went into chapter house and the pyx chambers.... For some reason these were much quieter and well worth visiting. We all found the atmosphere there to be very peaceful and you can tell the area is steeped in history. I felt that a lot of the areas should have had some signage as at times it was too noisy to hear the audio guides. I imagine this would be a very interesting and insightful visit if it's done at a less busy time.... The building is impressive.... Just the huge numbers spoilt it a bit for us.

Historically fascinating but expensive.. Appalling mess - broken lights stuffed into corners, old furniture (?) left in walkways along with chairs piled higgledy piggledy, even a small organ left half covered in a chapel. It's difficult to see some interesting things because there are so many (inconsiderate) tourists. £16 per adult seemed expensive even before we got inside, and it was a relatively quiet day/time!
Sang evensong here for 3 days. Stunning abbey with so much history. With so many visitors during the day it felt rather like a cattle market until they left and it became a church once more.

spectacular. wodnderful sight to see ties i nwell with the parliament and big ben tour. would go early to avoid queus. you can have quite a good experience without the audio tour as you can take in the sights yourself.

Take the tour. We took a tour which was an extra charge but extremely informative. You are also able to visit areas that are normally not open to the public. You can purchase tickets inside or I think even ahead of time. The tours are given by clerical staff and it was not part of an outside tour company.

Definitely take the verger tour. Westminster Abbey is a real delight on its own. The architecture, history, and art are overwhelming. We would highly recommend taking the verger tour. It's a little more expensive, but you learn a ton and can go into areas you can't normally go into without a guide, like Edward the Confessor's tomb. I only wish you could take pictures inside! If you can, try to experience the cathedral as it was meant to be experienced, by attending an organ concert or Evensong service.

So much history here.............. This is worth the time and money if you are visiting London. So much history here. The audio guides do a wonderful job in explaining the history. Also, it makes the Royal wedding a little more real to see the place where William and Kate were married plus so many other royal speical occassions that have taken place here.

The highlight of our London trip. The Abbey is incredible. We took the audio tour, narrated by Jeremy irons, and felt the rich history of the Abbey. So much royalty buried there; our 3 kids, including 2 teens, say that the Abbey was the greatest part of their time in London. We returned to the Abbey to attend the Sunday morning service and it was beautiful as well.

Go early to avoid crowds/queus.. If you want to avoid the crowds and longer queus, plan to be there at 9 am. for a 9:30 am. opening. Only a few people ahead of us, and we got to visit the nearly emply inside and take in the atmosphere. We bought a 4 day London Pass which gave us "free" admission to this site and many more. But it does not give you Q-jump privileges here, so my recommendation to start your day here.

Favorite building in all of England. This was the second time that I visited London and I'm so very glad I got to go back to Westminster Abbey, which is spectacular. I watched the wedding of William and Kate, which took place there, and it was a special joy to see it again. We went on a rainy day and had no problem walking right in, with no lines. The place was packed, though, and it was a challenge the see everything, given the fact that people were crowding around the best sites inside. For a breather, we enjoyed getting a cup of coffee and sitting along the inner courtyard.

Stunning!. I had little expectation before walking into the Abbey. I was gobsmacked to see one of the most beautiful pieces of architecture I have ever experienced in my entire life. The craftsmanship was extraordinary. The details in this cathedral was saturated with much history, details and hertitage. Not only with past royals, but poets and scientists as well. Was such an enjoyable experience listening in on the audio tour. As always, you are able to go at your own pace. It was such a peaceful place to be in. It was definately the highlight of my London visit.

wants to see where the greats are buried?. westminster abbey, just across the way from parliament and big ben, holds the graves of the greats of English Culture, from Dickens to Kipling to everyone else you can imagine...a palce to walk among the spirits of the greats...

The BEST part of our London tour. After visiting the Tower of London, Oxford, Bath etc. on our summer vacation, our visit to the Westminster Abbey was truly the MOST memorable. The sheer history of the place is overwhelming. to walk over the tombs of Isaac Newton, Darwin and other luminary figures was just huge. I strongly recomemmend the guided tour that the Church offers (instead of the audio guides). You get to go to the tomb of Edward the confessor himself, something that is not allowed to other tourists. The church tour guide who guided us, was very humorous and witty. Even my kids (13 and 11) enjoyed it.

Westminster Abbey is awesome place to visit inside and out. Inside the give you tape recorders so you can listen at each station as to what is there. I was amazed at how many royalty, writers, etc were buried there. To see tombs of numerous Queens, KIngs, Sir Isaac Newton, etc was so inspiring. Also saw where Princess Dianna had laid prior to her burial and also where Princess Kate and Prince William got married. There was no admission fee which was nice for a change.

You haven't seen London if you miss Westminster Abbey!. A beauty off a building and an absolute highlight on a visit to London. It may take a while before you get access but its worth waiting. The explanation you get on an earphone is very good and clear.

Go to church!. Much like St. Paul's Cathedral, I found the tour at Westminster to be enjoyable and informative - but quite expensive. For my second visit, I instead went to the evening musical worship service, Evensong, and found that to be much more to many liking. I was still able to take pictures outside the abbey and experience the thrill of walking where the Royals had walked, but actually attending a service seemed much more authentic and WAY more appropriate than gawking like a tourist at the real parishioners. A great way to spend a rainy London afternoon!

Rip off for British citizens. We were in London for a couple of days and went past the Abbey, so thought we'd pop in and have a look. We were amazed to find as British tax payers that we'd have to pay to get in to see a part of our heritage. £32 for 2 adults and a child. We were humming and haring about it and asked someone from the Abbey if we went to the a service whether we'd see just as much. He told us there was so much more to see and how the Church needed our money. The lady who took our money was very abrupt and rude so that wasn't a good start. Once inside you arn't allowed to take any photos. It was very difficult to get to different bits of it as it's cordoned off in places and is very difficult to move to different areas. Moreover it turned out that as we'd been admitted at 4.30 p.m. bits were being closed off as they have a service at 6.00 p.m.! We asked one 'worker' a couple of questions but apart from him there wasn't anyone around to ask and it felt very much like they wanted our money but didn't really want us in there. I note in retrospect that if we'd gone in the evening it would have been alot cheaper - but that wasn't mentioned when we enquired outside. It feels unpleasant to be fleeced like this in your own country when we pay tax not only as employees but also as an employer.

Magnificent.. Westminister Abbey is a massive complex of stately architecture on the outside. Inside, it's a fascinating glimpse into several centuries of English history. Take one of the free, pre-recorded, self-guided tours, and listen to Jeremy Irons describe the chapels, memorials, and markers scattered throughout inside. Expect to spend a couple of hours here, as you won't want to hurry through this beautiful place.

I cannot believe the history of this place. Just so much History.
The Abbey was built of Reigate tone [from where I live]
Suprised it is still standing !
So full of history going back centuries. What the New World tourists must make of this place I can only imagine.
History alive. A living testament to the strength and power of the Church in England and to what makes us English. Well worth the queue. Stay for the Communion Service.

The BEST attraction we saw during a week's visit to London. I just can't explain how awesome the Abbey is, and how glad I am that we fit it into our itinerary. True, I am a history buff and enjoy this type of attraction when I visit distant places. Notwithstanding my penchant for history though, the abbey is a marvel of religious art, architecture, solemn beauty, and so much more. My young son (7) did the audio tour along with the kids' scavenger hunt and really enjoyed it. It got him moving through the abbey to actually find specific things, not just wander around like we old people enjoy doing. :) Of course I'm disappointed that photography is not permitted, but that's a small price to pay for having the opportunity to visit one of the world's greatest testimonies to important figures of our collective, human past. Poet's Corner was my favorite section, but simply noticing the scores of stone tomb faces you walk on throughout the entire grounds is incredible in itself. You will really miss out on something special if you visit London and don't stop here.

Magnificent Gothic Building. Westminster Abbey was consecrated on 28 December 1065 eight days before Edward the Confessor died. William the Conqueror had himself crowned here on Christmas Day 1066 followed by nearly every British King and Queen since. St. Edward the Confessor's Chapel is the burial place of Kings, while the sanctuary is the setting for coronations. A fantastic place to visit, a bit expensive but worth the money.

Beautiful. I've visited the Abbey 3 times - once for myself, the other times to take someone else to see it! I think it's a beautiful church and so much to see. I'm a history buff so I found the final resting place of many of England's royal family to be naturally interesting. The architecture is absolutely spectacular and don't forget to see King Edward's Chair on which every King (and Queen) of England has been crowned since the 1300's (and which contained the Stone of Scone). It's small, wooden and has been carved up/graffitied by what looks to be an assortment of medieval society (which I think adds to it's charm - if you were expecting something more regal, though, try not to be too disappointed). The one major issue I take with the Abbey is the cost of admission. In every church in Europe, it's free to enter. Not in England, however. To visit the Abbey (and St Paul's Cathedral) will put a serious dent in your tourist purse. I understand the Abbey would require money to run and therefore funding is necessary, I'm just not sure ripping off tourists to the tune of £16 each is the nicest way to do it. But, it IS worth seeing - even with the steep entry fee.

Great Abbey. Original bus company stops right outside the abbey and it is a true delight and easily recognisible. Worth a tour and the stop at the very good souvenier shop outside. We really enjoyed spending an hour here.You will need to stand back to get a picture to capture all the abbey from the front (or very wide angled lens camera)

Incredible, but so touristy!. It's overrun with people. The staff is on hand to keep everyone moving forward and sticking to the rules (mad at one point we went back to see something again). That said, the tomb of Elizabeth I and the Bath Chapel, coronation chair -- etc. etc. are so beautiful and historic it would be hard to miss this one, but it was the most unfriendly of all of the London attractions we visited.

A Must.... Definitely a must in London. Full with history at every corner.Also you can track footprints of some very known people's in here as well so pay good attention and do not miss them.It is from one of the top things to do in London, probably in top 3.Be careful with visit times and days and try going early in the morning to avoid business.

History everywhere you look. And tons and tons of tourists, too. Still, it'd be a shame to miss this, unless you just aren't a fan of seeing the burial place of kings, historians, scientists, artists, etc. Keep in mind, all the carved stones are actual tombs, though some are (Charles Darwin, for example). The building, itself, is pretty impressive, and also familiar to watchers of Royal weddings. There are audio guides available, and that helps to get a lot more out of the experience.
A must visit if in London. Trully spectacular, the architecture of the building is simply magnificant and that coupled with its history makes it a fantastic place to visit

History,History,History.. Superb place of worship not to mention the hundreds of years of history,famous people you'd read about at school,seen on t.v. etc.Its really mind blowing the amount of famous folk that you remember once your memory is jogged by seeing all inside.Oh and don't forget parts are over a 1000 years old,also it does (apparently)have the oldest door in the UK.Queing at very busy times so don't expect to walk right in.

Worth the price of admission. Yes, they do charge admission to a church -- but the clergyman we talked to explained that the Abbey gets no funding from the Church of England (since they view it as a historical building) and no funding from the British government (since they view it as a church). That's also the reason for the "no photos" rule -- they want you to buy postcards. However, we found no one stopping us from taking a few shots esp of things for which there are no postcards. Well worth the visit, with all of British history jumbled before you. Even our teenagers, who were skeptical and initially wanted to pop their heads in and then leave for someplace with wifi, were fascinated. We spent about an hour and a half there, far longer than we expected. Highlights for us were Elizabeth I's grave, where we noticed that she was proclaimed (in Latin) the queen of England, France, and Spain; the sheer wealth of talent in Poet's Corner (plus noticing that Christopher Marlowe's death date, on the stained glass window, has a question mark after it); the moving inscription on David Livingstone's grave; and the tomb of the unknown soldier. Unlike so many outer churches, there are plenty of clergy and volunteers around to explain what you're seeing and tell stories, and we found them well worth chatting with. Definitely a must-see.

A historical must!. I did not like the crowds but that is a given when you travel in summer. The self guided tour is amazingly well done and it is a pleasure to listen to the well modulated voice of the narrator. Don't hurry, take your time and listen to the entire narration at each point of interest; it is all well worth it.

Top sight in London!!. Where else can you see the tombs of Elizabeth the Great, Bloody Mary, Mary Queen of Scots, Henry V, Richard II, Chaucer, Darwin, Newton and many more. This is where the English Kings and Queens are crowned and it is a fabulous sight to see!

Great sight--at a steep price. While researching Westminster Abbey, I was surprised to find out that you have to pay to tour the church. Since virtually all other famous churches in Europe (like Notre Dame or the Vatican) are free, this initially put me off. But since I was really interested, I paid and was glad I did. We visited on a Tuesday morning in late June and didn't experience long lines or large crowds. Employees were polite to me. I loved the audio guide, it was truly excellent. It allowed me to tour the cathedral at my own pace and sit down at times while listening to the explanations. The cathedral was well worth the visit, I especially enjoyed the ceiling in the lady's chapel and the various tombs, both of famous and ordinary people. Some of the famous people buried here are many of the kings and queens of England (like Elizabeth I and her half-sister Mary and Mary, Queen of Scots) and composers, actors and poets. It was fun to see where the royal wedding took place and Elizabeth II was crowned--the chair used for crowning is also on display. My husband and teenage son chose not to take the tour. They came back later in the day (around 5pm I believe) and went to the evensong services. They were able to go into the church for free at that time and see the nave. However, visitors participating in the evensong services are not allowed to wander around the church during or after the service but are contained in one area.

Wish you could take pictures. For me, this was probably once in a lifetime visit and although I remember it well and have some postcards I would've loved to have my own pictures. I find it crazy to still have rules like those. Anyway, the abbey was beautiful and so full of history. The audio guide was invaluable and I liked that you could choose what you wanted to hear about. Poets corner was a great little section on the guide.

Be Aware. Westminister is not always open on the days you would expect. If you want to tour the inside, make certain they do not have a private affair that day.If you miss the tour due to a public closure, as I did...it is still well worth the trip. It is a beautiful piece of architecture and history...and there is so much to see in this area, it is not as if you'd be going out of your way!
Must see. Didn't pay to enter but even the outside is a must see. Stunning.Lovely gardens outside to take advantage of the occasional British sunshine!Very close to Westminster tube station.Must see!

Amazing!. Last year the quene was too long with the approaching royal wedding, so this year it was a must. I was overwhelmed! The self-paced audio tour guide was brilliant. The historical significance is one not to be missed- a must see for all who visit London.

Full of history. This church is stuffed full of English history and is atmospheric. Consider going for a service on a Sunday morning as not only will it be free to get in but you will experience the lovely music and choir.

Great visit & Vergers Tour. We visited Westminster Abbey and did the Vergers tour while in London last month, can't tell you how much we we appreciated the whole experience - 1000 years of history literally under your feet, not to mention the soaring Gothic architecture, the highlight for me was the Poet's Corner. Our Verger clearly loved his job and told us many tales about the abbey, the tour was for about 2 hours, later on we walked around some more by ourselves. An absolute must-see.

British Gem. Took me 17 years to actually go inside this beautiful establishment. £16 entry fee. No cameras inside, excellent audio guide. Listen to it, it's great. Was amazing to actually be inside the church I have seen on tv so many times. Glorious, go.

History beneath your feet. Lots to see; succinct audio commentary and friendly helpful 'staff'. Amazing architecture and interesting to compare the structure with what we normally see on TV. The tombs, memorials and plaques are here for so many royals and notables it's an absorbing trip into history as well as within living memory.

You can spend hours here. You can spend hours in this cathedral. There is so much to see. In this visit an audio guide is included that gives you lots of interesting information. Unfortunately not so much said is about some graves. Often you have to find that out yourself. And if you are not aware, you'll miss it. Unfortunately you are not allowed to take pictures, but some people do. It's not nice that you follow the rules and others don't and the people working in the cathedral let it go.

Great visit!. I am not religious but a visit to Westminster Abbey was well worth it for the history and fantastic architecture in and outside of the building. this is included in the London Pass and is good value.

Fabulous and fun for our kids. This was my third visit, but my family's first visit. Kids are 11 and 9. Children can fill out a scavenger hunt activity (write down answers to questions throughout the abbey) and then hand it into the giftshop at the end. The reward is a large chocolate coin. Our kids really enjoyed this. They said it's for under 10s but quite honestly I can see up to 14 year olds enjoying it. The audio guides are free, and each member of your group can get one. You hand them in when you exit. I think they could be expanded to include all on the sights numbered in the Abbey. What was included in the audio tour was excellent and just enough to not be overwhelming. Must sees include Elizabeth I's grave as well as Newton's, Darwin's, burial sites as well as those buried in Poet's corner. There are 5 minute periods of silence throughout the day that visitors are requested to observe for prayer or reflection. Caps and hats must be removed in the Abbey. It's amazing when you realize that the Abbey was first built in 960. It was my son's number one place to visit and a definite highlight for all of us. My husband is not a history buff but he really enjoyed our visit. We did not do the Verger tour, but we were very happy with audio guides. I read in a previous review about someone mentioning about not being able to revisit places and everyone travelling the same direction. Yes there is only one exit, but you can revisit sights (we did) and you do not have to see the numbered sights in any particular order. You can stay as long as you want (until closing).Sandwich shop available in the Cloisters and you can take photos there but no other places other than outside.
Get the tour. The tour was great. You get so much history and interesting stories. It is worth the extra money. Be prepared for a long line to get in!

Westminster Abbey Evensong. I would suggest going to this site during the week around 2pm. Get an audio guide(free with entrance) and tour this fabulous place. When finished circle around to the side of the church and wait in line to go and listen to Evensong. Which the Westminster Childrens Choir performs(other childrens choirs perform during certain months in summer). It is beautiful. The lines start to form at 4:15 and Evensong starts at 5pm. Truly a memorable experience.

Brace yourself. It truly is a remarkable church. Give yourself plenty of time to go into each corridor and room. Unfortunately, they did not allow us to use our London Pass during a special evening opening for tourists and neither were audio phones provided so many of the tombs we saw had inscriptions in Latin and so we didn't know who half of these people buried there were. We did ask one tour guide who was very helpful and friendly and a couple others who were a little pompous. There is so much to take in this place, no pictures allowed though, bummer. The fee is atrocious. I found it a shame that the church took advantage of that because like I said, we weren't allowed to use our London Pass which includes the Abbey visit. That was the only complaint and the no audio phone with tour included. I would have then left the Abbey knowing more about it's history however, you can buy a book as I did at the gift shop for an extensive background of the place.

Very beautiful. The church from the outside is very gorgeous as well as the inside. The glass window of different colors are very pretty. Convient location right next to big ben and the house of parliaments. Definetly worth a visit.

One of my top all time spots. Leave a good chunk of time for this. The history of this place is absolutely insane. You should get a guide book or audio tour because if you don't, you are guaranteed to miss the enormity of this place. There are secrets (and people) buried in almost every square foot

Take the tour to learn it all. If you want to know the complete history and have the most thorough tour of the Abbey, pay the price and take the electronic PDA. You will learn things you never will learn otherwise--and you get to go at your own pace, you can avoid crowding around trying to see over and between other tourists, and you can skip around if you want. Take as much or as little time as you like; learn as much or as little as you like. You can just sit and enjoy the atmosphere if you like. I was here many years ago and was sad that the entrance price seems to me to be quite high (it was free back in the day) and that you could no longer purchase a photography pass. However, for a tourist destination, the value is actually very good.

Amazing!. It's Westminster Cathedral so it is one place that most people should visit. It is a stricking difference from St Pauls. The audio guide covers things well while keeping you moving. Come early to be the first in line (there is Starbucks just to the North for a coffee while you wait) and the experience is much improved. Having the thin crowd of the first to enter makes the vist far more enjoyable.

Very nice architecture!. The history in this place is incredible. Westminster Abbey sits right in the heart of London and is very easy to find. Please note that it is more like a museum than a quiet church that you walk through. There are audio guides to walk you through the history of the place. There is a price to get in, which is reasonable I guess. Overall, a must see in London!

Beautiful Church. This was the second church we would see on our 23 day tour around Europe and it was one of the most stunning. Unfortunately we didn't see it until later in the afternoon after a 10 hour flights and 8 hours of wandering London so we were too tired to go in but it was definitely a sight to see, even from the exterior.

Westminster Abbey. Built in 960 AD, Westminster Abbey has been the site of all coronations since 1066 up until Queen Elizabeth II in 1953. It is the final resting place of Monarchs (17) including the tombs of Elizabeth I and Mary Queen of Scots, great minds (Newton, Darwin), poets (Burns, Lord Byron, Blake, Carroll, Dickens, Chaucer and Oliver). Awe inspiring is the ceiling of Henry VII Lady Chapel. This is an active church and services on Sunday's are open to the public. If you do not want to pay a tour fee and still would like to see the inside of the abbey consider a Sunday free service. A paid tour will will cost about 16 Pounds. There is a cash line which is shorter and a credit entrance line. A free audo-guide (several languages) comes with the tour which is narrated by Jeremy Irons. They have a nice kids self tour with parent accompaniment. Kids get a tour guide paper at the entrance. They fill it out as you listen to the audio tour. Once filled out the kids get a large chocolate gold coin. For a few Pounds extra take the verger guided tour which is about 2 hours, more detailed information and they take you to places in the abbey the other tours will not let you go. No photos are allowed in the abbey. There is a gift shop, coffee shop and snack shop. Gardens are open Tuesday-Thursday and the cloisters are free to explore.

Magical. Westminster Abbey was incredible. All the tour guides and staff were very friendly and the electronic guides provided so much information I didn't know what to do with it all! All the details of the Abbey were breathtaking. There were so many details. So much too see- I would recommend taking a full afternoon if you want to see it all. The gift shop downstairs was wonderful and extensive. I bought a lovely peace dove necklace. Highly recommended!

A LOT of history per square foot. It is almost overwhelming when you enter. There are statues and plaques covering almost every inch of space. It is a beautiful building, with so much history. Royalty, Isaac Newton, and Charles Darwin all RIP here. The audio tour, included with admission, is very helpful.

Full of History!. 1st went to Westminster as a kid and was awestruck then, was curious to see whether it would have the same effect all these years on.As you walk in you are immediately greeted with the grandeur of the Abbey, this place is huge! After paying the entry you can pick up the free audio guide which is definitely worthwhile listening to. It guides you round all of the accessible areas within Westminster giving you an overview as well as explaining which tomb is which and notable figures buried/commemorated within the building.Definitely worth the visit, busy or not!

Fantastic!. Lady Diana died in 1997, which was also the first time I visited London. I wanted to see the Abbey for myself, after seeing the funeral. When we came into the abbey, we were met by long queues, and one of the priests there took us "backstage" along with a group of American visitors. He showed us the rooms where the staff hold their meetings and have formal dinners. Walking around in the abbey he poined out the many famous people resting there, and we had w very nice conversation. It turned out he had been one of the people in charge of the funeral service, we had seen him on tv. It was not part of his job to show people around, so we were lucky that day! I have been in the Abbey on a later visit, and it was still a very fascinating place to walk around in.

Hear stories of kings and queens. This is a breathtaking Abbey with stories of the great kings and queens of Britian over the past 1000 years. Nothing compares to this. Be sure to use the audio guides. Crowds are heavy but not bad.

Number 32?. Westminster Abbey is not the 32nd best thing to see in London. This is deffinately a top 10 attraction that will knock your socks off with it's age and amazing history. Then to find out that many famous King's, Queen's and famous people are buried right under your feet...well it is amazing. Take the time to visit. You will not be disappointed!
love the history. Loved to see the tombs of those we only read about. Fascinating that King James built a bigger tomb for his mother, Mary Queen of Scots, than Elizabeth's. Family drama everywhere.

London's One Must-See. London is a city of treasures, but if you have to choose just one, choose Westminster Abbey. (If you get two wishes, add the Tower of London.)It's a bit intimidating from the outside given the long lines and expensive enterance fee (I think it's 16GBP), but do it. As other reviewers have said, it's much more of a tour through the entire history of England than just a church. You'll be amazed how many of the graves you recognize, even if you slept through high school social science class. Allow plenty of time for this breathtaking experience.Currently there's a great photo exhibit of The Queen and Her Abbey near the end of the tour. Check it out to see the Royal Family in all the places you just stood!We recently returned to Westminster for Sunday Matins (10am Sunday). The choir gave me chills for a solid hour, and the serman was one of the best I've heard in a while. Enterance for worship is free of charge but you don't get to see nearly as much of the Abbey as if you visit on any other day and pay the enterance fee. Sundays are reserved for worship and not open for tourists, so check the website for times if you're interest in services.Nearest tube stop: Westminster. Walking distance to Big Ben, Parliament, London Eye, London Aquarium, Trafalgar Square

Enthralling place, and quiet on Wednesday late opening. We had heard of queues and congestion at the Abbey but we visited on a Wednesday afternoon - the only day it is open late. It was just before the Olympics but there we no crowds, we could move at our own pace. Admission prices are high but it does include a free audio guide which is very informative. The whole place is enthralling with so much of England's history laid out before you. Well worth a second visit. As to the tip by a previous reviewer to bring cash nor credit cards we were held up by cash payers because the tills had run out of change. in contrast credit cards wend through very quickly, just put the card in the machine, enter your pin and it is done.

BEautiful, HisToriCal Edifice. YOu must enter the Abbey when in London! Pictures outside it, simple wont do. Its history spans more than a thousand years with no less than 3000 monarchs, poets, heroes, important historical figures buried in its foundation (ISaac Newton, William Wilberforce, Geoffrey Chaucer). It is also a favorite site for coronations and Royal Weddings. YOu may choose to do an audio tour or simply admire the intricate design of every nook of this enormous Gothic structure. Prepare to spend at least an hour in this amazing cathedral.

Excellent. Westminster Abbey is a must see location. The audio guides are excellent and well informative. If you get a chance, make sure to go to the prayers of Edward the Confessor in the chapel and you will get to see some of the abbey unseen by others.

Very moving experience. Very good audio tour included with admission. Wonderful to see the graves in poet's corner. Attended Evensong service and really loved the music! Nice that they have a little cafe mid-way to keep you going.

History of England in one building. While this is an abbey, it is more of a museum. Quite a different feel than St Paul's but also worth seeing. We bypassed this last year in August because the lines were too long, but since we were in London during early July and rain, the crowds were thin. Tip* bring cash to bypass the credit card window...it is a lot faster. The audio guides are included in the price and are offered in multiple languages. It was hectic and confusing as there are so many people pressing against you. If possible, get a seat and get your bearings in order to plan the order of viewing. No photography was allowed. The number of crypts and artifacts is overwhelming. To do it justice, don't go with any cranky children or teenagers. Be prepared to enjoy this magnificent historical venue at a leisurely pace. Each corner and nave is crammed with history. Having watched the recent Royal wedding, it was difficult to envision it with so many people but I did gain a better appreciation for Westminster after seeing it up close and personal. Also, go as early as possible to avoid the crowds!

A must see. But in need of modernizing the exhibit areas. The great thing about the Abbey is that it is virtually unchanged over hundreds of years, but they have changed one thing - they make you tour in a one way direction that is aggravating. When I visited in the 1980's, we walked in the front door and went in any direction we wanted. The one way tour was crowded and felt rushed. The audio guide is good, but the small museum would be better if it were larger and more modern with more artifacts with better labels and descriptions. That being said, it's a must see. I have stayed in the Abbey dorm rooms for three weeks one summer over 20 years ago, so this is a very special place for me. I was surprised it was not more so for my grown kids on this trip, but I think it was because we were forced into the one way tour - we sort of went in one way and popped out another.

Historic and exciting. The Abbey is very large with all the different rooms attached to it. There's so much to learn and the personal headsets for narration are quite helpful. Very fascinating experience. No photos allowed. This is kind of nice because then dozens of people aren't snapping and flashing away while you're moving through this surreal experience. But, you can buy a great DVD there in the shop.

Take the recorded tour.. There is so much history inside the cathedral that I would advise taking the audio tour, ours was narrated by Jeremy Irons. I was over awed to think of how many famous people from history had walked where I was now walking!

Still the Best. I've seen dozens of cathedrals throughout Europe but this one is my favorite. The Abby was founded in AD 960 as a Benedictine monastery and is now part of the Church of England. Each visitor is given a map and audio device at the Information Desk in the north transept. Each room is numbered to correspond with the device so visitors can meander at their own pace. Regular guided tours are also available.The Abby has a long and colorful history over the last thousand years as a living church. Each hour for a minute or so, everyone pauses to pray or reflect. You should allow at least two hours to view the Abby.

A lot of history under one roof. I absolutely loved this place. Seeing all the ornate grave markers and the resting places of so many famous royals, not to mention the famous poets and writers definitely inspores me. It is also very interesting that the Abbey is still a functioning place of worship and residence. To me the highlights were Poet's Corner, Mary and Elizabeth's tomb, Mary of Scot's Tomb, Longshank's Tomb and the Coronation Chair (sans Stone). The hours are a little bit cumbersome, and, as much as I loved Mr. Irons' audio guide, it didn't cover anything not in the main building, so gathering information in the pyx room or the chapterhouse is from reading signs only. It was also a shame that no pictures were allowed inside.

Jeremy Irons narrates. The audio guides greatly helped our enjoyment of the tour of the Abbey--hearing the voice of the Borgia Pope (from the Showtime series) describing the features and monuments of the Abbey made the visit that much more enjoyable. Our experience with staff, even as Americans, was more pleasant than some have mentioned here--even when I asked if Cromwell was buried in Westminster (which he was not, having been beheaded at the Tower).

Amazing. This sight is a must-see in London. I paid cash (no line). If you come during a service, there is no charge (of course), but then you won't get a tour. I took the audio tour and walked around at my leisure. The architecture, the history, the Poet's Corner! I was an English major in college and here I was, standing on the tombs of such writers as T.S. Eliot, Chaucer (!!), William Wordsworth, DH Lawrence, and many more. There are also tombs of scientists, such as James Watt, whose improvements in the steam engine were integral to the Industrial Revolution. Amazing place, everywhere you look.

Totally awesome. The Abbey is totally amazing. The guided tour is a must as there's so much history and detail. The guide goes over the building of the structure, it's history, architecture, people who influenced it, people who are buried there (Darwin! Newton!), the majesty of it is overwhelming.

Gloria in excelsis Deo. By a very, VERY serendipitous quirk of fate, the #24 bus disgorged me within spitting distance of the Abbey and I realized with disbelief that I could attend Evensong at 3:00 on Sunday afternoon. As a Roman Catholic, I am not familiar with the intricacies of the Anglican Church service minutiae, but OMG.There was a bit of a queue (I LOVE typing that word) to enter the Abbey, and one of the gentlemen (vicar? rector? usher?) was asking us queuers our purpose for being there. The camera-toting gal in front of me said "to visit." He told her to "visit" on Monday, when she could snap pics to her heart's content. I told him I was there to worship and he let me pass. Camera Lady got smart fast said that was why she was there, too, so he grudgingly allowed her in, which was a HUGE mistake because she took flash photos in spite of being admonished and adding insult to injury LEFT THE SANCTUARY EARLY. I am kind of a "lapsing Catholic, " but I have never, EVER felt more like falling to my knees and crying "Take me home, Jesus" than I did at Evensong. The music was, for want of a better word, thrilling. Five of the choristers were leaving service and there was a tribute to them, which I felt privileged to witness.Besides an edifying and hilarious half-hour chat with a London cabbie, this was indubitably the highlight of my three days in London. By all means GO and for heaven's sake turn off your camera if you attend a service.

Magnificent - definitely take the Verger's Tour!. Even though I lived in London, I couldn't remember having visited the Abbey since I was a child. So having a couple of hours to kill in the area, I thought I would take the Verger's tour so often recommended by TA. What a fantastic couple of hours and what a magnificent building. Why is it only ranked 37 by TA? I'm flabbergasted! Over 1000 years of history, stunningly beautiful architecture (the gothic ceiling of the Lady Chapel nearly had me in tears) and monuments to people of significance to people from every corner of the world. Yes, it's quite expensive to get it, but this is part of our cultural heritage, we should all be prepared to contribute a bit if we wish to visit it and preserve it for future generations. But absolutely pay the extra £3 for the Verger's tour - it really does help you understand the history of the abbey and the throngs of people seem less important. Our verger was a mine of information and made our tour very personal. He asked where we were all from and then found a monument related to each of our countries. I was most impressed. Thanks very much to TA for alerting me to the Verger's Tour, I learnt a great deal and was greatly entertained.

Beautiful Inside and Out!. Don't miss this venerable piece of a thousand year history! The architecture is impressive on both exterior and interior. Royalty as well as famous commoners are buried here. Audio guides provide clear explanations and a reasonable path to follow. This year, a special exhibit focusing on the Queen's Diamond Jubilee was available to see. I saw this Abbey 25 years ago and it was non-negotiable that I see it again--it's my favorite cathedral of all I've seen in Europe. **Buy tickets ahead of time to save time standing in line--we were grateful we did this!
must see. a can't miss on your london visit. so much history and beautiful architecture. plan enough time to see it all.

must see. you can't visit london without seeing westminster. unbelievable history at your fingertips and all around you. speak to some of the guards/staff. they have some interesting stories about events they've witnessed.

the abbey. Excellent,they have to charge because it gets no other funding,and its a world heritage site,founded in 960, its worth the historical information.Steeped in history,a friendly greeting on entering,free audio tour.or you can do the verger guided tour.god has blessed this place.

Interesting.... I'm not sure how I felt about the Abbey. It was very beautiful but also very crowded. If you have a london pass you can skip the really long line at the entrance and go to the cash only line which is much shorter. Once inside, it's a bit overwhelming. You aren't sure where to look first. The best thing to do is grab an automated tour device from the volunteers at the front of the church. Even with that the abbey is a little too busy to really enjoy it. I kind of felt like we were cattle being herded along. It would be nice to go back when it isn't so busy, although I'm not sure any such time exists. Worth a visit for sure, just be prepared for the crowds.
Expensive.... It's a bit expensive, really nice but you aren't allowed to take any pictures..

One of the "musts" to see in London. Been going to Wimbledon since 2003 and only on TripAdvisor a couple years so today I'm catching up on the sites I've seen over the years....LOVED Westminster Abbey. I see complaints from reviewers about the price and how it's just a place of dry history. That's what you're paying for folks...NEAR ONE THOUSAND YEARS OF FREAKING HISTORY!! There is more history in this building than near anything else anywhere anytime. I loved it. I ate it up. I soaked it in. Go.
amazing place a must see. loved it all and its so well organised u could spend one hour to 3 hours in it :)
Beautiful!. The Abbey was on our list of things to do while in London and it did not disappoint! Absolutely beautiful!

A place of historic magnitude. Take time to participate in the 45 minutes service mid afternoon. Although the service is vary ritual, the music that sourrounds the various parts of the service is the finest and breathtaking organ music you'll hear - especially when the organist plays newer British composers

Excellent but over priced!!. Although the Abbey is steeped in history and a showcase for English theological and monarch history, it is marred by a commercial overtone that charges for everything it can, Admission is £16.50 each for a house of God and therefore drops into the tacky zone for me, as it makes a family visit expensive. The queues outside can be very long. If they are, simply turn around and visit St Margaret's church for free and note the red leather covered doors for the members of parliament to access the church without being exposed to the electorate. The Abbey has a very impressiveness history to enjoy, but must rate as the most expensive church in the world to visit.

Crowded and expensive. Disappointed. Felt more like a cemetery than a church. Go in the afternoon! We made the mistake of going in the morning and you could barely move because of the number of people. We preferred Salisbury Cathedral and the Cathedral at Windsor castle.

Didn't Want to Leave. The staff at our hotel was very helpful in reserving us a spot in the morning's Verger-Guided Tour of Westminster Abbey. It's a 90-minute behind-the-scenes look at some of the places and stories that the general public aren't generally allowed to see and hear. We needed to get there early so we set out on foot because it's just down the street. A VERY easy walk from our hotel.A brilliant blue sky provided a very colorful backdrop to this striking ancient Abbey reportedly founded in the year 960. We stood in line and in awe at the magnificance of the buildings around us. Crowds were starting to gather as we were allowed in and purchased our audio tour. We didn't use the audio tour as much because the Verger tour was so good. But with Jeremy Irons doing the voice on the audio tour, it has to be one of the sexiest audio guides I've ever heard! LOLWe met our tour-guide, verger David Mott in his clergy robes, and our small group of about 15 was led to several special places throughout the large abbey and we were told some wonderful tid bits that others would have missed in their audio tours.Our group was taken behind the main alter into Edward the Confessor's Chapel. Around the year 1060, King Edward founded the church on this site. The Chapel of St. Edward the Confessor is the spiritual heart of the Abbey. Surrounding the shrine, which contains the saint's body, lie five kings and four queens.Hundreds, if not thousands, of famous politicians, royals, artisians, and spiritual leaders are buried or memorialized throughout the Abbey. One cannot help but step on memorials as they're laid out on the floor beneath you. Quite sad really. Apparently Winston Churchill refused to be buried there saying "I've had people walk all over me in life, why have it done in death".I've been readying a lot about the Tudor age with a particular interest in Queen Mary I and Queen Elizabeth I, King Henry VIII's oldest children. Both Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth are buried here at the Abbey in Henry VII's Lady Chapel built in 1516. Elizabeth's tomb is actually on TOP of Mary's, which is quite sad. But at the end of Mary's reign, she was known as "Bloody Mary" due to putting to death some 300 'heretics' who refused to recant their Protestant faith. I found Mary's life to be quite sad, and then to add insult to injury, her more famous sister is buried on top of her.On our tour, we were also allowed to sit in the roped-off Quire area. The Quire (choir) is a 'church wtihin a church' where we learned the history and symbolizm of each and every decorative element in the quire. Including where the current Queen Elizabeth II sits when she attends service there.At the end of our tour, we viewed the coronation chair, which has seen better days, but is the oldest piece of furniture in Britian still in use for its original purpose. Commissioned in 1297, the chair has been badly abused over the centuries and lost much of its original luster, but I'm glad they're not "redoing" it and leaving it. Yes, it's not pretty, but the history of that chair is highly significant.We wanted to stay at the Abbey all day. There is so much to see and so much history in these sacred walls that we just did not leave enough time to explore everything we wanted to. Our verge tour was wonderful and we highly recommend it.
Outstanding. One of the best places to visit in London. Definitely must see
Abbey. Although not cheap it is well worth a visit. The free audio tour is useful although a little brief in parts. For anyone interested in British History it is a must see.

Amazing. Another awe inspiring building in London. Audio guides free and sensational. How they built things like this so many years ago is staggering. Couldnt believe I was standing next to Charles Darwin and Issac Newtons burial site. Mind blowing
lady chapel. The Lady Chapel at Westminster is a must see sight in London, a beautiful chapel only second to Sainte Chapelle in Paris

Magnificent, steeped in history with great stories to tell.. On a weekend trip to London it was 1st on the list to visit the Abbey. There are 2 queues; one for cash and the other for cards. I suggest you join the shortest queue. Don't let the length of the queue put you off either as the place is huge inside and even though busy you can get around. The entry cost (£16) which includes a free audio tour and map. We decided to pay an extra £3 and go on the escorted tour with a Verger (you get taken to places in the abbey that non guided tour people can’t access). This we felt was really worth the extra £3. The Verger, Ben Shepherd (not the presenter!!!) was brilliant (a BIG thank you to him). He made some dry subjects and bits of information very enjoyable and in some cases comical. Make sure you ask about what happened to Oliver Cromwell!! We did not see it all but after arriving at 11.15am, we left at 3.45pm. There is a little coffee bar next to the Cloisters so if you need a rest. Of course there are seats in the Abbey but if you go on the escorted tour you can also sit in the Choir/Quire. Fully recommended.

A must see while in London. Lots of history here from the coranation chair that dates back hundreds of years, to the people buried here, its history, the architecture, the stained glass windows -beautiful!
Neat to see but... They won't let you go inside. But you can see the outside and meet interesting people on the lawn.

Great.... I was looking forward to seeing Westminster Abbey. It was not like I expected but it was really great anyway. It is really great because the audio guide comes with the admission price which is a rarity. It is expensive but where else do you see the graves of royalty and great authorists and musicians?
Political Education but interesting.. Magnificent building and contents. Prices very reasonable. Evening tours are best as the sun is sinking rather than mid day.Steeped in History. .
Far more then a church. The workmanship and skill required to create all the facets of the Abbey will leave you amazed at what was accomplished by artisans aver the centuries- absolutely stunning!!
Beautiful. This is a really beautiful and impressive building and well worth seeing, combine it with a visit to the Houses of Parliament

Amazing. I have been several times. It is a little pricey to get in and discount tickets are hard to find. The lines can be a bit long. Truly fascinating inside. It is possible to go to an organ recital, but you miss a lot of what it has to offer. Go early to avoid crowds. A true historic gem.
Beautiful!. The line was not too long, but go in the morning if you can!

Blown Away!. My second trip to London but first to the Abbey, I have been to many places with historic significance but this was fantastic as it had so many identifiable relics and tombs. The place of coronations, burial site to saints, royals, scientists and poets. We were amazed and could have spent a full day easily without tiring. A must see in London. Make sure you take the 3 pound guided tour, it gets you access to things others don't see and is very detailed. Our guide was fantastic!

Top sight in London. The history in touring this amazing church is incredible. You spend hours there. The admission price may appear steep, but you receive a free self guilded audio tour and there is just so so much to see. One of the greatest historical sites I have seen in the world.

Beautiful and filled with History. Impressive, worth entrance fee that includes audio guide and map....every corner is filled with a bit of history -It's a sureal moment as you have seen so much of it on TV.My 6 yr old enjoyed all the statues and angels.

Beautiful and moving place to visit. Excellant visit and the complimentary audio sets with a set tour are fantastic. They give you the advantage of a full tour of the Abbey in your own time with not too much information but enough to take all the history in. A must visit place.

The great and good. A wonderful awe-inspiring place. I felt truly humbled to be in the presence of such greatness - the royals, the poets, the greats of history... I agree with another reviewer - I do wish I could have taken photos!

Not just another museum. Westminster Abbey may be more than a thousand years of history enshrined in Gothic glory, but to visit it as merely another museum is to miss the point. It is first and foremost a church, so schedule your visit to coincide with one of the three services being held daily – Morning Prayer, Evensong, and the Eucharist – or those held on a Sunday.The latter is best as you get to enjoy the service without hundreds of tourists wandering about. Services on Sundays are free, and you enter by the main entrance (the side entrance used by tourists during the week is closed), but don’t try and get in some sightseeing on the side. Rather come back another day and pay the admission fee.I attended Evensong (15:00 on a Sunday/weekdays at 17:00), which was held in the Quire, and was welcomed warmly in spite of being dressed rather informally. The service, sung by the Choir of St Margaret's Church, Westminster Abbey, was a wonderful uplifting experience.
Kate & Wills. I just had to see where they were married. Beautiful church, a shame you can't photograph. you can at Notre Dame in Paris

Poet's Corner. The abbey was beautiful and full of history, although I was by far most enthralled with the Poet's corner, burial place of many great writers with honorary sites for many others. If you're into British literature, take some time to really enjoy this section, noting how many greats are there, and remembering the history of so many others being excluded (although there are memorials to most of them now).
Evening service. Instead of doing tour, we went to evening service (M-F 5:00PM). A different way to experience the cathedral. Get there a little after 4:00 PM - very popular.

Secret for those visiting with little ones!. Hard enough to get kids to go to church let alone one on vacation. Interesting place given the history. They have a audio guide provided for those over 10 included in the cost. For the under 10 they give a worksheet that is sort of a seek and find about things in the Abbey. My under 10 actually enjoyed it, so fun game and the secret. When you turn in the clipboard they provide at the end of the tour, get a nice big piece of chocolate
fantastic. what a place to go.so many great weddings here.but never invited!

Interesting if a little expensive..... The entrance fee is £16 as stated in previous reviews which is fairly costly. However the audio tour is interesting and the amount of history in the Abbey is amazing. There is also a small history of the Abbey in a museum towards the end of the audio tour.
A very famous Abbey!. Its pretty awesome and historical. Royalty have been married there!

Awe inspiring. We didn't pay to go in but instead went to the worship on Sunday evening at 6:30--what a great decision. I thought it was very cool that they don't allow any visitors in on Sundays and instead reserve it as a place of worship. The service was short and sweet, but very cool to worship in a place that has been serving that purpose for hundreds of years.
Majestic and beautiful. For me this is one of the most important place in British history. Westminster Abbey is majestic and beautiful and it worth waiting to get inside. A 'must-do' while in London.

great!!. good to see, this place has history of the queen being crown here. the architecture of the place is unique. I walk around the abbey is was worth going. Be sure to go around area during day time only.
Impressive bulding. It is nice to go and see Westminster abbey but I personally think it is over priced to go inside. the outside is the most impressive part and that bit is free

Worth the wait. We had quite a long wait to get inside, but it was worth it. The art and architecture are beautiful. Finding the names of so many 'famous' people in one church was humbling. A 'must-do' while in London.

More than just an abbey. It is worth our money visiting the Abbey. We learnt so much about the Abbey with the help of the audio guides. Westminster Abbey is majestic and beautiful. We usually see photos of the exterior. To see the interior of the abbey with our own eyes was absolutely amazing.We used our London Passes to go in for free had a fantastic time.

Wow!. Truly beautiful you walk up to it and you just need to feast your eyes on the architectural marvel of a building. Intricate details each with its own story, very very beautiful and majestic. This was a favourite for me in london. So much history when you just think about it and being there just takes you back and it it definitely better to look at in real rather than in pictures or T.V. A must on your trip to london.

Worth the money. 16 GBP for Westminster Abbey! I could not believe that a place of worship could have such a steep price to enter. However once I was in, it was a true surprise. The architecture is amazing. The audio guide is very informative. Its a pity that they don't allow pictures to be taken inside to relive the experience, but of course one does understand that it is a place of worship and needs to be respected. Very beautiful and definitely worth a visit if you are in London!

The Top "Must See" in London. Westminster Abbey was one of my favorite places in London. It is even more amazingly beautiful and majestic when you're standing inside than it is to see it on TV or in pictures. What is on the outside is only a fraction of the beauty. To stand in the place where so many coronations, funerals, weddings, etc. have taken place over hundreds of years was utterly amazing.We visited first thing in the morning and had no line to get in. It was fairly busy inside, but not overly crowded to where we felt pushed or rushed through at all. We spent roughly 2.5 hours going through and probably could have spent longer if we hadn't had other places to be in the afternoon.Included in the cost of entry was an audio guide, which was really informative. As others have said, the cost is a bit steep, but we used the London Pass to enter, so I feel like it didn't hit us as hard just how expensive it truly was. Regardless, it was well worth it, IMO.

Loved It. I loved it very much, I was very moved by the history and religious aspect of this place. I have to admit I only went to see Mary Queen of Scots Grave, but it was very magical to think about all the royalty buried there. And I especially like the old church in the back by the garden.

So Much History. We took our 11-year-old and he absolutely loved visiting the Abbey. We had visited St Paul's the day before and spent way longer than we intended to, so this time went expecting to take a minimum of 3 hours - and we needed every minute. The cost was £32 for a family of 3, and it was definitely worth the cost. We visited in December so there were no queues for admission, although at some of the tombs we may have had to wait several minutes to take a look. The only drawback of a winter visit is that often you enter an attraction in daylight, and exit when it is dark; probably nothing out of the ordinary for Europeans, but for us from Australia, darkness at 3.30pm was so frustrating.Upon entry into the Abbey our son was given a questionnaire to be completed during our visit; it was so much fun! It kept him (and us) entertained for hours, searching for the tomb of this person or that one, counting knights, etc. At the end he was given a chocolate coin for his troubles - I think the fact that he was given something to do meant that he did not have a chance to become bored, and we were able to spend a little more time ourselves. It was just like stepping back into a school history lesson, seeing the tombs of so many famous historical figures. We loved being in Poet's corner, searching for monuments and memorials to famous authors, scholars, poets. It was so pretty walking outside into the cloisters, then back to explore the interior further.I would definitely recommend Westminster Abbey for a visit - and DO bring the kids, they will love it! You will be amazed how much they actually take in and learn - six months later our 11-year-old still has recall on a lot of the things he saw, heard about, read, etc.

A must see, even if only the outside. A trip to London would not be complete without seeing Westminster Abbey. We hired a private guide that showed us a lot of the hidden interests inside, but the outside architecture is a photographer's dream. Go early morning to avoid crowds as afternoons are PACKED. No photos inside.

My favorite. My favorite tour in London. Free audio tour with entrance fee. I was in awe of it's beauty and the history. Many famous people buried within that I was unaware of. Also, I didn't know there was a guided tour option at the time but I would have spent the extra money to join in! You cannot take pictures inside but we stopped in the gift shop and bought postcards for ourselves as a reminder.

Worth the entry fee. When originally looking at going to Westminster Abbey I was surprised at the cost. It is well worth it though as it includes an audio guide to give you an insight into this historical place. There are lots of important British figures buried here.

Kids Guide to Westminster. Since I knew that St Paul's charged to tour, it wasn't a surprise that the same practice occurred at Westminster Abbey. The benefit here was the great audio tour guide and a fabulously hard activity - something of a scavenger hunt - for kids. Surprisingly well done, it kept my 11 and 8 year old entertained looking for the next tomb or sculpture. I'll also say it wasn't easy! It had the adults backtracking and searching, as well. In the end, everyone was awed by the magnificent place, the beauty, and the great history it holds. This tour is not to be missed - young or old!

HISTORY FANS MUST SEE. Book a vergers tour on arrival just right of the pay desk. It is well worth paying the extra three pund as you get to see things that normal visitors miss. The kings gallery where countless kings are laid to rest and where the queen prepares for Royal occasions. See who's buried there the list is endless it's positively mind blowing. This is a must see when in London and something to remember. Very humbling!

A Massive Tomb of Kings. Very impressive, large scale cathedral, and basically a tomb to the nobility of England for almost 1000 years. Home to the coronation chair. Takes a long time to see, and the lines inside move slowly. Try to couple it with a tour of Parliament and then when you're done at Parliament you can just walk accross the street. Tickets are not available in advance, you will have to wait in line to purchase them. Make sure you grab a headset or you'll be lost. No photos inside.

The abbey and the clock tower. The structure is beautiful enough from the outside but definitely warrants a trip inside if you have the time. Of course one of the most iconic portions of the abbey is the clock tower (which many people refer to as Big Ben, but Big Ben is merely the bell inside). The abbey has grave stones for some of the most famous English people in history and the church itself is home to wonderful music for the Christmas Eve service as well.

Pure history. I love the fact that this church is built on a site where over a thousand years of history have occurred. Many of our biggest state occasions have taken place here, from the burial of Edward the Confessor to the crowning of William of Orange, our own Queen's coronation and the marriage of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. The sense of history is incredible, as is the time you can spend searching for some of the tombs and memorials. Whatever you skip on a visit to the Abbey- and you will not see it all during a solitary visit- do not miss out on the royal tombs as they are a sight to behold.I try to visit the Abbey every time I visit London and never consider it a waste of either time or money.

Choral Evensong. This is a must do. Such an incredible was to see the cathedral that we all have seen so many times on TV. The service is about an hour long. you line up near the Abbey store and they start letting people in about 15 minutes prior. We had wonderful seats (we were probably about 20th in line) but there really are no bad seats. After the service you can walk about at your leisure and explore. Check their website for dates/times.

Steeped in history. Any trip to London should include a visit here. The sense of majesty and the passage of ages that pervades the Abbey is overwhelming, and for those interested in history, coming here is a veritable pilgrimage. I only wish that more information was included in the tours--for example, if not for my dim memories of high school Latin, I would not have figured out that the remains of the Princes in the Tower are contained in the large marble urn at the end of the small chamber with the tombs of Elizabeth I and Mary I. But overall it is an awesome (in the original sense of the world) experience. Make sure you do not miss the Henry VII Lady Chapel. I do find it unsettling to be charged to enter a place of worship. Contrast this with the British Museum, which is free and lets you take all the photos you want.
Interesting. Interesting place to visit, can get some good photographs outside, I don't think photography was allowed inside, entry charges to get in. Popular tourist spot so can be busy.

A Must-See. Westminster Cathedral is one of those places a visitor to London really can't miss. The one drawback is the very high admission price - 16 pounds per person when I last visited. If you want to see at least part of the cathedral without paying so much, try attending one of the daily services (which are free). The "Evensong" service in late afternoon (usually around 5PM) is especially recommended.

History at its best. You really need a lengthy guided tour to fully appreciate the huge amount of history attached to this place and we were fascinated by it. We were lucky enough to attend an evening tour but it must be interesting even when more crowded. If you like history then this is a must to visit.

A must do!. If you're into architecture, history, royalty, sciences, literature at all, you should definitely visit this place. There are grave sites and memorials to world famous Brits. Go to poets corner and see how many of the poets you recognize. Theres Chaucer, Tennyson, Browning just to name a few. Theres also a memorial for Shakespeare. In a bit of irony, Darwin was also buried at Westminster Abbey (located in the Nave).Also I second taking the verger led tours. For 3 extra pounds, you get a 90 minute tour of the abbeys history, famous people buried there and explanations of the ceremonies that take place there like coronations. Also you get access to the shrine of Edward the confessor, not accessible to the public. You get sit on the quire seats and cross the border to stand on top of isaac newtons burial site. The tour is really informative and highly worth the price.
Westminster Abbey. Seen throughout the world on many royal occasions, this is a fantastic piece of art and history. Very close to any Londoner's heart and a tourist absolute must!
London Travelor. Beautiful and very impressive. Be sure to use the audio tour. Allow a few hours to complete the tour.

The Abbey is Amazing!. My partner and I attended morning prayer here the Jubilee weekend. It was a really beautiful experience. From the music and the readings to the setting itself, everything combined to transport you to a place outside yourself in the midst of one of the greatest and busiest cities in the world on one of its busiest weekends! The abbey has so many historic sights to offer apart from being a spiritual space. These gems from down the years and across centuries - from the resting places of monarchs and public figures to memorials to those whom we know by name and reputation - will have you on a mental, whirlwind journey through time and nostalgia for a hour or two, if lose yourself in the abbey's assortment of plaques, tablets, monuments and sarcophagi as well as the history in which its very walls are steeped. The one and only discommodious experience we encountered was one of the ushers who, when I asked him if there was a toilet, gruffly replied by pointing to the door directed me across the street to the Public underground toilets! I would have thought that the Abbey would have trained its staff better and provided for the comfort of its worshippers better! But,overall, a magnificent building!

A must see. If you are planning a trip to London this is pretty much a must see. The architecture and craftsmanship for something that old is simply amazing. So much history to take in you wish they would let you take photos of all the tombs you get to see. The inside is breathtaking. Some people are put off by the fact that they charge to get in but get over it, with all the people going through the place and the upkeep it must require it should be no surprise they have to charge. Anybody upset over having to pay a fee doesn't get it or should simply buy a London pass then you can get more value out of the visit. Don't miss this amazing church.
A must see. If you are in London, this is a must see. There is so much history in this building that one cannot miss this site. Good for all ages, and not that time consuming.
Breath taking. I didn't know what to expect but loved the few hours we spent here. Use the audio guides, they are very informative.

Make sure you take the official tour. MAKE SURE YOU TAKE THE OFFICIAL TOUR.Most visitors I saw at the Abbey were walking around aimlessly or trying to listen to an audioguide when then should have been enjoying the stunning architecture, art and history.The official tour is only 3-pounds, but only offered a few times a day. If you cannot take the official tour when you get there you can schedule yourself for a later tour (or even one the next day) and come back. It is that important!Now I'll explain why I think the tour is so important. YOU GET TO GO TO OFF-LIMITS AREAS!Among the most impressive spots in the church is the shrine of St. Edward the Confessor. This shrine is NOT open to the general public. The only people allowed in are the official tour groups and pilgrims.The shrine was by far the most fascinating thing in the church. It dates back to the 1200's and is surrounded by other kings of England that cannot be seen from the general public area.Another bonus of the tour is the chance to sit in the quire (pronounced choir) seats in front of the high alter and to walk right up pass the tourists to the high alter and get a good look at it.The tour takes about an hour and a half, and the guide was a bit stuffy, but all-in-all this was a fantastic experience.

Shocking !!!!!!!!. Its a joke that the church are charging people to visit. Like most other churches in the Uk people should leave a donation if they wish. My christian girlfriend who lives in london had always wanted to nip in for a quick two minutes of refelction was not allowed in unless she paid something like £20. Im sure it has even went up due to the Royal Wedding in which tourists think all us Brits just love.I would advise any tourist visiting london to have a look around as we have thousands of stunning churches all over the country that are free to enter and are stunning building works of art. Please do not fall into this tourist trap and the church might come to its sences one day.

Attend the Evensong Service at no charge for a great experience!. On a recent rainy Sunday afternoon my wife and I attended the 3pm Evensong service which has no entry fee but we did make a contribution to the collection plate. What a beautiful church and delightful service. We loved the choir! All denominations or lack threre of are invited. An excellent way to see this special place. The service lasts about one hour.

take the Verger Guided Tour. We chose to pay the additional fee for the 90-minute Verger Guided Tour, and it was well worth the money and time. (We've used the audio guide on past visits to Westminster Abbey, but that gave just the basic facts.) The Verger provided so much more details and allowed us behind-the-ropes access (we sat in the choir). He pointed out the spots on the high altar where the coronation chair (built around the coronation Stone of Destiny that has been returned to Edinburgh Castle) was placed and where Kate and William got married. We were let into the Chapel of St Edward the Confessor (where Kate and William signed the marriage registry). The Verger Tour greatly enhanced my visit to Westminster Abbey.
Phenomenal place to visit. Great place to visit if you're into history or the church. Take the time to grab an audio tour and spend a few hours walking the grounds.

Great! See poet's corner!. Amazing! Make sure you see the poets corner. Note: do not go on Sunday as they will not allow you to enter (Sunday mass is on).
