Also, although they SAY they close at 4 PM, I believes that is the last time you can enter, as my family was able to stay until almost 5 (we then left on our own accord).
$30US to visit a church!!. Extremely crowded and they are charging like it's Disneyland.

Expensive, but Probably Worth It for British History Buffs. On my last visit to London, my son and I arrived too late to visit the abbey as a tourist, but we were admitted to the Evensong service. The few members of the public in attendence were seated behind the choir. While that's not a good way to "visit" the Abbey, it is a beautiful service sung by the Abbey choir and there is no charge.This time I returned at lunch-time on a Tuesday on June 12th. I was surprised to see that there was an adult admission fee of 16 pounds, about $25. (The Abbey literature states they receive no funds from the Church of England or the government which I find a little hard to believe, but whatever.) The price of admission includes an audiophone tour available in various languages and there is narration at 25 marked points around the abbey----although oddly, about 5 of them don't actually have any narration. Rick Steve's recommends a lunch time visit to avoid the most crowded times. We waited on a fairly short line and were able to see ehat we wanted to see even though it was crowded. The first structure on the site, a Benedictine Monastery, pre-dated the Norman Conquest of 1066. All British monarchs since William the Conqueror in 1066 have had their coronations here. The Abbey contains the graves (tombs) of many important people, including Queen Eliabeth I who shares a grave spot with her half sister with whom she battled for the throne. The famous Poets' Corner contains the graves or plaques dedicated to writers. The graves of Sir Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin were big draws for my scientist husband.The grave of Britain's unknown soldier of World War I and the graves of many generals and admirals reminds one of our dedication to war---in this holy place.For me, the goosebumps came from walking on stones worn down by the tread of 1,000 years of feet--- the famous, the doomed----and the tourists.
Unforgettable!!. It was so exciting visiting the abbey. My family and I wil never forget it. You can feel the history walking down the aisles.

Well worth a visit. Although the entrance fee is quite expensive you do get free personal listening devices to take around the abbey which tells you a little of the history. It's much bigger thank you think and there are so many famous royals, poets and others buried here.

Awe inspiring. If you are a spiritual person, Westminster Abbey feels like a pilgrimage site. But even if you're not, this place should not be missed because of the wonderful history that has taken place within these walls. Coronations have been held here since 1066 and the tombs of many kings of queens are here as well. I especially like seeing Mary, Queen of Scots lying beside her enemy Elizabeth I. You'll recognize the Abbey if you watched Princess Diana's funeral or last year's royal wedding between The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (Will and Kate). The audio guide is essential for understanding the history and for helping you find obscure tombs and markers. Go either first thing in the morning to avoid crowds, or show up around 4:15 to get in line for the 5:00 Evensong service. It's a shame you can't photograph the interior of the building but not having people snapping photos adds to the dignity of the building, not to mention the movement of the crowds! You haven't lived until you've heard music performed in this glorious space. Plan to spend several hours!
Great visit. Take the audio guide wich will guide you to visit the place. Although there was some queue it is so well organized that we went in quite easily.

fantastic!!!. what a beautiful abbey soaked in centuries of history. it was quite a surreal experience and a must do if you like visiting churches and enjoy history. there is so much to see you do not know where to look. this place is so special and you can feel it. lots of famous people buried here and it was a humbling experience seeing the unknown warriors grave. very busy around the abbey but the queue soon went down as there was one entry for cash payments and the other for card payments. there is a shop there and a small cafe also a small museum which i especially liked seeing queen elizabeth's 1st corset. a must do when in london.
Very nice. Didn't get to go inside during our visit but admired the architecture from outside. Very impressive with incredible detail.

This is the number one must see!!!!. Such an amazing place. One of my most enjoyable experiences ever. Something for everyone to see. Architecture, famous people who have been buried there and history!!!

Historical Richness. I'm not a big fan of visiting cathedrals in every city, but this "Abbey" is more like a trip back in time than a visit to a cathedral. The building itself would be worth several hours due to its beauty and awesome architecture; the fact that hundreds of historical figures from all walks of life are either entombed or memorialized there makes it that much more interesting. My favorite site was Charles Darwin's grave - in a church!!! The irony is just delicious.

Fascinating!. This is one of the most beautiful, intriguing churches I have ever visited. I have been to most of Europe's great cathedrals, basilicas and abbeys, but this one packs in more than any other. What makes it special is all the famous (and not so) people buried or memorialized inside. The Poets' Corner alone contains the tombs of some of the greatest authors of the English language, starting with Geoffrey Chaucer. British monarchs are crowned here, get married here and have their funerals here. Many are entombed within the walls of Westminster Abbey. If you don't have time to see more than one attraction in London, then go for the Abbey,

Gorgeous!. Westminster Abbey is absolutely gorgeous and a must see while visiting London. Its historical significance is immense and is absolutely breathtaking. I would highly reccommend visiting here!
So much more than a church. i didn't realize how much was at westminster abbey. very historical and interesting. if you're in london this is a must-do.

Praying at Westminister Abbey. Attending a prayer session at Westminister Abbey was one of the most special moments in my trip to the U.K. We had the opportunity to say our on prayers and then taking part in prayers by a clergyman of the Abbey.

icons of culture. Chaucer was the first poet buried in Westminster Abbey, but that was because he was a former clerk to the palace of Westminster, not because he wrote Canterbury Tales. It took another 150 years, when Spenser was buried too for the trend to become "entrenched." Ben Johnson wanted to join Poet's Corner but was poor, so he begged for a "mere two feet, not six". When his wish was granted he was buried standing up! The list of famous names grew: Dickens, Tennyson, Browning, Kipling. Thomas Hardy was mostly buried here except for his heart, which went to his Dorset home. Others have memorials but are buried elsewhere: Shakespeare, Keats, Shelley, Milton, Blake, TS Elliot, and Gerard Manly Hopkins. Sir Walter Scott and Robert Burns share the limelight with Jane Austen, George Elliot (Mary Ann Evans), Elizabeth Barrett Browning, and the three Bronte sisters.The collage of famous minds reminds us of British contributions to the evolution of human thought: Lewis Carroll,DH Lawrence, Dylan Thomas,Oscar Wilde--and newcomers Noel Coward and Lawrence Olivier. Handel is there representing musicians, Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin represent science, Cromwell, Gladstone, and Churchill represent politics. Thomas Parr is said to have been 152 at his death in 1635; his life outlasted most human memory in that time.And in the center of the room near the Western entrance is the British equivalent to the tomb of the unknown soldier, bordered in red flowers and where royal brides have taken to respectfully dedicating their bridal bouquets.The sheer volume of work produced by these women and men of letters rivals the fanfare usually reserved for kings and queens. Nowhere else is it memorialized all in one place.

A church so full of history. I liked it all. It is a treasure to see. So much history from so far back. The royal and church history is just so engrossing and the architecture is amazing. Another place not to miss when in London.
A TRULY HISTORIC BUILDING.. With its long association with the kings and queens of England, this is a fascinating place to visit, if anyone is at all interested in English history.

Must Go See. Another breath taking sight. Absolutely huge and beautiful. Very awe inspiring inside and out. You can't buy tickets on line, but the line for tickets can be long. If you arrive at about 9:10, as we did, the lines are just starting, so when they open at 9:30, you go right it. They will give seniors(over 60), a 3 pound discount on your ticket. They give you a map and a recording device so that you can walk around at your own pace. It is amazing to see how many famous people are buried at the abbey. As you walk around, you look down, and read who was buried under this slab of rock 300 years ago. Amazing!You have to keep craning your neck back to look high up at those gorgeous ceilings!My only regret, is that you are not allowed to take photographs.
Amazing. Wow!!! So impressive, so much history. The architecture is incredible! I just wish I could have been able to take photos.

You just have to take the tour. I visited on Tues, 6/5 after waiting for a glimpse of the queen.Not sure I've ever been more impressed by a historical bldg - the architecture, the history ( where coronations & royal events occur), the location of most English royalties thru the 1700's, and last, but not least the poets corner where most English writers you studied in school are buried.I highly recommend the 3 pound tour even after paying the 16 pound admission. Some things have such value, just pay it, it's worth it. What our tour guide was able to provide in explaining each room made the Abbey come alive.The Abbey just contained so much history & artifacts that I was reminded of the DaVinci code & Tom Hanks.If you have the chance, please visit it, you'll be glad you did.
Wonderful. Absolutely amazing. Make sure to get the audio guide. Poet's corner, Scientists corner and Henry VII Chapel (make sure to look up!) are not to be missed.

I need a seat. It is magnificent and beautiful, to imagine how long ago they achieved that massive architectural structure. I wanted to stay longer but there is no place to sit and admire, you need to walk and admire. Beautiful inside, no cameras aloud.
So much to see!. We found a family member's (ancestor) grave inside. It is so huge that you can spend hours wandering around looking at all of the crypts. Outstanding!
most beautiful architectural work i have ever seen. brilliant. you will like it. it is an amazing building.
Beautiful and impressive. A stunning building inside and out. A must see for a trip to visit London and as it is in close proximity to many other must sees it would be shame to miss it.

Long time coming & I'm glad to have seen it. I have been to London twice b4 1st time I didn't have enough time to fit the Abbey in the 2nd time my hubby wasn't interested mainly because of the price but this time (April 2012) I got to go with my Aunty & I have to say apart from the price 16 pound (which I still think is just a little to steep) was well worth the visit, we spent about 3hrs having a look around & it does make u stop and think about all the history this abbey has been a part off over the centries as well of the details in the building it's self, I still don't know how they ever built a building like this with such basic tools of the time. In someplaces u look up at the ceiling and just say WOW how on earth did they do it it really is just breath taking. It is worth having the audio as it gives u much more info on some of the tombs & different parts of the Abbey. A word of warning though don't sit on anything other than the seats provided as u will get told off (as my Aunty found out :-)

Westminster Abbey is Truly Magnificent. To my dismay, I had arrived at Westminster Abbey at 4pm, closing time. I was bummed but I see this little sign on the gate about a 5pm Evensong that was open to everyone. A young man asked the person at the gate if he could "visit" and he was denied. I went up to the man and told him I would like to attend the Evensong and he let me in!!! I was soooooo happy! I was soooo lucky to attend the Choral Service and on that evening, the Evensong was sung by the Choristers of Westminster Abbey. It was soooo wonderfully sung by such beautiful young voices!!!! Awesome experience!!!

Worth it. Westminster Abbey is one of the big London sights. OK, the admission fee is high but remember that all the major public museums and art galleries in London are free - where else does that happen? - so if you can't afford this there are plenty of alternatives and if you can it's a fair balance. I visited early (9:45) on a fine Wednesday in May; there was no line. It gradually became busy but not too crowded. The interior architecture is impressive from the simplicity of the cloisters to the splendor of Henry VII's Lady Chapel and to a royal history buff there is a major " wow" factor to be able to stand next to the tombs of Edward I, Henry V, Elizabeth I etc. I probably would not have been as happy - or waited to go in - if there had been excessive crowds, but I left feeling "I'm glad I saw it, it was worth it".

You must visit to hear the Evensong Choir. This should be the #1 site in London. It is beautiful on the outside but you have to go inside. We meet some younger couples who just saw it from the outside. The tour is a bit pricey but it is worth it. The audio guide is well done and takes you from station to station via a map. It is amazing to be surrounded by 1000 years of history. Now here is a bonus tip: on most days at 5 PM, there is a service and concert (free since is an active church BTW). The regular paid tours end by 5 PM. At 4:30 PM, visitors line up outside for the free service/concert. The trick is to stay inside after your paid tour. There is a separate and priority queue inside behind a blue gate. Ask the tour guides where you return your audio guide for directions. Just remember not to exit. We lined up inside between 4:15 and 4:30 PM behind the blue gate. At about 4:50 PM, we were escorted into the Choir Section and allowed to sit amongst the Choir members and other dignitaries. The main doors then opened from the outside and those folks were seated in the main part of the church. Still excellent seats to hear the choir but the key is to sit with the Choir. The Choir is World-renowned and they are so good, we got goosebumps while they sang. The Evensong service was great and one of the highlights of our London visit. You must see it and Westminister Abbey - that is why I rate it as the #1 site in London - enjoy!

More amazing than I had imagined!. Took my mum and my daughter here for a treat,children under 11 get in free and over 60s get a slight discount. Was quite surprised that there were no queues on the day we went (I have passed on many occasions and the queues are usually massive!) What can I say-I was amazed at how beautiful it was inside-looks even better than when you see it on t.v and in photos! Audio tour comes as part of your ticket price,I just walked around in awe,all that history under one roof! I was really taken by Queen Elizabeth I and Mary,Queen of Scots tombs,also seeing the tomb of the unknown warrior was quite moving.I just stood there thinking about all the weddings,burials,coronations etc..that had taken place here,just think of all the Kings and Queens that have walked there-AMAZING!!! I am actually considering buying an annual pass as i would love to go again.

Worth the Trip to London all by itself. I had the chance to tour the Palace of Westminster during a Saturday Opening last December. For anyone who enjoys watching events like the State Opening of Parliament or Prime Minister's Questions on TV, seeing the inside of the Palace of Westminster in person is a must if you get the chance. I was quite impressed with the level of access that our tour was given, particularly that we were allowed onto the floors of both the Lords and the Commons. Walking through the Lords, we came just a few feet away from the throne the Queen uses when delivering the Queen's Speech and stood in the back where MPs would stand to hear it. In the Commons, it was quite amazing to have the chance to walk through a voting lobby, past the Speaker’s Chair and the dispatch boxes (where the Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition stand at to stare each other down during their weekly face offs) and to stand in front of the benches that MPs sit on, before crossing the Bar of the House on our way out of the chamber. Other spaces in the Palace, such as the Royal Robing Room, Westminster Hall are also impressive to see, along with many pieces of artwork. It was well worth the fee for admission. You can save yourself some time on the day of the tour by booking tickets online ahead of time.

Wonderful, historic place to visit. I was almost happy when I saw the sign saying photo taking inside was not allowed, because there is just too much to see, and my own photos could not do justice to the grandeur that is Westminster Abbey. The audio tour was very informative, and we stayed for Choral Evensong, well worth the extra time.Oh, and it's not advertised, but if you're clergy, you can get in on a free pass! I mentioned it just as a joke when we were buying our tickets, and they said if I was clergy, I could get in free. Nice perk!

A Must. Get there as early in the morning you possibly can to get in line. It is evrything you studied in school come to life, no pun intended. I stood with my mouth open more than not, just not believing I was here. The spectacle for me was the light flooding in through the great stained glass windows. To think this country girl was in hallowed grounds below the marbles. AWE! struck.

Grand -interesting. Interesting lots of little burial monuments. Looked smaller than on the tele but if you are a Kate and Will fan it was brillant! Free audio guide was informative. Staff friendly. Be ready for you bag to be searched it speeds up the line.
Serene. Wonderful ambiance and history, beautiful building
Amazing. It's the place where all the coronation of kings and queens takes place! It is just stunning place!

A very famous home for the most important parts of History. This is a must see for the individual that wishes to get close to History everything has fantastic presence and real character you can feel here something special just give it time to soak in .

Interesting and memorable. The queue outside of the abbey was quite bad - it was very long and took us about 45 minutes to get into the abbey. Personally i find the audio tour very informative and helpful. The interior of the architecture was magnificent and impressive - it feels like you're walking into history and one could have vivid imaginations of the royal ceremonies that were once held in there. The visit would have been more enjoyable and fascinating if i have done some reading before visiting - so the tip is: do prep yourself with some of the English history background, the famous kings and queens and the royal families that could be quite confusing. Expect to see many of the names in the abbey, and most of them have unique stories behind. It took me about 1-1.5 hours to finish the tour. Overall it was a good experience and i would include this as one of the must-visits if this is your first time to London.
amzing place for weddding like royal couple prince william n kate. this place must to visit!!! this place was place of royal wedding... very historic and dont missed it..

Great audio tour!. The audio tour that comes with the admission is very informative and makes the entire visit more meaningful. In honor of the Queen's Jubilee, there was a special photo exhibit that was interesting and well done.

Outstanding Tour with a Verger - the heck with the audio tour. The Vergers tour was excellent and well worth the extra charge. The Verger assigned to our group, Peter, was perfectly entertaining as well as being extremely knowledgeable. OK, I didn't know what a Verger was, but learned about these lay assistants from our guide. The Verger tour goes places that most tourists can't, and I learned quite a bit about the history of the building iotself, plus the history of events that have taken place there over the centuries. Most importantly, with the crowds, the Verger's talent came in handy. This guy led our group around and did not tolerate interference. We were able to see all of the highlights in the 1.5 hour tour. Strongly recommend.

Ok from outside but surprisingly beautiful place inside. When we arrive in the abbey, we were not very impressed with the outside since seemed Notre Dame in Paris has more sculptures outside compare this one. Then we have to pay and queuing to go inside, add the negative point for visiting the place. We have to queue for ~ half hour before we arrive to the front desk to pay the ticket (probably due to weekend holiday). But we didn't regret our visit, since when we are inside then we were surprised with the detail and so many sections inside that has a history. The self-guided tour is good to explore the place. Following the map and the guided tour, you can explore the place for 1-1.5 hour. So many history with UK, that we're impressed with all the exhibition inside. There're so many names that buried inside the place. Additional exhibition for the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee, is a plus point.

Interesting but quite expensive. I spent about 1.5 hours looking around Westminster Abbey. The audio guide contained some interesting observations and directed you to look at certain things. It was very crowded the day i went. There was a queue outside, but holders of the London Pass were able to enter via a separate line, which saved a lot of time. It was interesting, but 16 pounds is a lot to spend on an attraction. I think there are more exciting things to do in London.
A wonderful place. Westminster Abbey has so much: history, graves of kings and queens, the coronation chair, a wonderful choir, the cloisters and some peaceful corners for quiet contemplation.
the place kings and queens get married. probably englands most historic religious place and well worth a visit

Amazing and Packed Full of History. What more can I say about almost one thousand years of history and human experience? It is a little pricey and can be jammed full of people, but you really can't put a price on all of the sights, sounds and tombs of some of the most influential persons in history. The audio guide was most helpful, and it is smart to visit either early in the day, or more towards closing. Visiting London after the high season also makes the entire city just a little more convenient.
Impressive.... To crowded, to long queue to get in.Pay attention to your pockets anyway in this crowd.

Impressive magnificent and full of history. I think this attraction needs a review and possible overhaul in terms of the way it is presented; I am sure it is not easy given its historic significance and therefore tourist appeal as well as being an active church. The queue system is cumbersome; poorly managed and slow; they could do with more people at the cash desk and doormen that know approximately how long the queue might take from a certain point. Although there is simple leaflet describing the key points of interest it was not clear to me where one went to obtain an audio guide and the key points of interest are not clearly described if you do not have the audio guide. We did enjoy the splendour and adventure of finding important elements that make this such an interesting cathedral church; particularly enjoyed the special exhibition of the Queen's relationship with the Abbey.

Nice but bit overpriced. IT was nice to see the Abbey, but again i found £16 a head too much money to walk around the abbey. The audio guide is good, but I think it could be better. and I just expect more for my money. I'm glad I went but I feel it's over priced.
history. When you visit this one make sure you go into the cellars ther is a wealth of things to see my friends from boston usa would not leave they were fascinated.

Take the verger tour, its was wonderful. When we first arrived at the Abbey the queues to get in were stretched in two directions almost to the side gates, one queue is for cash only, the other for those paying by credit card, surprisingly our 'cash only' queue moved reasonably quickly, we were inside in 20 minutes. Audio guides are included in the entrance fee but we chose to pay another 3 pounds and take the Abbey's Verger tour, it was fabulous. Our guide Ian, was passionate, knowledgeable, humorous and energised, very keen to show us many features of the abbey within our 90 minute tour. The best part of the tour is being taken to parts of the Abbey where general visitors cannot go, like the choir stalls, and behind the high alter where there are many famous royal tombs. The Abbey is a beautiful piece of history, it is breathtaking, we thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

History, history and...crowds!. This was a must on our recent trip to London, as my seven year old son has been reading about all of the famous people buried there, including Mary Queen of Scotts, Sir Isaac Newton, etc.But be prepared for crowds! And I don't just mean the ones you encounter queuing up just to get in. Once in, we found it very difficult to find our way around - the signage and directions are poor, especially given the importance and number of visitors (they'd be smart to take some cues from the Tower of London, for example). There were just too many people as well. It was hard navigating through the crowds, getting close to some of the sections (there are several which feature narrow entry ways). Another recommendation would be to meter the number of people entering to control the flow. The lines would be longer outside (maybe book ahead online?) but would make for a more pleasant visit once you're in. We didn't try the audio guides, but many did - which also makes it hectic as people are often distracted by what they are listening to and not really paying attention to the people around them.

Shame on you!. So we rip off visitors to one of our great historical monuments at £38 for a family. Visit the Tower of London instead, far better blue for money. Whats even more appalling for me is that if people want to show respect for the sacrifices of life for our country you have to pay this to visit the tomb of the unknown warrior!I left feeling very sad.

Breathtaking!!!!!. We were there at 13:50 on a Wednesday, the abbey was opening at 14:00, we didn’t have to wait to get in. Yes there was a crowd but it was to be expected for such a prestigious and grand site!We were not in a rush and we took our own sweet time and really enjoyed the visit.The Abbey is breathtaking. The history of centuries past are felt. The volonteers were really kind and available, taking their time with you answering all your questions and a little more.I have to say that I just don’t understand how someone could rate such a first class historical site as “terrible”...
A must visit in london. The building, the setting, the whole surrounding area is a must see if you in london for any period of time.

Incredible. Visited in late April 2012 with my wife. Line was approximately 15 minutes to get in. No pictures allowed. I didn't really know what to expect, but was blown away by the amazing amount of history in Westminster Abbey. A definite must see on a trip to London.

A lot of history. Tons of history here but I was actually a little disappointed. Too much hype surrounding it, I guess. Plus several parts of the Abbey were closed/off-limits. That's not to say you shouldn't go; you definitely should. The audio guide is very good and it's hard not to be amazed at the history that surrounds you.

Do not miss this. The history that is enclosed within the walls of Westminster Abbey is unsurpassed. The complimentary audio tour is extremely helpful and helps to get the most out of your visit. If only one could take photos! Around each corner was another amazing historical find. If I only had one thing I could do in London, it would be this!

Unbelievably crowded. Went to Westminster Abbey on a Tuesday in early May, and it was overcrowded to the point that it was impossible to enjoy. In many cities, it would have been in violation of the fire codes. There was no organized effort to keep the crowd moving in a safe and coherent manner, and the use of audio guides caused many people to shuffle into one another. I know that everyone who visits London wants to see this, but if they don't organize it better, no one will be able to enjoy it. The unfortunate fact is that many treasured sites around the world are approaching (or already exceeding) this level of overuse. I honestly don't know what the answer is, but I am glad I made a previous visit 12 years ago and got to take it all in. My friend whom I took for his first visit said, "And you said this was a nice place to visit."

Don't waste your money. We visited the Abbey at around 10.30 on 15th may. They had crammed so many people in it was impossible to spend any time looking at anything properly. The weight of the crowds forced you around the predetermined route. We left after 15 minutes resolve to tell everyone we could how tawdry the have made the experience simply so thet can maximise their profits

A dream come true. If you've ever studied architecture, you know this is a must see. Even a history buff or royalite would love this. Get there early, get in the credit card line to pay (it's a smaller line) and skip the audio guide initially upon entering. Just inhale and enjoy this beautiful Abbey and it's stunning architectural intricacies. Then grab an audio guide and learn about all you are seeing. Be sure though to really stop and absorb what you are reading, as these are dedications to loved ones, and are meant to be read. Oh, and the gift shop is worth a look. Go downstairs of the gift shop as well, especially if you are looking for one of a kind items or charms for a charm bracelet, as I was.

This is a Must See. We went on our own and I would suggest going early as the crowds get intense later in the day. this is a valuable piece of English history and not to visit this location would be not see the Grandeur that is London and the former British Empire. There are way too many historic people interned here than I would have time to list. The church itself is fantastic and like they say "they dont make them like that anymore" well worth a visit.

Amazing. Probably one of the best things we saw during our stay in London. It is amazing. I never knew that it was all that it is - I always thought it was just a church. Just a church, it is not. The chapel itself is beautiful, but the history and the tombs are incredible. The staff was very friendly and helpful to us, an well worth the money that it cost to get in.

Wanted to go but not at £32 for two people. We really wanted to visit this attraction as images of Kate and Williams wedding had been shown all over the world and theres so much more to see here than even just that. We arrived and could not believe when we saw it was £16 per person to get in,after all this is a church and was to our knowledge free to enter,With £32 fee for the two of us to get in to a church we decided that that was simply just robbery as its now the olympic season and obviously good time to rip off the tourists coming to london.We had decided that was easier to go back during the Sunday and visit during the services as this is free however you cant take pictures and obviously are more restricted in what you can see and do .Recommend that people go on the sunday and save a steep £16 entry fee.

Go on the Guided Tour. From the other views and guide books you know what to expect here. All I want to add is that it is well worth it to pay the extra for the guided tour. The guided point out many things I would have missed and added in fun details about events at the Abbey he had helped with, such as the royal wedding. Being on the tour is also the only way to see the tomb of William the Confessor.

Steeped in history - a must see!. Westminster Abbey was the highlight of my time in London. I was in awe of the incredible history of the abbey. I intend to go back again and spend an entire day there. Too amazing for words. Royalists will love it!

A hidden gem. A first visit for me to this attraction. It is an active church and you are welcomed to join in the services. The amount of history in one building is awe inspiring and quite difficult to take it all in. ~The free audio tour is a must, very informative and easy to use

Magnificient. Another amazing church with unbelievable history. I cannot believe they let you touch and tour such historical and amazing crypts. Another don't miss that didn't take but an hour or so to see.
Spectacular. So much history within the building. Surprised to find that there were so many non-royal, non-religious people buried here.
Living, breathing history. The feel of life in a magnificent building that has so much history

Too crowded!. All my life I had been wanting to go to Westminster Abbey, as it is steeped in so much history and tradition. I finally got there recently, and it was everything I expected. A beautiful, historic cathedral, amazing history.But the crowds! I booked, and arrived at the earliest possible time, so was almost the first person in that day. But the crowds were just allowed to pour in after me, and the experience suffered considerably by having to (politely) push and shove to move around. I am fortunate enough to be in Firenze as I write this, and visited the Duomo the other day. The numbers inside there are strictly limited (admittedly there is a resultant very long queue outside at times) and behavior strictly controlled - for example no loud talking is tolerated. The whole approach gives a much better experience for visitors.Dare I say it - perhaps the English could learn something from the Italians?But, back to the Abbey. Even if it is crowded make sure you go there. It is wonderful, despite the fact it is hard to find ways to avoid the crowds of other tourists!
JUST BEFORE THE WEDDING. Part of a great day. Saw it almost ready for the Royal wedding. Have a look round. You can take the audio tour and do it at you own speed!

If you love history and literature.... ...you MUST visit Westminster Abbey when in London. As others have said, it full of history. You can almost feel the ghosts of all those monarchs who were crowned there. And, of course, we've seen several royal weddings take place there -- most recently, Prince William and Catherine Middleton. I've been to the Abbey about 4 times, and my favorite part of the tour is Poet's Corner. As a voracious reader and lover of books, I'm always impatient to get to the place where so many literary figures are enshrined. Some are actually buried there; some are just commemorated -- like my favorite author, Jane Austen. Whatever the price of admission, it is very much worth it. As a New Yorker, I noticed an interesting contrast between my city and London: In London, the museums have free admission (though you can give a donation if you wish); the churches charge for admission. In New York it's the opposite. The churches are free; the museums charge admission. Anyway, go to Westminster Abbey. You'll be missing a lot if you don't.

Steeped in history, grand religious house.. As my title says. The abbey is steeped in a huge amount of history and I'm very proud we have this. I dO think it is a little over priced at £16 per adult with then areas to donate maybe around £10 would have been enough. I obviously understand that the have huge mantaince and staff bills. The abbey was incredibly busy for a weekday but however I dO suggest you pick up a free audio guide. It's very well explained and you can move through the abbey at your own pace. Amazing Place to visit. However I'm not sure about the mixed toilet facilities they offer??
Incredible history. Well-known and well-worth the price of admission. You can move at your own pace. The architecture, art, and history here are phenomenal. Well-done.

Save the money and attend service. As a student travelling in London, I looked for any way to save money and still see as much as possible. Instead of paying a lot of pounds to explore the Abbey, I attended Evensong one evening for free, since it's a church service. You can't explore all over, but you are able to experience a different side of the Abbey. It's about 40 mins long and you sit through some prayers and the amazing choir sings a few songs. You sit for the service, but you're able to look around and see a lot of the inside of the Abbey from your seat. If your interested, check the Westminster Abbey website a few days beforehand to check the times.Even though I am not religious, it was an amazing experience and I'll never forget it.

Full of history but not that great. The building is very interesting and huge, and inside you will found tons of history. Some beautiful statues and tombs, but with the crowds you sometimes need to walk faster than you would want, and to be sincere I was bored after a little while. It's a little expensive too, but for the first-time London tourist is a must-see.

Impressive to the last stone. Recently cleaned and looking even better than it did 10 years ago. High vault, great chapter hgouse and clisters, excellent east end, reredos, many famous people buried here. Magnificient Organ and choir - catch a week day service - you won't regret it - but make sure to sit in the choir if you can - the sound is superb. Make sure to visit the Cathedral just down the road (towards Victria station) another gem

Rich in history but limited access. Another one of those must see places, even if it's just to put a checkmark next to it on the list of historical sites. A very impressive building with so many monuments inside it that it feels more like a museum that has outgrown it's space than a church.In order to visit it, you have to be willing to wait in line for a while and then, once in, you have to be willing to follow the crowd. By far the place I preferred was the inner courtyard where one can actually feel that this place was meant for contemplation.Certainly a "been there, done that" sort of place
Historic and fantastic. A must see in England, close to Parliament and lots of important points of view in London, son can't miss it. Beautiful and 100% well conserved.

Allow a decent amount of time. Give yourself a decent amount of time at the Abbey as it is a big site, with a lot to see. We had to queue for about 30mintues to get in but it was a Saturday on May bank holiday. It was an impressive building with interesting history although if im being completey honest got a little bored half way round.

Unique historical site. Very much a tourist attraction and not cheap. Busy (Tuesday lunch-time) but not so that it was a problem - I imagine it is too busy at peak season for enjoyment. The audio guide was pretty good with helpfully short items on the main things to see. To get the most out of a single visit you probably need to read a guidebook first. Chapter House was closed - but no reduction in ticket price. Refreshments are very limited (compared say to St Pauls Cathedral).

Now I've been there, done that - crossed off the list. Visited on a cold May afternoon with drizzle outside, so maybe that made the place so crowded. Shame that people do not observe that this is a place that requires respect, so not many places for quiet contemplation, but the history can almost be touched in this fantastic, impressive historic building.
One of your must. Entrance fee is quite expensive but worth it. The audioguide its very interesting too and included with the entrance ticket. Spend 1-2 hours in it.

History in every nook and cranny. Take a pocket book and cram 2000 years of history, biographies, images and artefacts into it. The result is Westminster Abbey. Depending on the way you look at it, this can be either cramped or spectacular. For me, it was both. It was a spectacular and very alive introduction to the English monarchy, the church and history. The tombs, crypts, artefacts of monarchy, burials of luminaries such as Newton, fantastic stained glass windows... the list is endless. I spent about 5 hours exploring the place and still believe there was more to this place. Note the visitor timings - I was the last one to enter, past 12.30, more due to the sympathy of the guard at the entrance and one of the last to leave, at 5.00. The audio guide is a must - without this you will be lost and likely miss many of the spots. Do not miss the huge stained glass windows. Photography is prohibited inside the Abbey, but you can pick up the excellent guidebook - pricey as usual, at the souvenir store. The souvenir store has some interesting knick knacks, but nothing you will not find elsewhere, at a cheaper price. Budget atleast 3 hours to do any justice - I took 5.

Westminster Abbey: immerse yourself in history. Nearest underground:St James's Park (District and Circle Lines) and Westminster (Jubilee, District & Circle Lines). We took District (green) line to the Westminster stop. Take some time before you go in and walk around, take in the amazing detail everywhere -- all the statuary, gargoyles, grotesques....TIP: When you go in (East side) there are two lines: one for cash only (left side) and one for credit cards only (right side). When the lines are long & there are crowds it's hard to see the small signs on where you go to queue up & pay. Although the lines looked long, we only stood outside for about 5 -10 minutes. 16 pounds per adult. **NOTE: NO pictures are allowed inside, which is nice both out of respect to worship & the dead, but also no one would ever be able to get anywhere if they allowed them. Upon entering you can pick up a free audio guide - laughed a bit as it is Jeremy Iron's voice for the audio guide. The audio guide is a nice additional bit of info & history if you don't take the guided tour. (We didn't take the tour, just walked around ourselves and it still took 3+ hours.) Take your time and take a deep breathe to deal with the crowds....The Abbey has many, many small chapels and nooks to see - hard thing is the way in is the way out too - barely wide enough for one person - so get used to scooting sideways and giving looks to people who try to stop in the doorway and talk(really?)Take time to go through all the chapels and rooms - amazing detail & history everywhere. Interesting that there can be detailed shrines & coffins so ornate - for someone who was "only" a merchant or businessman -- if you had the money, you could buy yourself a place in the most prestigious church in England. Fun to read the stories of the families and look at the ornate, rococo details, cherubs, coffins, pillars, paintings and more. Look Down! Everywhere you & everyone else will be walking on coffins/ crypts and dedications. Whilst sometimes hard to get people to move & see - take the time- there are some amazing stories and dates on the floor. In the floor, just inside the great west door, in the centre of the nave, is the tomb of The Unknown Warrior, an unidentified British soldier killed on a European battlefield during the First World War. He was buried in the Abbey on 11 November 1920. There are many graves on the floors of the Abbey, but this is the only grave upon which it is forbidden to step.The audio tour and plaques help with the "main" focus of the main part of the Abbey - the coffins of the great Kings & Queens of England. Edward the Confessor (founder of the church), Richard the II, Richard the III, Mary Queen of Scots, Henry the II, Henry the V, Elanor of Aquitaine, Elizabeth I - with her death mask used on the carvings on top --- those and many more are there to see. Take the time to step back, reflect and realize what you're getting to view. Take time in one of the larger areas to look at all the crests for the knights of the garter on the large poles and banners - there are some standard ones and some really funny / curious ones ( a fish, a loch ness monster, an ostrich.....)There is the "Poet's Corner" as well where you can see famous writers who are buried there: Chaucer was the first to be interred there in 1400....Shakespeare, T.S. Eliot, Lord Byron, Spenser, Ben Johnson, Rudyard Kipling, Tennyson. There are also a great number of memorials there to writers (buried elsewhere): WH Auden, Jane Austen, the Brontes and more. Sir Laurence Olivier is also buried there. Take time to walk around the nave and other areas as well - we saw some areas bombed in the siege of WWII and learned some great history along the way. The coronation chair is also there --The Coronation Chair was made on the orders of King Edward I in 1300–1 to enclose the Stone of Scone (also called the Stone of Destiny), which he had brought from Scotland in l296 and placed in the care of the Abbot of Westminster. Until the removal of the Stone to Scotland in 1996 the Chair was the oldest piece of furniture in England still used for the purpose for which it was made. Pretty neat!There was a small cafe in the abbey as well and a very small gift shop. Most of the Abbey is not wheelchair accessible/ friendly and even those with other ambulatory issues (canes, etc) may have some challenges walking around the tiny areas. I can see that this would not be very interesting for your average kid under, say 10-12. We didn't do the guided tour, but sometimes were in the same area and gained some insight - so the tours may be well worth it. Took us 3+ hours and we definitely could have stayed longer.
More than I thought.. This was an interesting tour, and I had no idea the wealth of history in this building. I am happy that they don't allow photos because you would never get out if they did.

Must see! :). Very interesting place with its own history.There were a lot of people and the entrance fee was a bit high (for me as a student), but I think, you have to visit this place, one of the biggest symbols of London.

Wow for everyone -- believe me!. When I went to Westminster Abbey, I did not expect much -- I am not a keen 'sight-seeing' toursist, I normally get bored quickly after stepping into any tourist attraction. I took my friends to the Abbey because they wanted to (not I wanted to) --- but surprise surprise I found the place really interesting. All the very well-known/famous people buried there -- I know it sounds pretty daft, but all these famous writers/poet/politicians etc were all born in different places in different times but they were all buried in this place - quite interesting. Architect was great, history behind the place was interesting, a list of people who were buried there was impressive. Although it is not cheap to get in, it is definitely worth getting in and having a look inside.

get there early. a must-see in London. 16 pounds was very worth the visit, which includes the audio guide. Although they have a specified path through the Abbey, you can take all the time you need and go backwards if necessary.

A spectacular yet crowded church!. Westminster Abbey is a Gothic monastery church in London, located next to the Big Ben and House of Parliament. It is the traditional place of coronation (all English monarchs since the coronation of William the Conqueror have been crowned here, except Lady Jane Grey, Edward V and Edward VIII) and burial for 13 English monarchs (since the time of Edward the Confessor until the death of George II in 1760, most Kings and Queen of English were buried here) and national figures (Charles Darwin, Sir Isaac Newton, David Livingstone and Charles Dickens). It is neither a cathedral nor a parish church, but a “Royal Peculiar” under the jurisdiction of a Dean and Chapter, subject only to the Sovereign and not to any archbishop or bishop, in short it is a place of worship owned by the Royal Family. Since 1100, there have been at least 16 Royal Weddings at Westminster Abbey, including the latest royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton.My first impression of this UNESCO World Heritage site was during the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales and second was the royal wedding of Prince William. The Abbey seems smaller then. My first question when I entered was “Well, this is what the British called a church? It is spectacular and huge (or crowded as more than a thousand people were buried here)”. You would find something worth observing/admiring/exploring at almost every corner as there are 611 monuments excluding the graves and memorial stones on the floor. I've got no comments on whether it was worth the money to visit or not but i could certainly share the conversation i overheard and the information i found. While waiting for my turn to show my London Pass (so that i don't have to pay), I’d heard one tourist asked a staff why do we need to pay to visit the Abbey? The staff politely advised him that he is welcome to take part in the daily services free of charge and may proceed to the links to the lefts to find out more about worship at the Abbey. In addition, he may also enter the Cloisters, College Garden and St Margaret’s Church free of charge. I found out later that the Abbey really does not charge people who want to worship (so you get in for free after the regular opening hours for Evensong at 5pm on weekday and 3pm on weekend) but do rely almost entirely on paying visitors and tourists to cover running costs as it receives no funding from the Crown, the Church or the State. So kudos to everyone who visited the Abbey, you have done a good deed by simply visiting it (me too)!Highlights:i) The Shrine of St. Edward the Confessor with various British royalty tombs and the historic coronation throne nearby;ii) The statue of the Virgin Mary holding a baby Jesus;iii) The Henry VII’s Chapel (aka Lady Chapel) built 1503 to 1512, with a magnificent vault.iv) The tombs and monuments of the famous;v) The cloisters originally built in the 13th century;vi) The beautiful octagonal Chapter house with original tile floor dating from 1250; andvii) The Nave with the grave of the unknown warrior.Important information:i) Open daily 9:30am to 4:30pm (last admission 3:30pm), except Wednesday till 7pm (last admission 6pm) and Saturday till 2:30pm (last admission 1:30pm). Closed on Sunday (for worship only), religious holidays and December 24 to 26;ii) Admission fee is applicable at £16 for adult, £6 for children 11 to 18 and free for child under 11. Free of charge with London Pass (but no skip-the-line priority);iii) Free admission to the Museum, Cloisters (you can find kiosk in the north cloister with souvenirs, books, food and drink for purchase), College Garden (Tues to Thursday only) and St. Margaret’s Church with the admission ticket to the Abbey;iv) A Children’s Trail (in English) is available free at the information desk as you enter the Abbey, and children are able to dress up as monks and have their photo taken in the Cloisters (Go to the the Abbey Museum and ask to borrow a costume); And lavatories are situated in the exit near Poet’s Corner. v) Large or bulky items, such as rucksacks, suitcases and bagpacks are prohibited. Leave it in your hotel or else you may be asked to leave it at the left luggage facilities operated nearby;vi) Audioguides are available free of charge.

Special events. I have had the opportunity to attend a few celebratory special events here. The Abbey has dignity and gravitas for these. Otherwise, it's definitely something for tourists to see, but not the most exciting religious building in London (St Paul's outshines it by a mile).

1,000 Years of History. If you want to see where all the coronations and several royal wedding have happened plus visit the tombs of kings, queens, writers, actors, scientist and musicians, this is a must see.Be prepared for a long queue (and make sure you are in the right one - there is one for cash & a separate one for credit/debit). Once you are in you will receive a very basic map and a free audio guide. I don't usually like audio guides but this one was easy to use and simple to follow. As an added bonus, it was narrated by Jeremy Irons! My only complaint about the guide was it really skimmed the surface of what there is too see. Understandable as there are so many memorials/tombstones and works of art. My advice it to do some research beforehand or take the time to stop and look around. There are also guided tours but I think they cost more.Also be forewarned, the washrooms are hard to find and there will be another queue. There is a good gift shop and a 'coffee club' where you can enjoy drinks, sandwiches, soup & deserts looking out onto the cloisters. Not much seating though and it is on stone benches.
A bit samey. I won't do it again (£21 each). Just too many tombs for me all crammed in! History was interesting but I didn't think it was worth the money - but hey! it's a world heritige site.

Absolutely Beautiful. I can definate see why there are some many famous weddings here. It is gourgeous - lots of staques and tombs of famous people here as well. My husband and I were also fortunate enough to be able to take communion here. The services are free and open to the public. I definately recommend at least an hour here its a lot to take in. The architecture is in stark contrast to St. Pauls. Its definately a close call regarding which is more beautiful.

Can't be missed. You can feel the history and revel in the peace and quiet of a walk through the Abbey. The audio guide is a must (and included in the entry fee). Take a seat and absorb the atmosphere.

Historical London. A great way to see the Abbey and other notable attractions such as the Tower of London & St. Paul's Cathedral is to buy a London Pass. It gives you reduced rates to approximately 55 different attractions including a Thames River cruise and in many cases gives you rights to go to the head of the line for entrance. London is an outstanding city and easy to get around. Check out London Pass on your browser.

Not just for the religious. I'm not a religious person but I am a history buff. Westminster Abbey should be on the must-see list for anyone interested in English history. The Abbey itself is enormous and beautiful. It's the resting place for many English royals and you will be able to view their tombs. The audio tour is an excellent way to get the most from your visit. Tip: get there early and avoid the crowds because it gets very busy.

You have to see it to understand the scale. We loved our visit to Westminster Abby. If you have an ounce of love for the royal family, and all the pomp and ceremony, you have to see the Abby to visualize all that has transpired here over history. We loved seeing where it has all happened; we also loved the garden, which is really beautiful. A tranquil place in the middle of London. It is great that the ticket price includes an audio tour, which brings the visit to life.We had underestimated the crowds, and it would be great to wish them away.... but of course we made up some of that crowd. Also it is disappointing that photo's inside are prohibited, even without a flash.Still a have to see on a London visit.

Disappointing and expensive. You can't deny that Westminster Abbey is spectacular. And this is what made our visit so disappointing. As London residents my husband and I frequently pass by and often say we should visit (in fact we've attempted to do so before, but gave up after queuing for a long time).We arrived yesterday and despite being slightly surprised at the high entrance fee (£16 per adult), we picked up our audio guide and looked forward to the visit.All I can say is that the audio guide is superficial and sporadic. Very little detail is given on many of the historical figures buried there and there is very little reference to architectural features. For example, a stone commemorating Oliver Cromwell is completely overlooked in a 90 second description of the RAF Chapel; a 45 second description of the tomb of Henry VII and Elizabeth of York fails to explain the political significance of their marriage and the description of the tomb containing Mary I and Elizabeth I makes no mention of Henry VIII's marriage to the mothers and the implications of his divorce for religious reform in England.Overall we came away with the impression that the audio guide was designed to propel visitors through the abbey as quickly as possible - with an emphasis on keeping visitors moving, rather than trying to explain the history of the Abbey. Last year we visited St Paul's and had been hugely impressed by its audio guide - which had so much detail that after 4 hours we still hadn't completed the tour. Westminster Abbey should learn from this. At present, it fails to cater for any visitor hoping to achieve more than crossing it off a "things to do in London" list.To any tourists with time just to visit one cathedral while in London, I'd recommend heading straight for St Paul's.

Too much to take in. I have visited Westminister Abbey several times before and as always I am ober awed by what is in it. Certainly a catalogue of the extensive history of England. Make sure to plan your visit. Last admissions are at 3.30 and it is not always open to the public. Read about it before your visit, maybe do a search to find out if any of your heros are buried or memorialized there and search out their tomb. The Abbey is very busy, especially by the entry door, but noone minds if you stop and check things out in more detail.

First Rate!. I love to go to Westminster Abbey. I always find something different when I go on the verger tour. This time was no different. The verger was interesting and knew a lot about the Abbey and the history of the UK as a whole. I would tell everyone who goes to London to stop in and see it.

A walk through history. If the architecture doesn't knock you out, then the history will. And if you have a question and ask a person in a cape, you will get chapter and verse on the story and backstory of anything and any person (dead or alive) in the Abbey. The place just knocks me out.

Worth the $$. My teen girls were not excited about this stop on my itinerary, we are not church goers, they saw the long line etc. We recommend taking the audio guide AND a map, it got a bit confusing when we headed to the garden. The place is just stunning, the history contained in this place is overwhelming. The girls loved seeing the markers for authors they had read people whose work they had studied - Darwin etc. The liked little tidbits about feuding Queens etc. I wish I had done a bit more research on my own as they asked questions that I could not answer and there was no one to ask. There were 2 lines - one for cash and the cash line moved much faster! If you want a more in depth tour I recommend London Walks - a great walking tour company.

One of the best London attractions. It is steeped in history... Only go if you have the time to take in everything, it is truly one of the most beautiful and interesting buildings I have ever visited....from the suprises of whom is buried there to the architecture.... Amazing....

Outstanding. My wife and I spent 3 hours in the afternoon of April 9, 2012, slowly walking the entire site, although we were too late in the day to see the museum room. The place was absolutely magnificent!! Whether you are interested in history or not, this is a must see for anyone visiting London. From the architecture to the multitudes of famous people that are buried there, it is mezmorizing. We found the accompanying hand-held audio tour interesting and a must when you visit. Well worth the 16 pounds per person, especially on a rainy day.

Wonderful. We went in April of 2012, it is a wonder I agree, but after seeing so many other fantastic things in London, we found it a bit expensive for the amount of time we were there. You only need an hour or so to see it all and at 32 pounds for a couple it was a bit much. We went to the Notre Dam in Paris and it is free to get in. I am not opposed to paying but this was a tad rich.

Organ recital and service for free. If you want to visit the Abbey and dont want to pay, go along as a worshiper. Oran recital was on at 5:45 and you can stay on for the short service (30 minutes) which starts at 6:30. Just lovely
Magnificant. Awesome. I didn't realise there were so many famous people buried there. Certainly didnt know Elizabeth 1 and Mary Queen of Scots are there.

Outstanding!. That's a place you should visit in london! Huge place and definitely worth to see. Have in mind that the Abbey closes at 2pm, so you should go at least one hour before to have the time to go around.
such a beautiful place. one of the wonders of the world,a must visit while in london,easy to reach by london transport

super friendly staff. Was on the London eye and when children asked what building that was pointing at Westminster Abbey , after telling them they asked if they could go as they were doing the Tudors at school. Cost (when we went summer 2011) adults charge under 16 free. As soon as I was meet by a helper who gave the children a clipboard and survey for them to do as going round. This is a great idea kept them busy and asking questions all staff happy to answer and when we got to the Royal area a member of staff took the girls to where the Queen sits and let them sit there they were very chuffed. They found out so much history it was well worth the visit. Thought i would be only there for hour or 2 but stayed for 4 ..

Take Thee to the Abbey. This review is based on a visit to London more than a year ago: I've visited just about every major tourist site in London and this one was always at the top of my list of things to see.If you sightsee like I do, and you've got the time, you will choose one or two major sights and spend the day enjoying them. Leave enough time to get through the line up at the entrance (not so bad during the week), take the guided tour, re-trace your steps at your own pace and spend some time reading all the plaques and markers. There are so many famous people from history who have graced the halls of the Abbey and who are buried there that a quick 1hr in-and-out tour just won't cut it.I'm amazed at what people complain about when on vacation but I can assure you that the entrance fee is worth it and the fact that you can't take photos in the church should not detract from the grandeur of your visit. You'll be able to take photos (like I did) in the cloisters and you'll always know where they came from and smile fondly at the memory.Definitely a must see!

A basket full of history. From the onset of queuing, you know this is a british attraction ! Visitors are speedily dealt with at the credit card counter, they were a little slow in informing queuing persons that the cash counter was further round. Anyway once equipped with an audio tour the history lesson begins. Being versed in wayfinding and orientation etc it became a niggle that the numbers on the brouchure were not specific enough for the audio tour. At one particular number the coronation chair was supposed to be positioned, but we hunted high and low to no avail. The shop and food were discretely located, but the toilets were even more hidden (if there were any) a shame as all tourists have a need once in a while! The amount of history was immense and being British my chest felt rather more puffed up than usual.It is thirty years since I last visited and I am glad I made the effort this time, especially at Easter time. It is a shame that photographs are not allowed.

Don't miss!. There is so much history attached to the Abbey that you must see it while in London. St. Paul's is more beautiful on the inside, but there are many stories here. You cannot skip the queue with a London Pass, but use the cash payment side since it moves more quickly (it is on the left side when looking towards the entrance). Some areas were off limits for restoration, but we still spent a couple of lovely hours here.
Fabulous experience although very crowded. Fabulous and steeped in history , the children's trail made it very interesting and you saw more than you might have done without the children.
Church of queens and kings. Worthy of all the talk and full of historical celebrities!

The history here is breathtaking.. The entry charge looked pretty steep to me at first but I found that it included the hire of an audio guide. This is much better than at the tower of London where the hire of a giude is on top of the allready steep entry charge. I found the audio giude great . It was narrated by Jeremy Irons who's voice is clear as a bell. The information was consice and to the point. The toumbs of all the various Kings and Queens was very impressive but I was most impressed by Poets corner. We visited the Cathedral at 2pm and there were no queues but I believe that if you visit early there can be an uncomfortable crowd. So go later.

An 'OH WOW' moment. We caught the tube to St James station and approached the abbey amazed at the architectural detail. Joined the queue (before opening time) which already had at least 20 people by the time we got there. We bought our tickets and collected our audio guide and then looked up and around. OH WOW!!! The audio guide was a valuable tool enabling us to fully understand what we were seeing. At ground level, there were tombs and plaques indicating the kings, queens and various famous people who were buried within the the abbey. Looking up, we saw the most amazing masonry and ornate timberwork on the gothic vaulted ceilings. No photography was allowed which disappointed DH so as we left, we added another booklet to our collection.

This cathedral is awesome!. The audio guide was great, but only gives small snipets and does not cover all the points of interest on the guide map. But the cathedral is the draw and is well worth waiting for the queues to enter. A pre-pay option would help out some with crowds, I think.
Glorious!. A beautiful church filled with history! Not to be missed!!

To me, this is a must-visit in London. Westminster Abbey is flat-out an amazing place to visit, but allow yourself several hours or else you'll be rushed. It is a one-stop shop that surpasses pretty much any other place for historical-impact-per-square-meter - there is an informative audio tour that talks you through all the statues and crypts and tombs and historical memorabilia, and my kids (9 and 7) and I really, really enjoyed it. My daughter just finished reading some historical fiction about Queen Elizabeth I as a child so was excited to see her tomb, and my son recognized many names, as well, and was impressed that they were all gathered together. There's also a fun "scavenger hunt" kind of sheet that directs them to answer questions about various spots in the Abbey to keep them reading / listening to the tour, and they were so engaged in it that they were upset because we had to leave early so they couldn't finish. The Abbey's very close to Big Ben and Parliament, too, so it's a good tourist stop, generally - not much to eat nearby, though, so be sure to plan accordingly. You have to walk quite a ways to get to find anything...

Highlight of London. Westmister Abbey was the highlight of our trip to London. I am not a religious person, but was totally humbled by this place. Our visit was not long after the Royal Wedding, and I loved knowing that I was standing where only weeks ago where the eyes of the world were focussed. It was busy on the day we visited, but we were expecting that being a bank holiday in summer. Can not recommend Westmister Abbey enough.

Full of history. Westminster Abbey is so full of history it will take your breath away. If you get the chance speak to some of the volunteers who work there, they have some great knowledge of the place and it will give a new dimension on your visit. We went here for a few minutes and ended up staying hours. The best church in London.

Rude staff and overpriced. Considering the cost of a family visit to the Abbey, one would have hoped not to be treated rudely by staff. After being pushed and shoved by a large group as we tried to queue up for devices for the self-guided tour, we were then insulted by the individual handing out the devices, who also made rude remarks about Americans in general. We began our visit being made to feel most unwelcome in this house of God. To be shaken down for almost $100 and then mocked did not make for a pleasant visit at all. For the rest of the visit we continued to be pushed, shoved and knocked as the crowds of people forced themselves into small spaces. One of the devices we were given malfunctioned, but after how terribly we were treated we were afraid to go back and ask for another.
Great for history. A wonderful place to vist, just so much history contained within he Abbey walls. Very moving to just sit & have prayer.

Unique. I have been here any number of times. It is absolutely unique in the same way as St Peters in Rome, and I am not talking in any religious way. Its history pours out as you walk around. My favourite spot is Poets Corner. If you are visiting London this is a must visit, and then also see St Pauls.
Westminster fun. Absolutely breathtaking. A must. Go early and avoid the lines.
Quaint. Quanit? Beautiful? It's just another church.......others around the world are much more impressive; however, this is nice & worth a visit
expensive. Very expensive for a family, not really what I would have charged for a place of worship. Nice photo on the outside, grounds are nice, but closes at 3:30pm for last admission.

Words cannot describe. Westminster Abbey is truly gorgeous. It's beautiful inside and out, and there is so much to look at. There is a huge amount of extremely famous and important people buried here, and you'll have to go yourself-touring the Abbey was a great experience!!

A must see!. A must see from the outside and inside! The free audio tour is good, would highly recommend it so you are not passing by some important tombs or statues. Can do this site in 1.5-2 hours. Amazing architecture and attention to detail. be sure to check the main web site for any scheduled closings due to maintenance or what not. I have been twice and would go again with other visitors. There is wheelchair/stroller access for most of the abbey but not all parts. I did not feel like I missed out on much with a stroller.

Huge Cemetery. Lots of history. I'd never guess that so many people if buried around and inside the Abbey. The history there is not dead, as the bodies. The history is still alive, and is impressive! There is various sections: Sirs, Dukes, Barons, Poets, Scientists (Darwin, Newton, Maxwell...), Musicians (Handel) and many monks . Kings and Queens are buried there too, and one of the most famous is Elisabeth I, the "Virgin Queen". Worth each pound the visit!!

A Must-See London Attractions. A friend from Portugal and I visited Westminster Abbey in late March of this year. I had been there before (in 1978) and thoroughly enjoyed it but wanted to see it again, especially since my friend had only seen it from the outside on a previous visit. The abbey is rich in history and beautiful throughout! We had an excellent audio tour of the abbey and loved seeing it this way. The royal tombs alone make this a must-see attraction for anyone interested in British history!

Evensong is a beautiful alternative to being a tourist. We attended the afternoon service of Evensong and it was a beautiful experience to be welcomed into Westminster Abbey by the clergy and the clergy staff and to experience Westminster as a living breathing thing. The head of the clergy even stood at the door and greeted everyone one by one as we were leaving. A lovely inspiring service with exquisite music which made us forget about the tourist madness playing out just outside the Abbey's doors.

The Past & the Present - not to miss experience!. Really visited Westminster Abbey - sat through House of Commons & House of Lords sessions! Very easy to get in, the queues were not too long and the authorities really control the movement well. Could admire the old architecture and also witness the Government at work.
Beautiful to behold. If you like old, gothic looking,definitely go here. There is so much to take in. Words can not describe the beauty of this place.
this was sooo cool. This sight was amazing and beautiful. We did the audio tour so we learned all about everything we saw. It was beautiful and would do it again.
beautiful church!. too bad no pictures are allowed but it is a beautiful place. Sir Isaac Newton is buried there (I had no clue!)Friendly volunteers eager to answer questions!

Amazing Place. Step into an historical marvel at Westminster Abbey. With over 3,000 people buried within the abbey, from kings and queens to poets and statesmen, it's an incredible journey through history. In order to take the fullest advantage of it, arrive early and spend the extra 3 pounds per person to take the verger guided tour. While you wait for the tour (which runs every hour or so), grab an audio guide and explore the various naves around the main alter, as these are not covered by the guided tour. The vergers do a wonderful job of leading you through the main parts of the abbey, including several ares that are only accessible with the tour. They provide detailed explanations of the history of the abbey, a good slug of english history, coronations, royal weddings & funerals, etc. Plan on 2 to 3 hours for your visit and enjoy.

Number One Sight in London. This is the quintessential place in London to visit. It combines incredible historical importance with majesty, spirituality and architectural beauty. There is so much to see that you could spend hours here, admiring the intricately carved choir, locating the burial places of history's most significant scientists, artists and political leaders, and gazing at the beautiful stained glass windows. On top of that, it has perhaps the best gift shop in London. It's an absolute don't miss.
snap. real photo op and a beautiful building plus close to the London eye

Amazing and Awsome, Must See London Institution. Architecturally amazing. The thought of the Coronations, the weddings the splendour all happening here is overwhelming when you think about it. Must see !

History and familiarity. Many of us have seen Westminster Abbey as the site of Princess Diana's funeral and Prince William and Kate Middleton's wedding - viewed from out television screens. However, the building has far more to offer and a visit makes this abundantly clear. Read something about the history before visiting and you will double your enjoyment. I thought that the price was reasonable. The control over the number of visitors allowed in at a time gave me the opportunity to see everything I wanted at my leisure.

They could do whatever they want.... ... probably nothing could go wrong with this sight. I have been to London a million time, but can never get enough of the Westminster Abbey. So much history, such amazing architecture, it's simply working. It's worth paying attention to the hidden details, like the oldest door in Britain to get the full experience.

Expensive, as we only wanted to see one exhibition, not the whole Abbey. We actually wanted to go to the aviation museum, as it features one of our ancestors. But I didn't expect it to be nearly 40 pounds to get in. Many other people looked at the entry fee and turned away also.

An overworked word, but “awesome”. When you see Westminster Abbey on the TV for state occasions, you know how small (compared to say St Pauls) is the public area of seating for events. What you don’t get to see is how big the whole Abbey complex really is.You need at least two to two and a half hours to do this visit justice. And it is truly “awesome” because I doubt that there is any other place in the UK that has as much history to the square foot packed into it. What with the tombs of Kings and Queens and tombs of and memorials to poets, composers and other significant figures, it really is quite mind blowing. Everywhere that you look is another piece of history; look down occasionally too, because you never quite know who you might be walking over!The audio guide that is included in the admission is pretty good, but cannot in any way cover everything, so don’t be afraid to ask questions of the many staff placed around the Abbey. If I had not done this I would not have learned that the magnificently decorated tomb painted with medieval heraldic devices , but with absolutely no inscriptions anywhere, is the tomb of the Standard Bearer to Henry V. Check it out, it is just to the left before you go up steps into the Lady Chapel, and it is beautiful.

The Abbey...more like Westminster Crabby. How could I not visit the Abbey that Joey from the tv show Friends was so excited about? Westminster Abbey has been, with a couple of exceptions, the setting for every coronation since since 1066, and it is here on April 29, 2011, that Prince William married Kate Middleton. The present church mostly 13th century and it's 98 foot nave is the tallest in the country. Well worth the visit and make sure and do the audio tour.

A Must See. This was one stop on our itinerary that was a definite must see. There is a real sense of history at this cathedral. You should allocate about 4 hours for this visit. We took the self guided audio tour which provided a good explanation to all areas of the cathedral. You can look around at amazement and see all the famous people that are buried here. We are glad we visited here and highly recommend this as a London destination. It is located near the Parliament building so you should do both on the same day.
great wedding. the plethora of famous and insignificant dead folk cramming themselves into a small a place as possible is quite amazing. Bit like celebrity big brother for the dead.
Beautiful. I can't review this place. It is amazing. A must see.

Worth the steep entry fee. I baulked in the past at paying the entry fee but went for it this time. You get an audio guide which is very well done and the tour took about 2 hours. Very informative and enjoyable.

Is there another place like this?. I am not a British history buff in the least, but i couldn't help be amazed at the centuries of rich history contained in this magnificent abbey. Do the verger led tour. He got us into all sorts of areas others didn't have quick access to. And his command of the history was unsurpassed. There were crowds, but it didn't feel crowded on the tour.
Contains a who's who of dead Brits. Busy spot! The audio tour is good, it walks you through in logical flow and offers good explanations.

Unique Pageant of British History - Coronations, Royal Weddings and Burials. Westminster Abbey was founded in 960 and stands near the Embankment at Westminster, opposite the Houses of Parliament between Victoria Street and Abingdon Street.
