It's Lantern Tower stands tall, and nestled at its foot is St. Margaret's Church. It is expensive to go in for a tour, which takes about two hours. Sixteen pounds sterling or approx. CAD$25.00. But it is worth it as you will discover many fascinating, historical treasures inside. Besides, when will you be coming this way again. Originally a Benedictine monastery, Kind Edward (later Edward the Confessor) greatly enlarged it into a large stone church. His magnificent tomb sits behind the High Altar. The coronation of William the Conqueror took place in 1066, and every monarch since has been crowned here. The Coronation Chair dates back to this first coronation. The Abbey is the burial place of kings (Henry III,Edward I, Edward III, Richard II, Henry V), statesmen, poets (William Shakespeare, Charles Dickens, William Blake, Robert Burns, Lord Byron, John Keats, Rudyard Kipling, John Milton, William Wordsworth), scientists (Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin), warriors (grave of the Unknown Warrior is now a place of pilgrimage) and musicians (Henry Purcell). The Abbey is also home to choristers (WA Choir), an organist, scholars (Westminster School). The glorious Lady chapel was built by King Henry VII, first of the Tudor monarchs. Queen Elizabeth I is buried in the north aisle. It boasts the Battle of Britain memorial window by Hugh Easton. The Abbey contains over 600 monuments and wall tablets, and over three thousand people are buried here.

Awesome. This was incredible and beautiful. I had no idea how intricate and beautiful it would be. The history was amazing as was the audio guide. Well worth the trip.
Something to think about if going to London - purchase a London Pass - well worth the money!
Did not want to leave.. Mesmerizing place! The history sort of sucks you in. I want to go back...
History Seeps thru every brick. An amazing place to visit -- steeped in History and folk lore. Need to really spend time here

Amazing amount of History. Visited on a busy Saturday morning and used the Audio Tour which is very informative. Amazing amount of history in one building,
Would like to return again when the gardens are open and also take the verger tour.
Worth the wait in line. Absolutely beautiful. Pictures do not do this place justice. However, the wait in line is ridiculously long and that was on a weekday!

If you visit London - visit Westminster Abbey. Just go and see this fantastic site. If you have the slightest interest in British history you will not be disappointed.
The entry cost is £16 , remember to collect you audio guide which explains it all
Well preserved. A good travel back in time, you can feel the centuries passing by.
It's a gorgeous place. Think Will and Kate but better. It's an iconic destination.

We had a wonderful visit to the abbey. I agree with previous reviewers that you want to avoid visiting Westminster Abbey when the crowds are bad. Jeremy Irons (who narrates the great audio tour which is included in the price of admission - currently 16 pounds) alludes to this when he stated at one point that "you may not be able to get into this area of the Abbey"! However, luckily, when we were there, the crowds were not at all bad, and we had a ton of space to really appreciate this wonderful building. So much history really makes you feel small, but it is truly wonderful to visit the place where all of England's kings and queens have been crowned. Well worth the small admission price, especially in a city where many of the best attractions are free.

Don't go when it is busy. To be honest I have no idea what Westminster Abbey is like inside. I have been told it is spectacular and the cards make it look lovely. But in my experience the interior is dark, grey, and mostly made of synthetic fabrics. I only ever saw the backs of the other tourists as we were snaked through the building like a very busy day at Ikea. Being only 5'6" probably didn't help, and having to queue for ages to get in and even longer to get out didn't help my mood. Perhaps if at the end of the experience I had some memories of a few stunning carvings it may have been worthwhile but sadly all I remember is just how many people were wearing grey synthetic coats. My kids of course hated it with a passion! If you can find a day when there are few other tourists then it might be worth a visit but otherwise I would give it a wide berth.

Charming and beautiful. The history behind this amazing Abbey takes your breath away, with special dedications and great stories. Take the tour, it's the best way of getting to everything. The architecture is beyond impressive. A fantastic visit.
Another great Church. Take your time here with the audio guides, you'll discover a lot about this beautiful place. Another London must see!

Packed with history and pageantry. Awesome site, full of historically significant tombs of kings, queens, politicians, war heroes, scientists, and poets. Anyone who has made their mark in a significant way in Britain is likely buried here. No photos inside.
Amazing place. So much has happened at the Abbey, so much history. When you get inside, the place embraces you with all that has happened there.

Amazing history. Really enjoyed visiting Westminster and can highly recommend paying the extra to go on a guided tour. Were able to see parts of the abbey not open to the public. Go early to avoid long lines.
Do the Tour. Magnificent but do the tour. I studied British History but I couldn't believe how much I learnt by doing the tour. Worth every penny.

Too expensive. Came here with my brother and sister (25 and 21) who were visiting from Oz. We took the audio tour and spent about half an hour carefully inspecting and educating ourselves on all the nooks and crannies but then totally got bored and sped through the rest and went to the pub. I think us Gen-Yers need a little more song and dance to justify a massive queue, £19 and enough tourists to sell out a music festival.

History, intrigue and grandeur. If you are in London you must visit Westminster Abbey. The history both recent and ancient, the grandeur and the sense of story that exists are all fantastic. Couple this with the fact that this is still a working church and the end result is amazement. Highly recommend the guided tour conducted by one of the vergers.

Awe Inspiring. Westminster Abbey is one of the most awe inspiring venues I have ever had the pleasure to visit. The sheer history contained within the place is incredible. It contains the tombs and remains of some of the most influential people in history who shaped not just the future of England but the world. From some of the most influential monarchs to have ever ruled over England to Scientists, naturlists, poets and literary greats.The audio guide is included withing the price of the entrance fee and is very well done. I found I spent a goode 3 hours in the Caterdral listening to the audi guide and visiting evry knock and cranny the building had to offer.I would urge anyone considering visiting the place to bite the bullet and pay the fairly high entrance fee. You won't be dissapointed.
Westminster Abbey. A super wonderful place to visit. Alot of crowds at times. Check prices and times for best time to visit.

Timeless. Another essential when coming to London. Right next to Big Ben, Westminster Abbey has seen the most recent Royal Wedding (and maybe the ones before?!). It is the most important church of London and has to be seen.

£16 per person! Good gracious!. We took a short break in London and decided to revisit Westminster Abbey (not been since we were children). We were horrified to find it cost £16 pp at the door. They did offer you free access from a side door if you wished to attend a service but really! We kept thinking of families, especially so soon after the Royal Wedding, who might really be disappointed at perhaps not being able to afford the price. We both thought it was shameful. On principle we didn't go in but instead visited St Margaret's, almost next door. This is where the "big" weddings used to occur. It's also known as the MPs' church, being just opposite the Houses of Parliament. It was wonderful. Well worth the visit. And free! As an English person, I think it's disgraceful that our museums are free but we have to pay to visit our most famous church. Talk about the Church of England cashing in. I know it's a World Heritage Site but I still think it's disgraceful. As you can no doubt tell, I'm extremely angry about the cost of this entrance fee. We've visited some beautiful churches in Europe with world famous works of art and not had to pay.

A place that makes history. Royal weddings, coronoations, burials - the abbey is a place where history is made. The lofty edifice with its soaring towers stands almost dead center in the City of London, a focal point of the city metaphiorcally as well as literally speaking. It enchants with its pleasing symetry, a highlight nof Gothic architecture abd thrills with all the things to see inside.
Go to a service. A must see. This beautiful church is filled with history ancient and recent. Try to attend a service - it is magical!

Shrine to the Nation. I've lived just two hours from London all my life, and it never occured to me until recently to visit Westminster Abbey, but having been there now I really wish I'd visited it sooner. It's FULL of history: not only are many British monarchs buried here, there is also the 'Poets Corner' with graves and dedications to so many literary greats such as Chaucer, George Eliot, Jane Austen, Dylan Thomas, Shakespeare and Dickens. Isaac Newton and (most surprisingly) Charles Darwin are buried here, and of course there's the grave of the unknown soldier, which is very emotional. Visiting here sparked a wave of patriotism in me that I didn't even realise was so strong.

Wonderful Abbey - well worth a visit. We are travellers from Australia and we do truly marvel as such history. We didn't realise that so many were buried at Westminster Abbey, it is a magnificent building. We watched, along with millions of others, the wedding of Kae & William and to see the abbey "in the flresh" was very enjoyable. The grounds in the confines of the abbey area were lovely.The audio guide was very easy to use, well done and very informative. Staff were all very helpful

Beautiful but Small. Ok you saw the royals get married here and thought wow it's huge. No it is not. It's amazing how the cameras made it look so large. However it is still an absolutely beautiful Abbey with our royals buried there and the grave of the unknown soldier. Our heritage is also crowned here which gives it a sense of sheer regency. Yes it is quite expensive to get in but you walk where royals have walked and there is so much to see. Definately take the audio tour, you can switch around and listen to what interests you. They also have little packs for children to follow so they are kept amused. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful. This is a definite must see if you have the time. You can spend hours in here.No photos
Beautiful. Engaging audio guides and staff. Lots of information available.
Evensong at Westminster Abbey. A beautiful service and music in a spectaular setting.

A serene place in the middle of London. If you like history the Abbey is the place for you, you can see the tombs of some of the great people Britain has known. It takes about 90 minutes to go around, the audio guide is included in the fee. If you can plan to go on a Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday when the cloister gardens are open to the public, they beautiful and you can easily forget you are in the middle of London.

I just dont know?!. There is no doubt the abbey is stunning, the history and sights amazing but something just does not feel right when you have admission booths in a churchI know they have a massive financial upkeep and they do not charge for worship but still.....Ive got to agree with the previous reviewer a donation box would be miles better

Definitely pay the little extra for the Verger Tour. The tour with the Verger was delightful. We gained access to places that others could not go, he was fun, energetic and insightful. It's only a slight fee and well worth the attention to details.
A World Heritage Site. St Peters Church a living history but i didn`t like that we had to pay to get in and that photo was forbitten.
Westminster Abbey. A must place to visit - so many events have taken place here which have formed part of our history.
Free church - don't think so. I object to paying to go into a church. I don't mind giving a donation but being forced to pay is not on

Stunning!. How much history can you squeeze into one place - the abbey is full of hugely famous amazing people that formed our history, you feel priveleged to meander through such awe inspiring tombs! The building itself is incredible and the recent resoration of the Lady Chapel has revealed exquisite detail on almost every surface. Outstanding.

Beautiful Abbey with a TON of History. We were a little hesitant to go into Westminster abbey because of the price to enter, but once we came to my senses to realize that the Kings and Queens of England as well as brilliant academics, scientists, and poets were buried here we just had to go. No photos allowed inside but who needs photographs when you can experience the history in your own time without burying yourself behind a camera.We only had one day in London and this was one of the places we went. Definitely get a head set (they are free as you come in) because there are not many plaques to show what all of the tombs are and where everything is so I feel like we may have missed out on a little bit because of that. Spend as much time as you can here though... it is worth it!
History !. A beautiful place ,full of history and a delight to the eye. Well wortha LONG visit
so much history in one place. just seen from outside, need to visit gain soon...

Beautiful & Eerie. We visited during a crisp January morning. The building was relatively empty, and you could truly feel the spiritual presence of the place. The Gothic reaches seemed to hold up the very sky. If ever there was a gateway, the Abbey is it. Amazing, detailed crypts, including the fabulous Death tomb. To see it in person is surreal. The tombs of the great kings and queens...it is endlessly fascinating and alluring.
Westminster Abbey. Historical and religious it has it all and the architecture is amazing to see.
Weekend visit. Looking at the whole site and viewing the items in the abbey was very good if not seen before

Full of history - very little else. We visited the Abbey as the last group allowed entry one weekday. The Abbey is full of the history of England, its monarchy and other notable personalities through the ages. The audio guide supplied was very informative, however does not exactly match a logical walking sequence through the Abbey. Towards the end of the audio tour we were ushered out because a service was to commence within the next hour... thereby missing some important aspects we would have liked to have seen - such as the Coronation Throne, and certainly detracted from our overall experience. It did seem like there were a lot of people in red coats doing very little except getting people to leave.
Majestic Westminster Abbey. It is so majestic, beautiful & historical - an ideal place for royal weddings & coronations!
a wow factor of history. need a long time to take it all in. lots of different area's to see.
Evensong. See it as you attend a service. That way, you won't be in a crowd of tourists and you'll hear wonderful music

A beautiful building but so expensive to get in.. Had to queue to get in which was fine but so crowded once you were inside. There were hand held audiosets which you do need as there is so much to see. Worth a visit if only for the Poet's Corner.

A Must See. One of my favourite spots in London as a tourist. Myself & my daughter visited the first time whilst my husband sat outside with the baby in the buggy. We expected to pop in & out in half an hour. After 1 1/2hours, we emerged from a fantastic tour. Needless to say, I returned with my husband for a 2nd time last year. You are given a headset as you walk around and marvel at the history. My No.1 recommendation in London if you like history.

A Special Day. My husband and I visited here once again, this time on St. Valentine's Day 2012. We were lucky enough to attend midday Eucharist services and celebrate the feast days of Sts. Cyril and Methodius. Mass aside, the audio tour was very interesting. I believe that, if you are interested enough, you were certainly need more than an hour here, to get the complete experience. We spent an entire afternoon.

Westminster Abbey is a "Must See". My daughter and I visited the Abbey in September 2011, which has beeen on my bucket list for some time. This is the most amazing church, I was in such awe and just stood still for ages trying to take it all in. I visited several old churches in England and Europe on our holiday but Westminster stood out above them all. An absolute must do if you are even slightly interested in this place, you will be so impressed. We went on a Saturday and only had to queue for about 5 mins so was great all round.

Best thing in London. 1000 years old and still bringing them in! This place reeks history and elements such as the tombs of Elizabeth I and Mary and Edward the Confessor are almost an afterthought in the cornucopia of graves and memorials. The vergers are great guides and try to stay for a service.
As seen on TV. You may have seen this abbey several times (Princess Di's funeral, weddings, coronations, etc) so if you are in the area you can see it for yourself. It is impressive anyhow.

Well worth a visit. Go early in the day before the queues build up. You will need an hour or two to see it all. There are an amazing number of famous people buried there. Though the entry price is expensive , I would still recommend it. Anyone visiting in a wheelchair will not be charged entry.
Stunning. This is a must see, so much history, amazingly beautiful inside, the surround cloister area is a must see.
Westminster Abbey. Spectacular inside, filled with history! Important place to visit
Unmissable. Peace, majesty and history all in oneplace. Don't rush...soak it up.

Pictures Do Not Do It Justice!. We feel very fortunate to have been able to visit this landmark. We went on a Tuesday in January so there was no wait. Tours are 17 pounds per adult and the last tour is at 3:30 PM. The tour is a self-guided audio tour available in many languages. You cannot take pictures or video inside the Abbey. I just stood in awe most of the time. The detail of the work just cannot be captured in photos or video. So many amazing things to see like the areas for different kings, the High Alter and the Coronation Chair. Seeing the burial site of Geoffrey Chaucer was a highlight for me as I remembered learning about that as a child in school studying the Canterbury Tales. Words cannot describe this place. The tour ends at the gift shop where many interesting souvenirs can be purchased. I recommend placing this site on the top of your London list!
Unforgettable.. Worth a visit whether or not you're religious. The choral services can be surprisingly uplifting even for folks like me.
Wow!. I love London and Westminster Abbey is so full of history.... I visited it a very long time ago but it is still marked in my memonry!
Witness to history. Historical weddings and funerals have taken place in here. Take a look inside.
One of the most important buildings in the history of Britain. Here is the place where the official ceremonies usually take place. Very well taken care off inside.

Never mind the picture - see the real thing. Not sure what the picture is showing, but the Abbey (off Parliament Square and across from the Houses) is a great Gothic building, the venue for the coronation of the monarchy and royal weddings and funerals. It houses Poets' Corner where many literary figures are buried and commemorated, and the tombs of numerous kings and queens of England, including Elizabeth 1 and Henry V
Sublime Heritage. Loved the architecture, the peaceful aura and the location.

Very expensive buyt everyone should do this once. As much a history of English consciousness as an abbey used for coronations and the like, this is a must-see at least once in your life! Don't forget to look up at the ceilings too - quite simply magnificent. Not to mention Britain's oldest door! Do not miss out the museum and the little cloister "out back" is delightful. The audio guide was not particularly good; my advice to anyone who has never been before would be to buy the guidebook first. Of course there is the obligatory gift shop, but the quality of goods on sale is a cut above the norm, and at the moment there are some nice diamond jubilee souvenirs which aren't as garish as some of the offerings seen elsewhere in town! One final thing. Having seen and marvelled at it all (not forgetting the coronation chair which is now near the front entrance!) pause at the tomb of the unknown soldier and reflect.........
Not to be missed. It's expensive to visit nowadays, but the architecture of this magnificent abbey and sense of history inside are second to none

worth the money. Yes, it's top-of-the-range expensive but where else can you find almost 1000 years of history in such an extraordinarily beautiful setting? We went on a Wednesday and there was no queue. We chose a Wednesday because it's open to visitors until 6pm but part of the church was blocked to tourists at 4.45 for a 5pm service so we still didn't get to see it all. My other criticism is the audioguide - it's good as far as it goes, but the explanations are very brief and only mention the top highlights. There are lots of really old looking and big tombs and monuments which you can only find out about if you are able to read the Latin inscriptions. I accept that there is so much there it would be impossible to include everything on the audioguide, but I think they could do much better and include more material. Still worth it though - one of my top places to visit in all of Europe.

Not just for the religious. This is my second favourite attraction in London and again worth a second visit which is what we did recently.It is a little pricey so make sure you get your moneys worth by spending your time among the 'residents' who are among the great and the good of England.Poets Corner is ofcourse the most famous bits of the sections you will recognise from the Royal Wedding but there are also other parts of interest.For example in the Chamber with Queen Elizabeth (the first) and her sister you will find an urn at the back engaved in Latin which is said to contain (and with good reason) the bones of Edward V and his brother Richard of York ( The Princes in the Tower). Spend long enough and all sorts of interesting things pop up and the staff there are very amenable especially when it is not too busy. It's quite easy to lose yourself in the place and so I would definitely schedule a good two hours to spend there!

Westminster Abbey. We have visited the abbey twice in our travels. It is very busy so go in the morning or see if you could pre purchase your tickets. It is worth the visit but if you have limited time check out St. Paul's Cathedral for a fantastic church!

Can't believe I paid so much to enter a church!. As someone who lived in France for 4 years and visited hundreds of places of worship across that country, I was horrified at the pricing and line-ups to enter the Abbey! Despite all the interesting tombs and names, it just wasn't my piece of cake at all.
Tyremarxx. Steeped in history, both secular and religious. One of the great cornerstones of Christianity.
Stunning architecture and history. Beautiful building. I especially loved poet's corner. I'm not religious but the spiritual significance was definitely not lost on me. Some beautiful stories here.
Go West. From my earliest memory of the Coronation this place has been in my life long distance. More than just religion, art, history and little corners of peace.
Fascinating. Visited twice in the last few months. Really beautiful and integral to understanding our history. Student discount available.

Just beautiful. I have seen alot in Paris and I was expecting to be surprised by Westminster Abbey. You just have to see it to really appreciate it because photos and film or tv footage just doesn't really show you. I saw it starting from the bridge with the London Eye behind me. I would recommend seeing if the same way.... walk across the bridge, then cross the road to the church and find your in.

A must-see for any visitor to London.. We’ve lived here for 60 years & finally got around to visiting the abbey! Expect to queue for up to an hour, especially in holiday periods and summer weekends. We went early on a Saturday in October & were lucky not to have to wait long to get in. The staff said the quietest days are Tuesdays & Wednesdays. I’d say the guided tour is well worthwhile for the extra £3 if you have the time but we followed the route given on the guide at our own pace, using the audio guide included in the entry price. The coffee bar in the cloisters is excellent value. Nice food & coffee &, despite having a monopoly, prices were reasonable & quality was good. Admittedly there are only stone seats but they do provide cushions. Do check the website for visiting times & be aware there is no visiting on Sundays, worship only.

Must, Must, Must Go!. Don't be discouraged if the ticket line is long, it is completely worth the wait. Absolutely amazing and humbling. When you really absorb the artistry and time periods of some of the tombs it blows you away. Highly recommend!!

Need to see at least once.. I am one of those people that want to see everything. Westminster Abbey is beautiful and I hate to think that its only tourists that get to see it and like it. It has lots of historical information and is a lovely building. It was quite expensive to get in though compared to other places but is worth the fee if just for the one time.
Nice Place. Here's where the Royal Wedding Happened.. Nice beautiful Gardens.. a must visit
Architecture. Thats what its all about. Westminster abbey, the tower of big ben - the rosy cheeks of the little children.

What a Gem. We have visited London so many times and I even worked there in my younger days but we had never been to Westminster Abbey. It may be the £16 admission charge had put us off in the recent past but it was so worth it. The place is beautiful and full of history and there are so many extra chapels and areas to visit. If you go mid week (Tuesday to Thursday) you can even go out into the Abbey gardens to the side of the Abbey.Do not miss this place - you will not be disappointed and well worth the price.

Unreal! The must-see church in London. Truly breath-taking! The experience of being in the Abbey was nothing like what I thought it would be, or saw on TV...it was spectacular. We only had a short time in London (2 days) and the location is so convenient to see easily see Parliament/Big Ben and Buckingham easily. The price to enter is a bit high, but includes an audio tour and really the best money we spent in London.

Unbelievabley prices, I mean wow just wow. Still gorgeous though.. This is the cake of cakes on tourist traps. You stand in line and the guys come out and virtually handpick who goes in and who does not. They only allow people into the Abbey till 1pm which for tourism, is just insane. The Abbey itself is a bit more restrictive then before in terms of what you can see which is a shame. When I first started going there years ago, I got into everything without an issue. Now you can barely sneeze without getting someone on your case. And the Abbey is packed, just packed. You cannot stand around and read something or take in the grandeur of the cathedral. On top of the horrible rip off price to get in, I still recommend going but like everything in London, prepare to sell a kidney.

Stunning location!. Disappointed that a charge of £16 each was required. I didnt feel it necessary to pay, as the outside of the abbey is simply stunning. All the photos I wanted to take were from the outside. Had the fee to enter been a little cheaper I would have gone inside.

Beautiful. Having been lucky enough to attend an event in the Abbey, I have been privileged enough to visit it in a ll its glory. I didn't have a tour or anything, but one can appreciate with one's own eyes the beauty within!

Una Vergogna. This is how my friends described their Westminster Abbey experience.My Italian friends were so looking forward to visiting London and in particular westminster Abbey. Not only were they expected to pay to enter what they described as the house of God but a ridiculous amount as well.They were disgusted at the £16.00 admission charge and left without visiting. They were shouting that it was a vergogna, which translates to, a disgrace. I am embarrassed and agree with them totally. Westminster Abbey, you should be ashamed.

Stunning. The Westminster Abbey was at the top of my “To Do in London” list and it did not disappoint. From the moment we walked in I must have said “wow” about 1,000 times. I think what REALLY impressed me was you can actually see how old everything is. If you look behind the statues, you can see the walls behind them and how much they’ve changed. Look on the walls and you’ll see how high the door ways used to be. Look up and around and you’ll see old passage ways that you desperately want to know where they lead to. The history of the building is absolutely amazing to think about, I mean the floor at the high alter is older than my whole country!!! It was mind blowing to sit and think that I was in the ACTUAL Westminster Abbey. The Abbey is absolutely amazing; HOWEVER, the Henry VII Lady Chapel puts it to shame. You will know exactly what I mean when you step into it. It took my breath straight from out from my lungs. The ceiling in this Chapel was in the running to be one of the wonders of the world, and I’m surprised it’s not a wonder. It’s stunning!! You will not be able to stop looking up; they’ve even put a mirror in the room so you can instead look into the mirror to look up. I spent a great deal of time in this chapel taking in its beauty. There’s another part of the Abbey that has a few of the original windows, flooring and paintings that made it through the Blitz that are impressive. If you’re looking for Charles Darwin’s tomb, it’s very easy to miss; we had to have a staff member point it out to us. If you’re facing Newton’s tomb walk to your left, almost directly beside it and there it is on the floor. A lot of the tombs around the Abbey have inscriptions about the person buried there but Darwin’s just simply has his name.I've read a few of the negative reviews of Westminster Abbey and would have to say I completely disagree. I know that each person has a different experience but in no way do I think the staff was rude or that the £16 was a rip off. In fact the many staff members that we talked to provided "inside" facts that you probably would have missed if you hadn't talked to them. Such as, the wooden seats in the Henry VII Lady Chapel is dedicated to the very first Prime Minister of Canada (I'm Canadian and a HUGE history buff, and one of the staff members gave my British bf this tip to impress me and it definitely worked). We were also told that a lot of the jewels on tombs (etc.) are missing to a certain height because people used to steal them, not because of their age. Keep that in mind when you look around and you’ll see how much has actually been stolen. Some have said the staff is rude but if anything, I would encourage you to talk to them. The audio tours are free and are definitely worth it so make sure you grab one. I think someone might consider this a rip off if they weren’t really into history or churches, but if you are, this is a MUST SEE! In my opinion, the Abbey is worth every penny and every moment you’ll spend in it!

A must for history buffs. This is where most of the british celerities through the ages is buried - and this is where you get Mary Stuart and Elisabeth Ist in the same room. Take your time walking around reading the epitaphs.
Not to be missed. Try to attend a concert with the choir - to hear those soaring voices in that setting is very special
Westmisnter Abbey. Gothic architectire at its most impressive but the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior is humbling.

A Classic Point Of Interest. Westminster was absolutely fabulous. It is better than what you expect in terms of ancient english history. My daughters were pleasantly surprised by all of the historical information inside as well as being able to see where notables like Darwin, Charles Dickens, Isaac Newton, Edward the Confessor, and various other people were buried. The recorded guide information was outstanding. Highly recommend this site. The Abbey is easy to find, it is located behind Big Ben and Parliament.

Wonderful experience. W.A. is so fascinating. I went on a walking tour with Original London Walks and we had priority entry. Othewise, you will have to wait in line. The walking tour gave me so much more information than I would have discovered on my own.

Staff were rude. Was shocked to arrive at the Abbey and find that, where once it was free, they are now charging £16 for entry. Not only that but they were really policing entry to the evening service, clearly viewing all potential supplicants as freeloading tourists. We'd been to the Abbey before many times so weren't there as tourists; we simply wanted to attend the evening service again, something we've done before several times and really enjoyed. The Abbey is an amazing space and, while I can understand why they are charging tourists for entry, I think the Abbey needs to really rethink how they operate. As a UK citizen I was horrified to see how staff spoke to tourists from Spain, Italy and the USA. It was very rude and people were visibly taken aback. I'd say give the Abbey a miss until they reacquire some Christian humility.
Westminster Abbey. Don't just go inside; walk all around the building.From College Green the roof of the original tower can be seen.

See Evensong. Go see Evensong, you won't regret it; the choir service is stunning.If you do go though, show some respect; don't start looking for a better seat in the middle of the service, and drop a couple pounds in the collection plate.

Get There Early. Once again, Westminster is a place you should get to early. We tried to go the first day we were in London, but it would have been 3+ hours of waiting, according to the guy at the door. There are two lines, one for credit cards and one for cash. The London Pass line jumping privileges don't apply here, you still have to choose a line. Luckily, we had another day. We came back the next morning 45 minutes before it opened (we planned on 30, but it didn't take us as long to get there as we had thought), and we were 2nd in line. I would also recommend planning ahead of time what you want to see. You'll save a lot of time. I had a guide book with maps that my mom had given me, and I had mapped out all the graves I wanted to see. We got through it in about an hour, instead of wandering all over the place.
Enthralling. I've been here several times and still haven't seen enough. There it too much pack in every corner. My family and I spent hours walking around.

The setting was perfect and the interior and exterior design was great. I liked the Abbey because the architecture was so detailed. The audio tour was great along with all the history. Every piece had history and so many famous people are buried there. Usually, if only one of those people were buried, it would already be a tourist attraction. But instead, so many famous people were all in one place. Also, I recognized most of the interior from Kate and William's wedding. The interior and exterior details were fascinating up close as well as from a far. It surely is worth a visit. It is about a 10 minute walk from Glocuster Road. Enjoy!rubystar2245

Shrine of the English People. This is the centre of the English nation and society, it is where our kings are made and buried. Everyone who was anyone is buried here. It is steeped in history and a must see for anyone visiting England who is interested in our history. Beware - there are strange opening times so check online when it is open for visitors.

Breathtaking history. We made this our first stop on our trip to London. The history in this church is overwhelming. I spent most of the tour with my mouth open in amazement. We hired a private Blue Badge Guide for this visit, but they have individual audio tours available. Take time to enjoy and appreciate this gem.

So much history. There is just so much to see here and take in. The Abbey itself is stunning in its architecture and design. I could have spent hours just looking at the church alone. The tombs and memorials, the chapels only enrich the experience. Also, to have been in the spot of coronations and funerals was very moving to me.
dark. It lacks light, so quite dark and depressing inside

Interesting to go inside. It is £16 to enter the abbey and you get a free audio guide. It is quite amazing inside and you can retrace will and Kate's steps! There is a lot to see and a lot of tombs!! The guide helps to make sense of it all.
Another must see.. This can be enjoyed in about 30 minutes or 4 hours, depending on your level of interest.
Princes and Poets. History ancient and modern, it has all happened here! Beautiful Abbey Church - what else can one say!
Overpriced. Westminster Abbey is interesting but I down-rated it due to the over the top entry prices
AMAZING. Beautiful !! Pat extra and take a guided tour. It is so worth it and one of my favorite places in London.
A must see without a doubt. This is without a doubt a place to put on your schedule. Unfortunately I didn't get to see it all but what I did see what incredible! Top of my list for next trip!
WOW. History to die for.. Excellent presentation of information with personal handsets with the delicious Jeremy Irons narrating. Unmissable. Probably not suitable for all the most academic children.

a lot of history in one place. Intricate stained glass & sculptures surrounds the walls. It houses several tombs of monarchs & elites. It felt like a mausoleum more than a church. The "Coronation Chair" was being restored inside a room with viewing glass window. The ceiling was very elaborate & impressive. There are two lines (cash & credit) to buy ticket, make sure you're in the right line. We waited 20 minutes to get in.

15 Euros to get in, come on.. We visited many basilicas and churches throught France, Italy and Germany in our 15 day trip through Europe and I can't remember and entry fee for a church in any other country except England. St. Paul's basilica had a large entry fee as well. I would say that only 1 in 10 visitors paid the entry fee to go inside. If they were smart, they would lower it to 5 Euros and attract 5-8 times the amount of people they get now.

Historical. Well worth a visit coupled with the Houses of Parliment, London Eye, Big Ben as they are all located a couple of minutes walk from each other. A superb building and great for some photos to remember your trip by. Steeped in history both yesteryear and modern day one to visit on your trip.
marvellous!. the ceiling in the lady chapel is a miracle! check it out!
A must - of course. Devout christian or Athiest - you must visit the Abbey! It holds something for everyone and if you have a London Travel Card it wont cost the earth.

Historic and Beautiful. I have to admit, my wife dragged me to see this. I saw it 30 years ago and could not imagine that it had changed. Well, even if it had not changed--I have. This was a wonderful experience.Not only was there was very recent history made with the wedding of Prince William and Kate, but there are many famous people buried there--not the least of which is Issac Newton and Charles Darwin.We showed up on our way to Parliament (it is very close by) and buying a ticket and getting in did not take long at all. However, take your time once your are inside. This is really a site to behold.The gift shop is small but there are some items of interest (not for sale) that you will find there, if you stop by.

Westminster Abbey: So much history in one place. Westminster Abbey is a definite must see. Go early in the day to avoid the crowds. There is a fee to get in with audio guides included. St James Park and Westminster are the closest tube stations. The abbey is close to Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament with several other site-seeing spots within walking distance. You could feasibly spend the entire day in the general neighborhood checking out a variety of historical places.I had no idea there were so many tombs and memorials of famous people throughout history enclosed within the abbey walls. Royals. Poets. Scientists. Statesmen. I was surprised by the actual size of the abbey. TV camera men for the royal weddings made it look way bigger. There is fabulous art and architecture to take in while you wander in and out of the different areas of the abbey. While we were visiting, there was a photo exhibit of William and Kate's wedding set up within the abbey to view.All-in-all, it was quite awe-inspiring. The audio guides provided excellent information. If you have the chance to visit Westminster Abbey, do. Word to the wise . . . don't confuse the abbey with the cathedral of the same name.
impressive. So much to see. Not only a beautiful church but also a historylesson. So many famous people are burried here. The entrancefee was high, but the free audiotour made up for it.

History you can feel.. I hadn't been to Westminster Abbey for well over 10 years. We wanted our kids to see this amazing place. The kids scavenger hunt provided by the Abbey was excellent, as were the audio tours included with admission. I was able to explore the Abbey in a new way and get more detailed information. There is something interesting in every part of the Abbey. I especially enjoyed the chapels where Queens Mary and Elizabeth are buried. I also loved Poet's Corner, and I enjoyed seeing the marker of Charles Darwin. I asked the guide for any tidbits of info and discovered that the archbishop and Prime Minister refused to attend his funeral. In that immediate area, a poor man is buried standing up, as it was too expensive to pay for him to be buried laid out. Very grand and beautiful and the cloisters are interesting too. I was sorry there was no brass rubbing any longer. The kids were thrilled with the huge chocolate coins they were given after completing the scavenger hunt. A great day out. Tip: Avoid going during the Xmas holidays, it was PACKED!
A wonderful expereince. This Abbey has so much history to take in well worth the visit from Florence Nightingale to Royal Weddings

Pleased by the Nova Scotia connections. I can't remember them all now, but I was very surprised to find them since it's my home.The audio tour was reasonably good, a bit confusing in parts, doesn't always correspond well to the map but overall not bad. Some of the assistants were obviously students and they were more interested in each other than the tourists. Fortunately that wasn't too big an issue for me but might be for others. I was pleased that the wait to enter wasn't as long as I thought it might be. Nevertheless, the Abbey was still surprisingly crowded, which did detract from my visit, but overall a good experience.

Steeped in history and grace. Take you time when exploring - there is so much to see.We paid £3 extra for a guided tour with a Verger that lasted more than an hour and a half....what great value. We saw and things about the Abbey that we would not have got from doing our own walk round.We stayed for Evensong, a delight and the icing ong a fabulous visit.

Unforgetable!!!. I first visited Westminster Abbey as part of a tour in January 2007; it was a fairly quick walk-through with a guide, very interesting, but I wanted more time; finally had the opportunity on a return trip in April 2011; this time I used a self-paced audio tour so that I could take my time, stop whenever I wanted to and look carefully at everything. You definitely want to do this, because no inside photography is allowed. One huge highlight was St. Edward's chapel, closed to tourists for the most part, but open for a short prayer service at 3:00, which I attended; I spent several hours at Westminster on a Wednesday afternoon, then returned on Sunday for Palm Sunday services, which was absolutely amazing, and unforgetable experience!!! There was a fee on Wednesday to visit, but not to worship on Sunday.

Impressive Abbey. Westminster Abbey is a must-see when you visit London. There are many important people that lie inside it's walls, like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin,William Shakespeare and Mary Queen of Scots. The building is quite big and you need at least 1.5 hours to listen and learn what the audio guide plays.You have to be aware that the last admission time is at 3.30 pm. You can combine the abbey with the Houses of Parliament, which is really worth the visit as well.

Westminster Abbey was very interesting. In case you do not know it, Westminster Abbey has a lot of famous people's graves or memorials inside. It is also the location of the recent wedding of Prince William and Kate. It was very interesting to see Westminster itself, as well as who all is commemorated there. Take the time to go see it. Even our teenagers were interested.

The Gardens are 'Wow'. You can't take photos inside the Abbey, but you can once you get outside into the Gardens -- some of the people who work at the Abbey live there in apartments that look into the walled Gardens -- each has its own little patio looking out onto a piece of heaven -- imagine looking at this every day!

Buried kings from the last thousand years & Shakespeare. The abbey is a worth visiting, being that it houses kings and queens from the last thousand years or so - a tour would be even more informative. Highly recommend the steep 16 GBP admission for adults. n.b. the abbey closes early on Sat, and is not open on Sunday, so plan ahead if you would like to visit.

Attend a service. We attended the choral Eucharist on New Years day, and it was a wonderful experience. If possible, sit in the right trancept, as this section takes communion in front of the High Altar. The choir was incredible.

Speechless.... Westminster Abbey was magical. Everything is just amazing. The abbey is huge and there's so much to see from several different centuries, but the audio tour did a fantastic job of directing you and giving you the important and interesting information. Easily one of the best things I saw in London!

A wonder. visited the Abbey with my goddaughter and her grandmother during the christmas period, the queues were not too bad and the movement into the inside was fairly fast you do have your bag checked, there is a charge for entry but kids under 16 are free, when you enter you can pick up your own recording of the Abbey information with numbers to follow. My goddaughter was enthralled by the Abbey and to think she had seen this on the tv to now be standing in the Abbey. The Abbey is a spectacle to be seen with some wonderful history information and exhibits to see and learn about. Although the charge may seem a little high it was worth paying to spend the time visiting and remember this fee is to help toward the upkeep of the Abbey. You are not allowed to take pictures however it was sad to see the number of people using their mobile phones to do this, please respect the request. Once again somewhere I would visit again allowing more time to take more in. on exit the coronation chair is exhibited behind a screen as it is being restored it looked smaller than you would imagine.
Pretty neat. A must visit place.. It´s a bit expensive, but one of the must see places in London.

Christmas mess of lessons and carols very special. When you're in London during Christmas, it's really worthwhile to book in advance (on the website of Westminster Abbey) tickets for a Christmas service. These are free, but there are limited places available. We really enjoyed the choir, organ, the great atmosphere of this special place and the lessons that we're read by different notorious people.

A great place to get an understanding of British culture. I had one "free" day in London during a business trip, and an English coworker recommended I include Westminster in my plan. I was so glad that I did. The audio tour included with the admission price was also very helpful. In addition to understanding some of the history of the monarchy and appreciating beautiful architecture, you also get to understand some of the "valuable contributions to society" that those memorialized at the Abbey have made. As an American, I realized we don't have a single place of honor like this for not only political, but also societal and academic leaders. Well worth the few hours to go through! (Be aware, public restrooms are across the street, 50p)
It has been awhile.... since I have been to Westminster Abbey, but I remember being quite over-whelmed with the sense of history. I am planning on going back.

Impressive cathedral, great self-guided tour. Pros:1. Self-guided tour is so the way to go. We were able to see this massive building at our own pace and with the guide in our ear instead of straining to hear an actual tour guide in a large group.2. The tour goes in a very logical order3. Works with the London PassCons:1. If you do not have the London Pass, you will pay a lot of money for this attraction. It is worth it, but if I paid fill price it may have been only 4/5 instead of 5/5.2. The line to get in can be extremely long and it is entirely outside, so bad weather (which we had) will affect you.

I had no idea all our famous are burried here.. I'm a 29 year old Londoner ands was facinated to find all the greats (and rich) in our history are burried here. I would of loved the audio guide to of told more stories about what these great kings and queens etc did as I had my auntie with me and she would tell me all their stories which I loved. But I'd still highly recommend this as a must do now for any tourist or Londoner to do.

Listening to history come alive!. Poet's Corner is a must-see when visiting. Many famous people can be visited, beautiful architecture, and the "special chair" used for coronations. Of course, one must listen to the wonderful narration that serves as a guide throughout your self-tour of the Abbey. A nice afternoon spent listening to Jeremy Irons!
Royal. Was in london on business and took in many attractions. One of those was Westminster Abbey. It has a very Classic and Royal Feel to it.

Tackey and commercial. Historically rich but the abbey has become commercial and tackey & the staff are very rude and unhelpful - Madam Tussauds will be running this in 20 years time I'm quite sure. The Anglican Church seems to have forgoten it is a church.

Magnificant!. My companion really wanted to visit the Abbey and I just went along with her. But once inside, the depth of its spiritual and historical significance takes your breath away! I was truly moved and inspired. Very much worth your time.
iconic Church. So interesting to see who in commemorated here. Ancient church with a special feel. Royal history is made here.

Go during services. I've been to Westminster Abbey on numerous trips because of its historical attractions, but like so many still active churches I lost the spiritual element in seeing the thrones, coffins, windows, niches, etc. I was planning yet another such visit when one of the guards shouted "Services only." I quickly threw my camera in my purse and went in, even though I am not Anglican/Episcopalian. I had to smile when they said one must stay a full hour -- I cannot begin to imagine the same in France or Italy! But for the first time during Chorale I really appreciated Westminster Abbey as what it always was and is supposed to be, both historically and from a religious standpoint. The previous times I resented it because it never was open (only the gift shop) when I wanted to enter, and so it seemed a great inconvenience. This time it was magnificence. Go for any of the services and you'll get so much more than you bargained for!There's no cost if you go for services.
Just as magnificent as one imagines. My wife wanted to see the Abby, but on our first foray it was occupied, so we returned and she was just impressed. She love British history so it was a must see.
Truly Historical and Atmospheric.. A must for all Royal fans and admirers of British History and Architecture alike.

Interesting historical sight that's worth seeing. Overall I think it's worth a visit even with the cost of getting inside.The audio tour was quite fairly informative without going on for to long.I've only given it three stars just because it's not the kind of thing that truly interests me, I just wanted to see it as it's a great sight in this country, looks very nice and has a lot of history behind it.

A must for history buffs of all natures.. Apart from the building which is magnificent, to be in the resting place of so many 'Greats' of our heritage is awesome. Royals, poets, musicians, scientists, battle heroes, politicians - names that come from school studies, film documentaries, and historical movies, all we're somehow 'made real' as you walk by or even ON their tombstones.It was off season but still crowded. There is a pretty stiff entrance fee £16 each, the self guided tour using that hand held phone tape is very interesting and quite timely, just the right amount of info at each spot with extras if you want to listen to more. Easy to use . Jeremy Irons is the speaker and I could listen to him all day anyway. Take the time to wander into the cloister garden. It was a treat for me to see what they claim to be the oldest garden in England!
awe-inspiring. Gorgeous....awe-inspiring and definitely worth a visit. The audio tour was very helpful...and surrounding yourself with their history....amazing

A must see when in London. The abbey is like a living history book. The staff walking around the monuments are very friendly and eager to explain what you are looking at. Beware of not-so-friendly window clerks - they are dreadfully disinterested in helping you. I entered a long line with a sign posted "cash and credit cards accepted" only to get to the window 30 mins later to find that they were only willing to take cash. The clerk could not care less - even though a co-worked confirmed the sign was there. I kept smiling though - it is a church after all.
Wow how grand. Great piece of history take the time to spend looking at all the unique things about this property!
one of the gothic top churches. i entered in a relatively sunny day and i was overwhelmed by the sunlight through the glasses on the thousand details of the space of the Ladies Chapel

Go to Evensong Service. We went in at 5:00 PM for an Evensong service with the Westminster Abbey Choir. What a treat to enjoy the beautiful voices in this magnificent cathedral. We didn't have time to tour this time, have done it on previous trips and you could easily spend a full day here.

Attend an Evensong, it is a must. We attended an Evensong service on a Saturday. We wanted to avoid the high entrance fee, and also wanted to experience a service. It seems a lot better to me to hear the organ play and experience a religious service, rather than pay a high entrance fee and just look around. Churches are places of worship, not just sights to see, therefore I feel it is important to take part in the services that are conducted there. We were priveleged to sit in the choir stalls next to the choir. It was uplifting and breathtaking to hear their voices and to hear the magnificent organ being played. I would recommend to skip the general tours, and attend an Evensong service to hear Westminster in all its glory.

A Must See. My friend and I decided Westminster Abbey was one of the must do places while we were in London. We worried about lines at the church on a Saturday so we went first thing in the morning and got there about 30 minutes after they opened. I think we paid 16 pounds each to get in, but you get a free audio tour included with that price. I was really impressed by the amount of spaces that you are able to walk into and around with little limitations on what you can and cannot touch. Lots to see and the audio tour gives just the right amount of information for the average tourist. If there are parts that interest you more, there are extra options on the audio guide you can choose from. When you get the audio guide, a helpful staff member will help you get one with the proper language.
Very interesting. It told you a lot of information about the place and it had some really old things it.
A must see. Great site, definitely worth seeing. We didn't take a tour on the inside, but the outside is very impressive!

The Crushing Weight of English/British History. If you're going to see one thing in London, this should be it. Coronation site, royal marriages, tombs, monuments, etc., this place has all of it and then some, centuries of world renowned history, all in one place. We waited about ten minutes to get in the door. The entry fee is reasonable. The self-guided tours are fantastic, very easy to use and very easy to understand, and narrated by the incredibly English Jeremy Irons. The handsets allow you to go at your own pace, and they even have little video screens that offer supplemental videos for aspects of the tour. You can go as fast or as slow as you want. Be sure to keep a watch under your feet for the hundreds of burial plaques in the floor. And check out the oldest door in Britain, coming in at almost 1,000 years old. Very cool place, extraordinarily impressive architecture, art, and history. Very helpful and friendly staff, too.
Impressive!!. This place is huge and amazing!!! All the details and the history!!. A must see in London!!

ok. I think it would probably have liked this much more, if I weren't a VERY impatient person. It is CRAZY busy with tourists - and I found myself paying more attention to who cut into my path than the scenery. Also, not being able to take pics detracts somewhat. Still glad I saw it - but for me, more enjoyable from the outside. For anyone interested in history - I imagine it would be amazing!

The Abbey. A must see if in London. It is a beautiful structure with incredible history. There are so many people buried in the building, they have run out of space. Take the audio tour to get a real description of what you are viewing.
beautiful. went for the free evensong service at 5:00 and heard the choir perform. The Abbey is so beautiful, historic and you just feel like you are seeing something magical

Amazing, spiritual place. Wonderful, beautiful building, packed full of history - not just the royal weddings and funerals and coronations but also from the many hundreds of historical figures buried there. The Tomb of the Unknown soldier is a very special place. The free audio tour was excellent.
it was so amazing!. when they told me it's 16 gbp to go inside i was shocked, but i did and it was worth of every penny. the site is so elegant, historical and interesting. i recommend it!!!!

A must do!. An expensive but interesting place to visit. Very busy although we visited on a week day, but not feeling cramped. Audio tour very useful and keeps the crowds moving! I don't like paying to enter a church, it feels wrong, but I suppose funds are needed.

History, History and more History!. It is difficult not to be overwhelmed by the history of the Abbey. There are kings, queens, writers and an unknown soldier buried within its walls. The architecture, from its origins, through its renovations is astounding! If you like beautiful music, try to catch evensong in the early evening. The guided tour, for a few british pounds more was very informative, enriching and entertaining.

Do something different, attend the matins. We did something different than just peering into history and architecture, we went to the matins. It wasn't too unfamiliar as we were Christians, but the environment is definitely different from our Sunday service! Choir was good and the sermon was extremely enlightening. If you are there on Sunday , go for it. Even not on Sunday you can attend the evensong for experience!

Get into Westminter Abbey for FREE. The Abbey is closed to visitors on Sundays but is open for church services! It's only a 30 minute service, but some have choir concerts and although they don't let you take pictures or stick around too long afterward, it's a great way to get in and look around!

Beautiful in every way. Was completely bowled over by the architecture and the fine detail. It's just the most intricate work I've ever seen in stone. London can be so very expensive to visit, and I hate to say I really did grudge the admission price, but I got over it quickly. The side chapels of the Kings and Queens are just incredible. Keep your eyes heavenward because the detail is extraordinary. And it's very humbling to see Poet's Corner celebrating the lives and works of so many individuals, juxtapositioned with the grave of the Unknown Soldier. I found my visit deeply moving.

Church, commercialized?. From the outside this place looks amazing. But since there was a royal wedding there, they now charge about $20 to get in and then you can't take any photos. The tombs of all the old kings was interesting if you know the history. After seeing this place, we went to Cologne, Germany and stopped in to see the Dom Cathedral there. After seeing that, Westminster held no interest to me. Westminster disappointed me, they have a coffee shop in the middle of the church. Unbelievable. I thought they were disrespecting some tradition but what do I know.

Surrounded by History. Amazing place, a true must see attraction in London!! The Abbey itself is breathtaking and the tombs of former kings are a nice touch. Plus, with the audioguide you can learn more about the ones buried there, as well as English history. There is also a cute little garden which is a perfect place to relax after walking around the cathedral. There you can also get a different view from the Big Ben

Heavenly Evensong. I was there for Evensong and was able to sit in the stalls just a few feet from the choir. For those who love sacred music this is an experience you will remember the rest of your life. I know I will.

God Save the Queen. We went to the Westminster Cathedral Prayer service and enjoyed it tremendously. There's no charge. Get there early so you get one of the comfortable centuries old seats and don't have to sit in modern folding chairs . You get a prayer guide so you can follow along and yes, you do say a prayer for the queenl While you are hustled out right after, you do walk by Isaac Newton's grave - very cool.

terrible and disappointing.. It was terrible because they were actually charging and the charge was too expensive because there were three of us and disappointing because we were all looking forward to going in and viewing where the big wedding took place.. I can honestly say from being in Paris last year, that it is well ahead of london as a tourist friendly city

A must for London. The Abbey is huge. I live and work in London and I like to visit this place annaully.Its very hard not to catch your breath when you walk in.A must is the tomb of Queen Elizabeth 1.The coronation throne can be seen with all its ancient grafitti.

A rude and aggressive member of staff spoilt my visit. Pros:Architecturally attractive building. Moving Remembrance Day tribute featuring hundreds of poppies and poppy crosses in the garden outside the Abbey. Well stocked gift shop with friendly staff. Cons:£16 entrance fee. Unfortunately a female Abbey Marshal member of staff outside, wearing a red gown (name withheld) was rude to myself, my friend and two other tourists at the main metal gates (adjacent to the shop entrance). I enquired about the times of services and she just gestured at a timings board, as she clearly couldn't be bothered to speak them to me. I watched  another couple ask a similar question and she shrugged her shoulders. I asked a Marshal adjacent to her for her name and he walked off. However, when I asked her a second time for her name, she went into a rage, pointed at her name badge and said "report me then" before a male Marshal pulled her back towards the Abbey. We asked in the Abbey shop for a customer comments form, but they don't use them, so they gave us the website address instead from which we could phone our concerns about her attitude. I don't easily get angry but a member of staff representing the public face of the church at such a sensitive time of year should know to be respectful and helpful to visitors.I phoned Westminster Abbey - [--] - and spoke to a polite and understanding supervisor about myself and my friend's concerns. He said it would be "dealt with" and wouldn't be "pushed to the side". I hope the member of staff is robustly dealt with by the Abbey.

Highly Over Rated. If you have visited other abbeys, you may find that Westminster Abbey just does not live up to all the hype. Yes, it is the coronation place and it is a magnificent, large church and abbey, but there are bigger and nicer ones. It probably has more Royals buried there, but is that a reason to visit? How about the Poet's Corner? There are four poets buried there, and there are memorials to a dozen or so more. The tour virtually forces you to follow a strict and crowded path. The best part of the of the tour was the astonishingly beautiful mosaic floor near the entrance. A note of warning: you do not want to have to use the one toilet.

A must see attraction for tourists and natives alike. Definitely pay the £16 entry fee to see Westminster Abbey. I was surprised to learn that only a handful of British people visit this splendid attraction everyday compared to the number of tourists! It is a busy attraction, so get there early. Check website before going as they are closed several days/times a week for services. We arrived on a Monday morning at 10am, queued just 15 minutes to get in and spent well over an hour in there. A great audio tour narrated by Jeremy Irons. There are so many tombs of monarchs in there it is unbelievable. It is a magnificant building. This attraction is not just for people who are religious or like churches. There is something for everyone. Look out for the coronation chair - fascinating.
A world heritage, indeed. Firs of all I like the architecture of the building.Second, I enjoy the history of the place.

A Must See - Lots of History. A short wait gets you through the ticket line and into ths famous Church. Spring for the audioguide to get directions to each site within the church and a good explanation of what you're looking at. Otherwise, especially if you're not British or a history buff, much of the significance of the various people buried there and the statues and such, will be lost. Of course, get the required camera shots from outside of the entire building, Big Ben, and from the bridge with the Thames in the shot along with the Abbey. This is about the only attraction in London that doesn't sell advance tickets, so you'll have to put up with the ticket line.

Interesting. It's worth taking the audio guide and there's much to learn about the Abbey.Whilst interesting, unlike Catholic places of worship, The Abbey seems cold and stark.Although expensive, it's worth making a visit - if only once!

Toured, then returned for Evensong. Lines are long for the tour. The cash line seemed to move faster than credit card line. Once inside, pictures aren't allowed, so I made sure to purchase a guide book to bring home (that or some post cards). It's crowded, but take your time to visit all the chapels and look down on the floor for memorial and grave plaques. In the evening the boys/mens choir, adorned in traditional robes, since a delightful classical worship - the amazing sound echoes through the abbey. Not as crowded either.

Expensive and very crowded. Impressive building, but didn't feel at all like a Church. It was a cramped and difficult procession around a vast collection of tombs and monuments, which were VERY poorly labelled. Even the audio guides were little help, which was a shame. Absolutely unique and historic of course, but once you've been, you've been.

Audio guide in about 40 languages. It might take time to get inside. Not too cheap, but quite spacious inside, nice and interesting. They offer free audio guide in impressive number of languages, we found in our language too - which is not a usual thing.

European Highlight - take the audio device !. Take the free audi device along with your tour. It is a concise, meaningful and focused tour of the highlights of the abbey (the English version narrated by Jeremy Irons). Don't be surprised at the life in the abbey - we found ourselves in the middle of the Keats society celebrating his 260th birthday with an official from the church at the Keats memorial. Make sure you take in the ceiling in Henry VII's Lady Chapel - spectacular. Fine gothic architecture throughout with more than a 1000 years history in the church !!

Thoughts from the Abbey. The audio tour was an excellent innovation ... probably not new to anyone except me. It really helped identify the surroundings, and make me reflect..... reflecting that the Abbey was really an old indoor graveyard to allow the rich rulers of the day to leave their memory behind........and reflecting that Poet Corner plaques to people like James Joyce and DH Lawrence seemed incongruous in a church setting After that coffee bought and taken in the cloisters seemed almost normal.

Very crowded. Very impressive Abbey but minimal audio guide, seemed like they wanted to get you through as quickly as possible. It was extremely busy so this is understandable, but just a bit more detail would have been very welcome - and made you feel a bit more welcome.

Fabulous place but steep entry prices. I visited London in the summer and at the time decided to see St Paul's instead of Westminster Abbey. When i found myself back in the city again this month i thought it was time to see the Abbey, especially in the year of the Royal wedding.The entry fee is pretty steep £16 if i remember rightly. But for that you get an audio guide and plenty of time to explore the place at your own pace.I felt the audio guide was pitched perfectly. Enough information to make things interesting and add to your knowledge, but not too much to be boring or feel like a history lecture. Its voiced by Jeremy Irons.The thing i enjoyed about the place the most was that the historical figures who were involved with the Abbey and are buried here, are the people you learnt about in school and are in films etc now. So you already know a bit about them which, for me, made it far more interesting to learn a bit more through the audio guide and see where they were buried.The surprised about the Abbey was the scale of it. Inside was mostly as i had imagined, but there are lots of little chambers off the main part. There is also a lovely courtyard area which we spent a while wandering around.We were there for around 90 mins which for us was enough time to see everything that we wanted to without feeling overloaded. One tip is that we arrived as it was opening on a weekday morning and found that the volume of people was entirely manageable. The audio guide often said "this part of the Abbey is very busy so make sure you keep walking here". So its obviously somewhere that can get a bit overwhelmed with visitors as the day goes on. We never had to compete with lots of tourists and had time to look at things for as long as we wanted to. So maybe its a good idea to make this your first port of call on your day of sightseeing.

One of our favorite sites in Europe!. My boyfriend and I visited the abbey in September and Paid an extra 3 pounds to go on a tour. Our tour guide was very informative and kept the group interested and asking questions for the whole 2 hours or so. It is also worthwhile to take the tour as you get access to Areas of the church that aren't open to the public. Would definitely recommend visiting the abbey.

Tour was great. We lucked out an arrived at the Abbey in time to catch the day's last tour with Canon's Verger David Mott. He was fantastic! The information he provided was so interesting and we were able to see things in the Abbey that are not ordinarily open to the public. It was well worth the time!

A must for history buffs!. If I had to choose between the two, I'd go with St. Paul's, but being lucky enough to have time for both, I was thrilled to visit the Abbey. Highlights include the tombs of Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots, and King Edward's chair, which has played a role in the coronation of every monarch since the 11th century. A wonderful Who's Who of English literature, Poet's Corner features memorials to great British writers buried elsewhere as well as those entombed at the Abbey. As an American, I was pleased to see T. S. Eliot and Henry James remembered by their adopted country. And the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, surrounded by poppies, is a moving sight indeed.I'm a little shocked by previous posters' suggestions that the admission fee is too high, and it dismays me to think that people would "sneak" photographs despite the plainly stated prohibition. Avoid the crowds by arriving early, before the doors open, and spend a half an hour in the queue. You'll have a chance to admire the splendid exterior and chat with other excited tourists. I've read many recommendations of the verger tours, which cost a little extra. No doubt they're excellent, but I found the audioguide to be more than adequate. Jeremy Irons' narration makes a delightful companion to a thousand years of English history.

Disgracefully expensive. £16 to get in, need i say more, it used to be free! I am seething with rage at the outrageous price for entry.You are being taken to the cleaners if you pay £16 to get in, great building, disgusting price for entry.Personally I believe that whoever chose to charge £16 to get in should be pelted!What is going on in London, is nothing short of a mass scale fraud.... On the public.

Don't rush your visit - linger & enjoy!. I stayed for four hours and could have spent another four in such a peaceful, beautiful & historic place. The audio guide was helpful, but I wish it had been a little clearer about the locations and only a portion of the Abbey's contents are covered. I left wishing I knew more. But, there lies my excuse for going back! Wear good shoes, and listen for announcements of prayers being offered and services being held. Now I can say I participated in a communion service at the Abbey, and it was the highlight of my trip to London.

Lots of History, but There are More Beautiful Cathedrals. After enjoying so many of London's great attractions that charged nothing or some modest entry fee, I must say that the cost of admission to Westminster Abbey was not a great value relative to what's inside. Don't get me wrong, it's certainly a nice place that gets pretty crowded even when it's not peak tourist season, but it isn't a breathtaking. awe-inspiring experience by any means. There are certainly tombs and tributes to a great many famous historical figures and giants of the various arts, etc., but...if you're looking for a breathtakingly beautiful venue: go to St. Peters in the Vatican or almost any church in any major city in Italy. Although it's a nice touch to have Jeremy Irons doing the 'play-by-play' in the audio guides, his slow, monotonous tone only adds to the sense of 'ho-hum' after you've been there for 20 minutes.

Good Visit. Westminster Abbey is another one of those attractions in London that is probably rated as a must see. I agree with some of the other peoples comments that the price can seem a little high, and yes, there are much better churches around Europe, but its Westminster Abbey, and worth a visit. I definitely recommend getting the audio guide, as there is quite a bit to see inside, tombs of previous Kings and Queens, and other various sights inside, including a nice little courtyard on the way out.Glad we went there, so if you're unsure, I'd say you should go rather than miss it.

Beautiful church, but a tourist trap. Westminster Abbey is an absolutely beautiful structure, however, the Abbey charges GBP 16 entrance fee just to walk through the church. Photography is not allowed inside the church. Very crowded with tourists.

Take a guide if you can or at the very least and audio guide.. Check opening hours carefully before you visit and allow for very long queues in main holiday season to get in. Best done with a visit to Houses of Parliament as they are adjacent.There is enough written to know this is a "must see place" in London. It is a huge abbey and on first entry a bit overwhelming inside. To make sense of it all you really need to go with a guide if you have time.Failing which audio guides in a limited number of languages were available. Not much use to my Vietnamese friend though.Why don't they do more languages?If you don't do either of the above you may just feel a bit lost by it all.All the usual facilities are available.Metro stop is Westminster. If you are lucky the bells in the adjacent church may be pealing whilst you wait to get in.

A must if you don't mind paying 16£ !!!. Westminster Abbey is a must se in London. The audio guide with the voice of Jeremy Irons is good.I must however protest paying such a high fee (16£) and not be able to take ANY pictures. They are quite direct if not rude to anyone caught trying to take a picture. If their booklets actually had any great shots you could just buy it and be done for the day. This is not the case. The Abbey has so many beautiful details that it is unfortunate not to let people take any photos (without flash). If most of the big museums let you take pictures, surely they could as well...

Magnificent and historic abbey. Westminster Abbey is a beautiful and ancient abbey which contains the tombs of kings and queens, poets and other illustrious historic figures. The excellent audio tour allows visitors to go round the building at their own pace. A splendid and moving experience.

Great Cathedral, But Once You've Seen One..... Westminster Abbey is definitely worth a visit, and I would recommend doing it inconjunction with the guided tour of the Houses of Parliament as the stories go together well.There is a fee (about $30 USD) but that includes the audio guide, which was vital to the experience. It gets very crowded inside, but you are able to see everything and keep moving. It took about 60 minutes to go through the audio tour, and I spent another 30 sitting and looking around (had time to kill before the tour of Parliament) at the end. So relatively quick visit (its very crowded, so it is not easy to stroll through). They do not let you go backwards, so once you move forward you must keep going forward on the audio guide path.
