I found it worth the visit due to its historic values, but honestly once you have seen one cathedral (i.e the Vatican or Notre Dame), they all kinda run together...or the visit loses its "wow factor" in my opinion.Overall worth the visit and a must-see in London.

WESTMINSTER ABBEY - WASTE OF TIME & MONEY. Don't waste your money paying to enter Westminster Abbey. Take photos outside and move on. Save your GBP 16 for something else more worthwhile.1) There isn't much to see inside unless you are a fan of tombs or would like to pay your respects to some famous dead people ! There are other churches in Europe which have far more beautiful interiors that cost less than GBP162) No photographs - There is CCTV everywhere and the staff will chase you down like a fugitive if you dare sneak a snap. They were extremely rude to some tourists who tried to take photos. This is how desperate they are to get you to buy the postcards and books in the bookstore. 3) Long queues - I would say the main reason for this is because the staff at the ticket counter are inefficient. When it came to the person in front of me, the person in charge of selling the tickets suddenly left the counter and for awhile nobody came to take over

Fascinating, a must for British History buffs. I visited on a quite rainy day and wasn't able to get the full effect of the outside, but took the audio tour as I went through. I am an avid history buff and was not disappointed at the richness of history throughout this building. I did not witness any live tours on this, my first trip, but I would definitely do a live tour next time to get a fuller effect and I would leave myself more time (I had about 2 hours).

Definite Must-See, Absolutely Beautiful and Historic. We visited and loved it. Very beautiful and lots of history every. Audio guide was included in the fee, which was not cheap, by the way. But we were satisfied. (Except for the ban on photography, which I think is unreal. Photography is allowed everywhere in the Vatican except the Sistine Chapel, which is too small for the size of the crowds already, and although Westminster is crowded there was no reason to ban photography. I guess this is just another point on which the Anglican Church differs with the Vatican.)

A very interesting visit. My husband and I visited the abbey expecting that it would be just another interesting church that we could peruse quickly. We were surprised to find there was an entry charge and almost turned away, but were glad we didnt. This is not like any other church we have seen. Not only is it a beautiful building, but it has a very interesting history which was detailed in a rather organized manner utilizing an audio guide with short and succint explanations that made the visit very interesting, informative and not at all tiresome. Having had a little bit of a history lesson on the kings and queens of the country was quite helpful as we were given a tour of their resting places. We got to see memorials to and resting places of manys famous English poets, scientists and writers, including Shakespeare, George Elliot, Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin. It was worth the entire amount spent and a lovely cap to our last day in London. There did not seem to be a strict dress code, but then seeing as it was a cool rainy day everyone was dressed warmly and therefore conservatively. Some areas would prove difficult to manouevre for wheel chair occupants and I would recommend comfortable shoes. On the whole a tour of the place, with my compulsory stop at the gift store (much to my husband's chagrin!), took about 1.5 hours.On the whole, highly recommended.

Too busy for me, but a nice building. The Abbey was something I kinda wanted to see, but was not set on; I was not about to spend ages in a queue, so I did not go inside. From the outside, the building is stunning and located in an interesting part of London near plenty of other interesting locations. Definitely worth a look - queue and go inside if that is your thing, but otherwise take a look at a stunning building then move on to the other spots.
Beautiful. This is a must see in London. We were lucky enough to here the choir sing while there! Get there early or wait in line forever!

Great History. I think the goal of the Abby was to put as many monuments as possible in one building. Too much to comprehend really. Check out the lesser rooms and the older buildings. The detail of the old buildings and construction was of more interest to me than what king was buried where. Hey how is that Charles Darwin is buried there! Didn't he write something about evolving from apes and not in God's likeness? Anyways, well worth visiting.
awesome. A must see for anyone visiting London. There is so much history here.

Interesting, but... We got there on a very crowded day that probably took off from the experience... Admission was a bit too high and the guide was not working properly on some places. Would love to take the tour again on a quiet time when it is possible to take it all in. It felt way too touristy.

Westminster Abbey is a real treasure that anyone visiting London cannot miss.. Westminster Abbey is so much more than just a cathedral or 'abbey'. It's an historical gem, just walking through the various rooms and learning about the history of the many people buried there and remembered there is an education in itself. The crowds are well managed and for the most part the audio guide is quite helpful, though near the end some of the stations have been omitted. Take the time at the end of your tour to sit around the benches that encircle the inner courtyard (The Cloisters) and just try to imagine all the famous people that have looked at the same walls and feel the history - amazing!

We go again and again. This is our favorite attraction in London. We visit every time we come to London and usually add the Verger tour. What a wonderful combination of history and religion this is. We have a tour book of who is buried in various locations and always find some new tidbit of information when we visit. The Henry VII chapel is absolutely beautiful, and the statues in there are great to look at (bring binoculars for these). Look up and see where the Monks came into the Abbey at night along the second floor wall. Don’t miss walking around the cloisters and the Chapter House with the old wall paintings.

Best Attraction in London. DO not miss this incredible place, the place where kings and queens begin and end their reigns over the centuries. Here you can match history to reality with the actual tombs and deathmasks of regents long gone who put civilization on it's present course.Use the audioguide, and don't rush through, there are maximum thrills per minute here.

Great place to visit. This is a great place to visit with school age children. So much history and so much to see. Really a unique place. Our granddaughter was interested throughout our whole tour. They give you recorders that explain much of the interior of the Abby. There are also many nooks and crannies to explore. We didn't get to see it all, so we are planning to go back. A great way to spend an afternoon.

Interesting but over-priced and rude staff (religious and othrwise). We arrived about 30 minutes before the last visitors were allowed. 16 pounds sterling each for admission (about $25). For that you got a handset, a map and overbearing staff and probably volunteers who rushed you through (we did not even get to see everything before we were being pushed to the exit). One of the clergy was conducting a private tour and generally pushed his way past us on a number of occasions and was speaking so loudly that we could barely hear our little hand held tour handsets. They kept telling us to move along, not to linger.Distasteful that the church would charge so much and then provide such a poor quality experience. But then again, churches tend to be about the money.I would not do it again.
Was disappointed at lack of respect shown by visitors. Was disappointed to see all the trash left behind at the door to Westminster Abbey. Shame on all the tourists.

Worth having a tour. Yes, it is expensive, and yes, you get an Audio Guide Jeremy Irons) included in the purchase price. But for 3 pounds more, if you come in at 10:30 you can get a great tour in English which includes the Edward III area which otherwise is not open for viewing; it is quite interesting in and of itself, and the tour is exceptional. Ours was given by a docent of the Abbey who had a great deal of personal information at his disposal, including information about the recent royal wedding for one thing (if you like that sort of thing), and about the ultimate disposition of Oliver Cromwell for another.It's hard to believe this is the #30 London attraction behind Mamma Mia and Priscilla, but there it is. When someone does a one man Benny Hill Show I'm sure that will top the Abbey too.

Took my breath away. From the moment I walked through the doors until I stood before the tomb of the unknowm warrior at the end of the tour, I was speechless. These walls contain so much history and beauty and we all enjoyed having our own personal electronic "guide". I just kept thinking about the Royal Wedding and Diana's funeral and so many other historic events that have taken place there. To walk where kings and queens have walked was truly awe inspiring. I highly recommend a visit to these hallowed grounds.

The spiritual history of the Nation in one building.. I have been to 'the Abbey' a few times in the past, but my Wife and Grandsons (11 & 12), had never been. The queues to get in were uninspiring, but fortunately it didn't rain. One queue was for cash entry, and one for cards. Surely an anachronism in a digital age; and very annoying for the few who had just 'joined a line' as it was not apparent until reaching the door which queue was which unless you went to the front first to find out what was going on. (we did)The Abbey itself is spectacular and crammed with history, although one cannot help but feel it is out of time and place in the here and now.I very much felt that I was in a museum rather than a Cathedral Church and place of worship. The 12 year old enjoyed it, the 11 year old was bored. The coffee shop was of reasonable price and quality but really ought to invest in some tables an chairs.On the whole, an enjoyable enough couple of hours, however, many years will pass before I would consider a revisit.

Outstanding to visit - inspiring to participate to a Mass. The building itself is outstanding and perfectly conserved. Visiting it at dawn the interior will gain an unique color and acient athomsphere that is quite rare to find.If you are very luck you'll be able to partecipate to one of the Mass where in the simple perfection of celebration, choir, music it will really inspire.

You won't believe who's buried here!. Westminster Abbey is a must see. The church is beautiful and it's fun to picture who was standing/sitting where at Kate & Will's wedding. But the most fascinating part of the tour (audio - very good) was who is buried there. There are, of course, some kings and queens, but also a "poet's corner" and lots of very recognizable historical figures. After the tour, we just walked around and read the names of the people we were walking on!

Beautiful but Expensive. The admission fee was pricey, but Westminster Abbey is so gorgeous and has so much history that we couldn't pass it up. We were mostly interested in visiting the Poet's Corner -- a section of the South Transept of Westminster Abbey because of the number of poets, playwrights, and writers buried and commemorated there. It was beautiful!We didn't get an audio guide and weren't part of a tour, so we walked ourselves around. It was crowded, quiet, and we didn't stay long at all. You are not allowed to take photos inside either.I'd say this is worth seeing if you have your heart set on seeing all of London's historic and/or religious properties, but if not, save your money.

Beautiful - but crowded. Westminster Abbey is one of the must see attractions in London. There is so much history here. Inside, the Abbey is packed full of monuments and tombs of Kings and Queens, poets and scientists.I did find that the audio guide was sub par when compared to many other audio guides I had used at other attractions in the UK. I suppose because it is so crowded that they don't want you hanging around in one place too long so unfortunately you don't get much detail. Another thing is that you cannot take photographs. Again this is likely due to the extreme crowds and not due to any religious issues. If everyone was trying to take photos it would be a mad house. I have taken photos at several other Cathedrals and Abbeys in the UK without issue - but none were as crowded as Westminster Abbey.

What an amazing historic place!. I went in the early to middle of the afternoon when it was not very crowded. There are always crowds but it was moderate when I was there. The admission price is a little steep but worth it. The history, architecture, and the exhibits were spectacular. Easily spend 1 to 2 hours here. I would like to attend evensong or a service in the future. MY favorite parts was the Lady Chapel, the cloisters, and the quire part. I bet all the royal weddings here were magnificent.

Beautiful, Busy and Expensive. The Abbey is just beautiful and so full of history. But £16 per adult is expensive. The queue waiting to go in was very long and be careful. There are two queues one for paying by credit card and one for paying by cash. In the half an hour we queued two couples left as they realised they were in the wrong queue. The staff are all very friendly and the abbey itself is lovely. As we were leaving it was around 2pm and we noticed there was hardly any queue so maybe that would be the best time to go.

History and more history. Very impressive !!!When visiting , guided by the magnificent voice of Jeremy Irons, I thought: the whole British history and literature are burried here.Only a country where tradition is among the most important things to preserve could have such a monument well kept along centuries (and even millenia).I was very impressed by the tomb of perhaps the most important monarch of England - Elisabeth I- This church is far from being just a church.. is a proof of how the history passed and of the most important participants in this history, a vivid museum.Some of the cornerstone moments of this country's history took place here: coronations, burials ...;not to forget the Poets' Corner from Geoffrey Chaucer to Dylan Thomas ,passing from Dickens to Oscar Wilde and evidently Shakespeare (they were not necessary all burried here,but commemorated by a stone or a window/ statue)Here are also giant actors as Garrick,Laurence Olivier, great politicians,scientists and the list could go on and on..Very impressive is the grave of the Unknown Warrior all surrounded by red silk poppies.My last lines shall be those written by Laurence Binyon: "They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old:Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn.At the going down of the sun and in the morningWe will remember them."

Wonderful! Don't miss the Vicar tour!. This 1000 year old London landmark is filled with extraordinary history and magnificent statuary. I would recommend getting there at opening or preferably before to avoid massive crowds. I would also sign up for the 1.5 hour vicar tour. This is a inexpensive addition and was fascinating. You will need to reserve a spot for this in advance by calling the Abby the day before. There are only about 15 people allowed on the tour. Our vicar was the one seen on tv that led William and Harry to their seats before the recent wedding! Sandwiches are available in the courtyard behind the Abby where you exit.

Not worth the price of admission. The cost of admission is expensive and the crowds inside are huge. The interior of the church is not as pretty as St. Paul's Cathedral and far more crowded. On the day I visited, it closed at 4:30pm and the last entry was at 3:30pm. If you're going to go inside, enter at least 2 hours before it closes. One hour is not enough. I entered at 3:30pm but at 4:00pm (half an hour before closing) they start to shut down the various parts of the church. So there was a lot I couldn't see because the crowds inside slow you down and they close down access to areas starting half an hour before closing. I think it's worth seeing from the outside but probably not worth the cost of admission to go inside.

I liked it.. It was very nice to visit Westminster. However, you can see relatively the same thing at the York Minster in York with much less crowds. But, you must visit one of these churches to get a real sense of how much people in the past cherished Christianity.

Great Experience. Westminster is beautiful. Be sure and tour it. We actually attended a Sunday evening service. It was very intimate, very few people there. We were so glad we went. Then in April during the 'Royal Wedding' my daughter called and announced "Mom - the Middletons are in our seats." Indeed, they were sitting exactly where we had sat for the service. A neat reminder of our trip!

One Of The Best Things About London. Westminster Abbey is a must see and is totally worth the entrance fee. The content and history of the abbey is absolutely stunning and it's quite overwhelming to try to take it all in, in one visit. I arrived early on a weekday so the cue was not too long. There is a free audio guide. Although this seems good a first, don't get too excited. The accompanying map is misleading and being swarmed with fellow visitors, it is not hard to get lost. The audio guide wasn't very extensive and kind of gives up after the main things to see. A few items have just a voice saying "no entry". I would have liked more information but I guess that is what Wikipedia is for!

Spectacular!. During our London visit we attended an evensong service at Westminster Abbey. It was absolutely ethereal. The Abbey closed in the afternoon & the guard at the gate almost turned us away until I inquired specifically about the evensong service at which time we were granted entry. We were then ushered quickly along to the seating area. This service was by far the high point of our London visit. The choir was like listening to angels singing & then to have the experience in such historic surroundings was enough to give me goosebumps. An absolutely incredible experience!

Wonderful Historical Site. Yes, I know this is a "working church"...however it felt like a museum and so full of history.We spent about 2 hours here and used the audio guide....it is well worth the expense. It is spread out over a very large area and much walking in crowds is experienced. We arrived at 9AM sharp and stood in line for about 15 minutes...there are two lines for admission...one for credit cards and one for cash...both were very speedy. When we departed we did see that the line was out to the street and then some...many tours arriving and my opinion is that you do not need to be on a paid tour if you use the audio guides but the extra knowledge of a tour guide could enhance the experience. I would say that very young children could not possibly understand any of the history and the crowding would be a hindrance to those with strollers etc.The footing and small amount of stairs was easy to navigate.

One amazing building. It was so big, I couldn't fit it all in my camera! We spent a long time in the grass outside, just staring at the size and detail of this amazing historic structure. The line to enter was extremely long so we opted not to go in but even just seeing the outside was incredible. Definitely worth stopping to check it out.

Great, lots to see. We arrived just after 9.30am and already the queues had started but they moved quickly so it wasn't too bad. Make sure you get in the correct queue- cash or cards, they're signposted. Once inside there's so much to see, really interesting. The audio guide directs you but you can take it at your own pace. It was busy even on the morning but we found that the further along the your, the quieter it got. The museum, grounds, garden and the royal wedding photo exhibition were all quieter and there was more space to wander. It's also nice to experience the offer of prayers on the hour, everybody pauses for a couple of minutes. So much to see you need at least a couple of hours. It's a beautiful place with lots of history and atmosphere, definitely worth a visit.

Spectacular but yet also intimate. I've been to Westminster Abbey many times over the years, but I decided to attend the 5 pm Evensong service while there in early August 2011. It was a simply beautiful service and brought the abbey alive for me in ways I had not experienced previously. Highly recommended to experience Westminster in this way.

Very Nice, a little too 'touristy'. My wife and I went to the Abbey on Monday August 8, 2011 at 1pm. We had the London Pass so we were able to bypass the long lines for those without tickets or paying with a credit card. It was very crowded but worth a visit. Includes an audio guide. You just get the feeling while there that they were trying too hard to appeal to the tourists.

Historic, beautiful and busy. I feel ashamed giving this an average review - but I did have 2 teens in tow.. so have to be honest about our experience - but I will explain :D. The abbey is fantastic - included in the ticket price are audio guides. The English audios are narrated by Jeremy Irons "Scar" in Disney's Lion King - although known invariably for this part he is a classically trained actor with a lovely emotive voice. You cannot take pictures inside the abbey itself - but there are still opportunities to take pictures in the gardens and cloisters.When we arrived (afternoon) it was very very busy - and indeed, this was mentioned in the audio so this may be an ongoing factor at any time of the day. I enjoyed the break when a cleric went into the pulpit, requested silence and stillness (which in the main was adhered to by the tourists) and he delivered a brief prayer.Fascinating to see the richness of history - helped immeasurably by the audio ... our two teens listened throughout ... but were rather quicker than us at going from place to place (throughout the abbey there are key points numbered and you key in the number and listen to the brief description of the history). They ended up waiting for us to finish. They waited quietly - remembering that the abbey is a place of worship - however I wouldnt advise taking very young children .The Abbey gift shop was good - all price ranges were available... saw no tacky gifts.

Amazing and wonderful. Can't speak highly enough of this visit, the history is amazing. We got there early as a line forms fast, one for cash and one for credit cards. This was a highlight of the London Trip. The woodwork and workmanship is just breathtaking.
Rip off. This is far too expensive. There are two lines depending how you intend - one for cash the other for credit cards. Churches are supposed to be Holy Places should be free....!

Beautiful building but very crowded.. I really admired the stained glass in this beautiful church built centuries ago. To think that people have worshipped here for hundreds of years and that so many historic coronations and weddings have taken here is just amazing. So many people in mid-summer in a not-so-big buidling and the sparse washroom facilities were the only drawbacks.

Not that great. Visited here on a wet Thursday morning. The line to get in was quite long but it only took about 15-20 mins to reach the entrance in the "cash only" line. Having collected an audioguide we proceeded along the guided tour. Overall, the information provided was very limited and hardly worth the effort of listening. Some of the commentary in the cloistered wasn't even working. The abbey itself isn't spectacular to be honest. Sure, there are the tombs of dead queens, kings and other important people but the building itself and the way everything was organized in it was unimpressive. I wouldn't recommend this if you were tight for time in London or tight for cash, at 16 pounds it's definately overpriced.

Unpleasant in July - far too many people in far too small a space. So I went yesterday because my mum wanted to go:Pros: There are two queues outside; one for cash and one for credit cards and the queues move quickly so that was good. Your bags are checked, which is good and I rather liked the fact that no photography is allowed so you weren't being elbowed all the time or having to dodge cameras.Cons: - very expensive £16 for adults, £13 for senior citizens.- it was heaving yesterday and I found that really unpleasant as we were being pushed and jostled all the way through. The place is much smaller than I expected.- some areas are really badly signposted so you don't know what number to press on your free audio guide. Could one of the guides walk around with the audioguide and check that everywhere is listed?- more tours please. We had just missed the 2.30pm tour, which seemed to be the last of the day, and for £3 it would have been good value for money.- really crass that you are directed through an overpacked, overheated, small gift shop at the end. Not on guys.- and what about Gift Relief for your entrance fee? Surely you have charitable status and I'm sure you have a fair number of UK visitors. You might be able to lower your entrance fee as a result!!I think I will go back in the Autumn when the crowds have died down and go for one of the non-fee paying services as advised by the previous poster.

Go to Evensong for a Heavenly Experience. Westminster Abbey is a great cathedral and is important as a place where royal weddings and coronations happen. And, of course, there are many, many famous people buried there. The building itself is impressive but there are better elsewhere. What set it apart for us from so many churches and cathedrals all over Europe was attending an Evensong service late in the afternoon with the all male choir with young boys singing the higher parts. Only Evensong at King's College in Cambridge was better. Not being Anglican or Episcopalean we weren't familiar with Evensong services but have decided they have to be the best church service available. When else can you get heavenly music, lots of scripture and prayers, all in 45 minutes, and NO sermon. Sounds perfect!Note that while there is a hefty fee to tour Westminster Abbey, attending Evensong is free. We found you notice a lot more when you sit in one spot for 45 minutes then when you walk at a regular pace through any building. Enjoy the atmosphere.

Highlight of our London Trip!. My husband and I visited Westminster a week before the Royal wedding and it was WONDERFUL! We walked from Buckingham Palace after the change of the guard and got right in line to enter. Westminster is overwhelming at first glance because of all the monuments, shrines and memorials. With the use of an audio guide, it was very manageable. I spent a great amount of time just taking in all of the beautiful architecture and design. I also couldn't help but imagine the Royal Wedding that was quickly impending!The audio guide is extremely informative and the map helps to explain where to walk. Although there was a ton of people located throughout the Abbey, we never felt overly crowded. Be sure to check out this wonderful Abbey and remember that although it is expensive, it is worth the experience.

Huge rip off. Admission price is too high--16 pounds a person. Your purse is searched before you go in. No pictures are allowed in the abbey because they have several "well stocked gift shops" full of picture and postcards you can buy. Oh yes, you do exit through a gift ship. It' crowded and hard to see any of the features of interest. The staff is RUDE. Horrible experience. Don't waste your money. Take pics from the outside and go somewhere else.

Impressive! Worth the money.. After watching the Royal Wedding on TV and how different and beautiful Westminster Abbey is, we decided to it will be one of the few "pay" attractions that we will visit in London. We thought admission wasn't cheap, but it was worth it!We were given audio guides to tour the abbey at our own pace. There were many people, but people weren't pushing and we were able to spend as much time as we want to appreciate the beauty and history of the place. Our guide book recommend 2 hours, but we spent almost 4, listening and reading every single details. It is more than just a church. The audio guides gave us a good history about London and the abbey. It is an impressive place to visit.

Don't Miss It!. Oh, how I loved Westminster Abbey. We visited more churches and cathedrals than I can even count on our trip but Westminster Abbey was my husband's favorite. Yes, it is super busy and yes, it is hard to turn around without bumping into someone but it is worth it 10 times over. The church has so much history in its walls and more memorials and monuments than anyone can keep track of. If history is not your thing, that's OK---just go inside and take a seat. Look at the amazingness surrounding you! While the church is humongous it surprisingly has a homey feel to it. The High Altar was gorgeous, the cloisters were jaw dropping. The only thing that I didn't like was no photos (as is the norm in most churches). I just wish I could have a photo of this amazing church to show to people. We used the audio guides and found them extremely helpful and informative. At the top of the hour the staff takes a moment for a prayer which we were present for. Love, love, loved it!

Evensong at Westminster Abbey. I visited Westminster Abbey in 2000 and took the grand tour. On my last visit in December 2010, I didn't have time to take the full tour, so I went to the Evensong service. It was a rainy Winter Solstice evening, which lent itself beautifully to the serene atmosphere. The service is free, and a perfect, solemn way to end a busy day of sightseeing.

It's expensive but worth it !. I haven't been to WA for many years and I was really looking forward to my trip here. I must admit it was a fantastic couple of hours and extremely informative. I've listed below a few tips which may assist with your visit.Upon arriving at Westminster Abbey, the first thing you see is 2 long queues, which many people took one look at and walked away from. Dont. The queues move very quickly, so just join one.The 2 queues are for different payment types. When we were there the queue on the left was for cash only and the queue on the right for Credit Cards. Make sure you get in the right line!If you can, pay cash as this line moved quicker.There is no bag storage available. So i wouldn't suggest this is an attraction which you visit on your last day in London, and you are carrying lots of bags.The visit is expensive. £16 for adults. When some people saw this price, they got out of line and walked off. Dont. It may seem expensive to start with but it is definitely worth it.As soon as you enter the Abbey get a guided audio tour. They come in many languages and are very informative.There are also stands with guides to the Abbey located at the entrance. Pick up one of these as well.Together the guide and the map will plan your route around the building, ensuring you see everything and at the same time, you'll hear some great historical facts. The first 3 audio recordings are long, but stick with them, it's just sets the scene and the rest of them are much shorter.Make sure you visit every area you can get into, as there are some fantastic tombs and rooms through some of the tiny doorways you never would have thought to visit!The Abbey is vast and you could easily spend a couple of hours, if not longer, but looking at everything. Make sure you leave yourself enough time to see it all.Above all just enjoy your visit and soak up the historical atmosphere, it really is a special place and very beautiful.

Five star destination - decidedly two star visitor experience. There's no doubt Westminster Abbey is a magnificent building, full of history and royal and political associations. Unfortunately, the Abbey itself is clearly being used as a cash cow by those who run it. First off, you need to queue - and you'll be in that queue for a long time. When one finally reaches the ebtrance, one's bag is searched. Of course, we all have to accept that in these times - but that's no excuse for the brusque arrogance of the man doing the checking on the day I visited; he turned rudeness into an art form. Once inside, having paid a steep entrance fee, the Abbey is heaving with other visitors, giving little or no chance to appreciate the beauty therein. The Abbey also has a no photography rule. That's their right, of course, though I can't help thinking back to a visit to Notre Dame in Paris two years ago when I could take pictures of anything I wanted. What isn't pleasant is the the Draconian way in which the policy is policed. Worse, I downloaded an app for my iPhone ahead of my visit. This app has been developed and is sold by the Abbey itself and contains a map and points of interest in the Abbey. Naturally I assumed I could use this app as I walked round - indeed the app would only make sense inside the Abbey itself - but I was snapped at (no exaggeration) to turn it off when I tried using it. Clearly, then, the app is regarded as another source of revenue and not an aid to the visitor. To say I was disappointed in the way the Abbey is run is an understatement. It could, and should, be so much better; the Abbey staff could learn lessons from, say, The Tower of London, where the Yeoman Warders and the Tower staff are magnificent. The pity here is that Westminster Abbey is a wonderful place to visit and I'd recommend it to anyone. But they really do need to brush up their customer service skills.

Absolutely Fascinating. This is a must see in London. The amount of history here is almost overwhelming. We started out with the audio guide (narrated by Jeremy Irons) but decided to pay the 3 pounds (yes, only 3 pounds) for the guided tour. Best three pounds we spent in London. The guided tour is an hour and a half and the verger who led the tour was very knowledgeable. He led us to many of the tombs of famous people buried here, including poets, authors, kings, queens, scientists, and politicians. But there was also a great deal of history about the cathedral itself, including its use in coronations and for the recent wedding of William and Kate. Plan to spend about three hours. Some tips: - Do get there early; the lines were much longer during the day - They do not allow photography - It is an active church, and every hour someone leads a one minute prayer, and they ask everyone to be quiet. About 98% of the visitors observed this; the other 2% got very dirty looks from the staff and other visitors. - Food, drink, and toilet facilities are limited. Take care of that ahead of time. - The gift shop had one cash register open upstairs, and there were about 30 people in line. At the back of the gift shop are stairs down to a gift shop annex area that has much nicer items and a second checkout, and there was nobody in line. This was well worth the time spent, and in terms of priorities I would put it on a par with the major castles (Windsor and The Tower).

Crowded - think about prebooking a tour. This was the most crowded place of our visit - over 1 hour to get in, elbow to elbow once inside. You HAVE to go here, of course, it is the most historic thing besides the Tower in London. It IS beautiful and historic. BUT.... even though we had studied some on the history, it is so overwhelming and so cluttered and so crowded, and the signage is very poor unless you are a latin scholar. There are many beautiful things that seem important but you have no way of knowing what it is.I wish I had prebooked a private guide here, or at the very least prebooked a guided tour. Of all the places in London this would have been the best to have a guide.

Amazing!. I loved Westminster Abbey, it was amazing, one of, if not my favourite site I visited in London. I made sure I was there for when it opened so there wouldn't be as many people. I was overwhelmed, in a good way, when I was inside. It's so beautiful that I cannot describe it, it's simply something you must see for yourself. I found the audio guide very helpful and informative. I could have spent hours in there looking around and I can't wait to go back and see it again.

Amazing church full of interesting chapels, monuments, artifacts and tombs.. Amazing church full of interesting chapels, monuments, artifacts and tombs. The audioguide is great, but also use a printed map to help find your way arround. The architecture is breathtaking. Make sure you also get to see College Garden. Beautiful! The admission fee is not included in the London Pass. Last time I visited, the entry fee was approximately $20 USD per person, but for me it was well worth it!

amazing but wasted to much time queueing for the toilet. We went on a coach trip to the houses of parliament but our tour never started till 3pm so we decided to visit Westminster Abbey. We wasn't disappointed what an amazing place we arrived at 12pm and followed the herd making our way through the abbey with the help of the hand set explaining as we were going along .The history and the abbey was fantastic and after an 1hr 30 sat down for a well earned cup of tea we had a slice of cake and a muffin also which came to £6.50 which i thought was reasonable but i did notice the a meat pie the size of a scotch pie was £4.50 which was massively overpriced.After our refreshments we went to the toilet before leaving This was at 2.10 .,that's when the problems began There seems to be only toilets in the poets corner of the abbey .We joined the queue which was very long ,we got talking to other people waiting and some of them did nor realize the queue was for the toilet the (sign was so small and waist height) so hastily left the queue we finally got to the toilets which are in a small yard outside at 2.30. People were getting wet waiting in the rain and i discovered that there was only 4or 5 toilets for the whole of the abbey which is quiet bizarre considering the amount of people.The toilets are unisex and had the wash basin and drier inside the cubicle.There is a shop outside the main Abbey but because we spent so much time waiting for the toilet we had no time left and we hotfooted it to our tour at 3pm at the houses of parliment .

Breathtaking. My husband and I decided to see the Abbey shortly after the wedding of the year ! It was absolutely breathtaking to see the history of the Abbey. We missed taking the private tour by 5 minutes and it was already overbooked, so get to the area early if you plan on a guided tour. We used the headsets provided and it wasnt all that bad. The history is fascinating to listen to and to see the detail craftmanship of the architecture was awesome. We spent 3 hours walking around. Don't even think of taking pictures. There are 2 lines at the entrance. One taking cash, the other charge. the giftshop was small but you will find a nice souvenir to remember the abbey by.

Enjoyed it immensely but leave your camera at home!. It was a thing of beauty and I was completely awed. We did have to queue for awhile but we went after noon and at a very busy time of day. I would like to go back at the opening so we could have more time, less noise and not have to walk around the inside like a herd of cattle. I would love to see a CG video on how cathedrals such as Westminster Abbey were built 1,000 years ago. I was very thankful for the audio guide as we would have been lost without it. I was very disappointed to see the "No Photos" sign as I bought a new camera for our trip to London, specifically to photograph the beautiful cathedrals. We went inside other churches, paid no admission fees and were able to snap away. However, we paid a steep 16 pound (per person) admission fee to Westminster Abbey and were not allowed to take a single photo. I'm not sure of the reason or if it has anything to do with the gift shop at the end. I had my camera around my neck since we'd been out sightseeing all day and my camera bag was in the bottom of the backpack my husband was carrying. I'm glad I'm not the only one who was harassed by the "tour guides" at the Abbey. I know some people do not abide by the rules (or perhaps did not see the signs since there were only a few and posted in English only) but there was no need to walk around like the camera police. The gentleman who spoke with me was extremely rude and was unnecessarily so. If they're going to be that strict about the rule then they should have a secure place for people to check their belongings at the door. Overall, it was a beautiful sight to see and we enjoyed it immensely. However, the admission was a little steep and I found the staff to be rude and unhelpful.

Don't miss this one in London - even if history isn't your thing!. Tried going here on a Sunday morning first, but as it's a working church, could only go inside if worshipping.That's fine - we came back after the Royal Wedding and enjoyed our tour then. The audio guides are great - gotta love Jeremy Irons rich voice telling you all about the Abbey - so you can listen to as much or as little as you like.My hubby thought it was basically a big tomb, but still enjoyed the visit. We were lucky enough to also visit the gardens and even the little museum/gift shop has some good displays. If you can have a bit of a private group tour, there is lots more to know and we did get to overhear that all the chandeliers were donated by the Guiness family - there's some trivia for you!It was busy, but not crazy - do try and set aside at least an hour to get the most out of your entry fee.

very informative audio tour. This is another attraction in London that is in the top of the things to see list. The cathedral is well worth the time spent - and expect to spend at least 1.5 hrs if not more. It isn't cheap to buy tickets but with that comes a very informative audio guide that walks you through the Abbey. The audio tour takes you all around the Abbey and talks about many of the parts you look at plus the history. What is really amazing is all the famous people buried at the Abbey, many of which you discover just by wandering around.Upon leaving the Abbey, there is an excellent gift shop that has souviners and books to cover everything about the Abbey

To Appreciate, some British History knowledge would help. We paid thirteen pounds senior entrance fee, but with the audio information on all the areas of the Abbey, well worth it. I'm not so sure that a foreign tourist would understand all the historical aspects, but all the interior monuments and names are well known to the British population. If you want to get the most out of a visit, a brief history of the British Monarchy would be beneficial. The actual building is awe-inspiring, how craftsmen were able to construct the soaring cathedral ceilings without modern machinery is a miracle in itself.

Entry fee is too high. Watching the Royal Wedding on TV I commented that I'd never visited the Abbey, so last Saturday we decided to be tourists and give it a go. We queued for ages to get in - to be expected: it was a Saturday, just after the Abbey's starring role on worldwide TV and it is high tourist season.The Abbey is an interesting visit for anyone into history. I was rather thrilled to see the tombs of some of our most famous sovereigns. I do not want to put people off visiting.But......I do have an issue with the entry fee. £16! What??!!! Britain take note: many other nations do not charge nearly as much for comparable sites, or they charge nothing at all. (We visited some of the greatest artwork in the world in Rome's churches and the only money we spent was voluntarily, in the gift shop and in the donation box - a fair exchange and as there were no charges, we spent and donated generously. I think people would do the same here.) After queueing and paying the fee we gained entry at about 12.30. The Abbey closed for worship at 1.30. Whilst no one actually told us to leave, as it neared 1.30 chairs etc were being moved about hastily by staff and it felt like visitors were now unwelcome. Fair enough, but if they want people to leave after just an hour perhaps they should not charge so much to get in. To add to the frustration, the parts I really wanted to see - the Alter screen, the Last Supper and the restored pavement were closed off and could only be seen from a distant and awkward angle. I know they are sacred and I didn't want to stomp about on them, but I would have liked a closer look. These are beautiful highlights of the Abbey.Places of worship are just that, not tourist sites, but if they are famous people want to see them. The upkeep and facilties need paying for...but the fee is too high.

so much history.... My wife and I visited here the day after the Royal Wedding. We waited in line about an hour and paid the 16 GBP entry fee, which seems very steep to walk around nose to tail inside for an hour or two. The "no camera" policy is a joke aimed at driving people to the gift shop. (I saw the same tact used in Italy on Holiday a few years ago.) That said, it is steeped in history and you get a real feel for the age of England when you walk through the Abbey. I'd go again in the future, but pick a less crowded time.

Fantastic. My review is about the piece of pavement just in front of Westminster Abbey which I occupied prior to the wedding of Wills and Kate. Most interesting views, very comfortable as it had two built in butlers who looked after me and provided foodHad a great time and will go again for the next wedding or coronation!!!!

Rip Off £16 each and treated like criminals because we had a camera. The Royal Wedding, the beauty of the trees and flowers inside the Abbey. We joined the queue on Saturday 30th April in the afternoon for an hour and then we were told we would not be admitted before it closed at 3pm. So we had to go back for the opening at 5.30pm. Now, we accepted this as it had been very busy obviously with the Wedding so we went to the London Eye in the meantime.We then joined the queue for Westminster Abbey for the 2nd time at around 4.40pm. We Eventually gained entry at 6.41pm, 2 HOURS waiting cost us £16 EACH...which we accepted, but.... then to be HARRASSED and CHASED, by staff all because my husband had a camera around his neck was appalling! Other people were subject to the same. We just could not get peace to look at anything in the Abbey withour some jumped up official was in our faces about our camera.We are miidle aged, we can READ and we saw the polite notice to advise that no photos were to be taken. But, all around we could see were small cameras or mobile phones flashing, and staff did tell these individuals to stop, which ok was fine. But to be challenged by some jumped up "official" when we abided by the no photo rule after paying 32 bloody pounds is bloody appalling. This was a total WASTE of our money the attitude of these wardens/ jobsworth whatever...there wasn't even any candles to light for our dearest departed. All we could hear was "turn your camera off, have you got a lens cap on that camera you are not allowed to take photos"Not once were staff there to help or guide any of us who had paid well over the odds to get into the Abbey.Well we reckon it was a rip off and we will be asking for our money back. Because they are a supposed House of God does not mean they can RIP off people, remember Jesus overturned tables because of money making rackets!

Very interesting and historic. We went in the middle of March so it wasn't too crowded. Arrived maybe 10 minutes before it opened, and it was just a matter of processing the line to get in, maybe 20 mins? I guess 16 pounds is on the pricey side, but I'm glad that we spent the money on this and not the London Eye. The free audioguide tour was interesting, everything is very beautiful in there, too bad that you can't take any photos in there, I had no idea that there so many royalty members and others are buried there. I would give yourself 1-1.5 hours to see everything. It's too bad that some of the other people who wrote reviews experienced rude parishioners, I found them to be very helpful and greeted us very warmly.

Boring and expensive and very RUDE Parishoners!!!. Was planning on spending a couple of hours here , however 10 minutes was long enough. Its looks really nice inside but thats about it. i remember asking one of the parishoners a question , and the response that i got was basically " sssshhhh". Time and money is better spent elsewhere!

One of my favorite places. I was at Westminster Abbey in 1987 and was so happy to visit again last month with my husband and 19 year old daughter. We are all very interested in history, and this place just oozes history! First, go as early as possible. There WILL be crowds, some of the areas are very tight, be patient and polite, but assertive when needing to move around.Second, I don't think 16 lbs (around $26 US) is asking a lot considering what you have the honor to see here. Think of it as a donation for upkeep of this beautiful Abbey. This place holds so many treasures of history! You do have to have an interest in these things, if you're in London for shopping, theater, and the nightlife among many other things, and have very little interest in history (to each his own) you may not appreciate it.However, if you're like me (and my family) pay the extra 3 lbs for the verger tour....it's extraordinary! You go into places in a small group that the general public IS NOT ALLOWED to enter. Our verger was an excellent tour guide, my husband, daughter and I were just so impressed with him and this private tour was priceless. We went into the chapel of Edward the Confessor for example, this is not open to the general public. Just awesome! I didn't watch the royal wedding except for a few moments to see the inside of Westminster and we were elated to see that our verger was standing behind Catherine Middleton during the readings! That was him with his verge ! Wow! I was actually on those steps that the couple were married on just last month with the verger who was standing right near them. Lucky us! Can't wait to go for the third time some day.

More history per square foot than anywhere else in London. Yes, it's crowded, pricey to visit and can get noisy, but you can't miss a visit here if you come to London. The church (yes, despite some reviews here, it is still very much an active, working church) is literally packed with the remains of Britain's most recognized names from history. Best bet to see it all and get a true feel for the history...take the London Walks tour on Mondays...meet at Westminster Tube station at 10:45 and you'll beat the entrance queues and get a personal tour...all for about 5 pounds more than you'd pay for admission to the site (16 pounds). Well worth having someone point out the hidden gems of the site and allow you to marvel at this man-made wonder.

Nice, but wish I'd spent the day elsewhere. Ok so the good points first.... It's beautiful and if you are around it's worth seeing. The bad points- firstly the 2 hour wait in line to get in. And the Italian tourists that decided to cut in line 20 mins before the end then pretend not to know English when we protested. That's hardly the Abbey's fault though. Secondly the massive entry price. Thirdly, when we got our audio headsets we found that my wife and mine were different. My commentaries were double hers and some sites that mine had commentary on hers didn't. When she took hers back they told her that MY audio was wrong. Because it was such a busy day, they were handing out the abridged version of the tour to get people through quicker. I would be more understanding of that if we hadn't just paid 16 pounds to get in. It was Easter Saturday and it had been closed for 3 days before and was going to be for 2 days after which explains why everyone was there and why it was so busy, but it wasn't a highlight of our trip. If you can come if it's an off day and you're and English history junkie or religious type then it's probably worth doing, but for me I wish I'd headed to the museum or one of the other places I've missed on this trip. Oh and keep your wife away from the gift shop. Probably another thing that's not the Abbey's fault ;)

Appauling, Rude, Church Parishioners. March 26, 2011 - I only had 7 hours in London. Due to a national protest taking place in the city which was another surprise, the buses were running at the speed of a 1 footed turtle, all taxis were experiencing the same difficulties as the buses, literally NOT being able to move, some of the trains weren't running, and getting to and from specific points was extremely difficult to do. I knew my time was limited so my expectations to make it to just 2 sites I felt was reasonable. One site was Westminster Abbey. By the time I found it, the Saturday afternoon church service was getting out. People were walking out the doors and I waited until most of the people had exited. There were 2 male parishioners standing by the gates where the people were exiting. I explained to both men I was from the U.S., I realized that I wouldn't make any tours, but I wanted to know if I could please just look in the doors, and not go in any further because I knew I probably wouldn't ever get back to see this church in my lifetime. I had been crying because of everything that could go wrong did go wrong on this day. Instead of a kind, or nice "no mam, I'm sorry but you can't" , these 2 men responded with "NO, that's just too bad for you lady". I was extremely kind and their lack of respect put me into more tears. They knew they had further upset me and told me to get out of their way. There was a couple that heard me that came out of the service and they tried talking to these 2 men and they were just as rude to them. Now, I'm a little confused with this. In the United States, when you visit a church people are friendly and helpful and don't treat you like you're a second class citizen. Shame on these 2 men. People like this, especially working in a church, give the reputation to London of being snobby and rude. Even if I could, I never want to go back. These 2 men should have their butts thrown out onto the street and not allowed to be part of a church. Obviously, people that have the appearance of having money are treated completely differently.

Pricey but worthwhile. You definitely have to hit this tour at the right time or you'll wait in line forever. It is an expensive tour, and definitely annoying to not be able to take pictures, but the audio guide is well done. As expected, it is just gorgeous inside. It is neat to be in a spot where so much history has taken place and literally surrounded by royalty.

not a church!!. It is a nice site. Amazing construction but it is not a church any more. It is more a cemitery than a church. Worth to visit but not if you love and look for churches. I am not very religios and I am saying that because I love to see the old churches.

Impressive, but expensive!. My brother and I visited the cathedral yesterday and the history and beauty of the place is amazing. However, there are some negative points I need to make, not about the building itself and its contents, but about the way tourists are managed. Firstly I was shocked by the price -£16 per person! I had thought of bringing my family to visit, but it would just be too expensive. This is our national heritage and should be accessible to everyone. There is no way people on lower incomes could afford these prices, meaning that this is a facility only for those who are well off. I don't think Jesus would have approved of this.The other thing was that initially we did not wish to use the audio tour, but wanted just to enjoy the atmosphere of the cathedral. This seemed to attract unwelcome attention from the stewards in their red gowns. One came up to me and said 'may I help you' in a very suspicious way because I was not walking in the direction as required by the audio tour. He then pointed to the audio equipment; when I explained we didn't want to use it , he looked perturbed and asked to see my ticket. In the end we did use the equipment, because the leaflet provided included very little information, and there weren't many information signs. At the end of the tour we realised we had not seen Queen Elizabeth 1st 's tomb and so asked another steward, who seemed shocked and asked to see our tickets, expressing disbelief that we had not seen the tomb.It seems that because our movements around the building deviated very slightly from the 'standard' tourist , we were seen as potentially dishonest.

Stunning and moving. We visited Westminster Abbey on Sunday 10 April and took aprt in the morning eucharist servise. It was a stunnign occasion with the sun flooidng through the windows and the wonderful signing of the choir. Afterwards we admired all the tombs of politicans and poets and the tomb of the unknown soldier. One of the great churches of the world and a magnificent London building.

So much history!. This is the place to visit if you're not into history but need to visit one historical location in London. It's interesting even for non-history buffs. I loved it. There's so much to see, and the audio guide is excellent. Interestingly, it's not only Christians that are buried here - lots of poets, political figures, scientists (even Charles Darwin!) are buried here. We also visited for the 12:30 pm communion service; if you're Christian, I highly recommend it. It was a very spiritual experience taking communion in the church where others had taken it for the past 1,000 years.
Awe Inspiring. Best sight in London. The free audio tour was well worth it.

Westminster Abbey - pay extra and do the Verger Tour. We went to Westminster and did the Verger Tour. The Verger reminded us of Rowan Atkinson. He was funny and informative. It is great to get to to to places that the rabble can't!Well worth it.

Good visit, but St. Paul's is better with kids.. We visited recently with two kids (ages 8 and 10). They said that the audio tour was inappropriate for children under 10, so we all ended up not using the audio tours. St. Paul's had an audio tour that was appropriate for the entire family.

Very haunting but magical place. I loved Westminster Abbey.It's a must-see when visiting London. It's been worn down a little too much by tourists, but it is just incredible. The architecture and sculptures are overwhelmingly beautiful.Some parts of it are a bit haunting and eerie, in a magical sort of way (if that makes any sense at all)It seems like everything was made of stone, there's not really any color in the place.The Poet's corner was my favorite, even though it was crammed with Japanese tourists stomping all over graves. That was annoying,Overall, I loved it and can't wait to go back someday.

Historical Landmark. Do Not Miss This!. We arrived just as the doors were opening on New Year's Day and were lucky enough to hear Big Ben chiming the hour. We used the audio guides to get around and I definitely feel like I learned more with them than I would have without. I enjoyed seeing the royal tombs, effigies in the museum, and walking around in Poet's Corner. In fact, when I returned to the states the next day, I went to see The King's Speech, and was overjoyed to have been where part of the film was based. Definitely arrive early to miss the crowd and use the audio guide!

See where William and Kate will get hitched. GOOD-- The Queen's coronation was here.-- William and Kate will soon get hitched here.-- There are audio and self-guided tours.-- Tombs of the kings.-- Tombs and memorials to poets and writers.-- Pure history and architecture.-- Staff were friendly and helpful.BAD-- You have to pay and it's not cheap.-- Eerie that there are so many tombs, i.e. dead bodies, in this place.UGLY-- The self-guided tour (map only) is not marked very well and is nearly impossible to follow.

A must see in London. Westminster Abbey is definitely one of London’s most important sights. Even if you are on a short visit to London, do leave some time for a visit to the Abbey – there is nothing like it to give you an insight into British history and culture. Besides, some parts of the cathedral (such as the Lady Chapel) are stunningly beautiful, and the Poets’ Corner is a must see for anyone familiar with British literature.The cathedral tends to get quite crowded at times, and more often than not there are lines at the entrance. One way to avoid lining up is coming nearer the latest admission time (which is 3:30 p.m. on most days and 6:00 p.m. on Wednesdays) – say, around 2:00-2:30 p.m. because if you come right at the end of the day, you might find some of the chapels already closed. The entrance fee is ₤ 15 per person including a free audio guide available in a big choice of languages. There is a separate line for those who want to pay with credit cards.Make sure you get the audio guide, which gives a fantastic commentary on all the highlights of the cathedral. Taking pictures is not allowed but the cathedral gift shop has a good choice of postcards, booklets, and books as well as different memorabilia. Don’t miss St Margaret’s Church next to the Abbey with some beautiful stained glass windows (the entrance is free).In addition to coming as a tourist, consider attending a daily service (there is an evening service at 5:00 p.m. on weekdays) or an organ recital on Sunday at 5:45 p.m. – and you will get a very special feeling of the Westminster Abbey as a living church not just a monument.

Don't leave London without a visit to Westminster Abbey.. This makes for a wonderful day out. A great old building with lots of interesting features.Pay a visit to the restuarant before leaving. If you pre-book on the official website there are some excellent deals available.

Not well publicised but well worth a visit. A visit to Westminster Abbey, which will cost between £12 and £15, is better organised, more interesting and at least as spectacular as a number of better-publicised attractions in London.
The audio guide is complimentary, comprehensive and very professionally done and the staff, in their distinctive uniforms, are very helpful.
A great diversion on a rainy day

Simply stunning, overflowing in history and beauty!. Entry fee is steep like most other london attractions, photography not permitted. Ques look big from outside but pass quite quickly. Audio guide is informative if not somewhat confusing with numbers and locatiuons but plenty of staff walking around to help anyone who needs it. This is definately something I am glad I visited in London

Westminster Abbey - Impreesive. Great place to visit if interested in the history of the kings and queens of UK. Many spendid tombs that you can view. Disappointing that you are not allowed to take pictures of them. Very impressive building. You get to see where the coronations take place.

Magnificant!. What a magnificant buiding filled with so much history! There is so much to see and learn here. It helps if you already know a little bit about the people resting there. It is worth every penny!

Do not miss this!. Even at £15 per person, this is well worth it. We happened to be the last two in line on the day we went, and we were only in London for a day. When you think about all the history that happened here, all the way back to Edward the Confessor and up to Princess Diana's funeral, it is almost surreal to be standing there. The upcoming royal nuptials will be held here too! The only negative is that you cannot take photos or videos. A free audio guide is given with wonderful Jeremy Irons narrating. Be sure to grab that. Don't think twice about paying that money. Go here.

100% pure history. I take an excursion with my wife on our recent visit to London. Actually walking along museums are not our favorite pastime. But I should admit that Westminster Abbey is a great place to see in London especially for those who like history. Audio guide is free but sometimes is boring. I was a little disappointed that photo is prohibited even without flash.

Highlight of my short trip. The highlight of my recent first time trip to london, great audio guide, from start to finish. Fills you with awe, whether looking up at the vast ceiling or imagining the monks chanting around the cloisters. Seeing the graves of so many kings, queens and liturgy greats was amazing, a little bit sad hearing about princess diana's funeral. Every room in the abbey fills you with awe, as you look at how this building was built with so much attention to detail.Don't let the admission price put you off. Although a few pictures would be nice, I could understand why it is not allowed as it may be disrepectful but I actually beleive that tourists going around with audio guides in god's house could be disprecptful aswell.

Expensive but worth it.. My wife and I have traveled quite a bit and have visited many cathedrals, abbeys, ect. When we saw that the admission price for Westminster abbey was 15 pounds each we almost decided not to go in. However we are so thankful that we did. We have never seen anything like it. We were there for a couple of hours at least just exploring the place. We also took advantage of the free audio guide which gave you a lot of information but after about an hour became maybe a little too much information. Don't let the admission price deter you this place is incredible.
i was so impressed. the admission is a bit steep to get in there and I did not think I would find it all that interesting but I was blown away with all the history there. you have to go!

Beautiful abbey. England's Westminster abbey is one of the prime attractions of London. It is located at Westminster just behind the Houses of Parliament and the Big Ben. On its side is St Margaret's church.You enter through the north side entrance and the fee is around 14euros and you are provided with an audioguide. The abbey is full of memorials of important English personalities, and the Gothic architecture is marvellous. Unfortunately it tends to close early (at 4.30pm) and thus we had to rush through the church. The Lady Chapel built by Henry VII is impressive! Also do not miss the Coronation chair which has been moved to a niche near the main entrance, the museum with all its important relics and the cloister areas. Unfortunately you cannot take pictures in the abbey - just in the cloister.
Worth a visit. Westminster Abbey ia a really impressive building full of history.

a beautiful and interesting experience. The visit to Westminster Abbey was one of the most intyersting thing my family and I did in London last August.The queue to access the abbey is quick and the staff inside is very polite and ready to help in any occasion.The audio guides (you can choose among a large range of languages) are very clear and interesting even for my children aged 9 and 12 who listened carefully to the story of the abbey all the time, following the map and the guide. They learned a lot. I would definetely suggest a visit. It's worth buying a family ticket if you travel with children.

Glorious!. Went to the abbey on our first day in London and luckily was in time for a Verger tour. The tour was very informative and provided a wonderful introduction to the abbey. The abbey is amazing -- the architecture (especially the lady chapel) and all of the history behind the different areas inside. Would definitely list as a 'must see' when visiting London!

Very impressive. I have to say that I did not know what to expect about Westminster Abbey. Having been to London 4-5 times, this was one of the "must-see" sites that I hadn't gotten to just yet. I am glad that I finally did.For those who have been to Europe a few times, thinking "this is just another church", I would argue that Westminster Abbey is quite different. First, unlike Italian churches which would be more about art and religion, this Abbey offers great insight into English history and the birth of Anglican church (ie - kings and queens). The architecture is also quite different from the Catholic, Lutheran, Orthodox churches that you will find on the mainland. Although not a huge fan of audioguide, I have to say that this is probably one of the best one that I have listened to. Narrated by Jeremy Irons, the audio passages are relatively short and to the point.As this is a place of worship, the opportunity to take pictures indoor is limited. The Abbey has a nice little gift shop aat the end that is surprisingly affordable. A good spot to get some London memorabiliaA throrough visit of the Abbey will require at least 60-90 minutes

An amazing building, only a few blocks from Parliament and Big Ben. We were stunned when we saw this building up close. It just rises magnificently into the sky. The architecture is so beautiful. Once we left here, we walked over to the nearby Parliament building, saw Big Ben, Downing Street, and the Queen's Cavalry.
Worth the entry fee. We hesitated on the entry fee after the London Eye, but we are so happy we visited the Abbey and listened to the audio tour.

Westminster Abbey sent shivers down my spine - in a good way. Not having any particular attraction to old churches, we visited the Abbey mostly to see where kings, queens and other greats of the past are buried. But we were blindsided by the awesome sense of history and breathtaking architecture inside; in the end, it was the top highlight of my trip to London,You will definitely need the free audio guide, if you aren't part of a guided tour (we weren't). This walks you through and points out the highlights. You can't help but feel a sense of awe as you walk slowly through the hushed chapels and rooms, past tombs of great kings and queens and historical figures, see the places where monarchs were crowned and the throne they were crowned on.The building itself is stunning. The ceilings in particular, are breathtaking even for a non-architectural type like me. Everything in the abbey seems ornate and detailed. One can only imagine at the time, cost and effort involved to build this place, bit by bit, over the centuries. It's a marvel of a place, and I am so glad we bothered to go inside.

Absolutely wonderful, stunning. I cannot rate the guided tour highly enough. How anybody can say the entrance fee and the extra £3 for the guided tour is too expensive is totally beyond me. 1000 years of history is here in this building, and the verger made it live for us. Not only did he take us to where 'regular' tourists cannot go (close to some of the medieval royal tombs), he was completely knowledgeable and his enthusiasm for this beautiful building and everything in it was so infectious. Everything about what makes us English is contained within its walls, from the medieval monarchs to the war heroes and poets and authors of our past all within a soaring building built to the glory of God. The medieval Cosmati pavement is permanently covered by a carpet but at the end of the tour I asked him a question about it and he took me behind the barrier and uncovered the pavement to let me see it in its glory. If you are at all interested in our history this is the most important historic building in England, and well worth seeing for its sense of history and glorification of God.

Wonderful!. Seeing Westminster Abbey was a highlight of our 10-day trip. We highly recommend the verger tour. The site was very crowded, and it really helped to have our guide leading the way. We might have missed important pieces otherwise. If you are a history buff, you won't be disappointed....there are many, many historic figures buried and/or memorialized here.

Deffinitely worth seeing. The Westminster Abbey is worth seeing and the headsets explaining all points of interest are essential. If you just walk through and look at all of the statues, the building, museum, etc. it will take you about 2 hours. If you have an interest in British history and listen to the entire recorded tour, one could spend the whole day there.

Verger tour was great!. We visited many abbeys in our travels, but this was by far the best! (As expected.) I am glad that I took the advice from the other reviews before we went and paid the extra 3 pounds for the Verger tour. This was amazing, our guide Benjamin was awesome...he wrapped up 900 years of history in 90 minutes. He was also very patience with our group and answered all questions..even some silly ones. If you are a little rusty on your english history the guide will get you up to speed in no time! We were also able to access many areas that were restricted to other tourists and really enjoyed being in the history of it all. Highly recommend!!

Beautiful, awesome, gothic!. I think this place was my # 1 favorite in London. Seeing it on television and in photos so many times made me want to see it, so actually being there was just wonderful. The building is stunning ... medieval, gothic, spectacular architecture ... and oh, the history. My husband and I used the audio tour guides, and we spent about 4 - 5 hours touring the tombs and the marvelous effigies. I really loved Poet's Corner. The icing on the cake of the experience was staying for Evensong and getting to sit with the Abbey choir. It was so moving that I cried a few tears of happiness, which thrilled my sweet husband. And when the service was over, we exited surrounded by the marvelous peeling of the bells. We walked over the long bridge and the bells could still be heard for blocks. What a great time! A wonderful memory that will last forever in my heart.

Nothing to get excited about. We took the tour on a recent visit to London. It does have a lot of history, but my family found the audio tour to be pretty boring. To be fair, walking through museums or cathedrals are not our favorite pasttime, but found this one to be pretty mundane. We found the history and tour at the Tower of London to be much more entertaining.

Do a bit of research in advance. A wonderful site, full of history. But that said, it will probably be most appealing to those who like history. If you know who Henry the 7th is, and his history, and Elizabeth of York, and then Elizabeth I and Mary, and even the various Edwards, it's going to be much more meaningful to you. You have to be able to puzzle together a bit of Latin, too, because nothing is marked well. Even with the audio guide it was hard to figure out everyng I wanted to because if something wasn't an audio "highlight" it wasn't mentioned. Read up in advance on who is here, and where, and you'll enjoy your visit much more.That said, it was amazing to be here, to feel the long reach of the historical vibe and I wouldn't miss it.

Worth the £15. The Abbey is most definitely worth the £15 to get in. The audio guides are free, and a must have for wandering around, they give lots if info without it being overload and boring. There is so much to see in the Abbey, all the tombs, Kings, Queens, Actors, Poets, Writers. There is plenty to keep everyone entertained. Allow a bit of time here to read the tombs and spot other well known names, enjoy the experience. It was a little crowded when we were there, and we had to back track a couple of times, but still enjoyed the visit.

One of my favorite sites. Of the sites that I've visited in London, this is among my very favorite. I've read a few grumblings about the entrance fee, but in all honesty, considering the historical value of this site and the need to maintain its preservation, I feel that it is a very small price to pay for the privilege to see it. At the time of my visit there was a group of preservationists restoring a floor mosaic from the 13th century, and I can promise you that kind of work doesn't come cheap. It is worth it to me to contribute.Anyway, along with your entrance fee you get an audio tour. Definitely pick up one of these, it really adds so much more to your visit and directs your attention to important areas that you might have otherwise missed. As a history lover, I was absolutely thrilled to be standing at the graves of so many monarchs and other noteworthy individuals in British history. While the full scale of the history you will come face to face with is staggering, the absolute beauty of the place is worth seeing on its own. There was one particular chapel with a delicate stone ceiling that was just stunning.If you're going to be in London, don't leave without visiting this landmark. It's a World Heritage site for a reason.

I'd seen it once, had to see it a second time (maybe a third?).. I have to say I tried to go around the Abbey as calmly as I could, trying to take in everything I could. There is a lot of history there, and a lot to see and learn. It especially helps if you know something about the people resting there. I was especially interested in Queen Elizabeth I, Queen Mary I of England and Mary, Queen of Scots tombs (interesting how they are now so close together).The people at the Abbey were very nice and very helpful.

Too Expensive!!. There are only 3 World Heritage Sites to see in London and £15.00 to get into a place of worship is just too much.The Christian Church is very rich - why are we paying this much when all the lovely museums in London are free, and as a council tax payer, I am paying so much anyway - and Westminster Council has so many very rich people living there.It is outrageous... I wasn't able to go in.. Are there not rules that if it's a World Heritage site it should be free???

Worth every single penny!!. Yes, the abbey is slightly expensive. However, its an absolutely brilliant experience. My girlfriend and I went on the Verger Tour around the Abbey (it cost £3 more) and it was one of the most enjoyable things we did on our whole holiday. The verger was intelligent, eloquent, friendly and immensely helpful. We were able to access one or two areas of the Abbey that other people are unable to get to unless they are on a verger tour (makes you feel a bit special ha ha), and every room, memorial and tomb that we saw on the tour was well explained and all questions the group had were answered well. The Abbey itself is an immense place - full of history and heritage. It is not a Cathedral and it is not the same as St. Paul's, so if you go there expecting something like St. Paul's you will be disappointed. I would also say that you should DEFINITELY go on a Verger tour as it seems to me this makes the experience so much more interesting, informative and worthwhile. Its cheap and absolutely fantastic. If your not able to do this for some reason then make you you get the audio tour, there isnt many signposts and you will definitely need some direction as well as explanation as to why things/people are important etc.If you do the verger tour, honestly, one of the best things you will do in London!

See Westminster Abbey for free!. I'm not sure I should let people in on this secret because it will make it more difficult for the locals and the people who know about it to attend, but here goes. You don't have to pay a thing to see Westminster Abbey. Attend Evensong, usually weekdays at 5:00 pm - check the schedule. This service is free! You don't have to wait in the main line that normal tourists wait in to tour the abbey.
