The Evensong service has a separate door on the side and there are usually a very small number of people lined up to attend the service. 1st people in line actually sit in the pews with the choir boys. AMAZING EXPERIENCE and I'm not even religeous. It was a reflectful calm in the storm of a whirlwind vacation. It was a highlight of all the things we did in London and something I'll never forget. After the service we were able to walk around a bit to see things. (St. Paul's conducts Evensong services too, but I did not attend that service. I'm sure it was just as lovely.)
Great, but expensive. Fascinating place to visit, but at 12 quid per adult, I am disappointed that the Church of England has turned this holy place into a cash cow. The British Museum nearby is free!

Expensive - but still worth the entry fee. So much history under one roof, but it comes at a price that made me gulp (£51 for 2 adults and 2 students aged 21 and 18), especially as we only had a little under an hour for our visit. I'd recommend double this amount of time to do the place justice.

Eyeball deep in English History. A chance wander round here made St Paul's seem a most sterile experience. From St. Edward, thought the tombs of Edward I, Henry VII & Elizabeth to the poets, engineers & scientists who made the modern world; this is truly a ride that carries the visitor through the history of Britain. It's also a superb building, the main cruciform of the church being of grand scale & the lady chapel quiet beautiful. Admittedly a great deal of what the building has to offer might be lost on those who have no background knowledge; while those who do might be disappointed by the audio guide information & maps, which is quite superficial. At £15 it's far from the cheapest attraction in London but if you have some knowledge of English history this is a must see.

Westminster Abbey-History in Progress. I was very excited to go to Westminster Abbey. I wasn't sure what to expect. I ended up doing a whirlwind tour of London (1 day), and just decided to go for it. When I walked through the doors, it was like walking back in time. It reached me on a level I wasn't expecting. I spent quite a long time wandering through the different areas of the Abbey, and I did go for the headset tour option...which I didn't use. It moved me along too quickly, and I personally thought it was confusing. So, I ditched the headset, and went along on my own. I respect that photos inside the Abbey are not allowed, since its still a place of worship. But it would have been cool to bring back photos and show people my experiece. I wandered around, in amazement, because I didn't realize this was the final resting place for so many notable people! The big surprise was seeing the tomb of Queen Elizabeth I and Queen Mary of Scots. There is so much history here, and while it doesn't have the glamour of St. Pauls, it does have centuries of history. And it continues daily with the services offered. Pretty cool to me. Also, as I was walking along one of the corridors, I found a very modern tribute to the soliders of WWII. It was cool to see such a modern object along centuries old walls.

Great place for children. Visited with my family and friends a few days ago and everyone absolutely loved it. What surprised me the most was how much the kids enjoyed it (ages 12, 11 and 9). The children were reluctant to go but we talked them into using the special guide designed specially for children to explore the cathedral. The children learned just as much, if not more, than we did. Since they were busy working on their guide, the adults were able to use the adult audio guide and explore the Abbey on our own. Everyone was happy.

A slice of history.. Even if you aren't a religious person (I'm not), Westminister Abbey provides a real sense of history and culture. The architecture is beautiful and it's really neat to see all the tombs of past royals. Make sure to get the audio tour or else you'll be hopelessly loss (there is very little signage or explanations within the Abbey). Some of the key rooms, such as the tomb of Elizabeth I, are awfully cramped, so you're asked to keep moving and to refrain from stopping (I managed to stop and appreciate it for a little bit). Admission is a little steep (15 pounds), so while I would recommend going, I'd recommend the Tower of London over Westminster Abbey as a paid-admission attraction (the tour at the Tower has a lot more to it, and you can spend a little more time there).

A suprise. This place suprised me a little. i did expect something extraordinary, but even so, I waas suprised. The place is an intriguing place to explore. The audio guide is very informative even if it doesn't talk so much about all the tombs of famous people. This part of the Abbey was very interesting. Once again - arriving early is a great advantage! The "No photos policy" pulls down the grade one step.

For me, a very secular experience. What amazed me about Westminster Abbey was that touring it felt like walking right through the last thousand years of British history. The people who are buried here are not all Anglicans. Many of them were not even good Christians, but they all made a contribution to British government, society, or culture in some way that bears remembering. I love that about this place. I suppose a visit to this vast church could be a religious experience for some, but I just found it to be spiritual in that it offers a profound sense of the continuity of human history and achievement. I was moved by the opportunity to stand at the grave of Elizabeth I, one of the most remarkable women of all time. I was also impressed that the Abbey proudly houses the tombs of several scientists whose works are considered by some to be in conflict with Christianity. That, to me, was the ultimate beauty of this place. Come here to be impressed by a connection to history, and you will not be disappointed. Oh, and by the way- despite the comments of a previous reviewer, Henry VIII is not buried here. You'll find him at Windsor Castle. His daughters, Mary I and Elizabeth I are here. So, too, are his son Edward VI and his short-term wife Anne of Cleaves, but that's it for the Tudor family.

from jackie. just got back.. Westminster Abbey was one of my favourite aspects of London. The fact that Henry the 8th's tomb is there was the main attraction, however I was amazed at the history and the other beauties of this amazing building. I really felt a sense of the depth of a spiritual experience while I was in there. There are tombs everywhere and a very strong sense of a higher power.

Do the walk in the Gardens as well!!. The audio guides are the best I've seen. Narrarated by Jeremy Irons, they conveniently correspond to the numbered areas to view. It has an on/off switch, so you can pause when you want or travel at your own direction. No need to follow a planned route. I couldn't help but think of Princess Diana's Funeral there & wished there was some recognition of it. Perhaps there was, but i didn't see it. The Gardens are beautiful & well worth a walk through & sit. The Abbey is dark & historical & awe inspiring, but it is nice to sit outside in the gardens & cloisters to rest your feet & have an moment of reflection amongst the beautiful plantings.

Disappointing and overpriced. Even though I am a lover of history, art, and architecture, I must take the minority view that Westminster Abbey was a disappointment. Yes, it's tombs and monuments make it a "Who's Who" of British history and culture... and yes, it is an impressive building. But, frankly, I would not list it anywhere near the top of my list of the most awe-inspiring churches and cathedrals that I have seen in the course of many years of travel. I felt that the admission price of 15 pounds (nearly $50 US for the 2 of us) was overpriced. Never in my life have I paid such a price to visit a church. Is the Anglican Church milking the Abbey for all it's worth, or have they set the admission so high in hopes of cutting down on the high tourist volume? If the later is the case, it hasn't helped. Which brings me to my next complaint, the abbey is so jammed with tourists (you truly have to squeeze through the crowds in some tight spots) that you lose the sense of being in a church. Finally, I am very respectful of restrictions on photography in churches... after all it is a place of worship. But after paying that admission price, and seeing the hordes of visitors trooping through the place, the restriction seemed ridiculous. Non-flash photography would not have distracted one iota from its dignity (or lack thereof).

Worth seeing. The Abbey is quite big and from the outside you can see its amazing structure. We arrived there around 3pm and supposedly they closed around 4pm or so - however, once you're in, they will allow you to stay in and finish your tour. Since we were there in April, there were no summer crowds, so we went through the entire place in about 2 hours.I recommend the audio tour cause it will give you an idea of everything you are looking at and the history behind from the alter, the throne and each room. There are many famous people either buried or paid tribute to throughout the abbey including some unexpected folks, such as Sir Isaac Newton. It took some time to reach many of the plaques on the walls and floors.A few other things to note: there is no photography or filming in the abbey, so just enjoy it with your own eyes. There is an entrance fee and I don't think there are any coupons out there. I heard that you can get in for free to watch the Evensong performance which is when the choir sings around 5pm on certain days of the week. That was recommended to us, but we didn't have time to go during this performance. The abbey is also very close to Parliament, Big Ben, Trafalgar Square, the National Gallery, London Eye and Downing Street, so it gives you a chance to check out other places nearby in the same trip.

another don't miss place to see in london. There are 4 or 5 places in london i wouldn't miss and this is one of them. The architecture alone is awesome, the audio guide informative and easy to use. One thing though is you really do need to check to see when and if it is open as we went on a Weds first when according to it's own website the day before it was open till 7, only to find it was closing at 3:30 for a 'special service".

My Favorite Memory of London. Westminster Abbey was one of my absolute favorite memories of London. I managed to cram 31 attractions and three plays into two weeks, and still this came out on top. The key part was paying the extra 4 pounds for the Verger led tour, which took about 90 minutes and gave all sorts of commentary and insights, as well as taking our small group of about 6 people "behind the scenes" and showing photos of the inside of the Abbey when it was remodeled for Queen Elizabeth's Coronation. One of my favorite parts was being led upstairs into Edward the Confessor's Chapel, which is off limits to the public now because of its fragile state. It was amazing to hear how the different parts of the Abbey tie together, and I would have missed all the details pointed out to us if I had just had the audio. And they let you actually sit in the stalls of the Quire, another part that is off limits to the public--and the people watching looked quite jealous.So my two cents are: go early, there was no line there when it opened on a Friday morning, so no need to queue up before it opens, just get there at the start. But it rapidly became crowded, so by the end of my two hour visit it was pretty packed. Pay for the Verger tour, definitely. And I'd say that even if you wander around at a leisurely pace, two hours gives you a good, in depth view of the Abbey.

Westminster is Beautiful. I visited Westminster Abbey for the first time last October (2008). I went on Sunday afternoon for one of the short vespers-type organ recitals, which are free. Afterwards we were also able to stay for the Sunday evening worship service. The architecture was awe-inspiring and the music was divine. I was moved to tears.

Incredible history. The building itself is magnificent and the sense of history is overpowering. This is a 'must do' when visiting London. I'm not sure what the best time to go is, we were there in the morning about an hour after opening and it was absolutely jammed. It closes kind of early, I would guess it's like that all day during the busy tourist times of the year. I had no problem paying the admission. With that number of people coming every day it seems reasonable to me that we should help with the maintenance and restoration.
Impressive. An impressive building, vast inside, so much history to be discovered, should be visited whilst in London. A unique experience.

Great but expensive. Having been to Westminster Abbey before in the Winter I was not surprised this venue would be busy in the summer months. If you want to go to this place for a service in the daytime I wouldn't recommend you do so unless you like large numbers of tourists flocking around you during it as services are held in front of the rood screen during the day. I have mixed feelings about charging to go into a place of worship, but if you see it as a visit to a sight, then it is the average charge to a large scale historical monument. If you are used to being able to visit museums and cathedrals free of charge you may feel this charge is too high. However, if you want to see the tombs of so many famous people of history it is the place to go. The Lady Chapel is stunning and clearly just restored. The Abbey operates a flow system as well as a free audio guide, so you will find key numbers for different parts of the building to tap into your audio guide. As the building is clearly under continuous restoration the audio guide hints that certain parts of the building are sometimes closed because of it. There wasn't much closed for us although there were restorers working on the mosaics in front of the high altar. If you really want value for money, attend choral evensong when it is free and you can get to sit in the choir stalls themselves.
Was not what I expected. The Abbey is full of dead people. Some of which were not very good people. The building was extremely impressive. Worth seeing once, I would never go back.

Take the Verger-guided tour for more history. We went to Westminster Abbey and paid the 3 pounds extra to take the Verge-led tour. It was well worth the money if you really enjoy learning about the history of Westminster Abbey. You are able to access some areas that are not available to the general public. We enjoyed our trip in the abbey much more with this tour than just the regular audio guide.
Very nice but not incredible. It is a really great church, but I must say history shadows the arts: many interesting tombs not so many art masterpieces.

Amazing Place, Must See. I would recommed Westminster Abbey as the #1 place to see in London. Sure, there are a lot of other places; but to me, Westminster Abbey is by far the most interesting, unique place. I would recommend the audioguide as well, it points out a lot of things you wouldn't otherwise notice. This place is just crammed with stories and a guide or book are necessary to fully appreciate it. Its also a good idea to show up for the Evensong (usually at 4:30). Its generally crowded, but there aren't many times where you could avoid that. I posted some photos and my London narrative on my travel blog at:http://adams-travel-blog.blogspot.com/2009/06/first-couple-days-in-london.html

History, pure and simple. In no other place that I have ever been can you experience so much history in one place. This building exemplifies British history and is really a must visit. The only negative is that you cannot take photos, but this is understandable.

Don't Miss Out On Westminster Abbey. I visited Westminster Abbey on May 13 2009, and I thought it was the most fascinating and beautiful church I'd ever seen. I arrived just as it opened at 9:30 in the morning and paid 4 pounds extra for the verger led tour. It was definitely worth it because you can only see the Confessor's Shrine on the verger led tours. This area had the oldest and most beautiful tombs of the kings and queens of England. The verger was very informative and I learned a lot more about the abbey from him than from just the audio-guide. He also led us to other places in the abbey that the public can't just enter by themselves. I loved every minute of the five hours I spent there. Yes, I was there for five hours. The verger guided tour was about an hour and a half. Then I took the self guided tour and after that I visited the abbey museum. Don't forget to go to this museum. Inside you can see the funeral effigies of some of the kings and queens as well as a duplicate set of the Crown jewels which were made for Queen Mary II. I will never forget this incredible place. It was one of my most favorite places that I went to on my London trip. I can't wait to go there again on my next trip there.

Simply one of the best churches in Europe. We spent an entire morning here on our first day in London. Westminster Abbey was simply spectacular. The architecture...the history...the sheer beauty of this church will leave you breathless. No wonder it was chosen as the site of the coronation of English royalty, and as the resting place of Newton, Dickens, Elizabeth I, Mary I, and countless other renowned figures in British history.Expect huge crowds, as it is an extremely popular attraction, and rightly so. Do not expect a serene and peaceful church! I've been to quite a few famous churches across the world (St. Peter's in Rome, St. Paul's in London, Notre Dame in Paris and Montreal) but Westminster Abbey is still at the top of my list as one of the best. The audio guide (narrated by Jeremy Irons!) is also superb.

You simply can't NOT go inside". We actually were thinking of not going inside because of the entrance fee. Thankfully we didn't pass up this opportunity. Going to many cities around Europe you can get a bit catherderal weary - mainly because the significance of the history of the buildings can be a bit lost in foreign language. The history within Westminster Abbey is one of the best I have ever experienced. Mainly because I come from Ireland and the roll call of England's kings and queens had such implications for the history of our own island.

A Walk through History. While St. Paul's Cathedral is probably more visually appealing with its white and gold interior, neither it nor any other structure comes close to the history housed within the walls of Westminster Abbey. I was appalled by the review that suggested that tourists look at the outside and pass up the tour of the interior because it costs a few pounds. You may as well tell a child that you are taking them to Disney World, and then you take a picture of the parking lot gates. The museums of Great Britain are free because they are supported by government monies. These cathedrals are maintained by tourist dollars and donations. It gave one reviewer the creeps to walk among so many tombs; I felt blessed to be among the remains and spirits of such renowned and revered historical figures. I found it ironic and touching that Elizabeth I is buried directly across from her arch-enemy and cousin, Mary, Queen of Scots. Poet's Corner was like a trip through my high school and college literature courses; every British name of renown seemed to be represented. I heartily and warmly encourage all those who have an affinity for history and literature to visit this place. It is not a gloomy mausoleum or a spooky chamber of horrors; rather, it is a walk among the spirits of England's great and glorious past where the famous and infamous rest in peace, with their souls now revealed to none but their creator.

Evensong is Free. You can pay to tour the place during the day or get in free for the evensong. We chose the later and while the service was interesting we were not able to tour the inside much. We were able to see many famous graves as we found our seats, but after the service we were pretty much immediately ushered out. Not sure if they do that every day, but if you want to visit the graves you're going to have to pay.

A definite must-see!. Westminster Abbey is an architectural and historical sight you just can't miss. From Elizabeth I's tomb to the tomb of Mary, Queen of Scots, I was stunned by the history of the abbey, and amazed at how beautiful it is. If you're in London, you must see Westminster Abbey.

Lovely--try to make a evensong service if you can!. I love choral music, and hearing the Westminster Abbey choir in this beautiful location is a great experience. The music reverberates off the arched stone exquisitely. Definitely worth going, I can't wait to do it again. Westminster seems to have heart that many other cathedrals I've visited lack--it's a beautiful place & very easy to spend hours in. Highly recommended.

A must see!. Just walking in your are overcome with how incredible the architecture is. Then to see all the amazing burial places for past kings and queens. The amount of history in this building is unbelievable- it is literally indescribable. You must go see this.

A dive in history!. I like places with nice architecture and rich history,so Westminter Abbey was one of my "must sees" when I visited London for first time at the end of January.I walked there early, about half an hour before opening time, and no one was around, so I had plenty of time to appreciate the exterior of the Abbey. It's very impressive and "atmospheric" .When time came to enter, I realised that inside area was even more moving and special. Every single corner, even the smallest detail of the Abbey has an history to say! Every single tomb, every single statue, every picture, every item!I took an audio guide which was one of the most informative guides I used during my visit to London, and believe me, I used a lot of them in various attractions!It's not easy to describe how beautiful and intresting W.Abbey is, and the feelings you get when you are actually there... It's like you get a taste of history its self just by been in the Abbey and stand among all those tombs and statues and stuff.It definately worths the entrance fee, and there are always plenty of Abbey people around you, willing to offer information and advice. I am not a religious person at all, but just looking at their calm faces and listening to their polite way of speaking, I felt sort of inspired of these people!Next time I come to London, I will visit again to take a guided tour with a member of staff that time.If you have the slightest interest on history, don't miss Westminster Abbey!!!

poets and actors buried next to kings. So one of our English friends made fun of us for going there because it's touristy. I suppose not too many native Londoners have stepped foot inside, which I really think is a shame because it's incredible. Of course we live in New York and I have never been to the Statue of Liberty, so maybe we are even. Anyway, I went to the Abbey expecting nothing more than an old church but left feeling enchanted and haunted by the history and beauty of it.Get there early, they have short hours: 10:30 to 4:00 pm. We were completely unprepared for this, thinking any place would be open until at least 5 and we showed up at 3:00 so we really had to hurry to see everything. You definitely want to set aside a few hours for this place if not a half-day.That said, it was amazing. When we walked in there was beautiful angelic singing coming from a boy's choir that filled the whole place, beautiful old latin hymns that transported us back in time a few centuries. As you listen you can walk through and see the tombs of kings and queens that span a thousand years. Among those buried there are Laurence Olivier, Charles Dickens, Henry VIII and Elizabeth I. We walked around for a bit but ended up sneaking onto a tour already in progress because the tour guide was so enigmatic and a complete character. He told fascinating stories about each tomb and the hall of flags making sure to leave in the bawdy and vulnerably human bits. Dark and bloody history with so many complicated plot-lines I can't get it all straight, but the place definitely feels alive with ghosts of great men.One of the most interesting things to see was the coronation chair, where all the kings of England were crowned. On it there is graffiti that is hundreds of years old, carved into the chair by mischievous choir boys when no one was looking. It was interesting to see something so contemporary and relate-able on an ancient relic as 17th century graffiti. We sat at the pews when the choir began Gregorian chanting and it was incredibly meditative, I wished that we could stay and listen but they began to shoo us out since it was almost 4pm and closing time. Next time I will reserve more time to soak it all in. ...And I would even recommend it even to a skeptical Londoner.

The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. Westminster Abbey is yet another "must-see" in a city that seems to be full of them. You can either enter as part of a formal tour or on your own. I visited on a Tuesday morning and found a minimal line, moderate entrance fee(12 pounds) and audio tour to boot. There were several docents/real clergy available when I visited and they were all very accessible and added to the ambience.There is enough history here to satisfy anyone, including the Coronation Chair, Tomb of Elizabeth I, and Poet's Corner. Also of note, and quite a surprise to me, was the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior, which I believe to be the first of its kind in the world. All foreign dignitaries lay a wreath here as a part of their State Visit to the country. Walking amongst this area was the most moving experience for me on my trip to London.A visit to Westminster Abbey is absolutely essential for understanding the country itself and should be included on even the most cursory of itineraries.

One of my favorite places in London! Not to be missed!. I loved Westminster Abbey. Yes it is expensive but so is everything else in London! The place is a history lovers dream and the Poets Corner left me in awe. I loved that they stop every hour for corporate prayer, even in the midst of this busy place. The crypt was amazing!!!! Don't miss the ancient life-sized wooden effegies of Queens and others. Fascinating. We loved it so much we went back for the Sung Eucharist on Sunday morning, a true English experience.

OMG!. Ok, maybe I'm morbid, but I thought Westminster Abbey was one of the best attractions in London, even though it is not really an attraction, it's a church still in use today. We were not prepared first of all for the beauty of the outside structure, but inside, is unbelievable. With so many buried inside, there are spectacular memorials to loved ones buried inside, and they are everywhere on the walls, in little hide-a-way rooms and in the floor. The overall size of the building is overwhelming, but as you make your way through the magnificent memorial carvings and sculptures, you come across the burial places of kings and queens, even Mary, Queen of Scots, and her cousin, Elizabeth, who eventually had her killed. Poets' Corner has some unbelievable names, and we even found the burial place in the floor of Charles Darwin. Overall, it is well worth the price of admission (for upkeep of the building) they ask for when you walk in the front door. Diana's funeral was there also and you can picture how it may have been. It is wonderful and I recommend it highly.

Pricey, but you do get 1000 years of history!. After the shock of paying £12 to enter a church, you soon realise that it's going to be a long and interesting visit.Get there early to avoid the crowds. Price includes a very interesting audio guide and staff are on hand to answer questions and show you where particular people are buried should you be looking for someone. (I went to see Charles Darwin's grave).It's unfortunate that there is no membership scheme, which means every time you want to visit, that's another £12!! At least St Paul's only costs £20 to visit as many times as you like in a year!

Westminster Abbey well worth a visit. Just returned from London. Although I do not think it is right to pay to go into Churchs when museums in London are free, I did relent most reluctantly and paid my £9.00 senior citizen rate for the visit. What an awesome place. Steeped in history, a wonderful place which takes you back into our historical past. Tombs of Kings and Queens and poets, writers and musicians all together making a great atmosphere. We used the audio guide which makes things easier to identify. A fabulous place which I would recommend to anyone visiting London. I may even be persuaded to pay to go into St Pauls the next time I visit

Church or Indoor National Cemetery. For historical value, you probably can't find a place in London that surpasses Westminster Abbey. The list of famous personages that are buried or memorialized there would require a great deal of space and can be found elsewhere on the Internet. (Try Wikipedia.)As a place of worship, however, it's a sad commentary on the state of religion in England. Lots of great monuments to kings, queens, unknown nobles and war dead, virtually nothing about saints or those who provided models of Christian virtue (excepting the statues far atop one of the entrances--you might miss them if someone didn't point them out). You are not allowed to visit the tomb of St. Edward the Confessor (who was also a king--I guess that's how he made it in) which might provide you with some connection to Christianity. Memorials to John and Charles Wesley--which might appeal to some Methodist tourists perhaps--were cordoned off and had folding chairs and tables stacked against them. I guess these guys are still not popular with Anglicans. Overall the Abbey is a fascinating study of how power and privilege usurped a place of honor in a religion that is supposed to be dedicated to the service of "the least of these."Finally, you really need to get the audio tour because the "docents" are clueless.

Disappointed!. I went to London and was planning to visit Westminster Abbey. I was with a large group and we all took pictures of the front of it. Westminster Abbey is beautiful outside. The bad and disappointing part was that we didn't get to go in. Westminster Abbey was closed that day because the prince was coming or something of that sort. I understand that something was going on inside, but I really wanted to go inside and visit.

Fantastic monument. It's a magnifical monument, full of history and meaning. The Central Nave is splendorous such as the laudable recovery of the High Altar, at the time of my visit. The Shrine, Chapels, Tombs, Organ, Quire and Cloisters are more than enough argument to visit it, which enriches this Royal symbol of London. I recomend to beware with pickpockets, specially at the queue entrance. Enjoy it.

Go to a Sunday Service and See the Abbey Up Close. Westminster Abbey is a treasure trove of history and art. During the week, you can spend large amounts of money getting tours, but we found the most enjoyable way to experience the Abbey was to attend a Sunday service. While not being religious ourselves, we were warmly welcomed to attend the Evensong service in early May 2008.For that service we were seated right by the high altar (where the coronations take place) and got to see all of the architecture and historic statues while listening to lovely choral music. The service lasted about 45 minutes and did not make us uncomfortable with serious religious dogma. Best of all, it was free! (You may make a donation as they pass a collection pouch at the end of the service.)While you can't walk around the Abbey before and after the service to see all of the areas, we found the sights available to us were plenty and the chance to be so close to the high altar made this a very memorable experience.

worth a trip. Definitely was on my short list of things to do in London. It did wow in the areas I was expecting and I found some new surprises. Yes, you are not allowed photos but I found I was too busy staring to do much else. Brush up on your British history, science and literary history before you go, makes it that much more special. I was a bit sad to see to the worn stones that you cannot even tell who was tributed but amazing none the less.

Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey“Spectacular, Utterly, Breathtaking”One of the greatest examples of Medieval Architecture known to man, this place is a wellspring of beauty and historical depth. I first glimpsed Westminster whilst touring the city on a bus with my parents, immediately I was struck by its sheer beauty and when I actually got to see it up close, and saw the magnificence of its interior, I was ensnared by its marvelous wonder. Even now I find myself fondly remembering the time spent within the abbey as a great and wondrous experience which has become a highlight of my young life. I visited Westminster during my family’s trip to London in the summer of 2005, and the excursion soon became one of the highlights of the entire stay. We got tickets ahead of time, so we were able to bypass a lot of the lines, but we still had to wait a considerable amount of time. We spent most of it gazing at the utterly beautiful exterior (one of the pinnacles of Medieval Gothic Architecture) and trying to name the apostles and old-testament prophets commemorated on the archway. Once inside we were immediately struck by its sheer wonder and stunned by the beauty of the expanse. However, I must say that the greatest and most impressive feature of the Abbey was the tombs.Although it may sound morbid, I was fascinated by standing in the burial place of so many great men and women during my visit to Westminster Abbey. Being obsessed with the great annals of History (particularly that of the continent of Europe) the tombs had a great impact upon me, and I was awed at being surrounded by the bodies and the spirits of so many great men and women. We visited the tombs of Henry V, Henry VII, Charles Darwin, General Wolfe, Elizabeth I, and so many other monarchs, poets, scientists and generals, all of which were splendid and would defy any attempts to describe them.Even without the vault of historical knowledge encapsulated by the tombs Westminster is still a magnificent place. It is here that you can gaze upon the coronation chamber, where almost all of the English Monarchs were officially crowned, from Edward the Confessor of the Saxon line, to Elizabeth II Windsor. Occasionally you can also see the Stone of Scone, where the kings and queens of Scotland are Crowned (although as of 4/18/08 it is still in Scotland), as well as countless other items of royal significance. Or failing any of those, you could just simply gaze upon the wondrous and captivating spectacle of the Abbey itself. Another great quality of the abbey is it doesn’t actually cost much to get in (₤10.00 for adults or ₤26.00 for a family of four), although concessions and tours do cost additional fees. Overall, I would highly recommend it as one of the greatest sites in this fabulous city. Should I ever find myself in London again, I will make sure to visit this wondrous structure once again, and bask in the beauty that is Westminster.

Waste of time. First up dont expect a church/cathedral on the inside - the Abbey is purely a tomb. May be just me but I find walking around people's final resting place as too morbid and not particularly interesting.Dont be fooled by it's magnificent exterior, the inside is not that appealing and you are not able to take photos.Be prepared for a seriously long line - I went on a bitterly cold Saturday and waited well over an hour outside. Plus there is a hefty entrance fee to get in.My suggestion is to walk around the outside and not bother queuing, paying or going in.

Unforgettable. This is one of the most amazing places I have ever visited on the planet. The amount of history in this one location is hard to imagine. It has almost been a year since my visit and I still think of the Abbey often. One bit of advice--pay a few extra pounds and get a guided tour. You actually get to go places in the abbey that the general public does not. Don't miss this place...it is awe inspiring.

More than meets the eye...... This is a must see for any visit to London! Lots of famous people buried here and the church itself is amazing!The best tip I can give is to do the Vicar's tour, you learn so much more!

A MUST visit when in London. Absolutely amazing, that's the only way to describe this Abbey. The history and the monuments, crypts and memorials are not to be missed. We were here last September and it should be number one on anyone's list when visiting London. Word's can't really describe the inside. Thousands of bodies lie beneath the floor and in tombs.We experienced no line when we arrived. We also did the self guided audio for an extra 5 pounds and it was well worth it. You will learn so much more by getting this audio guide.We spent half a day in here and probably could of spent even more time but the only drawback is there's only a snackbar for food. Go out back behind the Abbey to the courtyard and take in the views from back there. You can sit on benches or lay in the grass and relax for a while. You will not be disappointed be this amazing place.

visit on Sunday evening -free and intimate. We went to the Abbey on Sunday, at 6:30pm -coincidentally that's when an evening service was about to start. We insisted on going in (we knew it was free on Sunday) and the usher asked us if we were able to stay for the FULL service..we said yes (although I knew I was lying:)Me and my two friends walked in (yeeees, freee) and a few more Abbey employees showed us to our seats. The service was held at the very end of the building, by the ALTAR. Never in my wildest dreams had I hoped to sit there (for 30 minutes!). I believe it was that location where the Queen and Royal Court must be seated during ceremonies. There were 6 rows of chairs for the people at the service (3 rows on each side of the altar). I was asked to sit in one of the three chairs in the first row. It was INSANE. The pastor was about 2-3 meters from me. The Cathedral was semi-dark, with the altar part well lit. It was SOOOOOO QUIET! That's the difference between going inside on a crowded visitor day and going in during a service. All the time, I felt like I was part of a small, secret society, inside this huge, misterious Cathedral. We were given a booklet with the sermon and songs we were supposed to sing (I didn't, I am not Episcopalian). I stared at the ceiling, the arches, the windows, the mosaic floor (black and white). I felt both oppresses and impressed by the place and the service. This is where Queens and Kings have walked by. Where my feet were resting it's where a King's feet have rested. ROYAL atmosphere, from beginning to end of this "twilight zone" service and experience. Like in the 1001 nights story, when for 1 day you can exchange places with the king.

Do not miss if you go to London. Westminster Abbey should be at the top of any London traveler's list. The impressive history and architecture warrants at least a two-hour visit to take the verger tour or an audio tour, longer if you have the time. I visited on July 7, 2007, the first day of the Tour de France. Plan to arrive before opening (9:30); many of the smaller rooms in the Abbey can get really crowded later on in the day. Admission is 7 pounds for students and 10 pounds for adults. Unfortunately, the verger tour was not scheduled until 10:30, so I decided to take the 5-pound audio tour instead of waiting around for an hour. That's not necessarily a bad thing though, since the audio tour approached the quality of a human tour guide, and I normally don't like audio tours. The tour goes through every area of the Abbey accessible to the public. Every part of the building's history is covered, from the early Medieval monks' cloisters to the parts of the Abbey damaged during World War II. Of course, the Abbey contains thousands of graves and memorials of famous people, including numerous monarchs, war heroes, and literary figures. One highlight is the coronation chair, which no longer holds the Stone of Scone. The tour is about 90 minutes long, but can be made longer by several optional sections that give more detailed information; it is well worth the 5 pounds. The Abbey museum about halfway through contains several artifacts and is a good source of information.The only drawbacks to visiting Westminster Abbey are the high cost and the fact that cameras are not allowed inside. That being said, this is one of the greatest churches in the world, and one of the coolest places I have visited in Europe (or anywhere else). Any minor quibbles are greatly outweighed by the experience.

Wonderful. I loved Westminster Abbey on my trip to London. The outside has some of the most beautiful architecture. The inside has many burial places of famous british leaders, poets, scientists, and artists. It is elaborately decorated and of breathtaking historical significance. To be walking around such a historical building was awe inspiring. Don't miss it.

Worship in Westminster. My family and I traveled to London back in November 2005 over Thanksgiviing break since our girls (ages 7 & 9) had a longer than usual break. FYI it gets dark at 4:30 pm and that is when we tried to visit Westminster Abbey. No pics came out because of the dark, plus all the tours were finishing because of the winter hours and the approaching evensong. So we decided to attend the service. Well lets us just say that all four of us were moved by the worship service. All male choir filled the centuries old cathedral and we became a part of a very untouristy part of Abbey life/English life. It was our first major stop/sight in London and even though we did not have the usual Abbey experience the evensong jump started us to truly tap in to all things English.

Something to See, Although I only Saw the Exterior. I read some of the so-so reviews. Nevertheless, Westminster Abbey is something to see if you have not seen it before. I knew beforehand that the interior of the abbey is closed on Sunday. Nevertheless, the grounds, cloisters, museums, and gardens are all open for strolling and exploring. Frankly, the shock of history hit me in the face when I read that many parts of the abbey were built in the 1200’s and I was walking where others walked 800 years ago. The gift shop is nothing special and probably overpriced. They did have a good range of prices on their souvenirs from inexpensive to very expensive. I guess you have to think that the money goes towards the church.

Disappointing. Crowded, expensive and you cannot take photos inside. These reasons alone make it hard to reccomend. I say stick outside and take photos of the building, its the nicest part of the whole thing.

Gift Shoppe. Visited the Abbey in May with a London Walks Guide. I found the place absolutely fascinating. Read other reviews for historical relevance and recommendations on how to spend your time.I simply want to recommend a few things with specific regard to the gift shoppe.First, they make an amazing Blackcurrant Jam with Sloe Gin. It is one of the Best presents I have brought back to the states. It is absolutely delicious and I recommend picking up a jar or two for your favorite jam lovers. The label has the Westminster Abbey logo on it.Second, they have a wonderful array of gift items that aren't the usual lot you find in London. There are small pieces of window ware (Stained glass) that are copies of some of the windows you will see at the abbey and of course other famous churches in England (Such as the rose window). Lots of lovely postcards (a necessity as you can't take photos around the grounds) and many other little "treasures."So do stop by on your way, and if you can, get a little jar of jam. You will adore it when you return home and have a taste of England in your cupboard.

Outstanding historical and religious site. Westminster Abbey is the most interesting religious site in London, and perhaps in Western Europe. The building and grounds are very large and visitors should plan at least two hours. Inside are some of England's most influential monarchs going back 1000 years to Edward the Confessor, Elizabeth I, and many others. Besides the monarchs, the floor is almost entirely tombs of other important people in England and Britain. There is much stained glass, and the main building of the abbey is surprisingly bright. The tour is self guided, and different areas and tombs have good explanations. The grounds are quite large, and standard admission does not buy access to all areas. The oldest parts of the abbey do require an additional fee, and these areas should not be missed. There is no crypt or towerto climb, or at least none open to the public. Plan at least two hours inside. The snack stand serves surprisingly good soup and sandwiches. There is no climbing, but many small steps.

Take the verger tour!. Many reviews complain about the cost of going to this site. It is expensive, but think of what it costs to keep up a place of this magnitude (just a few years ago it was blackened by coal dust, now its as clean as when it was new). Plus, with what you've already spent to get to and stay in London, you should not miss a place that is really the soul of the country you are visiting.While at the abbey, be sure to take the verger tour. There are huge crowds at the abbey and the audio or book tour can not overcome feeling that there are just too many people..With the verger, you go to areas not open to the general public, get some personal attention and receive a somewhat offbeat appreciation for British history through the long line of kings buried at the Abbey (you can pick up those you miss here by going to Windsor....you'll find George III and Henry VIII here, as well as the more recent monarchs). I have taken the verger tour at Westminister Abbey twice, and both were incredibly entertaining. They make the stones come alive.I also recommend getting to the site early (the lines to get in are long), going to the Chapter House and seeing the museum. In the museum you will find effigies of various monarchs used in funeral processions (preservation hundreds of years ago was poor and the King/Queen would not hold up well enough for the state funeral).

Awe-inspiring Architecture. I originally didn't plan on going to Westminister Abbey but after I saw it up close, decided that I must. It was well worth it. My only regret is not taking the audio guide, which would have greatly enhanced the experience (not many things are labelled). When you enter the abbey, it is easy to get struck by it's impressive grandeur. The architecture is, quite simply, awe-inspiring. Walking amongst the tombs of Edward the Confessor and Elizabeth (amongst others), you definitely feel the rich history. But it is not only a final home to kings; within it's walls are also monuments to other notables such as William Shakespeare, Charles Dickens, Issac Newton, Charles Darwin, and perhaps most poignantly the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

very expensive. This place is just a money making exercise. You go in, and pay £12+ and £5+ for a guide book,or pay for the price for an audio guide.If you don't,you might as well be blind, as there is no labeling. Most of the Royal Tombs are totaly out of sight. You cannot visit them, as they are in the higher central section. You would need a ladder to view over the wall. You can see some tombs, but as I only had the expensive guide book, and not the audio, I don't really know what I was looking at. Past the royal tombs, lots of the sights are faked, I mean that if you see a memorial to someone famous, the chances are, that they are buried eleswhere.The tomb of the unknown soldier was more moving 15 years ago, when I didn't have to pay to get into the main church.TIP If you want to light a candle, but don't want to pay the twenty pence, bring your own.

Must See!. Westminster Abbey is an absolute must see if you are visiting London. It will take you approximately 2 hours to go around. The history and architecture are amazing and there is just far too much to see and take in even in the 2 hours. We arrived at opening (which is a great idea as you will beat the larger crowds that gather as the day wears on). As it turned out, the first Verger tour did not start until 10:30am, so we bought tickets for it, left for about 1/2 hour and walked over to the Houses of Parliament for an up-close look at the buildings before heading back for our tour. (Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament are extremely close). Glad we waited for the Verger tour - it was fabulous and a must do if you can afford the extra 4 GBP per person. Considering you are paying so much for entry, the extra 4 pounds probably won't hurt too bad - and I cannot emphasize enough how excellent this tour is. The Verger takes you into a few areas that are inaccessible to all other tourists. An expensive "tourist" attraction to say the least considering it is a church, but one of those places that you really must see if visiting London. We paid a total of 24 GBP for one adult (10), one senior (6), and the verger tour for both (8). The verger took us into the shrine of Edward the Confessor - a spot only accessible with a Verger. Since we were with a Verger, we also got to stop and sit in the church's nave pews (blocked to all others) where the choir sit, where he gave us more history. The stop to sit was very welcomed as there is a lot of walking. The additional areas that were accessible with a Verger as well as his indepth knowledge of the Abbey truly made this a highlight for me. Apparently, Westminster Abbey refused to let any of the DaVinci Code movie be shot inside the Abbey, and the shots they used of Newton's monument were from pictures, not the actual monument in the Abbey.

Exploring Westminster Abbey. Westminster Abbey was quite different than I had expected. Instead of a large cathedral like St. Paul's, Westminster Abbey contains a series of chapels and tombs. Although I didn't have to wait to get in the abbey was quite busy and the line backed up at several of the small chapels where space was limited. There are many unique areas of the abbey to explore, containing an overwhelming amount of history. I toured the abbey using the audio guide, which provided commentary at many of the points of interest. The poet's corner was a highlight and I sat a while looking through the long list of familiar names.Westminster Abbey is worth a visit to explore the history contained within it's walls.

Loved it!. I didn't go to WA on my 1st visit to London and I am definitely not religious, but on the advice of many - I went this time. The architecture and history of the place is amazing.I also went on the Verger tour. I was very lucky to have only 3 other people on the tour with me. This allowed us to have a more personalized tour. This is the only way to see Edward the Confessor's Chaptel, which also houses many other kings and queens. The entire Abbey is awe inspiring/beautiful/stunning. It is amazing to consider how long this Abbey has been standing and how it has endured over 10 centuries (especially through the Henry VIII years).It is definitely worth a visit and if you can afford the tour (£4), do it! I spent about 2 hours at the Abbey.

It's heresy, I know, but I wouldn't call this a must-see.. I may be the only tourist who wouldn't call Westminster Abbey a must-see, but I thought I'd register my opinion in case there are other tourists who would feel the way I do. I went to the Abbey with my husband, a history fiend. Unlike my husband, I don't have that much feeling for history. It was certainly impressive to stand so near the mortal remains of so many kings and queens, but I admit it also felt a bit creepy. There are lots of nobles buried here as well, some of whose monuments are surely impressive. Poet's Corner was nice too. The church and its stained-glass windows are attractive. Overall, though, I found the Abbey a bit underwhelming for the ticket price of £10, and I wish I hadn't spent as much time as I did here. I'm not saying I would have spent it at Madam Tussaud's or Harrod's, which to me are also overrated. I would have preferred to spend the money on a theatre ticket, and the time on a more thorough tour of the British Library, the British Museum, or any of the art museums I visited.In retrospect, after reading some of the reviews here, I might have done better to try and attend religious services on Sunday. I do respect the fact that the Abbey is still a working church, with prayers once every hour. I just feel that it should be approached in a spirit of reverence rooted in religious faith or a love of history or architecture. I was horrified to see a bored group of French schoolchildren !!scratching absently at the paint on some of the memorials!! The Abbey's roles as national monument, working church, and blockbuster tourist attraction just don't go very well together.

A House of Kings. A London must see.So much history. A stunning building with an amazing story. Take the Verger Tour. You get an excellent guide and access to the Tomb of St Edward. The tour takes 90 minutes.The Lady Chapel (chapel of Henry VII) is truly a wonder of the world. Today it feels more like a museum than a house of worship but people are respectful.The monuments to various great and good will take hours to study - the most moving is that to the Unknown Warrior. The cloisters, the Chapter house and pyxx chamber are other areas you should check out.

Stunning. Despite what some people think, St Paul's is not free! You have to pay to get in unless you are there to worship. However, Many parts of the Abbey are free to tourists and all is free if you go to services. This is despite the fact that it receives 80% of its funding from tourist entry as it gets no money at all from the Government, the Church (it is a Royal Peculiar and therefore not linked to the Cof E) or the Lottery Fund. Your admission charge is what keeps it standing. I work there approximately once a week and it is simply beautiful.

Loved it. Westminister Abbey is great. Admission was 8 pounds, and the audio guide was another 3 or 4 pounds. We just wondered around on our own. The actual worship area is quite small, but the church itself is hugh. There are small chappels, tombs, and corners everywhere, all with some architectural or historical significance. Your could easily spend hours wondering around. Saw the tomb of the unknown soldier. There are some great stained glass windows, and a couple of incredible windows. We arrived quite early in the day, crowds were not to bad, but got much worse later in the day. We were there in September on a Saturday. Remember that Westminster Abbey is still a place of worship so please treat it with respect. When you are in the chapel please respect the requests for silence and no photography - people go here to pray.

More like a museum. I liked the Abbey a lot and learned many things in the process of our tour. Example: I didn't know Issac Newton, Charles Darwin, or Charles Dickins was buried in there. Very cool to see their graves. I would definitely recommend a tour and beware they do indeed get on you if you take pictures in some certain places your not supposed to. I would say this, the Tower of London, and Shakespears home would be the top three things to do while in the London area.

Wonderful. Westminster Abby was wonderful. If you go, definately take the guided tour, whoch allows you access to areas not open to the public. And come back in the evening for Evensong - we were able to sit right next to the choir!

church no, museum yes. The Abbey itself was a great disappointment to me: I had expected it to have some sort of religious/spiritual impact, but I found it to be hodgepodge of monuments seen briefly from a very crowded pathway. (The ceiling of the end chapel was just beautiful, though). I do highly recommend the small museum off a side pathway, which contains a lot of death masks, sculptures, and clothing of many monarchs. I thought it might be creepy, but I loved it: it showed the kings and queens as real, individual humans with strengths and weaknesses.

Favorite Building in the World!. Inch for inch, Westminster Abbey has got to be one of the most intriguing buildings anywhere. Wherever you stand, you are in the shadow of a tomb, statue, or memorial to some important figure in history. Never visit London without visiting Westminster Abbey!

Wonderful experience. I was also surprised (see previous review) by how much I enjoyed Westminster Abbey. It is a magnificent, old building filled with history. I particularly liked the poet's corner where so many famous literary giants are honored. It was awe inspiring to see how the old stone steps are worn away from centuries of feet walking upon them. A great experience, even for the teenagers!

Surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I enjoyed Westminster Abbey much more than I had expected. I would definitely recommend the verger tour, I think it was about 3 pounds extra. It lasts an hour and a half, and tells you the history behind the things you're seeing, which makes it much more interesting. If you take the tour you also find out that they have to charge people to get in because they don't get any money from the government, and they don't have any parishoners to support them. Also, I have to correct the person who said that St. Paul's Cathedral doesn't charge you, they do. Maybe this was true in the past but I was just there last week.

Get a Verger. We went on Monday. Not too crowded, but can see how it would be on a Saturday. We paid a little extra for the verger tour. This was great because we got into areas of the abbey that are normally off limits and went right on ahead of other tourists in other areas. He answered questions and gave us extra info. Well worth the extra expense!

Very long waits. I can't really comment too much on the Abbey because we never did make it inside. I took home pictures of the huge line that we waited in though! The exterior is very impressive and I am sure that the inside is beautiful, but I find it amazing that you have to pay to go inside?? Visit St Paul's Cathedral instead! No lines and Free!

Necessery, but don't dawdle. The Abbey needs a good zoning authority. Memorials are almost built on top of each other, skewed to fit or covering older monuments. And the idea of charging admission does boggle the mind.Still, paying homage to the greats in the poets' corner is something everyone should do - just don't waste a lot of time on the huge monuments to history's nobodies.

Snore. First of all, you have to pay, yes pay, 8 quid to get into the place. Unlike nearly every other major attraction in London, with the Abbey one receives nothing in the way of guides or instruction.Second, it's extraorinarly boring. All you really have to look at are stain-glassed windows, puplits and tombs.Third, it's about the darkest, drabest place in London. There's simply no life to the Abbey. It's been sucked dry.Save your money. Visit the Tower of London, War Cabinet Rooms or Westminister instead.

Yikes! More 'old dead guys'. Let's face it: cathedrals aren't at the top of the "must see" list for most kids who are visiting London. In fact, after a few visits to historic sights and churches, parents are likely to hear a reaction like "MORE OLD DEAD GUYS!, Yuck!"A wise parent has a strategy to make such visits bearable for the whole family. In Westminster Abbey, for example, children can look up as they enter Henry VII's Lady Chapel and find the banners and crests of the Knights of the Order of the Bath (the clean nights). The banners form a virtual menagerie of animals, weaponry, peculiar symbols, colorful flags and coats of arms. .A more modern historical tidbit which kids can search for in Westminster Abbey is a tiny hole in the wall at the back of the Lady Chapel. The small hole was blasted out during the bombing of London in World War II.And even among the "old dead guys" in the abbey, kids may find something to look for--familiar names like Geoffrey Chaucer, Charles Dickens, Robert Browning, and Rudyard Kipling.David White

how to. Get there at 9am and be one of the first inside. Pick up the audio tour for a few pounds and enjoy. There will be no crowds and you can enjoy and learn without fighting the crowds. Works out well to go right from here to Buck Palace for changing of the guards.
